column2: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The railroads agreed today to a further suspension of the 6 per cent increase in freight rates which was ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission last April but suspended on May 15 until the end of the year. They suggested that this further suspension should be only for six months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Relaxation of dimout regulations in the coastal cities of the United States must not lead anyone to believe that the Office of Civilian Defense will wind up its business. As a matter of fact, the OCD has never had anything to do with dimouts, except in a few communities, including New York, where some Civilian Defense workers have volunteered to help out during the light-shaded periods.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 30 -- The need to keep skiing interest alive as a war measure was the keynote of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's twenty-second annual convention which opened tonight at the Hotel Bancroft.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Texas Aggies went completely pass-happy today to wallop Arkansas Razorbacks 13 -- 0.

The catalogue, just received from Chicago, reveals the fact that a one-man showing of work by Edward Hopper is being featured in the current annual at the Art Institute. Twenty-one paintings by this truly significant American artist have been assembled.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- The University of North Carolina, minus more than a dozen of its first string V-12 Navy and Marine players, scored a 27-13 victory over North Carolina State's 17-year-olds today before 7,500 fans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Public opinion in the Middle Western States of Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana and Michigan on the Hull-Eden-Molotoff conference in Moscow appeared to be plainly open-minded, perhaps even friendly and certainly not hostile.

THIS business is getting to be more and more peculiar, if that is the word. The week before last, two plays opened in theatres of the Forties, only a few steps apart as the ticket buyer trudges but some distance apart otherwise.

A LEADING radio engineer recently asked a New York audience to imagine a small boat plying a river separating two countries, with all trade and commerce between those countries limited to the boat's capacity. He then pictured a modern bridge to take the boat's place -- the bridge to be capable of carrying many channels of intelligence and commerce.

IN the interest of many millions of people like myself -- the invalids and the shut-ins -- I am writing to express the hope that the proposed plan of rebroadcasting evening programs over Mutual during the daytime will soon be an accomplished fact.

BELGIAN CONGO -- Leopoldville, 9.77 megacycles: This station was used recently for the first time to relay the BBC programs from London to North America. Not only is magnetic-storm fading thus eliminated but a powerful station in Africa or South America could probably relay Europe to North America on a single wave band throughout the year.

THERE is a photograph of Bourne as a child of about seven," writes Louis Filler, "his hair carefully combed over his left ear to hide a deformity. And in a picture of his high school graduation class he stands, more than a head shorter than the girls, back in the last row, obviously placed to hide as much as possible of his dwarfed body."

MEXICO, as seen through the eyes of Arthur Ewart, Scottish-born painter, is a pleasant rather high-keyed realm of sunlit walls and tree-shaded plazas as background for patterns of well-spaced human figures. Ewart seems avid of color, weaving it persuasively through his landscapes.

PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS and the Government of Liberia have signed a contract for airmail service from Monrovia to inland points where rubber, coffee, copra and other commodities are produced. For postage on these routes engraved 12-cents greenish blue and 24c brown stamps will be issued in designs showing a plane about to land, native workers and huts, a group of Americans and Britons, a modern office building and an automobile.

If these chapters about life on a California ranch are in what seems an overly naive vein, the reader must not be discouraged. Before long it transpires that the author's schoolgirl approach is a cover-up for considerable sophistication.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Oct. 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- South of the Apennines, there are only two routes of approach to Rome and both are dominated by towering mountains which must be swept clean of the enemy before troops can advance in the valleys.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Steve Filipowicz's passing and place-kicking by Pat Harder gave the Skycrackers of Georgia Pre-Flight a 14-to-13 victory over Tulane in a bitterly fought game today before 18,000 persons.

AFTER numberless war-time books on the Orient which have been compounded of "the stuff to feed the troops," "Shanghai Lawyer" is refreshing. It is honest. Its author has not bothered to edit history for our supposed benefit.

The birthplace of a pioneer scientific movement which laid the foundations for America's pre-eminence today in the field of astronomy will be the scene of a unique program next week when the American Astronomical Society joins with this city and its municipal University of Cincinnati in celebrating the centennial of the university's observatory.
The importance of the cooperation of the United States in safeguarding the peace of the post-war world was stressed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Don't forget to take up the tomato stakes when the last green tomatoes have been picked. The stakes are scrubbed and stored away in the cellar or garage for use next year. . . . It's time also to clip and pull off morning glories and any other annual vines from fences or arbors. They become more unsightly every week.

THE Office of Defense Transportation will be no more lenient toward pleasure travel this winter, it is said, than it was last. Travel, in fact, is to be restricted, so far as possible, to those who must get away for reasons of health or business or in the interest of the war effort.

TRANSPLANTING trees and shrubs this fall is an operation that needs be done carefully and thoroughly. On a Saturday afternoon with limited time or chill in the air, it is easy to omit the few simple things which will govern the future life of the plant.

I noticed with interest in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine Dr. Richard Merzbach's letter referring to an article on "Churchillisms" by Raymond Daniell. The phrase "the beginning of the end" is indeed a quotation from A.J. Cronin's "The Keys of the Kingdom," but one may, however, refer further back into earlier literature for a more original quotation.

THE honor of being the most unusual and spectacular plant of the early season easily goes to the giant Eremurus, variously known as the Desert Candle, Foxtail Lily, Giant Asphodel and Spire Lily. Very early the enormous shoots push their way out of the ground.

The ceremonies planned for the opening of King George V's ninth Parliament on Dec. 3, 1935, were sharply curtailed. Princess Victoria, the King's sister, had died, and official England was in mourning. Brief speeches by the King and his Prime Minister, Stanley Baldwin, emphasized Britain's loyalty to the League of Nations and its desire to avoid war.

Incapacitated war veterans can enjoy normal recreational activities, it was shown yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University, when a group of forty-five men and women engaged in athletic events and group games while simulating the handicaps of the disabled.

THERE are valuable elements in August Derleth's diligent loyalty to the Sac Prairie region with which his voluminous writings have become identified: He is intimate with the cultural and social history which made that area one of the strongholds of a free-thinking, slavery-abhorring liberalism in the middle decades of the last century.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Office of Price Administration was without an administrator this week but the lack was not apparent either in administration of the agency or in the reorganization program which proceeded there without a hitch.

The twenty-fourth annual Hope Farm Christmas sale for the benefit of the Greet School in Dutchess County will be held Nov. 16 in a suite of small ballrooms at the Pierre. The beneficiary cares for more than two hundred children whose homes have been broken by death, illness or other misfortunes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Sunday, Oct. 31 -- Allied ground forces continued their steady advances yesterday to clear the Japanese from Mono Island in the Treasury group of the northern Solomons and from the larger Choiseul Island, reports today said.

" I was hunting for a quarter-pound of butter with my four brown stamps. I came to one dairy store; they had at least a hundred-pound container of butter. The man said, 'No butter for you. Buy butter where you buy your groceries.' Am I right to make a complaint?"

The report of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., announced yesterday for the first nine months of this year, shows a net profit of $1,270,908 after amortization of war facilities, provision for contingencies and taxes, equal to 62 cents a share on the common stock.

The Senate last week debated America's post-war foreign policy. The atmosphere was both different from and similar to that of the historic debates of 1919 and 1920 when American participation in the League of Nations and ratification of the Treaty of Versailles was defeated.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Oct. 30 -- Miss Anne Empie Kidder, daughter of Mrs. Francis C. Curtzwiler of this city and the late George Everard Kidder, was married here this afternoon to Maj. John Robert Anthony Beatty, USA, of New York and Havana, Cuba, son of Mrs. Sophie S. Beatty of Havana and the late Frank J. Beatty.
UNCLE SAM has a very satisfactory substitute for Japanese "bushido." This becomes evident in Joe Foss' story of the air fighting over Guadaicanal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The effort to obtain -- in the words of Secretary Knox in his Navy Day speech at Philadelphia -- from the Democratic and Republican National Conventions of 1944 a "substantially identical" plank on international policy is a logical successor to those which produced the Connally resolution, now being debated in the Senate, and the Republican declaration at Mackinac. The convention project is beset with even more difficulties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. William Little has been awarded the French Voluntary Military Service Cross, first class, the Army announced today.

DARIUS MILHAUD may be a prolific composer, but nearly everything that he produces has precision, neatness and a well-knit structure. His music generally is composed with economy of means. His overall style -- for Milhaud has written in a variety of styles -- is both Gallic and modern; it has enough individuality to be distinctively Milhaud.

The City Council to be elected by proportional representation voting on Tuesday from a list of sixty-three candidates will consist of not more than twenty members and its roster may drop to eighteen or even lower, political observers said yesterday.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Oct. 30 (AP) -- In a final attack against a key Crown witness, Defense Counsel Godfrey S. Higgs charged in the Supreme Court today that a fingerprint offered to convict Alfred de Marigny of the murder of Sir Harry Oakes was "fabricated evidence,"

The New York Chapter of the Red Cross has made an impressive report of its first full year of war work. The department which deals with men of the armed forces and their families in Manhattan and the Bronx handled 130,000 cases during the year, as compared with 39,000 in the preceding twelve months.

UNIFORMS of the United States Army are seen often and in great numbers in our concert rooms among the members of the audience. They had not been seen on the platform till the late "Proms" season brought forward composer and conductor.
A rear-end collision between two northbound Third Avenue elevated trains at the 183d Street Station last night caused injury to twenty-four persons and tied up the track for two hours.

IT was President Roosevelt who was responsible for the title of this book. Looking around the circle of photographers who were taking his picture one day he noticed the absence of a familiar face. "Where's Sammy Shulman?" he asked.

With more than 95 per cent of the known oil reserves of the world under their control, the United Nations should not have much difficulty in meeting the demand for oil products necessary for military operations and essential civilian consumption, provided the full cooperation of all countries is obtained.

The War Food Administration's milk subsidy program, announced last week, entails "discrimination against the farmers for the benefit of dealers," it was charged yesterday by Fred H. Sexauer, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc.

ANGEL'S Trumpet is the beautifully descriptive English name of Datura stramonium, a large annual with white, purple or yellow trumpet-shaped blossoms, somewhat resembling the Easter lily in size and shape.

City Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Woolley warned 250 coal yards and 5,000 coal peddlers of New York City yesterday that the department planned to move against those found guilty of delivering inferior quality coal that is largely non-combustible.

THIS is the first non-mystery novel by the creator of that favorite of investigators, Mr. Albert Campion. As an admirer of Mr. Campion from away back, this reviewer approached "The Galantrys" with proper respect. But here Mr. Campion's creator has explored a mystery that requires far more than his suave ingenuity for its solution -- a mystery that goes as deep as anything we know.

In television the radio waves are so short that they are called quasi-optical, meaning that they behave much like light waves. "Visibility" ranges from thirty or 100 miles, depending on the height of the transmitter. Hooking-up a score or so of television stations for a nation-wide broadcast therefore presents a problem.

ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Breaks broke up a ball game here today, and a mighty Duke football team which made them emeregd the winner over Georgia Tech, 14 -- 7, in a dizzy engagement that attracted 30,000 fans.

Because war contract terminations to date have disclosed that payments to subcontractors working for "cost-plus" prime contractors have been held up, awaiting decision as to the power of the General Accounting Office to veto at any time settlements approved by contracting officers, serious concern was expressed yesterday by termination authorities over the ability of such subcontractors to wait indefinitely for settlement payments.

BEGINNING next February, housewives will carry in their purses red and blue plastic "coins," slightly larger than nickels, slightly thinner than dimes. These tokens, which will look somewhat like tiddlywink disks, will be used to make change from ration-book coupons.
THE American Concert Ballet makes its debut tonight in the Students Dance Recitals series at the Central High School of Needle Trades.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Revival of operations in the country's coal mines rested in the hands of John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers tonight as the National War Labor Board agreed to put a guarantee in its proposed wage formula under which no miner would make less on a straight time hourly rate than he would have made under the old contract.

Swiss dispatches said yesterday that Benito Mussolini was still in Germany, a virtual prisoner of the Nazis, who write all orders issued to his puppet republican fascist government over his signature, The United Press reported.

ONE of the most startling facts to which some of the smugger elements of the world must awaken is that, after this war, one of the greatest powers on the globe and almost certainly the greatest in Europe, will be the Soviet Union. This would appear to be incontrovertible.

A final installment of $7,140,000 on an accumulated bonded debt of $81,000,000, incurred in 1933 to meet the cost of home relief, will be paid tomorrow, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Representative Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, said today the Department of Justice was investigating the disposition of a $65,000 fund alleged to have been raised in 1940 by four aircraft companies seeking a change in the Revenue Act to lower their taxes.

THE movies are booming everywhere these days -- even in Sicily. Since American films returned to the island the local citizenry has literally camped on the doorstep of every available movie house, necessitating sale of tickets four weeks in advance, according to reports reaching the OWI Overseas Motion Picture Bureau from its field representatives.

The annual general election will be held on Tuesday for the voters of New York City and New York State. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 7 P.M., and, as required by law, sale of liquor will be prohibited in all bars and restaurants during those hours.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- While evidence piles up from many reliable sources of quivering German morale -- and on this point delegates to the three-power conference are fully agreed -- the Red Army continues to tie up every division the enemy has available for the Russian front.

Additional evidence that the mobilization of industry for war has reached its peak and that the War Production Board now is giving consideration to measures which will soften the impact of demobilization day on the nation's economy was seen last week in the disclosure that the agency will facilitate resumption of manufacture of 700 civilian items by small plants.

Six proposed constitutional amendments will be subject to the approval of the voters at Tuesday's election. This is the largest number to be submitted to the people in a single year since the constitutional convention of 1938, when the new constitution was submitted in nine separate proposals.

Ethelbert Smith said that in the matter of the Vice President's recent speech about the railroads he found himself thinking of Voltaire's famous words. Voltaire said to one of friends, or somebody other than Voltaire said it, because there is some difference of opinion about it, but anyhow someone once said, "I wholly disapprove of what you say and will defend to the death your right to say it."

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Liquidation of what brokers said was a line of long December rye carried the price of that delivery off 1 3/4 cents a bushel at one time today on the Board of Trade and unsettled other grains. Support was lacking and closing sales were about the bottom, with losses of 3/4 to 1 5/8 cents, July showing the least loss.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
A verdict of "not proven" was presented yesterday to the Appellate Division by Charles B. Sears, referee in the disbarment proceedings against former Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Senator Ralph O. Brewster of Maine renewed Congressional demands tonight for inquiry into petroleum supply problems, lend-lease operations and post-war aviation rights, and warned foreign interests not to interfere.
HENRY J. KAISER did not even take a deep breath when he said it: "I'm one who believes that 50 per cent of women now in war work will stay in industry after the war."
ONE of the most delightful of the shrub roses is Rosa hugonis, sometimes called Golden Rose of China. It is splendid for use in a shrub border, or as a specimen for the lawn.

THE Folk Arts Center, 670 Fifth Avenue, opens its galleries after a summer closing period with an extensive collection of oldtime coverlets. Three of the pieces were made by the same person, Elizabeth Stouffer, born in Baltimore in 1791, who made one of them when she was 11 years old.

" THE Framework of Battle" is more than a layman's guide to military strategy. In this work the fossilized structure of Colonel Burr's subject comes to life and, apart from the layman's guide, he has written an exceptionally interesting book.

McALISTER COLEMAN is a Norman Thomas Socialist who has had exceptional opportunities to study the militant wing of American labor from the inside. His new book is the second of Farrar Rinehart's "Labor in 20th Century America" series, edited by John Chamberlain, book reviewer for THE NEW YORK TIMES.
IN recent discussions of the role the United States should play or is willing to play in the post-war world, one word has been bobbing up with increasing frequency. The word is "sovereign."

Manpower shortages in the shipbuilding industry and in hospitals led yesterday to an announcement by the Bethlehem Steel Company that it would open its first centralized employment office in this city tomorrow and to an appeal by the Office of Civilian Defense for men from all walks of life to volunteer their free time for a variety of hospital tasks.

After nineteen months of dim-out, passengers in most of the subway trains were able again to read their newspapers without squinting yesterday as the Board of Transportation rushed the work of replacing the coated bulbs with unclouded ones giving 40 per cent more illumination.

George S. Counts, State chairman of the American Labor party, and Alex Rose, State secretary, issued a statement yesterday approving four proposed amendments to the State Constitution and opposing two of them.

" IT is not possible for Christians to take part in anti-Semitism," said Pope Pius XI. "We are Semites spiritually." And Rabbi Fineberg echoes him when he cries, "What a pity that the honorable name Christian can be bandied about by brutish irreligious rogues as a synonym for non-Jew!"

TO Cambridge he was simply "J.J.," to the world Sir J.J. Thomson, the outstanding physicist of his generation. Because of his infrequent visits to the barber he was often mistaken for Lloyd George, an error which he took no trouble to correct.

WHEN I hear people say they have not found the world and life so agreeable or interesting as to be in love with it, or that they look with equanimity to its end, I am apt to think they have never been properly alive nor seen with clear vision the world they think so meanly of, or anything in it -- not a blade of grass.

For me the most galvanizing experience of the week here in New York was provided by Charles Burchfield, who is having a one-man show of water-colors at the Rehn. The fact that this show contains only eight water-colors might imply sparseness.

PROFESSOR MULLER'S problem is how the sanity and breadth of the humanistic tradition may be maintained in a culture which is dominated by science -- and which is threatened by the confusion which arises from varying perspectives, and the dogmatisms and fanaticisms which are the frequent concomitants of various scientific disciplines.
For Heaven's sake, in what isolated corner of New England did you find the recipe published for red flannel hash? Or were you simply fishing for the real recipe to replace the parody you gave?

THE HOUSE OF MRS. CAROLINE was a mansion in the town of Racconigi, near Turin in the Province of Piedmont. In the early years of the present century, when this novel opens, the House was ruled over by Mrs. Caroline, widow of Joseph-Marie Ferrero and matriarch of the Ferrero clan.

LARGE American annuals continue punctually to put in an appearance despite war conditions. The Carnegie show, which opened Oct. 14, was commented upon in these columns a fortnight ago. The thirtieth annual presented by the Allied Artists of America opens today in the galleries of the New York Historical Society.

FINDING the first egg laid by pullets indicates that it's time to make preparation for housing them during the winter -- a season when, for best results, they should be confined to the house. If there is an outside run for the birds one need not hurry thus to bring them into the laying house.

An unofficial English visitor, I have just returned from a lecture tour in thirty-six States. It has been my privilege to address many university audiences, and I have been surprised at the large number of students who are unaware of the origin of the Stars and Stripes in the national flag.

With spring lines opening, the wholesale markets here were filled with buyers last week and more are expected this week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 30 -- On a mud-laden field Lawrenceville's powerful eleven conquered their ancient rival, Hill, 12 -- 7, here today. Bob Hamill and Don Hyde behind the beautiful blocking of Charlie Highley and Bill Heath proved to be the scoring combination.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The University of Rochester wound up a successful football season today by outclassing Case School of Cleveland, 39 -- 9. The victors, making free use of aerials, scored in every period but the fourth.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters is donating $2,000 this year to the Armed Forces Master Records, Inc., to set up libraries of records here and abroad. Walter Damrosch, president of the academy, and Deems Taylor, a director, have been active in sponsoring the action.

School systems in the boomtown areas of the country have been hard hit, suffering from overcrowding, lack of teachers, inadequate facilities and lowered educational standards. Reports from typical communities indicate that the problem is more acute this fall than ever before.
Mrs. I. Wistar Morris Jr. and Mrs. David Scull of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, have come to the Ritz-Carlton from Rocky Crest, Mrs. :Morris' summer home in Ardmore, Pa.

Camp Little Norway, the Royal Norwegian Air Force training center in Toronto, will be the beneficiary of the piano recital to be given by Stell Andersen on the night of Nov. 7 at Town Hall. Wilhelm Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Ambassador, and Mrs. Morganstierne, and Rolf A. Christensen, Norwegian Consul General here, and Mrs. Christensen head the committee of sponsors for the benefit.

Providense, R. I. THE Museum of the Rhode Island School of Design recently received as an anonymous gift a late painting by Paul Cezanne, entitled "The Seine Near Paris." The painting was purchased from the Durand-Ruel Gallery, which acquired it from Ambroise Vollard shortly before his death.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Jersey City jumped the gun on the rest of the Atlantic Seaboard by shifting from a dimout to its interpretation of the brownout at 8 o'clock tonight, forty-eight hours before the effective time set by Washington for the transition, assuming that Washington meant Monday night.

TWENTY-FOUR hours a day, seven days a week, half a dozen California radio stations blare forth more than 500 used-car spot announcements in fanciful language. Newspapers reject anywhere from ten to 100 columns of used car advertising a week.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 30 -- Mighty air battles developed in the South Pacific this week as waves of American bombers ignored swarming enemy planes, heavy flak and bad weather in an unremitting attempt to smash enemy airpower at Rabaul, and the Japanese continued to fly in new planes from Truk and other points in a frantic effort to maintain their chief remaining air base in this theatre of war.

AS the month closes in retail trade there has been a quickening of consumer buying which merchants believe portends an earlier Christmas shopping period. The public will not need urging this year, because many citizens already have discovered that some items are scarce and undoubtedly will become scarcer.

An increase of 90 per cent in new infections of syphilis among boys and girls 15 to 19 years old and of 34 per cent in the age group 20 to 24 years for the first half of 1943 was reported yesterday by City Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins.

SEVEN years ago a new musical organization was founded in New York. At the time, the Metropolitan Opera was in serious financial straits. The coffers of the Philharmonic Society had suffered as a result of four years of hard times. It seemed an inauspicious time to launch a new concert project.

The newest advances, in which the Allies took more than twenty towns and villages, gave the Eighth and Fifth Armies the shortest front across the Italian Peninsula they have held at any time since they joined up, The Associated Press reported.

Long Island's hunters will be afield tomorrow with the opening of the season on small game. While the regulations differ for various parts of the State, the shooting will begin simultaneously tomorrow on woodcock, pheasant, grouse, squirrels, rabbits and varying hares and quail.
ORIGINALLY written for an English audience by Dr. Wyndham Lloyd, the present edition of "A Hundred Years of Medicine" has been extensively revised and rewritten by Dr. Haagensen for American readers.

Gregor Piatigorsky's recital, given last night in Town Hall for the benefit of the European Friends of Ort, was an exhibition of 'cello playing at the peak of perfection. Seldom have any players of the instrument found it possible to infuse their work with the variety and subtlety of color effects at the eminent artist's disposal at this event.

BUFFALO, Oct. 30 -- Private enterprise operating under a profit system must provide the basis for production and employment in the post-war period if a free society is to be continued, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared today at the convention of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Playing before a gathering of 500 at muddy Lewisohn Stadium, City College went down to a 13-12 defeat at the hands of the Camp Kilmer eleven yesterday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Refreshed by a week's rest from competition, the Holy Cross football team outplayed Colgate's favored Red Raiders by a wide margin today to gain a 14-7 victory before 10,000 fans.

" Endocriminologists," the late Dr. Harvey Cushing once called the physicians who indiscriminately prescribe hormones extracted from the endocrine glands. Not that he had a low opinion of the corrective importance of the hormones but that in his opinion medicine did not know as much about them as it pretended.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Southern California maintained its record of being unbeaten, untied and unscored on as it turned back a stubborn University of California football team today, 13 to 0. Thirty thousand fans saw the game.

Accused of having bought 600 cases of whisky hijacked from a truck two months ago, Austin Gus Ruane, 35 years old, co-owner of three taverns in Manhattan, was held in $5,000 bail for the action of the grand jury at his arraignment yesterday afternoon before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter in the Federal Building.

An alert All Hallows Institute football team tumbled Fordham Prep from the ranks of the unbeaten on rain-soaked Fordham Field yesterday. Outplaying its Bronx foe throughout, All Hallows went 25 yards to get a touchdown in the second quarter and added two points via the safety route in the last period to upset the Maroon, 8 to 0.

THIS is a book about China of a different order. It is not concerned with the drama of China's resistance or the ideas of China's political future. It deals rather with underlying facts, of which there has been too little in recent writing about China.

PRINCETON, N.S., Oct. 30 -- Brown spotted Princeton two first period touchdowns today and yet came through to win. Striking for three scores in the second frame, the Brunonians held their foes off in the third, yielded one in the fourth, while they scored one themselves, and strode off with the victory, 28 to 20.

SORRENTO, Italy, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- Senator Benedetto Croce, Italian philosopher and political leader, threw the weight of his great authority behind the movement for a regency in Italy under Premier Pietro Badoglio today in his first authorized statement on the subject.

GLASS PLASTIC -- A new material is employed in aircraft construction. It is a plastic reinforced with glass fibers. Samples have been produced with a tensile strength of over 80,000 pounds per square inch. While the impact strength of ordinary plastics is about 2 foot-pounds, samples of the glass and plastic combination have shown impact resistance of over 20 foot-pounds.

Boysy, conqueror at one time or another of such good horses as Shut Out and Bolingbroke, added First Fiddle and half a dozen others to the number at Jamaica yesterday when he won the $11,525 Scarsdale Handicap on the final Saturday of the Empire City meeting.

ALGIERS, Oct. 30 -- Over the rostrum in the high ceilinged chamber where the Algerian financial assembly has met for many years there is a relief plaque of Charles Laferriere, an Algerian governor-general who established the financial assembly.

ONE cannot read far in the history of the American frontier without coming upon the name of Manuel Lisa, the Spanish merchant and fur trader of old St. Louis. Yet it is safe to say that to most readers he remains little more than a name. Although he was more colorful and daring than many a romantic adventurer, Captain Lisa -- as this fun-bodied novel shows us -- was primarily a business man.

EVERY parent knows that the "Don'ts" in bringing up children outnumber the "Do's." In his experience over seven years with some 3,000 boys and girls -- average age 10 1/2 -- Dr. Alexander Reid Martin has become increasingly aware of this "strong negative trend and attitude that characterizes the whole modern approach to human growth and development."

German firing squads in France have executed forty-six more Frenchmen in a mass reprisal designed to check a wave of anti-Nazi sabotage that, nevertheless, continues to mount in scope and intensity throughout France, according to Swedish press dispatches reported yesterday to the Office of War Information.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 -- An Iowa farm family was chosen by the Rural Electrification Administra tion today as the first recipient of an award of merit for "distinguished war service" in the use of electric power to increase food production.

Tuesday's election has unusual interest for this vicinity in the fight to beat Mr. Aurelio in the First Judicial District, in the race for City Council and in the contest for the Lieutenant-Governorship. Across the river in New Jersey a Governor is to be chosen. Our pre-election round-up, published in another section of today's issue, shows contests elsewhere in the nation that may indicate political trends.

OVERTRICKS are relatively unimportant in a rubber bridge game. The important thing is to make one's contract, and it is seldom wise to risk going down at a safe contract in order to try for an extra trick or two.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The German news agency, DNB, cited one home coming Nazi prisoner -- one of several thousand fitting in the recent exchange of prisoners between the Allies and the Axis -- as describing the British working classes as "poverty stricken" and clad in rags, half starved and living a "miserable existence while the British press jabbers of liberating humanity by the war of plutocrats."

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- No better evidence of the success of the Foreign Ministers' conference is required than the new Communist party line that Pravda prints today in preparation for the celebration next Sunday of the revolution's twenty-sixth anniver sary. Three slogans of the Communist party's Central Committee make clear Anglo-Soviet-American unity and determination to get on with the war.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 30 -- "A small city on the move" seems an apt description of the new troop transports which the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company is building these days to overcome the last serious bottleneck in wartime shipping -- lack of sufficient "invasion specialists," as the troop-carriers have come to be called.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 31 -- Yugoslav Partisans, supported by Albanian bands making common cause against the German invaders, have captured the town of Debar, situated beside the snow-capped mountains that divide the two countries, according to a radio announcement made over the Free Yugoslavia radio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Creation of a Philippine Post-War Planning Board by the islands' President-in-exile, Manuel L. Quezon, was announced today by the Philippine Department of Information and Public Relations.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that in cooperation with J. Edward Lumbard Jr., Special Deputy Attorney General in charge of the Election Frauds Bureau, he had completed plans to assure an orderly election tomorrow throughout the State and safeguard citizens in their right to vote in secret and free from fraud or intimidation.

Arturo Toscanini made his first appearance this season in New York with the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Radio City, this occasion being the opening of the NBC's winter orchestra season, under the sponsorship of General Motors Symphony Of The Air.
If they want to make the "Take Me Out to the Ball Game" song applicable to the football season, all they have to do is substitute the word "Baugh" for "ball."
ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A joint legislative committee said today it had found "long-standing abuses and costly injustices" in the State's methods of equalizing real estate assessments.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Philadelphia-Pittsburgh Steagles clicked off three explosive touchdowns in the first ten minutes of play today and went on to hand the hapless Chicago Cardinals their sixth straight defeat, 34 to 13, in a National Football League game before 16,351 fans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- First Lieut. Mary Ann Sullivan, Army Nurse Corps, of Boston, received the Legion of Merit for high performance of duty in the Tunisian campaign, it was learned from the American Red Cross here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Postponement of Senate action on the Connally peace resolution until results of the Moscow conference are known was proposed today by Senator Millikin, Republican of Colorado.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Large blocks of stock of the F.W. Woolworth Company are left to charities under the will of Clarion B. Winslow, former Woolworth executive, who died here on Tuesday at the age of 79. There are specific bequests of 29,600 shares of the stock, now worth $1,124,800 on the market.

The past week again was marked by a large number of buyers being in the market, looking for near-by deliveries and also placing orders on spring lines that were opened, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The last of fourteen subcommittee reports on an over-all simplified retail price regulation proposed by the Office of Price Administration for commodities other than food will be submitted to OPA officials tomorrow, it was announced today.

At least 50,000 city employes are borrowing money for one reason or another, according to a report submitted to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia yesterday by Harry W. Marsh, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, who was named by the Mayor three months ago to head a credit counseling service for the benefit of city workers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- China looks forward to full postwar cooperation with foreign nations, but only on the basis of full equality, the Foreign Policy Association reported today.
The 100th anniversary of the laying of the cornerstone of Grace Episcopal Church at Tenth Street and Broadway was celebrated yesterday morning with a sermon by Bishop William T. Manning.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine issued to all borough commanders yesterday a ten-point set of instructions for their guidance in obtaining voluntary compliance with the "brownout" that is to go into effect today to conserve electricity as a substitute for the dimout that has been in effect for eighteen months.

The Federal Reserve Board has just released a study showing that "business" deposits aggregated $38,700,000,000, or 70 per cent of total demand deposits, on July 31, 1943. Of the $18,000,000,000 increase in demand deposits since the end of 1941, it estimates that perhaps three-fourths have been in "business" accounts.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Switzerland elected a new Parliament today by a democratic vote at the polls -- a unique event in the center of Europe.

HANS NATONEK is a lucky man by some standards. He was driven from home and a distinguished literary career in Germany by the beasts of the new Apocalypse. He was forced to flee across five nations as Europe was engulfed by the brown pestilence. His wife left him and took their children with her when she became persuaded of the shame of being married to a German-speaking Czech Jew.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- With Goalie Benny Grant providing stanch support in the nets, the Toronto Maple Leafs operated behind the advantage of Mel Hill's two goals in the first period tonight to mar the season's debut of the Black Hawks, 4 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game played before a sell-out crowd of 17,124 in the Chicago Stadium.
GUADALCANAL, Oct. 27 (Delayed) -- The Japanese have introduced a new dive-bomber into the fighting in this area, but with a remarkable lack of success.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Expiration of the Government's guarantee that farmers who sold cash corn prior to Oct. 31 would share in any increase in the ceiling price if the latter is announced before Nov. 30 is expected to result in some falling off in sales of old corn by producers.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The purpose of the air war over Europe is to create confusion and smash the war-making power of the enemy by destroying his factories, distribution system and morale. Bombs, especially fire-bombs, do this work effectively, but there are other ways.

PROCESSED FOODS (most canned vegetables, soups, fruits and fruit juices, jams, jellies, preserves and fruit spreads -- except citrus marmalade -- dried beans, frozen vegetables and fruits, and prunes, raisins and currants) -- Blue stamps X, Y and Z in War Book 2 are valid through Nov. 20. Green stamps A, B and C in War Book 4 will be valid from Nov. 1 through Dec. 20.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 31 -- On the eve of the showdown in the stoppage of coal production, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in his annual report tonight assailed men in the American labor movement whom he accused of serving the Axis willingly or unwittingly by encouraging strikes and stoppages in war industries.

On the editorial page of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 29 appears a letter from Constance Warren, which quotes from a letter received from her nephew stationed in North Africa. The soldier states he received an application for a war ballot postmarked Sept. 7, which had evidently been sent to his aunt and forwarded to the soldier to be mailed on or before Sept. 20.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 31 -- Higher labor priority has been given to men engaged in cutting operations for the pulp and paper industry in Canada, it was announced today. This has been done to try to meet the threatened shortage of pulpwood and maintain the present rate of production and export of newsprint.

Salvaging waste fats is a daily, rather humdrum task that no amount of talk can make glamorous The fact remains, however, that it is vitally necessary, for from fats come glycerin and from glycerin come the munitions and medicines that are essential to the successful prosecution of the war.
The Allied governments are guilty of moral cowardice in failing to meet "the major political weapon of Nazi bestiality," that is, extermination of the Jews, Leon Henderson declared last night.

NAPLES, Oct. 31 -- Count Carlo Sforza gave Premier Pietro Badoglio his qualified support in an interview this morning, but made it clear that he demanded purification of the present leadership and, indirectly, he indicated he wanted King Victor Emmanuel to abdicate.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The fifth giant invasion carrier, the troopship General William Mitchell, was launched today at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here as a squadron of Thunderbolt fighter planes from Mitchel Field circled overhead.

Walter Hautzig, 21-year-old Viennese pianist now resident in this city, disclosed talents of a high order at his first full-length local recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Hautzig's playing was remarkable for its poetry and imagination, its inner life, spontaneity and insight.

A warning to be on guard against the foisting of un-American and un-Christian ideas on this country in the name of democracy was given yesterday by Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran at the annual communion breakfast of the Dongan Guild at the Hotel Commodore.
In a game that thrilled 46,208 spectators, the professional football season's record crowd, Green Bay crushed the Giants with two late touchdowns, 35 -- 21, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The clearing of Thomas A. Aurelio in the disbarment proceedings against him, contained in the report of Referee Charles B. Sears, was accepted yesterday in political circles as greatly increasing his chances of election tomorrow as a Supreme Court justice.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- Western Pennsylvania's mines prepared for a complete suspension of operations tomorrow following midnight expiration of the strike truce in the industry.

It is always a pleasure to put children to bed. There are two ways of looking at this, depending, of course, on how wearing the day -- and the children -- may have been. But take it at its face value; they will not always be of an age to be tucked to bed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Sid Luckman shot touchdown passes of 38, 51 and 25 yards and Gary Famiglietti bulled his way to two more scores today as the Bears scored their fifth straight National Football League victory by crushing Detroit, 35 -- 14, before a crowd of 25,187.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- All deliveries of wheat futures sold last week at new high prices for the season on the Board of Trade, increased buying attributed to distillers, millers and feed mixers disclosing a lack of selling pressure at times.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Lady Eunice Oakes will testify this week against the son-in-law charged with the murder of her husband.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, said at a press conference in the embassy today that the British people felt that the war was now approaching its climax everywhere. He spoke in the light of his observations during a visit of two and a half months in Britain, from which he has just returned.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 31 (AP) -- In a damp, rough-hewn dugout, wheezy Chinese-made presses brought here from Hankow rolled out today the first American newspaper published in Free China, the Chungking edition of The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, an eight-page, hand-set weekly tabloid.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Capturing the highest award tonight at the nineteenth annual all-breed show of the Kennel Club of Buffalo, held in the new Memorial Auditorium, was the brindle boxer Champion El Wendie of Rockland, owned by the Rye Top Kennels of Harrison, N.Y., and handled by Nate Levine.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- After having reached a new high in steel tonnage production two weeks ago, steel ingot output last week dropped a full point to 100 per cent of rated capacity. Practically all of this loss was attributed to outlaw coal strikes.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Chinese artillery, nestled in the Kaolikung Mountains on the Salween River front, has opened up on Japanese invaders seeking to control a big area west of the Salween River in the Burma-Yunnan border area and has inflicted heavy casualties, the Chinese High Command announced in a communique today.

Isabelle Sant Ambrogio gave a delightful piano recital at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon before an appreciative audience. The program was a heavy and exacting one, including Beethoven's Sonata in F-sharp major, Opus 78; Schubert's Impromptu, Opus 90, No. 3; three Capriccios and the Intermezzo, Opus 76, No. 3, A-flat major, of Brahms, the Liszt B minor Sonata; numbers by Debussy and A. Sant Ambrogio and the Chopin C-sharp minor Scherzo, Opus 39.

An underwriting group headed by Union Securities Corporation and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., will offer today two issues of E.R. Squibb Sons, consisting of 42,868 shares of $4.25 cumulative preferred stock, Series B, no-par value, and 44,799 shares of common stock.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 1 -- The fate of tens of thousands of German troops trapped in the Crimea was virtually sealed yesterday when the Red Army smashed to within eight miles of the Nazis' last escape railway by capturing Chaplinka.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- "Overwhelming quantities" of American gasoline were undoubtedly the key Allied weapon in defeating Nazi Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's army and driving the Axis out of Africa, the Office of War Information asserted today in emphasizing the importance of continuing large petroleum supplies to the fighting forces on all the world fronts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The purchase of "rueckwanderer marks," German "re-migration" money, led 923 enemy aliens, some of them "the most dangerous German aliens in the United States," into the hands of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, J. Edgar Hoover, director, disclosed today.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 1 -- London, as the halfway house between Washington and Moscow, today becomes the coordinating center of the United Nations. In effect, the three-power conference is not breaking up at all; it is merely changing its personnel from three Foreign Secretaries to their delegates and is moving to London where it will be set up on a more or less permanent basis as the Allied political commission.

Julian Messner announces that "Valiant Minstrel," by Gladys Malvern, a biography of Sir Harry Lauder, has been bought by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It received the 1943 Award of the Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation for children's books.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October dropped to the smallest of any month in a year, or since last November, but total business for the ten months ending with October was the largest since 1938. Sales failed to cross the million-share mark in any session last month.

Thirty-seven national Jewish organizations are affiliated and cooperating with the National Jewish Welfare Board in welfare activities among Jewish men and women in the armed services, Frank L. Weil, president of the board, announced yesterday.

Daily transactions in stocks during most of last week were largest since September, but prices changed little. News from the Russian front favored the Russians altogether; on other fronts, Allied advance was slower, though the news clearly enough foreshadowed ultimate defeat of Nazis.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Making his first radio address since German troops seized Rome and surrounded Vatican City, Pope Pius XII broadcast a message tonight to the Third National Eucharistic Congress at Trujillo, Peru. He did not touch upon political subjects.

It is significant that the bill to repeal the discriminatory tax on oleomargarine has been introduced in the House by the Chairman of the Agriculture Committee itself -- an indication of shifting farm sentiment that would have seemed scarcely credible a generation ago.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- With the veteran Ed Doherty, their canny field general, picking the proper spots in flawless fashion, Boston College's youthful Eagles rolled up the second lop-sided victory of their informal football season by crushing Brooklyn College, 37 -- 6, today before 9,317 at Fenway Park.
Mayor La Guardia, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday, urged all voters to go to the polls tomorrow and promised them full police protection and an honest count.

The minister of today should be regarded in much the same light as a physician, as an expert trained in the science of the spirit as the doctor is trained in the science of medicine, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and West Twenty-ninth Street, declared yesterday.

With the polls for tomorrow's election scheduled to open at 6 o'clock in the morning, candidates for State and local offices will continue their campaigns until the proverbial eleventh hour on the eve of the election, an unusual occurrence for what was expected to be an "off year."

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- A ripple of orthographical anarchy, which made its first appearance five days ago on the editorial page of The Times of London with the suggestion that people throw off the fetters placed on them by academicians and spell as they please, had reached by tonight the dimensions of a wave that threatened to swallow the language of the world's finest body of literature.

Delegates to the annual meeting of the Eastern Cooperative League in the Labor Temple, Fourteenth Street and Second Avenue, agreed yesterday on the need for supporting strongly the Office of Price Administration's price policing program, but they insisted also on the need for simplying regulations and giving greater representation to consumers in OPA's higher councils.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Justice, proverbially blind, is in no condition to smell, either, Senator Francis Maloney of Connecticut discovered today in a hallowe'en-timed inspection of vandalism at the United States Capitol.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The Jersey City Democratic and Republican organizations held their wind-up rallies of the election campaign this afternoon, with each side claiming victory for their candidates -- Mayor Frank Hague for the Democratic nominee for Governor, Mayor Vincent J. Murphy of Newark, and Senator W. Warren Barbour for Walter E. Edge of Ventnor City, the Republican candidate.

While American, British and Russian statesmen celebrated the conclusion of their first three-power conference with a fraternal banquet in the Kremlin featured by toasts to unity and victory, the Allied armies continued to support these toasts with smashing advances on all fronts that are drawing the ring ever tighter around the beleaguered Nazi fortress.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- British, New Zealand and Canadian warplanes battered the Cherbourg peninsula yesterday, striking especially at Nazi air bases, for the eighth Allied attack there in thirteen days and slashed rail targets in northern France.

Notre Dame is so far in front of the college football pack, following its crushing defeat of Navy, that the race for the season's top award seems all but over. Frank Leahy's thunderbolt in green towers above its rivals as did the Chicago Bears in the professional ranks in 1940, the year of the T renaissance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle completed today the drawing up of the papers for prompt Government seizure of the nation's coal mines under a Presidential Order. He acted at the approach of the midnight deadline set by the United Mine Workers June 22 for the end of a "truce" and resumption of a general strike if no contract had been signed.

MADRID, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The weekly Espanol said today that it had uncovered a "Spanish Masonic plot" led by Diego Martinez Barrio, former Premier and President of the Cortes of the Spanish Republic designed to overthrow Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

The bloodstained uniform worn by Wayne Lonergan when he bludgeoned and strangled his estranged wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, in her triplex apartment at 313 East Fifty-first Street was still the object of a search in the East River yesterday -- a week after the murder to which young Lonergan has confessed.

Charles B. Sears, referee in the proceedings against former Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio, has recommended that there be no disbarment. This decision is not based on the ground that Mr. Aurelio has been proved innocent, but apparently on the ground merely that there was no direct evidence that he knew of Costello's background at the time he asked for and accepted his aid in winning the Supreme Court nomination.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Premier Marshal Joseph Stalin, glittering in his new marshal's uniform and obviously in fine spirits, arose at last night's state dinner in the Kremlin and proposed toasts to the success of the three-power conference, the United States and British armies in Italy, and their airmen in Britain.

To insure that the port of New York realizes its potentialities as a major terminus for overseas and domestic air transport after the war, the Port of New York Authority is beginning comprehensive studies in the air transport terminal field, it was announced yesterday by Frank C. Ferguson, the chairman.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Harvesting of corn is becoming general in the main producing area following a few days' delay occasioned by rain. More than 20 per cent of the Nebraska corn is reported to have been gathered so far, and 10 per cent or more of the Iowa and Illinois grain is in crib or has been snapped for feed and other purposes.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 -- The Red Wings began the defense of their National Hockey League championship by smashing out an 8-to-3 victory over the Rangers tonight before 12,040 spectators.

Two new day-care centers for children of working mothers, the Cadman Children's Center, at 13 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, and the Fort Greene Children's Center, in the Fort Greene Housing Project, Brooklyn, will be opened today, under the city-State program, it was announced yesterday by Miss Helen M. Harris, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:
The six proposed constitutional amendments up for approval at tomorrow's election occupy the traditional place for referendum matters, at the top of the voting machines.

The New York Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York made public yesterday a report on "Arbitration of War Contracts," embodying a three-point program designed to formulate for government consideration a unified program to be followed in terminations of war contracts.

A triplex maisonette garden apartment containing sixteen rooms and four baths in 447 East Fifty-seventh Street has been leased by Count Giovanni Cardelli through William A. White Sons and the Payson McL. Merrill Company.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31 -- "Keep 'Em Skiing" was the slogan adopted by the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association as it concluded an interesting two-day convention today at the Hotel Bancroft.

America need not fear a post-war debt of $200,000,000,000 to $300,000,000,000, according to Stuart Chase, who has just completed a special report on "Where's the Money Coming From?" for the Twentieth Century Fund.

Since none of this season's new plays bears the stamp of unanimous approval by the critics, Mary Elizabeth Sherwood, a newcomer to Broadway, believes that a revival of a tried and true hit would ring the bell for all concerned.

Rabaul is not just another Japanese position to be captured in an interminable process of island hopping. It is the keystone of the arch through which all Japanese strategy in the southwest Pacific has moved since the beginning of the war. If the enemy is driven out of Rabaul he will probably be forced to abandon his first line of defense and offense everywhere south of the equator.

The success of parties for service men at 1 Beekman Place last season echoed through the far corners of the world, according to ample evidence at this season's opener. There were 200 men present and some told of hearing of the Saturday night parties while in remote combat zones.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The Treasury's Division of Tax Research estimated tonight that by Dec. 31 all corporations in the country will have earned an aggregate of $29,000,000,000, after taxes, since 1939. Dividend payments in the period are placed at $16,700,000,000, leaving the corporations with net earnings of $12,300,000, 000.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- The Albany County Democratic organization, controlled by the O'Connells, and which prevented Governor Dewey from making a clear sweep of all up-State counties in the 1938 and 1942 Gubernatorial elections, has thrown its full resources into a drive to duplicate those performances this year by giving a substantial majority on Tuesday to Gen. William N. Haskell, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor.

Any woman in search of beauty is invited to come on a guided tour of the shops and salons of New York. New forms of cosmetic art are turning up with amazing regularity -- considering the maze off restrictions and shortages which manufacturers face these days -- and each of them offers help for a wartime ill.

The threatened strike of employes of the Children's Bus Service, Inc., who transport 12,000 school children in the five boroughs daily, was averted yesterday as a result of intervention by Mayor La Guardia. The employes, members of the Amalgamated Association of Street Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, Local 1181, had announced on Saturday that they would go on strike this morning in a wage dispute in negotiations for renewal of a contract.

Laszlo Halasz, artistic and musical director of the St. Louis Grand Opera Association from 1937 to 1942, has been named artistic and musical director for a series of operatic productions to be presented this season by the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., at the New York City Center, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Unless some self-controls adequate to replace the regimentation of war are cultivated, the pendulum may swing from soldiers to playboys as in the "jazz era" after World War I, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in his sermon at Christ Church Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Public offerings of new securities increased sharply here in October, as underwriters resumed business activities following their participation in the Third War Loan Drive. New bond financing was more than double the September figure and well above that for a year ago. Stock offerings were the largest for any month since July, 1941.

Women professionally trained in social welfare work are being transported "from the mainland" to act as directors and assistant directors of clubs of the United Service Organizations in Hawaii, Edwin E. Bond, USO director of program and personnel for the territory, reported yesterday.

Relying upon assurances from Washington that rent control in New York, which starts today, will not be in the hands of "the politicians," the city is prepared to give its fullest cooperation to the Office of Price Administration in the task of registering 800,000 or more landlords, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

The increased and more deadly armament on Hitler's fighter aviation, which made us pay so heavily in bomber losses at Schweinfurt recently, should stimulate thinking about the tactical relationship between bomber and fighter types of aircraft.
ALGIERS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WITH THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET, Monday, Nov. 1 (Reuter) -- An American soldier is acting as Governor of an island that the Germans do not yet know has been occupied.

The Free World Congress, arranged by the Free World Association, in which Mrs. J. Borden Harriman is active, closed a three-day session at the Hotel McAlpin by adopting yesterday a resolution offered by Orson Welles, dramatist, endorsing the amendment of Senator Claude R. Pepper to the Connally resolution now before the Senate.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Demand for posed rollback in prices. The trade feature of the business last week being moderate sales to soap manufacturers, who are said to have taken both prime steam and pork rendered fat. Domestic demand continues on a hand-to-mouth basis pending further developments in regard to the proposed roll-back in prices.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The important Japanese air base at Rabaul, on New Britain Island, suffered another of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's sledgehammer blows on Friday. A strong force of Liberators, escorted by Lightnings, destroyed forty-

Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, retired, Democratic and American Labor party candidate for Lieutenant Governor, who headed a mission to Armenia after the First World War, spoke yesterday at a meeting of 500 Armenians at the Heckscher Theatre, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 323 West Thirty-ninth Street, near Eighth Avenue, has been sold by the trustees of Series C-2 Jerome Greene, realtor operator of 551 Fifth Avenue, for cash over a mortgage of $225,000.

KUKONG, China, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- Because of the food shortage in Hong Kong the Japanese are rounding up the elderly and infirm and persons incapable of work and dumping them ashore at Taipang on Bias Bay, where they become charges of the Kwangtung International Relief.

A UNITED STATES ARMY HOSPITAL in Britain, Oct. 31 -- The empty coat sleeves, artificial legs or stiff-jointed limbs that have been a badge of combat soldiers for centuries will not be so numerous among American fighting men seeing action in this war.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 111.3 to 111.05. This decline of 0.2 per cent was entirely due to decreases in the prices of agricultural commodities. The farm products index dropped 0.8 per cent and the foodstuffs index dropped 0.7 per cent, principally as a result of declines in the prices of eggs and potatoes.

Lest we forget 4,000 blind men, women and children served by the Lighthouse, headquarters of the New York Association for the Blind, we suggest a tour of the four buildings we maintain in Manhattan to help the blind to help themselves.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 -- "Blonde Brita" Banner, Swedish "radio siren" of the German broadcasting system, has suddenly walked out on her employer, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, and is back in Sweden with no intention of returning to Germany until the war is over.

ALGIERS, Oct. 31 -- The slow, grinding process by which Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army is pushing the Germans back to the rocky stronghold barring the way to Rome continued yesterday as the British and American troops captured Ailano and Nocelleto, crossing the narrow Savone River to envelop Ciamprisco.

As a soldier in overseas service I have been in a position to observe at first hand the reactions of service men to the so-called "cushioning" plan for demobilization, recently submitted to the President by the National Resources Planning Board Conference on Readjustment of Civilian and Military Personnel.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 -- Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, attempting to explain the prolonged resistance which Yugoslav guerrillas have maintained against Nazi forces, told the German home front in the Nazi press today that it was due to American and British support.
Five pictures are listed to have Broadway premieres this week. They are:

Cotton prices held virtually steady last week until toward the close of the period, when they registered a relatively sharp drop. At the close of trading on Saturday, active old-type futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 10 to 25 points.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- United States Tenth Air Force

ADMIRAL HALSEY'S HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 1 -- American forces are fighting a sharp engagement with the Japanese midway between the landing spot at Voza, on Choiseul Island, and the Japanese barge depot at Sangagai, which has been reinforced.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Oct. 29 -- Bishop Walter Baddeley, head of the Anglican Church in Melanesia, who stayed in Central Solomons throughout the Japanese occupation, said today he did not see anything remarkable in his accomplishment.

Mayor La Guardia declared in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall yesterday that even closer cooperation with the Office of Price Administration in "the administration of food laws and the control of ceiling prices" could be expected "with the reorganization which will take place in OPA."

A fateful question has been answered in Moscow, and the sense of the answer has already spread through Europe. While the official report will not be published until today, the effects of the conference are as visible in Germany, in the Balkans, in all the continental nations, as were the first repercussions of the collapse of Italy.

CAMP HALE, PANDO, Col., Oct. 25 (Delayed) -- Snow comes early in the Rockies and several inches of it lay in the shade of the aspen thickets and pine forests today as the Tenth Light Division, burdened with mountain packs, climbed slowly up the steep slopes of the Colorado mountains.

Metropolitan devotees of the strenuous pastimes of horse wrangling, calf roping and kindred Western activities turned out in greater numbers than ever before for this year's rodeo in Madison Square Garden, it was announced last night, after the final performance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The War Production Board announced today several substantial changes in its Order L-41, placing limits on construction, the changes being part of a redrafting of the order to make it more easily understood by the public.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 -- Continued favorable war reports and further lack of activity in spots brought in increased hedge selling and liquidation in cotton futures here last week. It was one of the quietest and narrowest weeks of the season thus far, with many traders evidently inclined to await further clues as to what the President will do about his talk to Congress on subsidies for commodities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- In a last-minute switch of casting Arturo de Cordova will have the lead opposite Betty Hutton in "The Incendiary Blonde," the Paramount picture to be based on the life of Texas Guinan, on which production will start tomorrow on location at Phoenix, Ariz.

First figures on the new series of advertisements by the Life Insurance Companies of America, data on the bond drive publicity and on readership of new campaigns and newly developed techniques, are contained in the report in the Sept. 9th issue of The Waukegan News-Sun -- No. 64 in The Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading series, issued today by the Advertising Research Foundation, Inc.
November is Food for Freedom Month, so named by the Government in an effort to draw attention to what it calls "the mightiest weapon of the war."
Four bond calls and one invitation to tender bonds have been announced for today.
Four bond calls and one invitation to tender bonds have been announced for today.

Growing nervousness over the favorable European war developments dominated the trading in cotton futures yesterday as aggressive liquidation and hedge selling brought about an easier tone in the market. After declining to lows of 7 to 14 points earlier in the day, the list of active old contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the session with quotations unchanged to 5 points below Saturday's finals.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Major league baseball men sat in on a quiet draft session at Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis' office today, those from eight clubs intoning "pass" each time their team's name was called and the remaining eight dipping into the grab bag for fifteen players, five less than were taken last year.

The campaign to elect Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, retired, as Lieutenant Governor came to an end last night with James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, charging Governor Dewey with having "misrepresented the record" on at least two occasions in his support of Senator Joe R. Hanley, the Republican nominee.

Samuel Miller, wholesale and retail meat dealer of 2308 Twelfth Avenue, who is described by the Office of Price Administration as one of Father Divine's suppliers, appeared yesterday at a hearing at OPA headquarters in the Empire State Building to answer to a charge of violating an OPA suspension order.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Ways and Means Committee today pushed the yield of the new tax bill up to an estimated $2,183,000,000 as it neared the end of work on the revenue raising sections of the measure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Roosevelt, in his longest message to Congress, today stoutly defended the use of food subsidies and left little doubt that he would veto any bill which sought to prevent use on them.

Striking at "a lot of unrealistic and undiluted optimism in post-war planning," Leon Henderson, chairman of the Board of Editors of the Research Institute of America and former administrator of the Office of Price Administration, yesterday urged business men to prepare for a business decline between 1944 and 1946 which may result in a peak unemployment of 12,000,000 workers.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- The Yugoslav People's Army of Liberation today announced the formation of a Partisan Air Force to aid its 180,000 ground troops, and appealed to all former military and civilian pilots and ground crews to register immediately for service against the Germans.

At the top of the voting machine today the voter will find six proposed Amendments, and below them a list of candidates for State and local offices. We summarize here the recommendations which this newspaper has made to its readers.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Charged with acting as a spy for Germany, John DaSilva Purvis, 43 years old, of 205 Walnut Street, went on trial today before Federal District Court Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a jury of ten women and two men. The court decided that because national security is involved, the public must be barred from the trial.

Command of the Eastern Sea Frontier was assumed yesterday by Vice Admiral Herbert Fairfax Leary at a brief ceremony in headquarters at 90 Church Street. He succeeded Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews, who reached the statutory retirement age of 64 last month but who will continue on active duty in another unspecified post.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The German propaganda machine, after four and a half hours of stunned silence, replied to the decisions reached by the United States, Britain and Russia in Moscow with the well-worn Nazi battle cry that Britain and the United States, but more especially the latter, were selling out Europe to Bolshevism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Although Secretary of State Cordell Hull went to Moscow with wide powers as a representative of President Roosevelt, to enter into executive agreements, some of the decisions reached were viewed in Congress today as having provided bases for pacts that would ultimately receive ratification by a two-thirds vote of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Purchase by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway of 60,000 shares of Wheeling Lake Erie common stock would be in the public interest and a step toward consolidating five Midwestern railroads into a unified system providing competition with other large systems in the area, the Interstate Commerce Commission was told today.

The new draft regulations under which delinquents will be placed in Class 1A without regard to dependency or employment status, and those between 18 and 38 years old ordered to report for induction immediately, became effective yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- After months of striving the aircraft industry last month finally achieved a production pace which, if continued, will give the United States an output of almost 100,000 planes annually. The October production exceeded 8,200 planes (some officials said it would be closer to 8,300 than 8,200) for the first time since the country's wartime production program for aircraft got under way.

ELGIN, Ill., Nov. 1 (AP) -- An unemployed cripple strangled his 19-year-old "mail order" bride with her own stocking, State's Attorney Charles G. Seidel said today, because the man "didn't want to see her suffer too much" from poverty.

President Ismet Inonu of Turkey, addressing the opening session of the Turkish Grand National Assembly yesterday, avowed his country's faith in "order based on the sincere cooperation of all free nations of the world, great and small."

The seven branches of the Office of Price Administration handling the enforcement of the rent freezing order that became effective yesterday opened on schedule at 9 A.M. Shortly thereafter many landlords began to arrive to make inquiries and to obtain the required registration forms.
NAPLES, Nov. 1 -- One of the most extraordinary evacuations in modern history took place in Naples today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Women are now working as welders in shipyards, aircraft factories, machine shops, munitions works and on precision instruments, and are making good in all these war industries, according to a report made public today by Miss Mary Anderson, chief of the Women's Bureau in the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Promp and gratified comments were forth coming here today from the diplomatic representatives of European countries with important stakes in the negotiations at Moscow. Ambassadors and Ministers of occupied countries stressed their expressions of satisfaction at the announcement that war criminal would be brought to trial in the countries that have been the scene of their crimes.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 10 per cent for the week ended Oct. 30, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Prolonged rainfall last week and the fact that the comparable week of last year showed a 19 per cent gain due to a "beat-the-tax" buying rush on liquors, were major factors in the sales drop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 27, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Decreases of $254,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills and $790,000,000 in United States Government deposits and an increase of $451,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

Camp La Guardia, the Department of Welfare farm at Greycourt, N.Y., for rehabilitating homeless men, was added yesterday to the list of beneficiaries of Department of Sanitation labor and equipment as Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands brought toward its final stage his public inquiry into the use of such labor and equipment in developing the vacation resort for sanitation workers near Holmes, N.Y.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State; Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, announced tonight that their Governments had agreed to closer collaboration in the conduct of the war and pledged the creation of an international organization to maintain future world peace and security -- a declaration to which China adhered as an original signatory.

GUADALCANAL, Tuesday, Nov. 2 -- Green-clad United States Marines swarmed ashore from landing craft early yesterday against fortified Japanese positions at Empress Augusta Bay on the west side of Bougainville Island in the biggest single Allied landing in this theatre.
