WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- American Liberty ships, like American bombers, are taking every thing the Axis can throw, and are still chugging to port when, by all the rules of seaworthiness, they should be on the bottom of the ocean.

Perhaps Max Reinhardt did not attain in America the unique position he occupied in Europe because Broadway had already thrilled to his touch of revolutionary theatre ten years before he himself was driven here by Nazi persecution. In Europe he was the pioneering producer of his generation, giving the classics and contemporary plays alike a scope and vitality others could not duplicate.

Government and anthracite producers' representatives conferred here yesterday on plans to stretch the city's meager supply of anthracite against the general strike of miners. Meanwhile, the City Markets Department began a license suspension action against one of the local major coal distributors charged with distributing non-combustible coal.

The Army-Notre Dame game was the main gridiron topic at yesterday's luncheon of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's restaurant. Talks were given by one of Army's coaches and the public relations counsel of Notre Dame.

THE football folk can converse about the past, the present or the future with equal facility, and were busily engaged in doing same at their weekly soiree yesterday. The names which were tossed around most frequently were Bertelli, Lujack, Davis and Hutson, all of them fitting neatly into the three-time categories.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 2 -- The Red Army trapped tens of thousands of Germans in the Crimea yesterday by cutting the Perekop Isthmus, and Moscow announced early today that one fleeing enemy group above the peninsula had been surrounded, losing 2,000 killed and 6,000 captured in a continuing battle of annihilation.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Ralph W. Gallagher, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, predicted here today a greatly increased demand for petroleum from Venezuela and said he expected an expansion of investment here to boost production and permit refining of the oil in Venezuela.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Bayard Sharp's Knight's Quest, after having poor racing luck in two starts, escaped trouble today and won the $5,000 added Battleship Steeplechase Handicap at Pimlico.

A city-wide search was started yesterday for Margaret Leighton Moore, 13-year-old daughter of Major David Dodge Moore of the Army Medical Corps and Mrs. Moore, who vanished with two sailors from the Mall in Central Park late Sunday afternoon.
J.J. Singh, president of the India League of America, issued an appeal yesterday for substantial immediate relief for famine sufferers in India by the United Nations.

IT has become almost platitudinous to say that the future peace of the world depends on Soviet Russia. She is the country that sits in back of our enemies. Her attitude toward Europe must inevitably determine the psychological climate of some twenty-five nations that are cramped between the Pripet marshes and the Atlantic Ocean.

A professor of New York University, lecturing to members of his class, referred yesterday to them as students of N.Y.U., only to be corrected by one who asserted, "We are not students, sir, but mans and womans learning at Washington Square College of New York University."

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Grain markets showed a weak undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but the surplus in the rye pit was taken by houses with Eastern connections. When shorts tried to cover they found offerings light and prices ran up 1 5/8 to 2 1/2 cents from the low, with the close at the top for gains of 3/4 to 1 5/8 cents, the latter on December.
Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wood Robert Jr. are expected to arrive today from Washington and will be at the Ritz-Carlton.

Trading was timid yesterday on the stock market and, except for bursts of strength in some specialties and a few "peace" issues, prices fluctuated irregularly. The failure to establish any definite trend was accompanied by the smallest business in more than a week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The three-power declaration on German atrocities, the most strongly worded yet issued on the subject and the only one in which Premier Stalin has directly participated, defined today for the first time the jurisdiction over the responsible individuals and the time for their trial and punishment.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Allocation of hundreds of thousands of dollars in new Seaboard Airline Railway securities will depend in part upon interpretation of ninety-year-old Virginia and North Carolina laws, attorneys testified in United States District Court today.

Despite the War Production Board's recent action clearing the way for use of synthetic rubber in civilian garments and products, the lack of skilled labor in elastic thread mills as well as the scarcity of both cotton and rayon yarns suitable for covering the synthetic rubber thread will prevent users of elastic yarn from taking immediate advantage of the opportunity, suppliers declared yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 1 -- Germany has now proclaimed mobilization of all Estonian males born from 1902 to 1922, inclusive, according to information received by telephone from Helsinki.

ALGIERS, Nov. 1 -- As rain swept the entire Italian front, the Allied Fifth and Eighth Armies pressed indomitably forward through mud yesterday to increase their threats to Isernia and Venafro. Further advances in the center of the line ranged up to four miles.

Reviewing the record of his administration, Governor Dewey made last night his final plea to the people of the State for the election of State Senator Joe R. Hanley, Republican nominee for Lieutenant-Governor.

Increase in the air mail postage rate from 6 to 10 cents an ounce, as proposed in the new tax increase recommendations of the House Ways and Means Committee a few days ago, could prove, in my opinion, most damaging to the future progress of American air transportation as well as detrimental to business and public morale.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- At press conferences last night Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden both made it clear the Moscow meetings had accomplished far more than the most optimistic had predicted before it began. Mr. Eden spoke off the record but Mr. Hull permitted attribution of his remarks without direct quotation.

A thirty-day newspaper drive for the production of a cord of pulpwood for every man in the armed services from pulpwood communities will be launched on Armistice Day, Nov. 11, it was announced yesterday by Walter M. Dear, chairman of the Newspaper Pulpwood Committee.

The Election Day scholastic football program in the metropolitan area today calls for twenty-five games. Seven contests are listed for city gridirons, with the thirty-sixth meeting between Manual Training and Erasmus Hall at Ebbets Field featuring the card.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The reports released here today that the Moscow conference has been a success cheered stock markets, although there was little favorable activity outside of the home railways section, in which all the leading issues went ahead.

As the children came in their eyes showed delighted surprise, and as they went out their arms were full of toys. At the opening of the Toyery, a toy-lending "library" at the Ethical Culture School, 33 Central Park West, twenty children from the school's community play center, for once in their lives, had plenty of toys.

Asserting that the biggest issue in today's election "is whether the combination of politics and racketeers in the greatest city in the world will prevail," Mayor La Guardia urged last night the election of Matthew M. Levy to the Supreme Court as the only means of assuring the defeat of Thomas A. Aurelio.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The European Advisory Commission will start work soon on the way in which civil affairs are to be handled in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Norway after the invasion of the Continent from the west, it was learned tonight.

For the next two weeks the thousand members of the New York City Cancer Committee's Women's Field Army will interrupt their program to man fifty booths set up in the metropolitan area for the sale of labels during the State-wide drive for funds.

Robert R. Kaufman, 29 'years I, a lawyer and former New York liversity football player, was tested at his home at 234 West td Avenue, Brooklyn, early yes:day morning as the sixth man an alleged conspiracy to extort 500 from Robert B. Wheelan, Z d of a photograph mounting ldio at 370 Seventh Avenue, to U off picketing of the concern by bogus "Congress of Industrial lions."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The hopeful prospect opened to all "sovereign peace-loving states" by the Four-Power Declaration and corollary proclamations of the Moscow Conference is so vast that only small areas can be closely surveyed at a time. Each of these is of supreme importance, and each will be the subject of millions of words and the locus of numerous events during the war and thereafter.

With the postponement of "The Innocent Voyage" from Nov. 12 to Nov. 15 at the Belasco, next week's entries have been reduced to three. Those players who started practicing on Oct. 4, when rehearsals began, are now under full salary, since the actors union rules allow a maximum rehearsal period of twenty-eight days for plays.

The confusing 2-year-olds became more involved than ever yesterday at the Jamaica race track, where Sweeping Time captured the $5,240 Apollo Handicap, returning $21.20, while several stake winners battled for the lesser places.

Having been reared on a farm central New York and now living retirement on this farm, that I bought more than thirty-five years ago, I would like to shake the hand of the man who wrote the unique editorial "Woodsheds."

Your newspaper has editorially advised the voters of the State to vote "No" on Constitutional Amendment No. 3, which would permit the division of the Town of Hempstead, Nassau County, into more than one Assembly district. The recent reapportionment act has apportioned to Nassau County four Assemblymen.

Hundreds of false registrations in Manhattan were reported yesterday by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who, in a joint statement, charged that the names of service men were forged on registration books and that Queens residents were found to have registered from a Manhattan apartment.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- In spite of soaring taxes and other expenses, 204 operating electric and gas subsidiaries of registered holding companies that were included in a survey by the Securities and Exchange Commission had an average common stock return of 9.55 per cent in 1942, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The following are the texts of the joint communique issued by the three-power conference at Moscow and of four documents issued in connection with the conference:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The War Production Board today lifted the ban against the use of patch pockets on men's wool clothing in a move to meet a growing scarcity of rayon and cotton linings for men's apparel. As a result of the move WPB believes that substantial quantities of linings will be conserved and available supplies will be spread more widely.

New and practical suggestions concerning the skillful use of soy in cookery were offered yesterday by Mrs. Ellen Semrow, who spoke on behalf of Durkee Famous Foods at a luncheon for the press at the Hotel Biltmore. The occasion was the introduction in this area of two products made by the company -- a soy flour called Soyarich and soy grits (a less fatty, coarser edition of the flour) trade-named Soya Bits.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Government is working on a program to permit manufacture of mechanical refrigerators and washing machines again.
OWI harnesses imagination to practical purposes when it tells the story of what American gasoline did to help break Marshal Rommel at El Alamein a year ago and turn the tide of war in North Africa.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- A communique:

By unanimous decision of the four justices who were sitting, the Appellate Division confirmed yesterday the report of Official Referee Charles B. Sears and dismissed the disbarment proceeding against former Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio, whose name will appear on the voting machines in Manhattan and the Bronx today as the nominee of the Democratic and Republican parties for the Supreme Court.

The General Electric Credit Corporation has been organized as a financing subsidiary of the General Electric Company under the banking law of New York State, and will broaden the scope of activities carried on since 1933 by General Electric Contracts Corporation, whose business will be assumed by the new concern.

Bob Steuber of De Pauw (Ind.) College regained the nominal leadership in the nation's football scoring race last week, but the real honors went to Tony Butkovich of Purdue, according to The Associated Press.

Small hats received the endorsement of Mme. Reine yesterday noon as she held her second New York showing in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel. This Parisienne, who arrived here early this year, displays luxurious furs and smart hats in her New York showroom at 4 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- During the small-scale Nazi air attack on the London metropolitan area last night British anti-aircraft gunners destroyed their first Messerschmitt 410 plane, which has been described as Germany's "answer" to the Royal Air Force's fast Mosquito fighter-bomber.

The voters of Manhattan and the Bronx will find the name of Thomas A. Aurelio on their voting machines today as the regular candidate of the Republican and Democratic parties. Both parties have tried to get rid of him, but there he is. He is running for a seat on the Supreme Court, which presupposes ability, experience and a spotless record.
The report of Charles B. Sears as referee in the disbarment action against former Magistrate Charles A. Aurelio follows, except for his summary of the evidence:

Dr. Harry James Carman, Moore Collegiate Professor of History, has been appointed Dean of Columbia College to succeed the late Herbert E. Hawkes, Dr. Nichoas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday after a meeting of the university trustees.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- President Roosevelt, in a message to the sixth annual convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, warned today that "new demands," including the freezing of labor in war plants, would be made of labor in the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Critical shortages of natural gas for industrial use in the Appalachian area today caused the Office of War Utilities to order all industrial consumers with standby facilities for burning residual fuel oil not to use natural gas between Nov. 15 and March 31.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- President Roosevelt took a hand in the bitterly contested Philadelphia Mayoralty campaign today by defending the record of William C. Bullitt, the Democratic candidate, as Ambassador to Russia and France.

The opening of Palestine to Jewish refugees and its reconstitution as a Jewish commonwealth were demanded last night at a meeting in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Zionist Organization of America in cooperation with other Jewish organizations, on the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Balfour Declaration.

Supplies of metallic raw materials for steel making appear sufficient to permit capacity production for a normal period ahead, unless unforeseen interruptions recur in the flow of these materials, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Warner Brothers will co-star Jack Carson and Jane Wyman in "Make Your Own Bed," a comedy to be based on a recently acquired play, "On the Hiring Line." The picture will be directed by Peter Godfrey.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an average increase of less than 1 per cent in October over the like month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The peak in the rate of Treasury borrowing has apparently been reached, owing to the decline in the sharp month-to-month increases in war expenditures and to the enlarged tax receipts under the Current Tax Payment Plan, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said in its monthly review of credit and business conditions, issued yesterday.
SOMEWHERE IN SOUTHERN ITALY, Nov. 1 -- Premier Pietro Badoglio told King Victor Emmanuel today that he could not form a representative Government while the King remained in power.

"Old Acquaintance," Warners' screen version of the John Van Druten stage success, will have its local premiere today at the Hollywood Theatre. Starring Bette Davis and Miriam Hopkins, the drama, which was directed by Vincent Sherman, features John Loder, Gig Young and a newcomer, Dolores Moran.

Times Square's incandescent tiara, hidden in the dimout chest for the last eighteen months, burst into about 40 per cent of its pre-war brilliance last night, as lighting restrictions were eased. It wore all its jewels except the giant spectaculars.

All Wall Street securities and commodity exchanges will be closed today, as will all banks in New York State, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Virginia, on account of State elections. Some banks in Ohio will be closed part of the day.

ALGIERS, Nov. 1 -- Unable to furnish much close support to the ground forces in Italy because of the weather yesterday, Allied planes continued their strategic attacks on targets far beyond the front line with blows at southern France and Albania.

Walter Duranty will be the speaker at the opening session of this season's Town Hall lectures, on Wednesday at 11 A.M. Mr. Duranty will speak on "Russia and the Peace.' Other authors who will speak this season include Ira Wolfert, Le Grand Cannon Jr., Andre Maurois, Waldo Frank, Emil Ludwig, Henry J. Taylor, Edward Weeks, Sinclair Lewis, Lewis Browne and Margaret Culkin Banning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The War Production Board announced today grants of 1,213 additional tons of newsprint to seventy-six newspapers for the fourth quarter of 1943.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- In anticipation of post-war plans for preserving the rural environs of London -- known as the metropolis' "green belt" -- the Hertfordshire County Council voted today to purchase the late J. Pierpont Morgan's Wall Hall estate near Aldenham.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The War Labor Board today approved amendments to the labor contract at the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation on recommendation of a referee, who reported that the relationship between union and management, once explosive, is now "a splendid one."

Unless private enterprise is unduly restricted by Government in the post-war period this country will see the largest market for advertising and printed promotion that it has ever witnessed in its history, Arthur P. Hirose, director of market research and promotion, McCall Corporation, and coordinator of post-war research, War Advertising Council, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- By cementing their military alliance into an effective implement for shortening the war against Germany and by agreeing among themselves and China on the necessity of post-war cooperation, the United States, Great Britain and Russia were believed by many here in Washington today to have produced results that alone were sufficient to be considered as the Allies' greatest political triumph of the war.

The eight-story loft building at 15 East Thirty-first Street has been sold by the trustees of Series C-2, represented by Oscar C. Mann, to a client of William Trow, broker. This building is assessed for $50,000 and was bought for cash above a mortgage of $36,000. Smith Levin represented the buyers.
Both the East and West Sides of the midtown section shared in the residential leasing activity reported yesterday by brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The four-nation declaration at Moscow today received a rousing welcome in Congress, with calls arising in the Senate for the adoption of its principles and provisions, if not the text itself, as that body's endorsement of continued Allied collaboration through the post-war period to maintain the peace.
The game of the year in college football comes to New York this week.

The rarely heard sonata for 'cello and piano by Debussy featured last night's 'cello recital at Town Hall by Stefan Auber, well-known artist, who had been with the Kolisch Quartet and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, Another sonata for piano and 'cello also was given, Beethoven's Opus 69, in A major.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The defense agreed today that Alfred de Marigny made the fingerprint being used in an effort to convict him of the murder of Sir Harry Oakes. But attorneys continued their fight against the contention that the print in evidence was found on a bedscreen in the room where the defendant's father-in-law was beaten and burned last July.

Artur Rodzinski and Bruno Walter will share the conductor's podium at the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts this month. Mr. Walter will lead the orchestra from Thursday through the 14th. Dr. Rodzinski will take over on Nov. 17. The orchestra will travel to Princeton on Nov. 20 and Kingston on the 22d.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The War Department announced today the names of 263 soldiers listed as missing in action. The Asiatic European, Mediterranean and Southwest Pacific areas were represented.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- American ground forces captured Empress Augusta Bay in a bold invasion of west-central Bougainville Island at dawn Monday, 260 miles away from Japan's big key base at Rabaul, and Gen. Douglas MacArthur challenged the Japanese Navy to come out and fight.

ALGIERS, Nov. 1 -- If anyone should go to 125 West Eleventh Street in Greenwich Village and ask for Nana Rae he would be told that she did not live there any more. She is now Staff Sgt. Nana Rae, who takes dictation from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Roosevelt, as Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, tonight ordered Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes to take immediate possession of the coal mines as a result of the fourth war strike of 530,000 bituminous and anthracite mine workers.

Ballet Theatre last night devoted its entire program at the Metropolitan Opera House to ballets by Antony Tudor, and an enormous audience in which were many prominent dancers turned out to enjoy an evening with this most brilliant of modern choreographers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 1 -- One of the critical problems that the Allies must solve when Europe is liberated is the future of Greece and of Yugoslavia. Those nations -- the only Balkan members of the United Nations bloc -- serve as a link between the Soviet sphere and that of western Europe and between any conceivable Danubian federation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Harry Mahnken, Princeton's wartime football coach, who was drafted from his job of tutoring the 150-pound team to the unenviable task of building a varsity eleven at Old Nassau, strongly favors limiting the defense for the duration.

Three well-known attorneys were appointed yesterday by General Sessions Judge John J. Sullivan to defend Wayne Lonergan, confessed slayer of his 22-year-old wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, in her apartment at 313 East Fifty-first Street on Oct. 24.

The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a net profit of $18,087,047 after reserve of $23,400,000 for taxes. The profit was equivalent to $4.52 a common share and compared with $17,067,231, or $4.26 a share, earned in the corresponding period of 1942.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Sales of soft wheat in the thirty-four States east of the Rocky Mountains were ordered today under maximum-price controls at $1.66 a bushel for No. 1 grade, St. Louis and Chicago basis, effective Nov. 6.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- American and British bomber and fighter fleets, continuing their attrition attacks on Japanese airdromes, supply centers and communications in Burma over the week-end, scored heavily on railway lines leading from the enemy's major bases of Rangoon and Mandalay, Allied communiques reported today.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Specifications of a transport plane that has been an open secret for almost a year and on which Britain will pin her hopes on international commercial air routes in the period immediately following the end of the war were made public today.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- New Jersey voters will go to the polls tomorrow to choose a new Governor and to decide whether to instruct the Legislature to submit to the electorate next year a revised State Constitution. The polls will open at 7 A.M. and close at 8 P.M.

Temporary letters of administration were issued yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty to the Fifth Avenue Bank of New York, executor of the estate of Miss Anne Depew Paulding, niece of the late Chauncey M. Depew, who died on Oct. 20, leaving an estate of $3,436,007.

Few situations since our entrance into the war have been more grimly ironic than that now existing in the coal fields, where half a million men are out on strike. The soft-coal miners have been offered by the War Labor Board an average wage of $60 a week. In January, 1941, they were getting an average of only $26 a week and in 1933 an average of only $14.47 a week.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted from Chungking in Mandarin to the Chinese press and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

FREDONIA, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Nearly 30,000 residents of the Dunkirk-Fredonia area faced a milk famine today as dairy farmers who were prevented by Office of Price Administration ceilings from obtaining a 50-cent-per-hundred-weight increase in milk prices, withheld deliveries to retailers.

With fewer than 4,000,000 voters scheduled to go to the polls today in this State to determine whether Senator Joe R. Hanley, Republican nominee, or Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, retired, Democratic and American Labor party, will be elected Lieutenant Governor, campaigning for these and local candidates continued until midnight.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Japanese forces attempting a new two-pronged drive from above Tungting Lake, apparently in another effort to conquer China's Hunan Province "rice bowl," have been checked or thrown back although fierce fighting is still raging, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The smashing success of the Russian offensive now threatening the destruction of at least forty German divisions along the lower reaches of the Dnieper River has moved one of the best-informed sources on the Eastern military situation to admit today that it is possible the German Army will be defeated so decisively on the Eastern Front this winter that the Reich will sue for peace.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A Tenth United State Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Confirming reports circulated last month the War Food Administration announced today that it has directed the release of approximately 2,790,000 cases of canned peaches, peas and tomato catsup to civilian consumers. The foods to be released are a portion of the reserves owned and held by canners to meet possible emergency requirements of the Government.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- The coal strike in the United States is a blow at the war effort of the United Nations in every theatre of action, writes The Times of London in the leading article this morning. Its survey of the American coal mining industry is linked with problems of price control and the need for taxation to siphon off new cash in circulation.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,268, which compared with 1,431 in the preceding week and 688 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- With rain and gasoline rationing holding the Rockland County vote to the lowest in recent years, Republicans retained control of county offices. State Senator Joe R. Hanley received 12,756 votes in the county against 6,723 Democratic votes and 489 American Labor votes for Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell for Lieutenant Governor.

With over 85 per cent of the plastics industry's production devoted to the war effort, the keynote of the fall meeting of the Society of the Plastics Industry, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Nov. 8 and 9, will be the interchange of information on new materials and processes of manufacture, the society announced yesterday.

City Court Justice Francis E. Rivers was returned yesterday by a 22,641 majority to the judicial post to which he was appointed late last summer. Complete returns from the 919 districts in New York County showed the Negro justice rolled up a total of 166,499 votes to 143,858 for Joseph T. Higgins, his Democratic opponent.

The Moscow Joint Declaration sets the framework for a new structure. It takes us out of the blueprint stage, out of the confusion of competitive and alternative plans drawn in doubt of what Russia, Britain or the United States will or will not do, and starts building for peace.

Senator Joe R. Hanley, Republican nominee for Lieutenant Governor, defeated Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, retired, Democratic and American Labor party candidate, in yesterday's New York State election by a plurality of approximately 345,000.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt, Dutchess County "tree grower" who sometimes identifies himself as President of the United States, voted at the village Town Hall today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Citizens have signed more than 12,000,000 pledges to kill black markets and hold the line against higher prices, Chester Bowles, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, reported today. In a survey of OPA's home front pladge campaign, Mr. Bowles cited New Orleans as the first city to support the voluntary stabilization drive.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans fought on bitterly today against the Germans as Russian armies driving into the Crimea brought nearer the restoration of Sevastopol as the Black Sea base of the Soviet Fleet and as a possible springboard for a thrust against Rumania and Bessarabia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A new high record of aircraft production was achieved last month with the output of 8,362 planes of all types, including the largest number of heavy bombers ever produced in a single month, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, reported today.

Football results so far this season have given the gridiron experts a pretty clear idea of where most of the power is to be found. And, in this week's Associated Press ranking poll, released yesterday, they summed it up in two words: "Notre Dame."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- James Work, founder, first president and a major stockholder of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation today blamed Navy-installed managements for the company's failure to meet plane production schedules.

The observation of Eric Underwood that the national emblem of the United States of America owes its origin to the coat of arms of the Washington family has often been put forward, but isn't the idea a bit too fanciful to be considered seriously?

ALBANY, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Republican strength manifested itself unmistakably in New York's Mayoralty elections today with Republican candidates, on the basis of available returns, holding a three-to-one edge.

The two-family house at 280 Winfield Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Five Corners Building and Loan Association, in voluntary liquidation, to Frank Malamisura through J.I. Kislak, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The contest in the Senate over the form of expression of its attitude on post-war collaboration to maintain the peace took a sudden turn today toward possible endorsement of the Allies' declarations of Moscow. The chamber was confronted with a forty-two-word substitute for the pending Connally resolution, reading as follows:...
Though Joe R. Harley is 67 years old, he seems just past middle age. About as well-known as anyone in New York State politics, he is a native of Iowa and originally was a clergyman.

ALGIERS, Nov. 2 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army has cracked the rocky shell of the German line between Mount Massico and the Matese Ridge and has brought both Venafro and Isernia within artillery range, it was officially announced today.

Though running behind six other candidates for the Supreme Court in the First District, Thomas A. Aurelio has managed to squeeze into the seventh place over a divided opposition and is elected. To whom should his thanks go? First to Frank Costello, characterized by Referee Sears as "an ex-convict, a person of bad reputation, an associate of malefactors and gangsters."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- The War Department revealed today the remarkable feat of an Army Air Force camera man who photographed one of the fiercest aerial battles of the war from the top of a Flying Fortress thousands of feet over Germany.

The Martin Mars, the world's largest flying boat, which has long been under development and has undergone exhaustive tests, finally was turned over to the Navy Department yesterday. This announcement, which opens the way for future construction of the ships in multiple numbers, was made by the Glenn L. Martin Company.

Retail price ceilings for turkey went up 2 and 3 cents a pound yesterday in the New York district at the same time that the Food Distribution Administration promised there would be plenty of birds for Thanksgiving.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Nov. 2 -- Acting Mayor Bernard Samuel, Republican, was elected Mayor of Philadelphia for a full term tonight, defeating his Democratic opponent, William C. Bullitt, as the climax of one of the most bitterly waged political campaigns here in years.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- Moss Hart's new Army Air Forces play, "Winged Victory," took off auspiciously at the Shubert Theatre here tonight before a crowd of well-wishers who filled every available place permitted by Boston's fire regulations.

The Clement Cleveland Medal, given annually for outstanding service in the cause of cancer control, was presented in absentia last night to Dr. Frederick L. Hoffman of San Diego, Calif., whose ideas led to the foundation thirty years ago of the American Society for the Control of Cancer.

FLINT, Mich., Nov. 2 (AP) -- More than 10,000 employes of General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division voted by nearly 4 to 1 in a referendum yesterday in favor of taking strike action because of accumulated grievances.

Swap shops for clothing and household wares, modeled after British garment exchanges, may be opened soon in various public schools in the city, Mrs. Nathaniel Singer, consumer chairman of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization, declared yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 2 -- The Democratic city administration here received its first political setback at the polls in more than fifteen years in a referendum to determine the method of revising the city charter today when a proposal for a city manager form of government was carried by a vote of 1,575 to 1,378.

Samuel Miller, whose Harlem wholesale and retail meat business which catered to Father Divine's followers was shut down last June for three months for price-ceiling violations, was found guilty yesterday by Harry B. Chambers, chief hearing commissioner of the regional Office of Price Administration, of having transferred his meat, without, any exchange of ration stamps, to a former employe.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Indictment charging fraudulent rental and valuation of construction equipment used in the expansion of Fort Bragg, N.C., the country's largest military post, were returned today by a Federal grand jury against T.A. Loving Co., a Goldsboro, N.C., construction firm, and two of its officers.

No worse night for fiddle playing could have been than the wet and the wan one of yesterday evening, when Josef Piastro, who in an earlier season had played in this city as J. Piastro Borisoff, gave a violin recital in Town Hall. He is the brother of Michel Piastro, former concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, who is now on tour as a soloist.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Gen. Fedor I. Tolbukhin's Fourth Ukraine Army yesterday captured the historic city of Kakhovka, where thousands of Germans drowned in the swirling Dnieper or died under murderous Russian fire as they attempted to flee to the west bank of the river.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A member of the United States delegation disclosed today that an international conference on food production and consumption would be held Monday in Ottawa, Canada, with Great Britain, Canada and the United States participating.

In her use of rocket types of aerial torpedoes in fighting airplanes, Germany has clearly beaten us to the punch. It is well that we recognize the German accomplishment in this respect and step up research and development in the rocket field, at the same time that we explore counter-measures to neutralize the new offensive means in the enemy's hands.

Vigorous opposition to the recently revised maximum price regulation governing certain paperboard products was registered yesterday by the Folding Paper Box Manufacturers Association at a meeting of folding carton producers with representatives of the Office of Price Administration at the Hotel Commodore.
DETROIT, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Mayor Edward J Jeffries Jr., was re-elected for a third term yesterday, defeating Frank Fitzgerald, labor's candidate.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Government issued today a unique White Paper on war expenditures -- its text consists of a single paragraph asking for a supplementary vote of credit amounting to 1,250,000,000 that "may" be used for carrying on the war through March 31, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The State Department recommends passage of the Magnuson-Andrews bill, already approved by the House, to repeal the sixty-one-year-old Chinese exclusion laws and admit 105 Chinese to this country annually on a quota basis. The Senate Immigration Committee was informed today.
ALBANY, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Three men were under arrest tonight on election law violation charges as the State's election frauds bureau conducted an intensive investigation of Albany voting.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- The threat of a complete tie-up of the city's public transportation system was averted late tonight as official of the Transport Workers Union (CIO) yielded in their dispute over the right to wear union buttons while on duty, after a six-hour conference with Federal conciliators.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Republican control of Westchester County was continued today by the election of the party's candidates for Surrogate, County Judge two Supreme Court justices, County Clerk and District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Opposing views on the application of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company for permission to issue $76,573,700 of preference stock and to distribute it as a stock dividend to holders of common stock were heard today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Until that day at the end of August when District Attorney Frank S. Hogan issued a statement charging that nomination of Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio for Justice of the Supreme Court by Tammany was brought about by Frank Costello, an ex-convict, in alliance with certain Democratic leaders.

Harriers from N.Y.U., short on experience but chock-full of determination, came through with a surprising team victory in the fifteenth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Without a major triumph all season, Emil Von Elling's Violet squad scored 28 points, one less than Columbia, the choice in the four-team competition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The coal mine stoppage brought renewed demands in Congress today for strict enforcement of the Smith-Connally War Labor Disputes Act.

The twenty-six-acre place, occupied for several years by Thomas J. Regan, secretary to Harry Payne Whitney, on the east side of Wheatley Hills Road, Old Westbury, L.I., has been sold to Clarence Heinsohn by Mrs. Whitney's estate.

HEADQUARTERS ALASKAN DEPARTMENT, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Simon Bolivar Buckner Jr., whose Alaskan Department of the Army lies closer than any United States forces to Japanese home soil, advocated the land occupation of Japan today.
East Side and West Side multifamily buildings figured in Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.
Marian Anderson will sing tonight at 8:40 o'clock in Carnegie Hall, giving her first performance in this city of three operatic arias, also Negro spirituals and songs by noted composers.

A report by the special committee on aviation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, calling for the opening of many "lend-lease airports" to American air lines, was made public yesterday by the chamber. W.D. Guthrie is chairman of the committee.

The household scrap metal salvage drive, which yielded disappointedly small amounts when the Bronx, Richmond and Brooklyn had their official pick-up days recently, will get a boost tomorrow -Manhattan Day -- from the garment industry.

With nearly half of the Statewide vote tabulated by 3 o'clock this morning, adoption of at least five and possibly all of the six amendments to the State Constitution which were voted on yesterday was indicated.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- If Congress follows President Roosevelt's suggestion to increase taxes this year and the decision has to be made between a national sales tax and increased income tax rates, the public can be counted on to favor a sales tax.

An atmosphere of gloomy uncertainty, almost as depressing as the damp grayness outside, took a strong hold on the first election night reception in the new Tammany Hall headquarters at 331 Madison Avenue early last evening, and the gloom never lifted as the hours passed.

Just a year ago to a few hours, we were reading, along with other election returns, the dispatches from London announcing that Rommel's army was in full retreat from the Alamein line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Reports from 2,674 wholesalers representing most kinds of business throughout the country showed sales for September, 1943, virtually unchanged from those of September, 1942, J.C. Capt. Director of the Census, announced today.

The proportional representation count of ballots cast for members of the City Council yesterday will begin this morning at designated tabulation centers in each of the five boroughs. It is estimated that it will take the better part of a week to complete the count.

New Jersey voters elected yesterday Walter E. Edge as Governor, a post he held during the first World War, and at the same time authorized the 1944 Legislature to revise the State's ninety-nine-year-old Constitution. Unofficial returns from 2,752 of the State's 3,647 election districts gave Mr. Edge 472,987 votes to 378,367 for Mayor Vincent J. Murphy of Newark, his Democratic opponent, a plurality of 94,620.

The eleven-story Engineering Building at 114 Liberty Street, through to 119-21 Cedar Street, has been sold by David S. Meister, operator, to an investing client of J.S. Linett, attorney. This structure is on an irregular plot 45 by 111 feet.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Continuation of the policy of offering merchandise of good quality appeared as the keynote of the Christmas "flier" now being mailed to customers of Montgomery Ward Co. The new sales volume closely approaches last year's book in size, color printing and in the number of offerings.

At a luncheon yesterday in the New York Advertising Club, Walter L. Pate, captain of the United States Davis Cup tennis team, and Miss Pauline Betz, women's national tennis champion, presented trophies to the 1943 national open paddle tennis tournament winners, Saul Sargent and Miss Helen Morris of Parkchester.
NAPLES, Nov. 1 (Delayed) -- At Capua, before their retreat, the Germans deliberately destroyed the archives of Naples, it was learned today.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Boston area of the Methodist Church denounced today the alleged beating of Jewish boys as an apparent expression of incipient fascism and, in a prepared statement, demanded:

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under Secretary of State and former Lend-Lease Administrator, has written his story of lend-lease in a book that will be published by the Macmillan Company for the benefit of charity, it was announced yesterday.

FREDONIA, N.Y., Nov. 2 (AP) -Retail deliveries of milk to 30,000 residents in the Dunkirk-Fredonia area were virtually suspended today as members of the South Shore Milk Producers Association continued to withhold milk from the market to enforce demands for a price increase.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The United States Government is "giving serious consideration" to the action of the Franco regime a week ago in sending a message of congratulation to Jose P. Laurel, head of the Japanese puppet government in the Philippines.

One of the two great Russian traps on the Eastern Front has snapped shut. The capture of Perekop has closed the last land exit from the Crimea, and Russian armies are even now marching into the peninsula from north and east. Its reconquest is certain.

Turrone is as essential to the Spanish Christmas dinner as plum pudding is to the American one, according to the manager of Joseph Victori Co., importers, 164 Pearl Street. He informs the writer that this rich nougat, preferably in the company of a glass of sherry, adds the final touch to the holiday meal.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, informed the British public today that he would extend the principle of pay-as-you-earn taxation to everyone by next spring, when the important forgiveness clause will come into effect. He made the statement before Parliament and was promptly congratulated for the common sense of his action and the speed with which it had been taken.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an amended plan of recapitalization for the Virginia Public Service Company, designed to distribute its voting power "fairly and equitably" among security holders.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Prices of hogs slumped again today, light weights showing the most decline. The cattle market was generally active with most killing classes strong to 25 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. Early sheep trade was steady on all classes. Large marketing of sheep and lambs are keeping prices for them so low that there is no necessity for ceiling prices, the War Food Administration announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- With a 500-pound bomb loose in the plane, Lieut. Comdr. Thomas W. McKnight of Salem, Mass., took off, flew out to sea and dumped it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- A preview of post-war footwear today offered glimpses of nylon pumps trimmed with copper kid, caterpillar-treaded rubber soles for moccasins, ankle-strapped plastic sandals with neither toe nor shank, and chartreuse plastic playshoes.

In the southwest Pacific all roads lead to Rabaul. This has been the point of convergence for the entire Allied campaign both on New Guinea and up through the Solomons. Now our Marines are on Bougainville, the bridgehead to Rabaul.

KANHSIEN, Kiangsi Province, China, Oct. 31 (Delayed) - Everywhere throughout this modernized city are gold characters on red backgrounds proclaiming "a day of universal celebration," for today is Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's fifty-seventh birthday and the administrator of Kanhsien is the Generalissimo's oldest son, Chiang Ching-kuo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Premium gasolines for civilian use will be reduced to 76 octane from the present 78 to 80 octane as a means of conserving tetraethyl lead and volatile gasoline fractions, both of which are required in the production of high-octane military gasoline, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Petroleum Administrator for War, said today.

BUFFALO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A request by the Economics League for the use of the Buffalo Memorial Auditorium for an address Monday by the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, director of the America First party, has been denied by the board of the stadium and memorial auditorium.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A statement that Alfred de Marigny spent more than $100,000 of his second wife's money was introduced today at his trial for the murder of Sir Harry Oakes after an earlier Crown witness had received a severe reprimand for changing his testimony.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Sixteen House Republicans, charging Administration leaders with "apathy" in their conduct of the legislative machinery, banded together today into a "drive for action committee."

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Hundreds of Austrian soldiers in the German Army were reported tonight to be deserting and a leader of the Free Austria movement predicted a "gigantic uprising" of the Austrian people when the Allied armies neared the country's border.
Comdr. Hudson Dravo, USNR, and Mrs. Dravo have arrived from Kennett Square, Pa., and are at the St. Regis.

ALGIERS, Nov. 2 -- Creation of a new United States Fifteenth Air Force that will concentrate on strategic bombing from this theatre of targets in Germany and occupied Europe was announced tonight by Allied Headquarters simultaneously with news of the new air force's first mission.

With the demand for women's apparel outstanding, Election Day trade averaged about 10 per cent above a year ago, according to estimates by department-store executives here yesterday. Larger percentage gains were indicated for some stores, while in others the comment was made the volume "was about usual for a warm Election Day."

On Election Day, when the electorate is perhaps more conscious of legislators and legislation, a summary arrived appropriately from the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission. This is the body which was established through the Council of State Governments.

Farrar Rinehart announces the purchase of the Radio and Technical Publishing Company, headed by Alfred A. Ghirardi, author of many technical books on radio and electronics. Mr. Ghirardi will join the staff as editorial consultant in radio electronics.

The Honest Ballot Association reversed its usual procedure this year and, instead of prosecuting violators of elections laws, found itself helping several persons who innocently found themselves in police custody for alleged infractions of regulations.

Up to now the eventful pre-Broadway career of Rose Franken's play "Outrageous Fortune" can be divided into three phases: in the beginning it started out as a Gilbert Miller undertaking; then it became a joint offering with William Brown Meloney, the author's husband, and when the curtain goes up at 8:30 tonight at the Forty-eighth Street, Mr. Meloney will be on his own.

The Warners film version of "This Is the Army," which ended a thirteen-week run Monday night at the Hollywood, has been booked for a nine-day second-run engagement over the RKO Theatre Circuit in the metropolitan area. Starting Nov. 30, the picture will be shown at the circuit's neighborhood houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester.

Bob Worst and Harry Abeltin, Manual Training High's workhorse backs, spelled defeat for Erasmus Hall in the thirty-sixth football meeting between the Brooklyn rivals at Ebbets Field yesterday. Worst and Abeltin contributed two touchdowns each as Manual overcame surprising resistance to win, 26 to 13, before 5,000 spectators.

NAPLES, Nov. 2 -- Medical history was made at a field hospital near the front today when three surgical teams of eight doctors in all worked simultaneously for six hours to save the life of a wounded pilot.

BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 2 -- Mayor Jasper McLevy, Socialist, easily defeated Lloyd R. Wheeler, Democrat, and Edward A. Young, Republican, today and thus became Bridgeport's first six-term Mayor. He polled 18,033 votes; Wheeler, 5,288, and Young, 4,269.

ALGIERS, Nov. 2 -- The stage is set for perhaps the most important speech of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's career. He will deliver it tomorrow afternoon at the opening session of the Provisional Consultative Assembly, after the news from Moscow confirmed fears that the French had been left out of all the major decisions by the conferees.

The political complexion of the State Legislature remained unchanged, with the Republican party in full control of both houses, as the result of elections held yesterday to fill seven vacancies in the Assembly and two in the Senate.

CHUNGKING, China. Nov. 2 (U.P.) American fliers have attacked two Japanese-held river centers in support of Chinese forces in central China, where the Japanese have launched a new offensive between Lake Tungting and the Yangtze River, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The War Shipping Administration took two steps today in advancing its plans for world-wide operations of an expanded United States merchant fleet under private ownership after the war.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, SOUTHWEST PACIFIC (Delayed) (AP) -- Sgt. Joseph A. Carroll of College Point, Queens, was among four members of the crew of a crippled bomber which was attacked by a dozen Japanese fighters over Wewak, New Guinea, who received today the Silver Star for gallantry in action.

The only presentation of "Giselle" on the schedule of Ballet Theatre took place last night at the Metropolitan Opera House and proved to be one of the most distinguished performances of the season. Its chief interest lay as a matter of course in the first appearance of Alicia Alonso in the title role, a role which is the richest and the most demanding in the entire classic repertoire.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters said today that Japanese and American warships had clashed in a battle that might have an important effect on the ability of United States marines to control their new invasion positions on the west-central coast of Bougainville in the northern Solomons.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 -- Retailers were urged immediately to strengthen their positions in order to forestall a collapse of the nation's distribution channels after the war by Nathan S. Sachs, New York, president of the Retail Credit Institute of America.

The supply of liquors in this market will not be curtailed during the next two months and distillers will maintain their rationing programs at current levels at least until the first of the new year, Gerald F. Dunne, executive director of the Metropolitan Package Store Association, assured retailers yesterday at a mass meeting of the trade at the Hotel Park Central.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- For the Allies the hardest fighting lies ahead, land warfare against Germany and Japan, Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, commander of American forces in the European theatre, said today in a cablegram which Hugh Baillie, president of The United Press, read in an address at the Union League Club.

Start Musial, right fielder whose stickwork brought him the National League batting championship and was a major factor in the drive of the Cardinals to their second straight pennant, has been named the league's most valuable player for 1943, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations demanded today the scrapping of the "Little Steel" formula and the substitution of labor's version of the proper basis for national wage stabilization.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- A communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Despite generally poor weather conditions over the whole area of Allied operational bases in this theatre during the month, the Royal Air Force and the United States Eighth Air Force dropped more than 17,000 tons of bombs on Germany and occupied Europe during October.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Nov. 2 -- The possibility that Navy-aircraft will be used in the future to strike at Germany, as well as at Japan, was hinted by Rear Admiral D.C. Ramsay, chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics, while on a tour of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation plant this morning with members of the House Naval Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Rescinding previously voted increases on out-of-town letter mail and on cigars, the Ways and Means Committee tentatively ended consideration today of the revenue-raising sections of the new tax bill. A subcommittee took up proposals for drastic changes in the War Contracts Renegotiation Act.

ALGIERS, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The American soldier in this theatre was too busy today trying to win the war and get back home to pay much attention to the results of the Moscow conference. The reaction of most was a shrug.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- British and Canadian Mustangs and Typhoons continued their round-the-clock offensive sweeps over France and the Netherlands today, destroying three enemy aircraft and damaging a number of locomotives, a communique said.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- News of the Moscow agreement is being pumped by air into Europe at the rate of hundreds of thousands of words each day in every tongue of the Continent as the Allied political offensive, designed to exploit the diplomatic victory to the utmost, rolls forward.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 2 -- Several successful engagements on the part of the guerrilla forces of Gen. Josip Broz [Tito] fighting in several parts of Yugoslavia were reported in today's broadcast from the "headquarters of the People's Army of Liberation" over the Free Yugoslavia radio.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Canadiens chalked up their first triumph of the National Hockey League season tonight, shading the Rangers, 2 -- 1, before about 8,000 fans. Phil Watson's second-period goal won the game.

Thomas A. Aurelio was elected yesterday to the Supreme Court, over divided opposition, in a race that was not particularly close. While he finished seventh in the list of seven justices nominated and elected by both major parties, the man they tried to disown won by a margin of 49,842 over his nearest independent opposition.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- Contrary to tradition the Quakers are a hard bunch to satisfy, for it now develops that when the game with Army ended last Saturday in a 13-13 tie, the Pennsylvania players were mad, throwing their headgears down on their dressing room floor disgustedy.

It was the sixty-third consecutive year that the Republicans have maintaind their hold on the city. The heavy trend to them in their traditional stronghold was noted early along with their sizable vote gain over the 1939 off-year election.

The largest diamond ever found in Venezuela, a perfect egg-sized gem weighing 155 karats, was bought yesterday by Harry Winston, Inc., diamond merchants, of 7 East Fifty-first Street, for $200,000, after being air-mailed here from Caracas for 40 cents postage.

Eleanor H. Schmidt, a 15-year-old Queens girl who was held in Germany, together with her mother and stepfather, for more than two years after the start of the war, has been missing from home since Oct. 25, it was learned yesterday.

We believe that the right interpretation to be placed on the election of Mr. Hanley is that a majority of the people of the State have decided that a Republican Governor who is doing a good job at Albany deserves to have a Republican Lieutenant. That is good common sense.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 2 -- A divorce case filed here secretly on Oct. 25 was disclosed today as that of Doris Duke Cromwell, tobacco heiress, against James H.R. Cromwell, former Ambassador to Canada. The case was put on secret file to assure service of papers on Mr. Cromwell.
The Moscow agreements were favorably received here yesterday by political refugees, especially spokesmen for smaller subjugated European nations.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The stock markets here were cheerful in tone today, but business generally was quiet. A good feature was fresh buying of gilt-edge stocks, although home rails were a trifle easier.

The city's electorate stayed away from Times Square last night almost as if by unanimous consent. There were no horn-blowers, no rattle-swingers, no confetti-throwers, no partisans assembled to applaud their own handiwork at the polls.

Placing five men in the first eleven, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School carried off its tenth consecutive C.H.S.A.A. cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, defeating St. Augustine's by 41 -- 51. La Salle Academy, the third team, tallied 103 points and showed the way to nine other schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The 10,000-ton cruiser Savannah was damaged when a bomb from an Axis plane smashed into one of her gun turrets during the landings at Salerno, but nevertheless the warship continued firing on the enemy, the Navy Department announced today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- History repeated in the $5,000 added Heiser Handicap when E.C. Eastwood's Challamore won it for the second straight year at Pimlico today. Carrying top weight of 128 pounds, Challamore scored in a photo finish with Max Marmorstein's Chaldon Heath.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- The Soviet press today hailed the Moscow conference's success as insuring the speedier defeat of Adolf Hitler and welcomed the Anglo-Soviet-American-Chinese post-war collaboration declaration with the enthusiastic comment that "the great democratic powers, comrades in arms today, tomorrow will become comrades in the struggle for the security of all peace-loving nations."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The authority of Congress to outlaw the poll-tax requirements of eight Southern States was disputed today by Charles Warren, historian of the United States Supreme Court and former assistant attorney general, although he said that such a tax was "unjust" and should be abolished.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- To relieve the scarcity of children's shoes the Office of Price Administration said today that an early 1944 supply of non-leather shoes would be available ration-free in the small sizes. The OPA also is permitting ration-free sales of the few rubber-soled gym shoes still on the retail market.

Breaking all attendance and betting records for Election Day racing. 32.958 persons who wagered $2,492,106 at Jamaica yesterday saw two fillies take the featured races and Ted Atkinson ride four winners. The victorious fillies were Ky. Flash in the $5,240 Recreation Handicap and Spiral Pass in the Ramoneur Handicap, a sprint named for a speed star of another day.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The volume of attendance and business transacted at Chicago's current shoe market "has been too good," according to some participants. Manufacturers reported that retailers, after having bought their allotments from established connections, have gone to other houses with whom they never before have done business, with the hope of adding to their stocks.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2 -- The Duke of Windsor visited Yale's Institute of International Studies today and was the guest of honor at a review on New Haven green.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased commercial space were K. Stenzel Sons, manufacturers of optical goods, who took through Hanford Henderson, Inc., the entire top floor at 21-29 Hudson Street and 164-66 Duane Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Moscow Conference, in my opinion, is as definite a contribution to decisive victory as a hundred military divisions. It is all a part of the strategic leadership of the President, Prime Minister Churchill and Marshal Stalin.

A general alarm was sent out yesterday by the police asking for the arrest of Edward J. Moore, a 20-year-old sailor who has gone absent without leave, on a charge of abduction. He is accused of responsibility for the disappearance of Margaret Leighton Moore, 13 years old, who has been missing from her home at 1172 Park Avenue since Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- In exultant mood, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said today that the landings of the United States Marines on Bougainville Island had caught the Japanese completely unaware. The operation, said the Secretary at a press conference, had been so carefully planned "without leaks" that the enemy "evidently was not prepared for it."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Harrison E. Spangler, charman of the Republican National Committee, made this statement tonight, commenting on the day's elections:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 2 -- The combination of the tremendous Red Army advances in the south Dnieper region, bringing the Russians daily closer to the Rumanian frontier, and the slow British-American drive northward along the Adriatic, with the pronouncement of the great powers' intentions toward Austria, brings the problem of the future of the troublesome Balkan area closer into focus.

Abraham Lincoln High's long football victory string was snapped yesterday. Intercepting a pass heaved by Joe Fox, George Shaffer sped 55 yards in the second quarter to give Curtis High a 6-to-0 triumph over the Coney Island school at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S.I.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Despite President Roosevelt's order that the nation's 530,000 striking coal miners return to the pits tomorrow, neither the coal operators nor officials of the United Mine Workers expected tonight that there would be compliance.

A widespread movement among Russian women to adopt children whose parents have died in the was has solved the problem of younger orphans, two Russian students disclosed yesterday. The movement is so strong, according to Zina Osipova and Kira Postnova, that in some Russian localities there are more homes offered than there are babies to adopt.

War bonds amounting to $48,508,243 were purchased in the Third War Loan drive by Americans of Italian origin in New York State, according to a report received by Nevil Ford, executive manager of the War Finance Committee for New York State, it was announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 2 -- J. Lyter Donaldson, Democrat, was narrowly leading Simeon S. Willis, Republican Governorship nominee, tonight in the first reports of the ballot counting in Kentucky. With 1,888 of the 4,293 precincts tabulated Donaldson was ahead 134,834 to 126,687.
ALGIERS, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The text of the announcement of the creation of the United States Fifteenth Air Force:

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 2 -- New Zealand's seventh Victoria Cross of the war has been awarded posthumously to Flying Officer Lloyd Allan Trigg, captain of a Liberator patrol plane, whose bombing of a surfaced U-boat while his plane was ablaze from enemy fire and subsequent fatal crash in the Atlantic were related by captured survivors of the submarine crew.

In all the discussions about a forty or forty-two or forty-eight hour week and the hourly wage and the portal-to-portal pay and the daily wage and the weekly "take home" there has been an almost complete absence of any evidence as to what the coal miner receives as his earnings for a year's work.

Francis Ellis Rivers was born in Kansas City, Kan., on July 30, 1893, a son of the Rev. David Foote Rivers, a Negro Baptist clergyman, and Mrs. Silene Gale Rivers. His election to the post of City Court Justice represents the highest elevation of any Negro to a judicial post in this State and probably in the nation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Heavy buying of wheat futures by commission houses and cash interests advanced all deliveries of that grain today on the Chicago Board of Trade to a new high level for the season, December selling at $1.58 1/2 a bushel, the highest price for that delivery since 1925.
ALGIERS, Nov. 2 -- A communique:...

Gifts of $250,000 to the campaign of the New York Committee of the National War Fund were announced yesterday by Emil Schram, the chairman. The committee is appealing for $17,000,000 for the support of twenty-six war-related agencies.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 3 -- The Republicans retained in yesterday's elections the major county and town offices in Nassau and all of the offices in the City of Glen Cove.

The article on the post-war set-up by Winifred Mallon made it appear that it would be a good plan for the Government to finance a college education for every man in the armed forces who wanted to attend some institution of higher learning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Newspapers gave $21,000,000 of the more than $36,000,000 worth of advertising and publicity contributed during the Third War Loan, the Treasury reported tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Grudging German recognition of what Berlin calls "ideological differences" in Spain has drawn attention to the growing opposition to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime among dissatisfied army leaders seeking the return of the monarchy.

Two hundred Army wives with children are now living in New York City housing projects reserved for low-income-bracket family groups, New York City Housing Committee authorities disclosed yesterday. Since August, when local housing committee officials first granted permission to servicemen's families dependent on allotments to "move in," Army wives and their children were able to find accommodations in the two largest of these developments, Queensbridge Houses in Queens and Red Hook Houses in Brooklyn.

With social studies teachers better informed about American history than any other group in our population, persons listed in Who's Who run a close second, it was disclosed yesterday in a survey conducted by the Committee on American History in the Schools and Colleges, headed by Dr. Edgar B. Wesley of the University of Minnesota.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Two amendments to the city charter, one providing for automatic election of the Mayor and the other assuring a council of at least five members, were overwhelmingly adopted in the election today. Although an official tabulation of the vote was not available, unofficial counts showed that the propositions had been carried by approximately three to one.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- Roger D. Lauham, a former industry member of the War Labor Board, was elected Mayor of San Francisco today to succeed Angelo J. Rossi, whose administration has spanned thirteen years.
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Oct. 27 (Delayed) -- This one-time frontier army post is now the highest "university" in the Army's extensive educational system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Special House (Smith) Committee investigating what it calls "government by directive" summoned officials of the Office of Economic Stabilization and Office of Price Administration today to appear before it in defense of the legality of their order controlling the price of live cattle.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 2 -- Lincoln High made another step toward the Hudson County football title today, defeating St. Peter's Prep, 26 -- 6, for its fifth straight victory. Joe Nester did most of Lincoln's ground-gaining, but Lloyd Skinner registered three touchdowns.

NAPLES, Nov. 1 (Delayed) -- Premier Pietro Badoglio left Naples today, outwardly pleased at the result of his efforts to form a coalition government. But those behind the scenes who ought to know say that he can have a more firmly based government if he wants, but it will not contain names to inspire the confidence necessary in this critical period.

CHUNGKING, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Chinese officials, hailing the decisions of the Moscow conference, declared today that it must put the Japanese "in a fearful mood," but it was not believed that Japan would regard the agreement as a cause for war against Russia.

Joseph A. Gavagan, new Supreme Court Justice, is a life-long Tammany Democrat and was born in New York City on Aug. 20, 1892. He was educated in the city's public and parochial schools and was graduated from the Fordham Law School.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board, has inaugurated an infants' and children's section, with Mrs. Crete Dahl of Stamford, Conn., as chief, it announced today. With its new section, the OCR is giving the infant-supplies industry what it never gave itself, a coordinating agency and a voice, Mrs. Dahl pointed out.

The three-family house, with a two-car garage, on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 1430 Harrod Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Michael Fichera. Henry Waltemade, Inc., and George F. Martocci were co-brokers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee sought to determine today whether President Roosevelt's executive powers should be broadened to include control of carrier pigeons.

Senator Joe R. Hanley, Lieutenant Governor-elect; Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle and other leading members of the Republican party, who received returns last night at headquarters of the State Committee, 41 East Forty-second Street were jubilant over the large vote for Senator Hanley.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The lowest death rate ever recorded for the United States was reported today by the Bureau of the Census, the figure being 10.4 per 1,000 population for 1942, against 10.5 in 1941.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Clifford Odets has sold film rights to "An Errand for Uncle," an unfinished war play, to Warner Brothers and will finish it in screen form on the Coast. Production will be in the hands of Jerry Wald, with direction by Elia Kazan, Broadway stage director.

Republicans swept through to impressive victories in by-elections in scattered parts of the country yesterday, in a showing which was already being interpreted last night as a rebuke to the handling of the home front by the New Deal Administration.

JOHNNY BLOOD was what the sports fraternity would call a character. His real name was McNally, but when he entered professional football he adopted the nom de guerre of Blood and played for blood, too. All impulsive, unpredictable fellow, he once went to Honolulu with the Green Bay Packers and jumped the team there for a job on a tramp steamer bound for the China Seas.
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight Supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 2 -- While possibility of a Republican victory was considered to be somewhat remote, observers read in the strength shown by Simeon S. Willis in the early returns a preview of next year's Presidential election.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Questions of considerable importance for the future of the whole Mediterranean basin are now under discussion in Cairo, Naples and Algiers.

In September, 1942, Secretary Morgenthau proposed to Congress the adoption of a spendings tax. He justified this measure on the ground that it would restrict consumer spending. He went on to observe that "if the proposals we make seem drastic * * * nothing less drastic will accomplish the results we must have."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Tessa Brind, the 15-year-old Viennere understudy to Ann Blythe in the part of Babette in the New York production of "Watch on the Rhine" who later played the role on the road, will have her first film part as the second lead in RKO'S "Are These Our Children?"

Word comes from Philadelphia that the Securities and Exchange Commission is considering issuance of a rule to back up the recent pronouncement by the governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., that, except with stocks selling below $10, a mark-up of 5 per cent is the virtual top.

SALEM, N. H., Nov. 3 (AP) -- C. Rufi's Mintlock went to the front on the turn today to take the Woodstock Purse at Rockingham Park. The largest mid-week crowd of the fall meeting -- 8,167 persons -- saw the 7-to-10 favorite win, with Mixer second and Tetra Rock third.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- The Navy announced today 46 casualties not heretofore on casualty lists. This list includes four dead, thirteen wounded, and 29 missing. In addition, the name of one sailor is included whose status has been officially changed from missing to safe.

State Senator Joe R. Hanley yesterday interpreted his election as Lieutenant Governor as an endorsement of the State administration headed by Governor Dewey and the Republican legislative record and "a mandate upon all of us to see that New York contributes its utmost toward winning the war, which in my opinion is the biggest job we have."

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Never ones to yield a title without a fight -- whether it is the pro football championship or first place in yards lost by penalties, the Bears reasserted themselves as the best ground-gaining team in the National Football League this week in preparation for their big game with their closest rivals, the Packers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3. -- The fate of[ whatever Germans remain on theI Dnieper's left bank now lies most-[ ly in the hands of the Cossacks.[ Outpacin the main Russian forces, and sometimes even tanks, with[ [which they are usually combined,/ I S. oviet horsemen are hounding' down the enemy from Karkinit Bay to the Dnieper.

ALGIERS, Nov. 3 -- In a triumph of mountain fighting comparable to that above Salerno, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army has virtually completed the occupation of the Massico Ridge with the envelopment of Mount Croce and has gained complete observation of the Garigliano Valley, it was officially announced today.

Judge Thomas F. Cosgrove of the Richmond County Court, a candidate for re-election on the Republican and American Labor party tickets, refused to admit defeat yesterday. According to the unofficial election returns he was beaten by Municipal Court Justice Thomas J. Walsh, the Democratic candidate, by fifty-seven votes.

ALLIED SOUTH PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 3 -- Seated in a jungle hut dressed in an open - necked khaki shirt and shorts, Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., with an air of self-confidence, disclosed to correspondents today that enemy warships as well as air forces had been dispersed by his forces in connection with the Bougainville operations.

Higher opening prices for the new raw fur season in comparison with the opening levels a year ago, but well within the OPA roof quotations recently announced, were predicted yesterday in the report of the United Fur Brokers.
