LONDON, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Demonstrations were reported today to have broken out in Vienna and other Austrian cities as a result of the Moscow conference declaration that Austria, first country overrun by the Nazis, would be liberated from German domination.

The election of Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court -- he ran seventh and last of the bipartisan nominees, but won by a margin of 49,842 votes over his nearest opponent in a divided opposition -- will lead to agitation for removal of the choice of judges from the hands of the electorate.

In one of the largest Fifth Avenue property deals announced in recent months Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, has acquired from various owners a large group of properties, including the Frances Building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

The American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, suggested yesterday that it might ask the Federal Government "to take over a good deal of the nation's networks and stations" if it becomes involved in a dispute with the broadcasting industry.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The best places to eat these days -- if one wants hearty food and does not have a dainty, bird-like appetite -- are not the expensive, luxurious West End hotels, but the "pubs" requented by stevedores, street cleaners, factory hands and truck drivers, or the non-profit-making government-controlled "British restaurants."
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Simeon S. Willis, Republican, was leading J. Lyter Donaldson, Democrat, by 4,301 votes tonight in their race for Governor of Kentucky.

Periodically there come to this desk optimistic bulletins announcing that Ephraim Tutt, Arthur Train's lawyer of fictional fame, would be introduced to the stage. Way back, Max Gordon was of a mind to escort Mr. Tutt to Broadway in the person of Walter Huston and in a dramatization provided by Owen Davis or by the Messrs. Davis and Train.

Excepting heavy fuel oil supplies, which were drawn upon further, stocks of major oil products on the Eastern seaboard again increased last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week the institute's index covering gasoline supplies stood at 36, compared with 34.9 a week earlier, and that of light fuel oil was up to 55.7 from 53.1.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- That one inhabitant of the United States has a $7,000,000 nest egg and that more than one American corporation has an investment of $500,000,000 abroad have been discovered by a broad survey of the American stake in foreign countries which the Treasury has been conducting since June 3.

ARMY had an open date on its 1913 schedule and Charlie Daly, the West Point coach, advised the cadet manager to browse around a bit with an eye to filling it. He asked that a Midwestern school be chosen, preferably one not too rugged but one which could be publicized on one count or another. So the manager unearthed the football equivalent of a Baedeker and ran his finger down the list of names.

Duck hunters who have been asking the question since the beginning of the season, "Where are the ducks," will probably listen carefully to bulletins coming in during the last two days from the breeding areas in Canada.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's air arm inflicted the worst defeat yet administered to Japan's seaborne power at the New Britain stronghold of Rabaul Tuesday, sending three enemy destroyers, eight large merchant ships and four coastal vessels to the bottom of Simpson Harbor.

For many months the public has been bombarded by both the press and radio in the urgent need for registered nurses. Having the desire to contribute my bit toward relieving the shortage. I applied to one of our large city hospitals for half-day work, six times a week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The possibility of disposing of some of this country's excess war plants to war-stricken nations, a proposal which is understood to be under discussion in official quarters, was urged for consideration today in a supplemental report on reconversion of industry made by the National Planning Association's Business, Labor and Agricultural Committees on National Policy.

With Dean McAdams, backfield kicking and passing ace, ready for full-time duty, Coach Pete Cawthon hopes that his Football Dodgers will turn on their best attack of a sad season against the Chicago Cardinals at Ebbets Field next Sunday.

Concerns in various lines of business have signed for space in the building at 512 Fifth Avenue through Tankoos, Smith Co., who also have arranged several renewals in the same building. One of the new tenants is the American Patriotic Plaque Company, which took space for executive offices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States might find itself in a difficult position in making good "promises" of relief for liberated peoples if the war in Europe should end in the next six months.

Our Government is properly "giving serious consideration" to the action of the Spanish dictator, General Franco, in sending a message of congratulation to the Filipino traitor, Jose P. Laurel, whom the Japanese have placed at the head of their puppet regime on what is still American soil.

ALGIERS, Nov. 3 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle opened the first meeting of the Provisional Consultative Assembly today with a restrained but unqualified reminder to the three major Allies -- all of which were represented in the diplomatic gallery -- that any world settlement without France would be not so much an injustice as a mistake.

Mrs. Annette Louise Sullivan, who pleaded guilty in Kings County Court to a charge of grand larceny on Sept. 10, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to two and one-half to five years in the State Prison for Women at Bedford Hills, N.Y.

Robert S. MacCormack smiled yesterday as he reached into his mail box at his home, 302 Autumn Avenue, Brooklyn, and his hand closed on a letter. It was a letter from a man in California, and he knew it, because letters like it have been in the box every year since 1919.
The other day I read with a certain amount of enthusiasm former Representative John J. O'Connor's statement of the danger confronting this nation with the return of a national prohibition law.

In a test case, Justice Carroll Hayes in the Municipal Court, Ninth District, yesterday ordered the Cuba Railroad Company to resume paying interest at the rate of 5 per cent annually on its first mortgage bonds. The case was brought by Beverly R. Myles of the law firm of Haggerty, Myles Wormser on the basis of a single $25 coupon.

Latin-American importers, anticipating the war's termination and enjoying a better supply situation, are now canceling orders placed with American manufacturers in an attempt to forestall a flooding of their markets with high-priced goods, exporters attending a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania, disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Continued spending by the Federal Government on a large scale after the war was envisioned today by Vice President Henry A. Wallace in an address at the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Consolidated net income of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company for the first nine months of this year amounted to $8,923,304 after all charges and provision of $5,818,000 for Federal taxes, William F. Humphrey, president, reports in a statement to be issued today to stockholders.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
The two-family house on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 231 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, has been bought by Andrew N. Miller through Samuel Hurwitz for cash. It contains nine rooms and is assessed for $4,000.

BACK in 1936 and 1940 the phrase "that man" usually referred to Franklin D. Roosevelt and the user thereof was obviously a Republican. Now "that man" refers to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and the user may be practically anybody.

ALGIERS, Nov. 3 -- In the long-range heavy bomber raid on the Messerschmitt plant at Wiener Neustadt in Austria yesterday, inaugurating the United States Fifteenth Air Force, a checkup today at Allied headquarters showed that at least thirty of the seventy-five enemy fighters were destroyed in a great-dog-fight. Six American bombers were lost.

Responding to an inevitable question growing out of Tuesday's Republican off-year election sweep, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said yesterday: "I am not and shall not become a candidate for the Republican nomination in 1944.

Assurances that housewives can send family wash bundles to laundries and get them finished, even in face of further manpower short ages, were issued yesterday at the opening of a two-day regional convention of the American Institute of Laundering at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Because of the light vote in Tuesday's election, the new City Council will consist of from seven to eleven fewer members than the present one, it was estimated yesterday as sorting of proportional representation ballots, preparatory to counting, got under way in all five boroughs.

The Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 457 Madison Avenue, opens today an exhibition of flags and pictures, symbolizing the age-old friendship between the peoples of France and America. The exhibition comprises French regimental standards and water-colors by Charles M. Lefferts of uniforms worn by the armies of the American Revolution.

One of England's early post-war construction problems will be to build 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 new dwelling units, to increase school facilities by 20 per cent, and to rebuild many factories and churches, according to Alfred C. Bossom, head of a British commission of four building experts now studying construction methods in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Proposed amendment of the 1934 Communications Act to circumscribe the powers of the Federal Communications Commission and to reorganize some of its procedures, was opposed by James L. Fly, FCC chairman, at the opening hearing today before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee on the Wheeler-White radio bill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- John L. Lewis and the officers of the United Mine Workers of America tonight ordered the 530,000 striking coal miners to return to work "at the earliest possible moment" because "the Government of the United States, through the Secretary of the Interior, has today executed a satisfactory wage agreement" with the union.

A fund campaign to wipe out the 5,000 names on the waiting list at Girl Scout headquarters opened yesterday. At offices of the Great-Far New York Council of the organization, 670 Lexington venue, reports were coming in of 2,000 neighborhood parties that launched the annual drive to make possible the formation of new troops and continue the training of the 26,000 girls now enrolled.

The liner Normandie left her pier yesterday morning for the first time in more than four years. She was officially the U.S.S. Lafayette, but the only name that showed on the blackened and rusted bows of the vessel was the name she bore as a French luxury liner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Rejecting still another Treasury recommendation, the Ways and Means Committee decided today against any change in the 20 per cent withholding rate for wages and salaries. The Treasury had advocated increasing the withholding to cover the full tax liability in all wage and salary brackets.

Industrial production in the United States, of which an estimated 70 per cent now is devoted to war purposes, is making only small increases, owing to the limitations of manpower, the National City Bank of New York says in the November issue of its bank letter.

Dissatisfied with being "kicked around," the American people showed their resentment in the Tuesday election, James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's government, which, more than a week ago, congratulated the puppet Japanese regime in the Philippines, has since, according to French, Hungarian and German broadcasts, concluded an economic agreement with the rump Italian "government" headed by Benito Mussolini.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Indians put fence-busting Hal Trosky in their showcase today as one of the winter baseball market's choicest selections of wartime' trading bait.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- Red Star, the Soviet Army newspaper, commenting on the Moscow parley's success, declares today that "Hitlerite Germany and her European satellites, which have already learned the strength of the blows of the Red Army and Allied armed forces, will yet experience the whole might of combined Allied blows from the east and west."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Dr. Theodore G. Klumpp, President of the Winthrop Chemical Company, said tonight that because medicine and pharmacy were so closely related enactment of the Wagner-Murray-Dingle Bill would result in regimentation of both sciences.

Influenced largely by weakness in grains and securities, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday broke to the lowest level of the season. Heavy liquidation swept over the market in the last two hours of trading. Closing quotations of the active old-type futures were at the lowest levels of the session and 28 to 41 points, or $1.40 to $2.05 a hale, below Monday's final prices.

Almost everyone wastes gas or electricity without realizing it, says a bulletin from the Office of War Information. It adds that nowadays such extravagance is particularly deplorable, for supplies of both fuels are critical. Production of manufactured gas demands coal, coke and oil, all of which are short, while the generation of most electricity requires coal, petroleum products or natural gas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Senate post-war policy controversy appeared to crumble today under the impact and influence of the American-British-Russian-Chinese agreement at Moscow, and the stage was set for united action, possibly tomorrow, upon a compromise embodying virtually word for word a part of the four-nations declaration as the Senate's own expression.
The advent of millions of women into America's essential war industries is responsible for the development of a new and "essential" cosmetic.

Photographs of many of the great writers of the Soviet Union are included in the exhibition of official Soviet pictures, posters and cartoons now on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, under the sponsorship of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.

The General Electric Company became yesterday one of the first major industrial companies to announce a definite program for easing the transition from wartime to peacetime production with the disclosure of a "reservation" plan for the purchase of post-war radio broadcasting equipment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- In a sharply worded letter, the text of which was released today, Secretary Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator, takes issue with statements made by Harry M. Vawter, general manager of the Bituminous Coal Institute, on the size of current stockpiles and on the ability of the coal mining industry not only to match but to eclipse last year's production total.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

This is Girl Scout Week. More than three-quarters of a million girls and adult members are celebrating it throughout the nation. Here in the city 1,132 Scout troops, 26,000 strong, are lined up to enlarge their organization and extend its beneficent influence.

PORT ELIZABETH, Union of South Africa, Nov. 3 -- The Japanese people are well geared for war and despite hardships at home are firm in morale, ready to follow their leaders for at least another five years.

Out of lifting English fogs the largest force of American heavy bombers ever assembled swarmed yesterday into northwestern Germany. There may have been as many as 500 of the great ships, appropriately accompanied by our Lightnings and Thunderbolts. The ruin which can be spread by precision bombing from such a huge force is unimaginable in countries which have not experienced it.
A new photography center will be opened to the public today at 9 West Fifty-fourth Street by the Museum of Modern Art, whose own building is one block south at 11 West Fifty-third Street.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- Well over 400 Flying Fortresses and Liberators, the largest force of American heavy bombers ever employed in this theatre, led a resumption of the great Allied offensive against the Third Reich yesterday with a shattering blow at the port of Wilhelmshaven, site of the German naval base and shipyards turning out submarines and E-boats.

NASSAU , Bahamas, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Sir Harry Oakes' widow told her story of a bitter family tragedy today in a highly emotional climax to the trial of Alfred de Marigny and the Crown rested its case against the son-in-law, who is charged with the murder of the wealthy gold mine owner.

The heavy influx of buyers this month and in October probably will be followed by a corresponding decline in the importance of January as the major buying month of the spring season, according to comment in trade circles.

An appeal for Danish refugees in Sweden is announced by the National America Denmark Association, of which Jean Hersholt is president. C.H.W. Hasselriis, national chairman of the fund which is to be raised, describes the situation in words worth quoting in full:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 3 -- German forces in central and northern Greece, aided by parallel attacks of the Elas' guerrilla army, have succeeded in smashing the resistance of Gen. Napoleon Zervas' Edes guerrilla organization around Voulgareli.

Abdications and regencies in the interest of the general welfare, if it should come to that, are nothing new for Italy and the House of Savoy. The first stirrings of Italian unity after the Napoleonic wars -- the Risorgimento -- forced the first Victor Emmanuel of Piedmont and Sardinia to abdicate in favor of a brother with a kinsman, Charles Albert, of Liberal leanings then, as regent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd declared today that Administration leaders had so "coddled" John L. Lewis that he thought he was greater than the Government, but if an industrialist had sabotaged the war drive to even a slight extent, he said, President Roosevelt would have denounced him as a traitor.

Calling the Moscow conference a great success and the agreement "100 per cent of what could be obtained," Paul Henri Spaak, Foreign Minister of the Belgian Government in Exile, said yesterday that the meeting was a severe blow for Nazi morale.

Besides the national implications in the election of State Senator Joe R. Hanley as Lieutenant Governor by a majority of approximately 350,000, the Republican victory in New York State seems likely to have two important results:

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 3 -- Coach Earl Brown greeted four new linemen today at Dartmouth football practice as new students and Naval trainees began to arrive for the opening of the winter term next Friday.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. "The North Star," Samuel Goldwyn's picturization of a Lillian Hellman story about the Nazi invasion of a Russian village, will have its world premiere at the Victoria and Palace Theatres.

Referring to the article on hormone balance in the Science Section in your issue of today, let me say that the real founder of the treatment was Dr. Otto Zajicek of Vienna, a sincere and gifted man, but over-enthusiastic and lacking scientific background.

The strong Republican trend in New Jersey, first evidenced last year in the decisive victory of United States Senator Albert W. Hawkes, has grown appreciably, it was indicated yesterday, as final election returns demonstrated the magnitude of Walter E. Edge's victory over Mayor Vincent J. Murphy of Newark, his Democratic opponent, in the contest for Governor, and the full extent of the blow dealt Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic boss of the State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Fifty-six per cent of all generals serving with Army combat units are under 50 years of age, the War Department disclosed today. These include generals serving with corps, divisions, separate brigades and separate air forces, but, in the separate air forces 64 per cent of the generals are under 50.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- It is always easy to read more into election returns than they signify, and that is a professional practice among politicians. When the contests are local and off-year, broad interpretations are even less reliable, and yesterday's elections were both local and off-year.

Slide Rule, the favorite, took the $33,200 Westchester Handicap yesterday at Jamaica, where 16,559 persons watched the close of the Empire City fall meeting and the end of the regular New York racing season of 180 days.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 3 -- Berlin political circles commenting on the Moscow conference communique, said yesterday that the Allies evidently entirely ignored the fact that Germany would have a word to say regarding the battle for Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- When war essential activities of a manufacturing establishment are inseparable from those which are classified as deferrable activities under the War Manpower Commission's regulations concerning the essentiality of an establishment to the war effort the entire establishment should be classed as essential if approximately 75 per cent of its activities are essential, WMC ruled in a memorandum to its regional directors.

Irving Cohn, 56-year-old president of the Interstate Stevedoring Company of 44 Whitehall Street, was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and charged with having conspired with Lieut. Col. Edward Gordon Jr. to solicit a bribe of $12,500.

The New York committee of the National War Fund has raised $5,219,582, or 31 per cent of its $17,000,000 goal, it was announced yesterday at the first city-wide campaign report luncheon in the Hotel Commodore. On hand to hear the report were 350 persons, including representatives of all branches of the armed forces, whom Emil Schram, committee chairman, called the "real bosses" of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 110 United States soldiers killed in action. The announcement included casualties in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- A football team that has fought its heart out for so many years in a vain effort to beat Notre Dame as has Army might understandably come up to this game in a spirit of morituri te salutamus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Theodore A. Schmidt, 52 years old, a native of Austria, on charges of acting illegally as an agent of the Japanese Government before Pearl Harbor without registering with the State Department.

Marian Anderson's recital at Carnegie Hall last night was her thirty-fifth concert appearance in New York since her debut as a prize-winning soloist at the Stadium Concerts in the summer of 1925, according to her management's count.

A new phrase, "There is no vitamin to replace affection," has been coined by Mayor La Guardia. It appeared for the first time yesterday as part of his text for a poster headed, "Share Your Home with a Homeless Child." Two thousand of the posters are being distributed by the Department of Welfare to stimulate the drive for foster homes for 3,000 homeless children sponsored by the State Charities Aid Association.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Labor disputes in this country reached a new peak for the period of the war in September when there were 200 strikes in progress, according to a Ministry of Labor official in commenting on the latest issue of the Ministry's Gazette.
Among the many gratifying points of the Three-Power Conference documents there is one, in the statement on atrocities, which deserves particular attention.

The former City Club Building, a seven-story and penthouse structure at 55-57 West Forty-fourth Street, has been purchased for cash by the United States Plywood Corporation, which will make changes and occupy it as executive offices.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A wave of assassinations and attempted killings, some carried out by bitter anti-Japanese elements against Filipinos and Chinese whom they accused of collaborating with the conquerors, swept the Manila area late last spring and in the early summer.

The role of the artist in Soviet Russia in informing and inspiring Russian soldiers and civilians is illustrated in an exhibition of Russian photographs and posters opened last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to continue through this month.
A telegram from Philadelphia arrived just before 10 o'clock last night at the home of Abram Marcus, 2704 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx. A police officer took it and read:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 3 -- The Rev. Hubert Stanley Wood, for the last twelve and a half years rector of St. George's Episcopal Church, Flushing, Queens, has been elected dean of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here to succeed the Rev. George A. Robertshaw, who resigned on July 9.

Bruno Walter will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall at 8:45 o'clock tonight. Haydn's Symphony in G major, No. 13; Theme, Variations and Finale by Miklos Rozsa (first time), and the First Brahms Symphony, C minor, will comprise the program.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 150 East Fifty-second Street has been purchased by Frederick Brown, operator, from 150 East Fifty-second Street, Inc., Julius Bendheim, president. The building contains forty-eight suites and is reported fully occupied at an annual rental of more than $45,000.
PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Nov. 3 -- Travelers from French Indo-China say that twenty-two Australian prisoners have been decapitated in that Japanese-occupied land for reasons unannounced.
Columbia's football team went through its second scrimmage of the week yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the meeting with Dartmouth at Hanover, N.H., Saturday.

The National Education Association's committee investigating charges of interference by Mayor La Guardia with the independent functioning of the New York City school system has completed three days of private hearings at the Hotel Biltmore, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan began hearing evidence here today in a stockholders' suit brought against the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and twenty-four officers and directors to obtain repayment to the corporation of alleged illegal bonuses received by the officers in 1939-41.

Selling pressure unmatched in almost a month engulfed the stock market yesterday and prices were reduced 1 to 2 points. Bonds as well as commodities felt the force of the liquidation, and no support was accorded in any of the markets until the sales had run their course.

Sir Godfrey D.N. Haggard, British Consul General in New York since 1938, will retire from the British overseas service next spring and return to England, he announced last night at the forty-sixth annual dinner of the Soldiers of Colonial Wars in New York in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Wheat futures broke around 2 cents a bushel from the early high today on the Board of Trade as the result of general selling induced by indefinite peace reports which were circulated quite freely after an early bulge had carried prices up 1/2 to 3/4 cent to a new seasonal peak.

With the conscription age raised to 50, English women over that age are playing a larger role than ever in volunteer war work, and doing a "great job," Mrs. Alice Throckmorton McLean, founder and president of the American Women's Voluntary Services, said yesterday after a three-month visit to England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Census enumerators will start knocking at the doors of 7,000 American households next week to obtain a scientific sampling of civilian shortages in 115 types of goods and services as experienced in every geographic area, every income group, and by every type of worker both urban and rural.

Warning the nation's investment bankers that unless they find improved methods of assembling capital and making it available to industry through private capital markets, the Government will lend to business the money that it requires and obtain it through taxes, Jay N. Whipple, president of the Investment Bankers Association, told delegates to the association's thirty-second annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that the transition from Government loans to Government ownership may be short.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Formal announcement of the resignations of former Senator Clyde L. Herring of Iowa and of George J. Burke from the Office of Price Administration was made here today by Chester Bowles, OPA general manager.

Benny Goodman, who starts many a terpsichorean stampede by the jive-conscious when he "cooks on the front burners" with his clarinet, moved into the classical Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music yesterday afternoon. Mr. Goodman was a success.

Prior to the start of the 1943 National Football League campaign, it was Steve Owen's opinion that a team could lose three games and still manage to win the Eastern Division title and a play-off berth. Early yesterday, while his Giants worked out in preparation for Sunday's clash with the Lions at Detroit, the portly coach was asked if he had changed his view.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- In a clean sweep of city offices, the Republicans rolled up the highest plurality for Acting Mayor Bernard Samuel in yesterday's municipal election since the Democrats, revived under the New Deal, made their first real election bid eight years ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3 -- The Moscow conference has had a favorable echo in the democratic Argentine newspapers, among which several organs, with the Buenos Aires dailies Nacion and Prensa in the forefront, today commented on the results achieved.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 3 -- Together with reports of growing tension in Austria as a direct result of the Moscow communique, rumors reached Sweden today of serious rioting in Berlin and elsewhere in the Reich, prompting a proclamation of martial law for the German capital and forty other Reich cities, including Flensburg on the German-Danish border.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The harrowing experiences of six wounded survivors of a Royal Air Force Coastal Command Halifax plane, who drifted eleven days in a rubber boat on the Atlantic, subsisting on concentrated foods and rain water and risking dangerous collisions with whales, but who lived to tell the tale, were revealed today by Air Ministry officials.

KUKONG, China, Oct. 30 (Delayed) -- Here, 150 miles north of Canton on the West River system, Cantonese refugees are telling themselves they will be home in a year and a half. Dawdling over lunch in an enormous noisy pavilion on the river bank, they hear encouraging rumors every day and believe them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Charges that the Office of Price Administration was guilty of "Government by directive" for its part in the promulgation last week of an order controlling the price of live cattle were denied today by Thomas C. Hart, acting OPA general counsel.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 (AP) -- James H.R. Cromwell, whose wife, Doris Duke Cromwell, has sued for a Nevada divorce, termed today as "utterly without proof" her court charge that he "had demanded control of $7,000,000 or any amount, of her $100,000,000 fortune."

Panama hat importers and dealers here yesterday reported that selling prices in Ecuador, principal source for the body hats, have been showing "startling" price advances, with quotations in some instances running 100 per cent more than the like period a year ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- Not only was Mayor Angelo J. Rossi swept out of office in yesterday's municipal election but Matthew Brady, serving his twenty-fourth year as District Attorney of San Francisco, was supplanted and, for the first time in the city's history, a Mayor's nominee for school director was turned down.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- It was said here today that the assault on Rabaul, the fifth heavy attack on the New Britain base since Oct. 23, was the fiercest air engagement since the battle of the Bismarck Sea. It was described in the communique as a "desperate" battle.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 3 -- Julius Rykovich, star right half of the Notre Dame football team, is in a Gary (Ind.) hospital suffering from intestinal influenza.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission heard today additional testimony on an application by the Chesapeake Ohio for authority to issue $76,573,700 in preference stock as a dividend to common stockholders.

To inquire after an election whether or not the voters have shown good sense is like asking how bright the human race is. The assumption of democracy is that in the long run the average citizen's opinion about important candidates and decisive questions is worth more than any opinion that could be substituted.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- Russian forces swept yesterday toward Kherson, Black Sea port at the mouth of the Dnieper River, as the retreating Germans poured back across the stream, abandoning thousands of dead and piles of stores and machines, Moscow announced today.

Of the latest Nazi achievement in Italy Benedetto Croce is the witness. To protect them from bombing, many cases of historic Neapolitan documents had been stored in Capua at the villa of Count Filangieri. Among them were the records of centuries of Neapolitan history, including the registers of the great house of Hohenstaufen in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries.

Directors of the United States Rubber Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock for payment on Dec. 17. Including payments of 25 cents each in June and September, holders of the common stock will have received this year $1 a share in dividends.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3 -- There were indications today that Howie Odell and the other Yale coaches are planning to gamble touchdowns with Brown on Saturday in the Bowl. Only this game and the annual and ancient one with Princeton remain to complete the wartime schedule of the Elis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A bill to prevent the Department of Justice from applying the antitrust laws to the insurance business was warmly supported and heatedly opposed today on Capitol Hill. The Bailey-Van Nuys bill would leave the matter to State regulation, on the ground that if the Federal Government stepped in the result might be an undesirable degree of Federal control.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- A delegation of eight representatives of liberal groups today urged Attorney General Francis Biddle to investigate anti-Semitism in Boston and New York and racial tensions in Detroit and other communities and to prosecute those who are responsible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Robert R. Young of New York, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, today urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to expedite the acquisition by his road of 60,000 shares of Wheeling Lake Erie common stock from Blyth Co., Inc., "as the New York Central Railroad Company is evidencing interest in Wheeling Lake Erie stock."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A working contract calling for a permanent arbitrator of any labor disagreements at plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation was signed today by Henry J. Kaiser, new president of the concern, and by representatives of the United Automobile Workers, an affiliate of the CIO.

Mayor La Guardia, in a speech that was sharply critical of the Office of Price Administration on several counts, suggested yesterday that the Federal agency be ignored "for the next few days" until it is reorganized to make "some sense."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Republican victories in New York and New Jersey in yesterday's elections and a "Republican trend" throughout the country "presage defeat of the New Deal in 1944," Gov. John W. Bricker said today.
WRIGHT FIELD, DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- Here the Army Air Forces Materiel Command is developing the theory of flight to its ultimate reality.

War production can be accelerated by adaptations of the sales promotion methods that have been successful in stimulating the activity of product distributors, C.E. Gischel, advertising manager of Walter Kidde Co., makers of fire extinguishers, declared yesterday at the luncheon of the American Management Association's sales promotion group in the Hotel Sheraton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Rubber requirements of the United States will be practically met by the synthetic rubber production program by the end of next year, but a tight situation will exist in the meantime, Col. Bradley Dewey, Rubber Director, told a Senate Agriculture subcommittee today.

Nicholas M. Schenck's "troubles" ended when George E. Browne and Willie Bioff were indicted for using the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes Union, which they controlled, in the extortion of $1,000,000 from the movie producers, Mr. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., said yesterday.

In an atmosphere of considerable secrecy, 600 food manufacturers gathered yesterday for a three-day discussion of their wartime problems at the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

With anthracite supplies in the New York City area at their lowest point in history, the pinch of the miners' strike began to be felt here yesterday in such serious ways as a lack of coal for tugboats working on a Navy yard contract, three schools with empty bins and 300 cold homes in the war production community of Farmingdale, L.I.

The Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate has approved the addition to the Connally resolution of the gist of Point Four of the Moscow agreements, which declares that the Four Powers "recognize the necessity of establishing at the earliest practicable date a general international organization" for the maintenance of peace and security.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered a number of changes in its food commodity classifications and amended some of its mark-up regulations for food wholesalers and retailers. At the same time the price agency made several changes in its provisions for store operations.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- With a burst of speed in the stretch, Platter carried the light and dark blue silks of George D. Widener to victory in the $40,520 Plimlico Futurity today.

Returns four-fifths complete on the six amendments to the State Constitution voted on Tuesday showed yesterday that five had been adopted overwhelmingly but that one was still in doubt. This was No. 3, which proposed a reapportionment of Assembly districts affecting only Nassau County.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Although some sections of the stock markets here were quiet today there were many bright spots and the tone generally was cheerful.

Two of Rose Franken's earlier plays found great favor -- "Another Language" and "Claudia." Her third, which William Brown Meloney brought to the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last evening, is not cut from the same piece of cloth. For where its two predecessors were simple, "Outrageous Fortune" is confused and complex; where the writing of "Another Language" and "Claudia" was easy, that of the third is conducted in a series of emotional gasps.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Following is the text of the "memorandum of greement" for returning striking coal miners to their jobs:

ALGIERS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A year ago the name "American" was a magic one to the French in North Africa. Today, a year after the Allied landings, it is more often a term of reproach than praise. The blunt truth is that the prestige of the United States among a considerable proportion of the French people has taken a nosedive.

When allotment checks need stretching, the Navy Wives Clubs of America steps in with aid ranging from a "revolving pantry" to a layette-lending service, delegates to the organization's sixth annual convention at the Brooklyn Navy Young Men's Christian Association at 167 Sands Street, reported yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- United States Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in a statement issued just before he left the Russian capital, said that the Tripartite Conference "not only testified to the great possibilities, but also to the great certainties and realities regarding the widest plans for the future," Radio Moscow said in a broadcast early today.

Operations of the Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries during the nine months ended with September resulted in a net income of $10,453,052 after all charges including taxes of $5,210,739 and $900,000 provision for post-war contingencies, according to a report to be released today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- During the week ended Nov. 3, member bank reserve balances increased $64,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from increases of $149,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $3,000,000 in Treasury currency and a decrease of $196, 000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, offset in part by increases of $264,000,000 in money in circulation and $3,000, 000 in Treasury cash and a decrease of $16,000,000 in gold stocks.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A British communique:

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC PORT, Nov. 4 -- "An enemy plane dropped flares which lighted us up as though you had turned on the electric lights for a crap game. Then we heeled as our salvos were fired. The flash of Jap guns on the distant horizon showed our shells falling around them.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- An official announcement from the Soviet Information Bureau, broadcast from Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Larry MacPhail, former president of the Dodgers said today he expected that major league and Class AA minor league baseball would operate next year, "but beyond that I am not optimistic."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- Randolph Scott and Ann Rutherford have been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the co-starring leads in "Stranger on the Highway," a film to be based on H.R. Hay's detective novel. John Brahm, who is completing "The Lodger," a story of London's Jack-the-Ripper murders, will be the director and Islin Auster the producer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Roosevelt will make two speeches this month, the White House said today.

Further ground was surrendered yesterday by the stock market under another steady stream of liquidation. Losses of fractions to 2 points were about the same as in the previous session, although selling increased to register the heaviest daily business in three months, transfers on the Stock Exchange rising to 1,154,240 shares, from 1,072,250 on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., just returned from a tour of Mediterraneon battlefronts, said today he found soldiers worried over the accumulation of national debt and the prospect that in addition to fighting the war they would have also to pay for it in the years to come.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 4 -- As a result of a tremendous national effort, this year's grain harvest in the Soviet Union considerably exceeds that of last year and the food picture for the impending winter can be considered relatively optimistic.

A record, a race and a romance waged a minor battle for interest yesterday in an Atlantic Coast port, and romance won. It all had to do with a 4,500-ton Norwegian refrigerator ship boasting a record of sixty-two wartime Atlantic crossings, a private competition between the ship and a sister craft, and the ship's captain who married his radio operator after he had at first refused to have her aboard.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 4 -- Various claims to victories that have bulked large in their guerrilla warfare of the Partisans last month appeared to be substantiated today by reports from other sources. Sixty kilometers [thirty-seven miles] double-track railroad between Zagreb and Belgrade and a bridge thirty meters [ninety-eight and one-half feet] long at Dubski Potok, together with two trains and sixty cars laden with German troops and electric pylons, and twenty culverts were destroyed.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs twice came from behind tonight to play the Red Wings to a 5-to-5 tie in a National Hockey League game before 9,738 spectators. Three goals in five minutes of the second period squared the count at 4 to 4, and then Babe Pratt's goal offset one by Pat Egan of Detroit in the third period.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 4 -- Chaplains of three denominations, Protestant, Catholic and Jewish, officiated at the dedication of the first United States military cemetery in the Holy Land yesterday. Inaugurated by Maj. Gen. Ralph M. Royce, commanding general of the United States forces in the Middle East, the cemetery lies on the slopes of the Judean foothills facing the Holy City.

The address of Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways System, at the annual dinner of the National Foreign Trade Council, as reported in your issue of Oct. 27, should not go unchallenged.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Britain and Russia are believed to have started diplomatic moves designed to gain Allied bases in Turkey and to drive Finland, Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria out of the war.
The best and poorest of Bruno Walter were both in evidence when he made his first appearance of the season as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

The press, radio and newsreels are thanked for cooperation in obtaining Red Cross volunteers and blood donors, in the annual report of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, distributed yesterday.

NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 4 -- How difficult it is going to be for the Allies to settle the war guilt of individuals and destroy fascism and nazism without destroying the whole structure of Italian and German society is becoming clearer every day.

Abraham Straus, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on July 31, transacted the largest volume of sales in their history, Walter Rothschild, president, reported yesterday in his annual statement to stockholders. Net sales totaled $31,157,476 and exceeded those of the previous year by $3,081,464, or 10.98 per cent.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 4 -- Grim-faced and earnest, Alfred de Marigny pleaded for life and liberty today with a firm-voiced denial that he slugged his aged father-in-law, Sir Harry Oakes, and left him to die in a flaming bedroom.

HOLMES, N.Y., Nov. 4 -William F. Carey, New York City's Sanitation Commissioner, stood upon a hill outside this Dutchess County hamlet today and swung his arm in wide arc which spanned ninety-four railway coaches scattered in apparent disarray over a wooded countryside, rich in autumn colors.

Louis Adamic, Pearl S. Buck, Harry Hansen and Emil Lengyel will open a new series of "Books and Background" discussion forums on Wednesday evening at the New York Times Hall. Louis Adamic's book "My Native Land" will be discussed, with the program built around the land and people of Jugoslavia and the Balkans.

A committee comprising W.G. Maguire, president, and I.L. Letts and C.E. Main, directors of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, known also as Mokan, was appointed at a meeting of the board of directors on Wednesday to study and report on appropriate means of effecting an orderly liquidation of the company and of guaranteeing the continued independent operation of Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, its subsidiary.

With the presentation yesterday by Lillian Gish, actress member of the governing board of the Medical and Surgical Relief Committee of America, of twelve small emergency medical kits, one large medical field set and 10,000 vitamin capsules to Lieut. Comdr. S.S. Daunis, commanding officer of Motor Torpedo Boat Squadron 29 of the United States Navy, this three-year-old agency again expanded its medical relief activities for the benefit of another branch of the country's armed forces.

Because of the player shortage, Frank Boucher, one of the great hockey centers of all time, will don his skates again tomorrow night when the Rangers meet the Black Hawks in the opening game of the home season at Madison Square Garden.

We should like to express our appreciation of the article in your paper on the occasion of the Pan-Dodecanesian Congress. However, we should like to point out that the delegates representing their countrymen all over the world did not "urge" or ask the union of the Dodecanese with motherland Greece, but proclaimed the union of the people of the islands with the people of Greece.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Thomas Vincent De Lorenzo, labor union leader, acknowledged today that he has used a half dozen different names "when they came in handy," and admitted that he had lied in several official documents, among them his 1940 income tax return and his draft board record.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- How to entertain a soldier or a sailor, help him solve his home problems and explain his financial and employment benefits are sample lessons which 750 persons, mostly young women, are busy learning at the American University where every classroom of the American Red Cross personnel training unit simulates a war atmosphere.

Appointment of Dr. Harry James Carman as Dean of Columbia College will be ratified unanimously by its stu- dents and its graduates. He served as Assistant Dean in the Twenties. Year after year the undergraduates have voted him the most popular instructor. That speaks well for their common sense, for he is no giver of easy courses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- The Bureau of the Census issued a statistical report today on changes in Negro population since 1870 which showed marked increases in literacy and school attendance, entrance into professions and a general trend away from farm laborer status to ownership of their own farms or to the cities.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted the General Chemical Company of New York, three other chemical manufacturing concerns, and seven individuals on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by conspiring to monopolize the manufacture and sale of laboratory chemicals in the United States, and by conspiring to eliminate competition by price fixing.
ALGIERS, Nov. 4 -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A report on "acts of German cruelty and wanton destruction" in the Naples area, all of which were "unnecessary" from any military point of view," was made public today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr.

After completing a survey of 225 coal yards in this city, Daniel P. Woolley, Commissioner of Markets, reported to Mayor La Guardia yesterday that about 25 per cent of the normal supply of coal of all sizes was on hand in New York.

KANHSIEN, Kiangsi Province, China, Nov. 2 (Delayed) -- Among the cities in free China Kanhsien is the most modern because it is administered by a progressive-minded magistrate. He is Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's oldest son, who is in his middle thirties.

Young men and women in the armed services in many parts of the world will be surprised to receive cards this year from the New York Public Library, but these cards will not be the usual kind that the institution sends out reminding of books overdue.
Striking coal miners trickled slowly back to the pits last night and reports from the field indicated that full production would not be under way, at best, until Monday.

In an attempt to build up a number of "favorite son" candidates for the Republican nomination for President and thus head off the nomination of Wendell L. Willkie, John D. M. Hamilton, former Republican national chairman, is on a political trip that will take him to the Pacific Coast.

American Youth for Democracy, which was organized after the dissolution of the Young Communist League, has received a charter as a campus organization from the Student Council of the Washington Square College of New York University by a vote of 10 to 9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The United States submarine campaign against Japanese shipping, which Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declares is proceeding "full speed ahead," has resulted in the sinking of ten additional vessels and the damaging of three others, increasing the total number of enemy ships sunk or damaged since Pearl Harbor to 487.

Love of ease, political cowardice and personal ambition threaten to betray our fighting men on the many battlefields of this war through the failure of Congress to enact a courageous tax program that will prevent inflation, Stabilization Director Fred M. Vinson said last night at the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Owing chiefly to the fact that the twelve regional Federal Reserve Banks bought substantial blocks of Government securities from member banks, excess reserves of the member institutions in New York City and for the country as a whole were enabled to show a small increase during the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Louis H. Pink, former State Superintendent of Insurance and now president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, was appointed yesterday by the Office of Price Administration as director of the New York defense rental area.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Quien Es, carrying the colors of the Calumet Farm, annexed the $5,000 added Janney Handicap, six-furlong sprint feature at Pimlico today. The 5-year-old son of Hygro had all his speed through the stretch and drew out to win by three lengths.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $184,966,000 during the week.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The Allied air offensive against Germany reached a new peak last night when an extremely powerful force of British heavy bombers blasted torpedo and U-boat parts factories at Duesseldorf with more than 2,000 tons of bombs in twenty-seven minutes.

Sound conclusions underlie the reasoning of William H. Lehman in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 3. If the type of education that is envisaged by the Federal Government will follow strict academic lines, then it would be definitely unwise besides wasteful to make available such training.

A dealer who has contracted to sell commodities at a certain price, but finds that before he can make delivery the Office of Price Administration has revised its schedules and outlawed the price agreed upon, must either invalidate the contract or accept the lowered ceiling price, according to a ruling yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The post-war policy resolution, which was revised by the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate yesterday to include the declaration of the Moscow Allied Conference for a general international organization to maintain peace and security, weathered two test votes today without further alteration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Despite the deep disappointment of some of the members of the National War Labor Board in President Roosevelt's course, and their belief that he had "let them down" when he authorized Secretary Ickes to negotiate an agreement with John L. Lewis while 530,000 coal miners were on strike, the board is expected to announce its approval tomorrow of the arrangement under which the union called off the strike last night.

The strengthening and expansion of the nation's commerce in the post-war period was advocated in resolutions and by leaders in the fields of marine and air transportation at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday at 65 Liberty Street.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 -- It took Frankie Sinkwich seven games to get his first professional touchdown and he's well down the National Football League list in individual achievement, but the Detroit Lions think the former Georgia All-America is all his college press agents said he was.

With individual contributions ranging from $1,000 to $19,000, the women's division of the National War Fund's New York Committee has raised more than half of its quota of $800,000, Mrs. Oswald B. Lord, section chairman, disclosed in a report made public yesterday.

Appealing to women not otherwise employed to help meet the manpower shortage facing retail stores, eleven New Jersey women's groups are backing a campaign to recruit them for jobs in the Christmas rush as a patriotic measure.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Leading all the way, W. Gullatt's Navy today won the Madison Purse by a length at Rockingham Park. Skipper Z. made a determined stretch bid, moving from fifth place to second. Star Whiz was third.

When Johnny Lujack steps out against Army on the turf of the Yankee Stadium tomorrow as the new quarterback of the Notre Dame team, the spotlight will focus on him as it has on no other player out of South Bend since 1930.
Columbia's football forces, pared further by scholastic difficulties, entrain this afternoon for the New Hampshire hills and the meeting in Hanover tomorrow with Dartmouth's strong team.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 (AP) -- One man was bound over for the grand jury and hearings for three others adjourned today as the State Election Frauds Bureau pressed its investigation of election practices in Democratic Albany.
Leasing of several large floors and midtown stores featured the commercial rental activity reported by brokers yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 4 -- More than 700 of the 2,950 steel workers who walked out in protest over the discharge of a CIO union grievance committee man faced a threat of almost immediate induction into the Army tonight unless they returned to their jobs in the National Supply Company's Spang-Chalfant division.

Eager to bring a speedy end to reports that Dixie Walker is the one Dodger player Manager Leo Durocher "doesn't like," President Branch Rickey of the Brooklyn Club announced yesterday at his weekly press conference that Dixie not only was in excellent standing with the Flock but already had accepted terms for his 1944 contract.

After a week of almost continual selling in which futures steadily declined on Wednesday to the season's lowest levels, trade buying on the New York Cotton Exchange made itself felt in late dealings yesterday as traders were attracted to the market largely by technical consideratitons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Office of Price Administration, in consultation with the industry advisory committee for the finished piece goods industry, will tackle the problem of assuring a sufficient supply of low-cost finished cotton and rayon piece goods at a meeting to be held in OPA'S New York office on Monday, it was announced here today.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, and William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, have proposed that their record subsidiaries collect fees on disks used by radio stations, but the plan has been rejected flatly by the National Association of Broadcasters, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Lindsay C. Warren, Controller General, reiterated with considerable vehemence to members of the subcommittee of the Senate Military Affairs Committee today his charges of irregularities and ineptitudes in war contracts negotiated by Army officers.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- Technical Sgt. George Ferrell of 117 Beech Street, Belleville, N.J., received the Distinguished Flying Medal from King George in a recent ceremony at Buckingham Palace, it was learned today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- In southern Russia on the Dnieper's left bank the Germans now are split into three groups, two of which, unless they find a means of crossing the sea, are threatened with complete destruction.

Groups of Venezuelan workers soon may come here to learn the newest industrial processes, Senora Margot Boulton de Bottomme, founder of the Venezuelan-American Center in Caracas, said yesterday. The adult education program of the two-year-old center, built around Venezuela's great interest in this country, has been so successful that she came here to arrange "advanced courses" for men and women workers -- inspection trips to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate today rejected, 70 to 15, an amendment by Senator Danaher, Republican of Connecticut, to incorporate in the post-war policy resolution a statement of the principles of the Atlantic Charter:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Weakening prices for certain agricultural products, particularly grains and livestock, brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets down 0.1 per cent during the last week of October.

Despite the success of the systhetic-rubber program there is a serious tire scarcity which will grow to a shortage of 2,000,000 passenger-car tires by Jan. 1, the executive committee of the tire division of the Rubber Manufacturers Association declared yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Notes in circulation exceeded a billion pounds as reported by the Bank of England today, reaching the new high record of 1,005,063,000, an increase of 6,601,000 in the week ended yesterday.

Root vegetables offer some of the purchases in the market this week, for many of the more perishable varieties now being shipped from the South and West are fairly expensive. Yellow and white turnips and parsnips are plentiful and average well below 10 cents a pound in price, and carrots and beets are comparatively inexpensive at 11 and 6 cents a bunch, respectively.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

NAPLES, Nov. 3 (Delayed) -- King Victor Emmanuel came to a sullen Naples today on his first visit since before the fall of Benito Mussolini. He drove ostentatiously through the streets in an open military car, with another auto carrying four officers standing upright, and a third car in the rear.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Not a single enterprise in south Russia's iron and steel industry has escaped damage, according to a report of Soviet specialists who recently returned to Moscow from an extended tour of the Donets Basin.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- Today's communique:

Investors have purchased from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company the fourteen-story store anti-loft building at 16 to 20 West Forty-seventh Street for cash, over a first mortgage of $720,000 for ten years, taken back by the seller. Occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet, the building was erected in 1925. It was sold through Omnia Properties, Inc. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured the title.
Apartments in the Beekman, at 575 Park Avenue, have been leased by Mrs. Victor Harris, Mrs. Alice Doscher, B.W. Morris, Allan Melhado, Edmund Randolph, Lieut. Comdr. C. Havemeyer and William Lord.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 4 -- It was learned here today that Dino Alfieri, former Italian Ambassador to Berlin, who was arrested by the Fascist "Republicans," has succeeded in reaching neutral territory after escaping from a Munich prison.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt presented the 5,000,000th free service man's ticket distributed by the New York City Defense Recreation Committee to Staff Sgt. John Dario, a veteran of the North African campaign, at a ceremony yesterday in the organization headquarters, 99 Park Avenue.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Nov. 4 -- A balance of $14,234,298 remains for distribution among heirs of the estate of Cyrus H.K. Curtis, publisher of newspapers and magazines, according to an accounting filed in Montgomery County Court by the executors, Mrs. Mary Louise Bok Zimbalist, only daughter of Mr. Curtis, and John C. Martin, husband of one of his stepdaughters.

An indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Nathaniel Seaman, 45 years old, a blind lawyer, who formerly had an office at 120 Wall Street. He was convicted Oct. 18 for trying to defraud the widow of Duncan Phyfe, descendant of the famous furniture designer, of $40,650.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- When Chairman Connally of the Foreign Relations Committee asked unanimous consent of the Senate today to a final vote at 4:30 P.M. on the post-war policy resolution, Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, objected but said that he would not oppose a vote tomorrow.

An even greater shortage of milk than exists at present may be expected next year, and consumers "will have to drink Washington propaganda instead of milk," Fred H. Sexauer, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., declared yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The Stock Markets here turned quiet again today and the main tendency was to decline.

ALGIERS, Nov. 4 -- The highly touted German line from Massico Ridge across Italy to Vasto was shattered at the vital central hinge at 3 o'clock this morning when Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British-Canadian Eighth Army smashed into Isernia, most vital inland point on the entire front, completing a ten-mile push in thirty-six hours.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Senator Joe R. Hanley, Lieutenant Governor-elect, as vice chairman of the State War Council, and of Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck as State Coordinator of War Plans. Both appointments were approved by the War Council.

President Roosevelt will deliver the closing address of the twelfth forum on current problems, which will be held under the auspices of The New York Herald Tribune on Nov. 16 and 17 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The President, as has been his custom in previous forums, will broadcast his message, which will be on a subject related to the general theme of the closing session, "The World We Want."

Eighteen hours after his step-grandmother had been found strangled in her apartment at 2704 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, Leonard (Buddy) Marcus, 15-year-old high school student, was picked up in Wayne, Pa., and, according to the police there, signed a confession that he killed Mrs. Jennie Flicker, 75, when she surprised him taking money from a secretary.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill revealed today that British liaison officers were aiding thousands of guerrillas fighting the Germans in Albania and confirmed that British officers had also been sent into Greece and Yugoslavia.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Three thousand Durham miners struck today, canceling out a slight improvement in the British labor situation resulting from the return to work of hundreds of dock workers on the Thames. Tonight there are more than 32,000 workers on strike throughout Britain.

In a London dispatch to this newspaper yesterday it was said that the two best places to get hearty, simple food cheap in London are the public houses and the state-controlled "British restaurants." We skip the latter, as the pubs are more homelike. Years ago, when every respectable Englishman wore a black coat, these places of refreshment were not in good repute with conformable Victorians.

Although the Four-Power Declaration issued by the Moscow Conference in the name of the United States, Great Britain, Russia and China takes full account of the legal and military situation existing in the Far East, it does provide for mutual aid among all the four signatory nations, including China, which is waging war against Japan only.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The "final test" of the Army's new super- bomber, the B-29, "is not now far distant," Gen. H.H. Arnold, commanding the Army Air Forces, said today in confirming recent re- ports that the Army's most powerful aircraft are on their way.

Paul W. Kesten, executive vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, restated yesterday the policies of CBS regarding the selling of time for controversial discussion and the broadcasting of unbiased news and news analyses by its commenators.

THERE are no good places to fight a war. But of all the bad places -- fever-ridden jungles, waterless deserts, snowy steppes and precipitous mountains -- surely one of the worst is the Aleutian chain of desolate islands from which we only recently chased the Japanese. "There's a woman behind every tree in the Aleutians," is a typical GI joke in honor of the fact that there are no trees there at all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Herbert Hoover, who fed the starving people of German-occupied Belgium during the First World War, begged a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today to favor a plan for transmitting food through neutral countries to millions of men, women and especially children in lands overrun by the Nazis in the present conflict.

Sorting of proportional representation ballots for City Councilmen was completed yesterday in Manhattan and neared completion in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens. A count of first choice votes in all boroughs but Brooklyn may be finished by tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 30 were 10 per cent above sales of the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 12 per cent for the week ended Oct. 23 when compared to the like period a year ago.

Three midtown theatres will present new film attractions this morning. At the Strand, the newcomer is "Princess O'Rourke," a romantic comedy written and directed for Warner Brothers by Norman Krasna. Heading the cast are Olivia de Havilland, Robert Cummings, Charles Coburn, Jack Carson and Jane Wyman. . . .
The buildings at 2014-24 Eighty-sixth Street and 4-12 Bay Twenty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the City Savings Bank of Brooklyn to the Johnson Holding Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A $215,368,444 deficiency bill which represented a cut of 82 per cent, or almost a billion dollars from budget estimates emerged from committee today only to run into a stiff fight on the floor because it carried unchanged a $5,000,000 item for the Office of War Information's foreign branch.
Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas has arrived from Newport, and is at the St. Regis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- General selling and scattered liquidation developed in the grain markets today on the Board of trade, and traders were more inclined to the bear side than for some time past as the result of the favorable war news from Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Praising the "heroic proportions" of the American infantryman, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson authorized two new badges today honoring "the case-hardened foot-fighter capable of carrying combat into the enemy's teeth."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 4 -- New Zealanders are now operating a passenger and freight service around Vella Lavella in which all customers must work their passage, a war correspondent reported today. The organization, calling itself the Umomo General Freight and Passengers Transport Corporation, at present possesses one dugout canoe, one light canoe, two outriggers and two collapsible Japanese assault boats.

The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it had made arrangements through the Mellon Securities Corporation to sell privately $84,000,000 of twenty-year 3 per cent debentures to sixteen insurance companies The major portion of the proceeds of this financing will be applied to the payment of bank loans, the announcement said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The War Production Board announced today a bonus system for newsprint use, which will allow a newspaper publisher using less than his quota in the last quarter of 1943 to carry over this saving for use in the first quarter of 1944.

There are just two spots on the Continent of Europe today where a free and democratic election can be held. Spain under General Franco has a dictatorial government which established itself by a civil war, with the aid of Italy and Germany. Portugal, though now a nonbelligerent friendly to the United Nations, has some "corporative" and dictatorial features which set it aside.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Allied casualties in the Mediterranean area during the past year are slightly less than 100,000 killed, missing and wounded, compared with 600,000 for the Axis, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson revealed today in commenting on the approaching anniversary of the landing of American and British troops in North Africa.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 5 -- A Japanese cruiser and four destroyers were sunk in the battle of American and Japanese warships near the Allies' Bougainville beachhead, it was announced officially today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Spearheading an attack on President Roosevelt's food subsidy policy, organized milk producers called upon Congress today to order an increase of $622,000,000 a year in the prices of milk and dairy products throughout the country.

A high-stooped brownstone house of the "little old New York" era was opened formally at 422 West Twenty-second Street yesterday by the Salvation Army to house the wives and mothers of service men. Called Hospitality House, it provides accommodations for thirty-five women at 50 cents a night.
The Victory race meeting got under way yesterday at Jamaica with the 14,461 persons present wagering $1,417,739 and the favored Black Badge first in the Hornet Handicap.

The Administration has made an all but complete surrender to John L. Lewis. Mr. Lewis has now got about $1.75 of the $2 extra a day that he demanded early this year. In negotiating an agreement with him, the Administration has set aside the War Labor Board's policy of refusing to negotiate with a union while its members were on strike.

A reorganization of the War Production Board's container control agencies which would put all types of packaging under the jurisdiction of one group and thus eliminate duplication of orders and aid consumer compliance was urged yesterday by Charles L. Sheldon, purchasing agent for the Hood Rubber Company and former chief of WPB's containers branch, at the annual meeting of the Packaging Institute at the Hotel New Yorker.

Some of the concern of retailers regarding having too much "ersatz" goods in stock in the event of sudden peace developments appears to have disappeared, according to comment here. For one thing, loss of business volume through not having goods in stock was held an offset to possibility of markdown losses.

With the Giants playing the Lions in Detroit on Sunday, the Dodgers will have first call on the football fans in the metropolitan area when they meet the Chicago Cardinals at Ebbets Field the same day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The President had appointments with Senator Hayden, Representative James Robinson, Secretary Stimson and Budget Director Smith.

The financial community is much interested in the hearing on competitive bidding for the sale of new railroad securities which will be opened today before the Interstate Commerce Commission. For more than a year the question has been more or less before the public as controversies developed over private sales of railroad securities and one group or another would file objections with the ICC.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP -- Loss of the blimp K-94 with her eight-man crew as a result of a fire was announced by the Navy today.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 4 -- The Japanese have resorted to the use of poison gas in their new offensive in Central China, the Chinese High Command charged tonight.

Over the protest of Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet, counsel for Wayne Lonergan, confessed slayer of his 22-year-old wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, in her home at 313 East Fifty-first Street on Oct. 24, received an eleven-day stay in General Sessions yesterday in which to enter a formal plea on the first degree-murder indictment against the Canadian aircraftsman.

Four sponsors (Lou Walters, Don Ross, E.M. Loew and Michael Redstone) have pooled their resources to put on an elaborate edition of the "Artists and Models" revue series. Tonight their latest conception will be inspected by all and sundry at the Broadway Theatre when the curtain goes up at 8:30.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4 (AP) -- With the Brown game two days off and the season finale against Princeton scheduled next week, Yale went back to fundamentals for its football practice today. In a spirited workout the squad drilled on blocking, tackling ball handling, and pass and kick protection.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Thousands of American soldiers who were taken prisoner after the fall of Bataan and Corregidor have already been removed from the Philippines to Formosa, Japan and Manchuria, where they undoubtedly now are doing forced labor.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Assurances by the Government that food is being dispatched to India for the relief of the famine victims and that prompt steps will be taken in other directions to improve conditions there failed to satisfy a critical House of Commons this afternoon.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 5 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique today announced that off Cape Pomas, on the Gazelle Peninsula, at the northern end of New Britain, a Liberator patrol bomber sank an 8,000-ton enemy merchant vessel before dawn Wednesday.

ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- American warships battling Japanese forces on even terms in a black night smashed a Japanese attempt to enter Empress Augusta Bay, on the west coast of Bougainville Island, where United States Marines have solidly established a beachhead.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Virtually complete but unofficial reports on Tuesday's general election showed tonight that Republicans were elected Governor, Lieutenant Governor and to most of the other State offices in a sweeping upset.

In pre-war days it seemed that every Navy recruiting poster carried the slogan, "Join the Navy and See the World." The slogan has vanished, for several reasons, one of them being that the Navy is already all over the world. Not only on all the seas and in many of the islands, but all over this America of ours.

Interest in the post-war disposition of the great network of air bases built by the United States all around the globe has been stimulated by the reports of the special Senate committee that recently returned from an inspection tour of the battlefields.

Margaret Leighton Moore, 13 years old, missing since late Sunday afternoon when she disappeared from Central Park with a sailor, returned to her home at 1172 Park Avenue early yesterday morning. She arrived alone, having traveled by bus from Columbus, Ohio, and the police reported that the family's physician, Dr. Richard Pierson, said she had come through her experience unharmed.

The first boxing card in Madison Square Garden for a month, headlined by the first heavyweight bout there since last March, will be presented tonight, with Tami Mauriello of the Bronx and Lee Savold of Paterson, N.J., as the principals in a contest scheduled for ten rounds.

Kickers and Kicked James A. Farley's comment on the election marks a complete break with his usual formula on such occasions. We always think of Mr. Farley as saying that the figures speak for themselves. It is another way of saying that comment is superfluous.
