Coming from behind in three of their matches, the Princeton Club sprang an upset when it defeated the Yale Guests, 5 to 0, in a Metropolitan Squash Racquets League contest on the Tigers' courts last night. The result sent the victors into first place.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 4 -- Louis Harmon, father of Lieut. Tommy Harmon, Michigan's All-America halfback of 1939 and 1940, said tonight that the Army had informed him that his son had been missing in action over China since Oct. 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Displaying an attitude toward President Roosevelt which was lukewarm at best and often critical, leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations made it plain today that they intended to take their time in selecting a 1944 Presidential candidate behind whom to throw support expected to embrace millions of votes and "an educational fund" of more than $5,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Definition of the regulatory powers of the Federal Communications Commission to keep them within more reasonable bounds than the expanding areas of control authorized by the Supreme Court's decision in the chain broadcasting case, and not abolition in toto of the commission's regulations in this field, is the purpose of the Wheeler-White bill, its authors stated at today's hearing before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

The War Food Administration has begun a survey to discover the actual "dollars and cents" return to the Government in its "War Fights for Freedom" advertising campaign, it was disclosed yesterday by Vernon D. Beatty, director of advertising.

The two six-story apartment houses on a plot 250 by 100 feet at 1865-75 University Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by the University Plaza Corporation to Isadore Silverman, operator, for cash above a first mortgage of $352,600. They contain 111 apartments. Armstrong Brothers, managing agents for the buildings, were the brokers. Abraham Leichter represented the buyer.

Surrounded by youngsters, former Gov. Alfred E. Smith became a modern "Pied Piper" yesterday morning at the Central Park Zoo. His familiar brown derby may have been less colorful than the piper's headgear, his down to earth "Come on, children," less musical than the sound of pipes, but they were just as effective.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A Chinese communique:

Like Nicholas M. Schenck, his predecessor on the witness stand in Federal court and fellow-victim of the extortionate habits of Willie Bioff, Albert Warner, treasurer of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., "pondered" extensively before he paid up.
Pennsylvania appears to be having some bear trouble this year, but the State's Game Commission believes that this will be partially remedied by the open season set for the bruins this month.
The Soviet early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Nov. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- Travelers who left French Indo-China early in October said that the French Provincial Government under Rear Admiral Jean Decoux, Vichy High Commander for the Pacific, was in complete control of the region and that the Japanese in recent months had been living strictly within the limits of the Vichy treaty with Japan.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The proposed increase from 10 per cent to 25 per cent of the retail price in the excise tax on furs, as recommended by the House Ways and Means Committee drew protests today from officials of the National Federation of the Fur Industry, Inc., holding its annual convention here.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 5 -- Moscow announced last night that the entire east bank of the Dnieper, from the river's mouth to its confluence with the Sozh, 100 miles above Kiev, was in the hands of Russian troops, who had inflicted 2,700,000 casualties on the routed German armies since July 5.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Army's combat edition of The Stars and Stripes opposed today the suggestion that experienced American troops be given home leave, saying "it would be foolish to throw away all the battle experience picked up by our veteran troops at so bloody a cost."

The Children's Division of the Domestic Relations Court issued yesterday a report showing that the number of New York City children charged with juvenile delinquency in the first ten months of 1943 had risen by 1,452, as compared with the same period last year, and by 1,850 as against the ten-month period in 1941.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador to Soviet Russia, announced today that he and the other members of the American Embassy staff planned to give the greatest possible consideration immediately to the "assistance the United States can give the Soviet Union in the rehabilitation of devastated areas and the repairing of other war-caused dislocations."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- There they sat on the platform of a lecture room at Walter Reed Hospital. Most of them had legs or feet missing. One was minus a hand. Another, with a broken back, had his neck and spine stiffly braced.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- German diplomats and propagandists, jogged into action by British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's talk with Numan Menemencioglu, Turkish Foreign Minister, and by the Turkish President's forecast of "greater sacrifices" for his country, sought today by public statements and private hints to warn the Turks that they were being "used" by Britain and Russia.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- If Dmitri Shostakovich's Seventh symphony for obvious reasons became known as the "Leningrad Symphony," his eighth, which received its first performance last night, a few hours before Moscow officially announced the results of the Red Army's summer campaign, might, for equally good cause, become known as the "Military" Symphony.

The stock market plunged yesterday to the low levels of August, although there was no resumption of the heavy selling of the preceding day until late in the session. Resistance spots showed up in various sections of the list, but the higher priced issues suffered the worst inroads.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Facts concerning the refusal of President Roosevelt last Sept. 7 to transfer radio intelligence activities of the Federal Communications Commission to the War and Navy Departments were disclosed today before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- British women can now be drafted into hospitals, schools and institutions as cooks, maids and cleaning women, Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, told the House of Commons yesterday.
ALGIERS, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- American medical units are operating in Italy under enemy fire only three or four miles from the height of the fighting.

Net sales of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on July 31 set a new annual record at $32,174,475 and exceeded the $29,575,790 volume for the previous twelve months by $2,598,685, or 8.79 per cent, Michael Schaap, president, reported yesterday to stockholders in the annual statement of operations.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Judge William F. Smith in Federal Court, here, sentenced today fifty-six persons on charges of conspiracy to possess or transfer gasoline ration coupons illegally, or for possession of counterfeit gasoline ration coupons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The National War Labor Board, by a vote of 11 to 1, approved tonight the contract arranged between Secretary Ickes and the United Mine Workers of America, subject to clarification and resubmission of some details to the board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones, appearing today before the subcommittee of the Senate Military Affairs Committee in the hearing on termination of war contracts, contradicted the statement yesterday by Controller General Lindsay C. Warren that they had agreed on legislation to be submitted which would bring the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries under review by the Government Accounting Office.
Sales of loft buildings and houses by savings banks and of a tall showroom and office building by an insurance company formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Wendell Willkie declared today the New Deal in 1944 "will be completely washed up." He made his statement in a message to Lloyd B. Marsh, Passaic County clerk and campaign manager for Walter E. Edge, New Jersey's Republican Governor-elect.

Activity in the local markets for new investments this week was curtailed somewhat by the Election Day holiday, and offerings of bonds to the public were the smallest in five weeks. Only two issues of tax-exempt bonds, aggregating $4,650,000, reached the market, compared with $22,990,000 for three diversified flotations last week and $1,037,000 for a single offering of municipal bonds in this week a year ago.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 6 -- A broadcast of the German Trans-ocean News Service said today that at 9 o'clock Friday night Allied aircraft attacked Vatican City, causing considerable damage. Four large bombs fell within approximately a hundred yards of St. Peter's.
AS THE NEW YORK TIMES was so kind as to publicize the precarious financial condition of Greenwich House in June, I would be glad to have your readers know what has taken place during the summer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- That child of wartime government known as "day care of the children of working mothers" is still trying to hurdle obstacles.

John Clifford Folger, president of Folger, Nolan Co., Inc., of Washington, D.C., was elected president of the Investment Bankers Association at the closing session of the association's thirty-second annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

In a letter to THE TIMES, "Austrian protests against the "ignominious and shameless phrasing of the Moscow Declaration." This Austrian objects that Austria is reminded of her responsibilities "for participation in the war of Hitlerite Germany."

Even at the height of battle, the United States is "carrying on all the decencies as long as possible," Lieut. John Mason Brown, former drama critic now in the Navy, told women workers of the United Hospital campaign yesterday at the Hotel Pierre, gathered for the final Manhattan and Bronx report meeting of the women's division.

Despite substantial price reductions sales and billings of the Packard Motor Car Company for the first nine months of 1943 totaled $251,874,429, exceeding those of the corresponding period last year by $106,296,801, George T. Christopher, president, declared in his report of operations announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 5 -- The People's Army of Liberation headed by Gen. Josip Broz [Tito] administered a sharp defeat to the Germans around Kolasin and Matesevo in Montenegro, it was announced today in a communique broadcast by the Free Yugoslavia station.

ALGIERS, Nov. 5 -- With the German line snapped in two at Isernia and the retreating Nazis flooding some western coastal sectors in the path of the advancing Allies, both the Fifth and Eighth Armies in Italy drove ahead faster yesterday.
ALGIERS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The text of the message from General Eisenhower to American military and civil personnel in the Mediterranean today is:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Hiram W. Johnson, whose once-mighty voice was a factor in United States rejection of the League of Nations, held the attention again today of a silent, respectful Senate -- and his only plea was a prayer.

A new issue of $3,000,000 of Tacoma, Wash., light and power system revenue bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1943, and due serially each Jan. 1 and July 1 from 1944 to 1963, and callable in 1955, has been awarded at a price of 100.0086 for $135,000 as 4 per cent, $835,000 as 2s and $2,030,000 as 1 1/2s.

Retail trade here was quite active this week. Department stores are estimated to be showing a gain of about 8 to 9 per cent over the like week last year. The increase for specialty shops was put at a considerably higher figure. The feature was brisk consumer demand for women's apparel on election day.
LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- The Russian today midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
Yesterday's Japanese communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The board of directors of the Chrysler Corporation, at a meeting in Detroit yesterday, approved an agreement for a $250,000,000 Regulation VT credit to finance war contracts and for liquidation of inventories in the event of cancellations of contracts.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Nurses entering civil service have been placed at a disadvantage by the State through the formation of a lower-paying junior professional classification, the legislative committee reported to the House of Delegates of the New York State Nurses Association today.

KANHSIEN, China, Nov. 3 (delayed) -- Suddenly every one started racing helterskelter down the street and gendarmes started striking brazen air raid gongs. It was a nuisance and probably unnecessary as one wrinkled old crone muttered.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 5 -- Reports suggesting the possibility of a New York-Cairo direct commercial airline via the Azores have been received with considerable interest among Middle East commercial leaders who have been planning for a post-war business boom.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, and William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, conferred yesterday with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, on their differences in the "canned-music" row.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A demand that lend-lease be thrown into reverse following the war, in order to reduce to a minimum the cost of post-war reconversion to American taxpayers, was made by the Truman Committee in a report filed with the Senate today.

BUFFALO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration obtained today a temporary injunction restraining four milk distributors in the Dunkirk-Fredonia area from purchasing and selling milk in violation of OPA price regulations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Russia and Czechoslovakia have completed negotiations for a twenty-year defensive military alliance against Germany, and the Czech President, Dr. Benes, will go to Moscow the sign the treaty.

Some years ago the American Foundation for the Blind was approached by John D. Burger, who informed us that he was the head of various companies manufacturing smoking pipes, and that he thought these pipes would afford much pleasure to blind men who were smokers.

Letters received here from officials of the War Relocation Authority have praised the work of church groups in various parts of the country in the resettlement of Japanese-American evacuees, according to an announcement yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

A campaign designed to dramatize the importance of advertising as a post-war planning weapon will be inaugurated next week by Macfadden Publications, using a series of newspaper and trade journal advertisements. Copy points out that successful post-war re-employment of war workers and service personnel depends upon "buying power -- on a larger scale than ever before."

Today's events: Wanda Landowska, harpsichord and piano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Ruth Freeman, flute, and Polyna Stoska, soprano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Collegiate Chorale, Town Hall, 8:30; Zino Francescatti, violin, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; "La Traviata," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill told Harrow School students today that "the path of this war is hard and long, and no one would be so foolish as to try to fix some point at which it would end."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- A flat increase of at least 15 cents an hour for 900,000 steel workers will be the opening demand in the campaign of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for wage increases greater than those allowed by the "Little Steel" formula, it was learned tonight.

The success of the program for wartime care of children in Soviet Russia provides a lesson for American child welfare institutions that should not be ignored, Mrs. Rose Maurer, author and specialist on Russian family life, declared yesterday. All existing child-care institutions in Russia, including nurseries, play schools and children's consultation centers have been expanded to capacity, owing to war needs, and are being utilized by both working mothers and housewives, Mrs. Maurer said.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The War Department announced today the names of 159 soldiers listed as missing in action on four fighting fronts.

Joseph Curran, 37-year-old president of the National Maritime Union, once again had his draft classification changed yesterday from 1-A to 2-A -- and this time his deferment as an essential union leader, by order of Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of Selective Service, should finally and safely remove any possibility of his induction into the armed forces because he will reach his thirty-eighth birthday before this reclassification for six months expires.

The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren will preach tomorrw at 11 A.M. his final sermon as co-pastor at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street. The following Sunday Dr. Warren will preach his first sermon as the pastor-elect of the Second Presbyterian Church in Baltimore, to which he recently, accepted a call.

Being one of the ranking geniuses of the night clubs, Lou Walters has figured that what Broadway can use just now is a show of girls, tunes, more girls, costumes -- and girls. No doubt he is right. At all events, he and a group of associates put the theory to the test last evening by opening an edition of "Artists and Models" at the Broadway Theatre.

Second, third and fourth choices are likely to prove the determining factors in establishing the winners of last Tuesday's proportional representation election of City Councilmen in the four larger boroughs, unofficial tallies indicated last night when counting was suspended for the day.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5 (AP) -- When Princeton and Villanova meet on the gridiron tomorrow -- the first time since 1911 -- the Wildcats will be seeking their first victory after eight straight losses in the rivalry which began in 1901.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Buying of wheat futures attributed to cash interests which are estimated to have taken about 500,000 bushels out of the pit, presumably against flour and feed sales, resulted today in higher prices for grains on the Chicago Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Prices of hogs here dipped again today, the average falling the lowest level since midsummer. Receipts of 9,000 head were larger than expected and were supplemented by the 9,500 shipped to packers from outside loading points, For the twelve principal markets receipts of hogs to date this week were 470,900 head, compared with 426,100 last week and 301,500 a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Pennsylvania, still unbeaten in six games, but tied by Army, meets the Naval Academy team in the twenty-eighth game of their series on Franklin Field tomorrow before a crowd of 72,000. Every seat has been sold for several days.

Purchasing fresh fruit these days is a hunt-and-pick business, for most varieties are scarce and expensive. Consequently, in our menus for next week this department has placed a good deal of reliance on the processed varieties -- dried prunes, grapefruit and tomato juice.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Complete but unofficial reports on Tuesday's general election showed today that only two Democratic candidates for State office were able to win in the Republican tide which swept normally Democratic Kentucky.

Predictions of business expansion and the need for consumer goods in unprecedented quantities in the period immediately after the war were made yesterday at the Eastern annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Indications point to definite shortages of toilet goods before the Christmas holiday period is concluded, according to reports in the trade here yesterday. Manufacturers, having shipped by far the bulk of goods for holiday selling on an allocated basis, currently find themselves unable to take care of additional volume that retailers would like to place.

IF Henry Steele Commager's "Majority Rule and Minority Rights"* had been published during the great Supreme Court pack squabble at the beginning of Roosevelt's second administration, it would have caused innumerable academic fist fights. For it is the somewhat startling implication of this book that judicial review of Congressional acts is both wrong in theory and dangerous in practice.

Not in a good many years, perhaps never, has a football season arrived at the point where the Army-Notre Dame game reached the importance of today's clash at the Yankee Stadium, at which some 75,000 will sit in and which hundreds of thousands will follow over the air and through the newspapers.

Henrietta Buckmaster, author of "Let My People Go," published by Harpers, is chairman of a book forum and tea at the Young Women's Christian Association, 135 East Fifty-second Street, tomorrow at 4 P.M. Dr. Liston Pope, Professor of Social Ethics at Yale Divinity School and Dr. Warren Banner, research director of the National Urban League, will speak on Dr. Charles Johnson's book, "Patterns of Negro Segregation."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- After a public hearing, the Interstate Commerce Commission took under advisement today the question of requiring railroad securities to be sold under competitive bidding.

" The Iron Major" today starts a second week at the Globe. "The Battle of Russia" is slated as the next attraction at that theatre . . . . "Jeannie" today starts its ninth week at the Little Carnegie . . . . A revival of "The Devil Is an Empress," a French film starring the late Conrad Veidt and Francoise Rosay, is the week's attraction at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse . . . .

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- With a bitterly fought $5,000,000 appropriation for the Office of War Information's Overseas Branch retained by the slim margin of seven votes, a deficiency bill totaling $214,854,124 was passed today in the House without a roll-call and sent to the Senate.

" Armistice Sunday" and "World Order Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches of the New York area. In the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 4 P.M. a "Service of Prayer for God's Blessing upon the Officers and Men of the Merchant Navies of the United Nations" will be held.

Vast production and scientific development resulting from the war will lead to a new era of prosperity, provided there is no curtailment of free enterprise, Judge Thurman Arnold of the United States Court of Appeals declared yesterday in a lecture on phases of this subject, in the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Supreme Court Justice William H. Murray ruled today that the Railway Mail Association, composed of 22,000 railway postal clerks, was not bound by State laws against racial discrimination because, despite its affiliation with the American Federation of Labor since 1917, it was not a labor union but "a beneficial insurance society."

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Britain is entering the fifth year of war with the health of the nation in "extraordinarily good condition," said Sir Wilson Jameson, chief medical officer of the Ministry of Health today.

Mgr. Robert E. McCormick has been appointed Officialis of the Archdiocese of New York by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, it was announced yesterday at the Chancery Office, 477 Madison Avenue. The Officialis is the third highest office in the archdiocese.
A new quick method of eliminating convicted stock swindlers from the securities business in New York State was announced yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Austria is undergoing a blood bath, intensifying as German defeats mount, in which hundreds of anti-Nazis are being beheaded each month, reliable underground reports to Austrian Socialists said tonight.

Jan Kwapinski, Deputy Premier and Minister of Industry, Commerce and Shipping of the Polish Government in Exile at London, arrived here yesterday by trans-atlantic Clipper to head the Polish delegation at the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Conference that will begin Wednesday in Atlantic City, N.J.
MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- This is the story of two maps -- and of the bad tidings they bear for Germany and her satellites.
The comparative dimout that local followers of college football have endured this season will give way today to the glaring spotlight for the prize game of the year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The War Department made public today the names of 113 soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean and Southwest Pacific areas.

A picture in the paper shows the honorary night superintendent of the Central Park zoo at the head of a group of refugee youngsters watching the seals being fed. It is just coincidence that the picture of A1 Smith in retirement should appear so soon after an election in which the New Tammany once more showed up as the Old Tammany.
ALGIERS, Nov. 5 -- A communique:

It is ten years this month since the United States recognized Soviet Russia and twenty-six years since the Communists seized power in the so-called October Revolution. The mass of Americans wouldn't care to have a similar upheaval, with similar results, here. Nevertheless they have reason to be glad that our ally on the Eastern Front today is a people who work and fight magnificently and not the corrupt and inept government of the Romanoffs.

Resale price maintenance will be of "immense importance" to American business in the post-war era, John W. Scott, secretary of the Bissell Carpet Sweeper Company, said yesterday at the meeting of the American Fair Trade Council at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Though the city has established an excellent record in dealing with venereal disease, measured by American standards, the recent revelations of Health Commissioner Dr. Ernest Stebbins must have shocked parents. In the face of a general decline for nine months of the year, there has been an increase of over 90 per cent in primary and secondary syphilis in the 15-to-19 age group and an increase of 34 per cent in the 24-year group.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The cutting questions of Attorney General Eric Hallinan laid bare Alfred de Marigny's private life today before the Bahamas Supreme Court jury, which is trying him for the murder of Sir Harry Oakes, his rich father-in-law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Ruth Hussey, on loan from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will have the feminine lead in "Marine Raiders," the Pat O'Brien picture which goes into production at RKO next Thursday. Miss Hussey has com-completed an assignment at the studio in the Ginger Rogers picture, "Tender Comrade."

The New York Rangers will open their home season in the National Hockey League race tonight when they play the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. Although the Blue Shirts, in three outings, have yet to score a victory, or even get a tie, they have shown gradual improvement, and Coach Frank Boucher is hopeful that his team's appearance before the home folks will result in a triumph.

A thorough investigation of that part of the lend-lease program which would jeopardize home-front requirements in cotton thread by requiring American producers, after filling military orders, to supply all African and European needs because Great Britain, which formerly dominated those markets, has decided to cut off such exports in the future, was asked yesterday by Josef Pollack, chairman of the board of the Cotton Thread Institute.

While present demands for glass containers are keeping the industry running at full capacity and shortages exist in some types, the liquor industry's contemplated program for re-use of liquor bottles would not ease the glass bottle situation, J.H. Toulouse of the Owen-Illinois Glass Company, stated yesterday at the annual meeting of the Packaging Institute at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Military officials of the United States and Britian conferred here today on what to do with their Italian prisoners of war in view of the co-belligerency status of Italy. No decision has been reached yet.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 6 -- Presaging heavy naval and air battles to come, Japan is ruhsing both heavy and light cruisers and destroyers down from Truk to Rabaul in a frantic effort to halt the Allied drive up the Solomons, headquarters disclosed today.

Enough butadiene to produce one-seventh of the entire wartime requirement of synthetic rubber soon will be turned out at the Port Neches (Texas) plant, Herbert Henderson, chairman of the Neches Butane Products Company, formed by five oil companies with refineries in the region which will operate it, announced here yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 5 -- That seventy-three-year-old Juho K. Paasikivi, Finnish politician, diplomat and banker, has been asked by the Finnish Government to stand by for a trip to Moscow to talk peace with Soviet Russia is the information received by the Stockholm newspaper Social Demokraten today.

Plans for the immediate training in American colleges, universities and technical schools of a considerable number of persons from the occupied countries, to prepare them to work in specific fields of reconstruction and rehabilitation in their own lands, have been approved by educational leaders of the United States and representatives of foreign nations, it was revealed yesterday.

Trading in cotton futures was considerably less active yesterday than in the last few sessions as traders held to the sidelines pending a better appraisal of war developments and a clarification of the Administration's price program.

The two twenty-family apartment houses at 728 East 156th Street and 229 East 139th Street, the Bronx, have been sold by the Damon Realty Corporation, represented by Samuel K. Beier, attorney, to the Silpow Realty Corporation, represented by Arthur Friedland.

Nobody who knows anything of Europe or of history imagines that the problems of that continent, much less its destiny, can be settled by outside Powers. It is true that the primacy of Europe in the world has been broken by two ruinous wars. It may be that we are witnessing the last attempt of a European state to dominate Europe.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON THE BURMA BORDER, Nov. 1 (Delayed) -- Pushing through weak Japanese opposition, Chinese troops have advanced a few miles down from the Naga and Patkai hills on the Assam-Burma border and have occupied the upper Hukawng valley a hundred miles into Burma.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The country will need a net gain of 85,000 coal miners by next March to meet the Solid Fuels Administration's 1944 coal production of 686,000,000 tons, War Manpower Commission officials said today.

ARMY vs. Notre Dame -- This is no time for hesitancy or timidity. Without even a chance to get warmed up to the task, a guesser has this struggle dumped immediately into his lap. A most careful analysis reveals that both teams use the T formation. So they are all even on that score. The Irish have speed-boy Creighton Miller and the Kaydets have fleet Glenn Davis. Even again.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York, in response to a suggestion that he enter his name for President in this State's Presidential primary in May, has informed party leaders that he is not a candidate.

NAPLES, Nov. 5 -- Mild shouts of "Down with the King" and "Viva la Republica" were heard today for the first time in Italy since the march on Rome in 1922. One cannot say that there was a great rage or enthusiasm involved, but those shouts were significant of the new Italy in which freedom of speech has returned.

The tenth anniversary of diplomatic relations between the United States and Soviet Russia will be celebrated with a three-day congress beginning today at the Hotel New Yorker and closing Monday night with a mass meeting at Madison Square Garden.

William Ziegler Jr.'s homebred Wait a Bit, rather like time and tide, waited for no horse in yesterday's Taranto Handicap at Jamaica, with the result that the son of Espino and Hi Nelli scored by three lengths.

Sitting in a public relations office yesterday morning an Army nurse recalled with a caress in her voice the "beautiful moon" that looked down as her lifeboat rolled in the Mediterranean Sea last December.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Lucky indeed may be the families in Eastern States who eat turkey this Thanksgiving and Christmas.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 5 -- Jean Politis, long a leading figure in the Greek Foreign Office, former Minister to Berlin, today gave the press a resume of conditions and opinions at present current in Greece.

Several hundred senior Girl Scouts will convene today at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, to exchange ideas about how they can help most in the war program and to hear speakers tell what teen-age girls in other countries are doing.
The Soviet early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- There was little activity today on the stock markets here, and general tone was dull.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Positive evidence comes from Germany that Nazi leaders are not slackening in the war effort despite signs of a growing spirit of defeatism and troubles within Austria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Senate, by a record vote of 85 to 5 with announced positions of absentees carrying the margin to 90 to 6 to represent its entire membership, declared late today for post-war collaboration to secure and maintain peace for the world and for the establishment of a general international organization that might become a new League of Nations.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A United States Tenth Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Another nurse heroine and another medical miracle were added to the wartime list when a soldier suffering from a brain tumor was brought from India to Atlanta, Ga., where he underwent a successful operation.

The Chungking radio said yesterday that a Chinese-American air wing, with Chinese and American pilots fighting side by side as a single force, had been organized in China, reportedly under the command of Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, and was ready to "go eastward."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- Republican election victories Tuesday reflect a rising tide of popular resentment against the New Deal, which is being swelled by millions of dissident Democrats, Joseph W. Martin, House Republican leader, said tonight.

At the same time that the City Markets Department reported considerable improvement in meat supplies and a glut of poultry selling below ceiling, but a slight drop in butter supplies, the War Food Administration announced yesterday that on Monday it was increasing from 45 to 50 per cent the amount of meat Federally inspected slaughterers will be required to set aside for the armed forces.

WEST ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Mrs. Mary Louise Gaylord, who for twenty years before the Communist revolution assisted her husband, the late Dr. Franklin A. Gaylord, in establishing a Y.M.C.A. movement in Russia, died at Holy Name Hospital here this morning of burns suffered yesterday when her clothing became ignited by contact with an electric heater in her home at 47 Englewood Avenue.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- The Japanese are using 30,000 troops in their new offensive in Central China, which appears aimed at removing the Chinese threat to the great Yangtze River base of Hankow, a Chinese military spokesman said today.

When Viscount Wavell became Viceroy of India last month he found himself fighting an old enemy of the Indian people -- famine. The food situation is bad in Bombay and in Madras and other areas, but it seems to be worst in Bengal. In the city of Calcutta alone 8,000 persons are reported dead in two months of hunger or hunger-connected diseases.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- The Westchester Professional Golfers Association concluded its second wartime season of competition with a pro-amateur tournament at the Hudson River Country Club today. Alex Watson, home club pro, won all the honors.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has agreed to pay $10,000 for the first American performance rights to Dimitri Shostakovich's new Eighth Symphony, which had its world premiere in Moscow on Thursday, it was learned last night.
Josephine I. Kevlin, Mrs. Cecelia Ronan, in 818 Lexington Ave; Mrs. Paul Haskell, Ward G. Fatherly Jr., in 533 E 82d St; Ann Hagan, Margaret Wing, in 62 East End Ave -- Webb Knapp, brokers.

Leonard Marcus, 15-year-old Bronx high school boy accused of strangling his 75-year-old step-grandmother, Mrs. Jennie Flicker, on Wednesday, re-enacted the crime last night in the office of Sylvester Ryan, chief assistant district attorney, in the Bronx County Courthouse after having been brought back from Wayne, Pa., where he was captured.

MORMUGAO, Portuguese India, Oct. 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- Dozens of Army nurses lest behind in the Philippines after the Japanese occupation have been administering to the ills of interned American civilians, repatriates who arrived here aboard the exchange liner Gripsholm said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that he still thought it desirable that he should confer with Premier Joseph Stalin despite the success of the Foreign Ministers conference at Moscow, which led some to believe that the long-discussed meeting between the two leaders and Prime Minister Churchill might no longer be regarded as necessary.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 -- George D. Widener's Stefanita strengthened her claim to the filly and mare championship when she scored an easy length victory over B.S. Campbell's Barbara Childs in the mile and a sixteenth Lady Baltimore Handicap at Pimlico today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 5 -- T.V. Miller, general manager of the British-owned Shell Oil Company, which held vast properties in Mexico, was quoted in yesterday's Prensa as saying that an agreement between the Mexican and British Governments similar to the one concluded with Washington was not satisfactory because the latter was "only a settlement dictated by political and not economic reasons."

Five Latin-American newspaper men yesterday inspected the Pan American Airways facilities at the Marine Terminal, La Guardia Field, Queens, and declared that during their six weeks' tour of the United States they had been greatly impressed with this country's war work and its ability to win the war.

Tami Mauriello made a gallant uphill fight to defeat Lee Savold of Des Moines in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Outpunched in the first five rounds, and even sent to the canvas in the second, the Bronx heavyweight staged a spurt from the sixth through the tenth to win convincingly.

A survey conducted by President Walters of the University of Cincinnati reveals that while the number of men students in our colleges and universities has dropped considerably the enrollment of women ham increased. Freshmen classes of girls are large in nearly all institutions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Early action by the Government to curb the heavy importations of Cuban gin, and thereby force diversion of molasses into the production of industrial alcohol, was predicted tonight by officials of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Roosevelt announced today the successful conclusion of a five-day British and American military conference with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on plans for a continental offensive against Japan. It means bad news for the Japanese, he said.

ALGIERS, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- Andre Philip, Commissioner of the Interier and of Underground Resistance, predicted that the Germans might pull out of France before an Allied invasion, and disclosed that if they did so a sixteen-man underground committee was prepared to take charge.

Japanese propagandists punctuated their campaign of belittling the Moscow conference yesterday with an announcement that the Axis, too, would have its first three-way meeting in Tokyo on Nov. 15 under the auspices of the "Japan-Germany-Italy Friendship Society."

Dave Wolper, theatrical attorney and proprietor of the Hurricane Club, discloses that he and Harry Delmar, general production manager for USO-Camp Shows, Inc., will sponsor "Ankles Away," the Guy Bolton-Eddie Davis musical comedy which once was on the producing schedule of Nat Karson.

ALGIERS, Nov. 5 -- Going much farther than Gen. Charles de Gaulle had in Wednesday's speechh to the Provisional Consultative Assembly, the French Committee of National Liberation in a promised statement concerning the results of the Moscow conference served notice flatly today that France would not consider herself bound by any decisions concerning Germany in which she had not participated.

After a survey and canvass of members of the Tammany executive committee had shown that those opposed to the continuance of Michael J. Kennedy as leader at present lacked the majority needed to oust him or the two-thirds necessary to call a meeting of the committee without action by its chairman, an appeal was made yesterday to Senator Robert F. Wagner to take the leadership in reorganization of the Democratic party in New York County.

Window designers for all Fifth Avenue shops between Thirty-fourth and Fifty-ninth Street will finish special displays today for the opening tomorrow afternoon of the National War Fund Fifth Avenue Window Pageant, Mrs. Sara Pennoyer, vice president of Bonwit Teller and chairman of the pageant committee, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Mrs. Dorothy Roosevelt, specialist on women's problems in war industries for WPB in the Detroit area, and the only woman holding such a title in the country, today urged a prepared food for carry-out service for women war workers such as has been successfully carried on by a Detroit food company in twenty-one stores of that city.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University issued a statement yesterday regarding the recent granting of a charter to American Youth for Democracy, successor to the Young Communists League, by the Student Council of the Washington Square College of the University.

The Koetser Galleries, long at 65 East Fifty-seventh Street, have leased a large store at 15 East Fifty-seventh Street and will open there about Nov. 15. The new lease was made through the James F. Durnell Company and Wm. A. White Sons.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Newspaper maps of the front today show the Red Army thirteen and twotenths miles southeast of Vitebsk, in the suburbs of Gomel, and fifteen miles to the north of Kiev and Krivoi Rog.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Germans have filed their answer to Thursday's Moscow claims of casualties inflicted upon them in the Russians' successful summer and autumn offensives. The Germans announced the Russians had lost 3,000,000 men in dead, wounded and prisoners, in contrast to the 2,700,000 German casualties announced by the Russians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Despite losses occasioned by the coal strike, new production records were broken last month through the steel industry efforts to reach steel output goals set up by the War Production Board's steel division, J.T. Whiting, director of the division, said today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- A communique:

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 6 -- Soviet forces swarmed down from the north into the northern and western suburbs of Kiev to outflank that historic cathedral city and surround it on three sides in a major new Russian drive that broke through two German defense lines, Moscow announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Plans whereby the present and future output of non-military radio receiving tubes would be made available from manufacturers to distributors on an equitable basis and thus receive wider distribution among owners of household radio sets for maintenance and repair were discussed by the Electronics Distributors Industry Advisory Committee meeting in Washington yesterday.

Mrs. Epstein's letter, published Oct. 25, is not really an answer to my letter, published Oct. 15, I think, since it contains no reference to my principal point. Mrs. Epstein had said, in her letter published Oct. 7: "Social security reserves * * * are Treasury obligations for payment in the future.

Anther step toward supplying members of the armed forces with fishing tackle will be taken today through the cooperation of the railroads. Starting this morning it will be possible for anglers who wish to contribute discarded tackle for reconditioning before it is shipped overseas to servicemen to deposit it either at the Grand Central Terrain I or the Pennsylvania Station in New York.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 5 -- Germany's resources for carrying on the war will be completely exhausted one year from now, says a traveler, evidently a prominent Swedish engineer, in the first installment of his appreciations of the Reich situation in the current issue of the Stockholm weekly pictorial, Se.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 6 -- It the heaviest American daylight attack on the Reich, close to 500 Flying Fortresses and Liberators flew through an unprecedented barrage of Nazi anti-aircraft fire yesterday to blow the heart out of the grea oil manufacturing center of Gelsen kirchen in the Ruhr and shatter the railroad yards at Muenster to the northeast.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Saturday, Nov. 6 -- The only chance the Japanese have to make a real attempt to knock the marines off Bougainville Island, northernmost of the Solomons, is through a naval effort of considerable size.

The testimony Harry Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., had given two years ago at the trial of Willie Bioff and George E. Browne for extortion, was repeated yesterday in Federal court at the trial of eight men accused of having conspired with Browne and Bioff.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- A newspaper came to life tonight as characters stepped from the pages and performed, via television, before about fifty editors and publishers.

One of the most important pronouncements of the Moscow Conference is the declaration in which the United States, Great Britain and Russia serve notice that "they regard the annexation imposed on Austria by Germany on March 15, 1938, as null and void," and that "they wish to see re-established a free and independent Austria."

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 5 -- One of the major paradoxes of a scrambled football season will take place here this afternoon, when a former Columbia ace leads a heavily favored Dartmouth eleven against his one-time mates. Don Kasprzak, who last year performed for the Lions, was transferred to Hanover in the Naval V-12 unit and has been the passing mainstay of the powerful 1943 Indian eleven.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- John Da Silva Purvis, 43 years old, a Portuguese, was convicted in Federal Court here tonight of violation of the espionage act, trading with the enemy and sending a letter abroad without submitting it to censorship.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill announced tonight the appointment of Lieut. Gen. Adrian Carton de Wiart as his special military representative to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Lieut. Gen. Sir Herbert Lumsden as representative to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Roosevelt named a five-man committee of War Labor Board members today to investigate the cost of living and to report within sixty days. This move, coinciding with the decision of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to scrap the "Little Steel" formula, was interpreted as "a delaying action," which insured retention of that wage program for at least two months.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 -- In 1843 the then second largest telescope in the world was placed in operation in the Cincinnati Observatory, whose founder, Ormsby MacKnight Mitchel, then said:
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Georgia defeated a sturdy but out-classed Presbyterian College football team, 40 to 12, tonight for the second time this season before a homecoming crowd of 4,000.

Hundreds of office workers at Rockefeller Center were interested spectators yesterday as two fighter planes, including the P-47 Thunderbolt, heaviest single-engined fighter in the world, and sections of bombers in current action were installed in the New York Museum of Science and Industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- The Army, with tanks and machine guns, today patrolled the Tule Lake segregation center, home of 15,000 disloyal Japanese aliens and citizens, after an attack on an internal security guard and a threatened move by several hundred Japanese evacuees to take physical control of the center had caused civilian officials to telephone for military assistance.

When there is a rain of letters on one subject in The Times of London you feel that in the midst of war the old habit of peace continues. Somebody writes a letter to show that conventional English spelling is but an inheritance from the days when ability to read and write distinguished the man of learning from the common run of folk.

Miklos Schwalb, Hungarian pianist, gave his third Town Hall recital last night before a large and responsive gathering. The program was devoted entirely to works by Liszt and Debussy. Liszt was represented by the sonata in B minor, the "Sposalizio" and three of the "Paganini Etudes," while the compositions of Debussy performed comprised the "Suite Bergamasque," "Masques" and four of the preludes.

Despite a plea at its luncheon meeting by Chester Bowles, Office of Price Administration head, that Government subsidies "properly controlled" are the only insurance against impending inflation, members of the Grocery Manufacturers Association, at the closing session of their thirty-fifth annual conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, formally resolved that the subsidy program is "fundamentally unsound."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Tom de Lorenzo, labor union leader at the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, offered today to barter his personal no-strike pledge in return for assurance that Congress will protect labor's rights and guarantee that prices will be tied to wages.

An exhibition of dehydrated foods, said to be the most complete collection in the United States, and showing a continuous development in dehydrating processes since the beginning of World War I, was opened to the public yesterday afternoon at the New York City Food and Nutrition Program's headquarters, 45 Lafayette Street.
Sale of a New York Curb Exchange seat for $6,800 was reported yesterday. The previous sale, at $7,000, was on Oct. 26. The present market price is $6,700 bid, $9,000 asked.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuter) -- Royal Air Force Acting Flight Sgt. Arthur Lewis Aaron, 21, was post-humously awarded the Victoria Cross, it was announced today. "He set an example of devotion to duty which has seldom been equalled and never surpassed," the citation said.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 5 -- Now that Soviet troops in the lower Dnieper region are almost within a hundred miles of the Bessarabian frontier as the crow flies and the fate of the Crimea seems sealed with approximately five enemy divisions left there to bar the use of airfields and Sevastopol harbor, the strategical picture of the Balkan Peninsula is subject to a re-examination.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 5 -- German newspapers today emphasized reports of maltreatment of German prisoners in British camps to increase hatred against the British and take the Germans' minds off armistice week.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Franklin and Marshall's Diplomats nominated themselves as the East's only undefeated and untied football team today by shading Swarthmore, 7 -- 6.

" WHAT makes a clock go?" "Why does electricity light up a room when a switch is turned?" "How does sound come over the radio?" "How do anti-aircraft guns work?" These are a few of the questions which alert, curious-minded children ask, and these questions and many others are answered in simple, satisfying fashion in Miss Britton's book.

Arthur Henry Truxes Jr., 20-year-old yearling cadet from West Point, became this year's top man in the heptagonal cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday when he led the harriers of five colleges across the finish line of the five-mile course. iris time was 27:45.6 and his margin nearly 200 yards over his closest I competitor, Don Burnham of Dartmouth, who was rated the favorite.

Despite the revolutionary currents in Italy today, democracy will be reborn there and the Roman Catholic Church will enjoy a better future there than in "the whole past from the Risorgimento to our day," Don Luigi Sturzo, exiled leader of the Italian Popular party, predicts in an article in the current issue of The Review of Politics, a quarterly published by the University of Notre Dame.

CHESTER. Pa., Nov. 6 -- Victor Andreoli, convicted killer who escaped from the Eastern Penitentiary twelve days ago, was shot to death in a crowded diner today by a State policeman, his boast that he "would never be taken alive" fulfilled.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 6 -- Resorting mostly to ground plays and with plenty of power behind their drives, the Mountaineers of West Virginia crushed Lehigh University in Taylor Stadium today; 53 to 6. The game was the home debut for the Engineers.
Allied agreements signed at the conference of Foreign ministers in Moscow were hailed last week as the greatest single victory of World War II.

sWORDFISHING is a new experience for Napoleon Bonaparte, the half-caste Australian detective- The opportunity to try his hand at this fascinating sport comes when he is sent to investigate the disappearance of the fishing launch Do-me, last seen heading for Swordfish Reef off the town of Bermagui carrying its normal crew of two men and a sportsman named Ericson.
I should like to take exception to certain statements contained in the poignant and moving article entitled "Europe's Children: A Peace Problem."
The Moscow pact was hailed by rabbis here in sermons yesterday as an assurance of a just and enduring peace after the war is won.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6 -- Argentina's keen desire to build up commercial contacts with Chile was confirmed today with the publication of an interview with the Argentine Foreign Minister, Gen. Alberto Gilbert, by a correspondent of the Chilean paper La Hora.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Roosevelt directed today that all contracts with the Government must contain anti-race-discrimination clauses, thus overruling an opinion by Controller General Lindsay C. Warren that the requirement was "directive" rather than "mandatory."

GRATE NEWS. Thirty thousand cast iron grates, for use in frosty living rooms this winter, have been provided for by the WPB. A recent order released sufficient metal for their manufacture and a model was designed to provide a maximum of heating efficiency with a minimum of metal.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Harvard scored its second victory of the season over Camp Edwards at the stadium today, clearly outplaying the soldiers for a 14-7 score.

The first week of November, 1943, seems certain to be long remembered in history for two great developments in the foreign policy of the United States. It witnessed the conclusion at Moscow of far-reaching agreements which were based fundamentally on an American formula.

The fifty-first annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers will open at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Thursday morning. Four sessions will be held before the annual dinner on Friday. The society is also celebrating its fiftieth anniversary with this meeting.

Penicillin is obtained from a natural common mold which grows on oranges and bread in about ten days in flasks and three to five days in large tanks. Currently about twenty drug manufacturers are trying to increase production and reduce the time required.

ALGIERS, Nov. 6 -- It was on a Saturday night like this, almost a year ago, that the news of the North African invasion reached New York. Since then, Americans have followed the progress of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's forces through Tunisia and across to Sicily and Italy.

A SAFE distance from the metallic clink of the Broadway wickets, the thoughtful folks of the National Board of Review assembled recently at the Hotel Pennsylvania for their annual conclave. As usual, there were speeches, this time upon the central theme of "Movie Trends Produced by the War."

Gaining its first victory in the thirty-eight-year-old series since 1936, Brooklyn Prep's football team capitalized on breaks to beat its Brooklyn foe, Poly Prep, 13 to 0, at Boys High Field yesterday morning. It was the first success in six starts this season for Brooklyn Prep.

The day after election an article by James A. Hagerty appeared in THE TIMES. Mr. Hagerty states: "This election will indicate to the nation that the Roosevelt's Administration's handling of the problems on the home front has not won the approval of a majority of yesterday's voters in the President's home State."

IF Harry Harrison Kroll had invented John Murrell, it would be easy to say that such a character is too cold-blooded and unscrupulous to seem a real person. But he was a real person, born around 1800, who early took to crime and throve on it mightily.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- The State Commission investigating damage to life and property inflicted by the German Occupation Army has published a detailed report on its finds in Smolensk and the surrounding region. It has established that more than 135,000 persons, most of them from 20 to 40 years of age, but including many old persons and children, were killed by the enemy by execution, starvation, neglect or poisoning.

A largely subscribed theatre party of the near future is that for the performance of "Othello" for the night of Nov. 16 at the Shubert Theatre. Proceeds will aid the maintenance of the Art Workshop of the Rivington Neighborhood Association, a center where evening classes in the creative arts are offered to young working men and women.

Cordell Hull returns from the Moscow Conference acclaimed as a world statesman. His steady rise from the Montevideo, Buenos Aires and Lima conferences to full recognition throughout the Western Hemisphere has now assuredly been confirmed by global recognition.

To create actual conditions of the business world in the classroom and to effect a working relationship between public education and private enterprise, City College, with the aid of New York concerns and executives, has established a merchandising laboratory at its School of Business and Civic Administration, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Noble Wright, president.

Educators generally are whole-heartedly behind the program for post-war education of veterans proposed by President Roosevelt in his recent message to Congress. Colleges and universities throughout the country have agreed that the returning soldiers should be aided in gaining an education, and are ready to help put the plan into operation.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- In the last three decades the United States, Great Britain and Russia among them have signed more than fifty international agreements, many of which were preceded by conferences, most of which proclaimed everlasting collaboration and international justice, and all of which failed to prevent the catastrophe of the present war.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The University of Wisconsin Board of Regents referred to its executive committee today a recommendation for the appointment of Professor Walter W. Wilcox of Ames, Va., to the university's agricultural economics faculty.

WITHIN ten days, perhaps even in less time than that, Leon Enken, co-owner of Leon Eddie's, hopes definitely to know whether he and his partner, Eddie Davis, will be able to open a Southern counterpart of their West Fifty-second Street establishment around mid-December.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- A communique:

AT SEA OFF THE ALEUTIANS, July 15 -- The mills of the gods seem to grind painfully slow at times, but it was a refreshing reaffirmation of the truth that eventually they mill out the right answer to hear over the wardroom radio at luncheon that Rear Admiral Charles E. Rosendahl at long last had been awarded the Navy Cross.

The American Council on Public Affairs publishes today "Czechoslovakia Fights Back," a record of Czechoslovakia under German rule, since the establishment of the Protectorate March 15, 1939. Subtitled "A Document of the Czechoslovak Ministry of Foreign Affairs," the volume has an introduction by Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of the Czechoslovak Government in exile.

ON Nov. 1, 1942, the final contracts were consummated with private companies which, up to that time, had been operating virtually all of the short-wave transmitters in this country. On that day they formally leased their facilities to the Government, to be coordinated into an air weapon of war, to be directed by the Office of War Information and -- in its good-will broadcasting to South America -- by the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Leaders of labor, management and agriculture pledged themselves for the first time today to a program which the National Labor-Management Policy Committee believes will avert the necessity for a National Service Act.

THE gardener who has enjoyed snipping a few herbs as needed for cooking during the summer will welcome any means of enjoying their flavor during the winter months. Some herbs have probably been dried, and others can be potted up and brought indoors for fresh material.

The automobile industry is expected by the public to be the leading industry in keeping up employment after the war, according to a survey taken recently by the Psychological Corporation and made public yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

INDICATIONS that Hollywood intends the screen to play a big part in helping to shed light on the problems of peacemaking and readjustment after the war are becoming increasingly evident. This development is manifest not only concretely in the preparation at major studios of subjects such as Darryl Zanuck's "Wilson" and "One World" but abstractly in the manner in which some stories, now being prepared for filming, deal with the enemy.
HANS NATONEK was formerly an author and journalist in Germany and is one of the writers saved from the Gestapo by the efforts of the Emergency Rescue Committee and the President's Advisory Committee.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Gov. Earl Warren informed a candidates' committee of the California Republican Assembly today that he was not a candidate for either position on the national ticket" in 1944.
Semper Fidelis is their motto. To prove its truth they have reddened the seas and stained with their blood the beaches and jungles and ice-scabbed mountain fronts of half the world.

Cashmere sweaters at popular prices are being promised for the post-war era by American textile men, who, it was learned last week, are awaiting only the release of vital metals to acquire sufficient machinery for processing this rare imported goat fiber on a mass-production basis.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Navy's football team came back from the defeat at the hands of Notre Dame to victory over Pennsylvania at Franklin Field today, 24 to 7.

WHEN Joan Raleigh Stevenson issues invitations for a small dinner party she knows full well that it is not going to be a pleasant affair. What she does not know is that one of the guests is to be murdered and that the hostess is to be the chief suspect.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 6 -- In a symposium on "Dwarf Stars and Planet-Like Companions" the American Astronomical Society, meeting here to celebrate the centennial of the Cincinnati Observatory, was told today that celestial bodies of small size and mass, even as small as the planet Jupiter, might play an important role in the evolution and structure of the universe.

I have just read the article on monopoly by Wendell Berge, Assistant United States Attorney General, in the Sunday Magazine. May I say that if the public is a victim of monopoly I am one of the sufferers and not a beneficiary.

One-third of the total labor force of Belgium, 600,000 men, has been deported to Germany since the occupation, Jef L. Rens, general secretary of the Belgian Government's commission for post-war reconstruction, said yesterday when he arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a trans-Atlantic clipper.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Soviet forces captured Kiev today in a lightning blow that drove the Germans from the Ukrainian capital that they had held since September, 1941, and swept northwest and southwest of the city in swift thrusts that threatened the routed Nazi forces with annihilation.

WE have had recently two little festivals of music of United Nations; a third is in progress. The first was devoted to the chamber music of France; then came a more ambitious effort lasting eight days and given up to Russia; the last introduces composers of Czechoslovakia.

A FAMOUS dairy company puts it this way: Imagine a river -- a great white river. Say it's forty feet across, two and a half feet deep and long enough to stretch 4,000 miles, which is the length of the Nile or as far as from Hudson Bay to the tropics.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Malcolm Bryan, first vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, predicted here today that the national debt would reach a total of $250,000,000,000 as a result of wartime expenditures, but asserted that the country might remain healthy finacially "from a business view" of national assets and liabilities.

When Bernhardt Berntsen, ironworker, leaves his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn for work each weekday morning about 6 o'clock, he takes not only his lunch, as his fellow-workers do, but a copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES and a black grease crayon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Charles H. Buford, vice president of the Association of American Railroads, told the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today that the chief needs of the railroads were more steel rail and manpower. He blamed the increase in train de railments on an insufficient supply of steel rail.

ORANGE, Tex., Nov. 6 (AP) -- James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, said today that the next joint announcement by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill on anti-submarine activities would show "a most extraordinary record of success."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- If Congress refuses to sanction further subsidies to keep retail prices from rising, American housewives will soon be paying considerably more for some important food products, Chester Bowles, Federal Price Administrator, told a press conference today.

A HIGHLY pertinent question is advantageously posed by Samuel Goldwyn's production "The North Star," which opened here last week. This is the film which Mr. Goldwyn has been clutching to his heart for several months, his self-avowed obeisance to the courage of Russia in this war.

THE Horticultural Society of New York will hold its thirty-sixth annual autumn exhibition at the club headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue, on Nov. 10, 11 and 12. Chrysanthemum classes will be featured, and roses, carnations, orchids, vegetables and flower arrangements will be included.

ROTHMAN'S book is directed at the amateur woodworker, a personage of a wide assortment of tastes and of prior knowledge. The author of such a book must face a perplexing problem in judging how much may be assumed and how much must be explained in detail.

DAVID O. SELZNICK'S first production in four years, "Since You Went Away," may yet turn out to be another "Gone With the Wind" in length, if not in Technicolor. The word is that the producer has four reels of the new venture finished, but still regards the script as only about a third of the way toward completion.

Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick's enlightening remark that not less but perhaps even more nationalism is displayed by Italian Leftists than by Italian Rightists points to the fact that a reasonable readjustment of Europe's interior frontiers cannot be expected of those Europeans who today, as Hitler's opponents, appear as friends of this country.

The stock market sagged further yesterday although evidence of resistance again appeared in scattered instances. As on Friday, the last few minutes of trading witnessed some resumption of the liquidation, but the worst that the list showed at the close was an irregularly lower movement.

WHEN Vice President Henry Wallace and Secretary Jesse Jones exploded last May into one of the most picturesque exhibitions of temperament Washington had seen and an aroused President Roosevelt hurled Jovian thunderbolts at them, the accompanying lightning flashes threw into high relief the handsome features of an agreeable and able men from Wisconsin named Leo Thomas Crowley.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 6 -- Purdue gained its fifth straight victory in the Big Ten today, scoring a touchdown in the last forty seconds to beat Minnesota, 14 to 7, before 43,000 homecoming fans. The Boilermakers struck with startling suddenness when it seemed the game would end in a 7-7 tie.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Virginia scored in every period today to defeat Maryland, 39 -- 0, in the twentieth game of a 45-year-old series before a crowd of 4,000.

FEW books about Whitman are dull, and this one is to a high degree interesting and challenging. I find it also irritating. It is the work of an old friend of mine, who knows that my admiration for Walt is even more militant than some of his prejudices.
ALGIERS, Nov. 6 -- The French Committee of National Liberation met again this morning but added nothing to its formal position regarding the recent inter-Allied developments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Asserting that "The 'New Deal' is through," Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, called upon his party today to "draft" General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, as its candidate for President.

THE public has received great benefit from many excellent orchestral programs, with great conductors at the head of some of the most famous musical institutions in the land, broadcast by the various radio organizations, sometimes on "sustaining" hours, sometimes at the hand of sponsoring corporations.

Aggressive selling pressure me indifferent trade support yesterday throughout the short session on the New York Cotton Exchange and closing prices of active old contracts were at the day's low marks, showing net losses of 13 to 16 points, or 65 to 80 cents a bale.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, scoring ten touchdowns, swamped Brooklyn College's outmanned football team, 68 -- 0, before a crowd of 2,000 today.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (Canadian Press) -- A powerful professional eleven representing the Royal Air Force defeated Scotland by 2 -- 1 today at Glasgow's Hampden Park in the feature match of Britain's weekly soccer program.

AMONG the diverse exhibitions in the heaviest week of the season thus far, two of the newly opened shows which fell to my lot are made up of carefully selected work which has definitely stood the test of time. Perhaps it is well to begin with these.

The Tokyo radio broadcast claims yesterday of sweeping naval victories in the six-day period from Oct. 31 to Nov. 5, during which the Japanese said combined sea and air operations sank a large and a medium aircraft carrier and about fifty other Allied vessels in the South Pacific.

EVEN though the liberation of Italy is not completed, Edward Johnson of the Metropolitan Opera Association is beginning to think of some way to celebrate the happy event. He is considering an extensive Verdi festival for the season of 1944-45.

THERE are books -- not enough of them even yet -- that, of themselves, are ample payment to offset man's long struggle upward from the slime. No matter when they "occur," they have all one feature in common -- they are civilized.

DR. MAX THOREK is one of Chicago's (and, one gathers, the nation's) leading surgeons. His autobiography was written with an eye to the guidance of younger colleagues. But he is, in these pages, first a warm and likable human being, speaking straightforwardly and without condescension to his fellow-human beings, most of whom are, of course, not doctors -- writing of the problems and hopes, experiences and achievements of forty years of busy medical practice.

ONCE it was the Hammerstein Theatre, which Arthur Hammerstein built in memory of his father, the great Oscar, but now it is CBS Radio Theatre No. 3, at Broadway and Fifty-third Street, and on Saturday nights it is another kind of shrine.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON THE BURMA BORDER, Nov. 2 (Delayed) -- In the jungle-cloaked mountain mass east of here known as the Naga Hills different peoples with different ways of waging war are being brought together in a remarkable demonstration of cooperation against the Japanese enemy.

AS though to start off the new month in a somewhat better humor, Mary Elizabeth Sherwood last Monday chased the ghosts and the bats from the New Amsterdam Roof and installed in their places a revival of "The Petrified Forest," by an unrelated Sherwood, Robert E.

The Port of New York is well equipped to handle all types of cargo and transferring New York freight to southern ports would be a needless waste of freight cars, according to a report by the Committee on the Harbor and Shipping of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

THE Wiggins family who lived in a log house on the Minnesota prairie in pioneer days was a family that, singly and collectively, had an instinct for getting into trouble. They were a topsy-turvy family; they freely admitted it, but they took their accidents and misfortunes in good part.

ADMIRAL HALSEY'S ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Saturday, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- United States marines have cleaned up Japanese opposition on Torokina and Puruata Islands off their Empress Augusta Bay beachhead on Bougainville Island's west coast, while forces on Bougainville are pushing the enemy eastward and down the coast, a headquarters spokesman said today.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Air Marshal Sir Arthur T. Harris promised the British people tonight that Allied air power would shatter all important war centers in Germany, of which he said there were ninety, and smash the U-boat campaign.

Capitalizing on a first-quarter break for a touchdown and adding another six-pointer in the last session, the Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School football team remained unbeaten and untied yesterday, turning back St. John's Prep, 12 to 0, at Boys High Field, Brooklyn. It was the fifth triumph for Hayes.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- War shadows, in the form of dim-out and blackout regulations, vanished from the Florida resort scene last week. Store windows, hotel and theatre marquees and the bright lights of night clubs, dimmed since last spring, went back to pre-war status as the regulations were lifted.

Attempts to teach Basic English to native peoples of Hawaii and the Philippines have failed because they did not understand the English they heard spoken by Americans and because they were laughed at by those unfamiliar with the language, Miss Elaine P. Swensen, former director of the New York Office of the Language Research Institute, said at the tenth annual Foreign Language Conference yesterday at the New York University School of Education Auditorium.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Cornell's football forces completed their home season today with a 13-0 victory over Penn State in a game marked by rapid-fire changes in possession of the ball through fumbles and pass interceptions.

BUFFALO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Steel production continued at a standstill today at the plant of the Republic Steel Corporation here as 375 blooming mill employes voted again to continue their work stoppage, which has left at least 1,800 workers idle.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Ohio State, operating with a host of talented freshman backs, finally exploded its power today, and the result was a crushing 46-to-6 triumph over hapless Pitt. It was the highest score run up by the Ohioans this year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6 -- For the first four minutes at Palmer Stadium today the Princeton eleven gave a flawless demonstration of how the game of football should be played. Marching 40 yards in five plays, the Tigers rushed to a 7-0 lead against Villanova and the manner in which they did it was a revelation.

For months Broadway has been hearing about "Winged Victory," the Army Air Force show by Moss Hart. Now the play is trying out in Boston, and is scheduled to open in New York on Nov. 20. Here are some of its highlights. Unlike Irving Berlin's "This Is the Army," it is not a musical revue, but a serious play with incidental music.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6 -- After enjoying what appeared to be a comfortable margin of fifteen points, Brown's football team found itself battling to save a slim one-point advantage in the closing minutes as Yale closed with a rush in the forty-eighth meeting of the rival elevens today.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Turkey has agreed to grant bases to the Allies, the Bari radio said today, but a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight that he had had no information from Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to confirm the broadcast.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- In the heaviest Allied attack ever on any target on the Asiatic mainland, American Liberators and Mitchell medium bombers dropped more than 250 tons of bombs Friday on Akyab, main Japanese supply port on the west coast of Burma, the Tenth United States Air Force announced today.

Gold production in the United States this year is expected to reach the lowest level in nearly 100 years, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The nation's gold output in the first nine months of this year was 1,059,512 ounces, the bureau reported yesterday, compared with 2,904,828 in the similar period of 1942.

" THE SENTIMENTALIST" is a difficult novel to describe. At times it is as stark as Dostoyevski, at others it is as airy as a romantic set-piece. The protagonist disintegrates in the best Russian tradition; his wife, the heroine, rises phoenix-like from the flames of his psychic self-immolation, much in the manner of Irene in Galsworthy's "Man of Property."

OUT at Sheepshead Bay twelve pianos were requested on Monday. The dozen were delivered and tinkling by Tuesday.
