ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP OF A BRITISH DESTROYER FLOTILLA OFF DURAZZO, Nov. 3 (Delayed) -- Albanian guerrillas slipped inside the German coastal batteries at Durazzo today and beheaded the Nazi gunners. They cleared the way for an uninterrupted British warship bombardment that pounded the big Axis-held Albanian seaport to a pulp.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 6 -- The Anglo-Turkish conversations continued today for the second day in the British Embassy.

THE magnetic torpedo, one of Germany's newest weapons, is simply an ingenious device to assure increased effectiveness of the long-used, standard torpedo. Fired from a U-boat moving astern of the victim, the new-type torpedo is attracted magnetically to the ship's steel hull, where the propeller vibrations detonate the explosive.

When the House Ways and Means Committee responds to the Treasury's call for $10,500,000,000 of more taxes with a proposal to raise not more than $2,000,000,000, the question whether taxes are not now high enough calls for serious thinking.

America's wartime labor policy was being rewritten last week. The "Little Steel" formula which limited wage increases to 15 per cent above levels prevailing in January, 1941, took on new meaning. The nation's vital need for coal in war industry and the refusal of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers Union to dig it except at wages higher than the formula allowed forced the change.

ADMIRAL HALSEY'S ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Nov. 6 -- After more than a year of preparatory actions in which land, sea and air forces were employed, the United States has initiated a new Pacific offensive against Japan.

NAPLES, Nov. 6 -- When Italians play politics they pull in all directions. At the present moment we are seeing that combination of forces at work. CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The executive board of the American Academy of Pediatrics, a national organization of children's specialists, wired Office of Price Administration officials today expressing concern over "the shortage of milk for young children under the present quota system and possible inequitable rationing which may later follow."

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Strong Japanese forces plunged deeper into China's rice bowl today in a general advance along a ninety-mile front from the Yangtze River to Tungting Lake and the Chinese High Command in a communique said the Yangtze River port of Sungtze was threatened by the invaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Representative Mary Norton of Jersey City, who is also chairman of the Democratic State Committee of New Jersey, declared today that the Democrats lost the election in New Jersey this week because the voters blamed the party for wartime privations.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Representatives of the Hungarian, Rumanian and Bulgarian governments have been in contact with the British in an effort to arrange a separate peace, informed diplomatic sources said tonight.

But, he continues, "Cuba ought to be able to produce decent gin, but maybe the Cubans don't know how to make it."

On the eve of today's celebration of the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution the Red Army gave the Russian people an anniversary gift. It was one of the greatest victories of the war -- recapture of the "Holy Mother City" of Kiev, third largest metropolis of the U.S.S.R. and key to the whole of the southwestern Ukraine.

Leading from start to finish of the $10,000 added Florence Nightingdale Stakes, A.B. Hancock's Whirlabout yesterday was the fourth consecutive winning favorite for the 29,372 racegoers that crowded Jamaica for the third day of the Victory meeting, which is having such success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Assurance that farm-machinery goals for 1944 would be met was given today by a War Production Board official. He also reported that truck and trailer production would get "top priority" on manpower, as part of a broad, four-agency program to ease the shortage of domestic motor-transport equipment.

FOR $15.25, the price a nonresident license, a lucky hunter can bag enough wild life in the Smoky Mountain region of North Carolina from now until New Year's to make his red ration stamps superfluous. For service men on leave or furlough from surrounding camps the fee has been lowered to $2.10.

A decision of importance to corporate and individual trustees of estates was handed down yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley in the estate of Harold W. Hulbert. It construes the effect of the new law on commissions allowable to trustees.

The power and glory that are Notre Dame's on the football field again were ascendant yesterday although the master hand had been taken from the throttle of one of the great teams to come out of South Bend.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Eighty-one pedestrians were killed in traffic accidents in September, the Bureau of Motor Vehicles reported today, as compared with eighty-two in September last year, while automobile crash deaths dropped from 168 in September, 1942, to 140 in that month this year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Rutgers defeated Lafayette at football, 13 -- 0, today before a crowd of 5,000, including Governor-Elect Walter E. Edge, more than 250 State officials and the Rutgers Army specialized training unit.

MR. BARE'S large, full-page pictures in soft shades of gray, green and brown are thoroughly in the spirit of childhood and convey the atmosphere of the Gaspe country. WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Federal penal institutions sharply increased their output of war goods in the twelve months ending June 30, James V. Bennett, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, reported today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6 -- Hopes of Great Lakes vessel men to move 10,000,000 tons of ore this month and meet the War Production Board's goal of 86,500,000 tons have been jolted by a governmental request for 15,000,000 bushels of American grain in the first fifteen days of this month, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Besides doing little damage of a serious nature the Luftwaffe's fast new fighter-bomber, the Messerschmitt-410, which has been sent against London frequently in the past month, was being knocked down over Britain at a rate three times that of Royal Air Force Mosquito losses over Germany, Sir Archibald Sinclair, British Air Secretary, said yesterday.

The Collegiate Chorale, under Robert Shaw, its gifted young conductor, presented a program devoted to modern English works at its concert last night in Town Hall. Thirteen composers of the British Commonwealth were represented on the lengthy and elaborate list, which afforded as comprehensive a survey of twentieth century English choral music as could be packed into an evening's entertainment.

A seven-week experiment in presenting Latin-American studies to sixty-three boys and girls at the Horace Mann-Lincoln School of Teachers College is described in a booklet made available to 20,000 teachers throughout the country, the school announced yesterday.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 6 (AP) -- North Carolina's eleven met stiffer opposition than had been, anticipated from South Carolina today, but scored a 1-6 Southern Conference victory in a game played before 8,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Administration has an inflation problem to deal with, but it also has politics, and the result is that the fight against inflation is weakening. If there was ever "a stab in the back" it is what the specter of 1944 has done to the war on inflation.

THE professional handbook is an indispensable tool of the practicing engineer, No electrical, mechanical, chemical or radio engineer pretends to remember all the facts and formulas he learned in school. It is sufficient that he can evaluate and apply them after he looks them up.

Nelson, War Production Board chairman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Roosevelt declared today in a message to President Mikhail Kalinin of Russia that, "with the strength derived from mutual understanding, confidence and active collaboration, the United Nations will overthrow the forces of aggression and establish and maintain a just, enduring peace."

The life expectancy of babies born in New York City today is about thirty-three years longer than in 1880, statistics gleaned from the current issue of the Quarterly Bulletin of the city Health Department revealed yesterday. The tables have been worked out only through 1940 so far, and the 1940 figures refer only to white persons, since data for other races have not yet been abstracted for that year.

This fall more than 100,000 pupils in elementary and junior high schools of the city are participating in the program of released time for religious education. The twenty-seven-State campaign to "cut a cord of pulpwood for every local boy in service," sponsored by newspapers in an effort to avert a further shortage of paper for essential civilian and military use, was endorsed yesterday by Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy.

At the September meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club an amendment to the rules was adopted which provided that certain breeds and varieties of breeds constitute the whole list of breeds for which regular official classes may be arranged at shows held under A.K.C. rules. ALBANY, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- New York had an accumulated surplus of $68,962,416 at the end of the State's fiscal year on March 31, with a net debt decline for the period from $517,828,444 to $496,098,245, according to the annual report of State Controller Frank C. Moore which was issued today.
ATLANTA, Nov. 6 -- Georgia Tech, showing power, precision and a devastating Lend-Lease punch, overwhelmed Louisiana State's civilian football team today, 42 to 7, before a crowd of 20,000.

The performance of "Lovers and Friends," with Katharine Cornell and Raymond Massey, for the night of Dec. 3 at the Plymouth Theatre has been taken over as a benefit for the Winter program of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 6 -- The city of Jersey City will seek an injunction to restrain the Hudson Manhattan Railroad from increasing the fare on its line between downtown New York and stations in Jersey City and Hoboken from the present rate of 8 cents to 10 cents, Charles Hershenstein, counsel to Mayor Frank Hague, declared today.

TWO sales of Americana will be held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries this week. One on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons consists of the library of the late Col. E.H.R. Green of South Dartmouth, Mass. Colonel Green's Americana interest was largely with New England.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 6 -- Behind the calling of the conference which is to meet here Monday to consider comparative food consumption levels in the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada is the fact that even here in Canada, which is one of the largest food supply countries in the world, reserves are running lower than justifies consumption on anything much above minimum levels.

NAPLES, Nov. 5 (Delayed) -- King Victor Emmanuel left Naples for Apulia early today after a two-day visit that, officially, was merely to see the state of Naples after the devastations caused by Allied bombings and German demolitions. However, it was inevitable that his trip should be linked to the precarious situation of his throne.

STAFF SERGEANT NANA RAE, General Eisenhower's secretary, thought she was "off the staff" the morning her boss mentioned the letter she had written to The Stars and Stripes African edition. But the General's unexpected comment both reassured her and made her blush. Said the General: "That was a delicious piece of humor you had in the paper this morning."

J. EDGAR HOOVER is known as the man who convinced the Dillingers, the Pretty Boy Floyds, the Picolo Petes of the underworld and their slimy satellites that crime really doesn't pay. WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Bernard M. Baruch was appointed today by James F. Byrnes to be head of a new unit within the Office of War Mobilization for dealing with war and post-war adjustment problems. The unit will also develop unified programs and policies to be pursued by the various agencies of government concerned.

The general tone of the testimony taken last week by the subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee in its hearings on proposals of legislation definitely placing the fire and casualty insurance business outside the scope of the Sherman and the Clayton Anti-Trust Acts was favorable to the insurance industry, which did not fare so well the week before, when the hearings began.
A year ago a hunting innovation was tried in Westchester County when deer hunting with bow and arrow was permitted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Any bright young man who still thinks freedom is best maintained, not by fighting for his country, but by evading his draft board, is due to find that he has chosen the hard way, after all. The Selective Service Bureau and the Federal Bureau of Investigation took new and determined steps last week in his direction.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Battling the heaviest aerial opposition encountered in the western Balkans, Mitchell bombers hammered the Berat-Kucover Airfield in Albania yesterday as Albanian guerrillas, aided by Yugoslav Partisans, advanced into southern Yugoslavia and occupied Kicevo, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The War Department made public today the names of 294 United States soldiers listed as wounded in action. The announcement included casualties in the Asiatic, European and Mediterranean areas.

THE Christmas shopping season is formally launched today by stores throughout the country as they impress upon their customers the need of shipping and mailing gifts before the Dec. 15 deadline set by Government agencies.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Wa Food Administration follows:

I DON'T have to go to school today. I have a Simple Simon [assignment]. A Simple Simon is when you go to be a newspaper man and write stories. I am wearing my man suit and my man tie for this Simple Simon.

WHEN I consider German cartoons I am on safe ground. I can see the points even if I dislike them. "And let me beg to inform you, Mr. Roosevelt," says the old white-headed man with the scythe, dictating an official letter to his secretary in Das Reich, "that there will not be for you, any more than for Mr. Churchill or Mr. Stalin, a special ration of time.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Experience is one commodity Temple University's all-civilian eleven can use plenty of and Holy Cross was a willing provider of lots of the bitter variety today as the Crusaders handed the Owls a 42-6 pasting before 10,000 at Fitton Field.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Bertie C. Forbes, financial writer and publisher of Forbes Financial Magazine, has consented to a Chancery Court separation decree in connection with the suit brought by his estranged wife, Mrs. Adelaide S. Forbes, it was learned today.

ALL the action of this story takes place in a London block of flats, and almost all the persons involved are tenants of those flats or employes of the tenants. One of the exceptions is Miss Maud Silver, formerly a governess but now a private investigator who does her sleuthing with less fuss than any other detective we can call to mind.

" I CONSIDERED the China story as my egg. I was determined to sit on it until it hatched." Hallett Abend quotes himself as saying this in 1926, shortly after he arrived in China. Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's nationalist revolt against the war lords was getting under way in Canton and Mr. Abend was there watching it when he made his decision to cash in his return ticket to America.

Although the "original" rubber crisis, the threatened exhaustion of raw material supplies, has been overcome by the Government sponsored synthetic rubber production program, the growing air might of the United States is proving to be a major factor in the development of what rubber manufacturers call "the new rubber crisis," the fabrication of tires in the quantities needed by the armed forces.

ALTHOUGH Arthur Edeson spells his name with an "e" and is not related to Thomas Alva, his connection with the motion-picture industry goes back almost as far as the Sage of Menlo Park's. Edeson has been a motion-picture camera man for thirty-one years, which dates back to a practically primeval era in the history of the screen.

Much is being said and written about the shrinkage of the world's boundaries and the new geography which demonstrates how near to us by air once remote peoples and countries have become. At Middlebury College recognition of this "One World" philosophy and the correlative need for intelligent assumption of responsibilities in the post-war world have taken the form of a new Field of Planned Study in Modern Language and World Affairs.

JOHN BURROUGHS once wrote to Sarah Orne Jewett, "I know you are from Maine. I can taste the flavor of the birches in your books." He might well have said the same to Gladys Hasty Carroll, whose "Dunnybrook" is a warm and wholesome, if sometimes sentimental, tribute to ten generations of her Maine family and neighbors.

THREE GENERATIONS This is the story of three generations cooperating in the all-out war effort. The baby's mother needs to work to supplement her $62 monthly allowance. She lives with her own mother, who also needs money, and the baby is the problem.

TORONTO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins scored their first victory of the National Hockey League season by overcoming Toronto 5 -- 2, at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight before 12,250 fans. The veteran Boston team was outplayed most of the way, the dashing young Leafs having 47 shots to 28 for the visitors, but the Bruins had superior skill around the nets.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 6 -- A project launched to provide a permanent memorial to Leon Blum, former Premier and Jewish freedom-loving fighter when the Vichy Government attempted to saddle him with the responsibility for the downfall of France in 1940, will assume a final definite shape next Wednesday at the formal inauguration of a village bearing his name in the most northeasterly corner of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, Democrat, declaring that petroleum sources were steadily dwindling, called today for Senate action Tuesday on his $30,000,000 measure to start the manufacture of gasoline from coal.

OTTAWA, Nov. 6 -- The strike of 8,500 coal miners in Alberta and British Columbia that threatened a serious fuel situation in these Provinces is expected to end with the return of the miners to work on Monday morning.

ONE of the easiest grown and most attractive bulbs, for flowering in the house during winter is the Cape Cowslip (Lachenalia pendula superba) for which reasons -- though relatively new to this country -- it has won a definite place in the window. These South African bulbs of the lily family grow rapidly.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 6 -- Are lend-lease goods to be paid for, and if so when and how? asked Norman B. Spencer, president of the National Chambers of Commerce yesterday. Most New Zealanders believed lend-lease supplies would not be paid for, Mr. Spencer said.

The short evening dress is receiving definite style acceptance. Smart women are finding that the frock that can be completely covered by an evening wrap is sensible to wear to dinner and the theatre. Their escorts bless them when it comes to the nocturnal chase for a taxi.

INCONSISTENCY in individual behavior may make a person "interesting." But the health and adequacy of a personality can be judged, it seems, by the extent of the strain toward consistency of its various parts.

Despite the desire of buyers to take a conservative attitude on purchasing of spring merchandise, conditions in the various wholesale markets are forcing retailers to place orders as far ahead as Easter in order to be sure of timely deliveries, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

THE abdication of the French upper classes, their failure to justify their role as defenders of French patriotism, is one of the most important events in modern French history. It restores the duty and the chance of remaking France to the people who again can say "Viva la nation!" while their betters are shouting "Vive le marechal!" as their spiritual ancestors shouted "Vive le roi!" at Valmy or Fleurus.

THE Oregon-California Trail is the most amazing road this continent has ever known. As early as 1826 its faint beginnings had been traced by fur traders, a vague path broadened and deepened by the wagons of Oregon emigrants and Mormons and by the hurrying feet of California gold seekers.

Mrs. Gertrude Weil Klein, American Labor party member; Lieut. Col. Charles E. Keegan, Democrat, and Michael J. Quill, independent and president of the Transport Workers Union, were elected last night to represent the Bronx in the new City Council as the borough completed its proportional representation count of the voting last Tuesday.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 7 -- It is more certain that Wendell Willkie will be the Republican nominee for the Presidency than that Mr. Roosevelt will allow himself to be nominated by the Democrats, in the opinion of The Sunday Observer's Washington correspondent.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- According to a leader of one of the principal French resistance organizations who recently arrived in this country from France, Gen. Charles de Gaulle's popularity there is greater than ever, there is considerable concern over Anglo-American intentions toward France and the Communist underground organization, of which my informant is not a member, is recruiting large numbers of young Frenchmen.

An all-day meeting planned and managed by 850 senior Girl Scouts of the city was held yesterday in the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, to discuss "Senior Scouting in Wartime."

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- Kiev is a rich prize, won after a hard month-long campaign in which the Germans offered stubborn resistance. Because it is the oldest Russian city as well as the former Ukrainian capital, Kiev has a tremendous morale effect, which is important here. Although the city also was an important manufacturing center, the Germans doubtless have destroyed much of its value.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 6 -- The whole question of Switzerland's barter trade agreements under "charter" from both belligerents is presently up for re-examination in economic circles here following last week's blacklisting of the firm of Sulzer Brothers of Winterthur, on charges of exporting war materials to Germany and "refusing to submit to foreign economic control of its business affairs."

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Prices of wheat fluctuated erratically today on the Chicago Board of Trade, being alternately easy and firm, reflecting changes in the news and the attitude of professional traders. An easy start was followed by a rally of around 3/4 cent a bushel, but the market eased again on selling induced by reports of showers in parts of the West and Southwest and a forecast for additional precipitation over the week-end.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 6 -- It was the same old story today as undermanned Columbia dropped its sixth straight game of its most disastrous football season in history.

BALLET THEATRE tonight brings to a close a season which, though eminently successful at the box office, must have been a considerable trial to all and sundry backstage. A ballet season is never exactly a placid and self-operating affair, but this one was beset by special and varied disasters, and only quick thinking by the management and real heroism by the company could have saved the situation.

THE worker who finds that the staggered vacation plan has left him with a between-seasons vacation, the person with a precious free week-end, the service man on furlough -- all these can find an answer to the perplexing "Where to go?"

DAVID ASHBY always remembered the Barbados planter who nicknamed him Captain Ebony -- "the only honest slaver of 'em all." He could hardly resent the tag, now that he had grown rich in the trade. In fact, it was a convenient mask to hide the face of a Virginia gentleman who had drifted into blackbirding more for excitement than gain.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- In a recent issue of the magazine Das Reich Dr. Joseph Goebbels wrote: "Allied bombings are the lion's share of all our troubles in civilian life." For once the little Propaganda Minister had made a statement that he did not have to prove; he had said something that all Germans knew.
LONDON Nov. 6 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

CHINA PLANS: Free China saw its first locally published American newspaper last week when the Chungking edition of The Shanghai Evening Post and 1Vfercury appeared. It is published in a dugout on rickety presses. Its advertisements took to the future. Ira one of them the China National Aviation Corporation extended an invitation to the opening of its new Shanghai airport -- "exact date will be announced later."

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Careful defense timing sent jurors trying Alfred de Marigny for murder into a week-end recess today immediately after an attack on Harold G. Christie's testimony that he slept all night at Sir Harry Oakes' estate the night the wealthy baronet was hit on the head and left to die in a blazing bedroom.

As part of its post-war construction program, New York City plans to build sixty new public schools, at a cost of $96,318,000. Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday in a luncheon address before 1,200 parents and teachers attending the annual conference of the United Parents Associations at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 6 -- Generally speaking, Middle Western farmers are opposed to subsidies to stimulate or maintain production. Not so militantly, perhaps, as some of the leading farm organizations and the farm bloc in Congress, but they just do not see the sense in subsidies with things the way they are now.

Indications that the food industry plans a "last-ditch" fight against the Administration's subsidy proposals was seen by trade observers last week, following the close of the three-day war conference of the Grocery Manufacturers of America here.

A contribution of $150,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York to the National War Fund was announced yesterday by Emil Schram, chairman of the fund's New York committee. The citywide campaign goal is $17,000,000.

ALGIERS, Nov. 6 -- The last grip on the enemy's first trans-Italian front below Rome was hammered loose by the British Eighth Army yesterday. It fought its way from San Salvo to Vasto while, on the other side of the country, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army took Venafro, the fall of which had been assured from the moment when Isernia was captured.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 -- Thousands of draftees originally rejected because they showed symptoms of heart or circulatory disease are becoming acceptable for military service.
ALGIERS, Nov. 6 -- A communique:

We are not enthusiastic about the kind of cartoon which shows a huge derrick marked "U.S.A. -- Britain -- U.S.S.R." dumping an absurd little man with a funny little mustache into the garbage can; or cartoons showing the same comic little creature held aloft on the convergent points of three colossal bayonets marked "U.S.A. -- Britain -- U.S.S.R."

ANY one of nine persons could have poisoned Earl' Falkoner, and it is Detective ick's job to fix the crime upon the right one. Each of the nine had a possible motive and none of them has an alibi. As a detective 'luck is unusual; he appears to believe everything that is told him.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 6 -- A San Diego Naval Training Station eleven sprang one of the season's big football upsets today by defeating the previously unbeaten, untied, unscored-on Trojans of the University of Southern California, 10 to 7.

Retail trade was excellent last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Election day coat events jammed departments.

FRED ALLEN will be resuming his Sunday night show over CBS (WABC) on Dec. 12, the comedian's physician finally having given the go-ahead signal The first several programs will originate in Hollywood, where Mr. Allen is preparing a film.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Otto Graham of Northwestern ran, kicked, and passed to a 41-to-0 Big Ten Football triumph over Wisconsin today.

MR. HOLBROOK has written the first general account of forest fires in the United States, with one Canadian fire added for good measure. The subject is of immense interest and importance, and the book is an excellent presentation of the subject.

Washington's announcement that the nation's undertakers are enlisted in a drive to round up food ration books of persons who have died evoked little enthusiasm among New York City Office of Price Administration authorities yesterday.

When the Cardinals and the Dodgers square off in a National Football League contest at Ebbets Field this afternoon it will be a battle of cellar dwellers of the Loop's two divisions. Neither team has won a game, each has lost six, and about the only edge the Cards seem to hold is that they've scored 44 points and the Dodgers only 31 against all opponents.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- Much attention is being paid in the Russian military press to building up a strong traditional sense in the Red Army officer corps. Soviet officers, as Red Star wrote recently, find a good deal in the old traditions of Russian officers that is making clear to them the origin and development of Russia's military strength.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 6 -- A Federal decree issued today put Argentina's wire and radio communications facilities, "whether national, provincial or private," under the control of the War Ministry on the ground that this was necessary for the national defense.

Heard at the Conference of the National Association for Nursery Education: "Marking off the working mother as someone who needs care for her child that no other mother needs" is a flaw in our current thinking, according to Dr. Alice V. Keliher, Director of Child and Youth Services, Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of Greater New York.

There are, first, "those German officers and men and members of the Nazi party who have been responsible for or have taken a consenting part in atrocities, massacres and executions."

He was perhaps not quite as venal as his enemies said nor as wonderful as his few friends -- mostly posthumous -- insisted.

But if mothers have no conveniently situated, capably run place in which to leave their young children during working hours they will not stick loyally at their war jobs.

IF parents have ever felt pushed around by the "experts"; if there was ever a time when the "experts" thought they could do a better job for young children than parents could, it is all over now.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- The text of a speech by Premier Joseph Stalin before a meeting of Moscow workers on the eve of the twenty-sixth anniversary of the revolution broadcast by the Moscow radio:
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The American National Red Cross sends out a new appeal -- an appeal that must be answered. "We cannot ask our men to face the withering fire of the enemy's guns and not have nurses to care for them when they are wounded and dying," says Miss Alice Weston, director of the Red Cross' Brooklyn Chapter, in what she forthrightly calls "an invitation to heartbreak."
ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- As the first year of the Allied Mediterranean campaign ended tonight the Allied air forces dug back into the record and produced, among others, the following statistics:
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The Anglo-Turkish talks in Cairo have been completed, it was announced tonight.

VICTORY is nothing new to Notre Dame. In fact, it has grown throughout the years to be a habit. Great teams also are nothing new to Notre Dame. The Irish have had them from way back. But Frank Leahy's current edition is being hailed by all and sundry as the best ever produced at South Bend and 76,000 witnesses at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday would be the last to file a dissent.

Women volunteers who have been driving automobiles for the Army Air Forces during the last year were commended yesterday by Capt. Ivan M. Annenberg, district transportation officer at the Eastern Procurement Center, Materiel Command.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -The Redskins, fought to a stand-still by the Philadelphia-Pittsburgh combined team, nevertheless took a long stride toward the Eastern division championship today as the two teams battled to a 14-14 stalemate before an all-time Philadelphia record crowd of 28,893 for a National Football League game.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Operations in grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade increased last week, business being stimulated at times by removal of hedges against sales of cash grain. There also was liberal selling at one time on peace talk.

Mayor La Guardia in his regular Sunday broadcast from Station WNYC charged yesterday that the Republican party was completely responsible for the election of Thomas A. Aurelio as Supreme Court Justice, denied that the election of Senator Joe R. Hanley, Republican nominee for Lieutenant Governor was a defeat of the New Deal and asserted that President Roosevelt, if a candidate for re-election tomorrow, would carry New York City by 750,000.
M'COOK, Neb., Nov. 7 -- I heartily approve the passage last Friday by the Senate of the amended Connally resolution.

Unlike their parent team, the New York Rangers, the Rovers opened their home season yesterday with a victory. The red-jerseyed team representing this city in the Eastern Hockey League skated through to a 5-to-2 triumph over the Philadelphia Falcons at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 8,027.

The Food for Freedom program, which started this month and is scheduled to continue for some time, is essentially a campaign to educate people in the role food is playing in the war. It aims to spread information about production, allocation and so on through a variety of media -- articles, speeches, advertisements and posters.
Tribute to the late David M. Bressler was paid yesterday afternoon at a memorial service and dedication of a tablet in the Beth Abraham Home for Incurables, 612 Allerton Avenue, the Bronx.

WHEN a modern warship takes part in naval action at sea only 10 per cent of its officers and men can see what is going on or even part of it; the rest are at their battle stations below decks, cut off far more completely from any knowledge of the events on which their lives depend than were the galley slaves chained to their oars in an ancient trireme.

The truly successful man, even though he may appear to have failed, is the man who has faith in better things ahead, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, professor at Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday in a sermon at James Memorial Chapel at the seminary.

Edward J. Moore, 19 years old, fireman first class in the Navy, was detained in St. Louis yesterday at the request of New York police for questioning in connection with the disappearance last Sunday afternoon from Central Park of 14-year-old Margaret Leighton Moore of 1172 Park Avenue.

American and Canadian women should unite "to form a solid body of opinion in North America to help prevent future wars," Mrs. Irene Baird, representing the National Film Board of Canada, said yesterday. She described the film board as "a combination of the Office of War Information and Hollywood, with a closer resemblance to the OWI."

From now until June 30 it will cost the city $835,000 to bring its street lighting back to 90 per cent of normal, as contemplated under the suspension of the dimout, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 -- The law of diminishing returns, known to business, industry and agriculture, was applied to astronomy today by Dr. Joel Stebbins, director of Washburn Observatory of the University of Wisconsin, in his address as retiring president of the American Astronomical Society, closing its seventy-first meeting.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A large force of American heavy bombers with a strong fighter escort ran "a dream mission" over fuel dumps, buildings and wharfs of the northwest section of Rabaul Saturday.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Virtually all sections of the British public paid enthusiastic tribute to the Soviet Union today on the occasion of its twenty-sixth anniversary. At the same time religious leaders, public officials and the Soviet Ambassador to Britain hailed the recent Moscow conference as a bright promise of the better world that would be established when the Allied victory was won.

Stell Andersen, American pianist, was heard at Town Hall last night in a recital to aid Camp Little Norway, the Royal Norwegian Air Force Training Center at Toronto. The program consisted entirely of music of the United Nations, partly of the Romantic school, mostly of the Modern.

TULE LAKE, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Heavily armed troops, some of them veterans of Pacific battle fronts, kept watchful eyes on 16,000 Japanese internees at the Tule Lake Segregation Center today, while the first of several investigations got under way to determine the cause and possible cure of repeated uprisings there.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Battle-toughened Soviet veterans stood on the heights before Kiev Friday night with tears of blind fury in their eyes as they watched the destruction of the "mother of Russian cities" by ruthless German troops.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Announcement that further supplies of lard and pork-rendered fat had been made available to soap manufacturers to avoid prospective rationing of soap was not a surprise to the trade as supplies of lard are expected to start to pile up from now on owing to the large receipts of hogs, the heavy make and the relatively slow domestic and foreign demand.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- The Germans have almost wiped out Austria's 200,000 Jews by extermination or deportation. Prisons and concentration camps are jammed with Austrian anti-Germans, but sabotage, aided by foreign workers, is increasing. Austrians generally know that Germany is losing the war.

The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren preached his farewell sermon yesterday morning in the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, where he has been co-pastor since 1931. He appealed for greater adherence to "the gospel of divine friendship."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- After nearly two years of efforts to persuade the Surgeon General's office to grant her a commission in the Army Medical Corps, Dr. Alice McNeal, a specialist in anesthesiology at the Presbyterian Hospital in Chicago, has not given up hope.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- British school teachers and youth leaders were urged today by the Board of Education to attend a new course on sex education.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Officials of the United Automobile Workers (CIO) said tonight that two strikes blamed for keeping more than 10,000 war-plant workers in idleness over the weekend had been settled, and that the employes would return to their jobs tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A breakdown of motor freight transportation in the absence of immediate steps to enable truckers to obtain necessary equipment, parts and tires was predicted today by Ted V. Rodgers, president of the American Trucking Associations.

Education as the best means of combating anti-Semitism was the theme of one of several seminars conducted yesterday at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street. It was urged that the Institute for Religious Studies of the seminary expand its work in this direction to other sections of the country.

Victory continues to elude the Rangers. For the fifth time in five National Hockey League games this season, the New York skaters bowed when they were defeated by Toronto at Madison Square Garden last night. The score was 7 -- 4.

The Pierpont Morgan Library announces publication of "The Berthold Missal," a detailed study of the famous illuminated manuscript in the Morgan collection that was executed at Weingarten Abbey in the early thirteenth century. Included are publication of documentary sources related to the abbey, and a descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts illuminated at the abbey at the same time as the Berthold Missal.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- The Bears gained revenge for the only blot on their National Football League record, a 21-21 tie with Green Bay, by beating the Packers today, 21 to 7, in the slime of Wrigley Field before 43,425 damp and chilled spectators.

The bombing of Vatican City last Friday night was denounced by Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre at the eighth annual memorial service of the Anchor Club of the Police Department yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 7 -- The impression that "something is happening" was further heightened in Helsinkl today when it was learned that Georg Gripenberg, the Finnnsh envoy in Stockholm, had been received at Field Marshal Baron Karl Mannerheim's headquarters.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Conflicting influences resulted in very rapid price changes in wheat last week, December having a range of 4 1/4 cents a bushel, advancing to a new peak since 1925 on buying headed by cash interests before encountering heavy selling induced by peace talk and reports that them increased movement of new corn had resulted in weakening the feed situation.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The newspapers of London are giving greater prominence to the results of the Moscow conference than to the United States Senate's debate and subsequent approval of the Connally resolution pledging postwar collaboration by America with free and sovereign nations in the establishment and maintenance of international authority with power to act against aggression and promote world peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov 7 (AP) -- The Red Army's triumphs and the Moscow four-power conference were toasted tonight by United Nations leaders at a Russian Embassy reception celebrating the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution. Soviet Ambassador Andrei Gromyko and Mrs. Gromyko received more than 4,000 guests at the party, annually one of the capital's most brilliant social events.

The cotton market suffered a sharp recession last week on rumors of an early ending of hostilities in Europe. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 32 to 40 points, following declines of 10 to 38 points in the week previous.
MONTREAL, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- The Canadiens remained unbeaten in the National Hockey League by defeating Chicago tonight, 5 to 1, before a crowd of 12,826.

A thirteen-day intensive drive for discarded clothing and rags, needed for rehabilitation abroad, relief at home and in war industry, will begin on Nov. 22, it was announced yesterday by Frank D. March, New York City salvage director.

Last week the Administration's labor and wage policy took a further disturbing turn. The country's coal miners once more went out on strike, ceasing to produce a material vitally necessary for the war effort. The President again replied, not by penalizing the strikers themselves, but by seizing the property of the mine owners, who were powerless in the situation.
The Dodgers finally broke the ice yesterday when they defeated the Chicago Cardinals before a pleased gathering of 13,340 at Ebbets Field.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 8 -- Australian Beauforts in a Friday night attack on Rabaul, New Britain, following up the smashing Friday daylight assault by Allied fliers, probably hit a heavy Japanese cruiser. They also blew up a cargo vessel and started three large fires on Rabaul's Vunakanau airdrome.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, Nov. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- The sergeant was so utterly weary that he slept, sprawled in the slit trench, despite the dampness, the sharp rocks and the cool wind that swept the front.
ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- It was "H" hour -- the hour of attack -- at 1 A.M. Nov. 8, 1942. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was pacing the floor of his headquarters 600 feet deep in the Rock of Gibraltar.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The great success of the Moscow conference, the magnificent feats still being performed by the Russian armies and the more rapid progress recently reported in the Italian campaign have failed entirely to stimulate the London stock markets.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Modere (Mud) Bruneteau bagged four goals, missing by one tally Ray Getliffe's National Hockey League individual record, as the Red Wings defeated Boston, 6 to 4, tonight before 12,594 spectators. Detroit remained undefeated after three games while handing the Bruins their first setback.

ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- One year from the first African landing of American troops in the dark hours of Nov. 7, 1942, responsible Allied observers here believe that the hour of Germany's defeat may be closer than the battle lines on the map indicate.

A shortage of milk in the New York City area was forecast yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall and by Fred N. Sexauer, president of the Dairymen's League, in a letter to Fred M. Vinson, director of the Office of Economic Stabilization.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 5 (Delayed) -- Discussions are proceeding among Palestinian Arabs with the view of selecting a delegation to go to Cairo for talks on an Arab union with the Egyptian Premier, Mustafa Nahas Pasha, who has been visited by representatives of Iraq, Syria, Lebanon and Saudi Arabia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -The nations of Europe will emerge from the war with fairly definite ideas about their future, some willing but others strongly opposed to forfeiting some of their sovereignty to attain their ends, the Foreign Policy Association said tonight.

A large industrial property in the East New York section of Brooklyn passed to new control with the sale by the W.W.W. Holding Corporation to the Marabert Realty Corporation of the four-story brick factory building containing 63,000 square feet of space at 2941 Atlantic Avenue, corner of Cleveland Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Methods of improving the war effort and the post-war development of Haiti were extensively discussed by Haitian and United States officials during the visit last month of President Elie Lescot, the State Department said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Harvesting of corn made good progress last week, and while rain fell in some areas this was favorable for the use of mechanical pickers, as the latter operate to best advantage when the husks are somewhat damp.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A demand by Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat, of Georgia, that the Senate include funds for the Farm Security Administration in the $214,854,124 deficiency appropriations bill passed by the House Friday raised prospects today of another spirited contest in Congress.

This letter is a report from the President of the Borough of Manhattan to the residents of Manhattan in response to many letters received by me, or which have appeared in the press, asking why in these times of material and manpower shortages it is necessary to continue to repair Manhattan's streets.

In New York City, as elsewhere throughout the country, this is Open School Week. All parents and citizens generally are invited by the school officials to visit the classrooms, talk with the teachers, and watch Johnny and Mary at work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A special Presidential wage board has decided to recommend pay increases ranging from 4 cents to 10 cents an hour for 1,100,000 non-operating railroad employes, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- An Anglo-American mission has completed a survey which resulted in information with which "it will be possible for the combined boards to complete the Allied nations' balance sheet of steel production and requirements," William L. Batt, American member of the Combined Raw Materials Board, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Ways and Means Committee's $2,000,000,000 tax bill is expected to be ready for the House Thursday if agreement can be reached on provisions designed to free small corporations from war contract renegotiation.

Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower Allied Commander in Chief in the Mediterranean, and Lieut. Gen Jacob L. Devers, commanding United States Army forces in the European theatre, marked the first anniversary yesterday of the landings in North Africa with hints of new and more powerful blows against the Axis.

Irene Rosenberg, 16-year-old Brooklyn pianist, who made her local debut in 1939, gave her fourth Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. This time she came forward in a program consisting of Bach's "Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue," Mozart's last sonata in D major, Beethoven's Thirty-two Variations in C minor, and offerings by Chopin, Liszt and Granados.

Numerous organizations are now working for the return of total prohibition. They hope that the momentum of the war effort will carry their cause to success now as it did in the first World War. They have introduced prohibition bills in Congress, and unless the public is alert there is always the danger that these bills may become laws.

" A New Life" will say good-bye to Broadway on Saturday night at which time it will have chalked up its sixty-ninth performance at the Royale. The Playwrights Company's first offering of the season features Betty Field and is the work of Miss Field's husband, Elmer Rice who also staged the attraction.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Assassinations of Italian Fascists and sabotage against German forces have increased to such an extent in northern Italy that the Fascist party secretary, Alessandro Pavolini, has ordered summary trials and executions of the "moral instigators," as well as those directly responsible.

The Marine Corps, which in the present war has added new luster to its record, will mark its 168th anniversary on Wednesday. Marines everywhere, sky fighters, jungle warriors, gunners aboard capital ships of the Navy, from Iceland to the South Pacific, from the Caribbean to the Aleutians, will pause a few minutes for the reading of the annual birthday message, reminding of their heritage and their obligation to carry on the tradition of the corps.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Transportation Association of America, in a letter mailed to members of Congress, said today that Vice President Henry Wallace "misrepresented" the association's position in a speech at Dallas, Texas, on Oct. 20.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Passage of her bill to provide a "very limited" National Service Act would free Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner, from the necessity of repeatedly apologizing for failing to marshal the country's manpower by voluntary methods, Representative Clare Boothe Luce, Republican of Connecticut, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A central agency operating under a "strong mandate" from Congress to take final responsibility for speedy settlement of canceled war contracts was urged today by Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, chairman of the Military Affairs subcommittee on war contract termination.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Inflationary trends almost all over the world, mounting to enormous pressures in many areas, are reflected in diplomatic living-cost figures reported by the State Department to the House Appropriations Committee.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 7 (AP) -- American and RAF divebombers, giving tactical support to American and Chinese engineers carving a new supply road to China, struck at Japanese bases and communications in the Hukawng Valley and upper Chindwin area of Burma yesterday and last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Awards to five men from New York State for participation in Eleventh Air Force bombing missions against the Japanese on Paramushiru and Shimishu islands of the Kuriles group were announced today by the War Department.

BUFFALO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- About 375 blooming mill employes refused for the third time today to end a walkout at the Republic Steel Corporation's Buffalo plant which has resulted in a tie-up of Steel production and idleness for at least 1,800 workers.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 7 -- The Foreign Minister's journey to Cairo and his contacts there with Allied statesmen are attracting the widest interest among Turks. His return is expected Monday or Tuesday.
ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- A communique:

Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, disclosed yesterday that his Richmond, Calif., shipyard had delivered thirty-two Liberty ships last month and that his Vancouver yards had turned out four aircraft carriers in the same period.

ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- An entire new company of Wacs arrived here today by air -- the first time so large a unit of the women in khaki have ever been transported from a port of debarkation exclusively by plane.

Rethinking on such terms as freedom, liberty and democracy was urged yesterday morning by the Rev. Karl M. Chworowsky in a sermon at the Flatbush Unitarian Church, Beverly Road and East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn. He said these terms still "remain for too many of us vague words or at the best pleasant generalities."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Local union balloting on resumption of work tomorrow morning under the new wage agreement is overwhelmingly favorable, it was revealed tonight as eighty-one of the first eighty-six locals voting decided to go back to work.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- The submarines Lionfish and Manta were added today to the Navy's fleet of underseas fighters in launching ceremonies at the Camp Shipbuilding Company.

In a two-hour ceremony witnessed by 5,500 persons, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine honored yesterday the merchant seamen of the United Nations "who are giving generously of their blood and labor in the great battle for decency and liberty."

At his Carnegie Hall recital last night Josef Lhevinne, who was in wonderful form, enchanted his large audience with a series of keyboard performances so phenomenal that even he has seldom equaled them. Never was his extraordinary mastery of the piano more completely to the fore in feats of sheer virtuosity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Jean Heather and James Brown, who had the romantic leads in the recently finished Bing Crosby picture "Going My Way," at Paramount, will have a similar assignment in the forthcoming "National Barn Dance," Paramount's version of the ten-year-old radio program of that title.

A hushed and thrilled audience of a thousand, including leading scientists and medical men, witnessed yesterday afternoon a motion-picture demonstration of pioneer experiments in the Soviet Institute of Experimental Biology at Moscow in which animals that had been dead as long as fifteen minutes were restored to life.

American aviation has been scoring brilliantly in the Southwest Pacific. Demolition of enemy aircraft by the score and occasionally by the hundred has become a familiar item in communiques from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters.

A syndicate of investors has purchased from the East River Savings Bank the twenty-story store and loft building at 594-98 Eighth Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty ninth Street, for cash over a first mortgage of $630,000. The property is assessed at $700,000 and is the third bought by the syndicate in the section.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 8 -- Soviet tank forces smashed through crumbling German defenses southwest of Kiev yesterday and captured the important rail junction of Fastov, threatening to cut off many German troops retreating from Kiev from those battling to hold the iron center of Krivoi Rog.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- The Navy is rapidly expanding its force of land-based, long-range patrol bombers for use against submarines in the Atlantic and for reconnaissance over the broad reaches of the Pacific.

Monday's news of the Three-Power Pact at Moscow, wherein the foreign secretaries of the United States, Great Britain and Russia, with the assent of China, agreed to stand together during and after the war, was followed by a fall of prices.

War in all its grimness came to Fifth Avenue yesterday in store window displays. A soldier on crutches wearing the Purple Heart, a white cross marking the grave of a fallen hero, a War Department telegram informing a mother of a son's death -- these and many other motifs were employed to emphasize the appeal of the National War Fund.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 113.6 on Oct. 26, compared with 113.9 a fortnight before, 114.3 a month before, 111.7 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- A two-front brush and forest fire in the Santa Monica Mountains tonight had consumed at least 115 houses, left hundreds of war workers homeless and caused damage estimated at more than $1,000,000 in loss of homes, farms, orchards, automobiles, livestock and watershed.

A superior aerial attack brought the Inter-Racial All-Stars a 13-0 victory over the New London Diesels in a charity game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The attendance was 8,000, proceeds going to the Associated Football Charities.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 -- Even though it appeared last night that the coal miners' wage controversy was near definite settlement, steel production losses last week were a direct result of the fourth general mine tie-up. While actual figures on the loss are not yet available, it is estimated that ingot output on a percentage-of-operation basis had dropped a fun point to 99 per cent of rated capacity.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7 -- With almost dramatic suddenness, cotton futures made a precipitous decline at midweek when a rumor spread that Lloyd's of London had offered to bet that the war would be over by Christmas. Although the report was denied, the market was under water for the remainder of the week on peace prospects.

The Union Folding Company of Union City has purchased for a freight terminal and garage the one-story garage building at 304-6 Jackson Street, in Hoboken, N.J., from the Majo Realty Company. Frank Bucino was the broker.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 111.05. Although the all-commodity index remained constant there were some changes in the prices of agricultural commodities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- The rise of juvenile delinquency is concentrated in large cities, production centers and service camp vicinities, it was revealed today in the report of a survey by the American Public Welfare Association and the Council of State Governments.

Despite the social maladjustments and changing economic conditions of our first full year at war, New York City in 1942 had the best record of crime prevention in its history, according to the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, Inc., which released yesterday its annual report.

FREDONIA, N.Y., Nov. 7 (AP) -Dairy farmers withheld milk deliveries to distributors serving about 30,000 residents in the Dunkirk-Fredonia area today as producers in southern Chautauqua County scheduled a meeting to consider cutting off milk from about 75,000 persons in the Jamestown area.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 7 -- Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav patriot forces operating between Presevo and Bujanovac have destroyed a considerable section of the Belgrade-Skoplje-Salonika railroad and cut all telephone and telegraph communications by which German forces in northern Serbia have been in touch with the south, according to a communique issued here today by the Yugoslav Government information office.

Champion Glynhir Gladly, wirehaired bitch owned by W.L. Lewis of the Glynhir Kennels of New York City, was adjudged best in the seventy-second specialty show of the American Fox Terrier Club yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.

It is evident that the contest for Rabaul is developing into one of the major battles of the war. The stakes are nothing less than control of the southwest Pacific. The outcome will determine whether we can break into the strategic circle which centers at Truk, Japan's main base in her mandated islands, or must still fight along the perimeter of the enemy's defense.

ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- Pilot Officer Claude Weaver of Oklahoma City and Lieut. Harold Rideout of Ashburnham, Mass., are resting in Italy after having escaped from the Germans exactly one year after Weaver's capture in Sicily.

Considering the recent criticisms made in some of the magazines and newspapers, I venture to call attention to the fact that the "tremendous success" of the Moscow conference of the Foreign Secretaries of the United States of America, of the United Kingdom and of the Soviet Union may have been due in some part at least to Cordell Hull.
The German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Books are one of the few recreations merchant sailors can enjoy on their long voyages around the world. They become voracious readers and depend on the public ashore to supply their need. Because of the rapid expansion of our merchant marine, the demand for reading matter aboard ship now far exceeds supply.

Both the church and Government must act vigorously to stamp out "evidences of a growing tension of an anti-Semitic nature," the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale declared yesterday in a sermon from his pulpit at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at West Twenty-ninth Street.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A Tenth, Air Force communique:

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Reports of sabotage, assassinations and increasingly daring guerrilla operations came today from France, the Netherlands and Denmark as the Germans, preparing for an uprising in Norway, were said to be erecting street barricades.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Prices of oats on the Chicago Board of Trade averaged somewhat higher last week, but the buying lacked the snap that characterized trading several weeks ago, and the upturn in wheat was responsible for a considerable part of the strength in oats.
Frank Leahy finally has come reluctantly to the conclusion that it might not be sinful if he took a day off to relax away from his team.
Three new films are scheduled for this week. In order of arrival they are:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Algiers, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Two pilots, one American and the other British, received decorations from each other's Governments in a single ceremony yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 8 -- A direct hit on a crowded suburban dance hall and milk bar during a brief German air attack on London last night caused a high number of casualties, which may include some Americans. It may prove to be the worst incident in the capital area since the bombing of the Catford School last Jan. 20 in which thirty-nine children and eight teachers were killed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (P}-President Roosevelt took the lead oday in honoring Robert Lee Doughton on his eightieth birthday.

Total shipments of all types of hosiery during September, amounting to 12,879,219 dozen pairs, showed an increase of 1.8 per cent over the corresponding month last year, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Like a straw in the wind, the increasing attention to the design of offices for women executives may indicate the more influential roles women are expected to play in the years ahead. The decorators from W. J. Sloane, who recently completed a suite of rooms for a local company, created a distinctly feminine atmosphere for the women who will occupy them.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Gerard Cote of Valley Field, Que., who won both the Boston and Yonkers races in 1940, duplicated the twin triumph by capturing the National A.A.U. marathon championship today. Cote, now a sergeant in the Canadian Army, won in Boston this spring.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The capture, conviction and punishment of the Nazis and all others who have perpetrated atrocities as set forth in the Moscow declaration will be supervised by the United Nations Commission for Investigation of War Crimes.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Runaway inflation will not result from the drive by the Congress of Industrial Organizations for wage increases for about 3,000,000 war workers, it was stated here today by Allan S. Haywood, vice president of the CIO, on the eve of the opening of a fight to increase the annual income of 900,000 laborers in the steel industry by more than $300,000,000.

Many retail buyers were in the New York market last week, looking for reorders on seasonal lines and also placing initial business on Spring offerings, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- The following statement was issued officially tonight:

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- In rain and mud, the Lions and Giants played to a scoreless tie today in a National Football League game before 16,992 spectators. Detroit made three field-goal attempts and New York one. Neither team got inside the 15-yard line.

Formation of a joint committee on Government relations of the commercial printing industry to lend support to paper conservation and to secure equitable distribution of available supplies was announced yesterday by the New York Employing Printers Association and the Graphic Arts Association.

ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- What is of much greater significance than Americans' reactions to North Africa is the attitude of the permanent population of cities like Algiers, Casablanca and Tunis to our soldiers -- by whom they naturally judge all Americans -- after one year of their presence here.
A gift of $75,000 from Harold S. Vanderbilt to the $17,000,000 campaign of the New York Committee of the National War Fund was announced yesterday by Harold H. Helm, city-wide vice chairman.

ALGIERS, Nov. 7 -- While the Germans hurled another infantry division against Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army surging to the Garigliano line, the British Eighth Army fully exploited the smashing of all enemy positions around San Salvo and Vasto by sweeping across the Trigno River along a twenty-mile stretch from the coast.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Battles raged today along the central Yangtze River front, where the Japanese have amassed an army estimated at 30,000 men to forestall any Allied offensive, the Chinese High Command announced.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Country offerings of new corn for deferred shipment are increasing steadily, reflecting the rapid progress of harvesting in many sections in the Central West. At the close of the week it is estimated that over 50 per cent of the Iowa crop had been cribbed.
John Nuveen Co. will offer today a new issue of $3,000,000 of Tacoma, Wash., light and power (revenue) bonds, Series A of 1943.
Recent developments in the land, sea and air battles of this war have shown that the enemy still has a technical lead in certain types of equipment.

The New Friends of Music gave their opening concert of the season with a program devoted entirely to Beethoven yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The advance announcement of this event had been coupled with the news that all the seats for this series of sixteen concerts of Beethoven's chamber-music and songs had been sold by subscription, and that there would only be standing room for additional customers!

The American Viscose Corporation, in its financial statement released today, reports a net profit, including the post-war credit in respect to the Federal excess profits tax, of $5,099,747 for the nine months, ended Sept. 30. After dividend requirements on the preferrd stock, this is equal to $2.43 a common share and compares with $5,040,428 or $2.39 a share of common stock for the corresponding period of last year.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 -- A post-war synthetic rubber industry able to maintain itself without tariff protection was forecast by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, in a talk today before the Economic Club of Detroit.

Approximately four out of every ten companies supplying information to a survey by the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board are planning total reconversion of war plants and war production facilities to the output of peacetime goods following the war, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The draft agreement for the establishment of a United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, as revised to meet criticisms raised in the Senate and among some of the smaller nations, will be signed by representatives of forty-four united and associated nations at a ceremony in the East Room of the White House tomorrow noon.
A.H. Feibel, president of the Kelley-Koett Company, Covington, Ky., has been elected chairman for 1944 of the X-ray section of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Anticipating a high scoring game between two weak defensive teams, Coach Harry Mahnken of Princeton and his aides today began preparations for Saturday's meeting with Yale by sending the Tigers through an intensive drill on the passing and ground attacks.

Dates for eight indoor track meets for the coming season were announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary of the National Amateur Athletic Union. Five of the competitions will be held in New York with Chicago, Cleveland and Boston each listed to play host to one.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie warned tonight that the danger that lay ahead was that the "regimentation" which the American people had accepted as a wartime necessity would survive victory.

Albany will be the scene today of the first auction of books and manuscripts through purchase of war bonds to be held in upper New York State. The auction in Albany, and a second sale tomorrow in Schenectady, are sponsored by the Books and Authors War Bond Committee.

A return of prohibition without benefit of legislation, with its opportunity for the bootlegger, rumrunner and gangster of the pre-repeal era to resume business at the same old stand, was visualized yesterday by the heads of New York and New Jersey State liquor enforcement agencies as one of the real dangers of mounting excise taxes and dwindling liquor stocks.

"I'll Take the High Road" and "Goodbye Again" will try their luck on Broadway this evening. The first is a new play and the other a stock reproduction of a comedy hit. Since tradition calls for a premiere to take precedence over a revival, the following data concern "I'll Take the High Road," which is being guided into the Ritz by Clifford Hayman and Milton Berle:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today to rule on the constitutionality of wartime price-fixing regulations, pillar of the Government's stabilization program.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Trustees of Midland United Company and Midland Utilities Company, which have been undergoing reorganization since 1934, announced today a joint reorganization plan for the two companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The fifteen non-operating railroad unions quickly rejected today recommendations of a special emergency board that the hourly wages of their 1,100,000 members be increased 4 to 10 cents an hour. The unions contended that the board had so distributed the increases that its program was unworkable and would destroy the wage structure built up in the last forty years.

Heretofore, the Treasury has issued its calls, or notifications of withdrawals from war loan accounts in commercial banks, on a weekly basis, so far as the larger banks were concerned. For example, calls might be made, effective the first two or three days of the week, or the last two or three days, skipping a day whenever a holiday intervened.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Senate and House conferees, meeting to adjust differences in the father draft bills, ran into a deadlock today which threatened to delay further, if not prevent, the completion of that legislation. After "agreeing to disagree," it was explained, the conferees adjourned without arranging for new meetings.

An 18-year-old American girl, Patrice Munsel, who is scheduled to make her debut as a coloratura soprano at the Metropolitan Opera this season, signed yesterday a contract in which she was guaranteed a minimum of $120,000 for concert appearances during the next three years.

Borrowing by members of the New York Stock Exchange on collateral other than Government obligations dropped slightly last month from $501,406,030 to $500,856,094. The decline in the aggregate market value of listed stocks of $533,410,149 and of the average price for each share from $32.82 to $32.44 had no perceptible effect on borrowings.

"The Battle of Russia," fifth in the series of orientation films produced for the Army by Lieut. Col. Frank Capra and recently released for public showing, will have its local premiere at the Globe Theatre on Saturday. Twentieth Century-Fox is distributing the full-length documentary for the motion-picture industry's War Activities Committee.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Exactly one year after the Allies' landings in French North Africa there are abundant indications here that Britain and northwest Europe are now the primary military theatre in the west, in which the United States and Britain hope to reach a decision within the next year.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Because of the urgent need for substitute teachers, eligibility requirements for a series of license examinations to be held next month will be relaxed, the Board of Examiners of the Board of Education announced yesterday. The tests will be open to candidates seeking licenses as substitute teachers of common branches in the elementary schools, of seven high school general subjects and five high school special subjects.

Georgie Kochan, 164 3/4, Akron, outpointed Vic Dellicurti, 160 1/2, Harlem, in an eight-round bout that featured Mike Jacobs' opening card of the season at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A capacity crowd of 4,000 witnessed the program.

Pre-induction psychological examination of men called to the armed services of the United States in order to eliminate the emotionally unfit is "far ahead of anything we have in England," declared Brig. John R. Rees, consulting psychiatrist of the British Army, yesterday after an inspection of the induction center at Grand Central Palace.

After having recovered sharply in the early dealings yesterday, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange in the late trading broke to new seasonal lows except in the December position. Continued unsettlement in the grain and securities markets was a factor in the decline.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 3, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Decreases of $221,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills and $569,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $150,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- On the twentieth anniversary of the National Socialist revolution -- and on the eve of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the German armistice parleys in World War I Adolf Hitler once again foregathered with the faithful in the Loewenbrau beer cellar in Munich, tonight.

Wendell L. Willkie marked the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Soviet Union last night in an address to the people of Great Britain over the British Broadcasting System in which he recalled some impressions of his visit to Russia.

Seven candidates in Queens and four in Brooklyn were eliminated yesterday from the City Council race as further progress was made in tabulating proportional representation votes cast in last Tuesday's election. In Manhattan, officials are ready to eliminate five candidates, one at a time, when the count is resumed today.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Despite the good war news from Russia and Premier Stalin's encouraging speech on Saturday, the stock markets here opened the week quietly today with little interesting activity in any section.

This week of anniversaries includes that of the Beer-Hall Putsch in Munich, on Nov. 8 and 9, 1923. On that famous occasion Adolf Hitler, with the doddering Ludendorff as a sort of figurehead, attempted to seize the Bavarian Government and then march on Berlin.

Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State in the Dewey administration and Republican chairman of New York County, demanded yesterday the use of radio time normally occupied by Mayor La Guardia's Sunday broadcast for the purpose of answering the Mayor's "venemous" and "vicious" attack on the Republican party in his broadcast of last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Senator Robert R. Reynolds, Democrat, of North Carolina, chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs and one of the five members of the Senate who voted against the Connally post-war peace collaboration resolution last week, stated tonight that he would not be a candidate for renomination in the primary in May.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Chester Morris has been signed by Terneen Productions, in which Pat O'Brien and Phil Ryan, his agent, are partners, for the second lead in "Pilebuck," a film in which O'Brien will be starred for Columbia.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Hog Prices declined 15 to 25 cents in a moderately active market today. Cattle prices generally were 25 cents down. Slaughter lambs were slow, steady to 15 cents or more lower.
Notre Dame has come, conquered and gone, and in its wake left a big void in football.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8 per cent last week, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The figure compared with a decline of 7 per cent in the preceding week, as compared with the like week of 1942.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8 -- "The international position of Argentina will not be altered by pressure exercised by capital or investments of any foreign country," declared Col. Juan Peron, Under-Secretary of War, who was recently appointed director of the National Labor Bureau and who is regarded as one of the most powerful influences behind the scenes in Argentina.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Freezing weather and snowstorms which in some areas reached blizzard proportions gripped the Middle West today. Highways were blocked, bus and train schedules were disrupted and some schools were closed.

Steel production in the United States in October set a new high record of 7,786,359 net tons, despite an estimated drop of 40,000 tons owing to the fourth coal strike of the year late in the month. The new figure is an increase of 115,000 tons over the previous peak of 7,670,187 tons in March, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- Taking the lead in the campaign of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to scrap the "Little Steel" formula and return wage increases to a basis of collective bargaining, the United Steel Workers of America adopted today a time-table for action which, if followed through, will see the union locked with management in little more than a month on the issue of additional pay for 600,000 members.

Hugh S.
