Robertson, executive manager of Rockefeller Center, announced yesterday signing of a renegotiated contract with American Federation of Labor unions under which 1,245 employes would receive pay increases. The new wage agreement revised the existing contract, which will not expire until the end of 1946.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Summer homes of film stars at Malibu Beach were directly in the path of flames tonight as changing winds whipped fires burning on scores of southern California fronts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Sixty executives of oil-trade associations from all parts of the country, in conclave here, emerged today with the declaration that they had decided it was high time they furnished the public with oil information as well as with oil.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have killed thousands of Japanese in fighting in the "rice bowl" area of central China, the High Command announced tonight, but other enemy troops have made gains in a new drive toward the Yangtze River gorge barring the road to Chungking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today ordered the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, Newark, N.J., to show cause why it should not reduce its plant accounts by $67,893,724.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 9 -- Driving through crumbling German defenses along an eighty-mile front, three Red Army columns have advanced to points forty-five miles beyond Kiev and within 140 miles of the Rumanian border, threatening the last north-south Ukrainian railroad still in German hands, Moscow announced today.

With more than 100 applications, the rush of candidates for the top job of the Office of price Administration in New York City -- Regional OPA Director at an annual salary of $8,000 -- came to an end yesterday. The local branch office of the United States Civil Service Commission threw out many applications but certified quite a few and sent the list to the office of the Civil Service Commissioner in Washington.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Miss Ella Widener's Iron Shot, the longest shot in a field of six jumpers, won the twenty-third running of the $7,500 added Manly Steeple-chase Handicap before a crowd of 9,000 at Pimlico today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Increased emphasis on the proper psychological approach to war casualties is indicated by the appointment of Mrs. Winifred Kahmann as superintendent of occupational therapy in the reconditioning division of professional services, the Office of the Surgeon General of the Army.

Still wearing lieutenant's bars on her Canadian WAC uniform, although she is only a private, Miss Betty Trimble, 19 years old, was permitted to plead guilty to petit larceny yesterday in General Sessions on a second-degree grand larceny indictment for recent thefts of $1,000 in jewelry and money from service women at the Military Service Club, at Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- Constantine A. Oumansky, Soviet Ambassador here, said today that Germany was on the verge of defeat because of the Soviet military victories and the material contributions as well as the military operations in other fronts of the United States and Britain.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Yale's board of strategy, consisting of Howie Odell, Charley Caldwell and Jud Timm, was deep in hieroglyphics today when a visitor dropped into the Lapham Field House. The blackboard was covered with chalk marks and, from all indications, the X's were taking a terrible lacing from the O's, as Odell did the talking and his two aides the listening.

A telegraphic request to the Office of Price Administration asking that the new price regulation for the fur industry not be promulgated until members could personally present their objections to it was made yesterday by the National Federation of the Fur Industry.

An audience of 20,000 that filled Madison Square Garden at a mass meeting last night in celebration of the tenth anniversary of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Soviet Union cheered when Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes declared that "the fate of civilization, and the lives and well-being of future generations, depend on the relations between the United States and the Soviet Union."
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 8 -- German treatment of Russian prisoners of war was described by an RAF fighter pilot just repatriated from the Reich as "not brutality but assassination."

At a meeting at which speakers forecast the continuation of civilian defense organizations after the war as local clearing houses and agencies for volunteers, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, declared last night that New York City departments would have to draw increasingly on volunteers as the draft depleted city personnel.

Nathan F. Spier, 29 years old, and his brother, I. Martin Spier, 27, both of 172 Beach 127th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny charges before Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel. Their bail of $5,000, each was continued for sentencing later.

The combined net earnings of utility properties in the North American Company system are no higher now than in the pre-war period despite the fact that their volume of business in kilowatt-hour sales is running 81 per cent higher, Edward L. Shea, president, declared yesterday in his quarterly report to stockholders.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- All but fifteen of the 315 acres of the built-up area of the city of Kassel, which with the devastation of the Ruhr had become one of Germany's most important industrial centers, were laid waste by the Royal Air Force attack the night of Oct. 22 and a seven-day fire that followed, the Air Ministry said today after study of reconnaissance photographs.

MOSCOW, Nov. 8 -- It was announced today that the "obstacles" to conclusion of a Soviet-Czechoslovak twenty-year treaty of mutual assistance and friendship had now been removed and that President Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile, was expected here shortly to sign it.

The Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit in the first nine months of this year of $10,604,752, after deducting $4,681,335 provision for Federal normal income tax and surtax, according to the report issued yesterday. No provision was made for Federal excess profits taxes.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 8 -- Dr. Francis E. McMahon, Associate Professor of Philosophy at the University of Notre Dame for ten years, was out of his job tonight in a dispute with university officials over speeches which he has been delivering on world problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Navy announced 140 casualties today, including seventeen men from New York of whom three are listed as dead. New Jersey has nine on the list and Connecticut three. Their names with next of kin follow:
A BRITISH PORT, Nov. 8 -Probably the oddest transport that ever crossed the Atlantic Ocean steamed into port here recently from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- In a reversal of its previous decision the Ways and Means Committee of the House today changed the rate on liquor in the new tax bill from $8 a gallon to $10.

ALGIERS, Nov. 8 -- To those prone to think of the Mediterranean campaign as primarily a triumph of Allied land and air forces, a summary of statistics made available today in connection with the anniversary of the first North African landings makes clear the constant role that the combined navies have played.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Elimination of expensive screen-printing on apparel fabrics costing such processors less than 27 1/2 cents a yard was announced yesterday by the Office of Price Administration as the first step in its program to safeguard the supply of textiles required to produce garments for low-income wage-earners.
The women's division of the New York Committee of the National War Fund received high praise yesterday at its "half-way" meeting from former Governor Alfred E. Smith.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Anglo-Turkish talks did not end in Cairo yesterday, as the communique had indicated.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company reported tonight that a flareup of violence delayed the scheduled return of 4,000 striking foundry workers to their jobs in its Rouge plant today, but that production was resumed with the afternoon shift.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Cross-Channel air warfare continued on a small scale today, while rescue squads toiled through the debris of Britain's worst bombing episode in a year, the smashing of a crowded suburban London dance hall and two taverns by a single Nazi bomb.

A more extensive use of "intermediate rubber-plastics," materials which combine the best features of synthetic rubbers and synthetic plastics, in the place of rubber was predicted yesterday by Dr. R. P. Dinsmore, vice president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Heels, soles, flooring and industrial molded goods, he added, are among the kinds of articles which first may be affected by the change.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Since their withdrawal from the eastern front, where they fought against the Russians, all members of the Spanish volunteer Blue Division have received a letter from Generalissimo Francisco Franco expressing the wish that they join the German Army, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- To Anthony Cramer, naturalized German convicted a year ago of treason because of aid to one of eight Nazi saboteurs, was promised a review of his case by the Supreme Court today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 8 -- The British Eighth Army increased its pace yesterday in curling back the German Adriatic flank and driving ahead to the Sangro River. It took at least five more towns and, at Casalbordino, it was within five miles of the next major water barrier.
The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 890-98 West End Avenue, southeast corner of 104th Street, has been sold by Realty Associates, Inc., to Rosenfeld Herring, operators.

Dr. Nathan Goldman, representative of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in a talk last night before the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, in convention at the Hotel Henry Hudson, charged appeasement of Arab Extremists by the British Government.

HILLSDALE, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Lieut. Col. Francis Ackerman Hill, 24 years old, who enlisted in the Army Air Corps in 1939 as a private, made a flying visit to his parents here yesterday but had to return this morning to his new base at Atlantic City for orders.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Alfred de Marigny's chief alibi witness ran afoul a prosecutor armed with a surprise document today and found himself in red-faced confusion before he finished his story of his close friend's activities on the night Sir Harry Oakes was slain last July.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The War Department made public today the names of 148 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Japan is paying a terrific price to hold Rabaul, anchor of her entire South Pacific position, and the showdown battle is yet to come.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Wide scale war activities of the National Council of Jewish Women, ranging from bond and stamp selling to plans for rehabilitating the men returning with physical handicaps from the battlefronts, were brought into focus today at the organization's triennial convention.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Weakness in securities and announcement that the business conduct committee of the Board of Trade and the War Food Administration had started a joint investigation of the situation prevailing in December rye led today to lower grain prices on the Board of Trade.

TULE LAKE, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Testimony that shots were fired, without any resulting fatalities, during events at the Tule Lake Japanese segregation camp Thursday night when the Army was called to control threatening internees was given to a State investigating committee today.

As evidence of its confidence in the continuation of the Wall Street area as the financial center of the city, the Bankers Trust Company has purchased the plot on which is situated its thirty-story building at the northwest corner of Nassauand Wall Streets, from the Sampson estate.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8 -- All provincial and municipal employes in the Province of Mendoza who do not approve of the neutrality policy followed by the central Government will immediately be dismissed, according to an order issued by the Federal Commissioner in charge of that Province.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 8 -- Thousands of American, British and Indian war prisoners Who escaped after the Italian armistice are making their way southward from Rome to meet the Allied armies as they near the capital. They are part of the "ghost army" that is adding immeasurably to German problems in occupied Italy.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 8 -Expansion in the field of teaching public health holds the answer to continued development of preventive medicine on a comprehensive basis, according to views expressed at today's sessions of the Inter-American Conference of Schools of Public Health, meeting at the University of Michigan.

Tradition took some peculiar jolts yesterday when the National Hotel Exposition, making its twenty-eighth annual appearance, opened for the first time in a hotel, accompanied by the seventy-fifth Salon of Culinary Art, which, also for the first time, was entirely devoid of food.
Notre Dame still dominated the New York football picture yesterday, almost forty-eight hours after the triumph over Army at the Yankee Stadium.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8 -- Twelve Mexican bankers and financial lawyers representing eight of Mexico's largest financial institutions attended here today opening sessions of a three-day seminar on United States trust practices sponsored by the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis.

TORONTO, Nov. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Laboring under the bearish influence of the Wall Street market, stocks slipped off easily today on the Toronto exchange and losses in points were scattered among the leaders at the close. Industrials led the decline with a drop of 1.98 in the index while the base metal stocks weakened 1.41, the golds .93 and the Western oils .31.

Louis H. Pink, president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York and former State Superintendent of Insurance, was sworn in yesterday as director of the New York Defense Rental Area at the regional Office of Price Administration offices in the Empire State Building.

Figures compiled in connection with a dispatch from Washington in THE TIMES of Nov. 4 under the heading, "Madrid Resumes Gestures to Axis," in which the debt of Falangist Spain to Fascist Italy for munitions and materials supplied during the so-called Spanish civil war is mentioned, may be of interest at this time.
Three sailors and a shipyard worker were overcome by smoke in the boiler room of a freigter undergoing repairs at Mariners Harbor, Staten Island, yesterday, but were dragged to safety by the crew.

PETE CAWTHON arrived, wearing a smile as wide as the State of Texas. "Boy, it was nice to win yesterday," he drawled. "That was the longest drought I've experienced since the last time I was in the dust bowl."

The fall of Kiev marks the end of the Battle of the Dnieper and the beginning of the Battle of the Western Ukraine. It is now apparent that while the Russians were forcing their salient across the river from Kremenchug, and diverting German strength toward Krivoi Rog, General Vatutin was building up an army to throw at Kiev.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a Cities Service Power and Light Company plan to donate to Ohio Public Service Company all the outstanding capital stock of the Alliance (Ohio) Public Service Company.

A new high quarterly record for all time was established during the third quarter of 1943 in the production of rayon filament yarn in the United States, it was announced yesterday by The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov., 9 -- Sixty-three more Japanese planes were destroyed as Allied airmen struck far and wide at enemy shipping, bases and airfields in the Southwest Pacific, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today.
Notre Dame headed every ballot cast in this week's Associated Press football poll to determine the ten leading teams in the country -- the first time any eleven ever received unanimous approval.

The current advertising campaigns by certain apparel manufacturers stressing the importance of brand names as such are soon to be extended to the drug field and later perhaps to nationally advertised products generally, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The War Production Board announced today that it is discontinuing its redistribution activities at the Steel Recovery Corporation, and transferring the corporation's records to WPB regional offices. The move is being made in line with the agency's program of decentralization, it was added.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Killing frost during October in North Carolina, Tennessee, Missouri and Texas caused some reduction in cotton production, the Agriculture Department said today in announcing an estimated 1943 crop for the country of 11,442,000 bales. This is a drop of 36,000 from the Oct. 1 estimate.
Nothwithstanding the absence of tournament golf this year, the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association held its annual meeting at the Biltmore yesterday.

Spiral Pass, speedy filly who carries the colors of Mrs. E.D. Shaffer, raced in front from start to finish in yesterday's feature at Jamaica, named in honor of the Waves, the feminine branch of the Navy.

Tonight's events: Concert by Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists, soloists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; recital by E. Robert Schmitz, pianist, Times Hall, 9; by La Julia Rhea, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30.

Referring to the letter published in THE TIMES of Nov. 7 under the title "Napoleon: A Precedent," I would like to say why I think that the association of the names of Napoleon and Hitler which occurs often in the American press may create a dangerous misunderstanding in the minds of the readers who have no extensive knowledge of European history.
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The majority of food manufacturers barely have sensed the merchandising potentialities of their packages under modern conditions of self-service operation, L.A. Johnson, operator of a chain of super-markets in up-State New York, asserted yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Eight Democrats of the House Banking and Currency Committee, assailing majority approval of anti-subsidy legislation, contended tonight that subsidies were the sole hope for keeping a tight lid on living costs while still encouraging vital food production.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Following is an abridged text of Adolf Hitler's speech at Munich on the twentieth anniversary of the Munich beer hall putsch, broadcast by the official German news agency DNB and recorded here:

The principal varieties of winter pears now on hand in city markets number the Bosc, Comice and Anjou, a representative of the Oregon-Washington-California Pear Bureau reported yesterday. He said that of these the most plentiful is the Bosc -- a fruit with a long tapering neck, rich cinnamon-brown hue and flesh sweet in flavor and in butter-like in texture.

Daniel Lewis, 83-year-old dog lover, obtained four more days in the Bowery Court yesterday in which to get rid of a kennel of dogs he has been housing in an abandoned tenement at Canal and Ludlow Streets. Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate denied the motion of a woman sympathizer and five lawyers, enlisted in Lewis' cause, to permit him to withdraw his previous guilty plea and reopen the case.

The general health of civilian's feet, in the opinion of Dr. Maurice J. Lewis, president of Long Island College's first institute of podiatry and of the foot clinics of New York, has become "decidedly worse since Pearl Harbor."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 8 -- Advices received here from Austria indicate the existence of two political tendencies there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Charges that the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company controls a large part of the country's food markets through monopolistic practices will go to trial as a result of a Supreme Court order today, denying review of the indictment.
Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw have returned from California and are at the Savoy-Plaza.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Stanley Mocarsky, 23, a Hartford arms plant worker who was invited several weeks ago by a Federal district judge to leave the country or face jail for refusal to be inducted into the armed forces, was sentenced today to two years in the Federal Correctional Institution at Danbury.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Increased purchasing power, creating a demand for higher-priced garments, is causing a slowdown in the cheaper-dress industry, the executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union of the American Federation of Labor was told today by David Dubinsky, president.

Patrolman Jacob Lehrer, attached to Motorcycle Squad 2, Brooklyn, was arrested on a charge of extortion at the Vandeveer Park precinct station last night. The arrest came after Deputy Chief Inspector Michael J. Murphy had investigated the payment of $20 in marked bills by an alleged speed-law violator in front of the Marine Theatre, Flatbush Avenue and Kings Highway, Brooklyn, last Saturday night.

It is axiomatic that a young artist is disposed in early stages to be a reflection of a teacher. This was suggested yesterday afternoon when Constance Keene, pianist and winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Prize, gave the recital in Town Hall to which that award entitles her.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- During the first nine months of this year United States exports amounted in value to $9,197,000,000, exceeding by 14 per cent last year's full-year total of $8,036,000,000, according to the Census Bureau, Department of Commerce.

Somewhat burdensome stocks of seasonal garments, particularly women's coats, which retailers have [been carrying as the result of the unexpectedly large shipments earlier this fall, have been steadily whittled down by active consumer demand, and inventories of most merchants now are well in hand, reports here yesterday indicated.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Nov. 8 -- Crash boats developed by the First Air Force of the Army are credited with having saved the lives of many pilots and crew members forced down in near-by waters, it was disclosed here today with the announcement that eleven such craft were operating out of this command.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The showing of women's, men's and boys' spring apparel opened in Chicago today with shortages of practically everything except all-wool garments, the outstanding feature. As a medium for creating a turnover of goods the market was "only fair."

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Five American boys, who pledged to sell their lives at a premium if their bomber was hit over Rabaul, kept their word by sinking a Japanese destroyer and then running their Mitchell almost down the guns of a cruiser before they died.

AT A UNITED STATES ADVANCED BASE IN SOUTHERN CHINA, Nov. 6 (Delayed) -- Although the United States Fourteenth Air Force is much too small for the job it has to do, it already feels expansionist. With an eye to the future it is working eastward, making ready for the great day when it can bomb Japan regularly.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Thomas N. McCarter, chairman of the board of Public Service Electric and Gas Company, said today the company would contest efforts of the Federal Power Commission and the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission to make extensive reductions in its book value.

NAPLES, Nov. 5 (Delayed) (AP) -- King Victor Emmanuel chatted for more than an hour today with Col. Edgar Hume of Frankfort, Ky., chief Allied Military Government officer of the Naples district, who said that "not one word of politics" had been discussed during the interview.

The more closely the Senate vote on the Connally resolution and the House vote on the Fulbright resolution are considered, the more impressive becomes the evidence that after all the great disputes and the bitter legislative battles of the last decade something like a virtual unanimity of Congressional opinion on the essentials of American foreign policy has at last been achieved.
Columbia's football team began preparations at Baker Field yesterday for its meeting with Navy on Saturday with a contact drill and scrimmage.
ALGIERS, Nov. 8 -- The French Committee of National Liberation will soon be altered to include probably three representatives of resistance within France.

Stockholders of the Dow Chemical Company, meeting yesterday in Midland, Mich., approved a pro-new $4 cumulative dividend Series A preferred stock to holders of common stock at $105 a share, in the ratio of one share for each five common shares held on Nov. 10.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 8 -- Blunt-speaking Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, commander in chief of the Allied Middle East operations, tonight warned all Yugoslav Chetniks who were collaborating with the Germans against patriotic Yugoslav elements that they must immediately desert the Nazi cause or henceforth be regarded as traitors.
Bob Steuber of little DePaw College at Greencastle, Ind., took a firmer grip on first place in the nation's high-scoring football competition last week by tallying 29 points against Fort Knox.

A general's wife started an "invasion" of her own yesterday. Exactly a year from the day when Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. led the first American landing on Morocco's west coast, his wife, Beatrice, took up words as a weapon of war.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. and a Mexican financial group headed by the Banco Nacional de Mexico announced yesterday formation of Inversiones Latinas, S.A. (Inverlat), to invest in Mexican enterprises and to foster trade relations between Mexico and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The War Department announced today the names of 173 United States soldiers listed as missing in action on three fighting fronts, the European, Mediterranean and Southwest Pacific.

No less deplorable than the final decisions in recent labor disputes have been the methods (or lack of method) by which they have been reached. Virtually every rule of sound organization or sound administrative procedure has been violated.

ALBANY, Nov. 8 -- Expressing concern over the necessity for rejecting a substantial number of applications under the program for maternity care for wives of men in service, the State Health Department issued a statement today, designed to clear up misunderstandings on the part of patients and some physicians regarding services for which the department is authorized to pay.

An enthusiastic audience last night heard Michael Zadora, pianist, who first appeared here as a boy prodigy in 1890, in his first Town Hall recital in two years. He played an exacting program with a brilliance of technique, a beauty of tone and a poetic charm in interpretation that, while marred by certain temperamental idiosyncracies, nevertheless resulted, if not in an evening of great art, at least in one of unusually fine piano-playing.

In the report of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York for 1942 the common impression that war increases crime is strikingly contradicted by the facts. For the year ending June 30, 1938, the city crime rate was 957 per 100,000. The next year it was 1,042.

The apartment house containing sixty-seven suites at 3175 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been sold by the Concourse-Williams, Inc., represented by William L. Rosan, attorney, to the Concourse-Rukas, Inc.

Reassured by the news that Frank Cope, star tackle, and Bill Paschal, rookie fullback, both will be available, Coach Steve Owen of the Giants will start today on a week of intensive preparations for his team's battle with the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Seventeen more industrial plants have won the Army-Navy Production Award for high achievement in the production of war materials. They are:

Despite the war's inroads on its manpower, the National Orchestral Association proceeds with its task of training young musicians in orchestral routine and repertory. As it opened its new season at Carnegie Hall last night it was clear that it would have to depend increasingly on woman power.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that the Little Steel wage limitation formula is in danger because of failure to stabilize the cost of living.

Lewisohn Stadium will be the scene of New York's "revenge" battle of the 1943 football season on Saturday when City College and Brooklyn College clash again. The Beavers beat the Kingsmen, 22 -- 6, earlier in the season at the Brooklyn field.

It is not really as self-evident a truth as some people would have you believe. They view with alarm certain undesirable conditions here at home and say that if we don't look out, "What happened in Germany could easily happen here."

FORT KNOX, Ky., Oct. 30 (Delayed -- The armored divisions of the United States Army, which are now numbered in two figures, have recently been reorganized as a result of the tactical lessons of North Africa.

Assistance Fund, Inc., 60 Beaver Street, receives a bequest of $1,000,000 under the will of Aaron E. Norman, industrialist and philanthropist, who died on July 1, 1936, leaving a gross estate of $3,862,645 and a net of $3,603,663, according to a transfer tax proceeding approved yesterday by Deputy Tax Commissioner Louis J. Lefkowitz.

An electrical gun director, characterized by Maj. Gen. Levin H. Campbell, Army Chief of Ordnance, as representing "one of the greatest advances in fire control made during this war," was demonstrated publicly yesterday at the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- China-based American fliers have sunk a 250-foot Japanese destroyer and four other vessels and shot up several enemy planes in the past forty-eight hours, it was announced today, as Chinese forces held their ground against the invaders in the Hupeh-Hunan border area south of the Yangtze River.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The forty-four signers at the White House today of the agreement establishing the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration were listed as follows:

ALBANY, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Vitamin inoculations and liquid nourishment kept a mongrel dog alive tonight, while its master hurried from an Army camp in Missouri for a last reunion with the 17-year-old grief-stricken animal.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in South Pacific, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Hundreds of Japanese landed from barges four to seven miles northwest of the United States Marine beachhead on Bougainville and sharp fighting is in progress there, Admiral William F. Halsey's headquarters said today.
ALGIERS, Nov. 9 -- A communique:

COL. CARLOS P. ROMULO, Philippine editor, publisher and Fulitzer Prize winner, member of General MacArthur's staff and "last man off Bataan," author of the sadly moving "I Saw the Fall of the Philippines," describes himself as an Americanized Oriental. As such he occupies a peculiarly advantageous position from which to act as an informed and reasonably impartial interpreter of Occident and Orient one to the other.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary N. Knieriem's Red Wrack closed fast on the inside today to nip the favored Mixer from the stable of Mrs. Wallace Renard in a photo finish in the Seabrook Purse at Rockingham Park.

With the Polo Grounds bearing a close resemblance to the St. George's pool, minus a roof, as a result of "local disturbances" of the past few days, Coach Steve Owen devoted two hours yesterday morning to telling Bear stories.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Creation of a bi-partisan joint committee to recommend ways to streamline the work of Congress and promote improved relationships with other branches of the Government is proposed in resolutions introduced simultaneously in the Senate and House today by Senator Francis Maloney, Democrat of Connecticut, and Representative A.S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma.

George Norris of Nebraska is no longer a member of the United States Senate, but as a respected elder statesman his word carries weight. Twenty-four years ago he was one of those Senators who voted against the Treaty of Versailles. Now he heartily approves the passage of the amended Connally resolution.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The stock markets here experienced today a general depression, and rumors of peace talks which caused the decline on Wall Street yesterday prompted a wave of light selling.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Northwestern's Wildcats, back in stride after a faltering start, will be at the peak of their power against Notre Dame Saturday.

Mayor La Guardia, returning last night from Montreal, denied that his radio address last Sunday, blaming the Republicans for the election of Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court, was a political utterance, but declined to say directly whether Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader, would receive the time he has demanded from station WNYC to make an answer.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., making his first public address since returning from the war front, will be the principal speaker at the annual dinner of the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Commodore Nov. 18, it was announced yesterday by Paul B. West, president of ANA.

The Graham-Paige Motors Corporation reported yesterday in its operating statement for the nine months ended with September a net profit of $1,007,434, equal to 23 cents a common share, after quarterly dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock.

NAPLES, Nov. 8 (delayed) -- Behind the brief German official announcement that the art treasures of the Benedictine Abbey of Monte Cassino had been transferred to "a safe place" lies one of the greatest potential tragedies in the history of art.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Prime Minister Churchill summoned the young manhood of Britain and the United States to fall upon their deadly foes across the English Channel in the climactic year of 1944, adding the solemn warning that great campaigns of that year would entail "the greatest sacrifices" of the war to both armies.

Deputy Police Inspector Hugo O. Wunsche, head of the Motorcycle Division since July 1, 1936, has been shifted to the Tenth Division, Bath Avenue and Bay Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, and Captain John T. Keudell, in charge of the Grand Central Parkway Motorcycle Division, has been placed in charge of motorcycle police, Police Headquarters announced yesterday.

One was the paean of the victor and the other the dirge of the vanquished facing one another across the widest and hardest-fought battle line in the history of war.

An evening of music that was cool and clear and that did not sigh or exult excessively was presented at the Times Hall last night by E. Robert Schmitz. The pianist played French music, and being French himself he gave it what was its due. He played with coolness and clarity and with a sure knowledge of the Gallic touch and style.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad awarded today, subject to Interstate Commerce Commission approval, a $2,025,000 issue of 1943 special equipment trust certificates to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., of Chicago, on what was announced as their high bid of 99.39 for 2 1/8 per cent obligations, an interest cost basis to the railroad of approximately 2.21 per cent.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 -- A gauge for measuring the mental fitness of individuals and of nations was presented today to the Tenth Institute on the Exceptional Child by Dr. George H. Preston, Maryland Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A Chinese communique:
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 10 -Red Army shock troops captured more than eighty northern Ukraine towns and villages yesterday and battled to within fifty-eight miles of the key rail city of Korosten to increase their threat to trap or force back to Rumania the depleted German divisions still hanging on in the great bend of the Dnieper River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. (AP) -- A formula for recomposition and nationalization of Egypt's public debt was outlined today by the Egyptian Legation, which said that "many, if not the majority, of these bondholders are now residents of the United States."

Prince Faisal, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, and his brother, Prince Khalid, who have been visiting the United States on the invitation of President Roosevelt, gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the West Foyer of the Waldorf-Astoria. Among the 500 guests were many prominent citizens as well as Government officials and representatives of foreign countries.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Japanese barges that landed several hundred troops with supplies early Sunday north of the United States Marine beachhead at Empress Augusta Bay possibly made the southward run from Buka Island, on Bougainville's northern tip, under protection of a heavy cruiser and two destroyers.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Recent anti-Semitic disturbances in the Roxbury and Mattapan sections of Boston "would not have been possible" if police assigned to those areas performed their duties conscientiously, John F. Stokes, Public Safety Commissioner, told Governor Saltonstall and his advisory committee on anti-racial activities in a report made public today.

Linwood I. Noyes, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, announced yesterday that the country's newspapers have agreed to a request received in a telegram from Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, to sponsor and engage in a waste paper collection campaign.

LONDON, Nov. (AP) -- Strong German forces are seeking to bottle up the Yugoslav army of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch in western Serbia, his headquarters reported tonight as the Russian advance toward the Rumanian border heightened tension in the Balkans.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9 -- A Ministry of Press and Information, designed to control all sources of public information and directly responsible to President Pedro P. Ramiriz, was established today. The new Ministry will be required to see that the "press, broadcasting stations, social and political literature, theatres, movies and public performances in general develop their activities in accordance with the intentions enunciated by the Executive power."

American industry is making rapid progress with preliminary details of plans designed to assure post-war opportunities and jobs for returning service men, C. Scott Fletcher, director of field development, Committee for Economic Development, declared yesterday at the luncheon of the Sales Executives Club in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Establishment of a Presidential commission to plan immediate action for relieving the plight of Europe's persecuted Jews was proposed today in identical resolutions introduced in the Senate and House with the active backing of ten Senators and two Representatives.

A jury in Brooklyn Federal Court took thirty-five minutes yesterday to acquit Charles William Francis Scott, 47 years old, of the Franklin Arms Hotel, Jamaica, Queens, of a charge of representing himself as an Army colonel with the intention to defraud. Scott explained on the witness stand that he had been a cadet in the Royal Air Force and that some of his friends addressed him as "Colonel."

October saw sharp revisions in short positions in several stocks on the New York Stock Exchange although the aggregate short interest changed little, dropping from 761,827 shares at the end of September to 729,291 at the end of October.

Tabulation of the proportional representation vote for City Councilmen was completed last night in Manhattan and Queens. The Brooklyn count, which was suspended at 6:30 o clock, is to be completed today, terminating the canvass for the city. The Bronx and Richmond completed their counts last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- The Office of War Information announced today establishment of a free advertising service to newspapers designed to help them "sell" the Government's essential war programs, such as food, stabilization and bonds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Legislation to restore to the radio the freedom of which it was deprived by the Supreme Court's decision in the chain broadcasting case was advocated by William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, at today's hearing before the Interstate Commerce Committee of the Senate on the Wheeler-White Radio bill.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Grains showed an easy undertone early, liquidation by holders of December rye affecting other markets, but the selling movement ran its course and later when Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address at the Lord Mayor's dinner in London indicated that there was little prospect of an early peace in Europe, short covering developed and prices advanced rapidly and the market closed at the top.
Following is the text of an address made by Prime Minister Churchill yesterday at the Lord Mayor's luncheon in London and transcribed from a radio broadcast by The United Press in New York:

The Tom Moore Distilling Company of Baltimore, Md., whose shares, which are listed on the Baltimore Stock Exchange, have catapulted in market value from $70 to $16C a share in ten days, declared on Monday a dividend of twenty-seven gallons of whisky for each share of $25 par stock payable Dec. 1 to holders of record on Nov. 24, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Supplies of rationed goods in 1944 are likely to be tighter than they were this year, Col. Bryan Houston, new deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administrator in charge of rationing, said today at his press conference.

CAIRO, Nov. 9 -- The present political crisis in Lebanon raises not only the question of France's rights and privileges in the Levant but the whole subject of the relationship between Middle East countries mandated by tile League of Nations and the European countries under whose control they were placed.

Possible tie-up of the $200,000, 000 popular-price dress industry because of the growing shortage of low-price dress fabrics has been averted by the contemplated OPA revision of MPR 127, Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers, declared yesterday at a special meeting of the organization at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- While camera men ground out pictures in the glare of spotlights President Roosevelt and forty-three other distinguished representatives of the united and associated nations signed an agreement at the White House this noon creat ing the United Nations Relief Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) as the first United Nations operating agency for political and socio-economic affairs in the immediate war and post-war period.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- A tentative effort to have the security regulations modified so that more war news would be made available to the public here and in the United States was crushed in the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Churchill.

Sixteen college basketball double-headers, two fewer than last season, will be presented at Madison Square Garden during the forthcoming court campaign, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon at Toots Shor's.

A witty and civilized comedy, "Goodbye Again," not seen in these parts since 1932, when it was a vehicle for Osgood Perkins, was revived last night on the New Amsterdam Hoof by Mary Elizabeth Sherwood, and all who found their way there had a reasonably good time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A national railroad strike will be averted and the railroads will carry out their agreement of Aug. 7 to increase the wages of their 1,100,000 nonoperating employes 8 cents an hour if Congress adopts the Truman resolution stating that the agreement is "an appropriate and valid settlement of the dispute."

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, released yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, showed a net income of $5, 291,214 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with a net of $6,519,815 in the first nine months of last year.

Here in its gracious and warming golden cover is the 152d volume of that standard treasury and encyclopedia, The Old Farmer's Almanack. Everybody on its staff "is in the armed forces or in war service." All this great mass of calculation and compilation is the fruit of evening and Sunday work.

Furs with fascinating names, and hailing from remote corners of the earth, took on the airs and graces of fine pelts yesterday morning at Saks Fifth Avenue -- and they did it at budget prices. The showing took place on the seventh floor, where the taste of the debutante is catered to especially.

Solemn ceremonies at the Eternal Light in Madison Square Park tomorrow will highlight the city's observance of Armistice Day this year, a quarter of a century after cessation of hostilities in World War I.

The New York Daily News, target with The Chicago Tribune and The Washington Times-Herald of an attack by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, replies editorially in today's issue, under the heading "Fourth Term Smear Tactics."

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The story of a never-ending fight between ingenious enemy smugglers and the dogged, persevering men handling the blockade of Europe was told today by the Minister of Economic Warfare.

The board of directors of Endicott Johnson Corporation, footwear makers and dealers of Endicott, N.Y., approved yesterday a plan providing for the exchange of each present share of 5 per cent preferred stock for one new share of 4 per cent preferred stock plus $6 in cash, in order to reduce annual dividend charges in lieu of a redemption or refinancing by the sale of other securities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- There was increasing speculation in the capital today that President Roosevelt would soon be off for his long-discussed conference with Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Premier Joseph Stalin.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9 -- William M. Emory, 42 years old, a marine engineer, was lodged in the Hudson County Jail this afternoon in default of $2,500 bail after his arraignment before United States Commissioner William J. Bartholomew on a charge of bringing into the country and disseminating written matter before it had been censored.

During the last few days, first Stalin, then Hitler and now Churchill have delivered speeches to their people. And while at this moment actions speak louder than words the speeches are still an interesting barometer of the atmosphere prevailing in the two camps, as well as a most encouraging forecast for the future.

A loan exhibition entitled "The Greek Revival in the United States" opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum. It opens to the public today and is to continue through February.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 9 -- A secret radio sender, believed to be located in Poland, broke into Adolf Hitler's Munich speech yesterday with rhymed remarks twitting the Hitler regime and predicting disaster for the German armies in Russia.

Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, immediately after the signing of an agreement creating the United Nations' Relief and Rehabilitation Administration:

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Board of Trade, for the first time in its history, had farmer representation on its governing body today when three non-members of the exchange began active participation in the deliberation of the board of directors.

All the questions asked by John Kirkland Clark in THE TIMES of Nov. 3 ("Miners' Wages Stir Inquiry") could be answered if Washington would release the facts on withholding taxes. It is not pleasant to reflect that the President and others quoted absurd figures for miners' earnings in comment on the rejected offer to the toilers, when by mere reliance upon the files of the Internal Revenue Department the exact facts would be revealed.

The stock market attempted yesterday a real recovery effort in the wake of the Monday's plunge, but the weight of "concealed" liquidation argued against anything more than a moderate upturn. Possibly as a result of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's remarks in London that the Nazis would not be defeated until 1944, the share list made a smart recovery in the first hour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A demand for an end to proposals that General Marshall or General MacArthur be drafted as Presidential candidates drew applause from both sides of the House of Representatives today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The War Department made public today the names of 124 United States soldiers listed as killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean and Southwest Pacific areas.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Harry Mahnken can understand why Frank Leahy was concerned lest his team score too early in the game against Army and regarded it as fortuitous for Notre Dame when its 64-yard drive from the opening kick-off stalled on the 2-yard line.

The most important current development in business is the switch in war agency policy from "What can we take away?" to the new program of "What can we give the civilian economy?" C.F. Hughes, business news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said last night in an address at the dinner meeting of the Infants' and Children's Wear Buyers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 -- Director J.E., carrying the colors of Mrs. Ella K. Bryson, romped to victory in the six-furlong Oden Bowie Stakes before 10,129 persons at Pimlico today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 9 -- Gen. HenriHonore Giraud has yielded to the apparently inexorable trend of French political feeling in the past four months and voluntarily retired from his position as chairman of the French Committee of National Liberation, it was officially announced today.

NAPLES, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- The formation of a regular Italian Army, drafted from units that have been operating as volunteers in the Naples area, was disclosed today in orders issued by Premier Pietro Badoglio.

Action to compel the Board of Education to abolish the practice of employing permanent substitutes in the elementary schools is being started by Theodore Fred Kuper, former $7,500 law secretary to the board, who was dismissed on Sept. 30 by the school board at the request of Mayor La Guardia.

ALGIERS, Nov. 9 -- The British Eighth Army continued to press back the German left flank yesterday and, by the capture of Torino and Paglieta, won domination of the south bank of the Sangro River for a distance of six miles from the Adriatic coast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Four-Power Declaration of Moscow, it is now definitely learned, was written in the State Department and adopted with only slight changes in the text and none in the set of principles.
Otis Skinner, actor, who died on Jan. 4, 1942, left a gross estate of $749,318 and a net of $712,851, according to a state transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

Business girls, housewives, women who have never done any kind of work, develop the "professional attitude" by the end of their first week of service as nurses' aides and do anything that must be done "without a murmur," according to the nurses' aides who has more hours to her credit than any other member of the voluntary Red Cross unit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Right Rev. Mgr. Patrick Joseph McCormick, who has been vice rector of the Catholic University of America since 1936, succeeded the late Most Rev. Joseph Moran Corrigan as rector today.

Almost constant winners of baseball pennants and world championships, the Yankees yesterday gained what might be called "a third leg" on the most valuable player prize when the third Yankee player in successive years won the award.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Lieut. Comdr. Mildred H. McAfee of the Women's Naval Reserve returned to her alma mater -- Vassar College -- today for the first time since she was commissioned to command the Waves.

The large seating capacity of the City Center, formerly Mecca Temple, will be utilized by "Marching With Johnny," opening there on Wednesday night, Dec. 29, for an engagement limited to eight weeks, it was disclosed last night. The admission scale for evening performances will range from $1.10 to $2.20 and there will be no change in prices for the premiere or New Year's Eve.

Impossible as it may seem in the light of a new day, the theatre as of last night still was up to its old tricks. Just as Broadway persuaded itself the playwrights had at last reached the bottom of their trunks, along came Lucille Prumbs with "I'll Take the High Road," land along came Clifford Hayman and Milton Berle to put it on at the Ritz.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Spanish Government denied today that its recent action in sending a congratulatory note to the puppet government of the Philippines in connection with its receiving "independence" from Japan was in any way an act of recognition of that government.

The Soviet Operational Bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission: During Nov. 9 troops of the First Ukrainian Front continued their offensive and captured a district center of Kiev Province, Borodyanka, and occupied more than eighty other inhabited localities, including the large inhabited localities. of Budyna-Beresnya, Diyatki,...

Thirty years' effort by the police to prove legally that Sam Boston 57 years old, is a gambler came to success yesterday in Special Sessions when Boston, one of the most conspicuous figures in the Broadway district, was convicted of maintaining a gambling establishment in his home at 240 Central Park South on the night of Jan. 28.

THE Baseball Writers Association recently cooperated in a poll taken by The Sporting News for the five events it considered outstanding in the game since the turn of the century. It is an interesting off-season recapitulation which was produced and, I suppose, no one can quarrel too strenuously with the first five choices.

This dispatch is written in the course of an extensive tour of the country. From questions asked by people in nearly all cities it is manifest that the recent Army regulations giving the air force tactical equality with the ground forces have caused confusion in the public mind.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The story of how United States Army planes and Coast Guard cutters scoured hundreds of miles of frozen Arctic wasteland to hunt out and destroy a secret radio and weather base established on a remote island off Greenland by a small Nazi landing party known as the "German Greenland Expedition" was revealed today by the Navy.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The offering price of $4,500,000 face amount of first mortgage sinking fund bonds to be issued by the York Corporation will be 102 1/2, it was disclosed today in amendments to the registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Business signs and posters in New York streets will often be found lingering long after time has passed them by. The exception is Fifth Avenue, where property owners have the means and the inducement to keep up to date.

Roberto Lanas Vallecilla, 35-year- old Colombian who contended that information sent to Nazis abroad was merely data culled from a newspaper and a magazine, was convicted yesterday of conspiracy to commit espionage and sentenced to ten years' imprisonment.
DETROIT. Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Robert Carl Peters wrote his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Peters, Detroit:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- French authorities have imposed a strict censorship in Lebanon as the result of an internal crisis precipitated when the Lebanon Republican Chamber of Deputies voted for full sovereignty and independence, Middle East radios reported tonight.

As the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration came into existence in Washington yesterday President Roosevelt made plain what a gigantic load it is that the forty-four signatory nations are taking on their shoulders. Comparisons with the end of the last war are not helpful.

A BASE IN NORTHEASTERN ASSAM, India Oct. 31 (Delayed) -- Now that the monsoon is over, progress has quickened on the construction of the Ledo Road that cuts into the Naga Hills from here toward the Japanese bases in northern Burma. Started last December, the road is now well on its way through the jumbled, jungle-covered mountains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, opposed before the House Elections Committee today any Presidential appointment of a Federal Election Commission to administer voting by members of the armed forces.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Berlin radio quoted Japanese dispatches today as saying that three Allied battleships, two cruisers, three destroyers and four transports had been sunk by Japanese warships and planes in attacks on a convoy south of Bougainville, beginning yesterday morning. There was no Allied confirmation of the claim.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Accusing the Office of Price Administration of refusing to act on protests against price controls, Safeway Stores, Inc., told the Supreme Court today that this was "arbitrary and capricious" treatment, and asked the court to compel OPA to act within the thirty-day limit prescribed by law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- According to a studio announcement, Paramount will reissue "The Sign of the Cross" which Cecil B. De Mille produced in 1932, with Fredric March, Claudette Colbert, Charles Laughton and Elissa Landi in the principal roles. The new release, according to plans, will carry a prologue, filmed by De Mille.

Now that the Moscow Conference is ended and a New Order -- not Hitler's -- has been agreed upon, based upon international justice, an enduring peace and respect for the sovereignty of all nations, whether great or small, I trust that a just peace for Finland is contemplated by the magnificent resolution of the conference.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The decline of prices of hogs continued today when heavyweights went down 15 to 20 cents a hundred pounds. Shipments of 45,000 hogs, of which packers bought 22.000 on direct consignment, caused the slump. Packers bought virtually everything at the lower rates, with the top price of $13.85 paid sparingly.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, declared today that freedom of individual enterprise in the post-war world was "the basic privilege" upon which other freedoms depended for existence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The President addressed delegates to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation conference, conducted his press-radio conference, and had appointments with Hooker A. Doolittle, Amir Faisal and Amir Kahlid, Secretary Knox and Alvin Wirtz.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Roosevelt announced today that the Allies had sunk more U- boats in the last three months than the enemy had sunk Allied merchant ships, and that our tonnage losses in October were the second lowest of any month of the war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The State Department announced today, on the basis of a detailed report from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, that the plane that bombed Vatican City on the night on Nov. 5 was not an Allied craft.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- A British Mosquito bomber shot down a German plane during a foray over Denmark yesterday while other British planes attacked France, the Air Ministry announced today.

AT A ROYAL AIR FORCE HEAVY-BOMBER STATION, Nov. 9 -- The boys at this station, who in the past have carried out many missions against Germany and still shoulder their share of the bombing burden, have just opened a community center of their own here, where dancing, wood carving, piano playing and art, among other things, are taught to all flying and ground personnel who are interested.

Men who are fighting the war in the southwest Pacific have supplied a pictorial record of their struggle in fifty water-colors, oil paintings and drawings that will go on public exhibition today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

Moon Maiden, a daughter of Challenger II, snapped the winning streak of the French-bred Resolute II yesterday at Jamaica's Victory meeting when she rushed on at the head of the stretch to wrest the lead from Don Juan II and score by two lengths.

Last week's landing on the island of Bougainville, in the northern Solomons, represents the culmination of more than a year of effort and the greatest stride we have yet taken toward Rabaul, key Japanese base in the Southwestern Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The proper allocation of consumer goods to meet shifting populations in the United States was discussed today at a combined meeting of the retail industry advisory committee and the wholesale and retail soft lines industry advisory committee.
WITH THE ALLIED FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Nov. 7 (Delayed) -- The Germans are now fighting desperately to hold the nigh terrain north, east and west of Venafro.

The admonition to "shop early" has been reserved until now for the purchase of Christmas gifts, but this year it may be applied equally well to the gathering of holiday foods for your own table. For, because of the exigencies of war, many of the plum puddings and other delicacies that are part and parcel of Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's are noticeably scarce.

As a former member of THE TIMES staff, I am distressed to see the paper so far behind the news as is implied by Mr. Krock's column this morning. Mr. Krock is concerned over the "dilemma" of the Office of War Information; whose major policy, he says, is the incarnation abroad of the United States and its war effort in the person of President Roosevelt.

Rallies in the grain and securities markets and the inflationary implication of higher wage rates lifted up the cotton futures market yesterday after new lows for the current movement had been reached earlier in the day.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,328, which compared with 1,268 in the preceding week and 769 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The Alaska Packers Association declared yesterday a dividend of $5 a share. The previous payment was $3, distributed in April.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Slender Nancy Cakes de Marigny, 19-year-old girl whose millionaire father was brutally beaten and burned to death last July, begged a Bahamas Supreme Court jury today to share her belief in the innocence of her accused husband.

"On the farm as in industry the war has pushed costs above the levels that prevailed before the outbreak of war. * * * These are the costs of war and it is entirely appropriate that they should be met out of the public treasury, just as are the costs of producing tanks and planes and ships and guns." -- From the President's food message.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- While the Administration sought a compromise on the food subsidy issue, the House Agriculture Committee, by a 14 to 11 vote, killed today a proposal to repeal Federal taxes on margarine.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Nov. 8 (AP) (Delayed) -- American troops who are now veterans of the two campaigns were reminded today of the anniversary of the invasion of French North Africa by a visit from Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark on an inspection tour of the front lines.

METUCHEN, N.J. Nov. 9 -- Three civilian employes were injured seriously and several others suffered minor burns when a terrific explosion followed by a series of other blasts wrecked a magazine and two freight cars being loaded with ammunition at the Army's Raritan Arsenal at Bonhamtown, near here, today.

A towering modern symphony and a brilliantly composed concerto for two pianos, which had its first performance in this city, were distinguishing features of the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Two motions for a mistrial were made yesterday in Federal Court, where eight men are being tried for alleged conspiracy to back up Willie Bioff and George E. Browne in their extortion of $2,500,000 from motion-picture producers and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

Harlem police were looking last night for an 18-year-old Negro who, at the point of a large kitchen knife, held up eight women teachers yesterday while they were having luncheon in Public School 68, 127 West 127th Street, and took six pocketbooks containing about $40, ration books and keys.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 10 -- The Japanese have succeeded in landing several hundred men in barges by night along the Laruma River of Empress Augusta Bay, and a battle is developing, said a communique issued today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Chief Justice Harlan F. Stone revealed tonight that the September conference of senior circuit judges adopted a resolution holding it improper for officers or employes of the Federal courts to become political candidates or to participate in political activities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it hopes to issue a revision of the price regulation for women's rayon hosiery before the first of the year. Reagan P. Connally, director, consumers' goods division of OPA, said that "barring unforeseen obstacles," the revision would be ready by that time.
Mrs. R. Henry Norweb has joined Mr. Norweb, United States Ambassador to Peru and Minister Designated to Portugal, at the Waldorf-Astoria.
New York's experimental antlerless deer season which ended in the Adirondacks on Oct. 26 was a success from "all known standpoints," stated Conservation Commissioner John A. White.

In view of all the unrest that has existed in the coal strike situation since the outbreak of the war, and the current necessity for curbing deliveries of coal as a conservation measure, it is interesting to note the record of the West Kentucky Coal Company, which is owned by the North American Company.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Today's communique:

The Consolidated Edison Company, with a donation of $150,000, headed yesterday's list of contributors to the National War Fund's campaign for $17,000,000 to be raised here for the support of twenty-six national and local war-related agencies, it was announced by Emil Schram, New York committee chairman.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Departing from his customary caution in commenting on the plight of the enemy, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox asserted unequivocally today that the situation of the Japanese in the South and Southwest Pacific theatre had become more than "critical" and that their recent naval defeats were "nothing short of a disaster" for them.
Tonight's events: Piano recital by Selma Kramer, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; concert by Russian Trio, Town Hall, 8:30; concert of compositions by Mordecai Sandberg, Carnegie Music Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Americans grossed a record $12,545,000,000 in income during September, the Commerce Department reported tonight, adding that despite higher tax payments they still have more money to spend than ever and are spending it at the unprecedented rate of over $91,000,000,000 a year.

The first Liberty ship to be named for an American publisher, the Charles Scribner, was launched Saturday at the yards of the Bethlehem-Fairfield Company near Baltimore. Mrs. Charles Scribner, wife of the president of Charles Scribner's Sons, was sponsor for the ship, which was named for the founder of the firm, grandfather of her husband.

"I Dood It." a Metro musical starring Red Skelton and Eleanor Powell, will be the seventeenth anniversary film attraction opening this morning at the Paramount. The film is the 650th feature and the first Metro picture to play the theatre since it opened in November, 1926.

Boatswain's Mate First Class John C. Cullen of the Coast Guard, who seventeen months ago brought about the capture of Nazi saboteurs on Long Island, received yesterday the Legion of Merit Medal. The presentation was made at 42 Broadway by Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, district Coast Guard officer.

Envisaging severe competition from metals and other light materials such as glass, Charles C. Livingston, chairman of the post-war planning committee of the Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc., yesterday warned approximately 1,000 molders and fabricators that they must unite in presenting a campaign on the value of plastics and must he prepared to launch annually, "starting with V-day, a mammoth show of the industry."

Deeply concerned by the growing black market in liquor, distillers and others in the industry in cooperation with the American Hotel Association are joining in a concerted effort to head off a return of the pre-repeal gangsterinfected liquor traffic, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The nature and results of Donald M. Nelson's mission to Moscow remained a mystery today when the Chairman of the War Production Board, reporting at a press conference on his month-long journey, enthusiastically praised the Russian war program but declined to reveal the chief purpose of his visit.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech last night at the Lord Mayor's banquet in which he deprecated all talk of an early end of the war did a little today to relieve the depression of the stock markets and business opened firmly.

At 8:30 this evening Mark Warnow, one of radio's prominent conductors, will give the go-ahead signal for the curtain to rise on "What's Up" at the National Theatre. At that moment Mr. Warnow will be making his debut as a Broadway producer with a $90,000 musical comedy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Warning organized labor that the War Labor Board would adhere steadfastly to its wage stabilization policy, including the Little Steel formula, William H. Davis, chairman of the board, declared today that if labor sought to obtain higher wages than those deemed fair as of Sept. 15, 1942, it would set off an inflationary spiral which would end in disaster.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- An official document compiled from all information available to the Allied Governments estimates that there are now more than 21,500,000 homeless or displaced persons scattered over the continent of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Navy Department announced today the loss during October of two destroyers, the Chevalier and the Henley, in the south Pacific, at the same time giving the lie to extravagant Japanese claims on the flicting widespread damage on the American fleet in the current northern Solomons fighting.

Mrs. Mary Penora Tilove, 20 years old, of 107 Havemeyer Street, Brooklyn, was found guilty last night by a Federal Court jury of the kidnapping last July 3 of 2-year-old Jimmy di Maggio of 35 East First Street. The jury of five women and seven men recommended mercy.

The fur manufacturing industry, confused over the proposal that fur garments be priced at 1941 base period levels whereas the new ceilings on raw furs to be issued shortly show substantial price advances over both 1941 and 1942, is awaiting official action by the OPA to end the dilemma.

Office of Price Administration officials yesterday told representatives of the plastics industry that a new regulation will be issued to supplant the three rulings under which the industry is presently operating. At the same time a plastics industry advisory committee to OPA was formed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- While the Ways and Means Committee struggled with proposed amendments to the War Contracts Renegotiation Act, eight organizations, including the Congress of Industrial Organizations, issued a statement today assailing the $2,000,000,000 tax bill which has been tentatively accepted by the committee.

Three leading railroads declared yesterday dividends on their capital stock. Directors of the New York Central Railroad Company ordered a payment of $1 a share on Jan. 15 to stock of record on Nov. 20. Previous payments were 50 cents a share on July 15 and $1 on Jan. 15, this year, the first since 1931.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Navy communique 481:

With independence of millinery design, Anita Andra of 558 Madison Avenue presented her winter collection of "escapist trends" yesterday at the Hotel Pierre. Invariably larger in size, the entire group represented this designer's resourceful use of a diversity of fabrics, novelty of trimmings and range of silhouettes.

Planned and orderly demobilization of service men after the war together with teamwork of private enterprise and government, must be the foundation of a program for post-war re-employment if chaos is to be averted, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator and chairman of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday.

An agreement ending a buyers' boycott that virtually halted the wholesale distribution of fresh fruits and vegetables at Washington Market and the Brooklyn Terminal Market was reached yesterday afternoon at a meeting sponsored by Daniel P. Woolley, Commissioner of Markets, and held in his office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- In a progress report which on the whole was far from optimistic, Col. Bradley Dewey, said today that tires and other rubber goods would continue to be scarce "for a long time." He held out no hope for relaxation of tire rationing in the visible future.

Mr. Churchill's declaration that the back of German U-boat warfare has been broken was supplemented promptly by President Roosevelt's supporting figures. In the three months of August through October sixty enemy submarines were destroyed, more than the number of Allied merchant ships lost through submarine attack.

Many a comedian has expressed a desire to play Hamlet, but Frank (Bruiser) Kinard, tireless captain of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers, is not a funny fellow and Shakespeare is farthest from his thoughts at the moment. Still, the Bruiser, unquestionably one of the best tackles in the National Football League and a sixty-minute man to boot, wouldn't mind a backfield berth with the Dodgers.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Direct control of the Central Railroad of New Jersey by the Reading Company and indirect control by the Baltimore Ohio Railway Company, principal stockholder of Reading, were described today by the State Board of Tax Appeals as possible reasons for Jersey Central's bankruptcy.

Celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding, the National Women's League of the United Synagogue of America held an all-day meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Sponsored by the metropolitan branch, and attended by 1,000 women, the convention was one of ten simultaneous conferences held throughout the United States and Canada.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- More than 500 Britain-based warplanes raided Europe yesterday in one of the Allies' biggest daylight aerial offensives in weeks and a large force of RAF bombers struck at German occupied territory last night. The night assault was believed to have been carried out in great force.
Fritzie Zivic and Jacob La Motta, middleweight rivals, who are to clash for the third time in a ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, yesterday concluded heavy work for the bout.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A "complete and overall" investigation of lend-lease and other Government financial activities abroad was voted today by the Senate Appropriations Committee only a few hours in advance of a Presidential message to Congress on the subject of lend-lease.

Patrolman Frank Hand of the West Thirtieth Street station was sent yesterday by a police surgeon to Bellevue Hospital for observation, after the patrolman's revolver had been discharged in a Bronx tavern and he had barricaded himself in his fifth floor apartment at 1435 Ogden Avenue, the Bronx, for more than an hour.
The Producers Council, national association of manufacturers of building materials and equipment, was advised yesterday to plan for a record volume of construction activity in the post-ward period.
Scene, Broadway. Characters, Author, Producer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The House passed today the Senate's resolution to extend the tenures of office of the President and Vice President of the Philippine Govern-in-Exile, Manuel L. Quezon and Sergio Osmena, respectively, until the commonwealth can be rescued from Japanese control.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 10 -- Slovenian units of the Yugoslav People's Army of Liberation are engaged in defense operations against strong German tank and motorized forces that have launched an offensive in the important hinterland north of the ports of Fiume and Susak, a broadcast of the Free Yugoslav radio reported today.

Hundreds of lawn sprinklers -- full-circle, half-circle, quarter-circle -- figured yesterday at the conspiracy trial of seven leaders of Chicago's gangland syndicate and a Newark business agent of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

George L. Bagby, president of the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for officers, trustees and members of the assisting committee of the organization. Plans were discussed for the annual concert in behalf of the foundation to be held on the afternoon of Dec. 6 in the main ballroom of the same hotel.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Facing what all hands here feel is one of the really tough games of the schedule, the Pennsylvania coaches and teams were recovering slowly this afternoon from a bad fright.
CARIO, Egypt, Nov. 10 -- Conditions approximating those of martial law prevail throughout Lebanon, according to information available here tonight.

A first-hand account of a fully lighted Army hospital ship, standing by under fire off the shores of Italy and Sicily to transport the wounded, was given yesterday by Miss Nell Ennis, first American Red Cross field director to sail on such a tour of duty.

Inadequate educational programs by the major political parties, not defects in the proportional representation system, caused changes in the composition of the new City Council, members of the New York City League of Women Voters were told yesterday.

Yesterday a correspondent of this newspaper sent from somewhere on the India-Burma frontier an account of a ride in a plane over the route of so much of the Ledo Road as is completed. This highway runs in a generally eastward direction along the south slope of the Himalayan range through some of the densest Indian jungles.
