Forty-four players have entered the second annual national amateur championship tournament which will start this afternoon, under the auspices of the United States Chess Federation, at the Manhattan Chess Club. A preliminary meeting of the competitors will inaugurate the affair.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The British Government announced today that 31,078 Jews who are legally entitled to enter Palestine but have failed to do so because of the war will be admitted when conditions make that possible. Col. Oliver Stanley, Colonial Secretary, who made the statement in the House of Commons, indicated, however, that there would be no change in the basic policy laid down in the White Paper of May, 1939.

ALGIERS, Nov. 10 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle emphasized and reiterated today that the French Committee of National Liberation was the only authority that had any value within France or would be accepted by the French.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Charles D. Steininger stood in Federal court today and heard the butter he makes extolled as superlative, his business methods as extraordinary and Federal Judge Harry E. Kalodner order a mental test to make sure the defendant, who is 54, was not "dumb like a fox."

Protestant women of the United States will vote today on resolutions dealing with post-war international organization for peace and with the prolongation of rationing restrictions. The vote will be taken at armistice services to be held in churches in several hundred cities and towns under the auspices of the United Council of Church Women.

Before an audience that virtually filled Carnegie Hall last night, Selma Kramer played a long and unusually exacting program of piano music, ranging from Bach to Shostakovich. In between were such tidbits as Beethoven's "Appassionata," Schumann's "Etudes Symphoniques" and three Chopin numbers, including the B minor scherzo.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A racket in foodstuffs, claiming to contain vitamins among other ingredients of special value, was attacked vigorously by the Ministry of Food yesterday in a White Paper announcing that henceforth no claims of such nature could be made in this country.

The "Little Steel" formula has failed. This could have been foreseen because the formula carries within itself the seeds of inflation. The 15 per cent increase which it allows to meet the increased cost of living was added to the wage rates. This means that where time and a half was paid for overtime the increase was actually 22 1/2 per cent and where double time was paid it came to 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- How an old four-piper destroyer of the United States Navy, named the Borie, tackled a Nazi submarine pack in heavy North Atlantic seas at night, and, straddling the deck of a giant U-boat, fought it to the death -- "like tom-cats in the dark," was told here today by the Navy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio said today at a press conference that he would enter the Ohio Presidential preference primaries May 9.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 10 -- One of the most comprehensive postwar public works programs yet developed by any community of any size in this country was laid before Portland metropolitan area leaders yesterday by a representative of Robert Moses, Park Commissioner of New York City.
ALGIERS, Nov. 10 -- The Fifteenth United States Air Force sent its heaviest bombers to a ball-bearing plant again yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Allies have requested the Italian Premier, Marshal Pietro Badoglio, to remove Gen. Mario Roatta, Italian Chief of Staff, as a result of Yugoslav charges that he was a "war criminal" responsible for a reign of terror in Yugoslavia, it was disclosed today.

The report of the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday by Richard J. Cullen, chairman, shows a net profit of $6,622,475 after taxes and other charges. This was equal to $1.73 a share on the concern's outstanding common stock.

A program for the termination of war contracts has been submitted to the Senate Small Business Committee by the National Association of Manufacturers which calls for giving authority to war agencies which made the contracts with industry to negotiate settlements under which at least 75 per cent of the amounts involved shall be paid immediately to hasten reconversion to peacetime operations, it was announced yesterday.

The Andre Seligmann Gallery announces the merging of its activities with those of the Koetzer Gallery and will conduct business from Nov. 15 on at the former's old address, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. Old masters, nineteenth-century paintings and work by living artists will be dealt in.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday formation of the New York City Post-War Industrial Committee to study the possibility of new manufacturing plants and the need for expansion and modernization of existing facilities in private industry after the war.

A new issue of $1,500,000 water and sewer bonds was awarded yesterday by the Washington Suburban Sanitary District of Maryland to a syndicate comprising the Union Securities Corporation, Glore, Forgan Co., Francis I. du Pont Co., R.D. White Co., Fox, Reusch Co., Inc., and Rambo, Keen, Close Kerner, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission's approval on the proposed sale to an underwriting group of all outstanding common stock of the Central Illinois Electric and Gas Company.

More general progress was made yesterday by the stock market in repairing the damage done on Monday to its price structure. Today's recess of all securities and commodity markets in observance of Armistice Day acted as a brake, however, on any spirited buying, and the best gains of the morning were whittled somewhat as buying dried up in the final hour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The second largest corn crop on record in the United States -- 3,086,000,000 bushels -- was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture on the basis of conditions on Nov. 1.

The oil-supply position on the Eastern seaboard improved slightly last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period, the institute's index of gasoline stocks stood at 36.9, against 36 a week earlier. The index covering light fuel oil supplies advanced to 56.7 from 55.7 and that of heavy fuel oil to 79.9 from 79.5.
A communique, broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Columbia's football team, now shaping up at Baker Field for Saturday's meeting with Navy, went through a general toughening up exercise yesterday, which included a half hour of bruising scrimmage.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 11 -- From the South Pacific Headquarters of Admiral William F. Halsey Jr. came reports that a large force of United States Army troops landed at Empress Augusta Bay Monday without the loss of a man.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of the statement issued by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, released by the War Department today:

Declaring that marines had landed on Japan once before and that they would do so again, Rear Adm. Edward J. Marquart paid tribute to the fighting qualities of Leathernecks all over the world at ceremonies yesterday to mark the 168th anniversary of the corps, the nation's oldest branch of the armed services.
The text of Lord Halifax's address at the dinner of the Academy of Political Science last night follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The State Department committees which, under the general guidance of Secretary Hull and the immediate leadership of former Under-Secretary Welles, drafted the text of the main Declaration of Moscow -- adopted with little change by the Four-Power signatories -- did not include Herbert Hoover or Wendell L. Willkie.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A decision has been made that the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs will not be broken up and Nelson A. Rockefeller, its director, will not be appointed Assistant Secretary of State.

ALGIERS, Nov. 10 -- In connection with the anniversary of Allied landings in North Africa, United States Minister Robert D. Murphy and Rene Massigli, French Commissioner of Foreign Affairs, have exchanged letters of thanks.
New York's theme song on juvenile delinquency is "Say It Isn't So," Austin H. MacCormick, executive director of the Osborne Association, declared yesterday.

Henry Goelet, operator, has purchased from the Garco Realty Corporation the ten-story and penthouse loft building at 291 Seventh Avenue, between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Streets, in the fur district.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 11 -- Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin's First Ukraine Army pressed forward yesterday in a seventy-mile arc with Kiev as its hub, killing 3,500 Germans and recapturing more than sixty places in a steady advance that carried it closer to the last German-held railroad east of the old Polish frontier.

I wonder what authority Nancy Schoonmaker has for her assertion in a letter to THE TIMES that England's opposition quenched President Wilson's desire for the promulgation of racial equality at Versailles. From participants at the time in Paris I learned the following:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- Penicillin can be manufactured in the home, with kitchen utensils, at practically no cost, according to Dr. Julius A. Vogel, who looks after some 10,000 employes of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation plants here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Lieut. Col. Lyda M. Keener, principal chief nurse at Walter Reed General Hospital, will retire tomorrow, ending the longest Army-nurse career in history, thirty-seven years and five months of active duty.

A discussion of plans "to prevent a recurrence" of Tuesday's hold-up of eight women teachers in Harlem public school by an 18-year-old Negro, armed with a kitchen knife, was held yesterday at Police Headquarters. Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, other high police officials, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, and Dr. C. Frederick Pertsch, assistant superintendent, took part in the forty-five minute conference.

When Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate learned yesterday in Downtown Traffic Court of the award of the Distinguished Service Cross to First Lieut. James K. Schullinger of the Army Air Forces for bravery in action in North Africa last winter, he suspended sentence in the matter of a "ticket" the flier had received for overtime parking.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Twin brothers -- the Browns of Westfield, N.J. -- are scheduled to battle each other when Princeton and Yale meet at the Bowl Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The House Naval Affairs subcommittee investigating the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation turned today from production troubles of that company to pre-Pearl Harbor airplane and armaments deals and contacts with Axis countries by Alfred J. and Ignacio J. Miranda, who, with two former Brewster officials, hold the largest block of Brewster stock.

By withdrawing on Oct. 24 from the American Jewish Conference on the ground that it was subordinating other Jewish issues to "the problem of the political structure of Palestine," the American Jewish Committee took the "morally indefensible position" of "disrupting the unity of the American Jewish community at a period of the greatest emergency in the history of the Jewish people," it was charged yesterday by the interim committee of the American Jewish Conference.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The War Department announced today awards to three New York men for "meritorious conduct" in the Southwest Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Ole Olsen of Olsen and Johnson's "Sons o' Fun," twenty members of the cast, half a dozen local night clubs and some of the press and public of the capital were among the victims of a whirlwind swindle perpetrated last week by one of the most daring emulators of J. Rufus Wallingford in the memory of Washington.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Alan Ladd, who recently received a medical discharge from the Army, has been named by Paramount for the lead in the forthcoming picturization of the Rachel Field novel, "And Now Tomorrow." He will play the part previously scheduled for Franchot Tone.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today, in answer to a question whether it was proposed to adopt a system of military training in this country after the war, "I hope so, but it is too early to say."

A vast program of post-war education for New York State, to include the establishment of fifteen training institutes, a greatly expanded system of scholarship aid for high school graduates and an extensive capital outlay budget for new college buildings, to cost an estimated $65,000,000, has been approved by the Board of Regents, Dr. William J. Wallin, vice chancellor, disclosed yesterday.

Slicing through the entire field at the far turn and threading his way around the leaders, Stymie, from the stable of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs, captured the Republic of Peru Handicap at Jamaica yesterday as the Victory meeting went into its sixth day with an attendance of 15,806 and wagering of $1,647,070.

AIR BASE NEAR BURMA BORDER, Nov. 3 (Delayed) -- From inside a transport that was doing a job I watched today while a plane load of supplies was dropped to Chinese troops advancing against Japanese positions in the Hukawng Valley of northwest Burma.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey testified yesterday that a careful record was kept of all overnight guests to Sanita Hills, the vacation resort for department employes, and that their meals and lodgings were paid for by himself or by the sanitation honor relief and welfare fund, which operates the tract near Holmes, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- It was bound to happen soon or later -- and last week-end it did. The Redskins took a setback in their passing game and the Packers suffered likewise in their ground attack, but the Bears had another field day and for the first time this season emerged supreme as pro football's top offensive team.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10 -- Establishment yesterday of a new "Subsecretariate of Information and Press" with wide powers to regulate the activities of the local press and foreign correspondents makes it plain that the Government plans force all Argentine newspapers to fall into line with its policies, eliminating those that are so foolish as to believe they still have the right of independent expression.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- An unauthorized strike which started yesterday at the Ford Willow Run bomber plant threatened today to close down the big establishment. It was characterized by Ford officials as a "CIO attempt to take over the bomber plant."

In your brief editorial comment with respect to Attorney General Biddle's testimony on the proposed legislation exempting insurance companies from the anti-trust laws, you state that Mr. Biddle "forgets" that "the precedent has already been established." You specify the precedent -- "labor unions have long been granted specific immunity from the Federal anti-trust laws."

By one of those constant reshuffles common to most Governments-in-exile which must necessarily rule in something like a political vacuum, the French Committee of National Liberation has ousted General Giraud as its Co-President and has put General de Gaulle in virtually undisputed control of French political affairs in so far as the Committee controls them.

The Giants, already forewarned of the loss of Mickey Witek with the announcement that their star second baseman had been classified 1-A by his draft board at Luzerne, Pa., were not kept long in suspense.

The new City Council, taking office on Jan. 1, will contain ten organization Democrats, one organization Republican, three in an independent group, and three radicals, two of whom are Communists while the other follows the Communist party line.

THE New York Rangers have bobbed up with a new center for the new hockey season, a 42-year-old stripling named Frank Boucher. He must be pretty good, too, because he started with the third line in his debut and whisked up to the first line in his next appearance. Did Lester Patrick think that Boucher showed sufficient promise to-----

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Grain markets fluctuated in an aimless manner today on the Board of Trade, with professional traders more inclined to even up for the holiday tomorrow than to take a decided stand on either side. Wheat held within a range of less than 1 cent a bushel and closed 1/8 cent lower to 1/8 cent higher.

Four years ago Joseph Campbell and Henry Morton Robinson began their work of unraveling James Joyce's "Finnegan's Wake." Harcourt, Brace will bring out their "Skeleton Key to Finnegan's Wake" next spring. The book analyses the work, clarifying the motives, conflicts and language of Joyce's characters and also contains a critical commentary.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Nov. 10 -- Wilbur H. Cox, principal of Hillside High School for more than twenty years, was suspended last night by the Board of Education pending a hearing on Nov. 23, when, according to Herbert R. Otto, a member of the board, Mr. Cox formally will be accused of conduct "unprofessional" and "unbecoming a principal."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A Senate filibuster against the anti-poll tax resolution appeared likely today after sixteen Southern Senators met in secret session to plan action against the measure, which is expected to be reported Friday by the Judiciary Committee.

Bids for this week's issue of $1,000,000,000 of Treasury discount bills, which are dated as of tomorrow instead of today because of the Armistice Day holiday, totaled about $100,000,000 more in volume than last week, and it was from banks in the New York district that most of this increase came.
LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The thirty-sixth annual Autumn Exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, which opened yesterday afternoon at 598 Madison Avenue, presented chrysanthemums of all types and sizes as well as many fine orchids and other popular greenhouse flowers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, returning from the Moscow conference, where he played a leading role in laying the foundations for a durable peace and enhancing the effectiveness of the Allied military coalition, was unexpectedly greeted by President Roosevelt himself this afternoon as he stepped from a big Army cargo plane at National Airport, a weary but happy looking man.

Newspapers in 1,200 pulpwood-producing communities in twenty-seven States are starting today a month's campaign based on the slogan, "Cut a Cord of Pulpwood for Every Local Boy in Service," to achieve the War Production Board's minimum requirement of 13,000,000 cords for 1943.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- In a three-to-two decision, the Appellate Division, Third Department, affirmed today the ruling of the Public Service Commission fixing temporary rates for the Staten Island Edison Corporation, to which the corporation offered objection.

About $420,000,000 will be distributed by Christmas clubs maintained by 4,800 banking and savings institutions and other organizations throughout the country, it was announced yesterday by Herbert F. Rewll, founder and president of Christmas Club, a corporation, 341 Madison Avenue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 10 -- President Getulio Vargas, addressing the nation today on the sixth anniversary of his coup d'etat in 1937, touched upon four important matters: Post-war political and internal reconstruction, post-war trade and financial reconstruction, readjustment in the pay of public employes, and consolidation of the labor laws.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Grey Wing, owned by Mrs. Tilyou Christopher of Miami, led for every step of a mile and a half to win the sixth running of the $7,500 added Grayson Stakes at Pimlico today.

James M. Malloy, credit manager of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn, has been named chairman of the post-war planning committee of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, it was made known yesterday by Louis H. Jacobs, president of the bureau.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies declined 6.5 per cent in October, in comparison with the like month of 1942, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The decrease, the largest for any month this year, is the third consecutive drop.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The decision of the Board of Regents that revoked the medical license of Dr. Edward Spencer Cowles, New York psychiatrist, for a year was set aside by the unanimous vote of the Appellate Division, Third Department, in a decision handed down today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- In an atmosphere aglow with mutual goodwill, government and the oil industry exchanged felicitations today for their respective achievements in what both designated as a superb record in an important phase of the country's war effort.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Office of Price Administration today came to the aid of store fixture manufacturers who customarily sell on long-term contracts. The agency announced that it would grant adjustments of present ceiling prices of such manufacturers who are unable to continue production under existing maximum prices.

The jubilant mobs running wild in every Allied city twenty-five years ago today, the fathers and mothers newly certain that their sons would come home again, the soldiers climbing out of the trenches in that eleventh hour -- it is sad to think back to them now. The Unknown Soldier sleeps well at Arlington, but today another fell on Bougainville Island, or in Italy, or over Germany.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Germans harassed by guerrilla activity from the Swiss border to the Riviera, have offered amnesty to Italian and French patriots who surrender before Nov. 15. The offer was believed to be aimed at an estimated 10,000 anti-Axis Italian troops who were reported to have dug in for the winter in the Maritime Alps.

"Sahara," a topical drama starring Humphrey Bogart, will have its local premiere this morning at the Capitol. The Columbia production, which deals with desert warfare and which was directed by Zoltan Korda, includes J. Carrol Naish, Bruce Bennett, Lloyd Bridges, Rex Ingram, Dan Duryea and Patrick O'Moore among its supporting players.

The four - story garden - type apartment house at 82 Bank Street, White Plains, Westchester County, has been purchased by Charles Walzer, operator, for cash above a mortgage of $120,000. This house is on a plot 100 by 100 feet land contains thirty-six suites and five stores. Goodman Mabel represented the buyer.

ALGIERS, Nov. 10 -- A new phase in the transformation of Italy into an "effective instrument of war against Germany" was announced by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight. It involves the formation of an Allied control commission for Italy to replace the Allied Military Commission headed by Lieut. Gen. F.N. Mason-MacFarlane, who will return to his former post as Governor of Gibraltar.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- An unbalanced air defense, alike helpless to halt Allied bombers or to sup port the German Army in Russia; the disintegration of the vital military transport system; the steady destruction of war industries; 6,000,000 homeless Germans -- these are the chief results of the Anglo-American air offensive.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 10 -- The first session of the council or policy-making body of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, which came into being yesterday at a historic ceremony at the White House at Washington, held its opening plenary meeting here this afternoon.

Interest in the game between C.C.N.Y. and Brooklyn College will not be confined to the players when the rival schools clash Saturday afternoon in Lewisohn Stadium. Fans from St. Nicholas Terrace and Flatbush annually demonstrate that they are as much interested as their athletes.

Edgar S. Bloom, president of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines, announced yesterday that arrangements had been made for a term bank loan of $3,000,000 and that all the 5 per cent collateral trust bonds due on Jan. 1, 1959, would be called for payment on next Jan. 1.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- Tons of woolen underwear, mittens and overcoats were issued today to American and British troops of the Fifth Army as wintry weather set in with an icy blast along the entire front and the Apennines were capped with snow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes told the House Insular Affairs Committee today that he was "tired to death of useless and fruitless committees of investigation."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The War Department said today that the Army Air Forces had withdrawn from anti-submarine operations and that the Navy had assumed "full responsibility."

SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Field Trial Champion Cinar Spot of Earlsmoor, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York and handled by Dr. Milbank, was declared the winner today of the open all-age stake for cocker spaniels, first event of the two-day twelfth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association.

With the Battle of the Atlantic won and the submarine menace under firm control, the Allies are ready to strike the death blow against Nazi Germany, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared last night.

Dog sentries have taken over the patrolling of the lonelier sections of La Guardia Field, the Air Transport Command revealed yesterday. Working with human sentinels, they patrol near military planes and attack strangers on sight, putting in nine hours' duty a night.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned to London today and will report to the House of Commons almost at once on the tri-power conference at Moscow and on the talks he had in Cairo, Egypt, with the representatives of Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia.

The six-story factory building at 808 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Ortley Realty Corporation to the Wilmore Realty Corporation. It is assessed for $64,000. Edward Wagreich was the attorney for the seller. Abraham J. Halprin acted for the buyer. Title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 10 -- Berlin correspondents of Stockholm newspapers are negative in their comment on Hitler's Munich speech.

As Army Air Force Captain Clark Gable says, aviators on bombing missions don't behave like motion picture actors. Captain Gable knows, because he has been riding with them over Happy Valley, otherwise called the Ruhr. They're very quiet, for one thing.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, like President Roosevelt, is beginning to move toward his opposition's policy in home affairs. This does not mean that the two leaders are moving in the same direction; in fact, since Mr. Roosevelt's opposition is on the right and Mr. Churchill's is on the left, they are for the time being at least more or less moving in opposite directions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A battle flag from Guadalcanal was raised over the Capitol today in observance of the 168th birthday of the United States Marines, and President Roosevelt made it an occasion for noting that the Marine Corps "even now is busy attending the baptism of more battle flags on the road to Tokyo."
A rosy commercial future for television after the war was painted here last night by speakers at a joint dinner-meeting of the American Television Society and the Advertising Club of New York.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Irving Berlin brought his all-Army show, "This is the Army," to London tonight and at its end, when the mink bedecked and uniformed audience stood up for "The Star-Spangled Banner" and "God Save the King" it was clear that Mr. Berlin's show had done as much for Anglo-American relations as a hundred after-dinner speeches.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- Passing to the counter-offensive in central China, Chinese forces have recaptured a strategic town on the north shore of Tungting Lake and inflicted losses on the enemy in other sectors south of the Yangtze River, it was announced tonight.

NAPLES, Nov. 9 (Delayed) -- Italy's distressed political minds, in seeking some way out of the present difficulties, have evolved a new formula, a regency for the 6-year-old Prince of Naples, with his mother, Marie Jose, the Princess of Piedmont, as regent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Congress received assurance today from Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, that production of essential civilian goods would be permitted on an increasing scale as fast as military requirements allowed the release of war plants and vital materials.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The President had appointments with Gen. Frank T. Hines, Under-Secretary of State Stettinius, Assistant Secretary of War Lovett, A.A. Berle Jr. and L. Welch Pogue.
ALGIERS, Nov. 10 -- A communique:

When a very tough opponent is to be faced, very tough conditioning exercises are required, in the opinion of Stout Steve Owen, head man of the football Giants, who must engage those Midway Monsters, the Chicago Bears, Sunday.

Homefront textile needs, already pinched severely in vulnerable spots by military and lend-lease priorities, face the further threat of inroads from the pending clothing purchases planned on behalf of the United Nations Relief Rehabilitation Administration, the new operating agency for political and socio-economic affairs created Tuesday in Washington by the United States and forty-three allied nations, it was declared yesterday by Worth Street textile suppliers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- The selective service system revealed plans tonight to defer necessary workers in West Coast airplane plants from military service to prevent a breakdown in aircraft production.

Whatever the nations that want peace may together decide to do after the war to maintain it, "an indispensable part of any larger plan must be the discovery of a firm basis for Anglo-American cooperation," Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, said last night in his first public address since his recent return from England.

Turkeys -- or rather the lack of them -- are causing considerable anxiety in the markets these days. For although Government spokesmen once predicted that supplies of these birds would be adequate this fall, few have arrived in Manhattan thus far and there is little hope of any heavy shipments in the near future.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A Middle East Air communique:
The outstanding lineman of the week in The Associated Press poll was Tackle Jim White of Notre Dame.

Four non-commissioned officers at Fort Jay, Governors Island, were found guilty yesterday of misusing gasoline rations by Benjamin L. Greenberg, special hearing officer of the Office of Price Administration. In each case decision as to punishment was reserved.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 10 -- The German revolution and armistice anniversaries find the German people in a chastened and sober mood, Berlin dispatches state, adding that even such customary outward manifestations as flag displays are completely lacking this year.

Declaring that a post-war boom is as much to be feared as a severe depression, Dr. Mabel Newcomer, chairman of the Department of Economics at Vassar College, declared last night. Federal taxes should be greatly increased now to prevent a dangerous inflation after the end of hostilities.

Increased selling pressure yesterday weakened the cotton futures market in the final moments of trading, after an early display of moderate strength on trade-price fixing and commission house buying. The list of active old contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the session with net losses of 2 to 4 points.

Although his counsel and two other lawyers, including a bankruptcy trustee, urged a suspended sentence yesterday for Paul E. Flato, who had pleaded guilty in one of a series of gem thefts from fellow-jewelers totaling $120,000, General Sessions Judge John A Mullen sentenced him to a term of two to four years in Sing Sing.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Churchill Government flatly turned down today suggestions that it relax the blockade and send food to German-occupied Europe, asserting that such an action would lead the Germans to create more starvation and shortages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The first comprehensive survey of war contracts by the Office of War Information disclosed today that arms commitments are being redrawn wherever practicable to provide a financial incentive to contractors, end labor hoarding and to reduce costs.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- A communique:
The early operational bulletin as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Although about half of the 20,000 salable hogs received here today remained unsold at the market's close, the War Food Administration estimated that tomorrow's receipts would equal today's run and be added to those that were held over.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company approved today payment of its thirty-second wage dividend to employes and declared quarterly dividends of $1.25 a share on the common stock and $1.50 on the preferred.

ALGIERS, Nov. 10 -- German guns blazed all along the Fifth Army front yesterday and, under the cover of artillery sheltered by looming heights, the German infantry strove repeatedly to break up the British and American threat to the western part of the Garigliano-Sangro line.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday asked James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to rule whether his radio address last Sunday, in which he blamed the Republicans for the election of Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court, was "political" and therefore an improper use of WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station.

Both Connecticut and New Jersey striped bass fishermen have had a share of luck in the late runs recently reported. New Jersey has its best striper to date as a result of the catch off Barnegat by Nelson Stone of a forty-two pounder, which has been entered in the Governor's fishing contest.

Secretary Hull comes home from the most important and successful of all American missions to Moscow with added cubits to his already high stature as a negotiator and a statesman. The historic task he has accomplished is a triumph for his country and the world because it lays the cornerstone of the structure of peace.
Many a liquor buyer was dizzy yesterday -- without even a nip from a bottle -- as a result of the growing unbalance between supply and demand.
For the third week in a row, Columbia yesterday concluded heavy practice for a game without benefit of the presence of its veteran head coach, Lou Little.

Cooler weather spurred Armistice Day trade here yesterday, and shopping crowds were heavy in local stores. Differing somewhat from the pattern established on Columbus Day and election day, business was well distributed through many departments, although apparel, particularly children's wear, continued outstanding.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- A few snowflakes early this afternoon merely served to pep up the frostbite dinghy sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Muffled from neck to toes, they set out in the second of their winter wind-jamming sessions, and Arthur Knapp came through as the point winner over five races With his craft Popcorn.
ALGIERS, Nov. 11 -- A communique:

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 11 -- Alfred de Marigny was freed of a murder charge in the Bahamas Supreme Court tonight and hurried immediately to the arms of his wife, Nancy, the daughter of Sir Harry Oakes, millionaire, whom he had been accused of killing.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today placed responsibility for the winning of the war and insuring "lasting peace" squarely upon Britain, Russia and the United States in his report to the House of Commons on the Moscow Conference.

Three midtown theatres will retain their film attractions for second weeks starting today. They are "Princess O'Rourke," the romantic comedy at the Strand; the dual Soviet program composed of the documentary, "Day After Day," and "Leningrad Music Hall," at the Stanley and "Son of Dracula," the melodrama at the Rialto.

LONDON, Nov, 11 -- An overwhelming concentration of Allied air power hammered at the citadels and outworks of Hitler's European fortress from Bolzano, in northern Italy, to Muenster, the German railroad center vital to the defenses of the Low Countries, in the past twenty-four hours.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -- Police announced today that they raided and suppressed various Communist organizations, including the local Argentine company that acts as an agent in Buenos Aires for the Press Wireless American Communications Company, with transmission facilities in Montevideo, Uruguay.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Attorney General Robert T. Bushnell sharply criticized today the report on anti-Semitic disorders submitted to Governor Saltonstall by the State Public Safety Commissioner, John F. Stokes, who stated that the disorders "would not have been possible" had patrolmen and sergeants carried out their duties according to accepted police principles.

A study of the national income, published by the Department of Commerce and summarized in the October Monthly Labor Review of the Department of Labor, reveals striking contrasts in the distributive shares of income between 1939, the year before our defense program was begun, and the present year.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 -- The shifting population of the United States is trending toward a predominance of elderly workers, a change that must be given consideration in our industrial planning, Dr. E.J. Stieglitz of Washington told a manpower conservation conference today at the annual meeting of the Industrial Hygiene Foundation in Mellon Institute.

As a foreign trade commuter, by both sea and air, and as a citizen keenly interested -- as all American citizens need to be interested -- in how our country is going to stand in the post-war world, I want to challenge the advice advanced by P.V.G. Mitchell in his letter of Nov. 5 in which he comments on the position taken by an airline president on the subject of post-war aviation.
Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia indicated yesterday that the results of the election of members of the new City Council had not turned him against proportional representation voting.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- Today's communique:

Impressive figures are available here about the fast-diminishing strength of the German Air Force, which, in the opinion of competent sources, goes far toward explaining the present plight of Adolf Hitler's armies in Russia. At the present moment, incredible as it may sound, the German command has not at its disposal more than 400 fighters in the eastern theatre of operations.

The British Chancellor's White Paper on Mutual Aid and President Roosevelt's report on "the reverse lend-lease aid which we have received" will enlighten those who really wish to be enlightened as to our economic relations with our allies.

The fifth annual exhibition offered by the American Veterans Society of Artists opened with a preview reception yesterday afternoon at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. It opens to the public today and will continue through the month. The hours are 10 M to 5 P. M. week-days; 2 I to 5 P. M. Sundays.

In his article of Nov. 7 Edwin L. James takes the view that the recent accomplishments at Moscow mean that we are "going back a quarter of a century and pick up where Wilson left off." He seems willing to uphold the Wilsonian failure to deal with the problem of aggression in the realm of reality when he argues at length against an international police force which Mr. Wilson failed to provide.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- After an overtime session the Ways and Means Committee approved this evening a $2,142,900,000 tax bill, about one-fifth of the $10,500,000,000 for which the Treasury asked.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 11 -- The food situation in Germany is rapidly going from bad to worse, writes "Industrialist" in the second installment of a much censored story on conditions inside the Reich written for the Swedish pictorial weekly Se.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The problems of paper production confronting the papermaking industry and the War Production Board were outlined yesterday to the newly appointed WPB newsprint manufacturers' industry advisory committee, WPB announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Navy is expected to translate into action soon the bill signed by the President this week which will give greater flexibility to rank in the Waves and women Marines and thus greater incentive to induction.

With civilian sheets and pillow-cases now in short supply, due to heavy military and foreign relief demands on productive facilities, merchandisers anticipate that after the initial period of pent-up consumer demand "when, as and if the civilian market opens up again," the problem of serious selling with its emphasis on the advertising and selling of national brands, will be of major importance to retailers.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill has decided to proceed at once with a program of post-war social reform for Britain. This is the meaning of a decision announced tonight to make Lord Woolton Britain's first Minister of Reconstruction, with a place of authority in the War Cabinet.

Eyewitness accounts of the destruction wrought in German industrial and communications centers by British-American bombardment are coming through across the barriers of German censorship. To the average person they seem to confirm the idea that aerial warfare is a peculiarly brutal type of warmaking.

Through the establishment of a special pool of about fifty tank trucks of milk a week, New York City has been assured of an ample supply of fluid milk during the low production season that will last until after the first of the year, Sol Pincus, Deputy Commissioner of Health, disclosed yesterday.

Following is the text of the accepting address delivered tonight by former Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York, after his election as director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A nine-room apartment with four baths at 1155 Park Avenue has been leased to Joseph Roby through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker, according to one of the reports of residential leasing received yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The War Department made public today the names of 251 United States soldiers listed as missing in action in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean and southwest Pacific areas.
A program consisting largely of new songs heard for the first time in this city was presented by Janet Fairbank, Chicago soprano, at her third local recital last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., today changed its plan for the payment of a $35,000,000 past due note held by its parent, the Electric Bond and Share Company, by substituting $30,000,000 in new notes for a like amount of cash which it had intended to borrow from banks.

Distillers have begun receiving complaints that their advertised brands of whisky, now almost unobtainable through legitimate package stores except by favored patrons, are being peddled by bootleggers to their pre-repeal customers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Starting almost from scratch in 1939, American industry by the end of 1942 had increased its war and post-war reserves by more than 2,800 per cent, it was disclosed today in a survey made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A return to old-time simplicity of Christmas celebrations, with the emphasis on the fun of just being together, may very well be the rule for most homes rather than unwrapping elaborate toys and games this year. Reports made yesterday by toy manufacturers and retail stores indicate that most metal and rubber toys have disappeared from the market and even wooden playthings are becoming scarce.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 11 -- German efforts to launch a new offensive against Yugoslav Partisan positions along the Dalmatian coast, to drive them inland and away from the seaports at present serving the Yugoslav as tenuous naval links with the Allies in Italy, appear again to have failed, according to information obtained here this evening from usually reliable sources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The tentative plan for an inter-Allied naval patrol, to keep the world in order during a "provisional peace period," which was broached at the Quebec Conference and detailed in these dispatches under date of Oct. 22, is still in the discussion stage in the admiralties of the United States and Great Britain.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Nov. 22 for a hearing on an application by the United Public Utilities Corporation for approval of certain transactions designed to aid in its divestment of the Alabama United Ice Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Accusing the United Mine Workers of "cynical and repeated violations of the no-strike policy" and of "sowing confusion" among union members, three public members of the National War Labor Board commented today on the contract made by Secretary Ickes and John L. Lewis.

ALGIERS, Nov. 11 -- The French story in this provisional capital of France today is, for a change, not compounded of speeches, declarations or debates. It is the story of the greatest demonstration this city has known since the Allied invasion a year ago this week turned the world of the ordinary Algerian upside down while at the same time bringing new hope to the motherland across the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Advancing prices for agricultural products, particularly fresh milk, onions, potatoes and apples, brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets up 0.1 per cent during the first week of November.
TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The President attended Armistice Day ceremonies at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and had appointments with Vice President Wallace, Speaker Rayburn, Senator Barkley, Representative McCormack, Secretary Hull, Assistant Secretary of War McCloy, Maj. Gen. Norman Kirk and Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntyre.

A survey of 9,000 restaurants and other eating places in Manhattan recently completed by price panels of the Office of Price Administration has disclosed that about 3,400 were charging above ceiling prices, Joseph Kraeler, administrator of the New York County War Price and Rationing Boards, and Louis Maier, his deputy, announced yesterday.

Under a 1940 amendment to the Philippine Constitution President Manuel L. Quezon would have to leave office on Nov. 15 and would be succeeded by Vice President Sergio Osmena. A resolution passed by both houses of Congress and sent to the White House, with the support of Secretaries Hull, Stimson and Ickes, overrides this provision, extending the terms of both Mr. Quezon and Mr. Osmena until the Japanese are driven from the Islands.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Supported by American fighter-bomber sweeps in which eighteen Japanese river craft were destroyed, Chinese troops fought bitterly along a ninety-mile front between the Yangtze and Tungting Lake yesterday and brought the Japanese invasion of the "rice bowl" nearly to a stop, a Chinese communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- When the rich plantations of the Far East fell into the hands of the Japanese, the United Nations, desperate for rubber to sustain their war program and their domestic economy, turned to the Amazon Basin, the original habitat of the rubber tree.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Thousands of Pennsylvania's soft-coal miners took part in an Armistice Day work stoppage which operators said was a protest against a Government ruling denying them time-and-one-half pay for holiday work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, appearing somewhat refreshed by a night at home after his journey from Moscow, made an extended first-hand report to President Roosevelt today on the Foreign Ministers' conference at the Soviet capital which resulted in the Allied program for hastening of victory against the Axis and the preservation of peace in the postwar world.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The statement of condition of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday, issued today, reported an increase of 5,798,000 in note circulation. This rise established a new high record at 1,010,861,000.

Soap rationing -- predicted by alarmists on several occasions during the last year -- is "nothing but a myth," in the opinion of a spokesman for the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, "because rationing is unnecessary and, in the second place, because it is impossible."

Jake La Motta, Bronx middleweight, will go against Fritzie Zivic in the Madison Square Garden ring tonight almost a 1 to 2 favorite, according to prevailing opinion. The men are scheduled to go ten rounds and, judging by the results of their two previous meetings, will go the full route.

Four men and a woman, arrested as common gamblers and gambling house operators in a police raid early yesterday on the White House Bridge Association at 846 Seventh Avenue, haunt of Sam Boston, betting commissioner, were held-by Magistrate William Hoppin in Felony Court in $1,000 bail each for a hearing Dec. 1.

Newsprint production in Canada during October was reported as 259,336 tons yesterday by the News Print Service Bureau, with shipments placed at 261,594, while output in this country was given as 63,470 tons and shipments 63,209, making total United States and Canada output 322,806 and shipments 324,803.

Early ballots from more than twenty communities where American churchwomen already had voter on whether the United States should join a world organization to assure a just and durable peace and share the burden of its expense "and all other responsibilities," disclosed that more than 2,977 women favored this, while only 106 objected -- a ratio of 29 to 1 -- according to tabulations made yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- The Bayonne High School football team lost more than a game when it bowed to St. Peter's Prep 13 -- 12, in the traditional Armistice Day contest today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Merchants must refuse delivery of merchandise which would cause inventories to increase above the permitted limits of its Order L-219, the War Production Board announced today in an interpretation of this order.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today a simplification of the gasoline rationing program which will not give to consumers an more supplies but which is expected to make use of gasoline ration books more convenient both for consumers and dealers.

The effort that Soviet Russia has put forth in repelling the Germans reflects more than military preparation. Back of a powerful army stand equally powerful industries and back of the industries stand some 1,600 scientific institutions. Science is winning the war for Russia as well as for Great Britain and the United States.

In his fourth purchase of a dwelling on the West Side in three weeks, M.C. Berg, operator, has acquired from the United States Trust Company the five-story town house at 46 West Seventy-fourth Street, former home of Dr. Thomas J. Tobin.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Nov. 12 -- American Marines, reinforced by Army troops, definitely have won the first round of the vital battle for Bougainville, and attempts of the Japanese to becloud that fact by wild claims of having sunk many warships in the area are "without any basis whatsoever," Gen. Douglas MacArthur's spokesman said today.

Eleven of the thirty-nine players who entered the preliminaries of the United States Chess Federation's second annual amateur championship tournament yesterday at the Manhattan, Marshall and West Side Chess Clubs, were returned winners in their respective groups.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- As Red Army troops continued to advance across the Ukraine and into the encircled Crimea the army newspaper Red Star confidently predicted today that the enemy forces would be driven from Soviet soil in the near future.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Higgins family was happy tonight. Special Technician Franklin E. Higgins was home, and so was "Pal," 17-year-old dog which had been grieving away its life for him for four months.

The United States cannot continue on its "splendid course" of public education and expect to have enough unskilled labor, Mayor La Guardia asserted yesterday, in suggesting a system of seasonal immigration to meet the shortage.

For the performances of the Schumann "Manfred" overture and the Beethoven "Pastoral" symphony the concert given by Bruno Walter as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall will long be remembered.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, urged in no uncertain terms today an accelerated effort toward conservation of America's gasoline in the interest of the war program. He discussed the present situation before members of the American Petroleum Institute at their closing session here.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- As a result of a statement made in Parliament regarding production of synthetic rubber in this country, British Celanese shares rose to 30 3/8 shillings early today on the stock market. However, a later statement that the company would commence production eight months hence and that the Government would allow only a small priority caused some disappointment and the shares fell to 28 1/2 shillings.

The program of scholarship exchange recommended by the United States Committee on Education Reconstruction proposes that young men and women of the occupied countries be trained in American universities and technical schools. This is lend-lease applied to the field of education.

The dissenting bondholders committee of the Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railroad Company (Soo Line) has decided to abandon plans to appeal from a decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals approving the plan of reorganization, it was announced yesterday by Edward Lamb of Toledo, Ohio, attorney for the committee.
The spotlight of battle is shifting to western Europe.

During the first ten days of residential rent control in New York City and Nassau and Suffolk County 5,000 petitions were presented by landlords asking for upward adjustments in rentals for certain apartments, houses or rooms throughout the area, it was learned yesterday at the New York headquarters of Office of Price Administration.

The improved situation in the war at sea was reflected yesterday in the announcement of further reductions on cargo war-risk rates by commercial marine insurance underwriters. At the same time evidence that the War Shipping Administration expects the present comparatively favorable situation to continue improving was seen in the disclosure by officials of that agency that it will no longer issue schedules quoting war-risk rates on export shipments.

" I'll Take the High Road," from which Clifford Hayman and Milton Berle (its sponsors) expected more encouraging returns, will close tomorrow night at the Ritz, after chalking up only seven performances. The reviews were unfavorable and this time the critics were heeded.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A Chinese communique:

WITH ALLIED FIFTH ARMY, Nov. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army honored its dead in the beautiful United States military cemetery of Avellino, where 425 Americans and-sixty-one Germans lie buried. General Clark, in a brief speech to the dead and living soldiers, pleaded that the Fifth Army be kept together until the end of the war.

Leon Henderson, former administrator of the Office of Price Administration and now chairman of the board of editors of the Research Institute of America, called yesterday upon American Government and business leaders to formulate immediately "a dominant national philosophy and central economic policy for attaining and maintaining a high level of peace-time employment and production."

SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Stoney Brook Sheer Bliss, English springer spaniel owned by Capt and Mrs. James Simpson Jr. of Wadsworth, Ill., today was awarded first prize in the open all-age stake; the leading competition of the twentieth annual meeting of the English Springer Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association.

Increased equalization of educational opportunities both through a sound financial basis for public schooling and a revision of the State aid distribution plan were advocated yesterday by Dr. John H. Bosshart, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, for the long-range educational program he declared was needed.

No doubt it is only an habitual pessimist who can look at "What's Up" and find it not altogether to his liking. All the elements of a Broadway musical show are there. The tunes are fairly catchy. Jimmy Savo -- who undoubtedly is among the great folk of the world -- is present, and the cast otherwise is made up of young people who are alike fresh and eager.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Regulation of radio broadcasting must be by "a commission set up to live with the industry," and not by any other agency of Government, or left as a matter of statute law to the courts, James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said at today's hearing on the Wheeler-White radio bill before the Interstate Commerce Committee of the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A grave Franklin D. Roosevelt stood bareheaded in a cold wind at 11 A.M. today in solemn salute to the nation's unknown dead.

Shipping, air transport, com- munications, oil, rubber and minerals are "possible items of conflict between Great Britain and the United States" after the war, Senator Ralph C. Brewster said last night, and he urged that great advantage would result from frank and friendly discussion of the problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -Pvt. Joe P. Martinez of Ault, Col., a 23-year-old former farm worker, has been posthumously awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for leading an attack which finally dislodged the Japanese from a stronghold on Attu Island in the Aleutians.

The question of when garments of synthetic rubber elastic will become available continues the major topic in the corset industry. While sample models may be included in the spring lines to be shown beginning Nov. 29, indications were that it would be several months at least before production is on the market.

Organized community action on a national scale for education as an antidote to the growing racial and minority tensions and prejudices in this country was urged last night by Attorney General Francis Biddle as the most likely effective method of coping with this problem.

George W. Norris of Nebraska was by no means the only progressive member of the United States Senate who voted against the League of Nations twenty-four years ago. He was one of the small group of liberal or radical Western Senators who formed the core of the opposition to the Woodrow Wilson peace settlement, even if history has designated Henry Cabot Lodge for the role of chief opponent.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Rockingham Park today saw its pari-mutuel record shattered as a crowd of 31,238 wagered $1,335,287 during a double-header program for the benefit of the National War Fund, Inc. That amount was for fourteen races, six of which were run during the morning.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Mush March skated through the Bruins' defense to score one goal and maintain threatening sorties throughout as the Black Hawks gained a 6-4 National Hockey League victory tonight before a crowd of 8,423.

Mrs. Junius S. Morgan will give a tea this afternoon at her home for a large group of persons active in behalf of the forthcoming exhibition of forty-two paintings from the J.P. Morgan collection to be held at the Knoedler Galleries from Nov. 24 to Dec. 11 for the benefit of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill's declaration before the House of Commons that the Greek people alone will ultimately decide their king's future has been received in Greek emigre circles here with noticeable satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Declaring that "the United States is once again on the road to victory," Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, in an Armistice Day review of America's military might, announced that Army casualties in twenty-three months of war have been 89,650, including 12,841 killed, compared with 260,496 casualties, including 50,280 dead, in the entire nineteen months of World War I.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- More than 2,000,000 rooms, providing living quarters for 6,000,000 Germans, have been destroyed by Allied bombs, Nazi statistics revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Charging that the British Government blocked shipment of food to starving European children, although American officials and public opinion were in favor of rescuing the Nazi victims, Dr. Howard E. Kershner told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today that that policy might leave only Germany healthy enough to reconstruct the Continent in the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Reports that the Administration was seeking a compromise on the subsidy issue revived at the Capitol today after legislative leaders discussed the question with the President at the White House. However, Vice President Wallace, Speaker Rayburn, Senator Barkley, majority leader, and the House majority leader, Representative McCormack, had little to say after they left the President.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Unanimously elected director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York announced his acceptance in a speech over the radio tonight.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 11 -- Completely unconfirmed reports reaching here tonight said 800 persons were killed in Grenoble and Lyon in Armistice Day rioting in France.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 11 -- With the atmosphere clarified -- rather unfavorably for them -- by interpretations given by Washington, London and Moscow to the tri-partite agreement reached in Moscow, the Finns are settling down earnestly to find a formula for instituting peace negotiations with the Russians before Dec. 6, which is the date of Finland's Independence Day.

WITH THE ALLIED FIFTH ARMY, Nov. 10 (Delayed) -- War correspondents go to the front to see action, to find out what progress we are making along those roads that lead to Rome, to get individual stories of bravery or interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Roosevelt informed Congress today in his twelfth lend-lease report that Great Britain has agreed to stop taking dollars for raw materials and foodstuffs provided to us by the British Empire. Instead, he said, these contributions, as well as the shipping to deliver them, will be counted as reverse lend-lease, offsetting our lend-lease aid to the British.

The Army Air Force urgently needs women who will take over important jobs at air fields, bases and other AAF installations. The AAF is enrolling Air-Wacs, making it possible for women who wish to serve directly with the air forces to join the branch of their choice. This is a new plan in Women's Army Corps recruiting.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 11 -- Germans have been using badly needed soldiers to hunt down Jews in Rome. Since a few days after the Germans occupied Rome, troops have been loading men, women and children into trucks and transporting them to unknown destinations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Dr. George W. Calver prescribed today a long period of rest and relaxation for what he called "an overworked, nervous and underpaid Congress." If he had his way, the Capitol physician said, he would order a recess until the first of the year, "to let members go home for a needed respite."
LONDON, Friday, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 -- The most difficult problem connected with the employment of women in industry pivots about child care, Dr. C.O. Sappington of Chicago stated today in a report on the results of a survey made under a grant by the Industrial Hygiene Foundation.

After passing its half-year mark, the Army Specialized Training Program is now operating close to capacity, officials of the War Department disclosed yesterday. Scheduled to maintain a maximum of 150,000 trainees, the program contains 140,000 student-soldiers in 222 colleges and universities in every part of the country.
The appeal for fishing tackle by service men overseas has been officially recognized by the War Department, and 25,000 kits have been ordered.

Coach Steve Owen figuratively put the whip to his Giants in their workout yesterday for Sunday's game with the Bears at the Polo Grounds, emphasis being placed on defense against Sid Luckman's long and often touchdown-producing passes.

The Borie was an antique destroyer, born in 1917, a survivor of that war, which any smart young ensign, ignorant of her record, would have been justified in calling an old tub. To make her more obscure, she was named after Grant's first Secretary of the Navy, who held that office less than four months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Canada and the United States agreed today to elevate their respective legations in Washington and Ottawa to the rank of embassy in recognition of the growing importance of their relations.

HOLLYWOD, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Dwight Frye, who was well known on the New York stage before coming to Hollywood for his first film appearance in 1930, died here on Sunday after a heart attack. His age was 44.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 (Delayed) -- Sixteen American farm pioneers, all of whom forsook urban occupations in the United States to enter a life upon the soil of Palestine, today joined fifty other young English, Canadian, South African and Baltic Jews at ceremonial exercises naming their new village for the French Socialist, former Premier Leon Blum, who is now held by the Nazis.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $23,205,451 in United States currency after charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.49 each on 14,584,025 common shares outstanding.

Paintings from the J.P. Morgan collection will be shown at the Knoedler Galleries from Nov. 24 through Dec. 11 for the benefit of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy. Mrs. Carle C. Conway is chairman of the executive committee and the ticket committee includes Mrs. Robert B. Bradley, Mrs. Arthur A. Ballantine, Mrs. Bruce Barton and Mrs. C. Kenneth Clinton.

I wonder if the well-meaning authors of laudatory articles and movie scripts concerning the Army nurse really know her exact status? I'm afraid even nurses don't know. I'm forced to conclude Congress doesn't care. She is a rubber stamp officer without full rank, privileges and oversea pay accorded male and Wac officers of equal rank.

Bitten by one of his seven pet rattlesnakes while attempting to clean the snake's cage, John McDonough, 17 years old, of 2448 Sixty-four Street, Brooklyn, was in a critical condition at Crown Heights Hospital, Brooklyn, last night after anti-venom serum obtained at the Bronx Zoo had been injected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- As late as July 31, 1941, little more than four months before Pearl Harbor, Japan officially told the United States that the Japanese Navy "would do everything possible to prevent a war between the United States and Japan."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Fifty enlisted men who, in order to advance medical research, voluntarily gambled with their lives by exposing themselves to malaria infection for a period of six weeks in the New Guinea jungles, have been awarded the Legion of Merit, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- An Army Intelligence Service report disclosing that the military might of the Axis is increasing rather than diminishing was made public today by Representative George E. Outland, Democrat of Calif., a first-term member of the House, as "an antidote to false optimism and wishful thinking" in this country.

PORTAGE, Wis., Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie warned today that Republican leaders were inviting a repetition of the "disastrous results" of Warren G. Harding's nomination by pushing "favorite sons" into the Presidential campaign to prevent any one candidate from amassing strength before the party's national convention.

The New York State Nurses Association took up a new role yesterday as representative for members of the profession in a wage increase appeal -- a case expected to establish this group as mediator in other questions affecting nurses' salaries and working conditions.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 11 -- Warnings that every division of the aviation industry faced chaotic conditions immediately after the war unless a program for the solution of post-war problems was speedily evolved were sounded by speakers opening the industry's "first national clinic of domestic aviation planning," which convened in the Oklahoma Capitol today.

John Adams scored a thrilling 12-7 victory over Xavier of Manhattan in their holiday football clash at Dexter Park, Queens, yesterday. A recovered faulty pass in Xavier's end zone gave Adams a first-period touchdown, but Xavier went ahead when Campo registered on John McCrane's 15-yard aerial and John Carlin placekicked the extra point in the second quarter.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 11 (AP) -Conservative Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, in his strongest speech of the war, declared tonight, "Our time has come to strike; henceforth we propose to give the Jap no rest anywhere."

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 11 (AP) -Conservative Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, in his strongest speech of the war, declared tonight, "Our time has come to strike; henceforth we propose to give the Jap no rest anywhere."

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 12 -- Soviet forces yesterday smashed within striking distance of Zhitomir and the last German-held north-south railroad east of the old Polish frontier, while to the north they resumed their offensive between Chernigov and Rechitsa, killing 2,000 Nazis and throwing them into another retreat.

Harry Wolkof, a power in the Brooklyn Democratic organization when the late John H. McCooey was county leader, has been suspended as the chief clerk of Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, Municipal Court by President Justice Keyes Winters of the Municipal Courts, it was disclosed yesterday.

ALL Washington Senators do not deserve censure. Nor do all of them deserve praise. But there was one particular group of Senators -- Clark Griffith prefers to call them "Nationals" -- who rate a very profound bow even at this late date. They are the baseball variety of the Senators who finished the American League campaign as runner-up to the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -The Navy announced today award of the Legion of Merit to Rear Admiral Francis W. Rockwell, for meritorious conduct as commander of an assault force which attacked Attu Island in the Aleutians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Capt. William B. Hubbell of New York, Intelligence Officer of the Eleventh Fighter Command, was killed in action Nov. 4 as a result of an operational aircraft accident in the Alaskan theatre, the War Department said today.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 11 -The Federal Government is doing "everything humanly possible" to assure every disabled service man of the present war an opportunity to rehabilitate himself and again become a "self-supporting member of the community," Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of United States Veterans Affairs, declared today.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- This nation remembered those who died in the earlier war for a brave new world today as Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden unfolded to the House of Commons and British people the shape of the world to come.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- Phyllis Thaxter, who was signed to a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer term contract several weeks ago after her Los Angeles stage appearance in the title role of "Claudia," will have the feminine lead in "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo" as her first film part.

Psychological "public enemies" that menace the coming generation must be fought with expanded educational and research programs, financed to an increased extent by Government funds, Dr. Nolan D.C. Lewis, Professor of Psychiatry at Columbia University, asserted yesterday.
The German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

TORONTO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A "picture'' goal by the veteran Lorne Carr in the last few seconds tonight gave the Maple Leafs a 2-2 tie with Detroit in a National Hockey League game. It was the second draw between the two teams this season.

HAVANA, Nov. 11 -- In view of the announced shortage of alcohol in the United States, sugar producers here are puzzled over the delay of the Defense Supplies Corporation in purchasing Cuba's available 1944 supply of molasses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A drop in the public's contributions of blood plasma because of Allied victories could mean "thousands of unnecessary Gold Star mothers on armistice day, World War II," Dr. G. Canby Robinson, national director of the Red Cross blood donor service, stated today.

The National Association of Manufacturers, through its manpower committee, yesterday called upon its members to make immediate and thorough surveys of their labor needs in an effort to avert national conscription of labor.

Nearly $20,000,000 worth of War Bonds have been sold to date in exchange for forty-eight manuscripts at the first fifteen of a nation-wide series of Book and Author War Bond rallies, it was announced yesterday at the first meeting of the Book and Author Manuscript Committee.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Great Britain's contributions to the war effort of the Allied powers through reverse lend-lease were reported today for the first time in a statement on mutual aid drawn up for Parliament by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir John Anderson.

Dashing, wearable hats took their place on the Plaza Hotel's runway yesterday noon in the Persian room. Erik, whose letterhead carries Paris, London and New York addresses, exhibited styles that he thinks suitable for daytime and evening wear in town, and also gave a forward-looking glimpse of resort and summer fashions.

TULE LAKE, Calif., Nov. 11 -- Disloyal Japanese aliens and citizens occupying the Tule Lake segregation center today engaged in an Armistice Day sit-down strike which reputedly paralyzed clerical and administrative operations. Those assigned to jobs reported for work but sat idly by doing no work.

ALGIERS, Nov. 11 -- While the Allies slugged their way forward for several sues on the central and north central sectors in Italy and the Eighth Army pounded its way to the Sangro River in the Adriatic coastal region, aerial photography indicated that the Nazis were scuttling ships and demolishing quays at Leghorn and Pescara.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 11 -- According to information available here, said by British authorities to be accurate, Jean Helleu, French National Committee of Liberation delegate to Lebanon and Syria, on returning from Beirut after consulting with higher French authorities in North Africa, ordered the arrest today of President Bechara El-Khoury, Premier Riad Solh and such other members of the Lebanese Government as could be found.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 (AP) -- An American communique:

Canned corned beef, a convenience for those who cook in haste, will be virtually impossible to buy in a short time, for an order just issued by the Combined Food Board reserves all supplies for troops in action. Service men in this country and civilians must depend on the local butchers who corn such cuts as brisket, plate and rump on their own premises.

If anything like the health insurance bill that Senator Wagner has introduced is to become law we shall need much more than an organization of physicians to distribute medical care uniformly. We seem to have learned nothing from Great Britain. Like that country we assume that medical education can be left to the schools and teaching hospitals, with the practitioner of medicine dealing with patients much as he now does in workmen's compensation cases.

ALGIERS, Nov. 11 -- In his first direct statement for publication since a press conference in London July 22, Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud assured this correspondent today in written answers to written questions that any representative of French resistance who felt that he, General Giraud, retained ties with Vichy was "misinformed"; and that the only reason he had refrained from a formal disavowal was that on principle he preferred not to insult other Frenchmen.
Helped by 22,577 shivering fans yesterday the Victory racing at Jamaica, which completed its seventh day, went far over the top in comparison with last year's meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -The Republican National Committee today recognized a grass roots desire for more participation in party affairs by inviting State leaders to meet with committee-men to select the time and place for the 1944 Republican convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The War Department announced today the names of 166 United States soldiers listed as missing in action. The announcement included casualties in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean, Pacific and southwest Pacific areas.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 13 -- One Japanese cruiser and two destroyers were sunk and a cruiser and eleven destroyers were damaged by a force of more than 200 Allied planes at the major enemy base of Rabaul, New Britain, on Thursday.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 13 -Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin's First Ukrainian Army yesterday pounded within shelling range of Zhitomir, most important Ukrainian junction still in German hands, and beat off determined Nazi attacks near Fastov, southwest of Kiev, destroying seventy enemy tanks in a day-long engagement.

OTTAWA, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press) -- A "pink pill" cure and preventive for seasickness and airsickness -effective for 75 per cent of persons normally susceptible -has been developed by the Royal Canadian Navy in a major medical advance of the war, it was announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -About 25,000 persons will see Yale and Princeton teams write the sixty-seventh chapter of one of the greatest rivalries in American college football when they clash tomorrow in the Yale Bowl. The series, dating from 1873, has been continuous since 1876 except for the First World War years of 1917 and 1918.

GUADALCANAL, Nov. 5 (Delayed) (AP) -- Several hundred seaborne marine paratroopers fooled Japanese forces on Choiseul Island in the northern Solomons for more than a week into thinking they were an invasion force of 20,000.

Giving Jake La Motta of the Bronx a pull of more than eleven pounds proved too much for that doughty warrior of the ring, Fritzie Zivic, former world welterweight champion, in Madison Square Garden last night.
