A warning against permitting the Federal Government to exercise control over the education of returning servicemen and displaced industrial workers at the end of the war was voiced yesterday at a conference of State college and university presidents and the Board of Regents during which a broad program of post-war education in the State was discussed.
Dr. George W. Calver, the Capitol physician, prescribes a long period of rest and relaxation for what he calls "an overworked, nervous and underpaid Congress."

Canada and the United States have agreed that their respective legations at Washington and Ottawa shall henceforth be styled embassies. At present the Canadian representative and those of the other Dominions at Washington have the title of Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -Vicki Baum's magazine serial "Hotel Berlin -- 1943" has been bought by Warner Brothers for production early next year. Herman Shumlin, who handled "The Watch on the Rhine" for that company, will direct it and Hal B. Wallis will be the producer.

The Manuscript Committee of the Book and Author War Bond Committee now holds a reserve of forty-six manuscripts, to be auctioned at future Book and Author War Bond rallies. The manuscripts include the first typescript of John P. Marquand's "So Little Time," a forthcoming scientific paper by Albert Einstein, a letter of Richard Strauss, an autograph of Johannes Brahms and the manuscript of "The Coming Victory of Democracy,'' by Thomas Mann.

People had better think twice before they take Mr. La Guardia as the starting point for revolutionary ideas in the use of language. The Mayor has just asked the Federal Communications Commission for a ruling on his post-election broadcast over the municipal radio.

The Ways and Means Committee has now approved a wholly inadequate tax bill which would raise only a fifth of the new revenue asked for by the Treasury. To the extent that we fail to siphon off excess purchasing power in the hands of the people, the alternative must be inflation.

The silver jubilee of the United Lutheran Church in America will be observed tomorrow in the 4,083 churches by its 3,635,588 baptized members. The pastors have been asked to preach on the text from Joshua xiii, 1: "There remaineth yet very much land to be possessed," and to proclaim the motto adopted for the celebration which is "Toward God's Golden Goals."

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Rumania, faced with the entrapment of four divisions of her army in the Crimea, today was reported evacuating thousands of civilians from eastern areas threatened by the advancing Red armies.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Arguments in a case which may determine whether the National Labor Relations Board has jurisdiction over a utility corporation operating entirely within a State were heard today by the Fourth United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

EVER since the first World War Count Coudenhove-Kalergi has carried on unremitting propaganda for a federated European Continent. He tells the story of his wily, pertinacious, resourceful but as yet unsuccessful struggle in "Crusade for Pan-Europe,"* a book that just possibly might become for the United States of Europe what "The Federalist" is and has been to the United States of America.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Governor-elect Walter E. Edge took the first step today in his program far the revision of the State's ninety-nine-year-old Constitution with the appointment of three committees comprising Republican members of the Legislature to study the matter and undertake the "necessary spade work" for revision by the Legislature during the 1944 session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A Senate investigation into the disappearance of liquors from retail markets, the prices imposed for secondary blends or lesser qualities, and the state of supplies was proposed at the Capitol today and apparently gained widespread support.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Aerial photos taken prior to the raid -- the latest in a series which have dealt crushing blows, particularly among the cruisers, at Rabaul -- showed twenty-three Japanese warships in Rabaul's harbor or just outside in Blanche Bay.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A substantial percentage of rayon-weaving facilities now operating on Army contracts are expected to be freed for production of civilian fabrics as a result of the impending Army cut-back in procurement of fragmentation-bomb parachutes, the War Production Board announced today.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- Heartened by growing air support, Chinese forces have begun successful counter-attacks against the Japanese south of the Yangtze River in central China, recapturing several strategic points and inflicting heavy losses on the enemy, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's High Command announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Making a sweeping denial of Japan's "incredible and fantastic" claims of sinking scores of American warships, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox revealed today that a big American carrier had just scored an outstanding victory against four waves of attacking enemy planes, thus defeating the only threat the enemy has offered recently to any of our major ships.

Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State and chairman of the New York Republican County Committee, charged yesterday that Mayor La Guardia was trying to maneuver him into an unwarranted three party symposium on the recent nomination and election of Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court.

The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. will conduct the thirty-fifth renewal of its cross-country run today at Van Cortlandt Park. With most of the teams unknown quantities because of the calls made by the armed forces and because of Navy and Marine transfers, the fifteen teams engaging in today's meet will toe the mark with no outstanding favorite among them.

Dominating the play throughout, the strong Poly Prep football machine grounded out an 18-0 victory over St. Paul's School of Garden City at Poly's Field in the thirty-sixth annual meeting between the prep school rivals. The Long Islanders continue to lead in the series, eighteen victories to seventeen with one contest ending in a tie.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12 (AP) -- One of a formation of enemy planes that unsuccessfully attempted to approach Colombo, on the island of Ceylon, was shot down today by anti-aircraft fire as Allied heavy, medium and dive bombers roared over Japanese-occupied Burma to attack communications and military installations.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 12 -- Attempts to compare the relative contributions of the United States and New Zealand to the war drive under reciprocal aid were deplored by Acting Prime Minister Walter Nash last night in a comprehensive survey of what the two-way traffic between the Antipodes and America has meant up to a few weeks ago.

Brooklyn College moves into Lewisohn Stadium today to square off against its interboro rival, C.C.N.Y., in their return contest. A capacity crowd is expected to be on hand as Brooklyn goes all out to avenge an earlier 22-6 setback at the hands of the Beavers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The Central Vermont Public Service Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration covering the proposed issue of 195,000 shares of no par common stock as a part of its plan of reorganization. The plan has been approved by the SEC.

The Department of Justice asked the United States District Court here yesterday to declare illegal and void certain by-laws of The Associated Press, and to enjoin the cooperative news-gathering agency from adhering in the future to these or any similar rules.

While interested physicians looked on, Sister Elizabeth Kenny demonstrated yesterday the efficacy of her revolutionary ministrations on a score of young paralysis victims in Adelphi Hospital, Greene Avenue and Adelphi Street, Brooklyn.

Charging that "big business is campaigning to halt our democratic progress in the post-war period by calling for an unchanged America," Dr. Robert S. Lynd, Professor of Sociology at Columbia University, proposed yesterday that the United States operate under a centralized, national, planned economy after the war.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 12 -Cotton textile mills that lag behind in new equipment as well as in new, better and cheaper products will fall by the wayside during the post-war era of new competitive forces, Dr. H.E. Michl, economist of the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., New York, declared today at the annual meeting here of the North Carolina Cotton Manufacturers Association.

Telegrams were sent last night to President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull asking that the United States intervene "to help stabilize conditions in the Republic of Lebanon," it was announced by S.A. Mokarzel, president of the Lebanon League of Progress, with offices at 55 Washington Street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -Work in the children's field is the "most worthwhile and challenging" on the home front, Sister Paulette of Nazareth College, Rochester, said today in citing the need of volunteers in Catholic institutions and charities agencies for children.

I am surprised at the article in THE TIMES of Nov. 5 from your correspondent in Naples, Herbert L. Matthews, about the "cool" reception King Victor Emmanuel had there. Knowing well the Neapolitans, I am forced to doubt the veracity of this statement.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 12 -- The German Army today imposed curfew measures effective up to Nov. 21 as a "warning of still more severe actions to come" in the Milan area unless there is a modification of the public attitude, according to a broadcast from Munich to the Italian people tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 (AP) -Fierce street disorders in Beirut, capital of Lebanon, were described tonight by a traveler who said public feeling was running higher by the hour over the arrest of the small republic's President, Premier and some Cabinet members.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The thorny issue of food subsidies will come before the House again Thursday with consideration of the Commodity Credit Corporation Bill, and subsidy foes are predicting another victory over the Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Senate heard Senator George charge that OPA enforcement practices were "indefensible and un-American," passed a House-approved resolution designating Dec. 7 as Armed Services Honor Day, received an amendment by Senator Ball cutting in half the $30,000,000 appropriation for newspaper promotion of war bond sales and recessed at 1:52 P.M. until noon Monday.

Four scientists will receive the Townsend Harris Medal, awarded by City College's Associate Alumni for "notable post-graduate attainments," at the sixty-third annual dinner of the society tomorrow evening at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Parachute spinnakers, those bulging balloons which have been banned in yachting since the start of the war, will be carried next summer by the Atlantic class sloops on Long Island Sound. That was voted last night at the dinner-meeting of the class at the Hotel Shelton.

Attorney General Francis Biddle, addressing a meeting in New York, said that though our Axis enemies may not have directly caused outbreaks of racial and religious intolerance in this country, they do profit by them. We do have groups which deliberately foment hatred "against Negroes, against Jews, against foreigners, against liberals, against all who believe in a tolerant democracy."

Thompson Products, Inc., manufacturer of engine parts and other steel products, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended with September, net profit of $2,018,912, equal to $6.43 a common share after estimated taxes on income and reserves for contingencies and renegotiation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Major changes in the top command of the War Production Board were in view tonight, with Executive Vice Chairman Charles E. Wilson returning to private industry and Chairman Donald M. Nelson resuming active control of both operations and policy.

Fearful lest the shortage of whiskies and the growth of black markets result in additional legal restrictions on their businesses, distillers, wholesalers, importers and retailers were all looking yesterday for some way of stamping out illicit practices and reassuring consumers that they are getting a fair share of liquor stocks.
An exhibition called "Prints of Our Allies" opened yesterday in the Brooklyn Museum, arranged by Una E. Johnson, curator of prints and drawings. This work may be seen through Dec. 5.

Not more than 300 men in the stock market community are concerned in the current argument about what the Treasury Department calls "over-riding commissions." These, it will be recalled, were omitted specifically from the ruling of the department that the old system of paying commission salesmen might be continued in force until the year-end.
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- In Serbia, near Uzice, seventy miles each of Sarajevo, the Partisans said they were engaged in fierce battles with Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's regular army forces, and the Partisans' Second and Third Brigades were said to be fighting Mikhailovitch troops on Majevica Mountain, in Bosnia.

Following is the text of a document filed with the United States District Court here yesterday by the Department of Justice, as a proposed final judgment in the Government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press:

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The concentration of Allied air power from west and south against the railroad system that is an integral part of the Nazis' defenses of Europe continued over Thursday with smashing pincers blows at the coastal lines between France and Italy.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Armed with a report that the Middle West would not furnish the Northeast with desperately needed winter feed for cattle and poultry, Governor Thomas E. Dewey warned today that the people of New York State faced an immediate crisis in their supply of fresh milk and eggs unless the economic policies of Federal agencies were changed forthwith.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Removal of hedges against shipping sales of 150,000 bushels of cash wheat, disposed of by local handlers, and buying by millers in connection with sales of flour to the Government earlier in the week advanced futures nearby 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

ALGIERS, Nov. 12 -- The Allied armies in Italy came to a virtual standstill yesterday as the weather worsened and the Germans clung stubbornly to the Garigliano-Sangro line, which prisoners and documents have said the German command intends to hold at least eight weeks.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- German invasion forces attacked early this morning the Dodecanese island of Leros, which has been in British hands since mid-September during the early days of the Aegean operations. Tonight's Middle East communique said that the enemy gained a footing at some points.

The twelve regional banks of the Federal Reserve System were heavy buyers of United States Government securities in the open market in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Amendment of the 1934 Communications Act as provided in the Wheeler-White Radio Bill was recommended at today's hearing before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee by Horace L. Lohnes and Herbert M. Bingham, of the Federal Communications Bar Association, a group of specialists on radio law who have been admitted to practice before the Federal Communications Commission.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- The Big Six Novice War Bond Stake featured the first session of the twenty-second annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England at Horticultural Hall today, with Joseph W. Crabbe judging.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Cooler weather spurred retail trade activity here this week. Department stores had an increase averaging around 8 per cent, a figure which may be bettered if temperatures are in the lower ranges today. Armistice Day trade was brisk, with many departments sharing in the added volume. Gift buying is now on the increase, although the pace is slower than merchants would like to see for this month.

The three four-family houses at 7914-18-22 Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, have been sold by P. Walker Morrison, Lazarus Joseph and Leon Leighton, trustees of series B-K, to a client of the Messina Realty Company, broker. Kramer Kaprow represented the sellers.

This city's fourth and latest tussle with proportional representation has produced a City Council in which the candidates generally favored by P.R.'s warmest friends are decidedly in the minority. The inertia of the voters, by reducing the number of votes cast, has cut the Council from twenty-six to seventeen members.

Huge quantities of tobacco stocks reserved for the armed forces coupled with a serious labor shortage and an increasing domestic demand, were said by industry spokesmen yesterday to be the principal factors responsible for the growing scarcity of popular brands of cigarettes and low-priced cigars.

The OPA's announcement this week that no revisions will be made before the end of the year in MPR-339, governing prices of women's rayon stockings, means that current advertising plans will not be disturbed during the holiday buying season, always the peak turnover period at retail for the product, it was declared yesterday by merchandisers.

OTTAWA, Nov. 12 -- The employment of drafted men of the lower medical categories on railway "development and maintenance" has been authorized by an order of the Canadian Government, it was learned today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 12 -- Gen. Georges Catroux, who has a long record for shrewd and successful dealings with the Moslem population, will leave immediately for Beirut to see what can be done with the suddenly disquieting situation in Lebanon, the French Committee of National Liberation announced tonight.

BERNE, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- Eight persons were killed and scores, including women and children, were injured by police gunfire at Milan as citizens of German-occupied northern Italy defied a German curfew and celebrated World War I Armistice Day, border dispatches said today.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Full employment with the highest possible yield to the country, something never achieved in any save a totalitarian State, will be attempted in Britain after the war, Herbert Morrison, Home Security Minister, said tonight. He spoke of a translation of social security from theory into practice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An intimation was given by William Green today that the American Federation of Labor might withdraw its members from the National War Labor Board. Writing to Chairman William H. Davis in protest against a statement issued by Mr. Davis and two other public members of the board suggesting the possible need of more drastic labor legislation than now exists, the president of the AFL said:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- Angry protests and biting comment and threats were heard from many quarters in the Arab world today as reports continued to come in from Lebanon, where the French are said to have established martial law and entrusted its enforcement in a good portion to Senegalese soldiers.

The menus for next week, as those for the last month or so, require the use of any six eggs. This limited number is employed because the supply of large grade A's, the kind preferred by New York housekeepers, is inadequate to meet the demands.

A nine-point program for a national fiscal policy for the post-war period designed to aid in reaching a healthy condition of high employment and high production was outlined last night by Dr. Beardsley Ruml, treasurer of R.H. Macy Co. and chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a lecture on the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation at the Hunter College auditorium, 695 Park Avenue.

David Sarnoff, president of the ] Radio Corporation of America, and William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, have failed to reach an accord with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musiicans, on the recording situation, it was disclosed yesterday.

A check representing a contribution of $4,161 was presented yesterday to Arthur A. Ballantine, president of The Greater New York Fund, by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at a ceremony held in Mr. Sulzberger's office, 229 West Forty-third Street.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ALGIERS, Nov. 12 -- A leading French Communist told this correspondent today that Gen. Charles de Gaulle had specifically offered to the Communist party the extremely important post of Commissioner of Information on the Committee for National Liberation and that the party was now "waiting for the formal appointment by the committee."

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A state of near chaos in the Carpatho-Ukraine, easternmost province of Hungary and formerly the southeastern tip of Czechoslovakia, was reported today by the Czech Government in London as Premier Nicholas von Kallay of Hungary fervently appealed to his countrymen for suppression of anti-Axis outbreaks.

Cross currents were at work yesterday in the stock market with the result that early gains failed to hold and the closing was mixed, with emphasis on the lower side. Brokers reported a continuation of the mild selling to establish results for tax purposes, and business was again lighter, transfers on the Stock Exchange reaching only 796,367 shares, the smallest in a week, against 926,000 shares for the pre-holiday session of Wednesday.

Princess Juliana of the Netherlands yesterday told a gathering of Dutch women here that a women's corps would be organized and trained for relief work in the Netherlands after that country's liberation.

Educational and charitable institutions shared $121,298 of the estate of Mrs. Ines Stress, widow of Ludwig Stross, it was disclosed yesterday in a transfer tax proceeding. Mrs. Stross died on July 18, 1942, leaving a gross estate of $344,564 and a net of $311,121.

On Tuesday morning this newspaper published the most complete version of Hitler's speech which was then at hand: an abridged text broadcast from Germany by the official news agency DNB, recorded in London and then brought from London to New York by The United Press.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- With his wife sitting by his side, Alfred de Marigny announced today that he would not leave Nassau despite a recommendation by the jury that freed him of murder charges that he be deported immediately.

Nine civic organizations yesterday petitioned Congress to enact a Federal sales tax in place of other measures designed to raise wartime revenue. The petition also urged the greatest possible economy in nonessential Government spending.

Balloting by American Protestant church women, under auspices of the United Council of Church Women, on the proposal that the United States join a world organization to assure just and durable peace disclosed a ratio of 132 to 1 favoring the proposal, with 83,134 voting yes and 630 no, when additional tabulations were completed yesterday at 156 Fifth Avenue.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Men's and boys' clothing is being allocated by manufacturers among their customers, a check of producers here revealed as the first week of the current market neared its close.

China must have three kinds of security -- military, political and economic -- in order that future peace in the Far East be fully insured, Chang Kia-ngau, former general manager of the Bank of China and until recently Chinese Minister of Communications, told a group of industrial and financial executives yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Protracted negotiations by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes to obtain a participation for the Government in the development of the exclusive oil rights of the California Arabian Standard Oil Company in Saudi Arabia have broken down and no agreement is in sight. Reports to this effect from bust-: hess sources were confirmed today from a high official of the Government close to the negotiations.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- United States Ambassador Norman Armour has informally protested to Argentina against the Buenos Aires police treatment of the local representative of the Coordinator of InterAmerican Affairs over a shipment of anti-Nazi posters, reports reaching here said today.

A plan for the organization of one or two subordinate opera companies, under the aegis of the Metropolitan Opera Association, that would put on good performances throughout the country was outlined by Thomas L. Sidlo of Cleveland, chairman of the Northern Ohio Opera Company, at the luncheon given yesterday by the Metropolitan Opera Guild at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The illegal possession of enough ration stamps to purchase 250,000 pounds of meat was charged yesterday to two men, while two others were accused of the wrongful possession of a million general food stamps. The defendants were brought in, in pairs, by agents of the Secret Service.
Thirteen are entered in today's $10,000 added Victory Handicap at Jamaica, the stake which will end the nine-day Victory meeting in progress since Nov. 4, but not more than twelve will run.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- John F. Sonnett has been appointed chief of the New York office of the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice, Tom C. Clark, assistant Attorney General in charge of that division, announced today.

A list of new securities, more diversified than recently, was offered this week to investors here, but the volume was still small by comparison with weekly financing in October. Four issues of bonds aggregating $11,025,000 were marketed, compared with two tax-exempt offerings last week totaling $4,650,000 and three State and municipal loans amounting to $2,098,000 in this week a year ago.

The New York Stock Exchange on Nov. 24 will consider transfer of the membership of John J. Robinson to Joseph V. Shields and that of Donald M. White to Charles A. Frankhauser. Charles A. Frankhauser is to be admitted to Hackney, Hopkinson Sutphen on Nov. 24.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- Two hundred and forty-three Polish officers and soldiers, including a woman and a priest were decorated today by the Supreme Presidium of the Soviet Union, and Soviet newspapers told how they had charged German soldiers with the battle-cry, "Follow me, avengers of Warsa."

As an antidote for ready-to-wear restrictions in fabric and style, clever American designers brightened fall dresses with splashy sequin motifs, bold floral sprays, and embroideries copied from the Chinese.

" The Battle of Russia," fifth in the series of orientation films produced by the Army under the supervision of the former Hollywood producer-director, Lieut. Col. Frank Capra, will begin its first local public showing this morning at the Globe.

The directors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., at a meeting held yesterday authorized prepayment on Dec. 1 of an additional $2,000,000 of the company's debt, making a total reduction of about $13,000,000 in debt of the company and consolidated subsidiaries since Jan. 2.

ADMIRAL HALSEY'S ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Saturday, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- A smashing marine counter-attack Tuesday against a new Japanese threat on the eastern flank of Allied positions on Empress Augusta Bay, Bougainville Island, resulted in the killing of 300 enemy troops and a gain of several hundred yards, Admiral William F. Halsey's headquarters spokesman revealed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Insurance against isolationism is the outstanding aim of the national board meeting of the National League of Women Voters, to be held here next week.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Henry Ford said today that if present plans worked out, big multipleengine, cargo-passenger planes would be manufactured at Willow Run after the war.

Warning that the ground must be laid now so that after the war builders of highly specialized naval craft "will not be turned out to grass as they were after the last war," Homer L. Ferguson, president of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, called last night upon the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers to "take the lead in preventing chaos in the shipbuilding industry."

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Evidences of uncertainty appeared today again in the stock markets here, but some prices rallied. British Celanese, which had risen on its supposed bright prospects in the synthetic rubber industry, suffered a further fall, closing at 28 3/4s, but Courtaulds picked up.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Sixteen persons were seized here this afternoon by Westchester County deputy sheriffs and New Rochelle police in raids on an alleged policy slip bank and six shops accused of being drops for policy runners and bookmakers.
Dyche Stadium, close by Lake Michigan in Evanston, follows the Yankee Stadium on the Harlem and the Cleveland Stadium on Lake Erie as the focal point of national football interest today.

The Rangers, still looking for their first victory of the National Hockey League race, will seek to crash the win column tonight at the expense of the Bruins. Although the Blue Shirts have been repulsed in five straight games, their followers have not given up on them, and it is likely that a crowd of 14,000 will be on hand at Madison Square Garden for tonight's contest.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Allied Europe will need an estimated 45,855,000 metric tons of imported goods to fill its minimum requirements in the first six months after liberation from Nazi occupation, according to a report submitted to the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) today by Sir Frederick LeithRoss, chairman of the Inter-Allied Committee on Post-War Requirements.

Stuart M. Crocker was elected yesterday president of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, one of the nation's largest utility holding companies, to succeed Edward Reynolds, who is retiring to devote full time to his duties as administrative head of the supply division of the Office of the Surgeon General of the Army.

Jail terms will be recommended for all who violate ceiling prices on foods, United States Attorney James B.M. McNally announced yesterday, coincident with the action of Federal Judge Murray Hulbert in fining three such offenders $10,000 each and sending two of them to jail.
ALGIERS, Nov. 12 -- A communique:

The deer season opens in the Catskills on Monday and continues in that area through the last day of the month. The legal hunting time for bear there also starts on Monday and continues through Dec. 15.
Your editorial "Pies" in THE TIMES of Nov. 7, especially your remarks about New York pies, finds me in agreement to the last raisin. Here are some answers I've worked out:

Thirty-seven buildings in the Times Square area received yesterday "Award of Alertness A" certificates, commending their owners for excellence in maintaining air raid precautions above the normal requirements.

The political crisis in Syria and the Lebanon is a sharp reminder of the vexatious marginal problems that will neither be solved by the great war nor wait for settlement until it ends. Mostly they are old problems, chronic irritations that antedate the last war or were aggravated by the last peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -Ranging in individual amounts from $2 to $500,000,000 and from suits of clothing to entire woolen mills, America's dollar stake abroad is as widely held as it is diversified.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Foreign Office announced today that the British Government had protested to French officials in Beirut against the summary arrest of the Lebanese President, Prime Minister and their colleagues.
ALGIERS, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- Gen. Mario Roatta, denounced by Yugoslavia as a major Axis war criminal, was dismissed today from his post as Chief of Staff of Marshal Pietro Badoglio's Italian Army.

Percy W. Thirtle, controller of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, is moving into town for the winter from his Connecticut home and has leased a furnished apartment in the building at 44 West Sixty-seventh Street through William A. White Sons, agents, who also rented a suite in 480 Park Avenue through Pease Elliman to Jerome Lewine, senior member of H. Hintz Co.

On Oct. 18 the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs sent a message of good-will to J.P. Laurel, the Filipino Quisling who was recently made the "head" of the Japanese puppet Government in Manila. This week the Spanish Ambassador in Washington, Juan Francisco de Cordenas, has protested to the State Department against the "erroneous interpretation" of this message in this country.

ALGIERS, Nov. 11 -- The first operational officers of the Women's Army Corps assigned to the North African theatre since the establishment of the new policy of using Wac officers on jobs formerly held by Army officers arrived in Algiers this afternoon.

Reversing the trend of the two previous sessions, slightly increased price fixing by the trade was sufficient yesterday to sustain the cotton futures market at moderate gains. At the close, the list of old-type contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange was 4 to 8 points net higher, with the strength vested in the distant positions.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $389,097,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was also at a new high point.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -House debate on the new $2,142,900,000 tax bill will begin Nov. 22 with proposed increases in liquor levies and postal rates likely to be the main target of Congressional criticism.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- Satisfaction over the Moscow conference decision to include a representative from Yugoslavia on the committee dealing with the Italian question was expressed in a communication from Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's headquarters issued today by the Yugoslav Government Information Office.
GUADALCANAL, Nov. 12 -A battalion of marines and that perennial puzzle -- what to do with old razor blades -- got together in the swampy jungles of Choiseul Island in the northern Solomons.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- On last May 17, a B-26 Marauder medium bomber group of the United States Eighth Air Force sent out eleven planes to attack a target in the Netherlands. One turned back with engine trouble, and the ten that went on were never seen again -- a 100 per cent operational loss.

Winning his game in the third round and also a match scheduled for the fourth and played in advance at the Marshall Club last night, Sol Rubinow of City College assumed the lead in the second annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation.

New York must become a "fighting city" from now on in preserving and expanding its $1,000,000,000 garment industries against all comers, Grover Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on New York as the World's Fashion Center, said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the central mercantile section of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The War Department made public today the names of ninety-eight United States soldiers killed in action in the European, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Pacific and southwest Pacific areas.
LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- The midnight communique, a broadcast from Moscow:

The playing put forth by Marisa Regules, Argentine pianist, at her Town Hall recital last night was scintillant and virile. It was in offerings such as the Chopin "Polonaise" in F sharp minor and the Schumann sonata in the same tonality that these dominant characteristics of her work found their most congenial outlet among the standard compositions of the repertoire performed.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12 -- The Nazi police rule in Austria is now 100 per cent. This is the result of Italy's collapse and that part of the Moscow decisions that promised the restoration of independence to Austria, according to a traveler just returned here from Vienna.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 12 -Three inventions applying to the automotive industry are of particular interest this week among the 535 patents listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The American Federation of Labor has not received an invitation to attend a United Nations labor conference in London in May. The make-up of the conference, it was said unofficially at AFL headquarters, if correctly reported, would preclude the federation taking part in the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -The Navy announced sixty-six United States Merchant Marine casualties today, including eleven killed and fifty-five missing as a result of war action, from Sept. 1 to Oct. 31, 1943.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- Apparently assuming the role of peacemaker between the Congress Party and the Government of India, Kamaiyalal M. Munshi, former Home Minister of the Congress-dominated Bombay Government, conferred yesterday with Viscount Wavell, India's Viceroy.

Coast-to-coast air transportation in sixteen hours at a cost 40 per cent under present tariffs will be offered immediately after the war by all major airlines, it was predicted yesterday by Edward C. Wells, 33-year-old chief engineer of the Boeing Aircraft Company.

Barney Josephson, owner of the uptown and downtown branches of Cafe Society, is planning to enter the Broadway producing ranks this season. He and Martin Gabel have acquired an untitled comedy by Donald Ogden Stewart. It is said to have an industrial background and deals specifically with the family of an automobile tycoon.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- Platter put in his bid for two-year-old honors as he raced to victory over eight rivals in the thirty-seventh Walden Stakes before a crowd of 12,587 at Pimlico today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Establishment of a Navy manpower survey board to make an investigation of the personnel, officers, enlisted men and civilians, of all Navy shore establishments for the purpose of weeding out unnecessary or incompetent persons and sending to sea qualified officers who can be replaced on land, was announced today by the Secretary of the Navy, Frank Knox.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A 12-to-6 vote of the Senate Judiciary Committee reported out the House-adopted Marcantonio Poll Tax Repeal Bill today, putting the measure in position for a floor fight that it was conceded would develop a filibuster such as killed similar legislation last year.

Secretary Eddie Brannick of the Giants revealed yesterday that the local National League office had just received a request "from a Pacific Coast League club" for permission to deal with First Baseman Dolph Camilli and that permission had been granted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Armed with the nerve of a paratrooper and a piece of paper signed by Maj. Gen. James H. Doolittle, Technical Sgt. Kurt J. Hermann 2d of Babylon, L.I., "hitchhiked" home from Tunisia, by way of Algeria, England, Scotland, Iceland and Nova Scotia, entirely by air in nineteen days, which included ten days out for a good time in England.

New York City has its only chance of the season to see one of the greatest teams in the recent history of the United States Naval Academy today. In preparation for their "private" game with Army, the midshipmen are staging a final dress rehearsal against Columbia in what is the next to the last game of the year for both teams.

A little more than a year ago I began to wonder in what way I could contribute best to the war effort. I am a veteran of the first World War and had offered my services to the Army but nothing materialized in that direction.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Favored by ideal hunting conditions, the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association began its annual meeting this morning on the grounds of the Ingham Hill Game Farm under the sponsorship of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America.

New York City agencies are planning the first direct contribution from local residents to war-suffering civilians overseas, used clothing "which no money can buy there," Frank D. March, War Production Board-CDVO salvage director said yesterday.

For the first time in the history of City College, members of the Army will attend classes with regularly matriculated students. While undergraduates have become accustomed to soldiers marching through the halls to their own Army Specialized Training Program courses, mixed soldier and civilian classes had never been held.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 12 -James Hogan, 44 years old, a political enemy of Mayor Frank Hague, was convicted today for the second time for the highjacking of a truckload of cigarettes on June 3, 1932. He was sentenced to serve two to three years in State's prison by Judge Thomas H. Brown.
Several sales of apartment properties in and near Riverside Drive were reported by brokers yesterday.

ALGIERS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- On three different occasions in the past four months, all planes of one German fighter squadron were either destroyed or made unserviceable, intelligence officers of the Northwest African Air Forces learned today.

The resources of the various countries able to provide relief supplies must be drawn on equitably and distributed according to need, Dr. Frank C. Boudreau, chairman of the Food and Nutrition Board, National Research Council, said yesterday at the second annual meeting of the Nutrition Foundation, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Department store sales for the week ended Nov. 6 were 10 per cent above sales of the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 11 per cent (revised from the 10 per cent reported last week) for the week ended Oct. 30, when compared to the like period a year ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- A Westchester County budget and fourteen special district budgets for 1944, calling for gross expenditures $534,546 below those of this year, were filed with the Board of Supervisors today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach.

Tomorrow may well be the decisive day in the 1943 schedule of the National Football League, with the possibility that the race for honors in both the Eastern and Western division will be decided then.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- President Roosevelt designated the last Thursday of November as Thanksgiving Day in a proclamation issued today in which he expressed thanks to God for His great help "in this year of march toward world-wide liberty."

The Rev. Dr. Russell F. Auman, pastor for the last thirteen years of the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer, Scarsdale, N.Y., has accepted a call to the pastorate of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, Manhattan, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, announced yesterday.

The prospect of Thanksgiving without turkey is faced in homes throughout the United States, it became known yesterday when the Food Distribution Administration's daily market report estimated that the supply this year would be from one-third to one-half that available last year.

SUBSTITUTE STOVE -- A bantamweight cookstove -- in insulated pottery to replace pre-war metal models -- is being tested this week in Washington by the Federal Housing Agency, for use in Government-sponsored homes. Already approved by the WPB, this product is expected to be offered to the civilian public within a few months.

Henry George was once upon a time accosted by a critic who said that the single tax was no panacea. Henry George replied, "No, I know it is not, but freedom is; and I am for the single tax because it is the way to freedom."

ALGIERS, Nov. 13 -- "Labor saving" technique when the weary Fifth Army litter bearers decided to capture some Germans to take the burdens off their hands was recounted today by Sgt. Lloyd Brink of Melvin, Iowa, liaison officer for the field collecting station.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Employers may make bonus payments to employes without formal application for approval under the Salary Stabilization Program if they do not exceed amounts paid in the 1941-42 period, subject to certain limitations, Commissioner of Internal Revenue Robert E. Hannegan said today in outlining the regulations to guide employers.

Since the outbreak of war in 1939, New York Stock Exchange firms, formerly little interested in placing large blocks of securities, have moved in on this business. In addition to all the special offering business on the Exchange floor, they now do three-quarters of the secondary distributions of listed stocks off the floor.

REMEMBERING his past success with condensed versions of the legitimate stage's "Meet the People" and "Of V We Sing," Jack Harris, proprietor of La Conga, early last week presented "Fun for Your Money," an hour-long revue, at his West Fifty-first Street spot.

IT'S a far cry from this bustling little academic community to the teeming Hollywood vineyards, but there have sprouted here of late the roots of a thriving, though still infant, movie colony. It is here that George Gallup, the public pulse feeler, has set up headquarters for his Audience Research Institute, which keeps faraway Hollywood posted on what the rest of America thinks of its personalities and the pictures it makes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 13 (Reuter) -- Indications that a German-sponsored coup d'etat may be threatening Finland are reaching Swedish diplomatic and newspaper sources from various well-informed quarters.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Nov. 14 -- The American beachhead at Empress Augusta Bay on the west-central coast of Bougainville in the northern Solomons has been extended. Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today that the Japanese have left 300 dead in fighting there.

Spanning 78 yards in seven plays with less than five minutes of the game left, Abraham Lincoln High broke a 6-all tie to beat its neighborhood Brooklyn foe, James Madison, 12 to 6, in the thirteenth meeting between the schools at Lincoln Field yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- American forces are reported here to have effective land, sea and air superiority over the Japanese in the South and Southwest Pacific areas.

Senator Ball's argument in THE TIMES Magazine that we should abandon any insistence upon "sovereignty" in a post-war international organization -- insistence which he attributes to a minority of "fearful nationalists" is not very persuasive.

Richard Korbel, 9-year-old pianist, who made his debut last season in Town Hall, gave a recital yesterday afternon in Town Hall before a large audience, even the stage being filled with youthful listeners. The Boy Scouts of America contributed 100,000,000 "boy hours" of work in the war last summer, Milo G. Clark, assistant national camp director of the Boy Scouts, announced yesterday at the twenty-second annual meeting of Scout leaders from New Jersey and the New York metropolitan area, at the Hotel Commodore.

Announcing a new plan for national scholarships for women, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College disclosed yesterday that beginning next May twenty-one scholarships will be awarded to incoming freshmen who desire to attend Barnard, Bryn Mawr, Mount Holyoke, Radcliffe, Smith, Vassar or Wellesley Colleges.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- A cross-sectional view of typical American youths who have died in the war is provided by fourteen biographies that prominent authors have written of Tarrytown's fourteen gold star soldiers and sailors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A reinvigorated drive to conserve and salvage paper was urged today by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, who said that war needs for paper and paperboard are greater than the country's present ability to produce.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A five-billon-dollar privately financed housing boom in the first year after war restrictions are removed was predicted today by the Federal Housing Administration, as the result of a survey by FHA's sixty-two field offices covering every important housing market in the country.

The twenty-first season of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra began in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning at 11 o'clock with Rudolph Ganz again the conductor. The hall was filled with children and their escorts.

NOW that the year's planting is almost completed, gardeners are beginning to turn to other tasks and wondering whether it is too late to attack them. For instance, there is the problem of overgrown rose bushes which can be pruned easily now if it seems safe to do so.
