I am the son of the late Charles E. Duryea, inventor and builder of America's first gasoline automobile (1892) and I wish to correct statements in the Frank Duryea interview, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Sept. 19.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A small but well-organized group of Japanese evacuees was responsible for disorders at the War Relocation Authority's center at Tule Lake in northern California early this month, Dillon S. Myer, WRA Director, said in a report today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 13 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army wrested a new salient two miles deep from the Germans between Montaquilo and Venafro yesterday, but the over-all picture on the front changed little.

IN this timely little story two children sacrifice a beloved object to their town's scrap metal collection and thus do their part to help win the war. Peter and Nancy were proud of their father's fine new barn with its cupola, and persuaded him that it deserved a weathervane worthy of the position.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13 -- The college training programs started by the armed services will have "far-reaching social implications" after the war, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, declared today in a report to the Princeton board of trustees.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- The State Commission for the Investigation of Atrocities and Damage inflicted on the Soviet Union's people and property by Germany today published a detailed report on the findings in Stalino Province of the Donets Basin.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Played to a standstill in the opening quarter, in which it failed to make a first down, Dartmouth threafter demonstrated its superiority over Cornell by a substantial margin in a 20 -- 0 victory at Fenway Park today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 13 -- Paced by Bela Rieger, who scored all the touchdowns and added the extra points on placement kicks, Rutgers defeated Lehigh in Taylor Stadium today, 20 -- 0. It was Rutgers' second victory this season over the Engineers to maintain an unbeaten stride in Middle Three competition.
For many years we have had in New York a Bureau of Encumbrances. Don't ask me why, but there it is on the twenty-first floor of the Municipal Building.

IN this medley of fighting men and fighting planes -- marines, Allied fliers and their craft, and the Navy crews who man the guns of our Atlantic merchantmen -- we have heroes, sudden death, lively writing and tedious.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- President Roosevelt still believes that the Government should take no official notice of Dec. 7, despite passage by Congress of a resolution requesting that he proclaim the second anniversary of Pearl Harbor as "Armed Services Honor Day."

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13 -- In a speech delivered late last night, Constantine Oumansky, Soviet Ambassador, indicated that Russia was determined to retain the part of Polish territory she received on the basis of the German-Soviet agreement of Sept. 28, 1939, after the German invasion of Poland.

ATLANTA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Forrest Armstrong, War Production Board official, said today that the armed services had released priorities on used laundry and dry-cleaning equipment and that the laundry situation throughout the country should be promptly alleviated

NOT often does an artist paint for twenty-five years before having his first one-man show. Samuel Rothbort, whose retrospect exhibition is current at the Barzansky Gallery, has only come to public attention in the last five years through unpretentious little groups of oils and water-colors.

ITALIAN GOVERNMENT HEADQUARTERS, Southern Italy, Nov. 13 -- Premier Pietro Badoglio organized a "technical" government today in a makeshift move obviously forced by the refusal of Italy's main political leaders to join any government until King Victor Emmanuel had abdicated.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The cause of the Cocoanut Grove night club fire that took 492 lives on Nov. 28, 1942, has been recorded as "unknown" in a report by State Fire Marshal Stephen C. Garrity to Gov. Leverett Saltonstall.

" SCHWAB'S" is a drug store at the corner of Sunset and Laurel Canyon Boulevards where, for the price of an Ice-cream soda or a nickel coke, you get the best free show in town. You can look at Anne Shirley, in short shorts and brief blouse, drinking lemonade, or listen to a big film deal between two baldheaded gents being worked out over a bowl of the chef's special vegetable soup.

In a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 7 Charles Warren proposes dealing with Hitler and his gang according to the Napoleonic pattern. That means Hitler and his henchmen should be sent as prisoners to some desert island, a modern St. Helena.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Wendell Willkie, in winning the rank and file support of the Republican party, faces an uphill fight -- just as he did in 1940, prior to the Republican convention in June of that year.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13 -- A parliamentary committee composed of members of the Mexican Revolutionary party began an investigation today into the right wing Accion National party and the Sinarquist Union that were branded as "traitors and outlaws."

Heavy shipment of tobacco abroad under lend-lease added to extensive earmarking of supplies for the Army and Navy is regarded as one of the contributing causes for the growing scarcity of popular brands of cigarettes and lower-priced cigars reported here and in many other cities throughout the country yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 -- The "father of war-bond loans" was honored this afternoon when the Liberty ship, the SS. Frank A. Vanderlip, was launched at the Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyards here.

MANY of the sponge fishermen who work in the Florida waters are Greek and, though they dive in modern equipment, their methods are much the same as those which their forebears have handed down through centuries.

ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The United States Army Air Forces have solved one of the major financial problems of the war by instituting a "flying banking service," enabling its men to get their pay on time and under conditions of actual attack in the combat theaters.
CHILDREN go into fits of laughter over things that leave us unamused; they say something is "funny," but can't explain why -- at least, not in so many words.

WORD has just been received here that the Germans have arrested Peter Freuchen, Arctic explorer and author of "Arctic Adventure." This is the first word concerning Freuchen that has reached here since the Nazis invaded Denmark.

THE life of Henri Fabre as portrayed in this recent biography makes a book of appeal and distinction about a modest, gentle man of France. Memories of old fields and small villages around Avignon, peasant farmers and their simple lives; the indefinably French feelings imparted by a sympathetic author, together create an intrinsic quality. Miss Eberle seems to know and love the soil of France, and to know, too, Henri Fabre and his entomology.

A MEMORIAL meeting for Joseph Achron, composer; David Roitman, cantor and Abraham Dzimitrovsky, choirmaster and music publisher, will be held next Monday at the Jewish Music Forum, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

As a result of the increased strain placed upon the medical schools of this country because of wartime demands for more doctors, many of the colleges have had to lower their standards and are facing a dangerous period in which graduates of the future will be inadequately prepared and professionally immature.

TULE LAKE, Calif., Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- War Relocation Authority employes said that Col. Verne Austin declared martial law in the Japanese segregation center here from 7 P.M. tonight to 10 A.M. tomorrow after a demonstration this afternoon by about 1,000 internes.

LONDON. A FORMATION of Flying Fortresses recently roared out from their British base for a raid on Emden, northern terminus of the Dortmund-Emden Canal, which feeds Scandinavian ore into Hitler's war machine. Escorting the winged dreadnoughts was a force of the new P-47's, the Thunderbolts.

Chemical companies producing basic raw materials that go indirectly into the construction or operation of ships, tanks, guns and airplanes are faced with a serious manpower problem that must be alleviated if present high production standards are to be maintained, Dr. J.W. Raynolds of the chemical division of the War Production Board, declared yesterday in a survey made for the American Chemical Society.
JUST how good the Blackwood convention is must, it appears, remain a moot question.

MRS. DABROWSKY is an American citizen. She came from Poland nine years ago. As food shortages began to be felt, Mrs. Dabrowsky became an important friend to her American-born neighbors. She taught them to stretch meat and make delicacies from foods they had traditionally tossed away.

THE third and final part of the famous Alexander Biddle papers will be sold by the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. Among these records of great personages is the letter of Thomas Jefferson containing his pledge of "eternal hostility against every form of tyranny over the mind of man," now engraved on his memorial at Washington.
IN this war cold science is playing a share equally with military strategy to a degree hitherto unheard of.

Aided by a sharp upturn in volume on Armistice Day, retail trade here showed gains last week over the like period of 1942. Department store volume was estimated at about 8 per cent ahead, with substantially larger percentage increases noted for specialty shops. Gift and toy buying began to gain headway.
Rested and refreshed after a week's furlough from the ice wars, the Rangers showed little improvement in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. They lost to the

FOR the first half of almost twenty years as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation J. Edgar Hoover had been more or less frustrated, for during this period the bureau was little more than an impotent investigating agency for the Department of Justice.

Canada's Fifth Victory Loan has just raised $1,350,000,000. This is a small amount by our own standards, but when considered in the light of the size of the Canadian economy and the magnitude of its war effort, it represents an achievement of considerable importance. Canada like the United States is devoting about half of its economic efforts to the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Reports from the Italian frontier said tonight that German occupation forces had set explosive mines beneath all war factories in Florence, Genoa, Turin, Milan and Brescia and were practicing a "scorched-earth" pattern as vicious as any destruction that they spread in Russia.

With due respect to a gallant, though weaponless Columbia squad that tried right up to the last second, the Navy football team, at least three deep at every position, probably could have run up 100 points in their one-sided encounter before 20,000 at Baker Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Ways and Means Committee has approved a tax bill which would yield about $2,143,000,000 and all signs point to a measure around that figure instead of the $10,500,000,000 asked for by the Administration.

AN accusation of subversive activities has been made, and almost immediately thereafter the man who claimed to have the evidence is murdered. All this occurs at the university which numbers Dr. Jeffrey McNeill among its faculty members.

ONE of Maine's offshore islands, by reputation deserted except by its ghost, became the haven of the Little family when they lost their mainland home. Dave Little refused to be beholden, and his Children, Susan and John, were of the same independent stripe.

The Good Neighbor policy must be implemented by a federation of all the American nations, Ely Culbertson, the bridge expert, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Latin American Economic Institute at the Hotel Roosevelt.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Bucknell's Bisons fought every inch of the way today to a 19-13 victory over Case. A crowd of 2,000 saw the Bisons register their fourth straight victory.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Thousands of Yugoslavs of all political parties are flocking to the standard of General Tito's Partisans -- who now number about 300,000 men -- encouraged by the intensified Allied aerial and naval activity, Cairo dispatches said today.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Archie Putnam, charged by the State Attorney General's election fraud bureau with paying $5 each to two voters on election day, Nov. 2, was ordered held today for Albany County grand jury action.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13 -- The Argentine Government published a decree today under which the remaining Graf Spee officers and men will be subjected to stricter vigilance.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The long journey home from the Moscow conference has necessitated some delay in implementing the decisions taken there. This delay, in turn, has resulted in London in a vague feeling of anticlimax about the conference; but, in fact, more has been done to act on the Moscow decisions than is generally supposed.
The biggest rent registration job ever undertaken by the Office of Price Administration will start tomorrow in the New York Defense Rental Area.

On the smallest volume in a month stocks on the New York Stock Exchange drifted yesterday in narrow ranges and closed irregular. Distillery shares were weak. Turnover was 314,106 shares, against 337,110 shares in the previous two-hour session.

The War Shipping Administration announced yesterday that a new method of obtaining Selective Service deferments for 115,000 eligible American seamen will be instituted tomorrow. The new system replaces the present procedure of obtaining such deferments adopted on March 15, under which 106,779 applications were handled before Sept. 1.

Placing a five-man team in the first twenty-eight runners to finish the course of two and one-quarter miles, Curtis High's cross-country team won the Public Schools Athletic League championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday for the second straight year.

L. Walter Stephens of the Manhattan Club, vice president of the United States Chess Federation, led the field last night after the conclusion of play in the fifth round of the annual tournament for the national amateur championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The American Red Cross will represent all relief organizations at the pier in Jersey City when the exchange motorship Gripsholm arrives on Dec. 2 with repatriated Americans from the Far East. the State Department said today.

Elementary school buildings erected in New York City within the last ten years have been found poorly adapted to many of the functions they are expected to perform. The cubicle-classroom and lack of such facilities as sound-proofing are definite handicaps to the development of a good educational program.

BUSINESS is looking up in the majority of those road cities where there are Theatre Guild-American Theatre Society subscribers. In New York, for instance, the Guild is on its own and has 12,000 subscribers, as against 7,000 last year. Philadelphia's 8,000 is about 1,000 more than in 1942.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Germany's "secret weapon" may be either rocket guns, suicide parachutists, stratosphere bombers or gas -- arrayed in the order of their possibility -- but all of these have become the subject of much speculation since Prime Minister Churchill gravely warned of possible new forms of attack on England.

Conducted by the Science Clubs of America, the third annual science talent search is now under way. In thousands of schools throughout the country principals and teachers are seeking promising young scientists. The forty boys and girls who show the greatest potentialities will be awarded suitable scholarships to enable them to continue their scientific studies in college.

MRS. LOMAX was born Elizabeth Lindsay in Norfolk, Va., many years before the Civil War. Her father was Col. William Lindsay, an officer in the Revolutionary Army and an intimate of General Washington and the Marquis de Lafayette.

UP to the present time there has been no single source of information on all of the requirements for successful installation and operation of aircraft power plants; for that reason it has been difficult to train power plant engineers in the aircraft industry.

CHUNGKING, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Counter-attacking Chinese troops, supported by American and Chinese fliers, have ousted the Japanese from several more strategic points on both sides of the Yangtze River in central China and killed large numbers of invaders, the High Command announced tonight.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 -- George D. Widener's filly, Stefanita, out-gamed Alsab in the stretch today to win the twenty-first running of the $15,000 added Bryan and O'Hara Memorial Handicap before approximately 18,000 persons at Pimlico.

There'll be a new type of clerk behind the counter in department stores as the Christmas rush gains force. Women who have never worked before, women who thought that middle age was "too old," women with sons or husbands overseas and too much time to think.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 3 C.L. Sulzberger, speaking of some possible consequences to the Moscow Conference, makes the point that "the reconstitution of Austria should facilitate the eventual establishment of federation moves in central and eastern Europe."

A half-century of service on New York's lower East Side will be celebrated next Sunday by the Educational Alliance, the nation's largest community center which has stood for fifty years at East Broadway and Jefferson Street.
I DON'T know if you have a Department of Correction and Amplification, but if so, it is to this department that I send the following contribution.

THIRTY years ago this month Samuel Goldwyn began making his first moving picture on a shoestring. The man; then 29, who had come to this country a penniless boy eighteen years before, has traveled far since he staked all his savings on turning a stage play into a moving picture. What has happened to him since then makes most movie scenarios seem dull

ALGIERS, Nov. 13 -- To join the historic list of the conquerors of Rome the Allied armies now forging slowly ahead up the Italian peninsula have to overcome the natural obstacles of Caesar's time as well as those savage refinements introduced by Hitler's Wehrmacht.
LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- The midnight supplementary communique as broadcast from Moscow:

FUTURE historians of American thought looking back on the Thirties and Forties of this century will, I am sure, write long and interesting chapters about the neoscholastic movement of which Jacques Maritain is the most distinguished exponent and certainly the most prolific.

THE war has changed many aspects of Mr. Lyman's law offices. His three nephews, whom he loved as the sons he never had, are overseas; and there he is, at 74, working so that they will have the firm to come back to.

In the magazine article "Some Are Leaders, Some 'Headmen'" there appeared a glaringly noticeable omission. Probably the most brilliant mind from the all-important standpoint of basic knowledge of governmental theory and technique to concern itself with the Presidency was that of Thomas Jefferson.

Exclusively for the decoration of the frequently uncelebrated United States infantryman are the two new silver badges shown at right. They are open to officers and enlisted men. The Combat Infantryman Badge, at top, the higher of the two, is awarded for exemplary conduct in combat or for combat action in a major operation.

HEADQUARTERS, AMPHIBIOUS TRAINING COMMAND, UNITED STATES ATLANTIC FLEET, NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 30 (Delayed) -- This is the "cradle of invasion" where the Army and Navy are working in unprecedented unity to build a mighty striking force for the large-scale assault on Europe.

Cotton futures rebounded sharply from earlier losses in the final moments of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as aggressive demand by trade sources encountered a shortage of offerings. With the exception of the distant July position which ended the short session with a loss of one point, the list of active old contracts registered advances of 4 to 8 points, the day's best levels.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Governor Dewey awaited clarification today of Washington reaction to his warning that New York and the entire Northeast faced a critical milk and egg shortage unless Federal policies were changed to permit the monthly shipment of at least 15,000,000 bushels of feed grain from the Middle West, with 5,000,000 bushels for New York State alone.

Don Burnham, intercollegiate mile champion, sped to victory yesterday in the thirty-fifth intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country championship race at Van Cortlandt Park, and by leading the green-clad Dartmouth team to a triumph over the Bronx course. Burnham brought disappointment to Coach Earl Thomson of Navy, who in another generation was bringing athletic glory to the institution that nestles in the New Hampshire hills.

THESE two collections of old tales have the same worthy purpose -- to link the childhood of these United Nations in their common heritage of folklore. As they offer entirely different material, overlapping only in purpose, a comparative review will perhaps bring out useful points concerning each.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13 -- A Young Lebanese was reported today to have shot at Emile Edde, who has been selected as a substitute Premier of Lebanon by the French and who is dubbed a Lebanese Quisling by the Arabic press. The shot missed.

NOT within memory has there been so much of what is sometimes known as "good" dancing, as distinguished from hoofing, in the Broadway theatre. Attention has already been called to the subject in these columns on several occasions, but evidence continues to pile up.
Quantity production of an air-cooled radial Wright Cyclone engine of 2,200 horsepower, more powerful than the Cyclones that power the Flying Fortresses, was announced yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Austrialia, Nov. 13 -- Dark Felt, 6-year-old brown horse, co-favorite at 7-2 with Skipton, who won the cup as a 3-year-old in 1941, was the winner of the Melbourne Cup at Flemington today.

A VOLUME of medieval sermons is at the bottom of all the villainy recorded in this book. We are betraying no secret in making this statement, for it is evident from the beginning that somebody is trying to steal those sermons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The War Department made public today the names of 352 United States soldiers listed as missing in action. The casualties included reports from the Asiatic, European and Mediterranean areas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The task of reconverting the national economy from a wartime to a peacetime basis affects more citizens directly and acutely than any other activity save the war itself. Next to popular concern over the outcome of battles and the toll of human lives comes that over reconversion.
WITH a restraint seldom found in a first novel, Jeanne Singer broaches the problem of anti-Semitism in a

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Disorders at the segregation camp for disloyal Japanese aliens and citizens at Tule Lake in Northern California, along with subsequent disclosures, have lost considerable face for the War Relocation Authority and have increased demands for Army administration of all centers housing West Coast evacuees of Japanese descent.

TRY to think of adding anything new to "Cinderella" and the imagination is stumped. Not that of the late Mrs. Miller, however, who some time before her death retold it in verse, not changing the story, which faithfully follows the old beloved pattern, but bringing to it humor and wit, and the merest suggestion of sophistication, which brightens rather than tarnishes the fairy-tale mood with a delicate air of worldliness very flattering to the young.

THE publication of screen plays has never been matter of course -- never a practice to compare with the publication of plays for the stage. Except for a few "best film" anthologies, it has, indeed, been virtually nil. And that is for several reasons, one of which is the simple fact that producers generally hold the copyrights and they don't like to put their scripts out.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The season here at Pinehurst and Southern Pines, resort towns in the Sandhills of central North Carolina, has opened against a background of olive-drab uniforms, decorated with gold and silver bars, maple leaves, eagles and occasional stars.
AFTER more than ten long years of very slim political pickings, Republicans today are eyeing covetously and hopefully the lush pastures that lie in executive control of the National Administration.

LITTLE dog Trumpet is the central figure in this third book about Peter Churchmouse and his friends, who made themselves so at home in Parson Pease-Porridge's church. Usually meek and quiet, Trumpet is discovered at the beginning of the story giving vent to such continuous and agonizing howls that Peter Churchmouse and Gabriel Churchkitten busy themselves at once to find a remedy.

Criminal informations against seventeen wholesale concerns and two individuals charged with violating Office of Price Administration price ceilings in the purchase of oranges and other citrus fruits were filed in Federal court here yesterday by United States Attorney James B. McNally.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Although we are again at war after the silver anniversary of the signing of the Armistice of the First World War, Rabbi Joseph Zeitlin declared in a sermon in Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue, yesterday, that there was hope for an abiding peace "if this generation shall rise to the noble and inspired opportunities that destiny has prepared for it."

The New York University School of Education Association held its annual reunion yesterday at the Washington Square Center of the University. A series of panels was held on the theme "Education at the Highest Possible Efficiency During the War and the Post-War Period," addressed by leaders in their respective fields.

The war-end threat of economic and social collapse, inherent in prolonged settlement of war contracts, has not been removed by the appointment of Bernard M. Baruch to a post in the Office of War Mobilization to study modification and termination problems, according to industrial leaders who spent last week checking latest Washington developments.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 13 (AP) -- William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France and Russia, declared tonight that Europe has been the "great unrepresented" in current peace talks and deplored what he said was "a certain formula for the production of a new world war."

THE welding of metals has become one of our major industrial processes. It includes gas welding and electric welding, the latter comprising are welding and resistance welding. Resistance welding alone has called forth a special technology for controlling the duration and intensity of the brief "shot" of electric current that fuses two pieces of metal into one.

THE film industry has run into still another set of official wartime restrictions -- this time a directive from the War Department against the showing, or reference to in dialogue, of atrocities committed by the Japanese against American civilian or military prisoners of war.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The highly favored Tufts eleven started out like the proverbial house afire today, but had to battle for existence before it subdued a stubborn Harvard eleven, 13 to 7, before 10,000 at Harvard Stadium.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Colgate's Red Raiders defeated R.P.I., 26 to 0, before 1,500 in their last home game today, with fumbles by the visitors paving the way for the first two scores. A. short punt aided another and a long forward pass the fourth.

LOOKING fit and cheerful, the old King of Jazz sat there at the luncheon table, and you would have sworn that it cannot be twenty years ago next February that he waved a baton over a new work entitled "Rhapsody in Blue" and sent an astounded audience into the street from Aeolian Hall, muttering of a new era in American music.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Marine Tubby Crawford, slim pole-vaulter from Ohio University, Sparked Penn State to a 13-to-0 Triumph over a hard-fighting Temple outfit today before 5,000 fans.

Red Army triumphs were mounting last week. Everywhere along the 1,000 miles from the Gulf of Finland to the Black Sea Soviet legions were exerting relentless pressure against a Wehrmacht that was groggy from five months of pounding.

The pattern of the "greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere" for which Japan fights was set in Manchuria. Some 30,000,000 Manchurians, living under the puppet regime of Emperor Henry Pi Yi, have come to know it well. Two great Japanese corporations, the South Manchuria Railway Company and the Manchurian Heavy Industries Company, have taken over all heavy industry.

A PRIEST comes to gossip columnist D'Arcy with a strange story which D'Arcy finds it difficult to believe. But when the priest is murdered D'Arcy comes to the conclusion that in that story may lie the reason for Father Walsh's death, which the police believe to have been suicide.

MARGUERITE KIRMSE'S pictures make Nipper, the little bull pup, as real and as engaging as her "Tinker, the Little Fox Terrier," of last year, and this latest story of Dorothy L'Hommedieu's is the best she has done.

GIOVANNI GABRIELI was one of the dominant figures of church music at the end of the sixteenth and the beginning of the seventeenth century. One rarely encounters his music in concert halls or on the radio, and the release of an album with striking examples is a valuable contribution.

PANAMA -- Colon, 6.00 megacycles, has a special musical round-up of American tunes Friday at 10:45 P.M. with English news sometimes relayed from the United Network in California, at 11 P.M. Operated by the Panama Broadcasting System, this station uses the slogan "La Voz de la Victor."

THE effect of a facial masque is thorough, manifold and immediate. Beauty experts are discovering that this treatment -- once considered an effete extravagance -- is one of the most popular among war-time women.

Materials vital to our war program, many virtually unobtainable elsewhere, are coming from Brazil in great quantities, Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store in Brooklyn, disclosed yesterday as he returned to his business duties following his resignation as executive director of the United States purchasing Commission in Brazil.

The Christmas bonus is a time- honored institution in Wall Street, in time of war as well as in time of peace; and in periods of depression as well as in boom days. This year will be no exception. However, this time banks and other financial organizations will have to study the new rules carefully.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Arkansas University's Razor backs, erstwhile Southwest Conference passing magicians, partly revived their wizardry of old today to beat Southern Methodist, 14 to 12, and win their first Conference Football game before 10,000 spectators.

In THE TIMES Magazine Mr. Sulzberger's article "What Does Russia Want?" draws what seems to me a rather inept comparison between Russia's sponsorship of Left Wing movements and the attitude of England and America toward liberal movements abroad during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

Next year's Victory garden campaign and the problem of increasing food production will be discussed by leaders and officials of the National Victory Garden Institute at its conference in the Hotel Blackstone, Chicago, on Nov. 16 and 17.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 13 -- Old Notre Dame still reigns over all.

THE merry-go-round horse is a favorite figure in children's books, and no wonder, for that earthbound Pegasus needs only a touch of imagination to send him prancing through the bright fields of fan tasy.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Piercing thick clouds, storms and icing conditions to reach their target, heavy formations of American Flying Fortresses and Liberators blasted the important German shipping and industrial city of Bremen today.

CORRESPONDENTS are keenly interested in the subject broached last Sunday in these columns, namely, the presentation of symphonic music by broadcasting organizations and sponsors, and the subjects discussed by the speakers who hold forth during the intermissions. Today we summarize the views of various readers on this theme.

OILS and water-colors by Segonzac, numerous examples of whose work appeared in the recent Crowninshield sale, are now to be seen at the Carroll Carstairs Gallery. Among the canvases is "Le Golfe de Saint Tropez," which, you may recall, got first prize in the 1933 Carnegie International at Pittsburgh.

Benjamin J. Davis Jr., Negro Communist elected to the City Council from Manhattan, declared yesterday that it was "crystal clear" from an analysis of the vote that he had not been "elected by Harlem alone or by the Communist party alone."

The Christmas bonus is a time- honored institution in Wall Street, in time of war as well as in time of peace; and in periods of depression as well as in boom days. This year will be no exception. However, this time banks and other financial organizations will have to study the new rules carefully.

With the bow and arrow hunting season on deer opening in Westchester County tomorrow there is at least one record that will confront the archers. When the experiment was tried a year ago exactly one of their number succeeded in downing a buck deer.

IF Admiral Farragut was a Navy captain at 12 there was good precedent for Chuck and Bob, self-made guerrillas just about that age, to be made colonels pro-tem when Army troops moved onto their father's Iowa farm for practice warfare.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- After sputtering like a damp firecracker through the first three quarters, today's intersectional battle between Pennsylvania and North Carolina exploded like a half-dozen "ashcans" straddling a Nazi U-boat.

FROM the fighting fronts of the world come letters like this one -- some of them V-mailed, many of them bearing censor's tape and the rumpled evidence of stormy crossings -- to cluttered desks of Manhattan department stores.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 13 -- Exeter won its annual football game with Andover today by a scoring attack in the fourth period. In the last quarter the Exonians tallied twice and Andover once, making the final count 12 to 6.

I SHOULD never go to the Oak Room at the Plaza. Destiny, like summer lightning, plays around my head in the Oak Room. Three years ago I took Gertrude Lawrence there for a bit of supper, and out of that midnight snack came four revolving stages, Gertrude Lawrence and "Lady in the Dark."

DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The astonishing Canadiens, alone undefeated in the National Hockey League, extended their winning streak to five games tonight by blanking the Red Wings, 2 to 0, before 13,515 spectators. Elmer Lach and Gerry Heffernan scored for Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- There is no immediate, direct method of adjusting the pay of about 15,000,000 clerical, white collar, unorganized employes to the 15 per cent "Little Steel" formula which applies to organized wage earners, according to Federal officials and legislators who were asked by THE NEW YORK TIMES for their views on the subject.

The increased cost of living, coupled with the 20 per cent withholding tax on incomes, has created a situation "bordering on the critical" for millions of American families, including many thousands in New York City, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

AT A BASE ON THE BURMA BORDER, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- The creation of a Chinese Army in India has for the last year been one of the prime war projects of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of American troops in China, Burma and India.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14 -- Amid the cheers of 60,000 delegates at the opening of the three-day Wafd party congress here, Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha announced today the Egyptian Government's deci sion to adhere to the terms of the Atlantic Charter and to proceed with negotiations leading to Egypt's inclusion among the United Nations.

The second of three scheduled performances of Spanish dances at Carnegie Hall last night found Argentinita and her company again in top form. The program was substantially the same as that of the night before, though it contained a few major changes.

A barrel of whiskey at less than half the ceiling price will be offered by the American Distilling Company to every holder of one of its nearly 250,000 shares of common stock, it was announced yesterday by Russell R. Brown, president of the company.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14 -- Crowds of Egyptian youths celebrating the Wafdist congress jubilee here milled around the French delegation's headquarters early today. The French authorities had previously requested that the premises be guarded, but no protection was forthcoming until some windows had been smashed.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- The Red Army's resounding success at Zhitomir was the result of a bold decision by General Vatutin to rely on the main tank force under Lieut. Gen. P.S. Rybalko for fending off the expected German coun ter-attack in the Fastov region southwest of Kiev.
The editorial "Post-War Soldiers" in THE TIMES of Nov. 10 raises two serious questions.

Broadway traffic in the Times Square sector was halted, six firemen were treated for irritation of the eyes, and 600 patrons of the Trans-Lux Newsreel Theatre at 1607 Broadway at Forty-ninth Street moved quickly into the street after dense billows of smoke issued from a fire in the basement of the theatre last night.

Millbarry's Sho-Sho, Yorkshire terrier owned by Miss Vera Lorima of Roseland, N.J., took both the award for best American-bred and that for best in show last night at the Progressive Dog Club's eleventh annual all toy breeds fixture, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
COVENTRY, England, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- On the night of Nov. 14, 1940, about 470 tons of German bombs knocked this city almost flat in eleven hours.

The recent death of Harry Williams offers an appropriate occasion, perhaps, to say something favorable of proofreaders. He was a man who had made a profession of proofreading, having been foreman of this newspaper's proofroom for a solid twenty-five years.

Just prior to the kick-off in yesterday's game between the Bears and the Giants at the Polo Grounds, Sid Luckman, former pupil of Lou Little at Columbia, received two $1,000 war bonds, one a gift of his home-borough admirers in Brooklyn; the other from his own football associates.

HEADQUARTERS AMPHIBIOUS TRAINING COMMAND, United States Atlantic Fleet, Norfolk, Va., Oct. 31 (Delayed) -- The theory of amphibious assault, according to Commodore Lee P. Johnson, commander of the Amphibious Training Command, United States Atlantic Fleet, is relatively simple: you find a soft spot on the enemy's shore; you hit him when he isn't expecting you; you hit him hard, and you keep on pouring in men until the beach is yours.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The British Government, in its relations with the United States, is approaching an economic and political dilemma that is becoming more acute as the war nears its decisive phase.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The I votes of the delegations fron. New 'York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Nov. 6 to 12 are given in the appended tabulation:

College football put on one of its most freakish shows in years in rain, wind and congealing weather on Saturday. When the curtain was rung down, Notre Dame was still in front, with another powerful foe, Northwestern, left in the dust and an even more feared one coming up in the Iowa Pre-Flight Seahawks.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Allied patrols clashed with Japanese troops in the Arakan and Chin Hills sectors of Burma, inflicting many casualties, and United States bombers in strong new raids slashed again at enemy communications, two communiques declared today.

Mayor La Guardia, in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall yesterday, warned food profiteers that jail doors were yawning for them. He hailed the drive against gouging by wholesale orange dealers started by the United States Attorney, who already has convicted three dealers and has filed criminal informations against seventeen other concerns and two of their buyers.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- German Army and Navy units have recaptured three Adriatic islands in moves to regain control of the Yugoslav coastal waterways, according to DNB, the German news agency, yesterday.

In his speech on the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Soviet Revolution, Marshal Joseph Stalin acknowledged the contribution to Russian victories being made by Allied air attacks against the common German enemy. Since Russian recognition of this factor has been grudging in the past, such acknowledgement by the top man helps to put the military picture into better perspective.

Linwood I. Noyes, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, with headquarters at 370 Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday the appointment of the Newspaper Committee for the Waste Paper Campaign. The committee will be headed by Edwin S. Friendly of The New York Sun.

The decline in stocks which followed announcement of the Three-Power Pact on Nov. 1 culminated last Monday. That day's transactions of 2,340,180 shares were not only double those of any day of the week preceding, but were the largest business done on the Stock Exchange since May 10, during the week in which the Allies captured Tunis and Bizerte.

The American economic system is doomed unless labor and management face "the inescapable fact that they must learn to live together happily," Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, told 2,000 members of the Catholic Men's League of the New York Navy Yard at a communion breakfast yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

To a New Yorker looking for a year's lease, the housing shortage may be irritating or unpleasant. To an Army or Navy officer, fresh from overseas batttle or on his way to the perilous front, it constitutes a crisis.
AT PREMIER BADOGLIO'S HEADQUARTERS, In Italy, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- Premier Pietro Badoglio announced today that when Rome had been liberated he would cut himself off completely from politics.

Cotton prices last week fluctuated over a fairly wide trading range. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the period ranging from an advance of 13 points to a decline of 14 points.

The juke box in the bar and grill of Sam Banfante at 2028 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, was blaring, "Lay that pistol down, Babe, lay that pistol down," just before closing time Sunday morning when two strangers who had walked in a moment before pulled out pistols and announced: "This is a stick-up."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A crusade for guarantees in future peace treaties of world-wide press freedom, on the premise that universal dissemination of the truth would make the chance of war remote, was proposed by Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, in a survey on "journalism in wartime," published today.

Its last two New York offerings having developed into successes -- and what resounding hits they turned out to be! -- the Theatre Guild will try its luck this evening at the Belasco with "The Innocent Voyage," hoping there will be enough lightning left to strike it a third time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Slingin' Sammy Baugh gave one of his greatest football performances today to lead the champion Redskins to a 42-20 triumph over Frankie Sinkwich and Detroit before 35,540 chilled fans.

Four hundred families in a four-block area along Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, north from 164th Street, were virtually marooned after a 48-inch water main burst with geyser-like effect in front of 1093 Jerome Avenue at 1 P.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The desperate quest of the United Nations for rubber, which began when the plantations of the Orient fell into Japanese hands, has taken American men and dollars into the Valley of the Amazon.

Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a consolidated net income of $7,434,252 after charges and taxes, equal to $2.25 a share on the capital stock. This compares with $11,245,166, or $3.40 a share, in the similar period of 1942.

The National Association of Manufacturers yesterday offered a sweeping program for eventual demobilization of service men calling for base pay of $100 a month with full family allowance for the first three months following honorable discharge.

TOROKINA POINT, Bougainville Island, Nov. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- How the Japanese attacked a United States Navy field hospital last Sunday during a battle near the Koromokina River on the marines' left flank was described by Lieut. Comdr. Gordon Bruce of New York and Englewood, N.J.

Women in the post-war world will have to accept jobs for less pay than men, Dr. Eveline M. Burns, former chief of the economic security and health section of the National Resources Planning Board, declared yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14 -- Turkey believes that she has abided by her alliance and, by refusing to go to war, protected Britain in the Middle East during the ebb of Allied fortunes and thus forestalled any efforts by the Germans to reach the Japanese in the Middle East or India.

Once again the full complement of Moscow's 224 victory guns boomed with twenty salvos to announce another major triumph of the Red Army -- the capture of Zhitomir. Unannounced as yet by Russia but from Berlin itself comes word of still another Russian advance, a break-through of 500,000 men farther south, in the Dnieper bend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The statement of Constantine Oumansky, Soviet Ambassador to Mexico, in Mexico City indicating that Russia was determined to retain the Polish territory she received after the German invasion of Poland, tonight excited much comment in Washington unofficially but officially there was silence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the award of the Legion of Merit to Brig. Gen. Joseph V. de P. Dillon of 1221 Woodycrest Avenue, New York City; Col. Ralph H. Hess of 555 Ardsley Road, Scarsdale, N.Y., and Capt. William Hammond of Georgetown, Del.

MADRID, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Nazis are readying a surprise winter operation from southern bases, probably a counter-offensive in Italy, in the opinion of persons recently returned from extensive tours in Germany and occupied Europe.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 -- Although early indications last week were that steel output the week before had dropped one point to 99 per cent of rated capacity, revised figures show that the rate the week before last actually was about 97 1/2 per cent.

Isobel Walters, soprano, well known as a radio singer, gave a recital in Times Hall yesterday afternoon before a good-sized audience that was responsive to the excellent singing. Miss Walters sang selections by Haydn, Sarti, Rossini, Leoncavallo, Harry E. Anik, who was the accompanist; Mallotte, Rosette and others.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Noting that "after the First World War and after the Civil War we experienced phenomenally rapid increases in manufacturing output," Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres declared today: "We shall surely have similar developments this time."

A nation-wide radio audience and several thousand persons in Carnegie Hall were treated to a dramatic musical event yesterday afternoon when the 25-year-old assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra Leonard Bernstein, substituted on a few hours' notice for Bruno Walter, who had become ill, and led the orchestra through its entire program.

The twelve-story loft building at 126 West Twenty-second Street was sold by the 130 West Twenty-second Street Corporation to David W. Frankel, operator, for cash over an extended first mortgage of $161,000. Bastine Co. were the brokers.

Advertising problems will be among topics discussed at the second of the series of "paint merchandising forums" under the auspices of the New York Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association at the Biltmore Hotel on Monday, Nov. 22.
Three new films are scheduled to have local premieres this week. The openings are:

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS IN CHINA, Nov. 14 -- A mountain resort, which in the United States would be a millionaire's dream retreat, has been opened as a rest camp for convalescent and tired American fliers and ground men.

The address last week by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commanding the Pacific Fleet, in which he stated flatly that the Japanese were about to be heavily attacked in a new area of the Pacific must be coupled with Admiral William F. Halsey's attack upon Bougainville and increased air and ground activity in Burma.

CAIRO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- French authorities, contending that the fighting in Lebanon was not so serious as had been reported, rushed General Catroux from Algiers to Cairo by plane today to confer with the Egyptian Premier. Before the conference Premier Nahas said that Egypt would use her influence with the United Nations to force the French Committee of National Liberation to release imprisoned members of the Lebanese Government.

Brewers' yeast contains twice as much protein, pound for pound, as meat, according to Lieut. Comdr. Clive M. McCay of the Naval Medical Research Institute. Commander McCay spoke at a recent luncheon attended by representatives of the brewing industry and the War Food Administration, who met to make plans for maximum output of the yeast.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, IN ITALY, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- Further important evidence that the Germans are taking with them the accumulated art and cultural treasures of Italy as they retreat came to light today.
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Cash dividends in October amounted to $301,000,000, as compared with $297,000,000 in October of last year, but the total for the first ten months of 1943 was less than that for the corresponding period of 1942, totaling $2,690,000,000, as compared with $2,696,000,000, the Department of Commerce announced today.

There has been no breakdown thus far in over-the-road transportation directly affecting the movement of war freight. Indeed, there is every indication that the motor carriers will handle an even greater excess in the last half of this year than the 15 per cent increase as compared with 1942, which was predicted early in the current twelve months by the Office of Defense Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Shortages next spring of beef, pork, lamb and poultry were predicted tonight by representatives of stock raisers as 500 of them gathered here, along with about thirty State Commissioner of Agriculture, to protest the Administration's food program at Senate Agriculture Committee hearings opening tomorrow.

President Roosevelt expressed gratification yesterday with the selection of the old Roosevelt family home at 47-49 East Sixty-fifth Street by Hunter College as an Interfaith Center, first of its kind in New York, and dedicated to a "mutual understanding among Protestant, Jewish and Catholic students."

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Don Hutson, Green Bay's brilliant end, turned in another great performance today, scoring 23 points as the Packers smothered the Cardinals, 35 -- 14, in a National Football League game before a crowd of 11,000.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Striking southward in several columns, reinforced Japanese invasion forces were thrown back in the mountains south of Ichang, the Chinese High Command reported today.

The trouble with Italy as a laboratory for the first experiment in political reconstruction under Allied occupation is that as a national organism it is almost unknown to those who are trying to operate on it. So many people know Italy as a museum that they imagine they know it as a nation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Germany is now manufacturing a rocket-driven four-engined bombing plane patterned on Flying Fortresses and Liberators, a Berlin dispatch to the Swedish press said today.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- Americans are giving German first-line soldiers a weekly German-language news pamphlet known as The Front Post.

Gifts of $25,000 from the George F. Baker Charity Trust and of $10,000 from the Whitney Trustees to the 1943 United Hospital Campaign were reported yesterday by William H. Zinsser, chairman of the campaign committee, with headquarters at 370 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Positive confirmation of reports that some of Spain's most influential military and political leaders have formally demanded restoration of the Spanish monarchy were brought to London today by persons with inside information reaching here from Spain.

Members of the armed forces retain for another year more than a "toe hold" in that glittering sector of the Metropolitan Opera House formerly famed as the "Diamond Horseshoe." The new season's list of boxholders, released yesterday, disclosed that both the Army and the Navy would be well represented at many forthcoming performances.

A Geneva report picked up by OWI says that Mussolini will make a public appearance on Nov. 15 at the first congress of his brand-new "Fascist Republican party" somewhere in northern Italy. The former Duce escaped, or was rescued or captured by the Germans on Sept. 12.

More than 450,000 of the 4,000,000 members of the Presbyterian Church are serving with the armed forces, the Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott of the Committee on Camp Activities of the denomination's General Assembly declared yesterday at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, in an appeal for contributions to the Presbyterian Wartime Service Commission.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The British Government was urged today by the London Women's Parliament, a gathering of delegates of British women's organizations, to take immediate steps to improve the standard of health and housing in this country.

Forty years ago thinking Christians believed that it was necessary to adjust Christ to modern civilization -- to modern scientific and intellectual concepts -- but today, if the world is to survive, the need is for adjusting modern civilization to Christ, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon in Riverside Church.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14 -- Fierce fighting continued today on the island of Leros between the British defenders and the German invasion force, with the British managing to drive the Nazis back on the range of hills on the northeastern peninsula of the island.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 15 -- Berlin announced early today that nearly 500,000 Russian troops had broken through the German Dnieper River bend defenses in a new assault aimed at closing a gigantic trap on the huge Axis forces in the south.

Eleven, including Iron Shot, who has top weight of 149 pounds, are named for the $5,000 added Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park, where the United Hunts Racing Association will close the New York season today.
TULE LAKE, Nov. 14 -- Children of the disloyal Japanese-Americans held at the segregation camp here staged a parade today carrying the Rising Sun flag of the Japanese Empire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines, in a dramatic sick-bed message tonight, solemnly assured his Japanese-conquered people that Gen. Douglas MacArthur "soon will be able to start the reconquest of our homeland" and he again vowed that he would return to Manila with MacArthur.

Acting on the advice of James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Thomas J. Curran, chairman of the New York Republican Committee, would receive time during the Mayor's broadcast from City Hall next Sunday to reply to Mr. La Guardia's recent charge that the Republican party was responsible for the election of Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court.

A recent order of the Board of Education designed to reduce the number of elementary school classes with more than thirty-nine pupils was issued to permit the board "to make distorted public claims about the sizes of classes in the city's schools," the New York Teachers Guild charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Substantial increases to the ultimate consumer in the cost of eleven apple products will result from the action of the Office of Price Administration today in establishing new maximum processor prices.

ALGIERS, Nov. 14 -- The American Red Cross and the British Red Cross will coordinate special relief work in connection with the operation of the Allied Control Commission and the Allied Military Government in Italy, it was announced today.
A wide-open fight for the post of majority leader of the State Senate has developed since the election of Joe R. Hanley, who now occupies the position, to the Lieutenant Governorship.

The United Lutheran Church in America, largest of seventeen national Lutheran church bodies in the United States and Canada, observed its silver anniversary yesterday in special observances at the regular services here.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 15 -- Liberator and Mitchell bombers, following up a strafing raid by fighter planes, plastered Madang and near-by Alexishafen with 223 tons of bombs Saturday morning in the heaviest aerial assault yet thrown against the Japanese on New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Grade labeling of canned goods, eggs and other products priced by grade, must be required if consumers are to do their part in enforcing price ceilings, representatives of thirteen national consumer organizations told Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director, today.

The hockey fortunes of the New York Rovers continue practically apace with their big brothers, the New York Rangers. Opposing the Boston Olympics in an Eastern League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon the Rovers encountered a storm of rubber that buried them under a score of 10 to 0.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14 -- The capture by Yugoslav Partisans, with heavy losses to the Germans, of the twin Slavonian railroad junctions of Koprivnica and Virovitica, thirty-five miles apart and close to the Hungarian border, was reported today by the People's Army of Liberation.

I cannot deny the Yugoslavs' right and interest in asking for the revision of the Treaty of Rapallo, signed in 1920 by Italy and Yugoslavia, and which fixes the present boundaries between them. For there is no doubt that the unhappy war between the two countries has called forth a wave of hatred and recrimination.

Emphasizing that in the hands of the children of today lies the future of our country, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed yesterday for "a fair start in life for all children." She was the guest of honor at a reception at the home of Justice Hubert T. Delany at 467 West 144th Street.

BUFFALO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart, D.D., Bishop of Ogdensburg, said today the government "can and should do more" in promoting social security, but contended: "Let us not purchase social security at too high a cost in human liberty."

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Three persons lost their lives by asphyxiation and two others were poisoned seriously here today as cyanide fumes seeped into a building at 161 New Brunswick Avenue from an adjoining public garage that was being fumigated, police said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- As a climax to the silver jubilee observance in more than 4,000 congregations throughout the United States and Canada of the founding of the United Lutheran Church in America, dignitaries of the church assembled here this evening to honor the church's first and only president, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel of New York, and its first and only treasurer, E. Clarence Miller, banker, of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Continuing their assault against the life-lines of Japan's immense but shrinking empire, American submarines have sunk seven additional enemy vessels, including a plane transport, and damaged two others, the Navy Department reported today.

A sudden opportunity was dramatically utilized when Leonard Bernstein, American, aged 25, and engaged this season as assistant conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, led that body, conducting without rehearsal and on very short notice, at its concert of yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.
In your issue of Oct. 30 you published an editorial on coal research, and rather chided the coal industry for not taking any interest in investigating the chemicals that can be obtained from coal.

Articles by Louis Stark in this newspaper yesterday and today once more call attention to the inequities in our national wage program. Both from an administrative and an economic point of view the whole program has, in fact, become chaotic. On the one hand are the workers, mostly organized, in industrial plants.

In addition to a reduction of $410,000 for 1941-42 granted by Supreme Court Justice Charles McLaughlin, a further reduction of $1,855,000 has been allowed by the Appellate Division on the 1941-42 assessed valuation on the Hotel Pierre at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Britain's swift Mosquito bombers dropped explosives on Berlin last night for the second time since Thursday in a new series of morale attacks on the German capital.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) is working on a plan whereby the costs of the entire post-war relief and rehabilitation program, for which funds will have to be raised, may be kept down to $2,500,000,000, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Senators James O. Eastland of Mississippi and John L. McClellan of Arkansas announced tonight that they were preparing "several hundred" amendments to the Anti-Poll Tax Bill and estimated that weeks would be required for their consideration.

Active buying continued in the market last week, with Chesterfields still in demand and merchandise sought in volume for both the spring and holiday seasons, according to a summary especially prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A breath-taking 69-yard scoring run in the third period by Captain George Titus, recently converted from a center, gave Holy Cross a hard-earned 12-7 victory over a gallant Villanova football team today before a chilled crowd of more than 20,000 at Fitton Field.

In its second change of ownership in seventy-five years, the property at 165-69 and 171 Mulberry Street in Newark, N.J., was sold by William S. Roe, Inc., to the Cap, Screw and Nut Company of America, with main offices in Desbrosses Street in Manhattan, a small distributing plant at 156 1/2 Summit Street, Newark, and a factory at Cold Spring, N.Y.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 14 -- The people of Connecticut bought $42,400,000 worth of war bonds in the Third War Loan drive and financed six Electric Boat Company submarines, Edward J. Hickey, State Police Commissioner, said today at the launching of the submarines Barbel and Cavalla, which made twenty-one submarines built by the company in the last thirty-eight weeks.

Sidor Belarsky, Russian bass-baritone, sang a program of Russian songs last night in Town Hall which contained much that was novel, and that enlisted the interest of a large and approving audience. For Mr. Belarsky is not content to follow the beaten path of the conventionally minded song recitalist.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Although farmers sold moderate quantities of cash corn last week, the amount was far below trade expectations, especially in view of the fact that the aggregate yield in Illinois and Iowa this season is far above last year's all-time record, the Department of Agriculture reporting that these two States have 64,000,000 bushels more than in 1942.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association announced yesterday that its special sales promotion bulletin is now ready for distribution. Containing much information on sales promotion and merchandising, it is intended to aid all interested in retail selling both within and outside the merchandising field.

THE Iowa Pre-Flight eleven has been moving along in its quiet way without attracting too much attention. In the normal course of events the Seahawks would finish up in the same unassuming fashion. However, one game will catapult the aviation cadets to the center of the stage and create more fan interest for them than they have had all season.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (By Mail) -- French medical men view with deep despair the alarming increase in illness, death and disease in France today, Gen. Adolphe Eugene-Marie Sice of the Fighting French Forces declared today in his offices at 3 St. James Square.
I have just read the article printed in your paper on Nov. 8 entitled "Americans Losing Friends in Africa."

In conjunction with the annual "Night of Stars" at Madison Square Garden tomorrow evening, the United Palestine Appeal will publish its 1943 yearbook, containing articles by many leading writers. Those included in the yearbook are Thomas Mann, Jacques Maritain, Louis Bromfield, Pierre Van Paassen and Sigrid Undset.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose 0.04 per cent. The foodstuffs index showed the largest change, an increase of 0.7 per cent, as a result of price rises in eggs, apples and potatoes.
ALGIERS, Nov. 14 -- There was a good deal of fighting on the Italian front yesterday but little progress was made.

A U.S. BOMBER STATION, in Britain, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Flying Fortress Lonesome Polecat II floundered helplessly behind a formation of heavy bombers attacking Bremen yesterday, with one of her engines knocked out, her entire tail section in shreds, and gaping holes from nose to stern.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York yesterday appealed to Robert E. Hannegan, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, for relaxation of a Treasury Department ruling to enable payment of commission actually earned to sales managers.

The campaign for the National War Fund is entering its final weeks. New York City's $17,000,000 quota out of the national $125,000,000 is still far from filled. Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Secretary Ickes objecting both to our news treatment and editorial comment concerning the contract he signed with John L. Lewis. The factual reply made by Louis Stark concerning our news story would also cover our previous editorial discussion of the same point.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- As the war news steadily improves so the stock markets here persistently deteriorate.

Max D. Levine of Brooklyn, a member of the champion C.C. N.Y. intercollegiate team of 1921, gained his seventh consecutive victory in Group D of the national amateur championship tournament at the United States Chess Federation headquarters, 279 East Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- The North American Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a brief in which it maintains that the Illinois Iowa Power Company is prevented from filing any claims against the North American Light and Power Company because of the statute of limitations and by reason of many benefits Illinois Iowa has received from Light and Power.

The business groups division of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, 386 Fourth Avenue, will begin today to sell Christmas seals, it was announced yesterday by Dr. J. Burns Amberson, president of the association. The annual sales campaign will open next Monday.

ALGIERS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- French Communist leaders reiterated their demands today for control of the Information and Labor Commissariats in the French Committee of National Liberation, while their party organ, the Liberte, called for support of the Moscow accord.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The Black Hawks scored four goals each in the second and third periods tonight, Cully Dahlstrom making three, to rout the Rangers, 10 -- 5, and drive to their third straight National Hockey League victory. Chicago tied the idle Maple Leafs for second place.

Back from somewhere in the Pacific, where he had seen action with the United States marines, Capt. Dan Topping, owner of the football Dodgers, dropped in at Ebbets Field yesterday, along with 7,614 others, in time to see his club play its best game of the National Football League campaign.

The Moscow agreement and the Senate vote on the Connally resolution mark the beginning of a new era in history, but the realization of its promise -- a new world order -- will depend upon the extent to which Christ is accepted by the nations as the key to that order, declared the Rev. Elmore M. McKee in his sermon yesterday in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and Sixteenth Street.

Since democracy as a principle of government "has its origin in religion, which teaches that man was endowed with certain inalienable rights" proceeding from God, the state "cannot be well served by persons who divorce God from government," the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration announced tonight that conferences looking toward simplified price regulations for retail stores would be held this week with various types of retailers in Chicago and Washington.
The German attack on the British-held island of Leros in the Aegean Sea is a definite but probably a temporary setback in what is rapidly becoming a Balkan campaign.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Although the stock markets here were quiet today it was obvious that last week's selling flurry had petered out completely as most groups did well.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Roy Barton White, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, told stockholders today that although gross revenues for the first ten months of this year were $46,898,017 more than in the 1942 period, taxes would cut net income to less than last years figure.

Beating off all counter-attacks, our marines and soldiers on Bougainville are extending their bridgehead at Empress Augusta Bay. We now stand on the last rampart before Rabaul. Rabaul airfields are cluttered with burned-out planes; Rabaul Harbor is dotted with wrecked warships.

The Treasury continues to lose no time in withdrawing funds from Government war loan accounts in commercial banks throughout the country. Yesterday it was made known that the Treasury will make further withdrawals on Friday and Saturday, making five withdrawal days this week.

AMPHIBIOUS TRAINING BASE, CAMP BRADFORD, VA., Nov. 1 (Delayed) -- Amphibious training of the thousands of soldiers and sailors who are going through the "invasion mill" on the Atlantic coast is a multi-featured operation which is put together like a mosaic.

The Army Intelligence Service report on the strength of Germany and Japan, parts of which were released by Representative George E. Outland and printed in THE TIMES of Nov. 12, should, in Mr. Outland's own words, "give cause for reflection and additional hard work, not false optimism."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Distinguished Flying Cross has been awarded to Second Lieut. John O. Post of Belford, N.J., "for extraordinary achievement while participating in fifty operational flight missions in the Southwest Pacific area."

Publication of flat dollars and cents ceiling prices for wholesale grocers will soon be required by the Office of Price Administration, it was learned yesterday. According to a spokesman at the agency's headquarters here, plans for the project were virtually completed at a meeting of OPA officials yesterday afternoon and the lists will be made available "very shortly" for the use of retail grocers and the local price and rationing boards throughout the country.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- At the front one hears no talk of a German "winter line." One staff officer, asked what he thought of the so-called winter line, replied: "A lot of baloney."
ALGIERS, Nov. 15 -- Medium bombers of the Twelfth United States Air Force, based in Italy, bombed railway yards at Sofia, the capital of Bulgaria, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during October totaled 846,209 bales of lint and 117,399 bales of linters, compared with 973,086 of lint and 115,900 of linters during October, last year.

President Roosevelt took pains in his message to Congress yesterday to explain what the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Admiuistration is not as well as what it is. It is not a charity. It is not expected to "solve the long-range problems of reconstruction."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 -- After receiving a message from President Roosevelt lauding the results of cooperation between Government agencies and private builders in meeting war-housing needs, the National Association of Home Builders of the United States today adopted a platform calling for removal of all wartime restrictions and emergency Government controls as soon as victory were achieved.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Reorganization of the Catholic Church Extension Society was announced today by Bishop William D. O'Brien, its president, after the annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers sent out today its interpretation of the wage agreement made with the Government as it applies to the hard-coal area.
President Roosevelt's message to Congress recommending enactment of legislation authorizing appropriations for the work of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration follows:

Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday authorized a year-end dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock, bringing payments this year to equal the $4.25 distributed in 1942. Christiana Securities Company, whose entire holdings consist of du Pont stock, announced yesterday the declaration of a dividend of $24.70 a share on the common stock, increasing 1943 disbursements to $75.70 a share from $74.10 paid last year.

Fighting men of the United Nations armed forces will join stars of stage, screen and radio as performers in the "Night of Stars" tonight at Madison Square Garden. A capacity audience of 20,000 is expected to attend the tenth annual presentation, it was announced yesterday by Nathan Straus, chairman of the entertainment in behalf of Palestine reconstruction, refugee aid and overseas war relief and rehabilitation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, whose marines began their bold invasion of Bougainville Island on Nov. 1, flew in today from the Southwest Pacific "kind of thinking" that the Japanese were being rocked back on their heels and crediting "team-work" for recent successes in the Pacific theatre.

The return world lightweight championship battle between Bob Montgomery, titleholder, and Beau Jack, former champion, in Madison Square Garden Friday night, will attract a gate of about $90,000 if present expectations are fulfilled.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Six members of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union charged in a Circuit Court suit today that the pay of the unionists had been reduced through a conspiracy involving union officials, film corporations and "representatives of the Capone mob."

The apartment house for thirty families on a plot 83 by 100 feet at 1130 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the L.B.T. Realty Corporation, Rose Toperoff, president, to an investing client of Samuel L. Paul, attorney.

When Notre Dame finished with Michigan, Georgia Tech, Navy and Army, the popular reaction was that it had got over the big humps on the way to establishing itself as the unrivaled team of the season in intercollegiate football.

A program of piano music by Schumann and Brahms was given last night by Alfred Mirovitch at Carnegie Hall. The pianist showed a genuine understanding of both composers, especially of Schumann, and played some of their most difficult works with honors.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 15 -- After conferences with Richard G. Casey, British Minister of State in the Middle East, and French officials here, Gen. Georges Catroux left hastily today for Beirut, where he is scheduled to arrive tonight, in a tremendous effort to get the situation in hand before the danger spreads to other Middle East countries.

Registration of residential places by landlords under rent control began in the New York City Defense-Rental Area yesterday with a minimum of confusion but at rather too leisurely a pace to suit the officials. Louis H. Pink, area rent director, announced that 34,800 rental units had been registered in the five boroughs and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Buying attributed to cash interests, part of which is said to have represented removal of hedges against shipping sales of 165,000 bushels from here, carried wheat futures up today 1 to 1 1/8 cents on the Board of Trade and the close was at the top.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 -John R. Longo, former deputy Hudson County Clerk and political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague, was convicted in Hudson County Quarter Sessions Court here today on an indictment charging him with fraudulent alteration of his voting record.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Connecticut is evolving a reciprocal trade agreement of its own with Central and South America, Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin indicated today after sessions with Edward R. Stettinius, Under-Secretary of State, and Victor Borella of the Office of the Coordinator of International Affairs, representing Nelson Rockefeller.
Before indulging in the pleasant business of buying a new lipstick or pot of lip rouge, every woman should decide what she wishes in the way of consistency.

Lieut. Herbert R. Lakow of 1631 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, navigator of a Flying Fortress based in England, has been killed in action, the War Department has informed his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sol Lakow. It is believed he was killed in the Sept. 6 raid on Stuttgart.

With many buyers continuing to arrive in the wholesale markets here, buying activity for spring continues strong. Many orders for coats and suits are being placed, and in one merchandising quarter the question was raised yesterday whether more than a few manufacturers may not be reaching an oversold condition in relation to piece goods deliveries.

ALGIERS, Nov. 15 -- Sharp local actions in Italy yesterday and limited advances ranging up to "a few miles" could not alter the fact that, for the most part, both Allied armies remained balked on their own side of the Garigliano-Sangro line in bad weather.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- By a vote of 9 to 8 the Senate Committee on the Judiciary declined today to report to the Senate the O'Mahoney resolution which seeks to abolish poll taxes in eight Southern States by means of an amendment to the Constitution
