DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- An expanded program to provide day care for about 10,000 children of working mothers in Michigan has been developed by community groups and has been presented to Gov. Harry F. Kelly for his approval.

Concern over the plight of the white-collar worker continues to mount in face of the fact that there are practically no white-collar workers. They are in the vast majority blue-collar workers, or striped gray and brown and green collar workers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Daniel P. Woolley, Commissioner of Markets of New York City, was appointed today New York Regional Administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

The charter of American Youth for Democracy as a recognized campus organization was rescinded last night by a vote of 13 -- 6 by the student council of Washington Square College of New York University. The council had granted the charter to the successor to the dissolved Young Communists League two weeks ago by a vote of 10 -- 9.

Governor Dewey, speaking on "Post-war Opportunities," will address the twelfth Forum on Current Problems of The New York Herald Tribune in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria this evening. He will be one of forty-five distinguished speakers who will address the forum at its sessions today and tomorrow.

For the third time since its in auguration sixty years ago in Gilmore's Garden, the annual presentation of the National Horse Show will be interrupted. This was made known yesterday when Amory L. Haskell, president of the National Horse Show Association, announced that wartime conditions had caused the show's directors definitely to abandon the fixture this year.
ALLIED HEADQUATERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today to review the constitutionality of Government rent control regulations applying to the homes of more than 80,000,000 persons.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 15 -- A woman and five children lost their lives here tonight in a one-alarm fire that swept quickly through an old two-story frame dwelling in the rear of 402 Palisade Avenue.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- The chief responsibility for the increase in juvenile delinquency in Connecticut in wartime was laid on "the doorstops of every home and every community in the State" in a conference of authorities in the field of child welfare held today at the Yale University Clinic of Child Development under the auspices of the Committee of Children and Youth in Wartime and the Connecticut Child Welfare Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Secretary Harold L. Ickes, as coal mines administrator, urged the nation's coal operators today to make a contract with the United Mine Workers, saying that the sooner they did so and the sooner the mines were returned to them "the sooner you will make happier men of yourselves and of me."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Professional baseball is "absolutely essential" to civilian and military morale, Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois said today in pointing out that the sport is making valuable contributions to the war effort while using an "infinitesimal" part of the nation's manpower.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 11 per cent over the like week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 9 per cent in volume.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- The annual meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers was told today that a majority of the country's industrial concerns were expecting an increase of 20 to 40 per cent in employment after the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 15 -- Coinciding with word that Pierre Laval's militia is receiving, among other favors from Vichy, an annual appropriation of 20,000,000 francs comes news that patriots in France are turning their attention to militia leaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Bankhead bill which would appropriate between $25,000,000 and $30,000,000 for Government advertising of war bonds in newspapers ran into unexpectedly strong opposition today on the Senate floor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- When Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to investigate the liquor industry, Chairman Van Nuys predicted a "startling ex pose" of what he called the efforts of liquor monopolies to evade taxes and raise prices for hoarding huge stocks of whisky.

READERS of THE NEW YORK TIMES Sunday Magazine know that some of the most remarkable long-term thinking about the war and the peace is being done by a Hungarian novelist named Arthur Koestler. Like the Melancholia painted by the luckless protagonist of Kipling's "The Light That Failed," Koestler has survived disillusionment after disillusionment without losing the ultimate inner serenity that enables the human race to endure through the darkest ages.

Erno Balogh, pianist, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, divided his program almost equally between contemporary music and older works. In his frequent appearances over WQXR he has made a point of giving the works of living composers a hearing.

A Federal Trade Commission order directing the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, Inc., to cease and desist from activities violative of the Sherman anti-trust act was upheld yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here. The decision, which was unanimous, was handed down by Judges Learned Hand, Charles E. Clark and Jerome N. Frank.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 15 -- Inside Germany, which seems the most popular subject of discussion among journalists and travelers reaching neutral countries these days, gives plenty of encouragement for wishful thinkers who prophesy an early collapse of Germany.

Right at the start there are a number of good things to be said for Paul Osborn's new play, "The Innocent Voyage," which he derived from the Richard Hughes novel also known as "A High Wind in Jamaica." In the first place it is out of the run-of-mine theatre, during these days a major credit.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Trading in a security by any member of an underwriting group while other members still were engaged in the distribution of the security would be in violation of the anti-manipulative provisions of the Securities Exchange Acts of 1933 and 1934, it was held today by James A. Treanor Jr., director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP) -- John W. Bricker, saying that "confusion and distrust reign throughout the land," asserted today that the country needed "a change of philosophy of government," and announced formally that he was a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1944.

THE Three Bears came in together. There was Papa Bear and -- oh, well, perhaps that is a slight exaggeration. At any rate the Bears answered to the names of Hunk Anderson, Luke Johnsos and Sid Luckman. One would not be far wrong in describing them as the coaches of the Chicago Bears. They do all the thinking for the Monsters of the Midway both on and off the field.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Despite the rapid development of consumers' goods manufacturing industries in Brazil, there is no reason to suppose the volume of British products shipped to Brazil will be cut seriously after the war, Minister of Production Oliver Lyttelton stated here today.

One of the largest apartment buildings in the easterly Grand Central zone area was sold yesterday when an investing syndicate known as the 140 East Forty-sixth, Inc., purchased the twelve-story Gilford apartment edifice on the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

Theodore G. Joslin, public relations director of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., will give today the last in a series of lectures on synthetic plastics sponsored by the New York Institute of Finance in the governors' room of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 10, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Decreases of $228,000,000 in holdings of Treasury Bills and $708,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $265,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- General Tito announced today that the Germans had opened a major offensive to recapture the Dalmatian coast and Adriatic islands offshore, and Yugoslav observers in London feared the Partisans faced withdrawal to the mountains of the interior.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 15 -- Wadislaw Neuman, Polish Minister here said today that Poland's frontiers could not even be discussed.

Convinced that conditions in the liquor trade are getting out of hand and threaten to become worse, a conference of legislative representatives from twelve industrial States has been called to consider a program for joint corrective action.

A new campaign to collect 300,000,000 pounds of used cooking fats in the next year got under way yesterday with an announcement by Roy W. Peet, chairman of the American Fats Salvage Committee, 247 Park Avenue, that the American Railway Express would cooperate.

Trading in the distilling issues broke out of all normal bounds yesterday on the stock market, but the remainder of the list was irregular and final prices were mixed. Characterized by a sensational climb in American Distilling which spiralled more than 37 points before late selling reduced the net rise to 23 1/4 points, others in the liquor section showed gains of 1 to 5 points.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 15 -- British troops on the island of Leros have struck back sharply against the Germans and have slightly improved their positions during the past twenty-four hours. As a result of fierce battles, especially in the northeastern sector, the Nazis have been driven back and the British position, at least for the moment, can be described as more favorable than it was during the past two days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Arguments in what the Government considers one of the most important anti-trust cases in the history of the Department of Justice lasted for thirteen hours in the Supreme Court obey on the appeal of the Hartford-Empire Company and other concerns of the glassware industry.

SADIYA, Assam, Nov. 10 (Delayed) -- Situated at the head of railroad communications in Northeastern India, this little border outpost at the foot of the Himalayas is the starting point for one of the many back-door communications lines into China.

In celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of its foundation, the New York City Cancer Committee naturally reviewed its own past and the status of cancer today. Though the cause of cancer is still one of medicine's major mysteries, the record of nearly a generation is gratifying.

" United Nations Book Quiz," the second program in the young people's series "Fun With Book People," will be presented at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, Saturday morning at 10:30 o'clock. The program, which will feature a quiz on children's books, celebrates National Children's Book Week.

The United Air Lines Transport Corporation has called a special meeting of stockholders on Dec. 22 in Chicago to consider a new financing plan, according to a notice filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

AT PREMIER BADOGLIO'S HEADQUARTERS, in Italy, Nov. 14 (Delayed) -- If the new Allied Control Commission and its head, Maj. Gen. Kenyon A. Joyce, doubted whether the road to Rome was strewn with rocks and thorns, Premier Pietro Badoglio's statement yesterday dispelled all illusions.

The Board of Education, answering a charge by the New York Teachers Guild, explained yesterday that the board long had followed a policy of reducing oversize classes in the city schools. This was countered immediately by the guild, which maintained that the board was concerned mainly with the arbitrary juggling of figures without considering the needs of the children involved.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Opposition to the so-called "American" plan to finance the $2,500,000,000 world relief task by 1 per cent of national income was voiced today at a committee meeting of the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) by Eurico Penteado, Brazilian member of the Council and financial attache of the embassy at Washington.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be congratulated for its full report of the discerning address of Attorney General Francis Biddle at the annual dinner of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America on Nov. 11. Mr. Biddle's portrayal of growing racial tensions and prejudices against minorities in this country pointed out one of the major dangers to our internal unity and the foundations of American democracy.

Morton G. Bogue, New York lawyer, who has been affiliated with the United States Golf Association since 1934, first as general counsel and since 1940 as vice president, will be elevated to the presidency of that body on Jan. 15 at the fiftieth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Scrapping of the "arbitrary and rigid Little Steel formula to make room for a more flexible wage policy" to meet the needs of workers and consumers was demanded by the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union in a resolution made public yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the union.

ON THE GERMAN-SWISS FRONTIER, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Chaos exists in northern Italy where the Germans have failed in their efforts to conscript Italian men as soldiers or workers, a foreign diplomat who left there Sunday said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt tonight assured the people of the Philippines, on the eighth anniversary of the establishment of the Philippine Commonwealth, that the United States was working and fighting "for the day of your liberation" and the time when "the Japanese enemy is finally and totally defeated."

Two men were killed and three others were injured at 5 P.M. yesterday by an explosion in an exchange feeder pipe at the refinery of the Standard Oil Company of New York at 400 Kingsland Avenue, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 15 -- The Germans took over the military administration of Odessa from the Rumanians on Nov. 13, it was learned today from a traveler arriving here from Bucharest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A bill providing a uniform method for members of the armed forces and the merchant marine to vote their choice for President next year was approved today by the Senate Elections Committee, 12 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- This political capital, especially because a Presidential election is approaching, felt powerfully the impact of two dispatches to this newspaper and its editorial describing the plight of unorganized workers who have not had wage increases, as organized workers have, under the War Labor Board's "Little Steel" formula.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 16 -- Striking into the eastern edge of the Pripet Marshes, Soviet troops yesterday extended their siege arc around Gomel, main German base in southern White Russia, by cutting the next to last railroad out of the city and narrowing the enemy's escape route to a forty-mile corridor on the northwest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A full-dress investigation into scarcities of liquors in consumer markets, the prices imposed for newly devised blends and the state of supplies throughout the country was approved unanimously today by the Senate Committee on the Judiciary.
In your editorial, "In Freedom's Mountains," on Nov. 5, you say, speaking about the Swiss: "Since 1939 they have had a coalition government, by agreement among the parties."
The 56,681 football fans who cheered Sid Luckman on his exit from the Bears-Giants game on Sunday at the Polo Grounds may have seen the passing wizard for the last time in action in New York.

With Archbishop Francis J. Spellman making the principal appeal for support of the drive, the New York Committee of the National War Fund opened a citywide solicitation campaign last night at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden attended by 20,000 campaign workers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Allied planes, attacking Japanese air bases at Buka, on Bougainville's northern tip, dropped fifty-one tons of bombs and destroyed four Zeros on the ground.

I marvel at the spirit with which New York City people go to work year in and year out and think nothing of it. When you stop to think how early some people have to get up to make trains on time, the hours they spend traveling, the hard days of work, and the little time they have left to themselves, you cannot help but admire their persistence and patience.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- The midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The United States Navy, after having overcome the greatest transportation and handling problems ever presented in any war, is pouring supplies into the southwest Pacific on a scale large enough to support a major offensive against the Japanese, Rear Admiral William Brent Young disclosed today.

A Kings County grand jury denounced Mayor La Guardia yesterday for his failure to curb lawlessness in Brooklyn's "Little Harlem," the Bedford-Stuyvesant area, and also took the Mayor to task for broadcasting over the municipal station, WNYC, that those who had complained about these conditions were "crackpots" and "publicity seekers."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Awards have been made to more than 550 officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Eighth Air Force, headed by Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A decision by the highest legal authority of the country on the disputed question of portal-to-portal pay for miners was assured today when the Supreme Court agreed to hear arguments on this matter.

Shares of the American Distilling Company soared yesterday 37 1/4 points on the New York Stock Exchange from Saturday's closing level and closed at 97 1/2, up 23 1/4 points for the day, in one of the most sensational market performances since the boom days of 1929.

ALGIERS, Nov. 15 -- It was confirmed today that the United States, like Great Britain, had made strong representations to the French Committee of National Liberation when the disorders in Lebanon broke out.

Mr. Hull's assurance yesterday that no secret agreements were made at Moscow is a good item for the record, but it wasn't really necessary. Secret agreements and Mr. Hull don't belong in the same category. Mr. Hull does not do business that way. He is a man of deep loyalty to his own convictions, an old-fashioned diplomat whose habit is plain speaking.

Prompted by the Government's conservation plan for fresh milk, which recently became effective in the metropolitan area, the nutrition department of the Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross gave a lecture and demonstration yesterday at Abraham Straus on the use of substitutes for the bottled fluid.

James W. Egan Jr., advertising manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has been appointed chairman of the five-man committee of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association which will prepare a plan of operation for a central organization to be set up by the association for the preparation and dissemination of promotional material on retail advertising, it was announced yesterday.

The booking congestion being what it is these days, "Lady, Behave!" will open this evening at the Cort, stay there only through Saturday night to make way for "Get Away Old Man," and then shuttle over to the Ambassador in time to give a Sunday matinee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The White House sent to Congress a message asking funds to permit the United States to participate in the work of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

WITH UNITED STATES TROOPS ON BOUGAINVILE, Nov. 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, chief of the South Pacific leg of the war against Japan, visited his farthest penetration into enemy positions in the Solomons today and commented:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- A plan for the reclassification of all the present stocks of the American Power and Light Company into a single class of capital stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

YUNGAN, Fukien China, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- Just before sunrise the garage mechanic poured a couple of spoonfuls of gasoline into the carburetor to prime it, cranked the motor by hand and Postal Truck 39 set out from Karhsien for Changting with a load of mail bags, a drum of fuel alcohol and six tires rudely patched with iron plates bolted to the rubber.

With one more preliminary round to be contested, in addition to a number of adjourned games, four players from Groups B and D have qualified for places in the national amateur chess championship finals.

Supported chiefly by routine trade buying, the cotton futures market yesterday moved up for the third consecutive session. The list of active old-type contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended with gains of 6 to 9 points over Saturday's closing quotations, with the strength again in the distant positions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- With the House fight on the issue scheduled to come up Thursday, the Senate Agriculture Committee today heard representatives of the livestock producers denounce food subsidies and the Administration's hog and cattle programs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Solid Fuels Administration for War, in its first move of the kind, established minimum standards of quality today for domestic-sized Pennsylvania anthracite coal sold for domestic use under present distribution limitations.

The cigar shortage, particularly in the lower-priced field, can be expected to last for the duration of the war, Harry McHose, director of the Cigar Institute of America, Inc., declared yesterday on his return from a two-month survey of the industry throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -The Supreme Court ruled today that a "reliable prediction" cannot be made concerning the amount of money required for the "happiness" of a woman.

The firm of Durand-Ruel is celebrating this year its 140th anniversary, and the occasion is signalized by a special exhibition that opened yesterday in the New York establishment at 12 East Fifty-seventh Street.

ALGIERS, Nov. 15 -- That the Communists would soon be represented on the French Committee of National Liberation was made plain today in declarations by two committee members, both highly influential in resistance circles within France.

The prediction by Dr. Eveline M. Burns, member of the now abolished National Resources Planning Board, that women would have to work for less pay than men in the post-war world was sharply challenged yesterday by Miss Charlotte Carr, assistant to Clinton Golden, labor representative on the War Manpower Commission, in an address before the student body of Hunter College High School.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- A communique:
The War Food Administration announced last night the release of 5,000,000 pounds of butter to the nation's hospitals for the period from November through March.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 -- Sophie Tucker has been signed by Andrew Stone for his forthcoming United Artist production, "Sensations of 1944." She will be featured in a "Gay Nineties Revue," singing several of her old vaudeville numbers.

While approach of the peak gift-buying season for women's stockings has not brought out any of the oft-rumored "hidden stocks" of genuine nylons for consumers, it has spurred activity among "con men" who have taken advantage of the wartime absence of nylon to mulct gullible shoppers in the busy midtown shopping area, it was reported yesterday in the hosiery trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Depopulation on a scale that threatens the power to recover is pictured in a pamphlet, "The Health of Children in Occupied Europe," issued today by the International Labor Office, which has headquarters here.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 -- The Russians this morning reported taking up positions for storming Korosten. Forward units were less than fifteen miles from that city last night. This town, on the Vitebsk-Mogilev-Zhitomir lateral railway, is perhaps even more important than Zhitomir as a communications center, for through it runs the only good road northward through the eastern part of the Pripet Marshes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, at a press conference today, described the accomplishments of the Moscow conference as a great forward step and one that held out hopeful and encouraging prospects for world peace.

BUFFALO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Robert J. Watt. AFL member of the National War Labor Board, asked for labor representation on community fund directorships tonight and said that there was real danger that social agencies would be "restrained from progressive social action by the highly conservative character of the usual board of directors."
LONDON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- The Soviet early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow:

From conquered fields in Italy our bombers have brought the war at last to Sofia. On Sunday two waves of Mitchells, escorted by Lightning fighters, blasted the railroad yards of the Bulgarian capital in an effort to cut main traffic lines from Hungary and Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A special House Committee investigating Federal executive agencies called upon Congress today to rewrite the Price Control Law to protect the people from practices of the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- In refusing to transfer to the armed services the control of radio intelligence activities exercised by James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, President Roosevelt was revealed today to have overruled Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Naval Affairs Committee as well as the Secretaries of War and Navy whose joint request was sent to the White House on Feb. 8.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Alfred de Marigny announced today that he would remarry his wife, the former Nancy Oakes, but the couple failed to appear at St. Francis Xavier Catholic Church where a priest waited to perform the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- A high Polish source, asserting that Poland would be the testing ground of Russia's European intentions, warned tonight that the first test would come when the Red Army crossed the old Polish border.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- Soldiers maintaining order at the Tule Lake segregation center for disloyal Japanese and Japanese-Americans began using land mine detectors today in a search for buried weapons and, according to unofficial sources, had found some knives and other arms, as well as radio parts.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 16 -- Catalina patrol bombers, maintaining an air blockade of Rabaul, New Britain, scored a direct hit with a 1,000-pound bomb on a Japanese light cruiser and struck a large merchantman with a 500-pounder in attacks Saturday night and before dawn Sunday morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- The Navy announced today thirty-five casualties including one dead, twenty-one wounded and thirteen missing.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 15 -- Heavy fighting is still under way in eastern Bosnia between the Yugoslav Partisans and the German and Ustashi forces, according to reports from the Free Yugoslavia radio. At the same time Yugoslav units under Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch were reported pressing home attacks against the Germans in the Dragachevo district in Serbia, the Yugoslav information office said in Cairo tonight.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Frank Maznicki, star halfback of the undefeated Iowa Pre-Flight Seahawks, and six other members of the first and second teams will not be available for the Notre Dame game Saturday, it was announced today.
Counsel for Wayne Lonergan received yesterday another week's stay of formal pleading on the indictment charging him with the first-degree murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.
The practical importance of Anglo-American cooperation during and after the war is too great to justify ignoring existing obstacles to cordial relations. They must be faced and eliminated.

The largest crowd ever to attend a United Hunts meeting, betting the largest sum in the 39-year history of that organization, yesterday brought New York's record-breaking racing season to an end at Belmont Park.

There are many variations of one of the six best stories in the world: The young corporal takes over the platoon when all the officers are down; the captain, with the dead admiral at his side, signals the fleet to go ahead; the young actress, fresh from Corinth or Ashtabula, steps into the star's role; the junior clerk, alone in the office, makes the instantaneous decision that saves the firm from ruin.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Dinner Party, the White Star Stable's gelded 3-year-old son of Cavalcade, came with a rush in the stretch today to capture the Goshen allowance purse, feature event on the Rockingham Park card.

The American Friends of Greece, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, are bringing out a new book, "Greece of Tomorrow," edited by George H. Chase, Dean of Harvard University. The book deals with various aspects of the peace as they specifically will affect Greece, and how these problems may be solved.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Bribery charges against former Gov. Leon C. Philips and his one-time parole officer, Robert R. Fitzgerald, were dismissed at the opening of their trial today on motion of the prosecution.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Salary increases and restorations for 535 employes of Westchester County are included in the proposed 1944 operating budget drafted by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach, officials said this afternoon when the Board of Supervisors met to consider it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -The Office of Price Administration established today ceilings over the farm sale prices of nine varieties of cigar leaf tobacco at levels representing varying advances over 1942 season averages.

New preferred shares of the General Tire and Rubber Company and of Thompson Products, Inc., will be offered today by separate underwriting groups. In addition, the $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Atlanta and Charlotte Air Line Railway were awarded yesterday to a banking group which will reoffer them subject to the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The Duke of Gloucester, whose first love is active soldiering, has been appointed by his brother, King George VI, as next Governor General of Australia, succeeding Lord Gowrie, according to an announcement from Buckingham Palace today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15 -- Men, women and children being repatriated to the United States from Japanese internment camps walked down the gangplank of the liner Gripsholm, as she docked here today, smiling at reaching the free Americas.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, in connection with its previously announced recapitalization program, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $38,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series due in 1968, and 40,000 shares of 4 3/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value, both to be sold at competitive bidding.

The Chrysler Corporation and its wholly owned domestic subsidiaries, in a statement of operations for the first nine months of 1943 to be issued today to stockholders by K.T. Keller, president, disclosed net sales of $651,008,540, representing an increase of $227,386,425 over the volume for the same period of 1942.

A new issue of $6,040,000 electric power refunding revenue bonds was announced yesterday by Chattanooga, Tenn., for award on Nov. 23. The issue will be dated Dec. 1, 1943, and will mature serially from July 1, 1960 to 1969.

Whether raw fur prices as given in the lists recently issued by the Office of Price Administration represent March, 1942, levels came to the fore yesterday as an issue in the discussion of the proposed revision of the price regulation affecting the fur industry, held by OPA officials and representatives of the trade at the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 231 soldiers killed in action in the European, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern and Southwest Pacific areas. Included were nine men from New York City, eight from other parts of the State, eleven from New Jersey and two from Connecticut.

Recipes were exchanged on an international basis yesterday by representatives of fifty nationalities. At an emergency conference on food and the foreign born, sponsored by the Common Council for American Unity, speakers explained how all groups could help the Government's Food Fights for Freedom program, and their words were illustrated by dishes prepared by foreign-born women who live in New York.

In a slightly censored address Thomas J. Curran, head of the Republican party in Manhattan, told the voters over the radio last night what he really thinks of Mayor La Guardia, who has been his party's Mayoralty candidate three successive times.
The unfortunate incidents in Beirut may well mislead those who do not realize the difficult task confronting the French National Committee of Liberation.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- A resolution calling for prompt Government action to provide for early and orderly liquidation of surplus Federal industrial plant and realty holdings after the war was adopted by the Society of Industrial Realtors, a branch of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in convention today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16 -- Gen. Georges Catroux arrived in Beirut today and immediately started trying to ameliorate the grave situation in Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senator Warren Austin of Vermont, who was a Republican pillar of the President's Allied aid policy long before Pearl Harbor made that a normal military measure, has been brooding over methods to assure non-partisanship and public confidence in the count of the votes which will be cast in the 1944 Federal elections by our armed forces abroad.

Vacant plots containing 100,000 square feet have been purchased in Forest Hills, L.I., by Samuel Barkin Sons, building operators, for improvement immediately after the war. The property is one block from Queens Boulevard and was bought from the Solros Building Corporation through Joseph Strauss and Louis J. Glickman, associate brokers.

Angelo DeSanza, 21 years old, who boasted that under the name of Terry Young he had averaged $10,000 yearly for the last three years as a lightweight pugilist, ten of his fights being in Madison Square Garden, was sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to a Sing Sing term of two and one-half to five years as the leader of a gang of young gunmen who perpetrated a series of hold-ups on the lower East Side.

Prices in the cotton futures market were irregularly higher yesterday in a session dominated by uncertainties over war developments and reports that Spain had postponed indefinitely her recent negotiations for United States cotton. Except for the January delivery, which ended trading on the New York Cotton Exchange with a 7-point drop from previous closing levels, the list of active old-type contracts advanced 3 to 4 points. Twenty-eight sales were transacted in the new contract.

AMERICAN football, a game which sends us into ecstasies of delight, leaves the Australians colder than a refrigerator car. Yet that should not cause too much surprise. There was an exhibition of the gridiron sport at the Los Angeles Olympics and not a European was left in the house at half-time. They just walked out on it in sheer boredom.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

During "The Star-Spangled Banner," which prefaced John Charles Thomas' recital at Carnegie Hall last night, a young man in the audience sang out with so much fervor and carrying power that he drew attention upon himself. When the audience resumed its seats, Mr. Thomas smiled and said, "So long as he is a tenor."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, said today that Congressional support of a bill to approve a wage increase of 8 cents an hour negotiated by spokesmen for 1,100,000 nonoperating unions and the railroads would mean that Congress itself would have broken the Little Steel formula.
"And don't confound the language of the nation

Arrangements for the overseas broadcast of excerpts from Broadway attractions, employing members of the original acting companies, and of other bits of theatrical Americana to service men of this country stationed in Britain were completed yesterday by Roy Lockwood, production manager of the British Broadcasting Corporation's New York office.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -- Guerrillas in the northern industrial section of Italy have begun what appears to be a large-scale and well-coordinated offensive against the Germans along a front stretching from Domo d'Ossola in the west to Venice in the east, with several "islands" of resistance harassing German communication lines south of the Po valley.

The Notre Dame eleven defeated a stalwart Northwestern team last Saturday, 25 to 6, but apparently lost a little prestige in doing it. Three of the ninety sports writers taking part in the weekly Associated Press poll to determine the ranking football teams picked the Irish for second place this week.

The expansion and further decentralization of the War Labor Board and the Wage Stabilization units of the Treasury Department would result in an immediate increase in vital war production, O.C. Cool, director of the Labor Relations Institute, asserted last night.

Civic and naval leaders gave public support yesterday to the current program of the National War Fund to attain a city-wide goal of $17,000,000 for the United Service Organizations, the United Seamen's Service, the New York City Defense Recreation Committee and twenty-three other agencies serving the United Nations.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- For the first time since William Caxton, British publishers can now produce any kind of book and be reasonably sure of its financial success.
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:...

Four hundred and twenty detectives and plainclothes men started a four-day survey of conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant district of Brooklyn yesterday on orders from Mayor La Guardia. The Mayor, with Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, was severely criticized by the Kings County Grand Jury on Monday for the "most unusual and extremely deplorable state of lawlessness that exists in this area and has existed for some years past."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A War Production Board order, issued today, instructed 450 work clothing manufacturers to set aside a minimum of 25 per cent of sewing machinery operated or controlled by them during the first six months of next year for fulfillment of what WPB called "urgent" Army procurements during that period.

The National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, will announce tonight an award for the best book jacket design in its thirty-eighth annual New-Book show, displaying 2,000 books published in 1943. This is the first time such an award has been given.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- After having opened well yesterday for the week, the stock markets here continued to go ahead today. Kaffirs improved on Cape and London support, Venterspost rising about 9d, Diamond shares also were strong, De Beers deferred putting on about 7 1/2s.

No matter what the rest of the football world may think of their chances, the New York Giants have not given up their quest of the Eastern title in the National Football League. Admittedly, their outlook is dark after Sunday's 56-7 nightmare, enjoyed exclusively by the Bears. However, until they are mathematically eliminated from the chase, the Giants will cling to their hopes.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Livestock and crop-producing resources of the United States are insufficient to "feed the world," Dr. Forrest F. Hill, head of the Department of Agricultural Economics at Cornell University, said today, and demands on American agriculture must be limited by what can he set aside to meet foreign needs.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Arthur (Bud) Metheny, 26-year-old second-string right-fielder for the Yankees, was rejected for military service when he underwent an examination here yesterday. A "trick knee" acquired several years ago in playing high school football caused the rejection.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Japan's fleet has been punished so badly at Rabaul by carrier task forces that she should be giving "serious consideration" to complete abandonment of the important New Britain base as "too hot to handle," a Navy Department spokesman declared today.

FEODOR DOSTOEVSKY was a writer of genius, one of the great novelists of world literature. Once when his creditors were too close upon his heels for comfort he fled from his native Russia to exile in Germany. He lived on borrowed money, wrote begging letters to his friends and tried to ease his financial straits at the gambling tables of Baden-Baden.

A million community ceiling price posters listing top retail prices for food products, effective today, are now being sent out to grocers in this region by the Office of Price Administration, it was learned yesterday.

The need for planning now for a more comprehensive and more efficiently administered system of social security as part of a larger economic and social program of post-war rehabilitation was urged by Leo Arnstein, Commissioner of Welfare, in an address last night at the opening session of the forty-fourth annual New York State Conference of Social Work at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A short time before the scheduled public opening of the exhibition of the art collection of the late J.P. Morgan at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, the galleries announced yesterday that one of the paintings had been bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This was the first announcement of the purchase of any of the pictures that Mr. Morgan's estate will offer at private sale thorugh the Knoedler Galleries.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- There is great fear among the repatriates aboard the exchange ship Gripsholm that some irresponsible person might say something that would get back to Japan by radio and cause the Japanese military police to visit reprisals upon the heads of thousands of internees left behind in China, the Philippines, Japan and elsewhere, it was learned here today.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Hundreds of British tankers carrying essential cargoes of gasoline and oil have been saved through the ingenious use of compressed air pumps after they had been struck by torpedoes, it was made known here today.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,445, which compared with 1,328 in the preceding week and 831 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 867, against 683 last Tuesday.

William S. Jack of Jack Heintz declared yesterday there is no actual manpower shortage in America because if labor is freed from its traditional fear of management and given true incentives "it prefers to work a twelve-hour shift instead of an eight-hour day in order to get the one thing that interests everybody the most -- a larger pay envelope at the end of the week."

Onondaga County, N.Y., awarded yesterday to the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and Barr Brothers Co., Inc., a new issue of $1,500,000 certificates of indebtedness. The bankers jointly bid an 0.43 per cent basis for the issue, which is dated Nov. 23, 1943, and is payable on April 22, 1944.

Many young women of society are serving on the junior and debutante committees for the performance of the Ice Follies on the night of Dec. 2 at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

In the first Federal court actions instituted under the rent regulations put into effect here Nov. 1 by the Office of Price Administration, two tenants obtained orders yesterday temporarily preventing their eviction from the apartment house at 10 East 198th Street, the Bronx. The suits were filed by Murray Schwartz and Max Steinzor against the Trajer Realty Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- A London boy 12 or 13 years of age today is 2.4 inches taller and 10.2 pounds heavier than his father was at the same age and a girl is 2.1 inches taller and 13.4 pounds heavier than her mother in the same relative period.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- Exploiting their successes west of Gomel, which were gained only after the stiffest fighting in hilly, wooded country, the Russian troops under Gen. Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's command were reported this morning to be broadening their grip on the southern White Russian railway cut yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- It is now apparent that the tri-power conference at Moscow was just the beginning of the great decisions that must be taken by the United States, Britain and Russia in their joint task of winning the war and maintaining the peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the award of decorations to 1,548 officers and enlisted men of the Army Air Forces who participated in the low-level bombardment attack on the Ploesti oil refineries in Rumania on Aug. 1, which destroyed 42 per cent of the total Rumanian refining capacity in a devastating blow at vital Axis war economy.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms, at its annual meeting yesterday in the governors' room of the New York Stock Exchange, unanimously elected the slate proposed for governors by the nominating committee headed by Albert H. Gordon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Prompt and final settlement of terminated war contracts by agreement between the contractor and the original contracting agency is essential, the Federal Reserve Board declared tonight, if Government and business are to meet the "stupendous" post-war task of converting to a peace economy.

Muriel Kerr, who gave her first Town Hall piano recital in nearly three years last night, has made, since her debut here with orchestra in 1928, a secure place for herself among the leading women pianists of the day, and this view was confirmed last night.

A post-war opportunity for 5,000,000 salesmen was predicted yesterday by Lee J. McCanne, secretary and assistant general manager of the Stromberg-Carlson Company, who said this will represent enough jobs to absorb one-half of the men who will be released from the armed forces.

Commercial paper outstanding in the United States at the end of October amounted to $187,800,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of this market. In the month the volume increased $18,300,000, or 11 per cent.

With Dec. 25 only five-and-a-half weeks away, you undoubtedly are thinking about, if not already purchasing, Christmas gifts. To aid you in your solution, we offer the following suggestions, all of which are available in city stores, and recommend that if you take a fancy to one or more of them you buy or order it as soon as possible.
State Senator and Mrs. Walter Watson Stokes of Cooperstown, N.Y., have come to the Waldorf-Astoria.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the newcomer is "Guadalcanal Diary," a Twentieth Century-Fox adaptation of the book of the same title by Richard Tregaskis. The topical drama dealing with the Marines' offensive against that Pacific outpost, was directed by Lewis Seller and includes William Bendix, Lloyd Nolan, Preston Foster, Richard Conte, Anthony Quinn and Richard Jaeckel among its leading players.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- Further steps in the corporate simplification of the United Light and Power Company system are in the offing as a result of the recapitalization plan just filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, a subsidiary of the American Light and Traction Company, which, in turn, is a part of the United Light system.

The five-story loft building on a plot 80 by 98.9 feet at 507-11 West Thirty-third Street was sold by the Remford Corporation, Charles Gadofsky, president, to Virginia Krulik and Belle Kahler. Steckler, Frank Newmark were the attorneys for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Wage negotiations between bituminous coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America may be resumed soon as a result of the mediation of Secretary Ickes, it was reported tonight.

Fines of $500 each were imposed by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday on thirteen wholesale produce dealers who admitted buying oranges at prices in excess of Office of Price Administration ceilings.

FROM A NORTH AFRICAN PORT, Nov. 16 -- The senior-grade lieutenant aboard the U.S.S. Destroyer Mayrant, whom all his shipmates call "Big Pancho," stood rigid in the rain this afternoon as Vice Admiral H.K. Hewitt pinned two decorations on him.

Bob Montgomery, world lightweight champion, and Beau Jack, fromer titleholder, yesterday were subjected to a physical examination by the State Athletic Commission and found to be in tiptop shape for their fifteen-round title fight in Madison Square Garden on Friday night.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Cantonese from Chungking and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

Former King Carol of Rumania, who has repeatedly offered his services to the Allied nations but has thus far failed to obtain a sympathetic response, will address the people of the United States by radio from his exile in Mexico City next week, when he will tell them of his desire to help the cause of the United Nations by forming a Free Rumanian Government as an instrument against Nazi Germany.

The stock market continued yesterday to back down, and, while dealings again centered in distillery issues, prices were reduced under the pressure of profit-taking. Traders showed no desire to re-enter the market on any large scale, and the opinion prevailed in Wall Street that there was small chance of any immediate change in the trend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Recognition of Russia ten years ago today was cited by Mrs. Charles W. Tillett, assistant chairman of the Democratic National Committee, as one of the "brilliant reversals of American policy" on which this Administration might claim continuance in the 1944 election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Cattle buyers today were advised by the Office of Price Administration that they will be required to report their total monthly expenditures for live cattle, and the total tonnage of beef by grade obtained from the slaughtered animals, when the live cattle price stabilization program becomes operative on transactions after Nov. 30.

City Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Woolley declared yesterday that when he assumes his new duties as regional director of the Office of Price Administration here next week he will wage "an unflinching campaign against black markets, deliberate violators and wartime profiteers."

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Persistent buying of wheat futures attributed to cash interests advanced prices around 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, December selling at a new fourteen-year peak. There was no material pressure, except from Northwestern interests, and closing trades were at gains of 1/4 to 3/8 cent.

Your editorial of Nov. 13 on the illusions of P.R. election of our City Councilmen prompts me to beat my breast and bow my head. I was among the earliest supporters of P.R. because, like so many other well-meaning civic enterprises, I thought it was a reasonably effective means of breaking the backs of the political machines engendered by the clubhouses and in control of our election machinery.

City College opens its seventeen-game basketball campaign Saturday night in the Beavers' gym aganst the Midshipmen of Columbia University. Although two veterans have returned, the quintet that will face the Middies will be, for the most part, young and inexperienced.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Counsel for the estate of the late Commodore Morton Plant, steamship operator, declared in Superior Court today that they would prove that Peter Bennett Plant was the adopted son of the commodore's stepson, Philip M. Plant and Constance Bennett, movie actress, instead of their natural son, as she claimed.

With an invitation preview last evening, the Museum of Modern Art opened its major show of the present season, "Romantic Painting in America." The large exhibition, retrospective and contemporary in range, occupies the entire second floor of the museum.

Use of names or photographs of Navy personnel in advertising is now permitted under certain conditions, if permission is first obtained from the man in question, the Navy Department announced yesterday. Text of the revised order is now being sent out to all advertising agencies by the Advertising Section of the Public Relations Office of the Third Naval District.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Senate, by a vote of 40 to 35, passed and sent to the House today a bill directing the Secretary of the Treasury to spend $12,500,000 to $15,000,000 a year in advertising the sale of war bonds in smaller newspapers of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senate and House conferees on the fathers' draft legislation broke their deadlock today and agreed on a measure providing for the delaying of inductions of pre-Pearl Harbor parents as long as possible "without affecting the usual regular and orderly flow" of required manpower into the armed forces according to quota schedules.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The swank to which past service entitles them was assured for the Wasp (Women's Air Force Service Pilots) when the War Department announced today an official uniform for these still-civilian fliers who will number 1,000 in service or in training by Jan. 1.

While rent registration continued to lag yesterday, it was stepped up considerably over Monday. Landlords registered 50,900 dwelling units during the day in the New York City Defense-Rental area, which takes in the five boroughs as well as Nassau and Suffolk Counties, as against 34,800 units on the first day.

"Lady, Behave!", which opened last evening at the Cort, probably is the "Hairpin Harmony" of the nonmusical stage. To say that it is bad is to state the clinical details as gingerly as possible, and with the kindest of bedside manners.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Wounded soldiers have almost twice as good a chance to survive as the wounded in the first World War, the Office of War Information reported today on the basis of information on battle casualties gathered from military medical departments.

The Metropolitan Opera Association's advance general sale for the opening week of its diamond jubilee season began yesterday, and was reported to have been the best for the last fifteen years. With a queue leading out from the boxoffice to Broadway and around Thirty-ninth Street half-way back through the block and then snaking back to Broadway, the executive offices of the Metropolitan declared it was "the day of days" in recent Metropolitan Opera history.

The annual autumn card party and sale in behalf of the Silver Cross Day Nursery will be held tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. There will be a sale of candy, needlework and decorative articles suitable for gifts. Mrs. Harold S. Smith is president of the beneficiary, and Mrs. Santo C. Ceribelli heads the benefit committee.

SOUTHWEST PACIFIC ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 16 (AP) -- For participation in fifty operational flights, the Distinguished Flying Cross has been awarded to Second Lieuts. Frederick T. Goldstein, 42-03 160th Street, Flushing, Queens, and George W. Walder Jr., 63 Jefferson Boulevard, Atlantic Beach, L.I.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Ann Shirley signed a Republic contract today for the feminine lead opposite Michael O'Shea in "The Man From Frisco," the film to be based on the shipbuilding career of Henry J. Kaiser. A camera unit is now filming scenes for the picture at Kaiser's Richmond, Calif., plant. Studio production will begin Dec. 1, with Robert Florey directing.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Nancy de Marigny intends to stand by her husband, Alfred de Marigny, even though he faces deportation, and today attempted to fly to Washington, where she plans to seek permission for herself and her husband to take up residence in the United States.

The preliminary consolidated income account for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, released today by the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries, discloses a net income before depletion of $25,854,242, after providing $24,514,500 for estimated taxes.

In THE TIMES of Nov. 11 R.L. Duffus grows lyrical about berry pies. He writes: "Have you never seen a blackberry pie as it came out of the oven, its crimson exuded juices brave against a tawny crust?"

The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company and wholly owned subsidiaries had a net profit of $1,032,075 in the first nine months of this year after $1,621,000 Federal taxes, following deduction of a $132,000 post-war refund, Edward P. Farley, the chairman, reported yesterday to stockholders.

No outside aid can diminish the splendor of the great Russian advance, which has swept the Nazis out of the vast area between the Volga and the Dnieper and is now approaching Bessarabia and the old frontiers of Poland. It is the Russian fighting spirit that made this victory possible and Russian blood that has paid for it.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 16 -- A suggestion that the 560,000 it is proposed to raise by loan to defray the cost of the land of the United States bases might better be diverted to "revolutionize" the educational system, is one of the main points in the report of the Manpower Commission, which has just surveyed the colony's labor needs, it was learned today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 17 -- Soviet forces smashed close to the Ukraine rail and road junction of Korosten at three points yesterday while another Red Army column moved nine miles deeper into the eastern fringe of White Russia's Pripet Marshes in a drive that threatened to collapse the Germans' Gomel front.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Federal expenditures for war purposes last month amounted to $7,105,000,000, a decrease of $107,000,000, or 1 1/2 per cent, from the $7,212,000,000 reported for September, the War Production Board said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Coach Harry Mahnken, who is big and strong and stout-hearted -- fortunately -- was busy with chalk and blackboard when interrupted today at the Princeton Tigers' dressing quarters. Mahnken, standing somewhere around 6 feet 3 inches and boned and muscled in proportion, had just moved two defense men out (with chalk, of course) when we broke in on him.
Several large apartments were among those reported yesterday as having been leased in various sections of the city.
Columbia's basketball team will open its intercollegiate season Friday night against Webb Institute on the University Hall court, Morningside Heights.

In a dramatic night landing, Greek guerrillas somewhat redressed the battle situation on Leros. Swarming ashore from an Allied destroyer, they struck the Germans just as they seemed about to overwhelm the island. Now Greek and Italian, late enemies, are fighting shoulder to shoulder with the British, to drive the common foe back to his beachhead. The Nazi paratroops, supported by dive bombers, are resisting strongly.

Our rent registration story yesterday said that the procedure involves an estimated two million dwelling units and a quarter of a million landlords. Even for a big place like New York this sounds like a lot of landlords, especially when some of the landlords may be the Waldorf-Astoria or the Mills Hotels with a considerable number of lodgers.

On the basis of a two-day informal inquiry into the liquor situation, the Joint Committee on Interstate Cooperation of the New York State Legislature found yesterday that available stocks were not being distributed equitably and that the public generally was not receiving fair treatment from the liquor trade.
ALGIERS, Nov. 16 -- The United States Fifteenth Air Force sent B-24 Liberators flown by Yugoslav airmen to bomb the Eleusis airfield near Athens, it was announced today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 16 -- It was indicated today that the New York Yankees would choose this resort as a spring training site in 1944.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner K.M. Landis has ordered all major league baseball players who have engaged in southern California winter league games to submit an accounting of their earnings, preparatory to fining them for violating a rule forbidding post-season exhibitions.

NAPLES, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -- Count Carlo Sforza, in the midst of some bitter comment today on King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Pietro Badoglio's new "under-cabinet" of technical experts, expressed the opinion -- widely held among Italian liberals -- that the Allies were supporting their enemies in Italy.

Imagination and volubility are common among the men and women, boys and girls picked up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for masquerading as military personnel, but the bureau has seldom brought to light such a combination of the two qualities as Lara Westfall displayed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Announcing that it would make a daily report on hog-marketing conditions throughout mid-Western markets, the War Food Administration today urged farmers to get in touch with their agents in various stockyards to make sure that their hogs can be handled before shipping them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Italian formula agreed upon at the Moscow Conference, under which there will be free and untrammeled plebiscites in due course for the peoples of liberated areas of Europe to choose their own governments, does not apply to the adjustment of boundaries except indirectly, according to explanations made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The Allied aerial offensive in northwestern Europe extended its range into Norway today when strong forces of Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force struck smashing blows at the molybdenum mines at Knaben and a power station and electrolysis plants at Rjukan.
The year-end dividend of 20 cents a share declared on the common stock by the Blaw-Knox Company increases 1943 payments to 60 cents a share, compared with 35 cents last year.
The text of the address delivered by Governor Dewey at The New York Herald Tribune forum at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night follows:

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -- Nine French civilians were killed and some fifty injured and one German soldier was killed and about a dozen wounded in Lyon during the explosions of two bombs and the shooting that followed.

A Gallup survey on the question of establishing a post-war system of compulsory military service in the United States clearly shows the impact of the war on American opinion. What used to be a substantial majority against such a system of service in peacetime has now become a top-heavy majority of more than two to one in favor of it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- More lend-lease aid was sent to Russia during the first nine months of this year than had been forwarded during the preceding fifteen months, it was reported today by Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator.

ALGIERS, Nov. 16 -- The belief that the recent reorganization of the French Committee of National Liberation had meant the end of the recurrent crises was drastically shaken today when it was learned that, since the settlement announced on Nov. 9, Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud had threatened several times to resign as Commander in Chief of the French forces.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16 -- The Royal Navy, continuing to maintain constant patrols in the Aegean Sea, has bombarded the German ports and positions on the island of Leros and has carried out numerous successful attacks on enemy shipping, it was announced here today.

The tenth annual "Night of Stars," huge variety show for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal, took place at Madison Square Garden last night. A capacity crowd of 20,000 contributed $100, 000 for the reconstruction of Palestine, relief and rehabilitation overseas and refugee aid in the United States.

Members of the Tammany executive committee, many of whom had been invited to attend a "reorganize Tammany" rally held last night by Harold R. Moskovit's Affiliated Young Democrats, snubbed the meeting, but virtually everybody else turned up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Senate approved unanimously today the Scrugham resolution calling for an investigation by a judiciary subcommittee into the scarcities of liquors in consumer markets and prices that are being charged for newly prepared blends, and for a fund of $10,000 with which to conduct the inquiry.

Warning that there must be "a halt to the concentration of power in the National Government," Governor Dewey declared last night at the twelfth New York Herald Tribune Forum at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that the United States need not fear its post-war problems if it approached them in the right spirit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Rules Committee cleared the way today for the subsidy fight to begin in the House on Thursday and allowed two days of debate on the Commodity Credit Corporation Bill which contains the provision prohibiting food subsidies after Dec. 31.

A six-month workhouse term was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Henry Horatius Thomas, 45 years old, a bogus physician and self-styled "instructor in Oriental science," for practicing medicine without a license in his elaborately furnished "clinic" in West 120th Street. Thomas, convicted two weeks ago, has since been pronounced sane at Bellevue Hospital.
Tonight's events: Concert by Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock; piano recital by Aleksandr Helmann, Town Hall, 8:30; recital by Alvina Grabau, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Abe Fortas, Under Secretary of the Interior, who has been criticized in some quarters for not being in the armed services, became Apprentice Seaman Fortas, USN, today and left Washington to start training.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder yesterday reserved decision in a suit to set aside a decree of divorce obtained in Reno by Mrs. Marie Ammermuller from her husband, Herbert M. Ammermuller, an insurance broker of 924 West End Avenue, last April.

Hundreds of thousands of peasants in the area of American military operations are learning to use modern industrial equipment and their countries are looking forward to American leadership in industrial development after the war, Edward C. Carter, president of Russian War Relief, and secretary-general of the Institute of Pacific Relations, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Senate passed the Bankhead bill authorizing expenditure by the Treasury of $15,000,000 to advertise war bonds in small newspapers. An allocation of $10,000 to investigate the liquor shortage was approved. Joint House and Senate conferees agreed on legislation to place pre-war fathers at the bottom of the national draft pool.

A ground headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including forty-six investment banking houses will offer today the $15,000,000 first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due Nov. 1, 1963, of the Atlanta Charlotte Air Line Railway Company, part of the Southern Railway System.

YORKTOWN, Va., Nov. 16 (AP) -- High explosives scattered by a crushing blast which killed at least six civilian workers and injured twenty more at the Naval mine depot here early today posed a perilous problem for officials seeking to recover bodies and remove threats of additional explosions.

FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Japanese evacuees at the Tule Lake relocation center, thoroughly disloyal, were encouraged by the Fellowship for Reconciliation and other pacifist organizations to make unreasonable demands, and social service workers at the center, employed by the War Relocation Authority, gave similar encouragement, R.E. Combs, chief investigator for the legislative fact-finding committee on un-American activities, declared here today.
YUNGAN, Fukien Province, China, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- After the frightening thunder of bombs come the cheerful sounds of hammering and sawing.

The proposal to place a Cardinal at the head of the German Government after Germany's defeat once more evokes the question as to how many Germans are Catholics. The plan could be carried out only if there are as many Catholics as Lutherans in Germany. According to the records of 1933, however, the Weimar Republic consisted of 63 million inhabitants, 22 million of whom, that is to say about 34 per cent, were Catholics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Spokesmen of labor and minority groups urged a House Postoffice and Post Roads Subcommittee today to report legislation to ban racially discriminatory literature or pictures from the mails. Representative Samuel A. Weiss, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, chairman of the subcommittee, predicted favorable action.

Secretary of the Navy Knox has revealed that construction has been ordered on the world's largest aircraft carriers: three 45,000-ton craft, as big as battleships and about 12,000 tons heavier than any carrier built heretofore. When completed, some time in 1945, these carriers will serve as floating bases for twin-engine bombers of larger range and hitting power than any that can now operate conveniently from carriers.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Montreal's undefeated Canadiens were overtaken for their second consecutive 2 -- 2 tie of the new National Hockey League season by the Bruins in a United War Fund benefit game tonight before a 13,852 crowd at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- G.M. Young, historian and chairman of the British Association for International Understanding in the Dominions and Colonies, told the Royal Society of Arts today that in the United States "the mass of positive ignorance about the British Empire is enormous."

NEW DELHI, India, No. 16 (AP) -- Royal Air Force heavy and medium bombers teamed up for a strong smash at the Japanese railway junction at Pegu, forty-six miles northeast of Rangoon, in Burma last night, a communique said today, while more sharp patrol actions were reported on land in the Chin Hills area.
ALGIERS, Nov. 16 -- Miserable weather continued to bog down the Allied ground forces in Italy yesterday and the Fifth Army was forced to yield a hill north of Venafro after two German counterattacks.

Secretary Hull's report to his press conference on the Moscow conference confirms the impression that the Four-Power Declaration is the cornerstone of a new world organization. He stressed the important but frequently forgotten point that the policy inaugurated at Moscow represents a departure for the other signatories as well as for the United States.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16 -- The German forces in Yugoslavia are conducting a strong offensive along the Dalmatian coast in a drive to eject the Partisans under Gen. Josip Broz (Tito) from the islands and the Adriatic seaports linking them with the Allies' Italian bases.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 16 (AP) -- It was Teddy Atkinson Day at Rockingham Park and the well-known jockey served as an honorary steward as Mrs. Wallace Renard's Mixer won the featured Ted Atkinson Purse on a track mantled with snow today.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Three young women are diving over Long Island these days in first-flight tests of the Navy's speedy Hellcats and Avengers. Part of their job also has been to try out feminine ability in this spectacular and strenuous field of flying -- a test that has won them an official "well done" from Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, maker of the planes.

TRENTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison today called the conviction of John R. Longo on a charge of altering his voting record an "outrage" and "another instance of Jersey justice that should make the judiciary of New Jersey hang its head in shame."
Whatever effect the ammunition shortage may have on those who pursue small game, those who roam the woods for big animals are likely to find their sport carried on in a bigger way than ever.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- On the tenth anniversary of the re-establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, Izvestia today published one of the most favorable pro-Allied editorials yet seen in the Russian press, declaring that it was well to combine joint blows for victory and to continue working together for peace.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16 -- Decisions affecting Turkey may be taken along with other important pronouncements soon, British sources said today, but it would appear virtually certain that Turkey, as Foreign Minister Numan Menemencioglu reputedly told British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, was highly reluctant to enter the conflict against the Germans.

A total of 260,000 tons of steel, calling for a supplementary allocation of 135,000 tons above the present quotas, will be made available for civilian production requirements in the first quarter of next year, Arthur D. Whiteside, vice chairman for civilian requirements of the War Production Board, stated yesterday.

DALLAS, Nov. 16 (AP) -- All unofficial of course -- and Cotton Bowl Headman Dan Rogers probably won't like such speculation -- but it appears you can count Duke as No. 1 choice to be the visiting team in the Dallas classic Jan. 1.

The major league draft meeting, which annually takes a collection of "ivory" from the minors, never had a thing on the "draft meeting" Uncle Sam has been putting on in the big leagues since the season ended.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Without a dissenting voice, the House of Representatives this afternoon passed a bill to increase by 15 per cent the disability compensation paid to veterans of World Wars I and II, and to their dependents. On a roll-call asked by Mrs. Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts 341 Representatives signified assent.
ALGIERS, Nov. 16 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle denied today that the French Committee of National Liberation had attempted to repress the liberties of the Lebanese.

To circumvent the sugar rationing program of the Office of Price Administration, flavored syrups in barrels are being shipped here in large quantities from Cuba and Mexico for use by manufacturers of soft beverages. The traffic has been known for months by authorities in Washington, and from time to time, various Government agencies have tried to stop the movement, but every time some method is found to get around the regulations.

Even in ordinary peaceful years handling the swollen Christmas mail is a strain upon the Postoffice Department, which has to call in extra help. This year the Christmas mail will be more enormous than usual. Millions of the armed forces are scattered about the country and the world.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced tonight that its forces on the Yangtze Valley front had broken into Japanese lines at many points south of the river and advanced to the outskirts of Ichang in Hopeh Province and Tangyang in Kiangsi Province to the northeast.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- The directors of the Union Bank of Commerce of this city voted today to submit to the bank's stockholders a proposal of merger with the National City Bank of Cleveland. Directors of the National City Bank approved yesterday the terms of the proposal, which has been under consideration some time, and submitted it to the Union Bank of Commerce.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Reports from London yesterday indicating that a meeting of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and perhaps Premier Stalin might not be far away coincided with further German retreats on the eastern front.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -- Outguessed, outmaneuvered and outnumbered on a front that has dwindled from 1,200 miles to less than a quarter of that length in six months, the German Wehrmacht is entering a third Russian winter without possession of protected quarters for its retreating armies.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- American citizens who have been living in this country for some time, most of them doing important war work, began registering today for selective service at the United States Embassy here and at various consulates throughout the United Kingdom.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 17 -- A spokesman for Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today that the Southwest Pacific area had less than 5 per cent of the American ground forces and their supporting elements and was receiving less than 10 per cent of what the United States was shipping overseas for military purposes.

How it feels to be blown into the air and wounded by an enemy shell and then to lie helpless in an enemy landing barge while your own planes made strafing runs on it was described yesterday by Pfc. Herbert L. Ehrich of 578 Barbery Street, Brooklyn, the first repatriated American captive from Germany to return to New York.

The season's first shipment of Thanksgiving turkeys from Argentina has arrived on the New York market. Despite the diplomatic coolness between the United States and Argentina, Argentine turkeys as well as Argentine butter and beef seem to be in demand here to supplement dwindling civilian food supplies.

This evening the Martin Beck Theatre receives an up-to-the-minute version of the Herbert Fields-Richard Rodgers-Lorenz Hart musical hit, "A Connecticut Yankee," which ran almost a year when first put on sixteen years ago. Inspired by the Mark Twain story, the book in its latest form spans 1,400 years -- from King Arthur's Camelot of 543 A.D. to Hartford of the present day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- The story of the United Fruit freighter Cape Neddick which was all but abandoned as lost after a torpedo hit her, off the coast of Africa, but survived to deliver her cargo of locomotives and tanks, and to return to her home port for reconditioning, was told today.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 16 -- An attempt on the part of Jersey City officials to have almost $96,000,000 in ratables put back on the tax books was denied today by the Hudson County Tax Board.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Sugar Bowl officials remain tightlipped, but the man on the street says it very likely will be the Ramblin' Wreck of Georgia Tech and Southwestern Louisiana Institute in the tenth annual football classic here on New Year's day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- Bertrand Russell, 70-year-old British educator, was awarded $20,000 today in his Federal court suit for $24,000 against Dr. Albert C. Barnes, art collector and head of the Barnes Foundation in suburban Merion, for alleged breach of contract.
