Eight recommendations to aid the American fashion market to maintain leadership in the post-war era and improve the existing situation among fashion leaders as well as the mass market in both garments and textiles were made at a panel discussion held yesterday by The Fashion Group at the Murray Hill Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- On the basis of "critical need," the Army sent out a call today for 1,000 women dietitians to serve in this country and overseas.

A drawn game, the result of a Ruy Lopez after 21 moves, between J. Straley Battell of Brooklyn and Leon Neidich of Elizabeth, N.J., was recorded at the Marshall C.C. Rooms last night in Group B, the first to complete its schedule in the preliminaries of the annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation.

Columbia's football team entered the final stages of its 1943 campaign yesterday with a light session in preparation for the meeting with Colgate here Saturday. The practice was the first of the week, the squad resting since the Navy game.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 16 -- The American plan for financing the work of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) proposes a quota of $320,000,000 for the United Kingdom and $505,000,000 for the United Kingdom plus the British Dominions and India, it was learned today.

Leon Fraser, president of the First National Bank of New York and formerly cairman of the board of the Bank for International Settlements, criticized last night both the British and the American plans for post-war currency stabilization and suggested, as an alternative proposal, reorganizing the Bank for International Settlements on a wider basis.

Predicting that 1943 income tax returns "will undoubtedly be the most complicated in our history," Maurice Austin of Klein, Hinds Finke, certified public accountants, declared last night that tax simplification "is one of the crying needs of today."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Following on the heels of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's intimations of a coming offensive in the Central Pacific, the Navy Department announced tonight that Army bombers had attacked Japanese positions on Jaluit and Mili atolls in the Marshall Islands and on Makin Island in the Gilbert group Monday.

Dr. Eveline M. Burns, who was a member of the National Resources Planning Board, declared yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania that she objected to being described as holding "a defeatist point of view," a phrase used by Miss Charlotte Carr, assistant to Clinton Golden, labor representative on the War Manpower Commission.

If there is any trepidation in Brooklyn about the invasion of the Green Bay Packers next Sunday, it wasn't evident among Pete Cawthon's Dodgers yesterday as they went through their "shadow" work at Ebbets Field.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Glenn Davis was with the Army football squad today for the first time since the Notre Dame game, and his mere presence seemed to fire the cadets with more than their normal enthusiasm for their work.

The more experience New York City has of proportional representation, the more doubtful do its alleged blessings become. Most New Yorkers were startled at the election to a Council of seventeen of two acknowledged Communists and one follower of the Communist party line.

Although at the outbreak of the war the United States lacked an adequate supply of maps, "our forces now have fairly good maps of all the strategic theatres of war," Helmuth Bay, cartographic adviser in Washington for Rand McNally Co., told an audience last night in the New York Public Library, where he delivered the eighth annual Bowker Memorial lecture.

The dispatches are full of rumors of an approaching meeting of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin. Some of the reports, obviously Axis-inspired, go so far as to specify the meeting place. The time and location would hardly be disclosed in advance, but a conference of the three supreme war leaders has long been expected and desired.

It was back in the fall of 1925 that Herb Kopf joined Lou Little at Georgetown as assistant coach of the Hoyas. Five years at the Hilltop school, eight more with Little at Columbia and then the jump to Manhattan College, where he's been on his own since 1938.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17 -- The press gives prominence today to a statement by President Manuell Avila Camacho that Mexico is ready to send troops abroad if asked by her Allies.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of Henry M. Brundage, regional director of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, as Commissioner of Markets to succeed Daniel P. Woolley, now regional director of the Office of Price Administration. Mr. Brundage, who will receive $10,000 a year, will be sworn in at City Hall at noon today.

Because of delay by the OPA in announcing the new price control regulations for fur manufacturers, as well as prices on raw furs, the market here has continued in a state of confusion, according to the market survey issued yesterday by the United Fur Brokers.

The nine-story apartment building on a plot 107 by 102 feet at 17 West Seventy-first Street was sold by the Weyland Realty Corporation, represented by Max Olesker, attorney, to the Garmil Realty Corporation. Sale was for cash above mortgages aggregating $264,560.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- As As a sequel to the recent shake-up of American military representation in Moscow, the War Department disclosed today that one brigadier general had been reduced to the grade of colonel and another "will shortly revert" to that rank.

Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries showed a net profit of $1,279,239 for the nine months ended with September, after a reserve of $575,000 for post-war adjustments, renegotiation and other contingencies and $5,005,000 for Federal taxes after allowing for a post-war refund of $483,000 the report disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (Aneta) -- The profits of Holland's biggest soap and margarine manufacturers plummeted again in 1942, according to information contained in the annual report of Lever Brothers and Unilever, Ltd., a copy of which has been received here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Non-service disability pensions for veterans of World War I were increased from $40 to $50 in a bill that passed the House unanimously today and was sent to the Senate. Veterans of World War II were included in the legislation, to which 352 members signified assent, under an amendment presented by Representative Paul Cunningham of Iowa.
We have read the story in THE TIMES of Nov. 13, informing us of the text of the Presidential Thanksgiving Proclamation, with a great amount of satisfaction.

The shortage of cigars may become considerably aggravated as a result of the tobacco price ceilings established earlier this week by the Office of Price Administration, according to dealers here. There is a prospect, it was said yesterday, that growers in sections where the ceilings have been applied will either cut acreage or give up raising crops.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Trouble-beset Alfred de Marigny, acquitted last week of the slaying of his wealthy father-in-law, was brought back into court today on charges of illegal possession of gasoline that figured in the murder trial.

Post-war retail trade should total at least $75,000,000,000 annually if it approximates the same proportion of national income as in the pre-war period, against $49,000,000,000 in 1929 and $56,000,000,000 last year, according to a special report presented yesterday by Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University, at the joint meeting of the Institute of Distribution and the Limited Price Variety Stores Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Red Wings will try to "get while the gettin' is good," at Madison Square Garden tonight. The holders of the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world are scheduled to cross sticks with the Rangers, and the visitors see no reason why they should not avail themselves of the easy pickings that promise to confront them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commerce Commission today authorized the Chesapeake Ohio Railway to purchase 60,000 additional shares of common stock of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway. The acquisition will give the Chesapeake Ohio and the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, an affiliated company, approximately 67 per cent of the stock of the Wheeling Lake Erie.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17 -- Constantine Oumansky, Soviet Ambassador, pledged Russia's all-out support for Belgian independence in a speech late last night at a Free Belgian meeting in the presence of many members of the diplomatic corps and of the Belgian colony.

As distillers denied yesterday the charge by State Senator James J. Crawford that they were withholding from a legislative committee information regarding the liquor supply, the committee tossed into the lap of the State Liquor Authority the problem of ending "chiseling" in the industry, both in prices and in distribution of inadequate stocks.

Gasoline and heavy fuel oil stocks along the Eastern seaboard declined last week, but light fuel oil supplies increased, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period the institute's index for gasoline stood at 36.6, against 36.9 a week earlier and that of heavy fuel oil at 78.3, against 79.9.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, bearing a personal message from the President, will speak at the dedication ceremonies of the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Memorial House, new center of religious, social and cultural activities for Hunter College at 47-49 East Sixty-fifth Street, on Monday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college.

The resignation, effective today, of Edward L. Coffey as chief attorney of the New York district Office of Price Administration was announced last night by OPA District Director Frank C. Russell. It was made clear that Mr. Coffey's resignation was unrelated to the series of departures by OPA officials here which preceded and followed the resignation of Sylvan L. Joseph as regional administrator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Early and favorable action on the Wheeler-White Radio Bill amending the Communications Act of 1934 was urged today at the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee's hearing by Neville Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters.

MONTREAL, Nov. 17 (AP) -- When Bill Cowley, Boston's star playmaker, set up Harvey Jackson's tying goal against the Canadiens last night he sent himself into a tie for the lead in the National Hockey League scoring race.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 17 (AP) -Green Bush, J.C. Montana's Canadian 2-year-old, won the $2,000 Canaan Purse by a neck at Rockingham Park today.

This evening's scheduled premiere of "Crosstown Bus" on the New Amsterdam Roof has been canceled, it was announced late last night by Mary Elizabeth Sherwood, who was to have presented the new play by Ned Armstrong and Orrie Lashin, dealing with life in an East Side tenement.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A special communique from Hitler's headquarters, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 174 soldiers listed as missing in action in the European and Mediterranean areas, and the names of 268 soldiers wounded in action on five fighting fronts, the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

A comprehensive social security program will be needed to meet the changing conditions of the post-war period, leaders in this field, including Federal and State officials, declared yesterday at the opening session of the forty-fourth annual meeting of the New York State Conference of Social Work.

Price-fixing orders by the trade steadied the cotton futures market yesterday throughout a session quieted by uncertainties over the final outcome of the food subsidy measure. This support counteracted light liquidation, profit-taking and lessened hedging operations as the list of active old contracts overcame slight early losses, to close with quotations unchanged to 5 points above Tuesday's last prices.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- As a result of their record-shattering performance in rolling up 702 yards against the Giants last Sunday, the Bears are comfortably en route to a clean sweep of offensive honors in the National Football League.

The Middle East Command announces that despite the determined resistance of its garrison, Leros, last of the Dodecanese Islands taken over by the Allies after the collapse of Italy, has fallen to the enemy, who was able to muster superior land, sea and air forces in that region.

Deposits in the 132 mutual savings banks in New York State increased $33,398,836 in October to a record high of $5,982,221,253, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York announced yesterday. During October the banks had a gain of 14,935 in individual accounts, bringing the total to 6,184,773.

The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration must rebuild lands shattered by wartime occupation if peace is to be preserved, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, the president, declared yesterday in a message to the Women's American Organization for Rehabilitation and Training at its annual membership tea in the Hotel Commodore.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Although "some people still jeer and sneer" at the idea of continuing air raid drills, "there can be no let-up in civilian protection services until the last shot is fired in this war," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

Public offering will be made today of $5,000,000 of Southern Colorado Power Company first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds due in 1968 by an underwriting syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc. The issue is priced at 102 and accrued interest.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The British Government remains extremely concerned over the situation in Lebanon, for each day brings fresh reports of mounting antagonism toward the French and, to a lesser degree, toward the British, not only in Lebanon but throughout the Near East.

Those who are over-optimistic about the outcome of the war were criticized yesterday by Postmaster General Frank C. Walker at a luncheon of the Associated Motion Picture Advertisers, held at the Hotel Astor to honor the men and women of the motion-picture industry in the armed forces.

A move to elect James H. Fay. Representative in Congress from the Sixteenth district and present chairman of the Tammany executive committee, as leader of Tammany Hall is under serious consideration, it was learned yesterday. The success of the move would be conditioned on the prior resignation or ouster of the present Tammany leader, Michael J. Kennedy Jr.

With many householders in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, termed the "Little Harlem" of Brooklyn, reported refusing to answer the personal questions asked by a small army of policemen sent into the section on orders of Mayor La Guardia, and others giving replies that tended to confirm grand jury charges of widespread crime and hoodlumism, the house-to-house canvass was abandoned abruptly in mid-afternoon yesterday.

Permit me just to add a few words to your today's editorial regarding inflation. It is quite true that inflation is "a flat tax without exception on everyone's income" and at the same time also "a capital levy." But the worst of it is that inflation hits only one part of the population while another part directly benefits from it.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Around 220,000 youths are now testing their wings in Britain's Air Training Corps which will provide the cream of the Royal Air Force's air crews in the closing phases of the war and train the men who will operate the post-war airlines of the empire.

New York's newest "Hall of Fame," unlike its prototype in the Bronx, is dedicated to living Americans. Situated in the lower East Side, within the walls of the Educational Alliance, at East Broadway and Jefferson Street, the hall will honor thirty leading citizens who received early training there.

Camden, N. J. Camden, N. J., awarded yesterday $300,000 of refunding bonds due serially from Nov. 1, 1950, to 1959, to a syndicate comprising Viackey, Dunn g: Co., Inc.; Reynolds Co. and H T. Greenwood Co. The bankers bid 100.33, naming the interest rate as 2 per cent_

The shortage of food and labor has brought about a discontinuance of bookings of social function at large hotels in New York City. A survey made yesterday disclosed that many hotels book only affairs for charitable and war organizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The Latvian Minister to the United States, Dr. Alfred Bilmanis, charged today that the Parliament of Latvia was "forced to vote Soviet annexation" when the Red Army invaded the Baltic countries in 1940, and added that full postwar independence would be demanded.

After a series of conferences yesterday following the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of new community ceiling prices for foods, the local headquarters of the Office of Price Administration formally announced the issuance of such price lists.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- German Army forces supported by bombing planes attacked an estimated 16,000 Italian guerrillas between Lakes Maggiore and Lugano in far northern Italy today, frontier reports said.

Little, Brown announces that Angus Cameron, editorial representative in this city for five years, has been appointed editor in chief of the trade department in Boston. Wallace T. Foote succeeds him here.

The national executive council of the Textile Workers Union announced yesterday after a meeting at 15 Union Square that it would demand an increase of at least 10 cents an hour for 1,250,000 textile workers, of whom 500,000 are union members.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Deliberations of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Association conference in Atlantic City are being closely watched by various women's groups in Britain who have been training here to play a part in the rehabilitation of Europe.
The daylight attack by bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force against Norwegian objectives Tuesday typifies the American bombardment pattern of the past five weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson dismissed today a petition by Mrs. Frances C. Little, acting librarian of the New Rochelle Public Library, for a new civil service examination of applicants for the post of chief librarian.
Granted that the best thing for a hunting and fishing addict to do is to go hunting and fishing, the next best thing, when that is impossible, is to read about those robust activities.

One hundred and seventy-seven Liberator bombers manned by 1,548 American soldiers took part in the raid which destroyed 42 per cent of the Rumanian oil refining capacity at Ploesti on Aug. 1, 1943. Every man knew in advance that this was a desperate venture.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 17 -- German sea-borne forces and paratroops, powerfully supported by planes that maintained consistent local superiority over the battlefield, have recaptured the Dodecanese island of Leros with its important naval base of Portolago, it was officially announced today.

The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes continued to be a source of income for Nick Circella even after George E. Browne and Willie Bioff had gone to prison for similar profit-taking, and when Circella followed the others to jail Paul De Lucia took over, according to a witness in Federal court yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- A voluntary plan for liquidation and dissolution of the North Continent Utilities Corporation was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which held that the early demise of the holing company would enhance the value of its assets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In the face of yesterday's warning by Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, that enactment of a pending resolution approving the wage increase of 8 cents an hour negotiated for 1,100,000 nonoperating railroad employes would mean a breaking of the "Little Steel" formula by Congress itself, the Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee in charge of the legislation approved tentatively today an amendment which declares:

The taxpayer at 630-636 South Broadway, Yonkers, Westchester County, was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of DiCostanzo Vellela, attorneys. Sale was for $30,000 cash above a purchase money mortgage of $35,000 for ten years.

The annual Christmas sale under the auspices of the Women's Farm and Garden Association will be held this morning and afternoon at the home of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street. A wide variety of handcrafts and products made by approximately 600 farm women who have no other outlet for their work will be offered for sale.

They brought back "A Connecticut Yankee" to the Martin Beck last evening, and on the whole it was quite good fun. Any musical which has Richard Rodgers tunes has won about half its battle by the time the orchestra has finished the overture, but this one does not stop dead at that point.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- An over-all advance of 3 per cent in living costs and a 7 per cent increase in the retail price of foods will be the immediate result if Congress eliminates subsidy payments after the first of the year, as provided in the pending Commodity Credit Corporation Bill, officials of the Office of Price Administration, asserted today.

The Pepsi-Cola Company, through its president, Walter S. Mack Jr., defended yesterday its practice of manufacturing finished syrup in Mexico and then shipping it here to the various bottling plants distributing Pepsi-Cola. He held that it makes additional sweetening available to the public and that it is not interfering in any way with the purchase of sugar by the United States.

The twelve-story apartment house at 601 West End Avenue, northwest corner of Eighty-ninth Street, plot 44 by 90 feet, has been sold for the Greenwich Savings Bank to an investing client of Gettinger Gettinger, attorneys, through the brokerage firm of L.V. Hoffman Co. The building contains 117 rooms.

Making a move that will carry them a few miles farther south, the Yanks announced yesterday they would pitch their 1944 baseball spring training camp at Atlantic City, N.J. Last spring, the first of the frost-coated training campaigns forced upon the major leagues by the war, saw the world champions hold their pre-season exercises at Asbury Park, N.J.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 17 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange and former chief of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, criticized tonight the program of the House Ways and Means Committee to alter the excess profits tax by reducing the allowance on invested capital.

A continued stepping up of rent registrations in the New York City defense-rental area was reported yesterday at the eighty-two schools lent to the Office of Price Administration for the purpose, Louis H. Pink, rent director, announced last night.

President Roosevelt declared last night that the great advance that has been made in the war during the last year can be measured by the fact that the important events of the war, and of the building for the peace to follow it, are now "being impelled by us of the United Nations and not by our enemies."

Serge Rubinstein, 35-year-old petroleum corporation executive, failed to report for induction into the armed forces yesterday and a member of his office staff at 63 Wall Street explained that he filed Form 301 with Local Draft Board 44 at 155 East Eighty-eighth Street, claiming exemption as a Portuguese citizen.

Ginjiro Fujiwara, one of the Cabinet advisers to Premier Hideki Tojo, was named Minister of State Without Portfolio yesterday in another major Japanese Government revision and he immediately issued a statement declaring that he would dedicate himself in his new post to "exceeding" United States' plane production "in the shortest time possible."

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The stock markets here were again bright in tone today, most features doing well. Industrial shares went ahead, Hudson's Bay gaining another shilling and Electric and Musical Instruments rising about 9d. Kaffirs, however, were uneven.

At his Town Hall recital last night, Aleksandr Helmann, Russian pianist long resident in this city, accomplished his most satisfying playing in the sonata in D major of the eighteenth century German composer, Friedrich Wilhelm Rust, and the short modernistic pieces by Satie and Lord Berners on a program which also contained the twenty-eight Paganini-Brahms variations in their entirety, a Chopin group and Balakireff's "Islamey."

The produce dealers have protested tie-in sales, and now it is the turn of the housewife. The New York City Sales Tax Law states that if you live beyond the city limits and have purchases sent out by the stores you don't have to pay the city sales tax. If you take your purchase you must pay the tax. In the old days it was fair enough.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- American lend-lease food shipments during the first nine months of 1943, in terms of pounds, were as follows:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Allied fighters and bombers raked the northern Solomons from Buka to the Short-land Islands and the northeast New Guinea coast from Finschhafen to Wewak Monday and Tuesday, bombing and strafing airdromes, supply points and coastal shipping, it was announced today.

Mr. Robinson's letter of Nov. 3 is an attempt to justify increased taxes for Social Security. This subject has been studied very carefully in the past, and, I believe, it has been pretty well decided that contributions are to be kept about in line with current costs so that no large fund may be built up.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Sir Oswald Mosley, founder of the British Union of Facists, is to be released in a few days from Holloway Prison where he has been detained since May, 1940, it was announced tonight by Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, who said reasons of health caused the decision.

In a London dispatch to this newspaper yesterday an unexpectedly golden light was thrown on book business in Great Britain. The blackout keeps folks at home nights. What shall they read? There is a strong demand for books; and "booksellers guardedly admit that it is pretty difficult to publish an unsuccessful book now if one avoids the scholarly things that used to have a modest sale of perhaps 1,000 copies."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- There will be more women members at the next session of Congress, House leaders believe, and both Republicans and Democrats say, "Good!"

The Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board "relies on advertising to help prepare the people for the critical period just ahead of us when many products will be going back into limited production," Henry A. Dinegar, director of the agency's durable goods and products division, declared yesterday.

With the avowed aim of helping to educate public opinion with regard to basic social and economic trends here and abroad, so that an enduring peace and prosperity may be attained, the New School for Social Research formally launched last night a new research organization.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Wage increases for 160,000 employes of the Ford Motor Company throughout the nation, with a consequent scrapping of the "Little Steel" formula, were asked today by the United Automobile Workers (CIO).

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, pressing their offensive in central China, have captured Lihsien, west of Tungting Lake, and are attempting to cross the Li River in an apparent drive into the heart of Hunan Province, the Chinese high command announced tonight.

ALGIERS, Nov. 17 -- Heavy and medium bombers renewed their offensive against German air bases in southern France yesterday when Flying Fortresses and Marauders in considerable force attacked the airfields at Istres-le-Tube and Salon, near Marseille.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 -- Cyrus C. Willmore of St. Louis, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, at the continuation of its convention today, called on the delegates to work for elimination of waste in government, stronger local government units and the preservation of private enterprise. Mr. Willmore opposed subsidized public housing and suggested instead that a system of rent allowances for needy families be set up.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Women are no longer handicapped and do not need help from anybody, but men need help now, George Bernard Shaw declared today. Answering questions put to him by Louise Morgan of The News Chronicle he gave the following answers:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- The Navy announced ninety-six casualties today. Among them are forty-five dead, nineteen wounded and thirty-two missing.

The stock market dropped yesterday under the mark set in last week's plunge as a stepped-up tempo of selling produced price retreats of fractions to 2 points and even more in a few cases. At their new low level for the current downward movement, values were at their worst point since last March.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The United Mine Workers of America and some of the bituminous coal operators resumed today negotiations for a new contract at the request of Secretary Harold L. Ickes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A basic plan whereby Selective Service problems in industrial plants may be handled on the basis of labor-management war production drive committees has been approved by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The loss of Leros and the imminent threat to the British garrison of Samos, just off the Turkish coast, have aroused a wave of criticism in Britain that may result in a debate in the House of Commons.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 16 (Delayed) (AP) -- Predicting one of the worst winters in the history of Manchuria as a result of crop failures, reliable persons who left that region last August said here today that the entire country is a mass of discontent, with the Chinese populace for the first time openly criticizing the Japanese.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 17 -- New Zealand is heading toward greater socialization and additional measures designed to spread the national income more evenly, it is indicated by a front page article in the government newspaper, The Standard.

In time to come the well-taught school child will know the map of China as well as he knows the map of Europe. He will wish to, for China will be important to him. He may even go there some week-end. There will be excursion steamers on the Yangtze and a good orchestra in the Hotel Sun at Sianfu. We don't know the map now.

DROWNING men clutch at straws, they say, and the New York Rangers, who have not yet been submerged beyond all hope of rescue, are grasping at one feeble wisp these days. A Blue Shirt spokesman, undaunted by seven straight defeats, bravely declared, "Last year we didn't have any brothers on the squad and we finished last.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A table of retail food prices, covering twenty-two items of foodstuffs, was prepared today by Office of Price Administration experts. It covers the August price and estimated rises in cents which would follow revocation of subsidies, as follows:

WHEN Edward Murrow, the London radio commentator, visited this country recently he asked for a good book on the home front. The best this department could do for him was to suggest John Dos Passos' articles on the United States at work. But now the gap has been filled with the publication of Selden Menefee's "Assignment: U.S.A."*

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- New York members of the House probably will line up 27 to 18 in favor of government subsidies to food producers, Representative Walter A. Lynch predicted today, if all are present when the issue comes to a vote.

ALGIERS, Nov. 17 -- A cutting wind that lashed the Allied ground forces in Italy with cold rain, while mud bogged them down worse than ever on the Garigliano-Sangro line, kept the land battle at a stalemate yesterday.
Maj. George G. Carey, USA, and Mrs. Carey of Lutherville, Md., are at the Ambassador.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 -- The California spring fashion showings held this week in Los Angeles brought forth a riot of color that was tropical in its brilliance. Inspirations taken from South America, Mexico and the Allied nations gave the keynote to all the styles shown.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- The Red Army's successes in the field and the agreement reached during the tri-power Moscow conference have stimulated interest in the vassal members of Adolf Hitler's camp whose defection, it is held here, would bring substantially nearer the victorious end of the war.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 17 -- French patriots in Grenoble have blown up a powder magazine where ten German soldier guards were killed. The resulting fire caused the explosion of two large gas tanks.

The World Jewish Congress submitted yesterday a memorandum on post-war relief and rehabilitation of European Jews to the council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration now in session at Atlantic City. Dr. Stephen S. Wise is chairman of the group's executive committee and Dr. Nahum Goldmann is chairman of its administrative committee.

Directors of the American Telephone Telegraph Company declared yesterday the usual quarterly dividend of $2.25 a share on the capital stock, payable Jan. 15. The cash distribution to the 643,000 stockholders will amount to around $42,000,000. The company's annual dividend rate of $9 a share has continued without interruption since 1922.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Men from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are among 100 officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Tenth Air Force, based in India, who have been awarded decorations, the War Department announced today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Pvt. Margaret H. Maloney, known among the Wacs as "Peewee" because she is just 4 feet 11 inches tall, received the Soldier's Medal for heroism today for rescuing a soldier from a gasoline fire. So far as is known here, she is the first woman to win the coveted decoration.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and Lucrezia Bori, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, were among the speakers yesterday at the noon-hour program of the CDVO Information Center at Pershing Square in the Drive for Musical Instruments Week.

The proposed doubling of postal charges on insurance, money orders and C.O.D. fees are not only inequitable, discriminatory and, in some cases, confiscatory, but may actually result in decreased revenue.

The other day I happened to hear a discussion among several youngsters in Lenox Hill House about the wonderful Thanksgiving dinner they always have here. My heart sank, for we had discussed the scarcity and price of turkey and food in general and had found we could not attempt our usual Thanksgiving and Christmas celebrations for some 400 youngsters.

The principal officers of the General Foods Corporation were elevated yesterday to higher posts as the result of the creation of a new top position. C.M. Chester was elected to the new post of chairman of the executive committee, Clarence Francis was named chairman and chief executive officer and Austin S. Igleheart became president.

Edward C. Gray, director of the department of member firms, New York Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday to member firms that drafts of the documents be submitted to the department before new partnership agreements or amendments thereto are executed.
Directors of the Potrero Sugar Company, Inc., have called a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 9 to vote on a proposal to dissolve the company and to distribute all its assets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Construction in the United States in September was valued at only $526,502,000, a decrease of 13 per cent from August and of 63 per cent as compared with September, 1942, the War Production Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A further curtailment in the use of newsprint was proposed today, presenting to newspapers the prospect of starting the new year with allowances 23 per cent under their 1941 base tonnage.

American manufacturers who hope to sell the Latin-American market in the post-war period must begin advertising in those countries immediately, "not with just a holding campaign, but with all the enthusiasm, smart advertising and money you can spend," A.L. Abkarian, export manager of Carter Products, Inc., declared yesterday at a meeting of the Export Advertising Association, at the Hotel Belmont Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Chairman Walter F. George of the Senate Finance Committee said today that the tax bill might be increased by an additional billion or billion and a half dollars through applying the proposed liquor tax of $9 a gallon to whisky held in bonded warehouses more than four years.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, will ask the Board of Estimate today to acquire two square blocks bounded by West 143d and 145th Streets, Lenox Avenue and the Harlem River, for a large children's playground. The property is occupied by various one-story garages and several old tenements.

WITH CHINESE FORCES IN THE HUKAWG VALLEY, Burma, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- American-trained Chinese troops, carving a path through the swamps of northeastern Burma for a new Burma Road, today won an important victory, cutting a main Japanese water supply route in engagements with grenades and three-foot-long knives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Navy today lifted the veil of security to disclose that three United States destroyers composed the entire task force that scored a "smashing victory" over the Japanese at Vella Lavella on Oct. 6, and that they were opposed by nine enemy warships, of which three were sunk, two definitely damaged and others believed hit.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Buying of wheat futures, said to represent removal of hedges against sales of 2,500,000 bushels or more of cash grain to distillers, millers and other interests, the largest single day's business in some time, resulted in a rapid advance in prices today on the Board of Trade.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- With a complete disregard of the usual secrecy, in order to emphasize the bond between the peoples of the Philippines and the United States, the aircraft carrier Bataan was commissioned today at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.

Dr. Moses Fuchs of the New World Chess Club qualified last night at the Manhattan Chess Club for the national amateur championship finals when he defeated Abe Turner in forty-two moves, thereby attaining a score of 6 -- 1 in Group A.

Industry itself can help speed settlements resulting from terminated war contracts, now and at the end of hostilities, by maintaining established production controls, and particularly through adherence to the Controlled Materials Plan, Maj. W.R. Comber of the Army Ordnance Department, Washington, declared yesterday at the aut,,mn conference of the American Management Association in the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 18 -- The Red Army, in its first admitted withdrawal since the start of its summer offensive, announced the loss of several places on the front west of Kiev yesterday, but, 170 miles to the northeast, it encircled the German garrison at Rechitsa and broke into a town twenty-five miles west of threatened Gomel.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- After a stormy nine-hour secret session of Parliament yesterday in connection with Foreign Minister Numan Menemencioglu's report on his conversations with the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, "the Government's conduct" was approved, it was officially announced.

Forthcoming holiday events were suggested as Arnold Constable's models moved in rapid succession through the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday noon. Included were not only warm country togs and smart opera styles but also prophetic notes for the new year.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. l7 -- New delivery procedures for small and large consumers of domestic sizes of anthracite coal in twelve Northeastern States and the District of Columbia were announced today by Secretary Ickes, Solid Fuels Administrator, who assumed control of retail distribution of anthracite at midnight tonight
In order to get canned salmon from his wholesaler, a Queens grocer testified yesterday at a Department of Markets hearing, he had to buy also V-mail envelopes, which he did not want.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Paris area and thirty-six other French targets are now prospective targets for mass aerial attacks seeking to knock out the French aircraft industry working for the Germans, according to a warning broadcast to the French by an Allied spokesman over the British Broadcasting Corporation European service tonight.
Strictly speaking, the war is not the whole reason why London school children at 12 years are more than two inches taller and about a dozen pounds heavier than their parents were at the same age.
ALGIERS, Nov. 17 -- The latest French crisis seemed to have subsided today with no further offers of resignation by Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud.

In spite of all that has been said and published on the subject, people in this country have not even begun to understand the extent of the suffering caused by the war in China, the Rev. Dr. Joel R. Saunders, 70-year-old Baptist minister, who returned recently after forty-two years in that country, said yesterday.

The Republican party achieved its objective in the last election in electing Thomas A. Aurelio to the Supreme Court, Alex Rose, State secretary of the American Labor party, declared in a radio address last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs at the twelve principal western markets fell today to 93,600 head after a two-day embargo was placed yesterday on shipments to South St. Paul. The War Food Administration reported that there were few holdovers throughout the country and that clearance here was fairly complete.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- The Japanese still have enough strength in the southwest Pacific to mount a major offensive, according to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's intelligence chief, Brig. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby, who said today that it was well within the capability of the Japanese to mount a major "strike" because they have the advantage of interior shipping lines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Ruth Warrick, who played the lead with Pat O'Brien in RKO's "The Iron Major," has been signed by the company to a contract calling for two pictures a year over a seven-year period. She has also been named for the principal role in the picturization of the Pearl S. Buck story "China Sky."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- With hogs moving to markets in heavy numbers, the Government tonight slashed ration point costs of all pork products by two points.
The text of Anthony Eden's message to the forum follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development (CED), said today that "from a material standpoint all the potentialities for a new high peacetime level of business activity are present."

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, today hails the growing good relations between the Soviet Union and the United States in the decade since diplomatic relations were re-established and predicts that comradeship in arms will provide a stable foundation for prolonged peace and economic, political and cultural collaboration in the post-war world.

New Yorkers who hope to have their Thanksgiving dinners assembled by caterers may encounter difficulty, for several catering establishments inform us that they already have a large number of orders and can take very few more. Only two, so far as we can ascertain, believe that they can fill last-minute requests.

St. John's University will play eighteen basketball games this season, Rev. Joseph W. Browne, C.M., director of athletics, announced yesterday. Seven games are to be played at Madison Square Garden seven in the home gymnasium and the remaining four on the road.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane has issued a booklet which tries to sell nothing. It appeals for more generous support of educational institutions and charities and analyzes various methods of giving in the light of current tax laws.

Contradicting the report he was having difficulty making the weight of 135 pounds, the maximum for the lightweight division, Bob Montgomery, world champion, yesterday concluded hard training at Stillman's gymnasium for the fifteen-round bout in which he will defend his title tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden against Beau Jack, former lightweight ruler.

The last few weeks have covered a big step forward in the making of a world which Americans want. In Moscow, a framework of understanding has been worked out which will enable us to fight the war more efficiently and arrive at a more lasting peace.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 17 -- China will need relief shipments from abroad costing $400,000,000 to $500,000,000, or close to one-fifth of the estimated $2,500,000,000 world-wide total for that part of the relief load that will have to be carried through outright gifts.

SEVENTH U.S. AIR FORCE, South Central Pacific, Nov. 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- American bombers tonight blasted Tarawa, in the Gilbert Islands, with tons of heavy bombs intended to prevent further use of that island as an enemy base for operations against American bases in this area.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Major league baseball players participating in exhibition games in the Southern California Winter League for as little as $3 a game were under investigation today by Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball.

John Foster Dulles, chairman of the Commission On a Just and Durable Peace of the Federal Council of Churches, yesterday hailed the Moscow Declaration as "a notable step toward realizing international order as envisaged by our 'Six Pillars of Peace' " and "a great development from the Atlantic Charter."

Two wars into which her country plunged the world were all that stood between Katharina Groninger and the peaceful enjoyment of her last days in her native Germany with funds amassed in America. Instead, she was buried yesterday in potter's field, her paper fortune of 7,256,000 marks consigned to the trash basket.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- Prof. Eugene Tarle, Russia's most eminent historian, has contributed to Pravda an account of a historical meditation that occupied his mind after hearing Premier Stalin's Nov. 6 speech.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans under Gen. Josip Broz [Tito] were reported today to have checked a strong German offensive employing five divisions in upper Slovenia, but the enemy retained the advantage along the Adriatic coast by seizing another island and a town on the mainland in the Fiume area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Relatively small amounts of food which are in short supply in this country have been shipped abroad under lend-lease, the Foreign Economic Administration said today in reporting on exports of food under the Lend-Lease Act for the first nine months of 1943.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- An alleged attempt by the General Gas and Electric Corporation to sell 82.9 per cent of the voting power of a $14,000,000 corporation for $55,000 was halted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission when it withdrew an exemption permitting deals of less than $100,000 to be consummated without its study.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Navy is looking forward to a period about two years hence -- if the Pacific war lasts that long -- when it will be able to test its new super-armed, "unsinkable," giant carriers against the Japanese.

A three-year research project to prepare a post-war educational pattern for school systems from the pre-school level to the young adult group was announced yesterday by Dean William F. Russell at Teachers College, Columbia University. The announcement was made after a two-day conference of the American Youth Commission with the staffs of Teachers College and the Horace Mann-Lincoln Institute of School Experimentation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Civilian America on the whole is better nourished than it was before the war, in spite of difficulties in obtaining favorite foods, Frank L. Gunderson, executive secretary of the food and nutrition board of the National Research Council, told the post-graduate assembly on nutrition in wartime today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 17 -- Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler is inventing daily new reasons for putting his countrymen to death. An example of his new ruthlessness was the execution in the north German town of Nordstemmer of three persons for failure to lodge properly a bombed-out family from Hanover assigned to them by Nazi authorities.

The vast merchant fleet of this country will be responsible almost completely for the distribution of the world's goods in the days that follow the war, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared last night in an address before the Foreign Commerce Club of New York in the Hotel Astor.
LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Hirose, director of market research and promotion of the McCall Corporation, said at the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers Association at the City Midday Club yesterday that the investment and financing field would be broadened after the war if two important conditions were met.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Relatively small amounts of food which are in short supply in this country have been shipped abroad under lend-lease, the Foreign Economic Administration said today in reporting on exports of food under the Lend-Lease Act for the first nine months of 1943.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- An alleged attempt by the General Gas and Electric Corporation to sell 82.9 per cent of the voting power of a $14,000,000 corporation for $55,000 was halted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission when it withdrew an exemption permitting deals of less than $100,000 to be consummated without its study.

Hirose, director of market research and promotion of the McCall Corporation, said at the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers Association at the City Midday Club yesterday that the investment and financing field would be broadened after the war if two important conditions were met.

Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, has been directed by the United States Emergency Court of Appeals in Washington to show cause on Wednesday why an order should not be issued by that court directing the Price Administrator either to grant or deny the protest of fourteen manufacturers of branded hosiery who filed their protest against the provisions of MPR 339 on May 6 last, it was made known here yesterday.

A syndicate comprising Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., Dutcher Co., W.N. Edwards Co. and Louis B. Henry Co. has been awarded a new issue of $303,000 Fort Worth, Tex., Independent School District refunding bonds, due serially from Feb. 1, 1945 to 1954.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 18 -- While resistance in France is becoming more openly defiant each day, the German occupying authorities are gradually taking charge of repressive measures despite all of Pierre Laval's efforts to galvanize his police into greater action.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- The North American Company, a public utility holding company, was accused today of expending a political slush fund of more than $5,000,000 since 1930 in six States and the District of Columbia.

Demanding the immediate appointment of at least 500 teachers who have been acting as so-called permanent substitutes, James Marshall, a member of the Board of Education, yesterday proposed a three-point program to meet the present substitute teacher shortage.

Announcement by the Principal Commonwealth Supply Commission in Washington that it has notified importers in British territories that it will respect requests for brand names and attempt to fill orders through the American suppliers specifically named by the importers, was hailed yesterday by traders attending a meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club as a "concrete step in preserving normal trade channels."

WHEN Jesse James Benton was 8 years old he left Kentucky for Texas with his pa and his ma and a passel of friends and relations. They rode in sixteen ox wagons, took sixteen foxhounds with them and plenty of Kentucky mountain moonshine whisky. That was in 1872. Today he lives alone in a one-room cabin near Tucson, an old man of nearly 80.

The campaign for women volunteers to join in the war program on the home front reached the Hotel Plaza yesterday. In place of the usual divertissements or fashion parade with soft music the 1 o'clock luncheon crowd in the Persian Room heard the five principal volunteer groups plead for new recruits.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 18 -- Apparently running out of gasoline after a daylight raid on Norway, three United States Liberators made forced landings in Sweden this afternoon. Their crews totaling thirty men, including a few Canadian and Dutch, were uninjured and will be interned here in accordance with international regulations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The nation's highest decoration, the Congressional Medal of Honor, has been awarded to a cavalry lieutenant who battled a tank with a tommy gun -- and stopped the tank.

The New York Young Republican Club went on record last night for the removal of Harrison Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, at a meeting in the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street. The vote was 33 to 7.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18 -- There is evidence today that within twenty-four hours the Lebanese crisis will be passed. There is no evidence the dispute will have come to an end, however, for emotions have been too much stirred.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 19 -- American warships, flaunting an implied challenge at the naval might of Rabaul, have ventured less than 200 miles from that Japanese fortress for the second time this month to shell enemy air bases on Buka Island, off the northern tip of Bougainville.
Secretary Hull's report to Congress on his mission to Moscow, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The unscrambling of the war economy of the United States by the various Government procurement agencies under the supervision of a central board following broad policies laid down by Congress was recommended today by the Senate special Committee on Post-War Economic Planning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Department-store sales rose 14 per cent last week over the corresponding week of 1942 and 12 per cent for the period from Jan. 1 through Nov. 13 over the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve System reported today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Buying of 1,000,000 or more bushels of wheat futures, attributed to Southwestern mills, coupled with purchases by other cash interests, carried prices up 1 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel in early trading today on the Board of Trade, all deliveries selling at new seasonal high levels for the second straight day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Justice Department has begun an investigation of the liquor industry.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- British children, who are as much in the front line in this bomb-blasted country as their parents, will be the happy "victims" of a deep but bright conspiracy this Christmas.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow: Troops of the First Ukraine Front forced the Uzh River and, as a result of two days' fighting, occupied the town and railway junction of Korosten.

F. Skiddy von Stade, long an important figure in polo as well as racing, yesterday was elected president of the Saratoga Association to succeed the late George H. Bull. Mr. von Stade was vice president of the Saratoga organization and for some time has been president of the National Steeplechase and Hunts Association.

Jobs, not charity, must be provided for returning service men and demobilized war workers after the war and home rule should be restored to municipalities for planned, local post-war programs, speakers declared yesterday at the opening session of the annual two-day meeting of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities, held in the Hotel New Yorker.

Gracie Square Gardens, comprising four buildings occupying most of the block between East End and York Avenues, Eighty-ninth to Ninetieth Streets, are now fully occupied, John Raymond, resident manager, announced yesterday.

WITH THE ALLIED FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Nov. 18 -- Better movies and a whole lot more of them, that's what the Fifth Army soldiers want in the entertainment line. And they would like them to be more recent productions if possible.

Pink-cheeked Stephen Bober of 2662 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, had an experience yesterday such as comes to few 2-year-olds. Unencumbered by an adult escort, he rode in solitary state for more than a mile in a wonderful red taxicab with white trimmings.

ALGIERS, Nov. 18 -- Commodore William A. Sullivan, chief of the Navy's salvage service and the man responsible more than any other for the righting of the Lafayette (the former Normandie), said here today that it would be many years before the Naples harbor was restored to its pre-war efficiency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Retail ceilings for citrus fruits now coming to market will be reduced 10 to 15 per cent compared with prices in the 1942-43 season, Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull told Congress today at an unprecedented joint meeting of the Senate and House in a crowded House chamber that the tripartite conference at Moscow would speed victory and that it pointed the way to an end of the old system of alliances and, instead, to an effective system of international cooperation for the maintenance of peace and security in the postwar world.

To the layman it comes as something of a shock to think of women as test pilots at the controls of some of our speediest combat planes, putting through their paces tons of flying death whose great engines of 1,400 horsepower rate them in the 400-mile-an-hour class.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- New insurance of a type formerly handled only by groups like Lloyds of London has appeared in this country in the form of a "third party ship repairer's liability insurance," written for the Bethlehem Steel Company by a group of twenty-one American companies in the amount of $10,000,000.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 19 -- The United States Marines have shoved the Japanese lines back several hundred yards in the Empress Augusta Bay area of Bougainville in sharp fighting, which increased the number of known Japanese dead by 500 in the past five days, said a communique issued here today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Ways and Means Committee formally delivered the second wartime tax bill today and its figures of $2,140,000,000 in new revenue were challenged by the Treasury as being $93,000,000 too high.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 18 -- The Germans are continuing their stiff offensive along the Dalmatian coast of Yugoslavia, employing tanks and aircraft to back up their troops in a determined effort to slam the Adriatic door through which Allied supplies can reach the Partisan forces of Gen. Josip Broz [Tito].

Scientific research in textiles, to meet swollen military and civilian demands, has helped to speed-up the development of new processes and improve existing output methods, it was declared yesterday by speakers at the annual meeting of the Textile Research Institute in the Roosevelt Hotel.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Minority stockholders of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, plaintiffs in a Supreme Court action against officers and directors of the company, rested their case today after placing in evidence documentary material concerning company procedures.

After he had received a number of threatening letters and a knife through the mail, and at least one threat orally, Leon Alexander, foreman of the August Kings County Grand Jury, which last Monday handed up a presentment charging widespread crime and hoodlumism in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was placed under twenty-four-hour police guard yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force blasted Berlin tonight, according to enemy sources, as the high tide of Allied airpower that has pounded targets on the continent from Norway to Greece for the last forty-eight hours touched the central citadel of the Nazi war machine.

A long list of favorable dividend actions provided the bullish forces in the stock markets with a good talking point yesterday and enabled securities to interrupt the downward movement of the week. On the average, values were enlarged only fractionally, however, with a few major gains in the higher priced section.

Since Cordell Hull is actually the living link between the executive and legislative branches of the Government, it is eminently fitting that he should be the first Cabinet officer to report directly to the Congress on a historic diplomatic mission. The appearance of the Secretary before the joint meeting of the two houses sets a welcome precedent.

In March the Legislature passed a bill for the reapportionment of Senate and Assembly districts. In his campaign Governor Dewey pledged himself to bring about reapportionment. Three Federal censuses had been taken since 1917, the year of the last reapportionment.

Bob Montgomery will endeavor to give Sidney (Beau Jack) Walker another boxing lesson when the pair clash in the star bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. They met last May, when Jack was lightweight champion of the world and Montgomery had little trouble baffling the Augusta (Ga.) Negro and relieving him of his title.
Rear Admiral Enrique Labarthe, Naval Attache of the Peruvian Embassy, and Mrs. Labarthe have arrived from Washington, and will be at the Ambassador for a fort-night.

For the last time this season the football players who have been representing Columbia this fall went through a hard practice yesterday. There will be only a review and limbering-up work today for the Colgate game tomorrow at Baker Field.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Near Venafro, Italy, Nov. 16 (Delayed) (AP) -- Christmas has arrived for the American Doughboys in the front lines. Great loads of Yuletide packages, bearing postmarks of home towns from Maine to California, are being rushed to the front by truck, mule train and hand to cheer the boys now living in cold, foggy weather in ankle-deep mud.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A Chinese communique:

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Indications of a unanimity of British, American and Russian views on the settlement of Europe's postwar boundaries were apparent here today as rumors were widespread that President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Joseph Stalin would meet soon on neutral ground.

Former glories of the Metropolitan Opera were placed on special exhibition yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York. The exhibition, which will continue through Jan. 18, was in celebration of the Diamond Jubilee of the Metropolitan Opera House, and is under the joint auspices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild and the Museum.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Fort Monmouth's normal complement was supplemented today by seventy-five organized labor representatives, including seven women union members, brought to the post for a two-day condensed version of GI basic training.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A statement covering the possible consequences of last week's court orders to wind up the affairs of the Chosen Corporation was made here today by Messrs. Nordon Co., solicitors. Commenting on the judgment handed down by Justice Bennett, they write: "His Lordship refers to the sale by the corporation to the Mountbreak Corporation of the corporation's American assets for $800,000.

ALGIERS, Nov. 18 -- Allied ground forces in Italy found the weather gods unrelenting yesterday, but despite continued heavy rain Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's Eighth Army managed to wrest a few miles from the Germans northwest of Atessa.

The Swedish Amateur Athletic Association yesterday sent a cablegram to Dan Ferris, National A.A.U. secretary, expressing regret that Gunder Haegg and Arne Andersson could not accept the invitation to compete in American indoor track meets this winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Declaring the shoe industry is faced with its most critical problem since the outbreak of the war through the sharp decline in the flow of leather in the last six months, members of a War Production Board shoe task force committee reported today that positive and immediate steps to alleviate the supply situation must be taken at once.
Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan and special assistant to the Secretary of State, pleaded in an address last night for fair treatment of loyal American citizens of Japanese descent.

Science may be hindering progress in seeking to postpone the advent of old age and death while at the same time it aids in the restriction of births, Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister and Special Assistant to the British Ambassador, declared last night in an address at the New York Academy of Medicine.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A warning to the business interests of Britain that American industrial post-war planning had far surpassed their own efforts was sounded today by Sir Patrick Hannon, M.P., in his presidential address before the National Union of Manufacturers here.

Immediate joint action by manufacturing, wholesale and retailing groups to define and shape now post-war steps on surplus commodities, distribution policies and trade practices was urged yesterday to eliminate present confusion by Arthur L. Garniss, executive vice president of the New York Council on Trade Diversion, Inc.

Debutantes of the season will act as hostesses at the special preview next Tuesday afternoon and evening of the exhibition of paintings from the J.P. Morgan collection to be held from Wednesday through Dec. 11 at the Knoedler Galleries to augment the triptych fund of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- A Berne, Switzerland, dispatch to the newspaper Dagbladet reported tonight that Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain, Chief of State of Vichy France, resigned last Saturday because he was prevented from making a speech in which he intended to announce the convocation of a Chamber of Deputies.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Japan probably will hold the remaining bulk of her battered but still formidable navy in reserve until Allied naval formations venture in force into the 1,500-mile-wide stretch of the Pacific lying
In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES H. Eliot Kaplan takes exception to the P.R. system of voting, and says he is disillusioned by this plan, of which he once approved.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and the American Arbitration Association in a joint declaration yesterday issued a five-point program for speedy and equitable settlement of canceled war contracts to maintain employment and preserve private enterprise after the war.

When a man wants to know about a gun, an automobile or a washing machine, presupposing that such luxuries were available these days, he's likely to find the makers of those contraptions the most authoritative sources of information.

American advertisers must recognize that as the possibility of peace approaches there may be a temptation to settle for less than the unconditional surrender of Germany and hence should devote their efforts "to doing something about it," Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., pleaded last night at a dinner meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Commodore.

Henry M. Brundage, newly appointed Commissioner of Markets, was sworn in yesterday at ceremonies held in the office of Mayor La Guardia at City Hall. Among those present were Daniel P. Woolley, whom Mr. Brundage succeeds; United States Attorney James B.C. McNally, City Sheriff John J. McCloskey Jr., and members of the staffs of the Department of Markets and the Smaller War Plants Corporation, of which Mr. Brundage was regional director.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Estabrook Co. and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., will offer today to the public a new issue of $11,300,000 of Blackstone Valley Gas and Electric Company first mortgage 3 per cent bonds due Nov. 1, 1973.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Allies appeared tonight to be about to write off a small but costly experimental campaign against the relatively weak perimeter of the German island defenses off Greece, but there were indications that the next lunge might be against the strong heart of the enemy's Aegean line, perhaps with the aid of Turkey.

The Group A and C preliminaries of the United States Chess Federation's amateur championship play were completed at the Manhattan Chess Club last night when Leo Churgin of the New World Chess Club defeated Barnet Stromberg in a French defense lasting 25 moves.

In the miniature theatre tucked away in the basement of the 135th Street Public Library, the American Negro Theatre essayed a novel experiment last night and succeeded in providing an entertaining evening. With the permission of John Golden, sponsor of the Long-acre's present tenant, the Negro company offered its version of "Three's A Family" and thereby introduced to Harlem the obstetrical phase of the current Broadway season.

The Blackfriars Guild opened its new season last evening on the home grounds of Fifty-seventh Street and with "Career Angel," by Gerard M. Murray. The habitues of the try-out drama arrived in a forbidding state, as usual, but they remained to thaw out a little as the evening went on.

The threat of a strike of custodial employes in city schools by Local 112 of the School Custodial Workers Union was denounced yesterday as an attempted raid on two American Federation of Labor organizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A proposal by Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, that distillers should be allowed to keep liquor tax-free in bonded warehouses for four years instead of the present eight was commended today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. Senator George's committee is about to consider a new tax bill and the proposal could be embodied in it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Against the continued opposition of the Postoffice Department, representatives of labor and minority groups are urging a House Postoffice and Post Roads Subcommittee to report legislation to ban racially discriminatory literature or pictures from the mails.

Workers in essential industries who provoke their employers into discharging them so that they can go to other jobs cannot be controlled under present directives of the War Manpower Commission but the New York area office of tile WMC has requested Washington for broader authority to meet this "knotty problem," Stephen S. Sheriden, acting area director, declared last night.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Russia has firmly banned any federation of small European States which might be used as a "cordon sanitaire" similar to that drawn around the new Soviet State after World War I, it was disclosed today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Today's communique:

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England continued its uninterrupted advance and established a new high record of 1,013,683,000, according to the statement of condition for the week ended yesterday, issued today.

With goals for farm food production in 1944 having been set by the farmers themselves, a group of forty State committeemen of the Northeast Regional Division of the Agricultural Adjustment Agency and other agriculturists began a two-day conference at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel yesterday to discuss means of attaining these ends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Senate and House, which kept their post-war peace policy resolutions separated for fear of conflicts over words and phrases, gathered together today in the House chamber and acclaimed Secretary Hull, himself a former member of both branches, for his major role at Moscow in bringing forth the four-nations pact for Allied cooperation in obtaining and maintaining the peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Roosevelt, in a stinging rebuke to the National Leather Workers Association, directed the unaffiliated labor union today to cease picketing tannery plants in the Salem-Peabody (Mass.) area and to return all those who have been on strike to their jobs.

As one who has been in close contact with service men and has had the privilege of singing for them many times in camp, may I pass on a very personal observation in the hope that it may be productive of future helpfulness to the armed forces?

The National Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries, among which are the Weirton Steel Company and the Great Lakes Steel Corporation, have rejoined the American Iron and Steel Institute nearly two and one-half years after resigning from that trade organization in June, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The House gave unanimous approval today to the conference agreement on legislation designed to put pre-Pearl Harbor fathers at the bottom of the national draft pool and to delay their inductions as long as non-parent eligibles are available.

While wholesalers forecast yesterday a Thanksgiving turkey famine for New York City and the Government Food Distribution Administration challenged their figures, Daniel P. Woolley, new regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, warned that turkey shipments were heading here for sale at black market prices.

NAPLES, Nov. 16 (Delayed) -- Inquiries among many Italians who were in Rome until the armistice disclose that a large part of the fascist archives have been burned and a certain amount of them carted off to Germany. This means that a great deal that future generations ought to know about fascism and its leading figures will never be known.

Unchecked hoodlumism and student rebellions will reach their most dangerous level two years after the war, Professor Willard Waller of Columbia University's sociology department predicted yesterday in a study of the effects of war on public school pupils.
"The argument has been put forth from time to time of late that college football is done for and that when the war is over it is the professionals who will pull the crowds, as in baseball.

Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that shortages of coal and coke which have forced curtailment of steel production on a number of occasions this year will prevent the company from setting a new record for ingot production.

Savings banks and an insurance company figured prominently in realty activity in Manhattan yesterday when they announced sales of repossessed properties over a wide area. A large apartment building on Park Avenue also figured in the day's list of dealings when it was resold by a prominent firm of operators and builders.

The three four-family dwellings at 8729-33 and 8737 Sixteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, were sold by Mrs. Rose Frankel through the M.J. Abrams Company, Inc., brokers. Each building contains twenty rooms and each is on a plot 29.6 by 104 feet.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 17 (delayed) -- Turkey is giving sub-rosa assistance to the Allied armed forces that closely approximates that which the United States gave to Britain in the months before Pearl Harbor, and is moving toward war with the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Coal Administrator, criticized the "captive" mine operators today for failure to join bituminous coal operators who are meeting here with the United Mine Workers of America to draw up a union-management contract as a substitute for the governmental one between Mr. Ickes and John L. Lewis, president of the UMW.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18 -- The police announced today that in pursuit of the Government's unrestricted campaign against communism they had arrested two persons, both of them Spaniards, on charges of printing and distributing anti-Government propaganda literature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Intimate observers of and participants in the steps taken by the administration toward a coordinated foreign economic policy with smooth operation are expressing fear that this goal has not been fully attained by the creation of FEA under Leo T. Crowley.
MANHASSET, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Three adults and two children suffered injuries this afternoon as the station in which they were riding crashed into a telephone pole on Northern Boulevard.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- A disturbing picture of an excited scramble for agricultural property by city families inspired by their victory gardens or fear of inflation, by speculators looking for a quick profit and by bona fide farmers seeking to meet wartime food demands was presented here today by Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- For some years after victory is achieved Soviet Russia will need help from the United States and other members of the United Nations to rehabilitate its war-wasted areas and this requirement is likely to have an influence on the political mood of the Kremlin, Admiral William H. Standley said tonight in his first public appearance since his retirement as Ambassador to Moscow.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The cheerful tone which has prevailed throughout the stock market here this week was absent today and most sections were dull.
Plenty of powder, but very few puffs to pat it on with -- such is the situation as reported by both manufacturers and merchandisers of these favored feminine "weapons."

The strategic spotlight of the Pacific war is now moving north of the Equator. That is the meaning of the recent and continuing air attacks upon Japanese bases in the Marshall and Gilbert Islands in the central Pacific.
The Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation announced yesterday the first dividend on its common stock since 1922 and the elimination of dividend arrears on two classes of preferred stock.

If butter has been scarce on American tables during the past few weeks the convalescent Russian soldier is partly to blame. He is to blame to the extent of about one-tenth of an ounce of butter a week. This is one detail of the latest lend-lease report. We sent abroad during the first nine months of this year 1,718,200,000 pounds of meat, or 9.6 per cent of our total supply.

Though he spent sixteen days in a lifeboat after his ship was sunk while returning from Murmansk and experienced a second torpedoing in the Caribbean and seven days under fire off North Africa, Robert Brogan, 46-year-old full-blooded Seminole Indian, refused yesterday to give more than an outline of the rigors of seafaring life during wartime.
