WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Lower prices for fruits and vegetables and for hogs caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices to drop 0.1 point during the week ended Nov. 13. The all-commodity index, which now stands at 102.8 per cent of the 1926 average, has fluctuated within a very narrow range during the past twelve months.
Although they encountered much sterner resistance than they expected, the Red Wings managed to contribute to the woes of the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today the Legislative Reapportionment Act passed by the 1943 Legislature, thus completing, beyond further appeal, the first redistricting since 1917.

By the terms of an arbitration decision, it became known yesterday that "Victory Belles," Alice Gerstenberg's farce-comedy produced and directed by Henry Adrian, will not be required to leave the Mansfield on Nov. 27 to make way for "Janie," which had been announced to move there on Nov. 28 from the Playhouse.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Those sections of the British public that reacted most violently against Sir Oswald E. Mosley's Union of Fascists before the war responded again today to the news that he was to be released from prison for reasons of ill health.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- J. Leonard Reinsch, managing director of James M. Cox's radio stations in Dayton, Ohio; Miami, Fla., and Atlanta, told the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today that broadcasters generally and newspaper-owned stations in particular needed the amendments to the Communications Act provided in the Wheeler-White radio bill.

The Board of Estimate yesterday fixed Dec. 2 as the date for a public hearing on two rival proposals for supplying gasoline and oil to be used by airlines at the new municipal airport now under construction at Idlewild in Queens.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Professor W.E. Gye, director of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund Laboratories, writes in the current issue of The Lancet that he has hit on a promising treatment for colds.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Charles H. Sullivan, an attorney, World War veteran and former chairman of the Suffolk County Democratic Committee, has resigned as a member of Selective Service Board 706 at Huntington in protest of the drafting of pre-Pearl Harbor fathers and what he called the delegation of the selection of men for military service to war industry management.

Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America, reported in an operating statement to be mailed to stockholders today a consolidated net profit of $4,622,518 for the nine months ended with September, after all deductions, including Federal taxes on income.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has been called for Dec. 15 to authorize $60,000,000 of new preferred stock with a dividend rate not in excess of 4 1/2 per cent, it was announced yesterday by John W. Thomas, chairman.

For the first New York concert of his twentieth season as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, last night in Carnegie Hall, Dr. Koussevitzky had arranged a program exclusively of Russian music. There was a personal element in this arrangement, as also, without doubt, thought of the relations of America and Russia today, and the heroic contribution of the Russian people to the life and the future of the world.

Western Electric The Western Electric Company, manufacturer of important war communications equipment, in a report submitted yesterday to the War Production Board and the Smaller War Plants Corporation disclosed that 50 per cent of its sales of war materials since Pearl Harbor had been produced by subcontractors.

Increased participation by organized labor in "the political and social life of the country" through the medium of social work was the keynote of yesterday's general session of the New York State Conference on Social Work, in which executives of Federal, State and municipal departments participated.

BEAU JACK returns to the pugilistic wars in Madison Square Garden tonight when he attempts to regain the lightweight championship from Bob Montgomery. The Beau shot up to the fisticuffing heavens like a rocket and the pyrotechnic display was slightly on the awesome side. Whatever goes up must come down, however, and the Beau plummeted with startling rapidity, losing his title to Monty and losing the last shred of his prestige to Bobby Ruffin.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski will give two special programs during the first fortnight in December. The concerts of Dec. 2, 3, 4 and 5 will be dedicated to the victims of Nazi and Fascist oppression and the program will consist of Bloch's "Three Jewish Poems," and the Second ("Resurrection") symphony of Mahler, with Astrid Varnay, soprano, and Enid Szantho, contralto, as soloists.

Reflecting a generally strengthened grain market and supported chiefly by routine trade buying, the cotton futures market yesterday moved moderately higher for the sixth consecutive session. A flurry of price fixations near the close of trading sent the list of active old-type deliveries to the day's best levels and 5 to 8 points over Wednesday's final quotations.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Just a week after he was acquitted of the murder of Sir Harry Oakes, debonair Alfred de Marigny was convicted in Magistrate's Court today of illegal possession of gasoline.

Simplified taxes and a renegotiation procedure that allows corporations to build up "fat" against lean periods were demanded yesterday by Livingston W. Houston, executive vice president of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in an address before the National Founders Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- During the week ended Nov. 17 member bank reserve balances increased $65,000,000, the Federal Reserve System reported today. Additions to member-bank reserves rose from an increase of $141,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and decreases of $4,000,000 in Treasury cash and $2,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $45,000,000 in money in circulation and $38,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks.

By this time most people in New York City and vicinity realize that there is a shortage of milk. It would be helpful, I think, if more of them understood the reason for this shortage and realized that the situation is likely to be much more serious next year unless early action is taken to reverse the trend.

Can a woman's happiness be evaluated in dollars and cents? Seven judges of the United States Supreme Court have just ruled that it cannot be done. Two judges dissented. The case involved a widow who was willed a fixed income from a trust fund plus such an amount from the principal as the trustee thought wise and proper for her "happiness."

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Three Royal Air Force airmen of the Transport Command -- one of them an American -- have been rescued from a gale-swept rock off Greenland, where they spent ten days after their Hampden trainer crashed on a transatlantic flight, it was revealed tonight.

The senior order clerks' section of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms wil hold its annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 1. Emil Schram, president of the Stock Exchange, will attend. Fred Hansen of Pershing Co. is in charge of reservations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee approved today a resolution setting forth that the contract made on Aug. 7, 1943, by the fifteen railway unions and the railroads calling for a wage increase of 8 cents an hour was valid and in accord with the Railway Labor Act.

Turkey does not intend to enter the war. A trustworthy diplomatic authority reports that last week Numan Menemencioglu, Turkish Foreign Minister, gave an assurance conceived in such terms to the German Ambassador to Turkey, Franz von Papen.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 18 -- The ill-fated Allied campaign in the Aegean Islands, which has just been marked by the loss of Leros following that of Kos and in which the present position of Samos is menaced, represented a successful diversion in the over-all Allied strategy, including Italy and the Soviet Union, Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, Allied Commander in Chief in the Middle East, told a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Income, spending and saving all increased in the United States during the second quarter of 1943, thereby increasing potential inflationary pressure, the Office of War Information reported today. This happened although the cost of living declined slightly.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 19 -- The Red Army has split the German armies of the Ukraine from those in White Russia with the capture of the rail junction of Korosten, on the Leningrad-Odessa and Kiev-Warsaw lines sixty miles from the pre-war Polish border, Premier Joseph Stalin disclosed last night in an order of the day.

The Greater New York Industrial Union Council, Congress of Industrial Organizations, voted last night to sponsor an educational campaign in defense of Proportional Representation and condemned politicians and newspapers that have attacked the system.

The War Production Board and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, joint sponsors of the national collection of used clothing for war relief, which begins Monday, announced yesterday that participating agencies could obtain today official signs to identify their offices as collection depots during the thirteen-day campaign.

The New York Committee of the National War Fund reported yesterday the receipt of additional donations of $5,145,177 within the last two weeks, which raise the total collections here to $10,364,759. The new figure places the committee $6,635,241 away from the campaign's Pearl Harbor Day objective of $17,000,000.

According to recent press dispatches, Anglo-American air power has received a "deadline" for knocking Germany out of the war by aerial offensive. If it does not finish the job by the specified date air strategy will be considered ineffective and a full-parade invasion of Europe by land forces will be launched.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The military stalemate in Italy, the German capture of Kos and Leros in the Dodecanese and the political crisis in Lebanon are by themselves events of limited importance but they happened at just the wrong time and at just the wrong place to be dismissed as temporary setbacks.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The 1944 Kentucky Derby, marking the seventieth running of the historic race, will be held Saturday, May 6, almost a week later than this year.

The Stevedoring School, housed in the waiting room of the United States Lines at Pier 59, North River, was inspected yesterday by Commodore Frederick G. Reinicke, USN, retired, Port Director of the Third Naval District. This unusual school, where Navy officers are taught up-to-the-minute methods of cargo handling, has been in operation for seven months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Oral argument was heard today before the Interstate Commerce Commission in the reorganization proceeding of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad Company, which operates a line from Jersey City to Stroudsburg, Pa.

The Lebanon crisis has brought to the fore the related questions of colonies, mandates and re-emerging nationalisms. It will be unfortunate if these matters are regarded as the special province of any power, or if they are settled unilaterally rather than in the spirit and within the framework established by the Moscow Conference.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Funeral services were held today for Mrs. Mary Florian, 28 years old; her three sons, Charles, 10; Kenneth, 8, and Edward, 2; and her two nieces, Jacquelyn Bastian, 7, and Alther Bastian, 2, all of whom lost their lives in a fire that swept the Florian home at 402 Palisade Avenue, here, Monday.

Owing to increased demands from military buyers for knitted helmets, output of which requires facilities normally used to supply headwear for children, the approach of colder weather has lifted current demand out of proportion to available civilian supply, it was reported yesterday in the textile market.

The new load of explosives dumped by American fliers on Nazi industrial plants in Norway emphasizes the fact that there is now almost no spot in German-held Europe beyond the reach of our bombers. On the same day American planes were hitting Nazi airfields near the Acropolis.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed a decrease of $33,127,000 in holdings of United States Government securities. Note circulation for the system as a whole showed an increase of $55,915,000 to a new record high at $15,974,140,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The announcement that $13,163,519,000 in Army appropriations probably would be saved in this fiscal year was made today to a surprised House by Representative J. Buell Snyder, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Military Appropriations subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Bernard Baruch, who recently was appointed head of the new demobilization unit in the Office of War Mobilization, told the War Production Board's Steel Industry Advisory Committee today that the actual job of unscrambling wartime industry would have to be done by industry itself in conjunction with the War Production Board.

"Madame Curie," the Metro film dramatization of the discovery of radium by Marie and Pierre Curie, will have its world premiere on Dec. 16 at the Radio City Music Hall. The biographical drama, co-starring Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon, was adapted from the book by the late scientists' daughter, Eve Curie.
The Soviet early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 18 -- Land-based Liberators of Maj. Gen. Willis H. Hale's Seventh United States Army Air Force again attacked targets in the Gilbert and Marshall Islands of the central Pacific on Tuesday and Wednesday, according to a communique issued here today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean areas.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Little Billie Mosienko made two goals and helped in scoring two more tonight as the Black Hawks defeated the Boston Bruins by 7 -- 3 to collect their fourth straight victory and move into sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- An annual subsidy of $100,000,000 or more on flour to prevent bread price increases was announced today by the stabilization director, Fred M. Vinson, while Administration forces in the House fought an apparently losing battle against a bill which would end all food subsidies on Dec. 31.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Roy F. Hendrickson, Federal director of food distribution, told the Albany Food Forum today that the American diet in 1944, despite the needs of the armed forces and our allies, will be above the average pre-war diet, if crops are favorable.

The O. Henry Memorial Award Committee, making its annual short-story awards, announces that Eudora Welty of Jackson, Miss., has won the first prize of $300 for the second consecutive time. Miss Welty, whose winning story is "Livvie is Back," also took a second prize two years ago, and is outranked only by Stephen Vincent Benet, three times a first-prize winner.
The German communique, from a Berlin broadcast recorded by The Associated Press:

It would be trifling with the truth to say that Stout Steve Owen fears the constantly losing Chicago Cardinals, with whom his Giants will tangle at the Polo Grounds Sunday. But with Steve confidence never begets carelessness, as his long and successful record of bossing the football Giants proves.

The rigors of another northern spring training siege hold no terrors for Manager Joe McCarthy. Neither is the Yankee skipper, who on Wednesday completed arrangements to have his world champions train at Atlantic City next March, greatly concerned whether the promised indoor facilities at the seaside resort come up to expectations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -- William Prince, who was signed by Warner Brothers to a term contract after his appearance as Private Quiz West in the Broadway production of "The Eve of St. Mark," has been named for the leading role in "Cinderella Jones" with Joan Leslie.

Testimony that defective bullets were knowingly included in a shipment prepared for the French Indo-Chinese Government was presented by Samuel H. Reis, assistant United States Attorney, in Federal court yesterday. The evidence was given before Judge Alfred C. Coxe and a jury at the opening of the trial of four men and a corporation for mail fraud in the alleged sale of bad bullets to the Amtorg Trading Corporation, Soviet agency.

Charitable and religious institutions share nearly all the estate of Mrs. Estelle A. Manning, widow of Joseph Jay Manning, one of the New York Stock Exchange's most colorful "lone operators." Mrs. Manning died on Nov. 12 last, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $20,000."

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City finished their reporting week, at the close of business on Wednesday night, with reserve deficiencies aggregating $25,000,000, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 18 -- In the presence of scores of prelates, 250 nuns and 1,200 of the laity, the Right Rev. Mgr. Francis Joseph Haas was anointed Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Grand Rapids in St. Andrews' Cathedral today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 18 -- A subcommittee of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration has decided to extend UNRRA relief activities to enemy territories after they have been seized by Allied troops, it was learned today.

Government reports and the opinions of industrial management experts indicate that most women are expected to return to their homes from factories and war jobs when peace comes, Dean Ruth C. Wright of City College declared yesterday at a meeting of the American Association of University Women at Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.
MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 to 2, tonight to complete their eighth successive National Hockey League game without a defeat.

NETCONG, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Convicted of neglect and improper care in the operation of a boarding house for children of war workers employed in the metropolitan area, Mrs. Minnie Haegler of Mount Olive Township, near here, was sentenced last night to serve eleven months and twenty-nine days in the Morris County Jail by Justice of the Peace Louis T. Huyler.

FOOCHOW, China, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- During the past two months the sympathies of Wang Ching-wei's puppet soldiers along the Central China coast have decisively turned in favor of Chiang Kai-shek's government, according to Pearce Hayes and Harry Cauldwell, American missionaries at Futsing, forty miles south of Foochow.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Britain is expected to appoint William Strang, acting Assistant Under-Secretary of State, as her delegate on the European advisory commission.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- Agricultural representatives of New York and eight other northeastern States, organized as a food committee by the Governors of the nine States, will meet in New York next Monday to develop a program of joint action to obtain feed needed to maintain the milk and egg supply in the Northeast.

Only 42,000,000 gallons of liquor, four years old or more, it is estimated, would be released for the open market if the proposal by Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to reduce the tax-free period for distillers in bonded warehouses from eight to four years, should be approved, W.W. Wachtel, president of the Calvert Distillers Corporation, declared yesterday.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, will reopen on Tuesday to the public for its 1943-44 annual exhibition of contemporary American art, consisting of oils, water-colors, sculpture and drawings. It will be the sixteenth exhibition of this na ture to be held since the museum first opened in November, 1931.

Based on the few reports so far issued, the net income of the railroads in October fell sharply below that of the similar month last year. The Erie Railroad, which has been showing excellent earnings since its reorganization almost two years ago, reported a net deficit in October. The loss resulted from the inclusion of $3,504,300 for estimated wage adjustments from February through October.

Under the auspices of the United States Army Air Forces, "Winged Victory," written and directed by Moss Hart, will make its Broadway debut tonight at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. The show, which has a cast of 300 members of the flying branch of the service and fifty-four civilian actresses, is described as a "straight dramatic offering in seventeen scenes" dealing with six potential pilots and the various stages they pass through before achieving their wings.

A ten-day-old baby girl was found abandoned at 6:30 o'clock last night, propped up on a kneeling bench in the corner of a confessional stall in the back of the Dominican Church of St. Catherine of Sienna, 411 East Sixty-eighth Street.

Capt. Paul Hendren, United States Navy hero in the invasion of Sicily July 10-12, has been warded the Legion of Merit medal by Vice Admiral H. K. Hewitt, Unted States naval commander in the Mediterranean theatre of operations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Although the Federal Government has discontinued all butter purchases until April, this twill not increase the supply available to civilians, the Office of War Information said today. The average annual per capita supply for home use will continue to be about four pounds less than in the years before the war, the statement asserted.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Fourteen "Westchester County civilian heroes" received "Oscars" this afternoon from Arnold Constable Co. at a luncheon given by the store at the Wykagyl Country Club here. Recipients of the awards had been chosen by committees of civic leaders.

The prosecution of dealers who purchase commodities at prices higher than those allowed by the Office of Price Administration was attacked in Federal court yesterday by Charles W. Newmark, attorney for a dealer that pleaded guilty to such a charge and was fined $500 by Judge Murray Hulbert.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The air strategy of the German High Command, based on the theory that Germany proper could not be effectively bombed, had already been defeated by the Royal Air Force and the United States Army Air Forces, Maj. Gen. William E. Kepner, chief of the American Eighth Air Force Fighter Command, said here today, and Allied aerial blows against the Reich would increase in weight and frequency.

The tremendous increase in the number of working children since the war began has aggravated old problems and created new ones, Mrs. Gertrude Folks Zimand, newly appointed general secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, declared yesterday.

Today's events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Helen Berlin, violin, and Irene Jacoby, piano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Artur Rubinstein, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Lawrence Tibbett, baritone, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; Britt String Ensemble, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; "Boris Godunoff," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

Maintenance of the good neighbor policy, based on mutual confidence and respect, is the foundation of future collaboration and sincere friendship between the United States and all the republics of the Western Hemisphere, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, Mexican Ambassador to this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Any worth-while world communications system must be founded upon five basic principles agreed upon at the peace conference when the war ends, James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said tonight at a dinner given in his honor by the Washington chapter of the National Lawyers Guild.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The United States Navy has been hunting for the Japanese fleet to engage it in battle in the South Pacific, but not one of the enemy warships has been found in seventeen days, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, told newspaper men today.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 19 -- The patent among the 528 listed as issued in the current volume of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office with perhaps the widest popular appeal this week is one for a motion picture theatre invented by James H. Owens of Camden, N.J.
The Hudson Motor Car Company and domestic and Canadian subsidiaries showed a net profit of $1,364,101 for the first nine months this year, according to the report issued yesterday.

When it became apparent that the Procurement and Assignment Service was unable to meet the civilian medical needs of several hundred boom towns and rural areas the proposal was made that the requisite number of physicians be withdrawn from private practice, put in the uniform of the Public Health Service and sent where they are needed.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19 -- Ray Atherton, the first United States Ambassador to Canada, today presented to the Governor General, the Earl of Athlone, the letter of credence by which the President of the United States accredited him as Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary.

Yesterday, Nov. 19, was the eightieth anniversary of the Gettysburg Address. Destined to immortality, it was unfortunate in the circumstances of its delivery. The audience at the dedication of the Soldiers National Cemetery had been on its feet for two hours hearing Edward Everett's oration, which had followed music and a long prayer.

Two months ago we were told that $100,000,000 of subsidies would roll back living costs by more than $1,500,000,000. Now Mr. Bowles announces that the payment of a $1,000,000,000 to $1,500,000,000 in subsidies might avoid a rise of $15,000,000,000 in living costs next year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Mrs. Roosevelt staunchly defended at a press conference today the use of funds out of the Treasury to hold down food costs.

United States Senator James E. Murray, co-author of the Wagner-Murray-Dingell Social Security-Health Insurance Bill now pending before Congress, charged last night that the American Medical Association, together with companies specializing in "quack medicines," have joined to defeat the bill, which is designed to bring adequate medical care within the reach of all the people of the United States.

At a hearing in Washington on Thursday before the Interstate Commerce Commission in the reorganization proceedings of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad Company, R.M.D. Richardson and Lyman M. Tondel Jr., representing insurance companies holding the road's bonds, supported a capitalization plan calling for the issuance of $16,250,000 of securities in the reorganized road.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Frank E. Gannett, publisher of the Gannett newspapers in the United States, finds the British people cheerful and confident while expecting a last desperate German assault on England, he said today in an interview after a three-week visit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The time is rapidly approaching when industry can begin planning its post-war operations, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, told the Senate Truman Committee today.

When restrictions and shortages puzzled American handbag designers, they solved the problem with a range of fabrics and styles that now are successfully filling the places formerly held by leather bags.

Dutton announces that Clyde F. Murphy, a native of Great Falls, Mont., is the winner of their first Lewis and Clark Northwest Contest, with his novel "The Glittering Hill." The award was offered last year for "the best book manuscript submitted by a Northwest author."

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein, "godfather" of the grand jury which caused a furor with its presentment on crime in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant district, imposed a prison sentence yesterday of forty to sixty years for robbery on a professional criminal who had several times returned from prison to that neighborhood for additional misdeeds.

E.L. Williams, president of the Insurance Executive Association, said last night, according to The United Press, that he considered the House Judiciary Committee's recent report on the bill designed to keep the insurance business within State Control, "a very strong document which should favorably impress members of both houses of Congress."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Members of the National Board of the National Women's Trade Union League agreed today that it is not necessary to be too greatly alarmed about women's unemployment after the war. The important thing, they said, is to keep open the doors of opportunity, to hold gains made toward equal pay, better working conditions and better representation in union organizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A resolution calling for formation of a Presidential commission to explore ways to provide haven for 4,000,000 Jews still inside Europe provoked a sharp attack on Britain's Palestine policy today at a hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The recommended scale of cuts in newsprint usage for the first quarter of 1944 will range up to 24 per cent of the 1941 base tonnage for the largest newspapers, the War Production Board said today in clarifying proposals submitted Wednesday by the Newspaper Industry Advisory Committee.

Once more huge armadas of bombers have swept across Germany to pound Berlin and Ludwigshafen. This was apparently the greatest of all the great attacks which have been made by the RAF since the beginning of the war -- with perhaps a thousand planes involved -- and its full fury was directed against the great chemical works at Ludwigshafen and the war industries in the suburbs of the German capital.

The Rangers got little besides sympathy when the National Hockey League's board of governors met yesterday to clarify playing rules and to consider wartime problems, including the situation of the New York skaters who have lost their first eight games.
Directors of the Aluminum Company of America yesterday authorized the distribution of $1 a share on Dec. 10 to holders of the new common stock.

Every welfare agency, public and private, will be taxed to the limit in caring for discharged service men, of which there are 35,000 a month at present, Lieut. Col. Augustin G. Rudd, officer in charge of Army Emergency Relief for the Second Service Command, declared here yesterday.

A Japanese repatriate from Los Angeles warned a Tokyo "hate the enemy" mass meeting yesterday that the fighting spirit of Americans was "decisively high" and "cannot be underestimated" and then declared, amid applause, that one weak point in the United States is the "democratic system," under which persons publicly disagree with the President and Vice President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- About 2,400,000 cases of canned grapefruit juice will be released from Government-held stocks and made available for civilian consumption some time within the next few weeks, the War Food Administration announced today.

" The Battle of Russia," the feature-length documentary produced for the Army as one of the "Why We Fight" orientation film series, which had its first local public showing at the Globe last Saturday, will end its engagement there on Tuesday.

With the announcement yesterday that Serge Rubinstein, 35-year-old oil corporation director, had been placed in Class 4-C by his local draft board as a result of having claimed exemption from military service on the ground that he is a neutral alien, it also was established that he had thereby debarred himself from ever becoming a citizen of the United States.
The following items are chosen at random from the recent news:

The New York Vassar Club, of which Mrs. Henry M.B. Chamberlin is president, will sponsor as its twenty-second annual scholarship fund benefit the performance of Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera" on the night of Dec. 17 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 19 -- A new approach to the housing problem by Federal agencies to lay stress again on private building operations was urged by the National Association of Real Estate Boards here today at the concluding business session of its thirty-sixth annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Final decision on whether Charles E. Wilson remains as executive vice chairman of the War Production Board or returns to the presidency of the General Electric Corporation will be made by President Roosevelt.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 19 -The text of Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain's address, scheduled for broadcast in France last Saturday but which the Germans forbade him to deliver, is:

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 20 -- The Russians lost Zhitomir, the Red Army's westernmost threat to Poland and Rumania, yesterday in their first major reverse in four months, but the Red Army dropped troops from the skies for a new crossing of the Dnieper and captured another rail junction seventy miles north of Zhitomir.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert sent seven violators of the draft law to prison for terms ranging from one to five years yesterday, but in each case he left the way open for the defendant to be transferred to a position of value in the war program should such a position be found for him by the Attorney General.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Home Secretary Herbert Morrison made his first statement today on l'Affaire Mosley when he sent a letter to the general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union chiding them for being hasty in their protest against the release of Sir Oswald, Fascist leader, and adding:

ARMY vs. Brown -- A careful perusal of the last three Brown scores makes one wonder whether the Bruins have been playing basketball or football. Such fancy figures as these give no indication, 34 -- 31, 21 -- 20 and 28 -- 20. But it is hard to imagine Brown running up such totals against that rock-ribbed cadet line.

The District Office of Price Administration launched yesterday a drive to compel compliance with, ceiling prices on turkeys and other poultry at retail and wholesale levels to protect New York City's housewives through the holiday season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Announcement that price ceilings would be placed on wheat and other grains shortly and probably involve a change in the price differentials on wheat between the leading markets resulted in confused price changes today on the Board of Trade.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 19 -- The first Rome mass meeting of the Fascist Republican party held last evening in the Teatro Adriano was an extremely stormy affair with "formerly well-disciplined Fascists suddenly transformed into a turbulent mob," the German correspondent von Hohenbach cabled to his Berlin newspaper.

The Newspaper Guild of New York, subject of an investigation ordered by the international executive board of the American Newspaper Guild, set forth its position yesterday in a four-page pamphlet sent to its membership.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Twenty-eight retrievers, many of them of national reputation and others of internationally famous ancestry, competed today in the opening series of the annual fall field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club, contested in the covers of the Timber Point Club in this village.

Present fashions have "a freshness, a genuineness and a suitability to American women that is the most hopeful sign yet presented for American fashion independence after the war," several hundred women in the fashion field were told yesterday.

Voluntary relief agencies both here and abroad will be called upon to aid in the international project now being formulated at Atlantic City under the direction of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, Luther Gulick, a member of the secretariat of that organization in Washington, declared yesterday.

The stock market snapped back yesterday with unusual force, prices rebounding more than a point on the average and 2 to 3 points in some of the higher-priced issues. Not since early August had the list shown such recuperative powers and despite a crack-up in the distilling group it hung determinedly to its advantages.

After an ownership of forty years the eight-story loft building at 41 West Twenty-fourth Street was sold by Bayard Sands Litchfield to an investing client of David Rapoport, attorney. Morgan Lockwood represented the seller.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had ordered thirteen dress manufacturers in New York City, all makers of formal evening dresses, to cease and desist from entering into agreements to fix prices.

Edward Martella, 24 years old, of 471 Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, and his 17-year-old wife, Elizabeth, were sent to the workhouse yesterday in the Felony Court after Martella had tried to save his bride of five months from conviction for aiding him in an attempt to rob an unidentified sailor, who was asleep on a bench in the BMT subway station at Seventh Avenue and Forty-ninth Street shortly after midnight.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- Moscow's guns were fired again today, this time celebrating a double victory. Both Korosten and Rechitsa were captured as the result of plans in whose skillful working out the enemy was completely outgeneraled.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 19 -- Eighty-seven-year-old Chief of State Henri Philippe Petain has made a move filled with consequences in that he reasserts himself as Chief of State over Pierre Laval as Chief of Government, recalls that France is a democracy and makes a bid for de Gaullist support by recognizing the authority of Parliament should he die before the new Constitution is promulgated.

ALGIERS, Nov. 19 -- The 35,000-ton French battleship Richelieu, newly refitted at the New York Navy Yard, took her place today at the head of the French battle fleet under orders by Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud to strike against the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission was asked today by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, to inquire into a broadcast scheduled for the United States by former King Carol of Rumania, speaking from Mexico City.

ALGIERS, Nov. 19 -- The weather let up a little on the Italian front yesterday and the Eighth Army tortuously carved out another small gain northwest of Atessa, but flooded rivers posed a new problem.

State committeemen attending the Northeast Regional Conference of the Agricultural Adjustment Agency wound up their two-day meeting at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel yesterday, confident that the food production goals for 1944 that farmers have set for themselves could be achieved.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19 -- The extent to which the "Canol" project in the Northwest Territories is operating, and the terms of the agreement made between the United States and Canadian Governments to assure a constant supply of oil for the American forces in Alaska and regarding the disposal of the properties after the war were made public here today with the consent of the United States War Department.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- While receipts of hogs here this week were under those recorded last week and clearance was good, the twelve principal western markets had the largest week's supply on record and some points were unable to clear the pens. The two-day embargo at South St. Paul was ended and trading started there today with 23,000 salable arrivals.

Bernard M. Baruch, head of the demobilization unit in the Office of War Mobilization, denied last night press reports which quoted him as saying that the War Production Board, under the chairmanship of Donald M. Nelson, should be in charge of post-war planning and conversion.

The following story was submitted to the Duke of Windsor by The North American Newspaper Alliance, and he suggested certain corrections and deletions, which have been made. In its present form he has approved its publication.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Germans claimed the occupation of four more pin-point Aegean islands today in a creeping counter-offensive along the sea line before Grece, while the Allied air arm fell with methodical violence across the Balkans from Salonkia to the Yugoslav coast.

The Children's Welfare Federation will benefit from the Dec. 13 performance of "A Connecticut Yankee" at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over by the federation, a coordinating center for 250 agencies in this city for the moral and physical upbuilding of needy children.
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Commnications Commission:

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Although the stock markets here strengthened a little today, their general tone was again dull. Industrials brightened, however, Electric and Musical Instruments and British Celanese each making a sharp gain.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 -- The first of the big CIO unions to breal silence on its aims for upward revision of the "Little Steel" wage formula -- the Aluminum Workers of America -- announced today that it would propose a drive for a straight increase of 15 cents an hour at plants of the Aluminum Company of America.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Warnings that the American economic and political systems will be endangered if too much reliance is placed on Washington in formulation of post-war plans were sounded today by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor; Dean Donald Kirk David of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and Representative Hatton W. Sumners of Texas, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Thomas J. McKee, secretary of the Jamestown Board of Public Utilities, said today that operating expenses of the utility were expected to rise in 1944 because of the increase in the cost of coal and the necessity of paying higher wages to employes.

When 57-year-old Sam Boston's two partners in a betting commission business were shot and killed last summer in a midtown club by a partner they had "frozen out" of the racket, Boston announced he was finished with gambling, would move to the country and live a retired life.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Trustworthy reports reaching Chungking today said heavy Japanese troop movements from Manchuria and North China were in progress with the Southwest Pacific as the most probable destination of the contingents.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Before a voluntary "jury" of seven women auxiliaries of the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson, presiding over Naturalization Court here today, admitted forty-four aliens to American citizenship, denied the applications of twenty one others and deferred the citizenship status of fourteen for various periods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The War Production Board's requirements committee has completed its task of alloting available critical materials to military and civilian agencies for their operations during the first quarter of next year, Donald M. Nelson, WPB chief, announced today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A limited partnership today purchased control of the National Refining Company for about $9,000,000, Otis Co., investment bankers here, announced. The banking firm said about 90 per cent of the company's prior preferred stock had been bought from holders at $100 a share and a like amount of common stock at $8 a share.
Led by Walter Budko and Bill Widmaier, Columbia's basketball team defeated Webb Institute, 60 to 15, on the Morningside gymnasium floor last night in the intercollegiate opener for both teams.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Alfred de Marigny, who won acquittal last week of a murder charge, today was fined 100 for illegal possession of gasoline.

ALGIERS, Nov. 19 -- Gen. Georges Catroux has sent back detailed reports on Lebanon to the French Committee of National Liberation, which reiterated to him in reply that it urgently desired a prompt settlement of the matter.

The twenty-eighth annual exhibition put on by the Society of American Etchers, Inc., opened this week and will continue through Dec. 8. It is being held, following the procedure of the last few seasons, in the Fifth Avenue home of the National Academy of Design (between Eighty-ninth Street and Ninetieth).

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Sonny Tufts has been named by Paramount to co-star with Veronica Lake and Eddie Bracken in the forthcoming Navy musical "Bring On the Girls." He will have the singing role for which Dick Powell was previously slated.
LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

In your issue of Nov. 14 and your editorial of Nov. 15 there are certain statements with regard, to wage increases and the cost of living for so-called white-collar workers. There are a number of statements which are made as statements of fact which are not in conformity with the information published by the Census Bureau or the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- The midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Former Ambassador Joseph C. Grew is as well qualified as any man to speak about the Japanese. He has been where they live. Out of his experience he makes a plea for a distinction between loyal Americans of Japanese descent and the kind of Japanese who have recently been making trouble in the internment camp at Tule Lake, Calif.
The importance of promoting ski touring and junior skiing was brought out at the twenty-first annual meeting of the Swedish Ski Club last night at the George Washington Hotel.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, pastor of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, will conduct at 11 A.M. tomorrow a reconstruction of the first service ever held by a Protestant group. The occasion will be the observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Holy Trinity, which Dr. Scherer has served the last twenty-three years.
Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, has come from Washington to the WaldorfAstoria. Also there are Salvador Duhart, First Secretary of the Mexican Embassy, and Sefiora de Duhart.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 19 -- The remarkable contribution of Fiji toward waging the Pacific war was praised today by Brig. Gen. John G. Wales of the New Zealand staff corps and former commander of the Fiji's army.

The first reports on activities along the up-State deer-hunting front are beginning to seep in, and about time, too. The season opened in the Catskill region last Monday and apparently the sport there is thriving with its accustomed vigor, gasoline shortage, ammunition shortage and sparetime shortage to the contrary.

" Thanksgiving Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches, the general theme being "Thanksgiving in Wartime." The Rev. Dr. John W. Behnken, National President of the Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other States, has proclaimed tomorrow a "Day of Penitence and Prayer" in the 4,414 churches under his jurisdiction, of which 200 are in the New York area.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- A communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 -- Headquarters of the People's Army of Liberation announced today their forces were still in possession of parts of the Peljesac Peninsula, focal point of the bitterest fighting along the lower Dalmatian coast. Only one section of the peninsula has been evacuated, it was stated.
A great little fighter came back to the heights last night in Madison Square Garden before a roaring crowd of 17,866 fans who paid $96,873 to see one of the biggest boxing upsets of modern times.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 -- An account of the French action by which members of Premier Riad Solh's government in Lebanon were arrested in the early morning hours of Nov. 11 was contained in a story published this afternoon in Paral Mokattan, a Cairo daily.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- A large share of future scholarly activities of the world must be carried on within the next decade on this continent, and to meet this challenge we need only to make certain that the fostering of the spirit of free enterprise shall be an ambition of the American people, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, told the American Philosophical Society tonight.

The saddest season in the history of Columbia football will come to a close today when the Lions line up against Colgate at Baker Field. Sad, that is, in the sense of victorious accomplishment. The Morningside Heights eleven, in seven games thus far, has been sent down to defeat exactly seven times.

Scoring in every period, Horace Mann yesterday defeated the visiting Carteret Academy football team, 25 -- 7. The losers held a brief one-point lead in the second period when Dave Alden plunged over from the 1-yard line and the point was added on a pass from Steve Palmer to Dave Laity.

It is with tradition in mind that this department has mapped out the Thanksgiving menu appearing in the meals for next week, the only departure from custom being the inclusion of a chicken in place of the turkey that threatens to be among the missing.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Australian forces Thursday closed in on the main Japanese defenses around Sattelberg, New Guinea, and Allied fliers over the Solomons downed at least eighteen Japanese planes Wednesday in smashing an enemy attack on shipping off Bougainville, it was reported today.

A suit by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein for a temporary injunction to restrain Jerome Fiske Collins of 25 East Ninth Street from selling securities through various cemetery corporations he controls was argued yesterday before Justice Kenneth O'Brien in Supreme Court.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 20 -- The great Allied aerial offensive, tearing at the roots of industrial Germany and pounding at the outworks of Hitler's fortress of Europe, is reaching another peak of intensity.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The punishment handed out by the Anglo-American air offensive, severe as it is, can never be accepted as a substitute for an invasion of the Continent in bringing about the defeat of Germany, it was said today in Manchester by Dingle M. Foot, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Economic Warfare.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Railroad and public utility financing featured the new investment market here this week. A single issue of carrier mortgage bonds, the largest of its kind since June, accounted for nearly half the $32,800,000 in new bonds offered to the public.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- With Dartmouth seeking a tie for top honors in the Ivy League and Princeton hoping for an upset to end an otherwise unsuccessful football season, the two teams will clash at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in Palmer Stadium.

Criticizing the Moscow agreement between the United States, Russia and Great Britain as a plan that will "Balkanize' all of Europe, Norman Thomas, leader of the Socialist party in the United States, forecast a third world war last night, and added that he was as certain of his prediction as he had been in forecasting the present conflict after World War I.

With rent control registration continuing heavy yesterday Louis H. Pink, rent director for the New York City defense-rental area, predicted it would exceed the 500,000-mark when the eighty-two schools being used for the purpose are closed at noon today.

Passage of a constitutional amendment transferring treaty approval power from two-thirds of the Senate to a majority in both houses of Congress was strongly advocated yesterday by Col. Henry Breckinridge, former assistant Secretary of War, as a means of "preventing the destruction of peace through the stubborn opposition of a willful minority."

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 19 -- Carrier planes joined land-based bombers as United States air forces for the sixth straight day struck at the Japanese central Pacific strongholds in the Marshall and Gilbert Islands and expanded the offensive to deliver a heavy blow at the enemy base on Nauru Island, 500 miles west of the Gilberts.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 -- United States Army forces in the Middle East came within an ace of not having turkey for Thanksgiving, according to this week's issue of Stars and Stripes, American Army publication appearing today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Capitol Hill heard tonight that the Navy might find it unnecessary to spend $5,000,000,000 of its funds for this fiscal year, thus bringing the total of "saving" by the armed forces to more than $18,000,000,000.

Stockholders of the American National Bank and Trust Company, Chicago's sixth largest bank, at a special meeting yesterday approved the issuance of 5,000 new shares f common stock to be offered to present shareholders for subscription at par of $100 a share on the basis of one new share for each two shares now held.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Three of nine Governors who met as the executive committee on post-war reconstruction and development of the Council of State Governments stressed in addresses today the need to "begin planning immediately."
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 19 (AP) -- J.L. Friedman's Overlin, the 11-to-10 choice, broke on top and led all the way today to win the Milan Purse at Rockingham Park.

With Christmas shopping making definite headway, sharp percentage increases in retail trade here were noted this week. Estimates indicated department stores probably will have an average increase of 15 per cent or more over a year ago, with gains for individual stores ranging well above this figure.

Approximately 60 per cent of the farm population believes that manufacturers in general are making "excessive profits" out of the war, according to a nation-wide survey based on 2,800 interviews among seven types of farmers just completed for the Association of National Advertisers.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 19 (AP) -- An Allied communique:

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Seventy-five representatives of organized labor, a little spavined and winded after forty-eight hours of intensive basic training with regular troops, pulled out for New York City tonight with a better understanding of Army life learned the hard way.

In the post-war world the nation's railroads will use advertising on a greater scale than ever before as one weapon in the battle with airlines, buses and private cars for passenger traffic, it is predicted by Railway Age in a special "passenger progress" edition.

Following assurance from two American Federation of Labor unions that they would replace any custodial employe of the city school system who might answer a strike call or a rival Congress of Industrial Organization local, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that negotiations between the city and the two AFL unions to obtain pay increases for 3,000 custodial workers will be resumed Monday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 19 -- Whether a top-flight college football team is in the same class with a crack professional club long has been a hypothetical puzzler in the category of how many angels can dance on the point of a needle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The mine owners who have been conferring for the last few days with Secretary Ickes charged today, in a memorandum to Fred M. Vinson, Stabilization Director, that "producers of 40 per cent of the nation's coal tonnage will fold up" unless the Government makes an upward adjustment in the controlled price of coal to compensate for higher costs and the expenses of Government operation.

The 15,000,000 figure was used by Chester Bowles, OPA chief, at a recent press conference, and I confirmed it from Department of Commerce sources. This figure includes heads of families and was not intended as meaning only heads of families.

New municipal financing next week will be the largest in several weeks, with seventeen communities throughout the country offering new issues aggregating $15,567,000. This compares with this week's total of $6,076,900, according to the Daily Bond Buyer, and with the weekly average of the year thus far of $15,616,412.

Edward S. Jackson Jr. of this city, amateur champion of United States Chess Federation, and Ariel Mengarini of Washington, the two seeded players, who did not participate in the preliminaries, were among four victors in the opening round of the second annual amateur championship play last night at the Manhattan Chess Club.

Ernest Friedlander, Viennese 'cellist, was heard in his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. The exacting program started with the Bach unaccompanied suite in G major, followed by the Brahms sonata in F major and the sonata in B minor of Kodaly for 'cello alone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Department of Commerce today provided a picture of the tremendous scope of business casualties during the war period, as Secretary Jesse Jones called upon Government and private initiative to cooperate in the interest of permitting "small enterprise to retain its rightful place in our traditional system of competitive capitalism."

The reports of Mr. Hull and Mr. Eden and the article in Izvestia revealing the views presented by Mr. Molotoff on the reorganization of Europe serve to give a pretty clear idea of the scope and limitations of the Moscow Conference. The Four-Power Declaration was an agreement to agree.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- The Navy told tonight the story of the Olsens -- the saga of a one-family naval service record believed to be without parallel.

While there's life apparently there's hope. At least that seems to be the credo of Stout Steve Owen, coach of the Giants, who yesterday announced that one Hank Soar, former Giant star, had re-affiliated himself with the club.

Paratrooper George Graves is one of sixteen men in a big plane waiting to make their first jump. He writes to his parents about it in one of the selections in Harry E. Maule's "A Book of War Letters."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- A communiquee:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 19 -- After the failure of a reported attempt by Soviet Russia to exclude the world press from the conference of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) Council, more news was officially released about the negotiations than on any previous day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The proposal that Social Security taxes again be frozen at the existing rates of 1 per cent for employers and workers, instead of being allowed to increase to 2 per cent each as the existing statute would require, was made today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A record production rate of 4,694,200 barrels a day of all petroleum liquids has been recommended to the various oil-producing States as a goal for December, Petroleum Administrator Harold L. Ickes announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today a petition of the Railway Brotherhoods challenging the legality of the commission's emergency order of Sept. 11, 1942, which permitted the railroads to disregard State laws limiting the length of trains.

Activity in the cotton futures market was virtually at a standstill yesterday as traders continued to mark time pending the fate of the subsidy bill now before Congress. With futures being held to an 8-point range, the list of active old contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange reversed the upward trend of the last week and closed with losses ranging from 1 to 8 points.

Indications of a glut of cattle and poultry feed in Buffalo, N.Y., multiplied yesterday as Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced that the nine Northeastern States were moving jointly to force Washington to release sufficient feed corn to maintain milk and egg production.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Exchange transactions are predominant in the Securities and Exchange Commission's official summary of transactions in holdings of securities between Sept. 11 and Oct. 10.

Adequate medical care for all, through the establishment of health units in designated areas throughout the country, was advocated at a wartime conference on labor health security under the auspices of the health council of the American Labor party yesterday in the Hotel McAlpin.

The seventy-five labor representatives who have just completed two days of Army life at Fort Monmouth under the tutelage of a specially selected tough sergeant must have learned something. They could not, however, have penetrated the psychology of the GI infantryman, who knows he is in and can't get out.

Ben Bernie, band leader, who died in Beverly Hills, Calif., Oct. 20, last, bequeathed nearly all of his estate to his immediate family, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court. The petition valued the estate at "more than $10,000 in personal property" and "more than $1,000 in real property."

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Distribution of a dividend of twenty-seven gallons a share in whisky to stockholders of the Tom Moore Distillery Company was restrained temporarily in an injunction issued in Circuit Court today upon petition of Mrs. Esther Liebling, a stockholder.

Georges Theunis, the Belgian Ambassador; Mrs. Theunis, and Paul Henri Spaak, Belgian Minister of Foreign Affairs, who is here as head of the Belgian mission to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration conference, will sponsor a preview performance of the operetta, "The Two Misers," on the night of Dec. 7 at the Brander Matthews Theatre, 420 West 117th Street.

MR. CAMP, night city editor on The San Francisco Chronicle, has put together a good reporter's account of the marines on Bataan. "Retreat, Hell!" has the immediacy of a documentary film. Here, as in Sergei Eisenstein's cinema masterpiece, "Potemkin," are no plot and little characterization.

W.H. HUDSON'S "Green Mansions" is probably the most deeply loved romance of our time. Both in England and in America men feel for it that peculiar affection which is reserved for the few books that really interpret us to ourselves.

Two children, a 2 1/2-year-old boy and an 18-month-old girl, were abandoned yesterday at the doorway of the East Sixty-seventh Street police station. Attached to the boy's suit was a note reading: "I cannot feed them on less than one dollar a day for food."

War conditions have wiped out the emergency labor supply and the reserve mechanical equipment the city needs for snow removal purposes, Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey announced yesterday in disclosing that he might not be able "to keep the city open" in case of an "unusual winter."

ULTRA-VIOLET PISTOL -- Navy nurses are now pistol-packin' mamas of a sort. Their pistols are air-cooled and electric, and they shoot ultra-violet rays. What we have, then, are miniature ultra-violet lamps which can be used in the treatment of slow-healing wounds, abscesses, ulcers and some skin diseases.

NEW ORLEAN, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Tulane struck swiftly for three touchdowns in the third quarter today and defeated Louisiana State, 27 to 0, before an estimated crowd of 40,000. It was the first Greenie victory over the Tigers in four years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A group of Senate Republicans agreed today to submit to a party caucus a series of amendments which would make wide changes in the Service Men's Vote Bill.

In "The Crusade That Failed But Lives On," published in THE TIMES Magazine on Nov. 14, David Lawrence has revealed something of the inner greatness that characterized the late war President, Woodrow Wilson, a man firmly unshaken to the end in his faith in a vision which called for responsible participation by Americans to assume "the moral obligations of freedom and honor."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Wendell Willkie talked politics tonight with Republican leaders of Louisiana and asserted that "if Southerners would vote logically, I think I would come nearest representing their political beliefs."

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- For the third night in a row heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force last night pounded the war chemical industry of Germany. Their specific target was Leverkusen, a suburb of Cologne, where one of the most important works in the Reich making ingredients for poison gases is situated.

Buying in the various wholesale markets tapered off last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell company. However, there were still quite a few ready-to-wear buyers here placing spring commitments, the report noted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Arms production in October scored its greatest gain since April, with aircraft output reaching a high record of 8,362 planes, Donald M. Nelson reported today. Measured by dollar value, October production advanced 5 per cent from September.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 20 -Northwestern, beaten only by Michigan and Notre Dame, ended a successful football campaign today by walloping Illinois' youngsters, 53 to 6, before 25,000 spectators in Dyche Stadium.
Hailed by critics of Chicago and Los Angeles as one of the top musical skating shows ever staged, the Ice Follies of 1944 will begin its New York stand Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.

The saddest, dreariest, most heartbreaking aspect of modern war is not battle, in which the soldier has literally a fighting chance. It is among civilians in occupied areas. Old people and children suffer most, and of those two groups the children are the most sorrowful spectacle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -The Administration's price-control machinery faced another challenge today, a threat to remove coal and oil from the jurisdiction of the Office of Price Administration.

AT this vast waterfront installation, which for reasons of military security must remain nameless, hundreds of women, night and day, are helping to move the great freight loads whose constant and timely delivery to our armies makes their fighting possible and brings victory nearer.

Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, and his advisers have sent to Governor Dewey a report suggesting changes in New York corporation taxes. The changes are designed not to increase revenue but to collect it more fairly.

THANKSGIVING is our traditional American feast day. The table where family and friends foregather expresses the gratitude and hopes of men and women in the armed forces abroad who remember past Thanksgivings at home and like to think that we are still cherishing the occasion.

Christmas shopping came into the retail picture in decided fashion last week and increased percentage gains over last year for many stores. Department store volume on the average exceeded 1942 figures by 15 per cent or more, it was estimated, with many individual stores going well ahead of this figure.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Sir Oswald E. Mosley, British pre-war Fascist leader, and Lady Diana Mosley slipped out of Holloway prison before daylight this morning on order of Herbert Morrison, British Home Secretary. It is not known where they went or what conditions were laid down by the government.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 20 -- Michigan's Navy-Marine studded team routed Ohio State, 45 -- 7, to clinch a share of the Western Conference football championship with Purdue in a season finale witnessed by 45,000 today.

HAVING promised King Feisal to tell the Arabs only the truth about themselves, Dr. Van Ess, American missionary who founded one of the most interesting of Iraq's schools, proceeded to write a friendly, indeed a complimentary book.
Federal and State officials looked searchingly into the country's fast emptying liquor barrel during the week and found among its dregs something which resembled the bootlegger of Prohibition.

LOS ANGELES -- Southern California's beaches, mountains, desert and communities arc continuing their traditional hospitality this winter. But the area's wartime guests are wearing the blue, khaki and olive green of Uncle Sam's services.

Mrs. Roger Wisner will give a tea tomorrow afternoon at her home, 79 East Seventy-ninth Street, for a group of women serving with her on the committee in charge of arrangements for the performance of "A Connecticut Yankee" on the night of Dec. 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Congressional tax authorities discovered today that the Ways and Means Committee, in effect, had put a premium on June brides and spring babies.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 20 -- Any doubts as to the majestic stature of the Notre Dame football team of 1943 melted today in the crucible of one of the great grid-iron games of this or any other season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The United States as early as 1936 suspected that Japan might be fortifying her mandated islands in the Pacific in violation of the Washington Naval Treaty, and tried in vain to find if the suspicions were true, the State Department revealed tonight in a new document of diplomatic records tracing our diplomatic relations with Japan.

A hundred trade union delegates, attending a conference called by the Victory Committee of German-American Trade Unionists to devise ways of helping German workers fight the Nazis, endorsed yesterday the proposal to hold a mass meeting of German-Americans in January in New York to demonstrate their unity with all Americans in the struggle against the Axis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- New seasonal high prices were established today for all deliveries of wheat and rye futures and July oats on the Board of Trade as the buying movement that developed earlier in the week gained momentum. There was a broad demand for wheat futures headed by houses with cash connections and regarded as reflecting liberal sales of actual grain to distillers.
THANKSGIVING dinner gets off to a good start when it is begun with this delicious soup:

BELFAST, NORTHERN IRELAND, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The police put an unspectacular end today to the spectacular activities of Hugh McAteer, Irish rebel leader who slid down a rope of bedsheets to escape from a Belfast prison last January after serving two months of a fifteen-year sentence for treason.

NO one, least of all Augustus, can tell what he is going to do next, but in spite of his natural talent for mischief it always turns out to be something good. In this case it is the Marines to whom, having already helped the Army and Navy, he extends his services with admirable impartiality.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- A plan under which the Cities Service Power and Light Company would receive from its subsidiary, the Public Service Company of Colorado, 875,000 shares of common stock with an aggregate par value of $17,500,000 for sale to the public was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- Best among 921 dogs in the forty-ninth show of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia in Convention Hall today was the superb golden fawn boxer bitch, Champion El Wendie of Rockland, owned by the Rye Top Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Crystal of Harrison and handled by Nate Levino.

W.B. Kirby, shipwright leader-man of the Houston Shipbuilding Corporation of Houston, Tex., an affiliate of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, has perfected a new vessel-launching device which achieves a saving of 400 man-hours and 3,378 feet of lumber every time a Liberty ship is sent down the ways, it was announced last Week by the company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Navy has canceled its contract with the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation for the production of bombers, at the request of Henry J. Kaiser, recently named president.

Mayor La Guardia told several hundred persons attending a youth forum yesterday at the Hotel Astor that "the overwhelming majority of the young people of this city are sound and good and we are proud of them." The Mayor put great emphasis on his words, as if he meant them as a defense of recent charges of widespread juvenile delinquency.

Stocks extended their gains yesterday in the broadest and most active Saturday session of the New York Stock Exchange since Sept. 18. Deals were 481,976 shares, and 744 issues were traded. Of these, 471 rose, 115 fell and 158 were unchanged. Bond dealings of $6,066,100 on the Exchange also were the largest since mid-September.

Once again the New York Rangers will try to gain the victory column in the National Hockey League. Beaten eight times in as many league starts this season, the Blueshirts, figuring that such a condition can't go on forever, will seek to snap their string of reverses at the expense of the Maple Leafs in Madison Square Garden tonight.
MARSILIO FICINO, philosopher, translator, alchemist, teacher and one of the foremost minds of the Renaissance has long waited for a "more complete and more methodical analysis of his thought."

With many young women of society planning to be formally introduced at the Grosvenor Debutante Ball on Dec. 4 at the Ritz-Carlton, frequent committee meetings are being held to arrange various details of the event, which will benefit Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

FOR years our musicians and critics have debated the question of opera and songs in English versus the original language in which they were written. No other country that I know has developed so delicate a musical conscience with respect to this issue.

TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The driver of a private automobile was killed and twenty-five passengers of a crowded Public Service bus were injured in a collision at Arlington and Forest Avenues here this evening.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- Penn State's Nittany Lions, led by Bill Abromitis, an ex-Pitt star, and wo Marine trainees who had joined the team only three weeks ago, struck for two first-half touchdowns today to down the Pitt Panthers, 14 to 0, before a crowd of 15,000.

HOLLYWOOD, which up to now has modestly used the screen to dramatize the altruistic attributes of the people within the industry, is making an about-face in this regard in two pictures now in preparation. These are the forthcoming Twentieth Century-Fox film "Four Jills and a Jeep" and Warner Brothers' proposed "Hollywood Canteen," each of which will pay tribute to the contribution which screen personalities are making toward the entertainment of the armed forces.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWESTERN PACIFIC, Sunday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Tank-paced Australian soldiers are continuing to move slowly ahead against Japanese entrenched in hilly country around Sattelberg on the Huon Peninsula of northeastern New Guinea, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's spokesman said today.

THE new organization called Tomorrow's Masterpieces, which is marketing art through special galleries in department stores, R.H. Macy Co., being the sponsor of the New York activities, has just opened its second exhibition on the ninth floor of that store with an even more diverse and well sustained show than the highly successful opening exhibition.

BECAUSE of the illness that kept him from leading the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last Sunday, Bruno Walter was unable to be present at last week's early rehearsals at the Metropolitan Opera House of "Tristan und Isolde," which he was scheduled to lead there next Wednesday night.
" THE DARK STAIN" treats a serious political problem. about which its author obviously feels deeply, in a form or mode which is not serious artistically. The results are doubly instructive.
ALGIERS, Nov. 20 -- Slogging through mud and whipped by incessant cold rain, the British Eighth Army gained four to five miles on the Sangro River front yesterday to capture the village of Perano.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Three touchdowns by Ed Faillace, all on end runs behind the perfect blocking of Franny Notch, paced White Plains High in a 27-to-12 football conquest of New Rochelle today. Notch took a 17-yard pass from Walt Piebes and raced 8 yards for the other White Plains touchdown.

The executive committee of the United Construction Workers, affiliate of District 50 of the United Mine Workers of America, will meet this afternoon in Irving Plaza Hall, 15 Irving Place, to discuss future action in its threatened strike of custodial workers in the city's 800 elementary and high schools.

ASIDE from naval victories and the Battle of New Orleans, the United States made a rather dismal showing in the War of 1812. The record seems to have been as bad on the home front as in the field. Many citizens, even among those who went privateering against British commerce, viewed the war simply as a chance to make money and chose their parts accordingly.

Former King Carol of Rumania, who hired two press agents to pave the way for his desired entry into the United States, will make his radio debut from Mexico City Tuesday night on a Columbia Broadcasting System program along with Dr. Louis Bozin, leader of an anti-Carol faction in America. Dr. Bozin will speak from Detroit.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 20 -- The chance of getting in a winter's supply of unrationed meat, coupled with the fact that the first legal season on does since 1919 means an abundance of legal game, drew a record number of hunters -- an estimated 150,000 -- to the Wisconsin woods this week as the deer season opened.
GREAT LAKES, Ill., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Bluejackets warmed up for their finale with Notre Dame next week by trouncing a hard-fighting Marquette team today, 25 to 6.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 20 -- A horse named Navy and an Army boy brought a crowd of 13,500 up standing at Rockingham Park today as the 7-year-old son of Annapolis dashed through the stretch to victory in the Loudon Purse under Euclid Le Blanc, having his last ride before he dons khaki.
MOST civilians have never heard of the man who is probably the most famous private in the whole United States Army.

The annual fall review of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, New York Guard, was held last night at the Armory, Twenty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue. Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, a lieutenant in World War I and a postwar captain in the "Fighting Sixty-ninth," was guest of honor, reviewing the troops and presenting awards to twelve officers and men.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -Minnesota defeated Wisconsin today, 25 to 13, to wind up its Big Ten season with a record of two victories and three losses.

Paul A. Curtis, an American gunnery expert who recently resigned as a captain in the British Army, shot and killed himself at 12:31 P.M. yesterday in the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Gahagan at 277 Park Avenue.

WHEN the story opens, there has already been one murder within the grounds of the Steane mansion near a Southern Army camp. The coroner's jury has turned in a verdict of suicide, but the District Attorney is not convinced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -George W. Healy Jr., managing editor of The New Orleans Times-Picayune, has been selected to succeed Palmer Hoyt as Director of Domestic Operations of the Office of War Information.

The Office of Price Administration announced in Washington last night that it planned next month to reward housewives who turn in salvaged fats to their retailers with two meat-ration stamps a pound in addition to the standard price of four cents.

FOR Henry W. Longfellow the Children's Hour came "between the dark and the daylight, when the night is beginning to lower," and its principal sound effect was the patter of little feet.
