For some millions of American children, age 7 and up, it now starts about 5 P.M. with the whine of machine-gun fire spilling out of a loudspeaker.

There is considerable discussion these days lending support to the dubious doctrine of "Europe for the Europeans." Such propaganda generally takes the form of "Leave Europe alone after the war and everything will be all right." Yet the very character of the war shows us that Europe needs outside help to get back on her own feet.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- A communique:...

The opposition of Postmaster General Frank C. Walker to the Lynch bill, which would bar from the mails matter inciting hatred against persons for their religion, race or national origin, was criticized by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Nov. 20 -- The University of Notre Dame is criticized as yielding to the pressure of "crypto-fascists in "the dismissal" of Prof. Francis E. McMahon in an editorial in today's issue of The Florida Catholic, publication of the diocese of St. Augustine, of which the Most Rev. Joseph P. Hurley is Bishop.

After the Casablanca Conference, in January of this year, the detailed plans for Allied offensives in the Mediterranean began to crystallize. Combat vessels to support these landing operations were available. Troop transports could be made available in the required numbers.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- Governor Dewey today appointed Edward Corsi, chairman of the State Industrial Board and former Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization at Ellis Island, as State Industrial Commissioner. Mr. Corsi succeeds Acting Commissioner Michael J. Murphy in the $12,000-a-year post.

I HAD read this book in manuscript and, seeing it again printed, its charm is no surprise. I had longed for the first glimpse of the finished pages and now I have been cogitating for a bit of poetry to set forth and to describe the way it affects me.

Capt. Peter J. Sigona, skipper of a tanker, is a man of few words. But there was an occasion in the recent past when Captain Sigona uttered a few significant commands on the high seas which resulted in highly expert maneuvering in avoiding several torpedo attacks from a Nazi submarine and the safe voyage into port with a 75,000-barrel cargo of valuable Navy fuel oil.

Ethelbert Smith said that the main outlines of post-war American education are already clear, though the details remain to be filled in. Broadly speaking, it will be an educational system in which the little girls in school will read books on the phase theory of electronics and atmospheric pressure in wind tunnels, and candidates for Ph.D. will read "Gulliver's Travels."

WEBSTER proves of no phenomenal assistance -- that is, does not provide us with any too specific definition covering the newest thesis at the Museum of Modern Art, where a large exhibition called "Romantic Painting in America" got under way last week.

I HAVE just spent a day with the Herrenvolk. As one of the few journalists privileged to visit one of the closely guarded American internment camps for German prisoners of war I have seen more than 1,000 husky young Nazis at work and at play, inspected their comfortable living quarters and well-filled kitchens, and learned something of their attitude toward the war.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- J.B. De Haven, president of Allied Mills, Inc., today informed stockholders that the company expects to receive about $27,000,000 from its proposed sale of the entire capital stock of the Century Distilling Company to the National Distillers Products Corporation. In a letter to the stockholders he called a special meeting of them for Dec. 8 to vote upon the sale.

OVER the border in Canada all the talk these days seems to be about the Royal Canadian Navy show, "Meet the Navy," which is now on a trans-Canada tour and which, like all good service shows, expects eventually to go abroad.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 20 -- The Duke Blue Devils, held in check for a period and a half by a stubborn North Carolina defense, Broke loose with a four-touchdown barrage today for a 27-to-6 victory over the Tarheels that clinched the Southern Conference title and the nation's top - scoring lead for Coach Eddie Cameron's charges.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has published a valuable study showing the accumulation of post-war reserves by the five largest corporations in each of fifty basic industries. Up to the end Of 1942, 146 corporations had set aside $515,000,000, while the other 104 corporations had established no reserves for this purpose.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With programs for the holiday planned by many hotels, Thanksgiving will draw an influx of visitors, according to advance reservations. Members of the British Navy stationed at "H.M.S. Asbury" are joining in the American feast as guests of residents and hotel managers.

With the fall semester well under way, reports from colleges and universities throughout the country indicate that there is a greater student interest in the study of American history than in previous years. In many institutions a record number of students are taking courses in the history and government of this nation.

Edward S. Jackson Jr. of the Manhattan Club, national amateur champion, defeated F.H. Squire Jr. of Brooklyn in a Sicilian defense lasting thirty-three moves for his third straight in the amateur championship finals of the United States Chess Federation at the Manhattan rooms last night.

TARO YASHIMA has been an anti-Fascist ever since he could think -- and in a country where independence of thought does not go unpunished. For years he fought against internal suppression and military aggression in Japan.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20 -- Military operations in the Balkan Peninsula are becoming increasingly imminent and perhaps much to everyone's surprise the greatest threat to the tenuous German hold on the unfortunate occupied lands of that area and the surly satellites suddenly looms from the east.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- A communique:

After meetings held on Thursday and Friday, the American Merchants Marine Institute, comprising sixty-two major steamship companies, released yesterday a resolution calling for the adoption of H.R. 3421, a bill introduced by Representative Alfred L. Bulwinkle of North Carolina.

THERE is one thing which should by now be obvious to anyone who makes (or sees) war-action films, and that is the air of actuality which an actor who is unfamiliar brings to a picture wherein the other actors (or some of them) are old and recognized hands.

ALGIERS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The French Committee of National Liberation will comply with a British demand that Jean Helleu be replaced as Delegate General in Lebanon, but still refuses to reinstall Riad Sohl as Lebanese President, a person close to the committee said tonight.

Mount St. Michael's unbeaten and untied football team routed Curtis High of Staten Island by 43 -- 6 yesterday at McGovern Field in the Bronx for its ninth straight success. Coach Howe Smith's players launched a brilliant ground offensive in the second quarter.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- Governor Dewey postponed today for a third time the executions of Louis Capone and Emanuel Weiss for the 1936 slaying of Joseph Rosen, Brooklyn florist, because, he said, their erstwhile leader and convicted fellow-slayer, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, was "protected from punishment by the failure of the President of the United States to grant the customary conditional pardon."

NOT every gardener has a pool or a rose bed or even a vegetable garden, but one thing is inescapable -- the foundation planting, or use of shrubs, trees and vines close to the house. This planting serves a number of purposes, chief among them that of providing a setting for the house and of bringing dwelling and garden together.

Charged with dealing in gasoline ration coupons stolen from the up town office of the Office of Price Administration, 1130 St. Nicholas Avenue, on Oct. 6, two men appeared yesterday morning in the line-up at Police Headquarters where one identified himself as Edward Gaeta, 37 years old, machinist's helper.

ALGIERS, Nov. 20 -- This story is respectfully and gratefully dedicated to all those wives, mothers, fathers, aunts, cousins, grandmothers and sweethearts back home who have been sending packages to their relatives overseas. This town is already bursting with such packages.

Bootleggers and speakeasies throughout the State are doing a thriving business and dabblers in the black market are waxing wealthy as a result of the drought of legalized ryes, Scotches and bourbons in taverns and package stores, Rudy Marwede, president of the New York State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, charged yesterday.

A good watch and a sheet of simple instructions are all that shipwrecked men adrift at sea need for navigation, said Dr. Charles H. Smiley (Brown University) in a General Electric science forum. The men in distress watch for the sun as it rises and note the time. Next they note the time of sunset.

The record of the West Side Iron Works, 801 Greenwich Street, in providing iron skeleton decks, or spar deck structures that permit the safe carriage of deck cargo, for about 7,000 vessels of all Allied nationalities, without once causing a ship to miss her convoy, was told yesterday by Joseph Yellen Jr., president of the company.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 20 -- Robert G. Casey, British Minister of State in the Middle East, gave his idea of the gravity of his mission here yesterday, although he declined to specify in what ways it had been necessitated "by the urgency of the political situation."

Resentful over the National War Labor Board's refusal to approve wage increases negotiated with their employers, 500 workers in the yarn dye industry yesterday overrode suggestions by union leaders that they abide by the regular thirty-day "cooling off" period and voted to strike tomorrow morning.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Louisiana State University's all-civilian football team will play in the tenth annual Orange Bowl game here on New Year's Day.

I HAVE been told that several experts in archaeology and art historians were sent to Italy from this country and from England to assist an expedition to bring to safety Italy's masterworks of art and to help to restore those damaged during the war.

SOME quickening developed in holiday trade in the week which led retailers to believe that the business will close with the usual rush in spite of efforts to spread it out. Demand and buying power assure another record Christmas volume dependent only upon whether supplies will meet the buying surge.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Attorney General Biddle issued this statement today concerning the case of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter:

LONDON, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Walsall, a little club from the Midlands, turned giant-killer in its thirteenth game of the English soccer season, downing mighty West Bromwich Albion by 2 -- 0 today for its first victory in the Northern League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, was graduated to his prominent post from the confines of a "district office" of the same agency. Because the district over which Mr. Bowles presided so successfully for more than a year comprises an entire State, Connecticut, his post was accorded the dignity of a "State" office.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin's First Ukraine Army, knocking out more than half the enemy's attacking tank strength and mowing down his infantry with artillery and trench mortars, turned back German thrusts near Korostyshev yesterday, halting the Nazi drive into the Zhitomir salient west of Kiev.

Extension of "democracy in trade unions" and elimination of discrimination where it still exists are advocated in an eighty-eight-page report released yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union, copies of which are being sent to union leaders and Federal and State officials throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- War contractors and subcontractors who are dissatisfied with the results of governmental renegotiation of their contracts would receive the right of appeal to the Tax Court of the United States under an amendment to the Renegotiation Law proposed today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

SOME who came of age before the first World War may recall the name, if not the career, of Ole Bull. Few are likely to remember that Ibsen based his "Peer Gynt" on the career of this picturesque Norwegian.

THERE is a magic in the merry-go-round that all children feel and that grownups find hard to forget. Elizabeth Foster's story, which sets forth the life of Gigi, a merry-go-round horse, from his imperial days in the Wurstelprater in Vienna through many experiences and vicissitudes till he joins the gypsies and becomes the chief splendor of the merry-go-round with which they travel about the country, is one that child and adult can enjoy together.

WHAT makes Mr. Thurber a great humorist is that he isn't kidding. You may learn from him practically everything, except why on earth one should go on living -- but after half an hour with James Thurber you are much too exhausted to ask such a profound question.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 20 -- Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain continued to retain full governing powers in Vichy today but did not exercise them.
For the first time in the memory of New York City hospital authorities Thanksgiving Day will be observed generally without the traditional turkey dinners.

THAT old story about the stork will disappear in Great Britain if local school authorities listen to the Board of Education. Simple, sensible answers to children's questions on sex, from an early age, are advised in an official pamphlet recently issued for use in a new course for teachers, leaders of youth groups, and ultimately in parent-teacher meetings throughout the country.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister of Aircraft Production, warned the country today against reverting to the old idea that the State should merely provide employment by means of public works and declared there should be post-war Government controls very much like those presently existing if there were to be a "New Britain."

A delegation, minus wrinkles but full of facts, arrived in town this week-end with a message from a small New England community on how to combat juvenile delinquency. The week-end is all it can spare. Tomorrow, its members must return to school to minding the neighbors' children, to putting the wood in cellars and raking lawns

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Inventories of retail hardware dealers have declined in recent weeks in comparison with the already low volume of last summer, but there is better than a mere possibility that this situation will improve after the first of the year.

Probably million of skeptics are now convinced that Magician Dunninger has telepathic powers. In his broadcasts he infallibly "mind-reads" what is written on a piece of paper to which he supposedly has no access. For Dunninger, it must be said that in the past he has pooh-poohed telepathy and that at intervals in his program he makes it reasonably clear that he is performing tricks.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 20 -- From out of the West came a golden retriever to shatter all precedent today in the history of the Labrador Retriever Club. At the conclusion of the annual field trial meeting of that organization, Gerald M. Livingston presented his own President's Trophy to Mahlon B. Wallace Jr. of St. Louis, emblematic of Field Trial Champion Whitebridge Wally's victory in the open all-age stake.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- In the fight against uncontrolled price inflation there is no secondary line of defense to which the Office of Price Administration can retire if Congress rejects its program for continuation of a "limited" food price control subsidy program, Chester Bowles, OPA chief, told a press conference today.

THE stage is set for one of those great occasions on which history hinges. Preparations have long been under way for a meeting of the three men who are the spokesmen and the symbols of the three most powerful nations on earth. Since the Moscow conference of their Foreign Secretaries it has been clear to all the world that they have an appointment with one another -- and with destiny.

Immediate action for implementation of the Moscow agreements was urged in a report presented yesterday by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace, headed by Prof. James T. Shotwell of Columbia University, at an all-day conference in the Hotel Commodore.

The contemporary literatures of thirty European countries are being reviewed and recorded in a single volume of 800 pages, Prof. Horatio Smith, head of Columbia University's Romance Languages Department and general editor of the project, announced yesterday.

Hearing from George Bernard Shaw is like getting a letter dated 1910 or 1960, one is not sure which. It takes one's mind off the rest of the day's news. Mr. Shaw, interviewed by a lady journalist in London, says that the feminist movement has so far overshot itself that "it is men who are handicapped now."

The frosty days of late November saw steam rising from the scalding barrel and butcher knives whetted razor-sharp in those pre-ration days of not so long ago. For this was, and in a few fortunate places still is, hog-butcherin' time, when the winter's supply of pork was prepared for smoke house, pickling tub and sausage jar.

LONDON Nov. 20 -- The German Air Force's night blows against London now are as nothing compared with those during the latter half of 1940, but the qualifying adjective "nuisance" is hardly an accurate description of them. The end results of the present operations may not be so spectacular nor so obvious as the earlier ones, but they do considerably more than annoy.

ALGIERS, Nov. 20 -- Master Sgt. Ira Gordon of Hunter, New York, a member of a bombardment group at an advanced base in this theatre, learned by mail that the election for town supervisor had ended in a tie. The townsfolk eagerly awaited the decision -- and the sergeant's absentee ballot is now en route.

THE attention of the philatelic world will center next Friday, Saturday and Sunday on Washington, where the Pan-American Centenary of the Postage Stamp will be celebrated under the joint sponsorship of the Pan American Union and the American Philatelic Congress.

IN future years the amazing series of events between October, 1942, when Rommel's panzers were still threatening the British line at E1 Alamein, and May, 1943, when the last organized Axis resistance crumbled on the Cap Bon peninsula, will undoubtedly be regarded as one of the great turning points of World War II.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 7, Ernst Karl Winter, former Deputy Mayor of Vienna, wrote from his viewpoint as Catholic partisan and active in the Anti-Anschluss movement since 1918. May I, as an Austrian editor who confesses to have been a militant adherent of the Anschluss even before 1918 and up to Hitler's seizure of power in Germany, comment on some of Mr. Winter's assertions?

CHUNGKING, China, Sunday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today the Japanese lost more than 4,000 killed out of a force of 18,000 men in a continuing battle in which the Japanese seized Tzeli, a highway town ninety miles south of the Yangtze River port of Ichang.

Certain tools have always accompanied man since he made the epochal discovery that metals could be fused and wrought into useful implements. The axe is a tool which has hewn history. Many men today, in the country and in the city, delight in the "feel" of a good axe.

WHEN I was 19 I thought I was, and maybe I was, in love with an awfully pretty girl who lived in Rochester. She must have been smart as well as pretty because she married a fellow who lived in Birmingham.

The standard proposal drafted by the War Production Board, originally intended for use by all procurement agencies now terminating war contracts either partially or completely, reached industry executives here last week along with "pipeline" rumors from Washington that this particular project may never mature beyond its current stage.

THAT there is more talent in the dance world than is being used advantageously is a fact kept pretty continuously in evidence by the persistence with which this talent attempts to put itself to advantageous, use.

THERE is nothing mysterious about war except our age-long delay in preventing it. Wars and fears of war will keep on until we are sensible enough to take militant, effective measures to put an end to them.

Last week marked the fourth anniversary of the closing of 600-year-old Charles University of Prague and the other Czechoslovak universities by the Nazis, following the reprisals against the display of national independence by the Czech students.
H.M. Post's letter "Sir Walter Did Write It" gives an amusing story of Professor Sir Walter Raleigh, but whether authentic or not can only be imagined.

Putting on a withering first-half attack that brought three touchdowns, Boys High's football team beat its time-honored foe, Erasmus Hall, 26 to 12, in the thirty-ninth battle between the schools at Boys High Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. A crowd of 6,000 watched the Red and Black turn back Erasmus for the first time since 1940.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A mystery explosion wrecked a five-story building in London's night club belt of Soho last night and for a while had Londoners discussing the possibility that the Germans had employed one of their oft-threatened "secret weapons."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Director General Herbert H. Lehman of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) has won his first big fight to keep his powers as head of this first post-war international operating agency from being limited to such an extent that he could not carry out his policies for equitable and economical administration of world relief.

Fans with an appetite for professional football fare will have a double menu from which to choose today. The play-for-pay experts will be operating on two local fronts, with the Giants meeting the downtrodden Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds and the Dodgers taking on the formidable Green Bay Packers at Ebbets Field.

THE importance of antiques as a background for today's craft work is illustrated in the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries which opens tomorrow morning at the Madison Square Garden. Although crafts of yesterday play only a small part in the exhibition, they emphasize by contrast with a wealth of modern-made examples the continuity of women's activities in embroidery, ruff making, weaving and other traditi0nall fields.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES TASK GROUP FLAGSHIP OFF BOUGAINVILLE, Solomons, Nov. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- The American naval task force raid on Buka demonstrates the Japanese won't be able to get the bulk of their estimated 40,000 troops off Bougainville Island, the commander of the task force said here today.

One of the definite trends in banking is that of increasing bank capital in order to preserve some semblance of the time-honored one-to-ten ratio of capital funds to rapidly increasing deposits. Dozens of banks throughout the country have increased their capital and surplus accounts, but it appears that twelve major banks of the land continue to get along with only 50 per cent paid-in capital; namely the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System.

For centuries colchicum, which is obtained from the corn or seeds of the meadow saffron, has been a standard remedy for gout. The modern derivative is colchicine, which is so poisonous that single doses are usually limited to about 1/120th of a grain. In the last ten years colchicine has been the subject of study in the hope that it may prove of value in the treatment of cancer.

May I take exception to the following phrase in the editorial "Anniversary for Russia": "Nevertheless, they (Americans) have reason to be glad that our ally on the Eastern Front today is a people and not the corrupt and inept Government of the Romanoffs."

The crack-down of the Government on black-market citrus fruit dealers continued yesterday, as an information was filed here in the United States District Court against Peter Martori's Sons, Inc., of 338 Washington Street, and the company's vice president, Stephen Martori, accusing the defendants of violating maximum Office of Price Administration ceiling prices and failing to maintain records for Federal inspection.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- While a reconnaissance contingent of Navy Scouts, headed by Keith Molesworth, looked on and shuddered, the Army football team trampled Brown University today, rolling up the highest total by a Cadet eleven in years.

IRELAND is the matriarch's promised land. There every woman is heiress to her own apotheosis; she is both saint and hagiolater. Her virtue is unquestioned. Her sorrows, multitudinous and varied, are celebrated in song and in story -from Deirdre to Brigit to Mina Purefoy.

To an anxious world whose anticipation of victory over the evil forces of Germany and Japan is already being clouded by fear of the complexities of the peace, the exposition of the results of the Moscow Conference laid before Congress last week by Secretary Hull is like a beacon light.

A yearly increase of $500 each for members of the New York City teaching staff to meet increased costs of living, was urged yesterday by the joint committee of teachers organizations, representing the seventy local school associations with a total membership of 30,000. The joint committee

A PECULIAR fate has dogged the writings of Miss Strong. She hitched her wagon to the Soviet star in 1920, but as it has zigzagged across the horizon of our times her wagon has generally been one zig or zag behind. In 1927 she wrote a glowing account of Trotsky just as he fell from grace.

Five hundred prison officials and correction workers from all parts of the country were told yesterday at the annual convention of the American Prison Association that they had better start thinking about the type of prisons to be built when the war ends, because of an expected large increase in the prison population, especially if there are economic dislocations.

Laundry problems being what they are, the apron-wearing fashion for girls is welcomed by mothers, and both making and wearing are encouraged at centers of the Play Schools Association (which has a new address; 119 West Fifty-seventh Street).

Seventeen-year-old Norris Arthur Edward Thornton, a slight, sandy-haired British seaman from Hull, England, sat in a doctor's office yesterday afternoon at the Marine Hospital, Ellis Island, and heard his 8-year-old sister, Sylvia, sing his favorite song to him by short-wave from London.

Only one untapped substantial source of Federal revenue appears to remain open to the Congress. And this column ventures the opinion that if the fiscal situation could be wholly divested of political considerations, the general retail sales tax could be enacted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace is declared by political leaders here to be carrying on a unique campaign for renomination as Vice President on the personal assumption that President Roosevelt will be a candidate for a fourth term.

LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The huge Lowell ordnance plant of the Remington Arms Company, which has been manufacturing 50-caliber shells for the Army since April 2, 1942, will close before Dec. 31, the Army announced today, because the Army has enough ammunition "for any crisis, however unexpected."

BEFORE selecting the 300 poems in "The Triumph of Life," Horace Gregory obviously read with patience and love through whole libraries of English poetry -- and made such demands on his authors that, simply as a demonstration of poetry, his anthology is a delight to explore.

THE late Dr. Luhr organized his book as a series of related short subjects, much like the exhibits of a well-ordered museum. Within each of these subjects he explains some principle of physics. "What is Polaroid?"

When Dr. Koussevitzky appeared on the stage of Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra he announced briefly that the concert would be prefaced by two national hymns, not one. The first would be the Russian national anthem. The second would be America's.

THE fans, aficionados, collectors and addicts of Sally Benson's New Yorker artifacts will find thirty-eight of them in "Women and Children First." A "garland" and "one-woman show," according to its publishers, the book is an arrangement of short contes dedicated to the modish principle that the action of human character is best revealed by a lack of character and of action.

" HISTORY," says the author, "sped across the West as fast as a painted Comanche on a pony, as quickly as a cowpuncher could rope and brand a steer," and convinces us of it by the terseness and speed of the racing prose in which she tells the story of the Great Plains.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Mark up one for Iowa's Hawkeyes in big letters -- they whipped Nebraska today, 33 to 13.

HELIUM, one of the "rare elements," promises to be more plentiful since the recent discovery in New Mexico of a deposit that may prove to be the biggest in the world. And new uses for the already versatile element will probably be one result of the increased supply.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Atlantic Fishermen's Union of the American Federation of Labor today called a strike of Boston, New York and New Bedford fishermen. The business agent, Austin Powers, said it would affect about 1,900 men and tie up about 120 boats in the three ports within six days.

THE backdrop for many of today's advertisements of the world of tomorrow is a giant diagram of an electron tube. If the electron's promise of even greater, more magical wonders is kept, the layman will have to know (if only for parlor self-defense) as much about elementary electricity as he knows now about automobiles.

One hundred thousand red, white and blue badges are being distributed in the five boroughs for presentation to members of youth groups who have given at least ten hours to community war service and have pledged at least one hour a week until the war ends, Dr. Alice V. Keliher, supervisor of the Junior Citizens Service Corps in this area, announced yesterday.

Christmas shopping has accelerated rapidly throughout the country during the last two weeks and indications are numerous that holiday sales will reach a new high record in dollar volume despite merchandise shortages and personnel difficulties.

Over a long and arduous period he has had such varied experiences as washing street cars, a Town Hall recital, stoking furnaces and selling pianos to disinterested Brooklyn burghers.

Leaders of industrial management and labor have agreed to sit down together for a comprehensive, on-the-record round table discussion of the problem of post-war employment, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

PIVA RIVER FRONT LINE, Bougainville, Solomon Islands, Nov. 16 (Delayed) (AP) -- For many anxious hours the American foot-hold on Bougainville hung in the balance as the Marines' line swayed and broke once at Piva No. 4 -- the fourth native village hearing the name Piva.

MISS EMILY KIMBROUGH, setting out sturdily alone to write the sequel to "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay," has a difficult assignment to cover, and she knows it from page one. In their first book she and Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner achieved something like a miracle.

NAPLES, Nov. 6 (Delayed) -- The opinion that the question of a regency and a new government should wait until the Allies had entered Rome was expressed today by Giulio Rodino di Miglione, head of the Christian Democratic party.

The harriers of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High maintained that school's monopoly on the private school cross-country championship when five of them finished in the first ten in the twenty-second annual running of this event over the two-and-a-quarter-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

BIRDS which can be attracted and encouraged during the winter make up in some measure by their liveliness for the quiet monotone of the garden. More and more people are experiencing the thrill of having wild birds drop in at their feeding stations for an informal call and friendly chat over the tray.

JOSE DE CREEFT'S monumental head of Rachmaninoff, in his current show at Georgette Passedoit's Gallery, may be safely designated as one of the outstanding pieces of the sculptor's career. The portrait in beaten lead, a medium de Creeft has made peculiarly his own, is one outstanding artist's tribute to another.

A recent survey asked a thousand different women what luxury they would miss most if governmental restrictions took it away. They were given a choice of several "unessential" commodities including sheer stockings, face powder, and ice cream sodas.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 20 -- Joe Marhefka Jr., son of a halfback on Lafayette's 1921 team, today paced the Maroon to a 9-2 victory over Rutgers in a Middle Three game before a crowd of 7,000.

Pulling away from their rivals in the late stages of the game, the City College basketball team inaugurated its season successfully at its home gym last night. Facing the Columbia Midshipmen's quintet, composed of graduate stars from several universities, the Beavers showed late strength to register a 43-to-37 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States on Tuesday will inaugurate a series of eight weekly public radio forums, entitled "America Tomorrow," at which top leaders of the national economy will participate.

HERE is a brew of reminiscence, bright incident and sensuous enjoyment of food by the author of "How to Cook a Wolf" -- a brew with sufficient flavor to delight the gourmet and enough intelligent observation to hold other connoisseurs as well.
Criminal statistics reveal a steady increase in juvenile crime and delinquency, the Youth Counsel Bureau, office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, reported yesterday in its annual survey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Further improvement in the WPB's allotment of carbon steel and other necessary controlled materials for domestic transportation for the first quarter of next year under the controlled-materials plan was noted today by the ODT.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Jan Kwapinski, Deputy Prime Minister of the Polish Government-in-exile and member of the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, revealed today that an UNRRA subcommittee is considering a plan to levy on post-war Germany for contributions to the UNRRA pool of supplies for the relief and reconstruction of liberated countries.

LONDON. THE British forgot that they were supposed to be reticent. "The show is a riot," announced The London Daily Mail. "'This Is the Army,'" remarked The Daily Herald, with fine disregard for the King's English, "knocked London sideways."

The operating statement of the Electric Auto-Lite Company and its subsidiaries, announced yesterday to stockholders, disclosed for the first nine months this year a net profit of $3,754,076, subject to renegotiation, equal to $3.14 a share.
German and Italian medical specialists attending Benito Mussolini in a north Italian retreat are amazed at the rapidity with which he has regained his health, the Berlin radio declared yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho's statement that Mexico's farmers should abstain from politics and concentrate on production was said today to have been prompted by the government's desire to obtain greater collaboration from them. Farmers are experiencing the worst agricultural year in a century.

IT is with a kind of happy despair that one attempts to review adequately a volume as sensitive and significant as this by Walter Horton. IN "Men of Maryknoll" Father Keller and Meyer Berger write of missioners and their odd and painful way of life -- of the curious selflessness of their satisfactions -- of the stubbornness with which they persist, in the face of war, in their knowledge that there is more happiness in giving than in receiving.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Nov. 18 (AP) -- When General Douglas MacArthur's communique of Oct. 10 said "thirty-seven of seventy interceptors were shot down with twenty more damaged and only one of our planes was unable to return to its base," it sounded fantastic. And it was fantastic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The original conception of lend-lease has grown into the much broader idea of pooling all resources for the common job, and Great Britain, in relation to her national income, is contributing almost as much to the United States under this arrangement as the United States, proportionately, is to Great Britain, Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, said in a broadcast here tonight.

TO put it with no nonsense, "Long, Long Ago" is the book one-half of the world will give to the other half this coming Christmas. PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Dartmouth's rolling power and speed were too much for Princeton today as the Green piled up six touchdowns, adding the point after each, to defeat the Tigers, 42 to 13.

The New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, has a display of orchids in the Tropical House this week. The collection includes, as well as "florist's orchids," examples of butterfly and slipper types, paphiopedilium, dendrobium, and several epidendrum.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Used Army landing barges, believed to be the public's first opportunity to buy second-hand Army equipment with souvenir value in this war, were put on sale today.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Samuel J. McKee, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation field office here, announced tonight the arrest of John Torten, a member of the executive board of Local 244, Motion Picture Operators Union, on a charge that he attempted to intimidate Andrew J. Roach, a witness at yesterday's session of the trial in New York of eight alleged motion-picture industry extortionists.

FOOCHOW, China, Nov. 18 (Delayed) -- Even war cannot wholly subdue the Chinese instinct to treat visiting foreigners like distinguished guests. This is the story of eight Japanese prisoners of war who, much to their surprise, did not have their heads cut off when they were captured near Futsing recently.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The War Department made public today the names of 291 United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern and Southwest Pacific areas.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 20 -- Only the nations firmly rooted in political philosophy and which, in contrast to other nations, understand what is at stake in this war will successfully survive it, Paul Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, contended in an article in this week's Reich entitled "The Secret Behind the War."

WITH SEVENTH AIR FORCE, Central Pacific, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -- Liberator bombers of the Seventh Air Force established a record for long-distance bombing operations in the Pacific when they flew more than 2,200 miles to blast the Japanese-held base of Jaluit in the Marshalls Monday.

NAPLES, Nov. 20 -- All elements of Italian opinion will now have genuine freedom of the press in accordance with a new directive from Allied Headquarters, it was learned today. The only restrictions will be on those based on questions of military security, but there will also be the grave limitations imposed by the shortage of newsprint.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- Serious though the German attempt to blunt Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin's strength in the Kiev salient appears to be, it was not unexpected, and unless German generalship introduces some new factor into the situation there seems little prospect of a major enemy success to follow up the retaking of Zhitomir.

ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A retired Georgia jurist promised today "after certain persons are dead" to clear Leo M. Frank of the murder for which he was convicted and lynched following a sensational trial thirty years ago.

ADOLF HITLER'S "new order," with its challenge to civilization, is, on the face of it, nothing new. In 1885 a young New Englander, 21 years old, clearly saw it coming and said so in a letter to his friend and tutor, Marshall L. Perrin, Professor of Sanskrit and Germanic languages.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans under Gen. Josip Broz [Tito] grappled desperately with the Germans tonight for the islands of Veglia [Krk] and Cherso [Crgs] which command the approaches to Fiume through which Adolph Hitler has been pouring reinforcements in the long, costly effort to beat down the ever-increasing menace to his southeastern Europe flank.

IN this book Miss Lyon, author of "Take to the Hills" and "And Green Grass Grows All Around," looks with pop-eyed admiration at personalities in the advertising business. Having sized them up as lovable wags she devotes most of her book to a description of their antics in Chicago.

The cotton futures market declined yesterday for the second consecutive session as persistent selling pressure met indifferent mill price-fixing. The list of active old type contracts ended the short session on the New York Cotton Exchange with quotations 2 to 6 points below Friday's closing levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Ways and Means Committee, making public its report on the $2,140,000,000 1943 Revenue Act, which would raise only one-fifth of the amount requested by the Administration, declared today that taxes were of secondary importance in the fight against inflation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20 -- Reassurance that officers and soldiers serving in Ante Paoelitch's regular Croatian Army or "domobrani' may still join Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's forces without risking personal reprisals were contained in an appeal issued by General Mikhailovitch and announced by the Yugoslav Government Information Office today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Award of the Distinguished Service Medal to Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt for services in establishing defenses of the West Coast and Alaskan areas was announced by the Navy today.

SINCE the arrival of Ted Lewis and his musical aggregation at the Hurricane some three weeks ago there has been a steady tinkle of that spot's cash register, giving further proof that the veteran bandleader has one of the town's better after-dark shows.

THIS department had occasion not long ago to remark upon the fact that this season, as never before, distinguished conductors will have charge of the Metropolitan repertory. With but few exceptions the performances will be directed by men of international experience and authority in this field.

Says she: "It's beyond my understanding why anyone beyond the fourth grade cannot peel plain tart apples, slice them atop a crust and sprinkle them with sugar and cinnamon, lay on another crust and bake the thing."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- A knock-down, drag-out, ten-hour fight between a German submarine and seven Navy and Army planes plus a blimp ended with destruction of the U-boat and one of the attacking planes, the Navy revealed tonight.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey and Sanita Hills, the departmental recreation resort at Holmes, N.Y., were warmly defended yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at exercises held at City Hall to honor members of the department for heroism and exceptional service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Democratic party will open its 1944 campaign Jan. 22 with a meeting here of its national committee to select the time and place for the national convention and with one or more Jackson Day dinners at which party spokesmen are expected to provide "the answers to a lot of questions."

DETROIT, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A civilian pilot was killed and another civilian was severely burned late today when a large Army plane overshot the runway at Detroit's city airport and struck two private planes.

For its annual benefit theatre party the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement, represented by its officers and board of managers, has chosen the performance of "The Voice of the Turtle," featuring Margaret Sullavan, Elliott Nugent and Audrey Christie, for the night of Dec. 10 at the Morosco Theatre.

Barnard College has a larger enrollment of foreign students than it has had in the past ten years, according to an announcement made by Dean Virginia C. Gilder-sleeve. There are fifty-seven from foreign countries, ten from the United States Territories and three of recent foreign background who are now citizens of this country.

" INDUSTRIAL ELECTRICITY AND WIRING" is a third edition, confined to that specialized, very practical and not too theoretical field covered by electricians engaged in industrial work. The edition, covering new developments in industrial electricity, includes chapters on fluorescent lighting and radio interference and contains the last revision of the National Electrical Code.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 20 -- The swift Russian offensive has kept Adolf Hitler and his headquarters staff on the jump, forcing them to move seven times within the past nine months, a reliable informant from Germany who has contacts with Hitler's bodyguard said today.

A new type of fishing vessel hit the ways at St. Augustine, Fla., last week. Since fishing is playing an increasingly important part in the nation's food supply and since crews to man the boats are becoming harder and harder to get, this craft offers interesting possibilities.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 2 gives a special press dispatch from Washington which says: "The authority of Congress to outlaw the poll tax requirement from eight Southern States was disputed today by Charles Warren, Historian of the United States Supreme Court, former assistant attorney general, although he said that such a tax was unjust and should be abolished."

Berlin is a city of cities. In its growth outward from its ancient center it not only built up new areas but also overran and absorbed many lesser communities, finally covering more than 330 square miles as a single municipality. In the process it became a puddingstone of industrial and suburban areas, the transportation hub of central Europe.

TORONTO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Canadiens swamped the Maple Leafs, 7 -- 2, tonight to strengthen their hold on first place in the National Hockey League and remain unbeaten. Gerry Heffernan and Fernand Majeau each tallied two goals.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine delivered personally to Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday his report on crime conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and the Mayor and the Commissioner then conferred for three-quarters of an hour.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 20 -- What has been officially described as "highly tendencious accounts of the search last Tuesday at Ramat Hakovesh [a Jewish village in the coastal plain] and given wide publicity calculated to mislead and imflame public opinion" has led to orders of suspension against nine daily Hebrew papers and a Jewish paper printed in German.

Padway, counsel for the union, said yesterday.

Retail trade continued very active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with main floor departments receiving major attention, particularly handbags, gloves and jewelry. Toy departments were crowded.

RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 20 -- Air bases constructed in Brazil for Americans and all installations will revert to Brazil, Brazilian Admiral Jose Maria Neivas, chief of naval operations in the northeast, declared today. ALGIERS, Nov. 20 -- Rain may bog the Allied land forces in Italy but it cannot affect what is probably the single most vital fact in the present Mediterranean campaign: that invading forces have already taken over all airfields below the battle line, have added many fighter strips and are using every minute of the day to gain from them the maximum contribution to the air offensive against Germany.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- France was reported tonight to be in the throes of its gravest political crisis since July, 1940, with the German occupation authorities and their collaborationist sycophants tensely on guard against a possible general internal revolt set off by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's rumored resignation and eleventh-hour "conversion to democracy."

The Glenn L. Martin Company doubled the annual dividend payments in the last year with the declaration yesterday of a dividend of $1.50 a share for distribution to common stockholders on Dec. 13. With the current dividend disbursements this year total $3, compared with $1.50 paid last year.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Substitute Bill Chestnut calmly drop-kicked the extra point to give the University of Kansas football team a 7-6 upset victory today over Missouri in a Big Six Conference game before a crowd of 8,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The National War Labor Board finally approved today the coal wage agreement between Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes and John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, but made a "minor" qualification which cuts the basic weekly wage by 30 1/2 cents below that of the agreement. The board's vote was seven to five.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Thanksgiving week will be observed in time-honored American style, with beachfront hotels featuring festive dinners and whole roast turkeys served with "all the fixin's." Hotel lobbies are decorated with mammoth chrysanthemum and autumn leaves and reservations for the festival are reported numerous.
In New York this week Jacqueline Cochran, head of the Wasps, the civilian group of Women's Airforce Service Pilots, appeared wearing for the first time the group's new official dress uniform.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Recent activities of candidates, and friends of prospective candidates, for the Republican nomination in 1944 have attested the genuineness of the feeling within the GOP that the results of the off-year elections on Nov. 2 showed it has a real chance at the grand political sweepstakes a little less than a year from now.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Administration and the opposition are bidding fervently for the greatest absentee vote in the history of the country. With the 1944 general elections brewing, neither side knows which way the vote will go, but both sides are hopeful of profiting by it.

ANOTHER link in the Hollywood-Mexico movie chain was forged last week when United Artists closed a distribution deal with Artistas Asociados, S.A., newly formed Mexican producing company. Dudley Murphy, the Hollywood director, organized the new company of which Jose Calderon is president.

THE Chicago Bears and the Washington Redskins collide head-on in the nation's Capital today. PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -Big Al Postus, closing out a brilliant career at Villanova College, scored two touchdowns and set up all three others in a brilliant display of running and passing before 10,000 in Temple Stadium today as Villanova swamped a game squad of Temple youngsters, 34 to 7, in the final game of the season for both teams.

Thomas J. Curran, chairman of the New York Republican County Committee, will share time, but not space, with Mayor La Guardia this afternoon on the Mayor's weekly radio "Talk to the Pople." Mr. Curran will do his talking from a studio of WNYC in the Municipal Building.

ANNE MORROW LINDBERGH has completed a first novel. An account of an "adventure of the spirit" experienced by a young couple during a flight over the Alps, the novel will be entitled "The Steep Ascent." March is the probable month of publication.
LONDON -- Britain's declining birth rate, one of her most serious problems for the past three decades, has taken a change for the better in her fourth year of war.

SINCE the war, "home for Thanksgiving" has become a phrase rather than an actuality. Formerly the Thursday-to-Monday Thanksgiving week-end was a high spot on the fall calendar. Trains began to move out of rail terminals with heavy loads the Wednesday before the feast day, and motor parties took off for this and that objective.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The roots of another depression at least as disastrous as the last one are seen by some economists in a current farm land boom which threatens to reach even greater proportions than that of the first World War.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Sixteen Navy officers and men were among the eighteen persons killed in the crash of a large American naval transport plane thirty miles east of Rio de Janeiro on Friday, the Navy reported tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 21 -- German newspapers gave a sober note to the rejoicing over the recapture of Zhitomir by stressing that the winter is expected to be extremely trying. One consolation, the newspapers say, is that the 1943-44 winter cannot be worse than preceding war winters in Russia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, long an Administration spokesman for labor in Congress, proposed today that Stabilization Director Fred M. Vinson recede on his refusal of an 8-cents-an-hour rail wage increase and thereby avoid a Congressional vote on the issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Police officers representing the International Association of Police Chiefs and the National Sheriffs Association asked the children's bureau of the Department of Labor today to head a cooperative committee, to include other Federal agencies and law enforcement and social agencies, for the purpose of exploring the need for and possibility of emergency training courses for police men and women dealing with child delinquents.

Soon after Mayor La Guardia, in his weekly radio talk, had defended his administration against charges of laxity in crime prevention, a stormy mass meeting was held yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn's "Little Harlem," the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, at which a resolution was adopted calling upon Governor Dewey to remove the Mayor for "misfeasance."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Persons who hold the view that women are entitled to a more wide-spread and important share in shaping the affairs of the world will be disappointed at the almost infinitesimal representation of women on the governing body of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, now in the full swing of its first session here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A recent proposal by Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, that guarantees of freedom of the press be included in the peace treaties as a preventive of future wars was praised today in a column-long editorial in the Correio da Manha, a leading morning newspaper here.

Clayton Farrar of the Millrose A.A. rallied in the last half mile to overhaul the leaders and capture the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 21 -- Orchardton Dorrando today won first prize in the annual meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club, held at the Timber Point Club in this village. The award was the culminating event in three days of competition that provided about every type of retriever field work.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- George R. Loveys, former State editor of The Associated Press, was named executive assistant to Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein today at a salary of $7,500 a year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Paced by Frank Basilone, brother of John Basilone, a Marine hero, Camp Kilmer snowed under a Brooklyn College eleven today at Rutgers University Stadium, 47 -- 7. The Raritan soldier made several spectacular runs and tallied a touchdown to boot.

Curran, chairman of the New York Republican County Committee, declared yesterday in a twelve-minute broadcast from the studios of WNYC, the municipal radio station.
