PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Since the Japanese on Tarawa had been holding out for twenty-four hours when Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's communique was issued, it appeared that American forces there were up against a win, die or retreat proposition.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 21 -- American forces have invaded the Gilbert Islands in the central Pacific.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Owen M. Richards, manager of the American Dairy Association, said that the organization's regular Sunday radio program from Chicago was "choked off the air at the eleventh hour" today by the National Broadcasting Company and replaced by a speech delivered from Detroit by R.J. Thomas, president of the CIO United Automobile Workers.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- William Strang was named British representative and Fedor Tarsovich Guseff was appointed Russian representative tonight on the United Nations' European Advisory Commission, established at the Moscow conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- C. Benham Baldwin, who before his recent appointment as area director in charge of Foreign Economic Administration operations in Italy had been a leading figure in New Deal farm administration affairs since 1933, will leave Government service to join Sidney Hillman's CIO Political Action Committee, it was announced here today.

In "Winged Victory," which opened Saturday evening at the Forty-fourth Street, Moss Hart has written a stirring, moving and, what is more important, a most human play about the boy next door. Being that boy next door, the Army Air Forces act it with understanding, dignity, humor and warmth.

Eighteen large cities raising money for the National War Fund and their own community needs have already met or exceeded their quotas, it was reported yesterday by Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman. These cities had total goals of $41,798,019 and raised $43,854,021.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The stock markets here staged last week a recovery that was as surprising as it was welcome. The continued good news from the war fronts might easily have maintained the fit of "peace blues" from which the markets have been suffering, but what dealers unanimously described as technical conditions came to their aid and were almost entirely responsible for the rally.

The war has wrought a '"revolutionary, impressive and gratifying change" in American prisons and reformatories, and has produced stimulating developments that have lifted them out of their "stagnation and routine," according to a report on "Prisons in Wartime" made public yesterday by the Government division of the War Production Board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- George Jessel's first film production for Twentieth Century-Fox will be "Kitten on the Keys," a musical scheduled for January production with Dick Haymes and Perry Como, singers, and the orchestras of Benny Goodman and Jimmy Dorsey featured.
" Boris Godunoff" will open the Metropolitan Opera Association's Diamond Jubilee season at 8 o'clock tonight.

The chaotic condition prevailing today with respect to future air transportation is getting entirely out of hand. Applications of all kinds, good, bad and indifferent, are being made for certificates of necessity, new routes established, property for airports bought up, without any thought of the real picture, which will eventually, unless checked immediately, show a tremendous loss to the people of this country.

BOUGAINVILLE ISLAND, SOUTH PACIFIC, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Roy S. Geiger, USMC, commanding all United States ground forces on Bougainville, said today the Japanese were refusing to accept a test of strength in a major engagement on the Empress Augusta Bay beachhead.

At the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, Eugene Istomin, 18-year-old pianist of this city, was the soloist in consequence of winning the Leventritt Award, which entitled him to this appearance.

During the first half of last week the stock market declined continuously. It nearly reached on Thursday morning the low point of reaction which began with the present month. This was largely a speculative movement, as was shown by the rapid recovery at the week-end, in which the earlier losses of the week were recovered.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- The most important news from the front today comes from the Cherkassy sector, halfway between Kiev and Kremenchug, where the Russians are reported massing guns in a systematic demolition of towns in the defense ring.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Representative J. William Ditter of Ambler, chairman of the Republican National Congressional Committee, was killed tonight when a Navy plane crashed into a hillside near Columbia, about ten miles from Lancaster.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Things are looking up for the New York Rovers. The local representatives in the Eastern Hockey League scored their third straight triumph when they turned back the New Haven Eagles at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, 6 to 4.

ALGIERS, Nov. 21 -- German military strength in the Mediterranean, from southern France to Greece, is believed to approximate less than fifty divisions, apart from Croat and Bulgarian units, and at least ten divisions are engaged in keeping the Allies south of Rome, it was said today.

The Giants, compressed to pigmy-size by the Luckman-Bear pressure group from Chicago a week ago, sprang back to normal stature yesterday when they defeated the Cardinals, 24 to 13, before 19,804 fans at the Polo Grounds.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The heavy cruiser Guam, second of a class of warships that are lighter than a battleship but larger than any other cruiser afloat, was launched today at the yards here of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

A special service for parents and relatives of service men who are prisoners of war was held yesterday afternoon at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-Third Street. Five hundred relatives in the congregation of 1,000 had been especially invited by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector, and by the New York Committee of the National War Fund.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 21 -- Yugoslav Partisans, hitting back at German efforts to expel them from the Dalmatian coast and the Adriatic link with the Allies' bases in Italy, have opened a new offensive of their own in that region besides counter - attacking the recently launched German drives in Bosnia and the hinterland along their rear, the Free Yugoslav radio said today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

One of the great unmourned casualties of our time is the close personal relationship that once flowered between the barber and his client. It is gone, we shall never see its like again, and nothing has followed after to take its place or heal the hurt.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) soon will call upon the United States and other member Governments to take "at the earliest possible time," whatever constitutional action is required -- legislative, administrative or budgetary -- to begin their contributions to the proposed $2,500,000,000 fund for liberated areas.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The proposed meeting of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Premier Joseph Stalin remained a main topic of discussion in this part of the world today. Everybody talks about it except the British, American and Russian officials concerned, who confirm nothing, deny nothing and deprecate all speculation.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 -- A continued heavy flow of cotton into the Government loan, which further tightened the supply situation, plus expectations of a strong anti-subsidy vote in Congress, aided constructive sentiment in the cotton futures market here last week, but many traders still took early peace prospects seriously and liquidated quickly on small upturns.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The British Council of Churches recommends in a pamphlet published today "spiritual preparation" immediately for the willing acceptance by everyone in Britain of more stringent rationing of fond and clothing after the war so these necessaries could be shared with the people of devastated European countries.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- In the first twelve months after war with Germany ends, British authorities expect to build 85,000 to 100,000 new homes under a program already well advanced, Government sources said today.

Alarmed by the "widespread lowering of sex standards," including a "large amount of sexual delinquency involving young girls," under war conditions, the Federal Council of Churches, 297 Fourth Avenue, appealed yesterday to "molders of public opinion" to join in a nation-wide program to uphold the highest standards of sex behavior.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Two unidentified merchant ships collided in a dense fog about fifty-eight miles off Cape Henlopen in Lower Delaware Bay this morning, bringing death or injury to an undisclosed number of men.

A ceremonial approaching the Roman Catholic Mass replaced yesterday the comparative austerity of the present-day Lutheran service at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity. Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The French action in accepting General Catroux's preliminary proposals for the settlement of affairs in Lebanon was warmly welcomed in London tonight, but it was recognized that the release and reinstatement of the Lebanese President were only the first step toward the restoration of normal conditions.

With thousands of registered nurses diverted to the armed forces, hospitals and physicians in private practice find it increasingly difficult to cope with civilian sickness. That difficulty is bound to increase as Government hospitals are called upon to care for more and more wounded soldiers and sailors.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The labor magazine War and the Working Class, saying the initiative in the Pacific was completely in American hands, charged today that Japanese extremists had "inspired various anti-Soviet plans" in behalf of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Administration leaders, engaged in a desperate last-minute effort to stave off defeat of the subsidy program in the House tomorrow, produced a prediction by Price Administrator Chester Bowles tonight that food prices would increase 7 per cent if subsidies were outlawed.

Paul S. Hitlin, operator and builder, bought from the Union Dime Savings Bank the two eight-story apartment houses at 306-314 West 100th St., between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, for cash over two first mortgages amounting to $195,000 and maturing in November, 1950, at 3 per cent.

Delegates of twenty-two Congress of Industrial Organizations and American Federation of Labor unions met yesterday in the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, under the auspices of the Greek-American Labor Committee for the first general meeting to acquaint trade unions with the guerrilla movement in Greece.

While telephone calls from three States were streaming in requesting the adoption of the two children abandoned Saturday afternoon in the doorway of the East Sixty-seventh Street police station, Mrs. Rose Mooney, their 30-year-old widowed mother, entered the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, yesterday morning and claimed them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Secretary Knox today accepted for the Government nearly 100 Naval paintings and drawings, the work of seven civilian artists under commission to the Abbott Laboratories, pharmaceutical company. The presentation was made by S. de Witt Clough, its president.

ALGIERS, Nov. 21 -- The Allied armies in Italy, up against the triple barrier of flooded rivers, incessant rain and a German army reinforced with inexperienced but young and sturdy troops, slogged and gouged their way yesterday to their most sub stantial gains in a fortnight.

A closing notice, effective Saturday night, was posted backstage yesterday at the Broadway Theatre for "Artists and Models." This was confirmed last night by Lou Walters, co-producer of the revue with Don Ross, E.M. Loew and Michael Redstone.

Buyers in the wholesale markets during the past week are of the opinion that Christmas volume will reach new high records, and were covering on seasonal merchandise as well as on spring lines, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices fell 0.02 per cent. The raw materials index dropped 0.1 per cent as a result of price decreases in eggs and livestock, which were larger than the increases in the price of cotton, apples, grain and potatoes.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 22 -- The Red Army withstood the mechanized might of massive German attacks against the vital Kiev bulge in fighting in the northern Ukraine yesterday and broadened two prongs of the Soviet wedge aimed at the iron wealth of Krivoi Rog and the manganese of Nikopol, Moscow announced early today.

DID you ever eat a sandoricum? Or did you ever hear of that wonderful island called Rapa, in the remote South Seas, where the women outnumber the men by four to one and the men are therefore sacred? It is known as the sailor's paradise and popular belief among Pacific sailors is that the men on Rapa are "too sacred to work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, announced plans tonight to protect the public's share in an estimated 17,000,000 barrels of oil and gas deposits under the Cerritos Channel between Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif.

The Krieger Steel Sections Company of Long Island City has leased the two-story building at 76 Crown Street, in Brooklyn, for a warehouse through the Brevoort Management Company, which rented to the same concern 16,000 square feet in 344 St. Marks Avenue.

A general strike in all schools where custodians fail to meet the wage demands of Local 112 of the School Custodial Workers will go into effect Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the executive board and shop stewards of the organization at Irving Plaza, Irving Place and Fifteenth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 -- The supply of steel ingots eased last week. Also noted were a slight rebound in ingot output, some isolated price adjustments in the steel industry and a general feeling that steel supplies were sufficient to cover all war requirements.

Awareness of faith in God and in His vision was described as the "priority of priorities" by the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

In a spirit of apprehension as to the future of their homeland in the post-war scheme of Europe, 4,000 Polish-Americans met yesterday in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the achievement of independence by the Republic of Poland.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Two spearheads of a Japanese force of 80,000 made progress toward Changteh in the "Rice Bowl" country west of Tungting Lake today. Reports of strong reinforcements at their Yochow base east of the lake indicated the invaders might be opening a fourth great battle for Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province in Central China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- All the United Nations are preparing post-war plans to improve the economic lot of their citizens, but each plan is being worked out independently and without regard to mutual relationships, the Twentieth Century Fund said tonight.

Conrad Heiden's "Der Fuehrer," an analysis of Hitler and his rise to power, has been chosen by the Book of the Month Club for its February book. It will be published by Houghton Mifflin. "Literally England," a book of photographs of places made memorable in English literature, by David E. Scherman and Richard Wilcox, will be distributed to the club's members as the December and January book dividend. It is a Random House publication.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Detroit and Philadelphia-Pittsburgh tossed defense to the wind today, putting on a thrilling show which the Steagles finally won, 35 to 34. The National Football League game was watched by a crowd of 23,338.

NAPLES, Nov. 21 -- The dream of all prisoners came true for ten days on the Island of Santo Stefano, next to Ventotene, northwest of Naples. Two hundred fifty-seven of them broke jail on this Italian Devil's Island and put their thirty-six guards and wardens into their cells.

The battle of Russia has developed into a slugging match of Russian attacks and German counter-attacks in which Russian valor and determination are being met by the desperation of trapped German troops fighting for their lives. It is perhaps too much to say that the issue of the battle has again been put in the balance, for the Russian offensive shows shifts in points of attack, but no slackening of momentum.

The publicity which you have given in three issues of the current week, together with a recent editorial entitled "The Forgotten Millions," has, I think, focused public attention on the weakest link of our republican government, that is, the fact that the unorganized millions have no representation at Washington.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- Maurice Thorez, secretary of the French Communist party, in an article prominently displayed in Pravda today, hailed the recent reorganization of the French Committee of National Liberation as a step forward in strengthening national unity.

The Marines landed again Saturday -- with the Army and the Navy in support -- and by nightfall it was probable that footholds on several of the Japanese-held Gilbert Islands in the central Pacific had been made good.
Mayor La Guardia suggested yesterday, in his weekly broadcast from City Hall, that groups of volunteers clean the crosswalks in their neighborhoods after heavy snowfalls.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Joint Congressional Committee, on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures, headed by Senator Byrd, today repeated its charges of wasteful and extravagant use of Federal personnel and called for the immediate discharge of 300,000 Government workers.

Dr. C.J. Blanford, administrator of the New York metropolitan milk marketing area, who is also local Market Agent in charge of the War Food Administration's milk conservation program, announced yesterday the designation of ninety-two representatives of milk handlers throughout up-State New York and Northern New Jersey to serve as members and alternates of seven industry advisory committees.

The hiring of paroled men to fill a variety of prison staff positions was urged yesterday by A.H. Conner, associate commissioner of Federal Prison Industries, Inc., as a way of relieving an institutional manpower shortage and as an example by the Government in the rehabilitation of parolees.

It is an error in dealing with delinquent youth to "barge in with religion at the outset," G. Howland Shaw, Assistant Secretary of State and president of the National Conference of Catholic Charities, declared yesterday at a communion breakfast of the Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

New York stores cooperating with window promotions in connection with the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera House have been invited by the management to submit photographs of displays, with the winning display manager to be awarded a box for a future performance.
Thirty-eight patriotic societies held their twenty-first annual joint services yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

IT was a mighty close call. A Notre Dame team which had been hailed as one of the greatest college combinations of all time had to rely on the unsatisfactory margin of a point after touchdown to edge out the Iowa Seahawks in a savage, bruising battle which ranked not only as Saturday's outstanding engagement but probably as the best the season yet has produced.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- British observers said tonight that Germany's air defenses, wearing down under the growing Allied bomber offensive from the west, possibly were reaching a state similar to that of the harassed U-boat fleets.
WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, in Italy, Nov. 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- A brave soldier in the British Eighth Army is "Little Itie."

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The magazine War and the Working Class, answering foreign press comment on the election of Metropolitan Sergius of Moscow as Patriarch of All Russia and the reconstruction of the Holy Synod, implied today there was no change in the formal position of the Soviet Government, the Constitution of which guarantees freedom of religion.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 22 -- Australian troops supported by Matilda tanks increased their pressure against the Japanese on the main trail a mile east of Sattelberg on New Guinea while Allied bombers dropped a 138-ton bomb load on Gasmata, on the south cost of New Britain.
MONTREAL, NOV. 21, (AP) -- Piling up a 9-0 lead, the Montreal Canadiens went on to wallop the Boston Bruins, 13 to 4, in a National Hockey League game tonight and remain undefeated.

For the last decade the substitute problem has grown increasingly acute in the New York City school system. Because of the falling student enrollment few appointments have been made to the elementary or high schools in recent years. Nearly 3,000 teachers are on the eligible lists, serving as substitutes, many since 1930.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Sales of cash lard have increased materially in the last two weeks as the result of Government buying for lend-lease purposes. Some improvement in the domestic demand also has been reported, although this demand is not regarded as up to normal and is largely in the way of covering current requirements, as large users of this product are said to be awaiting developments in the proposed roll-back in prices.
A champion who gets off the floor to win is all the greater a champion. He proves he can take it as well as deal it out.

Argentinita and her little company of Spanish dancers last night gave the last of their series of New York recitals for this season at Carnegie Hall. The program contained the "Scenes From Old Madrid," "El Puerto" and the "Habanera," which are new this season, but consisted for the most part of popular numbers from the standard repertoire.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Ralph J. Mitchell of the Marine Corps has relieved Maj. Gen. Nathan F. Twining of the Army as commander of aircraft in the Solomons. This change is in line with the policy of rotating this arduous front-line command.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- A new wave of sabotage against the "Fascist Republican" regime in northern Italy was reported today from Reggio Emilia, where strongly armed insurgents were said to have dynamited canal locks in the Po River area, thus rendering barge traffic impossible for a number of months.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 21 -- Still considering himself a prisoner because he is not allowed by the Germans to broadcast his own decisions, Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain again today did not attend the ceremony of saluting the colors carried out by his personal guard every Sunday.
Six new films will have Broadway premieres during the week. The schedule follows:

LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Theodore Bramley, secretary of the London district of the Communist party, told, a protest rally tonight that Sir Oswald Mosley, Britain's pre-war fascist leader, had sent a message to his followers shortly before his release from Holloway Prison, telling them, "Keep your-courage up -- I'll soon be out."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Col. John J. Llewellin, British Minister for Food and chairman of the subcommittee on the scope of UNRRA activities, announced at the Hotel Claridge today that his group had reached unanimous agreement on the areas in which UNRRA will operate, the range of supplies and services that it will be responsible for providing, and its relationships with existing intergovernmental and national supply and shipping agencies.

Defeating Dr. Leopold Tabatznik of the New World Chess Club in a cleverly handled ending after forty-two moves in the fourth round of the annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Manhattan Club, last night, Edward S. Jackson Jr., the titleholder took first place with four straight victories to his credit.
The twentieth anniversary show of the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industry will open today at Madison Square Garden.

Creation of an "international society of nations, with an international police force, is now an absolute necessity to America" if it is to avoid becoming "a totalitarian, militarized State," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- The Navy told tonight how the airmen of Fighting Squadron 26 became the first Navy air command credited with action in both the Pacific and European theatres.

After moving upward in the early part of last week, cotton prices turned easier and closed the period with irregular changes. With the exception of the January delivery, which was down 4 points, active old-type futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 6 to 15 points.

MOSCOW, Nev. 21 (U.P.) -- The Soviet publication War and the Working Class, stating that there were "reasons to believe that the opening of a second front is not far off," pledged today that the peoples of German-occupied countries would enjoy the right of self-determination after the war.

Striking a double blow in the central Pacific, American forces have landed on Tarawa and Makin Islands in the Gilbert group. Our Marines and soldiers have already established several beach-heads against bitter opposition on Tarawa, and the Japanese, though less stoutly, are still resisting on Makin.

ALGIERS, Nov. 21 -- The French Committee of National Liberation approved today a proposed settlement of the Lebanese crisis that would mean the immediate release of the arrested President and Ministers and action for freeing Syria and Lebanon within the framework of the mandate that the French hold under the League of Nations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- With prices of oats above full parity at all leading markets and prospects that the ceiling would be set at about parity, scattered liquidation developed late last week in the December future after an early bulge had carried prices to a new seasonal high.

I{The Canadian free dollar registered a sharp drop in value last week, getting down to a low of 89 cents, on Saturday, from a price on Monday of 89.87 cents. The close at the week-end was 89.12 cents, a loss of cent from the preceding week, and ]owest in the ]ast month.

H. Victor Schwimmer, attorney in the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has resigned, effective today, to join the law firm of Chadbourne, Wallace, Park Whiteside, it was announced yesterday.

Trustees, members, friends, and "alumni" paid tribute to a half century of community service on the Lower East Side by the Educational Alliance, oldest and largest neighborhood center in the country, and dedicated a "living" hall of fame to outstanding graduates at its fiftieth anniversary ceremonies yesterday in the building at East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Ceiling prices on all varieties of cash wheat are expected to be announced this week by the Office of Price Administration in an effort to curb the upward trend of the market. Brokers expect the ceiling will be full parity price at Kansas City and Minneapolis and somewhat above that figure for Chicago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Ceiling prices on all varieties of cash wheat are expected to be announced this week by the Office of Price Administration in an effort to curb the upward trend of the market. Brokers expect the ceiling will be full parity price at Kansas City and Minneapolis and somewhat above that figure for Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Cast again in the role of underdogs against the Bears, the Redskins once more ascended the heights with a stunning 21-7 upset of the Chicago aggregation before a crowd of 35,672 at Griffith Stadium today.

Mayor La Guardia proposed yesterday in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall that New Yorkers who found it difficult to buy turkeys should switch their Thanksgiving Day turkey dinner from Thursday to Sunday to "break the black market and teach these chiselers a good lesson."

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Country offerings of cash corn have fallen far short of trade expectations, and reports that new ceiling prices will be announced before the end of the month, probably effective after Dec. 1, have had a tendency to cause farmers to hold back surplus grain.

The temporary lull in the aerial attack on Hitler-held Europe revived the discussion of the old conundrum, "Can air power defeat Germany?" and the present resumption of large-scale bombardment is likely to give it new impetus.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

Selfhelp of Emigres from Central Europe, Inc., the Fighting French Relief Committee and the Jewish Labor Committee have enlisted in the national drive, opening today, for clothing from the homes of America to aid the peoples of the liberated countries, it was announced yesterday.

Eleanor Fine, 17-year-old pianist, who made her debut two years ago in Town Hall, appeared there again yesterday afternoon in a piano recital with an exacting program which she disposed of with extraordinary success.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- A policy of cooperation between the Intergovernmental Committee, which has long worked with stateless persons and various nationals who have been forced by the war to leave their homes, and the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration when the United Nations move into countries now occupied by Germany, was indicated here tonight.

In a booklet entitled "You and Your Brands," the Association of National Advertisers brings out the importance of brand names and keeping them alive, with the presentation being prepared "to remind you of some fundamental truths."

Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery has accepted the honorary chairmanship of an American committee to establish a memorial in Palestine to the late Brig. Frederick H. Kisch, chief engineer of the British Eighth Army, trustee of the Hebrew Institute of Technology at Haifa and former political chief of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, it was announced last night by Dr. Albert Einstein, Chairman of the committee.

Seton Porter, president of the National Distillers Products Corporation, issued yesterday a statement concerning the anticipated results of the deal through which his corporation and fourteen associates will purchase the capital stock of the Century Distilling Company from Allied Mills, Inc.

Willard F. Place, vice president of the New York Central Railroad, has sold his five-story limestone town house at 46 East Eighty-second Street to Mrs. Minnie Gage Ray of Huntington, L.I. The house, which contains fourteen rooms and five baths, is on a lot 18 by 100 feet and is assessed at $35,000.

Congress is expected to vote today on the Commodity Credit Corporation Bill, which contains a provision that would end all food subsidies on Dec. 31. Under certain special circumstances moderate food subsidies may be less inflationary than the alternative to them.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Stan Koslowski, slippery speedster of Holy Cross, staked a strong claim on Easthern football's individual scoring title by boosting his total to 75 points as the Crusaders overwhelmed Tufts, 41 -- 0, today before 15,000 at Fenway Park.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Treasury announced today an offering through Federal Reserve Banks of 7/8 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series G-1944, on an exchange basis, par for par, to holders of Series E-1943 certificates, maturing Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Treasury announced today an offering through Federal Reserve Banks of 7/8 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series G-1944, on an exchange basis, par for par, to holders of Series E-1943 certificates, maturing Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The next and fourth War Loan drive, for a goal of $14,000,000,000, will open Jan. 18, and close Feb. 15, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

The scene during the landing of our first troops in Sicily defies description. All ships, including the "water bugs," opened up with all anti-aircraft batteries. The noise was a somewhat muted tide of sound that ebbed and flowed over the area as enemy planes flew over various sectors of the sky, invariably reaching a momentary crescendo in any area where bombs had just landed.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The twelfth annual fixture of the Camden County Kennel Club, held today at Convention Hall, attracted an entry of more than 700 dogs. Dr. Lewis Hart Marks of Philadelphia selected for the best-in-show award the boxer, Champion El Wendie of Rockland, owned by Rye Top Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Crystal of Harrison, N.Y., and handled by Nate Levine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- The Federal Reserve Board is quietly conducting a survey to determine whether restrictions on charge accounts and installment buying, the media through which most families acquire their worldly possessions, should be eased or removed.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Terming Philip F. Mancuso's fight against a Selective Service induction order "a comedy of errors," the Third United States Circuit Court today set aside a five-year jail sentence imposed on him last September on a charge of failing to report for induction.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- A new Russian offensive on a fifty-mile front in the Dnieper bend, the eighteenth offensive launched by the Red Army since July 13, will force the Germans to abandon their five-day-old attack east of Zhitomir and make a general withdrawal of the southern group of armies, inevitable since the forcing of the Dnieper, immediately necessary.

To put the matter bluntly, and without the circumlocutions customarily expected of a polite reviewer of an opening night performance of the Metropolitan Opera Association, it is to be said that considerably the most individual and interesting performer in the cast of "Boris Godunoff" on the said opening night of the Metropolitan's jubilee season was the horse.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 22 -- There will be no discrimination against Women when it comes to selecting the personnel to administer the vast post-war relief program of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

The Board of Education upheld yesterday a proposal to fill 150 vacancies on the regular teaching staff in elementary schools throughout the city despite last-minute attacks on the plan by the Public Education Association and James Marshall, former board president, who cast the only dissenting vote.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Persistent buying, which brokers attributed to distillers, advanced wheat futures today on the Board of Trade to a new seasonal high, making the seventh straight day the market has been on the upgrade. Despite profit-taking sales and some spreading with Minneapolis, the close was 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel higher, with December leading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The quarrel, now coming to a head again, between the President and Congress over cost-of-living controls is the direct consequence of the failure of both to keep bloc politics out of the restrictive program. The President and the administration shied away from true wage stabilization under pressure from the New Deal's largest voting group, organized labor.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 22 -- In a dramatic last-minute maneuver that surprised the prosecution, counsel for John R. Longo, former deputy Hudson County clerk convicted last Monday on charges of "fraudulent alteration" of his voting record, produced "startling" evidence today in Hudson County Quarter Sessions Court intended to show that Longo, critic of Mayor Frank Hague, was the victim of "the most outrageous frame-up in the annals of Hudson County justice."

Volunteer workers, neighborhood groups and local service agencies swung into action yesterday as the city began to collect its share in the two-week nation-wide drive for used clothing for rehabilitation abroad and relief at home.

In a letter published on this page recently Secretary Perkins made the statement that "the Administration has been successful in stabilizing wage rates." This follows the assertion by Chairman Davis that the War Labor Board has continued "to hold wages to the general level of Sept. 15, 1942."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- For the first time in recent years, detailed figures on production of a group of selected chemicals were made public today by the War Production Board's chemical division. Today's list is to be expanded as conditions in the future permit, officials said.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- In his inauguration speech in Sanders Theatre today President Wilbur K. Jordan of Radcliffe College emphasized that it was the duty of scholars to guard their intellectual integrity and not fall into the dishonest kind of scholarship which had destroyed learning under fascism.

The hunt for "widespread crime and lawlessness" in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, alleged by the August Kings County Grand Jury to have been permitted to go unchecked by police, took a new turn yesterday as police directed their energies toward locating one of their number who had publicly criticized Mayor La Guardia and the police force.

The Radio Corporation of America and the Columbia Broadcasting System openly challenged yesterday the "honesty of purpose" of the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, in asking for payments directly to the union on each disk their record subsidiaries might sell.

Urging that all Americans learn the spirit of sacrifice as American fighting men already have learned it, Capt. Maurice Witherspoon, Navy chaplain, spoke before a hundred workers for the women's division of the New York Committee of the National War Fund yesterday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

With material surpluses constantly increasing, the "biggest job" the War Production Board's materials redistribution division faces is the return of excess metals to normal trade channels, Alfred O. Birkenmeier, regional redistribution chief for the WPB, stated yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 23 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- The Navy announced sixty-nine casualties today, including thirty-four dead, nineteen wounded, and sixteen missing. In addition the names of three in the Naval services are included whose casualty status has been officially changed from missing to dead.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Permission has been granted by the Japanese Government for remittances to be made each month to civilian internment camps in the Philippine Islands, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision sustaining the action of the Federal Power Commission in valuing the Niagara Falls Power Company on the basis of its "actual legitimate original cost" instead of its "fair value."
President Rooveselt took cognizance yesterday of the constructive part taken by prison inmates in wartime activities and praised them for their patriotic services.

Recently I visited a large military hospital for personnel incapacitated by mental illness. Many were repatriated prisoners of war. I was impressed with the fact that the readjustment of these casualties of war will be one of our greatest post-war problems.

Another big show moved into Madison Square Garden yesterday with women as the stars. Embracing the collective activities for war and peace of the so-called weaker sex, the twentieth Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries will be there for a one-week run through Sunday.
The Army yesterday rejected Billy Jurges, recently reclassified 1-A, and thus assured Manager Mel Ott and his Giants a shortstop- third baseman for the 1944 baseball campaign.

With celebrations today on the first anniversary of the Spars, the Women's Coast Guard Reserve, a campaign will be opened to enlist 3,000 additional members immediately, Lieut. (j.g.) Dorothy Beckwith, senior Spar officer for the Third Naval District, announced yesterday.
Developments of the past week make it quite clear that the Germans have by no means given up the Dnieper River line in Russia and that there is still considerable offensive Punch in the German Army.

ALGIERS, Nov. 22 -- The British Eighth Army battered its way through merciless rain yesterday to capture two more small towns on the central front and increase the Allies' threat to the vital junction above Rionero where the road to Rome splits in two.
Bond Stores, Inc., has declared an extra dividend of 20 cents in addition to a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share, increasing 1943 payments to $2 from $1.60 received by stockholders last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 513 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern and Southwest Pacific areas. Fifty-six men from New York, thirty-two from New Jersey and seven from Connecticut are on this list.

The enthusiasm and price strength revealed in the recovery of stocks late last week on the New York Stock Exchange failed yesterday to extend into the new week as the market turned slightly easier. The volume of trading slumped to the smallest in a month as transfers on the Exchange reached only 609,540 shares against 906,290 shares on last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Carlos Davila, Chile's representative on the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, meeting at Atlantic City, informed the opening session of the United Nations Forum here tonight that although the post-war relief task "seems overwhelming," the amount calculated as necessary is actually less than was spent for relief after World War I.
OTTAWA, Nov. 22 -- Harold L. Ickes' denunciation today of the canol agreement between the United States and Canada has provoked great wonderment here but no official comment.

What was said to be the first strike in this city against a decision of the War Labor Board went into effect yesterday when 500 employes of nine yarn-dyeing plants here, organized in the Yarn Dye Guild Conference, failed to report for work.

Medley, the humor magazine of the New York University Heights division, has been suspended for one year as "unbefitting of an N.Y.U. publication." Maurel Hunkins, acting director of student personnel, who issued the order for the cessation of publication, also ordered the dissolution of the staff and transfer of the offices to another publication.

Forecasting unprecedented post-war opportunities for expansion, and a ten-year boom unmatched in history, Robert H. Wells, president of Corrigan, Osburne Wells, Inc., management consultants, yesterday called upon business to "begin at once the important task of changing over individually from war to peace production."

Stockholders of the Walworth Company voted yesterday at a special meeting in Boston to change its capital structure in preparation or new financing. A new class of 5 per cent convertible preferred stock, $50 par value, was created, 308,758 additional shares of common stock were authorized and authorization for the 6 per cent preferred stock, $10 value, was reduced to the 61,912 shares outstanding.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Maj. Gen. William E. Kepner, head of the Eighth United States Air Force's Fighter Command, is getting unusual fan mail -- letters of gratitude from the bomber men whom his fighters have protected in attacks on the Continent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The White House and the War Department said today that they were without information about a Berlin report in an Italian newspaper that a son of President Roosevelt had been shot down and taken prisoner during an air raid over Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Ruling that the National (Railway) Mediation Board and not the courts has authority to settle jurisdictional disputes among railway unions and that the board is also paramount in selecting voting units among employes, the Supreme Court further held today that all board dicta on legal matters covering these important subjects are barred from appeal to the courts.

Dr. Kirby Dwight, surgeon, was chosen president-elect of the Medical Society of the County of New York at its annual meeting last night in the New York Academy of Medicine. He win automatically become president in January, 1945.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Nov. 14 totaled 9,930,593 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 10,676,552 a year ago and 8,808,276 two years ago.

While copy followed the policy outlined by the War Production Board for the promotion of scarce textile merchandise, soft goods showed gains in October in the advertising linage of New York and Brooklyn department stores, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22 -- The refugee leaders here of the largest and most influential Spanish republican parties began today a campaign to obtain recognition by the United Nations of a Free Spanish Government that will be charged with the task of re-establishing a democratic regime in Spain if Generalissimo Francisco Franco is overthrown.

Continued liquidation of the December position and switching of the spot month into later deliveries in advance of its expiration on Wednesday featured the somewhat limited amount of trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Commercial banks with Government war loan accounts were advised late yesterday afternoon that the Treasury will make withdrawals from these accounts next Saturday and next Monday, thus effecting another "split week-end call."

The Treasury's preliminary announcement of the $14,000,000,000 fourth war loan drive, to start Jan. 18, was favorably received yesterday in financial circles. The Government bond market was firm and closed slightly higher on the day.

Young people must learn to understand why others are different, Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt, speaking at the dedication exercises of the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House, told an audience of 2,500 students, faculty members and alumnae in the Hunter College Auditorium yesterday afternoon.

"Cry Havoc," Metro's film adaptation of the play by Allan R. Kenward, will have its world premiere this morning at the Astor. The topical drama, which deals with the role played by volunteer nurses in the present war and which was directed by Richard Thorpe, includes Margaret Sullavan, Ann Sothern, Joan Blondell, Fay Bainter, Marsha Hunt, Diana Lewis, Ella Raines, Frances Gifford and Heather Angel among its leading players.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 17, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. An increase of $610,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and a decrease of $790,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Corporations may save on taxes by distributing products, such as whisky, to stockholders as a dividend recorded on the company's books at cost, but the recipients will be taxed on the basis of the market value, Randolph E. Paul, general counsel of the Treasury Department and tax adviser to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., said here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 22 -- While one subcommittee of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today fixed the United States' share of administrative expenses tentatively at 40 per cent, another decided that the Axis powers must pay for any UNRRA relief they get and also must contribute to the relief of liberated areas from the supplies of food, clothing and other goods they have looted from occupied Europe and Asia.

Determined to attain his best fighting condition, Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City lightweight, has returned from Lakewood, N.J., and today will resume training here for his ten-round bout with Sammy Angott, National Boxing Association champion, Monday night in Madison Square Garden.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Japanese infantry, cavalry, artillery and aviation hammered at the approaches to Changteh today in an effort to blast open the way to the Hunan Province capital of Changsha, where they have previously met three great defeats.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- Several hundred residents of Tel Aviv staged an unruly demonstration yesterday afternoon until dusk as a protest against a search carried out at the Jewish village of Ramat Hakovesh last Tuesday and the suspension of ten Jewish papers.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Because of a cold, biting wind Cornell's football forces held light dummy scrimmage work in the Bacon cage tonight in the next-to-last session before the tenth and final game of the year, the clash with Pennsylvania.

Because of last night's blackout, fifth-round games were delayed in the annual amateur championship finals at the headquarters of the United States Chess Federation, 279 East Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn. Only one match was decided before the clocks were stopped.

"I'M beginning to enjoy life again," said Stout Steve Owen, grinning from ear to ear. "Hank Soar is back with the Giants and I finally have someone I can ride unmercifully again. The trouble is, however, that Hank is so happy to be back playing football he just laughs at everything I say to him."

Henry Adrian, producer of "Victory Belles," obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins a show-cause order to restrain Michael Myerberg, lessee of the Mansfield Theatre, from interfering with the presentation of his play.

Alice Orovan, young designer with European experience, presented a fall and spring collection of dresses at a fashion show luncheon yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis. Color, dressmaking details and rich fabrics were used to full advantage in this showing.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Ten-goal Tommy Hitchcock is picking up in a Warhawk where he left off twenty-five years ago in a Nieuport. According to information received here today, Lieut. Col. Hitchcock, now air attache to the United States Embassy, is believed to be slated for command of a new fighter group.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein revealed here yesterday that he had been asked by the Board of Elections for a ruling on whether delegates to the Democratic and Republican national conventions shall be apportioned, within the State, on the basis of the present Congressional districts, or the new districts that go into effect with the Congressional elections of 1944.
With the new "flat-top" effect in hair styles dictated by the season's close-fitting hats, back hair -- so long ignored by the stylists -- is now receiving attention.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Application for a license to construct and operate a $2,000,000 horse race track with pari-mutuel betting on the 550-acre Atlantic Pines golf course near Mays Landing was made today before the New Jersey Racing Commission by the Atlantic City Racing Association.

To solve war contract termination problems posed by the Controller General's contention that Government procurement agencies should not be permitted to make final settlements without audit and approval of the General Accounting Office, the Controllers Institute of America yesterday recommended a seventeen-point program designed to simplify and speed up termination proceedings.

LEWES, Del., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Nineteen men presumably died in a blazing sea after the tanker Bostonian crashed into the tanker Altair in a thick fog fifty-eight miles off Delaware at midnight Saturday, a Fourth Naval District spokesman said tonight.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The first retrial in the Haupt treason case was set for Jan. 17 by Judge John P. Barnes in the Federal District Court today.

"Burma Surgeon," by Dr. Gordon S. Seagrave, the recently published Norton book, which is now near the top of the best-selling lists, has been selected as the December choice of the Peoples Book Club. The January book will be Frances Parkinson Keyes' novel, "Also the Hills," brought out last week by Julian Messner.

Word was received here yesterday of the death in action in Italy on Nov. 1 of Capt. Howard A. Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Smith of Ridgewood, N.J. The father is vice president and treasurer of the American Express Company.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Reconquest of Samos -- last Aegean island of consequence held by the Allies off Turkey -- was claimed tonight by the Germans, but this success made only a rent in the storm cloud of Allied power gathering and rising over the Balkans.

WITH U.S. FORCES ON BOUGAINVILLE ISLAND, Nov. 19 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Pvt. John Perella of Springfield, Mass., slipped through a hostile jungle undetected by Japanese patrols, swam a strange tropical river in darkness with enemy bullets splashing about his ears, and saved a United States Marine platoon from possible destruction by American artillery during the Battle of the Koromokina River Nov. 7-8, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- British bombers, swinging back into action after a two-night lay-off, subjected Berlin last night to its ninetieth aerial assault of the war, according to announcements by the German radio early today.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Oakey will give a dinner on Saturday at their home, 322 East Fifty-seventh Street, for their debutante daughter, Miss Louise Sargent Oakey, before the Mayfair Assembly for men in the armed forces at the St. Regis.

WITH THE SEVENTH AIR FORCE IN THE CENTRAL PACIFIC, Nov. 20 (Delayed) -- Army and Navy bombers operating in alternating waves yesterday and last night left the Japanese island of Tarawa in the Gilberts in smoke and flame in a pre-invasion blow by American forces.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Nov. 22 -- Will Japan's fleet come out and fight? That is the big question in the Pacific now that landings in the Gilbert Islands have been made. Japan's island empire is dependent on seapower and defeat of the imperial fleet could end the war relatively quickly.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Nov. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- The American Army may produce another Gene Tunney in a series of elimination tournaments to determine the champion boxers among the Allied troops in the North African theatre of operations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs were larger today than a week ago, but clearance was fairly good and heavier weights held steady. Steady to 25 cents larger prices prevailed in the cattle market, which was burdened by heavy loadings. Slaughter lambs were strong to 25 cents higher.

Intercollegiate football closes down for the war season of 1943 this week except for a scattering of games in warmer belts and the usual bowl fixtures. This means the time is at hand for Army and Navy to furnish their annual climax to the campaign in the East on Saturday after Penn and Cornell have had it out on Franklin Field Thanksgiving Day.

From the Postoffice Department weeks ago came the urgent request that persons sending Christmas gifts and letters would "mall in November." Here in New York Postmaster Gold man asked the public to do the same. We have been told again and again that more than 30,000 trained postal officials are in the armed forces.
Vic Dellicurti, 159, Harlem, out-pointed Joe Agosta, 155, Brooklyn, in a hard-fought eight-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 2,562 witnessed the program.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The proceeds of a courtroom sale of 2,000 shares of capital stock of the Illinois Bankers Life Assurance Company, ordered by Judge Julius H. Miner in Cook County Circuit Court for Dec. 21, will go to 28,000 former policy holders of the company's predecessor, the Illinois Bankers Life Association of Monmouth, Ill.

The patriotic motive behind the wartime plan of an anonymous children's nurse to give up one-third of her working month to the free care of children of men in the armed services and war production workers has resulted in a similar brand of patriotism on the part of members of the board of directors of the Maternity Center Association, who are matching the nurse's contribution with war bond pledges, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- George Munger, Penn's coach, displeased with his team's practice to date, sent the first two elevens through a long, hard scrimmage today to build a defense to stop Howie Blose of Cornell, one of the East's top football scorers, in the game here Thursday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- The Regional War Labor Board revised its substandard wage policy today by extending the hourly level of fifty cents to include the entire area under its jurisdiction.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Radiolocation, or radar, the scientific development that is being used as an instrument of war, can and should be used after the war to protect the lives of mariners, reduce shipwrecks and collisions at sea in fog or storm and generally increase the safety of navigation, the British Government's select committee on national expenditure reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The publishers of the Encyclopaedia Americana, 2 West Forty-fifth Street, New York, were charged by the Federal Trade Commission today with misrepresentation of their publication and "unfair disparagement of competing encyclopedias, particularly the Britannica."

Your editorial of Nov. 19 points out the serious consequences which might flow from a strike by the employes of the city's school custodians. It also remarks that the difficulty is inherent in the continued existence of the indirect system by which the custodian-engineer who supervises each school building, rather than the Board of Education, hires and compensates his helpers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- In an atmosphere of political caution and apparent suspicion that party advantages might be hidden in its pages, the Green-Lucas Soldier Voting Bill went under Senate consideration today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The bombing of Berlin last night was described as a "big terror attack" by the German propaganda agency, International Information Bureau, this being the usual Nazi description for heavy, destructive assaults.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 23 -- Red Army troops, buttressed by fleets of tanks, smashed powerful new German attacks near Korostyshev, halting a savage counter-offensive toward Kiev, wrecking eighty enemy tanks and carpeting the battlefield with German dead, Moscow announced early today.

In his interesting letter on inflation in THE TIMES last Sunday, Professor Irving Fisher asserts that "a sales tax is an inadequate substitute (for a spending tax) because it cannot be graduated." He does not go beyond this statement and fails to give reasons to substantiate it.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The stock markets here opened the week quietly today with most prices holding firm.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 22 -- British sources here revealed tonight that, according to information from Beirut, President Bechara el Khoury of Lebanon, released and reinstated, was now in Beirut with Premier Riad Solh.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
The six-story apartment house on a plot 127 by 100 feet at 255 East 176th Street, the Bronx, was purchased by an investing client of Ann Inselstein, broker.

FOR two decades our ruling social theorists have lamented the "inevitable" disappearance of the small farmer. He is being "tractored off" the land in Oklahoma and Texas by the big cotton barons (see John Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath"). He is being sold down the river into tenantry (see Carey McWilliams' "Factories in the Field" and "Ill Fares the Land").

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Robert D. Murphy, chief American diplomatic representative in North Africa, was appointed today as the United States member of the Advisory Council to the Allied Control Commission for Italy, with the personal rank of Ambassador.
ALGIERS, Nov. 22 -- A communique:

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- German propaganda directed to the outside world is stressing the strength of the defenses around "Fortress Europe" while pointing to difficulties facing the Allies when the invasion is launched.

When Daniel P. Woolley took office yesterday as regional director of the Office of Price Administration he advocated immediate passage of national legislation establishing food subsidies, and declared that one of the gravest problems Facing his administration was that of black markets.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 22 -- Exasperated by continuing resistance, the Germans shot two Danes today, one for sabotage and one for an assault against German soldiers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey, died at his home here tonight of a coronary thrombosis. He was 55 years old.

The 43-year-old wife of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of Poland is being held by the Germans as a hostage in the Oswiecim concentration camp and may be facing imminent execution, the Polish Telegraph Agency reported from London yesterday.

Bids on six new issues of municipal bonds, aggregating $2,316,000, will be opened by the State Board of Administration of Florida on Dec. 7. The issues included in this financing, all of which is for refunding purposes, are as follows:
Stan Koslowski of Holy Cross took football scoring honors for the week by crossing the Tufts goal line three times and making five conversions for an aggregate of 23 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Congressional action on legislation designed to place pro-Pearl Harbor fathers at the bottom of a countrywide draft pool was completed by the Senate today in a voice vote, nearly two months after actual induction of parents began.

I wish to call your attention to the drive now under way by the Metropolitan Area Hospital Service's committee to provide for Christmas a living plant for the bedside of every hospitalized service man and woman in our immediate area. In addition, a decorated Christmas tree will be placed in every ward in all the military hospitals in the area.
The Metropolitan Opera played host last night to a distinguished audience which filled to capacity the world's most famous lyric theatre for the Diamond Jubilee Premiere.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- Primo Carnera, only Italian who ever held the world's heavyweight championship, was reported today to have been wounded and taken prisoner by the Axis in northern Italy and to be facing summary execution By German authorities for his anti-fascist activity.

New York's "brownout" became a dark and chilly blackout last night when the air raid sirens howled for the first time since the new regulations became effective. If Times Square was a criterion for the State, the blackout was a success.

Graduate members of Lock and Key, City College's honorary service fraternity, have broken their twenty-three-year tradition by electing the first woman student to the society, it was announced yesterday by Dean John L. Bergstresser.

The Ice Follies of 1944 will open in Madison Square Garden this evening for a run of eleven nights, with the exception of next Sunday and Monday. Two matinees also are slated. The opening performance will be for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Ralph Brizzolara, whose Bears hope to be hosts to the Redskins in professional football's play-off Dec. 19, was the only one of five invited club executives to confer with Commissioner Elmer Layden today, but the two managed to lay plans for the National League's title game.

Determined to stamp out "chiseling" salesmen and unscrupulous jobbers who are reported to be taking advantage of the liquor shortage by demanding black market prices from retailers caught with negligible stocks, the major distillers announced yesterday that they were "cracking down" on these profiteers.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow: In the Dnieper bend southwest of Dniepropetrovsk, units of X formatment, captured a strongly fortified center of enemy defenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Seeking to standardize scheduling procedure for aircraft components, the War Production Board today issued a new general scheduling order known as M-360, which permits scheduling of only those components, parts and subassemblies for which responsibility is assigned by WPB to the Aircraft Resources Control Office.

On Oct. 22, 1883, the Metropolitan Opera House was opened for its first performance, "Faust" with Nilsson as Marguerite. Last night's performance, beginning a new season, marked the sixtieth uninterrupted year of this operatic theatre. For two generations the greatest singers of Europe and this country have been heard there.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 23 -- The Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force made another strong attack on Berlin last night, according to accounts broadcast from the German capital early today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 22 -- Allied Force headquarters denied tonight that Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton had been reprimanded by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and stated that General Patton is still in command of the Seventh Army.
Japan announced yesterday, first in foreign broadcasts, then in broadcasts beamed to Japanese, the American invasion of the Gilbert Islands and said that heavy fighting was still in progress.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The State Post-War Public Works Planning Commission notified the Westchester County Board of Supervisors today that post-war construction work planned by all communities in Westchester and by the county amounted to $36,700,000.

Andrew J. Roach, movie projectionist, was back on the witness stand in Federal court here yesterday to continue testimony that allegedly had resulted in his being threatened with early death last Friday night. Under cross-examination by defense counsel, he stuck to the story he had told on Friday of having taken a sealed package to Chicago, for delivery there to a gangster.

Public offering by a nation-wide underwriting syndicate of 875,000 shares of common stock of the Public Service Company of Colorado, formerly owned by the Cities Service Power and Light Company, at $25 a share or a total of $21,875,000, will be made today.

The formation of the Emergency Committee for Indian Famine Relief, composed of American citizens aiming to cooperate with the British, Chinese and others in meeting the present tragic food crisis in India, was announced yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 40 East Forty-ninth Street.

The diamond jubilee of the Metropolitan Opera House, which opened for business on Oct. 22, 1883, with "Faust," began last night with a performance of "Boris Godunoff." Mussorgsky's opera, the greatest ever produced by a Russian, was chosen not only for its stature as a work of art, but as a tribute to the gallantry and heroism of the Soviet Union's fighting forces and people.

Football writers, convening yesterday at Toots Shor's restaurant for their final general meeting of the season, expected to listen to some "hot stuff" concerning Saturday's Army-Navy classic that they, in turn, could relay to the fans, but none was forthcoming.

A strong post-war status for personnel activities in the retail field as the result of marked progress in meeting the problems created by war conditions was predicted yesterday by Harry A. Barth, assistant director of personnel of the W.T. Grant Company, at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

Necessity has created a fashion -- an apron that solves the problem of what to wear when serving for home entertaining. Glamour aprons, designed for maidless days, achieve a party look when fashioned of brightly colored taffetas, bold checks and stripes.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Instances where a labor union picketed two Bronx cafeterias were unanimously held legal by the Supreme Court today, although the New York State Court of Appeals had denied that a labor dispute existed in either case.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The War Department is spending $134,000,000 under cover of military secrecy on the development of Canadian oil resources which have negligible military value and in which the United States has no post-war rights, the Senate (Truman) committee investigating the war program was told today by the Petroleum Administration for War and the War Production Board.

Re-establishment of a normal flow of corn from the Middle Western States to dairy and poultry farmers of the Northeast must be undertaken immediately if consumer requirements of milk and eggs in this section are to be met, a special Governors' feed conference, meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt, reported yesterday.
Drafting of men and women for war work would shorten the conflict and save lives, Grenville Clark, secretary-treasurer of the Citizens Committee for a National War Service Act, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Montgomery berets will be bobbing all over the American landscape soon after the first of the year when uniforms now in production catch up with the 88,492 members of the Cadet Nurse Corps.

Dr. Lynd of Columbia University, as reported in your columns, advocated before the New Jersey Education Association "that the United States operate under a centralized national planned economy after the war. He advocated the measure as the only method by which the nation could continue its advances in technology and compete with other nations organized on a similar basis."
LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The diminishing menace of Axis submarines was reflected today in a new reduction in maritime war risk insurance rates, announced by the Institute of London Underwriters.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Reiteration by the Moscow press of Russian determination to allow the people to decide upon their own post-war governments in Europe was seen here tonight as part of the preliminaries of a meeting of President Roosevelt, Premier Joseph Stalin and Prime Minister Churchill.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A sailor, who gave up his soft chair in a coach to fire the Pennsylvania Railroad's Jeffersonian after the fireman was incapacitatedin an odd accident, got a commendation from the railroad today.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Political warfare between the Republican-controlled State administration and Democratic-controlled Albany was renewed today when State Controller Frank C. Moore denied the city's request for permission to refund $1,144,000 of bonds maturing in 1944.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a picture based on the building of the Church of the Good Thief at Clinton Prison, Dannemora, N.Y. John W. Considine Jr., the picture's producer, will go East soon to gather material for the screen play.

One of the minor worries of the hour is the correct way to pronounce the Dodecanese Islands. Any sound that will convey the general idea is good enough. A person may put the accent on the first syllable, making dode rhyme with pie a la mode and slide over the rest of the word.

One of the minor worries of the hour is the correct way to pronounce the Dodecanese Islands. Any sound that will convey the general idea is good enough. A person may put the accent on the first syllable, making dode rhyme with pie a la mode and slide over the rest of the word.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 22 -- Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain has definitely made it clear that he is engaged in a "sit-down strike" as a consequence of the German refusal to allow him to broadcast to the French people.

Alexander Woollcott, author, critic and raconteur, left an estate of "approximately $70,000" and half of the residue will go to a young Danish physician whom the writer befriended many years ago and sent through college and medical school, it was disclosed yesterday.

"Carmen Jones," which has been dilly-dallying out of town waiting for a theatre, has finally booked passage for Broadway. With the closing of "Artists and Models" next Saturday the spacious Broadway Theatre becomes available, and that means Billy Rose doesn't have to worry any more about a New York home for his spectacular musical.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- With the addition of the Southern Appalachian operators to the joint operators-United Mine Workers wage conference today, prospects appeared to be excellent that virtually all of the nation's coal operations might be covered, by a new contract.

Consumers in the New York metropolitan area who have not used more than 12 per cent of their total yearly fuel oil allotment are within the safety margin, it was announced yesterday by Frank C. Russell, district director of the Office of Price Administration, in releasing the first weekly report giving householders an index to determine the maximum percentage of their fuel oil allotment they should have used to date.

Although taxes were substantially larger than those for the corresponding period of last year, earnings of two major airlines that announced yesterday operating results for the first nine months of 1943 almost equaled those of a year ago.
ABOARD A LIBERATOR RETURNING FROM TARAWA, Nov. 19 (Delayed) -- This Army bomber has just set a large, impressive oil fire on the Japanese-held island of Tarawa, 2,000 miles west of Hawaii.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 17 per cent last week over the like period last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the preceding week a rise of 11 per cent had been reported by the bank.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Radio commentators should be more fully identified and in their broadcasts hould differentiate clearly between factual news and their own interpretation of it, the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee was told at today's hearing on the Wheeler-White Radio Bill.

With a large influx of service men and other out-of-town visitors already indicated, New York City will observe its second wartime Thanksgiving on Thursday without the usual turkey and fixings. In most homes throughout the city chicken, ham or duck will have to replace the traditional piece de resistance of the holiday.

Extension of the so-called "joint-area-agreement" policy of the United States and Britain to the Belgian Congo market was seen by foreign traders yesterday following the disclosure that importers of cotton thread in the Congo are being officially referred to United Kingdom suppliers.

Notre Dame defeated Iowa Pre-Flight on Saturday in what Coach Frank Leahy called the greatest game of his coaching career out the Irish lost prestige with the football experts who voted in the weekly Associated Press poll to determine the country's ranking elevens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Early adjournment of the House this afternoon because of the deaths of two members postponed until tomorrow a continuation of the fight on consumer price subsidies which leaders expect will end in a vote on the Commodity Credit Corporation Bill before the day is over.

Walter Rountree of La Salle Academy led home a field of sixty-five in the first annual city C.H.S.A.A. freshman cross-country championship run conducted yesterday over a mile and three-eighths course at Van Cortlandt Park. Bishop Loughlin Memorial High of Brooklyn captured the team title with a total of 31 points, placing five among the first eleven.

The possibility of having roast turkey for dinner on Thursday remains remote, according to one authority, who declares that supplies are only one-fifth as large as last year and show no signs of an immediate increase. The Government continues to buy heavily, he reports, and whatever birds are left over for civilians are being sold near the farms.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22 -- Navy, with its record of eight victories and one defeat, today began tapering off for the game with Army on Saturday at West Point.

Undaunted by taxi shortages or L-85 restrictions, New York opera-goers staged a fashion parade last night that carried far more formal elegance than had been believed possible under war time difficulties.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 113.8 on Nov. 9, compared with 113.6 a fortnight before, 111.9 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22 -- Navy, with its record of eight victories and one defeat, today began tapering off for the game with Army on Saturday at West Point.

Undaunted by taxi shortages or L-85 restrictions, New York opera-goers staged a fashion parade last night that carried far more formal elegance than had been believed possible under war time difficulties.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 113.8 on Nov. 9, compared with 113.6 a fortnight before, 111.9 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

Alex Rose, State secretary of the American Labor party, issued a statement yesterday declaring that Thomas J. Curran, Republican county chairman, had "made a substantial detour" from intellectual honesty in his broadcast over WNYC on Sunday explaining the Republican nomination of George Frankenthaler for the Supreme Court on an independent line. Mr. Rose said:

The seven-story store and office building at 7 West Forty-fourth Street, adjoining the Fifth Avenue Bank at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, was purchased by William S. Sussman.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 23 -- Driving up the Sattelberg road with tank and artillery support, Australian troops have pushed to within a half mile. of that village, last remaining enemy strong point on the Huon Peninsula.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A special communique:

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 22 -- United States Marines have landed on Abemama Atoll, the third island group invaded by strong American forces in the new Central Pacific offensive started last Saturday morning at dawn.

Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force rained fresh destruction on Berlin last night as the German capital lay smoking and devastated from a record British assault twenty-four hours earlier, London officials stated early today, according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Carrying banners reading, "Mosley in, Morrison out," more than 1,000 delegates representing about 20,000 workers from all parts of the country demonstrated outside the Houses of Parliament today as that body reassembled and Home Secretary Herbert Morrison defended his action in transferring the Fascist leader Sir Oswald Mosley, from jail to a private home.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Rebounding from Sunday's 13 -- 4 drubbing in Montreal, the most humiliating setback in their twenty National Hockey League seasons, the Bruins outplayed the Maple Leafs for an 8-5 victory tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden.
