Evacuation of Samos, admitted by the British, brings an unhappy Aegean campaign to a close. With Samos, Leros and Kos in their hands again, the Germans have recaptured all they lost and the Aegean is once more a closed sea. In that region, at least, the surrender of Italy has brought the Allies no benefit whatever.

The sportsmen prowling the Westchester woods trying, red-man style, to bag a buck with bow and arrow are not likely to add much to their girths with the amount of game they bring home, but they are having the time of their lives.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 23 -- German rule in Lorraine is becoming harsher, according to reports reaching here today. The latest development is the imposition of the death sentence on all young Lorrainers seeking to evade service in the German Army.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 23 -- The final defeat of Japan will come from China, in the opinion of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet.

In an effort to move the nation's record surplus of 17,000,000 head of cattle, the War Food Administration announced yesterday suspension of quota limitations on slaughter of livestock. The new order permits packers and butchers holding Government slaughter licenses to kill livestock for civilians without quota limitations until further notice.

NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- An incident which shows the deep-rooted monarchism of southern Italian peasants and which permitted Crown Prince Humbert to play his traditional role occurred Saturday morning just after the Germans attacked Aversa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Angus Dun, dean of the Episcopal Theological School at Cambridge, Mass., was elected today Bishop of the Washington Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church. He will succeed the late Right Rev. James E. Freeman.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- New England's worst November snow storm in decades left a two-foot blanket over many regions today, took three lives, put 8,500 telephones out of order and cut off nine towns from electric service.

The Presidential election of 1944 will probably be determined by the voting, or the non-voting, of the men actually engaged in the winning of the war abroad, since there may be as many as 5,000,000 outside the borders of the United States by next election day. So far, no simple, workable plan which will enable those soldiers to vote has emanated from Congress or from the States.

The signs are unmistakable that after the war aerial traffic is bound to increase enormously. Hence the importance of the Lea bill, which will soon be the subject of debate in Congress and which would place all civilian aviation under stricter Federal control.
Land mines and booby traps in great number are being used as effective delaying agents by the Germans in the enemy's defense of Rome.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The recent Moscow conference should be viewed as the "first step -- and only the first step -- toward an articulated international society," rather than as an attempt of the great powers to plan for the domination of the smaller nations, Richard K. Law, Minister of State, told the Foreign Press Association here today.

By the terms of an arbitration decision, Eddie Dowling, the star, has received an award of $350, including traveling expenses of $50, in a dispute with Saul Heller, summer stock manager, it was announced yesterday. The star had been paid $200 by Mr. Heller and claimed a balance of $800 for the week he had played in "The Petrified Forest" last July in Cleveland.

In preparation for the first delivery notices today, aggressive liquidation of the December cotton contract yesterday carried that spot month off to losses of 25 points, or $1.25 a bale. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange the remainder of the active old-type contracts registered declines of 2 to 5 points.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 23 -- Maj. Everett J. Neuteboom of the Ordnance Service Command was severely admonished today by his commanding officer for striking a newspaper photographer and alleged threat to another camera man and two reporters when they sought his permission to take pictures of a fire at a lend-lease warehouse here on Nov. 8.

Declaring that war-time production proved that "we can easily enjoy a national income after the war of $140,000,000,000 to $160,000,000,000," Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, outlined last night the steps that he believed necessary to achieve the income.

A fortunate change of course, which swung his ship out of the path of a waiting submarine and brought his stern gun into position to put two quick shots into it, was responsible for Capt. Edwin E. Johnson, master of an American-Hawaiian Line ship, receiving the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal yesterday afternoon.

With a luncheon and preview yesterday afternoon, the Brooklyn Museum opened its eagerly awaited exhibition of work by "The Eight" -- the group of American artists that, early in this century, created an almost unprecedented uproar in the local art world.
The holiday scene was covered yesterday noon by Russeks in the Persian Room of the Plaza. The result was a pleasing review of many of the styles already seen this autumn.

An investing client Herman H. Sonkenberg, attorney, has purchased the ten-story and penthouse loft building at 31-33 West Thirty-first Street from David S. Meister, operator. This structure is on a plot 33.4 by 98.9 feet and is fully occupied. It has an annual rent roll of about $17,000 and is assessed for $96,000. Nehring Brothers, Inc., were the brokers.

The Tokyo radio told Japanese audiences yesterday that the United States invasion of the Gilbert Islands constituted a threat to the Japanese-mandated Marshall Islands and "presages a real decisive battle of the fleets."

Joe Governale, 157 1/4, of Bensonhurst, with an advantage of more than ten pounds over his opponent, defeated Johnny Jones, 147, of Pittsburgh, in the feature bout of eight rounds before a crowd of 3,000 at the Broadway Arena last night.
Walter Mitchell states in a letter to THE TIMES that persons paying rent pay higher income taxes because property owners may deduct interest and other than Federal taxes.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications commission:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- The evacuation of Samos, last British Aegean stronghold, was announced officially today in a Middle East communique that said the British and Greek garrison and part of the Italian troops had been taken off safely along with some of the population.

John Kirkpatrick, one of the best of "modernist" pianists, gave another recital in Times Hall last night devoted to American composers, mostly contemporary. Mr. Kirkpatrick, rather than the composers, came off with all the honors.

First to finish in the sixth round of the amateur championship finals of the United States Chess Federation at national headquarters, Brooklyn, last night, was Edward S. Jackson Jr., titleholder. He made it five straight when he defeated J.S. Battell in 36 moves.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The House late today adopted and sent to the Senate the Commodity Credit Corporation Bill, which would end food subsidies after Dec. 31. The vote was 278 to 117.

MISHAWAKA, Ind., Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- The family of Private Charles Herman Kuhl, 26 years old, disclosed today that he had written from Sicily on Aug. 4 that he had been slapped and kicked by Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. and that General Patton had apologized to him later at a hearing.
PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association announced to day a move to end "shotgun" championship return bouts and "chain-store" fights not "based on championship merit."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- The Federal Communications Commission tonight crystallized its policy against multiple ownership of radio stations by issuing a ruling that no person or corporation might own or control more than a single standard broadcast station in any one area.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Lumber production for the first three-quarters of this year totaled 25,031,777,000 board feet, estimated at 8 to 10 per cent less than in the comparable period last year, the War Production Board announced today.

A General Sessions jury late yesterday afternoon convicted Max Shamus, 55 years old, as the confederate of two confidence women who four years ago defrauded four middle-aged residents of the lower East Side of $38,000 in a fantastic "project" to smuggle $30,000,000 in gold into this country from Canada, offering $1,000 profit for every $100 they invested.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- German forces have recaptured islands held by Yugoslav Partisans off the Dalmatian coast of Yugoslavia, where Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel has begun an offensive to clear his supply lanes from the northern Adriatic into the Balkans, dispatches from Cairo disclosed tonight.

Harry Wolkof, who was a power in the Brooklyn Democratic organization when the late John H. McCooey was the leader, went on trial yesterday before the justices of the Brooklyn Appellate Division for removal as the chief clerk of the Gates Avenue Municipal Court. Fourteen charges of misconduct had been filed against him.

PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 23 -- A warning that filling of war orders must continue to be the primary responsibility of industry until the day of victory was given by James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, in delivering the Crawley Memorial Lecture today at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce.

The stock market gave ground grudgingly yesterday under moderate selling, while activity contracted further as Wall Street sensed something brewing on the international horizon. Values were not reduced more than fractions in the general list, although there were scattered losses of 2 points or more.
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Wheat futures developed a reactionary tendency today after having been on the upgrade for seven days and prices averaged lower. Uneasiness in regard to proposed ceiling prices on all varieties of wheat, coupled with liberal profit-taking and evening-up operations and the better character of the war news from Europe, kept the market under pressure a good part of the day.

Year-end dividend payments totaling millions of dollars were declared yesterday by many companies. Action by boards of directors called for the resumption of payments, after a lapse of years, in some cases, while in others extras and increased annual disbursements were authorized.

Fanning out in a three-pronged drive, Federal agents swept yesterday through Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx and, in a smashing blow against the revived bootleg industry in New York City, conducted thirty-six liquor raids in which forty-four persons, including an alleged ringleader, were arrested.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totale d 1,013, which compared with 1,445 in the preceding week and 777 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Although unsuccessful, the campaign in support of the Fulmer bill to repeal special tax restrictions on the sale of oleomargarine has crystallized, various trade and consumer groups concerned and the industry now are considering a joint advertising campaign of "consumer education" to enlist public support for a renewal of its legislative appeals, it was reported yesterday.

Skippers and crews of the International Class of sloops, the foremost racing group on Long Island Sound last summer, held their annual dinner meeting last night in the New York Yacht Club and awards were made to the winning owners.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- William Eythe, now in the cast of Twentieth Century-Fox's "Wilson," has been named by that company to replace Randolph Scott in the lead in "Wing and a Prayer," a naval aviation story formerly titled "Torpedo Squadron 8," which has been in preparation for more than eleven months.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Unmistakable signs of growing resistance to authority and even of a fatalistic acceptance of impending defeat are beginning to find their way into public statements inside Europe. Four broadcasts -- from Berlin, Budapest, Valladolid, Spain and Vichy -- yesterday illustrate the point.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, acting for King George VI, today decorated eleven officers and one former American member of the RAF for their heroic actions in war theatres from Iceland to the Middle East.

The radio address that was to have been delivered last night from Mexico City by former King Carol of Rumania over the Columbia Broadcasting System was canceled a few hours before the exiled monarch was to have gone on the air. An order of the Office of Censorship in Washington rescinded its previous approval of the broadcast.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Under an order signed today by Advisory Master Dougal Herr, here, Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell and her Nevada attorneys were restrained temporarily from proceeding with her divorce suit against James H. R. Cromwell, who had previously filed a New Jersey suit for separation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Nov. 23 -- Admiral William F. Halsey's air forces kept up their heavy pounding of enemy positions from Dutch islands to Bougainville in the Solomons yesterday, thus keeping the enemy engaged on his heels in this area while the central Pacific operations are in progress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- How American yard goods saved the Tunisian olive crop was told today to the fashion group by Jerome I. Udell, chief of the clothing and textile branch of the Office of Foreign Reilef and Rehabilitation Operations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -- Savings in the form of currency and bank deposits by American individuals during the third quarter of this year, according to an estimate made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, amounted to $2,700,000,000 against $3,000,000,000 saved in the second quarter and $3,800,000,000 in the first, or a total of $9,500,000,000 for nine months.

With Rudolf Serkin as an enkindling piano soloist, the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy gave a delightful concert at Carnegie Hall last night. Beethoven's infrequently performed Concerto No. 1, in C, Op. 15, received a memorable performance.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 23 -- The Bougainville offensive was hailed by New Zealanders today as an encouraging and even dramatic disclosure of the growing strength of Allied south Pacific forces, indicating a grave threat to Rabaul.
The Army expects almost to double its staff of occupational therapists within the next year and to do so must draw largely upon therapists already in the field, it was revealed here yesterday.

Twelve thousand spectators at Madison Square Garden last night cheered to the echo the opening of the Ice Follies of 1944, here for a run of ten nights and two matinees. The initial performance of this, the eighth edition of the Follies, was for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Fund.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 23 -- Makin atoll in the northern Gilbert Islands has been captured and our invasion of other islands is progressing well.

The four stix-story apartment buildings known as Riverdale Park at 254th Street and Riverdale Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by Webb Knapp, Inc. The development is the most recently completed apartment house project erected under a Federal Housing Administration insured mortgage in the New York area.

Paintings from the collection of the late J.P. Morgan, which are to be sold by order of his estate, were placed on exhibition yesterday afternoon at the galleries of M. Knoedler Co., 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. They will remain on public exhibition through Dec. 11.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A coalition of the oil and coal groups of the House put into action today a drive designed primarily to strip the Office of Price Administration of controls over the prices of these fuels, but which may be expanded to cover food as well. Complete success of the movement, it was conceded, would about wreck the OPA.
CHUNGKING, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

Four hundred women refugees from Hitler's Europe are now well paid skilled workers in the city's garment industry. Graduates of the only trade school for foreign-born women operated in this country by the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, they are demonstrating how easily bridged is the gap between the unskilled and the essential workers, ORT officials said yesterday on the school's first anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Increased coal prices to meet increased costs will be announced tomorrow by the Office of Price Administration, it was learned tonight after the Solid Fuels Administration had wired anthracite shippers in critical areas, including New York, to fill any coal orders they have held up because of the price uncertainty.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A record November snowfall lasting more than 36 hours ended tonight after partially paralyzing communications and transportation facilities in northern and eastern New York and contributing to three deaths.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 24 -- A great armada of British bombers won one of the war's most significant victories Monday night when in the heaviest air assault of history it blew the heart out of Berlin with more than 2,300 long tons of high explosive and incendiary bombs and repaid the debt of London.

GUADALCANAL, Nov. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Potato-shaped little Nauru lost most of its strategic air value to Japan as the result of a 1,400-mile blow today by heavy land-based bombers of Maj. Gen. Nathan B. Twining's Thirteenth Army Air Force.

THE Yankees have settled on Atlantic City as the base for their "Southern" training next Spring and that was refreshing news. Most of the correspondents who froze with the champions last year and had to resort to uninspiring interviews with Joe McCarthy in order to fill up space, breathed prodigious sighs of relief which blew off every hat in the neighborhood.

Four men arraigned here yesterday were accused of operating a black market in ration stamps that brought used stamps back into circulation and gave unscrupulous dealers in rationed commodities an unfair advantage over law-abiding competitors.

A hundred gaily clad children crowded into the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, yesterday for their annual Thanksgiving dinner. Before the feast, the children staged a one-act play entitled "The Farmyard."

High bidder yesterday for a new issue of $6,040,000 Chattanooga, Tenn., electric power refunding revenue bonds, was a syndicate headed by the Equitable Securities Corporation of Nashville, Tenn., with branch offices in New York and other cities.

There was no talk of championships yesterday as the Giants launched work for Sunday's return meeting at the Polo Grounds with the Dodgers. Until last Sunday Steve Owen and his men believed they had a real chance to catch the Redskins.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- In the most drastic action of his twenty-two-year regime, Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, today barred William D. Cox, president of the Phillies, from baseball for life for gambling on games in which his club was involved.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 23 -- An eyewitness from Berlin of the British bombing attack last night told the writer here today that the French Embassy on the Pariser Platz and the British Embassy on Wilhelmstrasse were razed by explosives and incendiaries.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 23 -- The subcommittee of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration that is charged with formulating policies for the repatriation of the millions of "displaced" persons who have been scattered all over Europe and Asia by the war is confronted with one of the most difficult series of problems that have come before the Atlantic City conference

NAPLES, Nov. 23 -- Cesare Rossi, one of the key fascist figures at the time of the Matteotti murder in 1924, was arrested two days ago in Sorrento. He will be held in Naples for questioning and, if he tells all that he knows, the history of fascism will be enriched with some lurid behind-the-scenes details.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for immediate action on a three-point program of Federal aid for demobilized service men and women.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23 -- Captain John E. Whelchel, Navy's head coach, today picked out fifty-two members of his Midshipmen football squad to make the trip to West Point for the forty-fourth Army-Navy clash on Saturday.

New York State's post-war education program, as outlined by the Board of Regents, deserves public support. Especially interesting is the plan for the establishment of fifteen educational Institutes in this State. These training institutions will bridge the gap that now exists between high schools and colleges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- In the immediate post-war period food rationing will have to be continued on an even stricter basis than at present, Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard said today in reply to a question put during his appearance before the Senate special committee on post-war policy and planning.

All branches of industry were warned yesterday by Lou R. Maxon, former OPA deputy administrator under Prentiss Brown, that unless they help preserve the traditional American "freedom of choice" by joining without delay the food trade's almost single-handed wartime fight against grade labeling they run the risk of having their post-war products standardized by "the present crop of bright young men in Washington."

The second week of the diamond jubilee season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, beginning next Monday night, will be marked by two revivals and three debuts. Verdi's "Rigoletto" will be revived on Friday evening of next week after a lapse of a year, and Thomas' "Mignon" on the next night after a four-year absence.

Napoleon never got the chance to knock large pieces off the Houses of Parliament the way his would-be successor did in the Battle of Britain three years ago. But if Napoleon could see what the British are doing with some of the pieces from their battered Palace of Westminster he would be more than ever convinced that they are a nation of shopkeepers.

PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 23 (AP) -- Husky, 28-year-old Robert R.M. Carpenter Jr., Wilmington, Del., socialite-sportsman, was named president of the National League Phillies today, youngest man in baseball's history to head a major league club.

Now operating as a municipal enterprices, the 2,800-seat City Center formerly Mecca Temple, will commence its theatrical activities, Dec. 13-18, with a revival of Rachel Crothers' successful play, "Susan and God." This was officially announced yesterday by John Golden, who will be responsible for the production, and Newbold Morris, president of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Hope for a United Nations Conference "this winter" to reach final agreement on a world bank and machinery for maintaining stability of international exchange was expressed today by Treasury experts as Secretary Morgenthau transmitted to the Finance Ministers a detailed outline of what our Government's technicians think the world bank should be like.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Powerful agencies working within the Netherlands for the future government of the country were encouraged to continue their close and effective collaboration with the authorities at exiled headquarters tonight by Queen Wilhelmina in a broadcast.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 24 -- German forces, driving back toward Kiev and the Dnieper line without regard for prodigious losses, yesterday reached the vicinity of Brusilov, less than fifty miles from the Ukraine capital, Moscow acknowledged today.

The New York Stock Exchange has suspended from dealings the $10 par value capital stock of the Simms Petroleum Company because of the small assets remaining after payment of a liquidating dividend and because of the small aggregate market value of the issue.

Pratt's Fresh Frosted Foods, Inc., packers of the quick-frozen spaghetti creole and Spanish rice that have been mentioned in this column, recently introduced, three new frozen product. One of these is a cooked chow mein, composed of bean sprouts, onions, celery and seasonings, that needs only to be heated and served atop hot rice or noodles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The United Mine Workers of America and soft-coal operators representing about half the country's tonnage have tentatively approved the terms of the wage agreement reached by John L. Lewis, UMW president, and Secretary Harold L. Ickes and approved by the National War Labor Board.
New York hotels and restaurants, expect a record Thanksgiving Day business because thousands of families unable to buy turkeys are intending to dine out.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Legislation to remove the registration fee on transactions in Government bonds on national security exchanges was approved today by the Senate Banking Committee and a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee.

The annual report of the A.M. Byers Company issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended with September shows a net profit of $1,148,225, equal to $2.84 a share of common stock, which compares with $1,195,422, or $3.02 a common share, earned in the previous fiscal year.

WEST POINT, N.Y, Nov. 23 -- In the opinion of Lieut. Col. Earl Blaik, the Navy football team that will play Army here in Michie Stadium on Saturday is so much better than the 1942 midshipman varsity that there is no comparison.

Following what is described as the heaviest aerial attack in history, the British Royal Air Force last night again carried the war to the heart and brain center of the enemy. Berlin, the capital from which declarations of war have been flung at other nations for the last two hundred years, was left a sea of flames by the first of these two attacks, which has now been hammered home by the second.

After being recalled from his vacation and questioned for hours Monday night, Patrolman David A. Liebman was suspended yesterday afternoon, without pay, pending a departmental trial on charges growing out of his speech in Brooklyn Sunday.

While New York baseball men, preparing for the major and minor league meetings that will be held here next week, were recovering from the reverberations in the wake of Commissioner Landis' banishment of William D. Cox last night, the deposed president of the Phillies stepped into the picture in person and, in a radio broadcast, gave "his side of the story."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A special board recommended today that freight carriers have wider latitude to arrange rate schedules and procedure as a means of improving their services to the public. The report, submitted to President Roosevelt and to Congress, suggested amendment of the Interstate Commerce Commission laws to give the rail, motor and water carriers this authority.

A meeting to protest against the August Kings County grand jury presentment on crime conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area in Brooklyn was held yesterday afternoon by the National Negro Congress and the Bedford-Stuyvesant Congress of Industrial Organizations Community Council at 474 Summer Avenue, Brooklyn, with 100 persons present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Under pressure from several Republicans and Democrats, the managers of the bill to provide for the casting and counting of 1944 Federal election ballots by the armed forces have made certain pledges tending to assure public confidence in the conduct of the poll, and the bill has been greatly improved.

ALGIERS, Nov. 23 -- Rene-Massigli announced in the Provisional Consultative Assembly today that the agreement made last November between Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark and the late Admiral Jean-Francois Darlan was considered out of date and would be revised.

CHUNGKING, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have thrown parachute troops into the battle in northern Hunan Province, where enemy forces are closing in from all sides on the important highway junction of Changteh, west of Lake Tungting, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Nov. 23 -- John R. Longo, former deputy Hudson County clerk, convicted a week ago yesterday on charges of "fraudulent alteration" of his voting record, is still held without bail in the Hudson County jail today, despite "startling" evidence introduced yesterday in Quarter Sessions Court, intending to show that Longo was the victim of a frame-up.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- After being questioned all night, Mrs. Anna Belak, a 77-year-old grandmother, confessed early today that she had killed her husband, John Belak, 69, on Sunday; under circumstances that she had hoped would result in his death being charged to his friend, John Kovach, who is 45.
FOOCHOW, China, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- The big question today in this isolated "open" port of China is whether or not the Japanese will invade and loot it again as they did twice in 1941.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, spent his sixty-fifth birthday today in planning new blows against the Axis.
Thanksgiving services will be held tomorrow morning in many churches and synagogues of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Senate adjourned today until Friday out of respect to Senator W. Warren Barbour, Republican, of New Jersey, whose death occurred last night. A committee was appointed to attend the funeral in Paterson, N.J., tomorrow.

ALGIERS, Nov. 23 -- There was less rain but more mud than ever on the Italian front yesterday, and, although there were sharp actions on several sectors, the Allies' gains were restricted to the seizure of limited additional ground southeast of Alfedena.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Property and plant equipment worth at least $2,652,000,000 have been acquired by the State as a result of war expenditures in Britain, the Select Committee on National Expenditures announced today. The committee proposed that accurate records be compiled against the day when the tangle must be straightened out.

The first political result of the death of Representative Henry B. Steagall, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, again calls attention to the anomalous consequences of the Congressional system of choosing the heads of committees on the principle of seniority.

All securities and commodity markets in the United States will observe the Thanksgiving holiday tomorrow. All banks will be closed, except those in Kentucky. Canadian and British markets and banks will be open as usual. Markets and banks in the United States that observe the holiday will reopen on Friday.

Matthew Damiani, a former small-time horse race book maker turned war emergency ambulance attendant, was held in $7,500 bail in the Felony Court yesterday in the theft of an $800 diamond ring and $125 in money last Monday from the body of Dr. Howard L. Mullen, a dentist.

The board of managers of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company and the directors of the New York, Lackawanna Western Railway Company signed yesterday an agreement to merge. The agreement will be submitted to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authorization and to the stockholders of the companies for their approval.

The Gilbert Islands swim into our ken gradually. Americans already have three of them. There are at least thirteen more. These shall be nameless here until conquered. In the mid-western Pacific the group rides the Equator, 4 N to 3 S, and a bit west of the 180th meridian line.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress on providing for the return to civilian life of service personnel follows:

Hollywood's foibles as seen through the eyes of the unpredictable William Saroyan are pointed out in his newest play, "Get Away Old Man," opening this evening at the Cort under the direction and sponsorship of George Abbott.

There is only a tenuous connection between the forty-four-nation relief conference plodding on in Atlantic City and a London report that salvaging companies are itching to get at the job of raising the sunken vessels lying in heaps around the coasts of the British Isles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The current central Pacific offensive, of which the successfully progressing invasion of the Gilbert Islands is the opening gun, marks "the beginning of a new campaign against the Japanese on a much more direct route to Japan," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared today.

The Dow Chemical Company, through a group headed by Smith, Barney Co., will offer today 196,126 shares of its new $4 cumulative preferred Series A stock at $105 a share, or a total of $20,593,230. The offering will complete the company's program to raise $26,000,000 in new working capital.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Beating F.A. Pairuli's Legation by a nose in a photo finish, Mrs. Wallace Renard's Clip Clop drove through a snowstorm at Rockingham Park today to win the feature race.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress on providing for the return to civilian life of service personnel follows:

Hollywood's foibles as seen through the eyes of the unpredictable William Saroyan are pointed out in his newest play, "Get Away Old Man," opening this evening at the Cort under the direction and sponsorship of George Abbott.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Ousting of Mrs. Ana Rosa de Martinez Guerrero as Argentine member of the Inter-American Commission of Women, and consequently from the presidency of the commission, is regarded by her friends here as a symptom of the trend toward a changed status for women under the Ramirez regime.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The stock markets here were almost inactive today and the tendency of prices generally was to decline.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- In a breeze so stiff it kept all their flags and banners billowing, the capital's 660 Spars paraded past Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today in their first anniversary review.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Retail prices, as measured by the Bureau of Labor Statistics' cost-of-living index for large cities, rose four-tenths of 1 per cent from mid-September to mid-October, largely because of increases in the price of eggs, clothing and miscellaneous goods and services.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- In a day's fighting during which the Russians reported nearly 200 German tanks put out of action the First Ukrainian Army Group held its ground against fierce attacks and Gen. Konstantin K. Rokossovsky broke through Gomel's northern defensive system, substantially widened his salient west of the Dnieper and drove the last Germans from the river's right bank south of Rechitsa.

ALGIERS, Nov. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. struck and insulted a shell-shocked American soldier in an evacuation hospital in Sicily last August and ordered the patient to return to the front lines, it was officially revealed today. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower denounced the conduct of the commander of the American Seventh Army as "despicable" and threatened to break him unless he made amends at once.

A warning that New York City's supply of milk would be "exceedingly short" today as a result of the heavy snowstorm in Eastern New York and New England was released from Mayor La Guardia's office last night.

Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, speaking last night in a forum discussion at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, called for the adoption of policies to stimulate post-war capital investment in independent local enterprises managed by the owners themselves.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Dean Acheson, assistant secretary of state and chairman of the first council session of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, revealed tonight that the total cost of UNRRA operations in the liberated areas was officially fixed at $2,000,000,000 instead of the $2,500,000,000 hitherto estimated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Congressional authorization for the acquisition, conversion or construction of 2,500,000 additional tons of auxiliary vessels and 1,000,000 tons of landing and district craft is asked in a bill introduced in the Senate today by Senator David I. Walsh of Massachusetts, chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs, upon the Navy's request.
" IT seems like a dream," said Uncle Mott, "that we're a-goin to move into a mansion and be somebody!"

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -- There's a gridiron version of "Where's Elmer?" going around the Pennsylvania campus these days of hurried last-minute preparations for the annual Turkey-less day embroglio with Cornell.

The Allied command in a special broadcast to France warned the population a few days ago that a series of specified industrial districts in that country had been designated as primary targets for Allied air attacks. Plants manufacturing airplanes and airplane parts hold first place in the objectives told off for destruction.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Shelter and housing were among subjects occupying the spotlight today on the many-sided program the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is planning to obtain the utmost in aid and comfort for stricken civilian populations in war-torn areas.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Nov. 24 (UP) -- A communique:

Tight market conditions on winter apparel, particularly women's coats, will not only defer traditional retail clearances until after the turn of the year, but are likely to make those which are held of comparatively small size in many sections of the country, reports here yesterday indicated. Markdowns for the most part will be confined to odds and ends, poor colors and odd sizes, merchandisers said.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Testimony was completed here today before Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan in a stockholders' suit brought against the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and twenty-four officers and directors to obtain repayment of alleged illegal bonuses received by the officers in 1939-41.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Community action to get women into jobs and community action to help them stay there have been found efficacious in nine labor-tight areas on which a report was made today by the Office of War Information.

Space for offices in the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue, has been leased to the Information Bureau of Uruguay under the direction of Roberto Fontaina, attache to the Embassy of Uruguay in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, defended the "Canol" oil project in Northern Canada before the Truman committee today as a bold undertaking which had uncovered from 50,000,000 to 100,000,000 barrels of oil which might prove the controlling factor in an air offensive against the heart of the Japanese empire. He said the War Department was "proud of Canol."

American exporters, in their current awareness of the post-war potentials of the Latin-American market, should not neglect the opportunities offered by Europe, the Middle East and other areas of world commerce, foreign traders asserted yesterday at a meeting of the American Office Supply Exporters Association.

Federal Judge John Bright cleared Ralph Pierce yesterday of having conspired with Willie Bioff and George E. Browne to extort $2,500,000 from the movie industry. Decision was reserved on defense motions for acquittal of the seven others with whom Pierce had gone on trial Oct. 5.

How puzzled a Japanese must be just now. Here, only a week or so ago, he was being told in triumphant broadcasts, night after night, that an American fighting fleet had been shattered off Bougainville. Battleships were sunk, cruisers sunk, airplane carriers sunk, and smaller craft too numerous to mention.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE in the Central Pacific, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- United States Marine assault battalions today conquered the west end of Betio Island, on Tarawa atoll, driving the defenders into the sea and others onto the eastern open flat sections where they became excellent targets for dive-bombing and strafing attacks.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The abortive British campaign in the Aegean Islands that resulted in the German conquest of Kos, Leros and Samos and in sharp criticism in London, was defended today in the House of Commons by Maj. Clement R. Attlee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner, announced today that the Procurement and Assignment Service of WMC would hold a National Nurses Mobilization Week, registration starting Feb. 7. Mr. McNutt expressed the hope that "every nurse in the country will appreciate the need for her services and will offer them voluntarily for either military or essential home duty."

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The question whether Home Secretary Herbert Morrison permitted himself to be made a catspaw by the Tories when he led the movement for the release of Sir Oswald Mosley has not yet been answered, but it appears that he took his political life into his own hands when he became "front man" for the maneuver that transferred Britain's No. 1 Fascist from prison to a private home.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- The Germans were reported today to have received fresh reinforcements, including tanks, during the last twenty-four hours and to have involved them at once in the battle still raging on the periphery of the Kiev bulge.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week reached new high records, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Pronounced gains were reported in industrial production, in originating shipments and in the volume of trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Mr. Craven in his testimony urged that Congress end the jurisdictional row between the FCC and Interdepartmental Radio Advisory Committee by redefining their powers and creating a Presidential mediation board with "Cabinet status."

Mortimer M. (Mort) Mahony, dean of mutuels managers at tracks in this country, has resigned at Belmont Park and Saratoga, but will continue in his position at Hialeah Park, Miami, this winter. Recently Mahony suffered a heart attack and, while his doctors have approved the Florida occupation because of the climate, the Maryland veteran thought it wise to place the two New York associations in a position to select his successor.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the speech delivered by King George VI at the opening of a new session of Parliament yesterday:

New York's importance as a transportation center is destined to increase tremendously after the war because of its growing industrial activity, George A. Sloan, chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, declared yesterday in outlining the economic progress of this city up to the present time and predicting its further development.

Except for some scattered postseason games to be held in the near future, the scholastic football season in the metropolitan area reaches the end of the road today. The Thanksgiving Day program, highlighted by many traditional battles, offers more than sixty games on four fronts.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 24 -- Eyewitness reports to the Swiss press from the frontier late tonight estimate that 25 per cent of Berlin was flattened by early Wednesday as a result of the two RAF attacks on Berlin.

Ralph W. Gallagher, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, who recently returned from an inspection trip to Venezuela, said yesterday that South America, particularly Venezuela and Colombia, holds the greatest future for the expansion of the world's oil productive capacity.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Nov. 25 (UP) -- A communique:

Patrolman David A. Liebman, who at a mass meeting on Sunday called to discuss the alleged prevalence of crime in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn declared that police morale was at its lowest ebb in ten years because of the attitude of Mayor La Guardia, must face departmental trial.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A grandmother, four young men and the mother of a three-month-old son have been summoned for arraignment Friday on indictments returned by the county grand jury in connection with the slaying of William Lederer, dance hall operator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- If you have spots before your eyes better see an oculist. If you have spots on your plate just pick up your fork and go to it, they're Norfolk spots, akin to perch, and quite edible. Introduced to the capital recently, they have already won adherents hereabouts -- although inevitably dissenters exist and are vocal about it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- With a burst of speed, the Senate Naval Affairs Committee approved today a $5,300,000,000 naval construction program -- largely involving craft for amphibious operations -- in advance of its formal introduction in the Senate.

The New York Stock Exchange was notified yesterday that Donald G. Millar had been elected a director of the American Distilling Company on Aug. 18. Last week the company sent in the information that Thomas E. Bragg had resigned as a director on Oct. 15 -- before the run-up in the company's shares and the announcement of liquor-purchase rights.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 25 -- In a Thanksgiving Day battle fought between midnight and dawn northwest of Bougainville American naval vessels sank four Japanese destroyers and damaged another of the six enemy destroyers intercepted, a communique issued by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

Sunday at the Polo Grounds marks the end of the road for the Football Dodgers, and a bumpy road it has been. Detoured from the main course in their first six trips, the hastily assembled Brooks started to click and picked up speed against the Cardinals and Steagles, but ran into a head-on collision with the Packers that sealed a permanent cellar berth in the National Football League's Eastern Division.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 24 -- Tuesday night's Royal Air Force attack on Berlin was as disastrous as Monday night's, with many more explosions than Monday, affecting principally North Berlin.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The blending of ancient customs with the ever present reminder of modern war at the ceremonial opening of the new session of Parliament in Westminster today harmonized with the twofold message given to the nation; that Britain's leaders hope to fight through to victory in the coming year and, while so doing, to lay the foundation for a better life when peace returns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Machine tool shipments last month totaled approximately $76,000,000, a decline of about 11 per cent from the $85,842,000 September value, a preliminary report from the War Production Board's tools division revealed today.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Two non-commissioned officers at nearby Fort Story are trying to make themselves as inconspicuous as possible these days.

Punishing blows against Japan's surface raiders and submarines by Allied air and sea forces have resulted in almost normal tea shipments from India and Ceylon to the United States, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said today, according to The Associated Press.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 24 -- If there are any priorities among war victims when the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration embarks on its mission of mercy agent after the war, the children come first. This policy was announced today for UNRRA by the welfare committee. With the additional state ment in regard to priorities "of paramount importance, too, is the provision of immediate aid to pregnant women and nursing mothers."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia, charged today that Argentina shows "strong fascist tendencies" and has encouraged a British-dominated monopoly pool embracing producers of a valuable leather tanning extract, quebracho, found chiefly in the Argentine.

Meyer O. Mortensen, 35 years old, a former ship rigger of Everett, Mass., who had admitted on his arrest on a pistol possession charge early in September that he had perpetrated seventy-five minor hold-ups in this city, entered a guilty plea yesterday in General Stations to robbery with a pistol as a second offender.
LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 25 -- Berlin, the political, military and commercial capital of Germany, is undergoing the greatest trial by fire bomb ever visited on an enemy city.

THE TIMES editorial of Nov. 20, "To Hold the Line," summarized the steps leading to inflation, particularly successive wage lifts to unappeased labor. You then said: "Farm prices have been raised under the insistent pressure of the powerful farm bloc, and farm incomes have recorded a larger rise than those of any other group -- with further increases certain if the wage drive succeeds."

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 -- Two well-trained United States Army levens will play the first game of American football to be seen in Egypt as a feature of Thanksgiving Day activities of the Special Services Division of United States Army Forces in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee voted today to call on Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, for "a full and complete" report on the case of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., who struck and insulted a knell-shocked American soldier in an evacuation hospital in Sicily last August, "and all incidents connected with it."

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Margaret Drury, 24-year-old Lancashire girl who stowed away to fly from England, has been allowed to enter Canada for six months to work with the Royal Air Force Transport Command.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 25 -- Russia's Ukrainian Army rallied to crack the furious German counter-attack in the Kiev sector on its eleventh day yesterday, killing 1,500 Nazis and blasting thirty-two enemy tanks in bitter defensive fighting that improved Soviet positions in the Chernyakhov and Brusilov sectors.

Members of the Alumnae Association of Hunter College participated yesterday in the annual Thanksgiving Day assembly, which was dedicated by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, to those who "carry the fight for freedom forward."

When we have finally succeeded in ordaining and establishing the century of the common man, will we allow the common man to decorate his parks and public squares with the kind of statues of the kind of famous men he likes, within reason?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Army's "Canol" oil project in north" Canada was justified before the Truman committee by Brig. Gen. Walter B. Pyron, its petroleum expert, on the ground that it was a safeguard in case of the closing of sea lanes to Alaska by Japanese attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Coordinator of the Solid Fuels Administration for War, sought today to enlarge the soft coal wage conference by appealing to twenty-one absentee operators to attend it for patriotic reasons.

Tuesday, Admiral Ernest Joseph King was 65. He became Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet in December, 1941. It will be two years next March since he succeeded Admiral Stark as Chief of Naval Operations. Effectually and imperturbably he discharges the duties of these two momentous posts.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- A Fascist punitive patrol led by Roberto Farinacci, former Fascist party secretary, killed twenty-two anti-Fascists by shooting them in the back of the neck in reprisal for the death of a local party dignitary at Ferrara, reports from the Italian frontier said today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recoded by the United Press:
LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

BOUGAINVILLE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- American planes have bombed the Japanese lines on this northern Solomons Island so effectively that when it does not kill the Japanese it stuns them out of the fight. That's the observation of Lieut. Col. W.K. Pottinger of the Marines, Hillsboro, Texas, air operations officer.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh of New York City "exceeded the discretionary power granted to him" when he declined to appoint Isidore Berger and forty-seven others to be firemen, the Court of Appeals decided today.

Both the Administration and Congress -- and both parties in Congress -- share responsibility for the wholly inadequate tax bill which was adopted yesterday by the House of Representatives under a gag rule, without any real debate and apparently without any real awareness of the dangers of inflation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 24 -- Brown and Colgate will close their football seasons tomorrow in the twenty-fifth game of their thirty-five-year-old series, with Colgate established the favorite. Loss of Ed Fiorentino, 200-pound end, on the eve of the game, struck heavily Bruin hopes.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Declaring that distribution of "anti-Semitic doggerel" was "damaging to the war effort," the four Massachusetts commanders of veterans organizations called upon citizens and officials today "to take immediate steps to stamp out the distribution of this unwholesome and un-American propaganda."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Hudson County Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan, who on Monday was accused by Raymond Chasan of suppressing evidence vital in a case, announced today he was preparing charges of unethical conduct against Mr. Chasan to present to the State Bar Association and the New Jersey Supreme Court.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 24 (AP) -- J.C. McLaughlin's Icystream took the lead at the halfway mark in the six-furlong Raymond Purse at Rockingham Park today and was never threatened thereafter. Mrs. F. Carberry Jr.'s Blue Steel was second and Lyle Phillips' Tetra Rock ran third.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- The Navy announced seventy-six casualties today, including forty dead, ten wounded and twenty-six missing.

Pre-holiday liquidation combined with selling induced by the expectancy of an announcement regarding the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference to produce yesterday a further easing of prices on the stock market. Repeated statements by Henry J. Kaiser, builder-industrialist, that the peak of warfare production had been witnessed also served to place accent on the post-war issues, against the weakness among the railroad stocks.

" TECHNICALLY, it's against the league rules for you to sit on the bench with us," said Curly Lambeau before his Pachyderms from Green Bay tangled with the Dodgers last Sunday. He thought a moment and added brightly, "I have it. You are hereby appointed assistant coach of the Green Bay Packers. That will do it."

Directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Chicago's largest bank, and the fifth largest bank in the nation, announced yesterday a plan to increase capital and surplus, which now stand at $50,000,000 each, to $60,000,000 each. These increases would be effected by transfers from undivided profits.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Wacs have been in the North African battle area almost a year and the first contingent has landed in Italy, the closest they have been permitted to the fighting front. Only five were in the first group that came here last December.
City College has awarded Tremain scholarships of $250 each to thirty-eight students, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Noble Wright, president.

Prospects for the post-war period will be bright providing a mobile and flexible system under which costs and prices are allowed to find equilibrium levels, Prof. Emerson P. Schmidt of the University of Minnesota and economist for the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said last night in an address before the Research Bureau for Post-War Economics at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The shameful misuse of victory after the last war paved the way to the present conflict and should serve as an example of what not to do when a war is over, Rear Admiral Thomas L. Gatch, Judge Advocate General of the Navy, yesterday warned 970 midshipmen at the fifteenth class commencement exercises of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University.

The store property at 1056-58 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the A.S.B. Realty Company, Inc., to Louis C. Kott through Benjamin Bernstein and Eli Maron, co-brokers. This property is assessed for $115,000. Schlesinger Krinsky were the attorneys for the seller.

The Committee for the annual Downey Award, made under the auspices of the Pro Parvulis Book Club, a national book club for Catholic children, announces that the award will be made on Dec. 8, with the presentatios of the silver medal "for the finest American children's book written in the Catholic tradition."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- More than 100 cases of Scotch and rye whisky were counted tonight by State Liquor Authority agents in the George Starr Liquor Shop, Inc., 148 East Post Road, whose license was revoked today by the S.L.A. for diversion of liquor to the black market and other charges.

EDMONTON, Alta., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Russian women pilots are playing a prominent role in United Nations lend-lease by piloting planes from Alaska to the Russian front after they have been flown to the Far North from United States factories.

For the 818 boys and girls who were enrolled yesterday afternoon by the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in the Junior Citizens Service Corps, membership means the tackling of a new war job. Until now eighteen of them have served as junior recreation aides, and the others, all from the Harlem area, have worked at salvage.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- German newspapers make it clear that the Allied air offensive is creating all sorts of difficulties for women on the home front.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- There will be turkeys aplenty tomorrow for hundreds of thousands of American troops in the Mediterranean theatre, many of them for the second time observing the historic holiday overseas.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 24 -- I have been a Quisling broadcaster for German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels for two years. Anyone thinking this work is a bed of roses is sadly mistaken. Like crime, it doesn't pay. It means only hard work, long hours for little money and ostracism even by the Germans.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The German air force, facing vastly superior British, American and Russian forces on three air fronts in Europe, boasts a greater first-line strength -- at the expense of depleted reserves -- than it had in 1939, according to a Royal Air Force commentator.

Every once in a while on Saturday afternoon, some of the thousands who will be tuned in on the radio reports of the Army-Navy doings at West Point will switch their dials to the Midwest, where another "private" football game brings the end of the trail to one of the great teams of recent years.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The stock markets here were quiet again today and uncertain in tone.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Shipments of hogs this week increased beyond packers' slaughtering capacity and about 10,000 head were hold over today and farmers were urged again to curtail loadings. Receipts of hogs to date this week were 57,600 head, compared with 53,485 head for the same period last week.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- On Bou

After Henry J. Kaiser, the shipbuilder and president of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, had met yesterday with R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, and officers of Local 365, the union's Brewster affiliate, representing 18,000 employes, both men joined in expressing satisfaction with labor conditions as they now exist in the corporation's three plants.

Henryk Szeryng, 25-year-old Polish violinist, made his initial appearance in this country last night at Carnegie Hall. With Erich Itor Kahn at the piano, the youthful artist was heard in a program comprising the Vitali "Chaconne," Beethoven's "Kreutzer" sonata, Wieniawski's concerto in D minor, and a final group composed of a Mozart rondo, Szymanowski's "Song to Roxana" and Sarasate's "Danza Andaluza."

Mitchel Field Brought a trio of former Long Island University players to Columbia's Morningside Heights gymnasium last night and defeated the Lion five, 45 to 36, in a game featured by a display of fancy ball handling and long distance shooting by Ozzie Schectman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Little Miami Railroad Company to merge the properties of the Columbus Xenia Railroad Company and to purchase the properties of the Dayton Western Railroad Company, and granted authority to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to acquire control of the Little Miami Railroad Company through ownership of capital stock.

Two 17-year-old youths were held on perjury charges yesterday in Kings County Court after they had testified for Thomas J. Kane, 25, who was being tried for stealing an automobile. Before the youths were booked Kane pleaded guilty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Federal Communications Commission has not now, nor can it be granted by Congress, power to discriminate against newspapers in the radio-broadcasting field, Whitney North Seymour of New York, successor to Judge Thomas D. Thacher as one of the counsel for the Newspaper-Radio Committee, declared at today s hearing on the! Wheeler-White bill before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

Some time ago the Fresno bombshell, William Saroyan, was lured to Hollywood to write what later became "The Human Comedy." At the time there drifted back fabulous reports from the Athens of the West, bizarre and weird chapters in the Saroyan saga.

NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 24 -- A picture of Benito Mussolini that goes further toward explaining his present "incorporeality" than any other was drawn yesterday morning by Gen. Antonio Passo, now Italian military commander for the region of Campania.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 -- Constantine Oumansky, Soviet Ambassador here, was understood today to be negotiating for the establishment of diplomatic relations between Russia and Brazil. Like many other Latin American republics, Brazil never has recognized the Soviet regime.

The Liebmann Packing Company of Green Bay, Wis., three of its officers and thirty-five other corporations and individuals were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that charged they had conspired to violate the ceiling prices on beef fixed by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Optimism about the country's post-war future was voiced today by CharlesI E. Wilson, president of the OeneralI Motors, in testimony before eF Senate Truman committee. He said that he believed in producing plenty rather than scarcity, andi was certain that the standard of] living of the -rnerican people: could be raised, i "

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The State Department has opened negotiations with Japan for further exchanges of interned civilian nationals following the recent exchange completed with the arrival of the motorship Gripshelm.

Heavy additions to stocks of gasoline and light fuel oil on the Eastern seaboard were made last week, but supplies of heavy fuel oil declined, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period, the institute's index covering gasoline stood at 39.5, compared with 36.6 a week earlier and that of light fuel off rose to 64.2 from 59.7.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- A foreshadow of tremendous problems facing the United Nations when the fighting ceases was given here yesterday when it was made known that the occupied countries of Europe will need 45,855,000 tons of foodstuffs, raw materials and "prime necessities" in the first six months of peace.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Celebrating with their fiftieth meeting the golden anniversary of their first clash in 1893, Pennsylvania and Cornell will play their annual football game on Franklin Field tomorrow before a crowd expected to reach between 55,000 and 60,000.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- The belief that Rumania was preparing to abandon Germany and withdraw from the war was expressed today by a spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Warfare.

The Music Box, one of the most desirable theatres in the Broadway sector, has been forced to operate under a form of city license usually reserved for the erstwhile burlesque houses because of objections by Paul Moss, License Commissioner, to "Star and Garter," present tenant of the theatre, it became known yesterday.

In your issue of Nov. 20 Secretary of Labor Perkins is quoted as saying: "The Federal Government, through an act of Congress, has recently provided for time and one-half pay for overtime for all employes for the express purpose of making it possible for them to meet the changes in the cost of living."

James Hadley, 40 years old, who has a seventeen-year criminal record, including four felony convictions and two State prison escapes, tried yesterday in General Sessions to persuade Judge John A. Mullen to suspend sentence on him for a midtown holdup.

Col. James Gardiner Conroy of 14 East Ninetieth Street, former commander of the old New York "Fighting Sixty-ninth," was killed Sunday in the assault on Makin atoll in the northern Gilbert Islands, it was learned here yesterday after his wife, Mrs. Marie Conroy, had received official word of his death. His age was 54.

After listening to testimony for two days, five justices of the Brooklyn Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on the proposed removal of Harry Wolkof as chief clerk of the Gates Avenue Municipal Court, Brooklyn. Wolkof, who has been in public life for twenty-six years, said it was a "plot" on the part of the Fusion administration when he was suspended on fourteen charges of alleged misconduct.

Benefiting to the extent of a full point through the nonappearance of Leo Churgin for his scheduled game in the seventh round of the United States Chess Federation amateur championship finals Edward S. Jackson Jr., titleholder last night in Brooklyn tied at 6 -- 0 for first place with Ariel Mengarini of Washington.

About 85 per cent of Argentina's people were on the side of the Allies even when the Axis seemed to be winning the war, and today virtually 95 per cent of the country's population is strongly pro-United Nations, Dr. Lucio Cherny, publisher of La Argentina, one of eight daily newspapers in Buenos Aires, declared yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria shortly after his arrival in this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A plan for handling orders for small tools for South Africa through regular commercial channels instead of through the lend-lease division of the Foreign Economic Administration has won approval in Washington and, if approved by officials of the Union of South Africa, will be put into operation in the first quarter of 1944.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 24 -- Walls of flame more than a half-mile long were reported licking at Berlin buildings today after the second massive air attack in two nights, but travelers said tonight that rain was helping Nazi firemen to keep them from spreading.

Because of acceleration in the rayon tire fabric program, announced Tuesday by the War Production Board, there is a distinct possibility that some weavers relieved by the Army's recent "cutback" of its fragmentation-bomb parachute needs may not be able to obtain a sufficient supply of rayon yarns suitable for producing essential civilian items, it was reported yesterday by cloth suppliers.

Capt. Nicholas N. Petterson, president of the Pettersen Lighter-age and Towing Company, 44 Whitehall Street, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents yesterday and turned over to the War Frauds Unit of the Department of Justice for prosecution.

Favorable war developments, sluggishness in grain markets and active liquidation of the December position cut prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday after slight early advances. All deliveries of old cotton futures recovered in the final moments from lows of 27 to 35 points to close 17 to 25 points under Tuesday's last levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Justice Department said that a Federal Grand Jury in Cincinnati returned today an indictment charging the Schweitzer Brothers Company of Cincinnati and two of its officials with sabotage and conspiracy to defraud the Government through defective welding of links used in tank baulks, supplied to the Navy.

Lieut. Claude Gravereaux, a soldier of Free France who won the Croix de Guerre and the Medaille Militaire for heroism during the French retreat through Belgium, received yesterday a military funeral at Governors Island before his body went to Arlington Cemetery.

Niles Trammel, president of the National Broadcasting Company, declared last night as he returned by plane from the Italian war zone that he would seek authority to extend the range of American broadcasting stations so that American news programs would be available half-way around the world.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Church and synagogue services, football games, many turkeyless dinners and a full day's work in war plants will mark New Jersey's second wartime Thanksgiving Day.

Furniture dealers have informally protested to the Office of Price Administration that it would be "impossible to live under three-way price control," which is being studied by that agency as a possible substitute for the General Maximum Price Regulation, retailers stated yesterday.

Despite snowstorms up-State on Tuesday, milk deliveries in New York City were normal yesterday and are likely to continue so, public officials and spokesmen for the leading distributing companies agreed yesterday. Mayor La Guardia's office had expressed fear on Tuesday that yesterday's deliveries might be short of normal by as much as 20 per cent.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Known throughout the Army as a "hot outfit," the untried Thirty-sixth Division, composed mainly of Texans, was singled out for the key mission of spearheading the American invasion of Italy at Salerno it was disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Herb Pennock, whom Connie Mack once called "baseball's smartest pitcher," was quoted tonight as saying he had been "approached" by Robert R.M. Carpenter Jr., new president of the Phillies, and offered the job of general manager.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- It probably will be taken at West Point with a liberal seasoning of salt, but the Navy football squad has been hit by another outbreak of colds, three days before the service academy elevens tangle in Michie Stadium up the Hudson.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (Reuter) -- "This is the real stuff," British Air Minister Sir Archibald Sinclair declared, shortly after Berlin reeled under Monday night's mighty air attack. "The real power of the Bomber Command is now operating normally.

AT ITALIAN HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHERN ITALY, Nov. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Marshal Giovanni Messe declared today that a complete purge of the Italian Army was necessary to remove technically incompetent and politically, dangerous officers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Office of Price Administration increased maximum prices for anthracite coal 35 to 70 cents a ton today, explaining that the advance was made to compensate operators to the extent required by recent increases in labor costs.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 -- Marriage, surprise winner of the New Orleans Handicap last winter, and eleven other thoroughbreds have been entered for the $2,000 added Thanksgiving Handicap for all ages here tomorrow in the opening feature of the sixty-five-day racing season at the Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that time was ripe from the standpoint of psychological warfare for the Rogers-Baldwin resolution recommending that President Roosevelt create a commission to "save the Jewish people of Europe from extinction at the hands of Nazi Germany."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Roosevelt, in an Executive Order signed on Saturday and made effective today, authorized the Secretary of War to take over and operate "any or all" of thirteen tannery plants in the Salem-Peabody area of Massachusetts.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A communique:

In its first major sale in more than a decade, the Trinity Operating Company, representing Trinity Church, has disposed of the ten-story heavy industrial and loft building at 233 Spring Street, through to Van Dam Street, to Ralph Dudley for investment, Alfred G. Nowakoski, head of the operating company, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Administration forces cast frantically about today for a compromise of the food subsidy issue, but opponents predicted that the House bill killing such payments would sweep through the Senate without being weakened.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- As a by-product of their 21-to-7 upset of the Bears last Sunday, the Redskins today own the best defensive record in the National Football League, having supplanted the Steagles, who won a 35-to-34 scoring spree from Detroit.

Injury overtook Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City lightweight, in training for his scheduled meeting Monday night with Sammy Angott and forced Promoter Mike Jacobs to set back two boxing dates at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- As of Oct. 31, the Defense Supplies Corporation disbursed $230,338,447 on account of claims for petroleum compensatory adjustments in connection with the transportation of petroleum and petroleum products to the Eastern Seaboard, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- The Wisconsin Public Service Corporation submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to change the voting power of the concern's authorized preferred stock to enable its parent, the Standard Gas and Electric Company, to include the corporation in a consolidated income tax return to effect tax savings.

The second "Long Parliament" in the history of England opened its ninth session yesterday with the unchanging ritual that typifies for its members and the British people the age and continuity of their free institutions. This Parliament has sat since 1935, the year of the ast general election, and by general consent will continue to sit until the war is over.

" All For All," the Jack Pearl-Harry Green starring vehicle, is in its last weeks at the Bijou, where it will terminate its engagement on Dec. 11. Having made its local debut on Sept. 29, the Norman Bruce (collective pseudonym) modernization of Aaron Hoffman's comedy, "Give and Take," will have received eighty-five performances.

Every nation has its feast of thanksgiving, but the American Thanksgiving will not be confused with any of the others. The distinction is not alone in the truly American kinds of food that we associate with this day -- the turkey, the cranberry sauce, the pumpkin pie. It is in the fellowship of a national memory.

Shipments of war materials in October by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company were the highest in the company's history, A.W. Robertson, chairman, reported yesterday. He announced, following a meeting of the company's directors, that billings for the month amounted to $63,113,578 -- a new high -- an increase of 3 per cent over last August, the previous high month.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Governments that receive food and other relief from the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will be required to refrain from using them as a political "weapon" to maintain themselves in power, according to a subcommittee report on distribution adopted unanimously today.

Lacking representation by a women's reserve, members of the United States Maritime Service are manning a booth at the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries in Madison Square Garden. While Wacs, Waves, Spars and women marines publicize their activities at recruiting stands, merchant seamen stanchly answer thousands of questions hurled at them by women visitors.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have occupied an important strong point in the southwestern outskirts of Changteh, Hunan Province highway junction west of Lake Tungting, but Chinese troops have killed more than 2,000 invaders and recaptured several villages on three other sides of the city, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's High Command announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were uneasy today and fairly general selling and liquidation developed, especially in rye, which broke sharply under heavy pressure from eastern and other commission houses, particularly the deferred deliveries.

The war against the bootlegger, the wildcat distiller and the whisky blacklegger reached new intensity yesterday -- with also a hint of padlocking thrown in as a warning to real estate owners -- in the following moves by State and Federal authorities:

The three five-story apartment houses at 1010-18 and 1020 Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, were sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to a client of Bernard H. Nearman, attorney, through the Eugene J. Busher Company, Inc., brokers. The property is assessed for $104,000.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 -- Broadcasting from Beirut this evening, General Catroux declared to the Lebanese:

The word most frequently used to describe Lorenz Hart was the word that fitted him best, puckish. He never quite grew up. He was the college boy of the Nineteen Twenties to the end. The peculiarly brittle quality of his humor stemmed from Morningside Heights, and two decades of deep immersion in Broadway never quite soaked it off.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:...

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 24 (AP) -- John B. Sullivan, an official of the Forestal Land, Timber and Railways, Ltd., declared tonight that the charges of Wendell Berge that the United States is at the mercy of an English-Argentine quebracho monopoly pool were "uncalled for and unjust in their failure to give credit where it is due."

Skiing in the northeastern United States will get off to an early start, the result of the heavy snowfall of the past few days. According to reports yesterday, many enthusiasts will don their wooden runners over the holiday week-end in the Berkshires, Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- Dennis O'Keefe has been signed to a two-picture contract by Edward Small, United Artists producer, and will play the male lead in "Up in Mable's Room." In his second picture he will be co-starred with William Bendix in 'Waltzing Mathilda," a comedy of American soldiers in Australia, to be based on an original yarn by Fred Chapman and Eddie Seabrook.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- With the destruction of the Nazi capital already greater than the Germans ever feared or even their most optimistic enemies ever dreamed of, the German press and radio screamed yesterday for "revenge," and a Berlin military spokesman told foreign press representatives this afternoon that the Allied "terror attacks against German towns now had assumed such proportions that we, to our regret, are forced to use our reprisal weapon."

Drypoint prints from color plates by Mortimer Borne will be shown at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries from Dec. 7 through 18. Mr. Borne received the Mrs. Henry F.
