Noyes Memorial Prize of $50 for "the best print in the exhibition" in the Society of American Etchers show, now at the National Academy of Design.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Here is a summary of the $2,140,000,000 tax bill adopted by the House today:
Well on the road toward recovery, Edward G. Barrow, 75-year-old president of the world champion Yankees, left the New Rochelle Hospital yesterday to spend Thanksgiving Day at his home in Larchmont.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle made a brief speech before the Provisional Consultative Assembly today but his few words were probably more significant than the declaration on foreign affairs that the Assembly passed unanimously in closing its three-day debate.
Here are a few hunting tales which, though not guaranteed, sound reasonable enough:

The performance of "Tristan und Isolde" last night was on the whole the most poetic and romantic interpretation of this particular opera that we have heard for many years in the Metropolitan Opera House. This was of course consequent upon Sir Thomas Beecham's treatment of the score.

The passage by the House, by more than a two-thirds majority, of the Commodity Credit Corporation Bill, with a provision that would end food subsidies after Dec. 31, presents an economic and political problem peculiarly difficult to solve under our divided form of Government.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24 (AP) -- In a list of seventy books selected by Princeton University's faculty and administration for some 1,200 Princeton students now in the armed forces, Homer's "Odyssey" is included with Lewis Carroll's "Alice in Wonderland."

With millinery plans for the Spring and Summer seasons of 1944 will under way, domestic straw braids made from synthetic yarns are recognized by the industry as essential to production of popular price millinery, according to a communication yesterday from the Millinery Stabilization Commission to Rubin Levine, a producer of these braids.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 24 -- The Gilbert Islands have fallen to American forces and resistance has ceased except for the efforts of enemy remnants to prolong final extinction of the last sniper and scattered foxhole inhabitant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- In line with its earlier announcements the Office of Price Administration today modified its restrictions in its price regulation for women's, girls' and children's outerwear garments.

A citation for service in the South Pacific has been awarded to Capt. Edward M. Littell of the Army Chaplains Corps, son of Bishop S. Harrington Littell, former Bishop of Honolulu, now retired, and Mrs. Littell of 110 Morningside Avenue, New York.

A long struggle for possession of the estate of August Diehn, German potash executive, who died in Berlin on Jan. 17, 1942, was foreseen yesterday when an accounting proceeding was filed in Surrogate's Court by public administrator James F. Egan.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 24 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain continues to consider himself a virtual prisoner today, while the Laval propaganda services strive to make it appear that nothing has happened.

One of the rarest of the rare arts of Spain was heard in Town Hall last night, when Andres Segovia played the guitar there again. An audience that filled every seat and the available standing room gave ovation after ovation throughout the performance, and went into cheers at the close, as the artist gave several encores.

Whatever the mood for relaxation after a long day's work, there is sure to be a trouser costume to fit it, so great is the variety of lounging styles being offered this season. Their inspiration is taken from the pages of history, from famous paintings or from South American countries.
Thanksgiving turkeys were involved in two family disputes that brought a pair of husbands into the Brooklyn and Queens Night Court last night as defendants in assault actions brought by their wives.

Three midtown theatres will present new film attractions this morning. At the Strand, "Northern Pursuit," a Warner Brothers' topical melodrama, will be the offering Errol Flynn is starred in the film, with Helmut Dantine, Julie Bishop, John Ridgley and Gene Lockhart in supporting roles. . . .

Advertisers generally have now become fully convinced of the actual seriousness of the paper shortage and the necessity for drastic economies in ther use of the product in order to avoid dangerous dislocation of their industrial operations, it was pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 261 soldiers killed in action in seven battle areas, the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, today requested the Marinship Corporation of Sausalito to delay action on the contemplated dismissal of 430 Negro workers, a course which the company had felt bound to take under an agreement with the boilermakers union of the American Federation of Labor.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Those ten scoring points that Buddy O'Connor of the Canadiens picked up in two week-end games had their effect on the official National Hockey League statistics released today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 -- The Fifteenth United States Air Force hammered two targets 1,000 miles apart today. Flying Fortresses attacked submarine pens, docks and repair facilities at Toulon, while Liberators made the first heavy-bomber attack on Sofia, Bulgaria.

Another large property in the Thirty-fourth Street retail shopping district passed to new control yesterday when Webb Knapp announced their purchase of 43-45 West Thirty-fourth Street through to 62-64 West Thirty-fifth Street from the Bowery Savings Bank.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Through the efforts of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command Berlin has now received a greater weight of bombs than any other city in the world.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., producers and refiners of vegetable oils, reported today a net income of $1,493,652, equal to $2.93 a common share for the year ended Aug. 28, after depreciation, interest and taxes, compared with $1,349,658, or $2.65 a share, the previous year.

Some men's neckwear manufacturers are reporting that they have been able to get out a little additional merchandise for the holiday period above previous expectations but indications are that the retail trade cannot look forward to any further supplies in addition to previous orders.

The General Motors Corporation has completed detailed plans for the rehabilitation and the re-employment of former employes who have been physically disabled in the war, according to H.W. Anderson, vice president in charge of personnel in a letter to general managers and personnel managers of the company's divisions.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 -- The British Eighth Army increased its pressure on the central front in Italy yesterday and, despite very little improvement in the weather, occupied Alfedena and an important though nameless road junction where the main highway from Isernia to Rionero splits in two.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- To establish fair standards whereby the War Shipping Administration can decide what compensation should be paid for the vessels it has requisitioned, purchased, chartered or insured, the Advisory Board on Just Compensation will hold public hearings at 10 A.M. Friday and Saturday.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor and chairman of its committee on post-war planning, made public yesterday a report submitted by the committee to Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate's special committee on post-war economic policy and planning, outlining some of the AFL's recommendations designed to ameliorate the expected difficulties of the transition period between war and peace production.

WASHINGTON, Nov 24 -- A plea for more time to complete its consideration of protests filed by fourteen hosiery manufacturers against provisions of MPR 339 covering women's rayon hosiery, was made to the United States Emergency Court of Appeals today by the Office of Price Administration.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 -- The Fifteenth United States Air Force hammered two targets 1,000 miles apart today. Flying Fortresses attacked submarine pens, docks and repair facilities at Toulon, while Liberators made the first heavy-bomber attack on Sofia, Bulgaria.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 -- One hot afternoon last June two correspondents, accompanied by a public relations officer, approached the staging area where final touches were being put to the plan for invading Sicily.

ALGIERS, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- The French Committee of National Liberation has capitulated entirely to British demands for a solution of the Lebanese independence crisis and has agreed to restore to office Premier Riad Soln and two other Ministers who it intended to dismiss, reliable informants said tonight.
TRENTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The approach of Christmas is delaying the enlistment of many eligible New Jersey women in the Women's Army Corps, the head of the State recruiting drive said today.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell made known yesterday that he would postpone decision on the recommendation of Frederick E. Crane, special master, for approval of the plan of compromise affecting the "recap" litigatic of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and the convertible debenture certificates litigation of the Associated Gas and Electric Company.
Seaman William Schaffer of the U.S.S. Yorktown, who gets his mail care of Postmaster, Division V-1-A, San Francisco, Calif., is going to receive a letter one of these days. It reads:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- T. A. M. Craven, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, told the special House committee investigating the FCC today that the agency is pervaded with "the doctrine of institutional social reforms through seizing powers not granted it."

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Unattractive salaries to part-time workers inconvenient centers where nurses can leave their children, and the gasoline shortage are preventing the return of hundreds of registered nurses to hospital duty, according to Miss Emily Creevey, executive secretary of the State Nursing Council for War Service.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- The amended recapitalization plan of the Southern Colorado Power Company, which will take the company out of control of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 -- Driving on relentlessly against obviously stiff resistance, the German troops along the Dalmatian coast continue to push the Yugoslav Partisans into an increasingly narrow coastal strip as the campaign to cut off Gen. Josip Broz [Tito] from the Adriatic waterway to Allied supplies in Italy proceeds.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 24 (AP) -- In a decision upsetting a twenty-three-year-old precedent, Judge John W. Delehant of Federal Court quashed an indictment for sabotage against Louis Roemig Jr., 44, on the ground that the grand jury which indicted him was illegally selected because women were deliberately excluded from jury service in Federal courts in the Northern Iowa District.
Leases of space on and near Broadway and expansion of quarters for several firms in that district constituted a feature of the commercial rental lists made public by brokers yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- That "special mission to London" on which Capt. Quentin Roosevelt and a group of fellow-officers came here today turned out to be the surprise of their lives -- a Thanksgiving eve party at Buckingham Palace.

The last faint rumblings having about subsided following the Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis explosion which on Tuesday had blasted William D. Cox out of baseball for life, attention yesterday turned to speculation on the identity of still another new figure about to make his appearance in the National League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The House dealt the Administration its second major defeat in two days with the passage of a $2,139,300,000 tax bill today, more than eight billion dollars less than the Treasury had asked. It was sent to the Senate by a standing vote, 200 to 27, members shouting down a motion by Representative Bertrand W. Gearhart, Republican, of California, to send the bill back to the Ways and Means Committee.
Many announcements were made yesterday of year-end dividends and several of them lifted annual payments of the companies making them well above the disbursements of the previous year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A method of including about 5,000,000 small business men and otherwise self-employed persons in the Social Security Act's old age provisions has been submitted to the Special Senate Committee to Study Problems of American Business.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 26 (UP) -- A communique:

ALTHOUGH the Netherlands now groans beneath the yoke of gauleiter, Gestapo and occupation troops and the Netherlands Indies now endure the frightful burden borne by all members of the Japanese East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere, the Dutch flag still flies over two other integral parts of the Dutch Kingdom, the territories of Surinam and Curacao.

The fifteen-story office and loft building at 170 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of Twenty-second Street, has been sold by the Chase National Bank to Charles Sturm, an investor, for cash above a mortgage of $112,500.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25 -Colgate had every reason to be thankful today, for it was largely due to Brown's generosity that the Red Raiders gained a 21-14 verdict and thus continued their domination of this football series.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- United States forces at Empress Augusta Bay, on Bougainville Island, in the northern Solomons, have repulsed another determined counter-attack by Japanese troops who seized positions northeast of the American positions and sought to prevent enlargement of the invaders' beachhead, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Nov. 25--The ten-year period immediately following the end of the war probably will not be marked by any radical changes in design of civil aircraft, Roy Chadwick, designer of the Royal Air Force Lancaster bomber and its commercial counterpart, the York transport, told members of the Design and Industries Association at Manchester today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 -- What was termed the apathy of the United States and British Governments toward the suffering of Jewish people in Nazi-occupied countries and the American Council for Judaism's opposition to Zionism were castigated today by Miss Naomi Chertoff of New York, national president of Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist organization of America.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Italy, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, speaking within the sound of his guns on the Sangro River front, declared today that the British Eighth Army's bridgehead across the river was "very firmly held and secure."

At the risk of being called over-confident, the New York Giants eschewed to take to the practice field yesterday. The Brooklyn Dodgers, whom they meet in a National Football League game at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, were not so complacent, however.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor drew a bead today on a suddenly detected provision in the House-approved $2,140,000,000 tax bill which would require labor organizations to make an annual financial accounting to the Government.

Efficiency engineers in a rubber factory installed special working tables and chairs for women employes and immediately new production figures showed that sixteen girls did as much work as twenty had done before. When special seats were provided in a metal working shop women polishers increased their output as much as 32 per cent.

At Thanksgiving services yesterday ministers expressed gratitude for the progress of the United Nations toward victory, for the spiritual unity and determination of our people in the war, and for the general recognition of the nation's responsibility to participate in a world organization to assure peace and freedom after the war is won.

Sixty-five educators, writers, journalists and publishers have petitioned President Hugh J. O'Donnell of Notre Dame University to reinstate Dr. Francis E. McMahon, recently dismissed from the university faculty. The letter, made public yesterday, was initiated by Harry Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College; Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, and Dr. William Agar, acting president of Freedom House.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that seventeen manufacturers of women's work clothing, seven of them from New York City, will meet with OPA officials here on Tuesday to discuss pricing methods for such clothing.

Lester Patrick, manager of the last-place Rangers of the National Hockey League, made deals yesterday in Boston that promise to bolster his sagging sextet considerably. The New York pilot announced that he had received Wilfred (Bucko) McDonald, defense veteran, from the Toronto Maple Leafs, and that he had acquired an entire forward line from the Boston Bruins, against whom the Rangers played in the Hub last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--Commodity prices in primary markets dropped 0.2 per cent during the week ended on Nov. 20 to the lowest level since February. Continued declines in agricultural products, particularly livestock, poultry and eggs, largely accounted for the decrease.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Net profit of $9,245,143 is reported by Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its wholly owned subsidiary companies, for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, compared with $7,123,579 for the previous year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Labor turnover headaches in this country are rooted in about twenty-six definite causes, taken singly or in combination, according to the Office of War Information. Some are familiar, others new. This conclusion is drawn from a study of coordinated information from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the War Manpower Commission and War Production Drive headquarters.
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast yesterday from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Train service was resumed today on the Baltimore Ohio Railroad lines, eleven hours after a streamlined passenger train, the Ambassador, crashed into the wreckage of a freight train collision near Newton Falls, killing two trainmen and injuring fifty passengers.

WITH THE SEVENTH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE IN THE CENTRAL PACIFIC, Nov. 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- United States forces attacked two islands in the Gilbert group today in the climax of a week of preparation by Army and Navy aerial assaults.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Britain is planning to get her overseas aviation going as soon as Germany is defeated and before the war with Japan is finished, it was indicated today by the authoritative but unofficial magazine Aeroplane.
LONDON, Friday, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Hunters with the long bow who have gotten little more than aching feet tramping around Westchester in quest of deer may turn a delicate shade of green when they hear how their prototypes in Michigan are faring. Not that the toll is terrific, but it's higher than here.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Wacs in London shared their first overseas Thanksgiving turkeys and their hoarded candy and chewing gum rations with sixteen small orphans today. They also used their next week's supply of clean sheets as tablecloths on which to spread the fourteen turkeys they roasted and the sixty pumpkin pies they baked.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25 -- Between 2,000 and 3,000 Western Pennsylvania bituminous coal miners failed today to heed an appeal by the deputy solid fuels administrator, C.J. Potter, for continued operation on Thanksgiving Day due to the war emergency.

War plants in this city and vicinity observed Thanksgiving Day yesterday on the production line. Except for the few plants that worked Labor Day, and consequently were idle yesterday, normal operation was the rule.

ALGIERS, Nov. 25 -- "Thanksgiving seemed more like Thanksgiving to many a soldier in North Africa today because the Wacs are here," said First Lieut. Beatrice Parker of Fall River, Mass., public relations officer, and who could doubt it?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Brazilian Embassy announced today that President Getulio Vargas of Brazil had issued a decree-law setting up a new system of payments on dollar and sterling obligations of the Federal, State and Municipal Governments in Brazil.

The Squire Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, which has been dark for some months, will be reopened tomorrow under the management of Eastern Thetre, Inc. The first dual program under the theatre's revival policy will be "Trail of the Lonesome Pine" and "Island of Lost Souls."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT FORNELLI, Italy, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The "battle of the house" was one of those savage, isolated fights that characterize present operations along the German's touted winterlines -- one of many patrol skirmishes in which Americans excelled.

Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. has contributed $50,000 to the National Fund campaign for $17,000,000 locally for support of twenty-six war-related organizations, it was announced yesterday by Emil Schram, New York committee chairman.

In a grim and sober spirit, America gave thanks yesterday for the blessings it has enjoyed during its second war year and, encouraged by the change in the military situation that has taken place since last Thanksgiving, raised voices in public and private prayer that victory will be won in time for next year's celebration.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE, SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Nov. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Willis H. Dale, commanding the Seventh Army Air Force, predicted today that the bombers of his command soon would begin a long campaign involving the most difficult flying in the world.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 25 (AP) -W. Gullatt's Navy took his fifth race of the Rockingham Park season today when he captured the $5,000 Tom Thorp Memorial Handicap before a holiday crowd of 10,000. Held off the early pace, the veteran gelding took command at the top of the home stretch and won easily.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Basler Nachrichten said in a dispatch from the Swiss border town of Chiasso today that Pope Pius XII had undertaken a mission of mediation between Germany and the Allies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The interest displayed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Perry Belmont and others in recent accounts in this space of the move in Congress to have regular question days on the floor for the Cabinet and agency chiefs suggests that, even though the general public has more vivid concerns in the daily news, the topic has not been obliterated in the rush of exciting events.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration tonight fixed rules governing maximum prices chargeable for specially packaged Christmas articles sold between Dec. 1 and Jan. 15. Holiday-packed cosmetics and nylon hosiery are excluded from the order.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission has recommended that the SEC withhold a recapitalization plan submitted by the Standard Gas and Electric Company unless the company amends it to provide a greater participation for holders of notes and debentures in new common stock than originally proposed.

Random House announces today the list of prize winners in the contest among contributors to "A Book of War Letters," edited by Harry Maule, which the firm brought out last week. Col. Joseph I. Greene for the Army, Lieut. Max Miller for the Navy, Lieut. Col. Laurence Stallings for the Marines and Carl Van Doren for civilians were the judges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -The Maritime Commission announced today the names of ten famous men, now dead, for whom Liberty ships under construction by the Permanente Metals Corporation, Richmond, Calif., will be named.

A post-Thanksgiving task facing many women today is the disposal of the holiday bird. One space-saving way to do it is to store the i meat in a covered receptacle in the refrigerator and to make a broth from the remaining bones. With the meat and broth anyone of a number of aain courses are possible.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Clifford Johnson, a Coast Guardsman, of Sumner, Mo., who has been in City Hospital since the Cocoanut Grove fire a year ago this week, will don a uniform again tomorrow morning and leave the institution. Doctors at the hospital said tonight that no patient ever before suffered such burns and lived, and they added:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Glen Cove High School defeated White Plains, 9 to 0, in a meeting between the unbeaten school football leaders of Long Island and Westchester County this morning at Parker Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Pointing out that Japan's "outer arc" defenses now were cracked by American military and naval might, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson held out hope today that our forces in the various theatres of the broad Pacific might be able to develop these cracks into "breaches" through which they might converge "to assault the inner and more important bastions" of the Asiatic enemy.
ALGIERS, Nov. 25 -- A communique:

In all parts of the world there are and always have been hangmen ever searching for prey. The case of General Patton has brought those hangmen to the fore again. They now demand the general's neck. It is interesting to consider who those hangmen are, their motives and the methods used by them.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony's concert of last night in Carnegie Hall opened solemnly with the performance of the Andante from Tchaikovsky's familiar string quartet in memory of Walter Winston Price, long a member of the board of directors and executive committee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, and voted its first honorary vice president when he retired from the board in 1942.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The German military authorities have little hope of winning the war and are now looking toward their politicians to turn military defeat into a political victory that will enable Germany to escape the consequences of losing the war on mankind, Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, declared today at a Thanksgiving luncheon of the American Society in London.

Leading life insurance executives of the country will address the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in the Waldorf-Astoria next week on the present and potential service of business and its relation to current trends and to widening social and economic responsibilities.

Maj. Isaac Brimberg, Army Signal Corps, of 1062 Park Place, Brooklyn, chief radio engineer of station WNYC on war leave, died yesterday following an accident, at Brookley Field, Mobile, Ala., where he was attached to the Air Force Signal Corps, according to word received here.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 -Frank's Boy, purchased at a private sale yesterday by R.A. Coward from Mrs. J.L. Chesney, showed high speed from the start to defeat eleven other sprinters and capture the $2,000 added Thanksgiving Handicap, inaugural feature at the Fair Grounds today.

On the same day on which he announced the capture of Makin Island and progress in other sections of the northern Gilberts, Admiral Nimitz told a press conference that in his opinion "Japan will be defeated from China." The Admiral is not underrating the importance of the fleet which he commands, but he is not narrowly committed to his own arm of the service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Maj. Ralph Cheli of Bethlehem, Pa., continued to lead a formation of Army bombers on to a successful attack on Dagua airdrome, near Wewak, New Guinea, though his plane was aflame, and finally crashed into the sea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Despite wartime shortages of many articles, 1943 dollar sales of retail stores will reach a record high of $62,900,000,000, or 9.5 per cent above 1942, the Department of Commerce estimated today. Sales will be "at least" as large in 1944 as in 1943, and this year's Christmas trade will surpass last year's record, it was predicted.

Agencies affiliated with the National War Fund are providing many types of aid, both here and abroad, for children whose homes the war has shattered. More than 1,500 refugee children in this country are being given the chance for normal, happy lives by the United States Committee for the Care of European Children, while many others are being maintained by other groups overseas.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 25 -- Terrific toll of Japanese air power was exacted by American forces during invasion and capture of the Gilbert Islands.

ALGIERS, Nov. 25 -- This is not a pretty story, but war is never pretty. The story is based on an investigation by a British Army officer who has a distinguished literary background and it concerns Maria Cafaro, who lives at Bellona, near Naples.

NAPLES, Nov. 23 (Delayed)--King Victor Emanuel was defended and Count Carlo Sforza, Professor Adolfo Omodeo, rector of Naples University, and Benedetto Croce anti-fascist author, were attacked severely in an interview that Gen. Antonio Basso gave to THE NEW YORK TIMES and another correspondent this morning.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Buzz Boll, veteran right winger, scored four goals while the Boston Bruins were subjecting the New York Rangers to their tenth consecutive National Hockey League setback, 6 -- 2, before 7,500 spectators at the Boston Garden tonight.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

A council of the United Nations with an executive committee consisting of the United States, Britain, Russia and China has a good chance to emerge from the oft-mentioned Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference.

Once upon a time the surgeons made an excellent job of setting a broken leg and in a couple of months the patient was as spry as ever. Nevertheless there were people who said the surgeons should not be content with their purely negative action in saving a man's leg.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The North Carolina Navy Pre-Flight School football team, using power plays and trick reverses, struck pay dirt twice in the second period and once in the third to defeat a fighting North Carolina State College eleven, 21 to 7, today before about 3,500 fans.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 25 -- The delegates to the first Council session of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today voted down, 24 to 16, a proposal to qualify a report recently adopted by the "scope" subcommittee to force enemy or ex-enemy countries to pay all the expenses connected with any UNRRA operations in their territories.

Wins With Winawer's Counter-Attack in U.S. Title Chess Edward S. Jackson Jr., defending champion, in the eighth round of the national amateur chess tournament defeated Samuel Fuchs at the Marshall Club in twenty-five moves yesterday afternoon. Jackson employed Winawer's counter-attack to the queen's gambit.

NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Up there in the bleak, foggy, windswept mountain positions of the farthest American advances on the Italian front, American doughboys ate turkey and all the trimmings with one hand today while they cradled their rifles with the other.

Mount St. Michael High strengthened its claim to city interscholastic football honors yesterday by beating the Cardinal Hayes eleven, 38 -- 7, on the victor's field in the Bronx. Mount St. Michael finished its season unbeaten and untied in ten games, the city's only team with that distinction.

Three Naval Reserve officers from the New York area have received medals for conspicuous service aboard the U.S.S. McCawley, sunk during the invasion of Rendova Island, it was announced here yesterday at the offices of the Third Naval District.

ALGIERS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Photographs of Toulon harbor made after yesterday's strong raid by American heavy bombers on that French naval base indicated effective interruption of Nazi submarine repair facilities.

ALGIERS, Nov. 25 -- Further re ports on yesterday's heavy bomber rails on Sofia and Toulon confirmed today that considerable damage was done to the French port, but cloud conditions made observation over the Bulgarian capital difficult.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Here's a Thanksgiving letter, 1943 style. It was written aboard a ship in the South Pacific by a 30-year-old naval lieutenant.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- In the most vigorously contested match of the season in the Chicago Stadium, Doug Bentley managed to pull the "hat trick" tonight and score three goals to lead the Black Hawks to a 4-3 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings before a crowd of 15,741.

NAPLES, Nov. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Count Carlo Sforza, Liberal Italian leader who returned to Italy from exile in the United States, disclosed today that he had pledged himself to take no active measures against the Badoglio government for the time being, but denied that he had agreed to collaborate with it.

NAPLES, Nov. 23 (Delayed) -- Curzio Malaparte Suckert, a leading Fascist journalist, was arrested by the Allied authorities in Capri yesterday. Curzio Malaparte, which is the name he wrote under, was once called "the strongest pen of fascism."

ALGIERS, Nov. 25 -- Andre Philip, Commissioner without portfolio, announced in the Provisional Consultative Assembly today that the number of delegates would be increased from eighty-four to 102. All eighteen of the new members will represent French resistance -- nine being associated with resistance inside France and nine with resistance groups outside France.

General Catroux's renewed pledge that Lebanon will recover her Constitution and the release of the jailed Ministers have been followed by an exchange of official visits, apparently cordial in character, between the French emissary and the Lebanese President and Prime Minister.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has been asked to submit to Washington complete details on the Patton incident in response to the Senate Military Affairs Committee's request for a full report, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson announced today.

The fiery inferno into which the British Royal Air Force has converted Berlin in repeated raids of record size this week marks a new climax in this most devastating of all wars. It is a climax of apocalyptic proportions, in which the most lurid descriptions of futuristic warfare with skies full of planes raining down death and destruction have become a reality.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 25 -- A new supercharger that uses only a jet of water at the right moment is supplying our fighter pilots with bursts of emergency power in those critical split seconds when it makes the difference between victory and disaster, it was revealed here today by the Pratt Whitney Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- More than 1,100,000 railroad workers will complete a strike vote tonight, but it may be several days before the result is known.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The Yugoslav Partisans reported today that they had driven back one of the German columns attempting to clear the Adriatic coast south of Fiume, but admitted that they were fighting defensive battles against superior forces throughout Dalmatia.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 25--Fighting with such gallantry that they drew special praise from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, the Chinese defenders of Changteh, highway junction west of Tungting Lake, have killed more than 5,000 Japanese, including four superior officers, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

ALTHOUGH the classic Army-Navy football game will be played in the privacy of West Point with only the neighbors and the neighbors' children admitted, a monumental job has been done in preparing a program for the affair. It is a tremendous 174-page copyrighted booklet which will be the delight of every historian and a treasure for all those with more than a passing interest in the series.

Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, district Coast Guard officer, presented the Legion of Merit medal yesterday morning to Lieut. Comdr. John T. Stanley, of 411 Bement Avenue, S.I., and the Navy and Marine Corps Medal to Lieut. Comdr. Arthur F. Phister, of 86-24 234th Street, Bellerose, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Confronted with stunning defeat for more than three-quarters of the game, largely as a consequence of its glaring fumbles, Pennsylvania's heavily favored football team seized upon Cornell's only bobble of the game to score the winning touchdown midway in the final period today in their golden anniversary meeting on Franklin Field.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- There was a "change of guard" at Buckingham Palace yesterday such as there never has been before. For during a period of more than two hours two United States Army G.I. military police shared sentry duty with the regular guards.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Notes in circulation this week rose to a new record high of 1,019,047,000, an increase of 5,364,000 over the previous week, the Bank of England reported today in its condition statement.
State Senator and Mrs. Thomas C. Desmond will come to Mayfair House today from their home in Newburgh.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- The welcome news that the Russians, in a day of particularly violent fighting, had decisively checked the enemy's advance in the Brusilov and Chernyakov sectors was followed today by a report that in the main fighting zone the Germans' losses were so heavy that they were obliged to break off their attacks and disengage yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The job of clearing the sea lanes of mines after the last war took about a full year of tedious, unclamorous toiling, but when this war ends it will take considerably longer to do a similar task, Capt. J.H.F. Crombie, director of mine sweeping in the British Navy, declared here yesterday.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 25 -- The statement of Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox on Pacific strategy echoed one by a high ranking officer here months ago that "we shall have to make the central Pacific an American pond" and begin by mopping up island bases, forcing southward bends in our communications lines to this area.

The unfortunate incident which has marred the unsurpassed record of Lieut. Gen. Patton I believe will be contemplated with deep personal regret by all the men who served under him in the last war and got to know him.
LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The shadows of defeat settled over the red brick buildings of Franklin and Marshall College tonight for the first time this football season.
Harry Kluge, 59-year-old veteran from Westfield, N.J., was first to finish yesterday in the thirty-third annual handicap marathon walk staged by the Walkers' Club of America.

The New Deal was denounced last night by John T. Flynn, member of the Board of Higher Education, as a venture in the direction of fascism and was extolled by Max Lerner, political economist, as a democratic base on which the foundations of an enduring peace were being built.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -Reminiscent of the public enemy manhunts of the last decade the Federal Bureau of Investigation turned loose today all its storied skill in a search for two brothers who have terrorized the West for months.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Although the stock markets here were again quiet today, their tone was firmer than it had been yesterday and most prices remained steady.

The Georgia International Corporation, with offices at 20 Exchange Place, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Georgia Hardwood Lumber Company, with offices at Augusta, Ga., has been formed, it was announced yesterday, to market and distribute various domestic products throughout the world.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- German women are being urged by officials to follow the example of British women in going into war factories, an article entitled "Now It Is Serious!" published in the Oberhausen edition of the National Zeitung on Nov. 9 says:

A sharp increase in new food stores despite manpower and supply shortages has marked expansion in the retail cooperative field, with nearly 100 grocery co-ops opened from New York to California since the United States entered the war, the Cooperative League of the U.S.A. reported yesterday following a survey of its regional cooperatives this week.

Mrs. Oswald Bates Lord has resigned from her post as assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense for this area, after serving more than 5,000 hours as a volunteer since her appointment in September, 1941, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Ottawa Food Consumption Levels Conference, which began last summer in Washington and London and now is continuing in Ottawa, has practically completed its work and will soon submit the results of its studies to the Combined Food Board here, that agency announced today.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 25 -- Texas defeated Texas A and M, 27 -- 13, today to win the Southwest Conference football championship in the wildest offensive game ever waged by the two rivals.

Two hundred and sixty tons of waste paper and twelve tons of rags were salvaged in the last week from the refuse dumpings at city incinerators, it was said yesterday by Frank D. March, director of the New York City salvage division of the War Production Board and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.
ALGIERS, Nov. 25 -- The Eighth Army has crossed the Sangro River.

It may be fashionable in intellectual circles to look down on an old warhorse of an opera like Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," but its attractions remain verdant for a huge public. At its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, it drew a capacity throng, and clearly the audience was delighted with what it saw and heard.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has been invited to any meeting that President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin may hold in the near future, it was learned today.

Wives of wage earners are cold to grade labeling, according to the wage earner forum conducted by the Macfadden Publications, Inc., and when shown the three government labels (Grade A, B and C), 38 per cent said they had never seen them on canned goods, while 85 per cent declared that most nationally advertised brands belonged in Grade A.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--Senate committees had in their hands today two of the major pieces of legislation remaining to be disposed of before Jan. 1, with indications pointing to a repetition of Administration defeats which were suffered in the House.

With pass interceptions paving the way for three touchdowns, the St. John's Prep football team continued its mastery over Brooklyn Prep yesterday as the Redmen handed the Blue and White a 19-to-6 setback in the twenty-sixth meeting between the schools at Boys High Field.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 25 -- Texas A. and M. College, winner by 28 -- 13 over Louisiana State University in a regular season football game, will meet the Southeastern Conference team again in the Orange Bowl on New Year's Day.

Is not the conduct of the medical officers involved in the Patton affair one of its worst features? These two officers were charged with the welfare of their patient, whom they believed to be genuinely ill or they would not have permitted him to remain in his bed. Yet neither of these officers prevented the general's recurrent attacks on this helpless man, but permitted him to go on.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Secretary Knox sent a special Thanksgiving Day message today to all Navy personnel ashore and afloat, asking them to show "thankfulness by exerting new effort to help bring victory speedily and decisively."

During the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, 1943, which marked the tenth anniversary of the organization, the Schenley Distillers Corporation produced and delivered to Government agencies a record output of approximately 68,400,000 proof gallons of alcohol for war purposes, according to the annual statement of Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman, and Lester E. Jacobi, president, mailed to stockholders today.

Thirteen free refresher courses for practical nurses have been established in metropolitan hospitals as the first step in a drive to enlist 25,000 additional qualified women in New York State, Dr. Beeckman J. Delatour, chairman of the Committee for the Education and Recruitment of Practical Nurses, announced yesterday.
The possibility of a German offensive move against England this Winter or next spring cannot be entirely discounted.

Sixty years ago Thanksgiving Day, John Drumgoole, a Catholic priest who had given the greater part of his life to the welfare of New York's neglected children, arrived at Mount Loretto on the south shore of Staten Island with a boatload of boys from the slums and back alleys of downtown Manhattan.
LONDON, Nov. 25 (A.P.) -- Some owners of Brazilian bonds expressed dissatisfaction today with the new Brazilian debt-adjustment proposal, but others declared it was "the best that can be obtained."

LONDON, Nov. 25--The Battle of Berlin, the most significant and most rewarding engagement of the Allied aerial offensive, has started successfully but the 5,000 tons of bombs dropped on the German capital in three attacks, the first of which was made a week ago tonight, amounts to only one-tenth of the total tonnage the Bomber Command is prepared to devote to the complete destruction of the city.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 25 -Bishop James E. Kearney of the Diocese of Rochester closed the diamond jubilee celebration of the diocese this morning by celebrating pontifical high mass during which, in a sermon, he lauded the work of his predecessors.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 25 -- The Hitler of today is not the Hitler of a few years ago. He has shed the mask of the proud artisan of the 1940-41 victories. The Fuehrer today is a tired man, reflecting the reverses sustained by the German armies.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Friday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Scenes of death and panic in Berlin air raid shelters this week were described today by reliable eyewitnesses, one of whom said half of all such shelters had been hit.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Basic items on the menu for Europe after the war will be fish, milk, breadstuffs, beans, peas and other legumes, potatoes, cabbage, brussels sprouts, turnips and carrots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Edward Klauber, retired executive vice president of Columbia Broadcasting System will take over the associate directorship of the Office of War Information Dec. 1, Elmer Davis, director, announced today. Mr. Klauber succeeds Milton S. Eisenhower, who resigned from OWI last June to become president of Kansas State College.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Angela Lansbury, 18-year-old refugee, who came to this country with 600 other British children at the height of the London air blitz, will play the feminine lead in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's forthcoming production of Oscar Wilde's "The Picture of Dorian Gray."

As a Police Department report that was in effect a flat denial of allegations by the Kings County August grand jury of unusual and growing conditions of lawlessness in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn was made public yesterday, it was learned at Police Headquarters that thirty-two additional detectives and two more radio patrol cars had been assigned to the section.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 26 -- The Red Army has torn a thirty-seven-mile-wide gap in the German lines north of Gomel in a new major offensive in White Russia, killed 2,000 Germans, captured 180 populated places and charged close to the upper Dnieper River in three days, Moscow announced today, while unconfirmed Stockholm reports said Gomel itself had fallen to the Russians.

A brighter future for the Allied Nations was predicted yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt when she addressed the International Thanksgiving Day party at the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- American civilians were urged today to "share gladly" the sacrifices asked of them and to remember that men in the armed services were prepared to make the supreme sacrifice to attain victory.

Only $1,768,317 of new municipal financing is scheduled to be done next week, according to Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's volume of $16,067,000, and with the weekly average for 1943, thus far, of $15,625,999. Next week's offerings will represent the requirements of eight municipalities.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Rallying in the stretch under veteran jockey Carol Bierman, the Four Oaks Stable's Big Head, 1-2 favorite, today won the featured Webster Allowance Purse at Rockingham Park.

Without any selling of real force, the stock market followed yesterday its downward course, losses averaging about a point. Suspicions of prospects of peace seemed to be uppermost in the minds of holders of securities, and the expectancy of some announcement regarding the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference stayed the hands of usually active traders.

The largest single contribution thus far to the National War Relief Clothing Drive was made yesterday by the Jewish Labor Committee, when the organization gave 15,000 pounds of salvaged garments to the War Production Board.

The City College basketball team will face Muhlenberg College of Alletown, Pa., tonight in the C.C.N.Y. gym. The Beavers opened their campaign last Saturday with a 43-37 victory over the Columbia Midshipmen, but this will be the curtain-raiser for the Mules.
ATTICA, Ind., Nov. 26 -- Mrs. W.F. Mullinnix received word from the Navy Department today that her son, Rear Admiral Henry M. Mullinnix, is missing in action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 20 were 882,287 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 34,604 cars, or 4.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 45,525 cars, or 5.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 82,901 cars, or 10.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago:

A recent report of the International Labor Office expresses in startling figures one of the underlying preoccupations of the European delegates to the Relief Conference at Atlantic City. The report is on "The Health of the Children in Occupied Europe" and gives a picture of a steadily increasing excess of deaths over births and, in particular, of the appalling mortality rate among children under 15.

It is obvious that a meeting of our war production goals now hinges in large part on the fuller employment of women in industry. It is equally obvious that women cannot be fully mobilized for war-essential jobs until they can be assured of proper care for their children.

Knowing full well that it's do or die for them tomorrow when they meet the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds, the Giants put in a brisk two-hour practice session yesterday with Stout Steve Owen playing the role of Simon Legree.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Thirteen large drug and chemical companies filed suit in District of Columbia Court today for an injunction to prevent the Office of Price Administration from setting a maximum price regulation for package vitamins or vitamin products.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today and sent to the White House a bill which President Roosevelt has said rectified a "historic mistake" by wiping the Chinese Exclusion Laws from the statute books.

For the third consecutive session prices in the cotton futures market sagged yesterday under the influence of renewed liquidation in the old December contract. With the spot month leading the way, the list of active old futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with quotations 12 to 16 points below Wednesday's finals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Administration plans on behalf of returning war veterans took legislative form today as two sets of bills were introduced simultaneously in the Senate and House, one calling for a mustering-out pay ranging from $100 to $300 for meeting immediate readjustment needs, the other to provide long-range security benefits and unemployment allowances of $15 to $25 a week.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- Wendell Willkie, former Democrat, who was the Republican standard bearer of 1940, tonight called for a return to the policies and program of Woodrow Wilson.

If Congress passes the resolution recommended by a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee, it will declare in effect that the railway workers are exempt from the "Little Steel" formula or any other stabilization rule applying to other workers and that they are entitled to the special privilege of breaking through ceilings to which other unions are obliged to conform.

The program of the National Consumer-Retailer Council, Inc., to promote informative labeling will have two major aspects -- service and educational -- according to the annual report of the organization, made public here yesterday.

It is not for an Irishman to offer any opinion about the desirability or otherwise of changing the Administration of the United States, but I trust that it will not be thought offensive to protest against a perversion of history. Mr. Willkie stated at Baton Rouge that "the English put out the younger Pitt in the middle of the Napoleonic wars because they wanted to change horses in midstream."

ALGIERS, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- French Communist party spokesmen criticized the French Committee of National Liberation today for failure to send more weapons to patriots in France, and appealed for the speedy opening of an Allied land front in France.

ALGIERS, Nov. 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Alexander Hood, Director General of the British Army Medical Services, announced today that fatigue or "exhaustion centers" established near the front lines were proving extremely efficacious.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Joseph E. Murphy, assistant chief of the United States Secret Service since 1919, whose major responsibility during his forty-five years' service has been the safeguarding of seven Presidents of the United States, will retire Tuesday at the age of 65 years.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 27 -- Sattelberg mission, the last Japanese stronghold in Huon Peninsula, lying between Finschhafen and Madang, New Guinea, was overwhelmed and captured yesterday by Australian troops, supported by tanks and artillery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- In less than eleven months the Navy has doubled the numerical strength of its combatant fleet, building 419 warships, exclusive of auxiliaries, mine, patrol and landing craft, as many as it had Jan. 1, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Department store sales increased 21 per cent last week over the corresponding period of 1942, and the weekly index stood at 201 at the end of the week, as compared with 166 at the end of the corresponding week of last year, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today.

The English king who signed on the dotted line in 1215 speaks of himself throughout the long document as We, and at the end of Magna Carta he writes: "Given by our hand in the meadow which is called Runnymede." Seven hundred and twenty-eight years later, or, to be more precise, on Wednesday last, King John's successor, in the speech from the throne at the reassembling of Parliament, spoke of himself in the singular person.

The Federal Open Market Committee, acting for the twelve regional Federal Reserve Banks, came to the rescue of member banks here and throughout the country that were hard pressed to maintain required reserves and made heavy purchases of Government securities during the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 27 -- A large force of British and Canadian heavy bombers hammered last night at Berlin, aflame from two previous heavy assaults this week. This fifth straight Royal Air Force attack on the Reich capital continued an Allied aerial offensive that has reached an unprecedented intensity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Permission for canners to release some 2,600,000 cases of canned string beans and tomatoes for distribution through regular trade channels to civilians was granted by the War Food Administration today. The canned goods are part of the stocks set aside from the recent pack for war requirements.

Stock flotations featured this week's offerings of securities to investors in the market here. Two large blocks of industrial and public utility shares reached the market, with two issues of municipal bonds. The bond offerings aggregated $9,040,000, against $32,800,000 for four diversified flotations last week and $3,250,000 for two tax-exempt loans in this week a year ago.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- The State Department of Health served a complaint on the city today for the unsanitary condition of streets resulting from a five-day accumulation of refuse and ashes, this the result of a strike of employes of the Street Cleaning Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Nine more Japanese ships have been sent to the bottom by United States submarines, ranging deeper into the increasingly threatened enemy waters of the Pacific, the Navy Department announced today.

Thousands of homeward-bound commuters probably a somewhat lesser number of city-bound travelers had to wait patiently in Long Island Railroad trains from 4:57 to 5:15 P.M. yesterday as power was shut off following the failure of the electric circuit system on an engine hauling a Montauk Point train from Pennsylvania Station, Manhattan, through one of the East River tunnels.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Chinese troops in a big enveloping movement have poised a trap around 100,000 Japanese invaders of Hunan Province's rice bowl and recaptured two strategic towns -- Tzeli and Shihmen -- above Changteh, a Chinese spokesman declared today.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar told the National Assembly today that a solution must be found for the situation in Portuguese Timor, seized by the Japanese early in the Pacific war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- "Scrambled eggs" on a captain's cap are optional, and Captain Mildred H. McAfee, director of the Waves, chooses no gold braid.

The first "G-for-Gallantry" award of the campaign of the National War Fund was presented yesterday to J.K. Smit and Sons Inc., of 157 Chambers Street, first company to report 100 per cent cooperation for the War Fund. The presentation was made by James A. Farley, War Fund commerce and industry division chairman, at ceremonies in Mr. Farley's offices 515 Madison Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a joint application on the proposed sale by the Argus Natural Gas Company, Inc., of its transmission facilities to the Northern Natural Gas Company for $65,792 cash and the cancellation of $700,000 of 4 1/2 per cent Series A notes.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Many things happen in the stress of excitement. A year ago two battalions of midshipmen were assigned to cheer for Army, but when Navy perpetrated a 14-0 upset victory some of the boys forgot their lines and their cues. That was natural, because emotions and reactions cannot be disciplined that perfectly.

Dropping of practically all restrictions on the use of wool by the woolen and worsted manufacturing industry was greeted with favor by mill men during the past week, according to the report of the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange, but failed to bring about any noteworthy improvement in the form of new business.
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast yesterday from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Office of Price Administration stiffened its regulations today to prevent what it called a growing tendency by laundries, shoe repair shops and other agencies to offer only "de luxe" services at fancy prices.
ALGIERS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- When things were tough around Salerno the Allied strategists moved in a tough outfit to take care of them, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox warned the public today to expect news of "heavy" American casualties in connection with the speedy conquest of Tarawa Atoll in the Gilbert Islands, although he said that the American losses undoubtedly were considerably less than the estimated Japanese casualties of approximately 4,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- In a move to relieve shortages of livestock and poultry feed, the House Ways and Means Committee approved today a resolution to suspend for ninety days all duties on the importation of wheat, oats, barley, rye, cottonseed, flax and hay.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 26 -- Attacks in the Arabic press against the French National Committee died down today and the note struck was generally one of victory for the part the Arab world allegedly played in befriending Lebanon and espousing the cause of its nationalists.

The coming of winter need not stop a man from going fishing. In fact, the authorities up in Albany are encouraging people to get out and try their luck at fishing through the ice wherever the practice is legal.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Rand Coward, whose Frank's Boy won the Thanksgiving Handicap, came right back with Regimental to take the $1,100 Place D'Armes Purse today at the Fair Grounds.

Late in October three years ago the 165th Infantry, the old famous Fighting Sixty-ninth under another name, gathered one morning for ceremonies around Father Duffy's statue. That night and the next day it left for a year's training in Alabama. Many remember that next day.

WITH UNITED STATES MARINE ASSAULT FORCES AT TARAWA, Nov. 23 (Delayed) -- United States Marines have won Tarawa, but they have paid the stiffest price in human life per square yard that ever was exacted in the history of the corps. "Nothing in any previous war or in this one compares with it," asserted Col. Merritt A. Edson of Guadalcanal "raider" fame.

It took Gen. Antonio Basso, formerly commander in Sardinia, now of the region of Campania, to demonstrate what happens in the mind of a Fascist adherent when fascism skids out from under him. The mind does not change much. It tries to apply the old principles to the new conditions.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 26 -- Zionism has released the creative forces of Jews throughout the world, produced a youth in Palestine which has accomplished miracles, and given faith and hope in oppressed Europe, Mrs. Moses P. Epstein of New, York said today in an address before 500 delegates to the Junior Hadassah Convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Civilian repair shops will get steel, copper and aluminum, as well as materials and parts, under a new CMP order No. 9A, issued today by the Office of Civilian Requirements.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26 -- The Red Army's new White Russian thrust in which the first phase took them across the twenty-mile stretch between Sozh and the Dnieper astride the main highway between Gomel and Mogilev was an important addition to a series of consecutive coordinated blows delivered at points so wide apart as to completely tie up the enemy's reserves.

With a general tie-up of all school buildings threatened for next Wednesday morning, a suit to compel the Board of Education to abolish the existing indirect custodial system was started by a taxpayer yesterday through Theodore Fred Kuper, former law secretary of the board, whose position was abolished last month by order of Mayor La Guardia.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Award of 1,213 decorations for valor and exceptional achievement by members of the Eighth United States Air Force was announced today by Lt. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commanding American air units in the Eureopean theatre of operations.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Reports that Pope Pius is about to act as mediator between the United Nations and Germany are completely unfounded, according to diplomatic sources here. The same is true of the rest of the big crop of peace rumors that flourished after important Allied victories, in this case the RAF attacks on Berlin.

A call for more young men to choose the ministry as their vocation was issued in a letter to his 489 pastors this week by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, and made public yesterday at the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street.

" The Battle of Russia," fifth in the "Why We Fight" series of orientation films produced for the Army under the supervision of Lieut. Col. Frank Capra, which ended its first local public showing at the Globe last Tuesday after on eleven-day stand, will start an engagement at the Stanley this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Freddy Fitzsimmons, who took over the reins of the faltering Phillies from Bucky Harris' hands in the middle of last season, will be "absolutely boss on the field" next year, his new boss promised him today.

LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- In a gesture of hospitality to the United States armed forces, the famous canteens of the British Navy, Army and Air Forces Institute have decided to serve coffee "American style."

Today's events: "La Forza del Destino," 2 P.M., and "La Boheme," 8:30, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Fritz Kreisler, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Phyllis Moss, piano, the Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, 3; Lener Quartet, Town Hall, 5:30; Mina Hager, soprano, and Margaret Fountain, violin, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Le Quatuor Alouette, Town Hall, 8:30; "Tosca," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 26 -- Lafayette and Lehigh will clash tomorrow at Taylor Stadium in what will be the final game for both teams and the seventy-eighth meeting of the old rivals. Both teams are composed entirely of civilian students and many of these men will conclude their college football careers with this contest.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 26 -- The Yugoslav information office here announced today that an agreement had been reported between Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch and Vladimir Matchek, leader of the Croat Peasant party, whose organization was said to be still a potential political and moral force.

The exposure in THE TIMES of the millions unable to get increased wages and yet are hard hit by inflationary prices is startling. But it does not tell the full tale of their plight and what it means to the country.

The performance of Richard Strauss' "Rosenkavalier" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was a conclusive demonstration of what a vivid and finished ensemble can accomplish. There were two first-class voices in the whole cast, though a number of good ones.

The New York State Liquor Authority yesterday announced that it had directed 130 distillers, rectifiers, importers and distributors holding licenses in the State to file with it before Dec. 1 figures showing their sales and inventories of whisky and neutral spirits between Jan. 1 and Oct. 31, 1943.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 430 soldiers wounded in action. The announcement included casualties in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

Keenly aware of the problems ahead, a new body has been organized which is called the American Otorhinologic Society for the Advancement of Plastic Surgery and which has for its purpose the spreading of knowledge of technical methods.

LONDON, Mar. 26 -- Every man, woman and child in these islands may be able to have a real egg on Christmas morning, the Food Ministry announced today -- it is rather like a message from Santa Claus, almost too good to be true, yet fun to think about.

As baseball men began preparing for the major and minor league meetings, which will be held at the Hotel New Yorker next week, developments which indicated that Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis is about to swing his big stick again came to light yesterday.

G.A. BORGESE'S "Common Cause"* may be an important book. But for me it is the most confusing book of the year. Its rhetoric runs in long, dizzy cascades, coruscating and colorful. Words such as "tardive," "ausculted," "logomyth," "discalced," "fustigate," "sorites," "oestrus" and "innuce" send one scrambling on many a page for the dictionary.

The Detroit Edison Company, one of the country's largest independent utility properties, is having its difficulties over a proposed 20 per cent excise ordinance tax which is being advocated by the city of Detroit's corporation counsel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- After graduation from Annapolis Admiral Mullinnix served with the United States destroyer force at Queenstown, Ireland, and upon his return to the United States in 1918 was assigned to aid in fitting out the Destroyer Gridley and later the Destroyer Brooks.

ADVANCE BASE IN THE SOLOMON ISLANDS, Nov. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese may have lost a fifth warship and suffered damage to a sixth in the disastrous second naval battle of the northern Solomons early today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The first real test of the ability of the non-socialist United Nations to make a workable post-war economic arrangement with Soviet Russia will come when Soviet monetary experts sit down with our experts to work out schemes for international exchange stabilization and a world bank.

The Celanese Corporation of America yesterday announced plans for erection of a new plant near Corpus Christi, Tex., for large-scale production of a wide range of chemicals. The plant, which will cost approximately $5,000,000, will be built with private funds and is expected to be in operation during the latter part of next year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- Susan Hayward will be lent by paramount for the feminine lead opposite William Bendix in the forthcoming Jules Levey-United Artists picture "The Hairy Ape" after her appearance in "And Now tomorrow" on her home lot.
Two items in today's news illustrate in a measure the reasons for crime in certain parts of our city.
ALGIERS, Nov. 26 -- All the fury of the Wehrmacht, aided by all the complications of miserable weather, was unable to dislodge the Eighth Army from its bridgehead across the Sangro River yesterday.

This year the traditional "trip to see Santa Claus" isn't what it used to be. Santa himself is just the same -- red suit, black boots and white whiskers -- but the magicians and old-time Punch-and-Judy shows have disappeared. In their places are camouflaged marines, carnival barkers, circus clowns -- or nothing at all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- After three years of experimentation the Army has developed an all-purpose, all-weather gasoline, which will be usable in temperatures ranging from zero to extreme heat, it was announced today. This new gasoline will provide a fuel standardized at 80-octane and will do away with the need for differentiating between summer and winter grades.

Joseph Fuchs, violinist, who has not appeared in recital here since he was a boy, gave a recital at the Town Hall last night that was memorable for the breadth of its musical values and the assurance with which they were projected. There was virtuosity enough to serve all purposes, but no emphasis on it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- "The strike hits the soldier harder than any Patton incident," the Rev. Dr. William B. Pugh, chairman of the General Commission on Army and Navy Chaplains, declared today after a ninety-one-day global air tour of American forces. He reported:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull commended the American Legion tonight for its contribution in support of the "good neighbor" policy.
ALGIERS, Saturday, Nov. 27 -- New Heinke 177 bombers, which never before had been seen in this theatre, were among thirty Nazi planes that attacked a convoy in the Mediterranean at dusk last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- An attempt to shelve a proposed Federal war ballot for men and women in the service and let them designate a proxy back home for next year's Presidential election was started in the Senate today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Two of the finest and most evenly matched football teams ever to represent Army and Navy will meet here tomorrow in Michie Stadium before a comparatively meager crowd of 15,000 spectators. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P.M. and the corps of 2,500 West Point cadets will march in at 1:15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a refunding operation involving the issuing and marketing of $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Atlanta Charlotte Air Line Railway. Commissioner Claude R. Porter pointed out in a concurring opinion that the price received at competitive bidding was less favorable than the Pennsylvania Railroad recently obtained by negotiated sale.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Board of Missions of the former Methodist Episcopal Church, South filed suit in Federal Court today for $500,000 against E.H. Rollins Sons, a brokerage house, and Walter C. Rawls, the company's St. Louis manager.

Because of a shortage of trained librarians and the need for conserving fuel, twenty-two branches of the New York Public Library will be closed on Saturday afternoons and Monday mornings, as well as on Sundays.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 26 -- J.J. Singh, president of the Nationalist India League of America, hinted today that India may drop out of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration if the latter fails to do anything about the famine in Bengal before the close of the conference next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's report on the Patton incident:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Senator Hugh A. Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, in a 176-page report to the Senate of a trip he made last summer through twenty Latin-American countries, charged today that the United States Government was lavishing $6,000,000,000 there on wasteful and unnecessary projects which were breeding hate, suspicion and contempt for this country.

Adet and Anor Lin, daughters of Lin Yutang, who recently have written their first novels, "Flame From the Rock" and "War Tide," will autograph copies of their books at the China booth of the International Women's Exposition at Madison Square Garden tomorrow afternoon.
