SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Engineers, their ingenuity taxed by the thick, lavalike waste from the Solvay Process Company's sodaash manufacture, experimented today with water and cinders in an effort to cope with the more than 40,000 tons that rolled over the countryside through a dike break.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The State Department announced in a statement today the approval of the United States Government of the adjustments made in Lebanon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Coach Frank Leahy and the members of what many think is the greatest Notre Dame football squad of all time came here to spend the night before the last game of their schedule, but Chicago wasn't paying much attention.

An investor has purchased from M.C. Berg, operator, the taxpayer on a plot 50.4 by 99.5 feet at 226-28 Bowery, just south of Prince Street. The property is assessed at $45,000 and was sold subject to a mortgage of $23,640 held by the North River Savings Bank, which erected the building in 1939 and sold it to Mr. Berg in April, 1942.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

With "holidays must be gay" as its theme, Altman's ushered in yesterday a series of table decorations designed to brighten the midwinter season. Sparkling glassware and snowy linen gleamed in its fourth floor display, lending a touch of pre-war elegance to a series of informal settings.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26 -- Two patents issued to Henry Ford, himself, and a number of unusual inventions in the "gadget" class stand out among the 534 listed in this week's official gazette of the United States Patent Office.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Grain markets showed pronounced weakness today on the Board of Trade, breaking 2 cents a bushel or more as the result of general liquidation and bear pressure induced by peace talk and announcement that the House Ways and Means Committee had approved a resolution to suspend for a ninety-day period the import duty on wheat, oats, barley, rye and several other commodities.

Post-war theatrical training in the armed forces as a means of morale building was discussed yesterday by members of the National Theatre Conference at the first of its annual three-day sessions at the Hotel Picadilly. More than 100 delegates, representing university drama departments and community theatres throughout the country, attended.

ALGIERS, Nov. 26 -- The Communist party held a peculiar "open press conference" this morning to get on the record -- in the presence of as many party members as chose to take a seat in a local movie house -- its position regarding the long-drawn-but and apparently still unsettled negotiations with the French Committee of National Liberation regarding the Communist representation.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 26 -- The Japanese, warned of the impending American invasion in advance of the arrival of our assault forces last Saturday morning, put up a terrific battle during the seventy-six hours of bloody and bitter fighting, surpassing anything in Marine Corps history.

One of the busiest volunteer groups in town this week is the Relief for Americans in the Philippines Committee at 101 Park Avenue. Swamped by inquiries about the arrival of the M.S. Gripsholm, scheduled to arrive at Jersey City, Wednesday, with American exchange prisoners from Japanese internment camps, the volunteers are working day and night to complete reception arrangements.

A loan exhibition of paintings, drawings, sculpture, documents and books relating to the French Revolution will be held for the benefit of the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes and the Societe d'Histoire de la Revolution Francaise at the Wildenstein Gallery, from Dec. 1 to 31.

Substantiating at least one phase of the August grand jury's presentment, that prostitution and venereal disease were rife in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, Brooklyn's "Little Harlem," Commissioner of Health Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins in a report to Mayor La Guardia yesterday afternoon disclosed that there were approximately 10,000 recorded cases of syphilis in the area in the last five years, an average of 2,000 a year.
The Walworth Company had a record gross, and net profit for the nine months ended with September, according to the earnings statement announced yesterday.

Ariel Mengarini of Washington became the only undefeated player in the United States Chess Federation's annual tournament when he defeated Edward S. Jackson Jr. of the Manhattan Chess Club, national amateur champion, after fifty-seven moves in the tenth round at the Marshall C.C. last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs today were moderate and prices gained substantially, especially on weights under 200 pounds. The cattle market was strong, with $16.75 a hundredweight the top price for steers. Fat lambs were active and 25 to 50 cents higher than on Wednesday. The hog supplies were completely cleaned up, including the large holdover from earlier in the week.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Col. Thomas F. Sullivan took command of the Boston police today following appointment by Gov. Leverett Saltonstall and confirmation by the executive council He told ranking officers of the department tonight that they had a free rein to enforce the law without fear of interference from any politician.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE, CHINA, Nov. 26 -- American and Chinese bombers and fighters bombed and machine-gunned the Japanese airdrome at Shinchiku, on Formosa, strategic island flanking South China's coast, yesterday, it was disclosed today.

Further analysis of the amendment of the highest price limitation of MPR 330, issued on Thursday by the OPA, indicates that but little relief has been accorded to most merchants and deepens the belief that the principle of price-line limitation, which is still retained, is basically "unsound and unfair," it was stated in retail quarters here yesterday.

The new maximum import price regulations of the OPA are "unfair" and will force established importers to stop handling certain lines of merchandise, leaving the business to newcomers not "hamstrung" by previously established prices, according to a summary of the results of a trade survey just completed by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Rutgers brings its abbreviated campaign to a close here tomorrow when Brooklyn College is to be met for the first time in the history of the two schools. After an upset at the hands of Lafayette last week, the Scarlet will be favored to make it a season of four victories and one defeat at the expense of the Kingsmen.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- The attack on Shinchiku was the first Allied blow of the war against Japan's immediate south-western defenses and came as a logical complement to American bombings of the Kuriles, north of the Japanese home islands, and to the current invasion of the Gilbert group, a stepping-stone for an Allied drive on Tokyo from the east.

DES MOINES, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The farm vote would favor either Gen. Douglas MacArthur or Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York over President Roosevelt if the Presidential election were being held now, according to the December "Farmer Speaks" poll conducted by Successful Farming Magazine.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed an increase of $532,058 in holdings of the United States Government securities, to a new high record. Note circulation for the whole system showed an increase of $157,232.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- A Federal Court of three judges enjoined the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company tonight from applying for fifty days an Interstate Commerce Commission order permitting the railroad to increase its present eight-cent fare between New Jersey and downtown New York to ten cents straight or eleven tokens for $1.

The New York Little Symphony, under its founder, Joseph Barone, offered a program last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The chamber orchestra, composed of players from the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, was formed to afford young American soloists, conductors and composers opportunity of making a formal debut, and at this concert granted an initial appearance here to Jean Geis, l7-year-old pianist from Springfield, Ohio, and Byron Cantrell, composer-conductor from Brooklyn.

Bishop Homer Tomlinson, overseer for New York State in the Church of God, challenged yesterday the validity of the selection of his younger brother, Milton, as general overseer for the nation to succeed their father, the Rev. A.J. Tomlinson, who died Oct. 2 at his home in Cleveland, Tenn.

With Christmas shopping again an outstanding feature, retail trade was very active here last week. Estimates indicated department stores had an average increase of 18 to 20 per cent over the like week a year ago, with many individual stores having still greater sales gains Specialty shop volume forged ahead sharply, with active consumer response reported to clearances of apparel.

It is encouraging to learn that in spite of the frigid reception which its tax proposals met in the House, and the equally cool reception they seem likely to meet in the Senate, the Treasury will none the less once more present its $10,500,000,000 tax program to Congress.

Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut, Republican, warned yesterday againsnt continuing centralization of authority in the Federal Government, which if permitted to go unchecked, he said, would engulf democracy and with it individual liberty and freedom.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The feature on the Stock Exchange today was the strength in Brazilian bonds following yesterday's announcement of the Brazilian Government's offer of new terms to bondholders. Rises of different issues varied greatly, but prices fell back on profit-taking and became steady before the close of trading.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Saturday, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- A combined naval and aerial bombardment has silenced newly found Japanese artillery on Magine Island, near the American beachhead on Bougainville Island, while the Solomons air force dumped nearly 150 tons of bombs on Bougainville objectives Tuesday and Wednesday, Admiral William F. Halsey's spokesman said today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Allied bombers and fighters have crisscrossed Burma from top to bottom with aerial attacks in the last week, and even extended their raiding activities to Thailand, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten. Allied commander in southeast Asia, announced today.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 27 -- Russian armies captured the Nazi stronghold of Gomel yesterday and stormed on eight miles beyond the city in pursuit of hundreds of thousands of Germans retreating through a fifty-mile-wide corridor toward Minsk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Progress toward consummation of the first national soft coal wage agreement in the history of the industry was made today when the spokesmen for the "captive" mines owned by the steel corporations and operators in "outlying fields" entered the joint negotiations.

A constructive program of social welfare, including the needed improvements in housing, health and school facilities to be provided by the city, was recommended yesterday as a means of alleviating conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and to supplement the benefits of increased police protection recently authorized for that area.

The five-story walk-up on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 1165 Morris Avenue, near 167th Street, the Bronx, was sold by Morris Luskin Son, operators, to the E. N. Corporation. This property contains thirty-four apartments and has an annual rental of $17,000.

Grocers have filed a petition with the Office of Price Administration for the designation of separate stamps for butter rations, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Enrollments in colleges and other institutions of higher learning this year numbered 1,110,500, including 608,050 men and 502,450 women, a decrease of 8 per cent since last year and a figure more than one-quarter below the 1940 peak, according to a preliminary survey made public today by the Office of Education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- John J. Burns, general counsel for the American Merchant Marine Institute, argued before a special War Shipping Administration Advisory Board to day that "war does not suspend" constitutional guarantees of just compensation for private property taken for public use.

TRENTON, Nov. 26 -- Governor Charles Edison announced the appointment today of Arthur Walsh of South Orange, his friend and business associate, to the United States Senate to succeed W. Warren Barbour, who died in Washington on Monday.

The building plot comprising the blockfront on the east side of Broadway, about 150 feet on East Twelfth Street and 150 feet on East Eleventh Street, Bayonne, N.J., was sold by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to John Avrutis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today an easing of its rationing regulations affecting rentals and sales of used typewriters, explaining that decreased Government requirements and resumption of limited production had made the action possible.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 26 -- Last month was the busiest October in the Westchester County real estate market since 1930 and was indicative of an upswing in progress since May, County Clerk Robert J. Field said today in filing a report on the October work of the Division of Land Records of his office.

" Lady, Behave," the Alfred L. Golden farce about psychoanalysis and things, will close a week from tonight -- Dec. 4 -- at the Ambassador Theatre. It opened Nov. 16 at the Cort and moved last Monday to the Ambassador, and it will have given twenty-three performances at the two houses.

THE importance of films as diversion for our soldiers and sailors overseas has been clearly remarked by observers and by boys writing home. All over the world American youngsters -- and oldsters, too, for all that -- are yelling for Hollywood movies to charm and beguile their idle hours, and reports sifting back from far places say they will walk, run or crawl to see a film.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- As the first stage of the new central Pacific invasion ended with quick victory for American forces in the Gilberts, Japan, looking out over the ocean highways to her home shores and witnessing the inexorable reduction of her outlying defenses, had every cause for anxiety.

MANY familiar toys once made of rubber, metal and plastics will be missing from the children's stocking and tree this year. But the shortage of manufactured toys need not mean a Christmas morning without playthings.

The Office of Price Administration granted yesterday to landlords of the New York defense rental area a fifteen-day extension, through Dec. 15, for registration of their housing units. The Federal agency also granted the same period of grace to operators of hotels and rooming houses for posting the required notice of maximum rents in each of their buildings.

THE folk music of the Spanish gypsies, sung with extraordinary fidelity and authenticity, are to be had in a new album, Flamenco (Songs of Andalusia), issued by Keynote (K 112, three ten-inch records). The singer is La Nina Valiente (the Valiant Girl).

ALGIERS, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- The Germans used their most formidable bombers -- giant Focke-Wulf Kuriers and Heinkel 177's -- in a heavy attack on an Allied Mediterranean convoy yesterday, but first reports showed today that damage had been negligible and the enemy had lost nine planes.

RADIO being the popular medium it is, everyone having access to a receiving set is a critic with, so to speak, a seat on the ethereal aisle. If he does not put into words his opinion of what he hears, his reaction to it is none the less decisive; he turns the dial if he disapproves, and he keeps listening if he is satisfied.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Chinese declared tonight that they were tightening their net around invading Japanese forces in northern Hunan Province and that nearly 10,000 enemy troops had been killed in fierce fighting for the "Rice Bowl" city of Changteh.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- In general the British tend to divide into three different groups on most questions touching the purposes of the war.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27 -- William L. Veeck, 30-year-old president and owner of the Brewers, American Association baseball club, enlisted as a private today in the United States Marines.

From high up in the clouds yesterday, from an Army bomber in flight over the Eastern part of the country, Lieut. Col. Ed Garbisch, former Army football star, spoke over the radio with Capt. Steve Barchet, former Navy star, in a submarine located in the waters off the Eastern coast.

Mr. Jewell's column of Nov. 16, discussing the Greek revival exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, is in the main a fair appraisal of the faults and virtues of the Greek revival, but ends on a note of disparagement and concern, emphasized by quotations from Miss La Follette, which I believe should be re-examined.

With about 90,000 ballots reported in the poll of Protestant women on Armistice Day on proposed participation by the United States in a world organization to assure peace and on extending rationing after the war, if necessary, all but two States had been heard from, according to tabulations reported yesterday by the United Council of Church Women, 156 Fifth Avenue.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The rights of liberated nations to the restitution of property looted by the Nazis and Japanese should not be prejudiced by the recent sub-committee report of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration on surplus supplies found in enemy territories after the war, it was declared in a "rider" attached to the report today.

Prices held relatively steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as slightly increased trade demand encountered a scarcity of offerings. At the close the active old-type futures were irregularly higher, with the January position off 4 points from previous closing levels and the remainder of the list unchanged to 3 points up.

As the time approaches for the annual Christmas appeal on behalf of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, THE NEW YORK TIMES acknowledges eleven bequests from men and women who wanted to help the work of mercy among the most distressed families and individuals in the city even after they had gone.

LAST Monday Lee Shubert leaned over the abyss to lower a rope (with running noose) to Billy Rose, trapped on a crumbling ledge. Mr. Shubert dragged Mr. Rose up the sheer face of the cliff and rescued him forthwith from the most desperate dilemma ever to imperil a man who has spent most of his professional life in undertakings rivaling the seven labors of Hercules.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- Rain, mud and wind were the chief news from the front today.

A preview for members, with a talk by Richardson Wright on "Garden Books," and one by Helen Morgenthau Fox on "Cook Books" will be held on Nov. 30 at 2:30 P.M.

Edwin L. James' interesting contribution, "Freedom of the Press Seen as Peace Factor," in your Nov. 14 issue takes us one step forward in the crusade headed by Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- A new crop of problems for Poland is fast approaching maturity. To make matters worse for the leaders of this unhappy country, they have no means of finding out where it will all end or, indeed, when and how the latest troubles will beset them.

The start of the Fourth War Loan Drive is seven weeks away, but the Treasury is losing no time in doing missionary work in banking circles to make the lot of the speculative purchaser considerably harder than in the past. One of the Treasury's chief targets is the system of bank loans for carrying Government securities where speculators edge in and attempt to collect quick profits soon after a drive ends.

JOHN APPLEGATE owns a corner drug store in a small town. He has a wife and two children. He is Anglo-Saxon, Protestant and independent Republican, though he voted for Roosevelt in 1932 and 1936. He is conservative, materialistic, tolerant, usually self-complacent and only rarely troubled by fundamental doubts regarding the destiny of his family, his community and his country.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Three times since the middle of the eighteenth century Berlin has been occupied but never damaged, by invading armies. Today the German capital reels amid smoking war destruction such as it never has known since the day of its founding in the thirteenth century -- and invading armies are still hundreds of miles away.

Secretary Hull's dramatic appearance before Congress has revived the proposal that Cabinet members be invited regularly to present their recommendations before Congress and to answer questions from the floor regarding them. It is instructive to recall that a measure to this effect was approved by a Select Senate Committee headed by George H. Pendleton in 1881.

A CONDENSED version of "Winged Victory," the Moss Hart hit, is to be broadcast next Sunday on the new "Radio Hall of Fame" program, which from this distance promises to be something pretty special. The program will be heard from 6 to 7 P.M. over the Blue network.

Among accomplishments of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., during the past year have been benefits of more than $9,000,000 from new Payrolls on which at least 3,000 New Yorkers found jobs, increasing contributions to the war effort, and direct and indirect savings to the city's taxpayers of $54,000,000, according to the annual report of the organization, released yesterday.

A pleasing performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" was given last night at the Metropolitan, one that held the attention at all times and was equally successful in conveying the humor and the pathos of the popular work. The efficient cast was headed by Jarmila Novotna as Mimi and Armand Tokatyan as Rodolfo, both of whom were in their best vocal estate.

Proposal of the Truman committee that contracting officers should disallow payment on termination of contracts for inventories in excess of materials permitted under the Controlled Materials Plan caused consternation among some war contractors last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced ceiling prices on 117,600 men's undershirts and an equal number of underdrawers of the same sort which have been released by the Army for sale to civilian workers in Northern logging camps, shipyards and other exposed locations.

Ariel Mengarini of Washington increased his score at the top to 10 -- 0 in the annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Manhattan Club last night. Conducting the white pieces in his twelfth-round game with Leo Neidich of Elizabeth, N.J., Mengarini won a king's bishop opening in thirty-six moves.

ON the authority of the British Ministry of Agriculture, squirrels are "quite good eating." This may have been news to some of Britain's 48,000,000 people when recently announced. To Americans it is old, for eating squirrels is traditional here.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Francis Biddie, United States Attorney General, told a group of Negro lawyers today that he feared a recurrence of race rioting "at any moment" and declared himself "profoundly disturbed by evergrowing racial tension."

ALGIERS, Nov. 27 -- There is one question which emerges from the welter of doubts concerning current Italian political developments and affects all others. It is simply the status of King Victor Emmanuel and it is likely to remain doubtful at least until the Allies enter Rome.

WHEN the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo plays its three-week spring season in New York, beginning April 9, it will be housed at the new City Center, which used to be Mecca Temple, and will play at popular prices.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The Red Army, after a year of consistent success, is poised for a winter campaign which, if it is "taken at the flood," may well lead to division and defeat of the German Army and invasion of eastern Europe by Marshal Joseph Stalin's forces.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Iowa Seahawks had far too much stuff on the ball for Minnesota, scoring as they pleased in the second half to trounce the Gophers, 32 to 0, today before 18,000 fans.

The sky became the major front of the war in Europe last week. The long-accumulating strength of the Allied bomber fleets was thrown against the German enemy in a crescendo of destruction such as the world had never before witnessed. The target was Berlin, capital of the Nazi world, cradle of the "total war" that Adolf Hitler decreed.

ALGIERS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Some elements within the French Committee of National Liberation are blaming the United States and, to some extent, Britain for hamstringing a purge of Vichyites, it was learned today, but American quarters quickly denied the accusation.

THE New York art market is being flooded with paintings supposed to be by Cezanne, and it is suspected that at least some of them are forgeries. Jason Emory, diminutive art expert, is asked to investigate and accepts the job, not dreaming that presently he will have a murder case on his hands.

IN his time Gideon Welles, as Secretary of the Navy under Lincoln, was the target for some of the most powerful slings and sharpest darts of outraged public opinion. With his cascading beard, unsteady wig, and pretentious name he was, superficially, an ideal subject for caricature, a slightly comic figure upon whom a country dismayed by military difficulties could heap embittered ridicule.

David Warfield, the theatre's lustrous star of another era, sat back in his chair at The Lambs yesterday, considerably amused that anyone still might be interested in his birthday. He is 77 today, and to Mr. Warfield that isn't especially significant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Vice President Wallace's expression of "regret" to Latin America over Senator Hugh A. Butler's attack on New Deal policy there should have been directed as an apology to "the hard-beset taxpayers," the Nebraska Republican said in a radio address tonight.

The first of the Mayfair Assemblies was held last evening in the St. Regis Roof. Before the dance Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Bissell of 214 East Seventy-second Street gave a dinner for their daughter, Miss Amoret Bissell, in the Iridium Room of the hotel.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The first council session of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is drawing to a close in an atmosphere of overall unity and harmony, which appears to augur exceedingly well for the success of post-war international collaboration in general.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- Former King Carol of Rumania said today that his broadcast scheduled to take place last Tuesday night had been stopped by "the United States censors after having been approved twice" as a result of "maneuvers coming from interested circles."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- With the achievement at Moscow of agreement for common action by the United States, Great Britain, China and Soviet Russia during the war and after it, the Senate's confirmation of this agreement by the passage of the revised Connally resolution, and the imminence of a three-power conference which may put the seal on world partnership, the forces of isolationism once so powerfully entrenched in Washington find themselves in retreat.
Christmas trade has opened with a rush in practically all parts of the country, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

Vigorously defending the City Administration against charges of neglecting the Bedford-Stuyvesant area in Brooklyn, Park Commissioner Robert Moses made public yesterday a report to Mayor La Guardia citing past and present improvements in the area and listing health and welfare projects contemplated for the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton will have to prove by future good conduct that he deserves advancement before the Senate Military Affairs Committee approves his promotion to the permanent rank of major general, members said today.

LONDON, Nov. 27 (Netherlands News Agency) -- The story of the 45,000-mile patrol of a Netherlands submarine in far eastern waters, during which at one time it lay helpless on the surface fifty miles from Japanese-held territory for two hours, struggling to make repairs, was disclosed by the British Admiralty tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The Royal Air Force Bomber Command, now making the greatest test ever of the theory that air power can force a decision in the war, rocked Berlin again last night. At the same time it dealt a heavy blow to the industrial and transport center of Stuttgart in South Germany.

We went early and hopefully, and with trust in reward for so doing, to the performance of Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House. Where the performance was concerned, the sum of it was rewarding, especially for Mr. Walter's reading of the score.

The phenomenal rise in the number of minors between 12 and 18 years old who have quit school to go to work -- many at abnormally high wages -- poses a serious post-war problem involving literacy and the maintenance of former high educational standards throughout the country, well-known educators declared yesterday.

ARMY JAUNDICE -- The 1942 epidemic of jaundice in the United States armed forces left many sufferers in a psychoneurotic condition, Maj. C.M. Caravati, chief of medical service of Percy Jones General Hospital, told members of the Southern Medical Association meeting recently.

A YOUNG woodcarver of unusual promise is having his first real one-man show at the Marquie Gallery. This young man, Nicholas Mocharniuk by name, has developed a strong tendency toward elongated stylization.

FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, China, Nov. 26 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The American Thanksgiving Day attack on the Shinchiku Airdrome in Northwestern Formosa -- first Allied assault against that strategic Japanese island -- caught the enemy completely by surprise, a Fourteenth Air Force spokesman said today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 27 -- The Senate, by a vote of 33 to 13, today approved the declaration of Foreign Minister Carlos Lozano y Lozano recognizing that a state of belligerency exists between Colombia and Germany. The action followed the sinking of a Colombia ship by a German submarine on the night of Nov. 17.

Yesterday, for the first time this year, no new high was made on the New York Stock Exchange. This year, with two or more markets running side by side, new highs have been made daily, even in the periods when the market average was falling rather sharply, as in July and early November.

The railroads of the United States are nearing the completion of their biggest transportation job in any one calendar year. Despite a shortage of equipment, it is estimated now that this year they will have moved a greater volume of passenger and freight traffic than they did in both 1918, the peak year of the first World War, and in 1939.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- In its simplest terms, the food subsidy issue grows out of the effort to stabilize price ceilings and to provide at the same time for the added costs of farm and food production.

IN quest of prints, you will want, of course, to visit the twenty-eighth annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, which remains current through Dec. 8 in the galleries of the National Academy. WITH UNITED STATES ARMY FORCES ON MAKIN ISLAND, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- Col. James Gardiner Conroy, New York attorney and commander of the 165th Infantry Regiment, the old Sixty-ninth of World War I, renamed, with whom I landed yesterday, was killed by a Japanese bullet near a sniper's nest at the western tank trap about 1 P.M. today.

A silent signal to which deaf children respond as quickly as if they heard a gong keeps air raid drills moving smoothly at the city's School for the Deaf, Public School 47, Manhattan, it was announced yesterday by the Board of Education.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Believe it or not, there were more than just a few persons, those who can take their football but can't leave it alone, who traveled to West Point today, confident that they could purchase a ticket to see Army and Navy in their forty-fourth meeting.

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers will begin its sixty-fourth annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow. Several thousand of the society's 17,500 members are expected to attend the sessions, which will continue until Saturday.

TWO events highlighting the panorama of the week just concluded served to focus attention upon American art in a big way. The cooperative system of professional training is probably the most significant contribution to education during the past century. Changes in academic methods are generally the result of the slow process of evolution, but the cooperative plan of education, first applied to the programs in engineering at the University of Cincinnati in 1906 by the late Dean Herman Schneider, broke sharply with tradition.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- The Navy football team again said it with touchdowns today for its retiring coach, Capt. John E. (Billick) Whelchel, as it did for his predecessor, Lieut. Col. Swede Larson of the marines in 1941.

THE paperwhite or polyanthus narcissus can be timed for flowering almost to timetable exactness. Approximately four weeks are needed for rooting and three for subsequent leaf and bud development, although this seems to be shortened when bulbs are planted after New Year's.

The Lener Quartet, formerly of Budapest, began a series of eight Saturday afternoon concerts at Town Hall yesterday with a revised membership. An all-Mozart program was presented before a good-sized audience. Jeno Lener remains the first violin, and the new members are Laurence Steinhardt, second violin; Ralph Hersh, viola, and Gabor Rejto, 'cello.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concerts are selling out almost regularly for the first time since the days of Arturo Toscanini. The Thursday and Friday concerts, of course, have the advantage of large subscription sales, but even the Saturday and Sunday concerts are usually sold out, although several hundred single tickets remain to be disposed of.

The Middle Atlantic section of the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education will meet at Manhattan College on Saturday. Arthur V. Sheridan, Commissioner of Public Works for the Bronx, will discuss "Education in Engineering for Public Services," and Dr. Dwayne Orton, director of education for the International Business Machines Corporation, will talk on "Education in Engineering for Industry."

SEVERAL months ago reconstruction work on the Monte Carlo Beach and Garden, operated by the real estate firm of Webb Knapp, began in earnest under the supervision of Franklin Hughes, night club designer. STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 27 -- The little man in Germany asks himself today whether he hasn't backed the wrong horse. "Was Hitler not worthy of my trust? Has he let me down?" he wonders uneasily today, because the little man has begun to doubt victory.

Led by Center Walter Budko's 13 points and Right Guard Vincent Lolordo's 17, Columbia's basketball team scored its second victory last night on the Morningside Heights court, 44 to 41, in a rough game with the midshipmen of the Columbia V-7 Training School.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Deafening cheers roared through Bancroft Hall, then out across Tecumseh Court at the United States Naval Academy today as the midshipmen's regiment, which had kept pace by radio with the Army-Navy game at West Point, poured out into the yard to voice its jubilation over the middies' 13-0 conquest of the cadets.

Price stabilization is not popular with most farmers and many business men. Wage stabilization irks great sections of labor. Higher taxes have few friends. Lieut. Arthur Tauscher, 22 years old, of 1753 Forty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, a former employe of THE NEW YORK TIMES, received the Silver Star for gallantry in action at Sicily, according to word received here by his father, Sam Tauscher.

Demands for withdrawal by Great Britain of the White Paper limiting immigration to Palestine and recognition by the United Nations of Palestine as a national Jewish homeland were voiced last night at the opening meeting of the twentieth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD has tapped a new gold mine, and a rich vein it is proving to be, too, through the simple expedient of dusting off some of its better-class old films and sending them out into the world again. In a drive to put the city-wide National War Fund appeal over its $17,000,000 goal, 50,000 volunteers will intensify their door-to-door solicitations beginning tomorrow morning.

THERE were all indications last week that the early Christmas shopping campaign has caught on. UNCLE SAM has mighty forces in this war which have never fired a shot in anger, and perhaps never will, but are at the same time performing a vital part in the global struggle for victory.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 27 -- Palestine Jewry today paid tribute to the memory and services of the late Judge Julian William Mack of New York City for his active interest in Zionist construction efforts at commemoration ceremonies in the village of Ramat Hashophet, named in his honor.

IN a period overshadowed by big museum exhibitions, a number of recently opened group and one-man shows distinctly merit attention. One of these is the assemblage of oils, water-colors, drawings and pastels by Pascin, Pop Hart, Preston Dickinson and Demuth at the Downtown Gallery.

IN his introduction to this excellent study Erwin Panofsky admits that the "voice of Germany is missing" from the great fugue of post-medieval art, and he goes on, with rewarding thoroughness, to demonstrate the individualism of Durer and, indirectly, the phenomenon of individualism in German art.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Nov. 28 -- Australian patrols above Finschhafen, New Guinea, have moved into a key position dominating the eastern half of Japanese supply lines from the coast to their inland outpost at Wareo after advancing northward from the Sang River and capturing Pino Hill, eight miles north of the Allied coastal base.

ATLANTA, Nov. 27 -- Georgia Tech's Navy V-12 powered eleven today marched to a 48-to-0 victory over an all-civilian Georgia team and immediately afterward accepted a bid to play Tulsa in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on New Year's Day.

HOPE springs eternal in the human breast but never was hope balanced on so precarious a structure of ifs and buts as the Giants' hope of beating the Chicago Bears for the world professional football championship. If the Giants topple the Dodgers today while the Steagles are upsetting the Redskins and if the New Yorkers can bowl over the Capital Braves three times hand-running -- well it is almost too fantastic to mention.

That American soldiers and sailors are anxious to continue with their education even though they may be on a lonely Alaskan outpost or aboard a destroyer in the South Pacific is evident in the growing response of the men in service to the school and college programs offered by mail.

THE war between China and Japan has spread to Hollywood. Here, too, the Chinese are fleeing from rice fields, terraced farms and thatched huts, before death from the skies and an advancing army. But it is all make-believe for the movie camera, with Katharine Hepburn in the midst of it playing the part of Jade in Pearl Buck's "Dragon-seed."

Increasingly our Good Neighbors are inspiring American fashions. Three of New York's young designers -- Tina Leser, Joset Walker and Natalie Renke -- eager for style adventure, traveled to the southern republics during the past year. They returned not only with ideas that have borne fruit in interesting styles, but also with materials woven by the natives that are exciting in color and texture.

A doughnut surprise, a sandwich combining chicken and cream cheese, a salad with ten fresh vegetables and a green-top soup were the winners in the daily wartime food contest conducted last week by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in cooperation with the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries in Madison Square Garden.

Headquarters of the War Shipping Administration's Recruitment and Manning Organization here reported yesterday the expected arrival this week of ten merchant seamen and a stewardess, Mrs. Marie Moore of Los Angeles, Calif., repatriated from Japan, on the exchange liner Gripsholm.

ALTHOUGH they work like men and wear sober slacks and overalls and uniforms, women, when through with the day's labor, revert to type and become fervently feminine again. According to Collector Harry M. Hickey, women in the Fourteenth Internal Revenue Bureau District comprising twenty-six eastern New York counties, have paid $3,288,711 in taxes during the past two years -- to look smart.

Reacting to what appeared to be an exaggerated proposal for additional revenue, the House of Representatives has adopted a "Revenue Act of 1943," by which the Treasury's program, calling for additional revenues of $10,500,000,000, will give way to a plan which, if enacted into law, will reduce the additional revenues to $2,139,300,000.

Ernie Pyle believes that the Americans who fight and survive this war will come home with a new patience with the other peoples of the earth, a new hatred of injustice and new pity for mankind in trouble. For this bright hope our Mr. Saunders offers three cheers. "If it comes true," he says, "it will do some wholesome things to American public life.

ON THE ITALIAN FRONTIER, NOV. 27 (U.P.) -- Bitterly denouncing the Germans as "not ordinary thieves but godless hordes of bandits," Ildefonso Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, was revealed today to have accused the German occupation forces in northern Italy of sacking churches on the outskirts of Milan.

Extension of the powers of Price Adjustment Boards, on the ground that their current function can be utilized most effectively in hastening the solution of economic and social adjustments facing the postwar period, was considered inevitable last week by some war contractors.

COVERING electrical circuit theory and practical applications of electrical machinery, this text is intended for a one-semester introductory course in colleges and senior grades of technical and vocational high schools.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 27 -- New England ended its longest racing season, and its most prosperous one, at Rockingham Park today when a crowd of 18,697 wagered $811,086 and saw the White Star Stable's Dinner Party capture the Rockingham Park Purse.

Leaders in religious and public life will gather tonight to celebrate the seventieth birthday of Dr. Louis Ginzbeg, noted Talmudic professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, who since coming to the country forty-four years ago has won an international reputation as one of the outstand- ing contemporary scholars.

Modification of WPB Limitation Order L-45, restricting the use of gold by the jewelry trade to one-half of the amount used in 1941, is a vital step in curbing black market operations in jewelry, which are now increasing rapidly and promise to supply a major part of such important items as wedding rings in 1944, W. Waters Schwab, president of J.R. Wood Sons, Inc., a leading producer, said in an interview here last week.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 -- Technical experts are making preparations for the post-war settlement of a million Jewish refugees in Palestine at the cost of a billion dollars, Dr. Emanuel Neumann of New York said today in an address at the closing session of the twentieth annual convention of Junior Hadassah.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

WHAT happens when punishment is made to fit the crime? The last in a trilogy of follow-up studies spanning fifteen years in the careers of 500 youthful offenders who had been inmates of the Massachusetts Reformatory, this volume by two of the country's most distinguished and gifted criminologists furnishes a convincing answer to that query, particularly insistent in this period of increase in adolescent and juvenile crime rates.

OUR young men are being toughened, physically and mentally, in the training camps; civilians are learning that they too must develop some degree of tough-mindedness to withstand the harsh impact of war. It is inevitable that this quality of toughness should be reflected in the new books.
ALGIERS, Nov. 27 -- A communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 27 -- Karl August Fagerholm, Finnish Minister of Social Affairs, has handed in his resignation, effective Jan. 1, it is reliably reported from Helsinki through private channels.

FORT DIX, Nov. 27 -- Col. Lloyd T. Jones, former commander of Olmsted Field, Pa., assumed command of the Fort Dix air base today, succeeding Col. William H. Garrison who was transferred this week to Memphis, Tenn.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 27 -- Turkish public opinion is strongly opposed to any unprepared entry into war and it therefore seems most unlikely that Turkey will change her status of a nonbelligerent.

THE state of the theatre being what it is, tomorrow morning would be a very good time to start buying your tickets for New Year's Eve. The Broadway wiseacres expect a tumultuous evening, with all the theatres packed. In fact, they expect it will be just like any Saturday night.

COLUMBIA'S film tribute to the life and music of Frederic Chopin, a subject which has been on and off the studio's schedule for more than three years, is slated to go before the cameras tomorrow under the somewhat cryptic title of "At Night We Dream."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Catholic hierarchy in the United States expressed "fervent support" today for a proposal to provide food to distressed women and children in Nazi-occupied countries.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Prune old canes that bore fruit this year from raspberry and blackberry bushes. Heavier clothing for cold weather gives protection for this prickly task. . . . It's time to bring garden furniture indoors and to look over trellises and arbors for any needed repairs. . . . Other late work should be completed as soon s possible: planting tulips, for example, and cleaning up rubbish and dead leaves.

ALGIERS, Nov. 27 -- Because the best possible surgery and the use of sulfa drugs have failed to produce more than 21 per cent of recoveries in recently investigated gangrene cases, the Army Medical Corps in Italy is coordinating preventive measures and increasing instruction in the detection of the dread infection.

Johnstown, Pa., is finally about to emerge from the shadow of a tragic fifty-four-year-old memory. On May 31, 1889, the South Fork Dam let loose a flood that took 2,300 lives in the valley where the little city stands. Since then it has prospered moderately, about doubling its population, but at every heavy rain strangers have dashed for the hills and cautious industrialists have sometimes avoided the city, in spite of its iron and coal.

This country is not the first to be threatened by inflation, and neither would it be the first to try to offset the undesirable consequences of inflation by subsidies. Experience with such subsidies, however, has not been favorable.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -Although this community is still filled with Army officers and their families, the season will formally begin here Dec. 1 with the opening of the Pine Needles Hotel, recently relinquished by the Army Air Force Technical Training Command.

"MARINES AT WAR" is a book to cherish. Years from now, when people ask: "What was it really like in the Solomons during the last war?" no other answer need be given than to hand them this little 128-page book of pencil drawings, pen-and-inks, water-colors and oils.

FIJI ISLANDS -- Suva, 6.13 megacycles, broadcasts for United Nations troops in the South Seas from 5 to 6:07 A.M. Though announced as "6.1 megacycles" the frequency is the same as Chungking's. A broadcast of American entertainment is anounced from the British Fiji station for 4:30 P.M.
In terms of quick and violent death among civilians, the world has never known anything to equal the Allies' air attacks on German cities, according to The Associated Press.

LIECHTENSTEIN, the small independent principality in Central Europe, has been engaged in pursuits of peace while most of her neighbors warred. One project has been the rerouting of mountain streams, incoming from glaciers, into a newly made channel to carry the melted snows to the Rhine, and concurrently the reclamation of land once inundated by the Alpine floods.

A warning that the existence of the Moscow Declaration and United Nations Relief and Reliabilitation Administration "should not mesmerize us into thinking that justice and wisdom will prevail after the war," was issued by Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein in West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street, yesterday.

THIS well-named book is the best primer yet written on the elements of human motion in factory operation. The illustrations, by multi-exposure photographs, are effective. The text material is simple, clear and to the point.
A BEACHCOMBER who calls himself Philip Stark suddenly becomes the correspondent in Puerta Vieja of an American news agency. His predecessor has died suddenly -- by accident, according to the police.
As a housewife I was interested in your recent editorial labeled "Buried Statistics."

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 27 -- Outclassed in all departments, Lehigh today suffered its most ignominious defeat in history at the hands of its archenemy, Lafayette, and in the course of the seventy-eight games played since the series started in 1884, the Engineers have taken some larrupings.

AGAINST the background of Philadelphia of the Seventeen Nineties, Janet Whitney weaves a highly romantic and sentimental tale of true love which conquers all, The heroine gives the book its title. Judith Greenfield was a dark-haired, blue-eyed Quaker lass of high spirits and forthright words.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- The Governments of the United Nations will be the first to be officially informed of the formation Friday night of the Spanish Committee of Liberation that will seek to obtain recognition of the will of the Spanish people "enslaved by Generalissimo Francisco Franco," Spanish Republican circles said today.

The Chungking radio, in an English-language broadcast reported by United States Government monitors yesterday, said that Dr. Sun Fo, President of the Legislative Yuan of China, had praised "the repeal" of the Chinese Exclusion Act in a speech for America as "reaffirming our faith, in American fair play and American friendship."

LONDON, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Blackpool, coming from behind in the closing minutes to defeat Burnley, 5 -- 3, gained undisputed lead in the English League North today with 22 points, two more than its nearest rivals. Trailing by three goals, Blackpool made five quick points.

I HAVE driven a taxicab for three days in New York. I have learned much about cab riders in particular and human nature in general. And I have also learned something about the ways of taxi drivers, the tricks of their trade, the rigid rules of the "feed line." It is nerveracking -- this hacking business -- but it's adventure.

GRACE BOWEN, "America's most beautiful model" of a dozen years ago, is probably the only pin-up girl in the world who runs two war plants. Both of them -- a small shop in a Fourteenth Street studio building where she formerly fabricated cellophane party favors, and a large, newly opened New Jersey unit -- were organized and are owned and managed entirely by Miss Bowen.

ECONOMICS, considered by some a prosaic subject, is the motivating force behind one of the most violent thrillers ever born of Eric Ambler's sinister imagination. With Rumanian oil as the stake and the nations of wax-arming Europe as the aspirants, the plot of "Background to Danger," read after five years, still seethes with intrigue and dynamite as the author proceeds from stabbing to torture-chamber, from bloody escape to a terrifying scene of near-suffocation.

Capt. Carl C. Von Paulsen, Coast Guard, commander of the Atlantic Fleet task force unit that "eliminated" the German radio and weather station on Greenland, declared yesterday that the Nazis had chosen the "most bearable and livable area in Greenland" for their base, and that the installations there indicated they had planned to stay for a long time.

SOME weeks ago this column set down a few random observations on the individual beauty of certain words and their power of suggestion. The quality of words, the company they keep, the changes of meaning through which they pass, are rewarding fields of exploration, and too little has been written about them that has the juice of life in it.

Long before the harrowing adventures of Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker and his companions thrilled the country the Navy had been trying to develop a way of desalting sea water to make it drinkable. Rickenbacker and his companions had to catch rain water in handkerchiefs and cloths which they wrung out -- the time-honored procedure of the shipwrecked.

THE reappearance of the old-fashioned Dominie is one of the most interesting recent occurrences in the educational work. It is not a resurrection. The Dominie never was completely dead. He was merely out of favor, and when he took the air he walked somewhat apolegetically, not to say furtively, in lanes and byways.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 27 -- The Gilbert campaign is over and with little more than a momentary pause for breath we make ready for the next leap in the general direction of Tokyo while the wounded are being brought out and re-establishment of the islands as military bases proceeds.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The first official report on war damage to the ancient buildings of Sicily during military operations there last summer was released today by the War Office. This based on evidence collected by members of the Allied military governments.

Due to the prohibitive cost of exhuming antique steam-operated pumps and appurtenances, once unsuccessfully sought as museum curiosities, Todd Shipyards Corporation has decided to fill in the old "Pump Well" at Erie Basin Dry Docks in Brooklyn.

Mr. Moses objects to the statue of Daniel Webster, whom he refers to to with questionable taste as the "Divine Daniel," because the statue shows his "unpressed pants." Could anything be more ridiculous?

AMERICANS have not forgotten the disastrous sequence of inflation and deflation which accompanied and followed the First World War. From 1914 to 1920, the level of prices was doubled and the value of the dollar was cut in half. In 1920, the boom collapsed. Within a year, prices fell by 45 per cent, visiting business with bankruptcy labor with unemployment, and agriculture with widespread foreclosures and prolonged depression.

Early relief for the many coal consumers whose orders have been backlogging in the offices of local concerns for months was forecast in the industry yesterday as shipments of anthracite into the city reached a heavy volume.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Several important steps have been taken this week and more are in prospect to coordinate the foreign economic, military and relief policies of the United States Government.

Retail trade continued notably active last week as Christmas shopping expanded in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Retail trade continued to show sharp percentage gains last week as Christmas shopping gained momentum. Department store sales on the average were estimated as running 18 to 20 per cent ahead of the like week last year, with the increase for specialty shops well above these figures.

A SHORT time ago this writer overheard an ensign say that because everything was in the rule book, including what tie to wear, it was not necessary for a Navy man to think. That particular ensign should have had a small volume titled "Command at Sea," by Captain Harley F. Cope, USN, thrown at his head.

DR. ERNEST JACKH is, indubitably, a "good" German. Yet the mere existence of such a man, with such a mind, as the former founder and director of the Hochschule fur Politik in Berlin, helped before 1933 (quite unwittingly on Jackh's part) to befuddle a good many Anglo-Saxons on the meaning of the Hitler bid for power.

iBOOIKS for the "read aloud" times for the youngest children-ms a preface to morning and afternoon rest periods and for just before bed- serve many good purposes. Entertainment is basic, of course, but along with that go the enlarging of horizons, the translation of impressions into ideas, the linking of the child with the outside world ands from good illustrations-some idea of form and color.

LONDON, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- Well-informed persons expect the Allied powers within a short time -- possibly a few days -- to drop a political "block-buster" on Germany and Japan that would have more violent results within the Axis than any previous development except possibly the American entry into the war.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The central post-war issue before President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Marshal Stalin, as before Woodrow Wilson, Lloyd George, Clemenceau and Orlando in World War I, is what to do with the Germans after they are beaten.

IT has become a truism to say that literature does not flourish in the heat of conflict. With respect to poetry, it is indeed true that war tends to stimulate a shallow and sentimental patriotism among second-rate talents.

Committees working in the interest of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies will meet tomorrow afternoon in the Palm Court of the Ritz-Carlton to complete arrangements for the benefit performance of the "Ice Follies" on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

About half the high school boys of this country favor post-war compulsory military service, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Institute of Student Opinion, a national organization sponsored by Scholastic Magazines.

MEXICO CITY -- Evidence is accumulating here that Mexico is looking to Soviet Russia as the champion of her rights in the postwar world. Following the arrival of Soviet Ambassador Constantine Oumansky earlier last summer, several manifestations have taken place which indicate that Mexicans are warmly supporting the Russians on international questions.
GREAT LAKES, Ill., Nov. 27 -- The Great Lakes Naval Training Station eleven defeated Notre Dame today, 19 to 14, with a finish that no Hollywood script writer would dare to turn in to his boss.
What were Adolf Hitler's thoughts last week?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Taxicab operators in twenty-two cities are conserving 1,250,000 gallons of gasoline annually by coordinating the services under joint-action plans approved by the Office of Defense Transportation, Joseph B. Eastman, ODT Director, reported today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- The government-controlled newsprint company announced today that, beginning next Monday, all publications in Mexico would be reduced by 15 to 25 per cent of their present size.

BOGOTA, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- Acting President Dario Echandia has sent letters to Provincial Governors, advising them of the Government's action and urging them to redouble their efforts in guarding internal safety.

When Fritz Kreisler came on stage at the start of his recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall the vast audience, which filled the auditorium and platform to capacity, rose and stood in homage to the great violinist, who at 68 still remains the undisputed master in his field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Prevention of a transportation crisis in the country next year because of a shortage of tires hinges on five "M's," muscle, military, machinery, materials and moderation, according to Rubber Director Bradley Dewey and the tire-making industry.

BETIO, Tarawa, Gilbert Islands, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- This island was won over the dead bodies of United States Marines. Betio fell because every marine who died had a shot at the Japanese before he went down and more marines kept coming and coming as those in front of them died until finally so many Japanese were dead, too, that the marines were able to get on the beach.

As the "only first-class armed powers" when this war is over America, Great Britain and Russia will be responsible for maintaining peace, Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, told a nation-wide radio audience yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- With individual increases amounting to as much as 3,700 per cent, 121 American corporations that are devoted entirely, or nearly so, to the war effort added nearly $10,000,000 to the salaries of their officers and directors between 1940 and 1942, it was shown today in an independent survey of reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Many CONSUMER ARTICLES made under wartime restrictions are so different from pre-war products that there is no criterion for price ceilings except by individual study and approval by OPA -- which reveals, incidentally, the ingenuity of American manufacturers in finding substitute materials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- The American Red Cross announced tonight that Robert E. Lewis, formerly of Philadelphia and Columbus, Ohio, and Harry H. Poague, formerly of Minneapolis, both Red Cross field workers, had been killed in an airplane crash in New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- Senator Taft, Republican, of Ohio, suggested today that the subsidy dispute be compromised by abandoning the rollback of butter and meat prices and allowing the use of subsidies only to maintain existing prices.

Where Russia's huge land armies roll back the invader and where American and British forces storm mountain passes on the road to Rome there is much daylight fighting. The precision bombing of our Eighth Air Force and many of its fighter attacks also go forward in the light of day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 322 United States soldiers missing in action in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean and Southwest Pacific areas.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII, designating Dec. 8 as a day for public prayers for peace throughout the world, said today that "only the Gospel can bring the nations together again."

EVERY now and then, as nature waddles conservatively after art, the theatre has an opening night such as is more often described in books than takes place on Broadway. The most recent occasion was a week ago last evening when the Army Air Forces arrived at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre with Moss Hart's "Winged Victory."

Angelo Bertelli, one of the most famed passers in Notre Dame football history, has been designated as winner of the John W. Heisman Memorial Trophy for this year, Chairman Bill Prince of the trophy committee announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The people of Berlin are having to endure an ordeal of relentless bombing after four years of war that leaves them at a great disadvantage, both physical and psychological, as compared with Londoners, who digested their blitz early in the conflict.

The Muhlenberg basketball team registered an upset by defeating City College on the Beavers' court last night. Trailing for the greater part of the game, City managed to pull ahead five minutes before the end, but was unable to hold the advantage and bowed, finally, by 50 to 47.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Letters circulated here among Republican members of Congress and other officials announce the formation of a committee to boom Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts for the party's Presidential and Vice Presidential nominations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The bearish sentiment that prevailed at the close of the grain markets yesterday was dissipated over night, and a wave of short covering on the Chicago Board of Trade, combined with purchases attributed to distillers, listed December wheat 2 7/8 cents a bushel to the highest price in eighteen years at $1.63 1/2.

Harry M. Parmley of Harrisburg, Pa., informs this department that about 15,000 tons of steel are rolled into motor-vehicle license plates for the country as a whole. The 1,100 tons required for Pennsylvania's license plates alone would make 220,000 rifles for soldiers. Why not save all this steel?

MONTREAL, Nov. 27 -- The high-flying Canadiens chalked up their eleventh game without a loss in the National Hockey League race tonight, beating the cellar-dwelling Rangers, 6 -- 3, before a crowd of 10,160. It was the eleventh straight loss for the Rangers, who have yet to win or play a tie this season.

Clinging to the long-shot hope that they can still finish in a tie for the Eastern championship of the National Football League, the New York Giants will trot out against the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds today, armed with the knowledge that a defeat will blast them completely out of the championship picture.

In the flames of burning Berlin there can be read a writing on the wall. The prophet Daniel translated the first words of the famous inscription, "Mene, Mene, Tekel, Upharsin," as meaning, "God hath numbered thy kingdom and finished it." This modern writing says the same thing.

WHAT shall be done about the window boxes, now that winter is near? Those boxes, once gay with balcony petunias, geraniums, vincas, lantanas and marigolds, are in need of attention. For as the season draws on, many a house front is marred by the ugly sight of bare window boxes filled with dead stalks and gawky swaying vines.

Overwhelming are the statistics in the news these days: 145,000 army trucks to Russia; 2,000,000 old garments reconditioned in England; 3,163,000 tons of scrap iron here, 804,000 tons of kitchen waste there; 1,385 new day nurseries; 90,000 canteen workers; 15,000,000 heads of families without a union card; 21,500,000 European homeless; $1,250,000,000 saved in Victory gardens; $4,800,000,000 stolen as "occupation charges" by Germany; fourteen touchdown passes tossed by two players in a single Saturday afternoon....

SHIPPING shortages and the need for feeding armies and civilians in all quarters of the globe have made the dehydration of vegetables, fruits, eggs and other food products a matter of compelling interest both to us and to our Allies.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Canadian Army engineers have started work on a $75,000 hospital wing in Sussex to serve airmen from the Dominion during the war. Later it will be a permanent memorial to those who lost their lives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight hailed Colombia's affirmation of belligerency on the side of the United Nations "as virile action * * * in keeping with the noble traditions of that great democracy."

Arrangements have gone forward rapidly in the last fortnight for the National Retriever Championship field trial this week-end in the Middle West, final details having had to await the results of two events in the East -- the meetings of the Labrador Retriever Club and the Women's Field Trial Club.

ANY wind is an in wind for beauty. Dermatologists explain that the brisk, frosty breezes of winter, if left to their own devices, will cause a rapid evaporation of the natural moisture which lubricates every skin and leave it unnaturally dry. The result is that perennial wintertime ailment, chapping.

Ensign Walter G. Sittmann of 87-52 Eighty-sixth Street, Woodhaven, Queens, received the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal in a ceremony yesterday at the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N.Y. Capt. Giles C. Stedman, USNR, superintendent of the school, made the presentation before 2,600 cadet-midshipmen.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- If West Coast opinion now on record could be measured in decibels there is no doubt that it would favor War Department control of the relocation centers in which persons of Japanese ancestry, evacuated from coastal military areas last year, are making their homes.

The legal right of the Office of Price Administration to issue suspension orders against alleged violators of its regulations was challenged yesterday when Gallagher's Steak House, Inc., 228 West Fifty-second Street, filed a complaint in the United States District Court here and asked for an injunction and restraining order against Chester Bowles, OPA Administrator, and three of his staff.

THE other day -- it was just before the dinner hour -- a serious-looking young woman walked through the crowded lobby of a London hotel and joined a group of other serious-looking young women waiting for her around a table. She wore the khaki uniform of a private in the ATS (the British women's army). Her stockings were lisle and khaki colored.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Most of the hogs arriving here today were assigned to the fat-stock show and, as a result, there was no test of market conditions. Prices were nominally steady with the top quotable at $13.75 a hundredweight on good and choice 200 to 270 pound offerings. The Food Distribution Administration announced that the corn-hog ratio for the week ended on Nov. 20 was 12.7, against 17.4 a year before.

NURSERY NEWS -- One room in the wartime home has been sadly neglected by the governmental powers-that-be -- according to the plaintive reports of local buyers. That is the nursery. In spite of a steady increase in the number of babies arriving, furniture for babies and children is virtually nonexistent in the wholesale market.

THE present master of Trinity, the most distinguished of living British historians, has written a concise and interesting account of the college he has loved so long and served so well. In his preface he disclaims any pretensions to writing a book of research or of adding to scholarly knowledge.

HERE is a book written by nearly a hundred authors -- all amateurs. Collectively they accomplish what no professional writer, war correspondent or historian has done in all the millions of well-paid words set down since Pearl Harbor.

FOOCHOW, China, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- Sharp Peak Island, where about 200 Japanese are garrisoned, lumbers out of the Pacific and sprawls across the mouth of the Min River, which leads to Foochow. From Sharp Peak the Japanese control steamer and junk channels into the river.

THERE was a time when the coming or going of a Hollywood personage in New York harbor was quite a heady affair involving champagne, orchids, not fewer than a thousand press agents and intimate friends, and -- if the party were feminine -- photographers' loud cries of "A little higher, please!"

TORONTO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Breaking a 1-1 first-period tie by scoring three goals in the second, Toronto went on tonight to beat the Boston Bruins, 7 to 4, in a National Hockey League game at Maple Leaf Gardens.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Time and the football season both ran out together for a hard-fighting Rutgers football team today as Bela Rieger, the Rockville Centre boy, missed the Brooklyn College goal line by inches in a desperate plunge on the last play of the game that would have meant a tie and a possible triumph.

PICKWICK goes through life with that god-like gullibility which is the key to all adventures. The greenhorn is the ultimate victor in everything; it is he that gets the most out of life.*** His soul will never starve for exploits or excitements who is wise enough to be made a fool of.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 27 -- The newspaper La Hora, in which President Rios is a stockholder, devotes a leading article today to Senator Hugh Butler's declarations regarding Latin America in which it says that "the only thing accomplished is building up arguments for Nazi-sympathizing elements devoted to agitation for neutrality."

The Mexico City newspaper Excelsior declared yesterday, according to The Asociated Press, that an assertion by Senator Butler that the United States was being played for a "sucker" through the "good neighbor" policy was "sabotaging" that policy just "when the sentiments of friendship and mutual comprehension are beginning to bear their evident fruits."

OSCAR MONTELIUS, a pioneer of archaeological research in Europe, was born in Stockholm on Sept. 9, 1843, and a series of stamps commemorating the centenary reached New York last week from the Swedish capital.

Despite the fact that food prices may advance as much as 5 per cent on some items if Congress rejects the subsidy program, the domestic food supply situation at present "looks far better than it did six months ago," Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., declared yesterday.

IN her new novel Frances Parkinson Keyes sets out to demonstrate patriotically and thoroughly the part that a New England farm family plays in the war. Not even Wendell Willkie can have done a more conscien-

A SIX-CARD suit as good as A-K-Q-J-x-x, or a seven-card suit as good as A-K-Q-x-x-x-x, is supposed to be "solid." It should not lose a trick. In the bidding and in the play, the holder of such a suit always assumes that he will be able to run the suit without opposition.

THIS could have been a good book. Most of the material is there. More of it could have been there. In this treatment, it emerges as a hurried job, a loosely told yarn in the style of the fact-detective magazine, interlarded with big moments which fail to come off, marred by amazing errors.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- The German bugler who has been blowing retreat after retreat in southern and central Russia is now preparing to sound a similar call in the Baltic states.

WITH THE 165TH INFANTRY ON MAKIN ATOLL, Nov. 23 (Delayed) -- With fewer than a hundred Japanese left on the several islands of Makin atoll and all semblance of organized resistance gone, this important Gilbert Islands base now belongs to the United Nations again.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Bushwhacker, brown horse owned by Byron H. Wise, decisively defeated seven rivals in the mile and 70-yard Bayu St. John Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Well ridden by George Burns; Bushwhacker, a 5-1 shot, was hustled into a good positiion at once, followed War Reward into the backstretch and, taking command going to the far turn, always held his field safe thereafter.
The seed of the sugar beet is not a single cell but a cluster of cells as in beans and corn. In most cases it is not difficult to separate the individual seeds from the group.

A glimmer of hope for a not too arid Christmas or a "painfully temperate New Year's Eve" came yesterday to a parched citizenry that had found it more and more difficult to obtain a bottle of Scotch, rye or bourbon whisky at neighborhood package stores.

The United States will be fighting in another world war by 1970, in the opinion of a third of City College's undergraduates. Although the results of a comprehensive opinion poll released yesterday by Dr. John L. Bergstresser, dean of students, showed them to be strongly anti-isolationist a heavy undercurrent of pessimism regarding the future was apparent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Reports this week that a high-ranking American Army commander had slapped a combat veteran in a hospital tent and ordered him back to duty because he thought he was malingering, instead of suffering from "shell shock," brought back to millions of Americans the question of the last war as to just what "shell shock" may be.

BETSY, Tacy and Tib, three little girls of Deep Valley, Minn., early in this century have found high favor among present-day readers about their age. The fourth Betsy-Tacy story lives up to its predecessors in story quality, naturalness and friendly charm.

Although approving Government aid for returning service men who wish to continue their education at colleges or technical schools, executives of national fraternities advocated yesterday that the choice of the institution be left to the individual.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast to the Soviet Union from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Oklahoma scored the first Sooner football victory in history on Nebraska sod today, gaining a 26-to-7 verdict before 4,000 fans that gave the Oklahomans a clean slate of five victories and no defeats in Big Six conference play this season.

BROADWAY ROSE will not like this book. (She is not mentioned in it.) In fact, most of us from over on the west, or peasant, side of town are not mentioned in it. This quick look at Cafe Society will be most appreciated by people who have dressers.

THERE is no denying that "Grand Parade" lacks the felicity of G.B. Lancaster's "Promenade" and "Pageant." In those earlier novels, which described the colonizing of New Zealand and Tasmania, plot and people, period and place were root, stem and branch of the same vigorous plant.

HIGH over the western Pacific some fine morning -- and it may not be many months ahead -- a flier peering down from the cockpit of his scout bomber will see off on the horizon a great array of blue-gray ships.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 -- The Tigers announced today the signing of Manager Steve O'Neill to a new one-year contract, thus ending speculation whether the former major league baseball catcher would be back for a second term. Salary figures were not disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The War Department said today that careful consideration of manpower problems involved in Army production retrenchment was assured by regulations covering such changes.

MURDER is done in the apartment of one of Detective Sergeant Gridley Nelson's best friends, and another old friend appears to be involved in a serious way. For a time it looks as though Nelson is obstructing justice -- and permitting friendship to interfere with his sense of duty.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Oklahoma scored the first Sooner football victory in history on Nebraska sod today, gaining a 26-to-7 verdict before 4,000 fans that gave the Oklahomans a clean slate of five victories and no defeats in Big Six conference play this season.

HIGH over the western Pacific some fine morning -- and it may not be many months ahead -- a flier peering down from the cockpit of his scout bomber will see off on the horizon a great array of blue-gray ships.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 -- The Tigers announced today the signing of Manager Steve O'Neill to a new one-year contract, thus ending speculation whether the former major league baseball catcher would be back for a second term. Salary figures were not disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The War Department said today that careful consideration of manpower problems involved in Army production retrenchment was assured by regulations covering such changes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- War expenditures will be about $92,000,000,000 this fiscal year, which ends June 30, instead of $100,000,000,000 as twice estimated by the Administration, Budget Director Harold D. Smith said today.

To initiate the Salvation Army's 1944 drive, Fritz Kreisler, noted violinist, will appear in a recital on the night of Jan. 11 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Kreisler will contribute his services for the occasion.
