FROM the beginning of the bombing of England the New York office of the Oxford University Press has received many inquiries as to whether this or that literary landmark has been damaged. "The public appointed us as experts," said a spokesman for the Press, recently, "and, of course, we aren't.

THE program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the concerts of the coming week juxtaposes two works by composers who had both a spiritual and racial rapport -- Gustav Mahler and Ernst Bloch -- and this arrangement has been evocative of a characteristic and revealing letter from Mr. Bloch to Dr. Rodzinski.

The New York Ordnance District, Army Service Forces, is participating in a plan which may result in the development of a new industry in the New York area -- the manufacture of truck axles, it was revealed yesterday.

General Smuts, in his Guildhall speech of Oct. 19, repeated his last year's denunciation of Nietzsche, the "Father of the Superman and the Blond Beast, which still hurls defiance at the Christian cod with its gentler virtues."

Brock Pemberton, in 455 E 51st St; Leonora Morton, in 222 W 59th St; Joseph Ryan, in 302 W 12th St through Bing Bing; Waldo Pierce, in 20 E 9th St; M. Dolleck, in 2 Horatio St through Bing Bing -- William A. White Sons, brokers.

The two-story store and office building at 2840 Hudson Boulevard, in the Journal Square section of Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by the Murder Corporation to the Charsol Realty Corporation, Sol Bookstein, president. Included is a plot 100 by 100 feet in the rear which was acquired by the seller from the city of Jersey City and operated until recently as a parking lot. J.I. Kislak was the broker.

Still another of Mayor La Guardia's commissioners has come to his aid with a report designed to refute charges in the Kings County August grand jury's presentment on crime conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section.

We can be thankful that our cities have been untouched by the worst horrors of war, the Rev. Serapion J. Reid, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Scapular of Mount Carmel, 339 East Twenty-eighth Street, declared yesterday at a military memorial and thanksgiving service of the Holy Name Society of the parish.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Philadelphia - Pittsburgh combination passed and sprinted to a 27-14 upset victory over the Redskins today in a National Football League game before 35,826. It was Washington's first defeat of the league season.

The pulverizing air attacks on Berlin naturally stir up emotion in freedom-loving countries that remember the German bombing of Warsaw, Rotterdam, Belgrade, London and a hundred other cities. The Nazis sowed the wind and there is a grim satisfaction in watching them reap the whirlwind. But, emotion aside, we should try to understand the military meaning of the attack on the Axis capital.

Ely Culbertson, whose plan for permanent world peace has been brought out in book form by Doubleday, Doran, will speak tonight at the Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University in the McMillin Theatre. Mr. Culbertson will talk on post-war problems and on his world federation project.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Nov. 27 (Delayed) -- Today we can lift a veil that has been covering the military campaign in Italy, for the anonymity of the American Forty-fifth Division, which fought in the thick of the battle for the Salerno beachhead has ended.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (Reuter) -- The Brazilian debt scheme has been commented on in several leading British provincial papers. The Manchester Guardian's financial editor wrote that it was clear from the statement issued that the Council of Foreign Bondholders thinks Brazil could have done somewhat better. After outlining the scheme, he added:

The New York Social Register for 1944, just published, gives recognition for the first time to the service with the armed forces of women listed in its pages, by entering their rank and branch of service after their names.

The U.S.S. Blue, the twentieth destroyer completed since Pearl Harbor at the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company's yard at Mariners Harbor, S.I., slid down the ways yesterday, sponsored by the widow and 1-year-old daughter of Lieut. Comdr. John Stuart Blue, Guadalcanal hero, for whom the vessel was named.

A memorial service sponsored by the Police Shomrim Society, was held yesterday afternoon in Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street. Before the service 600 members of the department marched from the Twentieth Precinct station house at 150 West Sixty-eighth Street along Broadway to the temple.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 29 (UP) -- A communique:

"The good gray poet," Walt Whitman, whose fame in his lifetime was not nearly as great as it grew after his death, will be honored again this week when the City Park Branch of the Brooklyn Public Library at 98 St. Edwards Street will be renamed the Walt Whitman Branch.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- The tedious litigation involving the Associated Gas and Electric Holding Company System moved a long way toward a conclusion today when the Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a plan of reorganization of the company whose assets, under the direction of Howard C. Hopson, mushroomed from $7,000,000 to $900,000,000 in seven years of the lush "Twenties."

ALGIERS, Nov. 28 -- While the British Eighth Army, in fine weather, continued to expand and strengthen its bridgehead across the Sangro River, the Fifth Army made its first gain in weeks. American units drove ahead two miles northwest of Montaquilo to capture dominating ground around the 3,400-foot height of La Falconara.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board defined tonight its policy for handling Christmas bonus disputes in an order reversing a decision of the Detroit regional WLB.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28 -- Dr. Arthur Souza Costa, Brazil's Minister of Finance, is receiving his share of applause for adoption of his plan for payment of the Brazilian foreign debt in twenty-three years at a saving of 37 per cent. His work has brought congratulatory messages from foreign and domestic sources.
"Thirty Seconds to Go for Immortality" could be the title Hollywood would slap on it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Prices of oats, rye and barley on the Chicago Board of Trade were affected last week by the action of wheat, but no additional relief in the way of larger supplies of Canadian grain is expected in the case of oats and barley. Millions of bushels of these two grains have been imported despite an import duty and an export tax on shipments from Canada.

The energy the city has exercised in battling ceiling price violators in food will not be diverted to helping the frustrated liquor buyer cope with black market prices charged for his favorite rye, Scotch or bourbon, Mayor La Guardia made clear yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28 -- The Russian delegation to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration meeting here has lost the first round of an effort to have higher priorities put on the repatriation of "displaced" persons whom the Nazis have moved from their homelands into other countries, and lower priorities on those who have been transferred to other places within their own countries, it was learned today.

With light trading, which on Wednesday (the day before Thanksgiving) increased, prices for both stocks and bonds declined. On the Stock Exchange, the explanation seemed to be that the exceptionally heavy aerial bombing of Berlin would hasten the end of the war and confront us with all the "peace problems."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Jack Sutphen's boat Rum Dum led the point scoring today in the winter season regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The prospective size of the Federal deficit is a crucial consideration in determining an appropriate fiscal program. The revised estimates of the current deficit just made available by the Bureau of the Budget, therefore, are very timely. The Director of the Budget also made it a point to label as "very misleading" the recent statement that the War Department had saved $13,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Many war production secrets soon will be made public because "our production position is now so strong that information concerning it will be of no aid or comfort to the enemy -- quite the contrary," Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board announced today.

In a recent letter to THE TIMES John Kirkland Clark asked, "What are the usual earnings of those in the lowest income group among the [coal] miners and what is the annual scale as affecting mine workers in general ?"

The clang of heavy hammer on solid iron anvil is resounding more frequently. The country blacksmith takes his place beside the airplane mechanic and ship riveter as a vitally essential war worker. Not only does the smith nail shoes on the farm horses.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Pennsylvania anthracite bootleggers and the forces of law and order were approaching a showdown tonight, with all signs pointing toward a general defiance of an edict that poaching of coal must cease by Tuesday midnight.

The Greater New York Safety Council again calls attention to the terrible waste, from both humanitarian and practical points of view, occasioned by accidents which have no relation to occupation. Last year 26,000 workers were killed in this country in off-the-job accidents and 2,200,000 others were injured outside of their working places -- on the streets, in the homes and elsewhere.

If any further evidence of the deadly effect of the air war on Germany's war effort and morale had been necessary beyond the terrifying testimony reaching neutral countries through correspondents and bombed-out refugees from Berlin, that testimony is now being provided by the outcries of the Nazi chieftains themselves.

Prices of cotton for future delivery again were sharply lower last week. At the close of trading Saturday active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 14 to 60 points on the week, with the greatest loss in the December contract.

The Japanese radio at Hsinking, Manchuria, said yesterday in an English-language broadcast directed to North America that the Cabinet of Premier Hideki Tojo had formulated and announced a new ten-point policy program -- a list of ten steps to be taken as "absolutely indispensable to meet the exigencies of the present war situation."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today it had ordered an election at the Botany Worsted Mills, Passaic, N.J., for purposes of collective bargaining. The company had asserted it was not engaged in interstate commerce and therefore not subject to jurisdiction by the NLRB.
ALGIERS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- communique:
LONDON, Monday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- A few light showers fell in parts of the dry section of the winter Wheat Belt last week, but they were ineffective in breaking the prolonged semi-drought that has developed west of the Missouri River and that embraces possibly 25 per cent of the country's total acreage seeded to that grain.

The Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., asserted yesterday that present-day civilization "needs above all things a restored humility and a renewed honesty in two high places -- the universities and the churches." Dr. Bell delivered the guest sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Religion assumes even greater importance in everyday life because of the "persistent psychological bombardment which we are all undergoing," the Rev. Walton E. Cole, minister of the Second Church in Boston, said yesterday in a sermon at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue. "If we are to stand up to life today,' he said, "we must learn how to increase our spiritual power."

Because Germany fears defeat, she has improved her treatment of United Nations war prisoners in the last twelve months, Sir William Kerr Fraser-Tytler, former British Minister at Kabul, Afghanistan, declared yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Field aboard a Pan-American Airlines Clipper.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
With regard to your remark that Lincoln's Gettysburg speech "made little impression on the contemporary mind," surely you have heard that the reaction to the speech was "the perfect tribute."

WASHINGTON, NOV. 28 -- Leaders expressed confidence today that Congress would, act quickly to make ready the provisions for demobilized service men and-women upon which President Roosevelt has repeatedly requested "immediate" action, but there was less assurance in other respects as to the Capitol's readiness for a sudden peace.

The number of buyers in the market during the past week decreased, but there still was much interest in placing orders for seasonal lines as well as for the spring season, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Steps were taken yesterday to change two Protestant houses of worship in Manhattan from white to Negro congregations. They were the Harlem-New York Presbyterian Church, 2 West 122d Street, and St. Matthew's Lutheran, at 145th Street and Convent Avenue. The latter is the oldest church of that faith in the United States, dating back to 1664.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins declared tonight that there would not be and "need not be" a depression after the war. She was discussing plans of labor, industry and Government to prevent post-war unemployment.

Additional opposition to the sale of the Century Distilling Company by Allied Mills, Inc., to the National Distillers Products Corporation developed yesterday when William H. Shane of Philadelphia, beneficial owner of 1,000 shares of Allied, began solicitation of proxies.
Six Broadway theatres will present new films this week. The schedule follows:

WITH THE TWENTY-SEVENTH DIVISION, Makin Island (Delayed) -- Private Temange, a native of Makin Island and a veteran jungle warrior with the Fiji Scouts, came home to guide part of the Shamrock Battalion of the famous "Fighting Sixty-Ninth" Regiment during the Twenty-seventh Division's invasion of Makin a few days ago.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 28 -- Approval of a 1944 budget of $1,171,590 for the Jewish Welfare Board was voted today by the National Finance Council, concluding a two-day session in Cincinnati. The council is the budgeting and allocating body of the Welfare Board.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 20 you published an editorial, "Two Kinds of Japanese," in which a plea was made for a distinction between loyal and disloyal Japanese in this country. In this connection it may be of interest to your readers to learn about one group of loyal Japanese and what they are doing for the war effort.

"The foundations of tomorrow's society are the children of today, and the condition of the children must therefore be a matter of crucial concern in the drafting of any plans for social reconstruction," says the International Labor Office in a gruesome yet constructive report on the health of children in occupied Europe.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, announced today an industry-wide drive through trade associations to achieve greater manpower utilization.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Among the wards of 1,213 decorations for valor and exceptional achievement by members of the Eighth United States Airforce as announced recently by Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commanding American air units in the European theatre of operations, were many men from New York.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Berliners, who last week reaped the whirlwind that the Luftwaffe sowed over London in 194041, awoke this morning from their first night's sleep ,interrupted by Royal Air Force bombers since last Sunday to clean up damage done by four heavy and two light aerial attacks since Nov. 18.

NAPLES, Nov. 26 (Delayed) -- Posters reading "Viva la monarchia" have been appearing in Naples in the last few days. There have also been leaflets and pamphlets espousing the cause of King Victor Emmanuel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- The Bears won the Western division championship of the National Football League for the fourth straight year by defeating the Cardinals, 35 to 24, in their intracity game today, but they had to rally three times, on each occasion on a touchdown pass by Sid Luckman.

Modern war reaches its climax of horror in the burning of a great city. This is the concept of hell come to life, but the old prophets could not picture a fiery furnace on the scale of the industrial center of today, with the vast and many layered network of pipes and rails and power lines to which twentieth-century life is geared.

This evening "Lovers and Friends," as interpreted by Dodie Smith in her six-character London drawing-room play, will be introduced at the Plymouth. An 8:20 curtain is announced, the management hereby warning latecomers they will just have to wait until the first scene is over before being guided to their seats.

CENTRAL PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 28 -- Sgt. Walter Schliesman, 25 years old, of New York's Twenty-seventh Division, killed five Japanese with a water-soaked Garland automatic rifle and blew two others to bits with hand grenades during the first hours of the invasion of Makin Island last Saturday.

Our offensive launched in the Gilberts enormously increases the pressure which can be applied to Japan's far-flung Pacific defenses. Yet it is likely that an appreciable breathing spell must pass before the next blow falls on that central front.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Samuel Goldwyn, after returning from a six-week stay in New York, has announced that he will star Danny Kaye in a second Technicolor musical which will go into production next May. Kaye's first film, "Up in Arms," is now being edited for a February release.

Mayor La Guardia assured New Yorkers yesterday that there would be plenty of meat from now until spring. In his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall he told consumers, however, that meat received here would "not be of the high grade to which New York is accustomed."

A representative of the United States Department of Agriculture said yesterday that a general understanding of how meats are graded -- that is, how quality is determined -- works to a consumer's advantage in two ways. It is a method of telling whether or not the price conforms with the ceiling set by the Office of Price Administration, and it helps in determining the right cookery procedure.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- Armed with credentials from economic and army groups in Germany -- the former headed by the Saar magnate, Herman Roechling, and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht and the latter by Field Marshal Gen. Fritz von Mannstein -- Franz von Papen, Germany's "negotiator extraordinary," is reliably reported to be in Rome awaiting a private audience with Pope Pius within the forty-eight hours.

Posing the question "Are we prepared for victory?" the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island and former rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church here, warned in a sermon yesterday morning that America must be prepared in character and discipline to accept its share of responsibility in establishing a just and durable peace.

Marking the first Sunday in Advent, which is also the first day of the Roman Catholic ecclesiastical year, the Forty Hours Devotion opened yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. It is a solemn devotion to the Blessed Sacrament in which "the faithful relieving each other in relays of forty hours" offer continuous prayers for peace.
MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- There is evidence of mounting appreciation among Russians of the great destruction being caused in Germany by Anglo-American bombers.
Business buildings and apartment houses changed hands in deals in the downtown and West Side sections reported over the week-end.
ALGIERS, Nov. 28 -- A New York couple in uniform were married at an Army hospital today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Air Medal has been awarded by the Navy to Arthur C. Apdorson, aviation ordnanceman first class, son of Anders B. Anderson of College Highway; Avon, Conn., and to Walter S. Gorka, aviation ordnanceman, third class, of 18 Seymour Ave., Windsor Locks, Conn. Gorka's award was made posthumously.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Independent miners meeting here today voted to ignore an order of the Anthracite Committee that bootleg coal mining halt at midnight Tuesday, while another group at Tower City, near here, refused to affiliate with the United Mine Workers and criticized the UMW leadership.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Responsibilities of the individual and of civic groups in preventing racial and religious hatreds were stressed tonight by church, Government and labor leaders at a meeting in Symphony Hall in support of racial and religious understanding.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST FACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 29 -- Japan's maintenance of a considerable naval force in the New Britain and New Ireland area and continued replacement of planes destroyed are among evidences so strong as to be almost conclusive that the Navy's Gilberts offensive has not altered Tokyo's determination to keep us from Rabaul, the southern barrier to Truk.

WITH THE SEVENTH DIVISION ON MAKIN ATOLL -- The invasion of the Gilbert Islands set a pattern for future amphibious operations in the Pacific and tested a number of new techniques for island warfare, Lieut. Col. James Roosevelt, who accompanied the first assault wave ashore on the western side of Makin Island, said before he left here for Pearl Harbor.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The suggestion made by market operators a week ago that the rally in the stock markets probably would be short-lived has proved correct. The past week has seen the markets again drifting in idleness and hesitation and renewed discussion about the uncertainties of the future.

GARWOOD, N.J. Nov. 28 -- This community, with a population of 5,000, swelled daily by 3,000 commuters who work in its twenty-three war plants, will be without a doctor after Tuesday unless the Government does something about it.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Nov. 29 -- A 1,000-pound bomb from a patrolling Liberator pierced the armor of a Japanese light cruiser and exploded inside in a spectacular nocturnal display to tally the forty-ninth enemy warship sunk or damaged in the northern Solomons during November.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The High Command charged the Japanese at Changteh used poison gas on thirteen occasions Friday, but said the Chinese had fought back and annihilated more than 2,000 of the invaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A two-pronged check-up on the dealings of the United States with the Latin-American countries is in the making as a result of the disputed charges of Senator Hugh A. Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, that the United States is being played for a "profligate sucker."

Although wartime conditions are supposed to have streamlined baseball to such a degree that it is now said to be a mere skeleton of its once robust self, New York will play host today to the largest group of visiting baseball bigwigs the city has known in years.

The contributions to Jewish learning and human understanding made by Dr. Louis Ginzberg, noted Talmudic scholar and teacher, were acknowledged last night by the spoken eulogies of his colleagues, the warm handclasps of present and former students and formal resolutions presented by representatives of religious institutions here and abroad.

The Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York, in its second annual report to Mayor La Guardia, issued yesterday a warning as to a possible danger from the prolonged use of sulfa drugs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Black Hawks ran their home winning streak to five straight games and took second place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating Boston, 5 to 4, before 16,649 fans. It was the third straight time the Hawks had beaten the Bruins here this season.

Members of Senate and House committees studying problems of small business yesterday were urged by the American Contractors War Advisory Committee to abolish the Smaller War Plants Corporation "to curtail waste of public funds."
Credit men were urged yesterday to consider eight points when, for tax purposes, business companies decided to change their status to the so-called "family partnership" form.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 -- The major problem of the War Production Board last week was to find as quickly as possible new channels for the distribution of excess supplies of raw steel. Contract cut-backs, outstanding production records in the nation's open-hearth furnaces and the excellent job done by industry generally resulted in a definite excess of steel ingots.

A tie was the best the Rangers could muster in their National Hockey League game with the Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last night. In times past a stalemate would have been derided by the Blue Shirts, but last night's draw, 2 to 2, was mighty pleasant to them.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Gen. Josip Broz's (Tito) Partisan guerrilla forces have hurled back Nazi troops in fierce clashes along the Yugoslav coast southeast of Flume a broadcast-Army of Liberation communique said today.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -The reacLion of London stock markets to the proposed Brazilian debt settlement has on the whole been decidedly favorable. Prices of bonds have been advanced sharply all around amid rather wild dealings.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 29 -- Gen. Konstantin K. Rokossovky's Soviet forces, driving an estimated 250,000 German troops through the narrowing White Russian escape corridor toward Zhlobin, pushed closer to that junction yesterday in an advance along the Gomel-Minsk railroad. [The Red Army's capture of Sharybovka, a village and railroad station on the Gomel-Zhlobin line, placed it eighteen miles southeast of Zhlobin.]

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, ranking majority member of the Military Affairs Committee, said tonight that it would try to learn this week whether there have been other Army incidents like the slapping episode involving Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr.

Erica Morini upheld her reputation as the world's greatest woman violinist with the performance of the Glazunoff concerto in A minor she gave yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- About $2,500,000,000 is being spent to expand the joint British-American air offensive from Britain, which reached a new peak of destructive intensity only last week, the Air Ministry news service announced today.

An agreement with Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Education on a new wage scale for custodial workers in the city's elementary and high schools has been reached, it was announced yesterday by the international vice presidents of the two American Federation of Labor unions involved.

Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels told a Berlin audience yesterday that Allied air attacks on Germany constituted the most acute problem of the moment for the Reich, and once again, asserting that German morale would never crack under such blows, threatened "reprisals" for the attacks "on our peaceful towns."

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 29 -- Massive Royal Air Force formations streamed across the Channel toward Germany from dusk to after midnight last night, apparently assigned to open the second week of a methodical aerial blasting of Hitler's Reich, it was disclosed today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Navy's triumphant football team returned to the Academy today to join celebrating midshipmen in ringing the old Japanese bell in traditional ceremonies after a fifth consecutive victory over Army.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The youngster who bought a city jail at a western tax delinquent sale recently would have a field day at a similar sale slated for Dec. 28 by Newark's City Tax Department.

BRISTOL, Conn., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, with most of the regulars in action for only one period, routed New London's Diesels under a powerful running and aerial attack, 62 to 14, today before a crowd of 10,000 in an exhibition football game.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A program designed "to eliminate as much of the personal hardship as possible" for soldiers demobilized after the war will be presented to the National Association of Manufacturers at its convention in New York next month, Arthur G. Drefs a member of the association's post- war committee, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Advertisers and publishers alike are urged, in an article in the December issue of Domestic Commerce, monthly publication of the Department of Commerce, to cut the size of advertisements and accept a lesser volume to meet the threat of the current serious paper shortage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- It is now possible to live in Washington with a better than fair chance of remaining sane.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Red Wings staged a third-period drive to defeat Toronto, 6 to 4, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 13,806 spectators, Mud Bruneteau of Detroit and Babe Pratt of the Maple Leafs each bagged two goals, but Bill Jennings' marker provided the winning margin.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- The battle for Changteh, key highway center guarding the approaches to Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, approached a climax today as the Japanese, disregarding heavy losses, thrust deeper into China's "Rice Bowl" city.

NAPLES, Nov. 28 -- Fist fights and shouts for the establishment of an Italian republic punctuated a meeting in the courtyard of the University of Naples today at which three prominent Italian liberals called for the abdication of King Victor Emmanuel and the establishment of a regency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Senate Finance Committee, headed by Senator George, will begin its consideration of the House-approved tax bill tomorrow morning by hearing Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. appeal for a restoration of the tax increases which the House reduced from $10,500,000,000 to $2,140,000,000.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose 0.04 per cent. The raw materials index rose 0.5 per cent, as a result of price increases in apples, grains, cattle and potatoes.
The Dodgers unwillingly put the good neighbor policy to good effect yesterday when they lost to the Giants in the second battle of the boroughs, this one at the Polo Grounds before a crowd of 28,706.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers (CIO), today accused the House Naval Affairs subcommittee, which conducted hearings in the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation case, of a systematic attempt to "smear" organized labor.

In looking forward to post-war contraction and conversion of industry, business management envisages four primary problems, one of the most important of which is the extent to which Government will remain the partner of business in the peacetime economy, Edwin G. Booz, president of the Association of Consulting Management Engineers, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Output of lard continues heavy owing to the heavy receipts of hogs at leading markets, and stocks have started to accumulate despite purchases for lend-lease purposes. The domestic demand, however, continues somewhat subnormal, as buyers are said to be awaiting further developments in regard to the proposed roll-back in prices.

WITH UNITED STATES MARINE ASSAULT TROOPS AT TARAWA ATOLL, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- This Japanese base is now under American control -- despite continuing machine-gun and sniper fire -- after three days and nights of the bloodiest, grimmest fighting in Marine Corps history.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28 -- The people of the occupied European countries must make sure that Germany is not allowed to reconstruct her industrial plant after the RAF and American Air Forces finish battering it down, it was declared today by P.A. Kerstens, chief of the Netherlands delegation at the meeting here of the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress, during the period Nov. 20 to 26 are given in the appended tabulation.

KIEV, Russia, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- Kiev authorities asserted today that the Germans had machine-gunned from 50,000 to 80,000 of Kiev's Jewish men, women and children in late September, 1941 and, two years later -- when Kiev's recapture by the Red Army seemed imminent -- had forced Russian prisoners of war to burn all the bodies, completely destroying all the evidence of the crime.

Ariel Mengarini of Washington, former District of Columbia titleholder, finishing with a score of 11 -- 0 last night in the tourney at the Manhattan Club, succeeded Edward S. Jackson Jr. of this city as amateur champion of the United States Chess Federation.

LIFE is a succession of lost opportunities. Even the shrewdest make their share of critical mistakes, and regrets are the lot of every man. These ancient truths were brought home sharply to Edward R. Hewitt early in his youth when he made a transatlantic crossing in the company of Andrew Carnegie shortly after the organization of the United States Steel Corporation

The National Labor Committee for Palestine ended its two-day convention yesterday at the Hotel Commodore, with the adoption of resolutions asking for the immediate revocation of the British White Paper restricting Jewish immigration into Palestine, and the cessation of "attacks" against Jewish reconstruction in that country.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday his determination to provide "cost-ofliving" pay rises for the city's 160,000 employes, to become effective on or about Jan. 1. In his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall and at a press conference that followed, the Mayor revealed that all city departments, by his direction, were making thorough surveys to ascertain how such increases could be provided within the limitations of the 1943-44 budget.

NEW MILFORD, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Two volunteer firemen were killed here this afternoon when a New Milford hook and ladder truck on which they were riding to a brush fire was in collision with a Rockland Coach Company bus at Main Street and River Road.

In the third week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning next Monday night, Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" will be revived on Friday night, Dec. 10, after a seven-year absence. A feature of the revival will be the debut of Martial Singher, who has just arrived from South America and will sing the role of Dappertutto.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Army's draft call for January is to be twice the figure that the War Manpower Commission has been expecting, it was learned today, and as a result the combined Army-Navy call will approximate 300,000 men.
Political, rather than military developments, took the spotlight yesterday as peace rumors spread throughout Europe and London said an important announcement could soon be expected.

Tony's Restaurant has purchased the building it occupies at 59 East Fifty-second Street together with the adjoining three-story dwelling at 61 East Fifty-second Street from the Franklin Savings Bank, which has owned the parcels since 1934. The properties were bought for cash over a mortgage of $40,000 by Dorothy F. Soma, wife of the proprietor of the restaurant, through Donald Muldoon, broker. Title was insured with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Despite the fact that the Government's conservation measures prohibit the making of circular, lined skating skirts, devotees of the sport find ways of filling this wardrobe requirement. Some are knitting full, short skirts. Others are making their own out of woolen fabrics.

Samuel Edelman sold to a client of Max Olesker the five-and-a-half-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 380-84 East 183d Street, southwest corner of Webster Avenue, in the Bronx. The building contains forty-seven apartments and seven stores and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $126,000. The assessed valuation is $150,000, according to Albert H. Graham, the broker in the sale.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 -- Results made public today by the State Department of Labor of a survey made in October of the earnings of office and clerical workers in 2,612 factories in the State show that women workers earn less than men in comparable jobs.

Defeated in an attempt to discredit the officers of the Mazzini Society, a left-wing group led by August Bellanca, an official of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, walked out of the third annual congress of the society yesterday with the announcement that it would form a new organization to unite persons of Italian Origin in this country against fascism.

The recital Yehudi Menuhin gave last night in Carnegie Hall was impressive testimony not only to his hold upon an immense public, but to the maturing of his gifts and his exceptional sincerity and idealism in his art.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Country offerings of cash corn have been disappointing to the grain trade, farmers holding back their surplus grain as the result of reports that the ceiling price would be raised 5 1/2 to 15 cents a bushel over the current ceiling of $1.07 for No. 2 yellow corn at Chicago.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- The Soviet Union regards the United States Senate's adoption of the Connally resolution for post-war cooperation as "undoubtedly an important milestone in the history of the international policy of the United States" that will aid "still greater collaboration between the United States and the Allies in bringing the war to a victorious end and insuring peace and security after the conclusion of the war."

The women's division in the New York War Fund's campaign for $17,000,000 has obtained additional contributions aggregating $188,850, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Oswald B. Lord, division chairman. Contributions made public yesterday included:

TWO of the cadets were leaving Mitchie Stadium together, one wearing the gray cap of the Second Regiment and the other wearing the white cap of the First Regiment. They had watched the Army-Navy game from opposite sides of the field, since the unhappy lads of the First Regiment had been forced to cheer for the midshipmen all afternoon long.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Seventy-nine oils, water colors, lithographs and pastels, done by United Nations' merchant seamen during their spare time at sea and in port, went on exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery of Art today under sponsorship of the United Seamen's Service and the War Shipping Administration.

Because of liquor shortages, inability to obtain additional help, and ceiling prices on meals, many restaurants that in the past served special New Year's Eve dinners will not do so this year, it was said by members of the Society of Rastaurateurs meeting last night at Cavanagh's, 258 West Twenty-third Street.

KIEV, Russia, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- After more than two years of German occupation and only fifteen days of Russian liberation, Kiev stands today as a city without lights and without running water. Its population of more than a million has dwindled to 75,000 cold and hungry people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A resolution requesting the British Government to abrogate its White Paper of May, 1939, under which further Jewish immigration to Palestine was to cease as of March 31, 1944, was presented yesterday to W.G. Hayter, first secretary of the British Embassy, by a delegation of five officers of the American Palestine Jewish Legion.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29 (AP) -- The excitement over Navy's 13-0 victory over Army subsided today in Crabtown, and talk turned to speculation about who will replace Capt. John E. Whelchel as head coach of the middies' football team.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Shareholders of the National Refining Company will meet on Dec. 7 to consider the sale of 100 service stations to the Shell Oil Company, Inc., and certain other properties, including a Coffeyville, Kan., refinery, to the Cooperative Refinery Association of Kansas.

One of the few important Greek bronze statues that have survived from antiquity has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This masterpiece is a life-size statue of a sleeping boy. His wings and the baldric of his quiver indicate that he was intended to represent Eros, the god of love.

BALBOA, C.Z., Nov. 29 -- An American Liberty ship was torpedoed and sunk with the loss of sixteen lives and an American tanker was sent down with the loss of twelve lives in the same general area after the sinking of the Colombian inter-island motor schooner Ruby, the Fifteenth United States Naval Headquarters announced today.

Setting an early shopping example, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made her yearly visit to the Christmas sale for the blind, 608 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. As guest of honor of the New York State Commission for the Blind she was received by Mrs. Hugh Grant Straus, chairman, and Miss Grace S. Harper, director of the commission.
Directors of the United Aircraft Corporation have authorized promotions of three of its principal officers, it was announced yesterday by Frederick B. Rentschler, chairman.

Lorenz Hart, song writer, who died on Nov. 22. named his brother Theodore and William H. Kron, a friend, as his principal beneficiaries in his will, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The will was dated June 17.
Sir Arthur and Lady Salter have arrived from Washington and are at the Ambassador.

Private David M. Davis, 27 years old, of 154 East 171st Street, has been in the hospital six times since he entered the Army Jan. 19, 1941, his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Davis, told reporters. He was injured twice in training, was treated twice for malaria in North Africa, and was wounded twice.

In the blaze of battle sweeping toward Japan from the Gilberts to New Guinea we are apt to overlook the most important front of all. It is still in China. It is there, according to Admiral Nimitz, that the decisive struggles of the war in the Far East will take place.
It is likely that by the beginning of the year, or shortly thereafter, the supply of tea available to civilians will be virtually normal for the first time since Pearl Harbor.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The stock markets here began the week quietly today with the tone tending toward unevenness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 24, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

The New York Clearing House Association announced yesterday that the United States Trust Company has been admitted to membership. Coincidentally, both institutions were founded in 1853. The admission brings to twenty-one the number of member banks of the Clearing House.

Harry Wolkof, veteran chief clerk of the Gates Avenue Municipal Court, Brooklyn, was removed yesterday from that office in a decision by five justices of the Brooklyn Appellate Division. Fourteen charges of misconduct in his official capacity had been filed against him by Kayes Winters, president-justice of New York City's Municipal Courts.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine confirmed yesterday that the police contingent assigned to air raid warden and Civilian Defense Volunteer Office duties is being considerably reduced. The actual number of men taken off was not given, but it was estimated that probably 225 of the 355 who have been on the war work were sent back to patrol and other regular duties.

The war against black markets is generally held to depend on having an extensive network of investigators to check on ceiling price violations. But the Manhattan War Price and Rationing Board, in quest of 4,000 "tactful, intelligent housewives" to serve nine hours a week as price checkers, has been able to round up only eleven, it was learned yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- William Harrison, 58-year-old real estate salesman, in two hours shot to death two men and two women and killed himself today.
ATLANTA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- There was gridiron talent to burn this season in Southeastern service camps, led by Navy, Marine and Coast Guard players.
ALGIERS, Nov. 29 -- A communique:

The World Theatre, where the French film, "It Happened In Gibraltar," is in its third and final week, will present on Monday the local premiere of the British-made picture "A Young Man's Fancy." The comedy-satire, which is set in London and Paris in the 1870's stars Anna Lee, was produced by Michael Balcon and directed by Robert Stevenson.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The drawing room from Lansdowne House in London's Berkeley Square will be dedicated tomorrow at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

As Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor, a frequent critic of Mayor La Guardia, was declaring that the police would have no difficulty in curbing crime in Brooklyn's "Little Harlem" were it not for "political interference from City Hall," Police Commisioner Lewis J. Valentine disclosed yesterday afternoon that Patrolman David Liebman had been an inmate of the Creedmoor State Hospital, seven years ago, suffering from a condition diagnosed as dementia praecox.

ELKHART, Ind., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Stockholders of the International Machine Tool Corporation approved today a proposal to merge Detrola Corporation of Detroit, a radio manufacturer producing electronic devices for the Army and Navy, into International, under the name "International Detrola Corporation," effective Dec. 31..
MINEOLA, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The Board of Supervisors unanimously adopted Nassau County's budget [for 1944 today. Totaling $19,494,1722, which is $1,750,428 below the'

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The War Department revealed tonight that 75 millimeter cannon had been installed in the Air Force's Billy Mitchell medium bombers, B-25s, that this "flying artillery" had "proved its worth" in the South Pacific and probably other theatres.

Two Picasso exhibitions enliver the current art roster in New York. One of them opened recently at Paul Rosenberg's, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street. The second starts today at the Pierre Matisse Gallery in the Fuller Building, corner of Madison and Fifty-seventh. Both will continue through December.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 29 -- The latest "luxury" raft which will carry torpedoed soldiers and seamen away from their stricken transports and merchant vessels in enemy-infested waters is designed to help meet the spiritual and recreational needs of the survivors as well as to make life easier for any seriously wounded men aboard.

As the mad scramble for bottled goods was continued yesterday by hopeful seekers of elusive scotches and ryes that have disappeared from package and department store shelves, the liquor industry held out little hope for additional supplies that would even partly meet the present abnormal demand unless some resumption of production is permitted by the Government.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Supreme Court Justice Pierce H. Russell ruled today that the Albany County grand jury cannot be restrained from investigating possible crimes committed by legislative officials in the expenditure of public funds, but that subpoenas duces tecum served on State Controller Frank C. Moore and the Tax Commissioner, Rollin Browne, were "too broad and oppressive."

Meeting in New York for the first time in twenty-four years, baseball's doughty minor leaguers did not take long to capture the center of the stage yesterday when the little fellows as well as the major leaguers converged on the Hotel New Yorker for their annual winter conclaves.

Development of revolutionary high-speed methods for cutting metals for airplanes, tanks, engines, gun mounts and other war equipment has made it possible to machine hard steel as much as ten times faster than two years ago and to cut airplane aluminums fifteen to twenty times faster, it was declared last night at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Amendments to the proposed plan of recapitalization of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, which would change the distribution of a new common stock to give preferred stockholders a greater participation and eliminate the company's Northern units through a stock distribution, were placed before the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

"Carmen" is an indestructible opera. Even if it is put together on the stage somewhat unevenly, as it was last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, it has the vitality to surmount most hazards. It is ripe with melodrama, it overflows with good tunes and its people are, for the most part, fully characterized human beings. It scercely ever fails of effect, and last night it won its way with a capacity audience.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 29 -- In a debate in which the Syrian President and Premier and a number of Deputies took part, Foreign Minister Jamil Mardam Bey stated that the Syrian people had never accepted the French mandate and certainly would not enter into discussions with the French authorities now on such a basis, according to information made available here from Damascus today.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Official quarters m London not only denied the authenticity of reports about German peace feelers today but deprecated the circulation of these reports, which, they said, are put out by the Germans for propaganda purposes.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to grant cost-of-living wage increases to city employes out of accruals in the 1943-44 budget was attacked yesterday by Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, who charged that the pay rises "will be reflected in the ensuing budget as regular pay and as an essential expense demanding more taxes."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Declaring its patience was exhausted because production had been "far behind schedule and of an unacceptable quality," the Navy, under an executive order from President Roosevelt, took possession of the plant of Remington Rand, Inc., at Southport, N.Y., which has a sub-contract to manufacture parts for the Norden bombsight.

ALGIERS, Nov. 29 -- Following an informal gathering of members this afternoon the first regular meeting of the Allied Advisory Council for Italy will be held tomorrow. Harold Macmillan of Britain, Rene Massigli of France, Robert D. Murphy of the United States and Andrey Y. Vishinsky of Russia form the council.

The New Jersey Women's Golf Association meeting and luncheon at the Montclair Golf Club tomorrow will be its most important in several years. The organization may decide whether to retain its full membership, which has long listed 200 dues-paying women golfers, with a long waiting group besides.

NAPLES, Nov. 28 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Italian Communist party will support Count Carlo Sforza as head of a new Italian Government, Dr. Eugenio Reale, party leader announced today. He said Count Sforza was the "only outstanding leader today capable of forming a government."

BOUGAINVILLE Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- Five American Marines land a combat patrol of seventy-five Japanese met at a river yesterday afternoon and for two and a half hours there was the dardnest shooting you ever saw.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The special House (Smith) committee investigating Federal agencies accused the Office of Price Administration and the Food Distribution Administration today of using the subsidy program, the Lend-Lease Act and the needs of the armed forces "as a subterfuge to impose legislation upon the country which Congress had failed or refused to enact."

ALGIERS, Nov. 29 -- The British Eighth Army lunged forward in darkness early yesterday morning against flame-throwing German tanks and is grinding ahead successfully into the main German winter defense lines across the Sangro River.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- What women of all nations could expect "were it possible for the totalitarian powers to achieve victory" is told in a pamphlet, "Axis Treatment of Women," prepared by the Inter-Allied Information Committee in London and released in this country today by the Office of War Information.
Several large leases of commercial space in the midtown section of Manhattan were reported yesterday. Jewelers, theatrical executives and advertising concerns were among the lessees.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration adopted today the "final act" of its first session, embodying two last-minute changes proposed by the Russian delegation on priorities -- first on UNRRA food and other relief supplies, and second, for the repatriation of Allied nationals displaced from their homes by the war and scattered throughout their own or other enemy-occupied countries.

Sponsored by the Distilled Spirits Institute and the Conference of Alcoholic Beverage Industries, a campaign against black market operators is being launched today in a list of 210 daily newspapers in thirty-seven States and the District of Columbia.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Joe Burns of Trenton, who never played football before this season, was awarded the George T. Cronin Trophy tonight at the annual Rutgers Gown and Town football dinner for being the most improved player on the squad.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 -- Ann Savage and Tom Neal, who had the lead in the recently completed "Klondike Kate" at Columbia, have been teamed again by this company for the forthcoming action yarn "Two-Man Submarine."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Instructions issued by the Civil Service Commission forbidding "loyalty investigators" from questioning applicants for Government jobs about their political philosophy or belief in capitalism stirred Representative Fred E. Busbey, Republican, of Illinois, to demand today an immediate investigation.

Active liquidation by New Oreans operators combined yesterday with commission house selling and hedging operations to send the cotton futures market to new lows for the current movement. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active old contracts were all below the 19-cent level and had registered losses of 24 to 27 points, or $1.20 to $1.35 below Saturday's final quotations.

With the election of officers for next year, the New York Football Writers Association held its final luncheon meeting of the season at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday. It was a business meeting, with none of the usual guests from college or professional teams present.
The chaplain on a naval transport bound for the Aleutians last January unwittingly played Cupid in the successful courtship of film star Greer Garson, it was disclosed here yesterday.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 30 -- Russian troops lunging in a pincers upon Zhlobin -- rail hub and fortress guarding the Nazis' Gomel escape gap -- speared to within eleven miles of the city from the south yesterday and seized forty villages in a battering offensive, the Russians announced early today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
A decline of more than 50 per cent in the number of home-relief cases in the past year was disclosed yesterday by the City Department of Welfare.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A German authority discussed today the possibility that British and American bombers might completely destroy Berlin, a third of which already is reported in ruins as the result of heavy Royal Air Force attacks last week.
DES MOINES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Football's "man of the year," selected annually by the Football Writers Association of America, will be found among the following five:
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger entertained the members of the New York Newspaper Women's Club last night at the Times Building in West Forty-third Street.

Plans for a large one-story industrial building to occupy a plot 100 by 600 feet at the northwest corner of Morgan Avenue and Ten Eyck Street, in Brooklyn, have just been filed by Murray Klein, architect for the structure.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 29 -- Heavy bombers of the Seventh Army Air Force continued to hammer away at Japanese airdromes in the central Pacific as construction parties worked feverishly to clean up the blasted Gilbert Islands.

At least fifty persons of about 500 war workers were injured when a heavy explosion shattered the ground floor of the Western Electric Company building at 395 Hudson Street a little before 1 o'clock this morning.

ALGIERS, Nov. 29 -- A straight-forward warning to American families of the psychological shock of receiving into their homes crippled and wounded sons, brothers and husbands was given today by Col. Joseph I. Martin of Rockford, Ill., surgeon of the Fifth Army in Italy.

The Swiss pianist, Oscar Ziegler, an American citizen since 1921, gave a long and exacting program at Town Hall last night before a large audience that was warm in its response to his unusual playing. For Mr. Ziegler has real musicianship and real pianism of a high order.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Christmas trade has opened up in a big way and indications are that November retail trade for the country as a whole will run from 20 to 25 per cent over the like month a year ago, William S. Street, vice president and general manager of Marshall Field Co., said yesterday.

BUFFALO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Federal Judge John Knight made permanent today an injunction barring four Dunkirk-Fredonia milk distributors from buying or selling milk in excess of Office of Price Administration ceilings, as dairy farmers in the Jamestown area gave the OPA until Dec. 15 to grant their demand for a higher price.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and Randolph Paul, general counsel of the Treasury, today presented the $10,500,000,000 tax program, which was rejected by the House, to the Senate Finance Committee and were subjected to sharp questions about the Administration's continued opposition to a sales tax.

It always is good to find Katharine Cornell on Forty-fifth Street, where, naturally, she belongs. It is even good to find her there in such a play as Dodie Smiths "Lovers and Friends," which she and John C. Wilson produced last evening at the Plymouth.

The expectancy of momentous developments in the international picture and more forceful rumors of an actual meeting of Allied leaders weighed heavily yesterday on the stock market. A midday respite given to selling, when Secretary of State Hull branded peace rumors as enemy propaganda, was followed by liquidation which gathered fresh force in the final hour and pushed prices perilously close to the lows of the month and since last March.

NAPLES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A storm of protest has burst in the Fifth Army over a recent editorial in the service newspaper, Stars and Stripes, on the question of rotation of American combat troops and home leave for men who have been in action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 384 United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Mediterranean and southwest Pacific areas. Included in this list are forty-one men from New York State, nine from New Jersey and four from Connecticut.

Through the purchase of stock from the Union Pacific Railroad, the Greyhound Corporation has acquired substantial minority interests in the Interstate Transit Lines and Union Pacific Stages, according to an announcement made yesterday by C.E. Wickman, president of Greyhound.

ALGIERS, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- An American Army transport plane carrying thirteen Army nurses and sixteen Army men has been missing since Nov. 8 when it vanished in a fog on a flight from Algiers to Bari, Italy, Brig. Gen. F.A. Blesse, United States surgeon- general for this theatre, announced tonight.

WITH THE UNITED STATES MARINES, at Tarawa, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- There still is occasional gunfire as American patrols mop up Japanese remnants huddling in the flame-seared wreckage of their cocolog blockhouses. One never can tell when one will run into a straggling sniper.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

As representatives of coal distributors and consumers reported "a little improvement" in the coal supply situation here yesterday, the complaint bureau of the Department of Health disclosed that it had received 578 complaints of no heat over the week-end.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The blistering heavy bomber offensive against Germany was resumed today after a two-day lull when a strong force of American Flying Fortresses returned to Bremen, which the "Forts" and Liberators of the Eighth Air Force attacked in record numbers last Friday.

The mobilization of the home front for war is now close to completion, and the principal obstacles to further expansion are the scarcity of raw materials and the growing shortage of manpower, according to the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, released yesterday.
For the first time that plaintive annual plea of the Post Office Department is falling on receptive ears -- Americans are actually "doing their Christmas shopping early."

FOOCHOW, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- Not long ago a 300-ton steamer formerly of Portuguese registry, came directly from Shanghai to pirate headquarters at Nankantang near the mouth of the Min River. She was bringing passengers and some cargo.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 29 -- Maj. Gen. Holland McT. Smith, United States Marine Corps, general of an amphibious corps of the Central Pacific force that took the Gilberts, said here today that we took Tarawa atoll only because of the supreme readiness of the American assault forces to die.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee postponed action today on a bill to exempt insurance companies from regulation under the Federal antitrust laws, pending an inquiry into underwriter organizations and their "rate-making machinery."

The friendly comment by the Soviet newspaper Pravda on our Senate's adoption of the Connally resolution for post-war cooperation is another sign of the steady improvement in the relations between Russia and this country and as such should be welcomed warmly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Mark A. McCloskey, West Side New Yorker, who is now National Director of Community War Services, today urged looking straight in the face at wartime juvenile delinquency and doing something about it besides raising a hue and cry.

American exporters who have developed markets for animal oils in Egypt and the Near East, despite the usual wartime difficulties, reported yesterday that those markets now are being reserved to British suppliers under the so-called "joint-area agreements." The information, it was explained, was disclosed in a private communication from the War Food Administration to individual traders seeking to clear outstanding orders.

The truck tire shortage ha6 become so critical that a central truck tire rationing board for New York City has been established in the Office of Price Administration's district headquarters in the Empire State Building, Frank C. Russell, district director, announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 29 -- The headquarters of Gen. Josip Broz's [Tito's] Yugoslav People's Army of Liberation has abstained in its recent communiques from mentioning the course of the fighting on the Dalmatian coast, where the Germans have been conducting an offensive to cut off communications between the Partisans and the Allied bases in Italy via the Adriatic Sea.

Your Nov. 21 editorial, "Hog-Butcherin' Time," would do credit to the best page in the Corn Belt. It proves again that New York City is not so provincially or internationally minded that editors do not know their hogs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A special meeting of stockholders of United Air Lines Transport Corporation to consider proposals for raising approximately $10,000,000 for post-war expansion will be held Dec. 22 in Chicago, the company announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Ingenuity in the use of materials is expected to mark a great American post-war building program, according to A.C. Bossom, member of Parliament and chairman of the British Building Commission, which has returned from the United States.

OLD LYME, Conn., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Joseph E. Bulkley, about 64, retired New York lawyer, shot and killed his wife, State Police Captain Leo F. Carroll said, then turned the gun and fatally wounded himself today at their estate here.

Tomorrow is the last day for filing with the Treasury a statement of ownership of foreign property. If the property is worth less than $10,000, a statement is not required, but if the "property" consists of a foreign bond, a return must be filed, regardless of the value of the bond.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A Dies subcommittee headed by Representative John M. Costello, Democrat, of California, heard testimony today about disorders at the Tule Lake relocation center for disloyal Japanese from Dr. John Thomas Mason of Cookeville, Tenn., who resigned two weeks after arrival at the project on Oct. 21.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 29 -- Germany's "secret weapons" are not much beyond bluff, in the opinion of a Swedish scientist who has just returned from the Reich.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 13 per cent last week over the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 19 per cent in sales.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Wally Kilrea of Hershey remained the top American Hockey League scorer today with 22 points.

The Music Box booking for "Feathers in a Gale" is now official. Under the auspices of Arthur Hopkins and Martin Burton, the Pauline Jamerson-Reginald Lawrence play about life on Cape Cod in 1807 will be presented there on Tuesday night, Dec. 21. Among those in a cast of thirteen, directed by Mr. Hopkins, are Peggy Conklin, Paula Trueman, Norman MacKay and Harry Ellerbe.

DENVER, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Wendell Willkie said today that the Republican party must change from a philosophy of "negation" to one which was "affirmative and alive" if it intended to win the coming Presidential election.

Sixty-eight players from New York, Southern, Eastern and Midwestern States played last night in the practice game that opened the seventeenth annual winter tournament of the American Contract Bridge League. This game was held at the Park Central Hotel, but the rest of the program, which includes six national bridge championships, will be held at the Hotel Astor.

To speed the return of idle machine tools into war production and to dispose of as much of the Government-owned property as possible, the War Production Board is expected to set up a system coordinating the redistribution of such property owned or controlled by the Defense Supplies Corporation, the Ordance Department, the Air Corps and the Navy Department, spokesmen in the industry reported yesterday.

STUART CHASE has been listening to his critics. In the mid-Thirties, when he spoke of "planning," he usually conjured up a vision of a technocratic general staff setting production schedules for the whole of American and even Canadian industry. The economic system was to run on the engineering principle of the balanced load," not on free customer choice.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 -- Anyone caught carrying on propaganda against the Argentine Government will be "inexorably" sent to concentration camps in cold and desolate Patagonia, according to a warning issued by the police yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Supported by waves of B-25's and their own tanks, Australian infantrymen are closing in on Bonga, a stubbornly defended Japanese jungle position northeast of Sattelberg, New Guinea.

One of the most important wartime jobs on the home front involves the maintenance of the well-being of our children. Everything we do today to help them to be healthier, wiser, happier children will be part of our insurance that their generation will be able to tackle the complex problems they will have to solve.
CHARLES TOWN, W. Vs., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Jockey Wilbur Rudert rode a triple today at the opening of the fall meeting at the Charles Town race track.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler has given the Germans his second warning this month that the alternative to victory is destruction, it was disclosed today.

Two policemen pursuing a pair of hold-up suspects were critically injured last night when their radio car crashed at high speed into a parked garbage truck at Eleventh Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street. They are Patrolmen Harry Heller and Dennis J. Clark of the West Sixty-eighth Street station.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Out in Kansas, the State of wonders, a Republican with all the determination of the indigenous breed is fighting hard for political revolution. Thus far he has few followers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Attorney General Biddle has written to Governor Dewey of New York asserting that "statements and implications" by the Governor that the Federal Government was blocking Mr. Dewey's efforts to have Louis (Lepke) Buchalter executed were "totally unwarranted."

Reporting on operations of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation and its subsidiaries for the first nine months of fills year, N. Peter Rathvon, president, informed stockholders yesterday that earnings reached new high levels in each quarter.

The six-story loft building at 46-50 Wooster Street, between Grand and Broome Streets, has been purchased by David S. Meister for cash above a ten-year mortgage of $60,000 at 4 per cent. The site measures 71.7 by 100 feet, and the building is reported to have an annual rental of about $13,000. Rubinton Coleman acted as attorneys for the seller.

THE most popular definition of an amateur is that he is an athlete who never accepts a check. Presumably all smart amateurs duck out in the dark of the moon and meet the promoters in some convenient doorway where the pay-off is strictly in cash. And unless some sinister character introduces marked money there never is any danger of discovery.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposed $42,000,000 bond issue by the Utah Power and Light Company, but directed the concern to reduce its capital structure to a single class of common stock and eliminate from the property accounts of the company and two subsidiaries alleged write-ups and other inflationary items, estimated to exceed $32,000,000.

Bad news reached the football Giants yesterday when it was learned that O'Neale Adams, their loose-jointed, nimble-footed left end, had suffered a fractured lower jaw in Sunday's interborough battle with the Dodgers.

New York City's share of the 300,000 men wanted by the War Department for the country's January draft quota may run as high as 20,000 registrants, or considerably more than the 280 local boards in the five boroughs had planned to call up, it was admitted yesterday at Selective Service headquarters here.

THE most popular definition of an amateur is that he is an athlete who never accepts a check. Presumably all smart amateurs duck out in the dark of the moon and meet the promoters in some convenient doorway where the pay-off is strictly in cash. And unless some sinister character introduces marked money there never is any danger of discovery.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposed $42,000,000 bond issue by the Utah Power and Light Company, but directed the concern to reduce its capital structure to a single class of common stock and eliminate from the property accounts of the company and two subsidiaries alleged write-ups and other inflationary items, estimated to exceed $32,000,000.

Bad news reached the football Giants yesterday when it was learned that O'Neale Adams, their loose-jointed, nimble-footed left end, had suffered a fractured lower jaw in Sunday's interborough battle with the Dodgers.
BERNE, Swtzerland, Nov. 29 -- TWO weeks after the Germans prevented Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain from addressing the nation the situation thus created remains unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Reorganization of the War Production Board's industry divisions with the dual aim of increasing their efficiency in meeting current wartime production problems and of preparing for the difficulties of re-conversion to peace time operations, is under way in WPB, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A variety of staff appointments and promotions in the food price division of the Office of Price Administration was announced here today by Jean F. Carroll, division director. In addition, Chester Bowles, OPA Administrator, announced the appointment of H.H. Williamson of Bryan, Texas, to the position of agricultural relations adviser to OPA.

Fines aggregating $900 were imposed on fifty food dealers and one defendant was sentenced to three days in jail yesterday for violating Office of Price Administration price ceilings. The cases were heard by Magistrate Alfred M. Lindau in Municipal Term Court.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Russians and Czechs, in a mutual assistance pact to be signed the next few days, will open the door for Poland to join in a barricade against Germany's "Drang Nach Osten" (drive to the east) for the next twenty years, it was learned tonight.

Bob Steuber of DePauw won high scoring honors with 129 points in the 1943 college football season although he played in only five games. Bob Brumley of Oklahoma scored 14 points against Nebraska last week and advanced to fourth spot with 79, according to The Associated Press.

Roi Ottley's recent book, "New World A-Comin'," brought out by Houghton Mifflin, is the inspiration for a tone poem called by the same name as the book, written by Duke Ellington. The world premiere of the work will be given at Carnegie Hall, Dec. 1, after which Mr. Ellington will play it on a country-wide tour.

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today that two Japanese divisions, about 30,000 men had been routed southwest and northwest of strategic Changteh in a three-day battle. It said that Chinese forces were pursuing the enemy, who were fleeing eastward.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States Navy has developed and now is using with deadly effect some astounding new secret weapons which are equal if not superior to anything the enemy can offer, Rear Admiral W.H.P. Blandy, outgoing Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, said at a farewell press conference today.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Four of seven naturalized American citizens charged with conspiracy to transmit military information to Germany went on trial today before Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a jury of eight men and four women.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The War Labor Board strengthened its non-coercion injunction in maintenance of membership provisions of collective bargaining contracts by prescribing a flat order stating that "the union," its officers and members, "shall not intimidate or coerce employes into joining the union or continuing their membership therein."

Legislation making automobile inspection compulsory in all States was urged yesterday by several speakers at the fall conference of Region No. 1, American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators, at the Hotel New Yorker.

A certain candidate's friends at a national convention were putting up a hopeless fight for their man when an opposing delegate lost patience. He shouted, "If a man doesn't know he is dead his friends ought to know!"
May I answer Mr. Parker's article from Moscow, "Russia Distrusts Finland," published in the Nov. 18 issue of THE TIMES.

A coupon plan to attract the widest possible audience to the City Center of Music and Drama, which will open Dec. 11 with a concert by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society Orchestra, was outlined yesterday to representatives of leading civic, welfare, labor, cultural and philanthropic groups by Harry Friedgut, managing director, at a meeting at the Hotel Astor.

Secretary Hull has put his foot down hard on all the current peace rumors by suggesting that they are, most of the time, inspired by the Axis to create overconfidence among the Allies and thereby impair their whole war effort. It is a timely warning which takes account of both the military and the psychological situations in a global war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- In twenty-five days of November, $648,950,914 worth of Series E, F and G war bonds were sold, but $146,740,284 worth was redeemed.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

NAPLES, Nov. 28 (Delayed) -- A petition to the Allies, for which it is hoped to get at least 100,000 signatures in Naples alone, is being sponsored by the Italian Communist party. It asks Allied authorities to permit anti-Fascist forces "to begin the economic, political and moral reconstruction of the country."

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The hog market was active today and the comparatively large shipment of salable stock was fairly well cleared at generally steady prices. Fed steers and yearlings topped at $16.75 in a strong to 25 cent higher cattle market. City butchers paid the top price of $14.85 for best native lambs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The possibility of a strike of 48,000 West Coast seamen was made known today by Capt. Edward MacAuley, deputy war shipping administrator, who disclosed an impasse of the War Shipping Administration with Harry Lundeberg, union leader, over the WSA program for periodical physical examinations of seamen.

The American Council on Education finds that too many of our textbooks persist in treating our Latin-American neighbors with condescension. For the most part there is a widespread perpetuation, especially in history textbooks, of the "Black Legend" myth of Spanish and Portuguese colonial ineptitude, cruelty, faithlessness, greed and bigotry.

The memory of Max Reinhardt, who died here recently, was honored last night in a concert at Carnegie Hall by eighty members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, led by Bruno Walter, and assisted by Kerstin Thorborg, contralto, as soloist, before an audience that filled the hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, acting after repeated charges that Federal agencies were among the most flagrant wasters of paper, today invoked a drastic economy campaign "to hold Government uses of paper to a minimum."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in Mandarin to China and recorded and translated by the Federal Communication Commision:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The rejoicing family of Army Pilot Tom Harmon attended a mass of thanksgiving today in celebration of the former All-America football player's second deliverance this year from the dread list of men "missing in action."
