The Acorn Insulated Wire Company, Inc., of 225 King Street, Brooklyn, and two of its employes, Alec Colmer of 247 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, a foreman, and his son, James Colmer, of 7002 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, plant superintendent, were indicted yesterday by the Brooklyn Federal grand jury on charges of sabotage and conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government in the manufacture of field wire for the Army Signal Corps.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 -- Tropea, carrying the colors of William Helis of New Orleans to the first success the local turfman has met with at the Fair Grounds since he has been in racing, took the $2,000 added Baton Rouge Handicap by a length in clever fashion today when he led a well-balanced field in the five and a half furlong dash.

Directors of Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of one share of stock on each five shares outstanding, payable on Dec. 28. This action will increase the company's outstanding capital from $12,230,325 to $14,700,000 by "capitalizing $2,469,675 of prior years' earnings," the company said.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The Allies "shall not fall into the trap" of a compromised peace, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, declared here tonight, as peace rumors continued to come from the world's neutral capitals.

Festive holiday clothes, designed by Sophie, were presented by Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton. The showing carried on many of the ideas introduced in previous collections, such as flowing bouffante evening gowns and slim tailored dinner suits.

The consensus of 131 sports writers throughout the country favors -- Washington, Georgia Tech, Texas, Texas A. and M., Southwestern of Texas and Southwestern Louisiana Institute to win in the Jan. 1 bowl games, judging by their votes in the final Associated Press poll of the football season.

The New York Committee of the National War Fund has raised $13,059,179 and is within 23 per cent of its $17,000,000 goal, it was announced by Chairman Emil Schram at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 30 (Reuter) -- Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt will meet Premier Stalin this week, according to the Berne correspondent of Stockholm's Svenska Dagbladet. Leading British and American military and diplomatic chiefs will follow the three leaders, his dispatch added.

Three apartment houses in the West Bronx have just been acquired by Thomas Moffa, operator, from the firm which erected them in 1929 and 1930. The three structures, all on Summit Avenue, have an aggregate assessed valuation of $325,000, and all are reported fully rented.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- British women who need corsets worst, big women and unshapely women, have not been able to get them in this country, but the Government, it was announced today, has finally agreed to do something about it.

The story of the voyage of a small, slow ship of World War I vintage through wintry northern seas was told yesterday in the offices of the Alcoa Steamship Company at 17 Battery Place. The tale had hitherto been untold because of censorship restrictions.

Steadying influences were at work yesterday in the stock market, but the improved note proved to be spotty and tendencies generally continued on the lighter side. Smart recoveries appeared in a few individual issues, but these were overbalanced by the dipping of the general list to further new lows for the current reaction.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30 -- A parade of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and other Government witnesses in Federal Court here before Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a jury sketched today the broad outlines of an alleged conspiracy to commit espionage in behalf of Germany, for which four men are on trial.

Thirty-five individuals and corporations, who were indicted by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn last week on a charge of conspiracy to violate the ceilings of the Office of Price Administration on beef, pleaded innocent yesterday through attorneys before Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn Federal court.

The sale of oranges at excessive prices was admitted yesterday by Peter Martori's Sons, Inc., produce dealer of 338 Washington Street, and Stephen Martori, its vice president. The two defendants pleaded guilty to a criminal information filed by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally in Federal court and Judge Murray Hulbert deferred sentencing to Dec. 14.

Southbound traffic on the Eighth Avenue line of the IND subway was halted for nineteen minutes beginning at 7:40 o'clock last night when a group of skylarking boys pushed a metal rubbish container in front of a train just entering the 163d Street station.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 937, which compared with 1,013 in the preceding week and 573 in the like' period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YOEK TIMES.

In a report on the final results of the auction sale of seven S.S. Kresge Company properties which he conducted in Brooklyn on Monday night, Joseph P. Day last night announced that the aggregate amount of the final bids on the properties was $282,500, and said the lively bidding and the interest shown was "reminiscent of the old boom days."

Contrary to "popular belief," the Army is not sending beef overseas but other types of meat such as pork, Col. Paul Logan, director of the subsistence branch of the quartermaster general's office, declared here yesterday.

The commercial printing industry will give its unqualified support to the War Production Board's program for fitting shrinking inventories and shrinking production to expanding war demands for paper and paper board, James F. Newcomb and Edwin Lennox, cochairmen of the industry's joint committee to assist government, pledged yesterday.

KIEV, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- When the lights went up again tonight in Kiev's opera house after darkness of a little more than two weeks, the first-nighters saw a happy cast freed from German domination present a variety show which, while not ready for Broadway, vastly delighted the Red Army men and women who packed the red plush-trimmed theatre.

Two men died in hospitals yesterday as the result of injuries they received when a leaking hydrogen tank exploded at 12:50 A.M. in the plant of the Western Electric Company at 395 Hudson Street. The condition of two others among the thirty persons injured by the terrific blast which shook the lower West Side for many blocks, still was critical last night.

BETIO, Tarawa, Gilbert Islands, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- Today two flags fly over this atoll, which, before the Japanese occupation shortly after Pearl Harbor, was the administrative center of the British Gilbert and Ellice Islands Crown Colony.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, commenting on the Orange County extraordinary grand jury's charge that Governor Dewey had refused to cooperate in an investigation of labor union rackets, said:
Several quick turnovers of loft properties in various parts of Manhattan feature reports of realty transactions in this borough yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 P) -Captaln Yeandle received his commission from the Coast Guard Acad-! emy in 1911 and spent three years with patrols in the North Pacific i and Bering Sea. A set of instructions he compiled during a tour of duty of the Aleutians is still used by the Coast Guard in those wa-i tots.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The troubles of those trying to supply the troops with beer and cigarettes were aired in the House of Commons today in a series of questions aimed at the Government.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 1 -- The Russian Army has fallen back from the strategic rail junction of Korosten, its second important retreat before the furious German counter-attack at the Kiev bulge, but has pressed forward in White Russia and at the Dnieper bend, where almost 4,000 Germans fell in heavy fighting yesterday, Moscow announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Office of Price Administration will cut the ration points on meat during December "rather substantially," Chester Bowles, OPA chief, said tonight in an address over the Blue Network.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The British Government has started grappling with the problem of shifting its all-out war effort against Germany to the new state of affairs that will be presented when Japan alone is the enemy, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, said in Parliament today.

At 69, the age which he reached yesterday, Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill is five years older than Premier Stalin, eight years older than President Roosevelt and fourteen years older than Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. We don't suppose the difference in ages counts for much when any two, three or four of these eminent gentlemen get together.

A new fluid catalytic cracking unit for the production of war gasoline will be dedicated today at Baltimore. The new plant, the sixth of its kind to be completed by the Standard Oil Company (N.J.), completes a $14,000,000 modernization program at one of the country's oldest refineries, which has been in operation for sixty-six years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Commissioner John H. Fahey of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration said today that an "unsound boom" in real estate prices and "inflationary practices" in mortgage lending are developing rapidly in the nation's crowded war industry cities.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 30 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill have completed a long conference in Cairo and are now en route to somewhere in Iran to meet Premier Stalin, it is known here definitely.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Dudley W. "Mush" Morton, famed United States submarine skipper, is missing in action, his wife said tonight, reporting that she had been so advised by the Navy Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Leaders of two farm organizations branded the Administration's food subsidy program as unfair and unworkable before the Senate Banking Committee today at the opening of hearings on the bill adopted by the House.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 30 -- Fascist Republican persecution of the Jews in Italy under the Nuremberg laws was resumed today on orders from the "government" to the regional authorities.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 30 -- "The German soldiers are coming to fetch me, so I must close. My handwriting may seem trembling but that is because I have only a stump of pencil. Death is calling. I do not want my eyes and hands bound.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Nov. 30 -- The Fifth Army has extended its lines north of Venafro to include the village of Castelnuovo, south of Castel San Vincenzo and across a lateral road leading to Atina. That town is directly north of Monte Cassino, so we are already threatening the left flank of the German positions in the massif around Cassino.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Unabridged and condensed versions of the Beveridge Report are now best sellers in six languages -- including Chinese. The British Treasury announced today that total sales of the report dealing with the security of the citizen from the cradle to the grave are now more than 600,000.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- It was announced here today that an undisclosed number of British miners are to be released from duty with the armed services to return to the pits. Maj. Gwilym Lloyd George, Minister of Fuel and Power, told Parliament that coal production still was dropping and that absenteeism was on the rise.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- This city, in the face of express disapproval by State Controller Frank C. Moore, sold today a refunding issue of $230,000 of debt equalization bonds at an interest rate of 1.80 per cent. The issue was among $474,000 of city bonds bought by the First National Bank of Boston.

NAPLES, Nov. 30 -- Premier Pietro Badoglio's Government announced today that it had shorn King Victor Emmanuel of his titles of King of Albania and Emperor of Ethiopia and that it was putting into effect measures designed to purge fascist elements from its administration.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique as broadcast from Moscow:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Dec. 1 -- Australian jungle-fighters, pushing north from Finschhafen, have captured Bonga, the seaward anchor of the Japanese principal supply line on the northeastern New Guinea coast, and its fall without a struggle has deprived the enemy of another hold on the Huon Peninsula.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Unanimous approval of a resolution supporting a wage increase of 8 cents an hour for 1,100,000 non-operating railroad workers was voted today by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee. Action was taken despite the protests of Fred M. Vinson, the Stabilization Director. Senators Alben W. Barkley, majority leader, and Lister Hill, Democratic whip, participated in the committee decision.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 105 West Fifty-fifth Street, on a plot 83 by 100.5 feet, has been purchased by J.L. Rosenthal, investor, from an operating group headed by Alexander Hirsch, in a deal negotiated by Emanuel Schwartz, M. L. Hiss, Inc., and the Loeb Rosenthal Company, brokers.

Fifteen hundred Americans and Canadians, back from Japanese internment camps in Japan, China and the Philippines, will arrive here this morning on the exchange liner Gripsholm, which is expected to dock at Pier F, Jersey City, about 10 o'clock.

A proposal to scrap Proportional Representation in Councilmanic elections was placed yesterday before the City Council, sitting in its next to the last session of the year with twelve lame duck members present.

WITH THE UNITED STATES MARINES ON TARAWA, Nov. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander of the Pacific area, visited today the battle-scarred Tarawa atoll of the Gilbert Islands, invaded a week ago.

The New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, conducting its thirty-seventh annual fund campaign through the sale of Christmas seals, sent out an SOS yesterday for more "Women in White" to man its booths and tables. Because of the many demands for womanpower this year workers are more difficult to obtain, association officials explained, in spite of the fact that each volunteer receives dinner or lunch money and carfare in return for her services.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Director General Herbert H. Lehman of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration told a press conference today that he hoped Congress and the legislative bodies of other nations whose approval is required would act as quickly as possible to appropriate funds with which UNRRA can operate.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court, in a decision on libel, took the position today that acts of public officials were of such concern to the public that misstatements about the acts were "qualifiedly privileged" if made in good faith and in the belief that the statements were true.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount, the new attraction is "No Time For Love," a comedy-drama produced by Paramount starring Claudette Colbert and Fred MacMurray. Featured in supporting roles are Paul McGrath, Ilka Chase, June Havoc and Richard Haydn....

In the wake of an acute liquor shortage for the holiday trade there come warnings, addressed to whomever it may concern. If certain parties do not mend their ways we shall have Prohibition with us again. A return to Volstead does not seem likely, unless human memory is even shorter than one suspects. But if the unlikely thing does happen there will be other developments too.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Attorney General Nathan L. Goldstein, wrote to Attorney General Biddle today that Governor Dewey would not assure Federal authorities that Louis (Lepke) Buchalter would be executed if he is granted a conditional pardon by President Roosevelt for that purpose.

It is a fact that employers are hiring youngsters who should be in school. Many of these are under the legal age for full-time employment, and they cannot be blamed because the attractiveness of the wages is too much for them. The employers cannot be blamed because the need for labor is very great.

Some secrets of new turbochargers, "wings of the stratosphere" that have put America's biggest bombers and deadliest, fighters on top of the enemy, were revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

On the basis of a Reuter dispatch from Lisbon, stating that the Big Three of the Eastern war have concluded a meeting in Cairo and have proceeded to Iran for a meeting of the Big Three of the Western war, it appears that the "diplomatic block-buster" the world has been waiting for is not one conference but two.

Having succeeded in ousting Benito Mussolini's Fascist regime and putting his country on the Allied side, we are having a difficult time of it occupying Italy. Air bombardment and the threat of more air bombardment, it is generally recognized, knocked Italy out of the war.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Germans have acknowledged that two entire Polish villages were wiped out and more than 1,200 other Poles were killed in retailiation for sixteen assassinations in the Bialystok Province of Poland last July, the Polish Telegraph Agency reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice has notified twenty railroads and seven unions that in thirty days they must cease all discriminatory practices which result in unfair treatment of workers and job applicants because of race, creed, color or national origin.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The extraordinary grand jury investigating alleged labor union rackets in the Hudson River Valley accused Governor Dewey today of refusing to cooperate and said it had evidence of transactions between public officials and unions in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Soft coal operators representing about 70 per cent of the nation's tonnage and the United Mine Workers agreed today to have a subcommittee of five from each side meet at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow to make a "firm" wage contract within the framework of the agreement negotiated by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes and John L. Lewis, president of the union.

Formal offering will be made today by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and seventy-six other investment banking houses of $25,000,000 of Central Power and Light Company first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds due in 1973. The issue will be priced at 99 1/2, to yield about 3.15 per cent Proceeds of the financing will be used to retire an equal amount of the utility's 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 30 -- The Syrian Chamber of Deputies has voted to rid the Constitution of Article 116 -- the only one, so to speak, with teeth in it -- reports from Damascus said today.

Professional baseball's embattled minor leagues, concluding their second successive day of intensive campaigning and caucusing at the Hotel New Yorker, stood poised last night to put on a show that is not likely to make New York regret it is playing host to the national pastime's "little fellows" for the first time in twenty-four years.

If the western end of Long Island Sound ever was famous for cod fishing, that day was long ago. Flounders, blackfish and tomcods, yes; but cod, no. Thus, when codfish are caught there, as a few have been in the last couple of weeks, the rowboat and party boat fishermen have something to talk about.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- An anti-Hitler group of old-line junker Germans, according to reports from inside Germany, is awaiting the psychological moment to attempt a Government coup.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A succession of witnesses, including Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and R.V. Fletcher, a spokesman for the railroads, advocated before the Senate Finance Committee today changes in the $2,140,000,000 tax bill adopted by the House.

The New York State Liquor Authority extended yesterday to warehouses its State-wide check on liquor stocks intended to determine the amount of whisky available for New York licensees in the present shortage. Warehouse operators were directed by John F. O'Connell, chairman of the SLA, to file inventories of their stocks by next Friday.

Anthony Campagna, builder of many of the skyscraper apartment houses along Park and Fifth Avenues, upon whom King Victor Emmanuel of Italy conferred the title of Conte de Castelmezzano in 1931, has been appointed a member of the Board of Education by Mayor La Guardia, it was learned last night.

Attacking international air monopolies in any form, officials of five domestic airlines yesterday urged a national policy which would permit broader post-war participation of domestic lines in international commerce and immediate Government action to assure such companies access to American-built overseas air bases.

It was an exciting collection that Lord Taylor showed yesterday afternoon, the first of the season to include styles for the South. They are the curtain-raisers for spring and summer -- a prologue, in color, design and fabric, for things to come.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals had before it today the contention of a Tennessee newspaper publisher that the constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press itself is a bar to application of the Wage-Hour Law to the newspaper industry.

Directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad and the Pere Marquette Railway at their regular meetings in Cleveland yesterday appointed subcommittees to "consider ways and means of bringing about partial or complete unification" of these properties and the Wheeling Lake Erie Railroad Company.

The statements of Secretary Morgenthau and Mr. Paul before the Senate Finance Committee merely emphasize the weakness of their argumentative position. They have properly insisted, as against Congressional leaders, upon a heavy increased volume of taxes. But instead of distributing or diversifying the increased tax burden, they wish to place it even more heavily on sources of income already taxed close to the limit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Declaring that there was no reason why the war should interrupt the democratic principle of a Presidential campaign, Postmaster General Frank C. Walker asserted tonight that his party was ready "to stand or fall" on its war and social record and warned the opposition that those broad issues, not local problems, would determine the 1944 election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Challenged by members of the House committee investigating executive agencies as to the War Labor Board's authority to require maintenance-of-membership clauses in contracts between employers and labor unions, William H. Davis, the board's chairman, replied today that the WLB could even order closed shops if it believed them necessary to end disputes and maintain war production.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30 -- A decree issued today creates a new "secretariate of labor and social security" to be in charge of regulating relations between capital and labor and securing the welfare of the working classes in accordance with Argentine legislation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- There is no religious "revival" among American troops, but there is in their willingness to die that others may live, "religion in the real sense of the word," which churches should use to build their future, the Rev. Dr. William B. Pugh, chairman of the General Commission on Army and Navy Chaplains, declared today at the first anniversary luncheon of the Service Men's Christian League.

One week after the War Food Administration announced indefinite continuation of the suspension of quota limitations on meat slaughtered for civilians, the weekly summary of New York meat receipts released by the Food Distribution Administration yesterday showed a drop of nearly 6,000,000 pounds.
ALGIERS, Nov. 30 -- The first meeting of the Advisory Council for Italy was held here today.

Mariano Nisito, 50 years old, of 711 East 183d Street, the Bronx, a widower who had seen three of his sons go into the Army since Pearl Harbor, shot and killed himself in the bedroom of his apartment just before dinner last night because he could not bear to see his fourth and youngest son go into the Navy.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Little business was done today on the stock markets here and the tone was again quiet.

Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York, Mrs. Margaret W. Wagar of Atlanta, Mrs. J.E. Folline of Richmond, and Mrs. Ralph C. Young of Philadelphia led the twelve teams entered after the first session of play for the national women's contract bridge team-of-four championship at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon.

The niche in baseball for which he often had expressed a desire came to Carl Hubbell, the Old Maestro, yesterday. His active days as one of the outstanding left-handed pitchers in history at an end after twenty-one years in organized baseball, sixteen of them with the Giants, the gangling Oklahoman yesterday signed as field director of the Giants' farm system.

Barbara Lou Erlichman, 5 years old and the "littlest" of the Spars, women's auxiliary of the Coast Guard, was sworn in yesterday as a Junior Spar at the Coast Guard headquarters at 42 Broadway. The special "oath" was administered by Lieut. (j.g.) Dorothy Beckwith, Spar recruiting officer for the Third Naval District.

New York has the poorest record of any State for recruiting nurses for the armed forces, Mrs. William Armour, chairman of the New York Red Cross recruitment committee for the Army and Navy Nurse Corps, declared here yesterday.

Maxwell Geismar, author of! 'Arriters in Crisis," brought out by Houghton iM[ifflin, will give a series / of three lectures on successive !Thursday evenings at the Brook!lyn Academy of ]VIusic. "The Changing American Scene" s the general title of the series, which is under the sponsorship of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

DONALSONVILLE, Ga., Nov. 30 (AP) -- A sentiment-sounding Presidential preferential primary in rural Seminole County today gave 816 votes in favor of a fourth term for President Roosevelt and seventy against, on the basis of returns from three of five precincts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Demands for industrial alcohol for war and lend-lease use for the rest of this year and 1944 are so heavy that additional distilling facilities will have to be erected to augment the current combined output of existing industrial alcohol plants and of the converted facilities of distillers of beverage alcohol, officials of the War Production Board said tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have broken into Changteh, key highway junction in northern Hunan Province, and savage street fighting is raging in the city, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

The continuation of bombing assaults on the Marshall Islands and Nauru in the Central Pacific support the belief that correspondents in Hawaii have expressed -- that there will be only a brief intermission before the next step in our new Central Pacific campaign.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Premier Joseph Stalin's plan to win this war and make sure that Germany cannot start another will soon be on the tri-power conference table if it is true, as foreign radio broadcasts have been saying all day, that he has left the Kremlin to confer with President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill, sources familiar with Russian policy said tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Wednesday, Dec. 1 -- An account of the Berlin damage from last week's Royal Air Force bombings, given here today by an expert observer, revealed that the railway viaduct across the Unter den Linden extension near the zoo, which the RAF had vainly tried to hit many times before, was now down.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 30 -- Kentuckians, who for the first time in sixteen years chose a Republican Governor and other State officials on Nov. 2, elected a Republican member of Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox asserted today that the Navy was "not fooled" in estimating Japanese strength before the costly attack on Tarawa atoll, but that "a sudden shifting of the wind" had contributed to the high American losses.
The New York District Office of Price Administration announced yesterday the new ceiling prices fixed for 6,000 American and Chinese hand laundries in the New York Metropolitan area.

Working on the assumption that as Sammy Baugh goes so goes Washington, Coach Steve Owen yesterday laid stress on pass defense as the Giants held their first workout of the week in preparation for the all-important clash with the Redskins at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

Ruchlin Brothers, manufacturer of mattresses, have purchased the former Hope Dyeing and Finishing plant at 5620 Hudson Boulevard, in West New York, N.J., in an expansion move. The company maintains salesrooms and a factory on Bergenline Avenue there.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 30 -- The Germans arrested 1,200 professors and students of Oslo University today, men and women alike, for deportation to Reich concentration camps. The step was said to be the result of last Saturday's fire in the university's assembly hall.
THE TIMES of Nov. 29 carried the story that a full draft of 300,000 men is indicated for January, which will probably mean the calling of pre-war fathers, and gives as a main reason the following:

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the December issue of its monthly review of credit and business conditions, reviews the New York money market, stating that a reduction here of $90,000,000 in balances kept by out-of-town banks was largely offset by the continued inflow of commercial and financial funds to this city.

NOT long ago I sat at a dinner table as one of many gathered together for sweet publicity's sake. Two colleagues, two publishers and a suitable number of wives were present. Someone mentioned style and the distinguished critic upon my left looked up from his gloomy contemplation of a green olive and a gray wisp of celery.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- A large short interest in December rye was disclosed today after reports that a cash grain firm was bringing 3,500,000 to 4,000,000 bushels of the grain here from Canada to make a delivery on December contracts. Of this amount about 2,000,000 bushels have been received from Fort William and the remainder is expected within a few days.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 30 -- Japan may now be expected to remain on the defensive along her harassed eastern flank, cautiously holding on to her powerful navy and fighting delaying actions wherever we attack, it was stated here today.

War made more inroads on athletics in this country, but the old American custom of record-breaking continued during 1943. While the quantity was smaller than usual, the high quality was maintained, as a total of sixty-three track and field and swimming records were hung up this year, Records Chairman Paul R. Jordan of the Amateur Athletic Union announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- In warning against a possible shortage of wheat for cereal production next year, the Millers National Federation today gave the following statistical summary of the wheat situation in its report to the War Food Administration:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 30 -- A new trade agreement between Brazil and Argentina, revising the present four-year treaty that expires in January, was discussed in Buenos Aires today between Brazilian and Argentine officials. The new treaty will lay the base for protecting the post-war situation in the two countries.

The national stock of rationed type shoes, which has been reduced by approximately 100,000,000 pairs in the last thirteen months, now totals slightly in excess of 200,000,000 pairs -- a point at which the national inventory must be maintained, W.W. Stephenson, chief of the shoe rationing branch of the Office of Price Administration, told a meeting of the Shoe Retailers League at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Senate reversed itself today and approved by a vote of 40 to 39 a Republican amendment to the Servicemen's Absentee Voting Bill requiring the President to appoint the four members of the War Ballot Commission which would administer the program, from lists submitted by the Republican and Democratic National Committees.

Two union leaders whose efforts in behalf of their members had been hampered by interference from George E. Browne testified yesterday in Federal Court in defense of seven men accused of having conspired with Browne and Willie Bioff in the extortion of $2,500,000.
In your editorial of Nov. 24, "Air-Raid Confusion," there were several comments which prompted this reply.

Last Saturday night Gen. Bernard Montgomery informed his Eighth Army and the enemy as well, "We are about to hit the Germans a colossal crack." In thirty-six hours of savage fighting he has made that promise good. His troops have "broken into the defenses of the enemy's winter line * * * and the advance continues."

There are between 400,000 and 500,000 jobs in the Army that could be done by women, Col. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Wac, said yesterday. "Nothing leads me to believe," she added, "that we are going to get a volunteer Army of 400,000 or 500,000 women.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- The Germans were reported today to be fighting hard to retain Zhlobin and their bridgehead on the upper Dnieper's left bank, but their strength was divided. Last night the Russians reported the capture of a place seven miles south of the town by units that, having crossed the Berezina River at Gorval with Partisan aid, have been now reinforced by tanks.

Rebounding from Monday's losses, the cotton futures market showed yesterday gains of as much as $1.35 a bale. Support came from aggressive covering, trade demand and commission-house replacement buying, with offerings supplied principally through scale-up hedging operations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A program calling for redistribution of 1,200,000 new brass and bronze valves, having a value of approximately $3,500,000, through normal trade channels, was announced by the War Production Board today. The program is designed to meet urgent demands for brass and bronze valves and to conserve manpower needed to manufacture new valves.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in November was the largest for a month since last July and the largest for a November since 1940. The turnover for the year to date continues to be the heaviest since 1938.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said tonight that the satisfactory solution of post-war employment problems would depend on unity among management, labor, agriculture and government.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- A new North Atlantic flying record was established yesterday when a Consolidated Liberator bomber of the Royal Air Force Transport Command covered the 3,100 miles between Montreal and an airport on the west coast of Britain in eleven hours and thirty-five minutes. Capt. Richard Allen of Melbourne, Australia, commanded the plane in its nonstop flight.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 1 -- For the second successive day and the third time in five days heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force attacked targets in Germany yesterday. Solingen, east of Duesseldorf, and one of the most completely industrialized cities of the Ruhr-Rhineland area with steel, tool and aircraft engine plants, was hit by large formations of Flying Fortresses.

Private residences in various parts of Brooklyn were reported yesterday to have passed into new hands. In the Bay Ridge section the single-family house with garage at 8217 Twelfth Avenue was sold through the Bulkley Horton Company for Alling Brothers to a client for occupancy.
UNION BEACH, N.J., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Pvt. John A. Rossi of Union Beach, who is somewhere in the Southwest Pacific, has written a man-to-man letter to his infant son whom he has never seen.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today, in response to a request by the New York City Board of Elections, that the present congressional, senatorial and assembly districts should remain in effect for the purpose of the spring primary elections, at which delegates to the national conventions will be chosen, and members in the party State committees will be selected.

The trial of Patrolman David Liebman on departmental charges growing out of his speech on crime conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area has been "postponed without date," it was announced yesterday at Police Headquarters. Liebman was scheduled to go on trial this afternoon at Brooklyn Police Headquarters before Third Deputy Michael A. Lyons, the trial commissioner.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended with October, net profit of $3,767,883, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.08 a share on 2,261,199 shares of common stock. This compares with $3,594,048, or $1 a common share, earned in the corresponding period last year.

Public hearings by the National Education Association on charges that Mayor La Guardia has interfered with the independence of the Board of Education will be opened on Monday morning at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, it was disclosed yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Dec. 1 (UP) -- A communique:

The formal signing of Joseph Vincent McCarthy, renewing his contract as manager of the world champion Yankees, was announced yesterday as one of the developments of the baseball gatherings in the Hotel New Yorker. The man who has piloted the club to eight American League pennants and seven world series triumphs, four of them in a row through 1936, 1937, 1938 and 1939, will manage the club three years more under the new contract.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- First Lieut. Bernard A. Gillespie of Gila Bend, Ariz., was revealed today as a modern Jonah who survived a bomber explosion and was imprisoned in an enemy submarine from which he was rescued when it was destroyed.

ALGIERS, Nov. 30 -- Ripping into the Germans with irresistible fury, the British Eighth Army has captured Fossacesia, Santa Maria Mozzagrogna and Romagnoli and merged its two bridgeheads across the Sangro River, it was officially announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, who led the American forces in the Guadalcanal and Bougainville offensives, was appointed by President Roosevelt today to succeed Lieut. Gen. Thomas Holcomb, effective Jan. 1, as commandant of the Marine Corps.

At a move against the threatened cancellation in Congress of the Administration's subsidy program to hold down prices, the executive board of the New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations, at at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania, called yesterday upon its 1,000,000 members in 800 affiliated unions "to immediately seek wage increases to meet the rapid rise in the cost of living."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Senate voted to require the President to select four members of the War Ballot Commission from nominations made by the major parties' national committees. The Senate recessed at 5:32 P.M. until noon tomorrow.

NO one ever should attempt to explain a football upset. They just happen and hence no effort will be made here to account for the twin upheavals of the past weekend, Great Lakes bowling over unbeaten Notre Dame and the Steagles toppling the unbeaten Washington Redskins. Yet, by sheer coincidence the two fall into identical patterns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Despite war order cutbacks and the shutting down of some munition plants the manpower crisis has not yet been settled, according to Willian Faber, assistant executive director of the War Manpower Commission, and head of its planning section.

Shoppers in search of Christmas presents appear to be devoting a good deal of attention to cakes, candies and other unrationed foods, with the result that many city shopkeepers fear that supplies will be comparatively low after mid-December.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the current issue of its monthly review estimates that in the twelvemonth ended Nov. 30 foreign central banks and foreign government, presumably chiefly Latin American, have added about $1,150,000,000 to their holdings in this country.
ALGIERS, Nov. 30 -- A communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- Roddy McDowall has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the role of "Father Chisholm" as a boy in the A.J. Cronin story "Keys of the Kingdom," which is scheduled for production early in January. The filming of "Son of Flicka," in which young McDowall will be starred, has been postponed until spring.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 30 -- Bulgarian and Rumanian Partisan units have joined the People's Army of Liberation under Gen. Josip Broz [Tito] and are fighting beside a formidable Yugoslav guerrilla force, it was announced today by the Free Yugoslavia radio.

ALGIERS, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle and members of the French Committee of National Liberation, of which he is chairman, will offer their resignations to the president of a provisionally elected French Assembly "after the liberation," according to plans announced here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- New animal products and new methods of processing and preserving meats have been developed to meet the needs of the war emergency and their place in peacetime should be given immediate and intensive research, Dr. L.A. Maynard, Cornell University, declared today at the annual meeting of the American Society of Animal Production here.

George Abbott still believes that "Get Away Old Man" is an entertaining play, but William Saroyan's expose of the inner workings of studio life in Hollywood isn't drawing enough customers to the Cort. So the producer-director is reluctantly closing the satirical comedy on Saturday night after a fleeting visit of thirteen performances.

NAPLES, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A British soldier's purchase of a dozen bottles of cheap wine led today to the arrest of what police believe are the key men in an Italian "black market" ring that has been dealing mainly in American Army rations, tires, gasoline and other articles valued at thousands of dollars.

WASHINGTON, Nov.30 -- T.A.M. Craven, commissioner of the Federal Communications Commission, told a special House committee today that it is "a well-known fact" that the FCC chairman, James L. Fly, had "visited reprisals" on members of the armed forces who opposed his policies.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 30 (AP) -- R.J. Thomas of Detroit, president of the United Automobile Workers (CIO), was acquitted in County Court today on a charge of violating the recently enacted Manford Labor Union Law.

Mr. and IVfrs. Leonard Clark Feathers of New York and liami Beach, Fla., gave an old-fashioned reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 270 Park Avenue, to introduce their younger daughter, Miss Joan Potter Feathers. Autumn flowers were used in the decorations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser said today that he "must have had blinders on" when he took over the presidency of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation. In asking for Congressional support and cooperation in his efforts to accelerate the company's plane production, he told the House Naval Subcommittee that he hoped to be turning out 150 Corsair fighting planes for the Navy each month by May of next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Personal testimony of police chief, sheriff and juvenile court judge, today tallied with Federal statistics to give the Senate's special subcommittee on Wartime Health and Education a national picture of rising juvenile delinquency.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- P. R. Mallory Co., Inc., of Indianapolis, manufacturers of metallurgical, electrical and electronic products, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration covering the proposed issue of 60,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock with a par value of $25 a share.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- For the third time in six months James J. Hines, former Tammany district leader, applied through counsel in Supreme Court today for a review of the State Parole Board's decision not to release him at this time from Sing Sing Prison, where he is serving a sentence of four to eight years for protecting the policy racket of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

A strike of service and maintenance employes in the city's 700 schools, called by Local 112 of the School Custodial Workers, an affiliate of the United Construction Workers, will go into effect this morning, it was announced last night by Leon Zwicker, regional director of the UCW, a branch of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The most unusual Western Conference All-Star football team in history -- including for the first time a freshman, a player who was performing in his fourth year of varsity competition, and another who made the team last year but representing a different school -- has been selected for The Associated Press by Big Ten coaches.

A large loan exhibition called "The French Revolution" opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. It has been arranged as a benefit for the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes (New School for Social Research) and the Societe d'Histoire de la Revolution Francaise.
Yesterday's Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins fought grimly against six Chicago Black Hawk forwards during the last 55 seconds to protect a hard-earned lead for a 6-5 National League triumph tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

Post-war plans are being pushed for the formation of an International Cooperative Trading and Manufacturing Association to aid in the rapid recovery of consumer cooperatives in the wartorn countries of Europe and elsewhere, it was made known yesterday by Waling Dykstra, European adviser to the American Committee for International Cooperative Reconstruction, in an interview here. Mr. Dykstra also told of steps now under way to put coops in the forefront of rehabilitation activities in Europe.

Frankie Terry, 154, of Bensonhurst, defeated Phil Enzenga, 151, of Baltimore in the feature bout of eight rounds before a crowd of 3,000 at the Broadway Arena last night. Terry was the aggressor throughout and floored his adversary with a right to the jaw for a count of one in the seventh round.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate voted to extend the right to vote by absentee ballot to persons serving overseas with the Red Cross, Society of Friends, Women's Auxiliary Ferry Service, Women's Air Force Service Pilots and the USO.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Today's first meeting of a ten-man operator-miner group to formulate a coal wage contract to take the place of the present temporary agreement between the miners and the Government saw no progress made and from operator sources came a prediction there would be none for some time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Charles Coburn has been announced by Twentieth Century-Fox for the lead in the picturization of Barry Fleming's novel, "Colonel Effingham's Raid," the title of which has been changed to "Everything Is Peaches Down in Georgia."

Benefits to pensioners on the rolls of twenty-one religious organizations represented yesterday at the twenty-ninth annual church pensions conference at the Hotel McAlpin increased 5 per cent, or a total of $653,319 over the previous year, according to a consolidated report made public at the conference.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 1 -- Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan reserved decision today in a $30,000,000 recovery suit brought against officials and directors of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company by two stockholders. The hearing had taken fifty-one days, constituting the longest trial in the history of New Jersey's Chancery Court.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 1 (UP) -- A special communique:

Yesterday was X-Ray Day at the Breslee Manufacturing Company. Promptly at 9:30 A.M., the first group of employes, ten women, took time off from making critical items for the Army and Navy at the 151 West Twenty-sixth Street plant to line up in front of a locker room to "have their pictures taken."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Following is the text of the joint communique on the Cairo conference:

Acting on complaints from leading perfume manufacturers, detectives from the office of Queens Distriot Attorney Charles P. Sullivan arrested yesterday in Long Island City four men accused of fraudulently selling cheap perfumes as expensive, widely advertised brands.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 1 -- India received today the gesture of sympathy for the famine in Bengal that had been asked on her account by J.J. Singh, president of the Nationalist India League of America. Speaking at the final plenary meeting of the three-week first session of the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, Dean Acheson, chairman of the session, said:

Fifteen of the fifty key cities of Germany already have been knocked out as industrial factors in the war, Lieut. Col. Nathaniel F. Silsbee of the Army Air Forces declared yesterday at a luncheon of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in the Hotel McAlpin.

Football attendance during the season just closed suffered a drop of 18.4 per cent from 1942, a survey of fifty-seven major colleges discloses. The decline was greatest in the South, 28.4 per cent, and smallest in the East, 6.4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The War and Navy Departments have taken steps to deal with problems of contract termination and property disposal by establishing new readjustment divisions, which will cooperate with the Office of War Mobilization in these fields.

Synthetic rubber faces the necessity of establishing its commercial value to a greater extent than it has thus far if it is to compete on an unsubsidized basis in a market in which crude rubber is freely available, V. A. Cosler, sales development manager for the rubber chemicals division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., stated yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut announced today he would confirm a compromise reorganiation plan for the Seaboard Air Line Railway and asserted that security holders "must take or leave what now has been offered them."

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Minister of Home Security Herbert Morrison's action in transferring Sir Oswald Mosley, Britain's Number 1 Fascist, from prison to a private home, where he is under a sort of "house arrest," was upheld by the House of Commons today when an amendment expressing "regret" at the move was rejected by the lopsided vote of 327 to 62.
Fulfillment of the pledges made in Cairo by President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and President Chiang Kai-shek will mean stripping Japan of one of the greatest empires ever put together.

Alvin S. Keys of Springfield, Ill., and Guy M. Landes of Tulsa, Okla., are new appointees to the executive committee of the National Association of Insurance Agents and Harry Perk Jr. of Los Angeles has been reappointed.
Mrs. John Foster Dulles will give a small reception this afternoon at her home, 72 East Ninety-first Street, for Miss Eleanor Lansing Thomas, debutante daughter of Mrs. James Augustus Thomas.

Despite its confused and confusing libretto, "The Magic Flute" is one of Mozart's and the world's great operas. Its music is radiant with humanity and it is the virtue of the Metropolitan Opera's production, which had its first performance of the season last night, that the music is conveyed with integrity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A bill to authorize and direct the Treasury Department to conduct bimonthly lotteries, with tickets selling at $2 each and pay $500,000,000 in Government bonds as "rewards" to 1,318 subscribers after each drawing, was offered in the Senate today by Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania.

Joseph M. Schenck, former chairman of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, was quoted yesterday as having told Willie Bioff in 1939 that the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, then dominated by Bioff, "had to win" a National Labor Relations Board election.

Frances Pisano, 20 years old, of 16 Baltic Street, Brooklyn, insisted on summing up the evidence yesterday in her General Sessions trial as a shoplifter. But in thirty minutes the jury of seven women and five men found her guilty and then Judge John J. Freschi committed her to Bellevue for observation as to her sanity.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Basing its action in large part upon a survey purporting to show that electric and gas companies fare better alone than in combination with one another, the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today that the Union Electric Company of Missouri not be permitted to retain the St. Louis County Gas Company in its holding-company set-up.

Physicians in this State got $5,000,000 from medical and surgical supply companies and laboratories as their share of the $18,000,000 spent last year for care of claimants under the Workmen's Compensation Law, according to testimony given yesterday at the renewal of a Moreland Act inquiry at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The proposed sale by the Durham Public Service Company to the Duke Power Company of its fixed properties for a basic cash consideration of $2,952,000 as of Nov. 30, 1942, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mayor La Guardia last night presented the Frank Hawks Memorial Award of Air Service Post 501 of the American Legion to Rear Admiral C.E. Rosendahl at a dinner of the post at the Lotos Club. The Mayor, himself a winner of the medal in 1940, praised Admiral Rosendahl as a "great pioneer" in the field of air transportation.

After an early display of strength, the cotton futures market yesterday reversed itself. Persistent selling came principally through commission houses that had been on the buying side earlier. Active old contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended at the day's lows, 8 to 11 points below Tuesday's final quotations.
Recent activities among the New York rod and gun devotees:

Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York, Mrs. Margaret Wagar of Atlanta, Ga.; Mrs. J.E. Folline of Richmond, Va., and Mrs. Ralph Young of Philadelphia won the women's national team-of-four championship yesterday in the contract bridge tournament in progress at the Astor Hotel here.
Bishop William T. Manning issued yesterday a Christmas message to the men and women of the Episcopal Diocese of New York who are serving in the armed forces.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals, in a 4-3 decision, has upheld the validity of Reno divorces in New York.

Sun-tanned, healthy and ecstatically happy, but exceedingly reticent about many of their experiences, more than 1,000 of the 1,440 passengers -- l,222 Americans and 217 Canadians -- aboard the diplomatic exchange liner Gripsholm debarked yesterday after the 18,353-ton Swedish ship docked at Pier F. Jersey City.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- To head off a depression and contribute the maximum to general recovery public works deficiencies due to war must be made good as soon as the war is over, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, said today in an address before the annual convention of the American Association of State Highway Officials.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- Along the whole active front, in widely differing conditions of terrain and climate, the Red Army is fighting to wrest from the enemy control of his main lateral communications.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The setting up of a small Federal agency to serve as a clearing house on the subject of juvenile delinquency was suggested to the Senate's subcommittee on wartime health and education today by Richard Chappell, Chief of Probation of the Administrative Office of United States Courts.

Unofficial reports here yesterday indicated that some 600 merchants still are restricted in buying additional merchandise in line with the provisions of the inventory control order L-219. In the last four months, however, the number has dropped from 1,100 to 800, and later to the present figure.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- Not since the days of the Ptolemys has Egypt been such a cynosure of attention from the civilized world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- In many respects the by-election of a Republican Representative in Congress from the Fourth Kentucky District is the plainest sign thus far manifest that the political trend is running against the New Deal and the administration in Washington.

Napoleon told his soldiers in the battle of the Pyramids that 4,000 years of history were looking down on them. Only a few days ago, it has been duly noted, the Pyramids looked down on another piece of history in the form of Roosevelt, Churchill and Chiang Kai-shek in conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Contract refunds of about $15,000,000 were made by the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company and the Budd Wheel Company as a result of renegotiation of war production contracts by the War and Navy price adjustment boards, Edward G. Budd, president of the two concerns, said today in a letter to[ stockholders.

Axis propaganda experts -- apparently taken off base by the actual American-British-Chinese conferences in North Africa -- drumming on the theme yesterday that a four-power meeting with Russia was under way at Teheran, Iran, sought to discredit it beforehand with an intensity perhaps betraying their own fears, The Associated Press said.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The longest receivership in railroad history -- a twenty-year headache for security holders -- ended today as the reorganized Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad began operating as a private corporation.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Cairo conference with President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill was his first face-to-face meeting with the leaders of great western nations.

Christmas trees began arriving in wholesale markets yesterday and probably will go on sale at retail next week. The early shipments are chiefly of large trees for store and public displays. The smaller sizes for private homes and apartments are expected to begin arriving in bulk near the end of next week.

The good news that meat is to be more plentiful during December prompted us to search our files for recipes that present meats attractively. The formulas that follow have all been tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES kitchen.

A gain of 24 per cent in gross volume of fur dressing and dyeing for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 over 1942 and a rise of 3 1/2 per cent over 1941 was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Fur Dressers and Dyers Association at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

The declaration drawn up at Cairo specifically provides that, in addition to territories stolen from China and all other territories taken by violence and greed, Japan is to be "stripped of all islands in the Pacific which she has seized or occupied since the beginning of the First World War in 1914."

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Roosevelt-Churchill-Chiang conferences were regarded in London tonight as an excellent prelude to the Stalin-Roosevelt-Churchill meeting that Prime Minister Churchill said he hoped would take place before the first of next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, defended food subsidies before the Senate Banking Committee today.

A holiday "Circus of Modern Art," for children between the ages of 4 and 12, will open in the Young People's Gallery at the Museum of Modern Art next Wednesday and remain through Jan. 9. The circus will consist of a miniature gallery, built to child scale, of modern paintings with special appeal to children, and a play center with easel tables and play tables, where they may make toys and constructions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, which is considering revision of the 1934 Communications Law, called on the Federal Communications Commission today for the recommendations on which it acted in denying all applications for circuits filed with it since December, 1942, by Press Wireless, Inc.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Reports from Oslo, Norway, said that German police had been ordered on a twenty-four-hour search of Oslo for suspected anti-Quisling students who escaped yesterday's raid on the university. Squads raided many homes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The way our boys live in the Pacific was shown at Mrs. Roosevelt's press conference today in movies of her trip taken in Technicolor by Yank, the service newspaper, and in black-and-white by the Signal Corps.

Business men and industry were urged yesterday to cooperate with the American Red Cross Blood Donor Service and "make it the business of business to bring 'em back alive" by giving employes time off to make donations. The appeal was made by Gordon Lamont, chairman of the recruiting committee, at the regular weekly luncheon meeting of the Kiwanis Club in the Hotel McAlpin.

New securities offered in November for public subscription con tinued in fairly large volume here, with stock flotations making the largest total for any month since May, 1941, and the best for a No vember since 1928. Bond offerings, although smaller than in the preceding month, were well above the figures for November, 1942.

He felt a bit lost yesterday sitting around his home at 3151 Perry avenue, the Bronx, with his two daughters. After fifty-two years of continuous employ in the postal service, William H. Farrell Jr., assistant superintendent of mails in charge of the protection of postal revenue in the city's general postoffice, was spending his first day of retirement in another world.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Trading in rye futures was less active today than recently, as brokers awaited developments regarding the December delivery and the congestion that has developed, as well as announcement of ceiling prices.

The twenty-seventh annual show of the Empire Cat Club, Inc., and the Siamese Cat Society of America's specialty show opened yesterday morning in the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, with 168 entrants competing. The show will end today.

AT A U.S. BOMBER BASE IN ENGLAND, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Hale and hearty, Capt. Herbert M. Light, who won the D.F.C. for the American attack on the Ploesti, Rumania, oil fields, now is stationed in England and he is worried because he can't seem to convince his parents he is alive.

The hijacking of $100,000 worth of liquor on two great trailer trucks had been nearly completed early yesterday, and the two robbed truck drivers were gradually strangling on the gags that had been placed over their mouths, when a group of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents appeared out of the shadows at Tenth Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

FOOCHOW, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -Although Japan controls the sea the Chinese still are able to sail it in certain circumstances. For a price paid to coastal pirates, who in turn pay a percentage to the Japanese, the Chinese can get to Shanghai from Foochow by water.

A citation was presented to Major Rosalind S. Cowen, director of the Manhattan unit of the American Women's Hospital Reserve Corps, yesterday by the Army Second Service Command for having "rendered faithful and able service in the fulfillment of the Army Emergency Relief objective of maintaining the morale of our soldiers."

NAPLES, Nov. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- Rosalbino Santoro, Naples attorney, has cabled Mayor Fiorello La Guardia of New York asking his assistance in a plan to obtain relief for the stricken civilian population of Italy directly from Americans of Italian extraction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Allied pledge to restore Korea's independence was hailed with enthusiasm by the Sino-Korean Peoples League today, a spokesman asserting it would touch off "plenty of fireworks" behind Japan's strategic areas.

In the first presentation of its kind, the Army-Navy E pennant for outstanding achievement in war production was awarded last night to the Industriail Home for the Blind at a ceremony held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. At the same time, E pins were presented to 228 sightless employes of the home's two plants at 520 Gates Avenue and 1000 Atlantic Avenue, both Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Representative Frances Payne Bolton, Republican, of Ohio, introduced in the House today a bill to give the women of the Army Nurse Corps regular officers' commissions instead of the "relative" rank they have had since 1920.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, "What A Woman!," a comedy romance produced by Columbia and starring Rosalind Russell and Brian Aherne, will have its premiere. Directed by Irving Cummings, the picture's supporting cast includes Willard Parker, Alan Dinehart, Edward Fielding and Ann Savage.

An advisory committee of physicians, educators and publicists has been set up to assist the health education bureau of the city Health Department to broaden its work, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday.

Paul H. Smart, a lawyer who is well known in the midtown district as a night club frequenter, was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to a nine-month penitentiary term on his guilty plea two weeks ago with two other men and two women to indecently exposing themselves in an East Forty-seventh Street apartment that the police raided on the night of Sept. 29.

Plans suggested to the Government for the handling of surplus war materials through normal channels of distribution were emphasized yesterday at the meeting of the Central Council of Retail Trade Associations at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The word "security" does not appear in the communique which sums up the results of the Cairo conference, but it is certain that the three heads of state who took part in that historic meeting are as much concerned about creating the conditions of a stable peace in the Pacific as they are about undoing the injustices which Japan has done in such cases as Korea and Manchuria.

Satisfied that his Giants now know what they have to do in order to stop Samy Baugh in Sunday's crucial game with Washington, Steve Owen yesterday devoted most of his coaching time to polishing up an offense since he realizes that merely stopping Sammy won't be enough.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- Delegates to the three-power conference are being housed in a number of villas here.

Amid an array of American and British flags, "Ye Olde English Faire," the annual three-days bazaar conducted by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, opened yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. The bazaar is conducted for the benefit of the Victoria Home for age British men and women Ossining.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans have ousted the Germans from the vital industrial town of Vares, twenty miles north of Sarajevo, but have lost the island of Uljan, off Zara, to strong German forces seeking to consolidated their hold on the Dalmatian coast, a Partisan communique reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The War Production Board's Office of Civilian Requirements will begin a series of regional conferences with manufacturers and wholesalers of consumer goods this month to get their reactions to the war agency's forthcoming order on equitable distribution of civilian merchandise.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces, having thrown Japanese troops out of the Hunan Province road junction of Changteh, have stormed the eastern suburbs of Japanese-held Ichang and broken into two important towns on the Ichang-Hankow highway north of the Yangtze River, a special Chinese communique said today.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Strong formations of Flying Fortresses and Liberators battled their way through clouds of German fighters to hammer the important industrial city of Solingen, north of Cologne, in the Rhineland, today, in a most important series of punishing attacks by Allied bombers on German targets in northern Europe.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- What might be termed a Pacific Charter, outlining a specific program for obtaining the unconditional surrender of Japan and her reduction to her frontiers before 1895 with the ensuing liberation of her vast Asiatic mainland and Pacific island empire, was published tonight following a sensational five-day series of conferences among President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and their principal military and political staffs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A statement by a Montgomery Ward Company spokesman that the Post-office Department curtailed its mail service in support of a strike at the company's Portland (Ore.) plant in May, 1941, brought a demand from a Congressional committee today for a prompt explanation by the department.

MADRID, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A suggestion that Germany may forego the use of her "secret weapon" if the Allies stop bombing cities was published today by the newspaper Madrid in a dispatch from its Berlin correspondent.

A delegation of major league baseball players, headed by Manager Frank Frisch of the Pirates, has left to entertain troops outside the continental United States. Among the players are three who saw action in the 1943 world series, and one other who topped all popularity polls as a member of the Dodgers.

The City Stores Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended with October a consolidated net profit of $1,158,690, equal to 95 cents a share on the 1,210,042 shares of $5-par common stock outstanding. The consolidated net profit for the corresponding period of the previous year was $725,412 or 60 cents a share.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 2 -- The Germans have struck out with new vigor in every sector of the Russian front in a major bid to stem the Russian offensive, counter-attacking yesterday as many as fifteen times in one area and slowing the Red Army to minor gains along the 600-mile front.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Although it's fairly well established that this is the age of air power, the National Football League has further evidence to submit, namely: For the first time in the loop's history, more touchdowns have been scored via passes than on the ground.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 -- The Standard Oil Company of Ohio will ask stockholders at a special meeting on Dec. 22 to approve an issue of $10,138,900 of cumulative preferred stock in its first major financing in twelve years, W.T. Holliday, president, announced today.

Hardly a ripple of interest was created in this country when Japan annexed Korea thirty-three years ago last August. Certainly the wildest imagination at that time would not have dreamed that the United States would ever use military force to undo that act.

Effecting a spectacular coup that doubtless will remain long a model for parliamentary procedure of super-strategic proportions, William G. Brambam, by a simple expedient of reversing himself, scored a crushing victory yesterday.

While their minor league colleagues were going at it hammer and tongs yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker, the baseball magnates of the National and American leagues moved along with comparative serenity as they opened the first of their two-day separate annual meetings.

Although more beef will be available in the New York market this month to meet the increased demand expected to result from the education in point values, most of it will be of poorer quality than is usually sold, representatives of the meat trade said yesterday.

WITH U.S. FORCES ON BOUGAINVILLE, Nov. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- By actual count of bodies, the Japanese lost 1,096 dead in their unsuccessful battle to prevent American forces from capturing Piva Ridge in Bougainville.

ALGIERS, Dec. 1 -- The smashing British Eighth Army offensive that has now brought the Allies complete control of the ridge dominating the Sangro Valley in the coastal sector surged ahead yesterday against fiercely resisting Germans.

A donation of $27,000 from the Western Electric Company was announced yesterday by the New York Committee of the National War Fund, which is campaigning for $17,000,000 for the support of twenty-six war related agencies. The Home Insurance Company gave $15,000, the Milbank Memorial Fund, $10,000, and the Great American Group of Insurance Companies, $6,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate Finance Committee today heard a long list of witnesses, one of whom, Michael J. Quill, said that he would allow a corporation doing a $120,000,000 annual business a profit of only $25,000.

Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, called on the Boy Scouts of America to salvage waste paper "in order to keep mills running at full capacity," in a telegram, made public yesterday, to Dr. Elbert K. Fretwell, Chief Scout Executive.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in Mandarin to China and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

Herbert Jefferis Pennock, who was plain Herb Pennock in twenty-one years of American League pitching as he established himself as one of the greatest left-handers baseball has ever known, last night found himself again associated with the town where he had started his major league career and on the road to becoming a full-fledged club president, but in another league.

So many requests have come to Macmillan's for lists of books on foreign countries that a booklet has been compiled called "Books on the Countries of the World," which will be forwarded for the asking by the mail order department.

The revelation last night that President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, meeting in Cairo, had agreed that Japan must give up all territory taken "by violence and greed," is probably only the first of a series of momentous announcements.
American Machine and Metals, Inc., announced yesterday a 25-cent dividend, bringing payments this year to $1 a share, compared with 50 cents last year, which was the first payment since 1937.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (Reuter) -- Reuter tonight issued the following statement on the agency's dispatch from Lisbon yesterday morning unofficially reporting that President Roosevelt, Premier Churchill and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had completed a conference in Cairo:

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Hog pens in livestock markets throughout the Corn Belt were jammed today with grunting porkers as the record-breaking movement of swine from farms produced the greatest congestion that has been seen this year.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION IN BRITAIN, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A German freak fighter-plane, painted half silver, to match clouds, and half deep gray, to resemble the United States Thunderbolt fighter, was encountered today by Flying Fortresses over western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Ration point values on meats and on fifteen types of processed foods were reduced by the Office of Price Administration today in establishing a scale which will apply beginning Sunday through December. The reductions reflected a seasonally easier supply situation in meats, and improvement in available stocks of a variety of processed foods, OPA officials said.

The work done by the August Grand Jury of Kings County, which issued a presentment exposing crime conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, Brooklyn's "Little Harlem," was praised in a statement issued yesterday by Thomas Cradock Hughes, acting District Attorney.

The advertising world must lead the way in providing citizens with essential home-front information that will do away with the overconfidence and wishful thinking that it terms "America's No. 1 enemy," the War Advertising Council declared yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1 -- The wage and policy committee of the United Steel Workers of America adopted a proposal today to scrap the "Little Steel" formula by demanding a wage increase of 17 cents an hour, a guaranteed weekly wage and a two-year contract for 750,000 employes whose agreements are on a thirty-day basis.

The strike called yesterday by John L. Lewis' School Custodial Workers Union, Local 112, an affiliate of the United Construction Workers of the United Mine Workers of America, was an almost complete failure.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 1 -Expressing its own sentiments as well as acting in response to the public feeling aroused throughout Sweden by the arrest for deportation to Germany of 1,200 Oslo University students and professors, the Swedish Government tonight appealed to the Berlin Government for cancellation of the deportation measures and release of those arrested "in the interests of future Swedish-German relations."

ISTANBUL, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Details of a mass exodus of Rumanians fleeing the Crimea, Odessa and Bessarabia in the face of the Red Army's onslaught in southern Russia have been brought here by travelers from Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, announced today creation of a consumer advisory committee to study the effect of OPA policies and regulations on households.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Complaints made in New York yesterday by United States exporters -- particularly of oils and fats -- that markets in Egypt, the Near East and Africa were being reserved for their British competitors were answered today by sources here close to the Combined Agency for Middle East Supply, which has jurisdiction in this matter.

A contest for plans to stimulate post-war employment in this country, in which the prizes will total $50,000 in war bonds, was announced yesterday by George V. Denny Jr., moderator of "America's Town Meeting of the Air," who will supervise the project.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation's profit for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, after provision for taxes, depreciation and reserves, was $4,115,550, G.W. Mason, president, reported today to stockholders. This compared with $3,828,355 earned in the previous twelve-month period and is equivalent to 96 cents a share on the outstanding stock.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation has filled 225 full-time plant jobs with 450 high school boys 16 and 17 years old who attend school during the day and build P-39 Airacobras three evenings each week. They are paired, one working the first three evenings of the week and the other working the last three.

At the annual meeting of the Institute of Life Insurance, held yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Frank Tripp, general manager of the Gannett newspapers, urged business and industry to tackle the job of public relations with courage, persistency and the determination to let the people have the truth, because "there never was a time when there wasn't plenty of public opinion waiting to be reasoned with.
