WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- President Roosevelt expects of the future a day of glory which can be set aside to honor the men of the American armed forces more fittingly than the anniversary of Pearl Harbor, a day of disaster stemming from "infamy."
PEARL HARBOR Dec. 1 -- Our total casualties among assault forces in the Gilberts occupation numbered 3,772 men.

Fifty-five Germans who had openly expressed their hostility to the United States and the Allied war program were rounded up as dangerous alien enemies in this area last month, according to an announcement yesterday by E. E. Conroy, special agent in charge of Federal Bureau of Investigation offices here.

Your correspondent, Herbert L. Matthews, in a dispatch from Naples, published in THE TIMES of Nov. 21 and dealing with the present position of Signor Rodino, has this to say: "Thus Signor Rodino, like all the other political leaders, comes around to a regency.

Terms upon which Negro voters will support a candidate for President next year were announced yesterday by representatives of twenty-five Negro organizations made public by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

Attending his first meeting of the Board of Education, Anthony Campagna, new member from the Bronx, promised that he would attempt to apply "common sense" and "business principles" to his new job. In an interview at his office in board headquarters, Mr. Campagna expressed pleasure over his appointment and promised to give as much time as was necessary to the post.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The dramatic meeting of the Pacific Big Three was hailed in Washington today as a turning point in the war which timed intensification of the drive against Japan with the faster ticking of Germany's clock of doom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Congress should see to it that the Government-financed housing program carried on as a war measure be discontinued at the end of the war and that the Government in future would undertake no housing activities which would compete with private builders, Eric Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, told the House Public Buildings and Grounds Committee on Post-War Construction today.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The stock markets have remained quiet today but were more cheerful than they have been recently. Gilt-edged stocks were unaffected by the day's distribution of 33,000,000 of interest on the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan.

ALGIERS, Dec. 1 -- Four weeks in Russia this summer as a member of an official mission composed of high Allied medical officers convinced Col. Elliott C. Cutler, chief consulting surgeon of the European Theatre of Operations that propaganda about the U.S.S.R. has been "all wet" and "will not lead to the right cooperation with your chief ally," he said here this morning.

The Chicago Western Indiana Railroad Company has called for redemption on March 1, 1944, for the sinking fund $356,000 of its first and refunding mortgage 4 1/4 per cent Series D bonds due on Sept. 1, 1962.
Reports that the American Distilling Company's plan for a whisky dividend might be revised sent its stock into a spirited advance yesterday. It gained 10 points and closed at 104 1/2.
Our only boy, George, was lost in bombing operations over Germany. May I, in this letter to your paper, thank the people of New York for their kindness, which is a bright spot in our loss.

Athletics as usual seemed to be the keynote of the first series of meetings among representatives of approximately fifty Eastern colleges which opened yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel under the aegis of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics. The sessions will end today.

Mrs. Jacob A. Riis will give a cocktail party at her home, 133 East Seventieth Street, on Saturday for members of the committee arranging the theatre party for the benefit of the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement on Dec. 10 at "The Voice of the Turtle" at the Morosco Theatre.
ALGIERS, Dec. 1 -- A communique:

From data filed by all of the 130 distillers, rectifiers, importers and distributors in the State, the State Liquor Authority began yesterday to make an analysis of the flow of liquor during the first ten months of this year from the industry's top level toward the consumer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate, which yesterday excluded Government employes and other civilians assigned to war posts overseas from the benefits of the servicemen's absentee voting bill, voted 52-21 today to include persons serving with the American Red Cross, the Society of Friends, the Women's Auxiliary Ferry Service, the Women's Air Force Service Pilots and United Service Organizations outside the United States and attached to and serving with American armed forces.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- Virtually every major martial figure from the United States, Great Britain and China foregathered here during the Allied conferences. Although the exact make-up of the talks never was revealed to the news-hungry population, some idea of the identity of the delegates was given from time to time by occasional brief public appearances of personalities who had hitherto been seen only in photographs and on the screen.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- It has been suggested that all dispatches reporting the historic Allied conferences be datelined: "Department of Utter Confusion, Somewhere Overseas."

James W. Johnson was sworn in yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox as Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York District, at the collector's offices, 110 East Forty-fifth Street. A former assistant to Joseph T. Higgins, who resigned to run for judicial office, Mr. Johnson was nominated for the post by President Roosevelt and confirmed by the Senate on Oct. 27.

Both the Detroit Edison Company and the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company now face a combined levy of about $2,900,000 on their 1943 incomes as a result of the 10 and 20 per cent excise tax on utilities adopted on Tuesday night by the Common Council of the city of Detroit.

Judge John M. Woolsey will retire from the bench of the United States District Court for the Southern New York District on Dec. 31, it became known yesterday. Although in his profession he is noted as an expert on admiralty law, he is best known to the public for his decision, in 1933, that a copy of James Joyce's book "Ulysses" was entitled to pass through the customs into the United States.

The proposal for a United Nations Bank for Reconstruction recently outlined by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau is "defective" in that it fails to recognize the primary function of a banking institution, Wilbert Ward, vice president of the National City Bank of New York, asserted yesterday.

Justice Peter M. Daly in Queens County Supreme Court decided yesterday, in what was understood to have been one of the first decisions on the application of the Soldiers and Sailors Civil Relief Act of 1940, that Reginald R. Litke of 61-14 Eighty-fourth Street, Elmhurst, was entitled to make gradual liquidations of his mortgage arrears at the rate of $5 a month.

Stocks of oil products along the Eastern Seaboard were virtually unchanged last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's index covering gasoline supplies stood at 40.4 at the end of the period, against 39.5 a week earlier.

The police were put on the trail yesterday of a man who disappeared from Pennsylvania Station last Friday with a tomcat and his wife's luggage, leaving behind a second cat and a wife so hysterical that she distributed an estimated total $1,500 to fortunate travelers that came her way.

FOR the better part of his life Heinie Brock has been completely at home on water -either in its natural liquid state or in that frozen condition of same which is known as ice. Heinie is the droll little fellow who produces great guffaws of laughter at the Ice Follies with a zoot suit comedy act, one of the smash hits of the current Madison Square Garden show.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A joint British Air Ministry and European Theatre of Operations, United States Army communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A declaration that the War Department was guilty of a slur on the courage of American soldiers who were taken prisoner in the Philippine, Wake and Guam islands was made before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today by Senator Dennis Chavez of New Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Director Elmer Davis of the Office of War Information was reported tonight to have sent a note of protest to Brendan Bracken, British Minister of Information, over the premature publication by Reuter, British news agency, yesterday of the Cairo meeting of United Nations leaders.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

One of the blood-red threads in the tragic tapestry of this generation's history runs to Manchuria in September, 1931. It was in that month, with the arrogance and duplicity with which Americans have since become better acquainted, that the Japanese took Manchuria.
Not all the drama aboard the Gripsholm as she docked yesterday was of war. Battlefronts slid into the background for a moment as the stork took over.

A goal by Lou Seitz of Grover Cleveland High School enabled his team to beat James Monroe for the soccer championship of the P.S.A.L. yesterday. The game, played at Monroe Field, resulted in a 1 to 0 triumph for the visitors, who brought to an end the three-year reign of the Monroe kickers as champions of the league.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins, Cleveland Negro ranked by the National Boxing Association as the country's top active heavyweight, received a ten-round decision over Lee Q. Murray of South Norwalk, Conn., at the Arena tonight. Bivins weighed 187 1/4 pounds to an even 200 for Murray.

Praising Wendell L. Willkie for his outstanding contribution in the fight against isolationism, Thomas W. Lamont, head of J.P. Morgan Co. Inc., yesterday called upon the 1940 Republican Presidential nominee to do a similar "job" on "current vital domestic issues," which, according to Mr. Lamont, the Republicans "seem to be leaving largely to the Democrats."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- A German submarine torpedoed and sank a medium-size Norwegian merchantman in the South Atlantic late in October and took the third mate prisoner, a woman survivor reported upon arrival here.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Dec. 2 -- American light naval craft shelled Gasmata, New Britain, and Madang, New Guinea, during the night and dawn hours of Nov. 29 and 30. It was the first sea bombardment of these enemy strongholds.

With early Christmas shopping a major factor November sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores set a new high record for the month, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. An average increase of 17.5 per cent was shown over November, 1942.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Defying the State, the anthracite industry and the United Mine Workers of America, hard coal bootleggers of southeastern Pennsylvania continued their operations almost without exception today following the passing of the deadline at midnight for the cessation of their illegal activities.

Always to be counted upon for novelties in the entertainment field, Billy Rose is introducing "Carmen Jones" this evening at the Broadway. Dipping into the treasure trove of grand opera, Oscar Hammerstein 2d has modernized the story of "Carmen" and supplied the lyrics for an all-Negro company of 115.

Recovery tendencies become more general yesterday in the stock market as the list showed its first over-all advance in a week. Strength was manifest from the start when the best enlargements of the session appeared, and, although a tapering of interest later shaded some of the gains, the average improvement remained just above a point.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company was ordered today by Judge William H. Kirkpatrick in United States District Court to pay $1,710,979 to bondholders and creditors on 1943 interest accounts.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The United States Tenth Army Air Force struck its mightiest blows in the China-Burma-India theatre when two heavy-bomber formations, each made up of more than fifty B-24 Liberators, pounded Rangoon during the week-end, dropping a total of approximately 250 tons of bombs.

Anatole Kitain, Russian pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall which was warmly received by an audience of good size. Mr. Kitain's playing had power and delicacy. When powerful his tone was brutal and edgy. When delicate the sounds produced were often pleasing.

Foster home day-care or government-sponsored day nurseries for children under two years old were acknowledged yesterday by State child-care agencies as the only ways to provide care for the young babies of mothers who have to work.

As social adviser to the City of Budapest after the first World War I was in charge of directing the distribution of American supplies among middleclass people. I never was in greater difficulty than when I had to select from among so many needy families the most meritorious, because all marshaled special influence.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 3 -- Allied bombers attacked Berlin again last night and thirty were shot down, a Nazi radio broadcast said today, indicating that another heavy Royal Air Force blow had been directed against the German capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An unusual Presidential candidacy was announced today by Representative Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois, who said he would seek the Republican nomination "in open convention" without entering State primaries. He said he would be neither a "stalking horse" nor a "favorite son."

The explanation of the British-American division of markets for fats and oils issued in Washington on Wednesday by "sources close to the Combined Agency for Middle East Supplies," while "equivocal and misleading," is at least quasi-official and serves to shed some additional light on the so-called "joint-area" trading agreements between the two Governments now in force, H.I. Malatzky, director of Himala International, declared yesterday.

A direct mail order and local advertising campaign marking the opening of the Consumer Purchase Club by Franklin Square National Bank, Franklin Square, L.I., has been initiated, stressing the aim of the club as an anti-inflation stop gap, and pointing out that the adoption of a similar plan by the nation's banks would serve to create employment for 20,000,000 workers in the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Secretary Morgenthau denounced tonight as "a potential waste of Government funds" the Senate-approved plan to spend up to $15,000,000 a year for war bond advertising in small newspapers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 -- A broadcast over the Free Yugoslav radio announced today that in a series of battles that had taken place in November in Slovenia near the enemy's fortified places of Catez, Kicma, Jelova, Gora and Ajdovac, the enemy had lost 1,200 dead and more than twice that number in wounded.

" Love Letter from an Impossible Land," by Lieut. William Meredith, is the first manuscript to be chosen by Archibald MacLeish in his new capacity as editor of the Yale Series of Younger Poets. Lieutenant Meredith, a Princeton graduate of 1940, received his commission in naval aviation early last year and has been serving since as a pilot in the Aleutians, where he wrote a group of poems in this collection.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Living costs may be expected to rise 10 per cent if Congress abolishes food subsidies, Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, predicted today to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- By a vote of 4 to 2, the Court of Appeals refused today to enjoin the building in the post-war period, of Stuyvesant Town, the eighteen-block "walled city" planned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on Manhattan's lower East Side

Farmer opposition to food subsidies was explained and justified by Albert S. Goss, master of the National Grange, in an address yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street.

While indications point to some easing of the metals situation, the toy industry is facing further restrictions on wood and paper on which it has relied this year for the bulk of its volume, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Malpractices involving the health and comfort of claimants for compensation under the Workmen's Compensation Law besides the diversion of funds through "kick-backs" were revealed at yesterday's session of th Moreland Act inquiry in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, suggested to the automobile industry today that it begin planning for aviation expansion, stating that "we are moving with lightning rapidity toward becoming a land of three dimensions."

BALBOA, C.Z., Dec. 2 -- A medium-sized Liberty ship and a small tanker torpedoed in the Caribbean subsequent to the sinking of the Colombia schooner Ruby were attacked at night without warning, according to additional information released here today by headquarters of the Fifteenth Naval District.

The season's first performance of Wagner's "Die Walkuere" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House was decidedly uneven vocally. But the orchestral support provided under the skilled leadership of George Szell, who had not conducted the work here previously, was so distinguished that it never failed to grip the attention, even when the singing on stage reached its weakest moments.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- More than 3,500 members of the International Association of Machinists, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, stayed away from their jobs at the four Henry J. Kaiser shipyards at near-by Richmond today to attend a union meeting held to act on a jurisdictional dispute with the AFL International Union of Operating Engineers.

The Gripsholm completed her second round voyage as exchange ship on the day set for it. She has a right to be proud of herself. On the east and west voyage she shares only with her Japanese counterpart, the Teia Maru, the freedom of the seas, though she has to advertise her diplomatic immunity extensively on her exterior.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States and Great Britain are still far apart on some features of the proposed world stabilization plan, according to Harry D. White, the Treasury's director of monetary research, who has represented the United States in the negotiations.

The ten-day-aid program of joint action by the Office of Price Administration and the State Liquor Authority against the retail black market in liquor has virtually collapsed, it was learned last night as delegates began arriving here for the fifteen-State conference of Federal and State officials on liquor controls that is to start this morning at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- United States Army casualties from the beginning of the war to Nov. 15 reached the total of 94,918, including 14,321 killed in action and 1,610 who died in enemy prison camps, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson reported today.

An all-woman jury, the first in Brooklyn Supreme Court, returned a verdict of $4,000 yesterday in favor of Charles Bailey, 50 years old, of 1039 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, in his suit against two defendants, Crane's, Inc., and the Wagner Whirler Derrick Corporation.

" There's always more where that came from" is an Americanism that has fallen into disuse after two years of war. In most cases, there is not any more where that came from -- whether "that" happens to be an elastic girdle, a gallon of gas or a piece of common-place business equipment -- and probably won't be for the duration.

The successful occupation of the Gilbert group of islands in the Central Pacific represents a tactical action of which Americans have every right to be proud. Aware of the heavy cost of amphibious warfare, the American command showed high wisdom in amassing a terrific preponderance of force.

Generally speaking, road business has been exceptionally good this season. Take the case of "Blossom Time," Through the years this musical favorite, based on Franz Schubert's romances and music, has been gaining its own particular set of adherents.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 3 -- Exchange Telegraph, a British news agency, reported yesterday in a dispatch from Istanbul quoting Ankara reports that President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin are conferring in Tabriz, Iran, and drawing up an ultimatum to Germany to surrender unconditionally or be destroyed by Allied bombers.

Importation of fifty-nine commodities or groups of commodities will be permitted by the Venezuelan Government without the requirement of import permits, according to information received from that country yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

Yesterday our neighbor, The Sun, printed a dispatch from Gault MacGowan describing the Thanksgiving Day dinner and after-dinner at Mr. Roosevelt's quarters in Cairo. The Associated Press reported the bill of fare. From shrimp cocktail to pumpkin pie it is a perfect symphony for the last Thursday in November.

LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Bank of England reported today an increase in note circulation for the week ended yesterday amounting to 11,777,000, which established a new high record of 1,030,824,000. This total comes within 20,000,000 of the authorized fiduciary note issue of 1,050,000,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- How a New York City bakery shop and bookstore were used in the transmission of information on America's war weapons to Germany was described today by Paul Grohs, a Government witness, in the trial of four men on espionage charges before Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney.

LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- German propagandists galloped in all directions today seeking to counteract the effect of the North African conference, describing it both as an empty bluff and as a prelude to a war of nerves.

Any expectations of an early peace in Europe which were held in the financial district, passed yesterday into the background and the stock market extended its recovery, gains of fractions to a point and more matching those of Wednesday.

A former White House correspondent who is handling Mr. Roosevelt's press relations then spoke of the President's trip. There was a sudden hush when he quietly stated that not only the President but the Army and Navy staffs were here.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 -- Since overall price control was established in Canada two years ago yesterday the cost of living has increased only 3.3 per cent, contrasting well with a 14.6 per cent increase during the first two years of the war and a 33 per cent increase during the second two years of the last war.
Stanley T. Stanley has become associated with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane as an account executive in the uptown office.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- More than 17,670 tons of high explosive and incendiary bombs were dropped on targets in Germany and occupied Europe by American airplanes in November, a monthly record that will be eclipsed by several thousand tons in the next few months, in the opinion of the American Air Command.

H. Donald Campbell, president of the Chase National Bank, announced yesterday that the executive committee of the board of directors had voted to increase the supplemental compensation now paid to the bank's employes. The present rate is 5.2 to 6 per cent on the first $3,000 of individual annual salaries that do not exceed $6,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- What has been called the "compromise" or "modified" plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad was urged by the road itself in a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The Alleghany Corporation, which owns a controlling interest, on the other hand filed a brief in support of the plan submitted on Sept. 27, last.

Each day since the war began two sisters, Miss Catherine Boesl, who will be 83 years old today, and Mrs. Anna Bellmer, 80 last July, went to St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, 225 Jerome Street, Brooklyn, to pray for an early end to the conflict. Of German descent, they were unhappy that their relatives in Germany were in arms against this country.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Sprint races took up nearly the entire program at the Fair Grounds today, the featured Franklin Purse drawing such a large entry that the race was run in two divisions. Favorites accounted for both ends.

Following two hard hours of work at the Polo Grounds yesterday morning, Steve Owen, Giants' coach, announced his starting backfield for Sunday's game against the Redskins, one the Giants must win to stay in the running for the Eastern championship.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 -- Preparations were under way today to accelerate the Asiatic campaign against the sprawling Japanese Empire by coordinating the separate Allied commands stretching half way across the world. While the European theatre remains far and away first on the United Nations' military priority list pressure will gradually be brought to bear against the Japanese.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 2 -- The Japanese are making isolated air attacks against our newly won bases in the Gilbert Islands and we are continuing our air attacks on the Marshalls, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, said in a press release issued this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The prospects of a tax bill being enacted before Christmas were dimmed today with the injection of the fight over Federal taxes on oleomargarine into the Senate Finance Committee hearings on the measure.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The Court of Appeals in a long opinion by Chief Judge Lehman decided unanimously that Inspector Camille C. Pierne and Lieut. Terence J. Harvey, New York City policemen, were automatically retired from duty when they had served more than twenty-five years and no charges were pending against them.

The economic situation in the United States is showing three significant and related trends, according to the National City Bank in the current issue of its monthly review. These are the "growing number of cutbacks in the war production program, the tendency of supplies of many basic materials to outrun war needs and, finally, the reduction in the Treasury deficit compared with earlier estimates and, therefore a slower rate of increase in inflationary pressures."

Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt Di Cicco, daughter of the late Reginald C. Vanderbilt and now the wife of Lieut. Pasquale Di Cicco, United States Air Forces and former Hollywood actor's agent, will have to get along on $89,250, between Jan. 1 and Feb. 21, 1945, when she will be 21 years old and entitled to receive her estate of approximately $5,000,000.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 2 (AP) -- China, welcoming Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek home from Cairo, rejoiced today over the three-power pledge to crush Japan and restore all Chinese territory lost in half a century of struggle with the Japanese.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners announced today that the Atlantic City Electric Company, which serves a large area of Southern New Jersey, had agreed voluntarily to reduce the book value of the original costs of its plants and equipment by $4,339,000. The board said the company has been carrying $49,000,000 as the original costs.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- The Chinese underground smuggled Lieut. Tom Harmon, former Michigan football star, through hundreds of miles of Japanese-infested territory to safety after the young pilot bailed out of a flaming fighter plane, it was revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said at his press conference today that the restoration promised by the Cairo Conference to China of all territory wrested from her by Japan, including Formosa and Manchuria, would have universal approval except by the Axis nations.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed an increase of $83,205, in holdings of the United States Government securities, to a new high record. Note circulation for the whole system showed an increase of $211,512.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Dec. 3 -- Attacking increased Japanese shipping off New Ireland, United States planes scored direct hits on two destroyers, set a large tanker aflame and sank a big transport.

More than 300 humorous cartoons on the subject of wartime conservation were placed on exhibition yesterday afternoon at the galleries of the American Society of Fine Arts, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Sponsored by the Office of War Information and the War Production Board, in cooperation with the American Society of Magazine Cartoonists, the exhibit includes work of leading cartoonists from all sections of the country.

Addressing the convention of directors at the general meeting of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore, Prof. Philip O. Badger of New York University, National Collegiate Athletic Association president, declared that at those colleges where there were naval trainees sports had been successful and were progressing, but that information had been gleaned that the Army would not relax its rule against intercollegiate competition for its specialized trainees.

Private capital rather than Government's should rebuild the post-war world, according to a statement yesterday by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange. The financial leader, formerly president of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced that the Exchange already had done preliminary research on a plan for mobilizing private capital for the task which will face it when the war has been won.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- The Ohio Public Service Company, part of the Cities Service Company holding system, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a plan to purchase from the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York all the outstanding common stock of the Marion-Reserve Power Company, consisting of 330,000 $5 par value shares, for $2,550,000 in cash. The price would advance $10,000 a month after May 1, 1944, the plan stated.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- "The greatest lesson to come out of this war is the value of power," Premier Jan Christiaan Smuts said in a speech here Nov. 25. "Peace unbacked by power remains a dream. Freedom and democracy to be gained and retained in the world must be believed to be supported by leadership and power."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 2 -- In anticipation of new Allied air attacks, the major part of the Reich administrative machinery is now being moved from Berlin to Lower Silesia, where it will be distributed among various localities, with Breslau as the center, according to information received here today.

The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee has unanimously approved a resolution supporting a wage increase of 8 cents an hour for 1,100,000 non-operating railroad workers. For Congress to pass this resolution would be a political and economic mistake of the first order.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Thomas W. Lamont, justly praising Wendell L. Willkie for the leading part he played in driving the Republican party from isolationism to Mackinac, has urged that Mr. Willkie now proceed to formulate definite and constructive programs to correct acts and policies for which the President and the New Deal have been widely assailed.

A capital outlay budget of $55,568,188 for 1944 was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board increased by $5,561,705 the total of $50,006,483 recommended by the City Planning Commission and moved to expedite completion of the huge new municipal airport in the Idlewild section of Queens by adding $12,654,000 to the allowance made for that project by the city's official planning agency.

Reflecting a scarcity of contracts, prices in the cotton futures market recovered yesterday as much as 85 cents a bale. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, the list of active old-type deliveries had registered advances of 14 to 17 points over previous finals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Following is an Office of War Information paraphase of the cable sent Nov. 30 by Elmer Davis, OWI Director, to Brendan Bracken, British Minister of Information:

ALGIERS, Dec. 2 -- A week after crossing the Sangro River, Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's Allied Eighth Army has smashed the main German defense line near the Adriatic, captured Rocca San Giovanni, is hammering at the outskirts of Casoli and Castelfrentano and has the German Army in "full retreat," according to a special communique issued by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 3 -- A large force of heavy British bombers crossed the east coast heading for the Continent as darkness fell last night. Later it was reported that the long-wave transmitters of the German news agency went off the air at 7:14 P. M., indicating an attack in the vicinity of Berlin where these transmitters are supposed to be situated.

The Iranian Institute, 9 East Eighty-ninth Street, will hold an "Artists' Evening" of informal discussion tomorrow at 8 P. M. Among those who will participate are Marc Chagall, Leon Dabo, Eric Isenburger, Nicolai Cikovsky, Georgia O'Keeffe, Mane-Katz, Arbit Blatas, Ossip Zadkine, James Lechay, Kurt Seligmann, Fernand Leger, Eugene Higgins, Milton Avery, Wallace Putnam and Wanda Gag.

Consolidated net income of the Greyhound Corporation for the first nine months of 1943 was $8,546,144 after all charges and taxes, according to the report announced yesterday. This is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.02 a share of common stock on an average of 2,784,353 shares outstanding during the period.

WITH ALLIED FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 1 (Delayed) -- It is slow, hard going in the hills north of Venafro, where the American force is slogging its way from hill to hill, the writer learned today on a visit to the front.

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the performance of the Ice Follies last night at the Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Wartime Sustaining Fund of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Navy communique 487:

The Truman committee's airing of the "Canol" oil project has rightly been given some prominence in your columns. Unfortunately, some readers may have gathered the impression that Canada is open to criticism in connection with it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Speaking as a co-chairman of the American Jewish Conference, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that the Baldwin-Rogers resolution authorizing the establishment of a United States commission to save the Jews of Europe, was "inadequate," mainly in its failure to recommend that Palestine be opened to unrestricted Jewish immigration.
ALGIERS, Dec. 2 -- Today's communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- The constitutionality of Lieut. Gen John L. DeWitt's orders evacuating all persons of Japanese ancestry from West Coast military areas was upheld today by the Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in a case on which the Western judges had queried the Supreme Court before acting.

No matter what the motives of their proponents, either the Bankhead Bill, recently passed by the Senate, or the related Cannon Bill, now before the House of Representatives, would be vicious and dangerous in its effects, the War Advertising Council asserted last night.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The firmer tone manifested yesterday by the stock markets here was noticeable again today. Attention swiftly turned to Chinese bonds as a result of the decision reached in the three-power conference to compel Japan to restore the territories taken from China.

A solemn mass of requiem for Col. James Gardiner Conroy, who was killed on Nov. 21 while leading the 165th Infantry Regiment, the "Fighting Sixty-ninth" of the First World War, in the assault on Makin atoll in the Gilbert Islands, was celebrated yesterday morning in St Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Joseph M. Egan, Army chaplain, formerly attached to the Sixty-ninth Regiment.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Setay Company, Inc., New York, was exempted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission from certain provisions of the Investment Company Act of 1940 for a series of stock transactions. These are:

" A Young Man's Fancy," an English-made satire, starring Anna Lee, will have its local premiere this morning at the World. Directed by Robert Stevenson and produced by Michael Balcon, the picture, which is set in London and Paris in 1870, features Griffith Jones, Seymour Hicks and Felix Aylmer.

Mayor La Guardia took issue anew yesterday with the city's newspapers on their coverage of municipal affairs and, offering virtually unstinting praise of radio as a medium of news dissemination, contended that more people found it easier to grasp the spoken word then the written word.

After a week's lapse because of the Thanksgiving holiday, the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League resumed play last night with the Princeton Club continuing to show the way. This time the Tigers were extended by the University Club and had to come from behind to win, 3 to 2, on the losers' courts.

The luncheon hour in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel was transformed yesterday into a festive Christmas party. Tiny youngsters with rosy cheeks and shining eyes voiced the yuletide spirit; Santa Claus with an enormous pack on his back contributed the final touch of realism.

Isidor H. Herk, 60 years old, of 601 West 113th Street, theatrical producer, who was found guilty with two others a year ago today, by a General Sessions jury of having given indecent performances of the show "Wine, Women and Song," at the Ambassador Theatre in West Forty-ninth Street, began yesterday to serve the six-month workhouse term Judge Owen W. Bohan imposed on him.

Your editorial of Nov. 26, "Subsidies: Two Kinds," was excellent and deserves careful study by everyone concerned with the current controversy. But I am still uncertain which way subsidies are to be used, if voted. That is n important question.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An assertion that the country's educational system had lost in two years, because of students taking war jobs, more than had been built up in fifteen years was made today by Dr. Donald Dushane of the National Education Association before the Senate subcommittee investigating juvenile delinquency.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- A formal demand for an immediate and complete investigation into the Hague political organization's "persistent suppression of civil rights in Jersey City and Hudson County" by the Department of Justice has been made to United States Attorney General Francis J. Biddle by the City Affairs Committee of Jersey City, it was announced today.

NAPLES, Dec. 2 -- Both the Army and the Navy are beating records for gross tonnage turned around in this port, an officer told correspondents today in describing the work of his organization. This feat is all the more notable when it is considered that before the Allies entered on Oct. 1, the Germans had accomplished a work of port destruction unequaled in history.

A clean white tablecloth came nearer causing an emotional breakdown on the part of repatriates bound for America on board the exchange ship Gripsholm than anything else on that joyous homeward voyage.
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow.

Participation by the United States in a world organization open to all nations that subscribe to the principle of judicial settlement of all disputes and agree to cooperate in putting down any nation that resorts to force was advocated yesterday in a statement issued by the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- War Information Director Elmer Davis said tonight he has protested to British Information Chief Brendan Bracken that premature publication by Reuter news agency of the Roosevelt-Churchill-Chiang conference was "a flagrant and possibly dangerous breach of the basic rules of security."

The camera photo finish as New York racegoers have known it for years will be replaced in 1944, according to plans being considered by the managers of the five New York State race tracks. This does not mean that the photo finish is to be abolished.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2 -- The United Steel Workers of America reaffirmed its "no strike" pledge today after completing the adoption of a wage policy report which included a demand for an increase of 17 cents an hour.

Determination of the mandamus against the OPA asked by fourteen branded hosiery manufacturers in objecting to the provisions of MPR 339 was adjourned yesterday for thirty days by the Emergency Court of Appeals in session at the United States court house here.

Mayor La Guardia's task of finding money within the 1943-44 budget to finance a general "cost of living" pay rise for city employes was made more complicated yesterday when the Board of Estimate dipped into the wage and salary accrual fund for $840,154 needed to supply city departments with fuel, acting on a recommendation of budget director Thomas J. Patterson.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 -- At a secret meeting of the Lebanese Parliament yesterday it was voted that the Lebanese flag -- red, white and red, with the cedar, symbol of the country from biblical times, in the center -- become the sole recognized flag of the land.
The extreme difficulties of landing on a strongly defended beach -- long a textbook axiom -- have now been personally experienced by Americans at Salerno and Tarawa.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2 -- A vigorous drive to extirpate the last traces of anything that even distantly resembles Communism from Argentine universities and schools has been announced by the Minister of Public Instruction, Dr. Gustavo Martinez Zuviria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- More and better radio time for the broadcasting of labor programs was urged at today's hearing on the Wheeler-White Radio Bill by Len De Caux, Publicity Director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -Hogs glutted the market today as fresh receipts of 20,000 head were unloaded here. Virtually the entire new shipment remained unsold. Packing houses which have been slaughtering to capacity were unable to absorb the offerings and the War Food Administration issued warnings to producers to hold stocks on farms until supplies were cleared.

Railroads in the post-war era could increase passenger travel by 500 per cent if they have the foresight to develop mass patronage by building cheaper, faster and more comfortable trains, according to Edward G. Budd, president of the Budd Manufacturing Company, Philadelphia, makers of railway equipment.

ALGIERS, Dec. 2 -- On the completion of its first six months tomorrow, the French Committee of National Liberation will be on the verge of making another strong move in line with its policy of cleaning up the Vichyites in North Africa before moving on to France.

It is more than forty-one years since young Jan Smuts went with other Boer leaders to Vereeniging to terminate a three-year war against the British Empired. Smuts came hard-bitten from a campaign in the Cape Colony but he had the sense to know that fighting had failed and that statesmanship must take over.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Maureen O'Sullivan, who has been off the screen for more than two years, will resume her role as Tarzan's mate, with Johnny Weissmuller, in the series produced by Sol Lesser for RKO. The first of the new group will be "Tarzan and the Amazons," which Kurt Neuman direct.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Battling in the year's worst fighting weather, Gen. Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's Soviet forces captured more than eighty towns and villages northwest of Gomel yesterday in their drive on Zhlobin, while other Russian troops smashed within six miles of the vital junction of Znamenka, southwest of Kremenchug.

Corporation executives were warned yesterday by A. Chauncey Newlin, member White Case, attorneys, that unless provisions of the pension plans that they have set up are broadened to conform to Federal tax standards, they will forfeit the right to tax reductions to which they are entitled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index markets for the last week of November remained unchanged at 102.6 per cent of the 1926 average. Quotations for certain foods were slightly higher, while price changes in farm product markets were mixed, with some weakness in the livestock markets.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 2 -- Ten Democratic Senators joined thirty-two Republicans in the Senate today to write into the service men's absentee voting bill an amendment to forbid political propaganda among the armed forces by officers and employes of the Government (including the Army and Navy) unless equal printed space or broadcasting time is made available to both sides in the campaigns for the election of the President, Vice President and the Seventy-ninth Congress.
MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Four fast goals in the dying moments broke up a closely fought National Hockey League game tonight and gave the Canadiens a 6 -- 2 victory over Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - Department store sales last week increased 13 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, raising the weekly index to 188, as compared with 166 on Nov. 28, 1942.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa and War Cabinet member, has suggested that Britain strengthen her position in western Europe lest she become a weak and unequal partner in the "great trinity of powers" -- Britain, the United States and Russia.
TORONTO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs tied Chicago for second place in the National Hockey League tonight by rallying for four goals in the third period to shade Detroit, 6 -- 5, before 9,484 fans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Secretary Stimson said today that the War Department had already conducted a "thorough investigation" of circumstances under which a number of Army contracts had been granted to companies in which Hans Wilhem Rohl, Los Angeles contractor, had been interested.

As the debarkation of the 1,223 Americans who were repatriated from Japanese internment camps on the diplomatic exchange liner Gripsholm was completed yesterday it became known that thirty of them had been taken by a Navy tug to Ellis Island for further questioning by Army and Navy intelligence officers and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

A dove of peace, slightly battered and its feathers still ruffled, appeared, after a fashion, to be sitting once more atop the baseball world last night as both major and minor leaguers approached the close of their annual winter meetings in the Hotel New Yorker.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- For the first time in Britain's industrial history young men eligible for service in the armed forces are to be conscripted for work in essential war industry.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- One hundred and fifty-six law students passed the October examinations for admission to the bar, it was announced today by John Kirkland Clark, New York; Philip J. Wickser, Buffalo, and John T. DeGraff, Albany, comprising the State Board of Law Examiners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Five enemy torpedoes could not sink the 22-year-old American tanker Gulf-prince in the Gulf of Mexico last spring, but one put her out of action temporarily in the Mediterranean later on, the War Shipping Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Now that it has been disclosed that Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, took a leading part in the American-British-Chinese strategy conference in Cairo, the question of paramount interest at the War Department today was: Will General Marshall return to this country, or will he remain overseas as Commander in Chief of Allied forces in the invasion theatre?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The loss of two warships, the U.S.S. Liscome Bay, a "baby flat-top," which was the only ship lost in the Gilbert...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A third of the Army Nurse Corps will be eligible for promotion under increased grades announced today by the War Department. The corps numbers about 33,000.

IT is no accident that year in and year out the New York Giants have kept the foot in football to a greater extent than any team in the game. They have been booting field goals with such remarkable consistency that some of the customers were inclined to grumble that the Giant attack was predicated only on the trusty right leg of Ward Cuff.

Seven men accused of having operated a loosely knit but active exchange in ration coupons were rounded up late Tuesday and early yesterday. In the group were a former volunteer ration board member of the Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, fuel panel, three bank employes, a shoe salesman, a radio instructor and his former employer, who was said to possess seventy-two dozen pairs of nylon stockings.

In appointing Anthony Campagna to represent the Bronx on the Board of Education, Mayor La Guardia has filled a vacancy that has existed for the last nineteen months. In replacing Dr. Bonaschi, whose term expired in May, 1942, but who was retained on a day-to-day basis until September of this year, Mr. Campagna has an opportunity to serve the city's school system at a critical time.

The New York City banks lost excess reserves during the week ended on Wednesday, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed, and one of the principal contributing factors was the jump of $214,000,000 in money in circulation.

As the toys, books and games were loaded into the large Police Department truck yesterday afternoon, the little girls looked on. Pride, mixed with a bit of wistfulness, showed on their faces, especially when the brightly painted hobby horse and the huge stuffed doll were added to the pile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -A special study of possibilities of lifting many of the restrictions invoked in the early stages of the war to conserve materials has been undertaken by the War Production Board in the light of easing supply conditions in the copper, aluminum steel and other key markets.

Billy Rose is a little man with gigantic ideas, which at suitable intervals explode over the city like a burst of fireworks. The display last evening was one of the greatest of them all, for Billy brought to the Broadway Theatre the work called "Carmen Jones," which has the Bizet music for "Carmen," an all-Negro cast and a new version of the opera's libretto by Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

With optimistic predictions for the future development of New York as an international air transport center setting the keynote, the fourth anniversary of the opening of La Guardia Field was celebrated yesterday in the Kitty Hawk Room of the administration building at the airfield.

Directors of the Ward Baking Company, at a meeting held yesterday, increased 1943 total dividend payments on the preferred stock to $4 a share from $1.70 distributed last year, with the declaration of a year-end distribution of $1.70 a share on the issue, which is in arrears.

Football in 1943 enjoyed one of its greatest scoring seasons in twenty-two years. The annual Associated Press analysis of scoring figures, inaugurated after the 1921 season, showed yesterday that eighty-seven college teams scored 11,263 points in 666 games, an average of 16.91 points.

Navy, winner of the Lambert Trophy as football champion of the East, landed three players on the annual All-Eastern eleven selected for The Associated Press by coaches, sports writers and officials, it was made known yesterday.

Life insurance purchased from legal reserve companies in the United States will approximate $12,700,000,000 by the end of the year, an increase of 5 per cent over the volume for 1942, Col. Franklin D'Olier, president of the Prudential Insurance Company, told the Association of Life Insurance Presidents at its annual meeting yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall had exceptional significance because of Dr. Rodzinski's magnificent interpretation of Mahler's Second symphony and the appearance of Leonard Bernstein, the young assistant of the orchestra, who conducted the opening performance of the "Three Jewish Poems" of Ernest Bloch and was warmly recognized by the audience.

A large group of young women will be introduced at a dinner in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton tomorrow night in advance of the Grosvenor Debutante Ball to be held later in the ballroom of the hotel in behalf of Grosvenor Neighborhood House.
The Soviet operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:...

Indications are that more materials will be made available to the nation's railroads next year for the construction of additional equipment. In anticipation of such development, some of large equipment builders which have completed their war contracts are reconverting their plants.

Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel announced yesterday that he had invited members of the still-functioning August grand jury, which investigated conditions in Brooklyn's "little Harlem," to listen to the charge he will deliver to the December grand jury when he swears in the members of the latter body next Monday.

ALGIERS, Dec. 2 -- A strong force of Flying Fortresses of the United States Fifteenth Air Force today carried the expanding Mediterranean air offensive to new German submarine pens and related harbor installations at the French port of Marseille.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (AP) -Washington, Southern California and the College of the Pacific, leaders in the Far Western college sgridiron whirl for 1943, each placed three men on The Associated Press' nineteenth annual All-Pacific Coast football team, which was announced today.
ABOARD TRANSPORT OFF MAKIN, Gilbert Islands, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- A Japanese submarine got through our guard before dawn this morning and sank the escort carrier Liscome Bay.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Dec. 2 -- Pleasure that the Allied leaders were at last getting down to specific policies, as well as war plans for the Pacific area, was general today in Australia, whose future depends upon the eventual outcome of events in this area.

Berlin is referring to the damage from the repeated RAF bombings as "architectural changes" with grim humor, the Berlin radio said yesterday in giving for the first time the Nazis' own picture of conditions in the German capital, according to The Associated Press.

UNRRA's three weeks' session at Atlantic City, just concluded, hasn't had the dramatic aspects of a conference of heads of Governments. Under the director-generalship of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman international relief and rehabilitation is not likely to display fireworks.
The German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

George Toporcer, known as "Specs" since his sandlot baseball days, when he attended public school in New York City with Jimmy Cagney, the movie star, yesterday stepped into the Red Sox post vacated on Wednesday by Herb Pennock.

Recent discussion on the electric device for shocking fish and who originated it moved the gentleman who prefers to be known as Sparse Grey Hackle to elaborate on the contraption and its uses. He was associated with the 1939 convention of the New, York State Conservation Council, where David C. Haskell introduced the device.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The War Manpower Commission today supplied its area offices with a guide for use in formulating local standards when dry-cleaning establishments apply for designation as locally needed. The term "dry cleaner" is defined by WMC as any establishment where clothing, household furnishings or fabrics of any kind are cleaned by the dry-solvent method, pressed or otherwise processed for compensation.
Mr. and _Mrs. John T. Lawrence are at the Seigniory Club, Province of Quebec. Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- While the miner-operator conference to obtain a new coal wage contract was in recess today, Secretary Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator, charged that Southern operators, who have refused to join in the conference, were conducting a "sitdown strike" after adopting a "to-hell-with-the-Government" attitude.

Charles H. Goren and Mrs. Olive Peterson of Philadelphia won the national contract bridge mixed-pair championship yesterday in the tournament in progress at the Hotel Astor here. Their score of 523.7 match points gave them a 12 1/2-point margin over two other Philadelphians, Charles J. Solomon and Mrs. Benjamin Golder, who were second with 511.2.

An unprecedented demand for cranberries for Thanksgiving has left the market virtually bare, according to a spokesman for the War Food Administration, and there is little hope for any substantial increase for the Christmas holidays.

Legislative action to define more clearly the scope of the functions of the General Accounting Office, limiting that office's duties to giving independent verifications of transactions fully completed by administrative departments of the Government, was urged yesterday by Lloyd Morey, comptroller, University of Illinois.

Mrs. Mary Lindsay Tomlinson, 34-year-old daughter of L. Seton Lindsay, a vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company plunged to death at 8:05 A.M. yesterday along with her two sons, Michael, 8, and John, 6, from a fifteenth floor window of the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Post-war prospects for job security and opportunities are as important to women as to men, the Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission said today. It added that it recognized fully "the fact that men in the armed forces will have to have their old jobs back when they return if they want them."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Dec. 3 (UP) -- Today's communique:

Widespread failure by industry to provide protective glasses for workers is largely due to ignorance, Charles P. Tolman, describing the results of a survey, declared yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, held at the Russell Sage Foundation Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

A six-point program by which the President, members of Congress and the Cabinet would be brought into closer touch with the over-all financial operations of the Government and which would ultimately lead "to better understanding of government" was presented yesterday by E.F. Bartelt of the Bureau of Accounts of the Treasury Department at the closing session of a conference on Federal Government accounting sponsored by the American Institute of Accountants at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The brilliant, extemporaneous speech which Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Premier of South Africa, delivered privately to the Empire Parliamentary Association last week has been praised in London more for its candor than its discretion.

" In Old Oklahoma," a Republic action drama starring John Wayne and Martha Scott, will open this morning at the Globe. Directed by Al Rogell, the picture's supporting cast includes Albert Dekker, Marrie Rambeau and George (Gabby) Mayes.

The six-story elevator apartment house at 735 Ocean Avenue, corner of Beverly Road, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Weprin Glass, officers of the Fanan Holding Company, from the 735 Ocean Avenue Corporation for cash above the first mortgage of $99,500.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 4 -- Mud-spattered Red Army troops bit into the important German railway network northwest of Gomel in two directions yesterday, stood firm against repeated Nazi counter-attacks in the hotly contested Cherkassy area and ex panded their Dnieper River bridgehead below Kremenchug to twenty miles west of the city through powerfully defended territory, Moscow announced early today.

New York importers disclosed yesterday that the Mediterranean area's bumper crop of olive oil this year may go begging. They revealed that to date they had failed to win the State Department's permission to bring in some 3,000,000 gallons to ease the domestic shortage.

Flotation of the largest issue of public utility bonds since mid-August lifted the total of new bonds publicly offered here this week to $25,350,000, compared with $9,040,000 last week and $12,500,000 in the same period a year ago.

" Pearl Harbor Sunday" will be observed in the churches tomorrow. In many, Tuesday will be referred to as "Armed Forces Honor Day" as President Roosevelt has asked. In 7,000 Northern Baptist churches in the United States, tomorrow will be commemorated as the "Sunday of Sacrifice," when it is expected the larger part of a $1,500,000 World Emergency Forward Fund will be raised.

Houghton Mifflin have awarded a Life-In-America prize of $2,500 to Dixon Lecter for his book, "When Johnny Comes Marching Home," which they will publish early next year. The book, based largely on unpublished letters and diaries, is an account of the American soldier's return from three wars -- the American Revolution, the Civil War and the first World War, and of his adjustment to life after the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A story of how a man wth a plan to assassinate President Roosevelt skulked about the White House for ten days last month -- and finally was arrested for walking against a traffic light, came out today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Long shots took both divisions of the St. Bernard Purse, split feature at the Fair Grounds today. Constant Aim, paying $66.60 for $2, won the first half and This Freedom, $37.80, took the second section.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 3 (UP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Although wartime anti-Semitism and anti-Catholicism have been evident in some parts of the country, the American people, on the whole, resisted the Nazi schemes to transfer the struggle from the battlefield to the domestic front, Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, 381 Fourth Avenue, declared in his 1943 report made public yesterday.

An appeal on behalf of selectees who were sent to the Grand Central Palace Induction Center Thursday and consequently were ordered to report for duty on Dec. 23 met with a sympathetic but unavailing response yesterday from Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city director of selective service, who said these cases were out of his hands as soon as they received their physical and other examinations by Army, Navy or Marine authorities.

The notion that the helicopter will be available for general public use and enjoyment as soon as the war is over was branded as "nonsense" and harmful to the helicopter's future development, by Grover Loening, chairman of the helicopter committee of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, in an address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 2 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Baron Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey, was reported today on his way back to Ankara after a mysterious tour through the Balkans ending in a lengthy conference with Bulgarian leaders in Sofia Wednesday.

Looking forward to post-war necessity, the Palestine Lighthouse is opening a campaign to raise $100,000, Mrs. Samuel D. Friedman, president, announced yesterday. This is the first appeal to the public for funds to support the Lighthouse -- the only institution of its kind in Europe or the Near East -- since it was established eighteen years ago, she said.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- The enemy is using every trick at his command in his frantic efforts to slow the Eighth Army's Sangro offensive as it rolls along at a steady clip after cracking the German "winter line."

WITH THE ALLIED FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 2 (Delayed) -- Far down below a mass of peaks the writer today watched our bombers coming over in wave after wave at irregular intervals. They and ground artillery were punishing an obstacle that stands between the Fifth Army and Rome.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- This is the sad story of Yepifan Sakharevich Lusanoff -- a dashing Cossack, who was at heart a fowl fancier with a frustrated fancy to raise ostriches, and how he lost his horse because of that frustration.

ON THE ITALIAN FRONTIER, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Led by United States officers, a force of forty British and American escaped war prisoners, thirty Yugoslavs and hundreds of Italian partisans attacked an industrial plant at Croce di Merone in northern Italy and defeated strong German forces in a pitched battle, frontier reports said today.

A black picture of the future faced by public housing in this country after the war was painted yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Association of Housing Officials, North Atlantic Regional Council, by Charles Abrams, board member of the National Public Housing Conference, Inc., who charged that private interests intend to "scuttle" the entire program.

Recommending that the New York State banking laws be amended to provide for the closing of all banking institutions in this State on Saturdays throughout the year, the Kings County Bankers Association announced yesterday that its stand was prompted by the shortage of manpower.

Flags fly on the eighth of every month throughout Japan and its conquered territories to recall the day of the attack on Pearl Harbor, which in Japan fell on Dec. 8, according to Marvin Rothschild of 105 Buckingham Road, Brooklyn, one of the American repatriates who arrived Wednesday on the liner Gripsholm.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- The Germans are pouring thousands of reinforcements into their Yugoslav coastal defenses in preparation for an Allied Balkan invasion, which the Germans expect will follow conferences between heads of the United Nations, Yugoslav sources said tonight.

Speakers and writers of slovenly English will doubtless read with satisfaction Dr. Wilfred Funk's note in THE TIMES of Nov. 29, but I wouldn't permit him to close the dispute over "shall" and "will," as he urges.

One of the most outstanding developments of the war has been the ability of American industry not merely to become the arsenal of democracy but also to produce huge quantities of consumer goods, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance of New York University and research director of the Institute of International Finance, said yesterday at the concluding session of the annual convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- After spending six days in rewriting the Green-Lucas Service Men's Absentee Voting Bill, the Senate threw that measure aside today and passed instead, by a vote of 42 to 37, a substitute sponsored by three Southern Democrats which would put the balloting program for the armed forces back into the hands of State election officials and under State laws.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad System, has written to Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, protesting the latter's "groundless and insulting slur" on the New York Central, it was learned today.

A minimum of 200,000 women are needed for essential daytime volunteer jobs in this city, a survey of a score of home-front services revealed yesterday. Waves, Spars and Women Marines, who need women, too, have set a ceiling on enlistments in this, their largest recruiting area.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 3 -- One of the difficult points facing the Allies in dealing with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Government is the extremely intricate internal political situation in China.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of Albert E. Fagan has been transferred to Anton W. Herbek. On Dec. 13 the Exchange will consider transfer of the membership of George A. Whiteside to A. Rhett du Pont, and on Dec. 16 the transfer of that of Fairman R. Dick to J. Robert Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker opposed before the Senate Finance Committee today the increase in postal rates carried in the $2,140,000,000 tax bill passed by the House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Here is the rollcall by which the Senate voted 42 to 37 today to scrap a Federal ballot service men's vote bill by substituting a proposal retaining State control over voting qualifications of armed service members:

The report of the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation issued yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 shows a net profit of $752,025 after all charges and Federal income taxes, but before post-war adjustments, equal to $4.68 a share on 160,683 shares.

Edward R. Murrow, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent who rode in a Lancaster bomber during Thursday night's RAF attack on Berlin, reported in a broadcast from London last night that two-ton blockbuster bombs burst in the German capital "like great sun-flowers gone mad."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Small-town newspaper publishers urged the Ways and Means Committee today to approve a $30,000,000 program of Government-paid war bond advertisements over Treasury Department contentions that it would interfere with the bond sales effort and would amount to a press subsidy.

TARAWA, Nov. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Five minutes ago we wrested this strategic Gilbert Island outpost and its all-important air strip from the Japanese who seized it from a few missionaries and natives weeks after they had attacked Pearl Harbor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The first break in the retail front against present Office of Price Administration price policies appears in the latest issue of N.A.R.D. Journal, publication of the National Association of Retail Druggists. Speaking of the expected changes in the OPA's maximum price regulations the Journal states bluntly that the "outlook for adoption of this (GMPR) formula is questionable The prospect that it would work is more than questionable."

The service newspaper Stars and Stripes is in trouble with some of its front-line readers because it said in a recent editorial that the soldiers in Italy were anxious to get to Berlin before going home. One veteran writes: "When a rear echelon Johnny says those boys don't want to go home and that they don't need a rest, I think of the old saying, hell has no fury like a noncombatant."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Indications that a Senate vote would sustain food subsidies when the bill to abolish the Commodity Credit Corporation subsidies on Dec. 31 comes up for action were given today at the Senate Banking Committee hearing on the measure.

Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis yesterday issued his official statement on the ruling against the protest of the so-called rebel minor leagues, a decision that made possible the landslide reelection of William G. Bramham as boss of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues.

A request for resumption on a limited scale of the production of alcohol for beverages, halted since October, 1942, by the War Production Board, brought yesterday from Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, a statement that the Federal agency was studying "the possibility of finding a solution" to evils caused by the liquor shortage.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. S-The French Berne Legation's diplomatic pouch today carried to Vichy six individual letters of resignation -- five diplomats and a financial attache. This leaves Pierre Laval, as Minister of Foreign Affairs, with very few career men within the Foreign Service or at the Ministry.

Leonard Shure, who played last night in Town Hall, is a formidable pianist. Very few of the young artists of his generation compare with him now in point of technical resource, control of tone, and very thoughtful musicianship. Why, then, is his playing prevailingly so unsatisfactory?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Manufacture of radiator supply valves with brass may be resumed after Jan. 1, within the limits of materials available, the War Production Board announced today. The agency added that although directives that prohibit the use of brass in the manufacture of radiator valve bodies will not be withdrawn prior to Dec. 31, these directives may not be renewed when they expire on that date.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The swimming committee of the A.A.U. refused today at the opening of the convention to approve the 200-meter and 200-yard breast-stroke records of Emmett J. Cashin.

Lieut. Elisha Lee of the Yale Club fought off the strong challenge of A.G. Townsend of the Harvard Club last night to win at 15 -- 12, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 18, 15 -- 7 in the Yale Club's invitation tournament sponsored by the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Again threatening retaliation for the air war upon Germany, the Berlin radio said today that the German High Command "intends by one fell, drastic stroke to end the unbridled mass murder," and added that "mankind is not far from the point where it can at will blow up half the globe."

LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Open letters -- one of which charges the Spanish Government with outright war aid to the Germans, including assistance to U-boats -- are being circulated in Spain, demanding the resignation of Generalissimo Francisco Franco and restoration of the monarchy to save the country from grave consequences of pro-German policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- More than 1,000 four-engined bombers were among 8,789 planes turned out by aircraft factories in November, and about a dozen aircraft carriers were included in more than 250,000 standard displacement tons of naval craft completed in shipyards during the month, which set new records in war production.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, viewed as "unfortunate" the Moscow radio announcement of the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Dec. 4 -- Australian jungle troops, supported by artillery, are closing in on Wareo, a Japanese stronghold on the Huon Peninsula of northeastern New Guinea.

After an early display of moderate strength on small price-fixing orders, the cotton market weakened considerably toward the close yesterday as liquidation and hedge selling entered the ring in greater volume. At the close of dealings, the list of active old futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were at the day's lows and 8 to 12 points below Thursday's final quotations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Because of the large number of hogs waiting for slaughter, fresh receipts went unsold today and brought the number of holdovers at the close of the session to 12,000 head. The War Food Administration today gave the following summary of hog-marketing conditions in other leading livestock markets:

Dillon S. Myer, director of the War Relocation Authority, said here yesterday that he had been requested to appear before a Dies subcommittee headed by Representative John M. Costello, Democrat, of California on Monday morning in Washington.

We publish on this page today a letter from A.F. Hinrichs, the Acting Commissioner of Labor Statistics, in reply to our editorial of Nov. 23, "Buried Statistics." We are glad to notice the new summary wage table to which Mr. Hinrichs refers, and to know that such a table will hereafter appear regularly in The Monthly Labor Review.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Western Conference adopted a basketball schedule of fifty-eight games today, arranged so that teams with Navy and 1Viarine V-12 personnel would not be away from home more than 48 hours, the absentee deadline for service students.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (U) -- The author of a bitter attack on Wendell L. Willkie as a potential 1944 Presidential nominee has been invited to come here Tuesday to address a group of Republican members of Congress.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 -- On being asked today whether Mexico would send troops abroad, President Manuel Avila Camacho stated that "until now our Allies have not asked this, although such an eventuality may arise. Therefore, it is necessary that we foresee and prepare for it.

Herr Goebbels periodically puts his propaganda factory to work on dire threats of new secret weapons about to be used. He becomes especially active every time the RAF or the United States Army Air Forces strike a particularly hard blow at "Fortress Europe." One or two of the supposed secret weapons have made their appearance, like the radio-controlled bomb, the acoustic-homing torpedo and the airplane rocket gun.

Wendell L. Willkie returned yesterday from a trip of more than two weeks during which he addressed audiences in Louisiana, Texas, Colorado and Wyoming, where he also conferred with Republican leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Great Britain must continue to get a good deal of "its daily bread" from the United States after the war in Europe to enable it to throw its whole strength against Japan, Col. John J. Llewellyn, new British Minister of Food, said today at a press conference held to introduce Ben Smith, his successor as British Minister resident in Washington.

Friends of Greece, Inc., will benefit from an exhibition of Christ Child paintings, representing the work of twenty-two artists, which will be held from Dec. 11 to Dec. 24 at 52 East Fifty-seventh Street. Figures from a seventeenth century Sicilian creche brought from Europe by Stark Young and a window display by E. McKnight Kauffer will be on view.

Pepping up a winter suit or dress can be done easily with frothy neckwear, gala gilets, or crisp collar and cuff sets. A wardrobe of changes in neckwear offers the opportunity to convert an office dress into a cocktail or evening costume.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- A plan filed by the United Publice Utilities Corporation involving the sale of a subsidiary and purchase or redemption of its outstanding bonds to effect compliance with an order under the corporation simplification provisions of the Holding Company Act was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin and Gen. Douglas MacArthur have concluded a discussion of the Cairo conference decisions, and as a result Australia's war effort is to be intensified to the limit for a southwest Pacific offensive against Japan, it was announced tonight.

Col. George Creighton Webb, the only living charter member of the Empire State Society, Sons of the American Revolution, said yesterday in his museum-like apartment at 125 East Seventy-second Street that his plans for observance of his ninetieth birthday today consisted simply of working as usual on his memoirs and lunching and dining with friends and relatives.

Charges that Mayor La Guardia and members of the Board of Education were interfering with the collective bargaining rights of custodial and janitorial employes of the city's school system were filed yesterday with the State Labor Relations Board and promptly rejected by the board for lack of jurisdiction.

Collective bargaining elections at the Bronx yards of the United Boat Service Corporation at City Island and at the Passaic plant of the Botany Worsted Company, in Passaic, N.J., have been ordered by the National Labor Relations Board, Charles T. Douds, regional director, announced yesterday.
