WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- In what was described as an unprecedented action, Dr. Robert Morss Lovett, William E. Dodd Jr. and Goodwin B. Watson filed suit today to test the constitutionality of Congress' passage of a measure cutting them from the Government payrolls because of alleged communistic sympathies.

Willie Bioff, former Hollywood boss of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, was pictured yesterday as a labor leader whose "jurisdiction was with the producers," and who used strike-breaking tactics against another union, likewise affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Expressing doubt that any Democrat could win the Presidency in 1944, Senator Wheeler, Democrat of Montana predicted today that President Roosevelt will not be a candidate for re-election next year regardless of the state of the war.

In the post-war world there must be greater liberty for individual Americans and greater economic opportunities in the South and West, Governor Ellis Arnall of Georgia asserted last night in a speech at the annual meeting of the New York Southern Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

When a little boy in 3-A asked what had become of the school janitor his teacher told him that the janitor was on strike. When the little boy asked why was the janitor on strike his teacher said that the janitor was really a mine worker and had to do what John L. Lewis told him to do.

Leon Alexander, foreman of the August Kings County grand jury, turned down yesterday the invitation extended by Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel for the jury panel to be present when the judge swears in the December grand jury on Monday.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Although little business was done today on the stock markets here, the tone was firm. Chinese bonds, which gained well yesterday, wavered and closed unevenly.

James A. Farley, chairman of the industry division of the National War Fund Campaign, spoke last night at a rally and entertainment for the fund at the Golden Gate Ballroom, 142d Street and Lenox Avenue, in Harlem, and stressed to the audience of 1,500 that a large percentage of the fund's money would aid men in the armed services.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Answering "criticism from armchair strategists" who have implied that the Navy had inadequate advance intelligence on the enemy's strength on Tarawa, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared today that the tiny atoll received worse punishment than Berlin before the Marines made their costly landing.

The refusal of butchers to accept fats from housewives, when the entire nation has been urged to salvage fats for the manufacture of explosives, is the subject of an investigation started by Borough President James A. Burke of Queens.
ALGIERS, Dec. 3 -- A communique:

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 4 -- The Moscow radio announced early this morning that President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin had met in Teheran, Iran, "a few days ago" to discuss questions relating to the war and the post-war period.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The "dismissal" of Dr. Francis E. McMahon from the faculty of Notre Dame University was declared today a flagrant violation of the right of academic freedom by a group of professors of philosophy attending a meeting here.

Baseball's spectacular week of powerful palavering drew to an official close yesterday, with the major leaguers, though they had the day all to themselves for their annual joint session before Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis in the Hotel Roosevelt, again finding news of their own business matters overshadowed by extracurricular events.

The Junior Officers Canteen, maintained by the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, will be the beneficiary of a bridge to be given next Thursday at 28 East Thirty-sixth Street. Mrs. Junius S. Morgan, founder of the canteen, is honorary chairman, and Mrs. Joseph A. Bennett, chairman.

The basic seven food groups, from which we are urged to select and consume at least one item daily, supplied a guide in fashioning the menus for next week for our model household of two adults and a school-age child. Each day's meals was checked against this plan, which represents the Government's translation into laymen's language of the scientific recommendations for good nutrition made by the National Research Council.

Ken Littlefield, regional chairman of the National Ski Patrol for southern New York, eastern Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland, yesterday announced the appointment of Russell Heaton, John White, Jack Linehan, Harry Voege and Ernest Dieterle as sectional chiefs.

George C. Warren Jr., president of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission for a dozen years, told a score of Game Conservation Society members at a pheasant luncheon at Luchow's yesterday that it was up to the stay-at-homes to guard the nation's wildlife resources for the boys now in service.
ALGIERS, Dec. 3 -- The Eighth Army has captured Castelfrentano and moved up the coastal road from Fossacesia toward San Vito. [The coastal advance covered six miles, The Associated Press said.]

Michael Todd has set back the Broadway premiere of "Mexican Hayride" at the Imperial from Jan. 18 to Jan. 20. The producer also has decided to open the Cole Porter, Herbert and Dorothy Fields musical production at the Shubert Theatre in Boston on the afternoon of Christmas Day, or two days later than originally planned.

Lack of substantial interest tended yesterday to stall the recovery drive in the stock market, although final prices generally showed fractional gains, Mild selling for income tax record purposes appeared, while the reported imminence of an announcement from the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference also acted as a brake on any real display of bullishness.

The revival of Verdi's "Rigoletto" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House attracted a capacity audience. This large attendance attested to the wisdom of the management in reinstating this work in the repertoire, for its popularity has waned not at all after the nine decades since it was first presented.

A backfield that sparkles in every department and seven fast, hard-charging linemen were selected yesterday by sports writers from all parts of the nation as The United Press All-America football team.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A girl friend of an Arab sheik wears today the Christmas earrings intended for Mrs. Philip Kerker because her Army captain husband couldn't speak French fast enough.

The volume of new State and municipal financing scheduled to be done next week is $11,779,555, compared with this week's revised total of $4,418,317, according to Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average for 1943, thus far, is $15,392,506.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Buying of December and May wheat attributed to cash interests lifted prices of those deliveries today to the highest marks of the season on the Chicago Board of Trade. The December developed independent strength late in the session and showed an advance of 7/8 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Dr. Eduard Benes, Czechoslovak President, may have been a mediator between the Poles and Russians, who are not on diplomatic speaking terms, at the Roosevelt-Stalin-Churchill conferences.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -- John R. Longo, former deputy Hudson County clerk and long a political foe of Mayor Frank Hague of this city, was sentenced today by Judge Thomas H. Brown to a prison term of eighteen months to three years on a charge of "fraudulently altering" his voting record.

Despite the general ban on trading with North Africa, shipments of non-essential goods are now being received from there in this market, it was learned yesterday. Importers of briarwood for the manufacture of smoking pipes, it was disclosed, are receiving shipments, and within the last two weeks 1,407 bags, each of approximately five gross of briar blocks per bag, have been received.
Several apartment houses, business properties and small homes in the Bronx were reported yesterday to have passed into new hands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Reports that radio intelligence activities of the Federal Communications Commission had been "more a hindrance than a help" to the armed forces both before and after Pearl Harbor were brought up at today's session of the special House committee investigating the FCC.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Labor will demand shorter post-war hour standards without reductions in earnings, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told the Senate Truman committee today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission modified today its restrictions on common stock dividends of Southwestern Public Service Company to permit Southwestern to pay a 50-cent dividend except during the twelve-month period commencing last Sept. 1, during which it may pay a dividend not in excess of $1 per share.

One more practice with the full squad on hand today will complete the New York Giants' preparations for the crucial game with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds tomorrow before what may turn out to be the largest crowd of the National Football League season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Paramount has closed a deal this week with Sherman Billingsley to use his name and the title "Stork Club" for a musical based on the New York night spot. The picture, to be made next summer, will star Petty Hutton.

ALGIERS, Dec. 3 -- Yesterday's air attack on the Marseille submarine pens involved one of the greatest aerial fights in the Mediterranean area in recent weeks, it was disclosed today along with word that Liberators had renewed heavy daylight bombing attacks on Bolzano, vital link in the Brenner Pass route to Italy, only thirty miles below Brenner Pass.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 3 -- Official figures received here from Germany today stated that Rumanian oil production in 1942 was down to 5,000,000 tons -- a 40 per cent decrease from the pre-war production.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Home-canned eggplant, containing lethal bacillus botulinus due to inadequate cooking at the time of canning, was blamed today by the State and New Rochelle Health Departments for the deaths here of two persons and the illness of a third.

A total of 2,697 physicians in New York City have received extra remuneration in the form of kickbacks for referring claimants in compensation cases to X-ray and surgical appliance concerns, according to testimony given at yesterday's session of a Moreland act inquiry in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

BASEBALL men are the most indefatigable lobby-sitters in the world. Glints of unholy joy appear in their eyes at the very sight of a hotel lobby. Overstuffed chairs for sitting purposes delight them and posts for leaning purposes are sources of ineffable bliss.

A NEW one-volume edition of Samuel Gompers' "Seventy Years of Life and Labor"* comes on the market just at the time when the ghost of Gompers is walking again in American labor. The old cigar maker who founded the American Federation of Labor has been in the doghouse up in Valhalla for a decade now simply because his "pure and simple" trades unionism has been deemed out of tune with the times.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a voluntary plan for the liquidation and subsequent dissolution of the North American Gas Company holding company system by a court decree as directed by an SEC order under the corporate simplification provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 3 -- A veteran postal employe was killed instantly here early today by a Long Island Railroad train when he drove his automobile through crossing gates left open, according to the police, by a "dozing" gate attendant.

ALGIERS, Dec. 3 -- It is most likely that about the time that the French Committee of National Liberation acts on the recommendations of its "purge" commission concerning Pierre Boisson and Marcel B. Peyrouton, similar though legally distinct steps will be taken against Pierre-Etienne Flandin, former Premier, who is in Morocco and who has never appeared before the purge body.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- More than 500 Lancaster and Halifax bombers of the Royal Air Force cracked the strongest defense the Germans had yet been able to organize and hammered Berlin last night with more than 1,500 long tons of bombs in a signal victory.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The British Air Ministry, outlining today the triumphs of the Anglo-American bombers in this theatre during November, when the Allies dropped 22,170 tons of bombs on Germany and Nazi-occupied territory -- a figure that is believed to represent a record -- stressed the importance of the twin-target type of attack in the winter air war tactics.
A communique transmitted by Chungking and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Lowell Bennett Jr., 23-year-old American newspaper man on the London staff of International News Service, and Norman Stockton, a New Zealander representing the Australian Associated Newspaper Service, are reported by the Air Ministry as missing from last night's air battle over Berlin.

Now that Government war-loan accounts in commercial banks here and throughout the country have assumed such sizable proportions, the New York Clearing House has decided to show the extent of these funds in its weekly reports on deposits of its member banks.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Edward J. Flynn of New York, former chairman of the National Democratic Executive Committee, declared today that Republicans had broken a promise to maintain a political truce for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Mayor F.H. La Guardia of New York told the Pepper Investigating Committee today that he would prohibit the transmission of any racetrack information by radio, wire or newspaper and the inter-State shipment of slot machines as one means of combating juvenile deliquency.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 3 -- Patents for an explosion-proof panel board, a wheel drive for aircraft, and an unusual type of building construction stand out among 619 issued during the past week, as listed in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The War Production Board, announcing that crude rubber supplies are diminishing fast, today ordered more emphasis on the use of synthetics in the manufacture of rubber goods.

Despite denials from police and court officials that juvenile delinquency is increasing at an alarming rate, statistics from the Children's Court show a steady increase of allegedly delinquent children from month to month and year to year since 1941.

The Court of Appeals having sustained the charge that he was in contempt of the New York County grand jury for refusing to answer questions in the investigation of the State printing scandal in 1941, Sdwin H. Greenleaf, director of an Albany bank, began yesterday to serve the thirty-day workhouse term imposed on him at the time by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions.

William L. Meissel, 49 years old, for a quarter of a century an insurance broker at 20 Pine Street, was released in $15,000 bail yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions after his arrest on allegations involving him in thefts amounting thus far to approximately $220,000 from fifteen insurance companies.

Retail trade continued active here this week as Christmas shopping again expanded in volume. Because of the larger sales base this month, however, percentage increases over last year are smaller than in the like week of 1942. Estimates put department store volume this week at about 10 to 12 per cent over a year ago.

John Munro Woolsey, a Federal District Judge for the Southern District of New York since the spring of 1929, has declared his intention of retiring at the end of this year. As he retires instead of resigning, the public may not wholly lose his judicial services. They have been most distinguished.

Mrs. Marian J. Bennett, 55 years old, a widow who has a police record as a confidence woman running back eighteen years, yesterday in General Sessions was committed to the Women's House of Detention to await trial on an indictment accusing her of having perpetrated a fraud on another middle-aged widow in a so-called "$100,000,000 copper mine deal."

In making public a proposed post-war program, the National Association of Manufacturers recommended yesterday that no reparations be exacted from the defeated enemy nations for damages caused by military operations but only for non-military damages such as looting.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Mitchell bombers of the Chinese-American wing of the United States Fourteenth Air Force again have struck at Japanese shipping and installations at Swatow and Amoy harbors on the China southeast coast, while furious fighting continues at the "rice bowl" control point of Changteh, it was reported today.

Following successful tests in Chicago and Detroit, Zenith Radio Corporation is breaking page advertisements in five newspapers here over the week-end to announce the opening of two local outlets for its Radionic Hearing Aid.

While the political outlines of the post-war world are being shaped in the series of great conferences which have been held at Casablanca, at Washington, at Quebec, at Cairo, and now at Teheran, a quieter beginning is also being made in the field of post-war economic planning. One example is the organization of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, which has just concluded its first meeting.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 -- The fifty-fifth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union tonight considered a program to expand the union's general physical fitness program by organizing A.A.U. clubs in all cities of more than 3,000 and spurring intercity competition.

Four basketball games are scheduled for the New York area tonight, with New York University's inaugural contest of the season attracting considerable interest. The Violets, with an all-civilian team, will see action against the highly regarded Fort Hancock team at the N.Y.U. gymnasium.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- The largest stainless steel plane ever built is undergoing flight tests. Intended for cargo use, it was built under a Navy contract by the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company, a pioneer in the construction of lightweight stainless steel railway cars, highway trucks and planes.

The New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital sold the three-story building at 245 East Twenty-third Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue, to a client of James Felt Co. The parcel is 48 by 98 feet and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $30,000.
Mrs. A.M. Sobel and B. Jay Becker of New York, coupled with Sidney Silodor and Charles H. Goren won last night the national team-of-four contract bridge championship in play at the Hotel Astor.
A drive to put women on an equal pay basis with men through the enactment of State legislation was started yesterday by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.
The early operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Deploring what he called "the definite drift toward collectivism and socialism in this country," Henry Waltemade of the Bronx told the members of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards yesterday that realty tax and assessment relief were necessary to protect private ownership of property.

A seventy-three-count indictment accusing fourteen officials and members of Local 324 of the Independent Laundry Drivers of Greater New York of conspiring to extort from and blackmail small laundry owners was dismissed yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions.

Representatives of industry, labor and Government, participating in the national conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management on problems of conversion to peacetime production agreed yesterday that there is no real manpower shortage and that management must plan now for jobs in abundance after the war.

Julius Lehrenkrauss, once head of a leading Brooklyn mortgage and investment house, died late Wednesday after six years of poverty, following his release from Sing Sing Prison, where he served three years of a five-to-ten-year sentence for grand larceny.
LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A saving of 97,000 workers sought by West Coast shipyards as a result of the operations of the West Coast manpower program was announced today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, on the basis of statements filed by West Coast manpower officials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Is the Navy satisfied with its policy of allowing its personnel to play football during pre-flight and college training programs?

While peoples are engaged in the present struggle in numbers that make it literally the first war of all humanity, a few persons play a part that is also without parallel in history. Both these phenomena are highlighted in the current conferences, the climax of a long series of deliberately dramatized meetings of war leaders.

ALTHOUGH a record holiday trade is already assured, there were some indications in the week that the closing rush may not prove as heavy as expected earlier. Thus, the latest Federal Reserve report on department store sales showed a smaller increase over last year, and the weekly index of sales registered a decline of thirteen points when the usual movement at this time is a continued advance from Thanksgiving to Christmas.

WASHINGTON. POLITICAL pin feathers have been flying about the Capitol over the proposal to give the President control of all civilian pigeons in the United States. The regulatory measure is sponsored by the Department of Justice, whose operatives are concerned lest any privately owned and operated carrier pigeons be hired out to Axis spies.

IT is only natural in these anxious times that artists and makers of books for children should turn to the account of the first Christmas as found in the Gospels. In "A Child's Story of the Nativity" Louise Raymond has retold the Bible story with simplicity and dignity, keeping close to the words of the original.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The strongly pro-Russian Yugoslav Partisan movement announced over the Free Yugoslav Radio today that it had set up a provisional regime in opposition to the existing exiled government now sitting in Cairo and recognized by the Allies -- including Russia.

Three thousand and five hundred of the nation's managers of industry will attend the Second War Congress of American Industry and the forty-eighth annual conference of the National Association of Manufacturers in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, F.C. Crawford, president of the organization, announced yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Twenty years of progress will be celebrated this winter by the St. Petersburg Shuffleboard Club, which has grown from an organization with a few adherents in 1924 to the largest tourist sports club in the world.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 4 -- Allied planes attacked Berlin be tween 3 and 5 o'clock this morning, the Aftonbladet's Berlin correspondent reported.

I have read your editorial "Controlling Aviation" in your issue of Nov. 24 in which you point out the importance of the Lea Civil Aviation Bill (HR 3420), which will shortly come before the House of Representatives for action. I am glad to see your approval of the necessary principles of Federal regulation of flying.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- British American bombings of German-held Europe have been stepped up to such a degree of effectiveness that next Spring's attack on the Continent may mean the occupation of territory already made almost useless to the enemy in the opinion of some of the air authorities of both countries in Washington.

Penicillin, the vital healing drug, will be available to civilian medical practitioners in adequate quantities late next spring, according to a report released yesterday by Industrial and Engineering Chemistry, journal of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A shortage of 100-octane gasoline threatening combat operations of United States and Allied air forces has been a constant menace since Pearl Harbor, Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War, said today in a review of the efforts made to meet this threat, which he said had not yet been removed even though new 100-octane plants were now beginning to go into operation.

Miss Patrice Munsel and Danald Dame made debuts at the performance of Thomas' "Mignon" given for the benefit of the New York Chapter of Hadassah last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. Miss Munsel was applauded vociferously and at length after her Polacca of the second act.

The American public and its leaders must fight on the home front for more social security measures to prevent the war heroes of today from getting on the relief rolls of tomorrow, Mayor La Guardia told several hundred wounded veterans yesterday.
WASHINGTON (U.P.) -- The Army's 2 1/2-ton "six-by-six" truck is doing its full share in carrying the war to the enemy.

ON Dec. 7, 1941, the "date that will live in infamy," military America "was promises." Today, two years after the treacherous Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the tense is present; the promises are being fulfilled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The members of the Women's Army Corps are doing sturdy and stunning jobs. Perhaps their recruitment campaign is falling down of sheer over-ambition -- lacking, of course, a compulsory service law.

At a recent meeting of Philadelphia's Cancer Forum Dr. Philip R. White of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research's Princeton station discussed cancer in plants in a way which leads this department to believe that much more could be learned about a dread disease from vegetation than the specialists in carcinomas and sarcomas may realize.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners recommended today uniform freight rate classifications for the entire country.

THIS is the story of a 33-year-old mountaineer from the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains in North Carolina. He had heard of the fabulous riches to be made in broadcasting and did something about it.

THE TIMES of Nov. 27 carried a story by Russell B. Porter reporting India's plea for relief at the current UNRRA conference. This letter is not concerned with that request, but with a second issue raised by India's representatives -- the ability of their country to supply its allotted share of the cost of postwar relief under UNRRA. Mr. Porter wrote:

Murray Goldman, awaiting sentence for attempted rape in the first degree, took a lie-detector test yesterday and after it was over he was paroled in the custody of his attorney. It was reliably reported that the verdict against him would be set aside tomorrow.

WINSTON CHURCHILL wrote in 1937: "It is already certain that Clemenceau was one of the world's great men." That verdict was rendered before history had cast Churchill to play in the second act of our modern Armageddon -- a part as Prime Minister of Britain very like that which, in the first act, Clemenceau had played as Premier of France.

Because notification of her commission as an Army nurse either went astray or was never sent, Miss Dorothy Davis walks free in America today instead of being a prisoner in the Japanese internment camp at Santo Tomas, Manila, where she spent two years.

APPLE-POLISHING, as a term for currying favor, has passed into our vernacular; so has "corny," as applied to the obvious and the sentimental, and where we once said "okay," the expressions "on the beam" or "in the groove" are slang terms in good standing, accepted, or at least understood, even by the middle-aged.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The great war is beginning to contract. For nearly four years it moved outward until it reached the nameless islands of the Oriental seas; now it is beginning to move inward at ever-increasing tempo toward the centers from which it began.

Stores in the major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles had extremely active trade last week, reflecting the early start of Christmas buying. Handbag, jewelry, blouse, notion, hosiery and toy departments were jammed.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Attorneys for John R. Longo renewed their fight today to save the long-time political enemy of Mayor Frank Hague from a prison term of eighteen months to three years imposed yesterday by Common Pleas Judge Thomas H. Brown as the result of a trial that Governor Charles Edison described as an "outrage."

ALGIERS, Dec. 4 -- Some explanation of why soldiers fight -- particularly American soldiers -- may be gleaned from excerpts from essays submitted in a contest sponsored by the education unit of the Army Special Service Section here.

ONE hundred years ago, on Dec. 11, 1843. Robert Koch was born in Clausthal, a mining town in the Prussian province of Hanover, Germany. In a sense, the first quavering baby cry of Robert Koch Was the birth-cry of modern bacteriological science, though more than thirty-five years were to pass before anyone knew it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Merging of the communications companies of the country to operate as one in foreign fields was advocated by Ray C. Wakefield, Federal Communications Commissioner, at today's Senate Interstate Commerce Committee hearing on the Wheeler-White Radio bill.
SEATTLE, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Eleven men were reported missing tonight after their vessel, a new Liberty freighter, crashed on the jagged rocks of an Alaskan island Nov. 25.

In this issue THE NEW YORK TIMES makes its thirty-second annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City. Since 1912 at this holiday season the appeal has gone out; and each time readers have come forward to rescue the sick, to lift the burdens from the faltering, to provide homes for the homeless, to give courage to the despairing.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- A group of Republican leaders and county committee members from four counties made preliminary plans last evening at a closed session to select a candidate to oppose Representative Hamilton Fish at the 1944 primary election. The meeting was held in Middletown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The possibility that Gen. George C. Marshall might proceed directly from Allied conferences in Cairo and Teheran to London to "take over duty as Commander in Chief of the Britain-to-Continent invasion forces," instead of returning to Washington, was discussed today by The Army and Navy Register.

The short-lived but heroic war record of the American President liner President Harrison was told yesterday by Mrs. Clara G. Main, a repatriate who arrived last week on the liner Gripsholm. Mrs. Main had spent the five years before Pearl Harbor as a stewardess on the President Harrison, and she told of the crew's learning about the attack on Pearl Harbor, the declaration of war and the vessel's capture all in one morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- The Electric Power and Light Corporation of the Electric Bond and Share Company holding company system and its subsidiary, the Louisiana Power and Light Company, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a joint proposal under which the parent company would make a capital contribution of 30,000 shares of $6 second preferred stock of the subsidiary to Louisiana Power and Light.

What is to be done with and for the children of the pre-Pearl Harbor fathers who have been and who are about to be reclassified and inducted into the armed services if the mothers of such children are expected to return to work? The lack of interest shown by our Congress as well as by our press to this vital question is surprisingly regrettable.
North Winship, United States Consul General at Toronto, and Mrs. Winship are at the Plaza.

WASHINGTON. THE supply picture for civilians is being so constantly changed by the shifts of war that the average householder may have difficulty keeping up with what is available and what is not. Several materials once highly critical are becoming sufficiently plentiful again for civilians to be able to look forward to more goods made from them -- always provided there is the manpower to manufacture them.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano condemned the recent German decision to intern all Jews in Italy and confiscate their belongings and warned that it would affect numerous Catholics of Jewish descent, frontier reports said today.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony program leaflet of recent concerts has addressed to the patrons a questionnaire which states that "The * * * Society is interested in knowing what symphony you would like to hear. The three symphonies which receive the largest number of votes will be played under the direction of Artur Rodzinski at the earliest possible date this season."
Compounds of gold have been used for the past fifteen years in the treatment of arthritis. Many physicians object to them because they are highly toxic. One per cent of those treated with gold die.

Planning for a more active campaign than last season, the Rowing Coaches of America held their annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Lexington. Tentative arrangements call for five regattas in the East, culminating in a new event designed to take the place of the Poughkeepsie and Harvard-Yale races.

Despite a severe loss in civilian enrollment, the colleges and universities of this country, after two years of war, are today in a strong position, having adjusted their programs to an all-out victory effort. Weathering the trials that arose immediately following the attack on Pearl Harbor, the colleges have maintained their liberal arts traditions while placing all of their facilities at the hands of the national Government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4 -- The Amateur Athletic Union today nominated eight persons for its James E. Sullivan Memorial Award, given annually to the person designated by the union as the outstanding athlete of the year.

CHICAGO Dec. 4 -- Four alien Japanese alleged to have been active in Chicago in movements designed to help the Tokyo Government, were arrested by FBI agents today. Spencer J. Drayton, agent in charge, said three had been decorated by their Government for activities in the United States.

A solemn pontifical mass commemorating the feast of St. Francis Xavier, patron saint of missionaries, was celebrated yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Auxiliary Bishop of New York. The mass is held annually under the auspices of the Catholic Students Mission Crusade of the Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Republican Busbey of Illinois has withdrawn an invitation to C. Nelson Sparks, former Mayor of Akron, Ohio, author of a book alleging that "irregularities" occurred in Wendell Willkie's nomination at the Republican Convention of 1940, to speak before the 78 Club, composed of Republican Congressmen, here Tuesday.

" MRS. HEATON'S DAUGHTER" is an interesting novel based upon an abnormally airtight mother-daughter relationship. The complexities and the agonies induced by the mother's selfishness and the daughter's loyalty are sincerely and relentlessly pounded home through 400 pages.

THE musical world is at last becoming aware of the shallowness of hitherto prevalent distinctions between pieces of music. These distinctions referred generally, to such categories as "good, mediocre and bad," "distinguished" and "vulgar," or "original" and "reminiscent."
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Bolivia, which declared war on Germany, Italy and Japan by an Executive decree last April 7, today reaffirmed its position with the approval of the Legislature.

THE Washington Redskins feel very much like the Shakespearean actor who majestically stepped onto the stage for his big scene and then fell flat on his face. The 'Skins tripped over the Steagles a week ago just as they were about to recite the immortal words of the Bard: "Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears, we come to bury the Steagles, not to lose to them."

The upward spiral of holiday business is exceeding all expectations and gives every evidence of tearing gaping holes in stocks much before the Christmas period ends, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Cornell and Columbia opened their Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League season tonight, the Ithacans winning in impressive fashion, 50 -- 36, before 2,000 in Barton Hall.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 4-- Effective labor participation under principles of sound economic planning and industrial democracy are needed to make our faith in democratic action triumphant, Clinton S. Golden, vice chairman of the War Manpower Commission, told 600 delegates at the sixth annual convention of the New Jersey Industrial Union Council, CIO, which opened here today at the Essex House.
If women in America hold a special position, there is a historic reason, according to James Truslow Adams in his new book, "The American." Women in colonial and frontier days had a scarcity value. "

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Under a counter-fire of German propaganda, President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin withheld official word tonight on the outcome of their Iranian conference to hasten Germany's defeat and reduce her military might for the future safety of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The "Big Three" of the Government's news control organization met in the White House this afternoon for a two-hour conference as Washington continued to be a zone of isolation so far as news of the meeting of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin of Russia was concerned.

The war has given those who cover the news many problems. It has meant danger, and in some cases death for correspondents. It has brought delay through censorship, and slip-ups and misunderstandings on news release dates. One of the worst of these took place last week in reporting the meetings of the Allied leaders at Cairo and Teheran.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Dec. 5 (zzP) -- Stepping upI an aerial offensive against the: western sector of New Britain Is-i land, Liberators, hitchells and Marauders have dropped 179 tons of explosives on the Japanese air i base at Cape Gloucester, headquarters announced today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- With an unexpectedly large entry, the two-day horse show of the Boulder Brook Club opened this morning in the club's riding arena on Old Mamaroneck Road and will continue tomorrow morning and afternoon, with the possibility of a second evening session.

The so-called "joint-area" agreements dividing world markets for export trade between the United States and Great Britain are not the result of any long-term postwar planning by the United States Government but rather a matter of simple expediency and the adaptation of traditional American thinking to immediate trading problems, it was asserted yesterday by an authoritative Government source.

Regardless of post-war economic factors the United States should continue, purely as a military security measure, production of synthetic rubber at an annual tonnage rate between 150,000 and 200,000, John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, declared in an analysis of the long-range rubber problem of the country.

Juvenile actors and actresses who receive their education at the Professional Children's School will appear in a production of the Broadway hit, "Arsenic and Old Lace," next Sunday afternoon and the evening of Dec. 19 at the Hudson Theatre.

Elisabeth Schumann devoted her annual Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon to lieder by Schubert and Wolf. As the eminent soprano herself announced to the large audience present, she was suffering from a cold. But like a true vocal artist she was able to sing "over" it, evoking fervent enthusiasm by her musicianship and interpretive skill.

FOR three and a half years this green and white countryside, the gray Channel and the grayish-blue skies have been a three-dimensional battleground -- a front line stubbornly held in dark days and fiercely exploited since. Now as Allied power waxes on land and sea and in the air the front line is ready to move forward across twenty-one miles of choppy gray water which serves England "as a moat defensive."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Private information reaching here from Berlin is that Germany's fond dream of a reply to the devastating Anglo-American bombings is to lob thousands of rocket shells across the English Channel into London.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- London is confident that the Roosevelt-Stalin-Churchill conversations at Teheran will expedite the defeat of Germany and lead to a unified United Nations policy that will put an end to the German menace for a considerable period of time.

THE 300th anniversary of the death of Monteverdi will be commemorated on Thursday evening by the Yale University School of Music. Marshall Bartholomew will lead a madrigal chorus and orchestra, assisted by soloists, in a program of Monteverdi's madrigals and cantatas and the "Ballo Delle Ingrate."
Paced by Sid Trubowitz who tossed in 20 points, the City College quintet gained a 47-35 victory over the marine barracks five of the Brooklyn Navy Yard last night in the Beavers' gym.

MANY a kitchen window sill is graced in winter with a window box or pots of herbs. Vegetable growing need not be confined then to the cellar or other appropriate spot for forcing -- let us say -- witloof chicory.

A STEPHEN CRANE writing the "Red Badge of Courage" of this war will not have a hero who carries his country's colors "quivering and aflare" before his charging comrades. In a war of tanks and foxholes, of planes and long-range rifles and guns the time-honored flag carrier has no place.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, IN ITALY, Dec. 2 (Delayed) -- Mount Camino, which was so heavily shelled and bombed today, deserves study by those interested in the Allies' campaign on Rome. For more than three weeks that mass has been holding the Fifth Army back.

In the Allied bomber offensive against Germany last week teamwork of two kinds dealt new punishment to the industries and the people of the Reich. The RAF and the American Eighth Air Force worked together to maintain the day-and-night pounding of Nazi cities.

FROM an American who has spent many years in Mexico comes word of the changes that have lately taken place in that land south of the Rio Grande. "Mexico is now more cosmopolitan, urbane and expensive than ever before," writes this observer.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 All nine Palestinian Hebrew newspapers and the German-language daily issued at Tel Aviv reappeared on Nov. 30 after eleven days' suspension.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- About 25,000 officers whose services the Army no longer needs will soon be returned to civilian life, while another 25,000 will be shifted from administrative positions to operations jobs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is out to eliminate the modern hijacker before he is able to become nearly as formidable a public enemy as his prohibition era forebear.

A FORTY-PAGE booklet listing the participation by 16,000 motion picture theatres in the 1943 drive for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and containing a message of appreciation from President Roosevelt is being distributed to theatre owners throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The highly technical plans for post-war currency control, which are nearing the final discussion stage prior to formal diplomatic negotiations, involve issues which will have a far-reaching effect upon the lives of individual citizens, and particularly upon foreign traders, in the years ahead.

At the annual meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club in this city next March there Will be offered for adoption an amendment to the rules which has been approved by the board of directors. The amendment is to Section 25-A of Chapter 19 of the rules and is aimed at a practice in awarding championship points which is contrary to the spirit of the rules and is unfair to certain competitors.

TWICE a week there is a jam session at Nick's restaurant and night club in Greenwich Village. The meetings have been going on regularly for seven years and they have become an institution. They were started by Nick Rongetti, owner of the place, who is a hot pianist of parts himself and who has a great fondness for good jazz.

A complete revision of the policy governing New York State's sixteen wildlife refuges under a plan which calls for breaking up the large nonhunting areas into more public hunting grounds was announced by Commissioner John A. White yesterday.
Showing considerable drive in the second half, the New York University basketball team defeated the quintet representing Fort Hancock at the Violet's gymnasium last night, 55 to 40.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Mainly through collections in United States Catholic Churches, $1,292,800 has been contributed in 1943 to the Bishops' War Emergency and Relief Fund, the Most Rev. Samuel A. Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago, treasurer, announced today.

Lumber production in the northeastern area of the United States will be seriously hampered if proposals made by the Office of Price Administration setting specific price ceilings on logs are put into effect, R.E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, Inc., declared yesterday.

American planes are systematically bombing the Marshall Islands. These attacks will grow heavier as the Seabees repair the captured air strip on Tarawa. But experience demonstrates that Japanese island strongholds cannot be neutralized from the air. Sooner or later the Marshalls must be attacked and occupied by our landing forces.

With programs at Madison Square Garden again promising to furnish the highlights of the intercollegiate basketball season in the metropolitan district, ambitious campaigns have been mapped out for most of the local quintets. Among these may be found New York University, C.C.N.Y., St. John's, St. Francis, Columbia, Brooklyn and L.I.U., all of which plan to do battle on a major scale.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 4 -- The decline in number, or at least effectiveness, of Nazi fighter planes has created a surplus of fighter pilots in Britain and Canada, it was revealed here today. As a result many Canadian air training centers are providing a controlled output of fighter pilots and concentrating on training bomber navigator, bombardiers, wireless operators, gunners and pilots.

THE library that William Lyon Phelps bequeathed to Yale contained many shelves filled with presentation copies, most of them dated early, for Mr. Phelps made it his habit to form friendships with writers when they were young, when they were first finding publication.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission announced tonight the naming of Liberty ships in honor of five engineers, the action coinciding with tributes paid to the men at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the Society for the Advancement of Management.

In the corridor of the Middle East, the land link between the great battlefronts of Europe and of Asia, two historic conferences last week shaped the strategy of the United Nations in the winning of the war and their policy in the peace that will follow victory. These conferences brought together for the first time, from the ends of the earth, the heads of state of the three great present enemies of Japan.

Under the exigency of war the transportation of oil is undergoing a change that will continue in the post-war period. The building of new pipelines and the rearrangement of others and the construction of a record number of large and speedy tankers are expected to be important factors in transporting oil after the cessation of hostilities although they were built primarily for use in the emergency.

TRAP passing -- which is passing on a good hand in the hope that the opponents will overbid and can be doubled -- is more an art than a science in contract bridge. At best it is dangerous to pass a very strong hand, because everyone else may pass.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- With the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration off to "a splendid start," Director General Herbert H. Lehman said in a radio address tonight that the United States should implement "immediately" its share of the broad program adopted at Atlantic City by the first council meeting to help war-torn lands to help themselves.

" BOOKS Are the Best Christmas Gifts" . . . Some thirty years ago this was the slogan of Norwegian publishers when they advertised the books published during the months of October and December -- at that time virtually the only season when books were published in Norway.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 4 -- Reich Propaganda Minister Dr. Joseph Goebbels, who is also Gauleiter of Berlin, has this week poured out much flattery to his fellow-Berliners for the "magnificent way in which you have borne the terror raids of the dastardly enemy."

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Lord Vansittart, former chief diplomatic adviser of the British Government, today offered a plan for the treatment of Germany after the war. In an article published in The London Sunday Dispatch the British peer, who has been urging stern treatment for the Germans, suggested that the Allies follow points that included the following:

Immediate appointment of 2,500 substitutes as regular teachers in the New York City school system was demanded yesterday by Dr. Bella V. Dodd, legislative representative of the teachers' union, at a conference held by the union at its offices, 13 Astor Place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Government authorized tonight a nine-cent increase in the ceiling price of corn, from a prevailing level of $1.07 a bushel to $1.16, Chicago basis, and simultaneously froze the price of oats, barley and sorghum grains preparatory to issuing a permanent regulation within sixty days.

WITH THE FIGHTING SIXTY-NINTH, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- Against determined opposition by strongly entrenched Japanese machine gun squads the Fighting Sixty-ninth has advanced eastward beyond the main village of Butaritari in two days of battle on the Makin atoll and now is attacking a well-defended tank trap where the main Japanese positions lie on the island.

Earnings of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange were higher in the first nine months of 1943 than in the corresponding 1942 period. A tabulation of 385 leading corporations in the current issue of The Exchange, a magazine published by the institution, shows an average gain of 11.4 per cent.

AS Christmas approaches -- bringing with it the season when normally 30 per cent of all book sales are made -- the 1,396 book manufacturing plants of the country are working under pressure as never before.

" The Cairo conference, together with the Moscow Conference which preceded it, strengthens the hopes of mankind for a peace that will be more enduring than the peace of 1919," Rabbi Israel Goldstein said in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway, yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- The German Government today coldly spurned Sweden's official 'most urgent request" that it cancel its threatened deportation of 1,000 arrested students of the University of Oslo and demanded that Stockholm mind its own business.

TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- Toronto raced through the Rangers almost at will at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight for an 11 -- 4 victory which lifted the home team into sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League standing.

To help the Treasury return to circulation millions of copper pennies and end the shortage in the larger cities, the American Mission to Lepers is appealing to its supporters to open their piggy-banks. It has issued 131,000 of these in the last thirty years, and many still are being used to aid the mission which represents all the Protestant denominations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A smoldering controversy between Senate Democrats came into the open today with a charge by Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania that Southern members of his party had joined in "an unholy alliance" with Republicans to deprive the armed forces of America of the right to vote.

THE way of the actress- manager, like that of the transgressor, is hard. It is particularly hard these days, when the playwrights are not living up to their professional contracts, or are living up to their incomes in Hollywood, which amounts at this end to almost the same thing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Consumers who regard too optimistically the prospects for increased production of civilian goods in 1944 are likely to be disappointed. An increase is in prospect, but its importance should not be exaggerated, for the actual supply of civilian goods that will be available will still be far below the peacetime supply.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Nervous disorders, usually resulting from fear, have occurred in 99 per cent of all cases of British airmen studied by Air Commodore O. P. Symonds of the Royal Air Force, he writes in the current issue of the British Medical Journal. His observations were made to determine the effect on men of flying strain.

American munitions output, including planes, tanks, guns, ships, ammunition and all other components, is approximately six and a half times the pre-Pearl Harbor rate, the National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday. The production figures, to be presented to United States industrialists during the group's annual convention this week in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was said to be the most complete and comprehensive of any available in the nation this year.

The importance of the motion picture in post-war education and as a promoter of international cooperation, was stressed yesterday by Mrs. Jeanette W. Emerich of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., and Prof. Broderick Cohen, director of the Hunter College Evening and Extension Division.

Lee Simonson's article, suggesting a national circuit of theatres showing plays with living actors, to be sponsored by self-imposed taxes upon the income of people benefitting from successes, can become a reality if he can tell who are to be the lucky ones, and if he can devise some plan to insure such continuous cooperation.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 4 -- Preparing to start tomorrow a new crusade for national outlawing of liquor on the tenth anniversary of repeal, Mrs. Ida B. Wise Smith, president of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, declared the elimination of the Eighteenth Amendment "the most cold-blooded political fraud in American history."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A formal report by the House Naval Affairs Committee on a fleet expansion bill proposing the expenditure of $5,000,000,000 underscored today the Navy's preparations for intensified amphibious warfare and invasions during and beyond 1944.
HERE are a few notes on the American soldier's way of living on one of those typical coral islands which freckle the face of the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Faced this week with the clear-cut declaration of the Cairo conference that the Allies intended to strip her of every foot of territory she has seized in nearly half a century of aggression, Japan was in a very unenviable position.

ALGIERS, Dec. 4 -- Three weeks ago the Allied road to Rome was barred by eleven identified German divisions in a line based primarily on the Garigliano and Sangro Rivers. Today there are elements of at least twelve Wehrmacht divisions facing General Clark's and General Montgomery's armies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation today urged a price stabilization program which, it said, was designed to "unleash the energies of farm people" and "free agriculture and its cooperatives from a maze of conflicting orders and paralyzing regulations."
A FRENCH artist, Bonnat, I think, once remarked: "I've been painting Mme. X.'s portrait, or, rather. I've been trying to paint one of her ten thousand expressions."

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The Red Army's winter offensive, the second of three great onslaughts on which the Allies count on for victory over Germany in 1944, is expected to start at the earliest possible moment and to star on a scale never before imagined for winter warfare.

" Wartime nerves," product of worry and overwork, result in physical fatigue and tenseness at nerve centers. A corrective for this condition, according to the exercise director at the Helena Rubinstein salon, is a series of exercises designed to relax knotted-up nerves and shake out painful muscle kinks.
PICASSO is with us again, after an absence of quite a while. And he reappears with a brace of concurrent one-man shows. You will find them at, respectively, Paul Rosenberg's and the Pierre Matisse.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 -- The United Nations have now moved far nearer to the potential settlement of the difficult problem of the future of Central and Eastern Europe, it was indicated today by an announcement that the treaty between Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union, whose details had already been publicized, was about to be signed.

More than ninety school children from the town of Wellesley are taking advantage this year of the Posture Clinic sponsored by the Department of Hygiene and Physical Education at Wellesley College. Children with poor posture come to the college Saturday mornings for a fifteen weeks' course in exercises and training in walking, sitting and standing.

Two economists declared yesterday that the real danger to the nation and business in converting to peacetime production was inflation. They spoke at the final sessions of a national conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management, in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States Treasury has received $5,106,989.44 in war gifts in the two years since the attack on Pearl Harbor. The amount includes a $25 War Bond from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, which he received from a Philadelphia admirer.

Flattening out of the trend of retail sales, which has been sharply upward practically since the start of the war in 1939, is likely during the first four months of 1944, according to projections prepared in merchandising circles last week.

HAMIILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 4-- Secret weapons -- "weapons of a revolutionary type" -- are responsible for "the lop-sided victories against the Japanese in the Pacific,'' according to Rear Admiral Ingram C. Sowell, commandant of the United States naval base, in a speech last night at the annual dinner to the Speaker of the Bermuda Assembly.

ALGIERS, Dec. 4 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army has pounded forward in a great attack ushered in by the most powerful artillery barrage of the Italian campaign, it was officially announced today.

Quiet trading, with fractional price changes in both directions, ended the stock market week yesterday. American Distilling was the strongest feature in a market in which THE NEW YORK TIMES rail average fell 0.05 to 24.53, the industrial average rose 0.01 to 156.21 and the combined average fell 0.02 to 90.37.

IT IS by no means an easy problem that has been posed by the organizers of the fascinating French Revolution show at Wildenstein's. The French Revolution itself, considered just in its political aspects, does not unfold -- unless for the deep-delving student of the subject -- a clear and simple panorama of events.

Arrangements for the staging of the intersectional football game next Sunday between Mount St. Michael of the Bronx and St. George High School of Evanston, Ill., Chicago district champion, were completed yesterday. The game will be played at the Polo Grounds at 2:30 P.M., instead of at Baker Field, which had been announced earlier as the tentative site.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 4 -- A strongly favorable response has been received by The Richmond Times-Dispatch to its recent proposal that the Virginia law segregating the races on urban street cars and buses be repealed by the Legislature at its session this winter.

On Tuesday, Nov. 30, the White House distributed to newspapers and press services an announcement of the meeting in Cairo of Roosevelt, Churchill and Chiang Kai-shek. There was an elaborate warning preface addressed to editors that under no conditions was any word of the release to be published, quoted or broadcast before 7:30 P.M. on Dec. 1, which made the release available for newspapers of Thursday morning, Dec. 2.

The impact of the war upon American society, the problems of the post-war world and the possible contributions of social science to the peace were discussed at the opening session of the two-day thirty-eighth annual meeting of the American Sociological Society at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A possibility that a provision would be written into the House-approved tax bill to require employers to deduct anticipated religions, charitable and educational contributions of employes from the 20 per cent withholding tax arose today as the Senate Finance Committee speeded hearings on the bill to an expected close Monday.

SELDEN MENEFEE wanted to know what Americans were thinking and doing about the war. For Princeton University's Office of Public Opinion Research, he traveled 15,000 miles through forty-one States, stopped off at eighty-four cities, towns and villages from Seattle to Palatka.

BARBI and Bobby, who could hardly wait for Christmas, found it made the days pass more quickly to think of them as signposts along the road, each one saying "This Way to Christmas." Of course it helped, too, to have the days as well filled as they were -- with a school play; the building of a feeding board

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ninety-seven war plant strikes out of 100 apparently ignored the cooling-off processes prescribed by the War Labor Disputes Act during the first three months it was in effect.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 4 -- A broad program of adult education as a prime post-war objective is the chief feature of the report to the University of Michigan by its president, Dr. Alexander G. Ruthven, on his intensive five weeks' survey of present and projected plans for education in England.

Production of war goods proceeded on an even keel during the first nine months of this year and earnings of American industrial manufacturing companies recorded an appreciable improvement over the corresponding period of 1942 in spite of heavier taxes and higher costs of labor and materials.

The most priceless Christmas gifts in the world are on the way for thousands of American servicemen. Babies. In New York City alone hundreds of wriggling, bawling, kicking babies are due to be born to servicemen's wives in December.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Secretary Ickes has told Congress that the country faces a fuel crisis unparalleled in its history as a result of the loss of 40,000,000 tons of coal production through miners' strikes.

PASSAIC, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Frank Santora, powerhouse triple-threat back, enjoyed a great day as Garfield High's football team downed Passaic by 38 -- 12 in a post-season benefit contest before 10,000 at Passaic School Stadium today. Garfield's only loss this season came at the hands of Passaic, and Coach Art Argauer's lads more than made up for that defeat.

Price-fixing orders by the trade, though small, steadied the cotton futures market yesterday throughout a quiet session. This support counteracted some commission house liquidation and light hedge selling as the list of active old contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange overcame slight early losses to close at net gains of 1 to 6 points, with the strength in the distant positions.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A sensational goal with only thirty seconds of play left gave England a 2-2 draw with Scotland in an Army international soccer match played at Liverpool today.

ONE of the most remarkable patriotic phenomena of this war has been the growth and power of guerrilla resistance in Yugoslavia. Almost immediately after the collapse of that country in the face of the German-Italian onslaught and the surrender of its armies in April, 1941, that resistance commenced to organize.

The Metropolitan division of the American Fencers League of the United States has issued its schedule for the coming year with the number of competitions restricted because of war conditions. Nevertheless, the women win go all out to keep up their fencing, with fifteen bouts on the list against twenty-four in the 1942-43 season.

IN keeping with its policy of striving for the distinctive rather than the elaborate in entertainment, the Waldorf-Astoria now is offering Paul and Grace Hartman, the dance satirists, and Annamary Dickey, the beauteous opera singer, at the Wedgwood Room.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- It was principally on motion of the United States that China was admitted on equal terms to the conference of the Foreign Ministers in Moscow that produced the Four-Power Declaration. In pursuance of this policy the chief of Free China, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, was a full member of the Cairo meeting of the heads of the three States which bear the present brunt of the military action against Japan.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee announced last night that it would send to Soviet Russia within the next few months $500,000 worth of essential supplies, including food and clothing, for civilian distribution on a nonsectarian basis in areas of predominantly Jewish population.
IN this war cold science is playing a share equally with military strategy to a degree hitherto unheard of.

Radical departures from normal Police Department procedure, it was disclosed last night, made it possible for Patrolman Glendon O. Bryant of 295 Convent Avenue, assigned to the Thirty-second Precinct in Harlem, to become a member of the all-Negro cast of "Carmen Jones," the modernized version of Bizet's opera, that opened at the Broadway Theatre on Friday.

CACTI and succulents make admirable house plants. Their ability to adapt themselves to homelike conditions has been a major factor in their popularity in regions where these plants cannot be grown outdoors the whole year round.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Capt. Marry C. Weems says the Women's Army Corps is turning out peppy, photogenic and, above all, popular military police.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Dec. 4 -- In the presence of nearly 200 persons, forty-six awards were made here today in ceremonies at the post theatre to families of Air Forces heroes by Col. Douglas C. Johnston, commanding officer here.

Discarding the traditional instruction, City College will become the first institution of higher learning in the country to use the new techniques of teaching foreign languages that have been developed and found successful by the Amy, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president.

IT IS a bleakly significant reflection upon the way films are loosely bought and sold that seldom does one hear any bowwow for some of the finest examples of cinematic craft. We speak of those wistful stepchildren of commercial entertainment -- the shorts -- about which this writer has been croaking like a man lost in a cave for years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- Australia and New Zealand cannot continue their present active part in the prosecution of the war and, at the same time, meet British and American demands for development and maintenance of base services and food supply, Sir Walter Layton, a London publisher, asserted today on his return from a press mission to the Pacific.

After you reported that Dr. Lynd of Columbia University had advocated that the "United States operate under a centralized national planned economy after the war as the only method by which this nation could continue its advances in technology and compete with other nations on a similar basis," you published a letter on Nov. 23 from Dal Keith, who seems to be under the impression that a planned economy is incompatible with an incentive system.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Paced by Harry Leggatt, former New York University star, who accounted for thirteen points, Dartmouth's Eastern league champions launched a drive for their seventh straight title with a 45-to-34 victory today over the Princeton basketball team.

A foretaste of Christmas will be enjoyed next Friday at the McBurney Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 215 West Twenty-third Street, formerly the Twenty-third Street Branch, it was announced yesterday. The occasion will be a Christmas festival, organized and directed by the branch's international groups.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a ban against Government agencies holding in reserve appropriated money which they do not need.
A FEW hours spent on providing proper winter protection for the garden pool before snowfall eliminates the irksome task in spring of repair-the damage due to winter frost.

After listening to voluminous testimony in a session that lasted more than six hours in the Hotel Roosevelt, Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis yesterday refused to change his Nov. 23 ruling in which he barred William D. Cox, deposed head of the Phillies, from organized baseball for life for having bet on ball games involving his club.

ROSELLE, N.J., Dec. 4 -- The directors of the First National Bank of Roselle have decided to call a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 27 to vote on a proposal to pay a 100 per cent stock dividend, raising the bank's capital stock from $100,000 to $200,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Former Gov. Alfred M. Landon of Kansas told Republican junior Senators today that adoption of similar declarations on foreign policy by the two major political parties "would accelerate the danger of a drift toward one party in our country."

ONLY one minor change has been made in the script of "Wilson," Twentieth Century-Fox's $2,000,000 film biography of Woodrow Wilson, as a result of the recent visit to Hollywood of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, grandson and namesake of the picture's implied "heavy."

ONCE, on a clear winter day, a wide stretch of plow land lay before me; it was beautiful in the rich coloring and fertility of its shallow, faintly shadowed furrows; but it was still and silent as nature seems to those who see nothing within and beyond it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Petty officer ratings as full-fledged air gunnery instructors are now open to enlisted women in the Naval Reserve and a training school for this field has been established at the Naval Air Training Center at Pensacola, Fla.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- A deft stroke by the Royal Air Force in execution of a heavy attack on the German city of Leipzig early today enabled strong formations of its big bombers to catch formidable enemy defenses flatfooted and drive home with complete success a blow against a target that had been called one of the best remaining unspoiled in the Reich.

COMEDY is taking on an ever-increasing burden in the present state of world affairs, and already the lowly "gag" is serving on three fronts. On the home front messages of the greatest national importance are channeled through the comedy programs.

SOME years ago, when I discovered with joy and amazement that seven centuries of music could be accessible to me, I started on an explorer's mission. I wanted genuine musical texts by early masters with the ultimate purpose of singing them, but none of these could be bought at any music publishers where only "arrangements" are available.

The matinee performance of "The Tales of Hoffmann" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Dec. 30 has been taken by the Near East College Association, Inc., for its sixteenth annual opera benefit. The cast is headed by Ezio Pinza, Martial Singher, Patrice Munsel, Lily Djanel and Jarmila Novotna.

The American Merchant Marine Institute, comprising sixty-two major steamship companies, last week filed a brief before the Advisory Board of Just Compensation calling for immediate reimbursement of American shipowners for their losses due to vessel requisitions, purchases, charters and insurances.

THE theatre, of course, is one of the most ephemeral of the arts -- only the radio has a briefer span. The elder statesman and even the retired business man may reasonably expect to give benevolent advice for years and years, but even the greatest figures of the theatre have a way of vanishing from the scene long before their days are over.

OMAHA, Neb. Dec. 4 -- The shoe is now on the other foot. Instead of begging townfolk to come out and help him get in his crops, the farmer is now being asked to lend some of his seasonal surplus of labor to the urban meat packer, to help clear away the avalanche of livestock, especially hogs, which threatens to overwhelm the industry.

Some hope is held out in The Journal of the American Medical Association by Drs. A.E. Bennet, J.J. Keegan and C.B. Wilbur that cases of schizophrenia, otherwise known as dementia praecox, may be restored to something like social sanity by removing a lobe of the brain with a tube inserted through a hole drilled in the skull.

CHUNGKING, China, Sunday, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Hong Kong was raided again Wednesday by Chinese-American planes which sank a 4,000-ton freighter, badly damaged two others in drydock, and destroyed railway equipment and buildings, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced.
The favorite food of the wounded soldiers at Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island, is, as may be expected, ice cream, Lieut. Mary Rose Conway, chief dietitian there, revealed yesterday.

Plans for post-war construction of passenger-carrying tonnage by the Swedish American Line are being held in abeyance until a reliable estimate of prospective steamship passenger business can be formulated, G. Hilmer Lundbeck Jr., vice managing director of the line, declared yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Dec. 4 -- Westchester County's elaborate switchboard set-up for distributing air raid alarms will be discontinued at midnight tomorrow and a simpler one will be substituted. If all goes well, the public will notice no change in audible alarms, the county will save $18,000 a year in telephone charges, and fewer volunteer workers will be needed in control rooms.

I have read with great interest the article dealing with the attitude of the German prisoners of war in this country. The article says that the Nazi salute has disappeared almost completely and that the two songs "Deutschland, Deutschland Ueber Alles" and "Horst Wessel" are no longer heard when these prisoners march to or from their work.

FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 4 -- Four Coney Island youths staged a guerrilla raid in Nassau and Suffolk Counties today, leaving behind them one dead swan, its mate badly wounded and dying, and an irate Navy captain. They were still absent from their home base late tonight, however, held in Freeport police headquarters for questioning by State Game Warden Charles R. Weinberger and State police.

LEARNING that Tallulah Bankhead had just returned from Hollywood, this courier last week made a pilgrimage to the northern reaches of Westchester, where for all of a year now the lady has maintained a handsome country place called Windows, complete with five fireplaces.
The fate of the New York football Giants now hangs in the balance and, unfortunately, it's in the balance of Sammy Baugh's good right arm.

FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City THE NEW YORK TIMES today makes its thirty-second annual appeal. Here on these pages are published a hundred stories of unfortunates whose need is greatest of all in the city.

Charles Brinton of Philadelphia, former national amateur and intercollegiate squash racquets champion from Princeton, was among those to gain the semi-final round of the invitation tournament at the Yale Club yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (Delayed). MEET the first member of the United States Forces to appear in a British feature film. He is Sgt. John Sweet of Granville, Ohio, and he plays a leading role in the new Michael Powell-Emeric Pressburger film, "A Canterbury Tale."

FOR a good many centuries the man of the house who came home to find his little woman in tears has had two courses open to him. Either he could beat her up, swear and stamp off to the neighborhood saloon or he could ply her with headache pills, sympathize and tip-toe off to the neighborhood saloon.

Randolph Evernghim Paul, 53-year-old New York lawyer and tax expert, in December, 1941, took over one of the most unpopular tasks in Washington. As assistant to Secretary Henry Morgenthau, and later general counsel of the Treasury, he has had the job of framing the Administration's drastic wartime tax programs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The United States should "arrange for broadcasting stations around the world" in anticipation of being a "part of this post-war world," Senators Brewster, Republican, of Maine, and Mead, Democrat, of New York, have advised a subcommittee on appropriations.

THOUGH the question-and-answer shows now throng the airways so that there is scarcely even a 250-watt station in all the land that lacks a quizmaster, the grandparent of all the audience-participation and interview programs goes serenely along in this its twelfth year and probably it is simple justice that it still surpasses any of its imitators.

Anglo-American naval cooperation in the Mediterranean was a major factor in the Allied invasions, Lieut. Dennis Jermain, commander of a British patrol-torpedo flotilla for four years, declared yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 4 -- One of the most ambitious ventures in prohibition ever attempted in modern India is being virtually written off as a failure by the government of Madras Presidency.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from, Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

In the Middle East, where recorded history begins, history was being written again last week. Four men -- the four most powerful men in the United Nations -- had traveled thousands of miles across oceans, deserts and frozen steppes, coming at times dangerously close to the reach of their enemies.

They are perfectly good words, but their continual use as epithets is so silly and shortsighted that one wonders how anybody with a modicum of sense can continue so to employ them.

Our American shipyards have delivered 25,284,287 tons of merchant shipping between Jan. 1, 1942, and Dec. 1, 1943, thus, with still a month to go, the industry has surpassed the 24,000,000-ton goal set for this year and last, Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, revealed yesterday.
