WITH THE TWENTY-SEVENTH DIVISION TASK FORCE EN ROUTE TO MAKIN ATOLL, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- Hundreds of troops, almost all New Yorkers, were brought together on the decks of this transport today under a blazing equatorial sun for their first mass meeting since they embarked on the road to the Japanese-held Gilbert Islands.
SOME gardeners regard winter just as a season to be endured until spring comes again. Yet even winter has its compensations -- among them the birds that enliven the chilly scene.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4 -- George Hermann Stoltz, coffee exporter and industrialist, will be tried on charges of sabotage and espionage that resulted in the torpedoing by Axis submarines of Brazilian ships on which more than 1,000 persons were lost.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 -- Salto, William Helis' 4-year-old colt, found his racing legs today under 111 pounds and a fine ride by Nick Jemas to win the six-furlong Mississippi Handicap, $2,000 feature at the Fair Grounds.

IT is not often that anyone has a chance to make a portrait of one of the ten highest salaried people in the country. Yet anything can happen in Hollywood, and this very thing happened the other day when I went to see Ginger Rogers. For Miss Rogers, blond-haired, blue-eyed and full of fervor and enthusiasm, was last year the highest paid movie actress in the land.

CHRISTMAS always comes early to the American Red Cross, for the globe is its parish and it really takes some early shopping and mailing to reach all its outposts in time. This third Christmas since Pearl Harbor will find Red Cross outposts with the military scattered as never before in remote sections of the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has described the Moscow agreements, it was disclosed today, as forging the United Nations into "a single sword" that is "being wielded as if by a single brain and a single hand."

THE wards of Walter Reed Hospital are astir with clipped metallic sounds. Nurses and orderlies are busy at the beds with portable wash basins. Clear morning sunlight bends golden bars across the cots. The wounded lie back on their pillows -- wounded from Salerno, New Guinea, Africa, Sicily -- and only their eyes move as they take in the action about them.

The nation's distillers, now engaged 100 per cent in making alcohol for war, were represented yesterday as definitely cool to the idea of returning at this time to the manufacture of beverage alcohol, although willing to do so if the War Production Board should decide that a limited resumption could, without impeding the war, overcome some of the evils caused by the current liquor shortage.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 5 -- Axis sources reported today that the Red Army had hurled 600,000 men into a massive offensive west of Smolensk as converging Soviet forces pounded to within eight miles of Zhlobin and threatened to engulf momentarily that last escape gap still open to the retreating Germans in southern White Russia.

CLEANSERS AND THE CHEMIST -- "One of the most wasteful characters in the wartime home," according to Dr. Dorothy Houghton, Assistant Professor of Home Economics at Columbia University, "is the 'inventive' housewife who thinks she is cleverer than the professional chemists who design her cleansing materials."

VICTOR ALESSANDRO, 28-year-old Texan about to begin his sixth season as conductor of the Oklahoma Symphony Orchestra, has been in town for a few weeks and has been telling about the unusual work being done by the organization he heads, especially for the young.

AT the opening of the twentieth century the direction of American graphic humor had been defined by three magazines, Puck, Judge and the original Life. Before 1900 these journals, following the example of Mark Twain, Bill Nye, Eugene Field and other native jesters, had set the standard of black-and-white comedy, an indigenous brand of humor illustrating the tall tales, meandering legends and glittering buffoonery of fun-loving pioneers.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- The Government's first attempt in recent years to prosecute Utah polygamists came to a climax today when John Zenz, 37, a half-blind auto mechanic, was sentenced to five years in the penitentiary and his 34-year-old wife, Lola, to two years in a women's reformatory for violating the Mann Act.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Any requests for a hearing on proposed transactions of the Northern States Power Company (Minn.) and Northern States Power Company (Del.) must be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission not later than December 16.

Calling for the annihilation of the Nazi party, Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs, declared yesterday that he feared the Americans and British "will become soft and sentimental soon again as you did after the last war."

The first large entertainment for debutantes this season took place last night in the main ballroom and Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton, where the Grosvenor Debutante Ball was given as a benefit for Grosvenor Neighborhood House, one of the city's best known settlements.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Trading in hogs was fairly active today as commission men worked to sell some of the 13,000 head held over from the previous session. An unprecedented situation developed here this week when far too many hogs arrived for the slaughtering facilities of packers. Major plants have supplies on hand to keep them busy into the early part of next week.

The nation's "unprecedented war effort" based upon "business-government cooperation" can be turned to advantage in a post-war housing program for all communities, John B. Blandford Jr., administrator of the National Housing Agency, declared yesterday at a luncheon sponsored by the Citizens Housing Council of New York and the National Association of Housing Officials in the Park Central Hotel.

The Rev. John Underwood Stephens, for the last four years assistant minister of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, will be installed Tuesday at 8 P.M. as pastor of Mount Washington Presbyterian Church, 84 Vermilyea Avenue, near Broadway and 204th Street.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 4 -- Four University of Wisconsin scientists have reported that animals fare as well on oleomargarine as on butter, if a balanced diet is fed to them, according to research conducted for six weeks on rats.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The State Department, the Office of Foreign Economic Administration and the Fats and Oils Committee of the Combined Food Board today declined to comment publicly on the charge of New York importers that Federal authorities had not properly explained their "reluctance in permitting the importation of Spanish olive oil into this market."

THE Associated Press has made available photographs of five stamps issued in London by the Czechoslovak Government in Exile. They mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of the Czechoslovak Republic, and it is announced they will be made valid for postage in Czechoslovakia after the war.

One hundred and six pairs began play yesterday for the national contract bridge open pair championship in the American Contract Bridge League's seventeenth annual national tournament, in progress at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A renewed indictment of Japan as an aggressor power in the decade preceding the attack on Pearl Harbor was issued by the State Department tonight in the publication of the second volume of its two-volume documentary record of the diplomatic relations of the United State and Japan during the ten-year period.

UNDER the sponsorship of the Pan American Union, a movement to expand stamp collecting as an extra-curricular activity in the public schools was inaugurated at the closing session of the ninth American Philatelic Congress in the Pan American Building at Washington last Sunday.

WHEN a scientist is on the track of a new vitamin, says Lieut. Comdr. Clive M. McCay of the Naval Medical Research Institute, he often starts his investigations with brewers' yeast. He knows that if the element is anywhere, it may well be concealed in this substance, which, along with wheat germ and liver, has been found to be phenomenally rich in nutrients, a kind of hunting ground for them.

MAYBE it is about time somebody said a good word for straight musical comedy dancing. Ever since Agnes de Mille struck oil in "Oklahoma!" everybody has been so busy watching the new trend toward the concert and ballet styles of dancing in the musicals that the good old staple variety has been allowed to pass without much notice. And that manifestly should not happen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- In an effort to step up production of hosiery for infants and children, the War Production Board today, under Paragraph C of Order M-328, took steps to bring production of such hosiery into normal line with total output.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- Two years ago this week the Kremlin was putting the final touches to plans for driving the Germans from Moscow's approaches in the Red Army's first winter campaign, and during the night of Dec. 5 forces were unleashed from Kalinin to Yelets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- On the capacity of the church and government to meet their responsibility to the general welfare in the postwar period hangs the future of civilization, Vice President Wallace said tonight in a radio talk over the Blue Network.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- An appraisal of the political situation -- as of today -- indicates that the two parties are running virtually neck-and-neck in terms of voting strength among the civilian population.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Led by Jerry Heffernan with four goals and an assist, the Canadiens rode to an 8-2 victory over Detroit tonight while playing their fourteenth straight game without loss before 12,000 fans. It was Montreal's eleventh National Hockey League triumph.
The Garden Club of Madison (N.J.) will hold its annual meeting and luncheon at the Morris Count Golf Club on Dec. 8 at 12:30 P.M.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY. in Italy, Dec. 4 -- In one of the most important battles of the Italian campaign, Allied troops drove their way up and over the highest peaks of the Mount Camino mass, it may be revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- As informal suggestions that the Republicans and Democrats adopt identical foreign policy planks next year ran into outright opposition from Alf M. Landon, Senator Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, questioned whether it was practical to pour these policies in the "same mould."

The Federal Bureau of Investigation landed a prize catch in its espionage net here yesterday in the person of 26-year-old Carlos Vejarano y Cassina, whose father is a cousin of the Duke of Alba, greatest of Spanish grandees under the monarchy, close friend of former King Alfonso of Spain, and now Franco's Ambassador to the Court of St. James.

Reports that an acute shortage of storage space soon would compel the Federal Government to release some more of its vast food hoards were confirmed last night by Joseph B. Eastman, head of the Office of Defense Transportation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--An Administration move to delay a Senate showdown on food subsidies for sixty days while it submits the issue to a Democratic caucus appeared tonight to be gaining some ground.

One argument that is frequently advanced for the use of subsidies in this country is their successful application in both Great Britain and Canada. It is true that subsidies have contributed to the stability of the price level and living costs in those countries and that this has been achieved at a relatively small cost.

Among men and women 50 or more years old with an unbroken marriage there is a lower crime rate than among persons in the same age group who are single or divorced, it was reported yesterday to the closing session of the convention of the American Sociological Society at the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The Office of Price Administration's typical housewife, Mrs. Philip L. Crowlie, just back from a look into civilian cupboards and closets, protested tonight that shoddy goods and high prices were the order of the day.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 5 -- Japanese and Americans have traded air blows across hundreds of miles in the central Pacific area where we are consolidating our new positions in the Gilberts and the enemy is attempting to neutralize our growing power and forestall deeper blows, it was disclosed here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Roosevelt-Churchill-Chiang Pacific consultations were held at Mena House, a luxury hotel five miles outside Cairo, it was disclosed today at a press conference in a room littered with Cairo newspapers announcing that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill had just concluded a conference with Premier Stalin at Teheran.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Mrs. John Hernandez was away earning $30 a week on the night shift at a local aircraft plant last night while her husband, a $50-a-week war worker on the day shift in the same plant, attended to her household duties in their home at 44 Elm Street here.

A guide to conduct for union shop stewards and company foremen, designed to smooth labor-management relations and increase war production throughout the nation, was outlined yesterday afternoon at an unusual meeting of 350 stewards and foremen of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States Steel Corporation served notice today that if union demands for increased wages were granted it had "no recourse other than to seek a compensating increase in steel prices."

Women business executives, fashion leaders, newspaper women, magazine writers and actresses honored yesterday Miss Dorothy Shaver, vice president of Lord Taylor's, for her achievements in the business world. The event was marked by a luncheon held at Sherry's by the fashion, business and professional women's division of the merged New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Expectations that ceiling prices on oats would be established by the Office of Price Administration below the current open market tended last week to restrict buying of that grain, and strength came largely from sympathy with wheat.

Relief and rescue work being performed by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee among Jews in Europe and elsewhere and plans for the coming year were discussed here yesterday. WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- In the front lines they call Second Lieut. Charles E. Kelly of Pittsburgh "Commando Kelly," for he turned out to be really tough where the Germans were concerned.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dee. 5 -- Paramount has acquired from Edward Small screen rights to the Richard Henry Dana classic "Two Years Before the Mast" with the intention of filming it in the summer on a large scale. Alan Ladd will be starred. A screen play, written for Small in 1939 by Seton I. Miller, went with the rights.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- The successes now attending Russian arms are built on a foundation laid during a 300-hour battle fought last July. Official descriptions, now published, of the German onslaught in the Kursk salient, its failure and the subsequent launching of the Russian counteroffensive disclose several factors relevant to the present situation in both its offensive and its defensive aspects.

With a large congregation present to greet him, the Rev. Dr. Russell F. Auman preached his first sermon yesterday morning as pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, and outlined the policy he intended to pursue in his ministry.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Bruins waged a determined battle all the way to subject the Canadiens to their first setback in their fifteen National Hockey League starts this season by a 5-4 margin tonight before a crowd of 13,500 at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Completion of pipeline and other overland transportation projects now under construction would solve within a few months the problem of distributing to points in need all petroleum produced in the United States, the Petroleum Administrator for War reported today.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- The Liberty ship Webb Miller, named for a correspondent of The United Press who lost his life in a blackout in London in May, 1940, was launched today, the 100th Liberty ship to go down the ways of the Todd Shipyards here.

Mrs. Erwin Seligman and Mrs. Ruth Chase Goldberg of New York won the national contract bridge open pair championship in the tournament at the Astor Hotel last night, topping thirty-two pairs which had survived, in three preliminary rounds, from a starting field of 106 pairs.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The stock markets here experienced no important reaction as a result of the Cairo conference. Business continued to dwindle, as is usual toward the year-end, but sentiment and prices registered a modest improvement. The Cairo conference, interesting though it was in its deep significance for the future of Japan, was not what the markets are looking for.

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America yesterday made public its annual race relations message challenging the evils of racial discrimination and segregation and calling upon all Christian people to be 'unprejudiced and wise enough to bridge and cross the chasms of racial isolation and segregation."

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A German news agency said today that the Turkish President, Gen. Ismet Inonu, conferred with President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill in Cairo yesterday. WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A communique on the conference at Teheran between President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin and their staffs will be issued tomorrow at 1 P.M. But it will probably add little to what is already known:

The announcement over the Moscow radio last Saturday morning which gave the first official news of the Teheran conference stated that the meeting had taken place "a few days ago." This revealed that the talks ended earlier in the week -- Thursday is the day now reported in London -- and implied that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill were on their way home.

ELVERSON, Pa., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Nine Army fliers were killed and two others were seriously hurt when a B-24 bomber crashed, exploded and burned just before midnight last night in a clump of trees on a farm near this southeastern Pennsylvania village, the Army said today.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 -- Production of raw steel last week remained unchanged from the week before, at 99 per cent of rated capacity. Indications were that the rate would be maintained this week.

BARI, Italy, Dec. 3 (Delayed) -- This city experienced its first air attack of the war today. What was probably the first bomb to fall knocked me flat.

Total shipments of hosiery during October amounted to 12,560,863 dozen pairs, compared with 13,011,889 for the 1942 month, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers announced yesterday. The decrease in shipments amounted to 3.5 per cent, the association stated, and was attributed to substantial declines in women's full-fashioned stockings, women's seamless stockings, half-hose and slacks, and children's and infants' hosiery.

A warning that Catholics should avoid acts that might lend encouragement to such movements as the Ku Klux Klan was voiced yesterday morning by Special Sessions Justice Myles A. Rationing may exercise some constraint over culinary operations, but it need not prevent traditional holiday celebrations, according to the New York State Emergency Food Commission. In the agency's opinion parties this Christmas and New Year's will still be possible providing the hostess knows what foods are abundant and has the ability to use and combine them in menus that are appropriately festive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Interpreting their responsibility in international affairs, both Democrats and Republicans of the House Foreign Affairs Committee plan to study and discuss fully the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration before voting on Chairman Sol Bloom's joint resolution authorizing Federal appropriations to UNRRA, it was learned today.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- A coordinated three-power multi-front attack designed to attain the Allies' first war aim, the destruction of the German Army, and the organization of peace after the war seemed one step nearer tonight after the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin meeting at Teheran in Iran.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Dec. 5--Dr. Hans Kindler, who led the National Symphony Orchestra in the chapel of Colgate University here last night, makes claim to being the first man to conduct while in sports clothes a formal concert by a major symphony.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Stocks of lard at five Western packing centers showed an increase of 1,590,000 pounds in November, the first rise of consequence in some time, and packers' brokers express the belief that stocks will continue to accumulate during the period of heavy marketing of hogs, which recently has been about the largest on record, bringing talk of temporary embargoes on shipments to some of the leading Western packing points.
F.J. Emmerich, vice president of Block International Corporation, announces that Ralph I. Sabin has joined their organization as manager of the textile division.

Eight hundred young people attended an inter-racial conference yesterday afternoon under auspices of thirty Brooklyn religious, social welfare and cultural groups. Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn issued a proclamation in connection with the call for the meeting, setting the day apart as Inter-Racial Unity Sunday in the borough.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Senator Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, in his role as one-man investigator of the diaper dearth in this country, has come up with some additional figures on lend-lease shipment of material for those nursery necessities to North Africa, along with millions of yards of light blue, lavender and pink dyed sheeting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- An Army fighter plane crashed into an unoccupied house in nearby Daly City today, killing the pilot, demolishing the house and damaging four other houses. Then the plane exploded, spewing flaming gasoline in the street.

WITH THE 165TH INFANTRY, on Makin Atoll, Nov. 23 (Delayed) -- Some of the Korean laborers who surrendered here are now helping to unload the transports that brought the 165th Infantry, better known by its old name, the Fighting Sixty-ninth, to the invasion of Makin three days ago.
NAPLES, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Leaders of Italian democratic groups fear that fascism is installing itself in Southern Italy under protection of King Victor Emmanuel and the Badoglio government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Two out of five men in the Army complained that their pants were too tight when they filled in a gripe-sheet given them, a survey by the director of morale of the Services Division revealed today. The War Department immediately issued a rule permitting the men to have their clothes altered without charge.

When Helen Traubel's singing was at its best during her Carnegie Hall recital last night her large audience had the privilege of listening to the finest voice to be heard in this country at present skillfully employed in decidedly effective interpretations.

Cotton prices fluctuated over a relatively wide range last week, but closed the period only slightly changed from the previous week. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 2 to down 5 points.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Dec. 6 -- The Fifth Air Force continued its shattering air offensive against enemy installations on the western end of New Britain Saturday as Liberator and Mitchell bombers dropped sixty-three tons of bombs on the Cape Gloucester area, Gen. Douglas MacArthur stated today.

Pfc. H.W. Shaw of the Medical Corps, now stationed at West Point, found himself eating breakfast yesterday morning with Mayor La Guardia. Private Shaw, who is from Canton, Mass., watched the Mayor put down oatmeal and chuckled.

In an editorial on Nov. 20 you state: "The Treasury recognizes that more than four-fifths of the country's purchasing power is held by those earning less than $5,000. But it has refused to recommend a tax program designed to reach this group." In your issue of Nov. 25 you virtually repeat this charge.
I have just heard over the radio that the Chinese are pleased, now that the Japanese are to be confined to their "tiny islands."

Unusually fine performances of Beethoven's chamber music were given late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by the Budapest Quartet in the fifth concert of the all-Beethoven series sponsored by the New Friends of Music. This was the first appearance in the New Friends' season of the Budapest Quartet, the members of which are Josef Roisman, first violin; Alexander Schneider, second violin; Boris Kroyt, viola, and Mischa Schneider, 'cello.
The goose still hangs high for the Giants, but where they needed a ten-foot pole to reach it, now a five-footer will suffice.
ALGIERS, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A communique:
David Anderson in an article entitled "Russian Advance Worries the Poles," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, mentions the "Curzon Line suggested in 1920 as the eastern boundary (of Poland)."
MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- The winter season promises to be as interesting in cultural as in educational activities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Some members of the Republican "78" Club tonight approved cancellation of the scheduled appearance Tuesday of C. Nelson Sparks, former Mayor of Akron, Ohio, who, in a recently published book entitled "One Man -- Wendell Willkie," alleged that Mr. Willkie's 1940 Presidential nomination was financed and engineered by international banking interests.
The Dakar radio said yesterday that Michel Clemenceau, son of Georges Clemenceau, French Premier during World War I, has been transferred from an internment camp in France to a prison in Germany.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The State Congress of Industrial Organizations ended its two-day annual convention here tonight without officially breaking its political alliance with Jersey City's Mayor Frank Hague. It had been predicted by many delegates that the "honeymoon" of Mayor Hague and the State CIO, which began with their choice of Mayor Vincent J. Murphy of Newark as Democratic candidate for Governor in the November election, would end today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 5 -- The emigre Government of King Peter II of Yugoslavia today flatly accused "Allied" institutions of stimulating the movement in Yugoslavia that has resulted in the creation of a temporary government under the presidency of Marshall Josip Broz [Tito] and his Partisan army.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Warrior, 4-year-old thoroughbred entry, tonight was awarded the championship of the hunter division of the two-day Boulder Brook Club horse show, held in the riding arena of the club on Old Mamaroneck Road.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 6 -- The United States Eighth Air Force shortened its swing yesterday and sent large formations of its heavy and medium bombers, escorted by American and Allied fighters, against Nazi targets in occupied France.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont and R.H. Macy Co., Inc., each contributed $15,000 to the National War Fund's city drive for $17,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Harold H. Helm, vice chairman of the city campaign.

Mischel Cherniavsky, 'cellist, made an excellent impression at his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The Russian-born artist, long active in England, last appeared here as a member of the Cherniavsky Trio, with which he made eight world tours as soloist and ensemble player.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Parts of Nebraska, Kansas and Oklahoma and Texas received light rain or
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The first group of major league baseball stars to visit one of the nation's war fronts arrived by air today to bring service men a bit of second-hand world series atmosphere.

In a move to speed conciliation of labor disputes in this region, the Conciliation Service of the United States Department of Labor opened an office in this city yesterday. Cases from New York and New Jersey, formerly handled in Washington, will henceforth be cared for in the new headquarters in the Parcel Post Building, Ninth Avenue and Thirtieth Street, it was announced by John R. Steelman, director of the Conciliation Service.

The campaign for the resumption, on a limited basis, of the distillation of grain alcohol for whisky blending received the support yesterday of the Society of Restaurateurs. Paul Henkel, president, announced that the board of directors had voted to send a brief embodying arguments for such resumption to Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board.

David J. Elmore, shipping executive, was appointed traffic manager of the Robin Line last week, according to an announcement by S.J. Maddock, vice president of the Seas Shipping Company, Inc. Mr. Elmore leaves his position as New York manager of the Studebaker Export Corporation and the post of special assistant to Capt. Granville Conway, Regional Director here for the War Shipping Administration, to assume his new duties.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Herbert Morrison, speaking before the Middlesex Federation of Labor parties at Wembley today, took on hecklers who disapproved his action in transferring Sir Oswald Mosley from prison to house arrest. In answer to cries of "Try Mosley," he said that if his critics would draw an indictment the case would be tried.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Wheat prices moved higher last week on American exchanges, with the December future on the Chicago Board of Trade selling at a new peak since 1925, with persistent buying by cash interests a factor. There was no material pressure except from profit-taking longs, and farmers as a whole showed little disposition to sell grain stored at terminal markets or held on farms.

ALGIERS, Dec. 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army hacked its way tortuously forward yesterday in the mountains south of the Via Casilina beyond Mignano, but the town itself remained in German hands.

BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 5 (AP) -- German forces retreating before Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's Eighth Amy's drive up the Adriatic coast face a rear threat from an Italian army estimated at 50,000 strong, gathered in the mountains of Abruzzi.

The "caravan" method of merchandising is likely to find renewed impetus in the post-war period as a method to obtain the broadest possible display and distribution of new products, according to trade observers. The method, which was initially developed before the outbreak of the war, although now more or less dormant among commercial organizations, has been adapted by the Army to meet its procurement needs.

Joseph Auslander's book of poem-letters to the people of the occupied countries of Europe, which Simon Schuster will publish Dec. 29, includes salutes to the people of Greece, Belgium, Holland, France, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Norway and Luxembourg.

HONOLULU, Dec. 5 -- Here along Waikiki's palm-lined Main Street and even more on the warm corners of downtown Honolulu one may be reminded at certain periods of the day of how Times Square looks on a Saturday night.

Ten rules for prayer were suggested yesterday morning in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. Declaring that prayer to be effective must be reduced to simple forms and procedures, he outlined the process as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 5--Aircraft of the United States Navy, the Royal Air Force and the Royal Canadian Air Force protecting three transatlantic convoys recently sank six submarines during an eight-day battle, the Air Ministry announced tonight. In these operations, which illustrate the increasing importance of aircraft in protecting convoys on the Atlantic routes, nine other submarines were sighted and attacked, but most of them presumably escaped with slight or no damage.

Sales figures continued to mount last week in the wholesale markets, even though stocks in apparel items were very limited, with some merchandise unable to be promised for future delivery, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 5 -- New measures in the war against inflation in Canada were outlined last night in a radio talk to his countrymen by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission expressed opposition today to pending Federal legislation which it said would extend authority over civil aviation.
LONDON, Dec. 5--Heavy pre-Christmas spending by the public was revealed by last week's jump of 11,800,000 in note circulation. In the same week of last year the rise was only 7,500,000.

Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, have purchased an interest in the Air Express International Agency, Inc., it was reported yesterday by Chester M. Mayer, president of the airline concern. Neither the interest acquired nor the price involved were disclosed, but Paul E. Manheim of the banking firm has been elected to the board of Air Express.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- British officials have explained to French representatives in London that the recent speech of Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, in which he painted a gloomy view of France's future, did not represent the view of the British Government.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that a check of his 1934 list of "things I wanted to do" revealed that most of the objectives had been achieved.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Things are not altogether normal this year, but to a surprising degree Christmas will in one important respect be as usual. This is the part the season plays in building up father's morale.

At yesterday afternoon's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, the order of the program as it had been given last week was changed, and the Mahler "Resurrection" Symphony, No. 2 in C minor, was presented first, with the First and Second Movements coming before the intermission and the symphony concluded after the intermission.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5--Losses in the second largest fire to sweep this resort were estimated today at $500,000. The blaze, which was discovered at 9:25 P.M. yesterday, destroyed sixteen buildings on the Boardwalk between Virginia and Maryland Avenues.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 6 -- Red Army troops fought to compress the German defense lines upon the approaches to the Gomel region rail hubs of Zhlobin and Rogachev yesterday and smashed forward northwest of Propoisk in a drive directed toward Mogilev, Moscow announced early today.

Tonight's premiere is "The World's Full of Girls" at the Royale. The curtain will rise at 8:40. Nunnally Johnson is the author of the play, having borrowed the plot from Thomas Bell's book, "Till I Come Back to You." Compressed into one day, the entire story relates the adventures of a young mechanic just before he joins the Marine Corps.
A traveler recently in France has sent to this country the following account of the French resistance movement:

Ingenuity in the use of costume jewelry can add greatly to the effectiveness of the individual pieces offered this season, which lend themselves easily to imaginative treatment. Many of the designs are miniature reproductions of animals, flowers or birds, developed in bright metals and sparkling stones.

One hundred and twenty-nine contributions for the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York had come yesterday for the start of the thirty-second annual appeal. These advance gifts are proof of the continuing interest of old contributors in the work of the fund among the families and individuals in the city whose need is the greatest known to eight leading private charity organizations.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, Dec. 3 (Delayed) -- The rain, the mud and the Germans have all been overcome in the battle for the Mount Camino massif and we have taken enough of it tonight to say with confidence that the struggle for this greatest obstacle south of Rome is being won.
NAPLES, Dec. 5 -- Today's Risorgimento publishes a first-hand account of the razing by a crowd in Milan last July of the birthplace of the Fascist movement, a hall on Piazza San Secolcro.

The report of the United States Plywood Corporation and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on Oct. 31 shows a net profit of $403,487, equivalent to $1.36 each on 274,932 shares of common stock after preferred dividends. This period is the first half of the corporation's fiscal year which ends on April 30, 1944.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5 -- Five thousand persons at the New Haven Municipal Airport today saw a B-26 Martin bomber named "The Air-Wac" and dedicated to the service of the women in khaki.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5 -- The Amateur Athletic Union concluded its fifty-fifth annual convention today by electing Lawrence Di Benedetto of New Orleans to his fifth consecutive term as president.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- With outstanding skill in sail handling under a puffy and shaky wind, Jack Sutphen drove the dinghy Rum Dum home a winner today in four straight races of the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Representatives of the rigidly controlled German press, meeting yesterday at Weimar, were told by Interior Minister Heinrich Himmler that "the German home front stands firm and united," while Fritz Sauckel, Labor Mobilization Director, said that accounts of mistreatment of foreign workers in Germany were mere "enemy propaganda," the Nazi DNB agency reported in wireless dispatches to European newspapers.

The State of Tennessee awarded yesterday a new issue of $160,000 of county reimbursement bonds to the Chase National Bank and the Commerce-Union Bank of Nashville, Tenn. The bonds are dated Dec. 1 and mature on Dec. 1, 1951. The banks jointly bid 101.021 for the issue, naming the interest rate as 1 1/4 per cent.
Yesterday's Japanese communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Paul Frederick Timm, German-born hero of the American Merchant Marine, pleaded guilty today to charges of claiming false American citizenship, and was fined one penny.

The Spirit of C.C.N.Y., a pursuit plane that has been flying high for the boys and girls at City College's School of Business, has been grounded indefinitely by the War Department. And so has the spirit of C.C.N.Y. at Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Because the statute of limitations under which Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, Gen. Walter C. Short and others charged with dereliction of duty in the Pearl Harbor catastrophe might normally be brought to trial expires tomorrow, the House of Representatives today passed unanimously an emergency measure extending the period in which a court-martial may be held, to one year after the formal declaration of peace with Japan.

The proposed 1944 Westchester County budget, which is scheduled for a public hearing tomorrow is unusual in several respects. It would reduce the county tax levy, yet give special wartime compensation to the majority of employes and create a new service to publicize the county's physical and cultural advantages.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Except for minor revisions at the bottom of the list, the top scorers of the American Hockey League, led by Wally Kilrea of Hershey, maintained their sharp pace during the past week.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The 300-mile length of invasion-threatened New Britain and the 150-mile length of invaded Bougainville have been blanketed by bombs of Allied planes in a new series of air blows, with guns of United States warships adding to the destruction in the Solomons.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Algiers, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Within twenty-four hours after President Roosevelt arrived in this war theatre en route to the Cairo and Teheran conferences the gossip grapevine brought the news to soldiers fighting in Italy hundreds of miles from where the Chief Executive landed.

In a letter published in your issue of Aug. 3 I pointed out the difficulty that might arise when discharged members of the armed services seeking reinstatement to their former jobs find that the employer's place of business or plant has become subject to a collective bargaining agreement which requires membership in a union.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The British Government is urging moderation and compromise upon the two factions contending for control of Yugoslavia, it was indicated today.

Because of the "ambiguous" wording of a special clause being inserted by the Treasury's procurement division in contracts being placed for woolens to supply foreign relief needs, suppliers declared yesterday that some weavers may hesitate to accept such contracts unless the Treasury's intentions in the matter are clarified.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- To assist in the formulation and furthering of a plan to save the surviving Jews of Europe from extinction by the Nazi regime, a Washington emergency committee was organized today under the chairmanship of George Maurice Morris, practicing lawyer and former chairman of the American Bar Association.
CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Jockey Carson Kirk, who rode five winners at the Charles Town track on Friday, came up with four more victors today.

Lou Little, football mentor at Columbia and chairman of the coaches' rules committee, recommended yesterday that forward passing be allowed anywhere behind the line of scrimmage by collegians and that the tee be returned as a rest for the ball at the kick-off, The Associated Press reports.

LONDON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Three American war workers said today after inspecting British factories that the British worker as an individual probably was producing more than the American worker, but that absenteeism in Britain was higher than in the United States.

Opposers of membership of the United States in the League of Nations, lest the League impair our sovereignty or embroil us in war, may be able to accept a war-prevention plan that would bind us on only one point -- cooperation in preventing and combating external aggression.

A large audience filled the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon when the annual Albert Morris Bagby Memorial Concert was given for the benefit of the philanthropic work of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation. George L. Bagby is president of the beneficiary.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The Board of Missions of the former Methodist Episcopal Church, South, today formally came into the proceedings of the Securities and Exchange Commission against E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and Walter C. Rawls, manager of the St. Louis branch of the company, on the side of the SEC.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Opinion in the executive branch of the Government concerning both the Teheran and the Cairo conferences was set forth by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today in a statement declaring that the concerted plans adopted "will undoubtedly result in making effective to the fullest extent the fighting strength of all of the United Nations."
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The text of a declaration by President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin:...

ALLIED AIR BASE, North Africa (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The man in the gray fedora rode slowly in a jeep past a mile-long line of men in uniform outlined by the setting sun. The jeep went to the end of the line, turned and stopped in front of the commanding colonel.

The German news agency DNB transmitted to the controlled European press yesterday a short summary of the declaration issued after the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference at Teheran, but omitted the passage stating that the three leaders had reached "complete agreement as to the scope and timing of the operations to be undertaken from the east, west and south."

Long Island University's varsity basketball team opened its season impressively last night by downing the Brooklyn Army Base quintet, 63 -- 47, in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium. In command of the situation from the start, the Blackbirds were pressed only once.

TWO statements, one very encouraging and the other very disconcerting, were made a couple of days ago. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared that the Navy was well satisfied with its policy of permitting its trainee personnel to engage in intercollegiate football, a most comforting item of news.

While visiting your city recently and enjoying your theatres I found a number of very thoughtless people carelessly striking matches to look at their programs to find out what the next scene would be.

Spread of the T formation and a tendency toward wide-open, "anything goes" offense were the outstanding technical trends of the 1943 football season as reported to The Associated Press in a nation-wide poll of coaches, sports writers and officials.

" Cuando Viajan Mas Estrellas" ("When the Stars Travel"), a Mexican importation, will have its local premiere this Friday at the Belmont Theatre. Jorge Negrete and Raquel head the cast of the comedy, the dialogue of which is Spanish. There are no English titles.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Contending that two 12-year-old Negro children were compelled to walk sixteen blocks to a junior high school because a city Board of Education "custom" would not permit them to attend an all-white school two blocks away, Robert Queen, Trenton lawyer, petitioned the State Supreme Court today for a writ that would compel the nearer school to admit the children.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 7 (UP) -- A communique:

One of the largest crowds ever to see a schoolboy football game in the metropolitan district is expected at the Polo Grounds on Sunday when Mount St. Michael High School of the Bronx will meet St. George High of Evanston, Ill., Chicago district champion.

If Prof. Everett L. Dakan of the Ohio State University Poultry Department, head of WRA's relocation office in Columbus, Ohio, had spent six months trying to think of ways to impede his own work he couldn't have done more than he did. Professor Dakan's task was to induce loyal Japanese-Americans to leave West Coast relocation camps and take farm jobs in the Middle West.

LONDON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan sources reported tonight that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel's German columns were striking along a 450-mile front to clear land supply lanes through Yugoslavia as Allied planes and submarines continued their steady drain on Axis Balkan shipping.

ALGIERS, Dec. 6 -- The battle of the mountains continued yesterday in Italy as Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army wrested three more peaks of the Mount Camino group from the Germans, who are putting up a fanatic battle for every inch of the rocky ground.

MONTREAL, Que., Dec. 6 -- If a Government monopoly of banking were set up in Canada, the socialization of the rest of the economy would be scarcely more than a "mopping-up operation," George W. Spinney, president of the Bank of Montreal, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 7 -- Russian troops smashed the enemy's Smela-Znamenka line in the central Ukraine yesterday, splitting huge German forces guarding those vital junctions on railways leading to Rumania and putting the Red Army within twenty-three miles of the Axis bastion of Kirovograd.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Stock markets here commenced the week quietly today. The chief interest was in tobacco stocks.

Contributions to the fund for the Neediest Cases already beginning to come in from members of our armed forces stationed abroad make this year's appeal world-wide. One American soldier sends his check from conquered Sicily. On the other side of the world a major with the Thirteenth Air Force mails his contribution from "somewhere in the Pacific."

Marvin Bryant, 159 1/2, Dallas, Tex., gained a hard-earned eight-round decision over Larry Anzalone, 155 3/4, West Side, in the feature bout before 3,200 persons at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The verdict was a split one, Referee Johnny Marto voting a draw, but Judges Sam Robinson and Marty Monroe deciding in favor of the Texan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Total assets of national banks on Oct. 18 amounted to more than $66,000,000,000, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today. Returns from the call covered the 5,058 active national banks in the United States and possessions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- All deliveries of wheat, oats and rye, except the September futures of wheat and rye, sold at new seasonal high prices here today on the board of trade. Announcement that the Office of Price Administration had raised the ceiling on corn by 9 cents a bushel, and placed temporary ceilings on oats and barley started a short covering and buying movement that swept prices up rapidly.
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by Reuter:

Men with experience in loading and unloading ships are needed by the Special Naval Construction Battalion, the Seabees Specials, Comdr. S.E. Mittler said in an interview yesterday after a two-month tour of Pacific bases in which he flew 25,000 miles.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The conversations that Prime Minister Churchill and, presumably, President Roosevelt had with President Ismet Inonu of Turkey in Cairo after the Teheran parleys have led to considerable speculation about the possibility of Turkey's entering the war. The background of these conversations would seem to justify this speculation. The question for Turkey, as an ally of Britain, now seems to be not whether but when and how she will help the Allies.

Although wholesale grocers have been granted List A priority for truck tires, the scarcity is so acute that a potential "crisis" confronts the trade which may find its priority position meaningless, M.L. Toulme, vice president National American Wholesale Grocers Association, declared yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- London's reaction to the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin declaration is one of polite enthusiasm, based on the knowledge that it was designed to conceal more than it disclosed.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

" Pillar to Post" has been postponed for a second time. Last scheduled to open this evening at the Playhouse, the premiere now has been deferred until Friday night. As late as yesterday new material for the third act was being inserted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Chester Bowles, Office of Price Administration head, today announced that he has established a legal advisory committee of which E. Barrett Prettyman, Washington, D.C., attorney, has been named chairman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson denied today charges that the war contract renegotiation law has been administered unfairly and declared that abnormal war conditions made the statute a continuing necessity.

The West Indies Sugar Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in the statement for the year ended last Sept. 30, net profit of $2,516,485 after deductions of $600,189 for taxes and $1,007,638 reserve for post-war rehabilitation or adjustments and for other contingencies.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 6 -- Contending that food production would be hampered materially through a proposed sixty-day delay by Congress in giving its final decision on the Administration's subsidy program for combatting inflation, Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, urged the Senate Banking and Currency Committee to take its pending legislation promptly before the Senate for a showdown.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Since the beginning of the war the Royal Canadian Air Force has lost in killed, missing or captured three times as many men as it had on its rolls before September, 1939. An estimated 30 per cent of all flying personnel of the Royal Air Force now is Canadian.

The Virginia Electric and Power Company, a subsidiary of the Engineers Public Service Company, has agreed to buy all the common stock of the Virginia Public Service Company from the General Gas and Electric Corporation for $1,000,000 plus up to $1,500,000 additional if available from future earnings within a limited time, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Donald C. Barnes, president of Engineers Public Service.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- President Roosevelt told a gathering of United States troops in the Persian Gulf Service Command that he, Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin had made great progress in planning "a world for us and for our children when war will cease to be a necessity."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- After a week's strike called by the Culinary Workers Union to compel seven food checkers and cashiers to join it, the Earl Carroll Theatre-Restaurant has reopened under a seven-day truce to give them time to reconsider.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross accused Fred Garb, a refugee Austrian chemist, and his wife, Claire, of being "menaces to every refugee in America," in holding the couple in Night Court last night in $100 bail each for hearings in Harlem Court today.

A suit for $32,535,976, naming as defendants the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and two corporations in which it was said to have large holdings, was filed yesterday in Federal court here. The plaintiffs alleged breach of a 1923 contract involving exploitation of Venezuelan oil property which since has become "the largest producing oil field in the world."

The stock market found yesterday no surprises or unexpected pronouncements in the communique on the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference. Neither did Wall Street find any basis in the wording of the announcement for hopes of early peace.

A hint that the American Red Cross is about to open a drive for the unprecedented amount -- for a relief fund -- of $200,000,000 was given last night at a dinner of the Fur Industry War Emergency Board at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Brooklyn Crescents, a new team in the loop, will take the place of the New Haven Eagles, which dropped out of the Eastern Hockey League on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by the circuit. The Crescents will play all their home games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace on Tuesday nights.

In "The World's Full of Girls," Nunnally Johnson has written a play which is curiously disappointing. It is so because it has several good passages and some nice characters -- enough of each so that the audience sits hopefully anxious that the whole succeed.

Referring to the Germans' fear of a greater retribution than in 1918, Lord Halifax is quoted in a recent address as follows: "Make no mistake about it; this time the German leaders, and, if they can be coerced, the people, will go on fighting even after they have lost all hope of victory."

Prices in the cotton futures market rose yesterday as the three-power conference in Teheran indicated continuation of hostilities. Commission houses did most of the buying in the late dealings. Active old contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended trading with net gains of 7 to 16 points, the distant positions being strongest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Admiral William F. Halsey, commander of the South Pacific area, promised today that new offensives would not stop with the recapture of territory taken by the Japanese, but that "each of us has an appointment in Tokyo."

TARAWA ATOLL, Gilbert Islands (Delayed) -- After three days of the fiercest fighting yet to develop in the war of the South Pacific, Marine Corps units are systematically mopping up day after day the Japanese snipers and stragglers remaining on the tiny islet of Betio, following a leatherneck victory that may well be the greatest achieved in the history of modern amphibious warfare.
ALGIERS, Dec. 6 -- A communique:...

It will not be necessary to wear black calf walking oxfords with pastel chiffons next spring. After a year of shoe rationing this particular style note remains a cartoonist's dream. The play-shoe manufacturers are producing for spring a wide variety of shoes made of noncritical materials.

Wendell L. Willkie, Republican Presidential nominee in 1940, declared yesterday that if the views of Alf M. Landon, the party's 1936 nominee, are to govern in the 1944 campaign, the Republican party should get a nominee other than Mr. Willkie.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Marriage, winner of the $25,000 New Orleans Handicap last winter, was assigned top weight of 124 pounds today for the $15,000 added Louisiana Handicap to be run at the Fair Grounds on Saturday, Dec. 18.

The overseas branch of the Office of War Information worked full blast last night to carry to the ends of the earth the story of the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conference at Teheran, The Associated Press reported.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The proposed sale of Highland Utilities Company's Mesa Verde (Col.) electric properties and Southern Arizona Public Service Company's electric, ice and water plant in Cochise County, Ariz., was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a step in the dissolution of the companies' parent, North Continent Utilities Corporation.

Details of the eight-day engagement in which six U-boats were sunk in the Atlantic are instructive. Our convoys were evidently passing Iceland behind a protective screen of Allied planes operating from coastal bases and later supplemented by United States naval carrier planes.

The Senate may vote today on the resolution approved by its Interstate Commerce Committee supporting a wage increase for 1,100,000 non-operating railroad workers. For Congress to pass this resolution would be a political and economic mistake of the first order.

The enemy guessed or knew of the conference of certain United Nations leaders at the Mena House near Cairo before publication of the official announcement of the meeting. Such things are bound to happen occasionally in spite of the best efforts to prevent premature leakages.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Fifteen additional industrial plants have won the Army-Navy Production Award, Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and Under-Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal said today.

The salesman is "the forgotten man of the all-out war," who may yet lead the country into full postwar employment, according to the Postwar Report of the National Association of Manufacturers, which is to be distributed within the next few days at the group's current War Congress of American Industry at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation have broken more than 2,000 production records in making 60,000,000 tons of steel since Pearl Harbor, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday. The new marks were set in raw materials pig iron, steel ingots and finished products, and in the construction of naval craft.

The second Monday evening concert of the season of the National Orchestral Association, given last night before a large audience at Carnegie Hall, was a "Salute to Our Members in the Armed Forces." The program was conducted by three former members of the association now serving in the Army.

Christmas foods of foreign flavor are being prepared with adherence to the original designs in two Manhattan shops -- the Swedish Pastry Kondis, 204 East Fifty-eighth Street (near Third Avenue), and Ugobono's, 406 Sixth Avenue (near Eighth Street).

ALGIERS, Dec. 6 -- There is an accumulation of evidence that the French role in the Allies' war effort is likely to assume a more tangible form and that Gen. Henri Honore Giraud will actually be a military commander in an active sense.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The National Football League will close one of its most successful season's on Sunday, with attendance for the forty-game schedule totaling 1,072,469. This represents an increase of 36.7 per cent over last year for each game.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Katina Paxinou, who is recovering from an illness which compelled her to cancel engagements with Paramount and RKO, will return to the former studio in early January for the lead with Barry Sullivan in "Marseilles," a picture dealing with the scuttling of a part of the French fleet.

Arrangements were completed yesterday for the ten-round heavyweight battle in which Tami Mauriello, Bronx favorite, will tackle Joe Baksi, also of the Bronx, in Madison Square Garden. They will clash on Jan. 14, Promoter Mike Jacobs announced following adjustment of financial terms which for severad days had held up official announcement of the match.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- After the war the materials for making munitions should be sold only by official prescription, Jan Masaryk, Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs for the Czechoslovak Government, said today in a discussion of the United Nations role after peace.

The first motion pictures of the Tarawa battle, which newsreel men proclaim the most dramatic and timely yet to arrive from any of our war fronts, will go into theatres here today in releases of the five major newsreel companies.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The text of an Anglo-American-Russian statement concerning Iran:

While American business faces a period of high-level activity in the immediate post-war period a serious problem will be confronted in restoring balance to the nation's financial structure "before many post-war years have passed," according to a study released yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- A special House Naval Affairs investigating subcommittee paid a surprise visit to the Johnsville (Pa.) plant of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation today, and the acting chairman, F. Edward Hebert, Democrat, of Louisiana, returned to Washington, expressing himself as "disgusted and discouraged."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The suggestion that Japanese could give lessons in bathing to tenant farmers in Ohio and Michigan, creating a furor in Congress over the War Relocation Authority after the idea was published in a bulletin put out by the Ohio unit of the agency which handles interned Japanese, resulted today in an order for the publication to be destroyed by the WRA.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 6 -- Strong carrier task forces and heavy Navy bombers have attacked a number of bases in the Japanese-held Marshall Islands in the last few days, indicating a new development in the central Pacific offensive, which was touched off by our invasion of the Gilbert Islands.

Max Reinhardt, producer of "The Miracle" and other spectacles here and abroad, who died on Oct. 31, left his estate to his widow and two sons and directed them to make provision for relatives and friends in Europe. This was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- An inter-departmental dispute over whether foodstuffs which civilians could use are being permitted to spoil through improper warehousing appeared tonight to be brewing among the Office of Defense Transportation, the War Food Administration and the Office of Price Administration.

One gracious incident of the Teheran conference related not to the future but to the past. On Nov. 29 Mr. Churchill in behalf of King George VI gave Marshal Stalin a sword forged in Sheffield in memory of the "steel-hearted city of Stalingrad." In the vast Russian military canvas there is a continuous exhibition of tenacity and valor, but Stalingrad is the classic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The War Production Board announced today that furniture hereafter will come under the agency's declaration of policy through which retailers agree to voluntary restraints on sales promotion. Arthur D. Whiteside, WPB vice chairman in charge of the Office of Civilian Requirements, announced the expansion of the policy declaration to include furniture.

Florence Easton, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, believes that singers should be intelligible. Carrying belief into practice, the American soprano prepared her own translations of the texts of songs by Schubert, Brahms and Schumann. As a result, her program was entirely in English, and her singing of it did much to prove her point.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee investigating wartime juvenile delinquency began a study today of a mass of expert -- but conflicting -- testimony on how to solve the growing problem.

General Motors Corporation is now producing war materials at a rate of more than $12,500,000 a day and has turned out more than $5,000,000,000 worth of armaments and other war supplies since Dec. 7, 1941, it was announced yesterday by C.E. Wilson, president.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- Official Moscow received with undisguised pleasure tonight the news that the "second-front" issue is resolved and that Anglo-American-Soviet relations will be on the firmest and friendliest basis in history.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

With the OPA expected to issue its new pricing regulation for raw furs in the near future, it was indicated yesterday that quality grading will be employed for at least six leading raw furs. However, no decision was reached with respect to grading of silver foxes at the conference held between representatives of the silver fox group of the industry and OPA officials.

A plan for the organization of an International Education Office to export scholars, textbooks and educational facilities to a war-torn Europe as soon as peace is achieved was approved yesterday at an all-day meeting of the Commission for the Establishment of an International Education Office of the United States Committee on Educational Reconstruction at New York University.

The American Can Company sent yesterday to stockholders and customers a special report on output prepared for the War Department in the course of contract renegotiations. The company received permission to publish the report after certain deletions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 1, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:...

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison and two predecessors, A. Harry Moore and James F. Fielder, all Democrats, were agreed tonight after appearances before an informal legislative committee that New Jersey's revised constitution should strengthen a Governor's veto powers.

United Air Lines Transport Corporation applied yesterday to the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to add to its nation-wide system 22 more cities and approximately 2,050 miles of new routes in the East and Midwest as well as Eastern Canada.

Having exceeded two goals in the National War Fund, the women's division of the New York committee held a "victory meeting" yesterday morning in the St. Regis Hotel. Final figures announced by the division chairman, Mrs. Oswald B. Lord, showed a division total of $1,437,896, or 70 per cent over the original goal of $800,000 which had been voluntarily extended to $1,250,000.

Back from Ithaca, where they opened their Eastern Intercollegiate League season on Saturday night with a defeat at the hands of Cornell, Columbia's basketball forces resumed practice on the Morningside court yesterday for their second league game and first at home, with Princeton on Saturday night.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- A senior American staff officer from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Southwest Pacific command, speaking on the eve of the Pearl Harbor anniversary, predicted today that Japan could eventually be crushed without the need of an Allied invasion of the Japanese islands themselves.

The American premiere of "The Two Misers," an operetta by the eighteenth century Belgian composer, Andre Ernest Gretrey, will take place tonight in the Brander Matthews Theatre of Columbia University, West 117th Street, under the auspices of the Columbia University Committee for War Relief and the Friends of Belgium.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Efforts to check excessive hog loadings continued unsuccessful, 20,000 head arriving here today. In addition, 17,000 hogs which had been bought at outside points for direct billing by big packers were received. The War Food Administration estimated that about 5,000 head would remain unsold at the end of today's session.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 5 per cent last week over the comparative week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported an increase of 14 per cent over the like 1942 period.

A BRITISH HOSPITAL IN ENGLAND, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Three American Air Force sergeants who "couldn't get comfortable enough to die" told from their hospital cots today how they survived seventy hours in bitter cold after their Flying Fortress was forced down in the English Channel Dec. 1.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- The greatest security measures in the history of the Middle East were taken for the protection of the "Big Three," their staffs, aides and scores of military, naval and air personnel accompanying them to the conference in Iran.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Anglo-American cooperation over a period of more than a century was held forth to the world as an example of how powerful nations can get along peacefully together, in a speech delivered tonight by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox before the English Speaking Union.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- Final concord on a campaign to destroy the German military power by land, sea and air and to erect an enduring peace in which all nations, both great and small, shall participate, was agreed upon in the momentous Teheran meeting between President Roosevelt, Premier Stalin and Prime Minister Churchill.

Charges that Mayor La Guardia has interfered with the city school system, causing educational officials to bow to his will and robbing the Board of Education of its independence by threatening to withhold funds, were made at the National Education Association school inquiry, which began public hearings here yesterday.

TETERBORO, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Women are not treated like machines in the maze of mechanism at the Eclipse-Pioneer division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation. The plant recognizes their value as operators of the huge turret lathes and gear-cutting machines, but more than that, it treats them as human beings, and there is Mrs. Edna F. Goodrich to prove it.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Circuit Judge James E. Chenot dissolved today an injunction restraining the Tom Moore Distillery Company from paying a Christmas dividend of whisky to its stockholders. Company officials announced immediately that the distribution -- twenty-seven gallons of whisky for each share of stock -- would be made on Dec. 21.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The three-power declaration in Iran stamped a final friendly seal today on relations that threatened Allied control over the Middle East two years ago, at the critical period when the German armies were plunging toward the Caucasus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- New ceiling prices on corn became effective by Office of Price Administration order today, and the prices of oats, barley and sorghum grains were frozen preparatory to issuance of a permanent regulation, expected in sixty days.

Paintings, sculpture, tapestries and various objects of art from the George Blumenthal collection (about 200 items in all) make up an exhibition that opens with a preview for members and guests at the Metropolitan Museum this evening and to the public tomorrow.

" TARGET: GERMANY"* is our Army Air Forces' own official story of the Eighth Bomber Command's first year over Europe. It is a story that began amid doleful shakings of the head, for many observers doubted the practicability of daylight precision bombing under the cloudy atmospheric conditions of the North European theatre.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- After three weeks of legal wrangling, Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the New Jersey Supreme Court today granted counsel for John R. Longo, former deputy Hudson County clerk, a certificate of reasonable doubt, resulting in Longo's immediate release in bail from the Hudson County jail and opening the way for appeal to the Supreme Court from his conviction on an election fraud indictment.
If the surplus of metals left over from war supplies continues to grow, American housewives again may be able to buy electric irons and washing machines in 1944.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- British and American Chiefs of Staff took time out during their return from the Teheran conference for a twenty-four-hour sight-seeing tour of the ancient city of Jerusalem, it was revealed here today.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 6 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho indicated today that the Mexican Government had already decided that a Mexican expeditionary force would be sent abroad to fight side by side with the United States in the Pacific.

Already under censure by the August grand jury in Kings County for alleged failure to suppress crime in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the administration of Mayor La Guardia was accused yesterday by the holdover July grand jury of inadequately policing the entire borough.

The Giants were the talk and toast of the town yesterday following their courageous triumph over the Redskins at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. The way they fought and came from behind and the way they played throughout the game, one of the best ever for the spectators, was still the leading topic of conversation in the sports world.

The board of governors of the League of New York Theatres, organization of Broadway producers, will meet at 2:30 P.M. Thursday to consider protests made by some of the league's members against the New York City Civic Center at Mecca Temple.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 7 -- Constant Japanese reinforcements in planes and troops as well as heavy movements of escorted convoys and renewed ferocity in the ground fighting in this area make clear that the enemy is bitterly determined to hold the New Britain-Solomons-New Guinea arc as protection for Truk from the south.

A new method for molding synthetic resins, which will reduce substantially plastics production costs and widen the market for plastics products, was outlined yesterday by the American Chemical Society at the Nineteenth Exposition of Chemical Industries which opened in Madison Square Garden.

This department's private optimist thinks the Cairo-Teheran publicity mix-up has certainly been irritating. It may even have done the Allies some harm in the rather misty realm of psychological warfare. But we must not jump from Allied mistakes in propaganda to unwarranted conclusions about lack of Allied coordination in other phases of the war, phases more important than propaganda.

Mayor La Guardia, who attended yesterday the first concert of the six in the Monday afternoon symphony series, given by seventy members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society for high school students at the Hunter Co llege Auditorium, selected four notes for Alec Templeton, pianist, to use as the theme for an improvisation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- The only three Anglo-American newspaper men in Teheran, Iran, during the tri-power talks there were John Wallis, regular Reuter correspondent in Iran; Edward Angly of The Chicago Sun and Lloyd Stratton of The Associated Press.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- Premier Stalin lifted his glass in a toast to "my fighting friend, President Roosevelt," then walked around the table, clinked glasses with the President and drank his wine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt does not like the word "sacrifice" applied to United States participation in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- United States submarines, ranging 3,000 miles over the Pacific and into Far Eastern waters have sunk eleven more enemy supply ships to close two years of undersea warfare which has netted a bag of more than 300 vessels.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- Geographically, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill met Premier Stalin considerably more than halfway when they went to Teheran. But Premier Stalin took a dramatic step that, a year ago, few would have ventured to predict -- crossing his own frontiers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Accumulating evidence and the opinions of competent observers "indicate that American agriculture does not have the capacity to produce the quantities of food which our Government has, at least by implication, promised to the hungry millions of Europe," H.P. Rusk, dean of the College of Agriculture, University of Illinois, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court ordered today reargument of a case involving the right of Negroes to vote in Democratic primary elections in Texas and granted the State permission to file briefs and participate in oral arguments.

Major warehouse interests of New York City disclosed yesterday that they already had taken steps to expand freezer capacity at least 1,000,000 cubic feet. This move is part of a program to ease storage, transportation and other problems caused by the Federal Government's vast hoard of food.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Military plans for the defeat of the Wehrmacht drawn at Teheran, Iran, by President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin, will probably be fully activated in the first three months of 1944.

FOOCHOW, China, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- On a sunny hill overlooking this brown Chinese city, and behind the vine woven compound walls, some of the old treaty port life of China still lingers in Foochow. It is not very bustling now. After two years of war the foreign population is reduced to eighty-one in a city of 300,000.

Dolores Miller, violinist and a winner of the Naumburg Musical Foundation Prize, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. She played with her pianist, Leonid Hambro, Mus. 3/C, USNR, the Brahms violin and piano sonata in A major, the Prelude and Fugue from the Bach G minor unaccompanied sonata, the Glazounoff violin concerto and shorter pieces.

The ticklish question of whether a prosecutor ought to shake the hand of a murder defendant because he has been obliged to recommend discharge of the case for lack of evidence was settled in General Sessions Court yesterday by Jacob Grumet, assistant district attorney, who accepted the hand of Irving Premisler, 41 years old, rather hesitatingly, with the words, "You had a close call."

The thirty-nine dental schools in the country have 5,884 soldiers and 1,891 apprentice seamen enrolled under the Army and Navy accelerated training programs, Dr. Gerald D. Timmons, dean of Temple University Dental School, Philadelphia, reported yesterday at the annual Greater New York dental meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
An epidemic of chapped hands is predicted for the coming season by one of Manhattan's most elegant manicure salons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The encouraging news of the Teheran conference and of the Navy's newest carrier raid on the Marshall Islands fittingly marked the second anniversary of Pearl Harbor today.
