Speaking informally at the annual meeting of the Lawn Tennis Writers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, President Holcombe Ward of the United States Lawn Tennis Association expressed himself as in favor of holding the national amateur championship again in 1944.

To expand its facilities for training Waves at Hunter College buildings in the Bronx the Navy has taken the eighty-five-family apartment building at 115-17 West 197th Street, it was learned yesterday.

Producers of wool and mohair must protect their markets by a comprehensive and intelligent program of experimentation, education and promotion without delay unless these textiles are to become blending fibers of secondary importance, subject to the dominance of synthetic fibers in price, style and usage value, F. Eugene Ackerman said yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisans, stubbornly holding open a breach in Adolf Hitler's southeastern Balkan defenses in anticipation of an Allied southern invasion as promised at the Teheran conference, tonight reported fresh, small, hard-won victories against Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel's Nazi invaders.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Loss of the vital rice bowl city of Changteh after fifteen days of siege by the Japanese was admitted by the Chinese High Command today in a communique that said the ancient city fell Dec. 3. The Japanese suffered heavy casualties during the battle for the city, the bulletin added.

The first of the new service ribbons to be awarded in this area to civilian employes of the War Department was presented yesterday to Mrs. Joan McMahon of Brooklyn by Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command, at a ceremony on Governors Island.
A new issue of $4,000,000 of temporary loan notes was announced yesterday by Boston, Mass., for award today. It will be dated Dec. 10, 1943, and will be payable on Oct. 2, 1944.

David B. Costuma, secretary of the Board of Elections, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia made public last night, revealed that the Mayor had attempted to enforce a 10 per cent reduction in the board's payroll. The board, he asserted, does "not propose to do that" and he charged that the Mayor's action showed "caprice" and was "mischievous."

OF the four Baltic States, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, only Finland has a population much greater than that of the borough of Brooklyn. What should become of them when hostilities cease could be a perplexing problem were it not for the fact that the lord of the Kremlin may well present the world with a fait accompli that no nation will dare to question.

Bias Gonzales, 45 years old, a fur dyer, could have pleaded guilty to second-degree murder for shooting a boy in Harlem last March and got off with a prison sentence of twenty years to life but he gambled on a General Sessions Jury trial, was convicted of first-degree murder and was sentenced yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan to die in the electric chair in the week beginning Jan. 17.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Supporting representations made last week by the City Affairs Committee of this city, the American Civil Liberties Union announced in New York today a request to Attorney General Francis Biddle to investigate "the denial of civil rights to citizens of Jersey City under the administration of Mayor Frank Hague." Roger N. Baldwin, director of the union, communicated with Mr. Biddle by letter.

MOSCOW, Dec. 7 -- The best Soviet reaction to the Stalin-Churchill-Roosevelt declaration came today from the workers, already working at top speed, who pledged further to speed up war production so as to provide sufficient arms for the final assault on Germany, the time and place of which were settled at the Teheran conference.

The Democratic majority in the City Council will demand an "official, detailed and satisfactory explanation" of the $12,154,000 increased allocation of funds for the municipal airport, now under construction at Idlewild, in Queens, before it approves the city $54,207,310 capital budget for 1944, it was learned last night.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Innocent Voyage" tomorrow night at the Belasco Theatre for the benefit of Washington Cathedral. The event has been arranged by members of the New York Junior Committee for the Cathedral of which Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander is chairman.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- Although spotted two early tallies, the Boston Bruins had to set off a four-goal blast during the third period to gain a 6-6 National Hockey League tie with the Detroit Red Wings tonight before a crowd of 7,500 at the Boston Garden.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY in Italy, Dec. 7 -- The Allies in this sector celebrated the second anniversary of America's entry into the war by finally capturing the peak of Monastery Hill, taking many German prisoners.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 -- Almost a year before President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill met President Ismet Inonu, Turkey sent approximately 100 army officers to the United States to examine this nation's war potential and methods.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,284, which compared with 937 in the preceding week and 754 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 500 against 730 last Tuesday.

One of Miss Helen Baxter's "300 war boys" came home yesterday, to bring his personal Christmas greetings to the woman who has befriended many young men and women. John Munson, 23-year-old yeoman first class, with ribbons for battle service and citations on his Navy uniform, walked into the Children's Aid Society at 103 East Twenty-second Street and surprised Miss Baxter, director of the farm home department.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- The battleship Wisconsin, largest and most powerful warship in the world, was launched into the Delaware River today as the Philadelphia Navy Yard continued its practice of making Dec. 7 a date for the Japanese to regret.

The ex-office boys drop in once in a while, home on leave, and after they have paid their respects to the office girls who have taken their places, they stop by to say hello to their ex-bosses. Some of them are privates or seamen, third class, but a few carry gold chips on their shoulders or gold stripes on their sleeves.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Turkish Government is ready to assume a more active part in the war when it feels its resources are equal to the strain of conflict, but an intensification of the psychological offensives the Allies are waging against the Axis is likely to be the only immediate visible result of the conference between President Roosevelt and President Inonu and Prime Minister Churchill at Cairo.

With open hearings on the pending tax measure apparently completed by the Senate Finance Committee, retailers are shaping plans in the expectation that the higher excise levies will become effective Jan. 1, it was reported here yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 7 -- To celebrate the issue of its fiftieth number, the clandestine French publication Combat appeared in a large format -- the size of a normal newspaper -- with many photographs.

Governor Dewey moved closer yesterday toward being a candidate for the Presidency in 1944 than he has heretofore permitted himself to be placed. Hailed by Alf M. Landon of Kansas, the 1936 Republican nominee, as "the outstanding possibility" just a few moments after he had conferred with Mr. Dewey, the New York Governor acknowledged the tribute, when informed of it by a reporter, with a "thank you" and "no comment."

Josef Lhevinne gave a piano recital devoted to Schumann last night at Times Hall in the "Concerts at 9" series, before an audience including musical notables. The program opened with the "Etudes Symphoniques," Opus 13, continued with the Toccata and four pieces from the "Fantasiestuecke," and closed with "Carnaval," Opus 9. Several encores were given at the close of the printed list.

For writing what was considered "the most challenging children's book of the year," John R. Tunis received a scroll of honor for his "Keystone Kids" at the opening yesterday afternoon of the annual Children's Book Exhibit of the Child Study Association of America.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7 (AP) -- One of the closest finishes of the Fair Grounds meeting resulted in the Magnolia Purse today. The race was for 2-year-old fillies at five and one-half furlongs and attracted seven to the post.

In a news item in your issue of Dec. 3 Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, predicted that living costs may be expected to rise 10 per cent if Congress abolishes food subsidies, stating that this would add $9,000,000,000 to the cost of items customarily bought by American families during the year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Suit for $18,500,000 damages charging a conspiracy to defraud stockholders of a defunct oil company was filed today in Federal Court in behalf of Dean Cauffield Daily of Los Angeles, nephew and executor of the estate of the late Wallace L. Hardison, publisher of The Los Angeles Herald.

Sixteen hundred enemy aliens, including some Italians, have been sent to internment centers from this area, according to E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of Federal Bureau of Investigation offices here, and Samuel K. McKee, head of the Newark FBI office.

Puppies may be non-rationed, non-critical and unfrozen as to price, but the holiday supply is going to the dogs along with street corner Santas, turkeys and Christmas trees. A survey of pet shops shows that junior has just half his former chance of finding that longed-for pup in his stocking Christmas morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -The situation in the hog market was considerably relieved today with only about 4,000 head remaining unsold at the end of the session. Fresh arrivals totaled 25,000 head, including 6,ten on rec consignment. report of the livestock markets by the War Food Administration follows:
A large apartment building and several private homes in Manhattan figured in residential realty transactions announced yesterday.
The annual Children's Holiday Circus opens today at the Museum of Modern Art -- activities to continue through Sunday, Jan. 30.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 -- Greatest possible care was taken in Ankara to prevent the Axis from learning about the departure of President Ismet Inonu for the Cairo conference.

Low-price clothing is disappearing from the city's stores. This consumers' complaint was acknowledged yesterday by various retailers and was borne out on the wholesale level by a survey of shifts in manufacturers' price lines.

Some questions on the subsidies are raised by F.A. Harper in your Dec. 3 issue. One of Mr. Harper's arguments is that if subsidies did save money for the public this saving would be only a paper saving, because he assumes that without subsidies profits would be greater and hence taxes greater, so that the public would not have lost quite all the money represented by increased profits.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Dec. 8 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Senate was in an uproar today and parliamentary courtesies went overboard when angry Southern members voiced their resentment against Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania, who had accused them of entering into "an unholy alliance" with Northern Republicans to defeat the Administration's Service Men's Absentee Voting Bill.

Testifying at the open hearing of the National Education Association's inquiry into local school conditions, Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, former member of the Board of Education, charged yesterday that Mayor La Guardia consistently "bossed" the board, interfered with its legal appointive powers, forced the acceptance of undesirable school sites and ordered the dismissal of experienced and greatly needed teachers.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, one of the few remaining State agencies still under Democratic control, announced the appointment today of Philip Halpern of Buffalo, Republican, as chief counsel to the commission at $15,000 a year.

" Happy Land," a picturization of the novel by MacKinlay Kantor, produced by Twentieth Century-Fox and starring Don Ameche, Frances Dee, Harry Carey and Ann Rutherford, will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Directed by Irving Pichel, the drama's supporting cast includes Richard Crane, Henry Morgan, Minor Watson, Dickie Moore and Cara Williams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Through an amendment to its limitation order on hosiery (L-274) the War Production Board today prohibited "drop-needle" or "needle-out" construction in filament rayon women's hosiery. WPB explained that the construction normally is designed for decorative effects on women's hosiery, but has been banned on filament rayon hosiery because it results in quality deterioration.

The fewer characters John van Druten puts into his plays, the more successful they seem to be. One recalls his smash hit "There's Always Juliet," with only four players. Tonight he will endeavor to surpass that feat -- and from all accounts he will -- with his comedy "The Voice of the Turtle," a title borrowed from "The Song of Solomon."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 7 -The mountain labored and brought forth a mouse, the Stockholm Aftonbladet's Berlin correspondent was told by official quarters late last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 (delayed) (AP) -- Approximately 1,000 trucks now are hauling military supplies from India into Russia over a new 800-mile East Iran route which was entirely handmade in three months by pick and shovel by an army of 30,000 men, women and children supervised by a staff representing fifteen nationalities.

An appeal for lend-lease aid for the provisional Government of Yugoslavia set up by the Yugoslav Partisans was made here yesterday by Louis Adamic as president of the United Committee of South Slavic Americans.

A program designed to assure ex-soldiers that industry intends to make the best use of their new talents and experiences, rather than automatically putting them back in the jobs they left when hostilities began, was announced yesterday by Richard H. Moulton, sales personnel director of General Foods Sales Company, a subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation.

The six-story apartment house at 101-103 Brightwater Court, Brooklyn, on a plot 81 by 111 feet, has been sold by the Farraday Realty Corporation to a client of Benjamin Neugeboren, attorney. The house accommodates forty-one families and is assessed for $150,000, carrying a first mortgage of $137,250. Louis Solomon was the broker in the transaction.

Something like 22,000 shooting-iron toters who had the forethought to acquire special licenses will spend a part of the next few days tracking down antlerless deer (those without horns or having horns less than three inches long) in fifteen of New York State's counties.

A gathering of 200 baseball men and writers, including two principals in the drama, Pitchers Marius Russo and Johnny Murphy of the Yankees, relived the world series of 1943 yesterday when the American League held a preview of its latest motion picture at a luncheon in Toots Shor's restaurant.

It would not affect consumer prices of textiles nor be inflationary if the Government would permit marginal producers as well as those willing to pay overtime wage rates to charge "offset" prices for such output in order to assure maximum output for military, home front and foreign needs, Frank L. Walton, former director of the War Production Board's textile, clothing and leather division, declared yesterday.

Ever since 1910, when Korea rose in mass non-violent revolt against Japan, she has been working against the greatest odds to free herself from the yoke of the aggressor. The Sino-Japanese war brought a glimmer of hope to the suffering nation, and Pearl Harbor brought in its wake the brightening of that hope of a free and independent Korea.

New municipal financing in 1943 will be the smallest in many years, on the basis of eleven months' figures reported yesterday by The Daily Bond Buyer. Up to Nov. 30 the volume was only $488,208,818, compared with $541,101,939 for the same period in 1942 and with $1,038,914,643 for the first eleven months of 1941.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Congressional action to enable the broadcasting industry to continue as freely as in the past the exploration and development of possibilities of radio art, such as television, was urged by Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, at today's hearing on the Wheeler-White bill before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

National and international economy in the post-war era must be based on full production, full employment and maximum national income, Wayne Chatfield-Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Following is the communique issued here tonight:

NEWARK, Dec. 7 (AP) -Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company of Philadelphia, sounded a warning tonight to "business men and economists who look at the future and think they see a line-up of customers a mile long, waiting to buy the things they have been wanting in these years of shortages."

Iran is a shadowy place to most Americans. They know that its name, a variant of Aryana, means that it is the traditional cradle of that Aryan race which Hitler has somehow confused with the Nordics but which is just about as exclusive and inclusive in the modern world as the human race.

The cost of the war will not be discharged for a century and will require all sorts of economies from United States citizens, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in an address at McMillin Academic Theatre, opening the university's four-day war relief drive.

In the heart of Times Square Mayor La Guardia unveiled yesterday a billboard with two stars. One, in blue, bore the number 78,808, honoring artists and craftsmen of America's entertainment industry now in the armed forces. The other, in gold, held the number 135, a tribute to members who had died in service.

The Western Department Stores Corporation has called a meeting of stockholders to be held in Oakland, Calif., on Dec. 27 to vote on a plan for capital reorganization which would eliminate arrears on its 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at 40th Street), member agency of the National War Fund, through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of three amusements available today.
Two large loft buildings were among the commercial properties reported by Manhattan brokers yesterday as having passed into new hands.

The theory and legality of "suspension orders" issued by the Office of Price Administration was debated in Federal court yesterday by counsel for a restaurant whose meat rations had been suspended and an OPA attorney. Judge Francis G. Caffey reserved decision on the plea to nullify the suspension.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- On the second anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Congress adopted and sent to the White House today a resolution to compel within six months the court martial of Lieut. Gen. Walter C. Short and Vice Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, who were the commanders at the base.

Rudolf Serkin is one of the great pianists of our day and he has a large following. But the public does not beat down the doors of concert halls to hear him as it does for one or two other virtuosos. At his Carnegie Hall recital last night Mr. Serkin had a near-capacity audience and it accorded him tumultuous approval.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Congressional committee just back from a flying inspection tour of United States military bases in Central and South America reported today that the "good neighbor" policy had produced mutual benefits throughout the Western Hemisphere, but stated that "bungling tactics by amateur good-will emissaries who bid against each other have created confusion and injured American standing."
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

In his Chinese peregrinations Brooks Atkinson has reached Foochow, capital of the province of Fukien. One of the five treaty ports established by the Treaty of Nanking in 1842, it used to be one of the great cities of China. Its palmy days began early in tile last century, when it was a chief port of the tea trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, charged today that the recent criticism of the Administration's Latin American policy by Senator Hugh A. Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, showed the author to be a "catspaw in a bit of journalistic ghost-writing."

Japanese propagandists paid tribute yesterday to the "successful propaganda" of the Allies in bringing about the surrender of Italy and indicated some uneasiness about the propaganda effect on Axis war fortunes of the Teheran conference of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin.

A last-hour wave of buying, unparalleled for several months by its intensity, struck the share market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and lifted many values 1 to 2 points and even more in special instances. Transfers of about 400,000 shares were crowded into the final thirty minutes of trading as orders poured into brokerage offices for issues with a purely armament flavor.

Word has reached the John Day Company that President Chiang Kai-shek has become so interested in Lin Yutang's new book, "Between Tears and Laughter," that he has instructed the Ministry of Education to arrange for an early publication of a Chinese edition.

The cotton futures market extended yesterday its gains for the third consecutive session, but active profit-taking and hedge selling offered resistance on the bulge. At the close prices of active old cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net increases of 8 to 25 points.

The students at City College's School of Business can stop pining for their "lost" pursuit plane, a Treasury Department spokesman declared yesterday. Absolving gremlins of all blame, he said machinery already had been set in motion to assure that The Spirit of C.C.N.Y., for which the students had raised $75,000 in bonds and stamps, would be christened within half a year.

The tissues of the mouth are being used increasingly by the medical profession as accurate mirrors of serious diseases hidden in other parts of the body, it was reported yesterday before the Greater New York Dental Meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Lieut. Comdr. Charles F. Geschickter, formerly Professor of Pathology at the Johns Hopkins University Medical School, now at the Naval Medical School at Bethesda, Md.

Surprise was occasioned in the New York Guard last night when it was learned that two officers of the Third Battalion, Fifty-first Regiment, had resigned and requested a transfer to the inactive reserve after a dispute with Col. Lawrence H. Beattie, commander of the regiment, over basic policy.

On Nov. 28 a United Press dispatch from London quoted the Yugoslav Partisans as announcing that the rail line from Sarajevo to Visegrad had been practically destroyed. Yesterday the headquarters of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, broadcasting from "the woods and mountains of Yugoslavia," declared:

The signatures at the bottom of the Teheran Declaration make a person wonder just how the order of procedure was determined. They read "Roosevelt, Stalin, Churchill." In alphabetical order the three countries would be, using the popular names, America, British Empire, Russia.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) (By Mail) -- The United States Army isn't afraid that women cannot keep a secret.

Apartment house dealing contributed to the realty market activity in the Bronx yesterday. The largest transaction of this nature was the sale of the six-story elevator house at 2290-2300 Sedgwick Avenue, on a plot 169 by 172 feet, by William Thomas, Benjamin Antin and Henry G. McDonough, trustees, to Samuel Rezniek, operator.

When New York University sent its green basketball team into action in the Heights Gym last Saturday night, Howard Cann was launching his twenty-first season as head coach of the Violet. Last evening, as he prepared to send his charges through the one hour -- 6 to 7 P.M. -- available for daily practice, the genial veteran said this would be the strangest season he had ever coached.

With an eye particularly on conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, Brooklyn's "Little Harlem," an attempt to solve the borough's welfare problems will be made at a meeting Friday afternoon of sixteen leaders of the city's health and welfare programs, it was announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland. Dec. 7 -- Killed, wounded and missing in the massive Royal Air Force attacks on Berlin since Nov. 18 number close to 200,000, according to information from travelers reaching Basle from the Reich capital in the past few days.

Too much must not be expected of Turkey too soon. By her rigid insistence upon neutral rights, she has contributed much already to the frustration of German aims in the Middle East. There have been hints from time to time that under certain conditions she might do more toward helping to achieve victory for the Allies, with whom she has now professed the "closest unity" and "identity of purpose."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- James F. Byrnes, the War Mobilization Director, made a fighting radio speech tonight on "Holding the Line Against Inflation," in which he struck at pressure groups in agriculture, labor and industry, at Congress and even the people as failing to comprehend the seriousness of the situation which he called "a crisis on the home front."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee began hearings today on a resolution authorizing appropriations to help finance the United States Relief and Rehabilitation Administration with a day-long session which produced not a single voice of objection to the proposal of the UNRRA.

For services in the salvage campaign of the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, twenty-five boys and girls received certificates from Aaron L. Jacoby, borough salvage chairman, in a ceremony yesterday at the CDVO office, 131 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 7 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho today had meetings with Gen. Lazaro Cardenas, Minister of War, and other high officers of the Mexican Army, it was stated in circles close to the Government with whom he has discussed a proposal of the House Military Affairs Committee of the United States Congress that Mexico be invited to participate directly in the war.

The news yesterday of fresh American attacks on the Marshall Islands was timed to the very day for the second anniversary of Pearl Harbor, when Japanese carriers steaming secretly from these same islands loosed their planes against our fleet.

MANEUVERS HEADQUARTERS, Camp Mackall, N.C., Dec. 7 -- Two invasion "musts," the ability of the troop carrier command to lift an air-borne division and deposit it on a penpoint target of strategic enemy territory, and the ability of an air-borne division, once set on the ground, to assemble itself and fight were tested tonight on the largest scale yet attempted by the Army.

Reductions averaging 16 per cent in the assessed valuation of the property at 435 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-eighth Street, owned by Robert E. Simon, have been ordered by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin for the tax years 1939 to 1943.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Until Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, addressing the English-Speaking Union of Chicago yesterday, described the wartime working arrangement of the United States and British Navies as "the backbone of our post-war naval police force, already organized and functioning," the project had not been brought forward as high Administration policy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- The Treasury Department issued tonight this questiona-and-answer guide concerning the Dec. 15 income tax declaration:

ALGIERS, Dec. 7 -- Both Allied armies in Italy are now obviously engaged in a knock-down-and-drag-out battle against an enemy who is returning blow for blow and is determined to keep the Allies not only south of Rome but south of Cassino, as well as south of Pescara, along the Adriatic.

There are two aspects of the Declarations of Teheran which merit the special attention of Germany's satellites. The first is the pointed and exclusive emphasis which President Roosevelt, Premier Stalin and Prime Minister Churchill, as representatives of the three most powerful nations in the world, have put on their determination to direct concerted and relentless attacks against the German armed forces until their complete destruction.

The historic property at Sands Point, L.I., which once was the estate of Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont and later the estate of Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, has been acquired by Edmund G. Burke of the Hotel Marguery, New York, who will make his home there.

Says the Department of Agriculture, in its November "Demand and Price Situation": "Average industrial worker's income has increased about 85 per cent from the level prevailing in the five years just before the war, whereas in the same time, the Bureau of Labor's index of the cost of living has gone up less than 25 per cent."

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Sir James Grigg, Minister of War, defended the War Office in the House of Commons today against the charge that it had adopted a mechanical device, said to be capable of guiding troops through fog and darkness in unknown country, twenty-eight years ago but had never properly investigated it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Two new and superior Army fighter planes are in production and will soon join the P-38 Lightning and P-47 Thunderbolt to give the United States the most potent fighter fleet in existence, Robert A. Lovett, assistant secretary of war for air, has disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A spokesman for the National Council of Farmer Cooperatives opposed food subsidies today before the Senate Banking Committee. Ezra T. Benson, executive secretary, suggested as an alternative wage subsidies of $482,000,000 in four important industries, which he said would enable the Government to achieve a direct price rollback of $4,750,000,000 on civilian and government purchases.

Let parents take notice: Christmas trees are arriving, although in smaller quantities and at higher prices than in any recent year. A survey of wholesalers and retailers revealed yesterday that the tightest tree market in memory now exists, with labor and transportation shortages combining to keep suitable balsam and spruce in their native habitats, but some dealers say that the supply may still be "adequate."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 -- Zharko Broz, son of Marshal Josip Broz [Tito], the new President and War Minister of the temporary Yugoslav government created in the part of that occupied land under Partisan control, has been decorated by the Red Army with its highest award.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 -- The strategically placed republic of Turkey closely identified herself with the interests and views of the United Nations in a communique issued today following seventy-two hours of intermittent conferences between President Ismet Inonu, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill.

That he is taking nothing for granted with respect to his approaching battle against Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City lightweight, is being daily demonstrated by Sammy Angott, Washington, Pa., boxer who is recognized as the National Boxing Association titleholder.

Major General Smith's statement quoted by George Horne that our losses at Tarawa were comparable "only to Pickett's charge" overlooks two cases of heavier losses proportionally. With no desire to take anything away from that glorious performance, it is proper to call attention to Burnside's attack on Marye's Heights, Fredericksburg, and Hood's attack at Franklin, Tenn.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES STATION, in Britain, Dec. 7 -- Standing on the mile-long runway of an airfield recently completed by United States Army engineers, Lieut. Gcn. Jacob L. Devers, American commander in the European theatre, said today representatives of the most powerful nations of the earth had written the epitaph of Germany and Japan and those Axis States "shall be stripped of territory and power."

M. Bennison, in 16 E 96th St; I. Sender, in 360 Central Pk West; Leroy Hollenbeck, in 41 W 72d St; R. Hardy, in 200 W 70th St; J. Rosen, in 25 Central Pk West; H.A. Austin, in 145 W 79th St; D.A. Lipton, in 164 W 79th St; R. Grayson, in 1 W 64th St; Paul Peay, in 233 W 77th St -- Apartment Renting Co, brokers.

Dr. Albert Mueller-Deham's letter of Oct. 31 does not state the historical facts about hormone balance correctly. He seems to have forgotten what he wrote in the Wiener Klinische Wochenschrift of Oct. 14, 1932. There he correctly refers to the "vita-hormones of Dr. Zajicek-Grohmann."

Beginning tomorrow, the United States Customs Service will sell at auction "without regard to OPA ceilings" $60,000 worth of choice wines and liquors that came into Government possession when it took over control of a number of ocean liners at the start of the war, it was announced last night at the Custom House.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Increased production of steel plate and sheets required for invasion craft needed in attacks on Japan and Germany was ordered today by the War Production Board.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $3,076,261,926 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Nov. 30 was $30.33, compared with $32.44 at the end of October.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- A picture by Clarence Holbrook Carter, Pittsburgh artist, took the Popular Prize in the Carnegie Institute of Technology's exhibition, "Painting in the United States," it was announced today. His picture was "Let Us Give Thanks."
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Although the Stock Exchange was cheered by the outcome of the Teheran Conference, the bond and share markets remained subdued.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Surplus stocks of textile and leather products are to be treated as have "rejects" and "seconds" in the past, the War Production Board ruled today in amending its orders M-328, which is the basic order controlling distribution of all textiles, clothing, leather and related products.

The Federally owned Steel Recovery Corporation is winding up its affairs after nearly eighteen months of work in locating and redistributing steel in idle inventories at hundreds of plants throughout the country, it was announced here yesterday by Charles F. Cruciger, president.

Navy's football team received one more honor yesterday when Capt. John Whelchel, head coach, accepted in his squad's behalf the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, symbolic of Eastern gridiron supremacy.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 8 -- A Red Army spearhead bore down on Znamenka, rail junction in the Dnieper bend, as three columns drove on the city from separate directions -- but in the north Russian defenders fell back from "a number of populated places" in the Kiev bulge before a German counter-attack using as many as 1,700 tanks, according to reports received here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Lowell Gilmore, New York stage actor who came west for Casey Robinson's RKO picture "Days of Glory" has been signed by Metro-Goldwin-Mayer for the part of the artist "Basil Hallward" in the forthcoming picturization of Oscar Wilde's "The Picture of Dorian Gray."

AT AN ARMY BASE IN THE PACIFIC, Dec. 7 -- The air attack on Mili Island, at the southern end of the Marshall chain, last Saturday was made by the largest fleet of Liberators ever assembled in the Central Pacific, a spokesman for the Seventh Army Air Force disclosed today.
TARAWA (Delayed) -- Marines will have their fun, even within range of snipers and during the strain of battle.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The executive council of the Transport and General Workers Union announced today that "after giving full consideration to the statements made in Parliament regarding the release of Sir Oswald E. Mosley it regretted the inability to accept the validity of the explanation."

Explaining his program to assure to New York City consumers "a proper, price structure, proper rationing and proper enforcement," Daniel P. Woolley, newly appointed regional director of the Office of Price Administration, in his first press interview yesterday, declared war on merchants guilty of upgrading food and other merchandise.

AT AN ARMY BASE IN THE PACIFIC, Dec. 7 -- The air attack on Mili Island, at the southern end of the Marshall chain, last Saturday was made by the largest fleet of Liberators ever assembled in the Central Pacific, a spokesman for the Seventh Army Air Force disclosed today.
TARAWA (Delayed) -- Marines will have their fun, even within range of snipers and during the strain of battle.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The executive council of the Transport and General Workers Union announced today that "after giving full consideration to the statements made in Parliament regarding the release of Sir Oswald E. Mosley it regretted the inability to accept the validity of the explanation."

Not one of the Hundred Neediest would starve if the campaign in their behalf failed to bring in a single dollar. The kind of social conscience which used to confine itself to charitable giving has more and more laid the burden of meeting the basic needs of the unfortunate on public agencies supported by taxation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Dec. 8 -- Allied heavy and medium bombers together with dive-bombing fighters blasted and shot up the northern arc of Japan's New Britain coast and near-by islands Monday in a relentless assault on the enemy's staging points and supply centers, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today.

A "full and frank" analysis of war and post-war problems confronting the nation is promised for the second War Congress of American Industry and the forty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, to be held simultaneously today, tomorrow and Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

For the second time in three years, two men from one school were selected on the college All-America football team -- a team that reflects the concentration of strength in the Midwest in a year in which institutions permitted to use Navy and marine trainees dominated the gridiron show.
Federal Judge Edward A. Conger decided yesterday in favor of the Borden Company in a suit brought by service employes of its main office building, 350 Madison Avenue.
ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Horse racing poured $19,306,140 into New York State's treasury through various channels in 1943, an 84 per cent increase over 1942.

The Remington Medal, highest award in American pharmacy, was presented last night at a dinner at the Hotel McAlpin to Dr. Robert P. Fischelis, internationally known pharmaceutical chemist of Trenton, N.J. Dr. Fischelis was honored for "his outstanding contributions to the profession of pharmacy," and for his "literary, scientific and organizational activities over a period of years."

Net operating earnings of the Bank of the Manhattan Company for 1943 will amount to approximately $4,000,000, exclusive of profits on the sale of securities, J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
To know that I had helped someone is the best Christmas gift I desire, so, for that reason I'm mailing you $1 to the "Hundred Neediest Cases Fund."

A plan to increase the capital of the Chase National Bank from $100,270,000 to $111,000,000, by transferring $10,730,000 from surplus account, will be submitted to stockholders at the annual meeting on Jan. 11, it was made known yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board, in a letter to shareholders which accompanies formal notices of the meeting and solicitation of proxies.

Assailing the Little Steel wage formula as "completely outmoded, unfair and unrealistic," the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America declared last night that the question of a general increase for 325,000 workers in the men's clothing industry would be "opened up."

The Department of Parks announced yesterday the reopening to the public of the northeastern section of Central Park, known as Harlem Meer. This area, which extends from the Conservatory Gardens at 105th Street to 110th Street and from Fifth Avenue to the East Drive, has been closed since the spring of last year for renovation.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The general tone of the stock markets here again was quiet today and most sections remained firm.

Two years ago Japan's sneak attack on Pearl Harbor pushed the United States into this war for survival. We were caught off guard. But not for long. Now the news from overseas is most encouraging. But the war is not won. Victory will take more time, effort and, sad to say, precious lives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- About 90 per cent of the $1,300,000,000 which the United States purposes to contribute to the work of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will be spent in this country for relief supplies for liberated areas in Europe and Asia, Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

With trade buying confined mostly to the scale down, accelerated commission house and Southern selling in the late dealings yesterday brought about an easier tone in the cotton market and futures suffered their first setback in four sessions.

May I comment on something that appeared in Topics of the Times on Nov. 30. Speaking of equal pay for men and women, there appeared these words: "It is a form of discrimination against which we have rising protest today in various fields, including school teachers."

Daniel P. Woolley, new regional director of the Office of Price Administration, is unable to see eye to eye with Frank C. Russell, district director for New York, and is planning to replace him, according to persons in close contact with the OPA.

It is obvious that the longer the war continues the greater will be the demand for food for fighting men, lend-lease and liberated countries. Economists point out that in order to fill these needs, which will continue after the end of hostilities, cereals will have to receive more emphasis.

Policy differences of long standing between the urban and rural wings of the Church of God were brought to a climax yesterday when church overseers and ministers from twenty Eastern States elected Bishop Homer A. Tomlinson of Queens Village, Queens, ,as general overseer to succeed his father, the late Bishop A.J. Tomlinson of Cleveland, Tenn.

Twelve "honor workers" of war industry, one of them 13 years old, one of them blind and another a 95-year-old messenger who once served President Lincoln, were presented yesterday to the National Association of Manufacturers at a luncheon of the organization's Second War Congress at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Speaking before the Council of Christians and Jews here today, the Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of Canterbury, declared that it was of "utmost importance" that the sufferings of the Jews "be kept in full view" of all people so that the spirit of indignation and compassion in them will not die out.

The synthetic rubber industry in the United States will produce 45,000 long tons of rubber this month, or nearly a third of the entire output of the Government synthetic rubber plants so far, but production will be raised to capacity of 70,000 tons a month by the end of 1944, Col. Bradley Dewey, Federal Rubber Director, declared last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- About 10,000 head of swine were held over at the end of today's trade, but prices held nominally steady and unchanged. While the 17,000 hogs shipped here were not excessive, in comparison to the recent heavy loadings, packers had an additional 12,000 head sent on direct billing and were unable to buy all the stock offered.

What its participants referred to as a "unique" attempt to bring top-flight leaders of labor and industry together to prevent further trouble took place yesterday at the luncheon session of the second War Congress of American Industry, National Association of Manufacturers, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Office of Price Administration gave Santa Claus today some items for his scanty pack by taking the ban off gifts of jams, jellies, preserves and other rationed foods. Shoes were also put on the gift list, and those which the service man might buy abroad to send home were made ration-free.

A little bigger sister of the Iowa and New Jersey, the Wisconsin was launched in Philadelphia on Dec. 7, another terrible reply to the Japanese challenge of 1941. The keel of the new giant was laid at the Philadelphia Navy Yard on Jan. 5, 1941. Work on her was slowed up somewhat this year by a shortage of workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Very Rev. Angus Dun, dean of the Episcopal Theological School at Cambridge, Mass., has accepted the offer to become Bishop of Washington in succession to the late Right Rev. James E. Freeman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- It was the prompt action of F.A. Nauheim of this city, a prospective army inductee, which resulted in the arrest of Dr. James H. Hens of Catonsville, Md., on a charge of accepting what he believed was $2,000 for instructing Mr. Nauheim in feigning psychoneurosis to avoid military service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Pro football in general and the champion Washington Redskins in particular set out today to clear the air of rumors that gamblers had something to do with some of the upsets this season.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 7 (Delayed) (AP) -- .~ communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- American heavy bombers on Monday attacked enemy installations of the Andaman Islands in the Bay of Bengal, which must be neutralized before a sea-borne invasion of western Burma or the Malay Peninsula is possible, the Southeast Asia Command announced today.
By Broadcast to THE NEW YORK TIMES. ALGIERS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

Operations in the domestic oil industry continued at a feverish pace last week, with the refining branch producing gasoline at a record rate. The output of 13,325,000 barrels of gasoline was about 25 per cent more than the 11,040,000 barrels produced in the similar period last year.

The St. George High football squad, which will meet Mount St. Michael High, the city's only unbeaten and untied eleven, in a postseason intersectional clash at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, is scheduled to arrive in New York tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The great success of the landing craft from which fighting men, tanks and other equipment are put ashore in American military operations all over the world is expected to result in a construction program of more than $5,000,000,000 for this type of boat, Rear Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, chief of the Navy Bureau of Ships, said at a press conference today.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Apparently fearing an Allied Balkan invasion as a result of the Middle Eastern conferences, the Germans have opened a new large-scale offensive in Yugoslavia, hurling fresh troops from Greece, Albania and Austria into action in an attempt to crush the Yugoslav People's Army of Liberation, it was revealed today.

Charles Daggert, who won the featherweight boxing championship of the Navy in World War I, was applauded yesterday by 3,500 industrialists when he was presented to the second war congress of the National Association of Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Last February, by a personal appeal, he stopped an unauthorized strike in the Quaker City Iron Works in Philadelphia and enabled war production there to continue.

Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, former Bronx member of the Board of Education, denied yesterday that he had ever followed "the will of the Mayor, whether I liked it or not," while he was a member of the board. He described as a "mixture of fact and fancies" the testimony presented by Theodore Fred Kuper, dismissed law secretary, before the National Education Association school inquiry.
There was a slight shock for the visitor to the St. John's University gymnasium yesterday, where Coach Joe Lapchick was found sending his basketballers through a brisk workout.

So comprehensive is the report on "Voluntary Medical Influence in the United States," which has been completed for Group Health Cooperative, a non-profit medical insurance corporation, that it will surely receive the attention of the Mayor's Committee on Medical Care, now engaged in formulating a health program for families in moderate or low circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Senate after hours of controversy today suspended its rules to write into the first supplemental national defense appropriation bill the McKellar amendment to take authority from the Bureau of the Budget to impound or make reserves of funds appropriated in excess of requirements.

Members of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., were supplied yesterday with an interpretation of the Board of Governors' controversial "5 per cent profit rule," which had been furnished to district committees on Nov. 9.

Twenty-five hundred service ribbons in recognition of at least six months of faithful and meritorious service were presented yesterday to civilian employes of the War Department in this area at ceremonies that were duplicated in all parts of the nation as part of the War Department Civilian Award Day.

General Sessions Judge John J. Mullen was angered yesterday when he learned that the Sing Sing sentence of two to four years he had imposed last Nov. 10 on Paul E. Flato, the former Fifth Avenue jeweler, had been held up beyond the ten-day stay of execution he had granted.

A novel by Fannie Hurst will open Harpers 1944 publishing season on Jan. 5. Titled "Hallelujah," it is a story of the Middle West during the five years preceding Pearl Harbor. From the same house comes word that the North Carolina State Literary and Historical Association has awarded its Mayflower Cup to J. Saunders Redding's "No Day of Triumph."

Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, announced plans for the 1944 war production program yesterday at the first day's session of the three-day Second War Congress of American Industry, being held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in connection with the forty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Declaring that neither the country nor the broadcasting industry could exist "half slave and half free," Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, urged the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today to check without delay "the clearly apparent trend toward Government control of radio."
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

A few weeks ago Congress was considerably excited about the more than fifteen million unorganized, inarticulate white-collar workers who are the victims of cruel taxes and inflation. The strident waves of protest have died down once more and all is quiet again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Norman H. Davis, chairman of American Red Cross, told the board of incorporators of the organization at the annual meeting today that never before has the Red Cross operated "on so vast a scale as in the year just closing."

The National Association of Manufacturers, through its president, Frederick C. Crawford, presented to the Overseas Press Club yesterday a plaque honoring thirteen war correspondents who have died in the war in line of duty.

Before the three little girls had their coats and snowsuits off they were surrounded. On all sides were photographers, calling "Sit in that chair," "Smile," "Look over here," or reporters, asking "What do you want for Christmas?"
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 -- Another trial of charges of illegal possession of munitions began before the Jerusalem military court yesterday. Seven Jewish settlers of the village of Kibbutz Hulda are ac cused of possessing seventy-eight mortar bombs and eighty-five shells, found Oct. 3 during a search for Polish army deserters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A warning was sounded by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs, to the House Military Affairs Committee today that in determining the mustering-out pay of military personnel Congress should not give any financial incentive for leaving the services or refraining from civilian employment.

The auctioneer's hammer will not fall today today on the scotch, rye, bourbon and other choice liquors and wines that Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port of New York, had wanted to sell in small lots to the highest bidders.

Stocks of major oil products along the Atlantic Coast increased again last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's index covering gasoline at the end of the period stood at 41.3, compared with 40.4 a week earlier. The light fuel oil index rose to 66.6, from 65.1, and that of heavy fuel oil to 75.9, from 75.4.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 8 -- Word of political "panic" in Sofia was received here tonight as Bulgaria and other Axis Balkan satellites awaited concrete results of the Roosevelt-Churchill-Inonu conference in Cairo, Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Loud and raucous laughter resounded through the corridors of the Pentagon and the Navy Department today over the extravagant claims of the Japanese on their victories since the start of the war in the Pacific theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Buying of rye for future delivery by houses with Eastern connections ran all deliveries of that grain up around 1 cent a bushel today to the highest prices of the season soon after the opening of the Chicago Board of Trade. Pit brokers estimated the purchases at 1,000,000 bushels.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 8 -- Prospects that the manufacture of beverage alcohol may soon be resumed are believed to be brightening in Canada. Until recently any inquiries as to if and when this might be so have been sternly answered with the statement that every available plant was needed for the manufacture of industrial alcohol.

With less than a month remaining for the shaping of policies regarding traditional "January White Sales," the Pepperell Company in its current bulletin indicates that retail decisions will have to be based on considerations of both immediate wartime scarcities and long-range wartime plans.

For those despairing feminists who complain that the male sex gets all the breaks, here's the latest proof that it's a man's world after all. Fashion sleuths discovered yesterday that before many weeks, a considerable quantity of wearing apparel made of silk -- real, honest-to-goodness silk, spun by silkworms and not diluted with skim milk, wood, coal or cornstalks -- will be placed upon the market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Lord Beaverbrook, Lord Privy Seal in the Churchill Government, who has been designated to coordinate British post-war aviation, has arrived in the United States and is understood to be in Florida, recuperating from an attack of asthma.

" ONE thing that impressed me in my twenty-two years of umpiring in the American League," remarked Billy Evans the other day, "is that the great players caused the least amount of trouble for an umpire. It's the run-of-the-mill athlete, the has-been or the never-will-be who do the most squawking and kick most vehemently at decisions."

The Columbia Theatre Associates of Columbia University presented last night at Brander Matthews Hall the operetta in two acts, "The Two Misers," by Andre Gretry. The piece was written by Gretry, Belgian composer, when he was living in Paris, and first performed at Fontainebleau on Oct. 17, 1770, as part of the ceremonies attending the marriage of the Dauphin to Marie-Antoinette.

Celebrating the second anniversary of Pearl Harbor, on which Japan still rejoices in her treachery, Tokyo broadcast a statement which for brazen mendacity surpasses even the best efforts of Hitler. It is so fantastic that it sounds completely ridiculous to Western ears.

That the Neediest Cases must not be forgotten was the thought that stirred the minds and sympathies of many of the 380 contributors whose gifts to the thirty-second annual appeal were received yesterday.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 9 -- Russian columns closing around Znamenka outflanked that Dnieper bend rail center from the south yesterday by cutting the big rail line to Nikolayev, but the Red Army fell back for the second straight day in the Kiev bulge before a mighty German counter-attack powered by perhaps 1,700 tanks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The newly created advisory committee of the Office of Price Administration has several chief functions, Miss Hazel Kyrk, associate professor of home economics and economics at the University of Chicago, committee chairman, said in outlining its contemplated procedure for the benefit of the consumer.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- The sensational series of conferences just concluded in Cairo and Teheran achieved results exceeding highest expectations in cooperation, good-will and unanimity, setting the stage for colossal victories of both military and diplomatic nature, Prime. Minister Jan Christian Smuts of the Union of South Africa declared today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Dec. 9 -- Over a hundred United States planes hurled almost 200 tons of bombs on the Cape Gloucester area at the southwestern tip of New Britain Island on Tuesday, bringing to nearly 1,000 tons the total weight of bombs dropped there within nine days.

So many New Yorkers take their ease and what fish they are lucky enough to snag Down East that it is not surprising to find three natives of the State, two of them from the immediate environs of this city, among the nineteen fishermen who made Maine's "The One That Didn't Get Away Club."

Upwards of $10,000,000 in commitments for new season domestic raw furs are being jeopardized by the delay in issuing the long-awaited price regulation for raw furs, the National Federation of the Fur Industry declared yesterday in a telegraphic protest to Price Administrator Chester M. Bowles.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The reason the Steagles were so tough in the National Football League now comes to light. They were the hardest-punching bunch of ground-gainers in pro football in 1943.

A new process for producing synthetic menthol at lower cost than that of the natural product, a development that may make the United States independent of Japan for its supply in the postwar period, was disclosed here yesterday by Dr. E. C. Merrill, assistant vice president of the United Drug Company.

The Dodgers, it develops, have begun some intensive shopping around for a baseball training site for next Spring in the event that plans pending for their return to Bear Mountain and West Point have to be abandoned.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALGIERS, Dec. 8 -- By the grim process of gouging its way from height to height and pounding, knifing and scrambling "up and over," Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army has won control of the major dominating heights over twenty-five square miles of the Camino-Maggiore mountain masses and in some sectors has broken through to the westward or downhill slopes, it was officially announced today.

World output of rayon yarn, totaling 3,472,900,000 pounds in 1942, has scared 56 per cent since 1939, the first year of war, when output amounted to 2,227,500,000 pounds, it was announced yesterday by the "Rayon Organon" published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

Last night's performance of "Angel Street" had to be canceled because three of the players in the five-character melodrama were suffering from colds. Those on the sick list are Leo G. Carroll, Judith Evelyn and Jetti Preminger. According to the management, the trio will be able to appear this evening.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Hungary will resist any attempt at invasion from whatever quarter, Hungarian Premier Nicholas von Kallay told his Parliament during a budgetary debate in Budapest, the Turkish news agency Anatolia reported today.

The Fairchild Aviation Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept 30 a net profit of $977,429 after charges, a provision for renegotiation of war contracts and Federal income taxes.

Prices of stocks were raised again yesterday 1 to 2 points or more as the early December rally generated further force. In the heaviest turnover in a month the recovery broadened to include virtually every section of the list. On the New York Stock Exchange transfers jumped to 1,320,000 shares from 883,750 on Tuesday.

Medium-priced dwellings continue to show steady demand in many sections of Brooklyn. Riker Co. reports the sale of the two-family house at 46 Sterling Street for the New York Life Insurance Company to Mrs. G. Clementine; the two-family homes at 1520 Seventy-fourth Street to Nicholas Mammi and 2129 Seventy-ninth Street to Leo Bodner.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 (Reuter) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden have had interviews with various statesmen staying at the present moment in the Middle East.

Large-scale purchases of military supplies will continue in the New York area until the end of the war, according to Brig. Gen. B.C. Dunn, division engineer of the North Atlantic Division, Corps of Engineers. Speaking at the Commerce and Industry Association's weekly business forum over WMCA last night, he said renegotiation of contracts is a major activity of his office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The trend of comment on speeches and statements made by Alf M. Landon since he came East from Kansas last week testifies that, whatever his foreign policy recommendations to the Republican party may be, he was generally understood to advocate these things:
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine called "unfounded" yesterday published reports that a police shake-up impended in Brooklyn because of conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant district.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews is able to report a Nazi setback in the United States during the past twelve months. It is true that there have been race riots in Detroit, Los Angeles, Beaumont, Mobile and Newark. Religious prejudice has shown itself in the cautious propaganda of anti-Semitism and in other forms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Roosevelt has set Jan. 1 as a national "day of prayer" in which 'to give thanks to Almighty God for His constant providence over us in every hour of national peace and national peril."

Under the recent decree of the Colombian Government, an import permit is a prerequisite to the procurement of exchange permits, according to information believed to be official, the Commerce and Industry Association announced yesterday.

The Football Giants finished about two hours of practice yesterday morning by watching the movies of last Sunday's victory over Washington. Then they called it a day, but their coach began his homework.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Chinese troops have recaptured the town of Tehshan, a few miles south of fallen Changteh, gateway to Changsha in China's "rice bowl," the Chinese High Command reported today.

Dr. William J. Doyle, through Edgar Ellinger, in 1075 Park Ave; Grant Gore, in 530 E 90th St; Edward Brown, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. in 21 W 58th St; John L. Cadley, in 34 Gramercy Pk; Leatrice Joy Gilbert, in 30 Fifth Ave; Mrs. Nina Paris Phelps, also Harold Spina, in 1 University P1 -- Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen rejected clemency pleas yesterday for Charles Ferreiro, 30 years old, a dancer, of 353 West Eighty-fifth Street, and Renato Matticari, 28, an artist, of 142 East Thirty-third Street, who pleaded guilty to an apartment burglary in the Fifth Avenue-Park Avenue district.

MANEUVERS HEADQUARTERS, CAMP MACKALL, N.C., Dec. 8 -- Completion this morning of the initial phase of the most ambitious night airborne maneuvers in Army history, demonstrated that it is possible to transport the major part of or even an entire reinforced airborne division by air under cover of darkness and land the troops by glider and parachute in enemy territory with such accuracy that they can reassemble quickly and start fighting.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- After a heated debate, the House passed today a bill to permit duty-free importation of feed for livestock and poultry for a period of ninety days.

Simon Barere, the Russian pianist, was heard in a recital last night in Carnegie Hall, the program of which consisted entirely of works by Chopin and Liszt. The chief Chopin offering was the "Fantasie," and the principal Liszt composition performed was the Sonata in B minor.

In view of the fact that a careless remark dropped by Col. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Wac, the other day to the effect that this country never had been able to raise an army of 400,000 to 500,00 men by the volunteer method, is being quoted in articles on the problem of getting recruits for the Wac, it is high time to nail this error.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 8 -- After months of threatening drastic "reprisals" for the Allies' bombardments of German territory, this week's issue of the Reich, cited today by the Berlin correspondent of the Gazette de Lausanne, promised that these reprisals would be inflicted "within the next fifteen days."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Despite the plea last night by James F. Byrnes, War Mobilization Director, for a continuation of food subsidies, Senator John H. Bankhead, Democrat, of Alabama, who will lead the fight against the subsidies program in the Senate, expressed confidence today that the Administration would be defeated on the issue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today increases in the House Revenue Bill's taxes on distilled spirits and beer, but made other changes which reduced its prospective yield below $2,000,000,000.

The coalition between the New Deal and the Democratic party is going to pieces, former Gov. Alf M. Landon of Kansas, the 1936 Republican nominee for President, declared yesterday in predicting the election of a Republican President next year.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest producer, announced today that it would negotiate a new labor contract with the United Steel Workers of America (CIO), and the union said that about 150 other companies also had agreed to reopen their contracts.

An estimate that 2,000,000 men, including at least 1,000,000 pre-Pearl Harbor fathers, would be inducted into the armed forces between now and July 1 was offered last night by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, as "the best guess" he could make.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- More than enough proxies were received by the management of Allied Mills, Inc., to ratify the proposed sale of the entire capital stock of the Century Distilling Company to the National Distillers Products Corporation and associates, J.B. De Haven, president of Allied Mills, announced today to stockholders at a special meeting.

Despite the efforts of medical science to keep her alive, eleven-day-old Mary Ann Maceli, twenty-six-ounce baby born three months prematurely, died yesterday shortly after 8 A.M. at the Shore Road Hospital, Brooklyn. Mary Ann, who measured less than twelve inches, was said to be the smallest baby who lived for that length of time when born at that stage of development.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Medical officers of the armed services are now lending a hand to overworked civilian physicians here as the widespread influenza epidemic continues without sign of abatement.

Precedent was swept aside yesterday in the award of the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque, presented annually by the Boxing Writers Association of New York for outstanding contribution to the preservation and advancement of the ring sport.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- One-quarter of the total built-up area in German cities already attacked has been "devastated," Air Vice Marshal R.H.M.S. Saundby, deputy chief of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command, said today in a review of the air offensive against Germany.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- Turkey has been intensifying military and security precautions for weeks, especially in the Dardanelles zone, and has militarized three-mile strips on each side of the strait, reports reaching Cairo today said.

MONTREAL, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadiens' Buddy O'Connor is back alone at the top of the National Hockey League scoring race, thanks to another of those spurts that have twice brought him to the top in the official weekly figures.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Swedish press reports from Sofia said tonight that all traffic between Bulgaria and Turkey had been suspended.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Seventeen recommendations for added Government services for children of minority groups, of which Negroes are the largest, and for added opportunities for trained Negro workers in labor, health and welfare fields have come out of a two-day conference here called by the Children's Bureau.
ALGIERS, Dec. 8 -- At least 10,000 tons of Christmas gifts have been or are being delivered to service men and women in the North African theatre.

The kickbacks by one doctor to another in workmen's compensation cases extended to the making of eyeglasses, according to testimony given before Moreland Act Commissioner William F. Bleakley at a public hearing in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad submitted estimated 1943 revenues to the Federal court today showing that the year would produce the largest gross take in history -$179,604,388.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Unemployed persons in this country, who ran into the millions several years ago, now total only 700,000, which is 300,000 below the "bedrock minimum" set by estimates a year ago, according to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

This column's sins in recent months have either shown a gratifying decline both verbally and factually or, what is much more probable, the readers have been occupied with much more important business.

Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have been advised by that institution's department of member firms to make provision in their partnership agreements for the possibility that a partner now in service may be reported "missing in action."

ALGIERS, Dec. 8 -- The process by which the French Committee of National Liberation is gradually ridding official life in French North Africa of all men associated in any way with anti-Allied or pro-Vichy causes before the expulsion of the Axis continued today with the retirement of two admirals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Office of Price Administration today amended its regulation controlling the prices of packed fruits and vegetables of the 1943 pack. Although most of the changes were of a technical nature, there were several of importance to both the industry and the consumer

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 8 -- Powerful task forces under Rear Admiral Charles A. Pownall attacked the Japanese Marshall Island bases with devastating effect last Saturday, sinking two light cruisers and four other ships and destroying seventy-two planes, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced this morning.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Admiral of the Fleet Lord Keyes said tonight the end of the war was near and called for a post-war separation of the German States by a great army of occupation. Addressing a Luxembourg Society meeting, he said he hoped that this time the guilty would be punished.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's newspaper, Voelkischer Beobachter, was quoted by the Berlin radio today as assailing neutral countries for their reaction to the Allied Middle-East conferences and expressing the "safe prediction" that such neutrals "would perform another about-face if the political and military situation should take a different course."

An attempt to burn a Long Island Railroad bridge at Westbury on Nov. 29 was attributed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday to three teen-age boys. The culprits, two 17 and one 16 years old, were not identified by E.E. Conroy, local FBI chief, because of their youth.

Thomas J. Patterson, budget director, and the heads of city departments and agencies, it became known yesterday, are making every effort to complete within the next two weeks the survey recently ordered by Mayor La Guardia as a preliminary to the granting of a "cost of living" pay rise to most of the city's 150,000 employes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- While Cape Gloucester's anti-aircraft positions were being destroyed and supply dumps exploded by fighter-escorted Liberators and Mitchells on Tuesday, Australian soldiers, eighty miles to the southeast, extended by more than two miles along the Huon Peninsula of New Guinea the coastal holdings from which New Britain may be invaded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A vote of 11 to 10 today by the Ways and Means Committee killed the Bankhead bill and two similar measures which would have directed payment by the Treasury for war bond advertising in newspapers.

The twelve-story Chatham Phenix Building, an office structure containing 100,000 square feet of office and banking space at Queens Plaza, in Long Island City, has been sold by the Guardian Life Insurance Company to the 29-28 Forty-first Avenue Corporation, a syndicate formed by Hosinger Bode, Inc.

Mrs. Lee Lipschitz, 29 years old, is now convinced that "the war must be won first" before her husband, Private Harry Lipschitz of the Seventh Army, can come home -- especially after receiving a personal letter from Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. Yesterday, Mrs. Lipschitz showed the recently arrived letter from General Patton. It follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture in its final 1943 report, today estimated this year's cotton crop at 11,478,000 bales, or about 1,340,000 bales less than last year and 996,000 bales less than the 1932-41 average.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 8 -- C.H. Carlisle, president of the Dominion Bank, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today that the plan of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation Political party to nationalize the chartered banks of Canada could result only in the abolition of the facilities that these banks have established after years of continuous service.

The sixtieth anniversary of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin at Pleasant Plains, S.I., was celebrated yesterday with memorial services and a high pontifical mass at the Church of Joachim and Anne on the campus. The mission was founded by John Drumgoole, a Catholic priest who gave the greater part of his life to aid New York's neglected children.

Mairin Cregan, Irish author and the wife of the Irish Minister of Agriculture, won the second annual Downey Award yesterday for "Rathina," a reminiscent tale of her early life, which was judged "the finest American children's book of 1942 written in the Catholic tradition."

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- In answer to questions raised in the House of Commons, Richard K. Law, Minister of State, declared today that the British Government was giving "more support" to the Partisan forces in Yugoslavia than to the forces of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The longest air freight line in the world is now operating on regular schedule between Patterson Field, Ohio, and India. The Army said today that C-87 planes, the cargo version of the Consolidated B-24 Liberator bomber, were flying the route regularly delivering supplies to the air forces in the Orient.

The forty-eight-family apartment house at 265 Cabrini Boulevard has been sold by Herman Epstein, the builder, to Abram Rachlyn of North Carolina for cash over a first mortgage of $168,000. It is assessed at $250,000 and was erected five years ago, according to Max Weinstein, the broker.

A Government program for post-war housing construction would be of considerable aid in minimizing industrial unemployment when the war is over, Leon H. Keyserling, general counsel of the National Housing Agency, told members of the Municipal Forum of New York, at a luncheon meeting yesterday at Block Hall, 23 South William Street.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Gunman communique :

The Brooklyn Crescents, newest entry in the Eastern Hockey League, have been awarded eleven players, six from the New York Rovers and five from the Boston Olympics, it was announced yesterday by loop officials. The Crescents, who will play their home games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace on Tuesday nights, are also expected to receive two more players, probably from the Philadelphia Falcons, the only other team in the league.
