Development of "liquid coal" of three consistencies, having a fluidity equal to that of Nos. 3, 6 and 7 fuel oil, to be used in fuel oil burners, was disclosed yesterday at the Nineteenth Exposition of Chemical Industries at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- A series of weather stations located throughout the British Empire was envisaged here today when the first progress report of the Colonial Research Committee was published as a White Paper. The value of these stations to the empire's postwar aviation plans was stressed.
Yesterday's Japanese communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Congressional study of whether the Elk Hills, Calif., oil reserve should be acquired by Government condemnation or operated by contract with private interests got under way today.

The gleaming white of a parachute flashed into the fashion scene yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel. It made its debut in a group of play and swim togs presented by Cole of California. The costumes were of naval twill.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- Unofficial contact of a political nature has now been established between the Allied authorities and the new temporary government headed by Marshal Tito in Partisan Yugoslavia. It is possible the confused Yugoslav situation may be somewhat crystallized as the result of conversations now taking place.
A series of free fuel conservation classes designed to help building owners and operators to meet heating problems will be held here next week.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan to make capital contributions aggregating $9,313,371 to four oil subsidiaries, it was disclosed today.

HOLLWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Katharine Brush, the novelist, will arrive at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio next week to write the screen play of an original story, "Red-Headed Woman in Washington," a yarn about a Broadway show girl in wartime Washington.

President Chiang Kai-shek of China noted the second anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor by sending a greeting to President Roosevelt in which he said that the tide of the Pacific war was "definitely in our favor" and that relations between China and the United States had been "greatly strengthened as a result of our recent conference in North Africa," the Chungking radio said yesterday in a broadcast to North America.
Premier Hideki Tojo of Japan boasted in a Pearl Harbor anniversary message last night that 1944 "will be our year to win," but declared "the war cannot be won easily."

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII, in a prayer for peace today in celebration of the feast of the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin, asked for a "peace for our souls peace that we might lay down arms."

The Union of South Africa has approved a plan to eliminate the lend-lease procedure currently employed in the shipment of hand tools to importers in that country and restore sales to a regular commercial basis, it was reported in foreign trade circles yesterday.

It is hard this year to find some of the gifts that were readily available in other years. But there is one gift that anyone may feel proud to make no matter how small -- the white gift, given with a free hand and happy thought, with no expectation of receiving anything in return.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Rumors started circulating here Dec. 3, when President Ismet Inonu left for Cairo, that the Government would call another 1,000,000 men to the colors before Jan. 1, reinforcing the 800,000 to 900,000 men already under arms.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow.

Dr. Eduard Benes has for several days been the guest of the Soviet Union. He undertook the journey to Moscow for the definite purpose of appending his signature to the long-projected Russian-Czechoslovak treaty of alliance. According to authoritative sources, that instrument has already been put in force.

Until European fats and oils requirements are accurately known the paint industry will not receive greater allocations of linseed oil, J.V. Thompson, chief of the industrial oils division of the War Food Administration, stated yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Prices of grains broke 1 cent a bushel or more in the early trading today on the Board of Trade as the result of selling induced by the passage of a bill by the House that would permit the import of foreign wheat and other grains for feed purposes duty free for a period of ninety days.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Swedish press dispatches reported today that the Hungarian Parliament had been called into special session to discuss the possibility that Turkey might enter the war on the Allied side.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Treasury Department revealed today that it had been making a country-wide investigation of black-market practices by liquor dealers, as well as a recrudescence of moonshining and the "cutting" and misbranding of spirits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The United States will aid the Partisans in Yugoslavia as well as the forces of General Draja Mikhailovitch, according to indications given today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The War Department believes that enactment of legislation to give mustering-out pay to military personnel would raise the morale of troops overseas, Brig. Gen. William F. Tompkins of the General Staff Corps told the House Military Affairs Committee today at a hearing on bills to give service men and women up to $300 upon their discharge.

"The Mad Ghoul," a melodrama produced by Universal, will open this morning at the Rialto. Directed by James Hogan, the picture's cast is headed by David Bruce, Evelyn Ankers, George Zucco, Turhan Bey and Rose Hobart. . . . Also arriving today at the Belmont is "Cuando Viajan Las Estrellas" ("When Stars Travel"), a Mexican importation starring Jorge Negrete and Raquel.

There was a man who was alone. He didn't mind it, however, because he didn't know he was alone. There was no food he could not buy and there was no book he could not read, and he had a more-than-comfortable roof over his head. Barring a headache now and again when he was careless he had not an ache or a pain.

The United Air Lines Transport Corporation filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission giving further details of its plan to raise more than $10,000,000 for post-war development, to be voted on at a special meeting of stockholders on Dec. 22.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The cost of living rose in October for the second consecutive month to cancel almost completely decreases registered during the summer, the Office of War Information reported tonight.

When the Football Giants trooped into the dressing room at the Polo Grounds yesterday, after a long, rather grim workout of two full hours, there was a newspaper clipping stuck on the bulletin board with a piece of adhesive tape. Steve Owen had put it up there on his way to practice.
ALGIERS, Dec. 9 -- A communique:

A decision upholding the right of the Office of Price Administration to issue "suspension orders" against dealers who violate the rationing regulations was handed down here yesterday by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind. The opinion noted that in previous rulings on the same subject two judges in other Federal jurisdictions had taken the opposite view and nullified suspension orders, while a third had upheld one.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- With 12,000 hogs unsold at the close of local trading today, the marketing committee issued warnings to farmers that any fresh arrivals on Friday and Saturday would be held over until next week.

There will not be adequate nurseries and day care centers for the children of working mothers in New York City "until Mayor La Guardia sets up a whole new program," Mrs. Elinor Gimbel, chairman of the Committee for the Care of Young Children in Wartime, declared yesterday.

Claims by aviation experts that the airplane in time would not only out-maneuver but out-shoot surface weapons, including battleships, used to be filed as a matter of course under "Fantasy." But even diehard skeptics will have to revise their filing system a bit now that the War Department has revealed that 75-mm. cannon are being flown by American bombers.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Bernie Bierman has had his say about football's T-formation -- it's just a wartime flash-in-the-pan, he calls it -- so now let's see what Frank Leahy, the Notre Dame coach, thinks about it.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- With the aid of reinforcements, the Germans have stepped up their efforts to safeguard their great trunk rail and highway communications in Yugoslavia by freeing lateral routes from the threat of Partisan attacks and sabotage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- John V.L. Hogan, president of the Interstate Broadcasting Company, owner of station WQXR in New York, urged the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today to write into its proposed revision of the 1934 communications act, "a perfectly unambiguous instruction" to the Federal Communications Commission as to the scope of its powers and "a really strong injunction that all proper consideration be given to the development of new radio services."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland announced today arrangement of credit for Victory and Victory Termination loans totaling $64,500,000 for three concerns in expansion of war plants and post-war conversion to civilian production.

The great Metropolitan Museum has entered intimately into the life of fashion design in New York, and is proud of it. Late yesterday afternoon at the museum an invited audience saw a collection of clothes directly inspired by the Greek revival exhibition now current there.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Dec. 9 -- Gen. Maximino Avila Camacho, Minister of Communications and brother of President Manuel Avila Camacho, told the Excelsior yesterday that a Mexican expeditionary force was "unnecessary" and termed the leftist groups that are agitating for direct participation in the war "demagogic."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- After taxes are deducted from income, the OWI said in its report today, there remains $35,000,000,000, which cannot be spent for goods or services and which tends to push up prices.

Curtailment of electric lighting in store windows, decorations and in homes was asked by the War Production Board regional offices in New York, Philadelphia and Boston last night as part of a joint campaign to conserve coal and other resources.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 9 -- Ignoring warnings made last week by the Swedish Government that the deportation of the Norwegian students arrested in Oslo would compromise future Swedish-German relations, the Nazis early this morning started a first block of 250 students on their way to a German concentration camp, according to a dispatch from the Oslo correspondent of the S.T.B. news agency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A special mission headed by Adlai E. Stevenson, Chicago attorney who had been assistant to the Secretary of the Navy, has been sent to Italy by the Foreign Economic Administration to survey the economic situation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The requirements of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration for food and other supplies in the United States are not likely to cause increasing rationing in this country, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee cut still more today from the House tax bill by striking out the proposed 5 per cent levy on pari-mutuel wagers, estimated to yield $27,500,000 annually.

Irvin S. Cobb, the humorist, has written to his old friend, Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, suggesting that circulation be given to the "enclosed little epistle to the Corinthians and the Paducahans."

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, beyond the Sangro, Dec. 7 (delayed) (U.P.) -- For eight long terror-filled days and nights a young New York woman and her 16-month-old baby lived under almost unceasing artillery and aerial bombardment in "no man's land," sheltering in a hand-dug cave with forty peasants as the savage historic battle for the Sangro River raged around them.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The capture of Wareo, announced today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur, was achieved by part of the same Australian force which late in November stormed and won the high plateau fortification of Sattelberg.

Twentieth Century-Fox supplied all the backing for "The World's Full of Girls," which opened Monday night. Now comes Warner Brothers, making the same gesture in behalf of Brock Pemberton's twice-postponed offering of "Pillar to Post," which arrives (positively) this evening at the Playhouse.

Wilfred E. Cohen, an inoffensive-looking man of 45, was accused yesterday of having perpetrated a neat $419,000 swindle. The alleged victims were a group of persons who had been eagerly lending him money at usurious rates. He seemed incredulous that the trick had been so productive, but Harold J. McAuley, assistant United States attorney, pointed out that he had been performing it for more than a year now.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Speaker Rayburn warned an attentive House today of "dangerous trends" in public talk about the war, and equally dangerous efforts of groups and individuals to profit by it at public expense. He urged members to combat these tendencies among their constituents during their Christmas holidays.

A mild type of influenza and other respiratory illnesses were found yesterday to be prevalent in epidemic proportions in many New York and New Jersey communities. While there was no significant rise in the number of influenza cases reported in New York City, the outbreak in New Jersey and up-State New York increased absenteeism in war plants and caused the closing of a number of public schools.

Coach Howie Smith sent his unbeaten and untied Mount St. Michael football team through a strenuous workout at McGovern Field yesterday in preparation for the Bronx school's post-season clash with St. George High of Evanston, Ill., at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

White-collar women have found their own way to beat the wage freeze. Thwarted in their attempts to get increases by ignorance of Government regulations or by employers unwilling to apply for them to the War Labor Board, they are quitting their jobs by the hundreds to take others at higher salaries.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Frank Sinatra will not lay that microphone down and take up a gun or a duffle bag. Completing a special engagement with Army physicians this morning at the Newark induction center, the crooner came out rejected and dejected. Another punctured eardrum case, he was classified 4F.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The resentment of Southern Senators over being accused of entering "an unholy alliance" with Northern Republicans to defeat the Administration's Federal voting program for service men was voiced in the Senate today by Senator Ellison D. Smith of South Carolina.

ABOARD A U.S. AIRCRAFT CARRIER, off the Marshall Islands, Dec. 6 (Delayed) -- This tremendous assembly of carrier task forces has caught the Japanese with their kimonos off. It has delivered its Sunday punch on the most important enemy bases in the Marshall Islands.

A group of children at the Floyd Horton Center of the Police Athletic League at 12 West 108th Street yesterday acclaimed Lauritz Melchior, tenor, and Rise Stevens, soprano, members of the Metropolitan Opera Company, for their good deed rather than for their ability as singers.

Figures of national production of steel for all months of 1943 have been revised by the American Iron and Steel Institute to take account of new facilities which have been added this year. Among these are steel plants operated by Henry J. Kaiser, a newcomer in the industry.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Roving power trains, described as capable of restoring electric service overnight in cities reconquered from the Axis, are being built to follow advancing Allied armies, Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company said tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The stock markets here were firm in tone today, although little business was done.

TO BEGIN with, he's a mighty quiet fellow, placid and unemotional. His features are ruggedly handsome and his teeth white and even. He always is smiling on the football field, probably because no one gets as much joy and honest pleasure out of bone-shaking blocks and tackles as this self-same Ward Cuff of the Giants.

The Board of Estimate at a special meeting yesterday voted to take the city out of the hotel business by selling at public auction on Dec. 31 the twenty-four-story Manhattan Towers Hotel, 2162-68 Broadway, at Seventy-sixth Street, acquired on July 19 by foreclosure of a tax lien of $420,115.

In one of the first public utterances by an insurance company executive on the current anti-trust action of the Department of Justice and the legislation now before Congress to support control of the business by the States, Esmond Ewing, vice president, The Travelers Insurance Company, asserted yesterday that the department's action was "unwarranted" and declared that "fire insurance companies openly and wholeheartedly support the legislation now pending."

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- Questions affecting the security in Jewish villages in Palestine were asked today during a resumed hearing of the seven settlers of Kibbutz Hulda who are being tried by a Jerusalem military court on the charge of possession of sixty-eight mortar bombs and eighty-five ballistite cartridges found there Oct. 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- By a record vote of 74 to 4 the Senate have its support today to a wage increase of 8 cents an hour for 1,100,000 non-operating railroad employes throughout the country, an increase which Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, had rejected as being inflationary.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Restoration of collective bargaining to a voluntary basis and safeguarding of "the constitutional rights of all citizens, union members included," were demanded by the American Farm Bureau Federation today in a resolution adopted at the end of its convention.

The concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the restoration of the Republic of Poland offered much that was exceptional, if not invariably entertaining to the audience in Carnegie Hall.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Dec. 10 -- The Australians on Wednesday captured Wareo junction, controlling most of the important trails of the Huon Peninsula, New Guinea, and have pushed on northward, it was announced today.

The National Association of Manufacturers, holding its second War Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, adopted yesterday a 1944 platform, reiterating its pledge of full wartime production for victory and adding a new post-war program for a "better America."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Office of Censorship came out in strong language tonight for the printing of still more war news, urging the country's press and radio to ignore "volunteer" censors who would tell them what not to publish.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- During the week ended Dec. 8, member bank reserve balances increased $7,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $666,000,000 in reserve bank credit, offset in part by increases of $411,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $195,000,000 in money in circulation, $32,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, and $2,000,000 in Treasury cash and a decrease of $21,000,000 in gold stock.

Public offering by a nation-wide underwriting syndicate, headed by the First Boston Corporation, of $42,000,000 of first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds of the Utah Power and Light Company will be made today. The bonds, which will be due in 1968, are priced at 100 5/8.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Ida Lupino will be starred by Warner Brothers in a comedy, "Made in Heaven," to be based on the unproduced farce of the same title by Muriel Roy Bolton. The play is about a wife, who, believing she has only six months to live, arranges several romantic adventures for her husband so that he can choose her successor.

Kenneth D. Steere, chairman of the board of directors of the Republic Insurance Company, has purchased for investment the eight-story office building at 87 Maiden Lane and 1-15 Gold Street. The building occupies a plot 30 by 106 feet at the northwest corner of the two thoroughfares in the heart of the downtown insurance district.

The announcement is made this morning that a quota of $911,000,000 has been set for sales to individuals in this State in the Fourth War Loan drive, which begins next month. This means that New Yorkers will be called upon to subscribe $60,000,000 more than during the Third War Loan, when they topped their quota by a handsome margin.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The London Daily Herald said today there was "strong feeling" in London that President Roosevelt "might come here before American troops leave these shores" to participate in the final planning of the invasion of Europe from the west.

OTTAWA, Dec. 9 -- Except in cases of "gross inequality or gross injustice," and even then only in cases where the employer is able to pay an increase without raising prices, wages will not be further raised in Canada during the war. The aim is to prevent wage increases leading to a rise in the cost of living.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- In a rush to authorize the Navy to spend about $5,300,000,000 for invasion craft, auxiliary vessels and other ships, the Senate and House passed separate and almost identical bills for this purpose today.

These things seem to run in cycles. Not long ago there was the story of the aroused "tame" buck named Jake up in Ithaca who went berserk and attacked three citizens and one policeman. The other day our neighbor, Don Stillman of The Herald Tribune, raised the question of just how dangerous a deer could become and concluded it could be pretty dangerous.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Today's communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 9 -- The British program for amalgamating small third and fourth class Indian States by attaching them to larger States has struck a snag. A special court ruled that the recent Crown representative's notification attaching several small States of Kathiawar to bigger Kathiawar States was illegal.

Hitherto the Treasury, in issuing a call on government war-loan deposits in the larger commercial banks throughout the country, has specified two or three days on which withdrawals would be made and specified equal withdrawals on each day.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Bank of England, in its condition statement issued today, recorded the largest weekly increase in note circulation so far this year, with a gain of 14,471,000, bringing the total to a new all-time high of 1,045,295,000.

Quantities of fresh raw furs now arriving in the market here are somewhat larger than anticipated. The increase in volume was attributed mainly to the higher prices being quoted trappers this season compared with the low levels of the two preceding seasons.

A large apartment property facing Straus Park on the Upper West Side was reported in new ownership yesterday. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold the modern twelve-story building at 949 West End Avenue to a client of Herbert Charles Co., brokers.

A new issue of $1,500,000 Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission bonds was reported sold yesterday to B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., Blyth Co., Inc., and associates. The bonds, which carry a 3 per cent coupon, are dated as of Aug. 1, 1938, and mature on Aug. 1, 1968, with certain callable features.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange last month climbed from 729,291 shares to 760,166 shares but did not quite reach the year's peak attained at the end of September, when the short position topped 761,000 shares.
Mr. and Mrs. Theron Ball Clement of St. Davids, Pa., have come to the St. Regis.

Although Dolph Camilli, veteran first baseman who refused to report to the Giants last summer after the latter had bought him on waivers from the Dodgers, was reported in California on Wednesday to have signed a two-year contract to manage Oakland of the Pacific Coast League, developments in the Giants' offices yesterday indicated the announcement was a trifle premature.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 10 -- Soviet troops tightened their grip about the Dnieper bend rail hub of Znamenka yesterday and, according to a German report, closed a forty-five-mile gap northwest of that junction by joining forces with Red Army units operating in the Cherkassy bridgehead, on the west bank of the Dnieper.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Marshal Josip Broz's [Tito's] Yugoslav Partisan Government announced over its radio today that it had decided to ask lend-lease aid to carry on its fight against the Germans and to seek representation on the Allied Advisory Commission for Mediterranean Affairs.

The Algiers radio reported the Eighth Army had forced a new crossing of the Moro River in the Orsogna area and had advanced up the Adriatic to within eight miles of Pescara, terminus of a main lateral highway to Rome.

Vacancies among court attaches of the city, many of whom recently have joined the armed services, retired or died, led yesterday to the temporary appointment of a youth not yet 18 as an attendant in the Manhattan branch of Special Sessions at an annual salary of $1,800.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 9 -- Apprentice Jockey Joseph W. Pannell was killed in a three-horse spill in the eighth race at Charles Town race track today. Crushed under a pile-up on the clubhouse turn, Pannell was pronounced dead from a broken neck on arrival at the Charles Town Hospital.

ALGIERS, Dec. 9 -- The French Committee of National Liberation is quietly seeking in Washington and London a definition of the terms under which Gen. Charles de Gaulle may enter liberated France as soon as possible after the Germans begin their withdrawal.

Yesterday's story of a field maneuver at Camp Mackall, in North Carolina, provided an especially interesting example of the thoroughness with which the American Army has mastered the methods of modern warfare. In the initial phase of this maneuver, nearly 6,000 soldiers, or more than half of a specialized division, were landed or dropped successfully from the air in a practice attack.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A series of violent explosions shook the village of Lerwick in the Shetland Islands recently when fires spread over several vessels moored at a wharf, it became known here today. Eight seamen were reported killed or missing and forty-two families evacuated from the waterfront area.

I read with interest the letter of Robert S. Fields published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Dec. 7, 1943. Having studied the Nazi propaganda and its undeniable effect on the German people, I believe that the "surrender or die" formula would be the correct approach to the problem of convincing the Germans that surrender is their best chance to survive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Representatives of farm organizations repeated arguments against the continuation of food subsidies today as open hearings on the issue came to an end before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
Youth certainly is accented on the Brooklyn College basketball squad, which plays its second game of the season against Webb Institute on the Kingsmen's court tomorrow night.

Succinctly called "Paris," an art exhibition was opened with a preview last evening at the headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., 457 Madison Avenue. It will be available to the public beginning today, at an admission price of 55 cents, including tax.

New channels of distribution have been opened to "soft goods" and at the same time pre-war relationships between different groups of distributors have been altered by wartime developments, Victor Lebow, sales and promotion manager of Chester H. Roth Company, Inc., hosiery mill agents, declared yesterday at a meeting of the merchandising group of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Sheraton.
There is a young soldier somewhere in town who is going to make a fine fighting man.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A threat of a crisis in the Balkans has followed the Cairo conference between President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Turkish leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A report showing that prices, money in circulation, war expenditures, corporate profits and the "inflationary gap" all were increasing on Nov. 1 was issued by the Office of War Information today. With it was a statement by Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, saying "there are constant and increasing pressures for higher prices."

Lester Patrick, manager of the New York Rangers, announced yesterday that he had acquired on loan two hockey players from the Canadiens of Montreal. The additions to the Blue Shirts are Johnny Mahaffy, 25-year-old center, and Fernand Gauthier, 23-year-old right wing.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 9 -- Chinese forces under Gen. Yu Cheng-wan, the "hero of Changteh," recaptured that stricken city in particularly savage fighting early this morning and moved on to push the Japanese invaders back from China's vital "rice bowl" region.
The article in the Sunday papers voicing the complaints of spokesmen for various organizations dependent upon contributions for their existence is quite touching.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A minimum wage of 50 cents an hour for employes of more than six months' experience in the cotton garment industry who work under contracts of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union was ordered today by the National War Labor Board.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Harold B. Beitler, a well-known lawyer, ended his life with a revolver early today, a few hours after he had been disbarred from practice in Orphans Court on charges of converting to his own use $4,067.95 belonging to the Children's Aid Society of Pennsylvania.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 9 -- A United States battle fleet including carriers has made a combined ship bombardment and airplane attack on the Japanese phosphate island of Nauru, west of the newly conquered Gilberts and below the Marshalls on which carrier planes made a shattering attack last Saturday, it was announced today.

ALGIERS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- While General Clark's fighters had overcome desperate obstacles to win the mountain tops of Camino, Maggiore and Croce -- sometimes literally clawing up steep, muddy slopes with their fingertips in the face of withering enemy fire -- there was every reason to believe their progress would continue to be slow and painful across the comparatively open country toward Cassino.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Early Christmas shopping raised the department store sales index of the Board of Governors, Federal Reserve System, to an estimated 152 per cent of the 1923-25 average in November compared with 140 in October and 132 in September.

The directors of the Dewey and Almy Chemical Company declared yesterday a 2 per cent dividend in common stock, payable at the rate of one share for every fifty shares outstanding on Dec. 24 to stock of record of Dec. 13. They also have declared cash dividends totaling $1 a share during 1943.

Jeremiah Sullivan, 46-year-old ex-convict and strong-arm man for the Owney Madden gang, is a character who could not be reformed even if he wanted to be. Now serving a reformatory sentence for coercion, Sullivan says that in 1918, when he was convicted of second-degree murder, he automatically lost his civil rights and "you cannot reform a person who has no rights."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- John Cowles, Minneapolis publisher, declared utterly false tonight charges by C. Nelson Sparks, former Mayor of Akron, Ohio, that Wendell L. Willkie's nomination at Philadelphia in 1940 was financed by New York bankers.

The St. John's University basketball team had little trouble disposing of the court pretensions of the West Point Field Artillery last night. The Redmen, never headed in a one-sided contest, buried the soldiers under a count of 69 -- 47 at the De Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn.

News from the battlefronts has been overshadowed during the past week by news of the great Allied conferences at Teheran and Cairo. These conferences have given us reassuring evidence of unity on the part of the Great Powers. They have undoubtedly shaped the strategy of the Allied offensive in the critical year 1944.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The conclusion of an agreement by a footwear, leather and hides mission which has just returned from a two months' trip to the United Kingdom to distribute importable and domestic hides in the ratio of 3.5 to the United States and 1 to the United Kingdom was announced today by William L. Batt, United States member of the Combined Raw Materials Board.

Here for a visit of "two or three weeks," during which he plans to see as many friends and Broadway plays as possible, Noel Coward, British playwright, granted a friendly thirty-minute group interview yesterday afternoon to newspaper men in the offices of John C. Wilson, 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

If families all over the country have anything to say in the matter, Gwen, 6 years old; Diane, 4, and Gerry, 2, three wide-eyed, blonde little sisters, aren't going to have any trouble finding a foster home before Christmas.

Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions yesterday ignored an ex parte order issued last Nov. 17 by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church for the appearance of Paul E. Flato, former Fifth Avenue jeweler, as a witness today in Flato's Federal bankruptcy proceedings.

Edwin Seaver, who in addition to his Book-of-the-Month Club activities is at present compiling a 300,000-word anthology of new American writing, to be published next year by L.B. Fischer under the title "Cross-Section," has found time to "ghost-write" Carole Landis' story of her overseas adventures, "Four Jills in a Jeep."

Whether a world bank is established or not, Latin-American exchange, with the exception of Argentina and Uruguay, will be tied closely to the dollar and New York will become the financial clearing house for Latin nations, John B. Glenn, president of Pan American Trust Company, declared last night.

Uncertainties in respect to legislative issues and military developments stagnated activity yesterday in the cotton futures market, holding the turnover to less than 70,000 bales and limiting price fluctuations to an 11-point range. On the New York Cotton Exchange, the list of active old futures contracts ended trading with quotations unchanged to 2 points below Wednesday's final levels.

ANKARA, Dec. 8 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Foreign Minister Numan Menemencioglu referred to the definition of the Turkish foreign policy expressed Nov. 17, when he said today that she stood on her present policy, Exchange Telegraph said today in an Ankara dispatch to London.

Jewels flashed in luxurious radiance at the luncheon hour in the Persian Room in the Plaza Hotel yesterday. A million dollar's worth of gems were exhibited by Frank S. Hartley on gowns from well-known uptown couturiers.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- J. Wallace Carroll, head of the London office of the United States Office of War Information, and three members of his staff have submitted their resignations, effective at the end of the year. It is understood that lack of cooperation by Washington officials caused the resignations.

Although the ski season is usually ushered in during the Christmas holiday period, providing the elements are in a cooperative mood, some sport is available at this early date, according to snow reports received yesterday.

It is amazing to observe the peculiar actions of certain members of Congress. Here is Senator John H. Bankhead, who is vehemently protesting that the Senate will vote down food subsidies and is unalterably against food subsidies and yet this same Senator Bankhead sponsored the Bankhead newspaper subsidy bill to force the Government to spend $15,000,000 each year in small-town newspapers.

Out of Patterson Field, Ohio, runs the longest freight line in the world, longer than any Casey Jones ever rode or hoped to ride, 14,000 miles to India. Its freight cars have wings, its signal lights are the sun and the stars in their courses and when it whistles for a crossing it can be heard a thousand miles away.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- Mopping up continued on the Mount Camino massif today, the sixth day since the Allied attack began.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson warned the American public today that after two years of war and a year of nearly uninterrupted successes the United States was still barely entering the "drag" phase of the war, in which the conflict begins to wear heavily on every nation involved.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Directed verdicts of not guilty were ordered today by Judge William J. Campbell for eight of the thirty-three individuals and corporations who were under Federal indictment for alleged fixing of prices for brick cheese, a violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Total advertising linage of eight New York newspapers for the first eleven months of 1943 registered an increase of 12 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures, released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended Dec. 4, led by higher prices for livestock, hides and coal. The advance brought the all-commodity index to 102.8 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Emphasizing the continued success of the anti-U-boat campaign, a joint Anglo-American statement revealed tonight that fewer Allied merchant vessels were sunk by enemy submarines in November than in any month since May, 1940, and that the number of U-boats sunk by us actually exceeded the number of their victims.

Many gifts to help children were among the 376 contributions to the thirty-second annual appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund received yesterday. In all the good that donors to the fund accomplish among broken families, the aged, the sick and the discouraged, none perhaps is more constructive and far-reaching than the aid extended to children who are homeless, neglected or mistreated, headed for trouble.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 9 -- In a race against the progress of a deadly snake bite, anti-venin was rushed here from Philadelphia by train and automobile today and administered to 14-year-old Fred Wege, who was nipped by a coral snake this morning in a classroom of the Red Bank High School.

Mrs. Olga Sleeis, 24 years old, of 264 Henry Street, the muscular wife of a soldier, was emerging yesterday afternoon with another woman from a rear entrance of the Criminal Courts Building, facing Baxter Street, when a heavyset man stepped from behind a pillar, struck her in the face with his fist and broke her nose.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 9 -- While German troops continued to pour into Bulgaria from all quarters last night, the Bulgarian Parliament was summoned to an extraordinary secret session -- with only a mere quorum -- to hear an "important report from the Government on internal and foreign policies," according to an official report from Sofia late tonight.

Although meat appears to be available in sufficient quantities to meet demand, the prevailing quality is poor. Much of the top grade beef and veal is being purchased by the Government for the military services, reports a spokesman for the United States Department of Agriculture, while a large amount of all grades and varieties is reserved for lead-lease.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Headquarters of the United States Eighth Air Force released details today confirming recent reports of improvements made in the Flying Fortresses and Liberators.

Establishment by the Textile Color Card Association of a research associate at the National Bureau of Standards in Washington to calibrate the 216 colors contained in the standard color card in terms of the Munsell system of color notation was disclosed yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director, at the annual meeting of the organization here.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 9 -- Gold, coffee and immigration are the topics that, for the most part, are occupying the attention of the economic convention here, it was stated today.

The chances were that Katie had never been a "good girl" so long in all her five years as she was yesterday afternoon. She watched the proceedings of the tenth annual Little Sister Show of the Boys' Club of New York at 287 East Tenth Street with enjoyment and confidence.

Mrs. Lee Lipschitz, who had proudly exhibited to reporters Wednesday afternoon a personal letter from Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., received another important communication late Wednesday night -- a telegram from the War Department that her family made public yesterday.

A quota of $911,000,000 for sales of bonds to individuals in New York State during the Fourth War Loan campaign, opening Jan. 18, was announced yesterday by W. Randolph Burgess, State chairman, at a meeting of the War Finance Committee for New York at its headquarters, 1270 Sixth Avenue.

Argentine butter that began arriving here in "moderate" quantities in the early part of October has been rejected by Government priority groups, for whom it was bought, as unsatisfactory and is being sold into civilian trade channels by the Commodity Credit Corporation, it developed yesterday after 195,776 pounds had been marketed privately.

The Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $1,670,432, after taxes and charges for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30. These results are before provision, however, for the undetermined liability which may result from any increase in wages provided for during the period from May 1, to Sept. 30, in new contracts with the United Mine Workers of America, effective from May 1.

ALGIERS, Dec. 9 -- The worst of the battle of the Camino-Maggiore mountains seems over. Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Allied Army has pressed its offensive in clearing weather to a point where virtually all twenty-five square miles of the battle area save the northwest tip of Maggiore and village of Rocca, more or less between the two rock masses, has been wrested from the fiercely fighting Germans.

Moreland Act Commissioner William F. Bleakley sharply rebuked a Park Avenue eye doctor, his secretary and his optician yesterday for the way they testified in a hearing at the Bar Association in the investigation of the kickbacks paid in workmen's compensation cases.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- The Fuller Manufacturing Company was permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Division to withdraw its common stock, $1 par value, from listing and registration on the Chicago Stock Exchange, but Commissioner Robert E. Healy, in a concurring opinion, urged that an investigation be made of the exchange's rule making the withdrawal possible.

The twelve central Federal Reserve Banks came to the rescue of the Government securities market and to the aid of their member banks pressed for reserve funds, by buying a total of $568,874,000 of Government securities in the open market in the fiscal week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Red Cross food packages not only keep up the morale of Allied prisoners of war, but at the Italian internment camp from which he escaped Oct. 3, they represented about 70 per cent of all the food supplied, Lieut. James L. Giblin, co-pilot of a Liberator bomber, told seventy-five women volunteer workers yesterday at the Red Cross packaging center, 39 Chambers Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- Winds which reached a velocity of seventy-four miles an hour on the Golden Gate Bridge swept over northern California last night and today, causing damage, with accompanying fires, of more than $2,000,000.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Following a union announcement that 2,500 employes of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation had quit work at plants in this area in a dispute over the employment of an assistant supervisor, the company issued a statement late tonight declaring the work stoppage affected only one of its several foundries and involved a total of only 510 employes.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 9 -- The decisions taken by America, Britain and China at the Cairo conference will have an important effect in the military, organizational and administrative affairs of India and southeast Asia.

I am wondering if all patrons of black markets are as unpatriotic as they are described. It occurs to me that, on occasion, an honest and Uncle Sam-loving individual might be provoked, even forced, into buying through such channels by the stupidity and unfairness of OPA dicta.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Wendell Berge, Assistant Attorney General, told a Senate subcommittee today that production of synthetic hormones, believed to be of use in the treatment of wounded soldiers for shock, was controlled by cartels between German firms and their subsidiaries in this country up to the outbreak of war with Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- A plan to refinance the Florida Power and Light Company through the issuance of $67,000,000 of new securities was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission in a joint action by the company and its parent, the American Power and Light Company, part of the Electric Bond and Share Company system.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 - Wendell Willkie's support for the 1944 Republican Presidential nomination is not nearly as strong as has been represented, John D.M. Hamilton, former national chairman of the Republican party, asserted today, following a tour of seventeen Western States.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of the musical, "What's Up," on Thursday night at the National Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild. Mrs. Charles Manton Richter heads the committee of patrons and patronesses for the event, and Miss Kathryna Hoffman Ray, debutante daughter of the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, heads the debutante committee for the benefit.

Students of City College, meeting yesterday to honor the school's war dead, heard a warning by Dr. William Agar, acting president of Freedom House, that despite its ferocity the fighting to date has merely been a foretaste of what is to come.

The Templeton, a five-story apartment building at 773-75 High Street, Newark, N.J., has been purchased by the Durland Corporation, represented by Sidney Lipstein of New York, from the Templeton Company, represented by William Baker of Jersey City.

"OPEN wider," said my dentist, thrusting his hand so far into my mouth I felt that his wrist watch would soon scrape against my eye teeth. "It beats me how you can stand such a dull job as yours. It would drive me crazy if I had to spend my time doing anything so boring and monotonous as reading books all the time."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- How to make war guilt personal has been under study by statesmen and international lawyers of the United Nations for a long time. But no proposed solution has impressed many as both workable and effective. The growing prospects of victory over the Axis have now intensified the study and brought the topic out of the academic category into the real.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- That Turkey will not join the Allies for the present as an active belligerent, even after President Inonu's meeting with Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt in Cairo, was borne out by Turkish Foreign Minister Numen Menemencioglu in a press conference tonight, when he said "our foreign policy remains unchanged."

Twenty charitable or religious institutions share more than $2,300,000 of the estate of Martin S. Paine, chairman of the board of Magnus Metal Corporation, who died July 14, 1942, leaving a gross estate of $2,707,660 and a net of $2,420,282.

It would be an understatement to say that the men who met in conference at Cairo and Teheran traveled to their rendezvous on the wings of the wind. Actually they flew at ten times the normal speed of the wind, at three or four times the speed of the hurricane.

J. Joseph O'Donnell, partner in the firm of O'Donnell Brothers, cotton brokers and importers with offices in the Cotton Exchange Building here and in Boston and Dallas, Texas, died on Wednesday in his home, 19 Groton Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

With the old clothing drive of the War Production Board and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office ended, Frank D. March, New York City salvage director, said yesterday that the need for used clothing for relief, both here and abroad, was a continuing one.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- According to reliable information here, the leak on the story of the conference held in Cairo between President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek occurred through the presence of a Chinese newspaper man attached to the Chinese mission, who transmitted the story to the Reuter Agency in Lisbon, Portugal.

The ten-day custodial workers strike called in the city's schools by the United Construction Workers, an affiliate of the United Mine Workers, was called off last night and the strikers notified that they might return to work this morning, it was announced by Leon Zwicker, regional director of the UCW.

The report of the Middle West Corporation for the third quarter of this year, issued yesterday by P.L. Smith, president, shows a consolidated net income of $1,150,408 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to 35 cents a share on the utility's outstanding capital stock and compares with a revised net of $1,079,904, or 33 cents a share, in the three months to Sept. 30, 1942.

Feel flu-ey? This might help. Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins advises: "Persons suffering from colds are better off in bed, both from their own standpoint and as a precaution against transmitting them to others."

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Riverview Hospital reported tonight "hourly improvement" in the condition of Fred Wege, 14-year-old sophomore of the Red Bank High School, who was bitten on a finger yesterday by one of two coral snakes he had taken to school to show to his biology class.

Only $2,672,500 of new municipal financing is scheduled to be done next week, compared with this week's revised total of $19,249,555, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average thus far in 1943 now stands at $15,471,221.

The F.W. Dodge Corporation has appointed T. Oliver Morgan, who has been district manager for construction news in the Chicago office of the company, as general manager of its home owners catalogues' division and executive assistant to Irving W. Hadsell, vice president in charge of construction news.

Brig. Gen. Albert J. Browning, director of the purchases division of the War Department, told the National Association of Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that a uniform clause for the termination of war contracts should be announced within the next two weeks by the Joint Contract Termination Board, organization of which was announced Tuesday by James F. Byrnes, director of the Office of War Mobilization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Navy's new cargo plane, the Mars, which is the largest flying boat in the world, has completed its first war mission, a flight to Brazil, Trinidad and Bermuda on which, at one stage, it carried as much as 35,000 pounds of war materials, Secretary Knox said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized certain transactions designed to comply with its corporate simplification order directing dissolution of the National Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company.

Ives Washburn will give a "coming-out" party this evening for Jane Goodell, author of the recently published, "They Sent Me to Iceland," when he acts as host of the "Angel's Table" at the Stage Door Canteen. Miss Goodell, who has been helping establish recreation centers as a Red Cross worker in Iceland, will take part in the entertainment at the service men's rendezvous.

The antique gold chatelaine that Mother may get for Christmas and the inexpensive gold-plated sterling pin for teen-age sister are but two examples of the ways -- some predictable, some perverse -- that the war has made new jewelry trends.
Fit as a fiddle, the Giants yesterday completed their last "rockpile" workout for their clash with Washington on the Redskins' reservation tomorrow -- the game they must win to continue to draw pay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Roosevelt studied from the air the battle course of the victorious Allied armies from El Alamein westward in his return trip across North Africa after the momentous conference he held in the Middle East.
ALGIERS, Dec. 10 -- A communique:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 10 (AP) -- E.C. Hadley, technical division manager, Remington Arms Company, has been named assistant to D.F. Carpenter, vice president and director of manufacture. A company spokesman said today that E.A. Doyle, present assistant to Carpenter, will return to E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., on Dec. 31.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 10 -- Dr. Thornbull Jacobs, who revived Oglethrope University in 1913 after it had been closed since 1863 when all of its students joined the Confederate Army, is being relieved as president at the age of 66.

Christmas carols of many lands were sung and pageants depicted the Yuletide in other countries last night at the seventh annual Christmas festival program of the international department of the McBurney branch of the Young Men's Christian Association held at the branch's building, 215 West Twenty-third Street.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The percentage of losses for each 100 aircraft of the RAF's Bomber Command during November's operations were as low as in any month of 1943 since February, despite the concentration of German fighters in Germany and northwestern Europe, and despite the scope and weight of the attacks carried out in the month, which included four major assaults on Berlin, the best defended German city.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The general vivacity and feeling with which "Tales of Hoffmann" was presented last night in the Metropolitan Opera House delighted an audience which packed the theatre. There was eminent reason for this. The opera is certainly one of the most original and fascinating in the repertory.
Four sales of dwellings for the Home Owners Loan Corporation were included in the residential deals reported in Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared today that the Japanese leaders "now know what way the war is going" and, in a desperate effort to keep their people fooled, have resorted to using the "sacred" person of Emperor Hirohito as a medium for disseminating false information.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 10 -- A new kind of plastic phonograph record and method of preserving wood provide the subjects of two patents which stand out among the 606 listed as granted in this week's issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

A mid-day demand of strong proportions enabled the stock market yesterday to resume its premature December rally. Under the sponsorship of the industrial issues, prices in several groups were bid up on an average of 2 points, with wider gains made in a few high-priced spots.

Concern for Gwen, 6 years old; Diane, 4, and Gerry, 2, the small blond sisters for whom the Children's Aid Society is trying to find a foster home before Christmas, is keeping the society's offices busy these days. Telegrams, telephone calls, letters and personal visitors continued to arrive in great numbers yesterday from all parts of the country.

Gifts to the Neediest Cases -whether to ease the pain and bewilderment of a widowed mother, cheer the aged ill, strengthen the despairing individual or meet the urgent needs of an abandoned child -- are gifts from the heart. Often they are made at sacrifice to the giver.
It was an Italian count who said to his American host some time ago: "America is going to turn either Fascist or Communist -- but will call it democracy."

The proclamation by the Partisans of a provisional Government in Yugoslavia in opposition to the Government in Exile brings into the foreground one of the thorniest of the problems that fill the background of Allied conference. This action of the legendary Tito, the experienced guerrilla fighter and able revolutionary leader, General Josip Broz, offers a serious challenge to the unity of the United Nations and the statesmanship of the Big Three.

Two pre-flight schools, Iowa and and Del Monte of California, each placed two men on the 1943 AllAmerica Service team selected by The Associated Press, it was announced yesterday. Vincent Banonis, 220-pound center, and Dick Todd, ex-Washington Redskin back, each gained berths for the Seahawks, while Raymond Bray, a tackle ,and Leonard Eshmont, former Fordham backfield star, came through or Del Monte.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Sofia was blasted for an hour and 45 minutes this afternoon by several waves of Allied planes, whose explosives caused great destruction and killed many persons, the Sofia radio said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Among more than 150 officers and enlisted men of the Army Fourteenth Air Force who have received awards for heroism and outstanding achievement in China, Burma and India are:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Proposals for breaking the black market in liquor and replenishing retailers' shelves by forcing 117,000,000 gallons of 100-proof whisky out of bonded warehouses were advanced by members of the judiciary subcommittee named to investigate shortages as it began its inquiry today.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Dec. 10 -- Arthur Stringer, who wrote mystery stories before he turned poet, has just solved mystery of his own. It has to do with the fruit that first caused the downfall of man. In the northwest corner of Mr. Stringer's three-acre lawn here is an apple tree.

Mutual recognition -- even between parents and children -- is difficult after being separated five years. Six young German refugees, part of a group that arrived by ship from England last week, described their war experiences and their emotions at being reunited with their families yesterday morning at the offices of the National Refugee Service, 139 Centre Street.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Kaffirs and diamond mining shares attracted most attention today in generally quiet stock markets. Interest in these holdings was prompted by disappointing dividend announcements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- When the American Federation of Labor's committee to consider the application of the United Mine Workers for re-admission to the federation met here today more than a score of federation unions asserted that the mine union was enrolling members in their fields.

Scott Holier, 35 years old, a "problem" soldier up to his arrest in Chicago last July 20 in the company of his bride of a month, a Wac, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to a Sing Sing term of 2 1/2 to 5 years. He had pleaded guilty to $5,500 in check forgeries and $1,500 in thefts from stores.

Under increased mill demand and commission-house buying on news of a better inquiry for the staple in the spot markets, futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at net gains of 5 to 15 points. Eleven December notices were issued, bringing out some contracts in the near months, but these notices were later stopped by spot firms.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The city of Sofia, shabby capital of Bulgaria, was heavily bombed by Allied planes today, according to German and Bulgarian reports, as affairs in that least helpful of Germany's Balkan satellites moved toward another crisis brought about by the struggle within the country between Teuton and Slav.

Truck fleet operators will participate in an "Information, Please" contest sponsored by the B.F. Goodrich Rubber Company, Akron, in which they will be asked to select the tire advertisement of the company they consider most effective.

The scrutiny of prices at which brokers and dealers, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, sell securities was held forth by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday as a proper and necessary function of the commission.

Public utility refinancing again dominated the new bond offerings this week, with a single issue accounting for $42,000,000 of the $47,500,000 in three new issues offered to the public, two of which were tax-exempt loans. The week's flotations compared with $25,350,000 for two offerings last week, when one represented $25,000,000 in public utility bonds, and $4,522,000 for three diversified flotations in this week a year ago.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 10 (AP) -- A revival of football at several major colleges was indicated today as the Southeastern Conference scrapped its last peacetime athletic eligibility restriction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -The Senate Finance Committee today approved legislative cushions to ease the impact of forced price readjustments on war contractors.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 -- A long-range research campaign on sugar will be undertaken at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in cooperation with the Sugar Research Foundation of New York, it has been announced jointly by Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, and Joseph F. Abbott, head of the foundation.

" The Courageous Mr. Penn," an English-made drama starring Clifford Evans as William Penn and, with Deborah Kerr heading the supporting cast, will have its premiere at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse on Wednesday, Dec. 22. "The Great Mr. Handel," the theatre's present tenant, now is in its fourteenth week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The new ration token plan for use in the purchase of foodstuffs will go into effect Sunday, Feb. 27, the Office of Price Administration announced today. By that time distribution to retailers of some 2,000,000,000 of fiber tokens will have been completed, it is estimated.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Tokyo propagandists are now sinking American battleships as fast as they are launched and months before they are ready to put to sea.

The General Motors Corporation has a post-war "master plan" that calls for the spending of $500,000,000 for reconversion of its plants from war to automobile production, technological improvements and retooling for new cars, it was disclosed last night by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Wartime radio developments and the post-war future of communications were discussed before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today by E.K. Jett, chief engineer of the Federal Communications Commission, and O.B. Hanson, vice president and chief engineer of the National Broadcasting Company.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 (AP) -Spare Man, 7-to-5 favorite owned by Mrs. C.S. Bromley's Cedar Farm of New York, made it two victories in as many starts at the Fair Grounds when he won the top division of the Terebonnie Purse, six-furlong dash run in two sections today.

A container re-use program for the cosmetics industry would call for the setting up of several agencies in various parts of the country to process more than 1,000,000 containers a day, H.D. Goulden, director of the board of standards of the Toilet Goods Association, Inc., pointed out yesterday in a report made public by the group.

Japan's defenses must be attacked from all directions rather than along any single "short cut" route to Tokyo, Lieut. Gen. A.A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, yesterday told the National Association of Manufacturers' second war congress at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Andrew Jackson High, defending champion, and Far Rockaway recorded second straight South Queens P.S.A.L. basketball triumphs yesterday. Jackson beat Jamaica, 40 to 27, and Far Rockaway crushed Lane, 59 -- 33. In the same division Richmond Hill turned back Adams, 34 -- 14.

An exhibition entitled "The Christ Child" opens today at the headquarters of Friends of Greece, 52 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until Christmas Eve. Among the artists represented are Louis Bouche, Jean de Botton, Jon Corbino, Buffy Johnson, Eric Isenburger, Barnard Lintott, Mane-Katz, Harold Sterner, Everett Shinn, Paul Meltsner, Stark Young and Henry Schnakenberg.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 10 -- The strike of between 15,000 and 17,000 workers in the five New Jersey plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, engaged in the production of engines for Army planes, including the new B-29 super-bombers, was terminated this afternoon by an agreement between labor and management that the issue that had touched off the walkout would be submitted to arbitration.

Mention in this space of the 17 3/4-pound togue that Alvah E. Davidson of Rye took Down East last summer prompted E.J.W. to remark that that was a nice fish and what did the writer think of togue fishing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Rear Admiral Stanford C. Hooper (retired) was revealed today by Representative Clinton Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico as one of the two officers on whom, according to testimony given before the Special House Committee in investigating the Federal Communications Commission, "reprisals" were visited by James Lawrence Fly, FCC chairman, because of opposition to his policies as chairman of the Board of War Communications.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Casualties in the country's armed forces since the beginning of the war total 129,422.

When a censor says there has been too much censorship, that's news. Byron Price's amended code and accompanying comments, made public yesterday, therefore deserve attention. Mr. Price seems to think that newspapers and radio stations have been too conscientious or too easily intimidated.

ALGIERS, Dec. 10 -- The Allied Fifth Army has expelled the last Germans from the Camino-Maggiore mountain area of Italy, enveloped Mignano and now controls the Via Casilina to a point within eight miles of Cassino. Meanwhile Canadian units of the Eighth Army have launched an armor-powered attack across the Moro River near the Adriatic and are engaged in a fierce battle around San Leonardo.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- The first Italian troops to be sent into the line on the Italian front attacked at dawn this morning from positions of the Fifth Army and found the enemy waiting for them. A few hours later they came reeling back to their original positions but many dead remained behind and their hospital back of the lines is full tonight of Italian wounded.

Thackeray is out of fashion now, but some of us old Thackerayites hear in the ears of memory about this time every year that poem in which are the lines: "And wish you health and love and mirth as fits the solemn Christmas-tide." How ironical those words seem as you look at the Hundred Neediest Cases.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Dec. 10 -Icicles decorated the gray barracks' ] eaves and thin gray smoke rose from barrack chimneys as the inspection party approached the prisoner of war camp for Italians before dawn here today.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The organizing of the prospective Anglo-American invasion of northwestern Europe is progressing swiftly, despite the magnitude of the task set for officers and men of the Allied armies, navies and air forces, it was indicated today.

The peoples of the West were warned last night by Dr. C.L. Hsia, representative of the Chinese Ministry of Information, that "they must take the peoples of Asia seriously in their striving for freedom." Meanwhile, "the peoples throughout Asia, articulate and inarticulate, are anxiously watching to see whether the leaders in the older democracies meant what they said," he added.

In a continuation of his drive against black market dealings in citrus fruits, United States Attorney James B.M. McNally arraigned fifteen fruit dealers yesterday in Federal court. Pleading guilty to charges of having bought oranges at excessive prices, the defendants were fined $500 each by Judge John W. Clancy.

While a mild form of influenza continued to spread yesterday, reaching epidemic proportions in many sections of the country, particularly in the East and Midwest, an anomalous and somewhat baffling situation existed in the city, where health officials reported a slight but not significant increase in respiratory diseases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- If the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration fails in its task, there will be grave doubt that any collaboration of these countries in any field can succeed, Herbert H. Lehman, UNRRA Director General, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 10 -- The steady bombing of enemy bases in the Marshall Islands is going ahead with drumbeat regularity that shows no signs of diminishing, it was disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States has admitted about 580,000 victims of persecution by the Hitler regime since it began ten years ago, Breckinridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Nov. 26 in secret testimony released today by Chairman Sol Bloom.

" GOOD morning," said Santa Claus as he brushed a flick of chimney soot from his beard. "I've got your pal Orville Prescott's list of Christmas book recommendations; now how about yours? Everyone's clamoring for good reading this year. It takes me back to 1850, when people used to hole in for the winter with three-decker novels that were guaranteed to last until the first crocus."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Arrangements to insure the movement into regular distribution channels of inventories of fabricated articles or components made idle by contract modifications or terminations were announced today by the War Production Board.

" We are watching carefully the growing need for care of children of service men, especially now that fathers are being drafted, but at present there are few cases in which Lanham funds can be used for the care of very young children, such as those born since Pearl Harbor," Mrs. Florence Kerr, Director of War Public Services of the Federal Works Agency, declared yesterday.

A century ago the world spoke of phthisis and consumption only to shudder at the words. Now it speaks of tuberculosis. Forty years ago the death rate from that once dread disease was 200 per 100,000; today it is 40 per 100,000 -- a decline of 80 per cent. No longer is tuberculosis the leading cause of death; it now ranks eighth on the list of deadly diseases.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is planning a film, to be released under the title of the old stage play "The Rosary," with a plot involving religion and soldiers in the present war. Lloyd C. Douglas, whose best-selling novel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The text of the Censorship Code of Wartime Practices for the press, revised as of Dec. 1, 1943, is as follows:

While increased hotel sales throughout the country during October (rooms and restaurants), showed a gain of 19 per cent more than the averages of the like 1942 month, October figures on the whole were not as favorable as those of the previous month or for the year to date, according to a tabulation by Horwath Horwath, accountants.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Francis E. McMahon, who recently let his position as Philosophy Professor at Notre Dame in a dispute with university officials, was appointed today associate professor of philosophy on the faculty of the College of the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Income payments to individuals registered another record in October, the total of $12,775,000,000 representing an increase of 3 points in the index of the Department of Commerce, which allows for seasonal influences.

Capacity kills in all classes of meats reported by local slaughter-houses have not increased supplies for civilians, it was disclosed by the weekly review of meat trade conditions released yesterday by the Food Distribution Administration's local office at 150 Broadway.

Allied control of the skies over the Mediterranean is now so complete that we may feel sure that there was no element of recklessness or unusual risk in the visit which Mr. Roosevelt has made to Malta. This being true, we can rejoice in the President's decision to go out of his way to pay tribute to that little island.

Leaders in science yesterday urged leaders in industry attending the National Association of Manufacturers Second War Congress at the Waldorf-Astoria to come forth with generous financial support of scientific research, the keystone upon which alone industrial progress can rest.

Liquidation of the New York State Mutual Savings Banks Fund, which was voted to be abandoned last June when institutions the served by the fund decided to take out insurance with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, has been begun.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Peter Masefield, British aviation expert, who criticized American airplanes and tactics early in the war, now believes that United States-built warplanes are the world's best in fifteen of twenty-two categories.

A contribution of $12,500 from the Book of the Month Club, Inc., has been received by the New York War Fund Committee in the campaign for $17,000,000 locally for support of twenty-six war-related agencies, it was announced yesterday by Emil Schram, New York committee chairman.

The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs reports that the Buy a Bomber campaign, in which the organization participated with the General Federation, has been oversubscribed, with the total amount of bond sales reaching a figure of $938,906 at the close of the six-week campaign period.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Representatives of the French Committee of National Liberation today promised French Indo-China a "more liberal" political status and control of its own customs after the war, and simultaneously renewed the committee's pledge that France will fight alongside the United Nations until Japan is completely defeated.

With the announcement in Montreal by Hector Racine, president of the Royals, that Fresco Thompson had been replaced as manager by Bruno Betzel, who skippered Durham in the Piedmont League last summer, interest in local baseball circles yesterday focused again upon the Dodgers, who of late have been quiet.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told the annual model Assembly of State Hi-Y Clubs today that with the privilege of asking something from the Government went the responsibility of seeing to it that the request did not infringe upon the rights of others.

Gregory T. Paige, in his letter published in your issue of Dec. 1 discussing blackout alarms, states that an all-clear signal by radio is the only solution left. However well this signal may work in the city, the unfortunate suburban air raid warden finds it no solution at all.

The six-story building containing forty-eight apartments at 205 East Eighty-second Street, in Yorkville, has been sold by the Steinco Realty Corporation (G.J. Goldstein, president), to the Coaching Lane Estate, Inc. for cash over mortgages aggregating $150,000.

Undismayed by the statement of Senator Harry F. Byrd in Washington that he was not and did not expect to be a candidate for the nomination for President, John U. Barr of New Orleans, temporary chairman of the Byrd-for-President Committee, declared here yesterday that the movement for nominating the Virginia Senator by the Democratic National Convention was growing in all parts of the country, particularly in the South.
As reported in your paper Dec. 4, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox stated that more tons of shells and bombs were dropped on Tarawa than the RAF dropped in the heaviest single raid on Berlin.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 11 -Soviet forces have captured the twin junctions of Znamenka and Khirovka, southwest of Kremenchug, giving the Red Army effective control of the northern Dnieper bend's entire railway system and intensifying the Russian threat to the industrial centers of Kirovograd and Krivoi Rog, Moscow disclosed last night.

A testimonial luncheon marking the retirement of Commissioner Edward J. Parker, national commander of the Salvation Army, and of Mrs. Parker from the organization after fifty-eight years of service was held yesterday afternoon in the Governor Clinton Hotel.

Proof of the favorable turn in the Battle of the Atlantic is apparent in the ease with which convoys pass now between the Old World and the New. It is also apparent in Britain's improved supply position, as well as in the steadily mounting total of new tonnage coming from shipyards on both sides of the Atlantic.

Never has the barrage against popular complacency about the war been as heavy as in the last few days. The barrage is getting heavier as Christmas approaches, and one might say that one reason is the very fact that Christmas is so near.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 -- Owing partly to increased industrial operations and partly to heavier freight shipments, business in the Pittsburgh district last week advanced to record levels, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Jokesters have told this one a million times. Yesterday it really happened. A patient with a toothache jumped through a window when he saw the dentist grab the forceps.

OTTAWA, Dec. 10 -- Following the recent elevation of the legations in Washington and Ottawa to the rank of Embassies it was announced here today on behalf of Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King that similar steps had been taken with regard to the diplomatic missions to the Soviet Union, China and Brazil.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs here today, while smaller than expected, were larger than they were a week ago and packers had enough swine in their holding pens to keep slaughtering at capacity for the remainder of the week. Receipts at the twelve leading Western markets today were 119,400 head, compared with 93,769 a week ago.
The present rage for Victoriana has now reached its peak with THE NEW YORK TIMES publication of an encomium of the Parlor Stove.

Linwood I. Noyes, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, reported yesterday that the current waste paper collection drive, if successful enough, can not only fill war needs for the products of salvaged newspapers, but can also relieve the shortage of newsprint by reducing the need for diversion of woodpulp from newsprint to other uses.

An end of unnecessary brilliance in the lighting of the Broadway sector and some other parts of the city was urged yesterday by Donald K. Vanneman, government requirements representative of the War Production Board, who said that "too many" business establishments had failed to do their part in the voluntary brownout intended to conserve electric power, coal and other resources.
