The Victory Book Campaign, which, since its inception in January, 1941, has collected 17,000,000 volumes, of which 10,000,000 were distributed to the armed services, will be dissolved Dec. 31, according to an announcement made yesterday by William S. Hepner, chairman of the board of directors.

Following is the text of the nineteen-point program urged by Alfred P. Sloan Jr. chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation, before the National Association of Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night, to be adopted by Government, industry and labor to insure maximum production and employment in the post-war period:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A first step in what many exporters regard as a return to normal trade channels of shipments of civilian goods to reconquered territories has been taken here and in New York by spokesmen of the buying missions established for French holdings in North and West Africa.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies showed an increase in sales of 3.2 per cent in November over the like month a year ago, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The gain compares with a decline of 6.5 per cent in October.

Formation of an Allied Nations Standards Body was revealed yesterday by R.E. Zimmerman, vice president of the United States Steel Corporation and retiring president of the America Standards Association, at the silver anniversary meeting of the organization at the Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -The Senate Military Committee rewrote the service men's discharge pay bill today, adopting a graduated plan which puts the emphasis on overseas service.
Some folk think that since subsidies have been successful in England we should imitate their experience.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Mitchell medium bombers resumed the aerial hammering of Japanese installations in the Cape Gloucester area of New Britain Island Thursday, dropping 48 tons of bombs on Borgen Bay to the east and raking the coast eastward to Rein Bay in a damaging strafing attack.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- A red hot attack on left wing elements in British politics was made today by Comdr. Robert T. Bower, Tory member of Parliament since 1941, who branded all Labor party members voting against the release of Sir Oswald E. Mosley as acting "in the purest tradition of Himmler."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 11 -- Combat victories of New Zealand airmen in the Pacific war zone over Japanese are in the ratio of five to one, it was indicated by Air Vice Marshal Leonard M. Isitt, chief of the air staff, today.

Five Brooklyn men were arraigned yesterday afternoon in the Brooklyn Federal Court before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein for allegedly receiving twenty-four cases of powdered eggs stolen from a lend-lease shipment in transit between Texas and New York State.

E.L. Hoffman, former wholesale manager of the Chrysler New York Company, has been appointed to take charge of the Greater New York region of the corporation, which embraces Greater New York and immediately adjacent points, according to announcement yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (AP) -Two strikes, one because of a conflict between an independent union and the CIO United Steel Workers and another over a wage controversy, stopped work at the Butler plant of the American Rolling Mill Corporation and the Lawrenceville plant of the Crucible Steel Company of America today.
Basketballs will be bouncing briskly off the backboards of five local gymnasiums tonight as court activity increases mightily throughout the country.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10 -- The Federal Commissioner of the Province of Santa Fe announced today the arrest of seven supposed Communists who were surprised while holding a secret meeting. The Commissioner said the prisoners had been handed over to national authorities for whatever action might be considered fitting.

There will be one departure from the Broadway boards this evening, "All For All." The Norman Bruce comedy, which opened at the Bijou Theatre last September, will terminate its engagement after eightyfive performances. Jack Pearl and Harry Green are co-starred in the play and A.L. Berman produced it.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Inclusion of the Niagara Falls Power Company in the proposed merger of Niagara Hudson System companies is opposed by the New York Power Authority. The Public Service Commission said today the Power Authority has filed a brief objecting to the planned consolidation on the ground that it is not "in the public interest."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Broader responsibility for the clearance of war news to the newspapers and radio was assumed by the Office of Censorship today, while Byron Price, the Censorship Director, simultaneously asserted that war information was being suppressed by unauthorized agencies.

In every country they have occupied the Nazis have won the deadly hatred of its inhabitants. Instead of trying to allay it, they steadily strive to increase it. More than three years ago they sought to fetter free teaching in the University of Oslo, but the professors and students resisted so strongly that the effort had to be postponed.

The nearest thing to a draft for women yet devised -- the classification system for nurses ordered by the War Manpower Commission -has produced 500 "A-1" nurses in the New York area since the system was put in operation four weeks ago, according to Miss Helen Young, who is in charge of the project.

Quick-frozen baked beans, time and labor-savers that have been reduced recently from six to two points a package, are suggested in the menus planned for next week for a model household of two moderately active adults and a school-age child.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans have broken through to the Adriatic coast and occupied the town of Biograd, twenty miles southeast of Zara, but German claims of a growing Nazi aerial threat against the forces of Field Marshal Josip Broz (Tito) today caused increasing concern among Yugoslav observers here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Announcement today that Canada is to be represented in Chungking, Moscow and Rio de Janeiro by Ambassadors instead of Ministers, is expected to be followed sooner or later by Australia and South Africa. It emphasized Canada's intention of playing an important part in post-war affairs.
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 11 (AP) -The midnight Friday supplementary communique:

Delegates from virtually every country outside the influence of the Axis powers are going to the projects of the Tennessee Valley Authority to study first hand TVA's methods of developing river valleys and effecting the industrialization of undeveloped raw materials areas, according to a letter just received by THE NEW YORK TIMES from David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the TVA.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Rallying to record what was probably the greatest block scoring in the annals of pocket billiard championship play. Irving Crane of Livonia tonight took a lead over the champion, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 710 t6 694, as they concluded the fifth block of their seven-block, 1,000-ball challenge series.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Ronald Ransom, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged the House Banking and Currency Committee today to give the board more time to enforce the ban on absorption of charges on exchanges by big city banks for their country bank customers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Declaring that Canadian breweries are being permitted to operate on a rotating schedule which permits them to manufacture whisky for three weeks and then return to war alcohol production, Senator Van Nuys said after the Senate judiciary subcommittee's liquor inquiry session today that he thought American firms should be allowed five days each month to turn out potables.

Two years after the war ends there will be traffic policemen in the sky to regulate airplane travel over New York, Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday. The Mayor disclosed that his post-war program included not only the completion of the $100,000,000 municipal airport in the Idlewild section of Queens but also the construction of one or two large airports for the use of private planes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- The vast increase in non-Government demand deposits in banks since the beginning of the war reflects increased needs of business concerns and farmers and not, as commonly assumed, the war-boom wealth of individuals as consumers, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago declared in a study released today.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Victorious Chinese soldiers fought on north of captured Changteh in the fertile farmland of northern Hunan Province today in a bid to clear the area of Japanese invaders, the Chinese High Command announced.
William Teitelbaum has resigned from Saks-Fifth Avenue as buyer of all men's furnishings and men's robes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Roosevelt has signed the draft bill which puts pre-Pearl Harbor fathers at the bottom of eligible lists and deals a blow to the prestige of Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Chairman, who opposed the measure on the ground that it would "sabotage" the overall manpower program.
Spear-headed by an astonishing $110,000,000 wagering jump in New York alone, the country's racing hit new highs during 1943 with $710,779,432 in bets and $32,534,484.30 in revenue to the States.

The pace of Christmas shopping here slowed this week as measured in dollar volume comparisons with a year ago. Department-store sales on the average were estimated as running about 3 to 5 per cent under the like 1942 week. Some establishments were able to show increases, but they were far under gains reported in November.

After surging into the light for a time, the local theatre last evening crept back guiltily into its melancholy ways when Brock Pemberton produced "Pillar to Post" at the Playhouse. A story of camp life and Army wives, it is neither well written nor well acted, presenting the gloomy picture of a comedy which wanders with leaden feet across the stage.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- All deliveries of wheat and rye and December barley reached today the highest prices of the season on the Board of Trade and only a price ceiling prevented December oats from going into new high ground. Buying was progressive throughout the day, and although profit-taking shaded the best prices at the last wheat futures closed 1 1/4 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel higher than yesterday.

The St. George High School football squad, champion of the city of Chicago, arrived yesterday and quickly resumed preparations for the post-season charity game with Mount St. Michael High, this city's only unbeaten and untied eleven, at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

Universal Bible Sunday, sponsored annually by the American Bible Society, will be observed widely in churches tomorrow, marking the climax of "Bible Week" which began with a service last Sunday evening under the auspices of the New York Bible Society in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

A YOWL of anguish comes from the vicinity of Chicago at the persistent use of certain football phrases in this column during the professional season. Albert Mitchell, radio's Answer Man, asks a few good-natured questions in affected indignation.

In reference to your editorial of Dec. 4, "Stabilizing Wages," bearing on the usefulness of a summary wage table over an extended period of time, a yearly index of average hourly wages and cost of living since 1914, which is given on Page 202 of Robert E. Summers' "Wages and Prices," reveals how average hourly wages maintained in large part the increases registered after World War I, while the cost of living slid back appreciably.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- As the result of deaths, resignations and by-elections, the Democrats in the House of Representatives now have a numerical majority of only one seat.

In the old song Daddy went a-hunting for a rabbit skin "to wrap my baby bunting in." Layette-seeking parents these days might be envying that father of former times whose quest was comparatively simple, if they weren't so busy figuring out ingenious new expedients for their own infants' clothing -- to say nothing of facilities to wash him and for sleeping.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 10 -The Stalin-Roosevelt-Churchill conference at Teheran, Iran, will immediately bring a softening of regulations in certain Latin-American nations regarding the treatment of Russia. Brazilians look with admiration and confidence on the successes of Russian forces, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Foreign Minister, declared today to me.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Attempts of the Red Sox to trade with the Indians have resulted in hard feelings between the clubs.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Dexter M. Keezer of Portland, Ore., now serving on an economic mission with the United States Embassy here, delighted members of the Council for the Preservation of Rural England at their meeting in London today by apologizing for the commotion caused by his fellow-countrymen in Britain.

CAIRO, Dec. 10 -- Despite the usual crop of rumors affecting Turkey whenever that country gets into world headlines, there would appear to be little change in the Balkan military situation these days. There is apparently no truth in the persistent rumors of German troop concentrations on the Turkish border.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Representative Fred E. Busbey, Republican, of Illinois, declared in the House today that the foreign-language division of the Office of War Information is overloaded with aliens, Communists and fellow-travelers whose avowed purpose was to destroy the American form of government.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Attempts of the Red Sox to trade with the Indians have resulted in hard feelings between the clubs.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Dexter M. Keezer of Portland, Ore., now serving on an economic mission with the United States Embassy here, delighted members of the Council for the Preservation of Rural England at their meeting in London today by apologizing for the commotion caused by his fellow-countrymen in Britain.

When the general price ceiling plan was adopted in Canada two years ago provision was also made for the fixing of wages. Prices and wages were generally frozen at the level prevailing in the fall of 1941. However, two types of wage adjustments were to be permitted:

FREDERICK, Md., Dec. 10 (AP) -Charley (King Kong) Keller, slugging outfielder of the world champion Yankees, received a six-month deferment from military service today, but Yankee fans can derive little joy from that.
Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant district was the scene last night of a fatal shooting resulting from a dispute in a lunchroom at 372 Ralph Avenue between two customers and a counterman, all Negroes.

ABOARD A U.S. CARRIER IN THE CENTRAL PACIFIC, Nov. 29 (Delayed) -- Lieut. Comdr. Edward H. (Butch) O'Hare, famous fighter pilot, was shot down in a night air battle over the central Pacific two nights ago while American airmen were breaking up an attack of thirty or forty Japanese torpedo planes on a United States carrier force, his flying companions said today.

Trade reaction to the announcement of the distribution of hides between Britain and the United States and the accompanying explanatory statement of Harold Connett, assistant director of the textile, clothing and leather division of the War Production Board, was extremely favorable yesterday.

IT now appears that George Seaton's comedy about death called "Out of This World," which was first tried out in 1940, is definitely on its way to Broadway. If all goes well it will turn up here in mid-March. The owner and producer of the script, Harry Joe Brown, is at this moment in negotiation with the Theatre Guild, which may very well sponsor its production here.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 11 -- A surprise counter-offensive against the Government's announced intention to give many workers a five-day vacation with pay over Christmas was launched by the National Employers Federation today.
THE commanding officer of a big military installation was looking over a long, elaborate report of attempted sabotage in his unit. Glancing down the index, his eye lit on this item:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Post-Dispatch said tonight in a copyrighted story that Wendell L. Willkie had "thoroughly explored the possibility of forming a third political party" and had canvassed the technicalities of getting a third-party candidate on the ballot in each of the forty-eight States.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY In Italy, Dec. 11 -- The Italians had their first chance to redeem themselves in the eyes of the world when a shock unit of their troops went into battle at dawn on Dec. 8 against one of the toughest spots in the Mignano area guarding the pass toward Cassino.

NOW that shrubs have lost their foliage and weeds are turning brown, it is possible to see along their stems yellowish white, shiny lumps which look like a kind of swelling but actually are egg cases of the praying mantis. They will not hatch until next summer.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czech Government-in-Exile, arrived here today to sign the Czech-Soviet treaty of friendship and mutual assistance, and expressed the hope that his work here would help the nations fighting Hitler to speed the liberation of those countries under the Nazi yoke.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Creation of a permanent world food organization, the purpose of which will be to promote concerted national action to improve nutrition, raise the general level of well-being among the populations of the globe, increase the efficiency of agriculture and better the condition of producers, will be recommended to the forty-four participating nations by the interim commission appointed by the recent Hot Springs Food Conference.

The special program being carried out by the American Foundation for the Blind among men of the armed forces was outlined in the organization's annual presented yesterday by the president, M.C. Migel, to the trustees of the organization at its headquarters, 15 West Sixteenth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Builders of machine tools in the Chicago area, who constitute about 25 per cent of the total for the nation, will probably do a business in 1944 of about one-fourth of the current year's volume, according to members of the industry.
Lieut. W. MacNeil Rodewald, USCGR, and Mrs. Rodewald of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., are at the Savoy-Plaza for the winter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- To handle the increased paper work which is involved in the processing of pay-as-you-go income tax returns and payments, the Treasury has asked Congress for funds to set up a new 2,500-man sorting office in New York.

SUZY-Q is a Flying Fortress, one of the wheel-horses of our aerial warfare in the South Pacific in 1942. As the flagship of the Ninety-third Squadron of the famous Nineteenth Bombardment Group, she sank Japanese ships, shot down Japanese planes, killed Japanese sailors and soldiers in gratifying numbers -- and incidentally circumnavigated the globe.

Princeton spurted in the closing minutes to register a 33-to-31 victory over Columbia in a Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game on the Lions' court last night. Trailing by 9 points with 10 minutes of play remaining, the Tigers at last found the way to the basket, wore their rivals down and walked off with the game.

Strong public response was reported here last week to one of the first "post-war products" developed by industry -- a new radionic hearing aid produced by the Zenith Radio Corporation after 5 1/2 years of laboratory experimentation.

An ambitious post-war plan by the United Fruit Company that would open up European markets for the fruit growers of the West Coast, by the establishment of a regular weekly service with large, modern, fully refrigerated ships operating between this country's western ports and Europe, was announced last week by William K. Jackson, vice president and general counsel of the company, in a speech before the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce.

Your editorial of Nov. 28 dealing with the current discussion of permitting Cabinet heads to appear before Congress leads me to call attention to an oft-repeated mistake which is made by writers on this subject.

HEALTH for house plants depends not a little on the amount of water they are given. To determine the proper amount, numerous factors must be taken into consideration. The best general rule is to apply water whenever the surface soil feels dry and then so thoroughly that the entire root system is saturated and excess runs through the soil into the pot saucer.

WARTIME HANDYWOMEN -- As the carpenters, cobblers and cabinetmakers of the nation take up arms, women on the home front are being obliged to take up their abandoned hammers and saws. The mending of broken furniture, essential now to conservation, is no longer the exclusive domain of the trained artisan or the man-of-the-house.

IN the theatrical profession, which can never be charged with inarticulateness concerning itself, no group has been so conspicuously articulate as the scenic artists. Lee Simonson, who is a wit and a man of letters as well as an artist, is in many respects the leader of the vocal band.

In less than a month from now the President will present his new budget to Congress. This Presidential budget in the past has been little more than a preliminary estimate of expenditures and revenues for the forthcoming fiscal year. It has not been accompanied, as has the British budget, with explicit Executive recommendations for taxes to raise the required revenues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The second installment of the Giant-Redskins battle for honors in the Eastern half of the National Football League, continued from a week ago when the party of the first part won, 14 to 10, at the Polo Grounds in one of the big upsets of the year, will be presented here in the nation's capital tomorrow when the two teams meet in Griffith Stadium, home tepee of the Redskins.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Japanese were on guard in their Marshall Island bases this week as the devastating attacks by powerful American naval task forces, taking a heavy toll of enemy warships, planes and shipping, seemed to presage the expected invasion -- perhaps in the near future of this heavily fortified enemy sphere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The series of extraordinary conferences in the Middle East came to an end last week with the strategy for the victory over Germany finally coordinated and integrated to a common time-table.

BROOKLYN is Brooklyn and Manhattan is New York and never will the twain acknowledge with any graciousness that they are sister boroughs of Greater New York. Brooklyn people do not call themselves New Yorkers; they are Brooklynites. But the Manhattanite considers himself a true New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, disputed today statements made yesterday before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs by Breckinridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State, that this Government had done everything legally possible to permit the immigration of victims of Nazi tyranny and that the majority of these had been Jews.
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 11 (AP) -- United States bombers resumed today their time-table blasting of the strategically situated Marshall Islands.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 11 -- In a fast encounter, Dartmouth's basketball team won its second straight Eastern Intercollegiate League game, downing Cornell, 52 -- 38, tonight. Capt. Aud Brindley threw in 13 points to lead the Green, which is seeking its seventh straight title.

SLOWING down of the Christmas buying rush grew more perceptible in the week. Local reports indicated that sales of the big stores here were running below a year ago on the average. Early shopping, broken assortments and even the mild influenza epidemic were offered as reasons for the trade slackening.

IN a period much inclined to experiment in the arts, such as our own has been, we have had more than a little intermingling of literary forms. One that has enjoyed some popular favor during recent years has been that blending of biography and fiction, commonly known as the biographical novel.

Although the climb from the National League cellar still may prove a long, hard one in the 1944 baseball campaign, Giant officials yesterday had reason to believe the outlook was made rosier for them by the new law which will delay the drafting of pre-Pearl Harbor fathers until all eligible single men have been inducted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Selective Service headquarters ordered draft boards today to delay the calling of pre-Pearl Harbor fathers as long as possible and set out on a quest for more young, single men and perhaps 4-Fs to serve in the country's armed forces.

Without mentioning President Roosevelt by name, Senator W. Lee O'Daniel of Texas, a Democrat, declared here yesterday that the time had come for a thorough "housecleaning" in Washington, including a change in the Presidency.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 -- In an editorial, entitled "unjustifiable affront" the Prensa, great Buenos Aires democratic newspaper, protested this morning against the suggestion made by Jessie Sumner of Illinois in the House of Representatives that the foreign policy of Latin-American nations was influenced by financial considerations.

The past week brought to a successful conclusion a series of momentous inter-Allied military and political conferences extending over a period of more than a month. Enough has been revealed to justify the statement that these conferences laid the foundations for a new and better order in the world and mapped out the means for creating it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Twelve thousand hogs held over from yesterday's session were placed on sale today in the livestock market here, but only about 3,000 head were taken. Prices of hogs averaged slightly lower this week as markets were congested with heavy receipts. The average here yesterday was $13.16 a hundred-weight against $13.36 a week ago and $13.64 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has approved adjustments to the plan of reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company. The modified plan calls for the distribution to bondholders of $52,038,036 of interest accruing during the trusteeship.

While the Department of Health reported no abnormal increase in the number of "no heat" complaints received yesterday when the mercury dropped suddenly to well below freezing, Mayor La Guardia announced late in the afternoon that the city was "facing a bad situation over the week-end because of the shortage of domestic coal."

MY high school is at war. A plaque listing the names of boys in service and of alumni who have died in battle appears in our main corridor. Our peacetime garden is now a Victory garden. Our bulletin board, once for the proud display of notes on how to parse an Elizabethan sonnet or conjugate the irregular verbs, now speaks of "How to Enlist in the Farm Program," "How to Help Civilian Defense."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The threats and conflicts which reverberated in the camps of both the Democratic and Republican parties this week can generally be traced to these causes:

The Liberators were attacked twice, first just after they left Sofia and again on the Albanian coast near Scutari, The United Press said. Liberator crews said the target was thoroughly covered with bomb bursts and smoke billowed up 5,000 feet from numerous fires and explosions.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The Luftwaffe suffered one of the heaviest blows in its history today when large formations of American Flying Fortresses and Liberators, escorted by United States Lightning and Thunderbolt fighters, delivered a paralyzing bombing attack on Emden, one of the most important ports of Germany.

Mayor La Guardia celebrated yesterday his sixty-first birthday. When he arrived at City Hall soon after 10 A.M. the only thing to show that the day was different from other days was a large floral bouquet placed on his desk by members of the office staff.

In spite of stringent measures speculation in the sale of theatre tickets has continued unabated on Broadway, according to theatre men. Although the legal maximum service fee for orchestra and box seats is 75 cents, instances have been reported of a pair of tickets, each $4.40, for a musical selling for as much as $25.

The "coma" which engulfed France in defeat and the French Army's role in the liberation of the nation were reviewed in an address delivered by Lieut. Gen. Paul Emile Beynet, newly appointed head of the French Military Mission in the United States, at a luncheon given in his honor by the French Institute at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

Advance on Rome In the Allied campaign in Italy the lines of forward command fan out from two olive-drab trailers. Somewhere on the left or center of the rugged mountain line there is one trailer which is Lieut. Gen. Mark Clark's advanced headquarters. Somewhere on the right is Gen. Sir Bernard Law Montgomery's.

HERE is the stuff of which sagas are made. Jesse James Benton is a name to conjure with -- yet it must be as true as the man who here sets down his adventures and his laconic observations on the life and times of the half-century during which the Wild West was tamed.

The classical muse -- propelled by Mayor La Guardia and a non-profit corporation of forty-six prominent and artistically minded citizens -- last night came to the City Center of Music and Drama, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street. Thus did the city embark on a career of music and drama to meet low pocketbooks.

Praising the conferences of the United Nations leaders at Cairo and Teheran, Rabbi Joseph Zeitlin in Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue, said yesterday, "The news of the increased unity among the powers of the United Nations is most heartening and strengthening to the cause of democracy."

THE play of end positions is almost the only department of bridge which can be learned readily from books. A full deal, with thirteen cards in each player's hand, is usually too complex for the student to analyze exhaustively.

SANFORD, Fla. -- Lifting of the dimout restrictions for the Atlantic seaboard has put a new glow on the Florida season already bright with promise. Miami's skyline, emerging from a year of darkness, clear and shining against the misty night blue, seems a sort of symbol to all the State of what it will mean "when the lights go on again all over the world."

UNUSUAL sidelights on painters and sculptors are often to be obtained from their work in black-and-white. So Curt Valentin has put together an unusual show at the Buchholz Gallery, with portraits by Chagall, Derain and Kokoschka, figure pieces by Kirchner, Picasso and Lehmbruck, and characteristic prints by artists as diverse as Rouault, Masson, Lipchitz, Kurt Roesch, Klee, Beckmann, Hayter and Hugo.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- A month has passed since the German counter-attacks began on the Kiev salient, and except for a brief pause last week they have been maintained incessantly.

The Lener Quartet gave the third of its series of eight concerts flare yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Two of the greatest of Beethoven's quartets, the examples in C major, Op. 59, No. 3, and in C sharp minor, Op. 131 formed the program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- Comdr. Thomas F. Reilly Jr., who spent eighteen years building sewers in the Borough of Richmond, led the Fourteenth Battalion of Seabees ashore here today after a year on Guadalcanal, during which the outfit won commendation for work under Japanese fire.

OMAHA, Dec. 11 -- What the nine-cent increase in the corn ceiling price means to the Corn Belt farmer depends somewhat on what happens to be his major interest. So large a proportion of Corn Belt revenue is derived from marketing livestock that the tilt, without a corresponding rise in livestock prices, means less in terms of bulk income that might be supposed.

AILEEN had her troubles, although she was only 3. At nursery school she liked to paint alone at her easel, outlining a crude circle or oval and then filling it in. She always used red paint, and usually called her art product "House." Of 187 paintings done in her first nursery-school year -- two to three times as many as any other child in her group -- 133 were drawn and colored like this.

On many occasions the controls imposed over prices have created more problems than they have solved. The latest illustration is the action of OPA in raising the ceiling price on corn from $1.07 a bushel to $1.16 (the parity price for corn is $1.06). This advance has been permitted in order to encourage the shipment of corn to the market instead of using it to feed hogs.

The thirty-second annual appeal for the Neediest Cases completed its first week yesterday with a total of 2,109 contributors, who have given $83,759.37. This generous response gives assurance that the distressed families and individuals whose cases, totaling 100, were published last Sunday will have their urgent material needs met and that they will have the friendly, skilled guidance that will help in their rehabilitation.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

THE vein of irony is so rare in novels today that to find even a vestige of it is news. Few writers in recent years have had the intellectual keenness to see into the idiotic inconsistencies of modern life, the poetic sensibility to feel their significance and the perspective to infuse their sense of irony into works of symbolic value.

THE-American doughboy is going to be not only the "singing-est" soldier in the world; he's also going to be the "musician-est," if there's any such word. Into the steaming jungles of the South Sea Islands. the cold barrens of the Arctic and the burning deserts of the East he's taking his own instruments and technique for producing sweet music to sooth the savage breast.

Encouraged by the success of his first Carnegie Hall concert, given a year ago, Duke Ellington led his orchestra in a second program in that auditorium last night. The event proved a gala occasion for the city's jazz fans, who turned out in such large numbers that not only was the hall filled to capacity, but it was found necessary to accommodate several hundred of the eager listeners with seats on the stage.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 11 -- The peopling of Australia is second in importance only to the defense of Australia. Peace will find her population depleted by war losses yet confronting a new world in which her policy of immigration restriction will be more than ever susceptible to challenge.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- A recommendation has been made to Governor Dewey by J. Edward Lumbard Jr., head of the State Election Frauds Bureau, that the scope of the extraordinary grand jury investigation in Albany County be broadened, and that a special prosecutor be appointed.

Executives of many British textile firms, when discussing post-war trade with the United States, are thinking of exporting to this country goods of types and qualifies different from those produced by American textile manufacturers, according to a statement yesterday by M. Stanley Brown, United States representative of the Cotton Board of Manchester, England, who recently returned here after a three months' trip to Great Britain.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 -- Pierre Laval's private army, the Vichy militia, is getting out of hand and causing him some concern, according to private advices from France.

The Columbia University War Relief Committee and the Sarah M. Sturtevant Graduate Fellowship will share in the proceeds from a subscription series of three piano recitals to be given by Rosalyn Tureck at Town Hall on the afternoons of Jan. 15, Feb. 5 and March 4.

Capt. Harry E. Stark, master of the SS Cape Neddick, will receive the first United Fruit Company gold medal for "meritorious service at sea beyond the call of duty" in a ceremony tomorrow, aboard his vessel at the Hoboken yards of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

A SPIRIT of hope is creeping over the land, more noticeable this winter than at any time since the war started and the lights went out. And as if in answer to this hopeful sign, the resorts are restoring some of the activities dropped when vacationists turned from beach clubs to factories.

After some three weeks of comparatively mild weather, New York was hit hard early yesterday morning by a cold spell that sent the temperature down twenty-two degrees in nine hours, and gave little indication of any substantial let-up. Last night the mercury started down again, reaching 13 at 10 P.M., the lowest of the season.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The newspaper Razon said today that the Government was studying a United States Government proposal for American operation of Bolivia's national quinine factory and its enlargement to increase production.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec, 11 -- The second anniversary of the German-Italian-Japanese military alliance produced broadcasts from leaders of the tripartite powers of which that of Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, was the most significant for its expression of confidence in the military positions of the Axis powers.

After a number of minor skirmishes in local gymnasiums, college basketball for the 1943-44 season will move into the "big top" this week when leading quintets see action at Madison Square Garden. Two double-headers are listed for the Eighth Avenue arena, one on Tuesday and the other on Saturday.

Only the other day did I learn of the two letters to THE TIMES of Emery Reves -- one published Sept. 19, and the other Nov. 23 in reply to mine published Nov. 14. Otherwise I would have been more prompt in replying to Mr. Reves' request that I explain why "a graduated sales tax which is actually now in operation in England and Australia is impossible here."

AN AMERICAN FIGHTER BASE, in Western Italy, Dec. 11 -- Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the United States Army Air Forces, predicted today, in a tour of the Italian front that Germany would be unable to offer much resistance to the Allies' assault from the west when it came.

Edward Lawson, regional director of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices, announced yesterday that an extensive investigation has been launched into alleged discriminatory employment practices in the maritime industry.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted from Chungking in Mandarin to China and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:
Operating on the theory that when telling fish stories (it applies to hunting, too) the safest place to start is as far away from home as possible, we take you now to Oregon:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- New York and Boston fishermen who have been on strike for two weeks were asked today by Roy F. Hendrickson, Director of the Food Distribution Administration, and Ira N. Gabrielson, acting coordinator of fisheries, to return to work immediately on the basis of a new four-point price program announced by the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Five German U-boats were sunk and three more were crippled by Allied warships and planes in a fierce two-day battle with a wolf pack of twenty in the North Atlantic recently, the British Admiralty and Air Ministry announced tonight in a joint communique. Only three Allied planes were lost and 99 per cent of two valuable convoys reached port safely, the communique said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The United States, in a move to split Hitler's Balkan satellites away from the Axis, tonight solemnly warned the governments of Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania that they must share the "consequences of the terrible defeat that United Nations arms are so surely bringing to Nazi Germany."

Joseph M. Dodge, chairman of the War Department Price Adjustment Board, contended last week before the Senate Finance Committee that experience with the administration of the contract renegotiation law in the field of standard commercial products clearly indicated that excessive profits had appeared consistently.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace declared here tonight that the coming peace must destroy for all time international "monopolies" on vital medicines and other elements necessary to fight disease.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Turkish radio said in a broadcast early today that the Russian Government had decided to recognize Marshal Josip Broz's [Tito's] Partisan Yugoslav Government as the legal representative of that country instead of King Peter's regime.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 11 -- The five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in Passaic and Bergen Counties were back on full production today after a stoppage that began on Thursday.

BINGO RIGGS and Handsome Kusak reach Thursday on Monday, which is not so cockeyed as it sounds, for Thursday, for the purposes of this story, is a small town in Iowa. They meet a turkey, and the turkey meets extinction.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Dec. 11 -- Col. Douglas C. Johnston, commanding officer, Mitchel Field, presented today awards and medals to the families of twenty soldiers, killed, missing or taken prisoner. Thirteen of the soldiers won the decorations for participating in the bombing of the Ploesti oil refineries in Rumania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- All deliveries of grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade advanced today to new high prices for the season except December cats. The upturn in this contract was checked by the price ceiling and all business in that future was at that level.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Navy reported today that it had developed a "revolutionary approach to the entire foreign-language problem" through a program whereby Navy personnel is taught to read and speak Japanese in the "record-breaking" time of twelve months.

Christmas trade here last week failed to hold its percentage gains over the like period of last year. Estimates indicated department store volume on the average ran about 3 to 5 per cent under 1942 levels. Some establishments had sales increases for the week but they ran well under the increases noted during November.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (Netherlands News Agency) -- A mass German slaying of Netherland collaborationists who joined the Nazi movement to colonize the Reich's conquests in eastern Europe was reported today by the Moscow radio, quoting dispatches from Stockholm.

ALGIERS, Dec. 11 -- The Allied armies on both sides of Italy found the Germans as tough as ever yesterday and progress continued to be slow. But the British Eighth Army thrust another bridgehead across the Moro River, while the troops that had previously crossed nearer the coast captured San Leonardo, just beyond the north bank.

Asserting that the United States must help in every possible way to restore order and decent living throughout the post-war world, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, avowed candidate for the Republican nomination for President, declared last night that this cooperation must be without abandonment of national sovereignty.

OBJECTION SUSTAINED: Congress wrote a resolution last week for the fortieth anniversary of the Wright brothers' flight expressing gratitude "for this * * * contribution to progress." Senator Bennett C. Clark of Missouri objected: "In my opinion it is probably the greatest disaster that ever happened to mankind."

EVEN if President Roosevelt isn't a candidate, the 1944 campaign will be a sizzler due to the war and because thirty-two Senators and the entire 435 members of the House of Representatives will be coming up for election.

DECCA has taken handsome advantage of its agreement with the musicians' union, which enables it to make records. The first major album to issue from its studios since the ban on this company was lifted is nothing less than selections from "Oklahoma:" (A-359, six ten-inch records).

The ultimate success of the meetings of United Nations statesmen at Moscow, Cairo and Teheran "will be in direct proportion to the accuracy with which those in authority express the will of their people," Wendell L. Willkie, former Republican Presidential nominee, declared last night.

The average citizen will not have to file an income tax declaration by Wednesday if he filed one on Sept. 15, James W. Johnson, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York district, said yesterday in an attempt to dispel confusion on the subject of filing.
What happens to a projectile in the bore of a gun? Col. H.H. Zornig recently gave the answer in a General Electric Science Forum.

A propos of the self-reliance of the young, one of the lighter items reported in a bulletin of the National Probation Association is this one: "Smelling smoke, adults in the Whitehurst home rushed to the room of Edson Whitehurst Jr. to find him trying to put out flames in his bed. Asked why he had not called for help, Edson said, "I wanted to handle this myself."

Lieut. Joseph Raphael Hunt of the United States Navy and Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, the national champions, head the rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1943, it was announced yesterday.

The proposal before a Senate subcommittee to force 117,000,000 gallons of aging whisky out of bonded warehouses to relieve the current liquor shortage was denounced yesterday by most of the nation's distillers as a step that in a few years would make domestic whiskies so inferior to imported stocks that this country's brands could not regain their popularity for many years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Thousands of foster-children, returning to Norway from Germany to destroy the country that had saved their lives, will provide one of the saddest pages in history, Lieut. Col. Carl Stenersen of the Norwegian army predicted today at a meeting of the Chicago Bar Association.

Trade and other business transactions between New York and Latin-American countries are being endangered through over-long delays in air mail transit, even with allowances made for wartime conditions, it was indicated in a survey by the Foreign Trade Bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, released yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The apparent consumption of beef and veal during the first eight months this year, based on Federally inspected slaughter statistics, declined about five pounds a person from the same period last year, while pork consumption rose about five pounds, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Money's no object, it seems, in New York State's frenzied rush of Christmas shopping, in which the most popular luxury items are costly lingerie and heavily taxed furs.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Brigham Young staged a fancy one-handed shooting exhibition in the first half to take an 11-point lead over Canisius tonight and went on to win, 45 -- 36, before 5,112 spectators in Buffalo's Memorial Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- George Preston Marshall was doing the talking -- which was not unusual. The Magnificent Marshall always does the talking. It was the eve of last Sunday's Giant-Redskin game and the chief of the capital Braves was expounding at great length in accordance with an old habit of his.

Time, Inc., was enjoined yesterday in United States District Court by Judge John C. Knox from displaying a part of a March of Time film showing Frank Sinatra singing before a group of Waves. The plaintiff was RKO Pictures, Inc., which is about to release a feature-length film, "Higher and Higher," starring Mr. Sinatra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Negotiators for coal operators representing about 65 per cent of the industry and for the United Mine Workers reached an agreement today on a wage policy which can be put into a basic wage contract if the Office of Price Administration agrees to compensatory price increases in coal.

THE first section of Part XI of the stamp collection of the late Col. E.H.R. Green, about 2,160 lots, realized $60,585 when sold at public auction through Harmer, Rooke Co. on Nov. 29 through Dec. 3. The amount brought to nearly $408,600 the total thus far received from the sale of these holdings.

What with the rapidly shifting international kaleidoscope these days, a mere Hollywood producer has to be a combination military strategist and political analyst with a touch of Cassandra as well. Instead of his daily racing form, he now reaches for the morning paper.

MAYOR LA GUARDIA'S pet project, the City Center of Music and Drama, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street -- not so long ago known as Mecca Temple -- tomorrow night will usher into its 2,800-seat auditorium, the John Golden production of "Susan and God," the first in a scheduled list of choice theatrical offerings that have packed the Broadway theatres in the not-too-distant past.
In a rousing, fast-moving battle, City College's quintet went down to a 70-61 defeat at the hands of the Ellis Island Coast Guard last night in the Beaver gym.

TO the Latin Quarter, Lou Walters' flourishing Broadway theatre-restaurant, has recently arrived a new revue entitled "Montmartre Madness." And the report this morning is that Mr. Walters' latest floor show is one of his most ambitious and entertaining presentations to date.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Plans for devoting Dec. 5 to a celebration of the first decade of repeal and of freedom from the evils of bootlegging, hi-jacking and rum-running which had been part and parcel of the prohibition era ending in 1933 were discarded last month by the liquor industry and those who helped to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment.

Highly selective trading characterized yesterday an active short session on the stock market. Gains were limited to fractions on the average and the list showed a ragged appearance at the close. Volume on the Stock Exchange, which was the largest for a Saturday in three weeks, was 424,300 shares, compared with 301,730 in the previous two-hour session.

REREADING Miss Millay's lyrics in this handsome volume one finds it hard to believe that she made a reputation as a rebel against convention. The form of her poems, the tone and metrical effects, are traditional and imitative.

Retailers in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles had brisk consumer response last week on Christmas gift merchandise, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

It has been at least fifteen years since a scholastic football games was staged at the Polo Grounds, but today will find Mount St. Michael, the city's only undefeated and untied eleven, squaring off against the Chicago district champion, St. George High, a postseason charity contest on the uptown gridiron.

IN making candy at Christmas or any other time the best results are obtained with a thermometer. Deviating from the stipulated temperature usually produces a confection that may be edible but that is excessively soft or hard. In addition, a wooden spoon is helpful, since it does not become too hot to handle when left in the cooking candy and will not cut into the hand when used in beating.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 11 -- The Teheran communique on the future of Iran has aroused particular interest in this part of the world. In responsible political circles here there were more discussion and expressions of satisfaction about the document referring to Iran than about the other Cairo and Teheran communiques, including that issued after the conference of President Inonu, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill.

Production of newsprint in Canada during November amounted to 256,336 tons and shipments 260,590, according to announcement of the Newsprint Service Bureau yesterday. Production in the United States was given as 66,465 tons and shipments 67,490, making total United States and Canadian production 322,801 and shipments 328,080.

MORE than any other art, literature feeds upon itself. First there is writing, perse. Then there is writing about authors. Then there is writing about writing. Painters and musicians occasionally borrow themes or techniques (giving credit each time) and try a new composition with the old material.

ONE of the most moving incidents of the Teheran conference took just twenty minutes. It was the presentation of a token sword, the gift of King George VI to the people of Stalingrad, in a crowded conference room by Prime Minister Churchill to Premier Stalin.

RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 11 -- Skiing enthusiasm has been running high in this region since the record snowfall just before Thanksgiving Day permitted the sport to get under way at a record early date on the lavish set-up here at Pico Peak.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Thomas H. Robinson Jr. was convicted here tonight of the kidnapping of Mrs. Alice Speed Stoll of Louisville.

There is "no evidence of a very alarming increase in respiratory illnesses in New York City," Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins declared last night in reporting that a check on absenteeism in a representative cross-section of the city's industry indicated a rise in the number of such ailments, including influenza.

The article by Samuel S. Fels in THE TIMES MAGAZINE is an interesting contribution to the requirements of post-war peace. Every one can subscribe to his enumerated ten safeguards against war. But they are largely ineffective because they do not treat of the causes of war.

ALLIED, HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Australian patrols swept aside light enemy resistance along the coast of New Guinea and inland from Wareo Thursday and Friday, further extending their grip on Huon peninsula.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The first step toward implementing United States participation in a tremendous program of international cooperation for the relief and rehabilitation of the war-stricken peoples of the world were taken this week by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Bulgaria, caught between German bayonets and American bombs and facing the prospect of her third crushing national defeat in thirty years, pondered intensely tonight the chances of moving closer to Russia, her traditional friend, and cutting loose from the tobogganing fortunes of Adolf Hitler.

OTTAWA, Dec. 11 -- Carrying its effort for the orderly prosecution of the war another step forward, the Canadian Government this week ordered the stabilization of wages for the duration, except in cases of "gross inequality or gross injustice." Then it will permit a wage rise only if the employer is able to pay the increase without raising prices.

The Elks Fraternal Center, the former home of Percy Rivington Pyne 2d, banker, at Madison Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, was opened officially yesterday by the Elks War Commission to house and entertain service men. The center is the eighty-seventh of its kind to be opened throughout the country by the commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- American fighter pilots have been knocking down German fighters "in their own back yard" at the ratio of four German planes downed to every American craft lost, it was disclosed here yesterday by Brig. Gen. Curtis E. Lemay, division commander of the Eighth United States Air Force, who led Flying Fortress formations from bases in Britain against enemy targets from October, 1942, until the middle of last month.

Contributions to cheer the Neediest at Christmas and to ease their burdens through the year came yesterday from warm-hearted friends in cities and towns as far distant from New York as Brunswick, Me., St. Petersburg, Fla., and Altadena, Calif. In addition to gifts both large and small from New York City and its suburbs and neighboring States, others came from Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, Ohio, Illinois, Vermont and New Hampshire.

Such articles as "Where Do We Stand on Inflation?" in THE TIMES Magazine state only half-truths. The article states: "Certainly, we need not fear the sort of an inflation that Germany suffered during the early Nineteen Twenties." I dissent.

The Treasury, with the aid of the foreign property control departments of the twelve central Federal Reserve Banks, has just completed the greatest census ever undertaken of this country's investments in foreign lands. These investments range from a half-interest in a small goat farm in Greece and ownership of an atoll in the South Pacific to corporate investments in excess of $500,000,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11 -- Shot Put, extreme outsider in a four-horse race, won the $3,500 added Pelican Handicap which topped a fine program at the Fair Grounds today. "Dropping from the clouds" under a rousing ride by Bobby Reeves, Shot Put hurled himself at two struggling leaders and passed them in the last stride to win by a head.
How free should a school board be of interference by the Mayor? That question was at issue last week in the National Education Association's open hearings on educational problems in New York City.

Every year since 1912 the Hundred Neediest Cases have been reported in this newspaper at this season. There has been time for two great wars, for enormous changes in our ways of living, for an older generation to pass from the scene, a younger generation to reach middle life.

THE O. Henry collection of short stories is indistinguishable from the Foley- O'Brien collection reviewed last month, except that some of the names are changed, and Eudora Welty. Dorothy Canfield (Fisher) and William Fifield, in that order, are given prizes.

FROM Buenos Aires came word last week that, at the suggestion of the Argentine Naval League, the Government had authorized the printing of a 5-centavos stamp (20,000,000 copies) to commemorate the "Semana del Mar" (Sea Week) festivities to be held at Mar del Plata, an Atlantic seaport and summer resort, late in January and early in February.
New York University's youthful but speedy basketball team registered its second triumph last night, overwhelming the Brooklyn Marine Barracks quintet, 67 to 30, at the University Heights gymnasium.

"SOME people when a doughnut is placed before them, claim they can see only the hole in it." That recent bit of homely observation from President Roosevelt prompted a TIMES writer to ask, "Is there a hole in the doughnut?" Bakers and delicatessen clerks between Times Square and Penn Station were quoted as saying that what the President had in mind was the cruller.

Vassar College alumnae and undergraduates representing the metropolitan area, who have been active for several weeks in working toward the success of the New York Vassar Club's twenty-second annual benefit opera party, report a large advance subscription for Friday night's performance of Verdi's "The Masked Ball" at the Metropolitan Opera House, which they have sponsored.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania opened its 1943-44 basketball season with a 58-31 victory over Yale tonight at Convention Hall.

Larger spring allotments are being made by manufacturers in some lines and stores are hopeful of having fairly good assortments for the public for the opening of the new season, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Stabbing straight for the heart of Japanese domination in Central China, Chinese troops and American planes have hit at the great metropolitan area of Hankow to relieve pressure on the struggle around Changteh.

A new celestial navigation instrument, which combines a sextant for use during the day and a quick means of determining true north, sun time, latitude, great circle course and direction, has been invented by F.H. Hagner of San Antonio, Tex., for use in life rafts. The instrument, made entirely of corrosion-proof plastic, weighs about one pound, floats in water and is clearly visible for a distance of twenty-five feet even at night.

The growing success of the Allied drive along many battlefronts has been due in a large degree to the united help of thousands of women working behind the lines, Maj. Gen. Frank O'D. Hunter, commanding general of the First Air Force with headquarters at Mitchel Field, L.I., declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Cost of Living Index, now under investigation by the War Labor Board to determine how truly it reflects wartime living costs, is a basic element in the nation's wartime economy. It is the key to WLB's "Little Steel" wage formula and the yardstick of real wages.

With a moderate volue of business, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday their upward movement and closed virtually at the best levels of the day. Active futures in the old list finished at net gains of 6 to 8 points and those in the new conness, prices on the New York Cottract were up 6 to 10 points. Opening prices were firm and 1 to 2 points higher than Friday's final quotations.

IN this friendly and readable volume, sold for the benefit of the canteen associated with St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, Archbishop Spellman, as Military Vicar of the Armed Forces of the United States, gives us the letters that he wrote to his father during an arduous tour of the fighting fronts.

SOME twenty-odd years ago that indefatigable anthologist, the late Joseph Lewis French, compiled a noteworthy collection of sea tales, basing his choices almost exclusively upon action -- "and action often more intense or more frank or more brutally elemental than in the best mystery thrillers," and the collection was published in two volumes under the title of "Great Sea Stories."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11 -- King George of Greece has promised Premier Emmanuel J. Tsouderos that, to further post-war unity in Greece, he will re-examine the question of his own return to Athens in the light of the national interests and the political and military considerations prevailing when the country has been liberated.

Tarawa. The name will take its place on the battle flags of the United States Marines as one of the greatest in their annals of courage. LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The Allied air offensive against Germany, which should reach a climax before March, will be less affected by weather conditions this winter than any previous series of winter bombing operations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Washington and the country are confronted, in view of Senate action last week, with the question whether a shifting of absentee balloting from Federal to State control would "disfranchise" the American service man in the election next year of a President, a Vice President and a new Congress.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 12 -- Red Army spearheads drove within striking distance of the industrial city of Kirovograd yesterday, while, according to German reports, other Soviet forces broke into Cherkassy, last major Nazi stronghold on the west bank of the Dnieper above the river's big bend.

OFFHAND a listener might not suppose that the wife of the Premier Duke, Marquess and Earl of Ireland had a twice-a-week spot on a local station, but that happens to be the case. At 8:15 P.M. on Tuesdays and Fridays over WINS the Duchess of Leinster is discoursing on current topics, probably the only person holding an English title to be a regular habitue of Radio Row.

The report of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation and subsidiaries for the nine months and the quarter ended on Sept. 30, issued by W.A. Patterson, president, for publication today shows for the nine months a net income of $3,305,141 after charges and Federal income taxes, equivalent to $2.20 a share on the outstanding stock, and for the third quarter, a net income of $1,151,741, or 77 cents a share.

MODERN armies roll on ball and roller bearings, the simple mechanical device that translates sliding friction into rolling friction and thus dissipates the costly drag on almost everything that revolves. The wheels of roller skates are hung in ball bearings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie said tonight he would be "delighted" to undergo "unlimited cross-examination" by a Congressional committee concerning charges that some of his supporters sought to buy votes at the 1940 Republican convention.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A situation which veteran grain traders called "highly unusual" developed today on the Board of Trade when the Cash Grain Association announced a new set of ceilings applicable to all grades of oats and barley except No. 3 white oats and No. 3 barley.

Paid advertising, with an estimated value of $500,000, was contributed through metropolitan newspapers and periodicals in support of the National War Fund campaign, it was announced yesterday by Emil Schram, chairman of the New York committee.

The "educational department" of the War Manpower Commission announces a unique sort of course which it plans to give this winter -- a program to train high school students in the art of REFRIGERATOR REPAIR. The reason for the course is a shortage of refrigerator men, since all the veterans are mending tanks and guns for the Army.

RUNAWAY adolescents and juke-box devotees of the "Pistol Packin' Mamma" variety highlight the day's news. Not so sensational is the story of how teen-age youngsters are relieving the help shortage by part-time employment after school hours.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Roosevelt spent two days with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at Carthage in North Africa "on his way home" from the Middle Eastern conferences, the White House announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Rev. Daniel A. Poling returned from a 35,000-mile tour of Egypt, India and China with a prediction that the American service men, now on foreign soil, would control practical affairs in the United States for the next fifty years at least.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Another general reduction in the ration values of all pork items on the consumer point-value table except variety meats and canned meats was announced tonight by Chester Bowles, Price Administrator. It becomes effective at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- An enlarged truck production program for 1944, together with the manufacturers' names and the number of commercial motor vehicles each will produce under it were announced by the War Production Board today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- All Russia celebrated this week the good news from Teheran that Premier Stalin, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill had agreed completely on the scope and timing of new military operations from the east, west and south designed to crush the German Army.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Republican leaders of eleven Western States, in a declaration of principles adopted tonight at the close of a two-day conference, asked "speedy elimination" of "the present un-American system of rule by appointed bureaucracy" which "affects acutely and adversely the entire economy and political and domestic life of our Western States."

Prominent educators representing the United States and many foreign nations adopted last week an eight-point program for the establishment of an international office of education. Meeting at New York University, under the auspices of the United States Committee on Educational Reconstruction, the educators, in adopting the plan, urged that post-war educational projects be undertaken immediately.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Selective Service Director, said today the new draft law signed by President Roosevelt would bring a minute scrutiny of occupational deferment requests through greatly expanded appeals boards.

IN this little book Louis Fischer, who has written much of Soviet Russia and Loyalist Spain, has turned the searchlight of his militant and self-conscious liberalism on British administration of India. He pronounces it bad and finds that England has no right to be in India at all.

WITH apologies for the enforced brevity in a crowded week to a dozen artists cited herewith, we begin a chronicle of one-man shows by noting that one of the best displays of work by the late Louis Eilshemius is current at the Valentine Gallery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Senator Carter Glass of Virginia put himself on record today as favoring legislation to permit members of the armed forces to vote in Federal elections under Federal authority and responsibility, thus aligning himself against the group of Southern Senators who recently blocked a measure to this end.

IRA WOLFERT, who won the Pulitzer Prize last year for his "Battle for the Solomons," expects to go overseas again for North American Newspaper Alliance soon after the first of the year. This time he will head for Europe.

TO a recent plea for material needed by the art class at Clinton Prison, Dannemora, published on the Sunday art page of THE NEW YORK TIMES, the following responded: Samuel Golden and Walter N. Jacobs of New York City; Mrs. Agnes H. Lincoln, Stonington, Conn., and Mrs. R.W. Middleton, Edgartown, Mass.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Andrew Ponzi, Philadelphia veteran, completed a successful defense of his world pocket billiard crown tonight against Irving Crane, former champion, from Livonia, N.Y. The defender completed 1,000 points, while holding Crane to 924, a winning margin of 76.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Roger Peckinpaugh, No. 2 man of the Indians, says there is nothing unethical about trying to sell a baseball player you don't own but expect to acquire.

I VISITED a science museum today -- between the covers of "Science at War." The curator, George Gray, has assembled an up-to-date exhibit of secret weapons and tagged each with as much information as is discreet.

The general sentiment of the shipping business was expressed by Ira A. Campbell on Friday evening when he told the monthly meeting of the Metropolitan section of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers that the decision of the Advisory Board on Just Compensation meant a great moral victory for American shipowners.

JANE'S FIGHTING SHIPS has long been the "Bible" of the world's navies. A compendium of information about men-of-war of all nations, it is as interesting and thorough as it is unique. It is not a book to be read in a subway; it is so big it would elbow your neighbor out of his seat and weigh heavily upon your knees.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- Still vainly seeking their first victory, the New York Rangers suffered their fourteenth defeat in fifteen National Hockey League games while bowing to the Bruins, 9 to 6, before 6,500 spectators at the Boston Garden tonight.

ONE of the items in this collection, "America's Most Famous Murder," by George L. Porter, is a documented account of the final disposal of the body of John Wilkes Booth Dr. Porter was a surgeon in the Union Army and the only commissioned officer present when Booth's body was buried.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11 -- It is now clear that the recent series of military and diplomatic conferences in Cairo and Teheran can be considered far and away the most important parleys of the present world war.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Today's Emden assault broke a week's lull due to weather in the heavy bombing campaign from Britain, and indicated that the heavy trip-hammer, 'round-the-clock blows against Berlin and other Nazi centers might be resuming.

TORONTO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Coming from behind a 2-0 score the Maple Leafs handed the Canadiens a 4-to-2 defeat tonight in a National Hockey League game played before 12,120 fans. It was Montreal's second straight setback after going through its first fourteen games undefeated.
ALGIERS, Dec. 11 -- A daring exploit, involving the flight of a transport plane to a tiny airfield in Yugoslavia, was described today by Major J.A. Roth of Cape Girardeau, Mo.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Dec. 12 (UP) -- A communique:

THE recent French-Lebanese incident, and the expectation that the news spotlight might soon again be turned to developments in that region, has given an impetus to RKO's "Action in Arabia" in the form of an almost 100 per cent increase in the film's budget since the start of production three weeks ago.

When field trial champion Shed of Arden captured the national retriever championship for the second consecutive year he established a record that may stand for many years. It is a notable feat to win among the best retrievers in the United States and do it twice in a row, but it is not impossible for Shed to do it again.

Nearly one hundred debutantes of the season will participate in various entertainment features planned for the Allied Flag Ball and Debutante Cotillion which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 20. The dance, to be given in a patriotic setting with flags of the United Nations predominating, will be the eighth of its kind presented here as a benefit for the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

THE Metropolitan Museum's collection of medieval and Renaissance masters has been substantially augmented through gift and bequest of art that belonged to the late George Blumenthal, the museum's former president, who died in 1941.

MARK TWAIN has often been made the sport of critical fashions. During his own Lifetime he was slow in gaining recognition, except as a humorist. His writing. especially because of his views on the institution of monarchy, disturbed some of the literary democrats of the Eastern seaboard.

Eighteen physicians who have completed the second post-graduate course in industrial medicine at the Long Island College of Medicine, Brooklyn, are undergoing supervised training periods of one to four weeks in the medical departments of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Consolidated Edison Company and Western Electric Company, New York City; American Cyanamid Company and Merck Co., Inc., New Jersey; and the Norton Company, Worcester, Mass.

Broken families, juvenile delinquency, marital difficulties and illness in the home were uppermost among the problems presented by a majority of the 11,561 families given help and counsel by the family service department of the Community Service Society during the last year, Bayard F. Pope, newly elected president of the society, disclosed yesterday.

The new national headquarters of the medical division of the War Shipping Administration and United Seamen's Service, at 107 Washington Street, will be formally opened and dedicated next Friday afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Daniel Blain, director of the division.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Bulgarian Premier Dobri Boshiloff and two of his Ministers have resigned under pressure of Leftists favoring Bulgaria's withdrawal from the war, Turkish reports said today, simultaneously with an announcement from Allied headquarters in Algiers that Sofia's railroad yards had received an "accurate and effective bombardment" from American Liberators, which were escorted by Lightning fighter planes.

REGARDING the letter of Artur Schnabel and Roger Sessions printed in this column, may I speak of their second point first, namely, "performers are able to play only the works of their native land." Mr. Schnabel himself is a striking example of the aforementioned point.

In a last desperate hope to save their dying mother, two sons, one of whom is with the Navy in Iceland, made a public appeal yesterday for some penicillin, the new drug that has proved almost magically effective in the treatment of infections not responding to other treatment.

GALE STORM is an unspoiled young lady who has, in the of some three space years, acquired an improbable name, a variety of acting assignments in Hollywood and a fairly solid perch on that shaky ladder of success.

It is right that we should be now studying the problem of full employment after the war. It is far from wise to get ourselves into the "or else" state of mind. We hear it said on every side that if our system of private enterprise fails to provide jobs for everyone it will be replaced by some other economic system.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Svenska Morgenbladet quoted travelers from Berlin today as saying that the Germans recently had used a new secret weapon to bombard Leningrad in Russia.

In both conflicts the Allies last week held the initiative. In both they struck new blows that forecast a grand climacteric in 1944.

In the light of developments in the last few years, it is becoming increasingly evident that the proposed reorganization plans of many of the nation's railroads now in process of recapitalization are toe drastic. Generally, these plans fix the capitalization of the carriers on experiences in the Nineteen Thirties, probably the worst period in the history of American railroads from the viewpoint of earnings.

When the Axis Powers have been defeated and their aircraft factories, airdromes and air squadrons are destroyed, what will the United Nations do with the airplane? That is the paramount question which every man, woman and child should ask themselves, because upon the answer the lives, happiness and prosperity of future generations will depend.

"REAL ornery and underfoot," Granny predicted of the black lamb, and he certainly was, but Jerry loved him -- more than anything or anybody in Cat Hollow, except, of course, Granny Kinkaid and maybe Uncle Hiram.

Rabaul, greatest of the Japanese bases in the southwest Pacific, is flanked by three volcanoes, the Mother and the North and South Daughters. In January, 1919, they burst into an eruption which drove the island Government (then Australian) from Rabaul to New Guinea.

EAST FISHKILL, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry L. Morgenthau went out of the dairy business today as 100 head of Jersey and Holstein cattle were sold at auction at his East Fishkill farm.

NO one likes to pay high prices. Every one of us wants to get the best bargains and the best values that it is possible to find. But your cost of living is far more important than that. Your cost of living today may decide the economic security of your family tomorrow.

The New York District Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had initiated suspension proceedings against three Manhattan steak houses charged with having used about 70,000 pounds of meats in excess of allotments made by the rationing administration.

THERE are two dangers that face us in a situation such as ours today. One is the danger of over-simplification in a world where the problems are so complex. Thus we falsify the real character of the problems before us and miss the real solutions. The other danger is what I may call the danger of following slogans or catchwords and so missing the real inwardness of the problems before us.
