IT is difficult, in reviewing a book of short stories reprinted from the New Yorker, to separate the writer from the magazine. Probably no other publication adheres to so carefully set a tone in its fiction. Its somewhat unadventurous rhetoric, its insularity, its limited geography of situation, its careful manipulations of pathos -- all these, to some extent, are shared by those who write its short stories.

ONE of the nicest things which we have come to expect from Mary Poppins is her unexpectedness. Like the wind, her old friend, she bloweth literally where she listeth, and no one can tell when that may be.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Aircraft manufacturers are taking the lead in employing discharged service men, estimated to total about 1,000,000 since Pearl Harbor, the Office of War Information reported tonight.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP) -- James F. Lincoln has ordered about $3,000,000 in Christmas bonuses distributed today to 1,300 Lincoln Electric Company employes, who he says are "the best as well as the highest paid" factory people in the world.

Harold E. Talbott was the leading owner in steeplechasing for the season recently closed, according to the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association's report, which establishes Mr. Talbott's Brother Jones as the leading jumper of the year.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- By tomorrow, Adolf Hitler will have outlasted Kaiser Wilhelm II as a wartime ruler.

With lacrosse representatives on hand from nineteen colleges and universities one of the oldest sports-governing bodies in intercollegiate circles opened its sixty-first annual meeting at the Hotel Victoria yesterday. The feature of the opening session of the two-day gathering was the announcement by Laurie D. Cox of the All-America team.
TO those fortunate ones who have never urgently needed a friend; to those even more fortunate ones who in time of need have found that friend, this appeal is made today.

In the most advanced step it has yet taken toward international cooperation in the field of education, the Department of State has appointed Dr. Grayson N. Kefauver, dean of the School of Education at Stanford University, as consultant assigned to work on the problem of educational reconstruction, it was learned yesterday.

China will provide "unlimited" opportunities for American business men in the post-war period, provided they retain the current high esteem in which they are held by the Chinese and develop fully their understanding of Chinese trade psychology, Mervin Rothschild of the Venida Hairnet Company declared yesterday.

The appeal of the National Maritime Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, for deferment of its 37-year-old vice president, Jack Lawrensen, now classified in 1-A, on the ground that he is essential to the war has been received and will be acted upon shortly, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Selective Service director, said yesterday.
ALGIERS, Dec. 11 -- A communique:

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- The county grand jury indicted eight Oklahomans today on charges that they participated in a conspiracy to defraud textbook purchasers by controlling prices and adoptions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A group of Senate Republicans, tinkering with the prospect of writing a workable compromise on the food-subsidy issue, seemed likely today to join opponents of an immediate showdown on the controversy.

Salvatore Baccaloni again successfully "stole the show" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House in Rossini's beloved "Barbiere di Siviglia," despite the splendid singing of Lily Pons as Rosina and the excellent performances of Charles Kullman as Almaviva and of Francesco Valentino as Figaro.

Three hundred women, representing a million members of organizations in industry, the professions and the home, met yesterday at the Pythian Plaza, 135 West Seventieth Street, in the first State-wide conference of its kind, to discuss their wartime problems and develop a program for action to be referred to local, State and Federal agencies immediately.

The newly authorized honorable discharge lapel buttons may be obtained without cost at forty-eight Army installations in New York, New Jersey and Delaware, starting tomorrow, Second Service Command headquarters announced yesterday.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 11 -- The Green Bay Packers came up today with some good and bad news for other National League football teams.

MOST of the common perennials grown in our gardens are fully winter hardy. Temperatures below zero do not harm them, but alternate freezing and thawing often prove fatal. If, then, snow blankets could be made to stay in place from November to mid-March, no tucking in would be necessary.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 -- Vessel operators are reaping a golden harvest as the 1943 Great Lakes navigation season nears a close.

THE seventy-eighth birthday of Jean Sibelius occurred last Wednesday. There were no advices received in this country as to whether ceremonies of a public sort were observed, or even information as to the whereabouts of the composer.

THE wind blows hard and cold from the ocean, only a few hundred feet away, where the gray waves thunder on the beach and shake the sand. An idea -- a dream -- in the minds of two men has taken form and rests on a track before the dunes. It looks like a big kite with a little kite fastened in front of it and it trembles and shivers in the wind.
DES MOINES, Dec. 11 -- Amos Alonzo Stagg, coach at the College of the Pacific, today was named football's "man-of the year" by the Football Writers Association of America.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 -- The Argentine Government looks upon the visit of President Higino Morinigo as an outstanding diplomatic triumph, especially now that Argentina's isolation has been emphasized by the fact that three South American republics are actually at war with the Axis and all the others, except Argentina, have broken diplomatic relations.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- The order from Washington which cancelled Sunday work at shipyards was sent out by Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the Maritime Commission, to the four regional construction directors in the country -- at Chicago, Oakland, New Orleans and Philadelphia.

ALTHOUGH the artist has appeared in many big group exhibitions, it is Walter Stuempfig's first New York one-man show that has opened at the Durlacher. Stuempfig was born in Germantown in 1914 and he grew up in Philadelphia. He paints American landscape, but with a striking "difference."

MRS. COOPER'S second novel -- "The Lighted Box" was the first -- is a story in which nothing tremendously important happens but in which every small incident has the heightened value of clear-cut, critical observation and deft, economical style.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- This nation is about to enter its third war winter with no certainty of having enough fuel to keep all its homes warm and its industries running.

The difference between hospitalizing soldiers "over there" and "over here" in 1918 and 1943 will be described by Col. Ralph G. De Voe, commanding officer at Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island, at an Army recruitment rally, "Calling All Dietitians," to be held by the Greater New York Dietetic Association at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on Wednesday at 8 P.M.

THE UNITED STATES aircraft carrier Hornet, sixth of a line of fighting ships dating back to 1775, lived just one year and six days. She was commissioned Oct. 20, 1941, at Newport News. She died in the blue sea off the Santa Cruz Islands in the South Pacific Oct. 26, 1942.

IRINA BARONOVA, who has been a ballerina in all three of the major ballet companies which have appeared in this country in the last ten years, is now making her bow in a broader and more popular field at the Roxy. It is not only her first experience in a movie theatre, but it is the first time that the admirably progressive stage policy of the Roxy has presented a triple-star ballerina on its program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Maritime Commission today ordered all shipyards to close down every Sunday beginning Jan. 1, and the commission's chief of production said later that the country was "over the hump" on merchant ship building.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- March Field's Fourth Army Air Force football team had too much power and weight for Amos Alonzo Stagg's game little college of the Pacific squad today and used it for a 19-to-0 victory that closed the 1943 season in Memorial Coliseum.

HAVING flung open its doors following one of the more extensive hullabaloos in radio's short but gaudy history, "Hall of Fame" (WJZ-Blue, Sunday, 6 P.M.) naturally became a leading topic of discussion along Radio Row last week, and doubtless will remain so for other weeks to come.

It has been known for centuries that some diseases never attack the same person twice. In other words, it was the practice to infect a healthy person with smallpox as a means of protection during an epidemic.

Disclosure of a list of products which are controlled by the so-called "joint-area agreements" between Britain and the United States and which is apparently used as a guide by the Middle East Supply Center in granting import permits to traders in that area, aroused increased criticism against the entire project in export quarters here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- New construction expenditures in the continental United States are expected to drop from an estimated $7,400,000,000 in 1943, to about $4,200,000,000 in 1944, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, stated today.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, and Sidney Hillman, vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, have accepted membership on the executive board of the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- A fact-finding committee of the State Senate sent a protest today to President Roosevelt and Secretary Stimson against the readmittance to military area No. 1 of any Japanese evacuees. It cited a Washington dispatch to the effect that the Western Defense Command had adopted a policy of permitting Japanese evacuees to return to the West Coast under some conditions.

Traveling President President Roosevelt last week was adding mileage to one of the most extensive trips he has taken since he entered the White House. He had traveled 8,000 miles from Washington to reach Teheran. Now on his homeward swing, he was following a somewhat roundabout route.

BERNARD WAGENAAR'S new chamber opera, "Pieces of Eight," libretto by Edward Eager, will be given its premiere by the Columbia Theatre Associates and the Columbia Department of Music and will be presented for the League of Composers in a preview on May 2.

DRIFTING about with Victor Moore among the cacti at Chatsworth, where "Riding High" was getting itself done, we came across George Marshall, the director. This was the fortieth anniversary of the first cowboy film, "The Great Train Robbery," and Marshall was the one to see.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Declaring that it could not condone "flagrant and unjustifiable defiance," the War Labor Board threatened today to exercise all its enforcement powers unless a strike of workers at the Pine Grove and Lansford plants of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company was ended.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Dec. 9 (Delayed) -- The Italian force fighting with the Allies was licking its grievous wounds today after its unsuccessful attempt to take Mount Lungo, and the episode can be considered over. So heavy were its losses that the unit will need reorganization.

ALGIERS, Dec. 12 -- An "advance reconnaissance party" of the expeditionary force Brazil will send to join the fight against Germany somewhere in this hemisphere is now in Algiers. It is headed by Maj. Gen. Mascarenhas de Moraes of the Brazil general staff.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Barring unforeseen developments, President Roosevelt will ask Congress for $95,000,000,000 for the 1944-45 fiscal year when he presents his annual budget message early next month.

A distribution of $37,695,000, or 59 1/2 per cent of total resources, is being made from the Mutual Savings Bank fund to all participating banks, it was announced yesterday by August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Bank Trust Company, trustee of the fund.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- In an effort to avert a spread of a strike at two up-State power plants of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, the War Labor Board has summoned to Washington several officials of the Utility Workers Organizing Committee of the CIO for a conference tomorrow.

Meat dealers start today for the first time since the beginning of the fat salvage campaign in July, 1942, to pay for all used household grease at the rate of two points a pound in brown stamps. This is in addition to the 4 cents a pound that has been the standard allowance.

War and peace aims "which are less hazy than 'the four freedoms' and which go far beyond the harshness of 'unconditional surrender'" were needed by the United Nations and should have come from pronouncements at the recent Mediterranean conferences, the Rev. Franklin P. Cole declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Congregational Church-in-the-Gardens, Forest Hills, Queens.

An eyewitness account of the occupation of Tunis by Allied troops will be a highlight of Andre Gide's newest book, "Imaginary Interviews," which Alfred A. Knopf will publish early next year. The book is to be first brought out in French by Jacques Schiffrin.

The Neediest Cases Fund started the second week of its thirty-second annual appeal with new cases from the most distressed families, fragments of families and individuals in the city known to eight leading private charity organizations, but with gifts for the day totaling only $4,274, the smallest amount received to date.

Tonight the theatrical career of what was Mecca Temple and is now called the City Center of Music and Drama, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, will be launched with "Susan and God," starring Gertrude Lawrence. The Rachel Crothers play will be performed there through next Saturday night at these bargain prices: evenings (including tonight), 85c-$1.65; matinees (Wednesday and Saturday), 55c-$1.65.
Allied armies in Italy, fighting in mist, rain and cold, struggled up the backbone of the Apennines last week to break the enemy's stoutly held Garigliano-Sangro River line.

Crocheted and knitted woolens have developed chic along with their utilitarian virtues, thanks to this season's clever designing. Originally, they were strictly winter sports items worn in the Austrian Tyrol; later, as knitted vests and bonnets, they became popular as American skiing and skating fashions.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 11 (Delayed) -- The over-all strategic coordination of operations on all fronts against the Japanese is assured by arrangements now being worked out between Admiral the Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters and Gen. Douglas MacArthur's command in the southwest Pacific.

Another step was taken by the Sugar Research Foundation yesterday in its program to develop and utilize fully chemical and nutritional properties of sugar with the appointment of leading men in the industry to the foundation's scientific advisory committee.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Raising of the fiduciary note issue by 50,000,000 this week is fully explained by the latest return of the Bank of England. This shows that if the fiduciary issue had not been increased the bank's note reserve would have been down to a meager 5,000,000.

The musical public of New York had the opportunity late yesterday afternoon to hear the rarely played Beethoven Sonata for piano and 'cello in A major, opus 69. It was performed in the Beethoven cycle of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall.

Joseph Medgeysi of the New York A.C., a 38-year-old defense worker, emerged victorious in the 10,000-meter national A.A.U. walk at Randalls Island yesterday. Medgeysi, who negotiated the approximately six-and-one-half-mile distance in 51:50.4, is a former national 3,000-meter titleholder.

ROSELLE, N.J., Dec. 12 -- One occupant of the three-story Van Court Inn here jumped from a second-story window and three others were taken down ladders from the third floor by firemen today during a blaze that Wrecked the structure.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 -- Asserting that American and European forces for democracy were interdependent, Louis Adamic, writer on Balkan affairs, declared here today that these forces could defeat fascism only by rousing their peoples to a full realization of the issues.

With the election of officers and discussions of post-war planning for the game, the sixty-first annual meeting of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association came to the close of its two-day session at the Hotel Victoria yesterday. During the meetings of Saturday and yesterday sixty coaches and officials had been in attendance, representing colleges from New England to Virginia and the two service academies, Army and Navy.

The sudden appearance, some months ago, of the German aerial rocket torpedo was a costly and most annoying surprise to our side in the Battle of Germany. We took serious losses and were obliged to improvise new tactics to meet the situation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Elimination of all restrictions on the use of steel for civilian purposes was urged upon Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board today by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, "since apparently there are insufficient orders from war procurement agencies to engage all of the industry's capacity."

The vendor relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday protested arbitrary changes by manufacturers "during this emergency period" of established conditions of sale under which unreasonable extension of deliveries is demanded and reduction or elimination of customary discounts is sought.

The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is a "very good and necessary institution, particularly to America," Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, declared last night at the fifteenth annual scholarship fund dinner of Yeshiva College at the Hotel Astor.
A commemorative service in celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding was conducted yesterday morning at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

NAPLES, Dec. 11 (Delayed) -- Count Carlo Sforza, speaking today for liberals and anti-monarchists, said he was "proud and happy" because Italian troops were fighting with the Allied Fifth Army, and hoped this "loyal cooperation" would continue to the end.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- Breaking a determined German attempt to strike at the center of newly-won positions in the Znamenka region, the Russians are reported broadening the front against the important road junction of Kirovograd and expelling the enemy from strongly defended garrisons that impede their advance southward toward points west of Krivoi Rog.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Recognizing the importance of melodrama to the state of the nation, the Professional Children's School yesterday afternoon put on the first of two performances of "Arsenic and Old Lace." Its players used the Hudson Theatre, where the show is running, and the setting the big people have at night.

Traveling overland in wartime is something of a corrective for the impressions made by flying statesmen hopping back and forth from Chungking to Cairo and Washington to Teheran. The aerial argonauts have made the globe seem very small to themselves and to their countries.

Social conditions in the Bedfordtuyvesant section of Brooklyn Were discussed at a mas meeting held yesterday afternoon at the First African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Inter-Racial Assembly. Six hundred persons attended the meeting, most of them Negroes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson and Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, in statements made public today, made it clear that no regulation prohibited Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen or any other officer from accepting a draft nomination for President.

The policy of the Pennsylvania Railroad is to perform a complete transportation service by rail, with such accessorial services as are necessary to give complete, efficient and low-cost transportation, according to a letter sent to stockholders by M.W. Clement, president.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 12 -- The airfields now available in southern Italy and other Mediterranean bases are enough for the total bombing of southern Germany and the Balkans, Gen. H.H. Arnold said today before leaving Italy.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The winter sailing dinghy skippers set out this afternoon from the Larchmont Yacht Club, going through five races, with Alton O'Brien the winner on a 46-point total with Frappe, to 41 for Warren Tomlinson in the Stinger.

ROBERT GIBBONS is a young Southern writer who holds a pretty low opinion of much recent Southern fiction. There is too much tobacco juice in much of it, he thinks, and too many magnolias in the rest. Since extremes are rarely the habitation of truth, he decided to write a novel about the South that would have only a little tobacco juice in it and no magnolias at all.
A news item in THE NEW YORK TIMES reported the Government auction of sized articles held in New York at which the prices bid in many case were four times above appraisal valuation.

There is every reason for satisfaction in the report of the British Air Ministry on the operations of the RAF Bomber Command for November. That it should show a diminishing percentage of losses in the face of a greatly accelerated tempo of attack on German and Nazi-dominated targets is particularly gratifying.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Monday, Dec. 13 -- A violent explosion, caused when a man entered a tavern and fired a hunting rifle at a tank of bottled gas, injured five persons here early today, wrecked the two-story brick structure housing the tavern, and damaged five other buildings.

Roy K. Ferguson, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, announced yesterday that his company had acquired perpetual cutting rights to 109,000 acres of timber land in Lewis County, Washington, and all the logging operations of the West Fork Timber Company, whose president, L.T. Murray, becomes associated with the St. Regis Company.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have cleared the Japanese from a thirteen-mile sector northwest of Changteh while United States Fourteenth Air Force fighter pilots have shot down or damaged nineteen enemy planes in turning back three attacks on an advanced American air base, it was revealed tonight.

The regional War Labor Board yesterday formally took over jurisdiction of the Shiffli embroidery industry, 90 per cent of which is centered in and around northern New Jersey and metropolitan New York, and adopted a tentative schedule of going wage rates for the industry, it was announced by Theodore W. Kheel, chairman of the board.

The fifth week of the Metropolitan Opera's Diamond Jubilee season, ending on Christmas Day, will feature next Monday night the debut of Christina Carroll as Musetta in the season's second performance of "La Boheme," with Cesare Sodero conducting.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Release of between 1,000,000 and 1,500,000 yards of parachute nylon cloth rejects and seconds for unrestricted civilian use was announced today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Redskins turned their other cheek to the Giants today -- and are their faces red? Completely outplayed in every department, including that of effective passing, the injury-riddled Redskins, proud and once-haughty champions of the National Football League, were bounced all over Griffith Stadium, the Giants beating them for the second time in eight days -- this time by the one-sided count of 31 to 7.

SCHENECTADY, Dec. 12 -- After thirty-nine years with General Electric Company, W.M. Stearns, manager of trade relations and special contracts, will retire Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by E.O. Shreve, vice president. Mr. Stearns will be succeeded by W.A. Sredenschek, who for the past three years has been assistant manager of trade relations and special contracts.
London, Dec. 12 (Reuter) -- The Allied Naples radio tonight quoted a statement by Count Carlo Sforza, Italian liberal leader, making his bitterest attack on King Victor Emmanuel.

New York City received a brief respite yesterday from the cold snap that hit the East Coast Saturday, but the Weather Bureau warned that a new cold wave was on the way. The forecast for today was much colder and snow flurries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Heavy rains blanketed a considerable part of the winter wheat area in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska last week, resulting in material improvement in the outlook for the winter wheat crop, especially in areas where there had been little or no rain since early last Summer.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- Forty to fifty Danish patriots, armed with sub-machine guns, overpowered guards at the important Varde Steel Works in West Jutland province today and planted time bombs which destroyed new power plants, two steel presses, a furnace and other installations, a Swedish dispatch from Copenhagen said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The desirability of President Roosevelt's giving an oral report to a joint session of Congress on his extended series of momentous conferences in the Middle East and North Africa has been seriously considered by the President's immediate advisers, it was learned today.

ALGIERS, Dec. 12 -- The British Eighth Army broadened the wedge of its thrust across the Moro River in the San Leonardo sector yesterday, but, despite increasingly severe casualties inflicted by Allied aviators and artillery, the Germans yielded very little to the hard-driving Canadians.

The Office of Price Administration has appealed to Congress to enact legislation to halt impending resignations of many of its most valuable voluntary workers throughout the nation, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A gradual demobilization of war manpower may well enable this country to avoid the economic upset of widespread unemployment after our military victory is achieved, a new Brookings Institution study reveals.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 -- National output of steel last week remained unchanged at 99 per cent of capacity, with indications that the same rate will prevail this week. The present position in raw steel with respect to total demand is described as fairly comfortable and to preclude any possibility of an activity much higher than the current rate.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade last week, all deliveries of wheat, oats and rye and December barley selling at new seasonal peaks, buying being stimulated by inflation talk, an active demand for cash grain, a rise of 9 cents a bushel in the ceiling on corn and the placing of ceiling prices on oats, barley and grain sorghums.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Conditions of the once-blockaded islands of the Caribbean have been ameliorated through the combined efforts of all the countries involved, according to a report of the United States Section of the Anglo-American Caribbean Commission, which was published by tile State Department tonight.

In all the Administration program during the last depression for making of work there was one conspicuous opportunity which was avoided, probably because it required too much constructive ability and seemed to offer to little opportunity for profitable politic.

The Philadelphia Americans retained their leadership in the American Soccer League by defeating the Brookhattans at Starlight Park yesterday, 3 to 2. At half-time the teams were in a 2-2 tie. The victory kept the Quakers a full point ahead of the Brooklyn Wanderers.

Last week began with financial markets awaiting release of the announcement regarding the Iran conference of British and Russian Premiers and President Roosevelt. This official bulletin was released at 1 P.M. Monday. It surprised no one, being quite devoid of particulars, except for friendliness at the conference and confidence in Allied victory.

When the Russians recaptured Kiev they found stoves installed in the German field defenses around the city, indicating that the enemy expected to fight from those positions well into the winter. Heavy tank reinforcements were already on their way to meet the Russian attack, which, however, was not looked for until the Dnieper froze over.

The Zionist Organization of America held a meeting last night in the Hotel Biltmore in honor of Dr. Israel Goldstein, its president and head of the Synagogue Council of America. A thousand delegates representing 150 Zionist units and groups in New York City attended the rally, which also marked the formal launching of the organization's New York campaign for 50,000 new members.

As a result of the intervention by Mayor La Guardia to ease the city-wide shortage of domestic coal, municipal and labor leaders will meet at Pier 18, Jersey City, at 2 P.M. today in an effort to get several hundred carloads of coal, accumulated as a result of a labor dispute, moving again.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Spotty reports were made by resident buying offices, taking in activities of last week. Fill-in business has dwindled on seasonal lines, and much spring and summer business has been placed, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- RAF Mosquito bombers struck in western Germany again last night, without loss, giving Adolf Hitler's people no rest from screaming sirens.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, in repeating a plea for early action on the subsidy question, called today for the separation of politics and food.

AN ADVANCED AIR BASE IN ITALY, Dec. 12 (AP) -- President Roosevelt almost lost his crown as the world's most photogenic leader, in the opinion of a crack United States Army Air Force combat crew who were the only photographers accompanying the President on his tour of North Africa, Cairo, Teheran and Malta.

The New York Rovers outplayed the Philadelphia Falcons in an Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The New Yorkers, held fairly even at the start, overwhelmed their rivals in the last two periods to register a triumph by the count of 8 to 2.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Marshal Josip Broz (Tito) dramatically appealed to his scattered mountain fighters today to rise up everywhere and wage a desperate battle against a major German drive to crush the Yugoslav partisans.

An extensive program for the improvement of the teaching of American history in the schools and colleges of this country and recommendations for a revision of the history courses now offered in the elementary and high schools have been prepared by a committee of prominent educators and historians who have just completed a nation-wide survey in this field, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (U.P) -- Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, Dec. 12 (Netherlands News Agency) -- National Socialist leaders, speaking upon the occasion of the Netherland Nazi party's twelfth anniversary yesterday struck a gloomy note instead of a festive air, translations revealed today.

What we need, of course, is a book that will tell a man how to take care of the baby while his wife goes shopping for a whole afternoon. This is a need which our writers have lamentably failed to meet; or, if such a book has been written, our publishers have failed to see their duty clearly to give it the wide circulation such a volume deserves.

Mrs. John Henry Hammond heads the executive committee for the sixteenth annual Christmas song festival of the People's Chorus of New York to be held Sunday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. A group of children will take part, presenting Christmas carols. L. Camilieri, founder and leader, will play and conduct.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 13 -- Russian troops, reinforced with massive armor-smashing equipment, yesterday shattered the German tank-led spearheads thrusting into the Kiev salient, forcing the first real German withdrawal since the enemy started a month ago his determined effort to avert the collapse of his southern front.

Cotton prices turned firmer last week and the market recovered some of the ground lost in the recent decline. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 30 to 39 points.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- onja Heine, whose Twentieth Century-Fox contract expired with Wintertime," has signed a term deal with William Goetz's International Company. She will make It's a Pleasure," in Technicolor, next spring, for the organization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Dec. 4 to 10 are given in the appended tabulation:

The need for religious instruction of children was stressed by speakers yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Teachers Association of the Archdiocese of New York in the Hotel Commodore. The 1,400 members first received communion in St. Patrick's Cathedral at a mass at 9 A.M., celebrated by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 12 -- Germany has about four hundred U-boats in operation, according to the 1944 edition of Marinkalendern, Swedish equivalent of Jane's Fighting Ships. The publication does not venture to guess how many U-boats are under construction, but believes they are now coming off "mass production lines."

Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, last night assured the Jewish National Workers Alliance that the Government of the United States was giving "every consideration" to the plight of the Jewish people in Europe.

Ken McAuley knows now that it can be done. The rookie goalie of the New York Rangers, who had seen victory elude his team in fifteen consecutive National Hockey League games -- fourteen of which resulted in defeat and one in a tie -- experienced the novel sensation of being on the winning side last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Full post-war employment of all who wish to work, including women, "can mean greater prosperity than the nation has ever known," according to John D. Durand, Department of Commerce economist, writing in the current issue of International Labor Review, publication of the International Labor Office.

Strong spiritual ties resulting from the war bind the countries of the Western Hemisphere, Miss Minerva Bernardino, recently named chairman of the Inter-American Commission on Women, said yesterday at a tea given by the Union de Mujeres Americanas at the Hotel Biltmore.
Columbia University will present gold medals to two Latin-American journalists and a radio commentator tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the Low Memorial Library, it was announced yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Sharp but localized clashes featured the fighting on ground sectors of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's command in the past three days, while Liberator bombers made long over-water hops northwest of Australia to blast the Japanese oil and supply centers in occupied Netherlands East Indies.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- It is too early for decisive action, political or military, on the part of any Balkan nation, according to usually well-informed quarters here. The stage is now being set, however, and study of it has produced guides to the future.

ABOARD AN ARMY HOSPITAL TRAIN, NEW YORK TO OHIO -- We're some three hours from a wintry dawn. It's Sunday morning and we're twelve hours out of Halloran Hospital on Staten Island. Most of the kids in the ward cars are asleep as we roar westward through Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks ran their home ice winning streak to seven tonight when they edged out the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 2, before a Chicago. Stadium crowd of 17,365, including 500 service men who were guests of the Hawk management.

One of the most vital issues at stake in this war is freedom of religion, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, declared yesterday in his sermon there.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Killing of hogs by packers last week was limited only by the available supply of labor, as there was no shortage of supplies even though the movement to leading markets was somewhat smaller than in the previous week.

Reports reaching here yesterday from up-State indicated that a united front against the Dewey-Jaeckle State machine is to be presented by "north country" members of the State Legislature and delegates to the next Republican National Convention.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 12 -- American battleships joined in shelling Nauru, Japan's most southeasterly outpost, in the attack last Wednesday by carrier-borne bombers and surface forces, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz disclosed today. The target area was well covered by bomb bursts and shellfire, starting many fires. Ten Japanese planes were destroyed, nine of them on the ground.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Prices for feed grains are at a new seasonal peak, December oats selling at 82 cents a bushel, the ceiling imposed on future contracts by directors of the Chicago Board of Trade after the Office of Price Administration placed a ceiling on No. 3 white oats at 80 1/2 cents.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12 -- A new American carbine made its bow in the South Pacific when the Marine Corps used it in the successful New Georgia Island campaign, which began on July 5, it was revealed for the first time today in a Marine Corps communication to the Winchester Repeating Arms Company, developer of the gun.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Charges that the American Slav Congress had become a Communist-front organization and no longer fostered unity and understanding of racial and religious differences among its members were made today by Dr. Wencel F. Hetman, a former member of the congress.
Four new films will reach Broadway theatres this week. The schedule follows:
A practical jokester's attempt to capitalize on criticism of a cup of coffee led yesterday to the accidental shooting of a soldier's wife by another woman, her best friend, in a Brooklyn drug store.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 12 -- Pierre Laval's "forces for the preservation of order" in France are so busy tracking down patriots and seeking to prevent attacks on German forces of occupation that they have no time for normal police duties. As a consequence lawlessness is increasing rapidly. At the moment it takes the form of raiding cigar stores, which in France are licensed under the State tobacco monopoly.
Theodore F.N. Gray of Bethlehem, Pa., was elected a vice president of Julius Kayser Co. at a meeting of the board of directors.

In preparation for expansion of the floor-covering market, Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company today opens the second and concluding week of conferences to prepare for inauguration of the company's new sales policy Jan. 1.

The United States' good neighbor policy toward Latin-American countries will continue, even though there might be a change in the national administration, a United Press survey of prominent Republican leaders disclosed last night.

The daylight precision bombing of Germany by the Army Air Forces is "really something terrific," Wellwood E. Beall, vice president in charge of engineering of the Boeing Aircraft Company, declared last night at La Guardia Field. He added that the German rocket planes were "quite a menace," but not enough to halt the Allied formations.

BOUGAINVILLE, Solomon Islands, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The long line of dirt-caked marines struggled wearily through the jungle. Two men half-dragged a third, suffering from mortar shell concussion. Here and there men carried stretchers; those with less serious wounds plodded ahead under their own power.

The Park Department's $115,093,545 post-war public works program will provide 200,000,000 direct man-hours of labor to help cushion expected unemployment in New York City, Park Commissioner Robert Moses discloses in an article in the December issue of The American City, out today.

The Trapp Family Singers made their first appearance of the season yesterday afternoon at Town Hall in a concert forming the second event in this year's Town Hall Endowment Series. At present the group is composed of the Baroness Maria von Trapp, her seven daughters and Dr. Franz Wasner, conductor and baritone.

Dealt an unfortunate blow by the time clock, Mount St. Michael High's football team met defeat for the first time this season at the Polo Grounds yesterday. With 14,000 looking on, the Mountaineers, unbeaten and untied in ten games before yesterday, bowed to St. George High, Chicago district champion, 25 to 20, in a thrilling post-season intersectional battle.
Two Episcopal ministers began yesterday their duties here as pastors of new congregations after being instituted by Bishop William T. Manning.

The work of the public health nurse in swinging public sentiment to the belief that health, life and freedom from suffering should be the privilege of all mankind has been as beneficial as the actual care given to the ill of needy families, Dr. Howard W. Haggard, Professor of Applied Physiology at Yale University, said last night.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens shattered a two-game losing streak by coming from behind to whip the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 1, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 13,106 spectators. Ray Getliffe and Leo Lamoureux each scored two goals for the league leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 A bonus system of offering ration points for used household fats is expected to double collections of the vitally needed product, War Production Board salvage officials said today.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- German reports reaching Stockholm today said that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel had been named anti-invasion chief to prepare for the Allied attack on western Europe.

For three-quarters of an hour they had all eagerly been putting in plugs for their own organizations. The East Hall of the Russell Sage Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street, rang with the fervor of young voices.

Senator W. Lee O'Daniel, Texas Democrat, who spoke here Saturday under the auspices of the National Republican Club, expressed the opinion yesterday that President Roosevelt would be renominated by the Democrats and probably would carry Texas, and he indirectly indicated his belief that the President was a better than even chance for a fourth term.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Giants tomahawked the Redskins once more and did it in mighty convincing fashion. They clipped the scalps neatly from the noggins of the capital Braves and now must do it again at the Polo Grounds next Sunday to make the job completely official.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia signed today a treaty of friendship and mutual assistance.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose 0.2 per cent from 111.35 to 111.57. The raw materials index and the farm products index rose 0.5 per cent and 0.8 per cent, respectively, as a result of price increases in apples, grains, cotton, potatoes and tobacco.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday his intention to approve at once a proposal submitted by Welfare Commissioner Leo Arnstein, under which 110,000 persons now on home relief or receiving other forms of public aid would get a "cost-of-living" rise in their allowances, totaling $3,926,316 a year, the equivalent of an average rise of $20.97 for each adult on the relief rolls.

When Leopold Stokowski, incidentally doing some of the finest conducting that we remember from him in the whole course of his distinguished career, led the NBC Symphony Orchestra in performances of Bach yesterday afternoon in Radio City, we could think only of the fundamental and incorruptible democracy of all great art, and of the manner in which that art, today, is given through the magic of modern transmission agencies to all people.

The Benenson Realty Corporation, Charles Benenson, president, has purchased the twelve-story store and loft building at 16 to 20 West Thirty-second Street from the Esterose Realty Corporation. Assessed at $270,000, the property is 66.4 by 98.9 feet and is occupied largely by manufacturers of ladies' handbags.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A triple legislative assault on the Administration's price and wage stabilization program progressed today in the face of an attempt to hurry the Senate into a holiday recess.

A day of reckoning for leaders who have plunged the world into war on the pretense of being saviors of the world was predicted yesterday by the Rev. Cyprian Truss of St. Francis' Capuchin Friary, Providence, R.I., in his second Advent sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The destruction of 138 Nazi fighters, with twenty more probably shot down, in the United States Eighth Air Force's bombing of Emden yesterday -- at a cost of twenty American bombers and fighters -- clearly showed that the operation brought a crushing defeat for the Luftwaffe, it was stated here today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The juveniles themselves have come up with an answer to the moot question: "What can be done to check juvenile delinquency?"

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre of "A Connecticut Yankee," which has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Welfare Federation. Mrs. Norman B. Woolworth, who heads the benefit committee, has as her aides Mrs. Dever S. Byard, Mrs. Peter Grimm, Mrs. Albert Francke Jr., Mrs. Abbot Low Moffat, Miss Julia E. Smith and Mrs. J. Frederick Talcott.

Artur Rubinstein, pianist, again was the soloist yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting. The program consisted of Noskowski's Symphonic Poem, "The Steppe," Opus 66, repeated from last week's programs; Saint-Saens' Third Symphony in C minor; the Szymanowski "Symphonie Concertante for Piano and Orchestra," also repeated from last week, and the Concerto for Piano and Orchestra by the Soviet-Armenian composer, Aram Khatchatourian.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 8 -- Speaking in the double role of Italian exile and American citizen Dr. G.A. Borgese, in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES, condemns the political tactics of Allied leaders in their treatment of Italy since the unconditional surrender when, he says, King Victor Emmanuel and Marshal Pietro Badoglio received "excellent cash, the support of the western Allies' in return for a bad check."
ALGIERS, Dec. 12 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle made a conciliatory gesture today toward Moslems living in the French Empire and mandated territories.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Challenging the legal and constitutional authority of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice to issue directives to cease discriminatory practices affecting employment of Negroes, sixteen Southern railroads and terminal companies informed the committee today that they could not comply with its orders of Nov. 18, 1943, because to do so would seriously handicap the war program.

The story of penicillin, by far the most valuable disease-fighting chemical in existence, was told for the first time here yesterday by its English discoverer, Dr. Alexander Fleming, who spoke from London on a two-way Transatlantic broadcast over WOR and BBC.

As a record number of "no heat" complaints for a week-end were tabulated late yesterday afternoon by the Department of Health, Mayor La Guardia announced a settlement of the labor dispute that has halted the movement of more than 25,000 tons of domestic coal from Jersey City to New York City.

The first fully-rounded picture of the great new municipal airport under construction at Idlewild in Queens was presented yesterday as members of the La Guardia administration defended $13,954,000 allocations for the project contained in the city's capital budget for 1944, now before the City Council for approval.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- An advance of 3 1/4 cents in oats futures featured trading today on the Board of Trade, scattered buying at the opening disclosing a lack of selling pressure. The July delivery shot up to 80 1/4 cents before there was any resistance of consequence, sales being made at the same price as May, compared with a discount of 2 cents at the close on Saturday.

In the largest transaction to date in the disposal of the J.P. Morgan properties in the Murray Hill section, Joseph Perlbinder Son, builders, have purchased the row of private houses at 26 1/2-36 East Thirty-sixth Street, with a frontage of 157 feet, and the row of similar properties abutting at 27-39 East Thirty-fifth Street, with a frontage of 155 feet.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- During the course of World War I Germany introduced, with an element of stunning surprise, poison gas and Big Bertha, the giant Krupp rifle that shelled Paris from a distance of about seventy-five miles. Both of them were what might have been called "secret weapons," but

DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- Attention was focused yesterday on Michigan's plan to tackle the problem of child care and juvenile delinquency on a State-wide basis, with particular notice being given to Detroit's announcement of new child-care centers.

In addition to handsomely assembled Christmas gifts, city stores offer a variety of foods that the purchaser may donate to his own holiday table. Among these are dehydrated, whole, raw cranberries -- a noteworthy buy now that both fresh berries and canned preserves are scarce.

After reading Arnold D. Pickar's letter in THE TIMES it is to be hoped that the majority of those students who "have been flocking to elect Spanish as part of their school course knew what language they were going to study.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Dec. 13 -- Operations in the furnace department of the McKeesport works of the National Tube Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, were tied up tonight in what is believed to be the country's first strike against "a production cutback."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed the gratification of this Government today over the arrival of Brazilian military leaders in North Africa.

The Tokyo radio, in a week-end review of recent war developments directed to Japanese audiences, echoed Premier Hideki Tojo's demand for a total war effort from the Japanese people and warned that Allied resources were "fathomless" while "it cannot be said that the Japanese Navy has the war situation under complete control."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Preston R. Foster and Ann Rutherford have been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the leads of "Murder Around the Clock," a mystery yarn by Scott Darling, which will go into production Dec. 21 with Benjamin Stoloff directing.
A sailor, they say, can pile up a prodigious roll of greenbacks during a nine-month voyage on dangerous seas these days. Ralph Puett, a seaman, from Orange, Texas, did.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 8 per cent last week as compared with the like period a year ago, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Fewer evening openings were said to be responsible for the decrease.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder held in a decision yesterday that a Reno divorce is not valid in this State if it is proved that residence in Nevada was established solely for the purpose of obtaining the decree. The court at the same time upheld the right of collateral attacks for tests of the validity of Nevada divorces in this State.

Mild forms of respiratory ailments, diagnosed variously as grippe, influenza, "cat fever" and common head colds, were reported yesterday to have reached epidemic proportions in many widely separated sections of the country, an average of one person in ten being affected in the hardest-hit areas.

College basketball, with virtually all teams shorn of their old standbys, and, therefore depending principally on green replacements, returns to Madison Square Garden tonight, when L.I.U. clashes with Brigham Young and C.C.N.Y. opposes the Oklahoma Aggies in the inaugural twin bill of the campaign.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses long ago made the discovery, a valuable one for any public man, that the best way to defend is to attack. Therefore when he discusses the planning of post-war public works he livens up his discourse by describing a good deal of such planning as "tentative, vague, grandiose, cautious, inadequate and silly."

The Rohr Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended with July, a net profit of $3,178,040 after Federal income and excess profits taxes, but subject to renegotiation of war contracts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The House, in what some Administration supporters termed the heaviest blow yet struck at the anti-inflation program, voted today to require an immediate increase of at least 35 cents a barrel in the ceiling price of crude oil.

The committee of key business men who will head the thirteen sections of the Commerce and Industry Division of the New York State War Finance Committee in the Fourth War Loan drive next month, were announced yesterday by William E Cotter, director of the division, at a luncheon at the Union League Club.

Joseph Midlik, 35-year-old superintendent of an apartment house at 1315 Merriam Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to a Sing Sing term of two and one-half to five years after having previously pleaded guilty to participating with three others in the rape in Central Park of the 17-year-old partly paralyzed daughter of a member of the New York University faculty.

Lulu Costantino, 134 1/2, East Side, won the decision from Al Guido, 133 1/2, Harlem, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The verdict was a unanimous one, Referee Arthur Susskind (Young Otto) and judges Abe Goldberg and Sam Austin all voting in favor of the winner.

After a lapse of twenty-one years the Brooklyn Trust Company rejoined yesterday the New York Clearing House Association, marking the third increase in the association's membership thus far this year. It is understood that two other applications for membership are pending.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Judge A.B. Lovett of the United States District Court has authorized Merrel P. Callaway, trustee of the Central of Georgia Railway, to pay $1,250,000 interest to the mortgage trustees of the first mortgage, the consolidated mortgage and the Chattanooga, Rome Southern Railroad mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Cutbacks in the 1944 war-production program appear inevitable and both production and manpower facilities should be easier by mid-summer, according to word which industry and labor people have obtained from informed Government sources, it was learned today.

In their raid on the great German port of Emden heavy bombers of the Eighth United States Army Air Force doubtless caused heavy damage to enemy shipping and installations. That was the purpose of the attack. The spectacular success of the America planes in knocking down 138 Nazi fighters for a loss of seventeen of our bombers and three of our fighters was a welcome by-product of the attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee asked three of its members today to explore the possibility of a compromise on food subsidies, but apparently none of the three was hopeful that such a formula would be found.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 13 -- With the filing today of briefs by other parties, some supporting and some criticizing the proposed findings of the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding the reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company holding company system, the way was cleared for oral argument on the plan before the five commissioners on Friday.

Nearly 3,000 letters addressed to Santa Claus by boys and girls, or for them, were opened and read yesterday in the office of Postmaster Albert Goldman in the general postoffice, their contents duly noted by the proper officials who act for the good saint and, in the case of unfortunate youngsters, their requests directed to the proper channels for action.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The National War Labor Board informed strikers at the Pine Grove and Lansford (Pa.) plants of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company this evening that if they failed to end a strike by Wednesday the case would be sent to President Roosevelt "for such action as he deems appropriate."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Athletics announced today that Buck Newsom, pitcher, has been obtained from the Senators in a trade for Roger Wolff, young right-hander. No cash or other players were involved in the deal, Roy Mack, vice president of the Athletics, asserted.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 13 -- The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation asked the Securities and Exchange Commisison today for an additional year in which to restore the balance remaining in its special capital surplus and surplus accounts prior to Jan. 1, 1938, to the common capital stock account.

MILWUKEE, Dec. 13 -- A vigorous defense of the right of the Republicans to question the national administration on matters of foreign policy commitments was made here tonight by Alf M. Landon, GOP standard bearer in the 1936 campaign.

If you believe everything you hear we are now in the wide-open splitting season. The party in power is getting ready to split wide open into Southern Democrats and Northern New Dealers. This will present the election next year to the Republicans on a silver platter.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Australian ground forces maintained their steady progress in the task of clearing the Japanese from Huon Peninsula, New Guinea, by pushing across the Sowi River for a gain of two miles.

ALGIERS, Dec. 13 -- The small Adriatic port of Ortona came under the dominance of Allied guns atop newly captured high ground just south of the town yesterday as the British Eighth Army gradually closed in on the secondary lateral road that links Ortona to Orsogna and Guardiagrele, fifteen miles from the coast.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Hollington K. Tong, Vice Minister of Information, today urged Elmer Davis, head of the United States Office of War Information, and Brendan Bracken, Britain's Minister of Information, to "make an official investigation of the premature publication" of the story of the Cairo conference.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Thomas H. Robinson Jr., convicted kidnapper of Mrs. Alice Speed Stoll of Louisville was sentenced today by Federal Judge Shackelford Miller to die in the electric chair at Eddyville State prison March 10.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- No spectacular activity marked the opening of the week's business on the stock markets here today and the tone tended to be flat.

Synthetic rubber is a billion-dollar industry, but an industry financed largely by the Government. No chemical engineer doubts that in the postwar years synthetic rubber will be improved in quality and that its price will be reduced. But is synthetic rubber meanwhile entitled to the protection of a tariff or support by subsidy?

Charles Moss, 38 years old, owner of a theatre ticket agency at 30 Broad Street, was arrested yesterday as the result of Mayor La Guardia's crusade against "bootlegging" in theatre tickets, Moss is accused of having charged $39.60 for four $5.50 seats for a show.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- To give the House of Representatives a chance to vote on the proposed equal rights amendment twenty years after its original introduction in 1923, Representative Pat Cannon of Florida has decided to petition the House to discharge the Judiciary Committee from further consideration of the measure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Actual movement of canned and bottled foods under rationing came within 7 per cent of the amounts scheduled by OPA for the six months from April through September, the Office of Price Administration reported today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 13 -- The Turkish Government has now undertaken to try to persuade Bulgaria to quit the Axis and sue for peace with Britain, America, Greece and Yugoslavia, it was learned tonight from a reliable source.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Many local organizations formed during the 1940-41 air assaults are now being marshaled to meet the shortage of household and nursing aid that has been made acute by the influenza epidemic.

Henry Iba, coach of the Oklahoma Aggies basketball team, which is to oppose C.C.N.Y. in the second game of tonight's inaugural double-header at Madison Square Garden, told the basketball writers at a luncheon at Toots Shot's yesterday that the three-second rule should be abolished.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 14 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Apparently beaten once today, the proposal to eliminate the requirement from the new tax bill that labor unions and cooperative farm groups be required to file financial returns with the government was revived again today in the Senate Finance Committee and probably will be decided tomorrow.
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 14 -- Russian troops, aided by powerful guerrilla forces behind the German lines, gained ground for the third day in succession yesterday in the great battle of the Kiev bulge.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 13 -- Army Liberators kept up a month-long series of raids on the mid-Pacific Marshalls by bombing a Japanese cargo ship and shore installations at Emidj in the Jaluit atoll on Sunday (West Longtitude date), Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today in a press release.

Morris U. Schappes, former instructor in City College, was recommitted yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan to the Sing Sing term of eighteen months to two years imposed in the summer of 1941 by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein for perjury before the Rapp-Coudert Legislative Committee in its investigation of Communist activities.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Better times ahead were seen by Prime Minister Churchill and President Chiang Kai-shek in an exchange of messages on the anniversary of the outbreak of the war in the Pacific. The messages were made public today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Approximately 10,000 hogs were held over at the close of today's market, and prices on heavy weights declined 10 cents in a slow trade.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- American soldiers and sailors from Manhattan who have had a chance to visit London and form an opinion of the British capital are a bit like the Virginian who, when asked what he thought of California, spouted praise of that State's Scenery, climate and people but wound up with the observation that "it's too far from Chesapeake Bay to be really successful."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- By agreement of attorneys after a day of argument before Federal Judge Michael J. Roche, three Federal district judges will rule on whether the Federal court has jurisdiction over cases in which Negro shipyard workers have refused to join a Negro auxiliary of the Boilermakers Brotherhood, AFL, and have been discharged under a closed shop agreement between the union and the shipyards.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 13 -- Dr. Allan Nevins, special representative of the Office of War Information in New Zealand, was gently chided by The Evening Post after a speech in which he made a frank review of possible causes of difference between Britain and the United States.

Welcoming the Moscow declaration for a "general international organization" and the adoption by the Senate of the Connally resolution, a group of nearly 100 Americans who have been associated officially with the League of Nations in various capacities have ended a thee-day meeting to discuss the contribution the League could make to the post-war settlement.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 13 -- After more than two years of occupation, Greece and Yugoslavia are slowly beginning to shape the rudiments of their political futures and there is every evidence that such developments as have already occurred are favorably viewed by the great Allies.
ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey broadened the extraordinary grand jury investigation of Albany County today to cover all phases of alleged crime in the Democratic-controlled county.
John Gunther's new book will be called "D Day." It tells the story of his latest visit to the European battlefronts and will be completed by the end of the year. Harpers will bring it out:

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The recapture of Niupitan, east of Changteh, the retaking of ten villages northwest of Changteh and the encirclement of 2,000 Japanese, more than 500 of whom were killed, were announced by the Chinese High Command today in continued bloody rice bowl fighting.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 13 -- The showdown in the spirited fight by the over-the-counter market to prevent the New York Curb Exchange from making a mass invasion of the unlisted securities field was postponed today for the third time by the Securities and Exchange Commission at the request of counsel for all parties.

Gifts both large and small, but all generous and helpful, came yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund from 305 contributors in New York and its suburbs and points as distant as Vicksburg, Miss., Flint, Mich., and Denver.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- On the ground that Congress must have meant to promote the interests of domestic vegetable oil producers through an excise tax against imported products, the Supreme Court today held the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company liable for a $2,532,643 levy on stocks it held in hand when a revenue act close became effective May 10, 1934.

Indications that the War Production Board may allot preference ratings to certain consumer goods in order to achieve an "even and equalized" movement of such goods through the regular channels of trade were seen yesterday by manufacturers who discussed a proposed distribution order with officials of the Office of Civilian Requirements.

Add to the films opening this week "Pistol Packing Mamma," a comedy drama produced by Republic Pictures, which will arrive at the Globe on Saturday. Ruth Terry, Robert Livingston, Jack La Rue and Wally Vernon head the film's cast.

Requests of wholesale grocers for "protection" of their floor stocks, where the price of the items is rolled back by the use of subsidies, will be considered by the Commodity Credit Corporation at a meeting with the trade to be held in Washington tomorrow, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- The text of the Russian-Czechoslovak mutual assistance treaty, as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by The United Press:

Local nursing schools are beginning to reach their saturation point in absorbing student nurses, and unless this trend can be eased by creation of new housing and clinical arrangements within the next few months the city's spring quota of 500 new nurses may have to be trained somewhere else, it was revealed yesterday.
Tonight's events: Concert by Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Oscar Levant, pianist, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock; piano recital by Flora Mora, Town Hall, 8:30.
Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday afternoon that 750 soldiers and 500 sailors will be brought here to aid in the delivery of Christmas mail in Manhattan and the Bronx, beginning today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 11 (Delayed) -- A wave of fear has come over Germany's satellites. In Bulgaria there are cries for peace, Rumania regrets that she changed alliances and Hungary is frightened and looking for a way out.

Youngstown, Ohio, has awarded two new issues of bonds, aggregating $875,000. One issue of $200,000 of street bonds, due serially from Oct. 1, 1945 to 1964, went to a syndicate consisting of McDonald-Coolidge Co., Fahey, Clark Co., and Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc.

One of the eighty-six draft delinquents arrested here by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents last week was an escaped murderer from South Carolina, E.E. Conroy, local FBI chief, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -The Supreme Court refused today to interfere with a decision upholding a Selective Service Board's reclassification of a draft registrant from 3-A to 1-A after he had become a father.

A decade after its passing, the speakeasy has attained a more dignified standing than it did in real life, for it has become a museum piece. This afternoon the Museum of the City of New York, which records the local passing scene, will open an exhibition called "Fun and Folly in New York," which reproduces the exterior of a hypothetical speakeasy in Greenwich Village.

I disagree completely with Representative Busbey, who declared in the House that the foreign-language division of the Office of War Information is overloaded with aliens "whose avowed purpose was to destroy the American form of government."

ABOARD AN AMERICAN BATTLESHIP, Somewhere in the Atlantic, Aug. 6 (Delayed by Censorship) (AP) -- Hundreds of miles away in icy Arctic waters a strong United States Navy task force, including some of the world's most powerful battleships, played a vital role in the Allied invasion of Sicily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Japanese Government has refused to agree to the exchange of any more American and other Allied internees in the Far East before conditions in the internment and relocation camps for Japanese and Japanese-Americans in this country have been investigated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Roosevelt paid a flying visit to Sicily during his return trip from the Cairo and Teheran conferences. He reviewed troops and decorated Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commanding the Fifth Army in Italy, and five other officers of the Fifth Army for heroism in action, the White House announced today in a report from the Presidential party.

Influenced by the apparent determination of Congress to raise wages and the prices of farm products, the cotton market recovered moderately in quiet trading yesterday as commission house buying increased. At the close, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 1 to 5 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Charges by Senator Hugh A. Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, that the Government was lavishing $6,000,000,000 on Latin-American republics to buy their friendship were declared today by Senator Kenneth McKellar, acting chairman of the Appropriations Committee, to be 95 per cent wrong.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Voice of the Turtle" tomorrow night at the Morosco Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for Berkshire Industrial Farm, the private institution for problem boys in Canaan, N.Y. Mrs. Frederick E. Donaldson heads the ticket committee.

Estelle Best, American pianist, who was a pupil of Tobias Matthay in London and has studied with James Friskin in this city, gave her first New York recital in Town Hall last night. Her program was an ambitious one, from the point of view of interpretation especially, the first half consisting of the Bach Partita in C minor, the Schumann Davidsbuendler and the Beethoven Sonata in A-flat major, Opus 110.

Whether or not the changes survive until they become law, the amendments to the War Contract Renegotiation Act adopted thus far by the Senate Finance Committee represent wide concessions to industry and a set-back to the Government's proposals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson disclosed in a report to the Senate today that Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. had "spoken threateningly and with undue harshness" to a soldier who had omitted to wear his leggings on combat duty because his ankles were swollen.

The resignation of Sinclair Hatch as director of the United States Office of Civilian Defense for the Second Region and the appointment of Col. Frank A. McNamee Jr., assistant director in charge of civilian protection, as his successor, effective tomorrow, was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- The Standard Oil Company of Ohio has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 101,389 shares of cumulative convertible preferred stock, $100 par value.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Senate heard Secretary Stimson's report on the Lieut. Gen. Patton incident; heard Senator McKellar dispute Senator Butler's charges of "boondoggling" in Latin-America; passed an amended joint resolution to establish a Philippine rehabilitation commission and recessed at 3:43 P.M. until noon Wednesday.

Title to a plot of about 100,000 square feet opposite the Pennsylvania Railroad Station was passed yesterday to the Greyhound Bus Line interests which will improve the site with a new bus terminal as soon as materials are available, it was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company and Fenimore C. Goode, vice president of Byrne, Bowman Forshay, brokers in the deal.

A UNITED STATES BASE IN CENTRAL CHINA, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- Somewhere in the depths of China five American warriors are maintaining a lonely radio station and attending other odds and ends for the Fourteenth Air Force.

Preview glimpses of millinery fashions for the next few months show a bumper crop of chaplets, half-hats and curvettes -- every one of them clinging smoothly and snugly to the crown of the head, the hair beneath being drawn sleekly back from the brow.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in Mandarin to China and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
There was an 18.4 per cent drop in football attendance during the past season, but the Jan. 1 bowl stadiums will be packed as usual, a survey by The Associated Press reveals.

In a radical shake-up of the local Office of Price Administration organization, following reports of a clash between some department heads last week, Daniel P. Woolley, new regional OPA director, yesterday announced the abolition of the posts of district OPA director and the five county administrators.

In furtherance of the development program proposed ten days ago at the annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union in Columbus, Ohio, a call for 250,000 volunteer workers was issued yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of that organization.

When "Meet the Navy," the service show of the Royal Canadian Navy, gets to New York around Feb. 1 (the exact opening date depends on the availability of a large enough Broadway house), the offering will take the form of a good-will gesture by our Canadian brothers-in-arms.
Allies air operations in Italy have been hampered in recent months by weather and supply.

An informal "family" rationing of the daily supply of milk may soon be adopted in New York homes to make sure the children get the necessary quart a day, spokesmen for the milk industry reported yesterday. At the same time they denied that there is or will be any real shortage of milk here.

IN a very quiet and unobtrusive way the basketball season has been progressing for the last couple of weeks, attracting only the attention of the court fanatics. But now the sport is ready for its big league debut, the opening of the Madison Square Garden campaign tonight. This is a significant opening in many respects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Abe Fortas, former Under-Secretary of the Interior, has been discharged from the Navy for physical reasons after serving one month as an apprentice seaman, the Navy announced today.

An "African Dance Festival" directed by Asadata Dafora served last night at Carnegie Hall as a dedication ceremonial for the newly formed African Academy of Arts and Research. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, a sponsor of the project, and Mary McLeod Bethune, president of the National Council of Negro Women, were guests of honor and speakers along with Kingsley Ozuomba Mbadiwe, director of the academy.
The role of spreading joy in the hearts of children played by a department store Santa Claus can have its poignant moments, too.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 14 -- Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force fought their way down an alley of Nazi anti-aircraft fire eight miles long and pounded targets in northwest Germany yesterday, as the campaign of attrition against the German Air Force continued.

On the second anniversary of their declarations of war against the United States, State Secretary Hull addressed a solemn warning to the Governments of Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria that irrespective of the sentiments of their people they will have "to share the responsibility for the consequences of the terrible defeat that United Nations arms are so surely bringing to Nazi Germany."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- The rumba, the tango and the conga line were recognized as instruments of international good will today when twenty-one Latin-American countries presented a scroll to the composer-band leader Enric Madriguera, making him the first "musical ambassador of the Americas."

Directors of the Peter Fox Brewing Company at a meeting yesterday in Chicago declared a dividend of an overriding royalty interest in certain oil and gas leases owned by the company in Garfield and Oklahoma Counties, Okla., to shareholders of record Dec. 22.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Partisan army of Marshal Josip Broz (Tito) announced by radio today that it was continuing to beat off, along a wild and irregular battle-line, all German attempts to break through into liberated territory."
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 14 (UP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

" Christmas Around the World," the third program in the young people's series "Fun With Book People," will be given at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, at 10:30 A.M. Saturday. The program will feature a children's play with a cast of children working under the direction of the American Treatre Wing, Committee on Youth in War Time at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

The drama section of the new City Center opened last evening, and a full house which had paid downward from $1.65 for its seats received in return about $1,000,000 in vitality. For the opening bill was a revival of "Susan and God," and through it swept Gertrude Lawrence as only she can sweep through a part -- hair flying, dress flying, scarf flying.
Payment of nearly $23,000 by two textile jobbers in settlement of treble damage claims for the sale of finished piece goods at over-ceiling prices was announced today by the New York office of OPA.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 11 (Delayed) -- The uninterrupted harassing warfare going on between Allied and Japanese troops on the India-Burma border is being waged along a jagged, discontinuous "front" of jungle-covered mountains and valleys stretching 500 miles from a triangular segment of upper Burma to coastal lowlands north of Akyab on the Bay of Bengal.
