ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Roving Australian cavalry units and modern war planes, combining the old and the new in warfare in a fashion seldom seen outside the steppes of Russia, are harassing the Japanese on a fifty-mile front along the western flank of enemy coastal strongholds at Bogadjim and Madang, in middle New Guinea, reports disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Fred Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, directed the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration today to assume specific responsibilities in a new program to assure adequate production of essential civilian goods.

The four-story corner building at 537-39 Park Avenue, Hoboken, N.J., containing eight apartments and two stores, together with a two-car garage, has been purchased by Charles H. and Lawrence Bender, plumbing contractors.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 14 -Russia has decided to send a military mission to Yugoslavia to work with Tito, the Moscow radio announced today.

NEW GEORGIA ISLAND (Delayed) -- To Marine Sgt. Maier J. Rothschild of New York City, who failed to qualify as a marksman with the rifle or with the bayonet in his training days, today was awarded the Navy Cross for using that same rifle and bayonet and a machine gun to assist in killing ninety-six Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton, seed crushed in the four-month period Aug. 1 to Nov. 30 totaled 1,884,351 tons, compared with 2,074,615 tons in the corresponding period a year ago.

SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Three National League veterans put their heads together today and came up with the unanimous opinion that the Cubs' slugging outfielder, Bill Nicholson, is the best player now active in baseball.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The White House statement today that, if Congress shall invite the President to address it on his return from Cairo and Teheran, the President undoubtedly will accept the invitation, makes it reasonably certain that this most helpful step toward better executive-legislative relations will be taken.

The Charity Organization Society, founded by Josephine Shaw Lowell in 1882, was merged four years ago with the Association for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor in the Community Service Society. Dec. 16 is the 100th anniversary of Mrs. Lowell's birth, and the C.S.S. is seeking to remind the forgetful citizens of New York of the debt they owe to Mrs. Lowell.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 13 -- Germany has been conducting tests with a rocket shell forty-five feet long, weighing twelve tons, which it hopes to put into use against Britain before the Allies can complete plans for the invasion of western Europe, according to diplomatic sources claiming to possess information concerning the Nazi "secret weapon."

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- The Governments of the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia published tonight the text of their twenty-year treaty of friendship, mutual assistance and post-war collaboration, which leaves the door open for later adherence thereto by any third power that borders on either country and that has been a victim of German aggression.

Seasonally appropriate, an exhibition entitled "The Christ Child" is current at Friends of Greece, 52 East Fifty-seventh Street, arranged as a benefit for that organization. The admission fee is 25 cents and the exhibition will continue until Dec. 24.

The post-war establishment here of a State Institute of Technical and Applied Arts, for high school graduates and other qualified students, was requested in a resolution adopted at a special meeting of the Board of Education yesterday afternoon.

Back home after giving the Redskins the neck of the chicken in Washington Sunday, thereby gaining a hold on at least half of the Eastern title in the National Football League, the Giants spent yesterday nursing their battle wounds and learning the words of their new marching song, "Half a League Onward."

Prices on the stock market yesterday went through a very thorough process of being mixed and shuttled about. The accent was, however, on the lower side at the close due to a mild selling wave in the final hour, when sharp breaks reduced the value of the distilling issues.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered an investigation to determine whether its rules should be amended to require that the stockholders of a company, instead of its board of directors, approve an application to remove a security from listing on a national securities exchange, it was learned today.

In December, 1942, the OPA fixed specific wholesale prices for beef. By February, 1943, the OPA knew by its own admission that the fixed price resulted in an inequitable margin and hence was illegal. But it made no change until October, 1943, and even this was made only under fear of an impending adverse court decision.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Russo-Czech treaty has brought to the fore perhaps the most difficult diplomatic question of the war -- the relations between Russia and Poland and settlement of eastern Europe.

A supper dance to aid the philanthropic projects of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will be given tonight as a pre-opening celebration at the Monte Carlo restaurant, Madison Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street. The fete has been arranged under the auspices of the senior and junior committees for the Girl Scouts, of which Mrs. Douglas Gibbons is chairman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 8, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Decreases of $518,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities and of $1,146,000,000 in United States Government deposits and an increase of $424,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.
The former Hearst estate of about thirteen acres at Sands Point, L.I., has been sold by the Dime Savings Bank to a client of Harvey Craw and W.F. Ardis, co-brokers in the deal.

Prices on the stock market yesterday went through a very thorough process of being mixed and shuttled about. The accent was, however, on the lower side at the close due to a mild selling wave in the final hour, when sharp breaks reduced the value of the distilling issues.

The presentation of evidence was completed by both Government and defense counsel yesterday at the trial in Federal court of seven men accused of extorting $2,500,000 from the motion-picture industry. Judge John Bright announced last night that he would recess the case today, and defense attorneys will begin to sum up tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -Theft and counterfeiting of gasoline ration coupons have developed into "a big racket" which must be smashed largely by the public, Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, said tonight.

According to details of the sale of the seventeen-story office, loft and store building at 24-26 West Fortieth Street by the East River Savings Bank to the 26 West Fortieth Street Corporation, announced yesterday, the sale was made subject to a mortgage reduced to $375,000, held by the seller and extended for purchaser.

ALGIERS, Dec. 14 -- Reports of the impending resignation of Lieut. Gen. Rene Bouscat, Chief of Staff for Air, closely following new offers of resignation by Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud, indicated continuing tension between the army and the French Committee of National Liberation.

Edward P. Lacey, 39 years old, of 360 Wadsworth Avenue, told Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday that he was guilty of third-degree larceny because he had become a victim of a loan-shark. He was held in $1,500 bail to await sentence.

MONTREAL, Dec. 14 -- The strike of Montreal's approximately 4,500 city employes, including police and firemen, appeared to be near a quick settlement tonight when it was announced in Quebec City that demands of the strikers would be met.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 696, which compared with 1,284 in the preceding week and 693 in the like period a year ago, according to the list published in THE NEW YORK TIMES: Yesterday's arrivals numbered 240, against 500 last Tuesday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 14 -- Typical of the systematic concealment of events in France is an official announcement printed in newspapers of Savoie concerning the town of Annemasse, which is so near the Swiss border that everything happening there becomes known here fairly soon.

Milton H. Mandel, attorney for John Felino, 53 years old, of 2905 West Fifteenth Street, Coney Island, navy yard worker who is awaiting a hearing Monday in the Bowery Court on a simple assault charge made by Mrs. Olga Sleeis, 24, of 264 Henry Street, denied yesterday that Felino was the aggressor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The head of the British Waafs, Katherine Janes Trefusis Forbes, who bears the imposing title of Air Chief Commandant, told today how one of the fastest-growing military groups of this war came into being.

As the approach of Christmas turned the thoughts to giving not only to loved ones, but also to aid the friendless and the less fortunate, generous gifts came yesterday from 560 contributors for the Neediest Cases, the fathers and mothers, the lonely individuals and the children who for reasons of sickness or misfortune are the most distressed in all the city known to eight private family welfare organizations.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Bruins gained the National Hockey League's runner-up berth tonight by topping the Black Hawks for an exciting 4-3 triumph while extending their string of unbeaten home starts to eight before a 10,000 crowd at the Boston Garden.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Two small squares of folded paper were drawn today from a box in the office of Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor.

Emphasizing that a foreign oil policy must be established at once if the interests of the United States are not to be sacrificed, a twelve-member foreign-operations committee appointed by the Petroleum Administrator for War has proposed a plan for the establishment of an international oil compact similar to the Interstate Oil Compact of 1935 as a post-war medium for the "efficient and orderly development of the world's oil resources."

Products that shorten the hours spent in cookery interest all women, some time and most women all the time. Accordingly, new uses for a few foods of the ready-to-serve variety, developed recently by the makers, are mentioned today.

The War Department is now redrafting Army Regulation 600-90, which restricts the sale and manufacture of insignia, and the new regulation will include licensing provisions similar to those which existed prior to June 26 of this year, Raymond Kay, executive secretary of the Military Suppliers Association of America, Inc., announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A group of school children of Clay ton, Mo., appealed to Congress today to prevent an inflationary spiral which might boost the prices on ice-cream cones and candy while their allowances remained stationary.

The Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $513,814 after reserves for estimated Federal taxes and possible renegotiation and for post-war reconversion.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission has ordered, in a sharply worded memorandum, elimination by the New York Telephone Company of what the commission terms a $4,166,510 "write-up of assets" in connection with equipment purchases about fifteen years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- About 60 per cent of Germany's primary industrial targets already have been destroyed by the hammer-blows of the combined American and British air fleets, it was reliably reported today.
Thirty members of the Long Island Golf Association, at their annual meeting last night in the Garden City Hotel, decided to carry on in 1944 with the same activities and tournaments staged this year.

The American Chapter of the Religious Emergency Council of Great Britain, 55 Leonard Street, announces publication of the late Lord Wedgwood's last work, "Testament to Democracy." The book, to be brought out next Wednesday, will have a foreword by Prime Minister Winston S. Churchill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Members of Congress were amused today by a list of names offered by Representative Noah M. Mason, Republican, of Illinois, for an "all-American Cabinet" to help plan the post-war future.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Warren H. Atherton, national commander of the American Legion, accused "the nation, Congress and administrative officials" today of forgetting that while they were busy thinking and talking about what they were going to do for the wounded men of the world war "men were being wounded and provision had not yet been made for adequate service to them."

THE train was speeding over the rails, bringing the Giants back home from their victory over the Redskins last Sunday. The boys were happy and bruised -- but principally happy. As Tuffy Leemans once remarked, "When you win a game, you never ache as much as when you lose."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 14 -- The evacuation of bombed German cities and the transfer of Reich industries to suburban areas has placed such demands on local traffic in the Reich that Nazi authorities have ordered several hundred coal-burning buses built to meet the need, according to a report from Berlin today.

The promise of a larger grant of State aid for New York City schools was held out yesterday at a meeting of the Joint Civic Conference of the Public Education Association at the Bank of Manhattan Company building at Madison Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Roosevelt will have to decide whether he will undertake to apply executive sanctions to enforce the directives issued by his Fair Employment Practice Committee against a group of railroads and railway unions for alleged discriminatory practices against Negroes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14 -- Germany's most powerful Balkan satellite, Bulgaria, has officially communicated peace feelers to the Allied Governments in an effort to get out of a war that both the Bulgarian Government and the population now realize is lost.

Midwood High broke a first-place tie with the idle Madison five and gained undisputed possession of the Section 2, Brooklyn P.S.A.L., lead yesterday by routing Abraham Lincoln High, 42 to 25, on Midwood's court. It was the third success in as many loop games for Midwood's strong outfit.

The stock market adhered yesterday to an irregular trend, while emphasis tended to the downside and the recent laggard aircrafts returned to life. Selling was moderate, but its force sufficient to chip values by fractions, with wider loses in isolated cases.

The weekly survey of meat receipts in the New York area released yesterday by the War Food Administration disclosed that for the week ended last Saturday total receipts were 35,261,416 pounds, compared with 32,144,229 the preceding week, a gain of 3,117,187 pounds.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 14 -Two new attacks oh Japanese bases in the mid-Pacific Marshalls, at Wotje and Jaluit, by Army and Navy heavy bombers were announced today by Pacific Fleet headquarters of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Government's announcement that it is sending a military mission to Yugoslavia is regarded here as further evidence of coordinated Allied reorientation with respect to Yugoslav policy.

Another Collection of triptyches is about to be placed on view, under the joint sponsorship of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy and the Architectural League. This material, destined for use in connection with religious services at Army camps, aboard ship, etc., has been arranged in rooms on the ground floor of the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

The constitutionality and validity of the Emergency Price Control Act and of Maximum Price Regulation 330 were upheld yesterday in a decision by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind. The court's ruling left Office of Price Administration suits against four chain-store concerns to be decided on the single issue of whether each chain should be bound by one set of price ceilings or by as many standards as it has stores.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Faculty athletic representatives and graduate managers of the Pacific Coast Conference today decided to continue division of the Rose Bowl football game profits as in the past. This means that all Conference members, even the six that abandoned intercollegiate football last fall, will share in the profits.

Charles T. Douds, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that the board would conduct today an election by the 4,000 employes of the Botany Worsted Mills at Passaic, N.J., to determine whether the workers want the Textile Workers of America, CIO, to be their collective bargaining agent.

The report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $5,611,104 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $4.46 a share on the company's combined $5 and $6 preferred stocks.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- An authentic account of the Reuter dispatch from Lisbon that reported the close of the Cairo conference a day before the news was released officially, and has been the subject l of controversy ever since, became available here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to freeze Social Security taxes at the existing 1 per cent rate for another year, and defeated a motion to strike from the tax bill the provision requiring labor unions and cooperatives to file a financial statement with the Treasury.

Looking back over the season now that the heat of combat has cooled, and cooled is the word these frigid December days, George Crowe of the Long Island Surf Fishing Club draws certain conclusions, none of them particularly flattering to the year's striped bass fishing.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 13 (Delayed) -- The Central Government has succeeded in imposing rationing and control of food prices in Punjab, the major food market's producing area of India. The Government has thus surmounted one of the most difficult economic and political problems it has had to face in dealing with the famine, high food prices and hoarding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The use of Russian bases by Allied planes was probably one of the issues raised at Moscow or at Teheran. There are two aspects of the problem -- first, the use of Russian soil as a springboard against Germany; second, the use of Siberian fields against Japan.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- The fall of the last big German stronghold on the middle Dnieper River, the old Ukrainian city of Cherkassy, was announced this evening in a special order of the day commending Gen. Ivan S. Koneff's Second Ukrainian Army Group. Soon after the announcement Moscow's guns were fired in a salute.

While there is widespread interest in the various proposals to enact new taxes or to change existing taxes, hardly anyone outside the legal profession or the parties immediately concerned pays any attention to the spirit in which the Treasury Department and the courts administer our existing tax laws.

Terming the 1943 Greater New York Fund campaign the "most successful in the fund's history," Arthur A. Ballantine, its president, revealed yesterday that a total of $4,306,158 in contributions from public corporations, private business and employe groups had been received to date.

Signed now instead of months ago when it was first agreed on by the two Governments the Soviet-Czechoslovak pact is set in a new international framework. In itself it is less important than it would have been if President Benes had been allowed to realize his plan of going on to Moscow after his visit to Washington last summer.

Directors of the National City Bank have voted to increase the bank's surplus account by $25,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Gordon S. Rentschler, chairman of the board. Of this amount, $7,500,000 will be transferred from undivided profits and $17,500,000 will be transferred from unallocated reserves.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The stock markets here were dull again today. Gloom continued to surround business in Kaffirs as white miners at the Cape threatened to strike for higher pay. Leading issues slipped back further. Diamonds weakened on selling by Cape interests.

Deposits in the 132 mutual savings banks in New York State have crossed the $6,000,000,000 mark for the first time, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York announced yesterday. Total deposits of these banks, as of Nov. 30, were $6,050,815,028, an increase of $67,805,838 during the month.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Powerful Chinese forces, supported by aircraft, have turned the retreat of the Japanese from Changteh into a rout, it was stated today by the High Command, and have recaptured Shihmen, Linli and a succession of other towns the invaders had occupied.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The city of Omaha, Neb., was permitted to intervene in proceedings on a voluntary plan of the Ameri can Power and Light Company to reclassify its stocks into a single class of common shares and forty-two pages of "canned testimony" were recorded at hearings which opened today before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

After having been in Brooklyn for fifty-eight years the Alfred J. Johannsen agency of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company will move to Manhattan on Feb. 1. It has rented the east wing of the eleventh floor in the Trinity Court Building, 74-76 Trinity Place, through Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.
ALLIED HEADQUARTER IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Dec. 15 (UP) -- A communique:

Contributions from as far away as Africa and ranging from $1 to $500 were received by the Metropolitan Opera Fund in the first mail on Monday, according to George A. Sloan, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association and chairman of the fund.

Mr. Ickes' warning that the nation faces a crisis in fuel due to the miners' strikes, which have caused an unparalleled situation involving the loss of 40,000,000 tons of coal production, calls to mind the waste of 2,200,000 horsepower of electrical energy by reason of failure to develop the St. Lawrence Power Project.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 14 -- The German military position in Italy continues to be viewed with confidence in Berlin.

Furniture and objects of art from the residences of the late J.P. Morgan at 231 Madison Avenue and Matinecock Point, Glen Cove, L.I., will be sold at auction early next year at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Asserting that the "preliminaries" were now out of the way in the war in the Pacific, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today that the United States was preparing major blows against the enemy there.

One of the few existing drafts of the proposed amendments to the Federal Constitution submitted by Congress to the States in 1789 and subsequently adopted in part as the Bill of Rights is to be placed on display here during the next war bond campaign, it was announced yesterday.

"Crazy House," a comedy produced by Universal, starring Olsen and Johnson, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's Criterion. Directed by Edward F. Cline, the picture also features Allan Jones, Leo Carrillo, Martha O'Driscoll, Robert Paige, Alan Curtis, Patrick Knowles, the dancing team of Tony and Sally DeMarco, and Count Basie and his orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Increasing consumption of coal and decreasing production, together with depleted stock piles, add up to a probable acute shortage of that commodity next year, the Office of War Information warned today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A drastic overhauling of the consumers goods field affecting pricing and production was projected today by Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director.

In the past four months an estimated 50,000 persons a week have perished from starvation in Bengal and other parts of India, and as yet there is no permanent relief in sight. Nobody who has not seen the suffering a famine can bring could contemplate the horror of it. Nor does famine mean death from starvation alone.

First among the actual participants in the recent momentous conferences at Cairo and Teheran to render a fuller account of them to his nation, Foreign Secretary Eden has just submitted a report to the House of Commons which strikes an admirable balance between the great results achieved at them and the even greater tasks that still lie before us.

Statements by President Roosevelt and Wendell L. Willkie defining what they believe to be the functions of the Christian Church in the world today were made public yesterday by the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Spring and summer came to town inside the Hotel Ritz-Carlton yesterday in spite of the icy winds that blew outside. The Cotton Shop held its advance showing in the Oval Room at the luncheon hour. Low necks, brief sleeves and sheer fabrics gave the presentation its tempo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York, investment bankers, wrote today to J. Haddon Alldredge, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission that they were not bidding competitively now on public utility issues of securities, although they had done so in the past, "because the number of bidders for competitive issues will inevitably be reduced and the prices offered for such issues lowered in conformity with the increased risk involved."

The Fairmount Court apartment house at 429-34 Fairmount Avenue in the Bergen section of Jersey City has been sold by the Fairmount Avenue Corporation (Marie Clerici, president) to Lillian Licht of New York. This structure is five stories high, occupies a site 90 by 165 feet and is assessed for $150,000.
GILMORE CITY, Iowa, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- A woman school principal sacrificed her life today to make certain that all her 300 pupils had fled safely from a fire in the Gilmore City public school.

Releasing figures of a survey which showed that absences due to respiratory illnesses had more than doubled over the week-end among a sampled 74,000 employes in all categories, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, New York City Health Commissioner, nevertheless insisted yesterday that "there is nothing alarming in the present situation in the city."

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The offensive launched by the Red Army on a five-division front in the Nevel sector, which was reported by Berlin, opened the Russians' northern winter campaign, according to military observers.

American young men are fighting with great determination "on all fronts" to end the war and are contributing to the great progress in the supply areas of the Middle East, the Rev. Dr. William Barrow Pugh, chairman of the Committee on Army and Navy Chaplains of the American Protestant Churches, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The cases of thousands of draft registrants who have been deferred because their jobs were essential were ordered reopened today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Dec. 15 -- More than 100 Liberator and Mitchell bombers blasted Japanese positions in the Gasmata area on the southern coast of New Britain on Monday, dropping 248 tons of bombs in a record three-hour raid, it was announced today.

The fur skin industry has entered the new season in a precarious manner; it is on dangerous ground as regards the advance in values, and alert houses will work with extreme caution during the coming year, according to J.D. Silberman, retiring president of the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc., speaking at the annual meeting and dinner of the organization last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 15 (AP) -The Russians have captured Cherkassy and perhaps have opened a new major offensive in northern White Russia, but, Moscow announced today, they were forced back from Radomyshl, fifty-five miles west of Kiev, by a fierce German drive to retake the Ukrainian capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- With five of the country's six principal munitions programs showing advances over October, war production in November rose to an all-time high mark, Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, said today in his seventeenth monthly report.

The greatest peril faced by the nation in achieving full production or full employment in the post-war period is the "divide and rule" strategy of private economic government in the form of cartels, Wendell Berge, assistant attorney general of the United States, told a meeting of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association yesterday.

A public offering will be made today of 60,000 shares of 4 1/4 per cent accumulative convertible preferred stock of P.R. Mallory Co., Inc., at $25 a share, or a total of $1,500,000, by the Lee Higginson Corporation. The proceeds will constitute a reserve for peacetime expansion of the company, manufacturer of metallurgical, electrical and electronic products.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- An American Historical Society committee decided today that the trouble with the schoolboy's American history was that it was too full of dates.

ALGIERS, Dec. 14 -- The German defenders of Ortona, just beyond the Adriatic flank of the British Eighth Army, fought back furiously yesterday and hurled repeated counter-attacks, powered by tanks, at the hard-pressing Allies. Canadian troops repulsed the thrusts and knocked out the tanks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Congestion developed today in December rye on the Board of Trade and the price shot up 4 7/8 cents a bushel after a small early dip. When aggressive buying and short-covering appeared there was little grain for sale.

Commenting on the decisions of the Federal Communications Commission and of the Public Service Commission of New York State in the New York Telephone Company's accounting case, the New York Telephone Company issued yesterday a statement in which it said:

Rationing of anthracite in the New York City area, with consumers receiving seven-eighths of the amounts they used during the cold months last year, was announced yesterday by Walter J. Dockerill, Solid Fuels Administrator for this region.

The protocol to the treaty which Russia and Czechoslovakia have just signed contains a clear invitation to Poland to join in what would then be a tripartite compact of mutual assistance in peace and war for twenty years. All parties to the treaty then would be pledged to respect each other's independence and sovereignty and mutually to refrain from interference in domestic affairs.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Defeat of Germany will bring "so considerable a decrease in the demand for munitions and ships that shortages of manpower will no longer be major problems," Brig. Gen. Leonard Ayres declared today.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been appointed corporate trustee, registrar and paying agent under the Utah Power Light Company's mortgage and deed of trust dated Dec. 1, 1943, under which $42,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 3/4 per cent series due on Dec. 1, 1968, was authenticated and delivered.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Associated Electric Company of New York today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission's approval of a plan to sell its holdings in the Union Gas and Electric Company, operating in Illinois, in compliance with the geographic integration clause of the Holding Company Act.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The war will be shortened as a result of the Teheran and Cairo conferences, but great battles are impending that will demand "all our strength, all our courage and all our unity," Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The 1,000th deadly Avenger torpedo bomber rolled off the asembly line of the Eastern Aircraft Division of the General Motors Corporation here today, but a Navy spokesman cautioned that the accomplishments of the plant should not be a cause of overoptimism.

All exhibition of recent oil paintings by Carl Wuermer -- erroneously advertised last Sunday as watercolors -- opened yesterday at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries, to run until New Year's Day.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 14 -Charles A. Barts, detective attached to New York's Thirty-second Precinct, who had received a number of citations for meritorious police work, was found guilty tonight of extorting $1,000 from Joseph Waters of Newark, now in State's prison on a charge of bringing stolen money into New Jersey.

By a vote of 171 to 92 the House has passed a bill to make it mandatory upon the Office of Price Administration to allow an immediate increase of at least 35 cents a barrel in the ceiling price of crude oil. Wholly apart from the merits of such an increase, this action is a major mistake.

Columbia's Lou Little, who said when he took over direction of the Lions' football fortunes, "I didn't come here to fail," will receive a glowing tribute to his lack of failure despite the fact that his 1943 team didn't win once in eight games played.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- If Craig Wood's putter start smoking again and brings him first money in the four-day $5,000 Miami open golf tournament, which starts Thursday, it'll be like an "earn-while-you-learn? bonus.

Sammy Angott and Bobby Ruffin, lightweight rivals who are to battle ten rounds Friday night in Madison Square Garden, yesterday received the State Athletic Commission's official stamp of approval as to their physical condition for the contest.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today conditionally a plan for reorganization and simplification of the central management and servicing arrangements of the American Water Works and Electric Company with the water operating and water subholding companies in its system.

A new issue of $1,100,000 of bonds has been awarded by the Mankato (Minn.) School District to a banking group comprising the Northwestern Bank of Minneapolis, the First National Bank of Minneapolis, the First National Bank of St. Paul, Paine. Webber, Jackson Curtis, John Nuveen Co. and associates.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 -- The Army broke up baseball's most famous brother combination today when it rejected Pitcher Morton Cooper of the Cardinals for military service after accepting Catcher Walker Cooper several weeks ago.

Despite the fact that the quarterly income tax period is at hand, banks in this city, and throughout the country generally, entered sizable subscriptions for this week's new issue of $1,000,000,000 of Treasury bills. Indeed, nation-wide subscriptions aggregated about $1, 800,000,000, which is close to a record.

Sweden, in anticipation of a possible resumption of foreign trade on a "peacetime" basis by next spring, is rebuilding its stocks of woodpulp to a normal level for the first time since 1939, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, House Majority Leader, characterized today as "petty criticism based on incorrect premises" a speech delivered in New York City on Saturday night by Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 14 -- Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel ruled today that Olga Shea, also known as Olga D. Lennox, of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was entitled to a judgment declaring her to be the widow of William J. Shea, Manhattan broker and a bachelor, who died on Feb. 27, 1940. She sought $10,000 and half the Shea estate, estimated at $600,000.

The destruction of records of Yonkers Local Board 735, for the sake of keeping her fiance and brother-in-law out of military service, was said to have been admitted yesterday by the assistant chief clerk of Local Board 734. The two boards occupy offices in different parts of the same building at 20 South Broadway, Yonkers.

The Weather Bureau here last night declined to break the record for "sticking out its neck" by predicting for certain that the city would experience the arrival of a record-breaking cold wave by this evening.

Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, City Health Commissioner, proposed yesterday that a national organization for the promotion of a more efficient use of the radio in public health education be formed by representatives of the radio industry and the public health and medical professions.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Meyer E. Ruback, counsel for James H.R. Cromwell, said tonight his client would continue to press for a divorce in New Jersey from the former Doris Duke, tobacco heiress, despite the announcement that Mrs. Cromwell would appear in a Nevada court tomorrow in defiance of a Chancery Court order obtained here today, which permanently restrains her from proceeding with her divorce action in Reno.

Judging from the Giants' appearance yesterday when they punched the Polo Grounds time-clock and went back on the assembly line for the first time since last Sunday's game in Washington, where they tied for the National Football League's Eastern title by beating the Redskins, 31 -- 7, the task must have been as simple in achievement as it seemed to those watching from the stands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The conflict between the air lines and the railroads over the latter's plans to enter the field of air transport became pronounced today on the eve of a meeting of the House Rules Committee to decide whether the Lea Civil Aviation Bill should be allowed to reach the floor for debate.

Vinton Freedley, who has always been partial to the Alvin Theatre (it was built for him and the late Alex Aarons and that's how it got its name), has booked the house for his new musical show, "Jackpot," opening Thursday night, Jan. 13. "Red, Hot and Blue" (1936) was Mr. Freedley's last offering, there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Action by the House on legislation for absentee voting by the armed forces probably will be deferred until after the new session of Congress in January, according to the view in informed quarters.

The first ten amendments to the Constitution of the United States, known collectively as the Bill of Rights, went into effect 152 years ago today. We miss their meaning, however, if we think of them as something new in the year 1791. They were omitted from the original draft of the Constitution, drawn up at Philadelphia in 1787, not because anyone was opposed to them but because the delegates mostly took them for granted.

It was surprising to discover how many of the composers on the "all-American" program given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, appeared as conservatives -- not as vengeful radicals, not as wild-eyed revolutionaries out to reform the art of composition or to frighten the bourgeois with things new, startling, disconcerting or obnoxious to say.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- London morning papers gave prominence today to reports from Sweden that Gen. Richard Jungklaus would replace Lieut. Gen. Baron Alexander von Falkenhausen as German military commander of Belgium.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Speedy action to provide cotton and rayon textile producers with incentive for expanding output of the many essential civilian products now in short supply was declared necessary yesterday by Worth Street suppliers, in order to prevent any letdown in production because of the threatened general advance in textile wages beginning some time early next year.

Details of the plan under which the American Distilling Company will sell at cost its whisky holdings to stockholders were made public last night. These involve the distribution of eighteen cases of whisky to a holder of each share of stock between Dec. 24 and Feb. 29.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 14 -- A last-minute burst of activity put Tropical Park in shape today for tomorrow's nine-race opening of Florida's third wartime turf season as watchful officials gave subdued expressions of confidence.

The first awards of a new special certificate of appreciation for supporting the blood-plasma drive were made yesterday by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross to Mayor La Guardia and Special Sessions Justice Irving Ben Cooper.

Describing the present method of fixing wage rates as "a most exact mechanism," William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, said last night that he believed stabilization of wages and prices could be achieved unless the program was "sabotaged" by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that the accounting performed by the New York Telephone Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in connection with four transfers of property from A. T. T. from 1925 to 1928 was "improper."

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's frank discussion today of the difficulties besetting the advance of the Fifteenth Army Group in Italy reinforced the tendency here to regard the Italian campaign as a long, laborious enterprise whose immediate military and political objective, the occupation of Rome, was still distant.

Describing the present method of fixing wage rates as "a most exact mechanism," William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, said last night that he believed stabilization of wages and prices could be achieved unless the program was "sabotaged" by Congress.

Prices of cotton were under pressure throughout the greater part of yesterday's trading and final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point higher to 4 points lower. A strike in the cotton mills in the Fall River area and threatened strikes in mill centers in the South, together with reports from Washington of a possible compromise on the subsidy program, were factors in the easiness of the market.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- By the use of diethylstilbestrol, a synthetic female sex hormone, cancer of the prostate gland "can be completely controlled and the patient rendered symptom-free" of the disease, Dr. E.C. Dodds, Courtauld Professor of Biochemistry at London University, announced here today at the annual meeting of the British Empire Cancer Campaign.

Surviving his rival's, last-round rally, Frank C. Terry, Bensonhurst, carried off the decision over Tony Reno, Chicago, last night in their eight-round feature bout before a crowd of about 3,500 at the Broadway' Arena, Brooklyn.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The subsidy debate has reached the point where extremists on both sides are engaging in a fear campaign. The opponents of subsidies hold that such payments will be highly inflationary; the proponents argue that the elimination of subsidies will mean a doubling of prices within a year.

Some people find an ambiguity in Secretary Stimson's reply to Senator Vandenberg. The Senator had asked whether Army or Navy officers on active service are eligible for nomination to high office, and Secretary Stimson said they are.

More than 800 superintendents of large Brooklyn apartment houses have been sworn in as temporary employes of the postoffice to make deliveries in their own buildings in an effort to solve the labor shortage caused by de war and a deluge of late Christmas mail, Postmaster Frank J. Quayle Jr. disclosed yesterday.

The eleventh annual appeal for funds by National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will be made between Jan. 14 and 31, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, head of the foundation. The "March of Dimes" drive will end on President Roosevelt's birthday on Jan. 31.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts said at a press conference today that the military and diplomatic picture was ever brightening for the Allies and predicted the defeat of Japan "sooner than some people think."

The Board of Estimate was asked to grant 15 per cent cost-of-living wage increases to all city employes earning less than $5,000 a year in a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday by the City Council.

Letters from friends in service overseas implore me to get them cigarette lighters, especially those with protective windshield contraptions, but where in the world does one get these things today? A canvass of the stores indicates none is to be had and a call to manufacturers elicited the response that cigarette lighters are unlisted war casualties.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Sweden towards host to 15,000 Norwegians of military age who are awaiting training in "police" duties. Already a number of them -- just how many cannot be disclosed -- have completed the course and stand armed and ready to return to their native land.

Responsible distillers throughout the country will welcome any steps that may be taken by the Treasury Department or the Office of finance Administration aimed at smashing the flourishing "black market" in liquor as suggested yesterday in Washington by Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan, Kenneth S. Baxter, executive director of the Conference of Alcoholic Beverage Industries, declared last night.

For the international juridical order that must be fashioned to assure peace and progress in the post-war world, nations should draw their inspiration from the Americas, where the conception was initiated through the establishment of Pan-Americanism, Dr. Pedro Cue, owner and director of the Mundo of Havana, Cuba, declared yesterday.

The six-story store and apartment building at 172 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Twenty-second Street, was sold recently by the Manhattan Savings Bank to Henry M. Margolis. This property is assessed for $130,000 and contains two stores and twenty-five apartments. L.T. Manning Son, the brokers in this deal, immediately resold the property to a client of Pearce Mayer, brokers.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A broadcast communique from the Free Yugoslav radio said the Partisans now were engaged in the heaviest defensive fighting since they had begun their guerrilla activities against the Germans.

Eighty-two famous paintings by early American artists will soon grace the walls of City Hall again. Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that the priceless art treasures were being taken out of storage where they were placed early in 1942 because of the danger of enemy air attack.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Civilians may expect to find 75 per cent of the country's food production on the grocers' shelves this coming year, Roy F. Hendrickson, director of the Food Distribution Administration, told the convention of the Vegetable Growers Association of America today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -Amendment of the 1934 Communications Act to include provisions designed to safeguard from discrimination in radio policy and practice the interests of all Americans, regardless of race, creed, color or national origin, was urged at today's Senate Interstate Commerce Committee hearing on the Wheeler-White bill by Luigi Antonini, president of the Italian American Labor Council, and Edgar L. Brown, president of the National Negro Congress.

College basketball returned to Madison Square Garden last night and in the presence of 13,409 fans the East-West double-header resulted in a stand-off as L.I.U. overwhelmed Brigham Young, 56 -- 41, and the Oklahoma Aggies overcame C.C.N.Y., 39 -- 27.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary Hull accused Senator Hugh A. Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, tonight of making an "unfair" and "wholly indefensible attack" on the Good Neighbor policy in his charges of extravagance and waste by the United States through expenditures in Latin America since 1939.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Yale found intercollegiate athletic competition so thriving in 1943 that it is going ahead full steam with plans for 1944 in football, baseball, swimming and basketball. The university has given its approval and Athletic Director Ogden D. Miller is frankly elated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- For action in the South Pacific:

Aviation enthusiasts who forecast the demise of battleships have been proved wrong, a naval spokesman declared recently. Because of their increased armament, he pointed out, American ships are now better able to withstand attacks from overhead.

IN December, 1940, the emanciated body of an old man was found dead of starvation in the streets of ruined Warsaw. So common an occurrence would hardly have been noticed if the victim had been only one of the nameless millions who have died so that the Nazis might live in the manner to which they have been so delighted to accustom themselves.

Christmas shopping in wartime takes on the proportions of major strategy and tactical planning. The list made out after much racking of the brain doesn't mean this year that the hump is past. Item 1 can be had in size 32 but not 42, Item 2 can't be engraved till after Christmas, Item 3 costs twice as much as expected, Item 4 doesn't come in yellow, and Item 5 is out of stock.

BATH, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- A small, wooden bus, carrying nineteen rural war workers to the Ingersoll-Rand plant in Painted Post, hit a heavy trailer truck in predawn darkness, near Campbell this morning, killing eleven passengers and injuring eight others, one critically.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 14 -- Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., badly burned in the torpedoing of the small escort carrier Liscome Bay on the morning of Nov. 24, during the invasion of the Gilberts, swam slowly around in the cooling waters of the Pacific and looked back over his shoulder to where the doomed carrier was going down.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (AP) --

HARTSVILLE, S.C., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Louis Norman (Bobo) Newsom, right-handed pitcher who has just been traded to the Athletics by the Senators, has just been mailed his reclassification as 1-A by his local Selective Service Board here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 15 -- Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt has fallen into disgrace with the Nazis because he responded to the appeal from German officers in Moscow to overthrow nazism, according to a well-informed source in Berlin.

Despite a record number of no heat complaints filed with it yesterday, the Health Department said last night that a survey by its inspectors indicated that there had been a slight improvement in coal supplies here during the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A bill embodying a compromise on the subsidy question was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, but indications were that it satisfied neither of the contending groups.

Emily Hahn, author of "The Soong Sisters," a Doubleday, Doran book, will be the guest of honor at a cocktail party today given by the New York branch of the P.E.N. Club, world association of writers, in the Rockefeller Center Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- December and May wheat sold at new seasonal high prices today on the Board of Trade, the market continuing the advance that started early in September and has continued with minor interruptions up to date.

The nation-wide wave of grippe, influenza and other varieties of respiratory ailments appeared yesterday to have reached a new intensity, although New York City itself did not appear to have the worst of it.

Retail liquor dealers of this city were advised yesterday that the laws of New York State prohibit them from acquiring shares or warrants of American Distilling Company, which has offered to sell eighteen cases of whisky at cost to stockholders from Dec. 24 to Feb. 29, 1944, or from assisting stockholders in obtaining the whisky.
ALGIERS, Dec. 15 -- The British Eighth Army has unified its two bridgeheads across the Moro River and captured Villa Caldari, barely a half-mile from the Ortona-Orsogna road.

Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn Federal Court warned yesterday that he would give jail sentences to violators of the War Production Board conservation orders in the future. In making the announcement, the judge fined five men $500 each after they had pleaded guilty to charges of using copper for other than defense purposes.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- The freedom of the press must be protected vigilantly if all the freedoms are to be safeguarded through enlightened public opinion, speakers said today at a service held here in historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church to commemorate the 152d anniversary of the Bill of Rights.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The European Advisory Commission created at the Moscow conference to help the United States, British and Russian Governments reach a joint policy on common political problems held its first meeting today in its new headquarters at Lancaster House, St. James's Street.

The continuing cold spell brought thermometer readings that averaged about half the normal for the date to the city yesterday, with the daytime high a fleeting 20 degrees, reached at 4 P.M., between 18 at 3 o'clock and again at 5.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- Morale among the troops he has visited is surprisingly good, Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner, administrative chairman of the Committee on Army and Navy Religious Activities of the National Jewish Welfare Board, said at a press conference yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will hold tomorrow at its headquarters here a hearing on the proposal by Central Vermont Public Service Corporation to sell 194,1295 shares of common stock to a group of underwriters headed by Coffin Burr, Inc., at a price of $14.92 a share to the company and at an initial offering price of $16 a share to the public.

Workers of the E.R. Squibb Sons Brooklyn plant yesterday received the second star for their Army-Navy "E" pennant from the hands of wounded service men and an Army nurse with front-line service, in a ceremony at the plant, 25 Columbia Heights.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 -- The Argentine Foreign Minister, Gen. Alberto Gilbert, and the Paraguayan Foreign Minister, Luis Argana, this morning exchanged ratifications of the commercial treaty concluded in Buenos Aires last month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- An assertion that the major responsibility for the failure of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation to carry out its war contracts rested with union labor leaders, headed by Thomas Vincent de Lorenzo, was made by a House naval affairs subcommittee in an exhaustive report today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- Arturo Toscanini will direct the final concert of a series to be presented by the new Philadelphia Orchestra Pension Foundation. His appearance for the foundation will be his only engagement outside New York this season.

Mrs. Maude Ranger Brazier, 55 years old, a motion-picture actress at Fort Lee in the old "flicker days" who, thirty-eight years ago, turned to check forging as a more remunerative means of living, was spared a life term of imprisonment yesterday in General Sessions and sentenced to a penitentiary term up to three years.

Honored by the War Department on orders from President Roosevelt, five members of an American Airlines crew received air medals yesterday in recognition of having made the initial survey flight to North Africa via Presque Isle, Me., for the Army Air Transport Command.

The whisky issues staged some spectacular performances yesterday on the stock market, but the remainder of the list held to an irregular course, with final prices mixed. Activity was limited except for the distilling section and a few low-priced shares as business on the Stock Exchange dropped to the smallest volume since Dec. 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Shipments of domestic sizes of anthracite bought by eleven States in the Eastern anthracite consuming area for use in State-owned or operated buildings will be slashed by 50 per cent beginning Jan. 1, and the coal thus freed will be made available to smaller users, Harold L. Ickes, Solid Fuels Administrator for War, informed Governors of the States today.

The battle against-inflation will not necessarily succeed or fail because of the action now taken concerning subsidies. But a reasonable compromise retaining those subsidies which can aid in the battle and discarding those which have the opposite tendency will indicate that a sense of balance is being achieved.

The tall boys of basketball have come in for a lot of attention and some adverse criticism (the latter perhaps by coaches whose squads were comparatively short). But it is doubtful that the tallest of them ever received the unique attention that was being devoted to one by Long Island University's team yesterday.

During the last few weeks President Roosevelt has covered many miles of winter sea and desert land by air. It would be foolish to compare the risks he has taken with those encountered by bomber crews over Berlin. They were not even so great as those Chiang Kai-shek took in flying and reflying "over the Hump" between China and India.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The great metropolis of Montreal, Canada's largest city, pulled safely through a spectacular fourteen-hour strike of some 5,000 police, firemen and public works employes today, but tonight faced a new difficulty, a threatened strike of 2,000 municipal white-collar workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The letter of Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York, investment bankers, to J. Haden Alldredge, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday, in which the banking firm denied having staged a "sitdown strike" against the recent competitively offered issue of Atlanta Charlotte Air Line Railway bonds, was described today by Robert J. Bulkley, counsel for Halsey, Stuart Co. of Chicago, as a confirmation of his charges.

Racking up its third straight, St. John's University defeated a youthful Montclair Teachers' quintet, 57 -- 34, last night in De Gray gym, Brooklyn. It was the Redmen's last warm-up game before their Garden debut against Detroit Saturday.

Two Red Cross certificates handed out this week in this city have a special meaning for everyone who wishes he could do a little more to aid the fighting men. One went to Mayor La Guardia in behalf of city employes who have donated 30,000 pints of blood to the Red Cross blood bank.

A comprehensive picture of the food prospects and problems of 1944 was drawn yesterday by Government officials and food leaders. There was also both a strong attack on the national food policy as well as defense of it at the public hearing of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition at the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- A Senate Military Affairs subcommittee decided today to postpone action "temporarily" on the pending promotion of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton from the permanent Army rank of colonel to major general.
CHUNGKING, China Dec. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

Mayor La Guardia's plans for expediting work to complete the huge municipal airport at Idlewild, Queens, were endorsed yesterday by the City Planning Commission in a letter to the City Council. The Council's finance committee will consider today the capital outlay budget for 1944, in which $11,540,000 is provided for planning and construction and $2,414,000 for acquiring additional land.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Chairman James L. Fly denied today the Federal Communications Commission had "discriminated" against Press Wireless, Inc., in authorizing circuits for communication with foreign points.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Eden, replying to critics of the Allied Mediterranean strategy in the House of Commons today, replied that it was only with regret that he restrained himself from saying many things he was longing to say.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 15 (AP) Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut of Baltimore ruled today that the thirteen-year-old receivership of the Seaboard Air Line Railway "must now be brought to a close without much further delay," through equity proceedings if possible, otherwise through bankruptcy proceedings.

WHEN the National and American Leagues recently conferred on their 1944 schedules, the junior circuit did not object too strenuously to the way the older league voted its suggestion for shortening the season. The original proposal had been that a week be chopped off each end of the campaign so that Sept. 24 would serve as the closing date instead of Oct. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, was permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to reduce the aggregate stated value of its no par common stock by $50,000,000.
The Exchange will suspend tomorrow "when distributed" dealings in the Consolidated Natural Gas Company's capital stock, $15 par value, and admit the stock itself.

The action of the Office of Price Administration in amending the regulations covering certain imported textiles, while apparently aimed at the current wartime trade in cotton piece goods with Mexico, is "ill advised" and will probably further restrict the already sharply curtailed shipments from Great Britain, importers asserted yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- The fratricidal warfare in Greece is reliably reported to have died down. The respite, however, is attributable only to the weather, which is described as the worst in years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Government's program for building supercargo planes of the flying boat type is being reconsidered and a decision on whether to abandon or go on with the project will be made next month, according to reports in aircraft circles.

Under ordinary circumstances one would be inclined to agree with Godfrey N. Nelson's statement that the sales tax does not deserve to be a popular peacetime tax. I wonder, though, if the sales tax would not fill a very important part in solving the post-war problems.

The possibility of Axis air raids is still keeping some of the city's art and literary treasures in hiding in the country, although the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced on Tuesday that it had begun to bring back its evacuated works of art and hoped to continue the process until its collections had been restored to normal.

Dr. Duncan A. MacInnes, physical chemist and member of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, was elected president of the New York Academy of Sciences, one of the leading scientific organizations in the United States, at the 126th annual meeting of the Academy last night at the Roosevelt Memorial Building, American Museum of Natural History.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Aneurin Bevan, his sharpest critic, clashed in the House of Commons again today over Allied strategy in Italy.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

With about 40 per cent of the offering of 37,950 muskrat sold, large buyers displayed hesitancy at the first auction of new season raw furs held yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc. The caution was said to reflect the uncertainty created by the delay in the issuance of the OPA price ceilings on raw furs and the possibility of larger roll-backs than the trade had anticipated.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday Midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

" Help Wanted! To Save a Million Tons of Paper," a booklet prepared by the War Advertising Council in cooperation with the Office of War Information and the War Production Board, containing suggestions to industry on the assistance it may render in the current paperconservation campaign, is now being distributed on a limited basis by the Association of National Advertisers.

Dr. Bilmanis attempts to raise doubts as to my Latvian origin. Here are the elementary facts: I was born in Daugavpils, Latvia, on Sept. 20, 1911. My father was a City Commissioner and Deputy Mayor. I was educated in Latvia and worked there. It was there that I took part in the democratic movement against the fascist dictator Ulmanis.

Hoping for a change in luck, which they need badly, the Redskins are breaking a long-established custom by coming to New York this afternoon so as to have two days of workouts here prior to the play-off game at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

Manufacturers' plans to revamp their distribution systems to improve their competitive situation by eliminating certain types of outlets and undesirable distributors may be delayed until after the war if the War Production Board's forthcoming order on equitable distribution of consumers' goods is made effective in its present form, company officials stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The individual income-tax plan approved by the House and the Treasury's proposals on the subject were rejected today by the Senate Finance Committee, which decided to keep the existing income-tax schedule, including the Victory Tax.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Issuance of a price regulation expected to slash prices on packaged vitamins at least 15 per cent below the levels prevailing in October, 1941, will be delayed for the time being pending a study of additional information on increased potencies in present-day offerings of vitamins by manufacturers, Chester Bowles, OPA Administrator, announced today.

Patrolman Marvin Landfish, 28 years old, a rookie policeman attached to the Borough Park station in Brooklyn, assisted yesterday morning at the birth of an eight-pound boy to Mrs. Molly Esses, 35 years old, of 2002 Sixty-sixth Street.

The six-story apartment house at 2680 Heath Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Frederick Brown, operator, from a client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers. This property is on an irregular plot 100 by 131 feet and is fully rented.

An auction and sale of articles made by the patients at the House of the Holy Comforter will be held on Saturday at the headquarters of the home, Grand Concourse and 196th Street, the Bronx. The event, to be known as a "Horse Auction," will include the sale of varicolored horses made of chintz and calico with manes and tails of bright-colored worsted, suitable for holiday gifts for children.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Sir Alexander Korda, motion-picture producer, tonight announced plans for a ten-year $140,000,000 movie program by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer-London Films, Ltd., a new company which he will head.

The Endicott Johnson Corporation's plan for reducing the annual charge for dividends on its preferred stock has been approved by stockholders and has become effective, George W. Johnson, president of the shoe concern, announced yesterday.

A quick turnover of a midtown loft property was reported yesterday, Henry Goelet, operator, resold the twelve-story building on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 356-60 West Thirty-sixth Street to an investor for cash over a first mortgage of $225,000 at 3 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today an application by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway company to issue $76,573,700 of $100 par value preference stock and scrip certificates to be distributed pro rata as a dividend to common stockholders of record Nov. 1 last.

Since mass migration of labor brought about an acute wartime housing shortage, the Federal Government has seen the completion of more than 1,400,000 war housing units and has speeded up the production rate to 50,000 units a month, John B. Blandford Jr., administrator of the National Housing Agency, declared yesterday at the opening day's session of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, which started a two-day session at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, it was learned yesterday, will take a vote of the city's 14,000 policemen on Mayor La Guardia's proposal that they work overtime for the duration of the war and six months thereafter in exchange for annual bonus of $450.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 15 -- Four issues of Italia Libera, clandestine organ of the Party of Action, published in Rome, and dated Sept. 26, Oct. 4, 17 and 30, were shown here today.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The approach of the holidays was evidenced today in a contraction of business on the stock markets here, but prices were steadier than on the two preceding days. The chief feature among the industrials was a sharp rally in British Celanese shares, which opened at 26 1/2 and jumped to 27 1/4 shillings.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Yesterday a German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Testifying in the Moreland Act inquiry into malpractices affecting claimants in workmen's compensation cases, Dr. David J. Kaliski, chairman of the workmen's compensation boards of both the New York County and State Medical Societies, advocated yesterday that "the whole Labor Department" should be "streamlined" to speed up the determination of claims.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Stockpiles of Government-owned wool may become the "guinea pig" on which to try experiments in the orderly disposal of surplus war goods.

CORAL GABLES, Dec. 15 -- A gala throng of 9,517, fewer than a thousand under the track's first day high, clicked the turnstiles today to establish an opening-day pari-mutuel wagering record of $442,830 for Tropical Park.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Boston's Bill Cowley is back at the top of the National Hockey League's official scoring figures, regaining the position he had twice gained and lost in the weekly figures.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Pork products accounted for about 60 per cent of last week's total estimated meat production of 424,000,000 pounds, the War Meat Board reported today. The pork output was 252,000,000 pounds, an increase of 2,000,000 pounds.

A demand for a wage increase of 17 cents an hour has been voted by representatives of 80,000 employes of the Westinghouse Electrical and Manufacturing Company, the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday from its national office at 261 Fifth Avenue.

Violations of the City Charter, serious enough to constitute misdemeanors entailing forfeiture of public office, were imputed to Mayor La Guardia and Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey yesterday in a report made public by the City Council committee investigating the affairs of the La Guardia administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Office of Price Administration today granted manufacturers of wood household furniture permission to advance prices 5 per cent above their existing maximums.

Daniel P. Woolley, Office of Price Administration administrator for this area, announced last night that he was working out plans for more rigorous enforcement of price and rationing regulations, with particular emphasis on price ceilings.

Reversing the customary procedure, Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City lightweight, yesterday approached the end of his training for tomorrow night's ten-round joust against Sammy Angott in Madison Square Garden like a fighter just starting the preparatory grind.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 15 -- Culminating a politically tense ten days of inter-party negotiations, the Radical, Catholic and Peasant parties pooled their votes today and returned Marcel Pilet-Golaz to the Political Department (Foreign Office) of Switzerland for another four-year mandate as Federal Councilor in a tame electoral session of the Federal Assembly between 8:30 and 11:30 this morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Bears, who won the Western Division championship, and the Phil-Pitt Steagles walked off with every major offensive and defensive team honor in the National Football League this season, the final statistics showed today.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 16 -- The Russians have joined their Cherkassy and Kremenchug bridgeheads, completing control of a 250-mile stretch of the west bank of the winding Dnieper River from Nikopol north to Cherkassy, Moscow announced today, while the Germans said two powerful Russian drives were under way to the north in White Russia -- possibly the beginning of a winter offensive toward the Baltic Sea.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Traditional business methods of America have been replaced by the philosophy of sharing scarcity, Owen M. Richards, general manager of the American Dairy Association, told members of the American Butter Institute at the concluding session of a two-day war conference here today.
A statement urging the elimination of racial segregation in American life was published yesterday by 317 leaders in the fields of education. religion and labor in thirty-seven States.

Alvin H. Hausen, special eco-[ I nomic adviser of the board of gov-/ ernors of the Federal Reserve Sys-/ tern and Professor of Political Economy at Harvard University, believes that an international development and investment bank and an international commodity corporation will have to be created if the world is to achieve its postwar goals of stability and full employment.

ALGIERS, Dec. 15 -- The Allies' air offensive in the Balkans thundered to a new high yesterday when more than 300 planes, including Flying Fortresses and Liberators, carried out a four-way attack on airfields and shipping near Athens. Thirty-five Ger man fighters battled the attackers over the target, but twelve were shot down and others were damaged.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Average weekly earnings of factory emploes in New York State were $47.09 in the month ended on Nov. 15, against $46.10 a month before and $40.80 in November, 1942, Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The aircraft carrier Saratoga made a series of "guinea-pig runs" against Truk, Japan's chief naval base outside the main islands, but failed to lure the enemy fleet into combat, Captain John H. Cassady, commander of the ship, revealed today.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, winding up the two-day debate in the House of Commons, said today that the military plans laid down at the Teheran conference would take all our energies "in the very near future."

The deal for Twentieth Century-Fox to film "Winged Victory" in Technicolor was signed here late Tuesday night by officials of the screen company and the Army Air Force spectacle, it was announced yesterday by Sgt. Bill Doll, chief press agent for the attraction.

Stocks of the major oil products along the Atlantic coast were mostly higher last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's index covering gasoline at the close of the week stood at 42, compared with 41.3 a week earlier.

A conference among research workers from both sides of the border was held at Queens University in Kingston, Ont., last week-end. The New York State Conservation Department now comes forward with information on what happened.

The Finnish radio "discussed peace proposals" in a program beamed to the Soviet Union, according to a British Broadcasting Corporation report recorded yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury investigation was projected today into practices in the country's billion-dollar liquor industry, already under the scrutiny of Department of Justice agents and a special Senate committee.

Over the objections of producer groups in the New York milkshed, the Board of Health has approved a change in its regulations that will permit producers in other areas to sell heavy cream here for manufacturing purposes on a permanent basis, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Expressing a fear that the educational program for returning war veterans, as suggested by President Roosevelt, might lead to federalization of education, 2,000 educators attending the annual convention of the American Vocational Association called upon Congress today to set up safeguards so that the State and local authorities would have control over the vast project.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 128 by 100 feet at 670 Riverside Drive, corner of 144th Street, has been bought by Isadore B. Geller, operator, for cash above a first mortgage of $217,500. This building was erected in 1930 and consists of sixty apartments, with an annual rental of $41,000.

Tax reductions for real estate owners, a 10-cent subway fare, and lifting of the State moratorium on mortgage foreclosures were among the proposals made by speakers at the eighth annual metropolitan realty conference held yesterday in the Commodore Hotel under the auspices of the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Dec. 16 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A somewhat reworked version of "There Shall Be No Night," Robert E. Sherwood's sermon against the mentality that makes war and its counterpart, which seeks to avoid a conflict at any cost, opened here tonight before an audience that remained seated to applaud noisily for at least five minutes after the final curtain.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., Dec. 15 -- While his wife was away from the house for a brief period this morning, Charles Hossack, 39 years old, killed two of their three children, Robert, 1, and Ronald, 3, with a razor blade and slashed his own wrists, but did not succeed in his suicide attempt, according to the police.
Governor Dewey issued yesterday a proclamation calling upon every resident of New York State to cooperate in the new campaign for salvaging waste paper that will get under way intensively here today.

A large camera portrait of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, Catholic military vicar of the armed forces of the United States, was unveiled yesterday in his presence at a reception celebrating the first anniversary of the Cathedral Canteen, operated by the National Catholic Community Service at 17 East Fifty-first Street.

Charging that the Federation of Crippled and Disabled, Inc., of this city "made beggars of the handicapped to mulct the public" of thousands of dollars, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein yesterday obtained an order to institute action to dissolve the federation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Charles E. Wilson, vice chairman of the War Production Board, warned industry the other day against encouraging a "right-wing revolt" so violent that the reaction would be disastrous. He named no names of those to whom he imputes such short-sightedness.

Frank Altschul will retire from partnership in Lazard Freres Co., investment bankers here, on Dec. 31, the firm announced yesterday. He will continue a member of the New York Stock Exchange and will remain president of the General American Investors Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Office of Price Administration revised today its maximum rent regulations applying to hotels and rooming houses in the New York City area and in defense rental areas having a maximum rent date of March 1, 1943.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Government war expenditures reached the highest level of the war to date last month when $7,794,000,000 was paid out. The figure represented a gain of 10 per cent compared to October and exceeded by slightly more than 1 per cent the previous high record established last June, when total expenditures amounted to $7,688,000,000, the War Production Board announced.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 15 -- Admiral Chester W.
