Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced today that heavy bombers of the Seventh Army Air Forces had bombed Taroa Island in Maloelap Atoll yesterday starting a number of fires in the hangar area and engaging in a fight with fifteen enemy fighters sent up to intercept them.

Cotton prices worked up to the best levels of the day in the final hour of trading in the futures market yesterday as a flurry of New Orleans and mill buying orders encountered only light scale-up hedge offerings. At the close of dealings on the New York Cotton Exchange advances of 8 points had been registered in all the deliveries of the old list of active contracts.

The Textile Workers Union, CIO affiliate, won yesterday the collective bargaining representation election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board in the plant of the Botany Worsted Company at Passaic, N.J.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Lucien Adolph Labaudt, 65 years old, Life magazine artist of San Francisco, Calif., was among twelve persons killed in an American plane crash in Assam near the Burma border Sunday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- A United States military mission consisting of four experts and their assistants have begun an intensive study of economic, public health, military and communications problems in Saudi Arabia at the request of King Ibn Saud, it was revealed today following the return of Maj. Gen. Ralph Royce, commander in charge of American forces in the Middle East, who accompanied the mission to Jidda to introduce its members to the King.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Dec. 16 -- American heavy and medium bombers ripped Arawe, New Britain, on Tuesday with the heaviest bomb load ever carried on a single mission by southwest Pacific air forces.

Announcement by the War Production Board that additional quotas of brass will be granted to replace a like quantity of other metals in the manufacture of oxyacetylene equipment was accepted by manufacturers yesterday as an indication of how WPB will determine the order in which materials will be put back to their original uses.

Collections of letters and parcel post packages in Manhattan, the Bronx and Pelham, comprising the New York City postal district, showed substantial increases in the first two weeks of December, compared with the same period last year, Postmaster Albert Goldman reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Although a decline of 43 per cent has been registered in new construction in the United States since the record high mark of 1942, the total for this year will still exceed $7,700,000,000, the Department of Commerce stated today.
In recent weeks Congressional action on certain questions has been more an enigma than ever, and I would like to express my opinion on two particular questions.

The loss of Cherkassy, river port on the Dnieper, is a sharp setback for the Germans in Russia. The junction of its captors with other Russian forces striking down from Kremenchug means that the Nazis have been pried loose from their last firm hold on the great river barrier.

The Fairmount Hotel, a 161-room building occupying the blockfront on Hudson Boulevard, from Fairmount to Duncan Avenue, in Jersey City, has been sold by the Fairmount Holding Company, Robert Carmichael, president, to the Fairmount Hotel Realty Company, headed by Dr. Joseph K. Esnard.

NORTH of Hartford, in the broad, placid valley of the Connecticut River, there is a region of big, seemingly lattice-sided barns, and wide fields that stretch as far as the eye can see under acres of white gauze strung on poles. It is the region of Connecticut shade-grown tobacco, a land that comes as a shock to visitors who have always heard of New England as the home of hardscrabble farms tilted on precarious hillsides,

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- German rocket-equipped fighter planes when they first appeared were "a terrific menace" to the Eighth United States Air Force in its daylight bomber attacks, but largely because such planes are fifty to seventy miles an hour slower than their rocket-less equivalents, the menace is now under control.

Marcel Hubert, French 'cellist, who has made frequent appearances here since his local debut a decade ago, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. Again the artist impressed by his sincere approach, musicianship and taste in a comprehensive and varied program.

From the American battleship Unknown, stationed in the Atlantic area called Somewhere, comes a dispatch, dated Aug. 6 and conservatively labeled "delayed by censorship," which relates how a combined British-American task force tried last July to make the Germans believe that Norway, not Sicily, was to be the next Allied port of call.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- In a fifteen-by-twenty-foot room in the basement of a tea planter's bungalow at an Eastern India bomber base live two New York City girls, Patricia Moore and Jessica McCormick.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis has suspended Lou Novikoff, Chicago Cub outfielder, for failure to answer a questionnaire about his winter baseball playing in Southern California.

Consolidated net income of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 amounted to $2,610,496 after provision for estimated Federal income and excess profits taxes of $4,900,000, according to the annual report issued to stockholders yesterday by Thomas Luke, president.

Even though the soldier fighting in the front lines today is sparsely fed compared to the service man of World War I, he receives better raw food supplies and higher vitamin content meals than did the combatant of '17 and '18, Col. Ralph G. DeVoe, commanding officer of Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island, disclosed last night.

ON THE HUNAN FRONT, China, Dec. 12 (Delayed) -- Although Japanese prisoners are as scarce as central heating in wartime China, eight captured Japanese soldiers and three Koreans were exhibited to a press party this morning. Dressed in Chinese blue winter uniforms, they were sitting on lounge chairs in the warm sunlight, feeling generally amiable despite ropes tightly tied around them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Two of the five Senators who recently inspected Allied war fronts told the Senate today that this country should formulate a foreign oil policy as a guarantee of adequate future supplies.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Associated Electric Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to approve the divestment of its interests in the Lake Shore Gas Company of Ashtabula, Ohio, and the Ohio-Midland Company, Canal Winchester, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The German Luftwaffe has congratulated Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker of the United States Eighth Air Force on the accuracy of American bombings.

The various offices of internal revenue here had a busy day yesterday but the tax collectors took it in their stride. The last-minute rush of taxpayers that marked the Dec. 15 quarterly payment in other years, usually swamping all facilities, failed to materialize this year.

The absence of loved ones abroad with our fighting forces has turned the thoughts of many this Christmas to the unhappy plight of those at home recorded in THE TIMES Neediest Cases. Checks remembering a son, a father, or a husband far away on armed service continue to flow in to the Fund.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "Madame Curie," Metro's adaptation of the biography by that scientist's daughter, Eve Curie, will have its world premiere at the Radio City Music Hall. Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon are costarred as Madame and Pierre Curie, with Henry Travers, Albert Basserman, Dame May Whitty and Robert Walker among the featured players.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15 -- Setting a joint nation-wide walkout date for the third time in history, the operating railroad brotherhoods today established Dec. 30 and the three succeeding days for a "progressive strike" which the National Mediation Board immediately sought to avert.

As Mayor La Guardia urged New Yorkers to continue their interest in the activities of the Police Athletic League, an organization devoted to the welfare of the city's youngsters, the league staged last night its second annual benefit show, "Stars Shine for Young America," at Madison Square Garden.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, urged in a speech today a "realistic and patriotic" foreign policy, proposed a limitation of the Presidential term and stated his creed of Americanism.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- In a letter received today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach of Westchester, the headquarters of the Army Air Forces in Washington reserved the right for the duration of the war to use the new $4,000,000 county airport in Purchase although it was not presently wanted.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- With food shortages eased, though not fully remedied, almost everywhere in Bengal the aftermath of disease sweeping the province is taking a toll of deaths comparable in some places with the fatalities from starvation at the height of the famine six weeks ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has named Walter Pidgeon and Lana Turner as prospective co-stars of a picture to be based on Fairfax Downey's "Richard Harding Davis -- His Day." Centered around the romance of the war correspondent and Bessie McCoy, the picture will be called "Yama Yama Girl," if title rights can be cleared.

NAPLES, Dec. 14 (delayed) (AP) -- The Italian Committee of National Liberation, representing the six major non-Fascist political parties, issued a statement today describing King Victor Emmanuel as "one of the gravest obstacles to the rebirth of the nation."

A landlord cannot raise the rent for a city apartment because his tenants have had a baby, the Area Rent Director of the Office of Price Administration has ruled in the first case on the subject to arise here. Answering a landlord's application in a letter made public yesterday, Director Louis H. Pink declared:

Many persons believe that homemade Christmas presents are best for whether or not they vie in magnificence with purchased remembrances they represent thoughtfulness, time and labor on the part of the donor.

The American Merchant Marine can and will be a factor of employment for millions throughout the nation in the days that follow the war -- the days when the United States becomes the "granary of democracy," Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared yesterday.

The nation's five railroad operating brotherhoods announce that nearly 98 per cent of their members have voted to strike on Dec. 30 unless their demands for wage increases are met. This is a tragic decision. By what mental twist could a group of ordinarily patriotic men, many of whom have themselves brothers or sons on the fighting fronts, bring themselves to make it?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Wartime jobs are instilling in thousands of first-time feminine workers a zest for the added income and the economic independence they have acquired through their employment, according to John W. Durand of the Bureau of the Census.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The British Government's hopes of developing a unified empire policy on postwar civil aviation before seeking an agreement with the United States have not materialized as rapidly as had been an anticipated.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, Italy, Dec. 15 -- Alto Adige, the southern part of the Austrian Tyrol annexed by Italy after World War I has been virtually reabsorbed into the German Reich, according to the Oct. 30 issue of Italia Libera, which is the clandestine organ of the Party of Actions published in Rome.

With all of its success, radio is still "underselling" the American people and, despite the coming of television, newspapers still represent the most economical form of direct advertising for department stores, Ira A. Hirschmann, a vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., declared yesterday at the luncheon of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Sheraton.

" Each year we look forward at the Christmas season to giving our small contribution to your wonderful fund, wishing it could be increased many, many times," wrote two donors whose $10 "In Memory of Ella" was one of 492 contributions received yesterday on behalf of the Neediest Cases Fund.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- Yugoslav Partisans, aided by the close support of Allied aircraft, administered a sharp defeat to the Germans in the neighborhood of the important Dalmatian port of Zara, it was announced today in a communique broadcast by the Free Yugoslavia radio.

Lured by the strains of the Army Air Corps Band from Mitchel Field, L. L, hundreds of passers-by braved the wintry winds at noon yesterday to observe ceremonies on the steps of the Subtreasury Building in celebration of the 152d anniversary of the ratification of the Bill of Rights.

Outbreaks of influenza have reached epidemic proportions in some parts of the country. Public health officials are not alarmed, because the cases are generally mild. Moreover this is the season when outbreaks are to be expected. Though the epidemic that is now overtaxing hospitals bears no clinical relation to the pandemic of 1918 which took 20,000,000 lives in Europe and America that catastrophe is enough to arouse fears.

The small girl was only too happy to help out her elder brother with his home-work drill in history. She opened the volume at the indicated place, readjusted her hair ribbon and said, with as grown-up an intonation as she could manage, "Describe what happened next."

A total of $111,289,000 of bankers' dollar acceptances were outstanding in the United States on Nov. 30, lowest in more than twenty-five years, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of this market. The volume is off $3,594,000 on the month, and is down $4,778,000 from one year ago.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- United States marine parachutists, fighting as shock troops on Bougainville Island, in six days of forced marching drove through the worst terrain yet encountered in the south Pacific to advance the American northeastern front line to the Torokina River, it was disclosed today.

If the Disney bill, which recently passed the House of Representatives by a vote of 171 to 92, is enacted into law, it will result in an increase in the price of oil products in virtually every country outside Russia and those dominated by the Axis powers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A warning that the country's transportation system could not maintain its unprecedented war pace without prompt and extensive replacements of many types of equipment was given to the Senate today by the special (Truman) committee investigating the war program.

The charge of hoarding whisky was leveled yesterday against the distillers, wholesalers, distributors and importers as a group by the State Liquor Authority on the basis of its analysis of inventories and warehouse withdrawals during the first ten months of this year.

MADRID, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Rome has become a city of nightly murders and sabotage, of starving people and of hunted men hiding out in the ancient honeycombed catacombs to escape the Gestapo, reliable reports from the Italian frontier said tonight.

Emile Cooper has been engaged as guest conductor for the revival of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" this season by the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager. The Russian director, who conducted the work in Chicago with Mary Garden as Melisande, will make his Metropolitan debut with this opera.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Declaring that reports of widespread spoilage of meats because of glutted warehouses and clogged channels of distribution were "exaggerations," Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, said today that his agency saw no necessity for suspending meat rationing until Jan. 1, to move heavy stocks into consumption.

When word comes that Winston Churchill, at the age of 69 and for the second time this year, has contracted pneumonia, we do not get the picture of a sick man but of a man stoutly contending with an adversary. Mr. Churchill has known danger all his life and has seemed to thrive on it. At 18 he was n'early killed falling from a tree. At 21 a Cuban bullet missed him by a foot.

The arrival of "Storm Operation" has been delayed from Dec. 27 to Jan. 5 at the Belasco. Now trying out in Baltimore, the Maxwell Anderson play will go to Pittsburgh next week and to Cleveland the week after. In the two cities last named the attraction will be a subscription offering of the Theatre Guild-American Theatre Society combine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The successful German air attack on the Italian port of Bari at dawn on Dec. 2 was revealed today by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson as a disaster of considerable magnitude in which "a number" of Allied vessels, including two ammunition ships and five American merchantmen, were destroyed or damaged and 1,000 casualties occurred.

Assuming the pose of a swimmer about to execute a swan dive, a 22-year-old ex-gunner's mate plunged off the parapet on the eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building at 4 P. M. yesterday and, after striking a building across the street, crashed into Thirty-third Street in front of hundreds of Christmas shoppers, a drop of nearly a quarter of a mile.
MONTREAL, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Two thousand City Hall clerks canceled a strike ultimatum today when city authorities agreed to discuss their demands for union recognition.

Owing to the receipt, by banks in New York City and throughout the country generally, of a temporary windfall of Treasury disbursements on Wednesday before meeting quarterly income tax checks of depositors, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended Wednesday rose $105,000,000 in New York City and $320,000,000 for the nation as a whole, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Albert A. Cree of Rutland, Vt., president of Central Vermont Public Service Corporation, outlined today for the Securities and Exchange Commission the events leading to his company's rejection of a bid of $2,583,750 by Harriman, Ripley Co. and the First Boston Corporation for 195,000 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Opposition to the provisions and the language of House Joint Resolution 192, under which Congress is asked to appropriate funds for this country's part of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, was voiced today to the House Foreign Affairs Committee by Representative Frederick C. Smith, Republican, of Ohio.

" The Desert Song," Warners' modernized version of the stage success of the same name, will have its world premiere this morning at the Hollywood Theatre. Dennis Morgan and Irene Manning head the cast of the Technicolor production, which retains the play's original Sigmund Romberg music.

Named Wednesday in dissolution proceedings by Attorney General Nathaniel Goldstein, who charged that it was "not really a charitable organization," the Federation of Crippled and Disabled, Inc., issued a statement yesterday defending its activities.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 840 Broadway, southeast corner of Thirteenth Street, has been purchased by a syndicate of operators headed by Alexander Hirsch, attorney, subject to a first mortgage of $67,000 held by the Mutual Life Insurance Company and maturing in eight years.

A wage rise of 10 per cent to meet increases in the cost of living was demanded yesterday for 85,000 dressmakers in New York and vicinity by the joint board of the Dressmakers' Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, at a conference with employers at the Hotel McAlpin.

Well into the start of a season which will give him a full quarter century as coach of basketball at City College, the veteran Nat Holman was not too discouraged yesterday, despite the fact that the Beavers have won only two and dropped three of their opening five games, including last Tuesday night's seasonal debut in the Garden when the Oklahoma Aggies turned them back, 39 to 27.

Bear Mountain, with all its picturesque scenic effects, plus the more practical attributes offered by Army's spacious fieldhouse at West Point, will again provide the setting for the Dodgers' baseball training activities when Manager Leo Durocher marshals his squad along about March 15 next.
FLORENCE, S.C., Dec. 16 (AP) -- William Wood, publisher of the Small Homes Guide magazine, passenger on the southbound West Coast Champion, said today:

Speculative enthusiasm in the liquor issues was raised yesterday to a higher pitch on the stock market as interest widened to include the entire group. Amid a crop of new but unconfirmed reports on dividends in kind, the "Big Four" whisky stocks blossomed out in an unprecedented wave of activity even for these shares and their values were increased by 2 to almost 6 points.

As one recently honorably discharged from the Army, I feel that the defeat of the Lucas soldier vote bill is one of the most despicable factional intrigues ever perpetrated on the floor of the Senate against a group unable to defend itself.

ALGIERS, Dec. 16 -- The Eighth Army has breached the Ortona-Orsogna road in three places and captured Berardi, two and a half miles from the Adriatic, in renewed pressure against the fiercely resisting Germans. This seriously affected the German line below Pescara.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 11 were 1 per cent below sales of the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 7 per cent for the week ended Dec. 4 when compared with the like week of last year.

The women's division of the American Jewish Congress yesterday turned over 20,000 pounds of reconditioned clothes to the salvage department of the War Production Board for distribution in war-torn countries by the United Nations Rehabilitation and Relief Administration.

Orderly liquidation at this time of the United States' share of the strategic reserve of foreign grown wool should benefit both manufacturers and domestic wool growers by reducing the amount of unsold wool to be disposed of after cessation of hostilities, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers declared yesterday in commenting on the War Production Board's announcement yesterday that proposals to divert the 330,000,000-pound stockpile of imported wool are under consideration.

The House has approved a rise of 35 cents a barrel in the ceiling price on crude oil. This action was taken after the application was rejected twice by the OPA and once by the Stabilization Director on the ground that it was inflationary. The available data appear to support this position.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Abandonment of the Army's $134,000,000 Canol oil development project in Northern Canada, upon which about $100,000,000 has been spent, has been recommended by the Navy Department, the War Production Board and the Office of Petroleum Coordinator for War, the Senate committee investigating the war program, stated today.

When the withholding tax went into effect in the middle of this year the original reason for a special "Victory tax" disappeared. In the interests of simplification and sense the Victory tax should now be absorbed in the regular income tax.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Reports that Western and Northwestern markets were offering cash wheat to come here at a price which figured close to a delivery basis on December contracts and lack of aggressive buying resulted today in the market developing an easier undertone on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The President has returned, after his long journey and protracted conferences on international problems of the war, to find Pandora's box wide open. Out of it have flown the most virulent and tenacious of the social and economic plagues that afflict the country and soften its attack on the Axis.

The epidemic of respiratory ailments continued yesterday, although the rate of acceleration in the number of new cases slowed down. Meanwhile, New Yorkers shivering from the cold were able to draw some comfort from the fact that it was not so cold during daylight yesterday as the day before, and the early forecast for today was "fair and slightly warmer."

A New York victory waste paper campaign was formally launched yesterday under the impetus of a warning from Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, that more paper mills may close unless additional waste paper can be collected and shipped to the mills.

Representatives of nine of the largest packing concerns in the United States, meeting yesterday with Henry M. Brundage, Commissioner of Markets, unanimously endorsed a proposal for a thirty-day moratorium on the rationing of pork and pork products.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 16 -- Craig Wood's putter could do no wrong today and the duration open golf champion from Mamaroneck, N.Y., turned in a 68, two under par, to lead at the end of the first round of the $5,000 Miami open tournament.

The three-story store and apartment building at 1622 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the estate of Jacob Frank, Inc., to the Food Dealers Industrial Bank. This property is assessed for $52,000. C.B. Barfield was the attorney for the seller and Samuel Rothenberg represented the buyer.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association of San Francisco announced yesterday that its board of directors had voted to transfer $13,000,000 from undivided profits to surplus account, increasing the latter to $75,000,000.

In his letter to THE TIMES in the issue of Dec. 13 Felix H. Levy quotes Shakespeare, or to be more exact, Portia's comments on the nephew of the Duke of Saxony, to substantiate Lord Vansittart's views on the "low character of the German people." It would be unfair to the playwright not to complete the quotation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- A countrywide guidance, retraining and employment program for the 30,000,000 returning veterans and war workers expected to need help in getting readjusted during the post-war era is to begin experimentally in seven States during the next two weeks under the auspices of the United States Office of Education, it was disclosed today at the annual convention of the American Vocational Association.

The largest gain in newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities during November was in the automotive field, according to a compilation issued yesterday by Media Records, with an increase of 40.6 per cent being shown over the like 1942 month.

Tonight at Washington, at the special invitation of President Roosevelt, Orville Wright will be the guest of honor at a notable dinner to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of powered airplane flight and to stress the role which the plane can play in peace rather than war.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Deep in the hold of an ice-sheathed troop transport which pitched and tossed in battle with a frigid gale in the North Atlantic one day last February, a unique drama was approaching its climax.

The American textile industry, if given the opportunity through "incentive prices," could produce probably 2,000,000,000 yards more than current output, Frank L. Walton, former director of the War Production Board's textile, clothing and leather division, declared yesterday.

Fire Commissioner Patrick J. Walsh explained to ranking members of his department yesterday a plan proposed by Mayor La Guardia to meet the shortage of firemen under which the city's firemen would work about eight hours more weekly and would get a bonus of about $1 an hour for the extra work.

An application signed by Mayor La Guardia on Oct. 6, 1941, asking Federal funds for construction of Sanita Hills, the summer camp of the Honor Welfare Relief Fund of the Department of Sanitation at Holmes, N.Y., contained false statements and withheld information requested by the Work Projects Administration, according to a report made public yesterday by the City Council committee investigating the Mayor's administration of city affairs.

Few important changes in the holdings of their own shares by companies whose stocks are listed on the New York Stock Exchange took place between the previous report and that issued yesterday. Sinclair Oil Corporation increased its holdings of its own common from 339,838 to 440,838 shares.

Although the Foreign Economic Administration under the direction of Leo T. Crowley now has the "organization and the will" to assist American foreign traders, the set-up of the so-called "combined boards" which direct the allocation of supplies on a world basis, constitute a "gap" in administration of the nation's trading, Gerald L. Le Vino of the Commerce and Industry Association declared yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans, supported by Allied warplanes, have regained some positions along the vital Dalmatian coast and have sunk two enemy vessels and damaged three others with artillery fire, a Yugoslav communiqu announced today.

The Moreland act inquiry into the practice among physicians and medical equipment companies and services of accepting kickbacks in the settlement of workmen's compensation cases revealed a similar practice yesterday among attorneys engaged to settle compensation claims.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Parole of Newfoundland, Britain's Newest colony, will have a chance to decide for themselves what form of government they will get after the war, it was stated in Parliament today in a debate on the present control commission established ten years ago.

As if walking a hospital ward we gaze at these Hundred Neediest Cases, and strange thoughts come to us. Here are tragedies, but the pity is ours, the terror on the patients. Distributive justice looks most unjust. "All men are created equal." "Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." Were the persons here, born deaf, blind, twisted irremediably in body or mind, created equal with their fellows?

Overworked mothers were cheered yesterday at prospects of a new supply of domestic help when a class of seventy-six women in blue uniforms and white aprons was graduated out of the relief recipient class and registered for jobs as housekeepers by the Department of Welfare.

A number of New York City rod and gun clubs have banded together with an eye to obtaining stronger representation in the State's conservation program, according to an announcement yesterday from John J. O'Connor, elected temporary president.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Although attendance sagged to 3,269 in the usual second day letdown today at Tropical Park, business continued to be encouraging. Attendance was up 700 and mutuel play up $105,000 in comparison with last year's figures as $234,923 found its way into the machines during the eight-race card.
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 17 -- The Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force, returning to the methodical destruction of Berlin, "king of targets" in the air war, attacked the German capital last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Senate insistence upon an appropriation of $9,907,890 for completion of twenty-four civilian airports started by the Works Projects Administration and for the construction of seven others was accepted by the House today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

The appointment of Mrs. Dorothy S. Bauman as supervisor of War Public Services for the Federal Works Agency in Region 1, comprising the New England States, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, was announced yesterday by Regional Director John M. Gallagher.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Britain has refused to accept Spain's disclaimer of responsibility for the incident in which men wearing Falangist uniforms broke into the home of the British vice consul at Saragossa on Nov. 19, the House of Commons was told today.

Immediate implementation of the Teheran Declaration of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin with respect to the preservation of Iranian independence and ultimate evacuation of the territory of his country by Allied troops was requested last night by Mohammed Shayesteh, Iranian Minister to the United States.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 16 -- The Byron Darnton, a 10,500-ton Liberty ship, was launched in the Patapsco River today from the Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- It is entirely possible the Germans have a rocket gun capable of bombarding London with huge projectiles from the French coast more than a hundred miles away, in the opinion of Maj. Gen. Levin H. Campbell Jr., Chief of Army Ordnance.

LUMBERTON, N.C., Dec. 16 -- Between 60 and 100 persons were killed and more than 100 others were injured when two crack, streamlined trains of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad were wrecked at 1:15 o'clock this morning in a shallow cut two miles north of Buie and about twelve miles northwest of here.

ABOARD A DESTROYER, off New Britain, Dec. 16 -- "I knew Japanese planes were coming because they signaled me from the ship to return. I stopped picking up men floundering in the water and put on all speed I could get from the ship's boat heading back to the destroyer.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- The China-based Fourteenth United States Air Force has deallt some of its most telling blows of the war on the Japanese in the past four days, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee moved today to lay the subsidy issue aside until after the holidays by approving a simple resolution to continue the Commodity Credit Corporation for sixty days beyond Dec. 31.

Joseph C. Whitehead, through Duff Conger, Inc, in 70 E 96th St; Ruth Foster, in 110 E 87th St; Harry Ginsberg, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, in 50 E 77th St; Marie Sarkardi, in 1391 Madison Ave; Florence M. Proctor, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, in 1088 Park Ave; James W. Scott, in 55 E 76th St. -- Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The announcement of Prime Minister Churchill's illness did much to depress stock markets here today and the tone was uneven at the close of business.

Christmas will bring far fewer turkeys than Thanksgiving did, according to one authority who reports that black-market operations and direct sales to consumers by farmers are tying up the already short supply. Because of the expense involved, few shipments have arrived from the Western States that ordinarily furnish many birds for Manhattan markets.
In your issue of Dec. 10 you discuss the problem of the handling of war criminals. May I point out a few basic principles concerning this problem?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A tax bill estimated to yield $2,284,000,000 -- $144,000,000 more than the House bill -- was reported late today by the Senate Finance Committee, but there was little prospect that it would be adopted by the Senate before some time next year.

Sundash, honeyglo and dawnhaze are featured in the spring, 1944, hosiery card just issued by the Textile Color Card Association. Sundash is described as a radiant sun-blush tone, while honeyglo is a tropical tan. Dawnhaze is a neutral beige.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Labor members of the National War Labor Board today filed a dissenting opinion asserting that the board majority erred on Saturday in rejecting a panel recommendation that a wage increase for members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers (CIO) in the cotton garment industry should be retroactive to Sept. 1.

ABOARD THE FLAGSHIP OF THE SEVENTH AMPHIBIOUS FORCE, off New Britain, Dec. 16 -- Amid heavy explosions of naval guns and the staccato machine-gun fire of strafing planes of both sides; amid blood-red tracers of Japanese automatic weapons and the devastating fireballs of our mortar-type guns, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's troops hit the New Britain beaches.

LODI, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Patrolman John Claus may get "Santa" for a first name in the Police Department and public schools here as a result of an incident today. Unwittingly he gave the 600 school children a half holiday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- New York's more than 1,000,000 victory gardeners, it was announced today, helped ease the severity of food rationing in 1943 by growing "at least 749,449 tons of food" on their farms, vacant lots and backyards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Secretary Morgenthau announced today the appointment of James J. Maloney as assistant chief of the United States Secret Service succeeding Joseph E. Murphy, who retired recently after forty-five years in the organization.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Aneta, Netherlands News Agency, said today that a young Netherlander who escaped from Germany last spring had given to one of its correspondents an account of how the Germans had used civilian and war prisoners as human guinea pigs to test poison gases.

Opening what is described as the biggest offensive in the war against Japan so far, American army troops under the command of General MacArthur have started an invasion of New Britain, that long and narrow island northwest of the Solomons which lies athwart their road to the Philippines and which contains the Japanese stronghold of Rabaul.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- United States Army casualties from the beginning of the war through Nov. 30 totaled 98,594, of whom 15,334 were killed, 35,049 wounded, 23,725 missing and 24,486 listed as prisoners of war, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson reported today.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first ten months of this year, issued yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, shows a net income of $5,696,248, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with $7,457,501 in the ten months to Oct. 31, 1942.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- Soviet forces yesterday drove back the Germans for the second consecutive day in bitter fighting west of Kiev, while 150 miles to the south battle lines were being drawn about Smela, important Ukrainian rail station fifteen miles southwest of Cherkassy.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The first meeting of the governing body of the International Labor Office since October, 1941, began here today. It is expected that before Monday, when the conference closes, there will be a debate on the question of the creation of a labor organization embracing the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and a score of others for the handling of problems after the war.

DEEMS TAYLOR has spent most of his life studying music, writing music and writing about music. But the new book he has edited is a picture book about the movies, a rather surprising change of pace that sets an interesting precedent. Perhaps we will have a new book about music soon written by Mickey Rooney.

George E. Roosevelt last night was elected commodore of the New York Yacht Club for the third year. Also placed in office for that length of time were Vice Commodore Gerard B. Lambert and Rear Commodore de Coursey Fales.

Forty pupils from two Manhattan junior high public schools, all members of Youth Builders, joined the fight against black markets yesterday when they visited the Office of Price Administration in the Empire State Building and received instructions in methods to combat illegal sales by merchants.

The Liquid Carbonic Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $1,309,935 after all charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.61 each on 728,100 shares of common stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Alfred E. Driscoll, New Jersey State Commissioner of Alcoholic Beverage Control, told the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee Investigating Liquor Shortages today that the country was facing "de facto prohibition and its attending lawless conditions."

Kent Cooper, executive director and general manager of The Associated Press, announced yesterday the appointment of four members of his executive staff as assistant general managers. Mr. Cooper said this was in connection with assumption of active administration of the affairs of The Associated Press, Ltd., by Lloyd Stratton, president of the AP's wholly owned subsidiary incorporated in Great Britain and distributing news and newsphoto services in the Eastern hemisphere.
While most of the ski areas in northeastern United States and Canada are virtually sold out for the Christmas holiday period, only a limited number have satisfactory sport at this early date.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- Three German officers and a self-confessed Russian traitor have pleaded guilty to indictments charging personal participation in numerous murders and other atrocities in the Kharkov area and their trial now is under way, it was announced today by the Russian press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Calling penicillin, the new drug, "neither a miracle nor a cure-all," the War Department reported today that "comprehensive tests" had proved that the drug had "high efficiency" against some types of bacteria but was "almost wholly ineffective" against others.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The foundation stone of the new social order that Great Britain hopes to create after the war was laid today when the Government announced details of its 80,000,000 education reform bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A price ceiling of 83 cents a proof gallon was fixed for imports of Cuban and Mexican whisky brought into this country in bulk under a ruling by the Office of Price Administration today. The price is the same ceiling as that fixed for domestic whisky six months or less in age.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- A Fourteenth Air Force communique:
WITH THE AMERICAN SIXTH ARMY, at Arawe, New Britain, Dec. 16 -- We were thirty-five yards from shore when the Japanese opened up.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed a decrease of $2,265,000 in holdings of United States Government securities from last week's high record. Note circulation for the entire system showed an increase of $108,386,000.

Art treasures in the local museums were shipped to a place of safety out of town on the outbreak of war. They are now being repatriated. The air raid danger is now officially a thing of the past, since we understand that the museum officials are acting with the advice and consent of the military authorities.
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 17 (UP) -- The Russian Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Maureen has seen quite some action in battle for a dog. The mascot of a German bomber on numerous raids over Sicily and North Africa, she was shot down at Salerno, where a Nazi aviator gave her to a Dutch sea captain.

" For the second consecutive year I shall spend the holiday in an Army hospital, but I am fortunate that I can look to future Christmases with hope for better things in a better world. I hope that my small contribution can help some child realize that there is much good in the world and that tomorrow will see a better world for all people."
Scoring half their goals in the second period, the New York Rovers had little trouble beating the Brooklyn Crescents at Madison Square Garden in an Eastern Hockey League clash last night.

Exactly forty years ago -- on Dec. 17, 1903 -- the brothers Wilbur and Orville Wright made the world's first successful flight in an airplane, at Kitty Hawk, N.C. It is fitting that Americans should note this anniversary. For though the significance of the event was not understood at the time, it was destined to change the whole character of human civilization.

The cotton futures market sagged yesterday after the Senate Banking Committee had recommended a sixty-day postponement of the food subsidy measure. Selling at no time was heavy, however, and in view of the recent rise in quotations the decline was considered moderate.

Contrary to what a great many persons thought they'd dare to do after the whaling they took from the Giants in Washington last Sunday on top of what they had absorbed here in New York the week-before, the Redskins actually have come back for more of the same, at least that's what the Giants and Giant fans predict.

If the nation is to have a system of economic security based on free enterprise after the war is over, the average citizen must be convinced that his cooperation is necessary to bring about more efficient and greater production, Frederick C. Crawford, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, told members of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Bankers Club.

Six men and a 7-year-old boy who had been doomed by a fatal heart disease stood smiling before a hushed audience of 200 specially invited doctors at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, where they had been literally snatched from death by the last minute intervention of the new super-drug, penicillin, the most effective disease-fighting chemical so far discovered by man.

Wartime causes of juvenile delinquency have prompted Archbishop Francis J. Spellman to study measures for dealing with this problem, and he announced yesterday the organization of the Youth Counseling Service of the Catholic archdiocese of New York, which he will head.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Teresa Wright, who returned to Hollywood today from New York, will be starred by Samuel Goldwyn in a comedy, "The First Co-ed," after her appearance in that producer's forthcoming "Those Endearing Young Charms."

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Note circulation as reported by the Bank of England in its weekly condition statement continued its uninterrupted rise, with a gain of 21,662,000 to the new high record of 1,066,957,000.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 15 (Delayed) -- Today's Fifth Army communique, mentioning "sharp patrol clashes," hides two dramatic incidents, one involving a British patrol, the other an Italian patrol.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The White House announced that President Roosevelt was back in the United States from his Teheran-Cairo journey.

Reforms in the teaching of history, recommended in the studies conducted by the American Historical Association and other organizations from the impetus furnished by THE NEW YORK TIMES survey, can, if given an opportunity to prove themselves, make that subject of far greater practical value to the student.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Commodity prices in primary markets moved moderately upward during the week ended on Dec. 11, led by higher prices for fruits and vegetables and for coal.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Mitchell medium bombers, manned by Netherlanders, and Australian Beaufighters intercepted two 5,000-ton, troop-filled enemy transports and an escorting destroyer off Deli, on the north coast of Portuguese Timor, and gave them a thorough bombing and strafing from low altitude, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

Bobby Ruffin, the Astoria light-weight who scored an upset victory over Beau Jack in his last appearance in the Madison Square Garden ring, will be back there tonight to fight Sammy Angott, Washington (Pa.) veteran. Although Angott is recognized as the champion of the division by the National Boxing Association, his claim will not be at stake, for two reasons.

Railroads and other major coal users, especially the operators of large apartment and business buildings using steam sizes, yesterday began feeling the pinch of the fuel shortage that has been troubling smaller consumers for some time.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE IN THE PACIFIC, Dec. 16 -- One of the heaviest air attacks on Jaluit, one of the southern-most atolls in the enemy's Marshall Island group, was made on Dec. 8 by formations of Liberators of this force, it was disclosed today.

Three of the five borough rationing administrators, whose positions were abolished on Monday, resigned all connection with the Office of Price Administration yesterday although they had been asked by Daniel P. Woolley, new regional OPA administrator, to remain as chairmen of local war price and rationing boards in their counties.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The White House announced today that President Roosevelt had safely returned to this country after his journey to the historic conferences in the Middle East.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The marketing of hogs here was more orderly today than it had been recently and prices responded by increasing 15 cents a hundredweight on all except the Government-supported weights, which sold at the top of $13.75. Salable receipts were 13,000 head, compared with 15,628 a week ago and 17,832 a year ago.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Friday, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- Within five hours the American beachhead positions had been consolidated, almost the entire Arawe Peninsula was in the hands of General MacArthur 's men, basically Texans, and troops and amphibious tanks were moving through the interior to blast out the enemy trotops.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Roosevelt may have to take personal charge of negotiations for settlement of the dispute between the railroads and the operating brotherhoods if the National Mediation Board fails to effect an agreement to avert a strike of 350,000 employes, set for Dec. 30.

An enlarged committee to press for a change in the method of selecting judges, started nearly two months ago by the three leading bar associations of the First Judicial District as the result of the nomination of Thomas A. Aurelio for justice of the Supreme Court by the Democratic and Republican parties, was formed yesterday at a meeting at the Bar Association of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, will probably remain in Washington in that capacity and will not go to London as Supreme Anglo-American Commander in the European theatre.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Dec. 17 -- American forces have landed on New Britain Island and established a firm bridgehead.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The East Coast's allotment of gasoline for civilian use was slashed 7,000 barrels a day to 372,000 barrels daily for the first quarter of 1944 by the Petroleum Administration for War today. It said the reduction was in keeping with seasonally lower civilian needs.

Hitting out at "the curse of drink, which has broken as many homes as gambling," Mayor La Guardia told 150 members of the Clergy Association of New York and Neighborhood yesterday that the number of saloons in the city should be cut down.

A six-month trial rental period for prospective home buyers was proposed yesterday to the New York State League of Savings and Lean Associations at the closing session of its two-day post-war planning conference as an approach to an era of happy homeowners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The question of newspaper ownership of radio stations will be decided by the Federal Communications Commission before Christmas, possibly mission before Christmas, James L. Fly, FCC chairman, said at the Senate's Interstate Commerce Committee's final open hearing today on the Wheeler-White radio bill.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 16 -- German military preparations in Poland in expectation of an advance by the Russian Armies were indicated today by the cancellation, "due to technical difficulties," of special trains intended for German parents wishing to visit their evacuated children there.

TORONTO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Toronto missed a chance to go into second place in the National Hockey League tonight when the Maple Leafs dropped a 4-1 decision to the Red Wings on their home ice. The Leafs also lost the services of their valuable center, Mel Hill, who suffered a broken ankle in the second period.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the application of the Standard Gas and Electric Company to sell for $800,000 cash its interest in the Market Street Railway Company of San Francisco to A.C. Allyn Co., an affiliate, and the Equitable Securities Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Post-war reorganization of the Army on a merit-promotion basis was proposed by Senators today as the Military Committee received legislation which would halt all permanent advancement in rank for officers during the war.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, deplored yesterday the action of the Interstate Commerce Commission in denying permission to his road to issue $76,000,000 of preferred stock as a dividend to common stockholders.
ALGIERS, Dec. 17 -- Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud in an order of the day hailed the French units fighting in Italy as bearing with their battle flags the fate of the nation.

Leaders of the fashion industry who comprise the membership of Fashion Group, Inc., held their annual Christmas luncheon party yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel with the presentation of gifts to the Children's Aid Society as the feature of the gathering.

Whether from the irresistible compulsion of his daimon of expression, the hope of making somebody hot in the collar, or the desire to amuse his public, Mayor La Guardia declares that he loathes politicians. The Mayor has been himself, of course, a veteran politician for a generation, and one of the most successful.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Depth charges from destroyers of one of Britain's deadly "killer groups" ripped open and destroyed two German submarines in a recent Atlantic battle in which a U-boat pack was driven off before it could strike at two important convoys.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander of the Mediterranean theatre, will go to London to become supreme commander of Allied cross-Channel invasion forces and Gen. George C. Marshall will remain United States Army Chief of Staff, the usually authoritative Army and Navy Register will say in tomorrow's issue.

Mayor La Guardia approved yesterday a "cost of living" pay rise of $100 a year, effective Jan. 1, for 10,300 employes of the Department of Sanitation who received an increase of $180 on July 1. The new increase was described by the Mayor as "a temporary supplement."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The President's first day back from overseas conferences was a busy one for Mrs. Roosevelt also. She met him, held a press conference and a luncheon, and went to see some crowded housing conditions in wartime Washington before hearing what he told his press conference in the late afternoon.

LUMBERTON, N.C., Dec. 17 -- The death toll in the Atlantic Coast Line double train wreck mounted today to seventy as the weary wrecking crews battled difficulties in their search for more bodies, and the task of identifying the victims made slow progress.

Japan's miscalculations regarding the war were certainly matched by our own misconception of her striking power. It led us through six months on humiliating defeat. But ours were errors of judgment, the results of which could be and largely have been remedied. Japan's miscalculations were fundamental and irremediable.

The board of directors of the Republic Aviation Corporation voted yesterday to retire on Dec. 22 the remaining outstanding 50,000 shares of second preferred stock held by Paul Moore, a director of the company, at $10 a share, it was announced by Alfred Marchev, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether the Federal Wages and Hours Act applied to persons engaged in the local distribution of newspapers from the plant of publication to dealers and newspaper racks.

A continued drop in the number of respiratory diseases here was indicated yesterday in the results of a survey of a group of 91,000 industrial, commercial, civil service and other employes by the City Health Department. The survey disclosed an absentee rate of .92 per cent, a, slight drop from the 1.13 per cent disclosed in the survey of 74,000 employes Wednesday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 17 --The issue of criminal negligence in the sinking of the Sea Scout ship Legionnaire in the Great South Bay off Sayville last April 19, in which ten Sea Scouts from Rockville Centre and vicinity lost their lives, was presented to the Suffolk grand jury in a John Doe investigation this week by District Attorney Fred J. Munder.

Despite the presence of several hundred Christmas shoppers, a Negro snatched $2,800 in cash and $2,100 in checks just before noon yesterday from inside a cashier's cage on the fifth floor of Saks-Thirty-fourth Street store and raced down the stairs to the second floor, where he escaped over the bridge leading into Gimbel Brothers on Thirty-third Street.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 17 -- A protest against the anti-Jewish campaign being carried on here by rightist and reactionary newspapers -- most of which are among the Government's stanchest supporters -- was presented today to Minister of the Interior Alberto Gilbert by Moses Goldmann and Davided Tabachman, president and secretary of the Federation of Argentine Jewish Associations.

Following two weeks in which large issues of public utility bonds were marketed, new offerings of securities declined this week to $9,522,000 for four diversified issues from $47,500,000 for three flotations last week, when one amounted to $42,000,000 in public utility bonds and $5,500,000 represented two tax-exempt loans.

A full bill of fare confronts the New York basketball fan today. There's a game scheduled at Columbia, where the Lions oppose the team representing the district office of the United States Coast Guard. And there's a game listed at City College, with the Beavers slated to do battle against the Brown University quintet.

A declaration of a state of emergency by Mayor La Guardia for both the Police and Fire Departments appeared imminent last night as Fire officials completed the draying up of a "two-platoon" chart and 14,000 members of the police force began balloting on their attitude toward doing extra duty.

BUCKO McDONALD deals in checks -- bad checks for the opposition and good checks for the New York Rangers. Bucko is the boisterous individual Lester Patrick recently obtained from the Toronto Maple Leafs to bolster the Blue Shirt defense. Before he arrived the local hockey heroes had lost every game played. Afterward they tied one and then won another, which is progress.

The response to the fats salvage campaign has been disappointing. In a new move to stimulate the saving of fats, the OPA has just put into effect an incentive plan. Henceforth, housewives will be given two brown ration points for every pound of fats delivered to dealers.

Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Office of Price-Administrator Director, disclosed yesterday that he hoped to replace with supervisors having jurisdiction over four or five local rationing boards the five county rationing administrators whose offices he abolished last Monday.

Ultimate freedom for the peoples now living in mandates and colonies was predicted last night by Wendell L. Willkie. Mr. Willkie spoke from radio station WYNC on the "Beyond Victory" program of the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation, presented in collaboration with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- The All-East team which will play an All-West squad in the annual Shrine Hospital football game in San Francisco Jan. 1 began assembling here today.

Mistakes that are evident almost as soon as new legislation has been passed or mistakes in new regulations that have been promulgated could be corrected by a simple method which would avoid seemingly endless delays.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Uncle Mark Thrash, who would have celebrated his 123d birthday on Dec. 25, died early today at his log cabin home on the Chickamauga-Chattanooga National Park Reservation.
A mother who said she could afford to give little, but gave generously in sending $5 for the Neediest Cases Fund, wrote:

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 17 -- This Christmas will be the most terrible for France in more than 100 years. "One would need a fortune to eat to one's content," writes a correspondent in Vichy, where the black market long has been a recognized institution, and the censor let the phrase go through because he agrees entirely.

A fish famine faces the North Atlantic and areas as far west as Pittsburgh unless the Office of Price Administration immediately steps in to help settle the strike of 5,000 fishermen, Arthur Coller, counsel for the Fish Fillet Dealers Association, warned yesterday.

For lack of contrary evidence the police had no right to assume that the 997 cases of liquor which Bernard Aginsky had stored in the rear of his Queens plumbing shop was intended for anything other than his personal use, Magistrate Henry A. Soffer ruled yesterday in Long Island City Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Persistent reports that at Teheran Soviet Russia was assured she would receive a free hand in northeastern Europe in return for renunciation of all ambitions for control of the Dardanelles, thus opening the way for Turkey's entry into the war, were denied today by a high official source.

AS one who has only recently had to reinvestigate children's literature, I marvel at the bloodthirstiness of the world of the brothers Grimm. In this world of prowling wolves, evil step-sisters, lying and cheating hedgehogs and kings who cast out their innocent daughters, one ceases to worry any more about the hardness of Superman.

Before the Russian armies go into Poland, the two countries should be "on speaking terms," if the Polish underground is to assist the Russians, Miss Natalia Aszkenazy, only Polish woman diplomat, declared here yesterday.

Despite a strike-caused shortage of an important plasticizer, the supply of cellulose acetate and cellulose acetate butyrate plastics is expected to meet the broader allocations of the material to fabricators of civilian items, industry officials stated yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 17 -- An unusually different kind of container for various liquids, and a new anti-hemorrhagic chemical resembling vitamin K are among the most significant of the 567 patents listed granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The right of an employer to determine the qualifications and ability of his supervisory employes and to retain them on the job despite the fact that they might be objectionable to an individual union, was upheld in a far-reaching decision today by Dean Young B. Smith of Columbia University Law School.

The safe transportation of explosives by commercial carriers under the direction of the War Department in contrast with the rising trend in accidents affecting the transportation of other war materials, was praised by leading officials in this field at the opening of the ninth regional conference on highway and motor vehicle problems called by the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation and the Council of State Governments.

Samuel Untermyer, New York attorney, who died on March 16, 1940, left a gross estate of $8,065,905 and a net of $5,177,894, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy State Tax Commissioner Louis J. Lefkowitz.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The volume of goods flowing to Russia overland via Iran has passed 70,000,000, Sir Francis Joseph, acting chairman of the United Kingdom Commercial Corporation, said today. He declared that "miracles of improvisation" had been performed to get the material in motion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Senate Naval Affairs Committee received assurance from Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, today that the Tarawa attack was "well planned and skillfully executed" together with a blunt warning that losses in such attacks in the future also would be heavy.

Refusing to indict on a bookmaking charge George Herrick, the betting commissioner who has been the chief target of Mayor La Guardia's campaign against "tin horn gamblers," the November Queens grand jury brought in a presentment yesterday recommending sweeping revision of the gambling laws to eliminate "criminal elements" in gambling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Congress moved rapidly today toward a holiday recess. It sent to the White House a bill to free social security taxes at 1 per cent for sixty days, but the Senate and House failed to agree on the time during which they would postpone the food subsidy issue.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- There was less apprehension in London tonight about Prime Minister Churchill's health, but plans were being made on the assumption that he would not be able to resume the full direction of Britain's war strategy for several weeks.

Count Fleet is the horse of the year. The colt, first to win the big four of 3-year-old racing since Sir Barton in 1919, gained 135 of a possible 143 votes from turf writers and sportscasters polled by The Turf and Sports Digest. Two of the ballots were marked for Slide Rule, two others for Market Wise, another pair left blank and the remainder went to Thums Up and Occupy, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Lemuel L. Boulware, deputy controller of shipbuilding for the War Production Board, today was named operations vice chairman of the war agency, succeeding Hiland G. Batcheller, who resigned Nov. 25.

Submission of evidence came to an abrupt end yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Dr. Aloysius M. Mulholland, 50 years old, on the first of three indictments accusing him of operating an abortion mill in his office at 403 West Forty-sixth Street.
" Pistol Packing Mama," a comedy drama produced by Republic Pictures, will open this morning at the Globe. Ruth Terry, Robert Livingston, Jack LaRue and Wally Vernon head the film's cast.
If one is sensitive to the changing stream of history there is something poignantly appealing about old cellar holes. They are part of the rich and revealing tradition of the Northeast.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Saturday, Dec. 18 (UP) -- A communique:

ON THE HUNAN FRONT, Dec. 13 (Delayed) -- While Chinese troops were pursuing the Japanese twenty miles north of Changteh, Gen. Chao Tseli, chief of staff of the Ninth War Area, explained tei day the vital importance of the Changteh victory in the early part of December.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded here:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- On the fortieth anniversary of the first flight of Wilbur and Orville Wright announcement was made tonight that their fragile craft, which has been in the British Museum, would be brought back to the United States and installed in the Smithsonian Institution.

At this season it is customary for mutual savings banks in this State to announce the rates at which they will pay interest on deposits for the last quarter, or in some instances for the final six months of 1943. Those that have been paying interest at the annual rate of 2 per cent have continued this rate with few exceptions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Nine and a half per cent of the country's total meat supply was exported to other countries under lend-lease in the first ten months of 1943, as against 6.1 per cent during the same period last year, but in compensation as reverse lend-lease substantial amounts of beef, veal, lamb and mutton were received from Australia and New Zealand, the Foreign Economic Administration said today.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 16 (Delayed) -- Mignano, gateway to Cassino, was a veritable inferno yesterday as Allied bombs, shells, tanks and infantry smashed around and into San Pietro, last great obstacle of the pass that throughout history has been a door leading to Rome.

The four-story building on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 327 West Forty-third Street has been sold by Marie Therese Kaufman to the Saint Michael's Independent Orthodox Helenic Church through Walter Samuels, Inc., brokers. This property, assessed for $32,000, was sold for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $7,000.

Mayor La Guardia's annual Christmas message, delivered in City Hall Plaza yesterday, was an appeal to the public to pray for a speedy and victorious end to the war so that Christmas in 1944 would be celebrated by and in a happier world.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 17 -- Ambitious new public housing construction programs, which are now being developed by Government housing advocates for the postwar period, must be opposed by real estate interests because they threaten private property ownership, national and State leaders of the industry told the members of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A series of four radio addresses will be made on successive Saturdays beginning Jan. 8 to acquaint the people more thoroughly with the role of the State Department in carrying foreign policy into effect.

For the first time in the brief wartime history of Government price regulations a definition of "branded lines" will be included in the revision of MPR-339 when that long-awaited change in the women's rayon hosiery price order is issued early in January by the Office of Price Administration, it was reported yesterday by producers and distributors of the product at the conclusion of a two-day conference with OPA representatives in the agency's local office.

Six East Side youths, whose ages ranged from 16 to 19 years, were arrested last night on charges of petit larceny as the result of a police investigation prompted by a December payroll shortage of $580 at the New York Hospital, 525 East Sixty-eighth Street.

CHUNGKING, Dec. 17 (U) -- A Chinese military spokesman today showed correspondents attending his press conference a captured field order al/eged/y issued by a Japanese company commander on the Tungting Lake front ordering his troops to use gas.

First survivors of the Atlantic Coast Line train wreck to reach New York last night said that they had been without light or heat for twenty-four hours between the time the accident occurred and the time they were able to resume their trip. During the entire period the temperature was below freezing and they had little to eat, they said.

Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, chairman of the City Council committee on reapportionment, complained yesterday that the task of drawing new lines for sixty-seven Assembly Districts in the city was being held up by refusal of the State Legislative Committee on Reapportionment to supply the necessary maps.

President Roosevelt is back in the White House after a journey about equal to a trip around the world at the equator. He cheerfully underwent discomforts from which not even a President can be spared in wartime air travel and he took some unavoidable risks.

ALGIERS, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- French military quarters said that the French troops in Italy are "the best we've got." Their equipment -- arms, vehicles, uniforms -- are all brand-new American products, it was said.
Promotions of five members of Doremus Co., four in the New York office and one in Boston, were announced yesterday by William H. Long Jr., president.

LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -The Ankara radio, quoting Turkish press reports, predicted today that Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr.'s American Seventh Army would strike soon in a Balkan invasion it said had been presaged by recent concentrated Allied bombings of Balkan bases.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 9 contains an article on Turkey which states that about 40 per cent of the teachers in Turkish higher institutions of learning came from Axis countries and adds that they were mostly former German bundists, suggesting that they ought to be removed now that Turkey is drawing nearer than ever to the United Nations.

A committee of the National Research Council finds itself dealing with the same hard decision that confronted, nearly forty years ago, a group of London physicians in Bernard Shaw's "The Doctor's Dilemma."
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. D. Woodward's Piccadilly led all the way today to win the first division of the featured $1,000 Kendall Purse before a crowd of 2,042.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- Capt. William P. Langheld, German intelligence officer, told a Kharkov military tribunal he had falsified and forged an affidavit asserting that twenty Russian war prisoners had attempted to lead an escape from a camp, for which false evidence the prisoners had been shot, according to a partial transcript of the testimony published in the Russian press today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Stockholders of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company -the nation's fifth largest bank -approved today an increase of $10,000,000 in the bank's capital to be effected by a 20 per cent dividend payable in stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today what the Russians said was a plot endangering his life at Teheran, the knowledge of which caused him to move his residence from the American Legation to the Soviet Embassy.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17 -- A charge that the Government of India was planning to remedy the consumer goods shortage in India by importing manufactures from Britain while curbing the development of Indian industry was contained in a resolution adopted at a meeting here of the committee of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- American submarines have sunk eight more enemy vessels in Pacific and Far Eastern waters, increasing the total of ships sunk or damaged in these areas to 524, the Navy Department announced today.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow of the Boston wool market:

Holiday trade here this week again failed to show an increase over the like period of last year, retail executives reported yesterday. The decline for department stores was put at 5 to 10 per cent under 1942. Volume slipped on Thursday particularly, compared with the comparable day a year ago when sales were the second largest of the month.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Hundreds of Lancaster bombers etched a fiery scar across the battered face of Berlin last night when the Royal Air Force returned to the task of destroying the German capital.

Warning that the chief weakness of the United Nations lies in the failure to agree on methods of dealing with Germany after the war, Mrs. Vera Micheles Dean, research director of the Foreign Policy Association, told members of the Vassar Club of New York that some sort of realistic program for solving this problem, to be administered by an international body, must be developed if World War III is to be avoided.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- News that Prime Minister Winston Churchill's condition had improved cheered the stock markets here today, but business remained quiet.

The St. Regis Paper Company has notified the New York Curb Exchange that it has offered to purchase all or any part of the outstanding minority common shares of the Taggart Corporation until 3 P.M. on Dec. 31 at $5 a share. The shares closed at that price yesterday and the range for 1943 has been 5 1/4 high to 3 5/8 low.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Capt. T.F. Reece, public relations officer at Lagarde General Hospital, said tonight that twenty-five soldiers were known to be dead as a result of the capsizing of a 60-foot cruiser-type boat on maneuvers about ten miles offshore in Lake Pontchartrain.

A drop in employment figures for October was noted for the first time this year, according to the regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, released yesterday. The reduction in the number of persons at work or in the armed forces, the study showed, amounted to 150,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Joan Fontaine and Joseph Cotten will be co-starred in "Double Furlough;" Dore Schary's initial production for David O. Selznick's Vanguard Company. The yarn will be adapted from Charles Martin's radio play about a returned soldier and his wife, recently broadcast by Gertrude Lawrence and James Cagney.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Japanese forces south of the Lin River, which twists eastward into Tungting Lake to split the Chinese "rice bowl" in half, were retiring under pressure at the rate of nine and one-half miles a day, Maj. Gen. C.C. Tseng, American-trained Chinese Army spokesman, asserted at a press conference today.

Women are now being employed as bus operators on routes of the city's transit system in Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday by an official of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit branch of the Board of Transportation.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Navy women have released for sea duty enough men to take twelve battleships to war against the enemy, according to a Navy statement announcing that on Dec. 31 the Waves will have 47,600 officers and enlisted personnel, exceeding by 300 the goal set in March.

New snow visited a number of areas yesterday in the North Country, and indications are that good skiing should be the offering at such popular havens as North Creek, Old Forge, Lake Placid and Speculator in the Adirondacks, Stowe's Mount Mansfield and Rutland's Pico Peak in Vermont and New Hampshire's Eastern Slope, Franconia Notch, Laconia-Gilford and Hanover regions.

Before farm prices started rising they were dreadfully low, but farmers generally were relatively well off. The least enthusiastic farmer could subsist on the farm about as well as elsewhere. The farm hand had shelter and three meals a day, with hunting and fishing thrown in.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) -One of the most complicated cases of utility reorganization ever dealt with by the Securities and Exchange Commission reached debate today with the commission considering eleven briefs filed in connection with a compromise plan of reorganization for the Associated

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Corporate profits in the United States both before and after taxes during the present calendar year are estimated by the Commerce Department's survey of current business to have set all-time high records.

The Federal Statutory Court that last October found certain agreements of The Associated Press in violation of the anti-trust laws refused yesterday to delay entry of its judgment long enough to allow the question of an appeal to be placed before the news gathering association's membership at its meeting next April.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today a bill to provide mustering-out pay ranging from $200 to $500, depending upon length and place of service, to honorably discharged veterans of the armed forces, men and women, up to and including the rank of colonel in the Army and Marine Corps and captain in the Navy and Coast Guard.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Heavy Liberator bombers of the American Seventh Army Air Force, making their second attack of the day, smacked the Japanese airdrome on Wotje atoll of the Marshall Islands with numerous direct hits at dusk on Wednesday.

WITH THE AMERICANS AT ARAWE, Dec. 15 (delayed) -- Two amphibious "ducks," manned by four men each and firing a new type of weapon, raced into the harbor here an hour after dawn and put the finishing touches on Japanese beach defenses in seven minutes before amphibious tanks waddled ashore to take and hold the land.
