The United States Steel Corporation will agree to union requests for the extension of present labor contracts with its steel-making subsidiaries beyond Jan. 3, the present expiration date, but is strongly opposed to a clause making any wage adjustments hereafter agreed to retroactive to that date, as demanded by the union.

Back from the West Coast, Lawrence Langner disclosed yesterday that the Theatre Guild, of which he is administrator, is negotiating to form a partnership with a Hollywood producer for the production of movie versions of Guild plays. If the deal is consummated, he said, the new firm will do two pictures a year with work starting on the first one next summer.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 -- More than 117,500 short tons of synthetic rubber chemical production annually has been added to the country's rubber program, it was announced today when it was revealed that Kobuta, the Government's newest synthetic rubber chemical plant near here, was now in full production, which is considerably in excess of the rated capacity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- A gradual change in sentiment in regard to the immediate trend of the wheat market has developed in the last two days, and with December selling around the highest prospective price ceiling and May at better than parity, a disposition has been shown to take profits on holdings and to await further developments.

ALGIERS, Dec. 17 -- Coincident with the first demonstration of French-Allied military solidarity on European soil by the appearance of French troops in the fighting line in Italy, it was learned tonight that a supreme effort was about to be made to attain political solidarity in a form that would remove all differences between the Allied Governments and Gen. Charles de Gaulle and his French Committee of National Liberation.

Tournament golf, which has been among the unmentionables since Pearl Harbor, got a vote of confidence from the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday when, at the annual meeting, held at the Hotel Commodore, it was decided to go forward almost at full tilt in 1944.

Take the case of thousands of midtown loft tenants who are in process of swallowing rent increases of 25 to 50 per cent. To smaller manufacturers struggling against diminishing sales and shortages of labor and materials such increases are next door to disaster.

The drive, sponsored by the city's newspapers, to step up the salvage of waste paper for war production gained new impetus yesterday as schools throughout the city set up collection programs in response to a directive by Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade.
If a man has any leanings toward braving the chill blasts in order to go fishing, these are the days to think about it, even if thinking about it is as far as he gets.

The struggle of the American Youth for Democracy organization to be chartered at City College's Main Center, despite attacks upon it as Communist-sponsored, made by the administration and the undergraduate newspaper, attained its first measure of success last night when the college's Student Council voted to recommend that the AYD be permitted to function on the campus.
GENERAL Mac ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Saturday, Dec. 18 (UP) -- At the invasion scene of Arawe in New Britain no additional casualties have been reported since the landing.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Fritz Schroeder of New York, former national leader of the German-American Vocational League, and three other naturalized American citizens of German birth were found guilty in Federal Court here tonight of conspiring to transmit military information to Germany in violation of the 1917 Espionage Act.

RENNERT, N.C., Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- C.G. Sibley of the Atlantic Coast Line said today that the railroad's investigation into the wrecking of two streamliner trains would be conducted in conjunction with an investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Bootlegging and black marketing in liquor, on the increase throughout most of the nation, derives far more sustenance from the diversion of legal whiskies than from illicit distilling or cutting operations, according to a twenty-seven-State survey conducted among State liquor administrators by the Allied Liquor Industries, Inc., which made public its findings yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Treasury Department came out tonight with the news that the new Federal income tax forms will go into the mails shortly after Jan. 1.

By the fury of his attack last night Sammy Angott, National Boxing Association lightweight champion, who is without recognition in this State, hammered his way to victory over Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City contender, in ten sizzling rounds at Madison Square Garden.

Specialized trading continued yesterday to form the pattern on the stock market as prices closed irregularly higher. Speculative interest was still present in the liquor issues, but late profit-taking reduced early sizable additions to fractional gains or even losses.

Two grave dangers to the democratic process have risen out of the current controversy over votes for service men and women. One of these dangers is that millions of otherwise qualified citizens, the very ones who are making the heaviest sacrifices in this war, will be for that very reason disfranchised.

With Feb. 1 now indicated as the probable effective date of the increased excise levies in the new tax bill, the belief was expressed in retail circles here yesterday that this will tend to ease difficulties in connection with lay-aways, C.O.D.'s, that would otherwise have been experienced if the taxes were to become effective on the first of the year, as originally expected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A Congressional investigation of the "appalling" number of wartime railroad accidents was asked in a resolution introduced today by Representative Louis J. Capozzoli, Democrat, of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House today from the meetings in the Middle East with Prime Minister Churchill, Premier Stalin and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, and promptly and confidently stated that his conferences with the Allied leaders had been in every way a success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House. He signed a number of bills, including repeal of the Chinese Exclusion Act, met with the Cabinet and held his press conference. His visitors included the Ambassadors of Turkey, Great Britain and China, the Egyptian Minister and representatives of the Russian Embassy and the Iranian Legation, and Secretary Hull, with whom he lunched.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- A charge that existing school agencies, such as the United States Office of Education and the State education departments, are constantly bypassed by the Federal Government in dealing with school problems, with the resultant loss of vast sums of money, was made here at the closing session of the American Vocational Association's convention.

Germany is still strong in troops, weapons, armor and industry. Her food situation is better than it was in 1918. Revolt against the Government is impossible so long as the army stands firm; and notwithstanding its setbacks in Russia, North Africa, Sicily and Italy the army shows no sign of disintegration.

Verdi's "Masked Ball," given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Vassar Club Scholarship Fund, was an uncommonly fine performance. In fact, it was so good that it freshly illuminated the opera.

Representatives of every department of the legitimate theater industry and spokesmen from other entertainment crafts, little theater organizations and drama clubs met yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor to discuss the proposed 20 per cent tax on theater tickets.
L.I.U. hung up its fourth straight triumph of the season last night, defeating the Rider College quintet, 56 -- 42, in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium, L.I.U.'s home court.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 17 -- The skies above Berlin were yellowish red this morning, reflecting fires burning after last night's RAF attack, said eyewitnesses arriving in Sweden by plane from the Reich capital.

Pre-Christmas services will be held in the churches tomorrow. Prayers will be offered that next Saturday will be the last wartime Christmas. In many city churches the 11 A.M. service will be preceded by breakfast and followed by dinner for men in the armed forces.

New York City's $17,000,000 quota in the National War Fund drive for $125,000,000 was topped not once but twice during the course of a luncheon yesterday marking the end of the city campaign, with the final total coming to $17,126,971.

The Kings County August grand jury, which recently handed up a presentment criticizing the Police Department for its failure to cope with alleged crime conditions in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area, will reconvene Jan. 10, it was learned yesterday.

The Rev. Drury L. Patchell will be celebrant of his first Christmas mass at midnight Friday as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Edward the Martyr, 12 East 109th Street, to which he recently accepted a call. He succeeded the Rev. Leslie John Alden Lang, who resigned to accept the rectorship of historic St. Peter's Episcopal Church in the Westchester section of the Bronx.

The three-story business building on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 512 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the 512 Eighty-sixth Street Corporation (Charles Kaiser, president) to a client of Joseph Silverson, broker, for cash above a mortgage of $257,000. This property is assessed for $305,000.
The decision to keep the schools of the city open despite the increase in influenza type of colds is wise. It is based on good precedent.

Looking very much like his old chipper and robust self, Edward G. Barrow, 75-year-old president of the world champion Yankees, was back at his desk yesterday for the first time since a heart attack laid him low the night of the first game of the world series.

Harry Davis, pianist from Bayonne, N.J., was heard in his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Davis disclosed a real gift for the keyboard, but his work was uneven, being at its best in slow-paced offerings like the Mendelssohn "Song Without Words" in G minor and the Chopin "Nocturne" in E minor, Op. 72, No. 1, which were well within his present limited scope as interpreter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, signed a two-year no-strike agreement today with more than two-thirds of the soft-coal industry and submitted it to the War Labor Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Sgt. Joe Louis Barrow, world's heavyweight boxing champion, will end his exhibition tour of Army posts in this country Jan. 20 and then go overseas to visit camps in various theatres of operations, it was announced today by the War Department.

ALGIERS, Dec. 17 -- A decision that reduces the area under control of the Allied military government and hands over to the Italian Government most of liberated Italy was announced today by the Allied Advisory Council for Italy. The question had been referred to the council by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 17 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels and his propaganda machine have begun preparing the war-weary German people for their gloomiest Christmas since 1939 by promising every child one toy -- and a home-made one at that.

A controversy that has been brewing since the opening two months ago of the George Washington Carver School, organized to provide adult Harlem residents an opportunity for formal education and to promote greater Negro-white unity, came to a head yesterday when six prominent educators and social workers resigned from the board of directors because they felt that the board was too much under Communist control.

W. R. Burnctt, author of "Little Caesar" and "The Quick Brown Fox," will have a new novel out Jan. 17. "Nobody Lives Forevers" Hr. Burnett's thirteenth novel, is another underworld story of crime and adventure. Knopf is the publisher.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Russian forces locked in a swaying battle for the Ukrainian industrial town of Kirovograd gained ground in one sector Friday and absorbed strong German attacks in another, Moscow announced today, while German reports told of Soviet assaults in White Russia that imperiled the German hold on the railroad city of Zhlobin and gained ground in the Nevel area.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The reluctance of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union to become entangled in the labor affairs of each other or the rest of the world has led to fear that labor interests may be left out when the post-war international boards and groups start functioning, delegates said at the meeting of the governing body of the International Labor Office here today.

The albatross which has been hovering over the good ship carrying the Giants to what they hope will be a National Football League championship, something they hadn't even dreamed of a month ago, apparently has been winged.

In one of his exuberant generalities Macaulay talks about the "attachment which every man naturally feels for his home." Unfortunately not every man has a home, and some people that have homes detest them. Luckily the majority of us think of home as a place of comfort, kindness and affection.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17 -- The sixth major German offensive against the Yugoslav Army of Liberation is now entering its third week without any signs of significant success. Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), following his usual strategy of attacking wherever possible, has started a series of counter-blows.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 -- Despite a considerably smaller than seasonal gain in retail sales, business in the Pittsburgh district head at record levels last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Moderate increases were reported in the volume of freight shipments and in industrial production.

For the second consecutive day uncertainties over the military picture combined with trade disappointment over the postponment of the Congressional vote on the subsidy issue until next February to depress the cotton market yesterday throughout a quiet session.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Dec. 18 -- As American troops eliminated all but a few Japanese snipers on Cape Merkus in the Arawe area of New Britain on Thursday, the Japanese attempted to strike back through the air.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The strategic value of the bases in the Gilbert Islands, which United States forces recently conquered after a brief though costly campaign, was emphasized today by the Navy when it announced that three airfields in the islands had been named for fallen naval and marine heroes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Anti-Franco elements in Spain have tried three times to overthrow the Generalissimo, according to reports current tonight among well-posted diplomats. Moreover, the dictator's foes were said to be persisting in their plans despite failure.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 17 -- President Roosevelt said today that there were some things he did not like about the father-draft bill which he signed while he was away, and that he would send at message to Congress on the subject.

Since next week's supply of poultry is expected to be inadequate to meet holiday demand, beef pot roast, accompanied by Yorkshire pudding, is this column's suggestion for Christmas dinner for our model family of two adults and one school-age child.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt will deliver a personal report on his trip abroad directly to the armed services and the public in a Christmas Eve broadcast, he said today.

The national headquarters of the medical division of the War Shipping Administration and the United Seamen's Service, at 107 Washington Street, a fully equipped six-story building, were dedicated yesterday in a brief ceremomy attended by nearly 200 persons, including representatives of the WSA, USS and the United States Public Health Service.
ALGIERS, Dec. 17 -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture in final figures for the year reported today that total crop production this year fell about 6 per cent below the record harvest of 1942 but topped the average of the five preceding seasons by 9 per cent.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 17 -- The recent declaration of United States Secretary of State Cordell Hull that German satellites must expect the same punishment as the Nazis still serves as the chief topic of conversation between the satellite countries' diplomatic representatives and their Turkish acquaintances here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Children's Bureau of thirteen war communities shows that working mothers should have a counseling service for general advice, and access to foster-home care at least for children under 2.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Two civilian workers, one on the swing shift while he plays golf this week, showed up the name players in the second round of the $5,000 Miami open tournament today and took over the lead.

The country is waiting for a fuller report of the historic conferences in the Middle East. Of the two questions that echo up and down the land -- When will the war end? What will come out of it? -- everyone has an answer to the first. It's the second that hangs suspended in the air, baffling and worrying a people just discovering the limits as well as the extent of its power.

The monetary gold stock of the United States apparently has passed its peak and now is declining slowly but steadily. Most of the plans advanced thus far envision the use of gold as a backing for world currencies and as a means of adjusting international trade balances.

In your editorial of Dec. 10 "World of Tomorrow" you made the point that the League of Nations scored "its most signal successes in economics and science." It may be of interest to your readers to know that such successes are still being scored, undramatically but no less surely.

FILMS of an inspirational or religious character promise to figure most importantly on studio production schedules for 1944. The trend toward this type of picture is no doubt traceable to the phenomenal reader interest in Lloyd C. Douglas' novel "The Robe," Franz Werfel's "The Song of Bernadette," and other recent best-sellers, and the industry acceptance of the tradition that during wartime there is a more general tolerance toward things spiritual.

Because of the war there will be only one Junior Assembly again this winter, the party taking place on Thursday night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton, its locale for more than a quarter of a century. This marks the third year that there will be one dance instead of the traditional three.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Harrison E. Spangler, Republican National Chairman, demanded today that the Navy make public a censored part of a letter in which Pfc. Edward Meyerson of the Marines explained to his mother his request for old Willkie campaign buttons.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 18 -- Yale's varsity basketball team managed to stave off a late rally by Harvard's informal quintet tonight and defeated the Crimson, 39 to 35.

After deliberating half an hour, a jury of eight women and four men in the Court of General Sessions yesterday afternoon convicted Dr. Aloysius M. Mulholland, 50 years old, of operating an abortion mill in his office at 403 West Forty-sixth Street.

THE brilliant entertainment which Billy Rose has presented with an all-Negro cast of singing actors and a transposition of the story of Bizet's "Carmen," set to the original music, is eloquent of several considerations that concern the essential nature of opera and its modern performance.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Sixteen points by Bill Feeney, former Georgetown University star, were a large factor in Villanova's basketball victory over the Princeton quintet today. The Wildcats won an exciting contest, 42 to 40 to remain unbeaten in four starts this season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The newest Selective Service legislation, designed to defer for last possible call the fathers of children born before Dec. 7, 1941, has eliminated some bureaucratic confusion, but done little thus far to lessen the deeper confusion in the minds of the men who presumably will benefit by it.

ANY similarity between the musical spot advertisements on the air today and songs by Shakespeare is obscure. The classic versifier never had to sell soda pop. Nor was he able to achieve a popularity equal to 300,000 performances in four years. But such is the glory of the household jingle by a broadcasting muse.

Measures to meet four major problems which will confront the American educational system at the close of the war are proposed by Dr. Edwin Sharp Burdell, Director of Cooper Union, in his annual report to the board of trustees. To do justice to demobilized veterans Dr. Burdell sees as essential the evolution of a nation-wide cooperative employment service capable of providing individual guidance as well as jobs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The first session of the Seventy-eighth Congress completed its work today and both houses passed resolutions to adjourn sine die on Tuesday and convene for the second session on Jan. 10.

CAN unemployment be prevented? My answer to that question depends on just what you mean by preventing unemployment. If you mean abolishing unemployment completely, getting every man and woman who is fit and free for work employed productively every day of his or her working life, I doubt if that can be done.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 18 -- The Brazilian Economic Convention, which has been in session since Nov. 25, ended today with the adopting of resolutions dealing with post-war economic matters.

" Westward the course of empire takes its way," wrote George Berkeley 200 years ago. Looking toward America, he thought he saw the curtain rising on the final and noblest act of Father Time's long drama. Persia and Egypt and all those ancient lands have had their day, it's true.

Heffron, executive secretary of the National Council of Catholic Men, addressed a letter today to Senator Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the committee, saying:...

The Oratorio Society of New York gave its 120th performance of Handel's "Messiah" last night, at Carnegie Hall, with the new conductor, Alfred Greenfield, formerly assistant to the late Albert Stoessel, making his first appearance in his new post.
VIRGINIA LEE BURTON has a way with such matters as tractors and steam rollers and locomotives which comes from a perfect understanding of what these mechanical contrivances mean to a child.

Dissatisfied over the delay by the Regional War Labor Board in ruling on the right of Wall Street firms to give Christmas bonuses, eighty employes of brokerage houses yesterday carried their protest directly to Charles A. Pearce, WLB stabilization director for this area.

Production of armament in Canada this year has not been as large as was projected at first, according to the annual address of S.H. Logan, president of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, delivered last week in Toronto, but the national effort as a whole was on a vastly greater scale than in 1942, with war expenditures of the Dominion 40 per cent higher at $3,947,000,000.

UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN CHINA, Dec. 17 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese campaign to capture the "Rice Bowl" in central China has cost them a "decisive defeat," toward which the American and Chinese air forces contributed materially, Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of the United States Fourteenth Air Force, said today.

EVER since "The North Star" came to town amid the more or less fervid praise of public and critics alike, Lillian Hellman has been mulling over certain personal exceptions to the film itself and, more generally, the extent of an author's rights and responsibilities in the making of a film.

THE ordinary GI doesn't get much chance to meet "The Brass" in this war, so in London he's doing the next best thing. He is going to Mme. Tussaud's famous establishment to look over Eisenhower, Stalin, MacArthur, de Gaulle and Stark in the wax.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The warmth with which the President was greeted by a miscellaneous and bi-partisan group of executive officials and members of Congress on his return yesterday from the long journey to the Middle East was more manifest and obviously greater than has ever marked his appearance in the capital. The reasons are not far to seek.

Loans, leases, purchases and sales made by the Smaller War Plants Corporation to small manufacturers to assist them in engaging in war work or the production of essential civilian items have reached a total of $50,903,184, Albert M. Carter, acting chairman of the agency, revealed yesterday.

MORIZ ROSENTHAL'S eighty-first birthday occurred yesterday. It will be recalled that Mr. Rosenthal, one of the most famous pianists of the last three-quarters of a century, was a pupil of Liszt, who died in 1886.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18 -- Addressing the Hungarian Senate on foreign policy today, Premier Nicholas von Kallay asserted that only fear of bolshevism kept Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria in a war, the alternative of which at the present juncture was unconditional surrender.

For no clear reason Mr. Moses included Photograph A as the last illustration of his recent article on the city's statues. After asking the rhetorical question "What could be worse, for example, than the new asphalt plant?" he adds that when he wrote about it to the Borough President, the latter in his reply "enclosed photographs of a model of the completed structure."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The dynamic "Labor Front" this week highlighted the threat of a country-wide railroad strike when spokesmen for five operating railroad brotherhoods fixed Dec. 30 as a strike date of 350,000 engineers, firemen, conductors, brakemen and switchmen.

A considerable literature has been written on the Star of Bethlehem, but without clearing up a mystery. If the exact date of Christ's birth were known there would be no such mystery. The date may have been as early as 11 B.C. or as late as 4 B.C.

A COMMITTEE of artists and art authorities has been organized by the College Art Association to make a practical study of art education in schools and colleges today with a view to post-war changes. Peppino Mangravite, artist-instructor at Columbia University and Cooper Union, is chairman of the committee.

Criticizing proposed legislation authorizing a $3,000,000,000 three-year Federal post-war highway program, because of "an inequitable apportionment" of Federal funds over State funds, delegates to the ninth regional conference on highway and motor vehicle problems, urged yesterday further study of "the needs of the Federal aid system of highways before proceeding with the consideration of any legislation."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -- State Department attaches and representatives of the Spanish Embassy were roaming the West this week looking into conditions at relocation and internment centers housing West Coast evacuees of Japanese ancestry.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Army and Navy boat crews scanned the waters of Lake Pontchartrain today in search of the body of one of twenty-six soldiers drowned yesterday when a sixty-six-foot whaling-type boat in a five-craft transport convoy foundered during maneuvers three miles off shore.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The operations on the Russian front, caught in the first grip of winter, slowed in tempo last week.

I have always been an admirer of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and particularly the accuracy and objectivity of both your news columns and your editorial pages. In all frankness, however, I believe you slipped somewhat from your usual high standard in the editorial in the issue of Dec. 12 entitled "Price Mismanagement."
THERE instead-of-turkey menus appear on this pageas suggestions for the Christmas day dinner. They are prompted by the fact that the bird most Americans enjoy at this season is unusually scarce.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- The last month has seen not only a considerable development in the Allied nerve-war offensive directed at southeastern Europe, as well as a definite improvement in the potential situation there, but for the first time now one is able to make out the fairly dim outlines of a blueprint for the future of this traditionally high-spirited and more than somewhat quarrelsome part of the Continent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt issued a call today to representatives of the railroads and the operating brotherhoods to meet tomorrow afternoon at the White House in an effort to avert the strike scheduled to start Dec. 30.

If roast poultry is your choice for the Christmas dinner, remember that a one-pound loaf of bread furnishes about eight cups of crumbs for the stuffing. Cook the bird in an uncovered pan at about 325 degrees F. A four-pound chicken requires thirty minutes of roasting for each pound. One weighing four and a half pounds or more will take approximately twenty-five minutes per pound.

THE song of the lathe, the clatter of the assembly line and the welding machine may be a far cry from Carnegie Hall. But take the twenty-four Slav defense workers who comprise the chorus in Michel Kachouk's Russian Opera Company -- they are equally at home with precision instruments and on the Carnegie Hall stage.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Among byproducts of the succession of Allied victories in the past year has been a stream of peace rumors through the neutral capitals.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- The Harry Percy, a Liberty freighter named for a war correspondent of The United Press, was launched today at the yards of the Houston Shipbuilding Corporation.

THE current issue of V-Disk of carols and other Christmas music is being flown overseas to make sure the records will reach the service men for the holiday season. V-Discs records are being supplied to soldiers in all commands of the United States Army throughout the world at a rate of 100,000 a month, the War Department announces, under a new program of the Music Section of the Special Services Division.
Today being the Sunday before Christmas the churches will tell the story of the coming of the Christ child in sermon, music, pageant, drama, candlelight and "white gift" services.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Raymond (Hap) Dumont, president of the National Baseball Congress, proposed today that batters be allowed to take off for either third or first base after hitting safely.

ON Dec. 13, 1774, Paul Revere rode out from Boston to warn the settlers that the British were coming. The time was four months before the "shot heard 'round the world"; his destination was not Lexington but Portsmouth, N.H.

Making up a first-half deficit of eighteen points, the United States Coast Guard District Office five managed to shade Columbia on the letter's court last night, 46 to 45. A shot from the middle of the floor, about forty seconds from the end, pulled the game out for the team, which had been a strong favorite before the game.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- The peak of America's war production in almost every item is past, Henry J. Kaiser told The United Press today in an interview in which he asserted that the time had come to begin the task of shifting back to peacetime economy of efficiency in production.

The task of transporting the bulk of materials and men needed on the various fronts, carrying the equipment to build their own ports as they penetrate strange territory and also bring along much of the equipment needed for the unloading of these supplies for our armed forces would make peacetime steamship management wince, yet this job is being handled very successfully by our American shipping companies, the American Merchant Marine Institute declared last week.

The barroom situation has come to a bad pass, Anthony Stucchio, a war worker, said in Brooklyn Weekend Court yesterday, when a man who stops in on a cold night for a nip of warmth doesn't get any protection against a woman drinker who chooses to assail him.

Patulin, chemistry's newest and most startling medical discovery, may turn out to be an effective weapon in combating the common cold. It is derived from the mold that produces penicillin, which has proved invaluable when the sulfa drugs failed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The mass-production facilities of the United States were in full swing this month spewing forth aircraft, tanks, ships, guns, ammunition and a host of other necessaries of war at a rate which amazed even those Government officials who drew up the optimistic production schedules for the war-converted industrial set-up last January.

THERE is one simple fact about "Swing, Sister Wac, Swing," due to open here on Christmas Eve, that has already drained the market of all prognostications of the show's failure. There is a harem scene in which a dozen of the loveliest Wacs in North Africa sport gauzy pantaloons and bare midriffs.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 18 -- The American landing this week upon New Britain, biggest island of the Bismarck Archipelago, marked the third move within a few weeks in the new Pacific offensive in which we have clearly wrested the initiative from the Japanese in a considerable part of this big ocean.

ON Monday of next week the Radio City Music Hall will enter upon its twelfth year as the "showplace of the nation." That slogan, if anything, is an understatement. For the mammoth Music Hall, seating capacity 6,200, is nothing short of a phenomenon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt expressed pride today in the American press and radio for keeping faith and observing international agreements relating to release dates for news on his recent trip, but expressed regret "that such loyalty should have been penalized by failure elsewhere."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The run of colds, grippe and other respiratory ailments, which since Thanksgiving has given the country its worst influenza scare since 1918, continues to be a matter of nation-wide concern, although in many areas, particularly in the East, the epidemic is reported to have spent its main force.

THE other day I watched Eddie and Bob carry a drop table into the secretary's office at the City and Country School in New York City and methodically and deftly fasten it to one of the side walls. I was witnessing members of the school's War Work Squad, Carpentry Section, in action.

NAPLES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Italian Committee of National Liberation, in the most serious controversy yet to arise between it and the Allied Military Government, charged today that the AMG, in banning a scheduled Italian political congress, had violated the Allies' Moscow conference pledges of free speech and assembly.

A NEWCOMER to philately is Duke Peter II, whose bearded likeness is within an oval on a regular series issued by Montenegro, which he ruled in 1830-51. The main design is a landscape with a background of mountains.

Can alcohol be successfully made from the waste sulfite liquor of wood-pulp plants? According to Chemical and Engineer News the cost of alcohol produced from pulp waste is 18 to 20 cents a gallon. The pegged Government price is approximately 50 cents. Plans of the pulp companies follow those successfully carried out in Sweden, where, it is said, 12,000,000 gallons of alcohol annually are produced by the pulp industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The United States destroyer O'Bannon is back from fourteen months in the south Pacific with a record of participating in five major engagements and helping to sink a Japanese battleship, three cruisers and six destroyers.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Tokyo and recorded by The United Press:

HOLIDAY trade has reached its closing days with a continuation of the slackening pace that was noted several weeks ago. The big increases were established in November, and most retailers can put away their earlier fears that they would enter the new years with empty shelves.

Again and again the Japanese have overrun this rice bowl, only to be driven out. Another major battle there appears to be ending in Japanese defeat after one of the bloodiest campaigns of the Far Eastern war.

OUTSIDE the commanding general's quarters on Guadalcanal in the Solomons was a crude board bench, knocked together from pieces of a packing box that had been left behind by the Japanese when the United States Marines landed on that steam-heated island paradise in the south Pacific on Aug. 7, 1942.

ALGIERS, Dec. 18 -- In southern Italy people have always liked the sun better than politics. When many of them face grave food and shelter problems, as now, their interest in politics drops even lower.

The Nativity scene whicl has attracted huge crowds to the DisI play House of the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, during the Christmas holidays will be repeated this year. Owing to last year's fire, the usual flower dis-i play will be omitted, but more space will be given to the tableau, i

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Results today assured a stirring finish to the League North soccer championship Christmas Day. Four teams, separated by only one point, share the first four places. Blackpool and Manchester United, Liverpool and the Doncaster Rovers compose this group.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Two Fedoeral court cases, separated by the breadth of the country, but both victories for the Securities and Exchange Commission, provided a curious twist last week in the matter of prices charged to customers by over-the-counter dealers.

CARRIE M'MAHON has written a book about the Japanese. She is known as Carol Bache to the readers of The Atlantic Monthly, as Carrie MacMahon to the even wider circle of Americans and Europeans who knew her in Tokyo.

ON the basis of experience in seeking to prevent the wartime use of stamp collecting in ways inimicable to the national interest, the Philatelic Unit of the Office of Censorship has made a number of changes in the regulations originally set up, and a summary of these was made public last week for the guidance of collectors and dealers who have international dealings in stamps.

The Balkan peninsula, Europe's causeway to Asia Minor, plays an important part in Germany's war effort. It furnishes most of the natural oil for German planes and tanks, some of the metals used in German factories, much of the wheat and grain consumed by Germans.

Christmas trade here last week again failed to rise above the sales totals of the like week of 1942, according to local merchants' estimates. Department store volume, it was indicated, ran from 5 to 10 per cent under a year ago, while recent gains of specialty shops also were cut sharply.
New partners to be admitted at the year end by firms which have membership in the New York Stock Exchange include the following:

Every agency concerned with war production and transportation is coming to realize the absolute necessity of keeping at least the irreducible minimum of passenger cars and trucks rolling. The Office of Defense Transportation and the Brookings Institution have agreed that, with respect to cars, this should not fall below 20,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Americans are more bothered over butter than over any other wartime shortage, with annoyances over meat, sugar, soap and canned goods following, than -- at a much lower level -- by lack of elastic, galvanized ware, underwear and alarm clocks, a WPB survey revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Completion of virtually all of the capital facilities required by the United States to win the war was indicated today when President Roosevelt signed an executive order transferring certifying authority for tax amortization privileges from the Secretaries of War and Navy to the chairman of the War Production Board.

In announcing the retirement yesterday of 125 members of the Department, Commissioner Patrick Walsh said that 238 applications for pension now remained for consideration at the next meeting of the Fire Department Pension Board on Dec. 27.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Dec. 18 -- French troops were solidly in the line today and "rarin' to go" after a relief operation that presented considerable difficulties had been brilliantly overcome.

A decision of the Court of Appeals, handed down on Dec. 2 in the case of Pierne vs. Valentine, has stripped the Police and Fire Departments of disciplinary control over all members with sufficient service to be eligible for retirement, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

From the bloody stalemates of World War I sprang the new mechanized war of movement, which in German military theory involved the use of armored spearheads to crash through and overwhelm enemy defenses. Early in the Russian war it became clear that the Red Army had a different idea.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 18 (AP) -- One of Berlin's largest munitions factories in the western suburb of Babelsberg was blown up in the RAF's Thursday night bombing, a Swedish engineer just returned from the Reich capital said today.

SUMNER'S "Short History of Russia" is the realization of the modern historian's dream. The tendency of our age to place emphasis on the living present and to look at its problems in institutional and genetic terms has begotten the theory that perhaps history should be written in reverse.

DESPITE the implication of its title, Mr. Taubman's new book is concerned rather less with music than with musicians. The author himself, after having accused the musical public of a similar distortion of relative values, cheerfully admits it.

YULETIDE CHEER. In spite of the "tinsel shortage," the "silverfoil shortage," the "ribbon shortage" and a horde of other new shortages that the season has revealed, Christmas trimmings can be just as bright and festive as ever before. And a lot more interesting.

City College will be almost doubled in size after the war with the addition of a huge seven-story building to be erected at the main center in Convent Avenue at a cost of $8,000,000, according to plans sent yesterday to the City Planning Commission by a joint committee of the Board of Higher Education and the general faculty.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 18 -- The triennial conference of the Australian Labor party, which has been in session here this week attended by six delegates from each State in the Commonwealth, is the governing body of the Labor party. It is the one authority to which the Australian Labor Government must give an account of its stewardship and from which it must take instructions.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18 -The German occupants in France are being drawn against their wills into the struggle between the Vichy government and the resistance movement. The Germans would have preferred to remain on the sidelines while the French police fought the saboteurs but resistance, however, has taken such an aggressive form that the German High Command can no longer feign to ignore it.

" PARIS," the loan exhibition at the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, for the benefit of which organization it was arranged, is at once spirited and heterogeneous, containing admirable work and much that is merely "atmospheric" or "curious."

TEAPFEES: The head-hunting tribes of Kachins who populate the hills of Northern Burma were last week reported to be hunting Japanese in true native fashion. Their modus operandi was to ambush the enemy first, then snare, him using an elephant trap of many pits dug across trails and the near-by jungle.

NO. 9 LEXINGTON AVENUE, built by the celebrated Peter Cooper, was for generations a center for whatever was best in New York life. Here lived his son-in- law Abram S. Hewitt, with his family of six children, Amy, Sarah, Eleanor, Cooper, Edward and Erskine.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- Germany was reported tonight to be appealing for Hungarian help in subduing the fighting Yugoslavs, and observers said the early Winter Nazi offensive in Yugoslavia, stalled before fierce Partisan counter-attacks in nearly every sector, was crystallizing into a battle for strategic Bosnia.

IF you believe what you hear on the radio -- and an astonishing number of people do believe what they hear there -- this will be the happiest Christmas, coast to coast, since 1940. In 1941 the shock of Pearl Harbor was heavy on the land; and last year, though the shadows had begun to lift, few could pretend that it was the feast day they had known in other, better times.

Frost deepens in the earth and primal forces gather strength as winter tightens its hold upon the land. Now comes the time when the very mists shall rend the rocks apart. The feathery snow shall gouge new valleys in the hills and the adamantine mountains yield to the subtle strength of their own cloud wreaths.

Nicolas Kopeikine, the Russian pianist, pupil in former days of Sokoloff and Lianpunoff in St. Petersburg, when the city was so named, and now a disciple of Isidore Philipp, at present of this city, gave a recital of high excellence last night in Town Hall.

War has not only turned the nation's schools and departments of journalism over to the women for the duration, but has reduced their enrollments, their faculties and their course offerings, and altered their relationship to the country's press. Men are as rare today in journalism classrooms as women once were in the city rooms of newspapers.

St. John's and N.Y.U. met and passed their initial Madison Square Garden basketball tests last night when, before a crowd of 13,457 persons, the Redmen conquered the University of Detroit, 44 -- 31, and the Violets downed St. Francis of Brooklyn, 52 -- 30.

WELCOME indeed to those who are constantly searching for more artistic line and color combinations in flower arrangements is the idea recently introduced by a firm of growers. Appropriately named "matched mates," this idea suggests combining species and varieties of flowers diametrically opposite in shape of bloom, habits of growth and foliage, yet identical in color tone.

While a trifle belated, the kennel world will welcome the New Year will a triple celebration on Sunday, Jan. 9. The big noise will be created by the Pekingese Club of America, the American Spaniel Club and the American Boxer Club, all having scheduled their annual specialty shows for that day and in this city.

THIS book has figured in the curriculum of history classes in England for two generations and more, but has by no means grown stale. It is as invigorating as ever and packed with drama on every page, the whole illuminated by Creasy's brilliant comments.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- At Moscow last Sunday Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Commissar for Foreign Affairs, and Zdenek Fierlinger, Ambassador to Russia of the Czechoslovak Republic, signed a twenty-year agreement of friendship, mutual assistance and post-war collaboration between their two countries. In so doing they turned a spotlight on the troubled affairs of eastern Europe.

THIS book, like all that Jacques Barzun has written, uses the history of ideas, not as a mere fascinating pastime or as a display of scholarship but as an instrument for clarifying the confusions of contemporary thought.

ONE of the most eagerly awaited books of the coming new year is the George Santayana autobiography, which Scribner's will publish on Jan. 7. The volume covers the first twenty years of the philosopher's life, from his birth in Spain some eighty years ago to his graduation from Harvard.

Last Friday as he stepped from his car at the White House President Roosevelt was met by a welcoming delegation which included virtually every important figure in the Government. Members of both parties joined in an ovation. After exchanging pleasantries with Cabinet members and Congressmen the President spied the White House butler, who doubles as barber.
Miss Frances P. Clucas has come from Washington to the Weylin, where she joined her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 18 -- Costly as the conquest of Tarawa was to the Second Marine Division, the atoll was worth the price paid and there was no way to buy it more cheaply, Maj. Gen. Holland McT. Smith, who commanded the marines and other ground forces in the Gilbert Islands' invasion last month, said here today in an interview reviewing the operation.

Andrew Jackson High's tossers, city finalist last season and a participant in the P.S.A.L. play-offs the last five seasons, served notice that they will again be a contender for the city title yesterday when they routed Far Rockaway High, South Queens foe, 43 to 28, in the feature attraction of the scholastic basketball quintuple-header at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Maritime "M" awards for outstanding production performance have been presented to seven manufacturing companies and two shipyards, the Maritime Commission announced today.

Councilman Stanley Isaacs, Manhattan Republican, served formal notice on Mayor La Guardia yesterday that minority members of the new City Council would not follow him "in blind loyalty" because they felt that he "varies in loyalty to himself and the things he used to stand for."
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Well, after all, Lieut. Col. Edgar W. Garbisch, three times West Point All-America center, won't have to keep his date with the business end of the Navy's goat.

Tlae Chinese High Command ann0unced yesterday in Chungking that Japanese attacking northwesterly from the "Rice Bowl" town of Lihsien had been routed, losing more than 400 killed, according to a broadcast recorded by United States monitors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The astounding antics of the Tokyo radio, which today sinks all our ships and decimates all our troops but tomorrow confesses to its people that the Japanese Navy no longer has the war situation under "complete control" have convinced official observers here that Japan's leaders realize at last that they no longer can be victorious.

American and British labor must have some voice in helping to determine the Allied Military Government's labor policy if the liberated peoples of Europe are to have confidence in AMG decisions, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Italian-American Labor Council, 218 West Fortieth Street.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Johnny Bulla of Atlanta turned in a sizzling 31, 34 -- 65, five under par and one over the course record, in the third round of the $5,000 Miami open golf tournament today, but it was not good enough to overtake flying Steve Warga Jr., the swing-shift leader.

The first of a series of four jazz concerts was presented at Town Hall yesterday afternoon under the direction of Eddie Condon, who directed a similar series at the same hall last season. As was the case with his previous programs, Mr. Condon assembled a group of musicians from the top ranks of the field, and turned them loose for an altogether informal afternoon.

Brown University's basketball team came through with a 66-61 overtime victory over City College on the Beavers' court last night. Trailing at the half by 26 to 23, and behind by nine points at one time during the second half, the visitors spurted to take a lead, 56 -- 48, with about two minutes left.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A secret session of the International Labor Organization will be held tomorrow at which the subject of Russia probably will be discussed. Ever since it was decided that Soviet membership hinged on participation in the League of Nations rather than in a special category like that enjoyed by the United States, the ILO has been embarrassed by the problem of how to reintroduce the Russians.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Prices of wheat held within relatively narrow limits today on the Board of Trade here, with evening-up operations in December a feature, commission houses being on both sides of that contract. An early break of around 1/2 cent a bushel was followed by a rally on short covering in sympathy with an upturn in Rye, and closing trades were 1/8 cent lower to 1/8 cent higher than yesterday.

JOHN MACVANE is one of the National Broadcasting Company's ace foreign correspondents. An experienced newspaper man before turning to radio, he has seen much of World War II. He was in London during the nightmare called "the blitz" and he was in one of the boats that headed across the English Channel on that daring and costly raid at Dieppe.

Arthur A. Ballantine, president of the Greater New York Fund, yesterday announced the formation of a committee of twenty-three community leaders under the chairmanship of Earl B. Schwulst, first vice president of the Bowery Savings Bank, to distribute the proceeds of the fund's annual campaigns.
ALGIERS, Dec. 18 -- The battle of Italy, in a sense, tended yesterday to become two distinct actions -- one for the Ortona-Orsogna road and one for the tiny village of San Pietro Infine.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, pointed out yesterday that elimination of the list of non-deferrable jobs, as provided for in the Father Draft Bill recently signed by President Roosevelt, in no way exempts workers in those occupations from the provisions of the WMC area stabilization programs.

DETROIT, Dec. 18 -- Whether Detroit in the early post-war period will be a city of assembly lines or a city of bread lines depends largely on how quickly the automobile industry will be able to reconvert from a war to a peace time economy.

HERE, heavy in my hand, is a thick red book, a book that nobody is going to get for Christmas because it is long out of print. I wish someone would publish it again, with Andrew Lang's beautiful introduction.

TORONTO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs vaulted into sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Black Hawks, 8 -- 4, before 8,618 fans who watched youthful Johnny Marois give a fine performance in his first appearance as Toronto net-minder.

AFTER months of repeating the statement in various parts of the country, this correspondent has yet to hear anyone disagree with the assertion that relations between its white and Negro populations constitute the greatest social problem confronting the United States today or likely to confront it after the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Assurance that he would do all in his power to get a bill to provide mustering-out pay for members of the armed forces to the floor by Jan. 15 was given today by Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, majority leader.

IN this column last summer there was a discussion of the slam-bidding method used by most Eastern experts. This method is best known as "cue-bidding," and those who use it are likely to speak disdainfully of the Blackwood and similar artificial slam tries used by the average player.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 19 -- The Fourth Ukraine Military Tribunal sitting at Kharkov convicted four men -- one a Russian traitor -- in the first war criminal trial of World War II today and sentenced them to death by hanging on charges that they had participated in the mass slaying of Russian prisoners and civilians.

The outbreak of influenza and other respiratory ills that has had this city and a large part of the nation in its grip for two weeks continued its slight recession of the last few days yesterday, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, reported. He warned, however, that the epidemic may still reach a new peak.

A FEW days ago a great radio inventor said, "After two years of intensive wartime development we engineers have made the discovery that radio is not old, but is in its 'very young youth.' Today we know that not one structure but whole new avenues of 'radio mansions' are going up at once, radically different from anything we have seen before."

War or no war, the work of the late Ivan Pavlov goes on in Soviet Russia. His camouflaged research institute at Koltushi, a little village near Leningrad, may be a little more dismal than it was in happier times, but there is nothing dismal about the scientists who are carrying out his program.

CHARLES DICKENS' "A Christmas Carol" completes its first century this month and enters its second as the most popular piece of writing, except only the story of the Nativity, in all Christmas lore. This week, by old and fond custom, it will be read, or quoted, or at least recalled with affection in most homes in the English-speaking world.

The effect of the news of the threatened railroad strike on our service men can only be "demoralizing," Rabbi Joseph Zeitlin said in a sermon in Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- An apparently organized campaign for a negotiated peace which would save Germany and Japan from the consequences of Allied invasions has been started in letters to members of Congress signed by George W. Hartmann, chairman of the "Peace Now Movement," it was disclosed tonight.

THE Christmas spirit, be it Santa or whoever, is delving deep into those seasonal pockets for as many of the usual miracles as possible this year. And there may be cases when the hands that should bring forth the traditional Yuletide tree will be empty, at least so far as a cut and ready-to-bring-home tree is concerned.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A young Russian mechanic, who admitted betraying his country, testified at Russia's first war criminal trial that he had aided the Germans in slaughtering sixty children between the ages of 6 and 12, the Moscow press reported today, while a German defendant told a packed, shuddering courtroom how the Nazis systematically had killed thousands of innocent Russians by gas, machine-guns and torture.

THE phenomenon of genius suggests an element of the miraculous which evades any ultimate definition or analysis. Although its origins are one of the secrets of nature, its motivations, like the human characteristics attributed to birds and beasts in fables, are often interpreted according to a reduced level of experience.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- At the annual American Vocational Association convention 2,000 teachers, administrators and school experts spent the major part of their deliberations in discussing post-war educational problems that this country is expected to face when peace comes.

RENNERT, N.C., Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- The engineer of the Atlantic Coast Line's Tamiami East Coast Champion, who declares he was ill with influenza when his train crashed into a sister train and killed at least seventy service men and civilians, said today that he did not have a "Chinaman's chance" to avert the wreck.

FOR the "forgotten woman" -- the hasty scrawl at the bottom of your Christmas list, or the one that is suddenly remembered at 3 A.M. of some sleepless night -- we present a series of last-minute gifts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania rang up a 57-51 Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League triumph over Cornell tonight at Convention Hall. Penn's victory came despite the spectacular opposition of Bob Gale, Cornell's freshman center, who sank ten of the Red and Blue's twenty-five field goals.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Dec. 19 -- The American Sixth Army drove one mile forward in New Britain Island under a heavy air cover to seize the village of Umlingolu and much enemy war equipment, it was announced today.

Youthful veterans of fifty or more bombing missions each, Maj. Clarence L. Thacker and Lieut. William S. Kent, Army Air Force pilots, described yesterday the rigors of the air war over Europe and in the Mediterranean area and the sheer luck that brought them unscathed through flak and vicious fighter interception.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 -- Mrs. E.L. Mulrenan's favored First Fiddle came from behind in the stretch to win the $15,000 added Louisiana Handicap today, the first major stake test of the winter season at the Fair Grounds. Eight thousand five hundred saw the race.

The office of Pride Administration may issue more complaints alleging violation of the "no higher price line" limitation of MPR 330, according to reports in trade circles here at the week-end. It was recalled that recently the OPA has been making a survey of some fifty-six concerns, including some chains and independent stores.

HOPE BRISTER WATKINS enters into the spirit of these folk tales of animals, taken from a wide range of European sources, with the same zest and imagination that she showed in a delightful little volume of stories from Herodotus retold for children, which appeared some ten years ago.

A PLEASANT little book, filled with the Christmas spirit, which tells how Clement Moore's famous poem, "A Visit From St. Nicholas," came to be written -- and suggests the New York of 1823, when Dr. Moore lived in the district we still call Chelsea, in those days well out in the country.

One of the great difficulties about a grand alliance is that one member or another sometimes feels that he is bearing a disproportionate share of the burden necessary for the common victory. So it was for a long time with Russia. With the Red Armies struggling desperately against almost the whole weight of the Nazi Wehrmacht it was only natural that the Russian people should look longingly westward for help.

WHEN I told my wife I had this book for review she chuckled and said: "This ought to be good. You know nothing about bridge, and what does he know about power politics?" Aware that he is "typed" by success at cards, Mr. Culbertson begins his book with proof that he is entitled to play a hand for the stakes of diplomacy.

For the holiday entertaining of juniors in society several subscription dances are in prospect. Tomorrow afternoon the first of two Mayfair Senior Dances under the direction of Miss Louise Irwin and Miss Ethel Clark will be held in the Neptune Room of the Pierre.

Open house will be observed Christmas Day at the Maple Leaf Service Club, 601 Fifth Avenue, for service men of the United Nations. The special fete, which will be held from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M., will be under the supervision of a group of women headed by Mrs. John Rousmaniere.

A NEW musical comedy, "Dream With Music," is in the works and Richard Kollmar, its producer, expects it to open at the Shubert in Boston on the evening of April 10. Mr. Kollmar has more than a financial interest, for his wife, who writes under the name of Dorothy Kilgallen, helped write the book.

Stocks registered selective gains yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing irregularly higher on the largest Saturday volume in a month. Transactions involved 482,630 shares, comparing with 424,300 a week before.

Act 3 in the gridiron melodrama "Who Goes There?" -- there meaning out West to Chicago to play the Bears for the National Football League championship a week hence -- will be performed at the Polo Grounds today before a tense and densely packed audience of more than 50,000.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Excess profits totaling $34,000,000 will be refunded to the Government by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, R.L. Fletcher, company comptroller, told a regional chapter of the National Association of Accountants last night.

For most of us the winter holidays are a season when we draw closer to those we love. The temperature may be low and the winds blustery, but there is a warmth in people's hearts, of which the hearth fire is only a symbol. This year millions of families know what it is to be separated and to be worried about those who are absent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The economic situation of the 15,000,0O0 white-collar and professional workers whose salaries have remained fixed while the cost of living has risen will be investigated at Jan. 25-27 hearings of the Senate Special Subcommittee of Wartime Health and Education.

Many items were active in volume Christmas trade in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Handbag, jewelry, hosiery, stationery, glove, toiletry and lingerie departments were jammed.

The recently announced programs of two distilling companies to distribute substantially all their whisky inventories, one by dividend and the other by purchase "rights," have been questioned by public authorities, who fear the distributions might place substantial quantities of whisky in the hands of persons unauthorized to deal in liquor and unfamiliar with laws governing its purchase and sale.
Gunder Haegg, Swedish runner with the violinist's hair cut, is 1943's athlete of the year.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The railroad walkout scheduled to begin Dec. 30 would go into effect first on major systems serving vital industrial areas, a "strike blueprint" sent to members of the operating brotherhoods showed today.

Last week in the Southwest Pacific the Allies struck a new, hard blow at the Axis enemy. New Britain Island, key to Japan's position over a large area, was invaded. In a theatre in which ground action had long been limited, sea, air and land forces were suddenly brought to bear in a new demonstration of the strength the Allies have marshaled.

" For the first time since Pearl Harbor the college graduate cannot find a bargain on the job counter," Miss Edith G. Stedman, Director of the Radcliffe College Appointment Bureau, said in a survey comparing calls in the six weeks preceding the May and November graduations at Radcliffe.

ALTHOUGH not technically a poem, "Give Us This Day * * *" invites comparison with the most famous of all poems about agriculture. Virgil in his "Georgics" dealt with ancient Italy, and Miss Leighton writes of the contemporary United States, but they share many qualities.

With Miss Patricia Potter as chairman, a group of debutantes of the season has been organized to assist with plans for the performance of "Carmen Jones" on Jan. 7 at the Broadway Theatre, which will be a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau, Department of Labor, said today that in November, 33,142 applications had been approved granting Federal aid in providing maternity and infant medical care for families of enlisted men in the four lowest pay grades of the military services. On Dec. 1 the total cases approved were 131,460.

Bitter night wind swept the pier, but the sunburned Navy Seabees shouting down from their docking transport had more important matters than the weather on their minds. Coming home -- in time for a Christmas leave at that -- after ten months in the Mediterranean theater, they poured forth a jumble of questions to the Red Cross Canteen workers and reporters waiting to greet them.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 18 -- The second Swedish note to the German Foreign Office on the arrests and deportations of University of Oslo professors and students was delivered on Thursday and published today.

" POETRY," remarks Max Eastman in a passage quoted in today's Treasure Chest, "is unconditionally upon the side of life." That is, it seems to me, a deeply true and suggestive observation, and one which applies not to poetry alone, but to the best in literature.

Condemning theories of natural conflict between urban and rural interests being taught in Indiana State universities, I.H. Hull, president of National Cooperatives, Inc., and general manager of the Indiana Farm Bureau Cooperative Association, predicted yesterday future success for city "co-ops" equal to that of country groups.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Black Badge, an ebony-hued son of Cohort who probably will fly Abe Hirschberg's silks in Hialeah's Flamingo Stakes, began his winter campaign with an easy victory in the Key West Handicap at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The length of the American working week was brought up again by the Maritime Commission's recent order that will end as of Jan. 1 all Sunday work in shipyards. How long a week do the 65,000,000 men and women in our work force put in at their lathes and drills, their benches and machines?

FOR some time now the nightly divertissement at the Riobamba has consisted of one or two well-known acts or personalities. Within a fortnight, however, a radical change will take place in that spot's entertainment policy.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 19 -- Russian forces in the southern Ukraine have captured several enemy strong points, killed 1,400 Nazis and wrecked twenty-eight enemy tanks in the Kirovograd area, Moscow announced today, while Berlin admitted a breakthrough by 250,000 Russian troops storming westward in the Nevel area seventy miles from the Latvian border.

American importers have begun a concerted campaign to obtain a thorough overhauling of the administrative provisions of the tariff law in order to meet the trading conditions of the post-war period, it was learned yesterday. The effort, which implements a declaration on the subject unanimously adopted at the recent National Foreign Trade Convention, is supported by foreign traders generally, and is being coordinated by the National Council of American Importers.

DORIS HUMPHREY and Charles Weidman will open their annual repertory season at their Studio Theatre in West Sixteenth Street some time in January. The date depends largely upon when Mr. Weidman and several members of the supporting company can get their extra-curricular assignments in Broadway shows finished and settle down to final polishings of the repertoire.

" GOOD bless us, everyone," prayed the little crippled child in Dickens' beloved Christmas story. His words express, as well as words can do, the universal friendliness of Christmas: To everyone good-will. And if to everyone, then surely to the Neediest, those in our fellowship of common humanity who, above all others, need friends.

With 13-year-old William Balash of 400 Seventy-first Street in the role of Grandpa Poland, "Christmas Around the World," the third program in the young people's series, "Fun With Book People," was held at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday morning.

The Kollmorgen Optical Corporation gave a dinner-dance last night in honor of its 1,000 em ployes for winning the third Army-Navy E award for excellence in war production at the Columbus Club Hotel, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The armed services and civilian agencies sharpened up some new slogans today to draw about 2,000,000 more women into war work.
