FAMILIARITY with Christmas song and legend adds much to deepen and enrich the meaning of the holiday season. Thus new Christmas anthologies are welcome because they emphasize the quantity and variety of verse and story available, and, though most of the material included is usually familiar, each compiler is likely to add one or two lesser known selections.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Serious fears were expressed by France as early as 1929 over the prospect of an alliance between Germany and Italy, according to diplomatic papers published by the State Department tonight.

ONE of the most individual artists in the Grand Central Galleries group, Carl Wuermer, is exhibiting recent paintings at the Vanderbilt Avenue quarters of that institution. Wuermer is a meticulous craftsman who infuses his detailed realism with a personal lyric quality.

THE Sunday drama section of Nov. 21 carried the first announcement of Alfred de Liagre Jr.'s production of Mr. van Druten's "The Voice of the Turtle." Mr. de Liagre's ad was a charming one -- and then one's attention focused upon its opening-night seat tariff -- and it became considerably less charming. $5.50 to $2.20 -- mighty fancy prices, Mr. de Liagre.

TONIGHT will see the start of Christmas festivities at some of the resorts with others falling into line as Saint Nick's gala day draws nearer. Carols and eggnog parties, mistletoe and long, fat stockings are features of the merrymaking at public hostelries as well as at private homes with the emphasis on the traditional tree and turkey dinner.

Bolstered by the addition of two newcomers to the team, the Rangers will tackle the Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Blueshirts, now that victory no longer is an unknown quality to them, have been awaiting the contest with confidence, and they are hopeful of scoring over the world champions.

Activity in the wholesale markets slackened last week because of the usual pre-holiday lull, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevy, Werring Howell, Inc. Christmas wholesale business is virtually finished and the various markets are now looking forward to new allotments after Jan. 1, the report noted.

Several dinner parties were given last evening in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis before the Mayfair Assembly. Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Banks of Hewlett, L.I., entertained for their daughter, Miss Emilie Banks. Miss Carolyn Mackie, daughter of Mrs. Van Cortlandt Mackie, had as her guests Miss Ann Welling and Miss Barbara Rutherfurd.

Bolstered by the addition of two newcomers to the team, the Rangers will tackle the Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Blueshirts, now that victory no longer is an unknown quality to them, have been awaiting the contest with confidence, and they are hopeful of scoring over the world champions.

Activity in the wholesale markets slackened last week because of the usual pre-holiday lull, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevy, Werring Howell, Inc. Christmas wholesale business is virtually finished and the various markets are now looking forward to new allotments after Jan. 1, the report noted.

Several dinner parties were given last evening in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis before the Mayfair Assembly. Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Banks of Hewlett, L.I., entertained for their daughter, Miss Emilie Banks. Miss Carolyn Mackie, daughter of Mrs. Van Cortlandt Mackie, had as her guests Miss Ann Welling and Miss Barbara Rutherfurd.

The season's first "Tannhaeuser," given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, marked the return of Marjorie Lawrence, whose superb singing as Venus brought her a protracted ovation of unusual fervor after the first act.

After early irregularity caused by commission-house liquidation and spot-firm selling, the cotton futures market recovered yesterday in late trading on New Orleans buying. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts ended the short session at gains of 1 to 5 points, with the strength in the near positions.

With gifts that betoken the spirituality of Christmas the thirty-second annual appeal on behalf of the Neediest families and individuals in the city known to eight leading private family-welfare organization rounded out its second week with a total of 4,891 contributors who have given $157,553.69.
What goes on behind the scenes in Germany?

Five hundred million dollars worth of ships, consisting of 145 assorted craft, headed by a fighting fleet of forty-five destroyers, have been built at the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's shipyards since this country entered the war, according to a statement made last week by Lynn H. Korndorff, president of the company.

ALGIERS, Dec. 18 -- Though a communique made no mention of it, it is understood the French Committee of National Liberation agreed today on a scheme for elections in France but will not make the plan public before it is submitted to the consultative assembly in January.

IN this story of the American people from 1865 to 1941 we have an excellent chance to test the effectiveness of what seems an ideal formula for a "popular" history. The Hayward-Hamilton book has everything likely to appeal to the average reader, except a sustained love story.

THROUGH the skylight of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's borrowed villa here, you can see the Tricolor on the roof whipping in the breeze from the harbor far below. On brisk days you can actually hear it, too. It is said by his intimates that the general himself always hears it, that he is as closely attuned to the needs of his oppressed homeland as if he maintained telepathic connection.

Secretary of War Stimson has announced that candidates in next year's election campaign, including Presidential nominees, will not be entitled to travel priorities on the airlines. Mr. Stimson points out that such priorities are reserved for persons contributing to the war effort.

Speaking of the third Victory Rally of this season, broadcast over the Blue Network and sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally Committee, Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State and American representative on the Council of the United Nations Rehabilitation and Relief Administration, declared that as soon as possible the whole responsibility for civilian supply in the liberated areas, now under military control, must be turned over to civilians.

AS children they used to sing, "Deck the Hall With Boughs of Holly"; or they helped to trim the Christmas tree, stringing festoons of popcorn and polishing the reddest apples to hang on the branches; or they used to light candles in the windows on Christmas Eve. Stockings were hung, letters written to Santa Claus, mistletoe hung from the chandelier.

ON weekdays through the year the door of many a city church stands open, and on those days -- notably now, as Christmas nears -- people come in from the noisy street, the busy avenue, to sit a while in meditation, to kneel a moment in prayer.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill is missed in London because he is not only a symbol of deliverance and victory but also the head of a system of government that cannot work at maximum efficiency when he is not available.

OTTAWA, Dec. 18 -- It is confidently expected here that some time next spring a conference of the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth will be held in London to discuss present and post-war problems.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), leader of the Yugoslav Partisans, has formally requested that the Allies withdraw recognition from young King Peter and his emigre Cabinet and acknowledge the Partisans' newly created temporary Yugoslav Government as the sole representative of sovereignty among the southern Slav peoples.

" THE Navy at War," comprising paintings and drawings by official United States Navy combat artists, will be on view at the Corcoran Gallery of Art from Jan. 30 through Feb. 20. The pictures are to be shown under the auspices of the United States Navy.

ARTHUR GUITERMAN has been gone almost a year (Jan. 11, 1943), and with his going we lost one of the best singers we had. For more than a quarter of a century he had been well known as a writer who could make words -- and ideas -palpitate with life and meaning, serious as well as gay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Twenty-five House members denounced today the Senate bill, giving the States -- rather than the Federal Government -- supervision over soldier voting next November, as "a substitute for democracy" and "a slap in the face" for those in the armed forces.

American history seems to be repeating itself out in the Lincoln country, where I have been for the past three weeks. A great act in popular education is being staged not unlike that historic drama that culminated in the Lincoln-Douglas debate. People are coming to close grips with the vital issue as to what part this country, in its own interest, must bear in a world organized for peace.

The Illinois Zinc Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, a net income of $439,257 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes of $2,665 and a deduction of $86,334 for contingencies. This is equivalent to $4.56 each on 96,140 shares of common stock.
A letter has just come in from a soldier and it turns out to be the kind you keep rolling around in your mind without knowing the answer.

I LEFT the woods for as good a reason as I went there. Perhaps it seemed to me that I had several more lives to live, and could not spare any more time for that one. It is remarkable how easily and insensibly we fall into a particular route, and make a beaten track for ourselves.

Two boys, who with a group of others were playing a game of war in a vacant lot at Third Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, were killed yesterday as realistically as if they had been on the battlefield when a 75-millimeter shell they had thrown into their bonfire exploded with a terrific burst.

Turning in a performance that compares favorably with some of the best hurling either major league has seen in close to a quarter of a century, Spurgeon (Spud) Chandler, the husky 34-year-old right-hander of the world champion Yankees, practicaly spread-eagled the field in carrying off the American League's top pitching honors for 1943, according to the official averages released for publication today.

MARLEY'S ghost, dragging chains and padlocks, will stalk again this Christmas season and once more Scrooge will charge the apparition to a piece of undigested beef or a clot of mustard. Millions of listeners will hear the tight-fisted misanthrope, reformed by a dream, shout to a crowd of youthful merrymakers to go down to the poulterer's and buy for him, "Not the small prize turkey, but the big one."

With the aid of the City Markets Department and the Coast Guard, Daniel P. Woolley, new regional Office of Price Administration director, yesterday threw the machinery of local OPA into a drive to protect service men and their relatives from paying excessive prices for wrist watches.

IT was announced last spring that the Lessing J. Rosenwald collection of prints and drawings had been given to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and his manuscripts and rare books to the Library of Congress. The first exhibition of Rosenwald prints and drawings opens today at the National, to remain current until Feb. 13.

THE show business being what it is, the qualifications for getting somewhere in it are many and various. If, for instance, you had a background of military school, business engineering, baseball, football, jazz-band playing in a Midwestern town, vaudeville and the motion pictures, you would probably wind up under the name of Jack Carson, with a show of your own on the Columbia network at 9:30 o'clock on Wednesday evenings.

In the application of income tax law, as a general rule, where a receipt of money is taxable to the recipient as income, the payment thereof is deductible from income by the payer. This rule could be circumvented in a case where the recipient was on a cash receipts and disbursements basis of making returns.

A series of Christmas parties not only for members of our armed forces throughout the world but also for prisoners of war and the children scattered to many countries by the Nazi war machine will be given by the twenty-six agencies of the New York Committee of the National War Fund.

Competitive bidding for new securities, as promulgated and enforced by the Securities and Exchange Commission, turned into a fiasco last week as the SEC found itself in the difficult position of trying to explain why it caused a public utility company to pay some $600,000 more than it should have in consummating a comprehensive refunding program.

The advisability of abolishing WNYC, the municipal radio station, was suggested last night by Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan, in a talk from the very station whose continued operation he declared might be undesirable.

STOWE, Vt., Dec. 18 -- Real winter has prevailed in this serene New England hamlet since Nov. 15, with the result that the huge network of ski runs and slopes radiating from lofty Mount Mansfield are covered with a thick white blanket that reaches a depth of four feet.

Tight conditions on most lines of merchandise will continue to face the many buyers from stores all over the country who are expected to arrive in the wholesale markets here next month, although the belief prevails in many quarters that the low point in consumer goods supply has now been passed.

IN "Derry the Wolfhound" these accomplished artists have added another breed to their gallery of dog portraits and have made an attractive, easy-reading book. Simply written, set in large, clear type and with a picture, full of action, opposite every page of text, this book will readily hold the attention and suit the capacities of beginners in reading.

In his report to the House of Commons Foreign Secretary Eden made some interesting and enlightening disclosures regarding Allied policy in the Balkans which should remove some of its puzzling aspects and allay some of the apprehensions aroused by it. He declared that this policy is being guided by three principles.

New York will be asked to contribute more than ever before to the American Red Cross for its work during the coming year, it was revealed yesterday with the appointment of John P. Stevens, president of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., as chairman of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York.

EARLY Cape Cod novels by Joseph C. Lincoln dipped back into the quaint past when one traveled to the Cape by stage from the end of the railroad, when retired sea captains ruled the roost and dire consequences followed upon the love of a "regular" minister for the daughter of a "come-outer."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Sunday, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- A communique:

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill was believed safely past the crisis of his illness tonight as a bulletin issued from 10 Downing Street announced the British statesman's "'temperature is subsiding and the pneumonia is resolving."

The advisability of abolishing WNYC, the municipal radio station, was suggested last night by Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan, in a talk from the very station whose continued operation he declared might be undesirable.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill was believed safely past the crisis of his illness tonight as a bulletin issued from 10 Downing Street announced the British statesman's "'temperature is subsiding and the pneumonia is resolving."

The somewhat paradoxical picture of the Mayor under whose regime the Tammany Hall structure at Seventeenth Street and Union Square was constructed and the present Mayor, who recalled that his administration "had put it ou of business," marked yesterday the dedicatory exercises of the one-time wigwam of the Sachems as the new home of Local 91 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

In a campaign against crew shortages which usually delay merchant sailings over the Christmas and New Year holidays, the War Shipping Administration is prepared to take special measures to prevent a recurrence of the situation of a year ago when seventeen United Nations' vessels were delayed in American ports during the season because of personnel shortages, Marshall E. Dimock, national director of the WSA's Recruitment and Manning Organization, said here yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 20 -- The Red Army has opened a powerful winter offensive in the Nevel area of White Russia, killing or capturing more than 22,000 Germans in five days of furious fighting that drove a Soviet wedge almost nineteen miles deep and fifty miles wide into Nazi lines guarding the Baltic states, Moscow announced today.

The Brenner Pass is again in the news. Last week it was the scene of the heaviest air blows delivered to date on the main supply line of the German armies in Italy. American bombers pounded the mountain railroad all the way from the picture-book town of Innsbruck on the Austrian side to the tumbling Avisio River south of Bolzano on the Italian side.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A work stoppage by composing room employes tonight restricted the capital's two morning newspapers, The Post and The Times-Herald, to a single edition of ten pages.
Prices of cotton fluctuated within a narrow range last week. At the close of trading Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to up 13 points.

With petroleum expected to play a far greater role in the nation's economy in the post-war period than it has done so far, the time is approaching when Washington should agree on a definite policy to augment domestic supplies from foreign sources.

SAN PIETRO INFINE, Italy, Dec. 18 (Delayed) -- American soldiers have won one of their bloodiest, bitterest and toughest battles of the Second World War on this 100th day of the Fifth Army's invasion of Italy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The tax bill which the Senate Finance Committee will report to the Senate this week is so objectionable to the Administration that officials privately are predicting a veto unless important changes are made in the measure.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 111.65, a rise of 0.07 per cent over the previous week's level of 111.57. The raw materials index rose 0.3 per cent as a result of price increases in cotton, grains, hay and livestock, which were slightly offset by decreases in apples, oranges and potatoes.

The London Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham, will tour in this country and Canada next fall, according to an announcement made yesterday by the National Association for American Composers and Conductors.

The annual report of Swift Co. of Chicago, meat packers, released for publication today by John Holmes, president, discloses record sales of $1,490,016,635 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 30. In the previous year of 1942 sales were $1,409,405,770.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Dec. 19 -- With the elimination of the San Pietro feature, it is possible at last to say that Mignano, the pass gateway to the Liri Valley, is in Allied hands.

In contrast with the many contributions coming to the Neediest Cases Fund from men and women in the armed forces who somehow find time to remember the very needy back home, three gifts came yesterday in memory of soldiers who have made the supreme sacrifice. They were:

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Little change occurred last week in the feed-grain situation, the final returns on the 1943 crops showing small reductions as compared with the preliminary returns, but the decrease was of little importance as a market influence, and all reports suggest that there is a close adjustment of supplies to demand.
NAPLES, Dec. 19 -- The most impressive political meeting yet seen in liberated Italy was held here today in the Politeama Theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Final returns on the production of wheat in this country this year, issued late last week by the Department of Agriculture, showed little change from the preliminary figures, and suggest that there is about 1,437,000,000 bushels of this grain available for use during the current crop year, a reduction of 70,000,000 bushels compared with the preceding season.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- The Royal household production of the pantomime "Aladdin" brought down the house today.

There is evidently considerable confusion in the public mind on the subject of air transport in relation to war strategy. Many persons fail to distinguish between air transport, which is just a faster and more efficient method of delivering goods, and air power, which is a military force for defeating an enemy.

Regardless of differences that exist between Russia and Poland, friendly relations and collaboration of the two countries are essential to lasting world peace, speakers declared last night at a meeting in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, asked Price Administrator Chester Bowles today to remove pork from rationing or make "an explanation to the farmers and the public as to why this valuable commodity is being withheld."

Pointing to "great cracks in the enemy's lines," the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, predicted in a sermon yesterday morning that the "great final issue" of the war might appear sooner than expected.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Members of the crew of a Flying Fortress who refused to bail out and leave a helpless comrade to his fate enacted a saga of heroism in the clouds 3,500 feet over the hills of Pennsylvania today.

KHARKOV, Russia, Dec. 19 (Reuter) -- The four accused in the Kharkov atrocities trial -- three Germans and one Russian -- were hanged in the battle-scarred, snowcovered Kharkov market square this morning.

A series of important meetings on themes of current interest, to take place in the next six months at Times Hall, is announced today by THE NEW YORK TIMES. These meetings will bring together leaders in many fields, as well as members of THE TIMES staff, to explore outstanding wartime and post-war problems.
War work is no excuse for neglecting "the things of God;" the Rev. Cyprian Truss of St. Francis Capuchin Friary, Providence, R.I., declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Henry J. Kaiser, one of America's greatest industrialists, announces that we have passed the peak in our war production in almost every item and that the time has come to begin shifting back to a peacetime economy in order to absorb energies and man-hours which will be released from war work with increasing momentum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Almost $100,000,000,000 in uncommitted balances now held by the War and Navy Departments, the Maritime Commission and the War Shipping Administration will be investigated to see if the amount cannot be returned to the United States Treasury, the joint Congressional Economy Committee promised tonight.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 1 I read of the request, in a resolution presented at a meeting of the Board of Education, for a State Institute of Technical and Applied Arts. I'd like to comment on it.

That something was amiss with the defenses of Bari against air attack on the night of Dec. 2 seems evident from the extent of the losses sustained by the large convoy lying in the harbor with supplies for the British Eighth Army in Italy. Secretary of War Stimson has disclosed that "a number" of Allied vessels, including five American merchantmen, were destroyed or damaged and 1,000 casualties suffered.

Christmas was brought to the House of Detention for Women yesterday by the Salvation Army, which conducted its annual pilgrimage to the penal institution at 10 Greenwich Avenue and conducted a service and distributed gifts to the matrons and the inmates.

Col. Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service director for New York City, disclosed in a radio talk last night that a new program of screening, designed to weed out psychoneurotics before they were inducted into the armed services, would be instituted here "within the next few weeks."

Mankind is in for a long-hard pull from the present world catastrophe to something better, and upon the church rests the principal portion of the task of leading humanity to a brighter day, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers declared in his sermon yesterday in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Prime Minister Churchill's condition is so greatly improved today that, it is understood, he is again taking a hand in the conduct of the war and key military figures of the United Nations have received messages from him.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- At Berlin the pall of smoke that rose from Thursday night's rain of British bombs had not lifted today. Reports received here indicate that the heart of the German capital is furrowed with nameless streets and cluttered with smoldering ruins.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 19 -- In a sudden, unexpected house-cleaning in Goebbels' Propaganda Ministry, inspired by the defeatism of Dr. Ernst Brauweiler, head of the foreign press bureau, and of Major Martin Sommerfeldt, Army spokesman, both have been suspended.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Stop order proceedings against the Colorado Milling and Elevator Company have been withdrawn by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a result of the filing by the company of an amendement to its registration of 70,000 shares of $3 cumulative convertible preferred stock and 269,231 shares of $1 par common stock to overcome objections of the commission which alleged serious deficiencies in the registration statement.

Robert Kitain, Russian violinist, was heard in a recital late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. He had prepared a program composed of the Corelli-Kreisler "La Folia," the "Adelaide" concerto of Mozart, Beethoven's "Kreutzer" sonata, Sarasate's "Carmen" Fantasie, and shorter offerings by Debussy and Joseph Achron.

Jesus Christ survived the Caesars of His time and He will outlive the dictators of our day, declared the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman in his sermon yesterday in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The participation of French troops in the fighting in Italy -- which was announced last week -- is probably indicative of the beginning of a new phase in the Mediterranean campaign.

It seems increasingly improbable that the Germans will be able to meet an Allied invasion of the Balkans at the water line or from subjugated territory. Though the fighting there has increased in intensity the Nazis have failed to break the resistance of the Yugoslav Partisans or clear the land bases they must have when the Allied armies strike.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 19 (AP) -- "Uncle Mark" Thrash, 123-year-old Negro, said to be the oldest person in the United States, was buried with military honors at a little cemetery near here today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Moscow newspapers gave these details of the testimony at the atrocity trial in Kharkov:

The life, crucifixion and influence of Christ demonstrate that final proof in every realm is offered not by debate but by achievement, declared the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in Riverside Church.
OTTAWA, Dec. 19 -- Production and shipment rates for newsprint and for pulp and paper products during the first six months of 1944 were announced here today by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board.

MERRICK, L.I., Dec. 19 -- Luther Childs, former president of the Childs Company and a brother of Samuel S. Childs, founder of the restaurant chain, died this morning from suffocation by a small fire in his home at 19 Lincoln Boulevard. He was 85 years old.
Several properties on the West Side passed to new control in deals reported over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A new rationing system for the country's 100,000 commercial and institutional eating places will go into effect March 1, with food allotments based solely on the number of servings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt directed Secretary of War Stimson today to take over operation of five strike-bound plants of the Western Electric Company in and near Baltimore.

I was pleased to see that a son of Rhode Island was moved to protest the recommended use of yellow corn meal in your editorial "Indian Puddin'," but I must protest his spelling of the word "Johnnycake."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The center of gravity of American economic life has shifted markedly westward and southward during the war, according to a study "Regional Shifts in Population, Production and Markets, 1939-43," released today by the Department of Commerce.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday his approval of "cost of living" pay rises for employes of the Department of Correction, the Welfare Department and the Department of Public Works. The increases, he said, are to become effective Jan. 1, but the first augmented pay checks, retroactive to that date, will not be given out until several weeks later because of bookkeeping difficulties.

Faced by a speedy and clever stick-handling team from the Royal Canadian Navy, the New York Rovers absorbed their second defeat in as many days when they dropped a 6-3 decision to His Majesty's Canadian ship York six of Toronto in the star battle of an amateur twin-bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Cold weather prevailed last week over the Winter Wheat Belt, but experts say they do not expect any damage of consequence, although grain that was seeded after the rains in the Southwest recently may be slow in germinating as the result of the low temperatures.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- Barbara Stanwyck, who has the featured role in the Warner Brothers' production, "My Reputation," has signed a term contract with that company. The actress, who is also under commitment to do a picture for Hunt Stromberg and United Artists, will be starred in at least two important pictures for Warners during 1944.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- A merger of the American and British air forces in the southeast Asia theatre into a single Allied air force under the command of Air Chief Marshal Sir Richard Peirse was revealed here today with the publication of a directive by Admiral the Lord Louis Mountbatten dealing with the organization of the air forces under his command.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs tightened their grip on second place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Black Hawks for the second straight night, 5 -- 2, and ending the Hawks' home ice winning streak at 7 before 15,345 in the Chicago Stadium.
Redskins, 28, Giants 0. Well, it was a nice dream while it lasted anyway.

Doubleday, Doran announces an award of $2,500 for any book dealing with American Negroes, "which seems to the judges to be worthy of this special recognition." The judges will be the editors of Doubleday, Doran. The offer, effective now, will remain open indefinitely within the discretion of the publishers, and the award will be given whenever a full-length manuscript meets the requirements of the judges.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Allied-supplied Yugoslav Partisans have killed, wounded or captured more than 10,000 German troops during the past twenty days, the Free Yugoslav radio said today.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Dec. 19 -- The United States Fifth Air Corps has introduced something new in the way of supply service in the New Britain invasion -- the fighting transport plane.
Women with children who leave their homes to take jobs in war plants cannot be accused of contributing to the rising rate of juvenile delinquency, Magistrate Anna M. Kross declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- After eight days of wandering over a South Pacific Island, five members of a United States Army Thirteenth Air Force bomber crew forced down by bad weather and an exhausted fuel supply have returned safely to their base, the War Department announced today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club was informally but practically turned into a war service today when students came over from the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., and sailed in the small racing craft.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Steve Warga Jr., young professional who is a spare-time golfer for the duration while he works here as an airline radio operator, took first money in the $5,000 Miami open tournament today with an even-par 280 for the seventy-two holes.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt's desire to remove the "regrettable confusion which has arisen recently over the issuance of official news relating to the war" is shared by officials and correspondents in London, but they are not completely satisfied with either his interpretation of the causes of that confusion or the solution outlined in his memorandum to the War and Navy Departments and the Office of War Information.
MONTREAL, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Montreal's league-leading Canadiens hopped on the team that handed them their first defeat two weeks ago and trounced the Bruins tonight, 3 -- 1.

This being the week of last minute preparations for the Christmas holidays, no less than seven Broadway movie houses will bring in new films, with three openings scheduled for Wednesday, one for Thursday, two for Friday and one for Christmas Day. Herewith the line-up:

Following last week's shake-up in the local Office of Price Administration, ordered by Daniel P. Woolley, new regional OPA director, Harry K. Lowe, executive officer of mileage rationing and executive officer of personnel for New York County on the staff of Joseph Kraeler, former county rationing administrator, announced his resignation yesterday, effective a week from today.
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 19 -- Army fighter planes are now able to extend air cover over the Marshall Island atolls and to attack the enemy bastions from our own land bases.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold the one-family dwelling on a lot 35 by 100 feet at 22 Condict Street, in Jersey City, N.J., to Marcel E. Wagner for occupancy, through the Walter Koster Realty Company and D.E.C. Somers. The latter, in conjunction with the Bardack Realty Company, also sold for the HOLC to Erminion Scappaticcio the two-family house on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 166 Clendenny Avenue, in Jersey City.

For the labor crisis that now confronts us, the Administration must bear the chief responsibility. Why are the nation's railway workers now threatening to strike, in spite of the disastrous effect that such a strike could have at this time upon our domestic economy and upon our war effort?

AN ambush needs the element of surprise in order to succeed. So the Redskins had their tomahawks primed for the assaults of the Giants in their championship play-off at the Polo Grounds yesterday and waylaid them with considerable glee and authority. Now they go out to Chicago next week with some $1,000 per man beckoning them.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 19 -- A cargo of German ammunition being unloaded in Oslo Harbor blew up today, killing four persons, injuring a great number, shattering tens of thousands of windows and setting off a 5 1/2-hour series of explosions in the Norwegian capital, the Swedish news agency said tonight.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday converted his usual Sunday radio broadcast from City Hall into a Christmas service, with himself as narrator. Avoiding the slightest mention of city business, the Mayor read Yuletide messages from eminent Catholic, Protestant and Jewish clergymen and "a typical New Yorker," former Gov. Alfred E. Smith.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- The question of the indemnification of victims of bombings in Germany is already throwing a shadow over the Reich's financial picture. Casual estimates in financial and insurance circles assume that anything approximating a fair settlement would involve sums beyond the capacity of any national budget.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel, who despite his defeats in Africa still enjoys tremendous prestige among the rank and file of the army and the confidence of the common people of Germany, has been selected by Adolf Hitler to command an army of maneuver to counter the Allied invasion of Western Europe, it was learned today.

As a student active for many years in the problems of alcohol in beverages and in industry, may I call attention to certain facts and considerations that might well be taken into account by the Distilled Spirits Institute, by Congress and by the public, particularly now?

One of the highlights of a memorable occasion, when leaders in the aviation industry and in our own and foreign Governments gathered in Washington on Friday evening to do honor to Orville Wright, was the disclosure, through a warm message from President Roosevelt, that the Wright brothers' first plane, at last, was to return to the United States for permanent exhibition.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's Chinese and American fliers bombed Japanese centers in the Lake Tungting district and harassed enemy rail and water supply lines over a wide area of southeastern Asia on Thursday and Friday, it was disclosed today, while Chinese ground troops recaptured additional villages in the "rice bowl" area.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The first women of the American Red Cross field service, assigned to the armed forces, to reach Chungking arrived today. The trio was led by Mrs. Alma B. Kerr of Chicago, Ill., and Valley City, N.D., assistant director of club operations in the China-Burma-India theatre.

" The Patriots," which ran for 172 performances here last season and won the Drama Critics Circle award "for its dignity of material, its thoughtful projection of a great American theme, its vigorous approach to the characters portrayed, and, in spite of certain limitations, its driving final effect on the stage," will return for a week's engagement this evening at the City Center under a guarantee by the civic venture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Progress toward averting a strike of 350,000 railroad transportation employes was made by President Roosevelt at an emergency White House conference today.

KHARKOV, Dec. 18 (Delayed) -- The military tribunal of the Fourth Ukrainian Front today sentenced three German soldiers and a Russian to death by hanging for participation in German atrocities in the Kharkov region.

Dr. Herman T. Leslie, in 530 Park Ave; Ms. Thomas G. G. Henderson, in 903 Park Ave; Mrs. John Grimm, in 116 E 68th St; Max Allen Vogel, in 670 West End Ave -- Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, broker.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Germany which entered the war with a larger air force and greater airplane industrial potential than any nation now opposing her, stands last today behind the United States, Russia and Britain in plane output.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Mediterranean-based United States bombers flying high over the snowcapped Dolomites were reported in a Berlin broadcast to have attacked Germany in daylight yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- So far the Russians have not participated in sessions of the United Nations Commission for the Investigation of War Crimes, which has met twice informally in London's law courts and has another meeting scheduled next month. It is not yet officially organized.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Dec. 20 (UP) -- A communique:

Lorenzo Camilieri and his People's Chorus gave their sixteenth annual Christmas Song Festival yesterday afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Camilieri obtained the able assistance of the audience that filled the ballroom and its boxes, all draped for Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Members of the Republican National Committee who will meet in Chicago Jan. 10-11 will spend the Christmas holiday season largely in a state of bewildered speculation over problems which already are assuming larger immediate proportions than the choice of a candidate for President.

An advertising campaign to encourage construction of homes in which adequate provision is made for frequency modulation radio and television will be launched next year by the Freed-Eisemann radio organization. Media to be used in the drive, it was said, have not been decided yet, but direct mail, trade papers and real estate pages in newspapers will no doubt be scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Two Southern Democrats of the House denounced today the action of a group of twenty-five colleagues in circulating a petition criticizing a Senate-passed bill to give the States, instead of the Federal Government, supervision over soldier voting in next fall's elections.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, Dec. 17 (Delayed) -- The Italian troops fighting beside the Allies have come through their hard test with flying colors and today it may be said that, barring wholly unexpected developments, the Italians will fight side by side with the Allies until the Germans have been driven from Italy.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that eighty members of his department would be promoted at 4 o'clock this afternoon in the line-up gallery at Police Headquarters. A deputy inspector will be advanced to the rank of inspector; a captain to deputy inspector; three lieutenants to captain; thirty sergeants to lieutenants, and forty-five patrolmen to the rank of sergeant.

New York's loyal Japanese, Bulgarians and Hungarians were hailed yesterday as part of the United Nations at a rally that marked the contribution to the National War Fund of $732,505 by committees representing residents of this city from twenty-five separate national origins.

Such activity as existed in last week's markets occurred chiefly in grain. Stocks and bonds went slightly lower early in the week, but prices were governed chiefly by uncertainty -- not regarding the war situation but with reference to the labor complications.

The Tokyo radio, in a weekly news review broadcast to Japanese home area audiences, said yesterday that Japan had "turned from a war of self-existence to one of self-defense" and that "the enemy, without regard for his losses, is coming forward with counter-offensive operations."

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, addressing 2,000 delegates yesterday at the convention of the Hias Council of Organizations at the Hotel Diplomat, emphasized that the United States, through a liberal interpretation of its immigration laws, and Jewish Palestine must take the lead in effecting a speedy rescue program for European Jews.

STOWE, Vt., Dec. 19 -- While being internationally famous for its variety of ski terrain and reliable snow conditions, picturesque Mount Mansfield is also the birthplace of the national ski patrol system.

BALTIMORE, Monday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Under Presidential order, the Army took over the strike-affected plants of the Western Electric Company in Baltimore, announcing that operations would be resumed today, but at midnight labor and management representatives were still at odds over seniority rights.

The number of buyers in the market last week tapered off to a considerable extent, but there were some requests for holiday numbers. Main floor departments are well sold out, and other sections also are showing shortages. Little merchandise was available for quick delivery, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The Treasurers Club of America, a fraternal organization representing the ticket sellers in the Broadway playhouses, held its annual election late Saturday night at the Hotel Edison. The following were elected: President, Irving Engel; vice president, Harry B. Nelmes; treasurer, Lep Solomon (incumbent); financial secretary, Thurber N. Wilkins (incumbent); recording secretary, Hugh J. McGauley (incumbent).

ALGIERS, Dec. 19 -- American infantry of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's. Fifth Army unlocked the road to Cassino yesterday, when, after three days and nights of savage fighting under incredible difficulties of transport and supply, it captured San Pietro Infine.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The first eyewitness report on a new Nazi "secret weapon" -- rocket-driven glider bombs resembling some Wellsian weapon from Mars but which exploded harmlessly -- was released today following a recent attack on a big Allied convoy by eight Nazi bombers.

Someone has termed it "the silvery fabric of laughter." Most of us with a fair margin of good health and prosperity have this priceless possession -- laughter that springs from whole-hearted mirth and joy, from the sense of well-being. We seldom pause to analyze it or give it serious consideration.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A program designed to cut the cost of litigation for reduction of real estate assessments will be recommended to the Legislature by its Joint Committee on Assessing.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

ALGIERS, Dec. 19 -- The first indication of a determination of Allied authorities to crack down on the incipient Fascist resurgence in occupied Italian territory appeared this afternoon with the announcement that the United States Army Intelligence Corps had rounded up fifteen young men and one woman at Trapani, Sicily, and turned them over to military courts.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Although the Stock Exchange here noted Anthony Eden's reference to the strain imposed upon Prime Minister Winston Churchill by his Middle East activities, the news of his illness came as a shock and cast a heavy shadow over the markets.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Monday, Dec. 20 -- The Allied bid for air supremacy over invaded New Britain brought reports of new successes today, including the war's first fighter plane sweep over the fortress of Rabaul from the new American airfield 250 miles to its southeast on Bougainville in the Solomons.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 19 -- The birth of liberal movements throughout Balkan Europe is seriously disturbing the peace of mind of those Kings and politicians who hope to re-establish after the war the old regimes in their respective countries.
F. A. iVattack has been appointed head of the newly reorganized and expanded research .bureauof the Bedaux Company, industrial engineers.

Business buildings and a vacant plot at Percival and Court Streets and the Gowanus Bay Canal, in Brooklyn, 267 by 250 feet, were sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company. The property has a frontage of 517 feet on the canal and is assessed at $105,000. The bank also sold the one-family house at 1958 East Ninth Street.

Victory has become a habit with the Rangers. Having registered their first triumph of the National Hockey League race over the Bruins a week ago last night, the Blue Shirts saw no reason for not continuing their success last night, when they tackled the Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight F. Davis, who directed the Red Cross Volunteer Services in their wartime expansion from a membership of 52,000 to more than 4,000,000 is being forced out of action by illness.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Despite record slaughtering of hogs at Western packing points, supplies of lard are increasing very slowly. Brokers report that tank cars are being made available for quick loading of the product and so far there has been no bottleneck in storage facilities.

The present muddled situation relating to current liquor stocks held in warehouses is expected to be clarified to some extent today, when representatives of the major distiller groups meet with John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, in his office at 420 Lexington Avenue.

The Physicians Forum, a national organization of physicians, officially endorsed yesterday the Wagner-Murray-Dingell Social Security-Health Insurance Bill, now pending before Congress, as "the most realistic legislation yet proposed for improving the quality and distribution of medical service on a national scale."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The first full and official report on what has happened to the nurses of Bataan after the fall of Corregidor was brought back to this country by Dorothy Davis, chief nurse of the Santo Tomas Japanese prison camp in Manila, who returned on the Gripsholm.

The Abbey Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street, which has been dark for some months, has Been acquired by the Brandt Brothers Theatre Circuit, and will be reopened as the Manhattan Theatre on or about Christmas Day with a revival of "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt appealed today to the chiefs of the five transportation brotherhoods, representing 350,000 employes, to settle their dispute with the railroad managements in time to permit him to present to the nation as a Christmas gift a peaceful adjustment of the controversy threatening a country-wide railroad strike Dec. 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously called upon the State Department today to work out, in cooperation with Great Britain, Sweden, Switzerland and other countries, a system for moving food supplies to the people of Nazi-occupied European countries.

In his first address since the signing of the Soviet-Czechoslovak Mutual Assistance Pact, Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs, hailed Russia as a "great and essentially necessary factor in the present and future fortunes of Europe."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary Morgenthau denounced Congress tonight for batting down his new revenue bill to one-fifth his recommendations and charged the lawmakers with opening the door to "truly extortionate profits" by war contractors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- War stamp sales reached $1,068,000,000 Nov. 30, the Office of War Information reported today, with a "particularly heavy" sale now in progress for Christmas gifts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) - The feud between the Senate's Northern and Southern Democrats got its second wind today, Senator Guffey, Democrat of Pennsylvania, asserting that he would not be "forced out" as chairman of the party's Senatorial campaign committee and Senator Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, demanding that Mr. Guffey be supplanted immediately.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court affirmed today a decision dismissing a petition by the Chicago Northwestern Railway Company which sought, because of higher wartime earnings, to compel the Interstate Commerce Commission to reopen proceedings leading to reorganization of the railroad under the bankruptcy act.

Graduation exercises for 155 students of the College of Physicians and Surgeons and the School of Dental and Oral Surgery of Columbia University will be held on Thursday at 10 A.M. at McMillin Academic Theatre. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will address the graduates at the ceremony, the second to be held this year under the accelerated wartime program.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 21 -- Veteran Siberian troops of the First Soviet Baltic Army killed 1,800 Germans yesterday in an advance that carried them to Privalni, twenty-six miles north of the big White Russian rail junction of Vitebsk, while Berlin reported evacuation of the German brideghead opposite Kherson, lower Dnieper River port.

Operations of the Caterpillar Tractor Company in the eleven months ended with November resuited in a net profit of $7,436,831 after all charges but subject to renegotiation of war contracts, L.B. Neumiller, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The War Department said today that steps had been taken in cooperation with the Veterans Administration to eliminate delays between the date a soldier is discharged for physical disability and the time he begins to receive a pension or other benefits.

The cotton futures market moved narrowly yesterday within a 7 point range in a session marked by hesitancy on the part of the trade to make any new commitments before the holidays and pending the clarification of domestic price control policies and military developments abroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, disclosed a plan today to make the United States Employment Service the coordinating part of vast post-war arrangements for returning veterans to civilian life.

PHILADELPH1A, Dec. 20 -- Major Wakeman Griffin Gribbel, 63 years old, a World War veteran who was acquitted of murder here thirteen years ago, was released on bail of $2,500 today on a charge of slashing the throat of a captain of waiters at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in an altercation arising from the disappearance of a red handkerchief from his overcoat.

Officials of the chemicals division of the War Production Board are considering placing tighter control over the allocation of cellulose acetates to civilian end uses, plastics molders and fabricators stated yesterday. While the supply situation of such plastics has eased recently, certain segments of the industry have pointed out that inflationary demands continue to keep their manufacturing activities at a level below that which the supply situation warrants.

A memorial service for Maj. Clark Robinson of the Army Air Forces, formerly for many years a well-known New York stage designer, who was killed on Dec. 12 in a plane crash near the Burma border in India, is being arranged by a committee appointed by the United Scenic Artists, it was announced yesterday.

Michael Schaap yesterday announced his resignation as president and managing director of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc. Mr. Schaap stated it is the intention of the board of directors of the store at its coming meeting to elect him as chairman of the board, succeeding Samuel J. Bloomingdale, who will become honorary chairman.

NAPLES, Dec. 20 -- One of more than 9,000 safety deposit boxes in Naples banks opened under the supervision of Allied Military Government officials was found to contain seven pistols, but they were the property of a Naples actor and six of them were stage weapons, it was disclosed today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- C.S. Bromley's Samhar, a fast-closing third in a six-furlong dash on the opening day, took advantage of a 11-pound drop in weights and won the mile-and-70-yards of the Dania purse in near-record time at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the winter wheat crop for harvest next year was indicated to be 526,957,000 bushels, compared with 529,606,000 harvested this year, 696,450,000 in 1942 and a ten-year (1932-41) average of 550,181,000.

Spurred by the promise of early action by the Office of Price Administration to relieve "ceiling" squeezes, producers of sheets and blankets reported yesterday that they are hopeful of being able to increase current allotments in time for traditional January "white" sales.

Christmas bonuses approximating $41,000 will be distributed to 300 employes of the Kenyon In. strument Company, nc., Arthur T. Newell,, president, announced yesterday. The bonus, which is based on length of service, will be paid to employes of record of Dec. 24, in addition to those who have left the company to join the armed services during the past year.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 20 -- The Indianapolis Star will say tomorrow morning in a dispatch credited to its Washington bureau that Gen. Douglas MacArthur is making "tentative plans" to return to Washington next March for a series of conferences.

The stock market encountered yesterday sufficient profit-taking to force the list into an indecisive session. A revival of interest among the motors, particularly the low-priced issues, imparted a better complexion before the close and, at the worst, prices were only mixed.
ALGIERS, Dec. 20 -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- A proposal today from Philip R. O'Brien, president of the Board of Trade, for a "permanent alliance" between the board and the Chicago Stock Exchange failed to get a favorable response from the latter organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Increased coal production, "heartening and encouraging," will enable employes of Government-held coal mines to take a holiday on Christmas, the Federal Coal Mines Administration announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- It is becoming increasingly clear that Russia intends to press for the rectification of her western boundary and for "friendly" Governments in all countries with which she has common frontiers.
On reading the various interviews and speeches of Mr. Landon I am convinced he is putting emphasis upon something that is secondary in this world's remaking we are witnessing.

Hannukah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, will begin tonight and continue for eight days. Announcements concerning the festival were made yesterday by the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine, and by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- After 350 days of political rebellion, the first session of the Seventy-eighth Congress will adjourn tomorrow, having substantially rejected Administration leadership on domestic issues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Army High Command has decided not only to complete its $134,000,000 Canol oil development project in Canada, the abandonment of which has been recommended by the Navy, the War Production Board and the Petroleum Administrator for War, but to expand it as an essential military operation for the offensive against Japan, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commander of the Army Service Forces, told the Truman investigating committee today.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP) - Women comprise 71 per cent of the employes in New York's retail stores and service industries, the State Labor Department announced today. A survey of eighteen cities showed that the hiring of women had increased almost 7 per cent over 1942, the department's report indicated.

ALGIERS, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- The United States Army newspaper Stars and Stripes today outlined a bizarre mystery thriller involving the apparent murder of a pretty young Frenchwoman who "confessed" suicide on her deathbed, and her American soldier-sweetheart, who "confessed" firing the fatal shot -- both of which assertions were disproved by United States military police.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Surprising Ralph Zanelli, 148 1/2, of Providence, upset Fritzie Zivic, 152, of Pittsburgh, tonight at Boston Garden, giving the former world welterweight champion a thorough going-over in the ten-round main bout before a crowd of 9,483.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- A twelve-hour search for two boys ended near dawn today when their bodies were found in the Millstone River near Princeton Junction, two miles from here. Both had drowned after an afternoon of skating on the narrow stream, which is a tributary of Lake Carnegie.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 20 -- A military discussion between a special mission sent to Egypt by Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), commander of the Yugoslav People's Army of Liberation, and the Anglo-American staffs has been taking place in Alexandria, it was announced tonight.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 21 -- The important North German port of Bremen, a center of U-boat production, was hammered by a very strong force of Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force yesterday in an assault that was a high point of extensive operations over Hitler-held Europe by American and British aerial formations.

LONDON, Dec. 20 - Considerable concern has been aroused in London by the failure to announce the name of the Allied Commander in Chief for the invasion of northwest Europe, a failure that many well-informed observers feel is hampering the organization of the enterprise, it became manifest today.

ALGIERS, Dec. 20 -- Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud has appealed to French farmers throughout North Africa to invite a French soldier and an Allied soldier to dinner in their homes on Christmas or New Year's Day so that the Allied soldier "may know the warmth of a French home."

ADMIRAL HALSEY'S HEADQUARTERS, Dec. 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- Regis O'Brien, 172, husky marine from Pittsburgh, knocked out Robert Henneberger, Baltimore sailor, after one minute and thirteen seconds of the second round of their semi-final match in the South Pacific boxing tournament tonight.

Judge Franklin Taylor, who has been a member of the Kings County Court since 1922, denied yesterday in a letter to Mayor La Guardia that he was a "notorious drunk." He accused the Mayor of characterizing him as such in a broadcast over Station WNYC on Dec. 12 when the Mayor was defending his administration in the handling of home relief.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- With an appropriation of $75,000 to be used as a trust fund at the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, the Will Rogers Memorial Commission has completed its affairs, Jesse H. Jones, treasurer, said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- A 1944 Westchester County operating budget and fourteen special district budgets were adopted this afternoon by the Board of Supervisors by 31 to 7. The operating budget provides salary increases for 535 employes and "cost of living" bonuses of $200,000 for all lower-salaried workers, yet establishes the lowest tax levy since 1938.
Due here today is the University of Havana basketball team, which has a Madison Square Garden date with L.I.U. on Saturday night.

New issues of temporary loan notes aggregating $89,220,000 were announced yesterday by thirty-one local housing authorities throughout the country for award through competitive bidding. A total of $43,467,000 of these notes will come up for award on Dec. 29, and $45,753,000 on Jan. 6.
Miss Patty Berg tossed aside her crutches this summer and marched off with the woman athlete-of-the-year designation in The Associated Press annual poll.

SALAMANCA, N.Y., Dec. 20 (AP) -- William L. Coston, chairman, John Walrath and A. Lee Armstrong, members of Selective Service Board 646, resigned today in protest, Mr. Coston said, against "unfair and unjust methods now being used to defer young men in industry while men with children are being used in the armed forces."

Eleventh-hour shoppers -- predominantly male -- are reported in force at the counters of every store in town. Each masculine hand is grimly clenched about a list of names -- predominantly female -which will be presented to some harried salesperson, probably without benefit of any further explanation.

In the four years since September, 1939, when Germany invaded Poland, total output of electricity in public utility plants in the United States has increased from 126,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year to the present level of 221,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours, or by 75 per cent, while generating-plant facilities have grown from 40,000,000 kilowatts to a 1943 figure of 50,000,000 kilowatts, or by 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A soldier bonus which would cost about $15,000,000,000, or four times the sum paid out to veterans of the first World War, has been proposed to Congress by the Veterans of Foreign Wars as a substitute for mustering-out pay.

ALGIERS, Dec. 20 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army is battering at the gates of San Vittore, the next obstacle in its path to Cassino, where one of the great battles of the Italian campaign is likely to be fought.

Providing an explanation for previous alarums emitted by Berlin, Moscow now announces that a powerful Russian winter offensive has been under way in the Nevel area of White Russia for the last seven days. The new offensive has been undertaken by what appears to be a new army group designated as the First Soviet Baltic Army, which has been specially equipped for fast movement with an ample supply of tanks, cavalry and ski troops.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Newspapers and magazines will be slimmer or smaller in 1944 under a War Production Board order today which curtails use of paper in all printing operations.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Marauders, the American medium bombers that some experienced airmen thought would be "easy" for the German Air Force, finished their first hundred missions against enemy targets in France and the Low Countries today with a loss ratio, in 6,700 individual sorties, of .3 per Cent.

Shares of the 122-year-old Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company were admitted to trading by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, which also was the date for the receipt by stockholders of the year's final dividend of 50 cents a share, bringing payments for 1943 to 90 cents, against 65 cents paid last year.

SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Tuesday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Indications that the Japanese are begining to pull out of the heavily defended southern part of Bougainville Island were disclosed today by a spokesman for Admiral William F. Halsey.

The terms of the corporation tax passed by the House and approved by the Senate Finance Committee are amazing. First a 95 per cent excess profits tax is levied, wiping out increased earnings, and then a 40 per cent income tax reduces the net earnings to below pre-war levels.

PASSAIC, N.J., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Botany Worsted Mills announced today it had filed a protest with the National Labor Relations Board as a result of the recent election won by the Textile Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A hundred wide-eyed children of historically minded parents enjoyed yesterday afternoon the traditional magician, ate Dutch cookies, and gazed, with their elders, at the large collection of antique dolls, hobby horses and other toys at the old-fashioned Dutch Christmas party for members and their families of the New York Historical Society, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

Three Germans and a Russian dangling from gallows in the market square at Kharkov have the grim distinction to be the first persons publicly convicted and executed as war criminals. Fifty thousand people looked on and motion picture cameras recorded the scene for millions of other spectators and perhaps for posterity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- General buying of rye that ran the price up around 2 1/2 cents at one time today on the Board of Trade and put all deliveries except December into new seasonal ground had considerable influence on other grains. The latter advanced 1 cent or more.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Four years ago the Supreme Court sustained a Postoffice Department fraud order barring a Chicago dentist from selling false teeth by mail, but today the same court held that the same dentist could deduct $36,600 from his gross income for expenses incurred in fighting the fraud order.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Soviet Russia is going to replace "The Internationale" with the music and words of a new national anthem that better expresses the "socialist context of the Soviet States," the Moscow radio announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Their guessing game finally over, the Chicago Bears today hopped into football suits to begin daily practices for the delayed National Football League championship engagement Sunday with the Washington Redskins.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Taft of Cincinnati have come to the Carlyle to visit Mrs. Taft's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wilson Bowers.
The outbreak of influenza appears to be losing its hold on the city, but pneumonia is increasing, according to figures compiled yesterday by the Board of Health.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation telegraphed to William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, today that the concern has already advised" the CIO United Steel Workers Union of willingness "to sign an agreement extending the present contract," but that it is not willing to sign a supplemental agreement presented by the union.

The cost-of-living pay increases being granted city employes, through June 30, 1944, were seen yesterday as strengthening the city administration's hand in demanding of the State Legislature increased municipal taxing power, possibly including restoration of the 2 per cent sales tax.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Although the tone of the stock markets here today was firm on news of improvement in Mr. Churchill's condition, there was little business done, as is usual just before Christmas.

The two two-story buildings containing two stores and six apartments on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 1831-33 Stillwell Avenue, Brooklyn, were sold by the Bank for Savings for cash above two purchase money mortgages of $3,000 each for fifteen years.

Another delay in imposing the sentence of fifteen years to life imprisonment facing Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, the middle-aged partner of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, extortion racketeer, was granted by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions yesterday because of a medical report that Shapiro is near death.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast From Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Some New York dry goods wholesalers are examining, with their larger customers, possibilities of extending "drop shipments" from mills to stores, now available on underwear, hosiery, blankets, workwear, etc., to men's and women's garments and accessories during the first quarter of 1944, it was reported yesterday in the textile market.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Dec. 20 -- Only a large-scale map would show the advances made in the last twenty-four hours -- hill features here and there, one village passed, another almost surrounded, a few more miles along the east-west side roads.

Just before the Congressional recess a bare quorum of the House Interstate Commerce Committee rushed into the railway wage controversy to do the wrong thing. The committee moved to remove all railway labor cases from the jurisdiction of the Economic Stablilization Director.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 15: an increase of $675,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and a decrease of $641,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Six Western division players and five Eastern pros were selected today on The United Press all-professional football team, with the Chicago Bears sweeping honors by gaining four first-team spots.
By a vote exceeding 2 to 1, 14,000 members of the Police Department rejected a proposal to increase their working hours, it was announced at headquarters yesterday.

It is common observation and belief that the poor are the most open-handed helpers of the poor. In the days before Latin was thrown out of the schoolhouse window boys used to hear from Sidonian Dido that not ignorant of misfortune she had learned to aid the wretched.

Advertising of New York and Brooklyn department stores in November totaled 3,457,379 lines compared with 3,788,544 lines for the corresponding month of 1942, a decrease of 8.7 per cent, according to the monthly breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Jersey Oil Heating, Inc., of Irvington, N.J., manufacturer of "Convert-O-Grate," a device for converting oil-burning furnaces to coal-burning furnaces, and Anchor Post Fence Company, of Baltimore, which sells and distributes the device, have agreed to cease and desist from certain representations connected with merchandising the produce, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- John Holmes, president of Swift Co., the packing house, said today, in the company's annual financial report, that there will be more meat on the dining room table in 1944. Larger servings for civilians are on the way, due to increased production of cattle and poultry, he said.

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. made his first attempt yesterday to close a return bout of ten rounds, non-title, between Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, and Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City challenger, as an attraction for Madison Square Garden Jan. 7, and ran into a stalemate.

"Some bacon to the consumer at a few cents more is better than too little bacon." Some months ago former President Hoover enunciated this principle in a discussion of the food program. Now it is to be applied in connection with low-priced lines, particularly wearing apparel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 - The choice of a city for the holding of the Republican National Convention next year may bring about a struggle within the Republican National Committee as hard as that expected over the selection of a date for the convention.

BUTARITARI ISLAND, Makin Atoll, Gilbert Islands -- Fivefoot-two-inch Nicholas Johannes Timmens, who was too little to get into the Netherlands Army, had to travel a long way from his native Netherlands to prove that little men can fight as well as big ones.

While operating my legal plow and awaiting, as did a famous Roman elder statesman after whom we have named one of our great cities, a possible call to help our beleaguered Republicans unseat the impractical and visionary New Dealers, my attention was called to your editorial "La Guardia on Politicians."

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 20 -- Concentrated air assaults were aimed at the important enemy base on Mili Atoll in the eastern chain of the Marshall Islands as the air offensive against the Marshalls entered its twelfth straight day.

Magistrate Frederick L. Strong, sitting for the first time yesterday, said he hoped that he would have "the gift of knowing when to spare the rod and when to lay it on." In Yorkville Court he heard various cases involving gambling, illegal peddling and violation of Park Department rules.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- William McArthur, director of the grain division of the War Food Administration, said today that a "wrong impression" had been given in his testimony recently before the Senate committee investigating the liquor shortage.
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 21 (AP) -The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Dec. 13 amounted to 10,774,805 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 11,744,992 bales to that date a year ago, and 9,914,549 bales two years ago.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) - Connie Mack, who'll be 81 years old Thursday, isn't quite his usual self these days.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday in English from Tokyo and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Christmas mail in New York and Brooklyn is breaking all records for volume this year, according to Postmasters Albert Goldman and Frank J. Quayle Jr. In both postal districts the number of letters, cards and parcels is running 15 to 20 per cent ahead of last year, which was a good year for volume.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Many war contractors, particularly those engaged in what is roughly defined as "small business," have presented a number of arguments to this correspondent to rebut the official objections to the Senate amendments of the Renegotiation Act which were listed in this space last week.

One of the most efficient workmen in the national League dropped quietly out of baseball for the duration recently when Elbie Fletcher, the crack first baseman of the Pittsburgh Pirates, was inducted into the Navy.

MADRID, Dec. 20 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime opened Christmas Week today with the most important gestures of conciliation that it has yet made toward the elements beaten in the civil war.

At the season's second performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, Licia Albanese sang the role of Mimi, which had been played by Jarmila Novotna in the first presentation. Charles Kullman was Rodolfo, replacing Armand Tokatyan.

Sidney Kingsley's "The Patriots" came in from the road last evening to spend this week -- with the exception of Christmas Eve -- as the guest of the newly opened City Center. The winner of the Critics Circle prize for the best play of last season, it remains upon its return an excellent study of Jefferson, Hamilton, Washington and of the doctrines of liberty and of democratic rule by the people.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company plans to reduce its capital stock from $6,000,000 to $3,000,000 and to transfer the amount of this reduction to surplus account, it was revealed yesterday by the bank in its notice to stockholders of the annual meeting to be held on Jan. 19.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Today's revolution in Bolivia was the result of purely internal circumstances and was not and will not be connected in any way with the recent army coup in Argentina, Victor Paz Estenssoro, leader of the junta that overthrew President Enrique Penaranda, said tonight in an exclusive interview by telephone.

During his good-will tour of Central and South America last spring, Vice President Henry A. Wallace visited Bolivia for five days from April 5 to 10. His visit coincided with the action of President Enrique Penaranda and his Cabinet in promulgating a decree of war against the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Ending a one-day stoppage which crippled publication of the Capital's four newspapers, officials of the Columbia Typographical Union acceded tonight to a War Labor Board request that its printer-members return to work.

Marvin Bryant, 161 1/2, Dallas, stopped Freddy Flores, 162 1/4, Jamaica, in the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds before 2,000 at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Referee Billy Cavanagh halted the contest after the fourth round had been completed because of a bad cut over the loser's left eye.

Hanson Baldwin, military editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will preside over the first of four book meetings to be held in Times Hall this spring. The topic of the first meeting, on Jan. 25, will be "When Will the War End?" Orville Prescott, book reviewer for THE NEW YORK TIMES, who is in charge of all arrangements for the four meetings, will preside at the last three programs.

Thomas J. Murray and his two steak houses and commissary were suspended for the duration of the war from dealing in meats after a hearing yesterday on charges of Office of Price Administration violations before Harry B. Chambers, Chief Regional OPA Hearing Commissioner, in the Empire State Building.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Maj. Gualberto Villarroel, a hero of the Chaco war and newly appointed President of Bolivia, said in an interview today that the aims of his Government were "to give back the people their civil rights."
The five-story business building on a plot 26 by 138 feet at 321 Fifth Avenue was sold by Baer Hyman, Inc., to Lydia N. Tadross and Kathy Tadross Court, owners of N. Tadross Co., rug importers.

Representing the "first installment" on 100,000 pints of blood, a scroll recording the donation of 10,216 pints in the last six weeks was presented by the American Women's Voluntary Services to the American Red Cross at noon yesterday at a rally in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art.

Chocolate-covered orange peel and wafer-thin mints -- a hair's breadth of mint cream coated with chocolate -- are among the more unusual candies handmade by Eugenia Tay and sold at her new shop at 50 East Fifty-eighth Street.
