They originated with the Russian-born confectioner, who for many years supplied well-known shops in this city, and are created exclusively by her in the kitchen adjoining her former store on Seventy-second Street.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Navy announced tonight a partial list of Navy personnel killed in the Atlantic Coast Line train wreck near Lumberton, N.C., on Dec. 16, with next of kin, as follows:

In a year which saw the war make heavy inroads upon the ranks of baseball's foremost batsmen it took only a mark of .328 to enable Luke Appling, veteran shortstop of the White Sox, to win the individual batting championship of the American League for 1943, according to the official averages announced yesterday.
ATLANTA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen D. Longstreet, widow of Gen. James Longstreet of Confederate fame, is not quitting her riveter's job at the Bell bomber plant -- just yet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 -- Virginia Bruce, who is playing opposite George Sanders in "Danger in Damascus," formerly titled "Action in Arabia," at RKO, has been named by that studio for the lead in the picturization of the Nancy Hale novel "Prodigal Women."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The country's transportation agencies in two years of war have done a remarkable job, but we are not yet lover the hump, Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, warned today. He said shippers must make every effort to increase their loads by 10 per cent in the next few months.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Japanese bombing attack on a main defense base of the Fourteenth United States Air Force caused only minor damage to the field, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

The Young New Yorker Shop at Lord Taylor's was turned over yesterday afternoon to a bevy of girls whose slender figures, pink complexions and bobs placed them at about 20. They circled in prints and crepes, rustling taffeta and billowing marquisette.

The Government filed yesterday a civil Suit in the United States District Court here charging three foreign and three American corporations with maintaining an international cartel in quebracho, a tanning material derived from a tree found almost exclusively in Paraguay and Argentina.

Four managements (Richard Skinner, Marie Louise Elkins, William A. Brady and William Deering found sufficient merit in "Feathers in a Gale," a comedy by Pauline Jamerson and Reginald Lawrence, to pay out option money. It is interesting to note that Miss Elkins' faith has not diminished, as she is one of the backers of the Arthur Hopkins-Martin Burton presentation, directed by Mr. Hopkins, which opens tonight at the Music Box.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Bolivian revolution has brought into power a nationalistic, totalitarian regime with apparent leanings toward Argentina, if not to-, ward the Axis, but the coup of Victor Paz Estenssoro and his supporters is not expected to affect materially the solidarity of the United Nations and the conduct of the war, according to informal expressions of opinion today.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- In the third week of major fighting along Germany's Balkan flank, the Yugoslav Partisan army cut heavily into the German forces tonight, and a Berlin communique for the first time frankly characterized the action as "grim battles" in which 5,668 fresh Yugoslav casualties were claimed in eastern Bosnia alone.

Their dreams of grandeur rudely shattered by what happened at the Polo Grounds Sunday, the football Giants yesterday were scattered to all points of the compass, some (Al Blozis for one) not to return possibly until it's over over there and others (maybe Mel Hein, Tuffy Leemans and a few more) never again as active players.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Oslo was shaken today by exploding ammunition thrown into the city by the blowing up of a German munitions ship in the harbor twenty-four hours earlier.

ATLANTA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Gov. Ellis Arnall has recommended that the Georgia Board of Pardons and Paroles pardon Robert Elliott Burns, the famous "fugitive from a Georgia chain gang," The Atlanta Constitution said tonight. It said Burns visited the Governor when he was in New York recently to address the Southern Society.

Christmas trade in local stores entered the home stretch yesterday with sales running behind expectations for the month. A last- minute spurt in gift-buying is due this week, which has five shopping days against four last year, but estimates indicated that December volume in department stores here might decline about 2 to 4 per cent under the 1942 month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Senate Finance Committee will meet tomorrow to give the tax bill a final scrutiny before reporting it. Chairman George late today decided to call Drew Pearson, Washington newspaper columnist, for questioning about his statement that Ellsworth C. Alvord, attorney, had boasted that he controlled the chairman's vote on taxes.

The little land-locked, mountainous country of Bolivia, with its 3,500,000 people, produces 15 per cent of the world's tin, ranks second only to China in the mining of antimony and is the third largest producer of tungsten. Bolivia also is South America's second largest exporter of rubber.

TRENTON, Dec. 20 -- John Borg, Hackensack publisher, today began a Supreme Court action to test the legality of the method by which the New Jersey Legislature has undertaken a revision of the State Constitution.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden put the British Government on record today as supporting the International Labor Organization as the body best suited to handle that field in the post-war reconstruction plans of the United Nations.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Dec. 21 (UP) -- A communique

ALGIERS, Dec. 20 -- Carrying a step further the strategy of a two-sided bombing of Germany, Liberators of the United States Fifteenth Air Force reached yesterday to the most northerly point they had yet struck, flying 100 miles beyond the Brenner Pass, and attacked Augsburg, American fighters escorted them all the way.

"Those of us who are fortunate enough to be at home this Christmas owe so much to so many, that the least we can do is try to lend a helping hand to those who have known better and happier days," wrote John A. Aaron, sending $10 to the Neediest Cases Fund.

Increased efforts by Communists to spread their doctrines among Negroes in this country were reported yesterday by Waiter White president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, who pointed to the George Washington Carver School in Harlem and to similar institutions in Chicago and Los Angeles as examples of how left-wing elements were attempting to shape Negro opinion.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York yesterday went on record as opposing the Kilgore Bill (S702) and has requested a hearing, charging that it is designed "to create a political mechanism which would drastically change the economic structure of the United States."

Ethelbert Smith thought that perhaps .too much was being made of the broken news release and the Cairo conference. It would be a pity to have the United States and Great Britain falling into mutual recrimination at any time, and especially so in this season of good-will.

A Legion of Merit decoration, posthumously awarded to Staff Sgt. Alfred H. Benjamin, 29 years old, for intelligence work in North Africa, was presented yesterday to his widow, Mrs. Ann Benjamin of 325 East Fifty-seventh Street, by Col. G. S. Beurket, post commander, in post headquarters at Fort Jay, Governors Island.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Dec. 21 -- Troops of the United States Sixth Army captured the Arawe air strip in New Britain while American bombers gave the Japanese Cape Gloucester air base a terrific 414-ton blast ing, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Army Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- In his testimony today, Lieut. Gen. Brehon P. Somervell denied as "utterly without foundation" charges that he undertook the Canol project without consulting his superiors or associates. He said that the fact that the project was outside the United States removed it from the jurisdiction of the WPB and Secretary Ickes.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20 -- A swift military coup carried out at dawn today by a group of comparatively junior Army officers ousted the President of Bolivia, Gen. Enrique Penaranda, and placed in power a mixed junta of officers and civilians.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Three members of the extraordinary grand jury which will conduct a sweeping investigation of alleged law violations in Democratic Albany County were selected today at the opening of a special term of Supreme Court convened by Governor Dewey.

A war-bond subscription of nearly $90,000 was realized last night through the Allied Flag Ball and Debutante Cotillion in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Set in a patriotic decor symbolizing United Nations amity, the ball served a triple purpose by aiding the war effort, raising funds for the New York Infirmary for Women and Children and providing an entertainment serving as the formal introduction to society of many young women of prominent families.

A HOSPITAL, Somewhere in England, Dec. 20 -- It is not a very happy Christmas story, but somebody should say a word about the doctors and nurses from the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center at 168th Street and Broadway who are now looking after a great many wounded and frozen men of the Eighth United States Air Force.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Packers, with two and three days' slaughter requirements on hand, were unable to absorb the 28,000 hogs marketed here today, and about 12,000 head remained unsold.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 20 -- This unhappy city, anathema to service men on brief liberty, seems today to cry in vain for some Government miracle man to lift it from the slough in which it has gasped, almost helpless, the past two years.

A war-bond subscription of nearly $90,000 was realized last night through the Allied Flag Ball and Debutante Cotillion in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Set in a patriotic decor symbolizing United Nations amity, the ball served a triple purpose by aiding the war effort, raising funds for the New York Infirmary for Women and Children and providing an entertainment serving as the formal introduction to society of many young women of prominent families.

A HOSPITAL, Somewhere in England, Dec. 20 -- It is not a very happy Christmas story, but somebody should say a word about the doctors and nurses from the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center at 168th Street and Broadway who are now looking after a great many wounded and frozen men of the Eighth United States Air Force.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Packers, with two and three days' slaughter requirements on hand, were unable to absorb the 28,000 hogs marketed here today, and about 12,000 head remained unsold.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 20 -- This unhappy city, anathema to service men on brief liberty, seems today to cry in vain for some Government miracle man to lift it from the slough in which it has gasped, almost helpless, the past two years.

Twenty-five industrial concerns of the metropolitan area received last night from the Greater New York Safety Council certificates recognizing outstanding records in reducing operating accidents during wartime. Howard P. Wall, chairman of the council's industrial section, which conducted a six-month interplant accident reduction contest, presented the awards to representatives of the companies at a council dinner in the Building Trades Employers Association rooms at 2 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Ninety-three German raiders have been destroyed by British anti-aircraft guns and searchlight crews thus far this year and fifty-nine more were probably destroyed, according to figures released tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- Acting swiftly, the Securities and Exchange Commission today set next Monday for a hearing on a request by the Illinois Power Company for exemption from the competitive bidding rule on a proposed issue of $65,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, due 1973.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTER IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Dec. 22 (UP) -- A communique:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21 -- The road remained rough for favorite players at Tropical Park today. When the Millbrook Stable's Swimmin Hole, picked over ten other sprinters in the Florida City Purse, raced far back all the way under Ted Atkinson, it marked the sixteenth consecutive downfall for public choices since Black Badge won Saturday's sixth event.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The first session of the seventy-eighth "Victory" Congress adjourned today, the Senate at 12:46 P.M. and the House at 4:23. Thus closed quietly and somewhat drearily a 350-day gathering, marked by eager cooperation with the Executive branch in prosecuting the war and preparing for post-war collaboration to make the peace secure, and by its disagreements and repeated revolts on domestic issues.
RENO, Nev., Dec. 21 -- Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell obtained a divorce today from James H.R. Cromwell, former Minister to Canada, on the grounds of cruelty and three years of separation.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Firmness again was prevalent in the stock markets here today but even less business was done today than yesterday.

As multitudes of New Yorkers busied themselves yesterday with last-minute shopping and hunting for Christmas trees, many others were equally busy with preparations for welcoming the strangers within the city's gates and with bringing good cheer to the less fortunate among the city's millions.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Well over 800 four-motored bombers of the Royal Air Force, one of the most powerful striking forces in the histroy of aerial warfare, were believed to have completed the destruction of the German chemical and armament center of Frankfort on the Main last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- Asserting that the Securities and Exchange Commission should not meddle in local politics, the Cities Service Power and Light Company and subsidiary companies requested today the denial of a motion by the city of Tucson, Ariz., that the Federal Light and Traction Company be required to divest itself of its properties in that municipality.

The United States Fish and Wildlife Service yesterday issued its annual report to Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes and made it the occasion to point out that the nation's wildlife resources are helping win the war.

A Christmas appeal for speedy adoption of the Senate resolution proposing the creation of a special commission to bring about the rescue of the surviving Jews of Europe was sent yesterday by eight religious leaders to Vice President Henry A. Wallace, Senate majority and minority leaders and members of the House and Senate committees involved.

Free transportation for men in the armed forces from this city to their homes in other parts of the country is the aim of the Service Men's Travel Canteen, newly organized by twenty-four business men and one business woman, it was announced yesterday by L.S. Marchiony, director of the agency's executive board, at its headquarters, 574 West 130th Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- In an attempt to move some 100,000,000 pounds of pork to civilians within ten days, the Office of Price Administration designated tonight the Spare Stamp One on the first page of War Ration Book 4 as a special pork stamp worth five points and good for the retail purchase of pork until 12:01 A.M., Jan. 2.

Newspaper readers were undoubtedly disturbed to read of the charges of fraud leveled by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein at one of the city's charitable organizations. Any final judgment as to the merits of the charges will, of course, have to await the outcome of the litigation begun by the Attorney General.

License Commissioner Paul Moss told a meeting of theatre managers and producers yesterday afternoon that "about the first of the year" he would start "holding a hearing on every renewal of a ticket broker's license." Ordinarily such licenses are reissued by the Department of License on application by the brokers.

Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands conferred twice with Mayor La Guardia, then issued late yesterday a statement branding Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine's action in dismissing charges of subversive activity against Patrolman James L. Drew as "a major defeat on the home front."

CAIRO, Dec. 21 -- Going on the assumption that, despite divergent political affiliations, all Greeks in the homeland were willing to fight the German invader, but emphasizing that Greek guerrilla elements committed to this purpose were at odds with one another and even engaged in fratricidal strife, Premier Emmanuel Tsouderos appealed tonight to his compatriots for unity, the alternative to which he forecast would mean ruin to their country.

More than 250 lower East Side children received gifts and were entertained by the singing of Mary Martin, stage and screen star, and the quips of former Governor Alfred E. Smith at a Christmas party yesterday afternoon at the Beekman Hospital, 117 Beekman Street.

Paul Lukas in Warners' "Watch On the Rhine," and Greer Garson in Metro's "Random Harvest," respectively, gave the best male and female performances on the American screen in 1943, according to the results of the third annual nation-wide poll of newspaper, magazine, syndicate, news service and radio critics and reviewers conducted by The Film Daily, a trade journal.

John B. Turk, chairman of the Downtown Rationing Board at 107 Walker Street, and his brother-in-law, Ralph Diamond, a paid employe at the Midtown Rationing Board, 1775 Broadway, have been suspended pending an investigation, Daniel P. Woolley, newly appointed regional director of the Office of Price Administration, disclosed yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Chinese troops have recaptured four important Japanese strongholds north of Tungting Lake, the High Command announced today, and apparently have regained control of the "rice bowl" region south of the Lin River except for a few isolated pockets of resistance.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec 21 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Headquarters communique:

The Music Box, which used to tinkle with the sound of the revue and the sight of the star and garter, now is pursuing quite another muse. For last evening Arthur Hopkins and Martin Burton set upon its stage a comedy called "Feathers in a Gale," a comedy which is one of the slowest little comedies Forty-fifth Street has seen in a long time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Although receipts at major livestock markets dropped somewhat today, packers had to contend with the largest number of hogs ever held over from a previous session, and the War Food Administration predicted that more local embargoes would be placed on the country's leading hog trading centers.

ARMY HEADQUARTERS IN THE CENTRAL PACIFIC, Dec. 21 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, has completed two days of conferences and inspection in the Hawaiian Islands and is now en route to Washington to report on the later phases of his 35,000-mile flight around the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Congress recessed today without receiving any report from the President on the Cairo and Teheran conferences, which were held in unparalleled secrecy; and this may add to the already large crop of dissensions between the Executive and Legislative branches of the Government.

Regulations of the Egyptian import licensing authorities have recently been intensified to a point which makes trading with certain areas virtually impossible and protests are being filed with the State Department, exporters reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The disrupted social situation in Norfolk, Va., due to the wartime influx of defense workers and hundreds of thousands of service men on leave and in transit has been "greatly improved" in the last six months, Corrington Gill, director of the Committee for Congested Production Areas, stated today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Spokesmen for several steel companies told the War Labor Board today that a wage increase for steel workers would necessitate a price increase for steel and upset the "Little Steel" formula as the basis of the Administration's wage-stabilization policy.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Japanese arc starting to evacuate the southern part of Bougainville island, their last major stronghold in the Solomons, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox revealed today at his press conference.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 21 -- A crowded fifteen-car troop train, traveling over the Pennsylvania- Reading Seashore Line, was flagged down tonight shortly after a burning tree was found blocking the tracks near the Iron Rock Country Club in adjacent Pennsauken.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 22 -- Taking his cue from the Russian choice of a new anthem to replace "The Internationale," George Bernard Shaw suggested today a new second verse for "God Save the King."

The apparent impasse between the sixteen Southern railroads and the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice over the committee's order to cease discriminatory practice affecting employment of Negroes will soon be broken, Malcolm Ross, chairman of the committee, predicted yesterday.

For a school which expected, when the Navy and Marines took all of last year's squad, to drop basketball for the duration, St. Francis College is not discouraged with its team. On the other hand, it is even a little bit proud of it. The defeat last Saturday by N.Y.U. in their first Garden appearance had some encouraging signs in it for Joe Brennan, who is back as coach.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- The German D.N.B. agency said today that "Allied armed bands" had made attempts to land from barges on the Dalmatian coast eleven miles below the Yugoslav port of Spalato, but had been repelled with "considerable losses."

A U.S. BOMBER BASE, in Britain, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Flying Fortress Whodat battled the thirteenth-mission hoodoo all the way to Bremen and back yesterday and then, with one engine, the oxygen lines and the landing gear shot to pieces, made a successful crash landing.

Carrying lighted tapers and clad in red and blue robes, 150 Rockefeller Center choristers circled the skating pond in Rockefeller Plaza last night, took their places on the double-tiered platform at the base of the Prometheus Fountain, and sang old-fashioned carols.

Before the New York City government embarks on its program for building new schools, hospitals and parkways, attention should be given to "certain old familiar problems dressed up in post-war attire," Matthew G. Ely declared yesterday upon taking office as the newly elected president of the New York Board of Trade.

ALGIERS, Dec. 21 -- Authoritative details of the plan of the French Committee of National Liberation for the restoration of republican government in France were given to this correspondent today. The plan received final approval from the Committee on Saturday and the text will be published when it is submitted to the Provisional Consultative Assembly in January.

NAPLES, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Germans, faced with a growing revolt in the occupied areas of Italy, were reported today to have evacuated large sections of Rome, apparently preparing to destroy these areas and perhaps eventually to abandon the capital entirely.

A group of women tenants in the six-story apartment house at 701 West 189th Street applauded and exclaimed "Good!" "Hooray!" in the Municipal Term Court yesterday when Magistrate William W. Hoppin imposed a $150 fine on Salvatore Manteon, their landlord, with the alternative of a ten-day jail term, for failing to heat their apartments properly.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 21 -- There are now more than 250,000 men and women organized into approximately twenty-six divisions fighting a savage war against some of Adolf Hitler's best veteran units along Yugoslavia's frontiers. That front stretches approxi mately 350 miles across forests, ravines and snow-covered mountains ranging between the Julian Alps of Slovenia and the forbidding crags separating bleak Montenegro from Albania and the south.

In his handling of the railway labor problem the President has violated every sound administrative principle. He has failed to lay down clear rules. He has failed to delegate power clearly, and to one top agency alone. He has failed to support the administrators and agencies to whom he has delegated power.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, Democrat, declared today that Congress was being asked to withdraw from regulation of the fire-insurance business at a time when New York State is making startling disclosures on the "combination" and rate structure of these companies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Arthur S. Lyons has announced a tentative schedule for Producing Artists, Inc., an organization recently formed by Lyons and David L. Loew, to produce for United Artists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The retention of Gen. George C. Marshall in this country as Army Chief of Staff and the assignment of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to lead as supreme Allied commander in western Europe will necessitate major changes in the high command in the Mediterranean and in Britain.

A firmer price undertone features trading in raw furs, with the market regaining some of the stability which was lost during the recent uncertainty surrounding the issuance of its new price regulation by the Office of Price Administration.

Award of a new issue of $455,000 of waterworks refunding bonds, dated Dec. 15, 1943, and due serially from June 15, 1946 to 1957, was made yesterday by Oneida, N.Y., to the Bankers Trust Company and the Chase National Bank. The bankers jointly bid 100.659 for the bonds as 1.10 per cents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The President held his press and radio conference and had appointments with Senator Lucas, Secretary Knox and Secretary Hull.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 312, which compared with 696 in the preceding week and 450 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The report of Servel, Inc., for the fiscal year ended with October diselosed yesterday a net profit of $1,828,236 before renegotiation but after Federal taxes and all other deductions. The earnings are equivalent to $1.05 a share on the 1,726,926 shares of common stock outstanding and compare with $1,052,846, or 61 cents a share in the preceding fiscal year.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill today forwarded congratulations to the chief of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command for the recent series of heavy attacks on Germany, indicating that the Prime Minister was recovering rapidly from his siege of pneumonia in the Middle East.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- More than 1,600 foremen struck at the Ford Willow Run bomber plant today, threatening to halt aircraft production. At the same time it appeared to be the opening gun in a showdown battle between the Foreman's Association of America and the Ford Motor Company and other Detroit area industries.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- With Bill Cowley, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, showing the way with three goals, the Bruins protected their home game slate by outskating the Toronto Maple Leafs for an 8-5 victory tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Rear Admiral E.S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, reported to Congress today that as of Sept. 30, sixty-six of 128 Government-owned ships which had been transferred to foreign registry remained under foreign-flag operation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- The grain markets made a firm start and an easy finish today on the Board of Trade. Buying early was based on a bullish construction placed by traders on a report of the Department of Agriculture issued late yesterday indicating relatively small yields of winter wheat and rye next year.

The supply of turkeys for Christmas is shorter than for Thanksgiving, and other dressed poultry is growing scarce, according to Federal and food trade reports which showed yesterday that New Yorkers as a rule are shifting from turkey and poultry to ham and pork during the holidays.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 21 -- Chileans continued to focus attention today on the Bolivian situation despite reassuring statements put out by the revolutionary government regarding its firm support of the democracies and lack of any inspiration from affairs in Argentina.

ALGIERS, Dec. 21 -- The Allies heaviest bombers thundered over Bulgaria and Greece again yesterday in earth-shaking assaults on railway yards at Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, and airfields at Eleusis, near Athens.

A five-hour radio program devoted to Christmas messages from boys of metropolitan New York who are serving in war theatres around the world will be broadcast from 5 to 10.15 P.M. on Saturday over Station WMCA, it was announced yesterday.

The current advance of industrialization in Brazil has been "handicapped, not helped," by wartime conditions, George E. Quisenberry, secretary of the Overseas Automotive Club, who has just returned from a 16,000-mile three-month tour of Latin America, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Falangist party has, according to a State Department announcement today, committed against the United States consulate at Valencia an outrage similar to that perpetrated almost exactly a month ago against the British vice consulate at Saragossa.

Landers, Frary Clark, New Britain, Conn., manufacturers of electrical appliances for the home, will release a national campaign in 1944 designed to promote post-war sales. First insertions will appear in the February issues of national magazines and newspapers and trade publications will be used by dealers throughout the year.

ALGIERS, Dec. 21 -- The American troops who captured San Pietro Infine were consolidating and mopping up in the San Pietro-San Vittore area yesterday but, as far as could be learned here, they remained a few miles from San Vittore and at least six miles from Cassino.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- With half their planes and a third of their men in the armed forces, the country's civil airlines nevertheless are carrying twice as much cargo and airmail as in peacetime and flying more passenger miles.

Despite the inclination of many Brooklyn and Bronx amateur "farmers" not to pull up their radishes and other vegetables until they grew in neatly tied bunches, the produce of New York's backyard and corner lot gardens reached almost astronomical figures in 1943, Carl F. Wedell, executive secretary of the Greater New York Victory Garden Council, announced yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21 -- A three-cornered economic agreement was negotiated today by Brazil, the United States and Great Britain for the purchase of the exportable surpluses of the Brazilian rice crops to be harvested in 1944 and 1945.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 21 -- It is no longer the business of Europe to act as the guardian of the Arab peoples, Emir Feisal, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, declared today. He said that the future of the Arabs lay in their own hands and "we should look after ourselves and our own affairs."

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Purchase by Armour Co., meat packers, of ten plants belonging to the De Soto Creamery and Produce Company of Minneapolis, was announced today by Armour. The transaction was completed over the week-end, the announcement said.

The black art of modern propaganda has been so profligate in inventing and misusing slogans, battle cries, songs and symbols that they have lost much of their meaning and most of their value in democracies exposed to the cacophony of rival propaganda drives. It is otherwise in totalitarian countries, where there is only one kind of propaganda, and where all rival propaganda or clash of ideas is ruthlessly suppressed.

Still smarting from the rejection by the police force of the proposal to increase working hours, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday afternoon at City Hall that pay rises of $420 annually as a "cost-of-living bonus" would be granted to the 9,000 members of the Fire Department, beginning Jan. 1, in return for working an extra twenty-four hours every twenty days.

The Government's drive against those who preyed on motion picture producers and others prominent in Hollywood may lead to additional prosecutions, Boris Kostelanetz, special assistant to the Attorney General, said yesterday at the trial of seven men accused of conspiracy to extort more than $1,000,000 from the motion picture industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Pig iron was freed of allocation control by the War Production Board today. According to officials this is the first metal so liberated since the war agency began imposing restrictions on metals prior to Pearl Harbor.

The poor, like the rich and the people in between, have their faults. The Hundred Neediest Cases include some in which a father has taken to drinking and abused his family, or has abandoned his wife and children, or in which growing boys add to their distracted mother's troubles by fighting, or in which someone has tried to escape responsibility by suicide.

ALGIERS, Dec. 21 -- Five Frenchmen formerly high in the nation's political life, including former Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin, were in Algiers' military prison today charged with treason by the French Committee of National Liberation.

The Metropolitan Museum is opening today a small but beautiful and timely exhibition for the holiday season. Thirteen early Renaissance paintings from the collection of the late Maitland F. Griggs, a trustee who died last July, have been specially installed in Gallery E-15.

Old-timers who were in the uniformed services during the last war will remember Norfolk, Va., if their duties ever took them there. With a city of 130,000 now playing host as best it can to 150,000 war workers and 200,000 service men, today's conditions make those of 1917 and 1918 comparatively idyllic.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "Riding High," a Paramount production in technicolor, starring Dorothy Lamour, Dick Powell and Victor Moore, is the holiday attraction at the Paramount. In featured roles in the comedy, with music, are Cass Daley, Gil Lamb and Milt Britton and his band. . . .

We have just been apprised that flyers of the United States Eighth Air Force will be equipped with a football-type steel helmet as protection against shrapnel fragments. The helmets will weigh two pounds for turret gunners, three pounds for other crew members.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Australian ground troops in New Guinea have reached Fortification Point, two miles north of the Musuweng River, a communique announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Al Reasoner, 23-year-old lightweight boxer, died in Columbus Hospital today, about five hours after he suffered a technical knockout in a ten-round boxing bout last night with Freddie Dawson of Chicago.

Future output of many civilian textile products heretofore available in white may have to be restricted to unbleached or natural effects in order to enable chemical suppliers to conserve compounds more urgently needed to meet expanding military needs in both the high octane gasoline and synthetic rubber programs, it was reported yesterday by Worth Street textile processors.

There are many men who will regret the passing of Dr. James H. Kimball, head of the United States Weather Bureau in New York, but none more than the early ocean fliers whose lives depended on his judgment, or those who go down to the sea in ships in these dangerous times, and who often paid a last-minute call to his office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The disclosure that General Marshall had held important conferences with commanders in the Pacific emphasized dramatically tonight the increasing tempo of the campaigns against the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A possibility that the Office of War Mobilization might direct the task of converting American industry to a peacetime basis emerged from a conference today between Bernard M. Baruch and James F. Byrnes, of OWM, and members of the Senate Committee on Post-War Planning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Roosevelt in a Christmas and New Year message transmitted to veterans in Government hospitals assured them of the nation's gratitude for service "so bravely and honorably rendered."

John Hersey, who wrote so vividly of his experiences on Guadalcanal in "Into the Valley," published last year by Knopf, accompanied the American invasion forces to Italy. What he saw there forms the background for his novel, "A Bell for Adano," which Knopf will bring out on Jan. 17.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in Mandarin to China and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Federal Judge C.C. Hincks approved today with some corrections the Interstate Commerce Commission plan for reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad under which common and preferred stocks of the carrier, in receivership since 1935, become worthless.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Governor Dewey took over the O'Connell-inspired investigation of the Republican Legislature today, stripping the local Democratic organization of the power it had started to use to try to prove that official corruption in Albany was as much Republican as Democratic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Senator Walter F. George, Finance Committee chairman, hit back today at Secretary Morgenthau's criticism of the tax bill, particularly its proposed changes in the renegotiation of war contracts.
Two properties which had been held in unchanged ownerships for long periods were reported yesterday as having passed into new hands.

Two paintings from the collection of the late J.P. Morgan have been bought as anonymous gifts to the John Herron Art Institute in Indianapolis, in memory of Daniel W. and Elizabeth C. Marmon of Indianapolis, it was announced yesterday by M. Knoedler Co., Inc., 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Rare indeed are those who can sing with Amiens in "As You Like It" that they see no enemy but winter, which begins during or just before the lunch hour today, and rough weather. The most peaceable and best-disposed householder, even in the most carefully neutral nation, must be aware that he has another opponent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- With representatives of the Cuban Government due here within a week to resume discussions on the disposal of that country's sugar, high-test and blackstrap molasses in the coming year, the entire question of recent imports of Latin-American gins, whiskies and rums is expected to be reopened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The decision of Congress on the subsidy question will determine whether living costs go up next year, Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, said tonight in a weekly broadcast on rationing and price problems over the Blue Network.

An unnamed donor has given $50,000 to the New School for Social Research for further development of a new system of demountable housing considered particularly suitable for military and post-war rehabilitation world, Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the school, announced yesterday.

New York courts are rejecting as waste paper those convenient licenses to sever old matrimonial ties and form new ones that Nevada grants so obligingly, provided one has sufficent money to pay the cost.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 21 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Propaganda Minister, and Reich Marshal Hermann Goering have invested much money of late in the Paris art market, buyinug old masters for cash dollar payments, according to an art expert who has just returned here from the former French capital.

In their own peculiar jargon, a quartet each of British and American war workers vied yesterday for complimentary phrases to describe their respective countrywomen's war efforts. In the words of the Britishers, their women have "come up trumps" and "are doing a job of work."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Drawing on the practical experience of Washington's between-trains nursery, as well as on scientific theory, Dr. Katherine Bain of the Federal Children's Bureau, gave a few travel rules today for the parents.
Apropos Lucius Peters' letter, "Parlor Stove Not So Hot," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 11, I am reminded of the open fireplaces in the homes of my friends in the British Isles.

It's the New York Yankees doing the rags to riches routine to move from the biggest disappointment of 1942 to No. 1 team of 1943, but Joe McCarthy's clan had to go hard to nose out the Irish of Notre Dame.

Although the Red Sox suffered heavy blows in their offensive equipment last Summer with the military induction of such stars as Ted Williams and Dominic DiMaggio, Joe Cronin's array managed to salvage something from the campaign by capturing the American League's team fielding honors for 1943.

The War Food Administration has just ordered that beginning Jan. 16 all yeast-raised commercial bakery products -- coffee cakes, sweet buns, plain rolls, doughnuts, crullers and so on -- must be fortified with the same nutrients used in the enrichment of white bread.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Canadian pulp production has exceeded expectations and will permit larger-than-scheduled deliveries of newsprint to the United States in the first quarter of 1944, the War Production Board said today, but publishers will not benefit immediately.

Originating in Russia, "Listen, Professor!" comes to the Forrest this evening by way of Cambridge, where the Harvard Dramatic Club presented the Alexander Afinogenov comedy a year ago for the first time in English as translated by J.J. Robbins under the title of "Mashenka."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Roosevelt said today that he had a simple policy regarding the soldiers vote, which was that every soldier should be given an opportunity to vote unless actual combat duties interfered. There probably would be relatively few of the latter, he added.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 -Field Marshal Viscount Wavell, Viceroy of India, concentrated on war, food and reconstruction problems and avoided political questions in his first major public speech, delivered today in Calcutta to the Associated Chambers of Commerce.

The realty business of the late Warren Marks, established more than twenty-two years ago, has been acquired by executives long associated with him in business, and will be continued under the name of Rossbach Associates, Inc., with Walter S. Rossbach as head of the new organization.

THE drubbing the Giants received from the Redskins last Sunday caused considerable surprise, naturally enough. It can't be explained any more than one can attempt to add up a couple of famous Redskin-Bear scores a few years back. It was 7 -- 3 in favor of Washington one week and a fortnight later the Monsters of the Midway, deftly removing the hyphen, among other things, crushed the capital Braves by the classic 73-to-0 count.

The Federal Government cracked down yesterday on a "million dollar" black market ring said to have been offering case lots of liquor above ceiling prices to hotels and night clubs. Seven men were arrested by agents of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department following a "tip" relayed from the Hotel Astor to the Government enforcement agency.

Switching operations predominated yesterday on the stock market, with prices on the easier side in irregular movements. Interest was restricted and trading on the New York Stock Exchange was the lightest since Dec. 3. Transfers reached only 656,320 shares, compared with 854,790 on Monday.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle filed today in Essex County Common Pleas Court a motion to intervene in the $50,000 libel suit filed against Thorn Lord, acting United States attorney for New Jersey, by Leo Rosenblum, president of the Hudson County Tax Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A subcommittee of the five railroad operating unions rejected tonight a proposal to end the strike threat of 350,000 train service and engine-men which had been offered by the three negotiating committees of the railroads.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 21 -- The revolutionary government which overthrew pro-Allied President Enrique Penaranda in a coup d'etat, tonight formally aligned Bolivia on the side of the United Nations, indicating the revolt might have been strictly national in nature.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21 -- Three new members were added today to the board of directors of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, Thomas N. McCarter, chairman, announced after a meeting of the board.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission on proposed transactions of the Florida Power and Light Company and its parent, the American Power and Light Company, a sub-holding company of the Electric Bond and Share Company, was adjourned today to be continued at the trial examiner's call for the purpose of presenting results of the public offering of securities.
ALGIERS, Dec. 21 -- A communique:

There's a new girl on the job in industrial plants all over the country. In the New York area she's at work simultaneously in 500 of them. Plant nurses who are worried over women with sprained backs, personnel managers beside themselves over the condition of locker rooms, call on this pert young lady in the blue coverall to point out to fellow-workers the error of their ways.
MONTREAL, Dec. 21 (AP) -- City Hall was virtually empty today with approximately 2,000 clerks and stenographers on strike for annual wage increases of $395 to $500.

TRENTON, Dec. 21 -- Representatives of the Army, Navy and Federal Bureau of Investigation took steps here today to intensify the campaign against careless talk by civilians and members of the armed forces. The drive will be conducted by Civilian Defense officials.

The twelve-story office and store building on an irregular plot 104.3 by 112.1 feet at 1476 Broadway, northeast corner of Forty-second Street, was sold at auction yesterday to Bertha Kanarek, trustee, as plaintiff, on a bid of $500 above a mortgage of $1,750,000.

For the first time since the outbreak of the recent epidemic of influenza and other respiratory ills, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, was willing to admit yesterday that the outbreak was getting no worse and appeared to be definitely on the wane.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Meyer E. Ruback and John E. Toolan, attorneys for James H.R. Cromwell, said today:

Johnny Colan, West Sider, now in the Coast Guard, notched his third victory in a row last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. Giving Buddy Knox, air-transport service, an advantage of 31 1/2 pounds, the guardsman handed the Army man a convincing beating in the feature eight-round bout before a gathering of about 2,500 fans.

ONCE a college professor's oh so musically cultured wife gushed fulsomely to the eminent violinist whose concert she had just attended. The names of his most distinguished colleagues rattled off her tongue while she sought for a really appropriate compliment. "The fact is, Mr. Spalding, that they are all technique and no soul -- whereas you," and she paused for breath, seeking the mot juste, the perfect tribute, "are all soul and no technique."

It is not true that when a nation signs a treaty of alliance it gives the partner a blank check to make war or peace. Treaties of alliance are not absolute commitments in practice. On the other hand, the lack of a formal alliance is compatible with a deeply rooted comradeship that manifests itself in a crisis.

The reported arrest of ex-Premier Orlando indicates that the Germans have carried out what Mussolini never dared to do. He never ventured to liquidate various strong opponents, like Croce, Badoglio and Orlando. Orlando's case was especially noteworthy; he was famous for the deluge of postcards he kept sending to friends all over the peninsula, with nothing on them but "Resist! Resist!"

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 22 -Russia's Baltic army, storming down from Nevel toward the Vitebsk-Polotsk rail line, has captured more than 100 populated places, killed 1,600 Germans and reached to within twenty miles of the German defense bastion of Vitebsk -- now menaced from two sides -- Moscow announced today.

Whether the Children among the Neediest Cases are members of a family of nine struggling against an accumulation of misfortunes, or a boy or girl needing shelter, clothing, affection and security, the plight of these children brings many gifts to the fund and many moving letters.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The names of thirty-seven members of the crew of the collier Suffolk "missing at sea while serving their country," were given out today, but the names of six members of the naval gun crew were not disclosed.

TRENTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Former Governor Harold G. Hoffman said today he often had asked New Jersey civil service heads to help his friends get State jobs while he was Governor, but added that he had never requested either civil service commissioners or employes to break the law to accommodate him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Walter W. Best, 38-year-old resident of Pontiac, Mich., who has been adjudged of unsound mind by a commission, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of threatening to take a "pot shot" at President Roosevelt.

For Americans the chief importance of the Soviet-Czechoslovak pact lies in its relation to the four-power declaration signed at the Moscow conference. Except for two minor changes in phrasing, this declaration was written in Washington and the pith of it was incorporated in the Senate resolution pledging the United States to cooperate in an international organization to enforce peace.

Unable to deliver the promised non-title bout for Bobby Ruffin against Beau Jack, the lightweight champion, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. yesterday signed the latter for two over-the-weight battles next month in Madison Square Garden.

A gift of $50 rushed by airmail from Hollywood, Calif., brings sharply into focus that fact that only three days remain in which contributions can be speeded before Christmas to the Neediest Cases Fund for the families and fragments of families, the aged and sick, the homeless, unwanted children who are the most distressed in the city known to eight leading private family welfare organizations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A pilot of a commercial airplane flying across the Atlantic in the military contract service dropped low to look at and report an iceberg lying directly in a convoy route.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 21 -- Carrying their attack into the northern Marshall Islands for the second consecutive day, heavy bombers of the Seventh United States Air Force poured twenty-five tons of bombs yesterday on Taroa, Japanese air base in the Maloelap Atoll, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander-in-chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean Areas, announced today.

Careful tests, checks and rechecks over a period of nearly three months have proved that the present-day heating value of No. 2 fuel oil has depreciated about 25 per cent, as compared with the same product as supplied in this area a year ago. One assumes that this is due to a war which all patriotic citizens wish to support uncomplainingly on the home front; and that the situation cannot be corrected at present.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

With the recommendation that Federal funds be allocated to provide care for the children over 2 years of age of service men's wives who must work, a solution appears to be in sight for one phase of the child-care problem in New York City.

Railway Revenues Railway gross revenues continue[ to increase, and indications are that those for December will reach the highest level for any month. The Association of American Railroads reported yesterday that on the basis of advance reports, the gross revenues of the nation's carriers last month were about 9 per cent ahead of those for November, last year.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The provisional regime of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) ordered King Peter's Government-in-Exile deprived of all rights tonight and "forbade" the King to return to his homeland until it is liberated.

ONCE upon a time, when I was working for a high-powered employer, a group of hired aptitude-testers moved in on me as I was quietly reading at my desk. Before I could climb down a drain pipe or hide under the rug, they had me figuratively bound and gagged. How was my finger dexterity, my tweezer dexterity, my structural visualization? When I said, "Thanks. I'm not having any," they leered and laughed.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- British Catholics received a surprise today with the announcement that the Most Rev. Bernard W. Griffin, 44 years old, Auxiliary Bishop of Birmingham, had been appointed Archbishop of Westminster, succeeding the late Arthur Cardinal Hinsley.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 22 -With the publication of an official list of 160 Fascist Republicans and twenty German soldiers killed in the last week in attacks by antiFascist formations in northern Italy, three days of "ten-to-one" hostage executions followed with 210 death sentences already carried out and another 1,590 threatened unless the attacks stop.

Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts of South Africa has written a post-war blueprint which Duell, Sloan Pearce plan to publish on Jan. 20. "Toward a Better World" includes statements of policy made by the Field Marshal over a period of twenty-five years.

WASHINGTN, Dec. 22 -- Although only one barge load of live eels came from Quebec this year instead of the usual two, a large enough catch has been made along the Atlantic Coast to supply the New York market with Christmas Eve eel stew.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 22 -Paced by Mike Shinkarik, who accounted for 22 points, Princeton's basketball team defeated Rider College, 51 to 33, tonight, for its third victory of the season. Dan Ullmann of the victors tallied 15 points, while Ken Kunsch led Rider with nine.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- An extensive post-war education program for this State, estimated to cost $80,000,000, including proposals for the construction of twenty-two new institutes and providing free scholarships for 48,000 high school graduates, was submitted by the Board of Regents today to Governor Dewey and the legislative leaders.

Some of the plans for the entertainment of service men and women who are in the city over the Christmas holidays were described last night on the weekly business forum of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York on a broadcast over Station WMCA.

Twelve Russian children were introduced yesterday to the American manner of celebrating Christmas at a party in the headquarters of Russian War Relief at 11 East Thirty-fifth Street. Before a Christmas tree decked with packages of dehydrated borscht, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt presented Santa Claus to the youngsters, who are children of Russian officials in this city and students at the Soviet School, 6 East Eighty-seventh Street.

Mrs. Sara Anderson Regneas, former opera singer, who was the wife of Joseph Regneas, died Monday night of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered on her way to her home, 200 West Fiftyseventh Street, after visiting her daughter, Mrs. Charlotte Oleen.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- American troops have advanced in the Arawe sector, New Britain, despite enemy air attacks, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today in a communique. Sixteen Japanese planes were downed in three attacks on our positions.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Four officers of the Burlington Liars Club gathered around a short-wave radio set today to listen to broadcasts from Tokyo and Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The War Labor Board refused tonight to direct that any wage concessions obtained by the CIO United Steelworkers under new contracts be made retroactive to the date of expiring contracts.

In the nine civil service job categories for which New York City is hiring women "for men's jobs only because there's a war on," the women are doing very well indeed, Esther Bromley of the Municipal Civil Service Commission reported yesterday. Women street car operators have, in fact, proved to the Board of Transportation that they are better at the job than men, she said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, protested to Mayor La Guardia today the dismissal of charges against Patrolman James L. Drew of the New York police force. He urged the Mayor to re-examine the case, "overriding technicalities to get to the bottom" of the charges, made by William B. Herlands, City Commissioner of Investigation, that Patrolman Drew associated with persons engaged in un-American activities.

'WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Harold L. Ickes, Coal Administrator restored to private control tonight the non-union coal mines of eleven Pennsylvania and West Virginia producers. Action was taken on advice that no work stoppages had occurred or been threatened at these properties since Oct. 25, when the wildcat strikes began which ended in a general mine walkout Oct. 31.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, South Pacific, Thursday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- United States destroyers, moving boldly into waters far above their base toward Rabaul, have added their shells to the thousands of tons of aerial bombs now blowing up supplies of the Japanese on invaded Bougainville.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- After serving in the last war Mgr. Griffin, who was appointed Archbishop of Westminster today by Pope Pius XII, returned to his books and be-

In the seemingly far-off days before the war, the term salvage had for most people a nautical, romantic connotation. It meant some gallant action concerned with "saving a ship or its cargo from the perils of the sea." When the war made its tremendous demand for industrial supplies, salvage came to mean the thrifty saving of aluminum, rubber, tin or paper.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The right of the Securities and Exchange Commission to order a solvent corporation to repudiate any of its indebtedness and the power of such a concern voluntarily to accomplish the same end were challenged vigorously today in oral argument on the plan of reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

Although the war had canceled his wedding twice before, Edward Baker of the British Merchant Navy is not a man to let global hostilities permanently prevent the ceremony. A believer in the adage, "Things happen in threes," Seaman Baker tried again yesterday at the Young Women's Christian Association, 501 West Fiftieth Street, and this time he finally married his fiancee of two years, Jean Cadden, a Canadian girl of New Waterford, N. S.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak government-in-exile, told the press today that the governments of Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union sincerely believed they would be able to reach an agreement with Poland in the near future concerning a stable peace and steps to prevent future aggression by Germany.

Children gave generously yesterday to aid the Neediest Cases, hoping to "make someone's Christmas happy," as one school group wrote. Among the day's many gifts to the fund were two sent by airmail so they would arrive before Christmas, one from a physician in a western State and another from a soldier in North Africa.

Action taken by the National Wool Export Corporation, affiliated with the British Board of Trade, in inviting Bernard B. Smith to England to discuss the situation with reference to exports of British woolen piece goods to the United States is not regarded in the trade as being indicative of an early lifting of the current embargo on allocations of the merchandise here.

MADRID, Dec. 22 -- The two young Falangists who fought on the Eastern Front in the Blue Division, which has now returned to Spain, and who invaded the American consulate at Valencia on Saturday evening and created a serious disturbance, now await trial.

By now housekeepers undoubtedly have laid most of the plans for Christmas dinner and all that remains is the actual buying of the ingredients. A last-minute survey of the markets indicates that with the exception of turkeys, which are exceedingly scarce, there is a fair supply of the traditional holiday food.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Roosevelt is to have a family reunion at Hyde Park for the first Christmas since he entered the White House.

Suggesting that the privilege had been abused, the Milk Industry Advisory Committee recommended yesterday that the War Food Administration consider withdrawing the right of physicians to prescribe heavy cream for their patients, at present the sole exemption to the nation-wide ban on the sale of whipping cream.

The first liquor package retailer in this city to be jailed for black marketing was sentenced yesterday in Brooklyn Magistrates Court to serve three days for having charged $6 for a quart of rye whisky on which the Office of Price Administration ceiling was $4.28.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday the election of ten new members, including the first Negro to enter the organization. The institute was founded forty-five years ago to honor "notable achievement in art, music or literature."

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The first United States military police battalion to arrive in Britain has now completed its first year in this theatre -- one in which commendation was earned for its service under German aerial bombardment and for its skillful organization of highway patrols and convoy escorts.
LONDON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Today's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Special programs of Christmas music will be presented in the churches of New York City and vicinity at tomorrow's Christmas Eve services and at Christmas services on Saturday and Sunday. The programs will include the following:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The proposed Green-Lucas-Worley compromises on legislation to insure the voting privilege to service men in November were rejected informally today by backers of the Eastland-McKellar-McClellan "State rights" bill which the Senate adopted on Dec. 3.

The provisional regime of Marshal Tito is trying hard to persuade the British Foreign Office that the dismissal of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, included in the Yugoslav Government-in-Exile in Cairo as semi-permanent Minister of War, should be pressed on the acceptance of King Peter.

As a result of a continuing decline in the stocks of many industrial chemicals, the War Production Board is expected to expand its allocation list within the next month, distributors stated yesterday. Among chemicals expected to come under such control, it was said, are carbon tetrachloride and manganese sulphate.

The Feast of the Nativity will be commemorated in this city tomorrow at Christmas Eve services, midnight masses in Roman Catholic churches, midnight celebrations of the holy communion in Protestant Episcopal churches and with candle-light carol services in houses of worship of many faiths.

Manhattan's Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will open soon after New Year's the first of a series of neighborhood swap shops, Mrs. Nathaniel Singer, chairman of the consumer service division, announced yesterday.

Brazil is planning an intensive campaign to promote the sale of mate in this market, it was disclosed here yesterday by Dr. Generoso Ponce Filho, a director of the Mate Institute of Brazil, who has just arrived here for the purpose of arranging details of the campaign.

Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, appealed last night for a united front of Communists, progressives and democrats on the basis of the policy laid down by George Dimitroff, head of the Communist International until its recent dissolution by Premier Joseph Stalin.
CHATSWORTH, N.J., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A forest fire, estimated by fire fighters to have swept 1,300 to 2,000 acres of pine woodland, was checked today by fire service men and soldiers.

Dissatisfied with the way "Sometimes I'm Happy" turned out after revising it three times, Arthur Kober jettisoned it and got to work on another play for John Golden. It's almost finished now and is called "My Dear Bella," with the action taking place in a Bronx apartment house.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

AN ADVANCED SOLOMONS BASE, Dec. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Additional troops as well as thousands of tons of military supplies and equipment are arriving in forward areas of the Solomons in the American campaign to capture Bougainville Island.

Stockholders of the Petroleum Corporation of America approved yesterday at a special meeting here the proposal to acquire the Sinclair Oil Corporation's interest in the company by offering it and other stockholders in exchange for their holdings a pro rata portion of the net assets of the Petroleum Corporation less 1 per cent to cover transfer taxes and other expenses of the transaction.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The plan for recapitalization of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, including the sale at competitive bidding of $38,000,000 of first mortgage bonus, 3 1/2 per cent, series due in 1968, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

KHARKOV, Russia, Dec. 19 (Delayed) -- Kharkov, once a modern, bustling industrial city of 925,000 population, today is a grim reminder of the war's horrors. The city, which was twice captured and twice liberated, is a good example of the tremendous job of rehabilitation and reconstruction facing Russia as the Germans are driven from Soviet territory.

As this year marks the hundredth anniversary of the publication of Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol," your readers may be interested to know that the blind people of this country now have their own special edition of this beloved classic as a talking book.

The Mount Holyoke College Glee Club gave an unusual Christmas program at Town Hall last night, the young women being assisted by John Kirkpatrick, pianist, who played the Beethoven Sonata in A-flat major, Opus 110. All the numbers on the list were Christmas music, many of them carols.

Six Office of Price Administration attorneys holding key positions in the metropolitan area office announced yesterday their resignations, effective on Dec. 31, but said their quitting had no connection with the reorganization that started shortly after Daniel P. Woolley was appointed regional administrator.

The city's larger department stores are salvaging an average of three tons of waste paper apiece daily during the pre-Christmas rush, the New York City Newspapers Waste Paper Salvage Committee reported yesterday. The public was urged to match this activity by saving all wrappers from Christmas gifts and cardboard containers for salvage.

MADRID, Dec. 23 -- The program of "relaxation" in Spanish internal affairs outlined by Jose Luis de Arrese, secretary general of the Falange party, yesterday, before party leaders, including Generalissimo Francisco Franco, was taken at face value here today in both Spanish and foreign circles.

The War Advertising Council has issued a campaign guide to national advertisers and their agents appealing for support of the Red Cross War Fund drive which will be carried on from March 1 to 31. The guide contains suggestions for promotional copy but does not offer any specific insertions.

WITH MOROCCAN TROOPS, in Italy, Dec. 22 -- Americans and Moroccans are forming the latest combination in the now very heterogeneous Fifth Army. The French forces here are really Moroccan Goums and Algerians with French officers and a large percentage of French non-commissioned officers.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Allied air power once again struck across the narrow seas into the fortress of Europe today. Large formations of Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force pounded industrial and military targets in northwestern Germany and Royal Air Force Mosquitos, Bostons and Typhoons bombed military targets in northern France, including, it is believed, emplacements for Germany's rocket guns, the enemy's not so secret weapon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Roosevelt took steps today to help the recruiting of women in industry and lessen their absenteeism in war plants by directing the War Production Board to make available materials for building more rest rooms, cafeterias, and other facilities for women war workers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -- Picked men from a Navy crew did the final machinist work on their ship in a San Francisco Bay dry-dock today after members of Local 1,304 of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, had refused the job in a wage dispute.

Stockholders of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation met yesterday in Chicago and approved a recapitalization plan which will permit the company to raise $10,000,000 for post-war development and expansion and approved a change in name to United Air Lines, Inc.

The untutored layman, especially if he does not happen to live in Albany County, may easily be confused by the news that the investigation of the Legislature which was started by the local Democratic officials is to be taken over by a new grand jury under Republican auspices. The layman may wonder how much is actually judicial in these proceedings and how much is political.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Twelve Army fliers were killed and two were injured in the crash of a bomber on a training flight near here today. The dead were:
SALT LAKE CITY, Dee. 22 (AP) -The Utah Ordnance Plant closed today and about 27 per cent of the women employed declined to take other war jobs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- It has been said that the President will run again and that he will not, but it remained for one Democratic party official to make the suggestion today that Mr. Roosevelt might accept a fourth-term nomination and, if elected, resign at the end of the war to head the American peace delegation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Santa Claus is going to visit all the Army posts possible, the War Department announced today.

Leading American artists, actors, musicians, dancers, publishers and architects presented gifts to fellow-artists in the Soviet Union at a reception yesterday afternoon at the Soviet Consulate, 7 East Sixty-first Street. The event launched a nation-wide campaign of America's entertainment and cultural fields for the exchange of information and material in arts and letters.

Franklin Kennedy Jr., formerly associate buyer of rugs for R.H. Macy Co., Inc., has been appointed corporate buyer of surpluses for all stores in the Macy organization. He will keep in close touch with the release by the Government of surplus merchandise stocks and report to Joseph Givner, director of Macy's corporate buying offices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Award of the joint Army-Navy production "E" to thirty-four additional industrial and shipbuilding plants in recognition of outstanding performance on war work was announced today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

Burton Stevenson's "Home Book of Verse" has an English adaptation of the Marseillaise in the body of the book and the original French text in the foreign-language section in the back. It may be a bit late to criticize a publication more than a quarter of a century old and a reference book without which it is inconceivable that newspaper men could earn their living.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The Churchill Government is expected to study and Parliament is likely to debate an official report that Scotland has the highest infant mortality rate of any country in the western world except Spain and Portugal. Sir John Boyd Orr issued the report last night.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 22 -- The conditions in Greece to which Premier Emmanuel Tsouderos referred in a radio broadcast to the Greek people last night was more fully described in an official report made available here by the Greek Government today.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Although business came almost to a standstill today on the stock markets here due to nearness of the Christmas holiday, the tone except in one or two features remained firm. British Celanese reacted unfavorably to yesterday's gloomy dividend news and lost a few pence.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks packed five goals into the last period tonight to rout the Detroit Red Wings, 7 -- 1, before a crowd of 7,616 and consolidate their hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League.

Under the generally accepted procedure of the income tax law, money payments taxable to the recipient as income are deductible, equitably enough, from the taxable income of the payer. This practice avoids double taxation.

ALGIERS, Dec. 22 -- In the pleasant coastal town of Ortona, situated on a rocky shelf overlooking the slate-colored Adriatic Sea, the noisiest and deadliest mobile units of modern war are battling, while the population of 10,000 or more has fled to the hills.

After thirty-three years in Wall Street, Joseph R. Swan, senior partner of Smith, Barney Co., will retire on Jan. 1. He will continue as a special partner in the firm but will devote most of his attention to his 900-acre farm in Connecticut, on which for years he has been conducting experiments with flowers.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 -- Putitthere, beaten a nose by Eric Knight in his recent winter debut, raced to a half-length triumph in the Miami Shores Purse at Tropical Park today. S.I. Crew's color-bearer sped six furlongs over the lightning-fast strip in 1:10 2-5, two-fifths of a second slower than Boy Angler's track record, in wearing down African Sun through the final strides.

The first of six hearings on complaints charging notaries public with carelessly assisting minors under 17 years of age to join the Navy was held yesterday before Abraham S. Wechsler, Director of Licenses of the New York State Department, who reserved decision on the case.

Ninety Wall Street firms that had asked permission of the Regional War Labor Board to pay Christmas bonuses received their answers yesterday. Twenty-four, said to have presented "adequate information," were granted permission to pay as scheduled or had their requests trimmed down.

Commercial paper outstanding in the United States on Nov. 30 amounted to $201,900,000, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was a gain of $14,100,000, or 8 per cent, in the month, making the fifth consecutive monthly increase.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The controversy between Secretary Morgenthau and the Senate Finance Committee, regarding the latter's proposed amendments to the law governing renegotiation of Government contracts, raises a whole series of issues -- economic, administrative, legal and technical -- which it would be difficult to disentangle in any short space.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet labor publication War and the Working Class called John L. Lewis, American labor leader, "that fascist sectarian" today and accused "reactionary leaders" of the American Federation of Labor of making political war against Soviet labor unions and the Soviet Union.

Little notes from here and there: Arizona is known pretty widely as a desert State, but it claims two of the world's best trout streams within its borders. These are the Colorado River below Boulder Dam and Clear Creek in the Grand Canyon National Park.
Syndicates were active yesterday in the purchase of business and housing properties in Manhattan.

Peggy Phillips is in her twenties. For some years as a Broadway press agent she has been a welcome harbinger of other people's plays. Last evening one of her own went on at the Forrest Theatre when Milton Baron and associates offered "Listen, Professor!" which she adapted from a translation from the Russian.

The stock market plodded yesterday through another irregular and dull session and gave no evidence of its immediate direction. Except for a handful of issues, price exchanges were limited to fractions. Business on the Stock Exchange took another shares contraction as transfers dwindled to 563,530 shares from 656,320 on Tuesday.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 23 -- Soviet forces pounded southward from Nevel yesterday in the first phase of their winter offensive, capturing twenty more towns and killing 1,900 Germans as they drove toward Vitebsk, while press dispatches reaching Sweden from Latvia said Red Army paratroops already were landing in the Baltic States.

LONDON, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- There is a tendency here to believe that the German threats of reprisals are an attempt to intimidate the western powers before they come to grips with the Germans on the Continent. Officially there may be no answer to the German spokesman's statement, especially as it was not an official German Foreign Office pronouncement.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Hawaii, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Gen. George C. Marshall, United States Army Chief of Staff, told American troops here that "we have got the Japs beaten, but we have to keep pushing," it may now be revealed.

Brooklyn ball players who may have felt some apprehension over their incomes for 1944 had their fears allayed yesterday when Branch Rickey went on record against reducing salaries next season. The increased cost of living was the reason the Dodger president advanced for his determination to maintain 1943 wage levels as a minimum.

The city's uniformed firemen rejected yesterday the "bonus" plan agreed to by Mayor La Guardia and the head of their own organization. A four-hour meeting of the Uniformed Firemen's Association at the new City Center, 131 West Fifty-fourth Street, brought a verdict that while the men were willing to work overtime, they wanted overtime pay at the regular hourly rate rather than the bonus proposed by the Mayor.
Former Gov. Gifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Pinchot are at the Ambassador, to stay through Christmas.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the special grand jury investigation of legislative spending ordered by Governor Dewey as a substitute for the Albany County grand jury inquiry, said today that District Attorney John T. Delaney, the Albany County Democratic prosecutor, had agreed to cooperate fully.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has bought the screen rights to the radio quiz show, "Take It or Leave It," to be used as the basis for a musical comedy in which Phil Baker will appear as a master of ceremonies and outstanding highlights from former Fox pictures will be incorporated.
