BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 22 -- Reprisals against American and British prisoners of war in Germany for the public execution in Kharkov of three members of the German Army charged with committing atrocities against Russian civilians are hinted at in an official statement released by the German Foreign Office today.

"A Guy Named Joe," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film starring Spencer Tracy and Irene Dunne, will have its world premiere this morning at the Capitol. In supporting roles in the comedy romance are Van Johnson, Ward Bond, James Gleason, Lionel Barrymore and Barry Nelson.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Dec. 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, who last New Year's Day predicted "Complete, absolute defeat for the Axis powers" in 1943, isn't so sure when the war will be over.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced amendment of the three fixed mark-up regulations by which wholesale and retail grocers determine maximum prices for the commodities they handle, and said the chief effect of interest to the housewife and retail grocer would be the provision allowing the retailer to purchase poultry alive or dressed and sell it drawn at what are now prevailing prices for sales of the drawn birds.

On Dec. 20 you published a small item about fifty-two children of Danish-Jewish parents, aged from 1 to 12 years, who had been sent to Germany from a Copenhagen freight station. Up to the time of their departure the children had been interned in the Western Prison, looked after by German nurses, who also took the very dirty and ill-groomed little ones in trucks to the station.
LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The 7-year-old daughter of an RAF gunner missing since April after a raid on Cap Bon Peninsula, was adopted today by WACS in Britain as their Christmas war orphan and mascot.

Slightly increased price-fixing by the trade against newly awarded textile contracts in the wake of diminished selling pressure was sufficient yesterday to recover a portion of Tuesday's losses and lift prices moderately in the cotton futures market.
A Japanese communique, as broadcast from Tokyo yesterday and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Administration leaders made known today that they are apprehensive over what they regard as public apathy toward the necessity of making sacrifices for victory, particularly on the part of organized pressure groups, and persons in high position are attempting to bring the realities of the battlefronts home to the people.
The directors of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., authorized yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents a share, payable on Jan. 5 to holders of record of Dec. 30.

With Beau Jack, world lightweight champion in this State, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, as his leading attraction, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. has attracted gross receipts of $1,136,228 thus far in 1943 to Madison Square Garden.

The number of babies abandone by their parents in New York City in 1943 will reach the highest figure in eight years, Sister Agnit Miriam, superintendent of the New York Foundling Hospital, estimated yesterday. To date, seventy-four deserted children have been brought to the institution run by the Sisters of Charity at 175 East Sixty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Limited shipments of hogs relieved the congested situation at the stockyards today and prices generally increased. Salable supplies were reduced to 9000 head and there were about 12000 farmer-owned hogs carried over by selling agencies from Tuesday. The War Food Administration reported that there would be a holdover of about 6,000 head tonight.

Stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio approved yesterday the issuance of $10,138,900 par value of cumulative convertible preferred stock ranking on a parity with the $12,000,000 of 5 per cent cumulative preferred now outstanding.

Metropolitan skiers, who have made the playgrounds of Bear Mountain in the Hudson Valley, the Catskills of upper New York State, the Berkshires of Massachusetts and the Poconos of Pennsylvania their popular rendezvous during previous winters, will find many improvements this season.
LONDON, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Marshal Tito [Josip Brez] today reported considerable gains by his Partisan forces against a stalled German offensive in Yugoslavia.

Whether wool products manufactured for the exclusive use of the Navy are subject to the provisions of the Wool Products Labeling Act has been raised as an issue by the Federal Trade Commission in its recent complaint against the Susquehanna Woolen Mills, New Cumberland, Pa., it was stated here yesterday by Leo Kaplan, counsel for the woolen mills.

Christmas gifts totaling $628,294.57 were distributed to fourteen charitable agencies yesterday by Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission and of the Turf Committee of America. It was in the latter capacity that Swope functioned in ceremonies at the River Club, for the occasion was the presentation of the profits from the nine-day Victory meeting at Jamaica Nov. 4 to 13.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters were Gilbert Verney, president of the Verney Brunswick Mills, who leased a furnished penthouse-terrace apartment at the Beekman Hotel, 575 Park Avenue; and Jack A. Pegler, vice president of Foote, Cone Belding, advertising agents, who leased a furnished suite at 31 Sutton Place South.

Seven men charged with conspiracy to extort $1,000,000 from the motion-picture industry were found guilty in Federal Court last night by a jury of nine women and three men, which had heard evidence since the trial began Oct. 5 and had deliberated its verdict for ten hours and thirteen minutes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The main subject of discussion today in the dispute between the Class 1 railroads and the five operating railway brotherhoods was the counter-proposal submitted by the union chiefs, who demanded pay increases of 64 cents a day, a reduction from the $3 originally asked, vacation with pay, added expense allowances and overtime for specified holidays.

Under the caption "The Hope for a New World" the following Christmas message was issued yesterday by the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, from his office in national headquarters of the communion, 281 Fourth Avenue:
LONDON, Dec. 22 (Reuter) -Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) is in -and Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch is on his way out, it is believed here.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of Canterbury, in a Christmas message delivered today, warned that the new year would make vast demands on "perseverance, endurance and sacrifice so that the war may be won" and "possibly also on labor self-restraint and sacrifice so that the peace may be won."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Scrawled words on little white tags make this year's national community Christmas tree a memorial to heroes living and dead.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22 -Yale defeated the Trinity College five tonight, 46 to 44, in an overtime game.

Excepting heavy fuel oil stocks, which were down sharply, supplies of major oil products on the eastern seaboard increased last week. The American Petroleum Institute index covering gasoline stood art 42.4 at the close of the week, against 42 a week earlier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- So much difference of opinion exists with respect to laws and methods of renegotiating war contracts that the name-calling in which some of the disputants have now engaged was perhaps inevitable. Its arrival was made more certain by the fact that the New Deal government has been a crusader against industry from its earliest days.
Football's old man river not only keeps rolling along; he keeps pickling up new honors along the way.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- One jockey was seriously injured, three others were bruised and two horses were killed in training accidents today at the Fair Grounds race track.

Two police lieutenants, one acting lieutenant and fourteen plainclothes men have been transferred from the Thirteenth Inspection Division covering the Bedford-Stuyvesant section in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

The St. John's University Indians ran their winning streak to five straight in the De Gray Gymnasium last night when they romped to an 80-to-32 victory over an undermanned Webb Institute quintet. The Redmen regulars were withdrawn after they had compiled a 22-to-1 lead in the first six minutes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The French Committee of National Liberation in Algiers has clamped down on the freedom of the press in North Africa to protect its position, according to advices received in diplomatic circles today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A possibility that the Bolivian revolution was inspired by Axis agents operating in Argentina threw doubt today on the question whether the United States would recognize the new regime.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- G.I. Joe, who likes a laugh -- particularly if it's on himself or the Army -- had himself an evening tonight at Rainbow Corner, where the American Red Cross runs an entertainment center for enlisted men.

Directors of the Chase National Bank authorized yesterday an increase of $13,000,000 in surplus account to a total of $134,730,000. This is the second such increase this year. The first occurred on Sept. 22 when $21,460,000 was added.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Out here where the snow begins, all sports conversation deals with the game between the Chicago Bears and the Washington Redskins for the National Football League championship Sunday.

A group of Chinese Air Corps officers and cadets, led by Major S.T. Wang, who made the first air raid in history on Japan -- the bombing of Formosa, six years ago -- has arrived in this country for rigorous special training, it was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Homer M. Groninger, commander of the New York Port of Embarkation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The War Department announced today award of the Silver Star for gallantry in action in North Africa and Tunisia to these officers and enlisted men:
"What you give is far more than financial aid; it is hope for a better future, and that is the best Christmas gift in the world," wrote one of yesterday's 561 donors to the Neediest Cases Fund.

Distillery stockholders who are not themselves licensed wholesalers may not bring into this State for resale any part of the whisky dividends that some distillers have offered, it was announced yesterday by John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

CHUNGKING, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -Chinese troops pursuing the retreating Japanese in northern Hunan Province have made "considerable progress" after clearing the enemy from both banks of the Lin River, sixty miles north of Changteh, a Chinese communique said tonight.
ADVANCE ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- A communique:
MONTREAL, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Canadian newsprint makers said today the United States Government may get very little newsprint for its proposed stockpile.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz announced today that he had designated Ralph W. Wescott of Camden, Russell E. Watson of New Brunswick and Arthur T. Vanderbilt of Newark as special assistant attorneys general to defend the Legislature's procedure for revising the State Constitution in the challenge of its constitutionality filed by John Borg, Hackensack publisher, and Mrs. Tina Richmond of Paterson.

One hundred nineteen men and women received yesterday degrees in medicine and forty-eight women and eleven men received certificates in nursing at a special commencement of the New York University College of Medicine and its affiliated Bellevue Schools of Nursing.

Ed Diddle, the towel-tossing coach of Western Kentucky, who is now in his twenty-second year as mentor of the Hilltop basketball team, is no stranger to Madison Square Garden. He's been there five times in the past, twice for the national invitation tournament.

As railroad terminals, bus stations and airline offices were thronged yesterday with holiday travelers, it appeared that Christmas travel this year might reach a record, surpassing that established over the July 4 week-end. The addition of many thousands of service men to the customary civilian crowds threatened to tax all travel facilities to the limit.

The Collins Aikman Corporation reported yesterday for itself and subsidiary a net profit for the nine months ended with November of $1,034,422 after all charges, including depreciation and Federal and State income taxes. This is equivalent to $1.57 a share on the common stock, after dividend requirements on the preferred.

Governor Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts asserted last night that the last year had seen a great change in "the attitude of our country toward other nations," an attitude that he believed presaged a greater amount of security in the post-war world than had been believed possible heretofore.

ALGIERS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- One year of untiring effort by Eugene Bonnier de la Chapelle, newspaper man, has won partial vindication of the name of his 20-year-old son, Fernand Bonnier de la Chapelle, a frail university student who died before a firing squad after killing Admiral Jean Francois Darlan.

Gert Hans von Gontard, son of a German baron and one of the heirs to the Busch brewery fortune, was held in $1,500 bail by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter yesterday pending Federal grand jury action on a charge of conspiring to evade service induction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- Government tax experts estimated today that about 16,000,000 taxpayers would be entitled to cash refunds on their 1943 taxes when they settle up on March 15. They will go to individuals whose periodic wage deductions under pay-as-you-go are such that by the end of the year they will have paid before than they actually owe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- An assertion that infiltration of communistic doctrines into training courses preparing Army personnel at Cornell University for military Government service in occupied countries had been "nipped in the bud" is made by members of a House Military Affairs investigating subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- As a result of the War Labor Board's refusal of retroactive pay adjustments the United Steel Workers were reported to day to be considering a thirty-day strike notice under the Smith-Connally Act.

In current discussion adverse critics of subsidies to maintain ceilings over food prices either assert or assume -in either case without proof -- that subsidies cannot control prices or prevent inflation and are merely temporary palliatives, resort to which disregards basic economic laws.

The shortage of steam-size an thracite, which is used in heating large apartment, hotel, loft and business buildings, was described as desperate yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York. United relief is forthcoming promptly the health of tenants may be jeopardized and water pipes may freezed was said.

Three pint-sized publicity agents for the city's 3,000 children needing foster homes discharged their last responsibility yesterday before settling back to normal childhood. Objects of a total of 520 requests for their care, the sister team of Gwen, 6 years old, Diane, 4, and Gerry, 2, posed once again for photographs before going to the foster home that has been chosen for them by the Children's Aid Society.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Hedging sales of wheat appeared in increased volume today on the Board of Trade and the market showed a rather heavy undertone from the start. Prices failed to respond to early strength in rye, and later when pressure increased they declined around 1 cent a bushel from the early top and closed about the bottom with net losses of 1/2 to 3/4 cent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Farmers in Wisconsin, Michigan and Indiana will get Christmas presents in the form of checks from the Government for complying with the Agricultural Adjustment Act conservation program during 1943. There are about 650,000 checks to be sent, W.W. Weldon, assistant disbursing officer for the Treasury Department, said today.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 24 -Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, in a Christmas message to the growing American forces in Britain, asserted today that there no longer was any doubt of Allied victory and said "We have both the manpower and material to bring this war to a successful conclusion" and to rebuild the world.

General Marshall's 35,000-mile flight around the globe signifies not only that we all live in Mr. Willkie's One World but that east and west we now fight one war. Nothing could link the battle line in Europe more directly with that in the Pacific than the visit of our Chief of Staff to New Guinea on his way home from the historic conferences at Teheran and Cairo.

The City Patrol Corps has suffered a loss of nearly one-half of its September, 1942, peak membership of 7,827, but is still able to put a force of 500 on the streets each night to augment the regular police, it was learned yesterday from Maj. Gen. Robert. M. Danford, head of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- During the week ended Dec. 22, member bank reserve balances decreased $255,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Reductions in member bank reserve arose from increases of $588,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $243,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, $147,000,000 in money in circulation and $32,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by an increase of $755,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -Paul V. McNutt, manpower chairman, made it clear today that honorably discharged service men did not have to take war jobs if they did not wish.

Bizet's "Carmen" received a particularly listless and weak-spined presentation at its second performance of the season, given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House under Sir Thomas Beecham's direction. Lily Djanel again had the name part.

A "widow's mite" of $2 for 6-year-old Toni, a gift from "a couple nearly eighty for the 84-year-old woman" of another case, and contributions from children, refugees, physicians, lawyers, business men and women; mothers, the poor and the well-to-do and members of the armed services came yesterday for the thirty-second annual Christmas appeal on behalf of the Neediest Cases Fund.

Probably there is even less than poetic license for -- as Rhode Island Daughter-in-Law writes you -- the legend that "johnny" or "jonny" cake stems from "journey cake." If we could dig deep and unerringly enough most likely we'd find that the word, in either of its variations, stems from the Indian vernacular.

DETROIT, Dec. 23 -- The Detroit Red Wings, loaning their spare goalie to the opposition in the third period, defeated the New York Rangers, 5 to 3, in a National Hockey League game tonight before a crowd of 5,646. When Ken McAuley was injured young Harry Lumley of Detroit replaced him in the Ranger nets.
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 23 -Striking evidence of Japanese determination to reinforce the Marshall Islands was reported by both Army and Navy fliers who attacked Kwajalein two days ago.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 23 (AP) -The majority of patrons who visited Rockingham race track this year were present primarily for "recreation and a good time," according to the results of a recent secret investigation conducted by the State Racing Commission.

Plans for insuring our demobilized men against the difficulties which will come with peace are offered every day, but will we not do well to give thought to how these benefits are to be provided and paid for?

Coals to Newcastle and borsht to Belgorod or Bryansk. Mrs. Roosevelt was a guest at a Christmas party for Russian children in New York where the Christmas tree displayed, in addition to the usual bright decorations, a number of boxes of dehydrated borsht.

Clare Boothe Luce and the Duchess of Windsor will share the title of best dressed woman of the world for 1943, according to results of the annual ballot taken recently by a group of forty fashion experts in which a tie vote for first place on the list occurred.

Prof. Carl Shipp Marvel of the Organic Chemistry Department, University of Illinois, has been elected president of the American Chemical Society for 1945, it was announced yesterday by the society. He will take office as president-elect Jan. 1, 1944.

Governor Dewey announced last night at Albany the appointment of George Frankenthaler of Manhattan and Archie B. Morrison of the Bronx as Supreme Court Justices in the First Judicial District to fill the vacancies caused by the resignation of Samuel I. Rosenman to become special assistant to President Roosevelt and the death of J. Sidney Bernstein.

The report of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation for the year ended on Sept. 30, last, disclosed yesterday an income of $230,570 from real estate operations and other sources, less administrative expenses. In addition, there were refunds of real estate taxes in respect of prior years, interest thereon of $46,921 and a credit of $161,000 for the cancellation of a provision for additional operating expenses in the previous year.

The College of Dentistry of New York University conferred degrees in dental surgery upon 140 students in the special commencement exercises held yesterday in the Gould Memorial Library of the University Heights division. One hundred and twenty-one of the students were commissioned first lieutenants in the Dental Corps of the Army and four were commissioned lieutenants (junior grade) in the Navy and Naval Reserve Dental Corps.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, New York, has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for exemption from competitive-bidding requirements so that it may sell 400,000 shares of its subsidiary, the Central Illinois Electric and Gas Company, Rockford, Ill., to the Central Republic Company of Chicago, an investment concern.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "The Ox-Bow Incident," the British-made "Desert Victory" and Warner Brothers' "Watch on the Rhine" have been chosen the best drama, best documentary and the most popular films, respectively, of 1943, according to the eighteenth annual selection of ten best films by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Sporadic clashes of land patrols from the Sumprabum area of northern Burma to the middle Chin hills and widespread air fighting in which both American and British forces participated were announced by the Southeast Asia command today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive order tonight nominally setting up the Selective Service system as a separate agency, as required by the Father Draft Bill, but in a companion order he directed that Maj-Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, consult with Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the War Manpower Commission as to decisions under the Selective Service Act.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals took under consideration today the question whether a dissolution or liquidation under the Holding Company Act of 1935 is so different from bankruptcy, equity receivership or financial reorganization liquidation that the rule of "absolute priorities" does not prevail and an interest can be awarded to common stockholders when the assets are insufficient for preferred stock requirements.

Advancing openings by about five weeks as compared with a year ago, separate summer season lines will be shown by members of the Sportswear Guild beginning Feb. 1, it was made known here yesterday by the group.

ALGIERS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- An American Red Cross girl, who formerly was secretary to Presidential Adviser Harry L. Hopkins, has been cited by the commander of an American Ranger battalion for her coolness under fire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Information is being exchanged by the American Governments concerning the Bolivian revolution and the question of recognition, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today. But no systematic conversations have been carried on by them thus far, and he was not prepared to say anything more than was set forth in his statement yesterday reflecting uncertainty about extending recognition to the new regime.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- A German communique, broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The United Press:

Fortified with an emergency message from Mayor La Guardia, the City Council struck a blow yesterday at the black market in rail, plane and bus transporation. It passed by unanimous vote a local law making it a misdemeanor for individuals or business concerns to charge more than $1 for services in providing rail, plane and bus tickets or Pullman and sleeping-car accommodations.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23 (AP) -The home front has won "one of the major victories of the war," Jerome A. Collins, acting district director for the Office of Price Administration, said in a statement today.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, and throughout the country generally, lost reserves during the week ended on Wednesday despite huge sales of Government securities to the central Federal Reserve Banks, as disclosed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board so far has found no way by which shareholders in the American Distilling Corporation in this State can import liquor bought from the distillery under a special stock plan, Horace A. Segelbaum, counsel for the board, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- During the week ended on Dec. 18, commodity prices in primary markets were comparably steady. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' all-commodity index remained unchanged at 102.9 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The domestic aviation transport industry has set a new high mark in safety records in 1943, according to Col. Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America.

ALGIERS, Dec. 23 -- Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, who was sentenced by the Vichy regime to ten years in prison after he had tried to resist the German occupation of southern France when the Allies landed in North Africa and who was expected to play an important role in the French Army, asked immediately to see Gen. Charles de Gaulle on his arrival here yesterday, it was announced today.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 24 -- The Russians have forced a new breach in German lines before Vitebsk, Berlin admitted yesterday, while Moscow dispatches said the Soviet Baltic Army had battered to within twelve miles of that Nazi fortress as its winter offensive entered its twelfth day.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine left his office last night without commenting on written requests for information as to what move he planned now that the rank and file of the department had rejected the Mayor's overtime work proposal.
The last-minute defeat of the Notre Dame football team by Great Lakes was such a surprise that the choice of that eyebrow-lifter as the outstanding sports surprise of the year wasn't a surprise.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 -- Egyptian leaders are reported to have been nonplused as a result of the statement made two days ago to the press by Emir Feisal, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, in which he interjected the Koran as a basis for any form of eventual Arab federation.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 (Delayed) -- The speech by Field Marshal Viscount Wavell in Calcutta on Monday brought into bolder outline a British policy toward India that has been making itself evident in official actions and attitudes ever since the new Viceroy took over his post two months ago.

All American air strategists, from Gen. Billy Mitchell to date, have pointed to Alaska as the logical base for strategic operations against the industrial heart of Japan. As the science of flying has developed, this logic has become clearer.

Directors of the George Washington Carver School, 57 West 125th Street, defended last night the school, which has been under fire as communist-dominated, as being non-partisan in the courses it offered and in its directorate.

Stimulated by the "contrast I get when I come from City Hall and find myself among intelligent people," Mayor La Guardia yesterday gave 3,000 City College students forty-five minutes of his views on oleomargarine, unemployment, the draft, politicians, modern warfare, the tariff and the value of the study of mathematics. As a parting shot, he told them in one word -- Want! -- just what was wrong with the world.

The manpower shortage has put a virtual end to another traditional angle of New York's Christmas street scene. Shoppers on Fifth Avenue and along Thirty-fourth Street may still hear the clanging bells reminding them to contribute dimes and pennies for Christmas dinners for the poor, but the bells are no longer in the hands of the old-time Santa's with their red suits and white beards.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- This isn't the story it was intended to be because those in authority were otherwise engaged. But this excuse was new, and somehow refreshing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Prices of hogs rose 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight today when extension of the Government-supported weights to include 270 to 300-pound swine went into effect, and no carryovers here were reported. A sharp decrease in receipts enabled packers to slaughter the stock on hand and absorb today's fresh arrivals.

Striking back against a Soviet attack upon American labor leaders as "reactionaries" and seekers of personal power, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday accused Moscow of hurting Allied unity and interfering in the internal affairs of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -Two proposals for compromising Southern opposition on the soldier-vote question were advanced today by Senator Taft of Ohio.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 22 -- This is going to be a red Christmas on the Italian front, not a white one. That hardy perennial "Christmas truce" did not even put forth buds this year.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 24 -Richard Gardiner Casey, Minister of State resident in the Middle East, has been made Governor of Bengal and his appointment has been approved by King George VI, it was announced today.

Pre-holiday influences were at work yesterday in full force on the stock market and prices again followed an irregular and dull course. On the average, values were somewhat better, but weakness among the distilling issues tended to limit the additions.

The danger of a milk shortage in the New York City market area has definitely passed and some of the precautionary measures that were instituted to assure an equitable distribution of available supplies in the face of the shortage threat are being dropped, Dr. Charles J. Blanford, Administrator of the New York Milk Marketing Area, announced last night.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The twenty-first birthday of railway grouping on the stock markets here saw fresh support for home railway securities, based upon anticipated dividends. Gilt-edge issues were higher as a result of year-end investment demand.

Nearly one hundred debutantes of the season and their escorts thronged the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the Junior Assembly, traditionally New York's pre-eminent entertainment for the young women who are being introduced to society in the current winter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The President may find it possible soon, without damage either to security or the strategy of the United Nations, to make some announcement concerning the status of General Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army and dominant member of the Combined Chiefs of Staff -the high command of the war program of the United States and Great Britain.

With Wall Street's usual Christmas celebration limited by war conditions, the New York Curb Exchange is inviting the entire community to sing carols on its trading floor this afternoon at 3:10 o'clock. Singing will be led by twenty choir boys from St. Teresa's Church, Brooklyn, under Richard M. Schwende, choirmaster, accompanied by a ten-piece orchestra.

In an effort to avoid being squeezed between rigid price ceilings and anticipated higher production costs in 1944, most manufacturers of cotton garments and other textile products are adopting the "open price" method of accepting new contracts from Army, Navy and foreign-relief buyers, it was reported yesterday in the Worth Street market.

Formal protest against the residential rent-freezing order which went into effect here on Nov. 1 and a request for a blanket increase of "at least" 10 per cent in the ceiling prices for all leased dwelling units in the city have been filed with the Office of Price Administration by New York property owners, it became known last night.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Allied Liberator heavy bombers have dropped 153 more tons of bombs on oft-battered Cape Gloucester, key Japanese airdrome and supply base on the western end of New Britain Island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -President Roosevelt conferred today with Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, who made a circuitous return trip from the Cairo and Teheran conferences by way of Australia, the Solomons and Hawaii.

That seven labor racketeers who conspired to extort a million dollars from the motion-picture industry have been brought to justice must cause widespread gratification. But it took justice a long time to catch up with this handful of men, who had meanwhile succeeded in doing serious damage.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed an increase of $537,702,000 in holdings of United States Government securities to a new high record. Note circulation for the entire system showed an increase of $172,598,000.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 -Vichy, on orders of the Germans, is intensifying its measures to prevent the French from learning what is happening either in France or abroad, it was stated here today.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA -- If Miss Marjorie Hendricks, Red Cross food specialist stationed with the troops at an advanced base in New Guinea, has her way, old-fashioned American apple pie soon will be introduced in New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Without waiting for Congress to pass on the subsidy issue, the War Food Administration plans soon to announce support price programs on 1944 food production which will probably involve subsidies of more than $600,000,000, if existing price ceilings are maintained.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 -- Adolf Hitler has now concentrated up to eighteen German divisions in Yugoslavia as garrison forces, guards for the vital Balkan supply lines and especially as an offensive army designed to crush Marshal Tito's People's Army of Liberation before the Allied invasion of Europe.

WHEN the Nazis poured the vials of their malice on London during the Blitz of 1940 and 1941 and loosed the fury of their "Baedecker raids" on Coventry and Canterbury, Winchester and Plymouth, we in America knew a sickness in our hearts greater than any that could be caused by mere pity human sympathy, mere concern for the fate of the only bulwark that stood between us and the brown pestilence of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Under orders from President Roosevelt, Attorney General Francis Biddle is drawing up the legal papers which would enable the Government to seize the railroads if the nation-wide railroad strike, scheduled for Dec. 30, actually takes place.
LONDON, Friday Dec. 24 (UP) -The Soviet Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Redskins, here for practice, voted today to divide their part of the receipts of Sunday's play-off into thirty-two and a half shares. They were so confident of winning that they figured each share of the winner's purse would be around $1,000 and this is the way they will split it up:

ALGIERS, Dec. 23 -- Both Allied armies in Italy found the going tough again yesterday, although gains were made against tenacious resistance both in the central sector of the Ortona-Orsogna line and in the mountains west and southwest of Filignano.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The punishment absorbed by Leipzig in the

Unable to frustrate the repeated crushing blows against their cities by American and British air power, the Germans have now created a diversion. That is the plain meaning of the reports from London disclosing that since Monday the RAF and the United States Army Eighth Air Force have been engaged in heavy attacks upon enemy fortifications along the Channel coast, especially in the region of Calais, which lies closest to Britain.

All drivers of motor vehicles have a special responsibility during the holidays. In spite of reduced driving last year there was a shocking number of fatal and other accidents during the Christmas-New Year period. Let us not make a travesty of "Merry Christmas," this year by carelessly bringing death or injury to another human being.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- The Geermans were reported today to be carrying out a mass evacuation of the Yugoslav population along a 230-mile stretch of the Dalmatian and Montenegrin coasts to forestall Partisan attempts to aid possible Allied landings from across the Adriatic.

After reading F.Y. Alletson Cook's article, "Nazi Prisoners Are Nazis Still," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, I can't help wondering if American conceptions of fair play and generosity have not caused us to exceed the elastic limit in our treatment of prisoners of war.

The Kelvinator division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation has distributed a comprehensive post-war planning guide to its retailers which is designed to aid them in developing basic plans for post-war merchandising of appliances.

With this jingle as its Christmas greeting, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office urged yesterday that every American "help send a 'present' to the Axis -- the kind the enemy won't like," by salvaging all gift wrappings and cardboard for conversion into ammunition containers, fuel tank linings, blood plasma cartons and other war necessities.

Sydenham Hospital in Harlem will function in the future as an inter-racial voluntary hospital, staffed by Negro as well as white physicians and directed by a hospital board composed of Negroes and whites, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Martinson, president of the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The War Department announced today that of 581 air crew members reported missing when sixty Flying Fortresses were lost in the heavy bombing of industrial plants at Schweinfurt, Germany, 346 were alive as prisoners of war.

Reflecting the pre-holiday mood of the cotton trade, trading was dull in the futures market yesterday with prices advancing on routine trade price fixing and evening up operations incident to the coming week-end. With the market a trifle more active in the last minutes of dealings on the New York Cotton Exchange, the list of active futures contracts ended at the day's best levels and 5 to 8 points over Wednesday's final quotations.

A telegram from the Jed Harris office yesterday confirmed the fortnight's revival of "Our Town" at the City Center, beginning Jan. 10, under civic, auspices. Frank Craven has accepted Mayor La Guardia's invitation to play the role he created in Thornton Wilder's Pulitzer Prize play.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Adrian Carton de Wiart, Prime Minister Churchill's special military representative here, predicted today that the war in Europe would end in 1944.

By the time we were old enough to have our stockings hung up most of us must have been highly happy on Dec. 24. We tried to keep awake to hear old Whitebeard come down the chimney. We got up early to see what he had brought. Christmas Eve we must have been at our happiest in expectation.
Today the Christmas program at The Cloisters, the branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park devoted to medieval art, will begin with special decorations and music.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -Clifford Odets, who recently returned to Radio-Keith-Orpheum after the deal to sell his unfinished play, "An Errand for Uncle," to Warners fell through, has signed a contract with the former company to direct "None but the Lonely Heart," an adaptation of Richard Llewellyn's recent novel in which Cary Grant will be starred.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 -- With the War Labor Board's refusal of retroactivity of pay in current negotiations, contracts covering 350,000 workers for 241 companies in the war-vital steel industry will expire at midnight tomorrow.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Dec. 24 (UP) -- A communique:

Charles Giammona, 20-year-old Coast Guardsman, is a confirmed believer in the adage of seasoned soldiers -- it's not the shells you can hear that you have to worry about -- for the German shell that filled his body with a thousand fragments during the Salerno invasion never made a sound, he declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Roosevelt's radio address from Hyde Park at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon will be carried over "the most extensive network of international facilities ever organized from America," according to a White House statement today.

NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Dec. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- American troops stationed here and their administration were sharply criticized today by Gov. Christian Laigret of New Caledonia, French colonial possession in the South Pacific.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- United Press correspondent George Jones, just returned from the Arawe front, reported that installations at the beachhead were growing daily.

Metropolitan skiers for weeks have been hopeful for a white Christmas and good running on slopes and trails close to home, but reports from the North yesterday gave them little encouragement. Unless the cold spell relents and in its wake comes a deep white blanket of snow, they will have to travel far for holiday skiing.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (Aneta) -The inflationary trend in occupied Holland has reached such proportions that 3,000,000 guilders' worth of "buy" orders for shares of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company have been waiting for execution on the Amsterdam Bourse for more than a year without a single share becoming available.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 -- The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company of New York filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 155,830 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- It was inviting frozen tear-drops to come out of the Bears' den on Wabash Avenue into the zero weather today after talking with the Bruins' "brain trust."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Office of Price Administration announced that it expects to conclude its studies of the new simplified price regulation for retail stores by the end of the month and hopes to have a rough draft to discuss with the Retail Council in January.
Yesterday's Japanese communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Rudy York, the robust, hard-clouting first sacker of the Tigers, was the American League's foremost run-driver for 1943, according to official figures announced yesterday.

Under the post-war education program of the Board of Regents New York City would get four new two-year colleges of applied arts, enabling 8,000 to 12,000 additional students to receive free higher education here, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, declared yesterday.

IN a few more days this marathon football season will have run its regular course when the Redskins go Bear-hunting on the frozen wasteland of Chicago's Wrigley Field, where the icy gales sweep in from Lake Michigan. The day undoubtedly will be cold but the play will be hot. The two championship contenders dislike each other with an enthusiastic intensity.

In various declarations to which it has adhered, notably in the Moscow Declaration regarding Italy, the Russian Government has come out for freedom of speech, of political belief, of press and public meeting. These "of" freedoms, as distinguished from the "from" freedoms of our own Government, have always been regarded in this country as the inalienable rights of man, legally anchored in the American Constitution.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Governor Dewey completed his Cabinet appointments today by renaming John A. Lyons as Commissioner of Correction and Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr. as Commissioner of Health. Both were holdovers from the administration of former Governor Lehman.

A. Carl Bredahl, chief of the mechanical-electrical-utilities division of the Federal Public Housing Authority since 1934, has been appointed technical director of the Westinghouse better homes department, Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Reporting today on the new tax bill, the Senate Finance Committee launchly defended its reduction of the Treasury's $10,500,000,000 program to $2,275,000,000, its changes in the war contracts renegotiation act and its proposal to freeze Social Security taxes for 1944 at the existing rate of 1 per cent.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- Scoring one of their greatest defensive victories of the war, China-based American fighter pilots shot down or damaged forty-five Japanese planes Wednesday out of a strong formation that unsuccessfully attacked the Fourteenth United States Air Force's main base, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 -- Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), commander of the Yugoslav People's Army of Liberation, has requested the Allies to hand over to his provisional regime all Yugoslav war and merchant vessels captured by Italy during the 1941 campaign against his country.

A personal tribute warmly praising the "humane" work of private family welfare agencies and letters from refugees expressing gratitude they are in this country accompanied gifts to aid the Neediest Cases yesterday. A donor of $2 wrote:

As the proportion of service men and women mounted to approximately 40 per cent of all travelers, railroad, bus and airline terminals were jammed yesterday with holiday traffic. Every bit of equipment available was pressed into service, but operating officials expected the strain on their facilities would be even heavier today.

The appointment of Prof. Frederick W. Maroney, chairman of the men's physical education department, as dean of students and chairman of the Personnel Service Department, and Prof. William R. Gaede of the German department as dean of studies was announced yesterday by Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 -Fascist Republican Government Headquarters announced today the postponement of the Italian "Riom" trial to an unspecified date in February. Simultaneously it was admitted the only accused person now in Fascist hands was Count Ciano, former Foreign Minister who was arrested last month.

In case you've been wondering about "smokeless" powder, or even if you haven't, here's a dissertation on that propellent from W.E. Witsil of the Remington Arms Company. Since the duck season ended in this locality yesterday and deer hunting stopped some time ago, the subject is perhaps of only academic interest hereabouts, although vitally important on foreign fields.

Although stocks of idle and excess machine tools listed with the War Production Board's regional redistribution division have risen to between 6,000 and 8,000 units, increased requests of manufacturers for replacements indicate that the inventory may not rise above the present level for some time, Worrell H. Holby, regional manager of the agency's facilities department, stated yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 24 -Royal Air Force heavy bombers thundered out over the North Sea from eastern British airdromes at midnight following American and British bombing attacks yesterday on mysterious targets in the Pas-de-Calais area of France -- now termed the "rocket gun coast."

The Christmastide was heralded at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall by two new Christmas overtures by American composers who were present, one of them officiating in the performance of his work.

Working conditions for women in New York State factories are substantially as good now as they were before the war, it was agreed yesterday by representatives of industry, labor and the Government. With its effective strict labor law, this State, at least, apparently is not affected by President Roosevelt's statement on Wednesday that women were being discouraged from entering war plants by poor cafeteria and sanitary accommodations.

Money in circulation, according to figures released yesterday, rose $147,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, compared with $237,000,000 during the corresponding week last year. However, to jump to the conclusion that the expansion in currency has about reached its peak would be premature, to say the least.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- A Southwest Asia Command communique:

Coiffeurs and other experts in such matters attribute a recent trend toward unhealthy hair and over-oily scalps directly to the nervous tension that is a by-product of wartime living. The slightest abnormal excitement of the nervous system, they say, may be reflected in an overstimulation of the sebaceous glands that provide lubrication for both scalp and hair.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 23 -- Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson dismissed today a proceeding brought by Mrs. Mabeline Serenbetz of Hempstead, L.I., to set aside the election of officers of the Women's Republican Club of Hempstead at a meeting on Nov. 8. A. number of new members had been admitted to the club and their admission and the regularity of the meeting was questioned in this proceeding.

Many of the 155 graduates of the College of Physicians and Surgeons and the School of Dental and Oral Surgery at Columbia University took their oaths as members of the United States Army and Navy at graduation exercises yesterday in the McMillin Academic Theatre on the campus.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 23 (AP) -Labor Minister Victor Andrade said today the new Bolivian Government planned a social security program to improve the living standards of the country's tin miners and peasants. Better wages and medical care also are contemplated, he said.

Two originals and two reprints make up the latest batch of Penguin Books, just off the presses. "My Own Murderer," by Richard Hull, and John Steinbeck's "The Moon Is Down" are the reprints. "A History of the War," by Rudolph Modley, which signals a departure in Penguin publishing by its inclusion of maps and pictographs, is a co-publishing venture with The Infantry Journal.

Dolph Camilli, Giant first baseman who never played for that team and who had been prematurely announced as manager of the Oakland Club of the Pacific Coast League, finally has the blessing of Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis in his new post.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -Connie Mack observed his eighty-first birthday today by telling of the greatest mistake of his long baseball career -- selling Southpaw Herb Pennock to the Red Sox in 1915.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 -- King Peter's Yugoslav Government-in-Exile retorted today to the attacks made on its legal standing by Yugoslav Partisans as the work of "impostors," and reaffirmed the determination of the forces led by Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch to fight at the side of the Allies until the end of the war.

WITH MOROCCAN TROOPS IN ITALY, Dec. 23 -- The entry of Moroccan Goums into the battle line has not been without its humor, because of the difference in languages and customs in the ranks of the Fifth Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Rumors of an impending gasoline "famine" in the Eastern States are without foundation, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Petroleum Administrator for War assured the public today in a bulletin concerning petroleum supplies for the East Coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Roosevelt feels that the "New Deal' Megan which has identified his Administration is out of date and should be changed to something like "win the war." The President made a statement to this effect to a visiting corre spondent who paused for a few minutes after the Tuesday press conference to greet him, according to Stephen T. Early, the President's secretary.

Dropping its biweekly War Production Board news, the agency will now issue a weekly publication devoted to a listing of available idle and excess supplies, the regional agency announced yesterday at its offices in the Empire State Building.

AT AN ADVANCED COMMAND POST IN ITALY, Dec. 23 -- The Italian campaign has well repaid all efforts involved in it, in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's opinion. It has won for us the great port of Naples and the invaluable airfields of Foggia.

Forcing the car of Abraham Furman, 50 years old, operator of a check-cashing office at 226A Sands Street, Brooklyn, to the curb in front of the Brooklyn Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, three armed thugs held him up at pistol point at 4 P.M. yesterday and robbed him of $18,000 in cash which he had just withdrawn from a bank.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 18 were 4 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Two films will arrive in midtown theatres today. "The Ghost Ship," a mystery melodrama produced by RKO Radio Pictures, and starring Richard Dix, will be the new offering at the Rialto. Featured are Russell Wade, Ben Bard, Edmund Glower and Edith Barrett, who plays the sole feminine role in the film. . . . "

The curtain has been lifted by the Office of War Information to give us a glimpse of the vital services performed by the private airlines of the United States during the war emergency. Operating with half their airplanes and one-third of their men in the armed services, the lines have been able nevertheless to perform a huge job of passenger and cargo carrying, and a host of special services arising from the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has ruled that the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company's failure to serve eighteen Negro seamen meals in a dining car while traveling from Tampa to New York City was not prejudicial nor did it reveal undue or unreasonable preference for white passengers.

Activity in the new investment market here this week was the slowest for any week in three months, a condition not unusual at this time of year. A single issue of municipal bonds for $455,000 was offered, together with several blocks of common and preferred stock. In the preceding week, four diversified issues of bonds aggregating $9,522,000 were marketed, and in this week a year ago, one tax-exempt loan for $350,000.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today that all Japanese troops west of the Sungtze River, which connects the Yangtze with Tungting Lake, had been cleared out and that the walled city of Sungtze had been recaptured.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The greatest number of American heavy bombers ever to take off from Britain attacked "special military installations" of the Germans along the coast of northern France today as part of record operations of probably 3,000 Allied warplanes across the Channel.
The St. Louis Cardinals displayed all their vaunted speed yesterday as they raced off with the distinction of being the biggest flop in 1943.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Dec. 24 -Ten military prisoners confined a Camp Shanks, a military institution near here, escaped in three separate outbreaks staged last night and early today, after over powering their guards and confiscating the latters' weapons.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England recorded a new all-time high for notes in circulation with an increase of 13,065,000 for the week. The total stood at 1,081,022,000 and was within 20,000,000 of the authorized fiduciary issue of 1,100,000,000.

MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Warren G. Wright, owner of mighty Whirlaway, came out today with the flat assertion that no horse now racing would surpass the earnings of $561,161.50 piled up by his long-tailed star.

The Minneapolis-Moline Power Implement Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday in its annual statement for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 net profit of $1,632,406 after $300,000 provision for contingencies and post-war losses, and $5,927,409 taxes after deduction of $585,847 post-war credit of which $400,000 was currently availed of through debt retirement.

At the same time that major coal distributors suggested that the crisis here could be eased if large consumers who were able to burn it would use run-of-the-mine soft coal, which is available. Mayor La Guardia urged "all who can" to use a mixture of soft and hard coal.

BETHLEHEM, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -The varied accents of America and the Western World mingled with the chatter of Arabic as Allied soldiers thronged the streets of Bethlehem today to pay homage to Jesus Christ in a midnight service at the Church of the Nativity.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 -- The Partisan movement in Yugoslavia represents a curious combination of communism, pan-Slavism and religious devotion, with emphasis heavily on the first two factors. Many powerful elements in Yugoslavia are eager either to join the Soviet Union or at least to form the closest sort of working agreement with Moscow.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- In spite of zero weather, the Chicago Bears, at the risk of frozen ears, noses and fingers, staged a three-hour workout at Wrigley Field today, almost all of it devoted to offense, which is what they figure they'll need when they meet up with Sammy Baugh, Anvil Andy Farkas, Wilbur Moore and several other Washington Redskins in the East-West play-off for the National Football League championship on Sunday.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- President Roosevelt promised the country and the world this Christmas Eve that they could look for insured peace with "certainty," even though "the cost may be high and the time long," and said that the United States, Great Britain, Soviet Russia and China were agreed to use force to maintain that peace "for as long as it may be necessary."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The appointment of General Dwight D. Eisenhower, now Allied Commander in the Mediterranean theatre, as supreme commander of the Anglo-American forces for the invasion of Europe, was hailed with enthusiastic unity by members of Congress still remaining in Washington today -- and for two reasons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -Lynn Bari has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the lead in a musical, "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling." The film will be put before cameras early in February as Damon Runyon's initial production for that company. Earl Baldwin is writing the screen play.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 24 -- A novel machine for making, sandwiching and then vending hamburgers, and an unusual rubber submersible boat received patents this week among the relatively few 513 listed and granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
Lofts, a taxpayer and several housing properties in Manhattan passed to new control in deals reported yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 -- American soldiers in the Middle East are prepared for the best eating and entertainment available to any of the millions of United States troops abroad -- and if they don't take advantage of their opportunity, they have only themselves to blame.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue has ruled that advertisers placing copy promoting wartime Government objectives may deduct expenditures incurred in such advertising from their corporate income- tax returns whether or not the insertions contain any reference to the advertisers' trade-marks, products or services.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A far-reaching five-point post-war program to maintain America's armed might as insurance for world peace was advocated today by Representative Wadsworth of New York, former chairman of the Senate Military Committee.

New York was far from a big, cold, gray city as it ushered in its third wartime Christmas last night with heart-warming church services, gay parties, gifts for the ill and unfortunate, and messages of good-will that brought cheer to its teeming millions and to the men and women visitors in the services.

CASTINE, Me., Dec. 4 (AP) -Five Royal Navy socks hung from a fireplace mantel here tonight and Santa Claus, arching his was across the wintry skies, saw to in that although the owners were far from home, they were generously remembered.

The stock market concluded yesterday an uninteresting and unproductive pre-holiday week with price movements narrow and net changes mixed at the close. It was the dullest five-hour session in two months on the Stock Exchange, where transfers aggregated only 511,780 shares, against 580,480 on Thursday.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- President Roosevelt announced today the appointment of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to lead the invasion of Europe from the north and west, and from London came word that Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery of North African fame would head the British troops under General Eisenhower to form a proved and hard-hitting team to lead the assault on Adolf Hitler's "Fortress Europe."

You find yourself thinking about the Liberty Bell. When the bell rang out to the people of Philadelphia on July 4, 1776, the good news that a new nation was born practically everybody rejoiced, of course. But did a leading citizen here and there take it upon himself to warn the people against complacency?

HYDE PARK, Dec. 24 -- Nothing could be of greater contrast than the informality of the atmosphere in which President Roosevelt gave his epoch-making report to the world this afternoon, and the vital decisions which he imparted to people all over the globe.
LONDON, Dec, 24 (AP) -- The German High Command asserted today that its naval shore batteries had shelled targets at Dover, Deal and Folkestone, across the channel from Nazi-controlled France.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 24 -- An appeal is being made to the Privy Council in London -- the highest judicial appellate body within the British Empire -- in one of the most complicated and unusual instances of probate litigation that has occurred in the Holy Land, where religious law upon mortmain, or "dead hand," bequests is exceedingly complex.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's appraisal of the results of his campaign in Italy -- an appraisal made on the eve of the President's announcement of his appointment to the command of the Allied forces in the West -- is another reminder that in this war mere miles of territory gained are a poor and incomplete indication of the success or failure of an operation.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- Miss Helen McKinstry has been appointed president of Russell Sage College, succeeding Lieut. Col. James L. Meader, now serving overseas with the United States armed forces.

Today's events: "Mignon," 2 P.M., and "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci" and Polovetsian Dances from "Prince Igor," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Russian Cathedral Choir, Waldorf-Astoria, 4:30; Alix Young Maruchess, viola d'amore and Blanche Winogron, virginals and piano in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; "Carmen," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen today canceled notices for a strike of their 230,000 members on Dec. 30 in view of President Roosevelt's offer and their acceptance of arbitration by the Chief Executive.

A series of messages promising that their hour of deliverance is fast approaching was broadcast last night to the people of occupied France by the Office of War Information as part of a special Christmas Eve program. The French nation was reminded of its noble history and urged to take courage so that its future will be equally bright.

A project that is saving the Army $1,500,000 a month in equipment was threatened recently by an industrial feeding problem. With more than 1,000, women workers employed to recondition 300,000 battle-scarred uniforms and "G.I. issue" a month at its Repair Sub-depot at 125 West End Avenue, the New Jersey City Quartermasters Depot operating this Manhattan repair plant found itself facing the problem of finding adequate eating facilities or losing the employes.

The fifth Christmas of the war finds a large part of the civilized world exhausted, ravaged, crazed or dulled by cruelty. The "countless thousands" who suffered from man's inhumanity to man in the past have multiplied into countless millions in the present. The horror has become so vast that it is almost impersonal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- In a general overhauling of orders covering the manufacture and distribution of cotton yarns and fabrics, the War Production Board today amended Orders L-99 and M-317 and revoked Orders L-99-A and M-207.

It was very interesting reading about the things we did, but there was something lacking -the thoughts of the men that participated in that invasion.

Sixteen bodies had been removed last night from a five-story brick structure at 437-439 West Fortysecond Street, between Ninth and Tenth _venues, the four upper floors of which were occupied by a "Bowery-type" lodging house, after one of the city's worst fires in years virtually had consumed the entire interior.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 24 -- The Neukoelln industrial quarter of Berlin, on the southeast of the city adjoining Tempelhof, was a principal target of the RAF's early morning attack, according to eyewitnesses coming here today from the Reich capital.

The Tokyo radio said in an imperial headquarters communique yesterday that a formation of seventy-five Allied planes raided Rabaul, big Japanese sea and air base on New Britain Island, Thursday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -Sharply opposing viewpoints on the proposal to subject issuance of railway securities to compulsory competitive bidding were voiced today in a simultaneous release of letters by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Arthur Dean of the legal firm of Sullivan Cromwell of New York.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Scheer Eis has been dissolved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -In giving Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower the job of opening new fronts against Germany, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill have put it in the hands of the soldier who, in all history, has had the most experience in directing vast combined land, sea and air operations.

ALGIERS, Dec. 24 -- The Allied armies in Italy kept up pressure all along the line yesterday despite the imminence of Christmas, but were unable quite to complete the capture of Ortona or accomplish substantial gains on the Tyrrhenian half of the front.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Dec. 25 -- Out here this year Christmas is just another day. It is not only as hot as that one insufferable day each summer at home, but damp also. Everyone is wringing wet.

Prayers for peace were offered by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, celebrant of the Pontifical midnight mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, with hundreds of uniformed men who again this year were in the majority in the crowded church.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 24 -- Three more air strikes into the Marshall Islands, where the Japanese have begun to reinforce their bases, were announced today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet.

Routine price-fixing orders by the trade, though small, steadied the cotton futures market yesterday throughout one of the quietest sessions this season. Overcoming slight early losses, the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the short session with quotations one point either way of previous closing levels.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- For the thirtieth consecutive Chrismas Eve, the pageant of the nativity was presented this evening on a hillside in the center of Bronxville. Civic groups, public officials, merchants and club women participated in the event.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, telegraphed today to Philip Murray, president of the CIO United Steel Workers, that if labor members of the board desired to reconsider their vote on the retroactive pay issue "the public members will favor such reconsideration."

ALGIERS, Dec. 24 -- There were many ways in which to regard this particular day in Algiers. Conceivably some soldiers may have noted it was the forty-sixth day after the first anniversary of their landing here. Others more politically minded may have observed it was the exact anniversary of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan's assassination.

The international spirit will prevail at Madison Square Garden tonight when the University of Havana basketball team opposes the Long Island University quintet in the feature game of a court double-header. The opening game on the bill will be between Brooklyn College and Western Kentucky.

On this Christmas morning, the spirit of sharing to help the less fortunate has lifted the Neediest Cases Fund for the relief of the most distressed men, women and children in New York City to the splendid total of $213,711.19. Since this thirty-second annual Christmas appeal started on Dec. 5 this amount has come from 7,753 contributors from all walks of life who have given in large and small amounts, often at personal sacrifice.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Pressing "successful offensive operations" in Eastern Bosnia, the Partisans of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) reported today that their units were closing in further around the town of Sarajevo, where World War I was touched off.

In a check-up of the Manhasset and Larchmont dinghies yesterday, it appeared that about twenty-five will participate Jan. 1 and 2 in the thirteenth annual Frostbite Regatta to be held at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. The list was of the Class B boats alone.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The appointment of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme Allied commander of the "western front" was accepted in Britain with satisfaction and relief. The British people are satisfied because they have confidence in "General Ike." They are relieved because, frankly, the feeling has been growing here that the appointment was long overdue.

The most important news in the President's Christmas Eve broadcast to our troops in the field and our people at home is the announcement that General Eisenhower has been chosen to lead the Allied attack that will be delivered against Germany from the West. This is further evidence that plans for the great offensive of 1944 are well advanced and that full agreement on them has been reached.
One wonders how long the economic situation of 15,000,000 white-collar workers would have been ignored by Congress if THE NEW YORK TIMES had not become interested in the subject.

Max Gordon disclosed yesterday that "Over 21" will arrive at the Music Box On Jan. 3, a day earlier than previously announced. Noting the attraction's financial success out of town, the producer estimated that this week's gross receipts in Boston would reach the $10,000 mark.

The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission comes forward with its first specific recommendation of interest to sports anglers, at the same time denying allegations that its only concern is with commercial fishing.
The following letter from my daughter, who is serving with the American Red Cross in Great Britain, may be of general interest. To protect her anonymity I must remain anonymous myself. She writes:

ALGIERS, Dec. 24 -- The appointment of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to the supreme command of the Allied armies which will launch the greatest of all invasions against Germany had been anticipated here for some times, particularly since the announcement in Washington on Dec. 11 that President Roosevelt and the General had conferred for two days in a villa at Carthage.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Trading in grain markets today was largely of a professional character, and although there was a little pressure early that caused a moderate decline, short covering developed later and a good rally followed, last sales on the Board of Trade being about the top.
Wacs, Waves, Spars and Women marines away from home for Christmas have found plenty of holiday cheer in the service women's centers about town.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- For some unknown reason the Germans are trying to stage a miniature Stalingrad in hapless Ortona, a seacoast town of 9,000 population, and Canadian troops are busily and dangerously engaged in shooting them out of windows, battering down their barricades and chasing them out of cellars and sewers.

The first indication that the War Production Board has taken definite action to prevent the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations from "raiding" existing supplies of essential types of civilian hosiery for men, children and infants was made public here yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Premier Raid Solh told an extraordinary session of the Lebanese Chamber of Deputies today that France had agreed during the recent Damascus negotiations to transfer to Lebanon and Syria all powers exercised over them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The United States submarine Grayling is overdue in action and "must be presumed to be lost," the Navy Department announced today.

MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Last-minute Christmas shoppers poured $317,262 into the mutuel machines for Tropical Park's largest handle since opening day and the best bargain they got was a $30.20 payoff on Mrs. E.B. Carpenter's Robins Crown in the fifth race today.

Christmas is the day for the annual preliminary report of our stewardship of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund. This has been a generous year for it. Despite high prices and taxes, the imperious call of national causes, the War Fund, the War Bond drive, the multiplication of miseries by the war and the new demands upon the charitable, this year's Fund at this writing amounts to nearly $214,000.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lightning fighters of an outfit with a brilliant combat record shot down sixteen out of thirty enemy planes over Wewak yesterday in a forty-five minute running battle with numerically superior numbers.

Major league baseball, which has been pretty much on the receiving end in its efforts to carry on in the face of ever increasing war difficulties, experienced its first substantial windfall in the nature of a holiday gift yesterday when Mayor La Guardia came out unequivocally for night baseball in the metropolitan area for next year, provided no new army or navy regulations stop him.

Pre-New Year and post-Christmas sermons will be preached in the churches of the city tomorrow. In most houses of worship the Christmas music will be repeated. There will be Christmas oratories, cantatas, pageants, mystery plays and candlelight carol services.

MERIDEN, Conn., Dec. 24 -- Mephistopheles: Well, Santa, old boy, I think I've got you licked this year. No use trying to spread good cheer when people everywhere are blowing each other to bits; destroying whole cultures and experimenting with even more dreadful weapons of devastation than the ones they already possess.

With men's clothing manufacturers well started on production of their spring lines, a more serious situation is developing in so far as linings are concerned, which, it is indicated, will materially curtail fabrication in the immediate future.

ALGIERS, Dec. 24 -- Within the last few days this correspondent has talked at length with many representatives of the resistance movement who have come from various parts of France, some within the last few weeks, by ingenious methods which may be more appropriately described after the war.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The total tonnage of bombs dropped on hard-hit Cape Gloucester on the western tip of invaded New Britain since Dec. 1 was raised to 2,500 tons today by Allied airmen who dropped 300 tons in their latest raid.
The ambition of Dr. Margot Quintana and the objective toward which her life's work will be directed is to see that the children of her native Cuba have good teeth.
