Following is an official English translation of Pope Pius' Christmas message as broadcast by the Vatican radio and recorded in New York by The Associated Press:
LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Friday midnight suplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

For the third successive Christmas we have to try to reconcile the beautiful dream of peace on earth, good-will among men, with the sad fact of war. The dream is not of peace on this side of the firing line but peace everywhere, and not of good-will to our relatives, friends and allies only but good-will to everyone.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Praying that this may be the last war Christmas and that a truly Christian peace may be celebrated in the coming year, Pope Pius XII today called for the world's responsible leaders to check the instincts of hate and vengeance and give rise to "the resplendent dawn of a new spirit of world union."
WITH THE AMERICANS ON BOUGAINVILLE, Dec. 24 (AP) -- What are the boys thinking and doing this Christmas Eve on Empress Augusta beachhead -- current and perhaps last battlefield of the Solomons?

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 23 (AP) -Officers of the Norfolk War Price and Rationing Board said tonight that this booming wartime port had gone on a Christmas buying jag which reached a climax today when a crowd swarmed about a truck and bought turkeys for as much as $20 each.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 25 -- The Russian Baltic Army cracked a model German defense-in-depth line and captured the heavily fortified lake town of Gorodok, seventeen miles north of Vitebsk yesterday, sweeping on over 2,000 German dead in a continuing offensive to take sixty more towns and hamlets, Moscow announced early today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The epidemic of influenza and pneumonia is causing a sharp increase in the death rate, although the rise in mortality is not comparable to that of the winters twenty-five years ago.

The Government and the grocery industry seem to have joined forces this Christmas season to make things easy for housekeepers. As a change from the prevailing trend there is an abundance of many kinds of food in city stores -- a circumstance that facilitates meal-planning in an unexpected, not to say pleasant, way.

Twenty choir boys from St. Teresa's Church, Brooklyn, led the carol singing yesterday at the Christmas celebration held on the floor of the New York Curb Exchange. They were accompanied by a ten-piece band.

Although the 1943 baseball season witnessed a general decline in the standard of play so far as offensive work was concerned, the American League nevertheless managed to show an increase over 1942 in the way of record performances, according to official statistics released yesterday for publication.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- More materials and more manpower, to overcome the shortage of children's clothes, were assured by orders issued today by the War Production Board and the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Bolivian Nationalist Revolutionary Government of Gualberto Villarroel tonight officially decreed that the 1938 Constitution, except for minor changes, would remain in force, that United Nations' commitments in their entirety would be adhered to and that a plebiscite would be held "at the first opportunity."

AND bow did Santa Claus treat you today? The jolly old elf seemed to have a slimmer pack on his back this year because of various shortages. Packages were fewer beneath most Christmas trees but the true spirit of the holiday season still managed to manifest itself despite its wartime handicaps. In fact, a casual survey of what Santa left some of our sporting folk reveals him to be a very knowing old codger.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Despite official statements to the contrary there was said today to be a better than even chance that all rationing of pork would be temporarily suspended to get it on the market and release freezing space needed for other purposes.

George Frankenthaler and Archie B. Morrison, named by Governor Dewey to fill the two vacancies on the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial District, are well qualified by character, ability, experience and reputation for the posts. The public interest will be served if both Mr. Frankenthaler and Mr. Morrison continue on the bench as long as they are willing and able to do so.

Betty Grable, blonde singing and dancing star of Twentieth Century-Fox, rose from eighth place in 1942 to this year's box-office championship, leading the ten leading money-making film stars selected in the annual survey of the Motion Picture Herald, it was revealed yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- A Get-] na communique, as broadcast

" Tarzan's Desert Mystery," the latest in a series produced by Sol Lesser for RKO release and starring Johnny Weissmuller in the title role, will open this morning at the Globe Nancy Kelly, Johnny Sheffield, Otto Kruger, Joe Sawyer, Lloyd Corrigan and Robert Lowery are featured in the adventure. . . .

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Football stars from the East and West, who will clash here New Year's day in the annual game for the benefit of the crippled children's hospital, started heavy training today.

Virtually all Exchanges and markets will be closed today in the United States and throughout the world. Banks likewise will be closed, except in Russia, Turkey and Saudi Arabia. A few livestock markets in the United States will be open. Markets and institutions closed today will reopen for business on Monday as usual.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24 -- Philip Murray, president of the CIO United Steel Workers, withheld comment tonight on the message of William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, stating that the board's public members were willing to reconsider retroactive pay within the present wage stabilization formula.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- The Navy intends to broaden its policy on eligibility of personnel to run for political office, but, it was made clear today, restrictions will stand against men whose friends would like to nominate them for such offices as sheriff or town councilman.

The German DNB agency yesterday transmitted a 2,300-word Christmas message from Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels in which he attempted to cheer the much bombed German home front by promising "a coming certain victory" and declaring that "the enemy will feel our strength next spring in the course of a military encounter with our armed forces in the west."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

Municipal financing scheduled to be done next week amounts to $44,215,173, including new issues of temporary loan notes of sixteen local housing authorities throughout the country, aggregating $43,467,000, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. Next week's unusually large total will lift the weekly average for the year to $15,136,889, on the basis of preliminary estimates on the new municipal financing for 1943 of approximately $787,120,000.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 24 (U.P.) -Henry J. Kaiser announced today that an Eastern banking concern had offered a prospectus on his proposed credit risk pool for financing industrial reconversion to peacetime production and that he had taken a sample "mustering out poll" at one of his shipyards.

Millinery showrooms are bursting forth with ribbons and flowers. Felts are in delicate pastel tints. Brims are renouncing their winter severity and are taking on the lightness of petal-shaped contours, hearts and tricornes. These are indications of things to come in the spring.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- The country's largest war plant, a series of structures sprawling over 500 acres of land, was ready today to turn out an unending stream of engines for Army bombing planes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 -- More than 100,000 Greeks have been made homeless and deprived of all means of livelihood as a result of German looting and pillage in the last few months, the Greek Department of Information said in a report issued today.

The Honor Board of the Police Department announced yesterday afternoon through Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine the presentation of departmental honors to 279 men. Included in the list of policemen whose actions during the last several months have been officially commended are eight for meritorious conduct, eight honorable mentions, eighty-three commendations and 180 for excellent police duty.
Furniture retailers will petition the Office of Price Administration for price relief at retail levels early in January, a spokesman for the trade disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- To the lonesome doughboy in the mud of Italy, the airman 20,000 feet above blazing Germany, the bluejacket behind the gun of a battleship in Japanese waters, the Marine on a bloody coral reef of the Marshalls, and all their brothers and sisters of the armed services, the Commander in Chief, President Roosevelt, and the highest officers of the Army and Navy expressed their gratitude and pride on this Christmas Eve.

Holiday shopping ended fairly quietly here yesterday, with active buying of liquors and main-floor pick-up items continuing until store-closing. Up to yesterday, department store sales on the average showed a nominal December increase over last year.

THE year 1943, from a Hollywood point of view, has been chiefly characterized by the dollar sign. Its record production expenditures have reflected the wartime prosperity that has given theatres and all distributing and producing agencies unprecedented grosses.

INCREASED sports and musical entertainment for the fighting men of the United Nations and the peoples of Axis and Allied occupied territories, coupled with a decline in enemy propaganda for America, are the distinguishing trends in the 1943 short-wave picture.

OWNERS of winter resorts in New York's Catskills and Adirondacks, Pennsylvania's Poconos, New England's Berkshires, Green and White Mountains and Canada's Laurentians have entered the 1943-44 season with widespread optimism.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A surprising number of the 500 to 800 patents issued each week would not have been applied for if it were not for the war. A "flush gun turret," a "digit signal translator" and a "cooling system for air-cooled internal-combustion engines," appearing in the list of patents granted during the week of Dec. 14, illustrate the wartime inventions.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of Poland has gone to the United States for conferences with President Roosevelt it was learned tonight.

BEETHOVEN won in the referendum vote by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's public for "my favorite symphony," receiving 627 votes, 225 of which were for the Ninth symphony, with the Seventh next in demand. Brahms was second choice, with 265 votes, his Fourth symphony leading.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Whistling in the graveyard of hopes for world domination, official German pronouncements assured the people today that matters might be worse and that, however bent the fighting fronts appeared, they remained unbroken.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra's rearrangement of the old-age retirement fund for its members has evoked the interest of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra officials, who have wired for particulars. By the new plan, known as the Pension Foundation, each player's annual-payment of $100 is matched by the association, which also has contributed $18,000 left over from the former pension fund.

THE most comforting part of the waning year in sports is that they were able to carry on at all. They did it under manpower handicaps and, although the quality of performances deteriorated somewhat, each form of athletics was a reasonable facsimile of the genuine article. The fans minded it least of all.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 25 -- Addressing forty-three sentenced prisoners in the county jail here today in an annual Christmas message, the Right Rev. James Pernette De Wolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, described the lowly birth of Christ and asserted that when God wanted to reveal his greatest love he showed the simplicity of a home.

The Metropolitan Opera Fund has reached its first milestone of $25,000 in contributions, according to announcement by George A. Sloan, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association and chairman of the fund campaign. He announced also the creation of a National Sponsors Committee for the fund, consisting of 150 friends of opera in all parts of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- The Seabees, the Navy's fighting builders, will be two years old Tuesday and their achievements already are known around the world.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, Dec. 25 -- Somehow it was just a little different up at the front today, a little less firing, a little more sunshine and a bang-up meal that included turkey and cake.

In addition to regaining its normal markets in the manufacture of pigments and inks, the war-spurred powder metals field expects an additional post-war volume of 200,000,000 pounds as a result of recent production developments, David A. Buckley, chairman of the board of directors, Unexcelled Manufacturing Company, Inc., stated yesterday.

In appointing Dean Grayson N. Kefauver as a consultant to work on the problem of educational reconstruction, the State Department has taken an encouraging step. Even before the war ends, the problem of rehabilitating the school systems in Nazi-held territories will assume increasing importance.

THE custom of this department to make an annual choice of those films which, in our estimation, have been the best of the year impels us now to a duty which we none too cheerfully perform. For the simple fact is that the pictures -- even the best -- of 1943 have been a generally middling lot of product in comparison with those of previous, pre-war years.

Psychology is attracting an unusually large number of students at Barnard College this year. The department has geared some of its courses to the war and post-war periods. Many of the students are planning what they will do either here or in some other country after hostilities have ceased, and are arranging their courses to conform with this program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The first World War brought forth a new word -- "profiteer" -- applied to individuals and concerns which made exorbitant profits out of war contracts. After the war, claims were made that 23,000 new millionaires were created by the conflict, and in the last twenty-five years more than 170 bills have been introduced in Congress for the elimination of war profits.

EARLY winter still finds the gardener busy with numerous tasks in preparation for this cold season. One that must not be neglected is the protection of young fruit trees from the nibblings of hungry rabbits. Most communities have their share of rabbits, and, though they are picturesque enough when hopping about the lawn, they certainly are not desirable as feeders on the bark of one's prospective orchard.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Declaring that Allied military successes have brought closer the dawn of a free world with independent nations, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek called upon China's soldiers today to fight until death for victory.

Means of improving the teaching of American history in our schools and colleges, together with recommendations for higher standards among history teachers, are offered in a comprehensive report prepared by a committee of prominent historians and educators.

A Christmas dance with special features devised in compliment to Brazil will be given Wednesday night at the Hotel Roosevelt by the Daughters of the American Revolution through its war service committee of Greater New York, of which Mrs. Harry D. McKeige is director.

Presentation next month by the Office of Price Administration of the tentative draft of its simplified price-control plan for retailing will bring into clearer focus the attitude of retailers toward the project, it was indicated in distribution circles here last week.

THE little man with the trim business suit -- a general appearance that gave little clue to his being a prominent conductor -- had a sparkle in his eye. He was entitled to the gleam. After all, he had passed, without interruption, his twenty-second year as a dispenser of good music over the radio.

Streamlined to the point where there was scarcely an ounce of waste at the waistline, but by no means emaciated, sports in its second war year presented perhaps the most extraordinary panorama ever witnessed since it became the fashion to chronicle competitive events of physical prowess staged for the dual purposes of enhancing the well being of the competitors and entertaining millions of on-lookers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- While the Red Army is rapidly exploiting Gorodok's capture by advancing across frozen wastes toward Vitebsk, large numbers of demoralized German officers and men, many miles behind the fighting area, are reported emerging from White Russian forests and giving themselves up to Russian soldiers and peasants.

TOMORROW night at 10:30 over CBS (WABC) there is the debut of a program devoted to condensations of Broadway musical comedies. William Gaxton, in one of his rare chores without the services of his perennial partner, Victor Moore, headlines the doings, aided by Johnny Morgan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A constitutional amendment, giving to Congress undisputed power to facilitate voting by service men and service women in Federal elections was suggested today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Wyoming. He said in a statement:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- A War Department spokesman said tonight that he was unable to give the source of a report that the enemy might attempt a sneak air attack on the East Coast on Christmas Day, but that Eastern Defense Command authorities apparently considered the source authentic.

LISETTE is a young girl whose peaceful life on a farm in Normandy is tragically broken by the war and the German invasion of France. Her mother and her two small brothers are killed by a German bomb. Her father, fighting with the French Army, is lost.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday a gift of $38,781 to the university from the Dyckman Institute for the establishment of the Dyckman Institute Fund. The gift headed a list of twenty-five cash contributions totaling $68,876.

Reunion at Christmas, one of the most cherished traditions of the human race took place at least in spirit for millions of American families, separated this year because of the war, by the magic of radio yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The text of King George's Christmas Day message to the empire:

American armament production, without which Premier Stalin admits the Allies could not win the war, was made possible only by the successful efforts of small companies to increase their manufacturing capacity by plowing back their profits into increased plant facilities.

Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, speaking yesterday afternoon from Washington at the fourth Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally of the season, over the Blue Network, declared that peace was "a thing to be made, not accepted," and that it must be made by "hard labor in common."

Gifts came out of an apparently bottomless grab bag yesterday at 99 Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, as attendance records fell before an unending stream of service men and women.

AT Christmas time, the season of gifts, it is the custom of this column to review the outstanding gifts which have been given in bridge hands played during the year. Such gifts are not properly in the Christmas spirit, for in every case they have been given unwittingly and reluctantly.

THIS is a better-than-average first novel. Fundamentally, it is in the tough-boy tradition of American fiction between World Wars I and II. Smith is not afraid of using exact anatomical terms of description and he doesn't shy away from delicate subjects like anti-Semitism and homosexuality.

FOR almost a year now my life has been inextricably interwoven with the career of Miss Corliss Archer. This Miss Archer, an attractive teen- age girl, is a composite of may daughters, Diana and Pamela, and she first saw the light of day in a short story.

The saga of a real Atlantic Ocean "work horse," a ship of only 5,184 gross tons that has carried thousands of passengers and covered more than 100,000 miles in the last twenty-one months -- the story of the S.S. George Washington's great war contribution to this country was told here yesterday by an official of the Alcoa Steamship Company, charterers of the vessel.

ABOUT a year ago Dr. David J. Dallin published a book on Soviet foreign policy from 1939 until 1942 that has been widely recognized as standard in its field. His present work, although smaller in scope, is more ambitious in aim. It is nothing less than an interpretation and analysis of the basic aims of Soviet foreign policy.

WITH the disappearance of alarm clocks from drug stores, early-risers have adopted many expedients -- one of the most ingenious being the purchase of antique and near-antique clocks which have alarm attachments. Many nineteenth-century French examples, which can be put into efficient working order, are now rousing busy war workers who have spent from $10 to $40 for them.

MANY people, even many who are deeply interested in art, think of the field of prints as a very limited one, a matter of specialization. In reality, the scope of prints is extraordinarily wide and has strong points of interest not only for the print lover but also for the lover of art in general, and even for the great public not so strongly interested in art.

At the annual opera benefit of the Smith College Club on the evening of Jan. 7 Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct the performance of "Tristan und Isolde," instead of Bruno Walter, as previously announced. Helen Traubel and Lauritz Melchior will have the leading roles.

A further step toward governmental control of all United States exports of synthetic textiles to Latin America will become effective in 1944 when, for the first time, domestic producers of spun rayon yarn and of staple fiber win be directed to divert part of their current civilian output to "good neighbor" countries previously served by Japan and Germany, it was reported yesterday by rayon suppliers.

The French governmental center in Algiers, over which General de Gaulle presides, is different today from what it was in the early autumn. By the side of the Committee of National Liberation a miniature parliament is at work. The committee was reconstructed in the first week of November so as to be in harmony with that miniature parliament which goes by the name of Consultative Assembly.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- President Roosevelt spent a quiet stay-at-home Christmas surrounded by members of his family in the house overlooking the Hudson River.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- The first detailed draft of a plan for the establishment of an international court to try Adolf Hitler and other war criminals is likely to be submitted early next year to the United Nations commission investigating war crimes, it was learned today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Bonnie Lee Laba, who is just 2, and her 4-year-old brother, Robert, were happy today. Santa Claus came, and their father, Adam, was sitting beside them looking on.

When Fritz Kreisler appears in a violin recital at the Metropolitan Opera House on the night of Jan. 11 the occasion will be one of importance to society, music and philanthropic circles. Mr. Kreisler is contributing his services as a means to initiate the Salvation Army's 1944 drive.
Mr. and Mrs. James Farley will give a reception for their daughter, Miss Ann Farley, on the afternoon of Jan. 5 in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 -- Although some incongruous evidence could be cited, it appeared reasonable today to expect that the Securities and Exchange Commission would uphold the view that its "bundle of rights" theory under the Public Utility Holding Company Act included indebtedness.

LONDON, DEC. 10 (Delayed). SIR ALEXANDER KORDA, who was to have opened up M-G-M's new British production drive a month ago, is now all set to start operations early in the new year. Wesley Ruggles is coming over from Hollywood to direct the first picture.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: The Christmas tree won't dry out or lose its needles so quickly if the holder is kept filled with water .... Don't forget to add water to those bulbs that are being forced in a cool, dark place. A few narcissus and Roman hyacinth bulbs, placed in a bowl of fiber or pebbles and water during the next ten days, will develop more quickly than those started in November.

Christmas brought to Madison Square Garden last night a pair of astounding upsets, the equal of which never had been witnessed in the 10-year college basketball history of the arena. Long Island University, previously unbeaten, fell before the University of Havana, the slickest ball-handling quintet seen here in many a year, 40 -- 37, after the Western Kentucky team had succumbed to Brooklyn College, 36 -- 35.

HERE is a beautifully illustrated book about the leaf-fringed legends which haunt the Great Smokies and the Blue Ridge -- about their history and geology and trees and flowers and their running brooks -- about the unspoiled people whose story continues as inspiring with Cordell Hull and Alvin York, as it was with Daniel Boone and the long-hunters.
I have just finished reading the article "Why Brooklyn Is That Way" by Betty Smith, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of December 12 and hasten to correct several erroneous generalities.
HAS anyone fed the chickens? This is becoming a constant question in the households that have added a little poultry-keeping to Victory gardening.

Although home-run laurels eluded him, Stan Musial, brilliant young outfielder of the Cardinals, literally stalked off with practically all the remaining batting honors in the National League last Summer, according to the official averages released for publication today.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Dec. 26 -- In new blows struck in the battle for New Britain Allied air might has battered a Rabaul airdrome while downing thirty defending Japanese planes, has sunk a troop-laden ship near the Arawe invasion beachhead and has raised the bomb tonnage poured on Cape Gloucester this month past 3,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO political action committee, has sent identical telegrams to Frank Walker, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Harrison Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, urging them to issue statements in support of legislation for a Federal ballot for the armed services.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Only now, two years after the grim events, details of the "Christmas party" the Germans gave 15,000 Jews of Kharkov are becoming available.

Wounded veterans of this war and of the last were not forgotten yesterday. Into the largest hospitals and the smallest sick bays poured gifts of appreciative friends to those whose fighting days have ended.

NICARAGUA, says a Spanish inscription on stamps received from Managua last week, "is confident of the triumph of democracy." A large "V" and "Victoria" are in red at the base, and centered under Nicaragua's coat-of-arms is the terrestrial globe surmounted by the flags of the United Nations.

Barring a major catastrophe in the closing days of the year, fatal accidents for 1943 will be fewer than in 1942, statisticians for the Metropolitan Life Insurance said yesterday in making public the results of a nation-wide survey.

BERMUDA is a lovely place but poor foraging ground for animals in wartime when food-laden ships are few and far between. That was the problem facing Eric, son of a British naval officer, and his collored helper and friend, eager, conscientious Stone.

With the hope of strengthening their hold on the play-off berth in the National Hockey League race, the Black Hawks will tackle the Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Hawks, successful against the Blue Shirts in all their clashes thus far this season, are resolved to keep their string intact and send the local outfit deeper into the cellar.

Prof. F.A. Harper recently told the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition that the economic level of living in the United States, for both food and non-food items, fails to show the effect of any wartime sacrifice. In fact, the upward trend that started from the low point of the depression during the Thirties has continued.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Construction has started on two of the Navy's 45,000-ton super-aircraft carriers which will carry twin-engined bombers as part of their regular plane complement, it was learned tonight.

The organization of a Bronx committee to direct a blood donor campaign in that borough was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Jose Antonio Arze, leader of the Bolivian Leftist revolutionary party, yesterday cabled Vice President Henry Wallace and Secretary of State Cordell Hull denying a report that he was associated with the new Bolivian Government.

I should like to comment upon certain remarks in Robert Moses' article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine. [Mr. Moses said: "I never warmed up to the Four Freedoms which according to a New Yorker 'Profile' of my friend Grover Whalen were always referred to by that gorgeous impresario as if they were the four Marx Brothers."]

Under the direction of Capt. A.F. Krueger, who used to be a professor at Stanford University's medical school before he joined the Navy, experiments were conducted with twenty-six powerful agents in the hope of discovering something that would be effective in cases of influenza.

IF there were extra toys under yesterday's tree -- doll dishes, cars for a train, a puzzle, or beads to string -- the children might like to choose some to put away as special playthings for times when they have to stay in bed. And if this seems to be borrowing trouble, on the day after Christmas, we hasten to add that a pediatrician first gave us the idea.
The spotlight of public attention and interest was recently turned on our courts and judiciary.

The whole moot question of war guilt has been precipitated by the recent Russian atrocity convictions and the earlier shooting of the captured Tokyo bombers by the Japanese. The time has come to place the right definition on war guilt and provide appropriate action to punish its incidence.

After a week of comparative quiet occasioned by the annual pre-holiday rest period, college basketball will resume big-time operations in these parts this week when three double-headers, involving some of the nation's most promising quintets, are staged at Madison Square Garden.

A comprehensive rehabilitation program, designed to give honorably discharged service men an opportunity to assume essential responsibilities on the home front and to aid physically handicapped veterans to take part in the normal activity of civilian life, has brought hundreds of World War II veterans into important positions with the Todd Shipyards Corporation, according to a statement released here yesterday by John D. Reilly, president of the company.

Eyewitness accounts of the fighting in Italy leave one with a sense of surprise not that we are advancing so slowly but that we are advancing at all. It seems impossible that human beings could struggle up these frozen peaks against a wall of fire and still survive.

CHANGTEH, China, Dec. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- This once peaceful city of 160,000 persons today is a mass of twisted and shattered wreckage. Piles of ashes mark the places where the Japanese burned their dead and freshly turned graves hold the Chinese soldiers who fell during the twenty-day battle for the city, the most frightful struggle of the entire Chinese-Japanese war.

Last spring Maxwell Anderson left Broadway far behind to tour the battlefields of North Africa. His play "The Eve of St. Mark" had been called by the critics the best drama about the war, but he wasn't satisfied with it. He wanted to see war first-hand and write a play that truly reflected it.

A kitchen worker who discovered the fire Friday in the lodging house at 439 West Forty-second Street, but told a bartender about it instead of promptly turning in the alarm was partly responsible for the heavy death toll, Fire Marshal Thomas Brophy said yesterday.

In these words President Roosevelt last week revealed the name of the man who will direct the long-awaited assault upon Adolf Hitler's Continental fortress from the west. The announcement came in a Christmas Eve message to the nation and its armed forces, a message that spoke of great blows to come and was filled with assurance of the results, a message that spoke of enduring peace.

Seven persons lost their lives yesterday in the metropolitan area in automobile accidents, with five of them, including an infant, being killed early yesterday morning when an automobile was struck by a Long Island Railroad train near Northport.

THE current production of "The Family Carnovsky," by I.J. Singer, which marks the Silver Jubilee of the Yiddish Art Theatre, is the first play of Jewish life under Hitlerism. To be sure, there were many plays both on the stage and on the screen dramatizing assorted Nazi atrocities inside and outside Germany.

MIAMI, Fla. -- The annual football game in the Orange Bowl on New Year's Day is an event of steadily mounting interest, and a record throng is here for the manifold activities associated with it. Reservations indicate that the armed forces in Greater Miami win be represented by greater numbers of officers and their families than last year.

Now that Berlin makes the flesh creep with talk of lethal super-rockets, we phone Professor Ensykle and ask him to comment on the subject. He replies that he is prostrated by the flu. He adds that he is happy to know that the Gerbads have it too, dab theb. . . .
Hunting tales, tall and otherwise:

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 25 -- A comprehensive edition of the works and letters of Thomas Jefferson, which will make available for the first time an accurate, scholarly and complete presentation of the writings of the great political philosopher, will be published by Princeton University as a memorial to Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1896 until his death in 1935.

United States soldiers in Australia have found the slang expressions of their Allies a bit hard to interpret at times. Picture the difficulty that might arise between a husky Aussie and a Yank commando if, during the course of a barroom argument, the native said, "You certainly spill a lot of dinkum oil, bloke."

From its inception the Renegotiation Act was not intended to be, or to operate as, a revenue law. Nevertheless, in effect, it is a revenue measure, in spite of the fact that proceeds from its operation "shall be covered into the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts," and not as Government revenues.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Russia is one of the strangest places in the world to celebrate Christmas because the setting is perfect, yet Dec. 25 means nothing to the Russians. The Russian Church still observes the old calendar holiday l on Jan. 7.

It becomes increasingly clear that the Russian campaign has strained Germany's manpower and material resources to the utmost. In the earlier stages of the war, when they were advancing, the German armies were forced to repair the roads and railroads, with all of their bridges, destroyed by the retreating Russians.

THE big event of the season thus far is tonight's performance by Martha Graham and her company at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. Not only will this be the first performance by anyone this season in the native idiom, that is, in the so-called modern dance, but it will be the first appearance of Miss Graham in two seasons.

AT informal parties during the holiday season -- when people just drop in and no meal is served -- drinks, alcoholic or other, hold the center of the stage. With many of these some sort of food is indicated, for which some recipes follow.
An unusually heavy influx of buyers is expected after the first of the year, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- After five weeks' absence at the Cairo and Teheran conferences, President Roosevelt has been at home nine days. He has dealt with one major issue, the threatened railroad strike, which is still unsettled, and has made a Christmas report by radio to the nation and the armed forces abroad upon his meetings with Stalin, Chiang Kaishek and Churchill upon the progress of the war and plans for future offensives.

All military and civilian defense agencies along the Atlantic Coast were alerted on Christmas Eve, the Eastern Defense Command announced last night in a terse statement that said the protective measures were taken "upon receipt of a report that a sneak air attack might be attempted by the enemy on Christmas Day."

ALGIERS, Dec. 25 -- Under a big red paper bell in the "day room" of the Wac barracks here a 10-year-old French orphan made a speech in English tonight that symbolized the spirit of Christmas in Algiers as well as or better than anything.

During World War I, mounting military requirements brought serious congestion of traffic on railways, then as now the nation's basic means of transportation. To break the jam President Woodrow Wilson used his war powers. Twenty-six years ago today he issued a proclamation that put railroads under Federal control.

An unexpected rush of customers in uniforms clogged circuits over the country yesterday as a new holiday record for long-distance telephone calls was set. The calls recorded between midnight and 5 P.M. yesterday were 55.7 per cent higher than last year.

The well-meant efforts of Miss Betty Smith to explain "why Brooklyn is like that" is handicapped by the obstinate fact that Miss Smith hails from Brooklyn. No Brooklynite knows why Brooklyn is like that.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 -- (AP) -- The final score in the New Year's Day Rose Bowl football game, Coach Ralph (Pest) Welch intimates, will be 0 to 0.

TRAVEL bureaus are finding that the urge to go somewhere is creeping up on many of their old clients. Patriotic citizens who for the past two years have felt it their duty to forego holidays are once more considering the possibility of a winter vacation.

The wind, breath of the passing year, keens through the treetops and moans in the chimney's throat, and in the winter sky it sends the low clouds scudding. It is a snow wind, an ice wind, a wind that bows the birches and creaks the oaks and strips the last few shriveled leaves from the beech and the ironwood.

The climactic stage of the war in Europe has led the leaders of the United Nations wisely to begin planning the care of those territories now occupied and devastated by the Nazis. The UNRRA conference held in this country has been to some extent overshadowed by the series of conferences held in Moscow, Cairo and Teheran.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- One of the fascinating enigmas on the eve of the opening of the "political season" is the position of Gen. Douglas MacArthur in regard to the Republican Presidential nomination. The primary question is whether he is or is not a candidate.

THE disappearance of Tyler Bunnell brings County Detective Jim O'Neill to Parkerton, where he soon discovers that he has a murder case on his hands. Evidence is hard to come by until two other persons are killed and the weapon is found. Even after the ownership of the gun is established O'Neill is not satisfied.

THERE are doubtless quite a few people who already have lists of post-war travel priorities. Some are simply keeping on hand their pre-war preferences, planning to tick them off as soon as may be, Others have had their interest awakened by the far-off battles of this war and will want to see the veritable Solomons.

NO boards will go up over train gates in Pennsylvania Station this season bearing such famed names as Florida Special, Orange Blossom Special, Miamian and Vacationer. For at least one more winter, travelers will find greatly reduced train accommodations to Florida.

BACK in the fabulous golden Nineties, when the old Emperor Franz Josef ruled over Austrian Poland, a young poet came to Warsaw. He came from the Tatra Mountains and his songs were strange, not precisely cut and shaped to conventional French verse forms, as was considered proper in one who would call himself a poet.

IN "Gunners Get Glory" Lieut. Bob Berry, who went into the Navy straight from North Dakota, tells the story of the handful of Navy men who go aboard merchant ships to man the anti-sub and anti-aircraft guns.

GWEN BRISTOW -- hitherto solely identified with old Louisiana -- has turned her back firmly on costume romance and has written a modern problem novel for a change. Its setting is Hollywood, which may be misleading, for "Tomorrow Is Forever" takes its background very casually and can hardly be classed, thank heaven, as a story of the movie colony.

PROFIT is the means of assuring maximum exchange of goods and services, and people cannot live in modern society without it. The concept of profit is virtually ageless. Every time a trade is made, even in the absence of currency, there is a profit -- perhaps only a mental profit.

TORONTO, Dec. 25 -- The New York Rangers, outscored, 28 -- 12, in losing four previous National Hockey League contests against Toronto this season, exacted partial revenge tonight by defeating the Maple Leafs, 5 -- 3, for their third victory of the current campaign.

TO you parents, seekers of suitable theatrical fare with a moral especially during the Christmas season, we present M. and Mrs. Gilbert Josephson, the Yuletide impresari of marionette and puppet shows. Right now, the Josephsons are presenting an enthralling cycle of the "Suzari Marionettes in a Xmas Puppet Parade" at their World Theatre, 153 West Forty-ninth Street.

WHEN the Friday performances are over -- at increased prices, of course -- Broadway will lower the curtain for a few moments to denote the passing of a year. It will go out into the streets and blow a horn, like everyone else, and, like everyone else, will wake up feeling not very well in time for the first matinee of 1944.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- The Royal Air Force has dropped 110,000 tons of bombs on Germany in the last seven months, the Air Ministry announced today as bad weather grounded both Allied and German air forces to create an unofficial Christmas aerial truce.

ARTURO TOSCANINI, who will direct without fee the final concert of the series of the Philadelphia Orchestra Pension Foundation given for its membership, has canceled all American and overseas engagements except the six concerts for the NBC Symphony Orchestra and one for the Red Cross.

PRIMARILY this is the story of a man who has lost all memory of certain events in his life and of a girl who helps him restore that memory, although Orson Welles deserves an assist on that score. It is also the story of a murder mystery that is not solved until the past is laid bare.

The current surplus of pork, which is likely to increase the popularity of the pig as a New Year's dish, will be followed within two months by a pork shortage, according to warnings last night in the meat industry.
MONTREAL, Dec. 2 5 -- (AP) -- Montreal's Canadiens celebrated Christmas by turning back the virtually defenseless Black Hawks, 5 -- 1, tonight.

Sometimes one laughs in spite of himself at the downright childishness of some minds in Hollywood. The other evening I went to see "Watch on the Rhine" and found I had to sit through a "Chatterbox" feature of Joe E. Brown and Judy Canova.

THIS is not a second or revised edition of what is almost without question the greatest single monument of American historical scholarship, long familiarly known and cited as the DAB. It is rather a reissue for a wider audience of the volumes that have proved their usefulness in countless ways.

In August of this year this writer in collaboration with Evelyn Simon Brand wrote an article on "The Lawyer and the Renegotiation of War Contracts," which appeared in The New York Law Journal.

IT is hard to conceive a more fitting exhibition for the holidays than the current showing of thirteen small Sienese and Florentine paintings of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, from the Maitland Griggs collection, at the Metropolitan Museum.

IN ancient times holly, along with ivy and mistletoe, served as a symbol of life surviving through the seemingly lifeless winter. It is easy to see why early pagans attached a mystic significance to evergreens amid a world that looked dead and forsaken.

" TELLTIME THE RABBIT," the new Crowell trick juvenile, written by their enterprising promotion man, Bill Hall, has had quite a pre-publication career. It is perhaps the first book in history that was thought up, written, advertised and manufactured by the same man.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Inter-American Committee for Political Defense published today the text of a message sent to the Foreign Secretaries of all American republics having declared war on or broken relations with the Axis.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Survivors of virtually an entire German army, shattered at Gorodok, northern outpost of Vitebsk, scattered through the forests and marshes of White Russia today with every man for himself in desperate efforts to escape Soviet ski patrols, Moscow dispatches reported.

ON the surface, this would seem to be another novel about the decay of the Virginian aristocracy. There is the 200-year-old plantation, Castiglione, that makes a traditional background for the story of Mrs. Cassatt and her children.

MR. BRANT has given us an excellent book. Generally sound and clear, though all too brief and somewhat plaintly written, it shows an unerring sense of the important and unflinching willingness to deal with difficult questions and reach definite conclusions, though always without dogmatism.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 25 -- Russia will never agree to the re-establishment of Poland within the 1921 boundaries, an unimpeachable source in a position to speak with authority said today.

In any winter, the Adriatic offers hazards to navigation. Chief of them is the bora, the northerly wind that whirls up boisterous squalls and blinding snow. Fishing boats and coastal steamers used to scurry for port when the bora blew. This winter, small boats in the Adriatic are facing both the bora and an extra hazard, from which escape is harder.

DR. VLEKKE has rendered a considerable service by his timely and stimulating book on the history of the Netherlands East Indies. It will show the reader how complex a problem these little known territories present -- and how different their development has been from what "general opinion" would like us to believe about this fascinating archipelago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- With negotiations for settlement of the railroad wage dispute adjourned for the Christmas week-end, Washington looked nevertheless for possible developments tomorrow on the return of union and carrier conferees for resumption of the talks. B.M. Jewell, chief negotiator for the fifteen non-operating unions, the 1,100,000 members of which are scheduled to strike Dec. 30, said after yesterday's conference that there might be some news Sunday night.
LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 26 (AP) -The Russian Saturday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Economic and financial rehabilitation of the Philippines is being planned now in preparation for the day when the Japanese are driven out, Secretary Ickes revealed tonight.

City Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins yesterday stressed the value during the current influenza epidemic of the lesson learned by hundreds of New York women in the home-nursing courses conducted by the borough chapters of the American Red Cross.

TODAY two of the finest triumphs of the florist's art -- the poinsettia and the cyclamen -- glow with lively health and beauty as they stand among the less animate gifts of the Christmas season. A month from now the poinsettia can still be a picture of crimson loveliness, while for twelve weeks the cyclamen may continue to open its multitude of buds.

CHRISTMAS business closed on the downtrend that was noted early in the month. While volume mounted as it usually does, sales barely held even with last year in the closing weeks of the gift-buying season. November furnished the real gains over 1942.
NEW work by Man Ray, Blumenfeld, George Platt Lynes and others will be placed, on exhibition at the Norlyst Gallery on Monday and will be shown through Jan. 15.

I WANT to tell Americans what I have seen. I recently spent some time at the front and I traveled a great deal over territory liberated from the Germans. I am trying to find comparisons which would convey the impression of a "desert zone." But I cannot think of any. I have seen destruction before, too.

The difficulty of locating specific short subjects at film theatres, touched upon in the article "Little Films With Big Ideas" in The Sunday TIMES of Dec. 5, suggests a need for breaking away from the stereotyped phrase employed in this regard by most picture houses in their screen trailers.

Fifteen boys between 14 and 16 years old spent their Christmas this year in cells of the City Prison -- the "New Tombs." They were boys awaiting trial or already sentenced at Children's Court and awaiting transfer to the overcrowded State Training School in Warwick, N.Y.

Plans for pooled buying by twelve independent retailer-owned wholesale grocery organizations operating under the project recently launched by the New York State Food Merchants Association, will be discussed at a meeting tomorrow of the individual managers of the group's cooperative units, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Harry L. Hopkins, aide to President Roosevelt, denied today that he had written a letter predicting that Wendell L. Willkie would be the next Republican Presidential nominee, this being interpreted by some persons as an attempt to "purge" Senator Tom Connally with Mr. Willkie's help.

N. Y., Dec. 25 -- The annual Westchester Cotillion, serving to introduce to society many young women of prominent families in the county, was given tonight as a gala Christmas party at the Apawamis Club here. Each of the girls was privileged to bring two escorts to the dance.

The food conference which was held at Hot Springs, Va., and the studies which have been made by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration have given us at least a rough picture of the problem of rehabilitating half - starved Europe. Though the immediate need must be met by sending abroad cereals, condensed and dried milks, meats and fats, much more than a transportation of surpluses is involved.

WAS Man o' War "The best hoss of them all"? Mr. Anderson, like Will Harbut, the famous horse's almost equally famous attendant, thinks so, and comes as near to proving a question of such relativity as is possible.

MANY American soldiers now stationed in Great Britain have expressed surprise that there are so few visual reminders of the fury of the German bombings of 1940-41. The reason is that in the months that have passed since Hitler abandoned his effort to win the war by breaking British civilian morale, nature and man have made much progress toward tidying up the wreckage.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "The Tales of Hoffmann" on Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Near East College Association. The funds realized will further the maintenance of the American colleges in the Near East which have been carrying on their educational programs without interruption in spite of war conditions.

New York's traditional hospitality to service men will be extended still further soon after the beginning of the new year, the American Women's Voluntary Service announced-yesterday. Visiting officers of the armed forces and their wives will have a place to "park" their young children.

Church celebrations of the birth of Christ yesterday brought with them remembrances of the absent, beloved members of families serving overseas and prayers for faith in God that will insure lasting peace.

Winter fighting reached new peaks of fury last week all along the Russian front. The struggle extended from the snow-covered forests of the Baltic region to the shores of the Black Sea. It followed the now familiar pattern of vast Russian attacks and major German counter-attacks.

The message from Bethlehem, "Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good-will toward men," came again to the world yesterday as it has on Christmas Day for nearly 2,000 years. It found, on this third year of war for Americans, a fervent response in the prayers of clergy and laity alike for a speedy victory over the forces of evil and oppression and for a just and enduring peace.

UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN CHINA, Dec. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- United States Liberator bombers, escorted by fighters, retaliated Thursday for a Japanese raid on a main base of the Fourteenth Air Force with a smashing attack on the White Cloud airdrome at Canton in south China.
IT is difficult in reading through (and looking at) "The Navy at War" not to compare it with "Marines at War," a recently published collection of paintings and drawings by Marine combat artists.

MISS JOSEPHINE PICARD is the most colorful character in this story of murder and general skulduggery in Oak City. She is neither young nor beautiful; awe-inspiring is the adjective that fits her best.

THIS is a new story by that strange, incalculable yarn-spinner who gave us "Wheels Over the Bridge." "Dirk's Dog Bello" and other tales. Meindert DeJong has a way of rooting his stories in the small homely things we know so well, yet infusing them with a high-tension vitality which adds up to miniature drama with a curious, dreamlike quality.

LONDON, Dee. 25 (AP) -- Germany poured fresh reinforcements into Yugoslavia today but Partisan forces continued to beat off all attacks in the Nazis' stalled sixth major offensive and scored successes of their own in counterattacks, an Army of Liberation communique said.

BACK in the Nineteen Hundreds, Dorothie Holland sang in the first Cole Porter operetta, "See America First." She appeared also with John Charles Thomas in "May-time," and worked on stage with Charles Dillingham and Billie Burke.

ADD another blessing to the "something-for-everyone" joviality of the current theatrical season. For the first time in some years a theatre by and for children is operating, and successfully, in New York -- if not actually on Broadway.

United Service Organizations, Red Cross and military authorities, aided by civilians, did their best yesterday and Friday night to relieve the nostaglia of military personnel in the training and reception camps near New York City. Traditional holiday dinners were served, with dances and parties for service men and women on and off the posts.

The Metropolitan Opera company celebrated Christmas with a triple bill in the evening, consisting of two popular masterpieces of the operatic repertoire. Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci," with the Polovetzian Dances from Borodin's opera "Prince Igor" between.

Advices reaching the offices of the American Kennel Club indicate that 1944 will be the most active in the kennel world since the United States entered the war if, indeed, it does not approach the high-water mark in the sport of breeding and showing of thoroughbred dogs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Women's place in the post-war world is far from settled. Government, industry and labor, however, are attempting to find answers to how many and what kind of jobs will be available for women after the war and the related problems of juvenile delinquency and declining birthrate.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Go-Gino, 4-year-old Dock Stable entry, won the $5,000 added Christmas Handicap over a muddy track at the Fair Grounds today.

THOMAS WALLER, known, without exaggeration, as "Fats," was one of the outstanding men of jazz. He was composer, pianist, organist and band leader, and to each capacity he brought abounding freshness and vitality. For "Fats" loved music, and it nourished him.

VARIOUS attempts have been made to streamline, speed up or otherwise alter the librettos of acknowledged operatic masterpieces, like "Carmen," in a way to conform to the manners and ideas of the modern age.

IT now looks as if Patricia Coleman and Nina Anton would be finished with the script of "No Haven" by the end of the month, at which time Gertrude Lawrence will read it and decide whether to accept Jed Harris' invitation to take the leading role.

LEARNING to tell time by the clock marks a milestone of independence in life. Here is a fool-proof and jovial aid to that achievement in the person of Telltime, a rabbit with one long ear and one short one. Although Telltime is not sensitive about his rakish appearance he is curious, and so, every hour on the hour, he asks his friends of barnyard, field and woods tile reason.

NINE poems of eloquent understanding form the backbone of this slim volume. Each of those nine is a "letter" to the people of one of the countries overrun and occupied by the Nazis, the people of France, of Czechoslovakia, of Norway, of Poland, of the Netherlands, of Belgium, of Greece, of Luxembourg and of Yugoslavia.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Britain tried hard to be merry today on its fifth wartime Christmas, but it tried so hard and failed so miserably that it seems even a little grimmer tonight than it did before.

IN a Swiss philatelic journal is illustrated a Hungarian twelve-filler stamp which brings the first postal portrait of Arthur Gorgei, who was one of the Magyar nation's illustrious warriors and statesmen in the nineteenth century.

An experiment in the use of French, German and Russian feature films to accustom language students to a wide variety of different accents and dialects is now under way in a group of Eastern universities where training in foreign languages is being given to service men under the Army Specialized Training Program.

By taking the investigation of alleged illegal expenditures by the Legislature out of the hands of John T. Delaney, the Democratic District Attorney of Albany County, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has entered a fight to a finish against the Albany Democratic machine, headed by Daniel P. O'Connell.

NAPLES, Dec. 23 (Delayed) -- Labor representatives of various parties met here today to draw up a program for a new syndical structure to replace the Fascist syndicates abolished by the Allied Military Government a few weeks ago.

OTTAWA, Dec. 25 -- During this Christmas week the Canadian troops attached to the Eighth Army in Italy have been doing some of the hardest fighting of that or any campaign. They were assigned to the task of clearing the Nazis out of the Adriatic coast town of Ortona, which is one of the anchors of the whole German defense line across the peninsula.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Rivals from way back, the Chicago Bears and Washington Redskins, two of professional football's most glamorous teams, are at "aim-fire" stage for tomorrow's game that will decide the National Football League championship for 1943.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Dec. 25 -- One person is dead, another missing and several are injured as a result of a $1,000,000 Boardwalk fire that destroyed three theatres, an amusement pier, two hotels, twenty-five stores and nine homes here today.

" INGRID BERGMAN is the realest thing in these diggings," said an ordinarily caustic Hollywood columnist The first time you see her you understand the reason for his description of her. She has brought into this capital of artificiality the simplicity and charm of her native Sweden. Unpainted fingernails, skin that doesn't look like icing on a cake, a natural manner, unpretentious clothes -- these usual things make her unusual among Hollywood stars.

OUT of this war will come eventually a record of service which will justify the fondest hopes and boasts of those who put their trust in dogs. Furthermore, as suggested in this story, the role of dogs in war will open up a new field for the utilization of hitherto unused canine intelligence, even though we had to learn a lesson from our enemies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Loans and purchases to facilitate increased war production of food, feed and fibres exceeded $3,500,000,000 in the 1943 fiscal year, compared with $1,600,000,000 in 1942, J.B. Hutson, president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, said today in a report to Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator.
A mother sending $5 "in joyful memory of our first boy," wrote to the Neediest Cases Fund on Christmas Eve:

THE Madison Square Garden Poultry Show, with competitions in chickens, pigeons, turkeys, geese, ducks, guinea pigs, rabbits and hares, will be held at Madison Square Garden from Thursday through Sunday, opening each day at 10 A.M. and closing at 10 P.M. (9 P.M. on the final evening).

Steel-makers in the post-war era will have little to fear from the competition of light metals and plastics, according to Dr. John M. Weiss of New York, industrial chemist, in a report to the American Chemical Society. Aluminum and magnesium, he said, have estimated annual capacity figures of 1,500,000 and 300,000 short tons, or a little less than 2 per cent of the projected annual steel capacity of 100,000,000 tons.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 25 -- Christmas Day work stoppages in steel plants, possibly the forerunner of a paralyzing strike involving a large part of the war-vital industry, today halted production of more than 70,000 workers in four States.

FOUR one-man shows and one group provided the other openings of the week preceding the holidays. One of these was the largest and perhaps most impressive exhibition yet put on by the veteran David Burliuk, whose more eccentric expressionist work has diminished with the passing of time.

THE New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, will reopen its courses for amateur and professional gardeners during the first week of 1944. Outdoor Flower Gardening is the subject to be taught in the two-year course in practical gardening, the class meeting on alternate Thursdays, beginning Jan. 6, at 8 P.M.
College football, which opened its season away back in August, comes to the end of the 1943 trail next Saturday with the annual Jan. 1 bowl extravaganzas.

The concordance of Hanukkah, the Jewish festival of lights, and Christmas should make for greater inter-religious cooperation and good will, rabbis declared in sermons yesterday. Hanukkah commemorates the liberation of Judea by the Maccabeans from the Syrian tyrant, Antiochus Epiphanes.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 25 -- Recent fierce interchanges on the Senate floor between Southern and Northern members have led to a revival of talk of splitting the Solid South in next year's Presidential election. Yet few practical politicians in this region feel that a split is in prospect, despite the undoubted hostility to the New Deal which exists in certain influential quarters below the Potomac.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 26 -- Soviet troops cut the Vitebsk-Polotsk Nazi supply highway, captured more than 200 communities, killed 2,000 Germans and took 600 prisoners yesterday in their drive toward Vitebsk, Moscow said early today, while Berlin announced the Red Army had struck with 150,000 men in a reopening of their Ukraine offensive west of Kiev.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- King George VI, carrying on the tradition started by his father, delivered a Christmas broadcast to the Empire today. It was a message of hope, sobered by the thought of trials and sacrifices lying ahead.

THEY SHALL INHERIT THE EARTH. By Otto Zoff. Translated by Anne Garrison. Introduction by Dorothy Canfield. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: The John Day Company. $3.By CATHERINE MACKENZIE WHAT have we done to the children of the world?"
DODGE CITY, Kan., Dec. 25 -- Salesmen of resources of Kansas will visit the industrial areas of the country next year to put the State in line for new industries.

Dr. S. Robinson and his associates of the Fatigue Laboratory at Harvard have been conducting experiments to find out how rapidly men who must fight in hot climates or work in hot industries can adapt themselves to high temperatures. It turned out that a short period will do.

President Roosevelt spoke for all the American people when he sent their hopes, their prayers and their blessings to the soldiers, sailors and marines on all fronts, and to those o the islands whose names we never knew till recently and in all sorts of far-off, out-of-the-way places.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 25 -- A record Christmas crowd of 11,840 turned out for Tropical Park's eight-race program today and set a new Yuletide wagering mark of $532,709.

ALMA is a pretty woman. When she went to work in that war plant last may, the handful of males scattered among the thousands of women workers smiled happily at her real pink cheeks, openly admired her strong but extremely feminine build. They kidded her about her silly snub nose until she blushed and then they made nice remarks about her blond, blond hair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- War has made aviation the country's leading business, an industry worth $20,000,000,000, employing 2,500,000 persons, according to the year-end review by Charles I. Stanton chief of the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

In his report on the North African campaign, Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, stated that more than ten portable pipelines, made of light steel so flexible it could be snaked around trees, were used to supply combat troops with liquids that varied from petroleum to water.

AS Deems Taylor points out in his foreword to this adventure in nostalgia, the moving picture is still in its infancy. After all, a half century is too short a span for a new art to come of age, even in America. But today, only the super-esthete can deny that the movie is an art form that is fumbling, however dimly, toward maturity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A high Government official, whose authority over the civil administration of the war program is very great, one day this week discussed with a group of reporters the President's concern and his own about domestic conditions fundamentally affecting the war.

WHEN the war ends, and the G.I.'s get together to talk over this and other campaigns, you can bet anything you want that the main subjects of conversation will be mud and fatigue, but, above all, that deadly, maddening, all-absorbing fatigue, to which mud contributes its share.

The new technique of skip-bombing was brought to success in the battle of the Bismarck Sea and in the Mediterranean. Skip-bombing is a cross between dive-bombing and shelling. Some the bomb is aimed to bounce on times the water and ricochet into a ship's side, and sometimes the bomb is dropped earlier so that it bounces, falls into the sea and strikes the target below the water line.

Nature-study enthusiasts, amateur astronomers and those who in these days of war production go early to work can enjoy the remarkable and unusual procession of morning stars visible these dark December mornings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The United States soldier has shown himself to be superior to German fighters on most counts, says Col. Albert S.J. Stovall of the cavalry, who has just returned from a six-month observation tour in the Mediterranean war theater for the Army ground forces.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 26 -- After testing several contract actors, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has chosen Van Johnson to portray Capt. Ted Lawson in the picturization of "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo." The film, to be produced by Sam Zimbalist and directed by Mervyn Le Roy, will go into production within the next three weeks.

Mrs. James Augustus Thomas of 540 Park Avenue and Homeside, White Plains, N.Y., gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Eleanor Lansing Thomas. The debutante, who was graduated from the Chapin School, is the daughter of the late Mr. Thomas.

The plan under which the city has been buying custom-slaughtered beef for use in its own institutions is "sound, prudent and legitimate" and devoid of black market features, according to a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, and made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Alternate cold and warm weather prevailed last week in the winter wheat belt which is regarded as rather unfavorable for the new crop. However, experts say that it is impossible to determine at this season whether there has been any damage.

Emphasis on the battlefronts inevitably shifts between East and West. An officer who travels regularly across the country describes the Mississippi as the dividing line between two states of mind. On the eastern side of the line people think first of the European war, he observes, while on the west their thoughts turn first to the fighting in the Pacific.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 26 -- A series of heavy blasts, roaring in from the sea, shook the South Jersey coast this morning, drawing thousands of residents in seashore resorts to the beaches in the expectation of witnessing a great naval battle.
Fred Apostoli, California fighter who formerly held the world middleweight title, is named the Boxer of the Year in the nineteenth annual rankings of The Ring, a boxing publication.

ALGIERS, Dec. 26 -- Many high officials of the French Committee of National Liberation and de Gaullists paid silent tribute today at the tomb of the young university student who assassinated Admiral Francois Darlan on Dec. 24, 1942.

NAPLES, Dec. 26 -- Art treasures, totaling more than 50,000 items, are being removed from Italian royal palaces in Naples and Caserta to specially prepared storage rooms for safekeeping against enemy action, Maj. Paul Gardner, chief of the AMG division of education and fine arts, announced today.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Continuing their aerial smashes against the Japanese in the mid-Pacific, Army and Navy Liberator bombers have probably sunk a small enemy transport and set installations afire in the Marshall Islands, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A possibility that the fifteen non-operating railroad unions would abandon plans to strike Thursday went unrealized today. Their spokesmen and those of the three operating brotherhoods which are scheduled to start a strike at the same time awaited President Roosevelt's return to the city.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The censorship of public information out of Britain for the past two years has in general been fair and even lenient. It has complied with the principle that in a democracy the people have a right to know all the facts that they need to know to form sound judgments and that would not be of material aid to the enemy.

DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Bruins moved into a tie with the Maple Leafs for the National Hockey League's second place by playing the Red Wings to a 4-4 tie tonight before 11,481. Boston twice came from behind and Don Gallinger's third-period goal produced the deadlock.

Last week the institute's Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.36, a rise of 0.6 per cent over the previous week's level of 111.65. The raw materials index rose 1.8 per cent as a result of price increases in apples, oranges, livestock and potatoes.

A sad task awaits some Red Cross worker some day next spring. At the request of a young Army captain now serving in the South Pacific, two rose bushes are to be planted on the grave of his mother, whose death occurred recently, one in behalf of himself and the other in behalf of his brother, a prisoner of war in Germany.

Herbert Matthews has heard a rather curious story from Moroccans fighting in Italy. A detachment of Germans sent a flock of sheep down a mountainside to explode the mines. The use of sheep for that purpose shows a characteristic savage humor. Then another flock of sheep comes down.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The time when the Allies will hurl their full weight into an invasion effort undoubtedly is closer now than ever before but there is no tendency here to consider it "imminent." Any impression that plans have been so far worked out that it is only a matter for assault troops to climb aboard boats would seem to be highly inaccurate.

A Manhattan property that was used some years ago by Thomas A. Edison for the demonstration and sale of phonographs and phonograph records has passed to new control with the sale by the inventor's widow of the five-story building at 10 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Eighth Street.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 25 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- United States soldiers and sailors watched enviously today as hundreds of American technicians stationed in Northern Ireland joined tens of thousands of Ulster war workers pouring across the border for a gay Christmas week-end in neutral Eire.
Probably few readers will agree with the bald proposition that the beginning of the Decline of Modern Civilization coincided with the general abandonment of the practice of eating pie for breakfast.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 26 -- That the Communist party is the dominating influence in the Partisan movement of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) is clearly indicated by a number of factors connected with the campaign.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The production peak has been passed in several important parts of the military supply program, the War Department reported today, although next year's deliveries are expected to exceed those of 1943 in dollar volume.

The entry of the United States in the war two years ago was observed yesterday afternoon by the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues with a Maccabean rally and massing of congregational service flags and colors in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street.

Increases in Federal debt since the United States entered the war have been accompanied by reductions in non-Federal debt, according to a report issued by the quarterly publication of the index of the New York Trust Company. In 1942, the first full year of American war participation, non-Federal debt fell 43,500,000,000 and preliminary figures, according to the report, show that 1943 will bring even a greater reduction.

Sterling Drug, Inc., will explain trade-marks and their significance in a series of twelve advertise-i ments to appear in drug-trade magazines. The insertions willi in January and col{tinue] begin monthly throughout 194.

Next week, the seventh of the Metropolitan Opera Association's Diamond Jubilee season, will feature a revival of Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" on Thursday night. Salvatore Baccaloni will sing the title role, Cesare Sodero will conduct, and the cast will have several singers who will appear in their roles for the first time at the Metropolitan.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Firemen were called out to extinguish a blaze that started anew today in the ruins of one of the thirty boardwalk buildings swept in a million-dollar fire yesterday. The flames were brought under control by the firemen within a few minutes after their arrival.

The New York Rovers handed the Philadelphia Falcons a 4-to-2 setback in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. In the preliminary game on the doubleheader program the Brooklyn Arma Torpedoes sank the Manhattan Arrows, 5 to 2, in a Metropolitan Amateur League fixture.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec. 26 -- Unprecedented weather conditions of the last two months have endangered the forest preserves of this area, according to Henry H. Tryon of the Black Rock Forest Experimental Station here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The latest tabulation of the Treasury Department's census of American-owned property in the six Axis countries shows a United States stake of $1,070,398,668, it was announced today. The amount, although certain to increase greatly as further reports are totaled, is far in excess of the estimated $450,000,000 value of all known Axis assets here.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- President Roosevelt urged steel workers and their employers tonight "to continue the uninterrupted production of steel and steel products under the terms and conditions of their old contracts until the differences that now separate them are peacefully and finally resolved."

The first performance of Charles Kingsford's Cantata, "We'll Answer -- Stalingrad," was presented yesterday afternoon at a reception and musicale given by the American-Russian Cultural Association at 200 West Fifty-seventh Street. The work, "dedicated to the heroic peoples of the U.S.S.R.," was arranged for vocal quartet and piano by the composer for this occasion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Placing of ceiling prices on oats and barley early this month has resulted in curtailing the movement to such an extent that in many areas there is now little grain available for sale, especially for shipment.

" A Lady Comes Home," co- starring Ruth Chatterton, Ralph Forbes and Frank Conroy, is officially slated to open at the Playhouse on Tuesday night, Jan. 4. Margaret Bannerman, who appeared in the Pittsburgh and Philadelphia tryouts, has withdrawn from the cast.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The death of the Scharnhorst in Arctic waters today reduced Germany's naval strength to a new low, almost to the vanishing point in military effectiveness. Admiral Sir William James, chief of British Naval Information, in an October recapitulation following the damaging of the Tirpitz said:

The city's response to the official alert issued by the Army on Friday was so complete, Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday, that the key men of the civilian protective agencies were ready at any time on Christmas Day to mobilize on short notice the entire army of nearly 400,000 men and women under their command.
Two City College players triumphed in the first round of the tournament for the individual championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League at the Marshall Club yesterday.

ALGIERS, Dec. 26 -- There was no Christmas lull for the Allied troops fighting in Italy. While the Eighth Army engaged in still another day of house-to-house fighting in battered Ortona, the Fifth Army stabbed forward in two local attacks, one of which won the important height of Mount Sammucro, north of San Pietro Infine and two miles east and slightly south of San Vittore.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, in its operating statement, to be mailed to stockholders today, reports net sales of $49,617,387 for the quarter ended with October, an increase of 15.2 per cent over the $43,081,495 volume for the corresponding three months of last year.
