In line with the custom of the season -- that of recollecting the outstanding events of the vanishing year -- the writer reviews some of the more interesting foods that were mentioned in this column in the last twelve months. All are still available, of course.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 26 -- The appointment of General Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, who has been head of the British Tenth Army in the Middle East, to the supreme Allied command in the Mediterranean in succession to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was considered here today as a clear indication of increasing Allied interest in the Balkans.

The American Jewish Conference, 521 Fifth Avenue, urged yesterday intensified efforts to rescue the Jews of Europe and criticized Assistant Secretary of State Breckinridge Long's report to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs on rescue measures taken since the discussions in Bermuda.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- One out of every three persons in the nation's capital, Alaska, Nevada and Connecticut filed Federal income tax returns last year on 1941 earnings, while the national average was one out of five.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Chairman Ramspeck of the House Civil Service Committee predicted tonight that the continuing economy trend in Federal Government would see close to 400,000 workers trimmed from the payroll in a few months.

HENRY PONSONBY was a British officer and gentleman who lived a useful and distinguished life in the last century, much Of it devoted to one of the most peculiar jobs ever assigned to mortal man. "His job was Queen Victoria." Maj. Gen. Sir Henry Frederick Ponsonby came from an indigo-blooded family of aristocrats who had settled in Ireland in the time of Cromwell.

Four changes in existing legislation, designed to make more effective the safeguards against sex crimes, were recommended yesterday in the report of Mayor La Guardia's Committee on Sex Offenses. The committee, headed by William R. Bayes, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, was appointed in 1938, as the result of public concern over the killing of three children in the Bronx in 1937 by sex perverts.

A warning that the fundamental principles that are at stake in this war "must not be overturned or destroyed while the war itself is being won" was advanced by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in his annual report, made public yesterday.

Narrow price movements in securities and commodities featured the pre-holiday markets last week. In addition to being influenced by the seasonal lull customarily expected at this time of year, security markets were also under the spell of day-to-day developments in the railroad labor dispute.
Although they were pressed right down to the wire, the Rangers managed to overcome the Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 27 -- Russia's First Ukranian Army has rolled back German troops twenty-five miles on a fifty-mile front in the Kiev bulge, killing 15,000 of them and routing ten enemy divisions fighting to hold the approaches to Zhitomir on the road to Poland, a Moscow communique disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- There were cheers -- laud, raucous, merry -- in the Chicago Bears' dressing room after their 41-21 victory today over the Washington Redskins for the National Football League championship but there were angry remarks, too, by the Bear bosses who suddenly discovered in the tense moments at the end of the first half that George Marshall, Redskins' owner, was sitting on their bench.

PITTSBURGH, Monday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- With more than 100,000 workers reported idle a crisis loomed in a great part of the nation's steel industry today despite a Presidential appeal for peaceful settlement of a wage controversy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace tonight forecast the destruction of Germany's war might within "a few months" after the cross-Channel invasion of Europe.

IN outward appearance he was stern and forbidding. Inwardly he had the soft sentimentality of a child. The true nature of Major Frank W. Cavanaugh, the grim-visaged Iron Major, was best revealed in the beautiful and touching letter he wrote from a French battlefield to his 10-year-old son at Christmas-time a quarter of a century ago.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Marine Maj. Gregory Boyington of Okanogan, Wash., shot down four Japanese Zeros in Friday's attack on Rabaul to bring his total of enemy planes destroyed to twenty-four, it was announced today.

Eight hundred thousand quarts of fresh vegetables were canned in the last six months at Camp La Guardia, the city's rehabilitation farm in Orange County, Welfare Commissioner Leo Arnstein announced yesterday. The work was done by homeless men recruited from the relief rolls and classified as unemployable.
Mayor La Guardia yesterday urged the savings banks of the State to perform a public service by getting the 1944 Legislature to permit them to enter the small loan business.

With the exception of a comparatively sharp decline on Tuesday, cotton prices held generally firm last week. At the close of trading on Friday, the active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines for the period of 4 to 11 points.

In his Christmas Eve speech President Roosevelt emphasized the determination of the United States, Great Britain and Russia to strip Germany of her military might and to give her no opportunity within the foreseeable future to regain that might. At the same time he also declared: "The United Nations have no intention to enslave the German people.

Despite recent indications from Washington that some consumer scarce goods again will be available in stores next year, a sampling of local manufacturers gives little hope that pots, pans, toasters and irons will be obtainable for many months. Factories are still too busy with guns and tanks, they say.

To meet post-war needs and opportunities, work is to be speeded on a great municipal airport at Idlewild in Queens. This site has many advantages. It is a very large area. Present plans call for the development of 3,276 acres, as compared with the 550 acres of La Guardia Field.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- The Yugoslav Partisans of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz], eluding German forces pouring across northern Yugoslavia, have again cut the Zagreb-Belgrade railway, a Partisan communique said today, and wiped out an enemy garrison at Goryani in western Slovenia in the same series of operations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The rescue of eighteen survivors of the Cuban freighter Libertad through the use of three Navy patrol airships and a surface vessel was disclosed by the Navy today.
The Greater New York City newspapers salvage committee yesterday called attention to the following ways in which collections of waste paper are made: ...

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26 -- The output of raw steel last week declined sharply to 92 per cent of rated capacity, off 6 1/2 points from the week before. Virtually all this decline resulted because some mills allowed as many employes as possible to observe Christmas Day at home.

The teachings of Jesus Christ are being disregarded every day by the love of the world for wealth, pride and position, Mgr. Walter P. Kellenberg, vice chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday in a St. Stephen's Day sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Martha Graham restored the dance to its status of a profound and creative art last night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre by giving the season its first serious performance in this medium. It was Miss Graham's first appearance hereabout in two seasons and the tremendous audience that turned out for her, in spite of the weather, was a brilliant one, containing notables from all the fields of art.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Dec. 27 -- Planes from a south Pacific carrier task force sank a Japanese destroyer and two large cargo vessels at Kavieng, New Ireland, Christmas morning, while in raids Friday and Saturday on Rabaul, New Britain, Allied fliers destroyed forty-one enemy planes. The attack on Kavieng was the first by carrier aircraft.

AKRON, Ohio, Dee. 26 (AP) -- The nation is about to enter 1944 with its rubber situation still an acute problem, Dr. R.P. Dinsmore, vice president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, in charge of research and development, said today.

American radio in 1943 maintained a "breath-taking" wartime pace and faces "a most promising field for post-war employment and opportunity," David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, said yesterday in his annual year-end review of the radio industry's achievements.

WITH AMERICAN INFANTRY BEYOND SAN PIETRO, Italy, Dec. 25 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Emulating George Washington in his crossing of the Delaware in 1776, an American patrol of sixteen men stole into the Germans' lines last night and, surprising them in the midst of a Christmas revel, killed or captured a large number of enemy troops.

The special feature of the concert given yesterday afternoon by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Howard Barlow, in Carnegie Hall, was the performance by Joseph Schuster, the orchestra's first 'cellist, of the Schubert-Cassado concerto in A major.

A series of recent statements have emphasized the claim that our country has passed the peak of war production, that output can be safely tapered off and that planning can now be directed to the rapid conversion of war industries to peacetime tasks.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 -- Except for a temporary dip of around a dollar a bale on Tuesday, when a large spot interest was reported to have liquidated, cotton futures were quieter and thinner last week on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

Freedom of the air and sea in the post-war era, so that goods and services can be exchanged throughout the world without international trade barriers, and so that the commercial and defensive interests of the United States can be properly safeguarded, was advocated yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Equal rights for British women in the matter of unemployment benefits is the next goal of Dr. Edith Clara Summers-kill, Member of Parliament and president of the Married Women's Association, who recently occupied the limelight by asking adoption of a bill to make the housewife an equal financial partner with the husband.

ALGIERS, Dec. 26 -- To all observers here, irrespective of bias, it seems clear that the United States Government must soon make a decision that is destined to affect, perhaps vitally, the future of France, our relations with France and our reputation in the world.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- One wartime annoyance, the steel penny, which has caused bitter complaints, will start on its way out this week when the Mint ceases its coinage.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 26 -- When Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in his new command of the Allied invasion forces launches his assault on the western bastions of Fortress Europe he will face not only German fighting troops, but Nazi units charged with systematic demolition as they withdraw.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The 26,000-ton German battleship Scharnhorst, which, with her sister ship the Gneisenau, escaped through the Strait of Dover in February, 1942, was sunk this evening off North Cape, Norway, after a battle with units of the British Home Fleet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Ten types of public works projects, topped by a national superhighway system, were recommended by the City Club of Chicago today to supplement private employment in providing jobs for an estimated 30,000,000 persons to be released from the Army, Navy and factories producing war material after the war is won.

" Joseph the Provider," the fourth and last volume of Thomas Mann's tetralogy, will be published by Knopf in April. The book tells the story of Joseph's rise to prominence as a statesman in Egypt, and of his restoration to his father, Jacob; of the migration to Egypt, and of Jacob's death.

Gifts from "a refugee from Italy," from one of the fortunate repatriates who returned on the Gripsholm, school children and other groups and many persons who hoped to help send "over the top" the fund in behalf of the most distressed men, women and children in the city known to eight leading private family welfare organizations, were received yesterday among 377 contributions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- December wheat contracts went off the blackboard on the Chicago Board of Trade on last Wednesday at what was not only the highest price of the season but also the peak since 1926. However, there were no untoward developments despite the unsettled domestic situation and the poor outlook for next year's winter grain crop.

The worst blow for Christianity in the post-war world would be for "others to steal its ethical thunder" while the church itself plays a "negative part," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared in the Riverside Church yesterday in one of several sermons from city pulpits on the challenge to the church in helping win the peace.

MADRID, Dec. 26 (Reuter) -- On Christmas Day, Generalissimo Francisco Franco reprieved 101 men under sentence of death. His decision was announced today by Eduardo Aunos, Minister of Justice, when he visited a political prison here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The National War Labor Board will meet at 10 A.M. tomorrow on the steel-strike situation, it was announced tonight after President Roosevelt had sent telegrams to Philip Murray, president of the Steel Workers Union, and to three major steel companies, asking a return to work and promising that any new agreements on wages would be retroactive.

ALGIERS, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The United States Forty-seventh light bombardment group, veterans of battles over Tunisia last Spring and the subsequent sieges of Pantelleria and Lampedusa and the invasions of Sicily and Italy, is preparing to celebrate Dec. 30 as the first anniversary of a complete squadron mission.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it would press for enactment by the State Legislature of a special program on the administration of justice, featuring a plan for the nomination of candidates for high judicial offices by the Governor.

The four-story building containing three stores and lofts on a plot 64 by 100 feet at 150-54 Lawrence Street, in Brooklyn, has been sold by the Irving Trust Company to Nathan Levine for cash over a mortgage of $55,000 for ten years at 3 per cent. It is assessed at $130,000 and was sold through Murray O. Handel, broker.

The Zurich daily Volksrecht in its issue of Sept. 27 publishes the newest battle song with which the Nazis try to inspire the German youth for the last, desperate fight. It is made obligatory in all schools throughout Germany and reveals both the conviction of the forthcoming Nazi doom and the savage resolve to have as many other peoples as possible share it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Paul Bunyan, that fabulous character who never met a problem, mental or physical, with which he was unable to cope, would be "stymied" by the new income tax forms, Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, said today.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Christmas and the nearness of the year-end completely blanketed stock exchange business last week. Year-end liquidation on a modest scale appeared, however, to have been completed and the markets displayed the firmest undercurrent.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Monday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Andrew G.L. McNaughton, who has commanded the Canadian Army in Britain for more than four years, has been forced by ill health to take a long rest, which will prevent hint front leading the Canadians in the invasion of western Europe, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Administration believes that the Democrats will get 70 per cent of the service vote in the 1944 election, and so plans a determined drive in Congress next month for legislation to provide Federal supervision of the absentee balloting.

There were very few buyers in the market last week, due to the holiday interlude, but many more are expected during the week of Jan. 10, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A Christmas lull in the air war over Europe continued through daylight today, with no operations by planes based in Britain reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Industrial production in the United States in November was 247 per cent of the 1935-39 average -- the same as in October and two points above September -- the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Coach Henry Frnka and his University of Tulsa forty-man football squad arrived early today, and after breakfast moved to Bay St. Louis, Miss., where the Golden Hurricane will complete preparations for its Sugar Bowl engagement with Georgia Tech in New Orleans on New Year's Day.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Kungan, one of the central China bases from which the Japanese launched last month's drive into the "rice bowl," fell to Chinese forces yesterday, the Chinese High Command announced today.
Col. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, USA, and Mrs. Whitney have arrived from Washington and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Taking the point lead in the afternoon dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Jack Sutphen, with his craft Rum Dum, wound up the winner of the first of the three winter series.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal diocese of New York, delivered the sermon yesterday morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He hailed the advent of the Christmas season as a conspicuous symbol of new hope and promise in a war-stricken world and the inspiration for strong, assertive leadership that would "call out the very best we ought to give" in the struggle for freedom and peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Petroleum Administrator Harold L. Ickes paid tribute tonight to the oil industry for its ingenuity in meeting the scarce metals crisis while constructing thirty-four major 100-octane aviation gasoline plants.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- The country's public libraries show a general decrease in the public's reading, but an improvement in reading taste, the American Library Association reported today in its annual survey. The study was based on reports from 110 libraries in big and little cities, towns and rural communities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's cost-of-living committee will need at least another month to be able to finish its survey, and there is reported to be a strong possibility that the members may submit a divided report.

On the complaint of a dozen tenants who declared that they had been without heat and service since Christmas morning, Magistrate Peter A. Abeles issued yesterday two summonses against the owners of an apartment house at 1075 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Boys and girls in cities have been able to get somewhat more schooling during the last fifty years than have their country cousins, the Census Bureau reported tonight, and the girls, wherever they are, have had more years of education than boys.

ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- Contributions to child-care centers receiving financial assistance from the State and the Federal Government and sponsored by local war councils, municipalities and boards of education are now deductible on income tax returns, according to recent decisions of the State Tax Commission and the United States Treasury Department.

As Emperor Hirohito told the Japanese Diet in an imperial rescript yesterday that "the war situation is most serious," the Tokyo radio reinforced the somber aspects of his declaration by telling the people that recent Allied operations in the South Pacific had brought the war into "the decisive stage in which the rise or fall of our nation will be decided."

NAPLES, Dec. 26 -- Epidemic typhus fever has made its appearance among the population of the city of Naples, it was announced this morning by Col. Edgar Hume, chief Allied Military Government officer of the Naples district, and as a result the city is being placed "off limits" temporarily to Fifth Army troops.

Our air assault on the Marshall Islands has now lasted considerably longer than that which preceded the occupation of the Gilberts. But it has not yet reached a pitch of intensity to suggest invasion. This indicates that Admiral Nimitz regards seizure of the Marshalls as a much more difficult operation and is taking full time to prepare for it.
I have been interested in the discussions on "What Is a Doughnut?" which have from time to time appeared in your pages, most recently in an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Dec. 12.

The letter from Mr. Bowles in your issue of Dec. 19 was interesting because of its omissions rather than because of the material contained therein. Since the letter was dated Dec. 16, Mr. Bowles must have been aware of your interesting editorials on Dec. 13 and 14 which were titled "OPA Vs. the Law."

On the subject of renegotiation, Judge Patterson, the Under-Secretary of War and the foremost advocate of the present law, gives an illustration of what the amendment would mean which proposes to renegotiate war contracts only after taxes have been computed.

Icy roads, rendered hazardous when rain froze on the surface, interrupted bus schedules and caused many traffic accidents, and the bad weather curtailed airplane flights as the post-Christmas exodus by railroad from New York reached a peak last night.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The city's net funded debt was reduced by $97,011,224 in the fiscal year ended June 30, and budget operations for the same period resulted in a surplus of $7,043,821, according to the annual report of Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, made public yesterday.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Dec. 27 (UP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Trading in cash corn has been at a virtual standstill for several weeks and the increase of 9 cents a bushel in the ceiling price early in the month failed to bring out the grain expected. In fact, brokers say, the recent movement has been so small that some industries have been forced to fall back on reserves of grain to continue capacity operations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Forced to stand idly by for four weeks awaiting election returns from the East, the Chicago Bears vent their pent-up fury on the Washington Redskins today when they won their sixth National Football League championship almost as easily as falling off a log.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Tobacco growers in the Connecticut River Valley, declared today that the country's cigar industry would be forced to suspend next year if "an official bottleneck" in cottonseed meal, which is used to fertilize the shade-grown crop, is not broken.

The Manhattan Theatre (formerly the Abbey) at Broadway and Fifty-first Street, which recently was acquired by the Brandt Brothers Theatre Circuit, will reopen this morning with a revival of "A Midsummer Night's Dream, the picturization of the Shakespeare classic produced by Warner Brothers and first released here in October, 1935.

Though "extremely grateful" to the Allies for their unstinting aid, leaders of the Unified Resistance Movement in France have warned their followers that they have no intention of allowing the French nation to become the "puppet satellite either materially or morally of any one or coalition of the three great Allied powers constituting that profane 'trinity' outlined by General Smuts," according to reports received here yesterday.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A back-to-work movement among Ohio's 81,000 idle steel workers was started tonight by district and local leaders of the union in compliance with telegrams from Philip Murray.
On Christmas Eve, a time for fun and joy, M.E. thought of the Neediest Cases, the men, women and children who are in greatest need of friendly help in this city. With her contribution she wrote:

The same kind of courage and determination displayed by Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright 4th as he led his troops on Bataan was demonstrated in action at sea by his son, Capt. Jonathan M. Wainwright 5th, who received yesterday the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal for his exploits in the Allied invasion of Italy.

From the fall of 1943 through the summer of 1944 it is expected that the civilian supply of fresh oranges will be larger than it was the preceding period. The number of grapefruit available will be almost imperceptibly less, while that of tangerines will be noticeably fewer.

In The American Scholar Professor Adelmann, the distinguished biologist and histologist of Cornell, gives to the public an address made before the Phi Beta Kappa Chapter. He says -- an excellent saying -- that both the humanistic and the natural sciences should be part of the heritage that the student ought "to enter into."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -Universal plans to star Deanna Durbin and Charles Boyer in "Strangers," a romantic melodrama which Samuel Hoffenstein and Betty Reinhardt are writing. The picture, set in the New York of thirty-five years ago, will be filmed next summer.
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (AP) -The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 -- S.I. Crew's Putitthere, running right back to his winning form of last week, took the featured Orlando purse today at Tropical Park as the Coral Gables track opened the eleventh day of its meeting by increasing purses to horsemen for the second time.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- Although Russia maintains diplomatic relations with Bulgaria, Pravda published today an outspoken article warning the Bulgarians that they had better break with Germany, cancel their war declarations against the United States and Britain and join the Yugoslav patriots in warring on the Germans.

With two important labor crises dominating the domestic scene -the walkout of steel workers and the threatened railroad strike -stocks fluctuated irregularly yesterday and closed mixed, with low-priced motor shares the feature, on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Lawyers Trust Company, which has total assets of more than $60,000,000, was admitted yesterday to membership in the New York Clearing House Association. The bank thus continues the membership of the former bank of the same name, which was a member from 1911 to 1933, when it withdrew on the occasion of the merger with the former County Trust Company.
A new sports poll, in which the voting qualification will be the purchase of a war bond, will be organized shortly by the Fourth War Loan Drive Sports Committee.

Despite the fact that Congressional sentiment is against the use of subsidies as a wartime stabilization device, there is still reason to hope that general price control, reinforced by high tax rates and the large flow of savings into Government bond purchases, will hold the price advance within much narrower limits than was the case during the last war, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27 -- Exports of raw silver to the United States will be resumed at the beginning of the second quarter of 1944, it was learned today from Mexican financial circles. As is known, exports of silver were suspended in May of this year and not one ounce of the metal has left the country since then.

Benjamin Parry, first assistant to Dr. James H. Kimball, who was in charge of the Weather Bureau's New York office until his death last Tuesday, has been appointed to succeed his late chief, it was announced yesterday by W.J. Moxon, regional director of the Weather Bureau.

While the outlook for increased supplies of many raw materials has brightened, tight packaging, shipping and labor conditions will make for continued rationing by manufacturers of important chain drug store merchandise next year. This was the consensus of a symposium on "what's in store for 1944," comprising the views of executives in the manufacturing and merchandising fields, forwarded yesterday to members by the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.

The full implications of New York City's desperate coal shortage became evident yesterday, when dealers reported their inability to supply coal covered by 300 applications for emergency deliveries certified by the Department of Health.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 27 -The Illinois Power Company pressed the Securities and Exchange Commission today for an exemption from the competitive bidding rule in connection with its proposed issue of $65,000,000 face amount of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds in order that the securities could be sold by Jan. 21, 1944.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 27 (AP) -A Southeast Asia Command communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -Government food and price officials disclosed today that tentative meat rationing plans for civilians for 1944 contemplated an average annual per capita consumption of 132 pounds, or about eleven pounds less than this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -Harry L. Hopkins said today that a letter signed with his name and predicting that Wendell L. Willkie would again be the Republican Presidential nominee was a forgery and that he had asked the FBI to investigate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- War weighs more heavily on British women now than in the days of the blitz, according to Miss M. Craig McGeachy, first secretary of the British Embassy, who has just returned from her annual visit to the United Kingdom.

Aimed to please the girl at home from college for the holiday was the breezy assemblage of daytime and evening clothes which Saks 34th Street presented to a customer audience yesterday in the Young Set Shop on the second floor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The following is the text of President Roosevelt's arbitration findings in the wage controversies of the locomotive engineers and the railway trainmen with railroad management:

The nation's railroads will have handled this year the greatest volume of freight and passenger traffic in their history, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, declares in his yearly review of operations. He placed freight traffic at 725,000,000,000 ton-miles, an increase of 14 per cent above that of 1942, the previous record year, and passenger traffic at 85,000,000,000 passenger-miles, an increase of 58 per cent above 1942.

The raw fur market was exceptionally active last week, with receipts of pelts even larger than usual for this period of the year, when they always reach a peak for the collecting season, according to the market report issued yesterday by the United Fur Brokers.

As a result of the loss of 40,000,000 tons of coal production through strikes, which has caused a consequent drop in benzol output and greatly reduced stocks of butyl alcohol due to a work stoppage at a Midwest chemical plant, January allocations of plastics for civilian end-uses are expected to be cut from the levels maintained during the last three months, molders and fabricators stated yesterday.

Fines of $2,500 each were assessed yesterday against two wholesale kosher poultry concerns and a thirty-day jail sentence was imposed on the president of one company by Federal Judge John W. Clancy. The defendants pleaded guilty to violating ceiling regulations of the Office of Price Administration.

ALGIERS, Dec. 27 -- The battle of Ortona still raged in the rain yesterday as Allied tanks gradually drove back the last German defenders block by block. Two and a half miles inland, Indian units of the British Eighth Army wrested the village of Villa Grande from the Germans.

The type of medical practice best calculated to meet the pot-war needs of the American people is a system of group practice, with hospitals serving as medical centers and maintained by a compulsory Federal Health Insurance Program, according to Dr. Ernst P. Boas, Assistant Professor of Clinical Medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University.

PEARL HARBOR, T.H., Dec. 27 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz presented the Presidential unit citation today to the Gudgeon, the sixth submarine to win this honor, and individually decorated six officers, including two former commanders of the Gudgeon and her former gunnery officer.

Premier Hideki Tojo, echoing Emperor Hirohito's grave appraisal of allied power, told the upper house of the Japanese Diet yesterday that the Allied "counter-offensive has become real and serious and fierce fighting is raging at various fronts."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Experts giving advice to supervisors of women workers in transportation listed a wide variety of basic differences between men and women, in a memorandum issued today by the Office of Defense Transportation. This memorandum is a fore-runner to a manual of specific suggestions for the transportation industry.

A program for the development of research and educational work bearing upon foods and restaurant management has been launched by the University of Chicago, through its Business Problems Bureau and the School of Business, in cooperation with the National Restaurant Association, it was announced yesterday by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the university.

What shall we do with the troublesome Balkans? Too long these naughty boys of Europe have been a menace to peace! Their deep-seated nationalisms breed war. "Perhaps only by luck," says C.L. Sulzberger, in your issue of Dec. 19, "World War II did not start in the Balkans."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice called on President Roosevelt today to enforce its orders for sixteen Southeastern railroads and seven unions to cease discrimination in the employment and promotion of Ne groes. Three of the unions and the carriers have defied the committee's authority to issue such orders.
Bids will be opened by Boston, Mass., on Dec. 28 on a new issue of $2,000,000 of temporary loan notes. The issue will be dated Dec. 31, 1943, and will be payable on Oct. 2, 1944.

Production of soft drinks for civilian consumption during 1943 averaged between 75 and 80 per cent of the 1941 level, after restrictions limiting it to 70 per cent of normal during the greater part of the year, according to a statement issued yesterday by John F. Leary, president of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, national association of the industry.

Holcombe Ward is named for re-election as president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association in the report of the nominating committee, included in the call issued yesterday for the sixty-third annual meeting of the association. The meeting will be held at the Hotel Vanderbilt Jan. 15.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Official preoccupation with the heating problem was evident here today as Government agencies sought to assure sufficient deliveries of heating oil and coal.

The Russian-sponsored Free Germany Committee said last night in a broadcast from Moscow that a German staff officer captured by the Russians had disclosed that Adolf Hitler had ordered "permanent mass murder" of Russians on a scale even more inclusive than that described at the recent Kharkov trial.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 27 (AP) -- British and American heavy bombers, flying as one team in huge formations, attacked Bangkok, capital of Thailand, Thursday night and set fires visible 100 miles away, the Southeast Asia Command announced today.

Their appetites whetted by last Saturday night's upsets, college basketball fans are expected to turn out in full force tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the holiday court carnival proceeds, with N.Y.U. meeting Pittsburgh and C.C.N.Y. opposing Arkansas in a twin bill, starting at 8:15 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -In other wars the wounded were brought back from the front to the surgeon. Now the United States is saving hundreds of soldiers' lives by sending topflight surgeons forward, often to operate within thirty minutes after the man is wounded.

Sol Rubinow and Sol Weinstock of City College were victors again yesterday in the tournament for the individual championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League at the Marshall Club and led the field with scores of 2 -- 0. Rubinow, the Lavender champion, quickly defeated Rhys Hays of Columbia, while Weinstock checkmated David Silverstein of Cooper Union.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Nazi threat to try American and British airmen as war criminals has made American crews "madder than ever," Lieut. John C. Morgan of Amarillo, Tex., and 325 East Fiftysecond Street, New York, winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor, told United States fliers at home in a broadcast today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Tedder, who furnished and directed the air warfare lightning that as much as any other single thing made possible Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's drive from El Alamein to Italy, was named deputy supreme commander, under Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, of the Allies' invasion force in an announcement issued today from l0 Downing Street.
ALGIERS, Dec. 27 -- A communique:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Hershey's Wally Kilrea still topped the American Hockey League scoring today with 37 points, two more than team-mate Gaston Gauthier, his closest rival, who last week drew closer to the lead by two points.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 27 -- Winding for 120 miles across mountainous sections of Yugoslavia freed by the People's Army of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) runs the only Partisan railway. It links Drvar with Jajce and Vakuv.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt ordered Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson at 6 P.M. today to take over all railroads in the continental United States at 7 P.M., despite assurances at 5 P.M. that the fifteen nonoperating unions were canceling their notices for a strike Dec. 30 and were ready to have him arbitrate the amount they were to receive for overtime pay.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh disclosed yesterday that he would declare a state of emergency in the Fire Department, effective at 12.01 A.M., Jan. 1, under which firemen will be required to work three extra eight-hour tours every twenty days and thus qualify for a $420 annual cost-of-living bonus.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Since Southern California never has lost a Rose Bowl game, the inspiration to repeat New Year's Day may be all with the Trojans, admits Paul Schwegler, one of Washington's all-time great tackles. Bur --

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -Hard-punching Phil Terranova of New York successfully defended his National Boxing Association featherweight title tonight with a sixth-round knockout over Jackie Callura of Ontario.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Commenting tonight on the Government's action in taking over the railroads, executives of the lines here expressed the view that the method used by President Roosevelt may be expected to work satisfactorily.

Advertising copy promoting drug products, which is designed primarily to aid the consumer in achieving good health, is far more successful than the type which aims at creating a fear complex in the minds of purchasers of these products, according to a survey of specific copy appeals by the advertising foundation of Seton Hall College.

Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy said yesterday that, after interviewing sixty-three persons in connection with the fire in the Standard Hotel, 439 West Forty-second Street, on Friday, he believed that the blaze, which took eighteen lives, was accidental.

John B. Turk, recently suspended chairman of the downtown Manhattan rationing board, an alleged go-between, and the president of the McGinnis Restaurant, Inc., 1589 Broadway, were accused yesterday of a conspiracy to tamper with Office of Price Administration records for the purpose of raising price-ceilings for the restaurant.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 81.3 per cent of capacity, against 93 per cent last week and 99.3 per cent two weeks ago, a decline of 11.7 points from last week and one of 18 points for two weeks, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 27 (UP) -- A special communique:

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -Russian troops, expanding their winter offensive on two fronts, smashed fourteen miles through the tottering German lines west of Kiev yesterday to move within eighteen miles of the Zhitomir railway junction, while in White Russia they tightened a siege arc around Vitebsk by cutting the Vitebsk-Polotsk railroad.

Interest in Scarsdale residences provided the important feature in the realty activity in Westchester County during Christmas week. The sale of three dwellings was announced by the brokerage firm of Prince Ripley. One was the house at 11 Campden Road, bought by Sarkies A. Gregory, a New York diamond merchant, from the Central Savings Bank.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- Brydon Taves, United Press manager in Australia, died yesterday as a result of a crash in a combat plane in New Guinea at dawn on Sunday, Allied headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -Text of President Roosevelt's executive order directing Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson to seize the nation's railroads:

The decision of President Roosevelt to take over the operation of the nation's railroads did not come as a surprise to the management of the railroads generally. Since the labor dispute became critical last summer, many railroad executives had expected the Federal Government to step in.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- American marines have pushed inland from their beachheads established in the invasion of Cape Gloucester, New Britain, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 27 -- The "interdependent character of the struggle of the Yugoslav Army under the command of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch and the Partisans" was emphasized today in a statement issued by the Yugoslav Government's information office, hitherto an ardent supporter of the Chetnik cause and an equally ardent opponent of Marshal Tito, indicating that a change in policy may be taking place in the emigre government, in which Gen. Mikhailovitch is War Minister.

Five men comprising the crew of Navy patrol plane were killed at 8 A. f. yesterday when the craft plunged into the water a half mile off shore in Sheepshead Bay. The crash occurred a mile and a half from Floyd Bennett Field, from which the plane had taken off a few minutes before on a routine operational flight.

Julius Schulman, violinist, gave a recital last night in Town Hall, playing so well that one marvels at such accomplishments being put to the service of so much bad or mediocre music. For Mr. Schulman's program, in great part, was weariness to the flesh not because of the performance but the music performed.

Orrea Pernel, English violinist, and Bruce Simonds, pianist, last night gave the second recital in a series of three at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The program was made up of Beethoven's Sonata in A major, Opus 30, No. 1; Honegger's First Violin Sonata in C-sharp minor, and Brahms' Sonata in D minor, Opus 108.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS QUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 27 -- United States Marines, many of them heroes of Guadalcanal, have landed at two points around Cape Gloucester, New Britain, and occupied Long Island, at the entrance to Vitiaz Strait, following a cruiser and destroyer bombardment and a blasting by 300 tons of aerial bombs.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The day after Christmas has become as much of a tradition as the night before. Yesterday was actually that day, for all practical purposes, as department stores will testify with a shudder and then a shrug of resignation.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt tried his best this Christmas to cheer up Prime Minister Churchill, who is convalescing from pneumonia in Africa. One hot sunny day, shortly before Christmas, Mr. Churchill received a large evergreen Christmas tree which had been sent from the United States tagged with Mr. Roosevelt's holiday greetings.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 27 -French circles here believe that the recent agreements arrived at by Gen. Georges Catroux and the Syrian and Lebanese Governments will reconcile Syrian demands for total independence with France's international obligations.

PITTSBURGH, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Back-to-work orders from union officials early today apparently signalled the sudden end of the steel walkout which threatened to imperil the nation's wartime production.

While indications are that 1944 will be welcomed by one of its "wettest" celebrations in many years despite the shortage of scotches, ryes and bourbons, it became known yesterday that more than one hundred of the city's better class restaurants were planning to close at 10 o'clock on New Year's Eve to conserve their limited liquor stocks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A liberal supply of hogs more than satisfied slaughter demands and 6,000 head were reported held over today at the close of the market, in which prices were steady to 25 cents lower. Fed steers and yearlings were strong to 25 cents higher in moderately active trade. Lambs were up 25 cents.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Partisans of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] broke through to the Zagreb area and destroyed a German air base at Velika-Goritza less than ten miles from the Croat capital, a National Army of Liberation communique reported today.

Everyone who has offered one of the new steel pennies for a dime, or even worse, received one in a similar exchange, will rejoice that these pesky things are on their way out. When the new year dawns the Mint will cease making them. Those that remain in circulation cannot last forever.

A letter in THE TIMES of yesterday laments the economic dilemma of 15,000,000 white-collar workers faced by rising prices and a static or diminishing income. This brings forcibly to notice the fact that an organized minority of our working people is profiteering at the expense of the unorganized majority.

Support of the city's five Borough Presidents for the scrap-paper drive was pledged yesterday at a meeting of the presidents or their representatives with the New York City Newspaper Publishers Committee in the Hotel McAlpin.

The successful landing by American Marines on both sides of Cape Gloucester in New Britain appears to have been a tactically perfect operation, planned, timed and executed with clocklike precision. Thirty-five hundred tons of bombs dropped on this area during the month must have warned the Japanese that an attack was coming.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 27 -Three generations of fliers in one family, 82, 41 and 18 years old, are to converge on the capital tomorrow, each piloting a plane.
I notice the publicity you gave in THE TIMES of Dec. 24 that there should be a different method of selecting Supreme Court Justices other than direct election by the people.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, said tonight he believed that President Roosevelt was "justified" in ordering Government seizure of the nation's railroads.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 27 -- The Board of Supervisors established boundary lines today for the four assembly districts to which Nassau County is entitled under the reapportionment act. But in so doing, it divided the town of Hempstead and thus contravened the constitutional restriction against dividing a town for assembly district purposes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTH PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Eighteen twin-engined Mitsubishi bombers unsuccessfully attacked the American carrier task force whose planes had bombed Kavieng, New Ireland, on Christmas morning, Admiral William F. Halsey's headquarters reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -Millions of radio listeners in this country will participate in more than a hundred home-front war campaigns during 1944, the Radio Bureau of the Office of War Information estimated today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Praise and congratulations showered today upon the Navy's Seabees, with President Roosevelt and their comrades in arms hailing these fighter-builders on the second anniversary of the creation of their first regiment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A special public utilities committee which will assemble information and recommend action concerning requirements, supplies and production of equipment necessary to re-establish electric, gas and water services in liberated and former enemy territories has been formed by the Combined Production and Resources Board, it was announced here today.

Gratification at the War Production Board's reshuffling of its controls over cotton textile output, to equalize among the industry's producers the drain on their essential civilian allotments forced by mounting foreign relief programs, was expressed yesterday by Worth Street suppliers.

In an extremely quiet post-holiday session, prices of cotton futures were sustained yesterday by a few local trade price-fixing orders, coupled with some rebuying by early sellers. Recovering as much as 55 cents a bale from the early lows, the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at near the best levels of the day and 2 to 5 points above last Friday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -Gen. Peyton C. March, Chief of Staff in the first World War, would not celebrate his birthday today because he is only 79, "not 80 or 90 or 100." He takes his birthdays by decades.
The newspaper panel of the War Labor Board in Chicago has given formal approval of a renewal agreement between The United Press and the American Newspaper Guild, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Gratification over the decision of Princeton University to publish, in cooperation with THE NEW YORK TIMES, the complete works of Thomas Jefferson was expressed today by Archibald MacLeish, librarian of Congress, and Senator Carter Glass, Democrat of Virginia, chairman of the Thomas Jefferson Bicentennial Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Living completely "up to our expectations during combat," and "responsible for the bulk of the extensive damage toll taken of enemy shipping," the Navy's newest bomber, the Curtiss Helldiver, went into action during the historic Armistice Day raid on Rabaul, the Navy Department made known today.
A Japanese communique, as broadcast yesterday from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today a regulation, effective Jan. 6, fixing processors' maximum prices on all domestic distilled spirits. OPA executives said that the regulation should result in sharp roll-backs in retail prices of some brands of domestic whisky.

Whatever you do don't destroy your Christmas wrappings! Harry A. Levy, chairman of the Salvage Committee of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, advises: "Fold all Christmas wrappings carefully.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The resignation of Henry A. Roemer as chairman and director of the Pittsburgh Steel Company was announced today.

Expressing hope that "in the after-war world justice may be done even within Germany to the victims of German aggression," Supreme Court Justice David W. Peck dismissed yesterday a suit in which two German expatriates sought to collect in this country the surrender value of life insurance policies written upon their lives in Germany by a Swiss company.

Mr. Archambault telephoned yesterday from Berne about internal conditions in France on the eve of the expected Allied invasion. He said: "Three elements within France have been preparing for the day when General Eisenhower's forces land."

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 27 -- Plans of Princeton University and THE NEW YORK TIMES to publish a comprehensive edition of the works and letters of Thomas Jefferson as a memorial to Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE TIMES from 1896 to 1935, were described today by Gov. Colgate W. Darden Jr. as 'just splendid." "
The Catholic Book Club, 140 East Forty-fifth Street, has chosen "The Captain Wears a Cross," by Capt. William A. Maguire, for its January selection. The book is published by Macmillan.

The final week of Christmas shopping here was marked by an increase in sales of 21 per cent over the like week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The increase was due chiefly to the fact that there were five shopping days last week against four in the comparative 1942 period.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Having come through this year with greater success than any of them even dared hope for, owners of franchises in the National Football League are already starting to lay plans for 1944.

Fingernails, according to the chemist for one of America's foremost manufacturers of manicure preparations, require more care at this season than at any other time of year. Chipping and splitting increase as cold weather makes the nails dry and brittle, and replacement by new growth is slower to appear.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Denouncing the Government's handling of major labor disputes along lines laid down recently by the Government itself, industry members of the War Labor Board contended unanimously tonight that a continuation of such a policy would eventually "destroy all honest collective bargaining at the source."

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- The resumption of the Russian advance in the Kiev region is the reward for the prolonged battle of the last two months in which a very powerful enemy group was gadually brought to its knees.

P.G. Johnson, president of Boeing Aircraft Company, announced in Seattle yesterday that production of Flying Fortresses by the company this year is 146 per cent higher than last year and constitutes a quantity "beyond the greatest hopes of two years ago."

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, has stated that he is not to be considered a Presidential candidate in the preferential primary in Illinois, it was disclosed today by Ben Berve, chairman of the Republican State Central Committee.

ABOARD A TASK FORCE FLAGSHIP OFF BUKA, Dec. 24 (AP) (Delayed) -- Fighting men of this veteran task force, spending their second Christmas far from home, sent holiday greetings to the enemy early, with twenty-five tons of exploding steel in a midnight bombardment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrest in Wilmington, Del., of Jacob Drucker, 38-year-old alleged member of the notorious Brooklyn murder ring, for three murders in New York City.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday placed its approval on the condition of Jake La Motta, Bronx middleweight, and Georgie Kochan, Akron, Ohio, boxer, and forthwith the prospective ring rivals repaired to Lou Stillman's gymnasium to complete hard training for their ten-round bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Keyed to the British Government's post-war policy of "export or die," Hilton Thorpe, manager of Marshal Field Co.'s European buying offices, came to Chicago today to study store operations and scan the outlook for peacetime.
Former Magistrate Leo Healy asked yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court the identity of "The Smiling Irishman of California."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -Following is the White House announcement of the Presidential order for seizure of the railroads:
In your issue of Dec. 16 you have an article by Arthur Krock with the heading "How Business Can Make Itself the Post-War Goat."

The Cessna Aircraft Company reported yesterday a net profit of $2,208,414, equal to $6.31 a share for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, against $738,202, or $2.11 a share, earned in the previous fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- With 170,000 workers remaining away from their posts at vital steel producing centers in seven States in the face of President Roosevelt's urgent appeal for continued uninterrupted production pending the writing of new contracts, the labor members of the National War Labor Board reversed an eight-to-four vote of the board of Dec. 22 which, in its effect, would have denied retroactive wage readjustments under the formula demanded by the unions.

Now it is the steel workers who "cannot work without a contract." It is the steel workers who will not "trespass" on the employers' property. Yet everyone knows that if the steel workers asked for it they could have an indefinite extension of the present contract in an instant.

Edward Phelan, director of the International Labor Organization, an arm of the League of Nations, declared yesterday that "considerable prosperity" rather than depression may be expected after the war in the United States and Canada. He said also that post-war unemployment in other countries was "not inevitable."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A program under which officers and men on active duty in the Navy will receive their pay precisely on pay day wherever they are even in wartime will be started soon after the New Year, the Navy Department announced today.

The Vatican radio tonight quoted Pope Pius XII as declaring that the aerial bombing of Vatican City on Nov. 5 had been "deliberately planned and dishonorably and unsuccessfully screened behind the anonymity of the pilot."

With "Doctors Disagree," opening at the Bijou tonight, Rose Franken will have two plays of her authorship, both of which she directed, on the boards. In case anyone has forgotten, the other one is "Outrageous Fortune." The sponsor of the two offerings is Miss Franken's husband, William Brown Meloney, which just gives you an idea how busy the Meloneys have been lately.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -- A combination of land power and air power, each directed by its own commander under a single plan of operation, is the key to success in warfare, Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery told British and empire air correspondents in a recent interview printed in the London press this morning.

More realism in reporting the "day-to-day grimness" of the war, rather than "scare predictions" about what is to come, was urged yesterday by E. Palmer Hoyt, head of the domestic branch of the Office of War Information and owner of The Portland Oregonian.

Now it is the steel workers who "cannot work without a contract." It is the steel workers who will not "trespass" on the employers' property. Yet everyone knows that if the steel workers asked for it they could have an indefinite extension of the present contract in an instant.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -- A combination of land power and air power, each directed by its own commander under a single plan of operation, is the key to success in warfare, Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery told British and empire air correspondents in a recent interview printed in the London press this morning.

More realism in reporting the "day-to-day grimness" of the war, rather than "scare predictions" about what is to come, was urged yesterday by E. Palmer Hoyt, head of the domestic branch of the Office of War Information and owner of The Portland Oregonian.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A decision concerning recognition of the revolutionary regime that has seized power in Bolivia was postponed today until American governments that have declared war on or have severed diplomatic relations with the Axis have consulted together.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Commission houses and mills were on the buying side of wheat futures today and prices were lifted as much as 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade at one time. The market was easily influenced, and lack of pressure rather than any large buying was responsible for the upturn, brokers said.

In his first public statement as newly appointed commander of the main Allied invasion of Europe General Eisenhower makes the flat and carefully considered prediction that "we will win the European war in 1944." Coming from General Eisenhower, that is a tremendous pronouncement which will send up a cheer in the Allied world.

HIS philosophy of life is simple -- never get excited. But to his perpetual dismay Dr. H.C. Carlson, the effervescent Pitt basketball coach for the past twenty-two seasons, always forgets to observe it. He explodes from the bench with the continuity of a string of Chinese firecrackers and then sits down abruptly to laugh at himself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P) -- Premier Josef Stalin was credited authoritatively today with forcing at the Teheran Conference a decision on a leader of the Allied expeditionary force for the "Second Front" invasion of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana warned today that the Administration would be "taking a tremendous gamble" if it allowed the proposed western European invasion force to be composed chiefly of United States Soldiers.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTH AFRICA, Dec. 27 -- Many soldiers in North Africa who, in normal years, would spend New Year's Day watching one of the football bowl games in the United States, may not have to forego that pleasure this year even though they are fighting a war, it was learned today.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 113 feet at 181-831 West 238th Street, the Bronx, has been resold by David S. Meister, operator, to a client of Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers in the deal, who have been appointed agents.

WITH U.S. MARINES ON NEW BRITAIN, Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- The thin line of green-clad men that has been creeping up the ridge of Target Hill has reached the top, planted a mortar and opened fire beyond. We can see this with our field glasses: It is noon and snipers' bullets are zinging near us, but we have taken the controlling hill.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The Anglo-American political warfare organization has been reorganized and will be centralized in London and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's assistants in this field will move here from Algiers, it was learned tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- In the Arctic Sea battle in which the German battleship Scharnhorst was sunk last evening the Allied convoy escorted by the British Home Fleet units that sent the Nazi vessel down, was untouched and only two British warships received "minor damage," the Admiralty announced tonight.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Issuance of 500,000 shares of common stock by the Rochester Telephone Corporation was approved today by the Public Service Commission, which said the issue will correct a security setup that has "virtually vested" control of the Corporation in one individual.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 -- Most of the more than 170,000 steel workers who had been idle since midnight on Friday returned to their jobs today with some of their leaders claiming victory in the first phase of the fight of the United Steel Workers, CIO, for a wage rise of 17 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Russia, although she came late into the field of lend-lease, has obtained more war planes and motor vehicles from the United States than have been exported to any other country under the Lend-Lease Act, according to a statement by Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator.

Reflecting uneasiness over domestic and military developments, as well as being influenced by reactions in grains and securities, the cotton futures market eased moderately yesterday from Monday's advance and at the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange the list of active contracts registered net losses of 4 to 6 points.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The policy of the Netherlands Government on the delicate subject of a post-war Atlantic bloc, as envisioned by Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts in his recent speech, was outlined tonight for the first time when Eelco N. van Kleffens, the Foreign Minister, broadcast to the Netherlands. He made the following points:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 22, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Decreases of $553,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $565,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- An appeal for an ending of conflicts in Congress and concentration upon compromising such controversial issues as food subsidies and the soldier vote was made today by Senator Wallace H. White Jr., Republican, of Maine, and acting minority leader of the Senate.

Reversing the verdict of a year ago, when Yale made a clean sweep against Harvard to capture the championship of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League, the Crimson quartet triumphed yesterday by 3 -- 1 over the Elis, thereby regaining custody of the Belden-Stephens trophy.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 -- Most of the 4,547 spectators at Tropical Park today apparently didn't believe that Sungino, the 85-to-1 shot that had made possible a $1,170.60 daily double last Tuesday, could repeat, and so the 7-year-old romped home again at 10-1.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 28 -- Today, with military honors we buried on a New Guinea hilltop Brydon Taves, United Press chief in this theatre, who was killed together with Pendil Raynor, Australian correspondent, when the observation plane in which they were taking off to report from the air the marines' landing at Cape Gloucester, crashed when a few feet off the ground.

WITH THE UNITED STATES TROOPS, in England, Dec. 28 (AP) -- In the biggest war maneuvers ever held, thousands of rough, tough and battle-eager young American soldiers are getting practical training day and night for the forthcoming invasion of western Europe under Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- As part of a drive to bring the insurance business within the scope of the Federal anti-trust laws, Attorney General Biddle filed a brief in the Supreme Court today insisting that insurance "unquestionably" operated in interstate commerce.

A representative cross-section of New York City coal dealers reported at a special meeting yesterday that most members were without supplies, according to Brig. Gen. Bryce P. Disque, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Committee.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Dec. 29 -- With big tanks blasting the way, Guadalcanal veterans have advanced two miles through the jungle from Cape Gloucester, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Polite bedlam was let loose today in the auditorium of the Social Security Building as fifteen motion pictures were run off simultaneously, some of them equipped with sound projectors, momentarily muffled in volume.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 28 -- The first day of the War Department's operation of the nation's railways today in the face of a threatened strike by three operating unions passed as smoothly as President Roosevelt had expected when he congratulated Secretary Stimson on the Army's "remarkable" plan for operation which the latter had presented to him Friday.

With the sinking of the Scharnhorst there remains not one large capital ship in the German Navy capable of going into action. The Nazis still have a considerable though much reduced fleet of submarines. But their surface forces now number no more than two 10,000-ton pocket battleships and a few light cruisers and destroyers.

The fishermen huddled around that fire over there are invited to stop huddling and listen to the tale of a Navy man's exploit with a sailfish in the sunny southland. The Navy man is Lieut. Walter S. Haas of Collington, N.J., and his prize is a twenty-two-pound fish, no great shakes as sailfish go.

Global cooperation and a world system of government to preserve peace were advocated yesterday by speakers on the opening day of a war problems conference in the Hotel Commodore. The three-day meeting is sponsored by the National Association of Teachers of Speech, the American Educational Theatre Association, and the Committee on Debate Materials and Interstate Cooperation of the National University Extension Association.

Government operation of the Eastern division under President Roosevelt's order placing the railroads under control of the Army went into effect yesterday, with Col. Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, as the director.

Lorenz Hart, co-author of the musical show, "A Connecticut Yankee," who died on Nov. 22, was pictured yesterday by his brother, Theodore Hart, actor, as ran "alcoholic addict" during the last three years of his life and incapable of drawing a will.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- International Harvester Company has moved deeper into the field of mechanical cotton pickers with the development of a two-row picker, it was announced here today. The new machine represents only a potential threat to existing lines and the hand picker of the South because Federal restrictions on materials prevent mass production now.

Your recent endorsement of Representative Kefauver's proposal that Cabinet members appear before Congress when requested to answer questions about their departments comes as somewhat of a surprise. No doubt you are interested in the establishment of closer and better working relations between the legislative and executive branches of our Government.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (AP) --The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 28 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval's police and the Gestapo are intensifying their activity in France with more arrests and executions. Each week Vichy issues a bulletin indicating how many have been lodged in jail or "put out of business."

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Hounded by cruisers and destroyers of the British Home Fleet, the German battleship Scharnhorst was driven to within range of the 14-inch guns of the battleship Duke of York, which pounded Hitler's last pawn in the great game of seapower into a mass of flaming wreckage Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- The Navy revealed today that American submarines had sunk twelve more Japanese ships, including a destroyer and two large tankers, in the intensified war of attrition against the enemy's battered supply lines.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 28 -- The confiscation of a shipment of gold whose value is estimated at hundreds of thousands of dollars has just been effected through the diligence of United States Army forces in the Middle East. At the same time, the leaders in an international gold-racketeering gang have been arrested and turned over to the Egyptian authorities.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- German troops fell back before fierce Yugoslav Partisan attacks in Croatia, the headquarters of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) announced today while farther south, in the embattled Livno-Duvno sector of western Bosnia, several hundred Nazis were reported killed in fighting of mounting fury.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind dismissed yesterday what he called a "heads I win, tails you lose" law-suit. The question before him was whether a group of employes without violating the "public policy" of the Fair Labor Standards Act could settle their disputed claim for unpaid overtime wages in such a way as to waive their rights to damages under the statute.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- Soviet troops were reported today to be increasing their pressure on Vitebsk, vital strong point in the Germans' Baltic defenses, and fanning out in their offensive west of Kiev toward Zhitomir, the important rail center captured by the Russians in mid-November but given up later in the face of large German tank and infantry forces.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 28 -- Liberators of the Seventh United States Air Force dropped more than fifty tons of bombs on Wotje Atoll, in the Marshall Islands, on Dec. 26, West Longitude time, and engaged in a fierce battle with six Zeros that rose to intercept our formation.
Among the buildings in which leases were reported yesterday was 522 Fifth Avenue, where the following eleven new tenants were listed:

A post-war international organization with the United Nations "big four" as the backbone and endowed with the power to fight aggressor nations was urged yesterday by Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, speaking by radio from South Africa.

Edward J. Noble, who recently acquired complete control of the Blue Network, disclosed yesterday that he had sold a 12 1/2 per cent interest in the national radio chain to Time, Inc., Henry R. Luce, chairman. In addition, Chester J. LaRoche, advertising executive, bought a 12 1/2 per cent interest, and Mark Woods and Edgar Kobak, president and executive president respectively of the Blue Network, acquired additional interests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Danny Kaye's next picture for Samuel Goldwyn win be "The Wonder Man," a Technicolor comedy to be based on an original story by Arthur Sheekman. The comedian will portray a grown-up Quiz Kid, and will begin next summer after Kaye returns from an overseas Army camp tour.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Tokyo and recorded by The United Press:

Appeals for funds for benevolences and for wartime relief, as well as for post-war needs, will be included for another year by the United Church Canvass in a program of coordinating financial drives by religious congregations, it was decided yesterday by the planning committee of the Canvass, meeting at 297 Fourth Avenue.

JANESVILLE, Wis., Dec. 28 -- Of the $500,000,000 which the General Motors Corporation expects to spend on plants under its post-war "master plan," $400,000,000 will be appropriated for new plants and equipment and the rest will be for re-arranging old equipment, C.E. Wilson, General Motors president, said today.

Patrolman Charles M. Neidecker, who had been charged with offering a Federal alcohol tax inspector a $20 bribe to overlook liquor stamp irregularities in a Queens tavern, was ordered dismissed from the force yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

Probably this year will be known in the informal histories of the Broadway theatre as the Season of Rose Franken. Not long ago William Brown Meloney, who is the author's husband, offered "Outrageous Fortune," which still is running; and last evening her second play, "Doctors Disagree," went on under the same auspices at the Bijou.

The invasion of the European mainland from the south appears now as a kind of dress rehearsal for the big show. Of course it was more than that. The decisive importance of the Mediterranean campaign was never so apparent as it is on the eve of the grand assault on Hitler's fortress.

Reporting on operations of the Burlington Mills Corporation during its fiscal year ended on Oct. 2. William Klopman, vice president, informed stockholders that the company's production was record-breaking in spite of difficult raw material and labor supply problems.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 29 -- Smashing through crumbling German lines west of Kiev on a sixty-five-mile front, Soviet troops yesterday advanced to within five miles of the five-way rail junction of Korosten and captured the enemy stronghold of Korostyshev guarding the approaches to Zhitomir.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Oats showed independent weakness today for the second straight day, breaking around 1 cent a bushel early as the result of scattered commission-house liquidation and professional selling said to be based on reports that new ceiling prices on this grain ant barley would be announced within a day or two, with the trade expecting that the maximums would be rolled back 5 cents or more from current prices.

WITH THE UNITED STATES MARINES IN NEW BRITAIN, Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- There are two holders of the Congressional Medal of Honor among the marines who landed here today and plenty of "characters," some of them from New York.

The New York film critics have voted "Watch on the Rhine," the Warner Brothers' picturization of Lillian Hellman's anti-Nazi play, as the best motion picture of 1943, Paul Lukas, who co-starred with Bette Davis in the film, was voted the best actor of the year for his performance as Kurt Muller, a role he originated in the stage play.

Although inducted into military service on the eve of the All-Star game in July, Howie Pollet, ace left-hander of the Cardinals, had by then already hung up a sufficient record for himself to win the National League's top-ranking pitching honors, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

Donors who were "sorry to be late," who gave a second time for this appeal, who were happy to give each year an increased amount, who regretfully gave less than previously, refugees from Hitler and many who are grateful for the blessings of health and freedom they enjoy were among the 381 whose gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund were received yesterday.

The man-in-the-street and the housewife are the principal targets of the Fourth War Loan Drive, it was disclosed yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who has accepted the job of recruiting 20,000 volunteer salesmen for the loan drive in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Roosevelt told in an allegory this afternoon why he preferred "win the war" to "New Deal" for the current slogan of his Administration, and despite the long tribute which the President paid to the New Deal's accomplishments in the allegory, he denied that it comprised a fourth-term declaration.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Roosevelt announced today the appointment of Maj. Gen. James H. Doolittle, leader of the attack on Tokyo, to command the Eighth Air Force, which includes all United States air units in the United Kingdom.

Today is the birthday of a great American -- Gen. William E. (Billy) Mitchell, who was born in 1879. Because his greatness has special significance in the midst of this epochal war, the anniversary merits more attention than it will receive.

Through Justice, official organ of his organization, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, replied yesterday to last week's editorial in War and the Working Class, official organ of the Soviet trade unions, assailing him and other American labor leaders, including President William Green of the American Federation of Labor, for alleged hostility to the Soviet Union and their opposition to having the AFL join the Anglo- Soviet trade union committee.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it would sponsor a program of voting reforms before the 1944 Legislature that are calculated to make it more difficult to vote a straight party ticket. The chief proposal on the program involves an adaptation of the Massachusetts ballot idea to voting machines.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 28 -- Lieut. Col. William I. Allen, USA, 46 years old, of Setauket, retired, died before noon today in Mather Memorial Hospital here of injuries suffered two hours earlier when he was killed by a Long Island Rail Road train at the Stony Brook station, a few miles from his home.

Despite prevailing higher prices for New Year's Eve in all but three of the Broadway theatres, a survey revealed yesterday that two attractions already had sold out, while many others had few tickets available at box offices. Entirely without tickets were "The Voice of the Turtle" and "Oklahoma!" The majority of the theatres reported the cheaper seats sold out.
