PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A plan for distribution of 1,120,600 shares of common stock of the Delaware Power and Light Company among holders of the 23,252,005 outstanding capital shares of the United Gas Improvement Company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Andy West, Andrew Fleming West, forty-five years a Professor of Latin at Princeton, dean and real founder of the Princeton Graduate School, which represents his idea and ideal of pure scholarship, is gone in his ninety-first year. Affectionate regret pervades the whole widespread family of Princeton men.

Jean Gabin, French movie star who until his recent enlistment in the French Navy had lent his talents to Hollywood, made a fair exchange yesterday. He supplied luncheon to fifty sailors at the Cantine La Marseillaise, 782 Second Avenue, after obtaining from them donations of blood plasma.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The seizure of the railroads was described by Representative Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota, as "entirely unnecessary." He said it was "a decided victory for the Brotherhoods" and declared "It's too bad we haven't got another Calvin Coolidge in the White House."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Both the Japanese and the Germans are being punished by "secret weapons" developed by the Navy, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared today in a year-end summary of naval accomplishments during 1943.

" His Butler's Sister," a Universal comedy drama, which opens at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's sole film arrival. Deanna Durbin, Pat O'Brien and Franchot Tone are starred under the direction of Frank Borzage. Among the supporting players are Akim Tamiroff, Alan Mowbray, Evelyn Ankers, Walter Catlett and Roscoe Karns.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- After coming from behind twice, the Bruins put on a four-goal rally in the third period to gain their first victory over the Red Wings during the current National Hockey League season by a 5-2 margin tonight before a sell-out crowd of 13,500 at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Royal Air Force heavy bombers which at the beginning of the war depended mainly on darkness for protection against enemy fighters, then added improved power-driven turrets and more guns when the Nazi fighter opposition became formidable now are tough customers for the Luftwaffe's best interceptors.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation got some data yesterday on the effectiveness of that gambling system by which a losing bet is followed by the placing of another, in double the amount. This is the system which has gladdened the chilly heart of many a racetrack bookmaker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- New developments, including certain "navigational aids," have enabled American bombers actually to capitalize on bad weather in carrying out their devastating raids against Germany, Maj. Gen. Frederick L. Anderson Jr., commander of the Eighth United States Air Force Bomber command, disclosed here today.

Warnings of a fish famine in New York City were sounded yesterday by Arthur Coller, counsel for the Fish Fillet Dealers Association. He announced that the association's members at a meeting at 137 Beekman Street had taken steps to dismiss 200 employes by Saturday if by that time the five-week strike of 5,000 members of the United Fishermen's Council were not terminated.

A police force consisting of 2,147 men has been assigned to New Year's Eve duty in Times Square, it was disclosed yesterday in an order released by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, who gave the command of this force to Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- An analysis of aircraft jobs that are too hazardous for workers 16 and 17 years old and those that are suitable is printed as a leaflet by the Children's Bureau.

The President has paid a heavy price for the settlement of the threatened steel and railroad strikes. He has rewarded instead of penalizing the big unions which were breaking or threatening to break their no-strike pledge and to paralyze the nation's industry. He has undermined the authority of his own boards and administrators by permitting their decisions to be defied and by setting aside these decisions for his own.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Office of Price Administration today acted to check practices which it said have resulted in inflationary prices for some woven decorative fabrics by providing that no jobber may charge more for a woven decorative fabric than 185 per cent of the manufacturer's or converter's ceiling price for the fabric and placing qualifications on the right of manufacturers to sell at jobbers' ceiling prices fabrics made by others.

Adoption of "proper accounting methods" as a necessary step under war conditions was urged yesterday to waste material dealers in order to determine costs of remaining in business. The recommendation, first of this kind in that trade, was made by the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, which warned members that they could not operate on "the old basis," under current regulations.

Paul Robeson, the baritone, headed the musical program in the "Salute to the Children of Stalingrad Festival" at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The fete was under the auspices of the Ambijan Committee for Emergency Aid to the Soviet Union and the Stalingrad Silver Ponds Club of America, an organization of New York City public school children which is sending milk, vitamins, shoes, blankets and other supplies to the Stalingrad children.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (UP) --A communique:

The gloomy picture of coal prospects presented in THE NEW YORK TIMES "Review of the Week" of Dec. 19 is based on Solid Fuels Administration estimates which do not take into account changed production conditions in the bituminous coal industry. "If the 415,000 miners now at work produce an average of 5.2 tons every normal working day (about 280) the yield will be only 604,240,000 tons," the article states.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Last month brought a marked increase in industrial idleness due to strikes, the Bureau of Labor statistics reported today. The report estimated that 300 strikes involved 500,000 workers and caused 2,825,000 man-days of idleness in November.

PHILADELPHIA Dec. 28 -- The Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a registration statement covering $3,500,000 face amount of fifteen-year sinking fund debentures due Jan. 15, 1959, with annexed stock purchase warrants.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 28 -- Returning to action after a two-week lay-off, the Dartmouth five swamped Williams, 75-47, tonight.
E. Palmer Hoyt, director of the domestic branch of the Office of War Information, appealed yesterday to members of the Sales Executives Club for support of civilian campaigns in behalf of the war.

LIPPY LEO DUROCHER has written a letter to Santa Claus. This living, breathing document has not received any sort of publicity to date, and it certainly should be made available to the legion of fanatical Brooklyn rooters so that they may know that the Lip is in there trying his best for them even in the off season. It is nice to know, too, that Leo believes in Santa Claus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Army, with the aid of eight railroad presidents who have been commissioned colonels and two union leaders who have been named labor consultants, is prepared to use troops if necessary to keep the railroads operating, to use its own trucks and supplies to avert possible shortages of civilian commodities, and will take firm steps against any strikers, Secretary Stimson and Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell declared today.

Large scale selling struck the stock market yesterday in the final hour and produced the worst setback in prices in more than a month. Although the liquidation was heaviest in low-priced issues, the main-stay sections of the list also felt some of the pressure, with serious losses in a few key spots.

No matter when our victory over the Axis powers is achieved, hotel facilities will continue to be taxed to the utmost for at least a year or two after the final shot is fired, according to Glenwood J. Sherrard, president, American Hotel Association.

IT is possible to read only a limited number of words in a limited number of hours. If you try to increase your hourly consumption of printed matter too drastically and to extend the number of your reading hours too heroically the law of diminishing returns begins to operate. Black spots dance before your eyes; fatigue, irritation and unworthy prejudices sully the crystal clarity of impartial judgment.

Air transportation and a rush printing job are being used in a race to get certificates for common shares of the American Distilling Company stamped today in time for the 2:15 P.M. delivery required for the 600 "stamped" shares that were traded on Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, it was learned yesterday.

Disclosure during the recent liquor hearings before a Senate committee that stocks of neutral blending spirits total approximately 26,643,165 proof gallons provides the first definite information on the subject in about a year, and requires a revision of supply estimates on an even stricter basis than had previously been available, trade observers asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Accusing labor unions of having 'repudiated" their no-strike agreement, Representative Smith, Democrat, of Virginia, and co-author of the Smith-Connally Labor Disputes Act, called today for revision of the law. He demanded, too, that the War Labor Board cease issuing union-maintenance orders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The War Production Board, after studying the war need for industrial alcohol, does not think the domestic demand for beverage alcohol can yet be satisfied by giving distillers a temporary "holiday" to resume its manufacture, it was learned today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Kieta, the principal Japanese base on the east coast of Bougainville -- directly across that Solomons island from the American invasion beachhead -- underwent a day-long series of air attacks on Sunday.

Edward F. McGrath, schoolboy ace from St. Augustine's High in Brooklyn, furnished an upset in eliminating the third-ranked entrant, Alan S. Watson of Hill School, in the second round of Eastern junior indoor tennis singles championship yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

General Montgomery, victor of many battles from El Alamein to Ortona, declares that the key to success in modern warfare lies in a combination of land power and air power, each directed by its own commander but operating under a single plan. He outlines seven rules for the practical application of this fundamental proposition, as practiced within his own famous Eighth Army.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Cheered by the news of the sinking of the Scharnhorst, the stock markets here reopened firmly today after the Christmas and Boxing Day holidays. Diamond shares did particularly well. De Beers deferred went ahead when further details were given concerning expansion of operations at the company's Dutoitspan mine.

Mayor La Guardia, in his weekly broadcast Sunday, made some very admirable observations. He did, however, strike a discordant note when he advocated immunity for city employes from garnishment of wages for payment of debts. The Mayor is all too wise to press for such an anachronism.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 28 -- Major A. Whitfield Hawkes of the Army Medical Corps died on an island in the South Pacific on Dec. 17, the War Department notified his parents, United States Senator Albert W. Hawkes and Mrs. Hawkes, today. Major Hawkes, a neurologist, succumbed to tick bite fever.

Eleven points behind Pittsburgh early in the opening half, New York University did not appear to have much of a chance to overcome such a lead, but overcome it the Violets did and with a late surge Howard Cann's team gained a 54-40 victory before 14,902 persons at Madison Square Garden last night.

ALGIERS, Dec. 28 -- American troops of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army, with the benefit of clear weather, have completed the occupation of the Mount Sammucro rock mass east and slightly north of San Vittore. Patrols, have already initiated the downhill phase of the battle by probing the defenses of the next objective before Cassino, which are strong.

Tonight David Lowe joins the Broadway managerial ranks with "South Pacific," which will have its premiere at the Cort. Starring Canada Lee, the Howard Rigsby-Dorothy Heyward play (originally called "New Georgia"), has a company of fifteen Negroes and one white player (Wendell K. Phillips).

In issuing its 1944 sales promotion calendar for retailers and national advertisers, the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday emphasized the need of flexibility as a quality all sales plans and sales promoters must possess during the next twelve months.

Miss Augusta Strongman, Wagner College senior, won the annual women's intercollegiate Christmas fencing tourney by taking seven of eight bouts in the final round-robin at the Salle Santelli last night. It wasn't until the last bout, in which Miss Strongman defeated Miss Mildred Mackay of the Jersey City Teachers College, 4 -- 2, that the Staten Island fencer emerged the winner.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 271, against 312 in the preceding week and 236 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 221, which compared with 59 last Tuesday.

Production of war materials and equipment by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in the first eleven months of this year amounted to $628,972,156 in net sales billed, or 40 per cent more than in the same 1942 period, A.W. Robertson, chairman, reported yesterday.

Thirteen properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn have just been sold by the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America to clients of William H. Whiting Co., brokers, who acted in conjunction with Ruland Benjamin in the deals.

The U.S.S. Brush, a new type of heavy destroyer reported to have the fighting power of a cruiser of World War I, was launched yesterday at the yard of the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company in Mariners Harbor, S.I. She was the twenty-second destroyer to go down the ways at the yard since Pearl Harbor.

The annual national conference of the Association of Internes and Medical Students adopted yesterday a resolution calling upon the Government, organized medicine and educators "to formulate adequate plans to assure young doctors now in the armed forces a high-quality post-graduate medical education after the war, and to provide the necessary legislation to assure financial aid for these men so they may be economically independent while they continue their training."

Describing reduction of the "terrific" rate of labor turnover in the wholesale drug field as a vital necessity for 1944, Dr. E.L. Newcomb, executive director of the National Wholesale Druggists Association, made known yesterday that a comprehensive campaign to lower the turnover will be launched shortly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Last night's seizure of the country's railroads was taken calmly here. Opinion was general, canvasses among those members of Congress still here indicating that President Roosevelt, in directing Secretary Stimson to take over the lines, had taken "the only action he could" under the circumstances.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A German news agency broadcast recorded today by Reuter said Rome was bombed at noon yesterday. There was no confirmation of the report from any Allied source.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 28 -- The whole story seems to have been a very roundabout and unsportsmanlike ruse to cash a bad check for $20, but Roger F. Gleason, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here, would very much like to know who the "staff sergeant" was.

Soviet Russia's new national anthem set at least one of our faithful readers to thinking. Everybody was saying that Stalin's abandonment of the "Internationale" for a hymn of Russian patriotism was a sign of great changes in the Soviet Union.

After five hours of heated debate the City Council approved yesterday, by a vote almost strictly along party lines, the report of the committee named last June to investigate the affairs of the La Guardia administration.

ALGIERS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Allied Headquarters revealed today that the Fifth Army, at the time of the original Salerno landings, was composed of just one American division and two British divisions and that the whole Italian operation had been a gamble whose success had hung by a thread for a while.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The United States Eighth Air Force has overcome the greatest climatic obstacle to daylight bombing in northwest Europe by introducing a technique of bombing through solid cloud that in the past three months has contributed to the success of such major battles as those fought by Flying Fortresses and Liberators over Wilhelmshaven and Kiel.

More than a ton of scrap paper was given to the city's scrap-paper drive yesterday by 150 members of the Lions Club of New York who trooped through the lobby of the Hotel Biltmore to the club's weekly luncheon meeting laden with their contributions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Importance was attached here today to the differences betwen the taking over of the railroads by the Government yesterday and in 1917.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Probable induction of more aliens into the United States armed forces through a revision of Selective Service and War Department policies was forecast today by the Selective Service system national headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- January point values for meats, fats, cheese and other brown - stamp foods, which become effective Sunday will remain virtually unchanged from the present figures, the Office of Price Administration said today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- In fitting tribute to his leadership of the world champions, Joe McCarthy of the Yankees was named the outstanding manager of the year by the Sporting News today, becoming the first person to win recognition three times in the annual selection of No. 1 men in baseball.

For the home-maker who is depending on new curtains, slip covers and upholstery to freshen up the house after the holidays, versatile new fabrics are arriving in the stores. Stocks of fine silk damasks, brocades and satins are limited, but their place is being taken by cotton, celanese and rayon weaves that look like silk and have much of its traditional elegance.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- In a broadcast beamed to America tonight, Mrs. Iphigene Bettman of Cincinnatti, Ohio, gave her impressions of England, gathered during a two-month lecture tour.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- With its accent on youngsters and novices, and an unofficial slogan of "Keep them skiing," the Sno Birds of the Lake Placid Club inaugurated another wartime College Week of winter sports competition today with six preliminary events in which the athletes ranged in age from 10 to 60 years and competed under the direction of Paul Sanborne, Sno Bird president, and Gerald Murchison, vice president.

Because the British War Relief Society expects to use only about half of its allotment of $5,700,000 from the National War Fund for the budget year ending Sept. 30, 1944, the agency announced yesterday that it would return -- barring "unforeseen emergencies" -- about $2,500,000 for use by other foreign and domestic beneficiaries of the American public's generosity.

The 1943 boxing season in New York hits the end of the trail tonight in Madison Square Garden. And, for the occasion, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C., has arranged what promises to be a rousing battle between middleweights.

Two-piano playing in the modern manner and devoted largely to modern music was heard last night in Town Hall by a large and enthusiastic audience as Vera Appleton and Michael Field made their first professional appearance.

Senator Wheeler of Montana has served warning on the Government that it will be "taking a tremendous gamble" if it permits an invasion of western Europe to be carried out largely by American troops. He believes that the British shrank from such an invasion as too costly and he hints that if we attempt it we shall be "following the demands of Mr. Stalin."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The American and the British Chiefs of Staff have agreed upon, but will not disclose, the proportion of troops that each country will send into the invasion of western Europe, the American Chiefs of Staff said in a statement tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- If striking workers had shut down the country's railroads, the result to the American war program would have been as staggering as if the enemy had been able suddenly to knock out our transportation systems, Secretary Stimson declared in a radio address tonight explaining why it was believed necessary for the War Department to take over the railroads.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- The proposal by Dr. Bohuslav Ecer, former Mayor of Bruenn, for establishment of a court to try leading war criminals was the first officially presented to the United Nations Commission. Dr. Ecer suggested that the constitution and procedure of the court follow details of a plan previously drawn by Marcel de Baer, Belgian jurist.
